column2: LLANDUDNO, Wales, Oct. 6 -- The Conservatives opened their sixty-ninth annual conference here tonight after a special daily session on local government. Preliminary formalities are now out of the way and for the next three days the conference will move upward hopefully into the major national issues that will decide the country's political fate at the next general election in 1950.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- Norman Thomas, Socialist party nominee for President, declared here today that to admit Spain into an alliance of Western European nations would be "to pollute an alliance designed to promote democracy with the despotism of Franco." He predicted, however, that "if the cold war intensified; everything will be forgotten in the interests of a military victory."

The Tournament of Champions, through Matchmaker Andy Niederreiter announced yesterday that it had closed the match between Ray Robinson, world welterweight champion, and Steve Belloise, Bronx veteran who is rated high among the current middleweights.

BERLIN, Oct. 6 -- The solidarity of opposition of three non-Communist parties against Communist maneuverings in Berlin has begun to disintegrate. It is the first hopeful sign the Communists have seen since last April when they began the blockade of the Western sectors of this city.

MOSCOW, Oct. 6 (UP) -- The magazine New Times today condemned the late Count Folke Bernadotte's plan for Palestine because "the unanimity of Washington, London and Paris is indicative that the Anglo-American monopolists and their French partners have concluded a deal on Palestine."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- An aircraft engine combining the force of a propeller and the boost of a jet is being developed for the Air Force to enable its big, long-range bombers to fly "farther, faster and higher."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Estimates which will play a role of primary significance in the formation of United States policy abroad place the active military strength of the Soviet Union and its satellite nations at about 5,200,000 troops, it became known authoritatively today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett indicated today that it might be some months before any program of United States military support for the Western European Union could be completed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Paramount today announced the purchase of "An Eye for an Eye," a screen story by Lee Horton, dealing with a man unjustly imprisoned for ten years, who seeks revenge against society after his release, but finally makes a peaceful adjustment.

Parents who blame comic books for juvenile delinquency are using them as "twentieth century scapegoats" to which to shift their own responsibilities, Edwin J. Lukas, executive director of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, declared yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A Republican's plan for a military alliance of the United States and most of the rest of the anti-Communist world, including Franco Spain, was presented today in a high-policy conference to all the principal military authorities of the Truman Administration.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Oct. 6 -- The New Jersey team of fifteen players won the fall intersectional match of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association for the Myra D. Patterson Trophy by scoring 54 1/2 points to 50 for Long Island and 30 1/2 for Westchester over the Echo Lake Country Club course today.

Fourteen 2-year-old fillies were in the $18,350 Autumn Day Stakes at Jamaica yesterday, and a dozen of them popped out of the starting gate ahead of the Greentree Stable's Boomdeay, the $5.90-for-$2 favorite. But she quickly buckled down to the business before the house, proved herself pounds the best of the group and won by a little more than a length.

The Pennsylvania Railroad sold yesterday a new issue of $9,675,000 of equipment trust certificates maturing over a period of fifteen years to Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates at an interest cost of about 2.567 per cent. In another equipment trust transaction, the Chicago North Western Railway sold $5,325,000 of serials maturing over fifteen years to Kidder, Peabody Co. and associates at an interest cost of about 2.445 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Farmers Home Administration reported today that it collected $136,697,980 on loans in the last fiscal year and lent only $75,000,000. Loans were made up to the limit of funds approved by Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- The Rev. Dr. Franklin C. Fry, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, said today that the denomination needed more enlistments in the ministry and the deaconate. He urged the clergy and laity to seek recruits.

In a barely audible voice, a convicted murderer yesterday shouldered the blame for the killing of Anthony Hintz, 43-year-old boss stevedore, in an effort to exonerate the two men sentenced to die with him for the slaying.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Since VJ-Day we have been living in a fool's paradise of "inflation-induced false prosperity," William C. Mullendore, president of the Southern California Edison Company, Los Angeles, asserted today before nearly 1,000 life insurance company executives.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Speaking here tonight before descendants of twenty-six racial groups at a huge gathering in the International Amphitheatre with a capacity of 14,000, Gov. Earl Warren of California said their presence under one roof proved that the United Nations could work.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Senator Vandenberg on the radio this week enumerated a few of the contributions to foreign programs which are of Republican origin, but that was not the main purpose of his speech. The same can be said of his vital reminder that if the Republican in Congress had not voted for these programs they would never have been transmuted into operating policies.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- Delegates to the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America endorsed this afternoon a proposal to raise $6,000,000 during the next two years for the "pressing building needs" of seminaries and colleges.

The Lehman Corporation, at the end of the first quarter of its fiscal year, which was Sept. 30, had a net asset value of $46.31 for each share of its capital stock, Robert Lehman, president, announced yesterday. This compared with $50.22 a share in the previous quarter.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 7 -- Virtually conceding that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey will win this state's three electoral votes the Delaware Democratic organization is concentrating upon local issues and capitalizing upon a popular gubernatorial candidate in an effort to win control of the state government and perhaps wrest a United States Senate seat from the Republicans.

Dmitri Mitropoulos, one of the most individual and incandescent of modern conductors, opened the season of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with a program that compassed such a range of music as the Respighi transcription of the Bach D major organ Prelude and Fugue, Richard Strauss' "Also sprach Zarathustra" and Brahms' C minor symphony.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore A. Gill, formerly of the North Avenue Presbyterian Church, New Rochelle, N.Y., has accepted a call to the pastorate of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, the fourth largest church in membership in the Presbytery of New York.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- The case of Ilse Koch is being reconsidered by the Judge Advocate General's Department to determine whether there is other evidence against her for which she might be tried anew as a war criminal, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- A surprisingly large field of seventy-one turned out for the next-to- last weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association season at the Scarsdale Golf Club today.

Pointing out that the textile industry needs all possible aid in maintaining stabilized relations with buyers as it emerges from the sellers' market, rayon converters yesterday urged the Federal Trade Commission to write a mandatory rule on written contracts into its fair trade code for the industry.

BAYORNNE, N.J., Oct. 7 -- In case of another world war many Government and industrial experts believe, some form of a National Service Act will be needed to direct civilian labor from unessential to essential war work.

A two-hour assembly of 1,500 City College students, called to act on petitions they were preparing to send to Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, requesting that he dismiss two faculty members, was advised yesterday that the petitions would not be valid but that Commissioner Spaulding would be requested to act as an "impartial arbiter."
In one of the largest post-war sessions to date, cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange advanced 60 to 130 points under rather general outside and local buying yesterday.

A continuation of the history that Salvador de Madariaga began with "The Rise of the Spanish American Empire" will be brought out by Macmillan on Oct. 26. It is "The Fall of the Spanish American Empire," an evaluation of its peoples, the foreign influences and the effects of the American and French Revolutions and the Negro rising in Haiti.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- President Truman today appointed James M. Mitchell of Chicago as the Republican member of the Civil Service Commission. He fills the vacancy caused when Arthur S. Flemming resigned on Aug. 30 to become president of Ohio Wesleyan University. He was born Jan. 3, 1910, in Washington, D.C.

More intensive campaigns for repeal of excessive taxes on tobacco products and enactment of uniform fair-trade-practices laws specifically banning below-cost price-cutting on smoking articles were urged yesterday on members of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, Inc.

Dallas, Tex., will receive on Oct. 19 bids on bond issues amounting to $3,340,000. One issue will consist of water and sewer revenue bonds of $1,900,000 dated Feb. 1, 1948, and due semi-annually on Feb. 1, 1949 to 1950. The other issue of $1,440,000 general obligations dated Nov. 1, 1948, will be due March 1, 1949 to 1968.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Sharply lower prices for most farm products and foods were mainly responsible for a decrease of 0.9 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended Oct. 2, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

An increase of 25 per cent in passengers on Staten Island buses since fares were lowered July 1 has brought on the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway a drop in passengers and curtailment of service, according to testimony yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.

When triplet daughters were born prematurely last Aug. 27 at Lenox Hill Hospital to Mrs. Bernice Breiner of 125-12 Newport Avenue, Belle Harbor, Queens, attending physicians and the hospital staff doubted that the babies would survive. Sue Anne weighed 3 pounds 2 ounces; Joe Anne, 3 pounds 10 ounces, and Carol Anne, 4 pounds 10 ounces. They were breathing faintly.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Continental diplomats in London showed concern today that a renewed interest in the United States in Spain's strategic position might indicate a belief in Washington that Western Europe north of the Pyrenees could not be defended and would be quickly abandoned in case of war.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- A preliminary hearing about continuation of a religious school and farm for refugee boys from Czechoslovakia that is located in New Castle, near here, was adjourned tonight until Oct. 26 in an effort to reach a decision that would be acceptable to the residents of that place.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The Polish Embassy here released today a White Book on Germany, 1948, which it proffered as an "indication of a constructive approach to the key problem of peace in our time -- the question of Germany."

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, charged yesterday that the Dewey administration was destroying the morale of the State Police and that troopers were being persecuted because of membership in the New York State Police Benevolent Association.

Three hundred and ten American colleges and universities will be represented at the installation ceremony of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, to be held Tuesday at 2 P.M. in the university's South Court. Delegates from thirty-six foreign institutions and thirty-four learned societies also will march in the academic procession.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein moved yesterday to investigate complaints of irregularities in voting registrations in 132 election districts in the city, including the hot campaign surrounding Representative Vito Marcantonio's bid for re-election to Congress.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 7 -- John L. Lewis served notice on the soft coal industry today that the United Mine Workers would tell its members how many days they should work if a surplus in coal production raised the threat of destructive competition, unemployment and wage cuts.

A new church edifice is planned by the Free Greek Community of Jamaica, Inc., of which John Chris is president, at the southwest corner of 182d Place and Hillside Avenue in the Jamaica Estates section of Queens, where a vacant irregular parcel, about 218 by 200 by 100 feet, has been purchased from Martin and Sylvia Lubash and Pauline Abramson.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- The Braves ran simultaneously out of miracles and pitching today and with that the magic feats of 1914 faded over the horizon like a mirage on this crisp and sunny New England afternoon.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 7 -- Partial or complete paralysis of the great factories that Argentina expropriated from the Germans under the Act of Chapultepec has led President Juan Peron to seek a renewed flow of technical parts and replacements direct from the former head offices of the plants now in the bizonal area of Germany.

Diversion of Far East cargo from strike-bound West Coast ports is beginning to show in increased movements through Gulf and East Coast ports and in the open ports of Tacoma, Wash., and Vancouver, it was reported here yesterday.

Lou Little was neither gloomy nor sanguine yesterday as he discussed Columbia's forthcoming clash with Yale. At the weekly football luncheon in John Jay Hall the Lions' coach expressed some disappointment at losing to Harvard last week, but indicated that he would not permit that setback to cause him to make any great changes for the game in the Bowl at New Haven tomorrow.

Thanks to a million-dollar dike that is partly completed, for the first time in four year a high autumn tide driven by a northeast wind failed to flood La Guardia Field on Wednesday, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port Authority, said yesterday.

LONDON Oct. 7 -- The fuel demands of the Berlin airlift are jeopardizing the gasoline ration for the average Briton, according to reports in official circles today. The Ministry of Fuel and Power is said to be working on a plan for suspending the motorists' basic gasoline allowance through the winter months to ease the strain imposed by the airlift on Britain's oil supplies.

Wallpaper designs with original abstract motifs which capture the feeling of a variety of subjects suited to different rooms are the latest contribution to decoration come from the West. The James Kemble Mills collection of California designs was shown yesterday by A.H. Jacobs Company, 509 Madison Avenue, where the papers are available on order.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- Relations between Italy and Russia took a turn for the worse today as the result of a sharp reminder by Foreign Minister Molotov to the Italian Ambassador in Moscow, Manlio Brosio that the Soviet Union expected immediate delivery of thirty-three Italian warships assigned to Russia by the Italian peace treaty.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Before it was repudiated by Senor Gil Robles, the purported agreement between exiled Spanish Socialists and Monarchists was received with sym pathetic interest by the British Foreign Office, which announced earier today that it was studying the text.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- During the week ended Oct. 6 member bank reserve balances decreased $300,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

If man could conceive time in terms of hundred of millions of years, the drama of forest and field would be an ever-present wondrous story. As drifting continents have taken shape and become anchored, as climates have changed from hot to cold and back again, and vegetation developed from simple algae to spore plants and then to seed-bearing, hundreds of millions of years have passed as man reckons time.

Unless it is illegal to do so, this column would like to express a feeling of general disappointment over "Love Life," which was put on at the Forty-sixth Street last evening. Although billed as "a vaudeville," it is cute, complex and joyless -- a general gripe masquerading as entertainment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 2 were unchanged from the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:
A new board to rate the job-performance of workers in the city's Department of Welfare will start operation this morning, it was announced yesterday.
SANTA FE, N.M., Oct. 7 (AP) -- A state district judge today found that Catholicism is taught in some New Mexico public schools.

Crude oil production last week increased 109,650 barrels to 5,452, 750 barrels a day, according to yesterday's report of the American Petroleum Institute. Production for the similar week a year ago averaged 5,207,550 barrels daily.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 7 (AP) -- A mystery car dealer who has been peddling nearly new automobiles at list price from his alfalfa field "showroom" in the last few months was bankrupt and under arrest on charges of fraud today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, announced today that he had sought to obtain from Gov. Thomas E. Dewey a detailed statement of his views on conservation of natural resources.

Direct and indirect savings running into many millions of dollars have been effected by the coordinated procurement program of the Army and Navy, according to Brig. Gen. Letcher O. Grice, commanding general, New York quartermaster purchasing office.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 7 -- The hold of party traditions and loyalty remains largely intact in Arkansas despite widespread opposition to President Truman's civil rights proposals, and there is every indication that the state's nine electoral votes will be cast for the Presidential nominee of the Democratic party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The National Federation of American Shipping, Inc., in a statement today defended the San Francisco waterfront employers' refusal to deal with Harry Bridges, head of the CIO Longshoremen's Union, now on strike, because of the union chief's radical views.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- The Boston Braves of 1948 today parted company with their illustrious predecessors, the "Miracle Team" of 1914. George Stallings' heroes of another generation won their world championship in four straight games but Billy Southworth's hired hands won't win this one in four straight. Maybe they won't even win it, period. They didn't look particularly awesome this bright but slightly chilly afternoon.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 7 -- A five-year program of Protestant foreign missionary expansion, geared to use every modern technique available and aimed at the world's "critical" areas, was outlined here today to 3,500 church executives representing sixty-two Protestant denominations.

The first of the autumn's bears arrived at the Fourteenth Street market the other day. This bear was not the colloquial name for current meat brokerage but simply was several hundred pounds of bear, suitable for eating. In the course of time it will be distributed in the form of steaks and chops and whatever else may be derived from a bear -- including the certainty of at least one rug.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 7 -- Dr. Aake Ording, former head of the United Nations Appeal for Children, said tonight on the eve of his departure for Paris that he would ask the General Assembly of the United Nations to continue the appeal on a two-year basis with a reduced budget and streamlined staff of thirty workers.

TOKYO, Oct. 7 -- Since July, when Gen. Douglas MacArthur outlawed strikes by civil service employes, the Communists have been centering their attention on taking over the electric industry union. They now control it, with the result that industrial production is being retarded and private consumers are being annoyed by frequent and often unscheduled power stoppages.

PAWLING, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is expected to explain his views on public housing when he speaks in New York City tomorrow at ground-breaking ceremonies for the Alfred E. Smith housing project on the lower East Side.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The drafting of technicians to insure the upkeep of security services in the coal mines was authorized by the Cabinet as the French mine strike completed its fourth day. It was denied officially that the Government had decided to call all miners into military service, and it was stated that before the technicians would be called, all miners individually would have an opportunity to take voluntary measures themselves.
Only small net changes were recorded in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Closing prices were 5 points higher to 3 points net lower than the previous close.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Life insurance in force in the United States has reached or passed $200,000,000,000, it was estimated today by Wendell F. Hanselman, vice president of the Union Central Life Insurance Company, Cincinnati.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to spend $9,000 to set up temporary parking facilities for 1,200 automobiles on the cleared site of the old Tombs and Criminal Courts Building. The site, now being graded under the supervision of the Department of Public Works, is bounded by White, Leonard, Franklin, Centre and Lafayette Streets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Chris M. Lample, veteran official of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, who has been a personal champion of Alaskan aviation for sixteen years, now has the job of expediting construction of new ports at Anchorage and Fairbanks.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Cornell University celebrated today the eightieth anniversary of its opening on Oct. 7, 1868, with the dedication of a $2,000,000 laboratory of nuclear studies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The oldest surviving personal political partnership in the United States, if not the oldest in all the country's history, was breached today on the issue raised by the States-Rights Democrats.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The Colgate football team left here tonight for its game with Boston University in the Hub tomorrow evening, and fair warning is given to Buff Donelli that his Terriers are in for no pink tea party,

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The most active section in the stock market here today was the gold mining group. Business was confined to favorites and New Pioneer shot up to a new high despite some profit-taking during the day.

Greater use of newspaper space along with increased advertising budgets was announced yesterday by two distilling concerns Carstairs Brothers Distilling Company said that a new campaign on its White Seal Whiskey appealing to consumer "price-consciousness" marks the beginning of greater frequency in newspaper and trade paper ads as well as substantial increase in its new fiscal-year budget.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 7 -- Hurricane winds struck Bermuda early this evening.

Despite an increase in sales, the net income of E.R. Squibb Sons and its consolidated subsidiaries fell to $3,811,939 in the fiscal year ended with last June from $5,525,386 earned in the preceding year, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

Strongly reminiscent of the Viennese fashions that women loved before the war and looking as if they had stepped out of fashion plates were the tailored suits that Knize showed yesterday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel. By and large they were of the "classic" type, beautifully fitted and of superb fabrics, many of them imported.
A nation-wide drive to raise $1,500,000 in six months to build a Polio Institute of Palestine sponsored by Histadrut, Labor Federation of Palestine, was initiated yesterday.

While a court still was deliberating whether the Argentine Government could legally take newsprint from one paper and give it to another, President Peron ordered that 8,000 tons belonging to La Prensa be expropriated immediately and distributed by the Government.

Innovations designed to make railroad travel as pleasant as moviegoing or a trip to an art gallery will be on display next Monday morning when the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway opens a two-week exhibit of its newest passenger cars in major cities and on-line points.

A novel experiment in ship construction that may save the nation millions of dollars in the event of another war emergency is in progress in the Maritime Commission's design department, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The United States Government will not support any move to bring Spain into the United Nations, and it will not take any initiative in Paris to change the United Nations status of the Franco Government. Nevertheless, it might support certain modifications of the existing United Nations resolutions on Spain.

Forty-two seamen on picket duty in the garment area were seized yesterday by detectives and taken to the District Attorney's office for questioning on complaints of coercion by three non-union dress manufacturers.

Spring and resort openings of the Fashion Originators Guild drew a large attendance of buyers on the second day of scheduled openings yesterday, according to a spokesman for the group. Three firms which gave initial showings said that order-taking throughout the day was brisk, indicating that a big spring season is in prospect.

A director of Mary Hunter's attainments isn't permitted to twiddle her thumbs. What may seem sheer idleness to the uninitiated is merely valuable time spent gauging scripts of one kind or another. Aware of her capabilities, the Theatre Guild has drafted the director of "The Respectful Prostitute" to stage Vina Delmar's new play, "Ungilded Lily," it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett intimated broadly today that Secretary of State Marshall had directed the State Department to "debunk" the latest Russian proposal on atomic energy.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a call as of Oct. 6 on Class B banks for 10 per cent of its war-loan deposits, payable on Oct. 14. The sum involved amounts to $62,288,400 for the banks in this area and to $189,323,000 for those throughout the United States.

TOKYO, Oct. 7 -- Japan's Liberal party, headed by 70-year-old Shigeru Yoshida, a former Premier and a pro-war Ambassador to London, moved today to form a purely conservative National Government, excluding Socialists and other Leftist groups.

The City Planning Commission made public yesterday a proposed 1949 capital outlay budget of $317,056,203, of which $218,265,542 would be subject to the city's constitutional debt limit. Mayor O'Dwyer in his certifying message of Sept. 15 set a maximum of $247,000,000 for projects within the debt limit.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman joined last night in calling for the support of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York's 1948 drive for $16,500,000.

The tragic and regrettable death of Count Bernadotte in no way validates his short-sighted recommendation. For it would deny reclamation of badly neglected and damaged lands of Palestine and prevent the full use with conservation of unique features and resources of Palestine that are surely the best basis for a lasting solution.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 2 were 908,581 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Home lighting equipment should be installed first whenever possible so that colors, carpets, wallpapers and similar furnishings can be matched under the light with which they will be used, Thomas Smith Kelly, New York lighting consultant, advised last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Iowa filed today with the Federal Power Commission a formal petition for a rehearing on the Moscow (Iowa) dam project on the Cedar River. On Sept. 9, the commission issued a final order granting a construction license to the First Iowa Hydro-Electric Cooperative.

The stock market, aided by a better demand, gained more ground yesterday, although it stumbled a bit near the close. A few issues rose as much as 2 points but fractional gains predominated, with the combined averages up 0.34 point at the final bell.
PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The thirty-fifth Paris Auto Show opened today, and visitors for the first time since 1939 had an opportunity to buy a car without a priority.

Mayor O'Dwyer added "verbal cement" yesterday to the friendship between the United States and Israel as he accepted a silver trowel brought from Tel Aviv as a gift from Histadrut, the Israel Labor Federation of 300,000 members.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Montreal put on two big innings tonight to defeat St. Paul, 7 -- 3, and even the little world series at one victory apiece. The Royals, who had scored four runs in their half, were forced to install a pair of relief moundsmen in the ninth inning to turn back a determined drive by the Saints.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Phil Masi, Boston Braves' catcher, roamed only inches off second base today when he reached that station in the sixth inning as a pinch runner for Bill Salkeld. Even before he inched off the bag the catcher grinned at Manager Lou Boudreau of the Cleveland Indians, and warned: "No tricks, now."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 -- Albert Lewin disclosed today he had an understanding with James Mason which "gives him every hope" that Mason will play the leading role in his projected independent production, "Pandora." Lewin, who is on leave of absence from M-G-M, has written the scenario from his own story and is now negotiating financing and distribution deals for the project, he said.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 7 -- In a fighting appeal for labor's vote President Truman warned tonight that the record of the Eightieth Congress was the "handwriting on the wall" for even greater concessions to special interests if full control of the government was turned over to the Republicans.

James H. Durkin, president of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO, denied yesterday that he had ever said anything to the Prudential Insurance Company about Communists among the union's officers.

Modern education has failed to give the student the preparation necessary to live in the modern world, W. Albert Lotz, executive director of the Y.M.C.A. Schools of New York, asserted yesterday in his annual report to the Board of Managers.
Butchers sliced a little more off their prices yesterday in all parts of the nation, but there were indications that this relief for family budgets would be only temporary.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Second-seeded Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and fourth-seeded Jaroslav Drobny of Czechoslovakia reached the semi-final round of the national hard court tennis championship today.

In the face of the brilliant ingenuity displayed yesterday at Revillon Freres in their showing of furs, one can only acknowledge that when such imagination and skill are at work there are few limitations in fur design. Here were seen such treats in silhouette manipulation as a full-length seal with a fitted back and sweeping wrap front.
An argument between father and son in a bar and grill at 113th Street and Eighth Avenue yesterday afternoon led to the slaying of a third man and the wounding of the son, the police reported.

Mississippi's program for planning parenthood was praised yesterday by Dr. C.-E. A. Winslow in an address before the Planned Parenthood Foundation in the Roosevelt Hotel. He listed Massachusetts and Connecticut as "the only two states in the Union in which the forces of religious reaction have succeeded in maintaining categorical prohibitions of scientific advance in the field of planned parenthood."

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 7 -- Henry A. Wallace celebrated his sixtieth birthday today with a slashing attack on monopolists, charging that the "power trust" had decided that "this is the time to wreck public competition."

A group of passengers and guests aboard a Washington to Jersey City train yesterday afternoon watched nearly all of the second baseball game of the World series by television. The train was the Marylander of the Baltimore and Ohio line, which left Washington at 1:30 P.M. and arrived at Jersey City at 5:32.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Representatives of Argentina, Belgium, Canada, Colombia, China and Syria, who constitute the members of the United Nations Security Council not directly involved in the issue of the Berlin blockade, held a secret meeting this afternoon in an effort to work out a formula for transfering the question to the Council of Foreign Ministers.
Random notes.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- A general strike of all state employes became an imminent possibility this evening when the Government replied with a resounding "no" to their demands for higher salaries. The strike would entail the stoppage of such essential services as railroads, posts and telegraphs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Thirty years of study of screw threads will terminate before the end of 1948 in agreement between Great Britain, Canada and the United States on a uniform angle of 60 degrees for screw threads, the National Bureau of Standards announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Atomic Energy Commission hinted strongly today that it was preparing a drastic decree withdrawing recognition and collective-bargaining rights from the United Electrical and Radio Workers, CIO, in the Peek Street Atomic Energy Laboratory at Schenectady, N.Y., managed by the General Electric Company.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Record stocks of car parts have been accumulated by car dealers in anticipation of another severe winter, according to a survey presented today by Verne L. Murray, president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York.

Peace, a light yellow hybrid tea rose, was voted the best bloom in the Rose Garden of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden on its twenty-first annual Fall Rose Day yesterday. Some 500 persons inspected the 350 varieties of red and yellow hybrid tea roses now in bloom there.

Coal exporters asked for two important changes in federal rules and policies controlling bulk exports, in resolutions adopted at their annual meeting attended by more than 100 members of the Coal Exporters Association of the United States, Inc., at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

PEIPING, Oct. 7 -- A panicky buying spree developed here today with the residents trying to convert their gold yuan into tangible goods and the merchants closing their shops to avoid sales at unprofitable ceiling prices.
BUTTE, IVront., Oct. 7 @z@P) -- Republican candidates were-accused tonight by Senator Alben W. Barkley of "evasion and hypocrisy," in conducting their carhpaign.

A committee of the City Council decided yesterday to seek Mayor O'Dwyer's views on this question: Should the Avenue of the Americas remain the Avenue of the Americas, or should it become Sixth Avenue again?

"When Love Calls," an Italian-made romantic drama with music, will have its local premiee today at the Golden Theatre. Gino Bechi and Ebe Stignani, Italian operatic stars, head the cast of the film which was produced in Rome's PEG Studio by Twentieth Century-Fox.

Belgium has achieved general economic equilibrium since the war, but is nevertheless perched precariously atop a pyramid of credit claims against her neighbor nations, Finance Minister Gaston Eyskens of Belgium said here yesterday.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Blair Academy, here, will mark its hundredth anniversary Saturday. The centennial service will be held in the First Presbyterian Church, where this boys' preparatory school was born at a public meeting on April 6, 1848. Dr. Allan V. Heely, headmaster of the Lawrenceville School, will speak on "The Role of the Independent School in America."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- To the Army, and more especially the Navy, the Air Force is the problem child of the national military establishment. As Secretary of Defense Forrestal these days is umpiring issues that arise in the preparation of the military budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1, 1949, and deficiency items for the current period, this view of the claims of the Air Force is undoubtedly the source of numerous disputes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The State Department denounced in a statement today the arrest in Hungary last month of Paul Ruedemann, of Hartsdale, N.Y., and George Bannantine of St. Louis, executives of the Hungarian-American Oil Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, on charges of sabotage.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 7 -- Gov. Earl Warren warned tonight that unless the Federal Government dealt cooperatively with state and local governments in the solution of problems, these governmental units would wither from disuse arid eventually die.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- Social Democratic party leaders prepared today plans for holding elections in this city next month. With the support of the Liberal Democrats, the Social Democrats hope to stage elections in which even Soviet sector residents will be permitted to go to the polls.
BOSTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the world series at Braves Field today follows:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- With the full-throated cheers of the entire corps of 2,400 cadets ringing in their ears, forty-two Army football players entrained at sundown tonight for Champaign, Ill., where on Saturday Earl Blaik will send his "two platoons" marching against the University of Illinois.
Three diverse one-man shows are in the forefront this week in local galleries.

Crystal accessories -- known as "singing crystal" because of the high tones of the pieces when tapped -- from the Belgian factories in Val St. Lambert will be exhibited for a month by Lord Taylor, starting today. Modern vases, bowls and ashtrays as well as traditional designs are being made in the factories established in 1784.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- The Soviet Air Force in Germany produced its greatest show of strength since the end of World War II today but failed to disrupt the United States-British airlift or blunt the plans for supplying the Western sectors of Berlin this winter.

Declaring that the international crisis has been following the Hitlerian pattern of just before World War II, Robert Gordon Menzies, former Prime Minister and Leader of the Liberal party in Australia, called upon the English-speaking peoples yesterday "to develop their strength so that aggression can be resisted and overthrown."
BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- Billy South-worth's Braves weren't singing as they tramped into their clubhouse today because, understandably, they were in no mood to break into song.

The four-story sixteen-family apartment house at 315 Eighth Avenue, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, has been sold by Isidore Siegel to Angelina Giancola. The property, assessed at $56,000, was held at $57,500. It was acquired for cash above a first mortgage of $32,000. L.L. Yearsley was the broker.

Neither life insurance companies nor bankers should go on depending upon "unsound public policies to pull us through the problems of the future," Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, told members of the State Chamber of Commerce yesterday.

The aura for mystery that follows the old river steamer De Witt Clinton -- recently renamed the Derecktor -- since her purchase from the Maritime Commission several months ago, was still in evidence yesterday as the vessel prepared to sail for the Mediterranean.
Most of the winter hats shown yesterday by Baroness Radvanszky in her salon at 867 Madison Avenue were small. They were worn directly off the face or to one side.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Spanish Republicans here have transmitted to United States, British and French officials, as well as to other delegations of the United Nations, what they said was an agreement they had reached with the Monarchists concerning a future regime for Spain.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Summer and Smoke," a new play by Tennessee Williams, on Tuesday night at the Music Box Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Prescott Neighborhood House.

The Republic of Indonesia appears to have broken all organized resistance in the Communist revolt in Java. Muso, the Moscow-trained leader whose return set off the revolt; Sharifuddin, the former Republican Premier, and other leaders have fled to a mountain stronghold where they eventually can be smoked out.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today that 166 national unions and 9,749 locals were in full compliance with the affidavit and financial report requirements of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Completion of the first mass planting in the Park Association's Citizens Golden Anniversary Planting program was announced yesterday at a luncheon for civic leaders at the Biltmore Hotel given by Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president of the association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The cost of living and corporate profits have risen to new all-time records, while industrial production has also risen but remains within the level of a year-long plateau, according to data, obtained tonight, which has been prepared by the Council of Economic Advisers for President Truman and Congress.

The children of eight firemen killed in the performance of duty in the last year placed white roses yesterday beside a fire fighter's helmet shrouded with purple ribbon, resting on the Fire Department's flag, in memorial services at fire headquarters in the Municipal Building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Berlin problem, including the latest Russian aerial activities tending to hamper the United States-British airlift over the Soviet blockade, held the attention again today of the National Security Council, which held a regular meeting in the White House.

"Policing of inventories" was given last night as "the outstanding cause for concern among credit men in the food industry," by William R. Dunn, general credit manager of the General Food Corporation.

STUTTGART, Germany, Oct. 7 -- A large-scale movement of refugees from Eastern Europe, particularly from Czechoslovakia, to the United States zones in Germany and Austria and to Italy, was reported here today by International Refugee Organization officials.

The proposed tentative capital budget for 1949 presented by the City Planning Commission follows expected lines and conforms in principle with the priorities laid down by Mayor O'Dwyer several weeks ago. Except for the Board of Water Supply, whose large and needed allocation is happily exempt from the debt limit placed on city borrowing, the Board of Transportation and the Board of Education are the leading beneficiaries in this budget.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, of Vermont, urged the Federal Power Commission today to permit New York to go ahead with development of St. Lawrence River power.

We can well understand the wishes of officials and aides of the Board of Transportation to forsake the rented quarters the Board now occupies at 250 Hudson Street, Manhattan, and 365 Flatbush Avenue Extension, Brooklyn, and move into a new home of their own in Brooklyn's new civic center.

The assigning of Pan American Airways to share the air route between the Pacific Northwest and Hawaii will have no effect on the plans of Northwest Airlines for early opening of air service on the new Honolulu run, Croil Hunter, president and general manager of the air line, announced yesterday.
Transcontinental Western Airlines announced yesterday a 15 per cent cut for thirty-day round trip fares on all two-engine domestic flights between Nov. 1 and May 1.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Jean Moreau, French Secretary of State for Air, spent today inspecting the De Havilland aircraft factory at Hatfield, near London, which produces the majority of Britain's modern jet-type fighter aircraft and which has been expecting an order from France for planes of this type.

NANKING, Oct. 7 -- The large mass of Government troops in the Mukden enclave was reported bestirring itself tonight for the joint purpose of lifting the Communist stranglehold on Chinhsien, key to the West Liaoning supply center, and of helping the isolated Changchun garrison to try to escape southward through Communist territory.

The time has not yet arrived when consumers are willing to sacrifice quality for price, W.W. Wachtel, president of Calvert Distillers Corporation, told over 2,000 liquor wholesalers yesterday at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The perpetrators of a series of pre-dawn "hit and run" burglaries in the midtown area were side-tracked suddenly into the City Prison, the police reported yesterday, because the suspects almost ran down four charwomen while speeding from the scene of a robbery.
PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Russia's "one third in a year" disarmament proposals were turned down by the West today, until they are backed up by Moscow with a specific plan for control and inspection.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Emergency steps to spur the lagging coal production in Britain's mines were decided upon today at a special conference of mine workers' representatives with the National Coal Board and the Ministry of Fuel and Power.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- There were cheers in the clubhouse at Braves' Field this afternoon but they came from the hostile Tribe, which tonight is speeding back home, ready to resume play tomorrow in Cleveland after squaring the world series with a rousing victory.
The following is the text of an address given last night by President Truman in Newark, N.J., as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Terming the hold-up of a West Fifty-seventh Street dress shop last April 19 an "atrocious crime," General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan yesterday sentenced three men who had pleaded guilty to the theft to long terms in state prison.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 7 -- The gas industry can solve its biggest problem -- the shortage of natural gas -- through a rise in the price of that fuel, without any inflationary repercussions on the national economy, according to Edward Falck, consultant on power and utilities to the National Security Resources Board.

One of four elderly sisters riding in an automobile died last night of a heart attack after the car went out of control and crashed at West Fordham Road and Cedar Avenue, the Bronx, according to the police. The other sisters were cut and bruised.

Possibility of a new truck strike involving 4,300 members of Local 282, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, was indicated yesterday with the announcement that a membership meeting on Sunday would consider strike action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- An agreement between the United States and Great Britain permitting the use of more than $200,000,000 of Marshall Plan counterpart funds for the retirement of short term debts of the Bank of England was announced today by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- President Truman and Governor Dewey joined national, state and local American Legion organizations, city officials, industrial and civic leaders in paying tribute to the Carrier Corporation tonight when the national award of the American Legion was presented to it as the outstanding employer in this state of physically handicapped veterans.

Gagged with a handkerchief and with her hands tied behind her back, the body of 63-year-old Mrs. Fanny Leeder, who had been on home relief for the last eleven years, was discovered in the bedroom of her three-room apartment yesterday morning at 80 East Seventh Street.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Interior Minister Julio C. Villegas said today that Victor Raul-Haya de la Torre, internationally known head of the Apra party, would be arrested and tried for complicity in Sunday's abortive sailors' revolt at Callao.

Meat is the food that first will attract shoppers' attention today. They'll find declines of 2 to 11 cents on fifteen-different cuts of pork, beef and lamb, according to the City Department of Markets. Tariffs on other items for the week-end market basket haven't dropped so drastically.

"Children of Divorce," a documentary dealing with the problems of children of divorced parents, will be presented from 9:30 to 9:55 P.M. Monday, Oct. 25, by the Mutual Broadcasting System. It will feature recorded interviews between Judge Paul Alexander of the Domestic Relations Court in Toledo, Ohio, and children whose parents have separated.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- British and French circles said today that Secretary Marshall had broached the question of annulling the United Nations resolution on Spain in a private talk with Mr. Bevin and again when he met with Mr. Bevin and M. Schuman on Monday.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The Czechoslovak Government's vigorous attempt to have Dr. Jan Papanek ousted from two United Nations posts were defeated here today when a thumping majority of the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee voted to retain Prague's former delegate, who was dismissed from his diplomatic post seven months ago by the incoming Communist regime.

Mia Slavenska gave her only performance of "Giselle" with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, and, as was to be expected, drew a packed house, armfuls of flowers and countless decibels of applause.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Helen K. Haggerty's Rampart gave her many backers some anxious moments at Laurel Park today as she eked out a neck verdict over Mrs. Oscar L. Nyberg's Irisen in the featured Fort Myer Purse.

John Ellis, Republican-Liberal candidate for Representative from the Eighteenth Congressional District, held last night his first campaign street-corner rally in the stronghold of Vito Marcantonio, incumbent and nominee of the American Labor party.

At a time when it is absolutely essential that America and England should be as one, save for local customs, it is terrifying to read some of the comics in certain American papers. American children who take these papers are being brought up on a series of drawings showing the English soldier engaged in Nazi-like activities, murdering men, women and children, promising Boers as slaves to kaffirs and bushmen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, last director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, has turned the final affairs of that organization over to Harry E. Howell, administrator for liquidation, it was announced here today.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Einar Holmberg of the home club and the last player to report in a field of thirty-five captured low gross honors in the final one-day Metropolitan Golf Association tournament today. He posted 36, 38 -- 74 over the Forest Hill Field Club course.

The New York City Opera Company launched its fall season with performance of Puccini's "Tosca" last night at the City Center. Presented by the same cast which had made a highly favorable impression in the work last spring, and with Laszlo Halasz, the organization's artistic and musical director, again conducting it, the melodramatic masterpiece served admirably as an opening attraction.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 7 -- The Egyptians threw in tanks and bomb-carrying Spitfires today in a renewal of the fighting for the important heights dominating the Israeli Army's only land route to isolated settlements in the Negeb desert area of southern Palestine, an Israeli Army spokesman announced.

The Gulf Oil Company, needing funds for large capital expenditures, plans to cash in on nearly half of its common stock investment in the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company by selling 500,000 shares back to the sulphur company, it was announced yesterday.

Never ask your decorator what are the "smart" or "new" colors to use this season, Cornelia Conger, Chicago decorator, warned women attending the all day forum on "The New Spirit in Decoration" held at Town Hall yesterday under the auspices of the American Institute of Decorators.

Valuable illumined manuscripts of the fourteenth, fifteenth and sixteenth centuries have been stolen from a private library collection near Trieste, Italy, it was disclosed here yesterday by Luigi Nardi, Italian Consul General. Both the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Police Department were notified of the theft, more than a week ago, and the police broadcast a thirteen-state alarm.
Most people with high blood pressure are relatively normal and they need little in the way of medical management, Dr. Dana W. Atchley told doctors at the New York Academy of Medicine last night.

So much criticism has been directed against the methods employed by various Congressional committees investigating communism in America that little attention has been given to the attitude and conduct of many of the witnesses lawfully subpoenaed to testify under oath on matters pertinent to these inquiries.

The Smith Act of 1940 was attacked as unconstitutional in Federal Court yesterday by an attorney for the twelve Communist leaders indicted under it for conspiracy to teach and advicate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- An economic agreement that will bring the French import and export agencies into a new three-power organization has been reached "to all practical purposes" and will be signed in a few days, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, announced today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Grain markets moved up steadily on the Board of Trade today and closed at the top under the leadership of corn.

DETROIT, Oct. 7 -- Top police officials of the State of Michigan filed charges today that Carl Bolton, 39, former official of Local 400 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, arranged for or made the attempt on the life of Walter P. Reuther, president of the UAW, last April 20.

With the most important football game in Brooklyn College history in store tomorrow night against New York University at Ebbets Field, the Kingsmen yesterday went through their first secret workout of the season. The Flatbush team feels that if it can win this week's big game from a rival it never has beaten, an undefeated season may be achieved.

Mayor O'Dwyer will participate in the first NEW YORK TIMES Youth Forum of the season at 10:15 A.M. tomorrow over Station WQXR, when six junior high school students from the five boroughs discuss the question, "Who Governs Our City?" The half-hour program, with Dorothy Gordon as moderator, will be broadcast direct from the City Council Chamber in City Hall.

Civil rights policies in the United States lessen our influence in behalf of international good-will, it was declared yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Sadie T.M. Alexander, an attorney who was a member of President Truman's Committee on Civil Rights.
New Jersey's Democrats turned out by the thousands last night to welcome President Truman to the industrial cities of Elizabeth, Newark and Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Scrap Industry Advisory Committee unanimously approved today the formation of a single private purchasing corporation to handle and expedite the importation of iron and steel scrap from Germany, according to an announcement by Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce.

A New Zealand proposal that the Big Five seek a basis for reconvening the Atomic Energy Commission was agreed on yesterday by a majority of the commission. The previous stand of the Western Powers, bluntly expressed in the course of the debate by the British delegate, Hector McNeil, was that two years of negotiation had proved so futile that the Atomic Commission might as well be indefinitely suspended.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Criticizing the wide lack of understanding about the United Nations, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt pointed out here today that many persons directly connected with the General Assembly session as well as the general public still displayed a basic ignorance of the aims and set-up of the international peace organization.

Two hundred and six physically handicapped youngsters viewed yesterday the jobs they might do when they grow up. Hobbling on canes, walking quietly because of heart ailments or pushed in wheelchairs by relatives, the boys and girls left their special classes in nine public schools in Manhattan and the Bronx to see the demonstration at the American Museum of Natural History.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Egan Hanover crowded into the picture for 3-year-old trotting honors today by winning decisively in two straight heats the $52,670 Kentucky Futurity, coveted second gem of the Grand Circuit's double crown.

LLANDUDNO, Wales, Oct. 7 -- The Conservative party, at its annual conference here today, went unanimously on record in favor of imperial trade preference and against the Geneva trade treaty and the Havana Charter in so far as they limit the preferential system.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- Dr. Abram Leon Sachar was installed tonight as the first president of Brandeis University with a solemn pledge that never would students or faculty be chosen on quotas of "genetic or ethnic or economic distribution."

The Board of Estimate appropriated $281,286 yesterday for the purchase of a new type of loader unit that will be installed on sixty-two Department of Sanitation collection trucks and is expected to double their carrying capacity.

There was a five-horse feature at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday, and it still was a four-horse battle at the head of the stretch. But at the eighth pole it had narrowed to a duel between the Mimosa Stock Farm's War Trophy, the even-money favorite, and Bermill Farm's Bug Juice, second choice of the 16,300 in attendance.

There was a five-horse feature at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday, and it still was a four-horse battle at the head of the stretch. But at the eighth pole it had narrowed to a duel between the Mimosa Stock Farm's War Trophy, the even-money favorite, and Bermill Farm's Bug Juice, second choice of the 16,300 in attendance.
A grand jury will receive on Monday evidence accusing nine seamen of coercion in connection with organizing activities in New York's multi-million dollar garment industry, it was announced yesterday.

Retail trade here this week made a small increase despite some rain and a slight falling off of business due to religious holidays. Department store sales were estimated as about 4 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were down 8 per cent.

Representative John McDowell, Republican, of Pennsylvania, denied yesterday that he ever had charged, as was published, that the conspiracy indictments obtained by United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey against twelve Communisth)0*0*0*ileaders had been drawn up deliberately in such a way that they would not stick.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- With a prospect of a coast to the eastward under started sheets, the New Rochelle Yacht Club's annual fall distance race was started tonight from Hick's Ledge.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 8 The B-36, the world's biggest longdistance bomber, is expected to develop a range of 12,000 miles, top officers of the United States Air Force and engineers of ConsolidatedVultee Aircraft Corporation said here today.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Success of the Australian 15,000,000 ($60,000,000) 3 per cent conversion loan, which was issued at parity, provided fresh stimulus to Britishh)0*0*0*iGovernment bonds in the stock market here today. By the close of trading, all-around gains up to 1/4 point had been recorded.

A stenographic account of a deathbed statement in which Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore, pointed at John M. (Cockeye) Dunn as "the man who shot me" was read into the General Sessions record yesterday as the prosecution rested its argument against a retrial for two convicted slayers.

Plans for launching a nationwide retail promotion based on the theme "Democracy Works Here," sponsored jointly by the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the Saturday Evening Post were discussed yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 -- Not in so many words would they say it, but it was plain today the Cleveland Indians are quite confident the road ahead runs smoothly to world series triumph over the Boston Braves.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 -Rita Hayworth's next picture, "Lona Henry," will go before the cameras at Columbia next month with Norman Foster directing, the studio announced today. Jo Swerling is writing the scenario from a novel by Thomas Savage which deals with a girl who inherits a Montana cattle ranch.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Rutgers, the state university of New Jersey, now has the largest full-time enrollment in its history, Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the university, reported today at the fall meeting of the board of trustees.

Undefeated Brooklyn College will nake its bid for local football glory tonight when it meets twice-beaten New York University before 20,000 fans under the lights at Ebbets Field. The kick-off is scheduled for 8:30 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Securies and Exchange Commission authorized today Standard Gas and Electric Company of Chicago to sell 250,000 shares of Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company common stock.

SEATTLE, Oct. 8 -- "Misleaders of labor in some unions" were denounced today by Henry A. Wallace, Third-party candidate for President, as "more dangerous to organized labor than the TaftHartley Law itself."

WASHINGTON. Oct. 8 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States announced its support today of "whatever bill would best serve" to remedy problems arising from the Supreme Court's ruling last June with respect to overtime rates under the Wage-Hour Law.

President Truman finds himself "in hearty accord" with the sentiments prompting the observance of Oct. 17 as Laymen's Sunday, according to a letter he wrote to Wallace C. Speers, chairman of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World, the sponsor of the project.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A nation-wide agreement covering the interchange of loaded trailers among highway trucking companies, to speed the movement of long-haul freight, was announced today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8 -The Yale football team today concluded an intensive week of preparation for its contest against Columbia in Yale Bowl tomorrow with calisthenics and a signal drill.

Next week's schedule of new issues of securities is dominated again by the borrowing by railroads. The Great Northern will come to market on Thursday to sell $12,720,000 of equipment trust certificates. On the same day, the Virginian Railway will offer $9,500,000 of mortgage bonds and the Illinois Central Railroad will take bids on $5,500,000 of equipment trust certificates.

Governor Dewey's remarks yesterday at the ground-breaking ceremony for start of construction on the Governor Alfred E. Smith Houses on Manhattan's Lower East Side will be examined with deep interest for what they may portend in the event of his election as President.

DURHAM, N.H., Oct. 8 -- Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan warned tonight that our "dynamic" foreign policy might involve "the risk of war itself," but that there must be "no turning back" if it were to succeed. He told an audience at the University of New Hampshire that the attempt to achieve justice and stability through the United Nations would call for "hard-headed decisions and no appeasement."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino, Los Angelesborn Japanese, was indicted for treason here today. The offense carries a minimum penalty of five years' imprisonment and a maximum penalty of death.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 8 (AP) -Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, States' Rights candidate for President, said today that President Truman, Governor Dewey and Henry A. Wallace were "equally guilty" in compromising principles to catch minority votes.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Members of the new faculty of Brandeis University were Counselled today by Dr. Paul Klapper, president emeritus of Queens College, New York City, to avoid "fatal dissipation" of their strength and "submergence" of individuality in meeting the challenges that confronted contemporary liberal arts colleges.h)0*0*0*iO
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 8 -- Gov. Earl Warren today joined a national Republican effort to prevent the Democratic party from capturing a GOP Senate seat in Minnesota Nov. 2.

Burton E. (Barney) Shotton, who twice in a little over a year answered the call when Brooklyn needed him, will be manager of the Dodgers next season. Announcement that the sedate, gray 64-year-old veteran of the Brooklyn baseball organization would retain the post he resumed in the managerial upheaval of last July was made yesterday by Branch Rickey, president and general manager.

Christopher Sykes' new novel, "Answer to Question 33,"* recalls the famous "Sonia" novels of Stephen McKenna. It combines the triune themes of (1) love, (2) politics and (3) the stately homes of England with the superbly superficial skill that made McKenna so readable. It also closes the bynomeans unbridgeableh) 0*0*0*ichasm between the saturnine Mr. Maugham and the imperishably immature Mr. Waugh.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today dragged out a long smoldering issue with the State Department by declaring that the federation was "profoundly shocked to learn that the United States Government is making no protest to the decision to hold the third general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organizations in Beirut, Lebanon, in November."

While some retailers and important specialty shops were said to be holding their own in fur volume, compared with last year, the general sales picture in furs has not been particularly good beginning with the August fur sales.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Contributions in Westchester County to the campaign funds of Governor Dewey and other candidates on the Republican ticket have been so far below expectations that the United Republican Finance Committee conducted a reception here tonight at Pennwood, estate of Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker, for 300 persons of large income.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 8 -- In mud and rain at Archbold Stadium tonight Penn State's hard-running team lost little of its speed as it rolled to a 34-14 triumph over the Syracuse eleven.
The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, announced yesterday that Fordham would require $2,000,000 within the next three years for a building program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan set off an unexpected controversy at a National Press Club luncheon today by demanding that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey state forthrightly his position on farm price supports.
The text of the address by Governor Dewey at the ground-breaking ceremonies for the Governor Alfred E. Smith Houses yesterday follows:
Random notes.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 8 Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches and Johnny Farrell of Baltusrol won the qualifying medal in the New Jersey woman-pro alternate shot golf championship with a two-overpar 37, 37 -- 74 over the Crestmont Country Club course today.

It is with pleasure that we urge the public to respond wholeheartedly to the United Appeal of the Young Women's Christian Association for $455,000. In helping the Y.W.C.A., contributors have the satisfaction of knowing that they are aiding a most worthy organization that helps itself.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- An overbought condition developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and prices reacted after a stronger open. December corn up 5/8 cent a bushel at one time to a new high mark since midAugust, but closing trades in that grain were 5/8 cent lower to 1/8 cent higher than yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today announced signing of a contract by which the Government will contribute $20,000 annually to a program of fundamental research in wool designed to improve the texture of fabrics made of every grade of wool.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Villanova Wildcats put on a great second-half offensive to come from behind 'and. beat the" University of Miami Hurricanes by 19 to 10 before 42,827 fans in the Orange Bowl tonight. It was the largest crowd ever to see a game during the regular season in Florida.

Federal Judge John C. Knox ruled yesterday that the General Electric Company, two of its subsidiaries and three officers of the concerns had violated the Sherman Anti-Trust and Wilson Tariff Acts by conspiring between 1927 and 1940 to monopolize trade and commerce in this and foreign countries in hard metal compositionsh)0*0*0*iand products.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 8 -- The valley of Ladakh, remote Buddhist province of Kashmir state, is now securely in the hands of the Indian Army, Maj. Gen. Kalwant Singh, Chief of the General Staff of the Indian Army, reported today upon his return from Leh, the 11,500foot-high capital of the ancient feudal substate in the Himalayas.

" The Challenge of Modern Art," by Allen Leepa, artist and Assistant Professor of Art at Michigan State College, will be published by Beechhurst Press in November. It is a study of the modern art form, using more than 200 reproductions and diagrams to illustrate the author's points.

Charges that the Liberty tanker Eliza Jane Nicholson was traveling at excessive speed when she collided with and sank the tug Ann Marie Tracy in the Hudson River last Saturday were renewed yesterday by witnesses at the hearing being held by a Coast Guard board of inquiry at 42 Broadway.

Most New Yorkers -- so Any we have always been told Other come from some place else. City Sometimes some of these New Yorkers go back, a long time afterwards, to the place they came from -- not to stay there, mind you, but just on a visit.

BAD KISSINGEN, Germany, Oct. 8 -- Displaced Persons Commissioner Ugo Carusi, facing fifty-six editors of newspapers in displaced persons camps, avoided a categorical answer today to the question whether the United States would be able to take in the 205,000 refugees by June, 1950, as the act permits.

Two million tons of American shipping are immobilized in ports of the nation as a result of the West Coast maritime strike, now well into its sixth week. More than 190 vessels of the 375 under West Coast contracts are involved, and one, by one others are coming into the dead ports of the Pacific, and to Gulf and Atlantic ports where smaller tonnages are involved.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Israeli representatives here complained today at Egypt's election to the United Nations Security Council on the ground that Egypt did not fulfil the conditions of the United Nations Charter.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 - Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, warned here tonight that "American political life is sick for lack of a great idea."

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Secretary of State Marshall told forty labor leaders from twelve Western European nations today that "well organized trade unions" were necessary to production -- the key to European recovery.

Cigarette manufacturers, described as having, concentrated most of their business good-will on jobbers, are now "gaining respect" for retailers as a result of the latter's growing drive for more widespread fair trade practices in cigarette merchandising, it was learned yesterday at the annual convention of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, Inc., in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The huge Transamerica Corporation asked the Federal District Court here today to enjoin the Federal Reserve Board from trying it on an anti-trust complaint unless it provides more particulars in Support of its charges.

Thirty-nine Russians, including consular officials and their families, said to be the largest group to leave here since the closing of the consulates, sailed yesterday at noon aboard the Swedish American liner Gripsholm.

The nursing schools of the nation are failing to meet the increased public demand for better patient care, it was asserted yesterday by Miss Virginia M. Dunbar, dean of the Cornell UniversityNew York Hospital School of Nursing and one of the country's leading authorities on nursing.

POTSDAM, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Jess H. Davis, who was inaugurated here today as the eighth president of Clarkson College of Technology, called on colleges everywhere to make the development of "ideals, character and culture" a part of their educational program.

The Moscow radio, which in recent months has frequently delivered bitter attacks against the United States' "The Voice of America" broadcasts, will increase its English-language programs beamed to this country by 30 per cent.

The Experimental Theatre, set up two years ago by Actors' Equity Association and the Dramatists' Guild for the purpose of aiding actors and playwrights in testing plays of artistic merit, will not function this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UP) -Paul G. Hoffman, ECA administrator, warned European recovery nations tonight that unless they agreed on a joint plan to ship 50 per cent of American cargo in United States ships he would insist that each meet the requirement alone.

Acting Secretary of State Lovett and Assistant Secretary Allen gave assurance in their talks to the United States Advisory Commission on Information in Washington Thursday that they not only appreciated the value of the State Department's information program but that they, and Secretary Marshall, are taking an active and intelligent interest in its operation.
The growing number of surveys in the welfare field are indicative of the increasing community demand for the coordination and integration of existing services, it was learned yesterday.

TOKYO, Oct. 8 -- The first tentative steps toward freeing Japanese economy was taken today. The occupation's economic and scientific section approved the immediate price decontrol of 137 categories of consumer and industrial goods, including eighteen food items.

The 1,115 members of the Manhattan and Bronx women's division of the United Hospital Fund raised $199,495 in the first week of the fund's campaign, it was reported yesterday at a luncheon at the St. Regis Hotel.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The executive committee of the Liberal party, Britain's third largest, declared today that "any proposal to enter into closer relations with Franco Spain would seriously jeopardize the movement for Western Union" in Europe.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Gannett newspapers, publishers of The Democrat and Chronicle and The Times-Union, announced today that they had signed a new contract with Local 15, International Typographical Union.

Hide futures pricks on the Commodity Exchange moved up sharply yesterday as short covering came into the market in good volume. At the close prices were 10 to 50 points higher. Prices climbed gradually during the first three hours of trading. Near the peaksfor the day some hedge sellinghtlted the advance, and prices-closed 20 to 35 points under thehigh.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- Flouting the Soviet blockade of the city, the Western powers will increase the daily rations in the three Western sectors of Berlin by 200 calories, Maj. Gen. E. O. Herbert, British commandant, announced tonight.

h)0*0*0*iNineteen Latin-American officials are being trained in the techniques of social research at Columbia's Bureau of Applied Social Research in preparation for the taking of an inter-American census of the peoples of the Western Hemisphere in 1950, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A universal, self-positioning beam-reflecting device designed to serve as a distress signal on sea or land, a maritime reflecting buoy, or as a marker of a given spot or approximate position sought by a distant searcher within observation range, was patented this week (No. 2,450,417) by Romeo A. Bossi of Newton Center, Mass.

A general turmoil reigned for several minutes in Judge Samuel Joseph's Bronx County Court yesterday when one of five defendants up for trial on an assault charge struck another and knocked him to the floor in front of the judge's bench.
PARIS, Oct. 8--The United States declared today that it had already made two major concessions in planning outlines for anh)0*0*0*iinternational agency for the control of atomic energy.

MADRID, Oct. 8 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, said today "Genlteman's Agreement" would be shown in Spain after a possible few deletions. He made the statement after a two-and-onehalf-hour talk with Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

An encouraging summary of the effectiveness of recently developed methods for treating human anemia was coupled in the program of the graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine last night with a warning that such blood disorders may be more common than usually suspected.

The Feldwin Realty Corporation has acquired the SchwarzenbachHuber factory, occupying the entire block bounded by Bergenline Avenue, Twenty-second, Twentythird and West Streets, in Union City, N.J., from the Dalesta Realty Corporation, who acquired the property two years ago from Charles and Robert Benenson, New York realty operators.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The Federation of British Industries through its standing advisory committee began today consideration of a plan to continue for one year beyond March 1 the voluntary limitation on advertising of scarce and luxury goods.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 (AP) -More cases of poliomyelitis have been recorded in Los Angeles County in the present epidemic than ever before, but a lower percentage of the population has been affected than in the epidemic of 1934, Dr. Sidney B. Clark said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The United States Advisory Commission in Information requested today that the State Department's Office of International Information make a study of the news "blind spot" areas of the world where adequate information on world events was not available.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Total employment dropped in September for the second consecutive month, the Census Bureau reported today, sliding off by 933,000 to a total of 60,312,000.
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- As a result of the elections today by the General Assembly the composition of the Security Council and the Economic and Social Council for 1949 will be as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A group of seventy-two members of the foreign service experienced in visa work will be rushed into Germany, Austria and Italy in an effort to break the log-jam that has been holding up the displaced persons program approved by Congress, the State Department announced today.

The cotton futures market failed to develop a trend either before or after the publication of the Government's cotton estimate yesterday and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 4 points lower to 3 points higher than the previous close.
