On dry, thin-soiled upland pastures, around the cliffs of low-browed mountains and along the stonewall-lined roads that wind back among the hills one can see the pale-green beauty of the hay-scented fern. It is a small humble plant compared with some of its cousins.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 8 -- The sixth and newest W. J. Sloane store opens next Thursday in the Ridgeway shopping center. Other Sloane stores are located in New York, San Francisco, Beverly Hills, Washington and White Plains.

The Nies-Berger Chamber Orchestra, under Edouard Nies-Berger, organist of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, gave the first in a series of three concerts last night at Town Hall. With Amparo Iturbi, pianist, as soloist, the ensemble composed of members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, presented an unusual and interesting program featuring four novelties.

The mechanics of wire tapping may be a mystery to the public but underworld "big shots" know all about recording telephone conversations, it was reported yesterday at the fourth public hearing conducted by the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association on wire tapping.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Directors of the First National Bank of Chicago called today a special stockholders meeting for Dec. 21 to act on a plan for increasing the bank's capital stock.

Two pictures, both foreign, will open locally today. "Foolish Husbands," a French production with Fernand Gravet and Micheline Presle, will arrive at the Ambassador .... The newcomer at the Stanley, "Without Prejudice," has a mixed cast of whites and Negroes and was produced in Russia.
MONTREAL, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Four members of the New York Rangers hockey team were injured tonight in an automobile accident just north of the United States-Canadian border.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Russian feelers regarding the possibility of a Council of Foreign Ministers' conference on a treaty with Austria were understood to have been conveyed to three Western powers today by Dr. Karl Gruber, Austrian Foreign Minister.

Lumber production for the week ended Oct. 2 was 15.5 per cent below the preceding week, though it was 8.5 per cent above the comparable week last year. Shipments were down 2.1 per cent compared with last year, and orders were down 8.4 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsement of Municipal Court Justice George J. Joyce, Republican, Democratic and Liberal party candidate for Kings County Judge, and Max M. Meltzer, Democratic candidate for Municipal Court Justice in the Second Manhattan District.

h)0*0*0*iWASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Five American educators have left for Tokyo on a three-month assignment with General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters to promote Japanese research in the social sciences, the Department of the Army announced today.

LLANDUDNO, Wales, Oct. 8 -The Conservative party at its annual conference here condemned the Labor party's policy of restricting newsprint. It approved unanimously a resolution offered by Walter Fletcher, Member of Parliament for Bury, which implied that should the Conservatives win the next general election, they would give priority to the import of newsprint.
A new American committee to aid Palestinian refugees met yesterday to plan a program of assistance on an "impartial" basis.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 (AP) Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, national singles champion, entered the semi-final of the national hard court tennis tourney today, but he did it the hard way.h)0*0*0*iO
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- Maj. Gen. John W. O'Daniel, new military attache of the United States Embassy, left Moscow today to visit Stalingrad.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger imposed a fine of $100,000 yesterday on the Shoe Factory Supply Corporation of 235 Lynch Street, Brooklyn, and additional fines and prison sentences on four persons who pleaded guilty with it to illegally extending priorities and to black markets sales involving 3,100,000 yards of cotton textiles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -Capital Airlines said today it earned an operating profit of $13,008 in August. It was the fourth consecutive month in which an operating profit has been shown.

MARINELAND, Fla., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Those forty pilot whales that ran up on the beach yesterday to their death were not suicides; they were just hungry. This food angle was brought to the fore today by Dr. Harold E. Anthony of the Museum of Natural History in New York.

Vitrified china manufacturers shortly will increase wholesale prices of some items as much as 10 per cent, industry leaders disclosed yesterday. The action was attributed to higher production costs resulting from a 10 per cent wage increase recently granted.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman fined Local 1250 of the Department Store Employes Union,independent, $20,000 yesterday for disobeying an injunction he issued on Sept. 14 barring the continuance of strike action against Oppenheim Collins Co.

The first break in three and a half months of deadlocked negotiations between the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, came yesterday with an offer of a 10-cent hourly wage increase by the employers.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8 -- President Aleman today appointed Commodore David Coello Ochoa Secretary of the Navy and elevated Manuel Ramirez Vasquez, UnderSecretary of Labor, to the top post of that ministry. The Chief Executive, however, did not carry out the drastic Cabinet shakeup that people had expected after several Ministers had been made targets of strong press and popular criticism two months ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 8 -- The nation's retail drug store business for the past three years has averaged approximately $3,600,000,000 annually -- nearly two and a half times as great as the 1939 figure of $1,563,000,000 and three and a half times what it was in 1933, it was reported here today.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Cornell University began today a two-year campaign for a $12,500,000 Greater Cornell Fund, during ceremonies marking the eightieth anniversary of the opening of the university.

Citing a survey of the Bureau of Labor Statistics showing that workers with cardiac impairments produced 2.4 per cent more than unimpaired workers on the same jobs, Robert R. Behlow, regional director of the bureau, told a symposium on heart disease in industry at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday that workers with cardiac impairments, properly placed, are not handicapped workers.

MADRID, Oct. 8 -- Angry headlines and editorials in the statecontrolled press today reflected the bitterness against Britain produced here by the British Foreign Office's statement publicizing the alleged pact between the Spanish Socialists and Monarchists in exile.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- An admonition that the nursery schools of America "cannot rest on their laurels" won over the years in pointing the way toward the finest kind of home-school relationships was voiced here tonight by Ernest Osborne of Teachers College, Columbia University.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 -- Disappointed but not discouraged, the Boston Braves, down 2 to 1 to the Indians, were confident today they could even the series here tomorrow.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- The strikers triumphed in the first major outbreak of violence in the French coal strike today when Mobile Guardsmen tried to oust sit-down workers from a steel mill in Lorraine. A Yugoslav worker was reported to have been killed in another clash.

In the absence Of war or greatly expended demand for steel for defense purposes, the backlog of steel orders from many consumer goods industries should be eliminated at the end of the next twelve months, Charles R. Hook, chairman of the Armco Steel Corporation, declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- Auxiliaries, pastors and congregations of the United Lutheran Church inh)0*0*0*iAmerica are called upon to give constant attention, study and prayer" to the problem of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union in a recommendation adopted at today's session of the biennial convention.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 (AP) -Glen Dobbs, throwing four touchdown strikes and setting up another tally out of seven scoring plays, passed the Los Angeles Dons to a 49-28 victory over the Chicago Rockets tonight in the wildest scoring spree in the All American Football Conference this year. A crowd of 31,119 watched the game.
BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- Berlin's City Assembly ousted a Communist City councilor and agreed to holdh)0*0*0*icity elections Dec. 5 at a meeting in the British sector today.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper ruled today that New Jersey Legislators did wrong in letting the State pay the tabs for their meals, drinks and hotel accommodations during the 1948 legislative session.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 -- Backing John L. Lewis in his anti-Truman stand, the United Mine Workers' convention gave indirect endorsement today to the Republican Presidential candidacy of Thomas E. Dewey

United Nations Week, a project sponsored jointly by the National Broadcasting Company and the American Association for the United Nations, will be inaugurated at 4:35 P.M. tomorrow over the NBC network. Warren R. Austin, permanent, United States delegate to the United Nations, will be interviewed in Paris, and George/V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State, will speak from New York.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- With the small powers still continuing their efforts to avoid a Soviet veto, the next meeting of the United Nations Security Council on the Berlin blockade, which had been expected to take place tomorrow, will not be held until Monday or Tuesday, it developed tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 -- President Peron today issued an executive decree limiting the pages of all Argentine papers, but declaringh)0*0*0*ithat all space devoted to publication of Government announcements, communiques, pictures or legal advertising did not count.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Norway and Cuba were elected easily today to the United Nations Security Council. But the General Assembly took four ballots to pick Egypt for the third of the three seats in which replacements were made among the six non-permanent members of the Council.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the third game of the world series at Municipal Stadium today follows:

Walter C. Hewitt, developer, purchased the corner business plot having a frontage of 335 feet on Carll Boulevard and 164 feet on Larkfield Road, East Northport, L. I., from the Carll family, owners of the property for over sixtyh)0*0*0*iyears.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Hoover Commission; which is studying reorganization of theh)0*0*0*iFederal Government, held its first fall meeting today and adjourned to Nov. 8.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 8 - Army, paying its first football visit to these parts in fourteen years, will meet the University of Illinois tomorrow in a test expected to cast significant light on the suspected status of Earl Blaik's undefeated cadets as one of the nation's gridiron powerhouses.

A special committee comprising six radio industry leaders was appointed yesterday by the Radio Manufacturers Association to aid the Federal Communications Commission in arriving at an early decision on opening ultra-high frequencies to television broadcasting.

Posthumous joint award of this year's Nobel Peace Prize is to be made to Mohandas K. Gandhi and Count Folke Bernadotte, slainh)0*0*0*iUnited Nations Mediator for Palestine, according to Christian S. Oftedal, a member of the Storting's (Norwegian Parliament's) Nobel Committee, writing in the newspaper Aftenblad of Stavanger, Norway.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct, 8 -orders desired to Strengthen state, banking procedures were issued today by John J. Dickerson, State Banking Commissioner. They stem from the investigation into the tangled affairs of former Newark Police Judge James Pellecchia Jr. that disclosed loop-holes in the regulations, the Commissioner explained.

The University of Missouri sold yesterday an issue of $1,745,000 dormitory revenue bonds due on Nov. 1, from 1951 to 1968, to a banking group headed by Harris, Hall Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.13 for 4s, 2 3/4s and 3s, an interest cost of 2.96 per cent.h)0*0*0*iO

Intermittent rain yesterday alleviated a dry spell in the metropolitan area, greatly to the relief of water supply officials and hikers. The downpours, however, were decidedly more than wet notes for home owners combating flooded cellars and plane operators at La Guardia Field, Queens, who wrestled with disrupted schedules.

DETROIT, Oct. 8 -- With many questions unanswered, James N.h)0*0*0*iMcNally, Prosecutor of Wayne County, obtained a warrant today for the arrest of Carl E. Bolton in connection with the shooting, on April 20, of Walter P. Reuther, head of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.
BUFFALO, Oct. 8 -- President Truman pinned his first big bid for New York's forty-seven electoral votes tonight on the issue of "hard times or prosperity."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Because of population shifts, Southern and border states stand to lost seven seats in the House of Representatives after 1950 -- all of them to California.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- The Italian Government, it was learned from diplomatic sources, is expected to appeal to the Council of Foreign Ministers against the Russian demand that Italy should deliver immediately thirty-three warships awarded to the Soviet Union by the four-power naval committee under conditions of the peace treaty.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 -- They moved the world series into huge Municipal Stadium today, but only the Indians kept moving. The Braves remained at a standstill.

Players of favorites made many happy returns to the cashier's windows at Rainy Jamaica yesterday. Six of the people's choices made the grade, the sextet including S. D. Sidell's Allie's Pal in the Class C feature for 3-year-old-fillies.

Fearing competition, local food chains refused yesterday to announce changes in their meat prices for Monday. No further reductions were listed for today, although seasonally heavy runs of hogs and cattle should lower the wholesale market next week.
ROME, Oct. 8 -- Minister of Defense Randolfo Pacciardi expressed deep concern in the Senate today over the Communist party's efforts to create Communist "cells" in the Italian armed forces.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 8 (AP) -Governor Warren brought his party's battle into this Democraticfarm labor stronghold tonight with promises of strong Republican support for conservation, rural electrification and farm prices.
LAUREL, Md.. Oct 8, (AP) -- Continuing on gamely after being carried out all through the stretch, Mrs. Elmer Truman's Send off captured the feature at Laurel Park today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 - David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, today advised Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, that withdrawal of recognition by the commission from two CIO unions at atomic-energy installations was a matter affecting the loyalty of the union officers "to the interests of the United States."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 - President Truman has been considering another direct appeal to Soviet Premier Stalin on the Berlin crisis.
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- At least three nations participating in the European Recovery Program are all set to profit from the refusal of the United States to sell certain types of goods to Eastern Europe.

World series or no, college football takes its customary large share of attention today with big games scattered through the country and with action centered in Illinois of particular importance in the national picture.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct.8,-The Christian foreign mession enterprise was described today by Harold E. Stassen president of the University of Pennsylvania, as a major bulwark against war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 - The text of the letter from Chairman Lilienthal of the Atomic Energy Commission to President Fitzgerald of the United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers of America was as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- As of 3 o'clock this afternoon, Coach George Munger of Pennsylvania's football team was out of sorts with the world. He felt that Princeton had played a low trick on the Quakers in losing to Brown and the prospect was that his team would have to face an enraged Tiger on Franklin Field tomorrow with only one of his six tackles available.

BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Senator Alben W. Barkley called today for election of a Democratic national administration to assure adequate housing for veterans, rural residents and low-income workers. In a speech delivered here, he accused Republicans of having blocked housing programs, which he said were intended to aid the masses.
Following is the text of President Truman's campaign address at Buffalo last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORKh)0*0*0*iTIMES:
We have it on good authority -no less than our City Desk reporter who covers "the food front" -- that the drop in retail meat prices this week was only temporary.

Governor Dewey, Republican candidate for the Presidency, expressed the conviction here yesterday afternoon that the problem of providing homes for an estimated 3,000,000 families could and would be solved and placed himself on record as favoring the use of federal funds when they were "required to get action.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 8 -Procedure by which the practical physician can assist in the early diagnosis and treatment of cancer was outlined by specialists at a conference on "clinical frontier problems in cancer" here today with 150 New Jersey physicians attending.
Many persons have complained, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday, that Manhattan "was robbing Brooklyn" of its share of civic improvements.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 8 Unofficial estimates tonight put the total damage from yesterday's short but violent hurricane at about 200,000 ($806,500). This takes into account the extensive cleaning up that will be necessary.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A three-point program to meet the "dangerously critical" shortage of housing for Army families was announced today by Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army.

SAN DIEGO, Oct. 8 -- A brief but intense cross-country investigation was set in motion today when a young man wearing the uniform of a Russian Army officer was apprehended by Marine military police among a crowd of civilians watching a large Navy-Marine amphibious landing exercise on the shore at near-by Oceanside today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -State Department officials said today that Russia had repudiated last May an agreement with the United States "regularizing" temporary visits of American Eskimos to the Siberian mainland.

SEATTLE, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The president of the Washington State Federation of Labor announced today AFL longshoremen will work cargo in Tacoma Monday morning despite Congress of Industrial Organization Maritime Union picket lines.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Prime Minister Attlee ordered a full judicial inquiry tonight into allegations of irregularities at the Board of Trade in which the name of its Parliamentary Under-Secretary, John W. Belcher, has been mentioned.
Robert F. Wagner Jr., city Commissioner of Housing, assailed Governor Dewey's housing record yesterday as "one of underhanded sabotage, or rear-guard stalling of piecemeal legislation."

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- An officer who rose from the ranks, Gen. Sir William Slim, former commander of the Allied land forces in Southeast Asia, was appointed today as chief of the British Imperial General Staff in succession to Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, now chairman of the new Western Union Defense Council.

TOKYO, Oct. 8 -- The Japanese Socialist party today decided to refuse to participate in the new Government that will be formed as a result of the collapse of Premier Hitoshi Ashida's coalition Cabinet. Instead, it decided to become the nation's principal opposition group.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Small Business Adivisory Committee of the Department of Commerce urged Secretary Charles Sawyer today to tell business management of its direct "responsibility" in keeping employes educated in "the American way of life" as a safeguard against Communist infiltration.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- William J. Granata, 42 years old, a Republican leader and member of the Illinois Industrial Commission, was murdered early today in front of the Randolph Towers Hotel Apartments in the Loop.

The New York City Opera Company's production of "Pelleas et Melisande," which was the best seller of the spring season, returned to the City Center last night. It came back a better integrated performance than it was last spring when it was new to the company's repertory.
The Mexican Government has filed an official claim to the 2,550 pieces of Mexican gold seized by customs authorities in Brooklyn last Tuesday, it became known yesterday.
A new tenant has moved into 240 Central Park South, the only one of 1,000 occupants getting his rent "for peanuts."

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 8 -- T. Y. Yun, Home Minister in the Korean Government, today told the press that he had information that 15,000 troops of the North Korean People's Army had taken up positions within three miles of the border separating the United States and Soviet zones of Korea.

The taxpayer with nine stores and garage and parking lot for 300 automobiles at 159-67 West Fifty-third Street through to 156-58 West Fifty-fourth Street were purchased by the Raynes Realty Corporation, Julius B. Raynes, president, from the 167 West Fifty-third Street Corporation.

The stock ,market experience yesterday considerable difficulty in maintaining its recovery effort mainly because of the slackened pace of trading. Prices on the Stock Exchange followed a narrow drift throughout the session land closed mixed, with a slight lean to the lower side.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The Russians claimed tonight they discovered the Pacific side of America in the first half of the 18th century.

A German journalist who spent six years in the Buchenwald concentration camp, proposed last night that Ilse Koch, former wife of the commandant, be held for trial in the regular German courts. He asserted there was sufficient unheard evidence to make this possible.

Hand-fashioned Scandinavian furnishings, difficult for homemakers to find outside of exhibits are grouped in a gift center in the new Bonniers, which opened yesterday at 605 Madison Avenue. In the balcony of the store, which also has a book and records department, the items range from Swedish crystal, Danish ceramics and pewter pieces to a few fabrics, rugs and tables.

LLANDUDNO, Wales, Oct 8 Anthony Eden carried the Conservative party's annual conference here behind him today in support of a moderate global policy based on unity with the British Empire, Western Europe and the United States.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 8 -- The Indian Navy, which now consists of one former British cruiser and a few small craft, will be augmented by three destroyers to be acquired from Britain next year and a second cruiser later, Vice Admiral W. E. Parry, Commander in Chief of the Royal Indian Navy, announced at a press conference today.

LOS ANGELES, ,Oct. 8 -- The American transport airplane of 1955 will be at least twice as good as the average transport plane of today, aviation engineers indicated today at the National Aeronautic Meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 8 -- Ah)0*0*0*iUnited States official confirmed today that Brig. Gen. Earl S. Hoag, chief of the United States Air Force group in Turkey, had given a statement to the newspaper Cumhuriyet denouncing an Ankara dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Sept. 26 alleging difficulties in the administration of United States aid to Turkey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Total business inventories reached a valuation of $52,667,000,000 by the end of August, $907,000,000 over the previous month and the high point for 1948, the Department of Commerce announced today.
PARIS, Oct. 8 -- The United Nations General Assembly approved today by a unanimous vote a draft of the protocol for the control of new types of synthetic drugs.
WASHINGTON Oct. 8 (AP) --A 1948 cotton crop with a record value of about $2,736,000,000 was reported today by the Department of Agriculture.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party candidate for re-election in the Eighteenth Congressional District charged yesterday that two Republican leaders of the district had registered "unlawfully" for the coming election.
BOSTON, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Everett Dorr, standing firmly on a shrapnelscarred left leg, booted Boston University to a 14-to-13 victory over Colgate in a driving rainstorm at Fenway Park tonight.

0*0*0*iOThe high rate of rejections by Army examiners of the 25-year-old group called up this month for military service under the peacetime draft was attributed yesterday by Col. Candler Cobb, director of the city Selective Service, to the presence of a large number of men who were of the 4-F class during the last war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today set dates for hearings in Chicago, New York City, Miami, Fla., and Los Angeles, at which it will require railroad and Pullman witnesses to go thoroughly into points arising out of charges of "black market" selling of sleeping car and reserved coach space.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 8 -- Regulations imposed by the Bank of German States will curb any inflationary tendencies resulting from the unfreezing of 1,500,000,000 Deutschmarks from blocked accounts, United States and German financial officials said today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 8 -- The Israeli Government announced tonight that the country's oil requirements had been assured in a newly signed agreement under which the Shell and Socony oil companies would sell sufficient supplies of refined oil to meet the new state's current needs.

This reader wishes to sympathize with A. D. Frunke, Lieutenant Colonel (Ret.), concerning his plaintive lament in your Letters column on the vagaries of sergeants. I am well-qualified to do so, being an ex-sergeant and an ex-technical sergeant, too.

THIS year augurs well to be a red-letter one for those who savor their cinematic scores, what with William Walton's "Hamlet," Aaron Copland's "Red Pony," Virgil Thomson's "Louisiana Story" and excerpts from Francis Poulenc in Hitchcock's "Rope." Not that this young genre has failed to show its mettle before this season, for a good many movies that are still running boast excellent scores.

IN Sunday's TIMES your critic offers a half-hearted defense of the curiously unorganized method by which the American theatre functions, presenting in its favor the opinion that its freedom "derives directly and perhaps solely from its poverty and anarchy."

THE need to reduce the cost of transportation, lodgings and fees for ski-lifts and tows was generally agreed upon by delegates attending the annual two-day convention of the New York State Winter Sports Council last week-end in Cooperstown.

THE latest brother team in the movie business is the Riskins, Everett and Robert, who have entered the independent producing field with Equitable Pictures. Although there are those in Hollywood who feel that the risks involved in independent enterprise outnumber the advantages, Everett Riskin is "sanguine about the whole business," believing that there always will be room for the fellow who "knows how to make pictures."
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Authoritative sources said today that an interim Indonesian Federal Government might be functioning by early December.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP) -- An unheralded and hard-playing St. Bonaventure football team surprised all but their few supporters today by battling a heavier and favored Boston College eleven to a 7-7 tie before 16,000 fans at Alumni Field.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 9 -- An undermanned Hofstra eleven was no match for Lebanon Valley today, the visitors winning by 41 to 0. Lebanon Valley made seventeen first downs to the home team's six, and showed a net gain of 359 yards rushing.

ROME, Oct. 9 -- Three hundred thousand Italian workers will find employment in the winter through use of the lire fund resulting from the sale of European Recovery Program goods, James D. Zellerbach, EPR administrator in Italy, said today.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Both Secretary of State Marshall and Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, may be present next Saturday when Cabinet members of the sixteen Marshall Plan countries of Europe formally submit to the Economic Cooperation Administration their first annual recovery programs along with an agreement on indirect aid in the form of trade grants among these countries.
MEMBERS of the Council of Parent Teachers Associations had on their minds the usual assortment of children's behavior difficulties when they decided that they needed some expert help.
I was happy to read Oscar E. Ewing's article, "To Improve the Nation's Health."
Yesterday's session on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet. Final prices were 1 point higher to 5 points lower than on Friday. The gain was a nominal one in the October contract.

EACH year Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine offers one First Prize and six Second Prizes in a detective short-story contest, and each year the editors of the magazine find more than that number deserving of prizes, and special awards are made in various categories.
REVERSING their usual procedure, the Hooper organization's statisticians have released the results of a survey among persons found not to be listening to the radio when the telephone call was made.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 9 -- Politically, the South is now "hotter" than it has ever been since 1928. For the fourth time since reconstruction days Southern politics has become national politics.

THE current disputes over the record of the Eightieth Congress should not be dismissed as mere political hokum, to be expected in a campaign year. Read in light of the relations between President and Congress for many years back, they signalize a widening preach between the two active branches of the Government -- an incipient total breakdown in democratic governmental process.

Stirred by the wanton slaying of an 80-year-old spinster, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander sent 200 policemen, one of the largest crime details in recent years, into the Bedford section of Brooklyn yesterday. The police head went to the scene to take personal command of the detectives and plainclothes men.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians have now reached such a pretty pass that they have started beating the Braves with a former softball third baseman. Steve Gromek, an angular young man whose early career was entirely in softball competition, polished off the forlorn Bostonians in even faster time than Gene Bearden had required yesterday.

Putting the world on wheels is the ambitious objective of the recently organized International Road Federation, whose far-flung activities girdle the globe. OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 9 -- The future trend of food prices paid by consumers and paid to farm producers was a prime topic of conversation in the Middle West this week.

ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 9 (AP) -Governor Dewey said today that America and Italy never had been "more closely bound together by common purpose than they are today".

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Wheat showed today an underlying firm tone in a grain market on the Board of Trade which otherwise slipped a little lower. Mills bought a little wheat and it was announced that six cargoes of 80 per cent extraction flour had been sold to Italy over night.

DALLAS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Oklahoma broke its drought of Texas football victories today with a blistering running game that swept down the Longhorns, 20 -- 14 in one of the wildest offensive battles ever staged between these intersectional rivals.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Premier Henri Queuille in a broadcast to the nation tonight called the miners' walkout a political strike and said the Government would not allow it to break down the Marshall Plan.

THE town with the funny name is La Jolla, Calif., and the name is funny both because nobody is sure what it means and because casual visitors make a grab bag of pronouncing it. Max Miller, before, between and since his excursions to war, has been making it his country seat -- a place to write and to keep track of what his Pacific Ocean is up to.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Attorneys for the National Labor Relations Board today announced legal action aimed at applying the Taft-Hartley Act to the construction industry. HOWARD FAST is historical novelist with a difference. He has always shunned the standard ingredients of that art -- sex, saber and swashbuckling -- and he has never permitted the drama on the stage to be obscured by the opulence of the setting.

Buddy O'Connor and Frank Eddolls, New York hockey players injured in an automobile accident in Canada Friday night, will be lost to the Rangers for at least six weeks, the National League club announced yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The Israeli Government sent today a strongly worded protest to the United Nations Security Council charging the Arab countries with "grave violations of the truce." The protest was contained in a letter by Aubrey S. Eban, representative at the United Nations of the Provisional Israeli Government, who, in listing the six "major breaches," complained that in each case the United Nations had failed to enforce the truce terms.

SIR Osbert Sitwell is an aristocrat, an eccentric an artist. He is also a Sitwell . Edith, Osbert, and Sacheverell have made the Sitwell name famous and colorful -- no easy achievement in what Sir Osbert calls "the present democracy age."
THE Postoffice Department made available last week the design of this year's twenty-sixth stamp -- a 3-cent brown marking the centennial of the establishing of Fort Bliss as "the Post of El Paso."
ALBANY, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A sharp rise in registration today sent the total for the four days this year over the mark for 1944, the last Presidential election year, in nine cities in up-state New York.

It was with great pleasure that I read your editorial in which you endorsed the candidacy of Hon. Thomas E. Dewey for the Presidency of the United States. CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 9 -- Czechoslovakia's Minister, Frantisek Krucky, asked the protection of the Egyptian Government today after refusing orders recalling him to Prague.

While the eyes of the world are focused on the "cold war" in Europe, with Berlin as the critical center, a broader, "hotter" and in the long run at least equally decisive front of that war has now spread across another and larger continent with ominous potentialities for mankind.
THE playwright of the month in London undoubtedly is Terence Rattigan, who has scored a smash hit with a double bill consisting of two longish one-act plays.

TICONDEROGA -- A trip to Fort Ticonderoga in the fall can be doubly rewarding. It is an authentic and absorbing historic shrine and a museum increasing in inter st as restoration work continues. Also, it is a vantage point for an autumnal panorama, with its commanding view of Lake George and Lake Champlain and its colorful setting of maples, aspens and beech against dark pines.

In an effort to convince representatives of South Queens civic organizations that planes using the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, were not making unnecessary noise, officials of the airport yesterday showed a group of civic organizations officials the airport facilities.

FOLIAGE is now at its peak of photographic possibilities. Although color film is a must, whether in still or movie cameras, amateurs should not overlook the opportunities offered by black-and-white panchromatic film.

WHEN it comes to motion picture pioneers, Gilbert M. (Bronco Billy) Anderson is one of the granddaddies of them all. Bronco Billy, the original movie cowboy who gained international fame more than forty years ago with "The Great Train Robbery" and his numerous Bronco Billy films, today lives unobtrusively in Los Angeles and has no connection with the motion picture industry he helped put on the map.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Action on the Argentine proposal that the Organization of the American States -- the regional body set up at the Bogota Conference -- receive a permanent invitation to sit in the United Nations General Assembly was delayed today at least until Monday by the Assembly's Legal Committee.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Competition in the Haebler Trophy series among the International sloops and renewal of that for the Godfrey prize among the Class S craft was carried on today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Oct. 9 -- Army Signal Corps engineers have developed a wind-measuring instrument, now in the experiment stage at the engineering laboratories here, that is devoid of movable parts and is electrically heated to prevent the accumulation of ice.

A lone armed thug held up a Pan American World Airways cashier yesterday morning and escaped with $3,365 in the first holdup reported at La Guardia Field since it opened in 1939. In his haste, the thief overlooked another compartment in the open office safe containing several thousand dollars more.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- Sir Hartley Shawcross denounced today the Soviet proposal for a one-third reduction of the Big Five armed forces as "a somewhat threadbare propaganda device." THE story of David is a favorite in the Old Testament. David, as Miss King has presented him, is a magnetic personality. Consecrated, while he was only a boy, to the service of a stern and relentlessly just God; his artistic, beauty-loving nature was tempered and balanced as he matured by strength of character and direction of purposes.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Canisius evened a 26-year-old football score with Fordham today, cutting loose with a fanciful lateral passing attack to whip the Rams, 30 to 21, before 5,184 spectators in Civic Stadium. Fordham had won the only previous meeting, 13 to 0, in 1922.

CURIOUSLY, in a city which was known artistically first for its elegant Greek Revival architecture and later for the cigar-smoking urchins of Duveneck, the citizenry of Cincinnati now sits serenely in the lobby of the new Terrace Plaza Hotel with a gigantic Calder mobile quivering overhead and dines happily there against a semi-circular wall with a fantastic, pinwheel-bright Miro abstraction.

AMONG the events of the most crowded week of the season thus far -- some thirty-five were on the calendar -- the Museum of Modern Art opened an exhibition of sculpture by Elie Nadelman. Some forty pieces, together with drawings, have been assembled by Lincoln Kirstein, who has been at work for two years sorting and arranging the thousand examples the sculptor left behind at his death two years ago.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 9 -- President Truman and John L. Lewis will be under the same roof Monday at the Netherland Plaza Hotel, which is headquarters for the convention of the United Mine Workers. Mr. Lewis is occupying a duplex suite and much of the rest of the hotel is filled with miners.

IN our eager preoccupation with Laurence Olivier's "Hamlet" last week, this column failed to make mention of two or three concurrent films which, against lesser competition, would rate such attention themselves. LONDON, Oct. 9 -- A 14 per cent drop in apparel sales in August compared with July was noted by Britain's Board of Trade today in a report on retail trade. The decline was sharper than usual for August and occurred despite easing of ration restrictions on many items.

It was then and then only time the Lions of Columbia were certain that victory over a stubborn Yale foe was theirs.

I., Oct. 9 -The best-of-breed trophy that Howard Newman's Kolo von Beckgold won today in the specialty of the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island was overshadowed in interest to the general dog show public by a new judging plan the organization introduced in its first show-giving venture.

CHICAGO, Oct 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder and Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, the national amateur titleholder, will meet in the final of the national hard court tennis championship tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 -- Before the largest crowd in World Series history, a gathering of 81,897, Lou Boudreau's Indians needed only one hour and thirty-one minutes today to topple Johnny Sain and the National League champion Braves, 2 to 1, in the fourth game of the 1948 fall classic.

Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second New York District, given by the New York City Post 505, Veterans of Foreign Wars.
ATLANTA, Oct. 9 -- Cotton-picking in the fields of the South is nearing a peak, and in many areas there is considerably more of the staple than can be gathered by available workers.

HONOLULU -- The second annual Aloha Week, Nov. 14 to 21 -- seven days of pageantry and festivity celebrating the islands' ancient cultures and traditions -- will mark the grand opening of Hawaii's fall and winter tourist season.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 9 (AP) -- A highly favored Brown football team scored in every period to defeat a smaller Rhode Island State eleven by 33 -- 0 before a crowd of 11,000 today at Brown Field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- A member of the National Mediation Board said tonight that the board would decide Monday whether to refer to the White House a threatened strike of sixteen non-operating railroad unions.

The new issue of the New York Public Library's "Branch Library Book News," available at the central building and all the branches, heads its suggested reading this month with material on the issues of the coming election.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- New Englanders wandering the streets between 1 and 3 P. M. this week were looked on with suspicion. All normal residents of this area were either at the ball park in person or glued to radio and television sets, at home, in offices or factories, following the fortunes of the National League Boston Braves playing against the American League Cleveland Indians in the 1948 World Series.

With the inauguration of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as president of Columbia University on Tuesday, the university will enter a new era of educational development. Plans have been advanced for the most ambitious expansion program ever undertaken by any college or university.
DETROIT, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Jigs and dies that will shape new General Motors and Chrysler 1949 lines virtually have been completed, although most car makers still are far behind in 1948 output.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The United States will have about 95,000,000 men and women of voting age by election day, Nov. 2, the Census Bureau estimated tonight. Many of them will be ineligible to vote for various reasons and others will not go to the polls.

THE author of "The Shadow" and "Doc Savage" thrillers has come up with a first-rate book on magic, thereby proving himself nearly as versatile as his literary brainchildren. This volume enables amateurs to spellbind and mystify with a professional flourish.

DON'T fall into the error of dismissing this as a quickie among those African books which flood the stalls these days. Come to think of it, most of the items in the current crop of Africana possess merit of one sort or another.

The final portion of the library of the late Thomas Bird Mosher of Portland, Me., will be auction tomorrow and Tuesday, together with literary porperty from the states of the late Dr. Bertala Nemenyi of Budapest, Hungary and Herbert Long of Jersey City N. J.

CITY gardeners, like their country cousins, busy themselves in October with the groundwork that will turn their back yards into green and flowering oases next year. Bulbs must be put in the ground now if they are to bloom in spring, and while the gardener is setting them out he can plant for next summer and fall as well.

NOT long ago, Evelyn Waugh observed that writers in the last twenty-five years have begun "a stampede to the heights." They have turned from tracts on strikes and sewage to parables of death and judgment. This may not presage the general scurry that Mr. Waugh looks for, but it certainly is the cardinal fact in serious writing just now, and Ethel Mannin's latest novel is a singular example of it.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The Soviet Union is leading on points in the championship propaganda battle with the Western powers, which opened three weeks ago in the Palais de Chaillot. This is the general feeling of those delegates to the United Nations General Assembly who are not bound hand and foot to either side.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Britain in the coming months must direct the attention of colonial governments to the importance of repressing Communistic agitation wherever it rears its head, Arthur Creech Jones, Colonial Secretary. said here today in an address closing the African conference that has been in session for a week at Lancaster House.

AUTOMOTIVE engineers are hard at work on further improvements of automatic transmissions for passenger cars despite the shortage of steels and other difficulties that have delayed a more extensive use of the automatic gear boxes.

PARIS, Sunday, Oct. 10 -- United Nations delegates were reassured early today when they learned that the apparent split between President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall over dealings with the Soviet Union had been settled.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 9 -- Lauding the poet Riley and his works as "part of Indiana," Gov. Ralph F. Gates has proclaimed the year 1949 James Whitcomb Riley Centennial Year. The Governor urged that organizations and institutions throughout the state "pay tribute to the Hoosier poet and thus build him a shrine where he would appreciate it most, in the hearts of Hoosiers."

NOT long ago a woman approached the Forty-sixth Street Theatre box-office and, fumbling in her handbag, produced two slightly soiled tickets to "Finian's Rainbow." Somewhat flustered, she launched into an emotional appeal to the box-office treasurer.

WHEN Tio Jose roared with laughter at the way his nephew was clearing his father's section of the road, Ricardo decided his father wouldn't think it funny. Neither would he approve of his uncle's gift of headstrong Blanquita. A wild ride left Ricardo white and shaken, but determined to keep the little white horse.

BATAVIA, Java, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Netherland Army said today that the see-saw battle between Indonesian forces and Communist rebels for the vital Tjepu oil center had caused an "extremely critical" situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- With President Truman carrying the fight all the way through the first five weeks, and with three more weeks remaining, the issues of the 1948 campaign have been stated, but not joined.
DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 9 -- Duke found the scoring punch it has been looking for all season and rolled over Navy, 28 -- 7, today for its first victory.

MADISON, Wis., Oct 9 -- Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education of New York, warned today that American universities must work to create responsible democratic leadership in order to avoid the twin evils of mediocrity and unscrupulous seekers of power.

President Truman, in an Executive Order issued last week, set in motion machinery for administration of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Program under the amended Trade Agreements Act enacted by Congress at its last session.

For the third year in succession, production of women's suits has run well over 40 per cent of the total of both coats and suits, it was pointed out in the trade. Preliminary estimates by leading manufacturers last week indicated that 1948 women's suit production may hit a figure close to 50 per cent of total coat and suit unit output on the basis of sales during the current season and early spring 1948.

THAT an increasing number of big game and bird hunters want to get away into the unspoiled wilderness is shown by the fact that there are now about twenty-four camps in Ontario which can be reached only by airplane.

Conditions under which members of the National Maritime Union, CIO, are to end work aboard vessels on the West Coast in the maritime strikes there were drawn up at yesterday's meeting of the union's national council.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 -- It would be unfair, as well as inaccurate, to say the Braves have lost hope of winning the 1948 world series. It is an old axiom in baseball that the game is never over until the last man is out.

In the dullest Saturday trading in five years, prices on the New York Stock Exchange drifted narrowly in yesterday's final session of the week. The market was irregularly higher on the week, with selected issues strongest.

LLANDUDNO, Wales, Oct. 9 -- In the strongest speech he has made since the end of World War II Winston Churchill today urged the United States not to destroy its atom bomb stocks and warned the Western World that only those bombs stood between freedom and Communist domination.

RETAIL trade in recent weeks has not been holding its earlier margins over a year ago. Production appears to be moving on a plateau. Exports have been easing. As a result of these evidences that a ceiling has possibly been reached in the boom, there is increasing mention of "soft spots" in the current business situation and some forecasts of readjustment in 1949.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 9 -- The people of the nation's vast Northwestern frontier await the Nov. 2 election as a test of what thousands of newcomers will do to traditional voting patterns.

Contrary to several recent reports, neither the United States Steel Corporation nor most of the nation's other large steel companies will abandon their hopes and efforts for eventual return of the industry's basing-point system of pricing, several steel spokesmen asserted last week.

IF "Charade" were not what it is, a brilliantly devised and beautifully executed story, it would scarcely be worth a thought: it is the sort of bold book which must either be a triumph or a fiasco. To show the adult world -- or let us rather say, the world which is run by people old enough to know better -- to show this world through the eyes of a child, is always delicate.

BRIELLE, N. J., Oct. 9 -- Mayor Harry A. Kroh declared today that State Highway Commissioner Spencer Miller Jr. was seeking to prevent an inquiry into Mr. Kroh's charges that the Highway Department had dealt secretly with the Brielle Planning Board in drawing a plan for the proposed Manasquan River bridge.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Democratic National Committee issued today an official "life story" of President Truman, using the colored picture and dialogue style of the comic books.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 9 -- Middlebury College shut out Hamilton College, 13 to 0, today before 3,200 Alumni Home-Coming Day fans at Porter Field.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Rounding out its first six months of operations this week, the Economic Cooperation Administration was at last pouring industrial goods into Europe in great dollar volume.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 9 -- The awesome power generated by the offensive unit of Army's "two-platoon" football squad carried the undefeated Cadets to a 26-21 triumph over Illinois before a capacity crowd of 71,119 at Memorial Stadium today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Notre Dame put on another victory march today against a tough Michigan State team and won, 26 -- 7.

Ignoring the uncertainty abroad, financial markets last week began to develop a firmer tone. Trading sentiment, which has been badly mangled by the Russian enigma, is becoming impervious to foreign developments. It may be reflecting the outlook of a change in Administration as a result of the Presidential election.

THE NEW YORK TIMES now supports Governor Dewey as its candidate. Mr. Dewey has publicly acclaimed the Eightieth Congress, stating on one occasion that "they had done a fine job." In many editorials you have castigated the Eightieth Congress for its failure to meet the demands for necessary domestic legislation.

H. C. Brockel, director of the Milwaukee Board of Harbor Commissioners, has been elected president of the American Association of Port Authorities, it was announced yesterday. The association ended last week its thirty-seventh annual meeting.

The sale of two former United States naval frigates, the Knoxville and Pueblo, to the Government of the Dominican Republic was announced yesterday by J. C. Berkwit Co., 551 Fifth Avenue. The seller had purchased the vessels along with a number of other craft from the United States Navy.

Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, the most sacred day in the Jewish religious calendar, will be marked by Jews throughout the world from sundown on Tuesday to sundown Wednesday. Prayers for the success of the new homeland of Israel will be coupled with personal pleas for health and prosperity during the coming year.

" SMILE PLEASE" purports, formally at least, to be the story of Mrs. Topp's mother, who was the first female portrait photographer to set up shop in Greenwood, Miss. Actually it is more the account of the childhood of its authoress and her sister, with some attention to aunts, uncles, a grandfather who is described as a "reconstructed Yankee," revivalists, gypsies, bankers and prohibitionists.

FOR several notable reasons this charming, active and altogether heartening novel deserves to be called "old-fashioned." Yet so fanatically con temporary are our days that a term like this one can hardly be used without a supercilious implication which, in reference to "Chinatown Family," would be shameful.

READING through this story of Old Man Crow and the motherless Sprout he brought up in Idaho in the Eighteen Eighties and Nineties, I have been seeing both through John Merchant, once boss of the San Simon Ranch in eastern New Mexico.
ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- Governor Dewey has chosen Pittsburgh as the place where he will deliver his major campaign address on labor, his secretary, Paul E. Lockwood, said today.

EXPRESSIONISM is, of course, the name we give that art in which the artist is primarily concerned with revealing his feelings. Usually these emotions, violent or melancholy, are disclosed by exaggerations of color and distortions of form, so that what he feels transforms what he sees.

THIRTY new skiing areas, five of them major developments, are to be added this winter to the nearly 200 ski centers of New England. With these additional centers, and with interest in skiing showing no signs of abating, the New England Winter Recreational Promotion Conference is looking forward to a highly successful winter season.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 9 -- The possibility that the United Nations Security Council might appoint a commission to attempt to settle the Berlin dispute was discussed today by Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States delegate.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- The voting machines in Albany County list six offices at stake this year, from President of the United States down to county coroner. For each of them there is a full slate of candidates entered by the Republican, Democratic and Liberal parties.

WHILE the rest of Hollywood is carefully hewing to the conservative line, John Huston and Sam Spiegel, in "Rough Sketch," their first independent venture, are presenting a justification of terrorism and assassination directed against tyranny.

An estimated 19,000 persons will attend the installation of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as the thirteenth president of Columbia University, on Tuesday at 2 P. M. The ceremony will be held on the university's South Court. In the event of rain the installation will take place in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

The sixtieth anniversary of the founding of the aluminum industry in the United States will be observed this week in Pittsburgh, the industry's birthplace, with the reenactment on Thursday of the pouring of the first commercial ingot by Arthur V. Davis, chairman of the board of the Aluminum Company of America.

In France and Italy, two key nations of Western Europe and of the European Recovery Program, there was mounting industrial unrest last week. Underlying the unrest are two factors: first, workers' discontent over the disparity between wages and prices, and second, Communists' efforts to use this discontent to force out the anti-Communist Governments in Paris and Rome and to hinder the Marshall Plan.

SOME day, perhaps, the surgeon-historians will get around to taking John Nance Garner apart cell by cell. Until that time comes, this personal history by a Washington journalist who has been an intimate friend of Garner for twenty-five years will no doubt remain the definitive biography of the former Vice President.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- As the Communist-directed strike of French coal miners -- reinforced by rotating strikes in the railway, steel, textile and other industries -- moves toward a second week, the situation holds growing dangers for the present regime of France.

TWO years ago, discussing the control of atomic energy, Albert Einstein wrote: "Proposals should be discussed in every newspaper, in churches and schools, in private conversations, for the real problem is in the minds and hearts of men." As a step toward spreading knowledge of the issue the United Nations has prepared a film strip for adults called "Atomic Energy -- Problems of International Control."

Thank you for another superior article on Russia -- "What Makes the Russians Think That Way?" by Frederick C. Barghoorn. * * * There are many of us who do not want war but are also not the "Communists" or "Russomaniacs" that we have been called.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 9 -- Edward H. Gerry and Mrs. Arthur Atkinson of the Piping Rock Club shot 33, 30 -- 63, seven strokes under par, to gain a one-stroke lead in the 36-hole mixed foursomes best-ball golf tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 9 -- Outplayed most of the second half, Rutgers University's football squad built up a big enough lead in the opening two quarters to turn back Temple's Owls, 34 to 20, before 13,000 at Rutgers Stadium today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- Legislation fostering Federal control of education and tending to handicap privately supported schools was denounced today by the United Lutheran Church in America in a resolution adopted at its sixteenth biennial convention in Town Hall.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week continued satisfactory on almost all ready-to-wear lines, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Although retailers tried to keep inventories on the conservative side, their purchases for the Christmas season were substantial.

THERE is a social revolution taking place in this country of which even the revolutionists are scarcely aware. It is a genteel revolt by middle-aged mothers -- and some grandmothers -- against their traditional role of dependents. Women whose children have grown up are invading the labor market in large numbers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The White House announced today a revised itinerary for President Truman's midwestern campaign trip starting tomorrow. The President is resuming his campaign, following his meetings with Secretary Marshall today.

PARIS, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Exiled Spanish Socialists published today an eight-point program for governing Spain if Generalissimo Franco is overthrown. Indalecio Prieto, president of the Spanish Socialist (Republican) party, (confirmed that this was the much-publicized anti-Franco pact.

Almost all veterans who were graduated last June from Indiana University have had "one or more" jobs offered to them. According to the university's placement director, 80 per cent of the veterans had accepted jobs before graduating at an average starting salary of $240 a month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The White House is a dull, quiet place whenever President Truman is on the road, politicking. When he departs on each tour the bustle in the Executive Wing fades out and the place becomes like the unfrequented corner of a museum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The exact location of the United States "frontier" has puzzled a good many strategic planners, geopoliticians, and sundry and assorted colonels, clerks and commanders this past week.

MR. SCHAFFER is a British journalist who visited the Soviet zone of occupied Germany in the spring of 1947. Authentic information on this zone is very much needed, but unfortunately very difficult to get -- which to some observers seems to be the fault of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Truman said this evening that he had decided after consultation with Secretary of State Marshall last Tuesday not to send Fred M. Vinson, Chief Justice of the United States, on a peace mission to Moscow to confer with Premier Stalin.

MAGNOLIAS, crabapples and forsythias will be the first plants to be set out in the Citizens Golden Anniversary Planting Program, sponsored by the Park Association. A few of them will be put in place at ceremonies in City Hall Park on Thursday at 4:30 P. M. Mayor O'Dwyer and other officials and representatives of civic groups will take part in the celebration.

These readers may very well have remembered that De gustibus non disputandum, that Delenda est Karthago and that even in the worst circumstances the word is Nil desperandum.

THE war-time success of visual training has been referred to and utilized in the production of this book. Three sections form the framework for the discussion. The first two deal with those tools specifically needed for woodworking and with types of operations in such work.

THE Graflite flash unit featuring five outlets -- for extensions, battery, shutter and remote control -- was introduced last week by Graflex, Inc. The new unit, designed for at-camera control of several extensions by hooking up two battery cases, is now available at $24.60 to $27.10 in two or three-cell, battery cases, supplied with a five-inch or a seven-inch reflector.
CLEVELAND, Oct, 9 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the fourth game of the world series at Municipal Stadium today follows:
THE UNITED STATES AIR FORCE is waiting for a heavy fog to test out the world's brightest lights. The search is on to find a way to take the blindness out of blind landings.

THE great Berlin air lift, a major issue m the U. N. debate between East and West, began as an improvised operation last June 24 when the Russians announced a complete land blockade of the city's western sectors. The West's reply was prompt. Available cargo planes were mustered and put into a shuttle service from Frankfort and various points in the British zone along twenty-mile-wide air corridors to Berlin.

ANYONE who attempted to forecast the economic happenings of the next few years would be a brave man indeed. It is reasonably safe to point out, however, that one of three developments is likely -- and that all of these developments are critical.

THOUGH the Ballet Russe de Mante Carlo closes its engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening, there are new activities to step in and take over at once. Tomorrow the New York City Ballet Company (otherwise the Ballet Society) begins its official career at the City Center in connection with the opera, under the artistic direction of George Balanchine, the musical direction of Leon Barzin and the general direction of Lincoln Kirstein.

Twenty-four Columbia College freshmen, representing seventeen states, Hawaii and Canada, are the first group of National Scholarship winners to enroll in the college under its expanded scholarship program. Their four-year scholarships range in value from $600 to $1,200 annually.

Prof. Donald W. Kerst of the University of Illinois announces the successful operation of a 75-million-volt betatron, an exact scale model of the 300-million-volt colossus which is to produce cosmic ray effects. Among these effects is the creation of mesotrons, believed a key to the force holding the atom together.

EACH season brings special pleasures for the palate. Fall, no exception, means many good things: the first fat oysters; snowy heads of cauliflower; crisp, cheerful - looking cranberries; sweet potatoes for a festive baked ham; dried apricots and raisins and prunes that may be stewed for a colorful compote or incorporated into baked goods, and -- perhaps the surest of all signs of autumn -- the new crop of walnuts, filberts, pecans and almonds.

DETROIT, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Making the breaks pay off for a 17 -- 0 first half lead, the Boston Yanks broke a three-game losing streak by beating the Detroit Lions, 17-14, tonight for their first National Football League victory of the season.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 9 (AP) -- California's Bears, main Rose Bowl hope of the West Coast, crushed Wisconsin's Badgers, 40 to 14 today in an intersectional football clash before 66,000 fans.

A proposed long-range Army program designed to make military education more easily available civilians who desire it will tested in the First Army area with a special command and staff training course at Camp Kilmer, N. J., and Fort Banks, Mass., from Oct. 17 to Oct. 30, it was announced yesterday by First Army Headquarters here.

Each year, at the close of National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week, which ended yesterday, many persons suggest, as did President Truman recently, that emphasis on employment of the handicapped-should not be limited to one special week but should be stressed fifty-two weeks a year.

PARIS, Oct 9 -- Yugoslavia will be able to satisfy all her own petroleum requirements by 1950, Leo Mattes, her deputy foreign minister told the Economic Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today.

LONDON, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- The scramble for leadership in the first division of the English Football League tightened today, but it remained a race between Portsmouth and Derby County, both undefeated this season.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Formation of the Defense Council of the Western Union powers has highlighted suddenly the importance to the United States of the imposing Georgian-style building at 20 Grosvenor Square, United States Army headquarters in the last war.

BEFORE Carl Sandburg's thousand-page novel on American history, filled with his brooding religion of America, criticism is perhaps an impertinence. Thousands will read the book, and find in it solace and reassurance; of the innumerable recent efforts, this is the supreme and lengthiest celebration of the mystique of America, the most uninhibited, and the most naive.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9 (AP) -- The will of the late Dr. Wilbur L. Cross, four-term Governor of Connecticut, was filed in Probate Court today.

New York University recovered from some early unsteadiness in its clash with the Brooklyn College football team at Ebbets Field last night and gathered itself together in time to hand the Kingsmen a setback, 21 to 7.

MOTION picture stars, unlike children, are intended to be both seen and heard; but every now and then, with suitable fanfare, the rule is violated. The latest to challenge the ordinary acting dimensions of the talking screen is the versatile Jane Wyman, who, although she stars conspicuously in "Johnny Belinda,'' utters neither sound nor syllable in the film version of Elmer Harris' stage play.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 9 -- The newspapers Prensa and Nacion informed their readers in special front-page boxes this morning that beginning tomorrow they would comply with the executive decree that limits them to sixteen pages, virtually cutting them in half and forcing drastic production changes while leaving pro-Government papers virtually unaffected.

AN auto-focusing enlarger, the Automega B-3 for 2 1/4 by 3 1/4 inch negatives to 35mm size, was announced last week by Simmon Brothers. An adaptation to the amateur field of the 5-by-7-inch Automega E-3 Professional unit, the enlarger will be available early in December.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 9 -- Lehigh's Dick Gabriel, 19-year-old sophomore back from Valley Stream, L. I., with four touchdowns in the first period, sparked the Engineers to a 45-0 victory over Drexel Tech today. It was Drexel's fourteenth straight defeat over three seasons of play.

THE Age of Mammoths isn't over -- or, at any rate, isn't over yet. Carl Sandburg's jumbo, reviewed up front, is 1,067 pages long, going last January's jumbo, the late Ross Lockridge's "Raintree County," exactly one page better.
THE theatre has always been everything it ought to be, but at the same time it has always been a great many other things, too.
Hampered by four costly backfield fumbles, the City College football team lost its third straight game of the season, 12 to 7, to Panzer College last night in Lewisohn Stadium.

Give a man a free hand and he builds himself a house with running water, several bathrooms, a two-car garage, telephones both upstairs and down, central automatic heat -- and a fireplace. He wants no stable, no carriage house, no dug well and old oaken bucket. But he insists on the fireplace.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Umpire Bill Stewart declared after the game today that the play "wasn't even close" when he called Manager Lou Boudreau out at third and drew a lusty booing from the big pro-Cleveland crowd.

CHRISTOPHER SYKES, the British writer, was brought to the attention of American readers earlier this year with a volume of short biographies called "Four Studies in Loyalty." His new novel, much admired in England, might be called "A Fifth Study," since Mr. Sykes is again examining the motives that sometimes lead foreigners to a passionate attachment to Britain.

An agreement On a new schedule of city pier rentals is reported nearing consummation following a series of discussions between shipping officials, the Department of Marine and Aviation and city authorities.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A postwar baby, the home freezer industry, will skyrocket total retail sales to $280,000,000 this year, the top producer estimates.

Faced with the possibility of a $20,000 fine and jail sentences for six of its officers, Local 1,250, Department Store Employes Union, independent, announced yesterday that for the present it would obey a Federal injunction prohibiting picketing of Oppenheim Collins Co.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- The most Rev. Patrick A. O'Boyle, Archbishop of Washington, D. C., has been named spiritual director of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul throughout the world. The appointment, made by the Most Rev. Amleto G. Cicognani, apostolic delegate, was announced today at the annual meeting of the society and the National Conference of Catholic Charities.

AFTER a month of the most gruesome theatregoing in recent memory, the British have mercifully come to the rescue. Robert Morley and Peggy Ashcroft have settled down at the Martin Beck Theatre in a sapient and fascinating performance of "Edward, My Son."

With the passing of the old guides something intangible withdraws from familiar covers, marshes or woods, for part of their magic is bound up closely with the man who initiated you into their mysteries, and tramping them without him is like gulping wine in thirst without appreciating its flavor.

THE first round in the battle between Fred Allen and "Stop the Music" goes to the comedian. After brooding darkly all summer over the cruel fate which spotted him opposite the giveaway show on Sunday evenings -- last spring he dropped to thirty-eighth place in the Hooper ratings -- Mr. A. came out of his corner a week ago with an uproarious spoof of the Santa Claus mania that afflicts radio.

ON Friday, Sept. 16, the body of W. B. Yeats was brought in an Irish corvette from Nice -- he died and was buried at Roquebruhe in 1939 -and re-interred in Drumcliff graveyard, in Sligo. It is just a year short of sixty since he published "The Wanderings of Oisin."
TRIESTE, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A Christian Democratic member of the Italian Parliament said tonight that Yugoslavia had undertaken to return all Italian prisoners "for whatever reason detained."

Dr. Bela Fabian, former president of the dissolved Hungarian Independent Democratic party, and his wife, Helene, were detained yesterday by immigration officers on their arrival here aboard the French liner De Grasse. Classified as "doubtful" visitors, they were taken to Ellis Island to await a hearing before a special immigration board of inquiry.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- As part of its stockpiling program the United States has completed contracts for the purchase of an unspecified quantity of industrial diamonds from Britain. Although both United States and British Government authorities were willing to disclose the quantity purchased and the price paid, they said the diamond interests raised objections to such disclosures.

BERLIN, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Soviet-controlled ADN news agency reported the seizure of "great quantities" of coal and food in a crackdown on truck traffic in the Soviet sector of Berlin today. The agency said that the cargo had not been authorized by the Soviet authorities.

According to an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for the First Department, entered on Sept. 24, 1948, the decision of that court in the case of The New York County Lawyers Association, Petitioner, vs. Bernard Bercu, Respondent, has been made final.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- What may well prove to be the most exhaustive inquiry ever undertaken into the workings of the Federal bureaucracy has been progressing quietly for more than a year and is now heading toward its final phase. A comprehensive report will be made to the Eighty-first Congress next January.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 9 -- Purdue was beaten by the University of Michigan, 40 to 0, today, before a crowd of 45,996, the largest ever to jam Ross-Ade Stadium.

The Student Council at City College defeated yesterday a resolution calling for a student referendum for permission to lead an all-day campus - wide demonstration against the Board of Higher Education and Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, if Prof. William E. Knickerbocker were not suspended by Oct. 20.

The American Civil Liberties Union in its annual report yesterday said that the issue of civil rights has been plunged into confusion and uncertainty over basic principles. On the one hand, it said, could he found restrictions on Communists and their allies and in some degree on organized labor; on the other hand, encouragement of the rights of racial minorities.

A scrappy Evander Childs eleven had an upset victory over Abraham Lincoln in the offing yesterday at Triborough Stadium, but a touchdown pass in the last ninety seconds enabled the Honest Abes to gain a 6-6 deadlock. In the opening contest of the scholastic twin bill, Christopher Columbus beat a favored Seward team, 7 -- 6, before 3,000 spectators.

Derek Wragge Morley of Edinburgh University's institute of Animal Genetics describes in Nature the extraordinary neurotic behavior of a worker ant which had learned how to find its way through a maze. On one occasion after this ant had run through a maze, Morley picked it up and put it back in its nest, took it out again five minutes later and placed it in the starting chamber.

WAKE FOREST, N. C., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Unbeaten North Carolina defeated Wake Forest, 28-6, today for its third straight victory as the Tar Heels rolled to a pair of touchdowns in the first quarter and added two more in the final period.
Permit me to express my appreciation of your very fine editorial in THE TIMES of Oct. 3. It was a splendid piece of writing, strong in logic, well-planned in content.

What was characterized as "an alarming growth of repression in American schools and colleges'' was denounced yesterday in a resolution approved at a conference on academic freedom at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Democracy's hope lies in "widespread, popular education," a world traveler told the Empire State Federation of Teachers Unions today.

Out of Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday came a woeful tale of a man who gazed into a crystal ball and learned that Boston would beat Cleveland 1 to 0 in the opening game of the World Series. The story has a moral, but first for the court record as related by the stenographer:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The recent marked increase in agitation for admitting Spain to full diplomatic membership in the family of nations, including the United Nations, is attributed in diplomatic circles to a few simple factors.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- British Friends of the Soviet Union called today for acceptance of Soviet proposals for disarmament and control of the atomic bomb and for renewal of negotiations over the Berlin dispute as the key to world peace.

A RESPECTABLE number of new recordings of contemporary works has reached the market in recent weeks. At least two of these compositions appear in the repertory with reasonable regularity, and they have been around long enough so that they scarcely can be described as new.

AN increasing number of gardeners who appreciate wildlings and would like to plant them, abandon the idea because they think that the environment of a garden is inappropriate or that wild flowers are difficult to grow.

OCTOBER finds many a gardener spending a great part of his time on his knees planting bulbs, to be sure that next spring will be the realization of his dreams. Combinations and arrangements of narcissus and tulips, by colors and heights and sizes, fill his mind.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 9 -- Henry Wallace's whirlwind tour of California, and its implications, was a major topic of speculation along the Coast this week. California, with its own Governor running for the Vice Presidency, has been generally considered safely in the GOP column, and the question was mainly how many votes the Progressives would draw from the Democrats.

Clifford Herzer, who played yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, is an experienced pianist. Besides the three previous solo recitals he has been a member of a two-piano team and played extensively for the radio. As a result, he plays with ease and confidence before an audience.

Gian-Carlo Menotti's brilliant little comic opera, "The Old Maid and the Thief," was presented last night at the City Center by the New York City Opera Company with a new singer in the spinster role of the title. She was Muriel O'Malley, Australian contralto, who made her debut with the company.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 9 -- A "pay-as-you-go" community project uniquely combining the business side of athletics with the improvement of. educational facilities is providing this city with a college dormitory-stadium and is also setting a regional record for financial success and civic development.

A COLUMBUS DAY ceremony marking another step in the construction of the mile- long Columbus memorial lighthouse and monument in Ciudad Trujillo, Dominican Republic, will be held in the Pan American Union Building in Washington on Tuesday.

In the perpetual search for more efficient operating methods, many department and specialty stores have shown intensified interest in the use of personnel training films during the past several years. Although the effectiveness of this medium is still widely disputed and is yet to be determined, it is significant that the majority of these two types of stores throughout the country are using some form of projected pictures in their training programs at this time.

IN February, 1845, at The Briers, Natchez home of the prominent Howell family, pretty, 19-year-old Varina Howell was married to a comparatively unknown, up-river widower.
