Although the husband that Varina Howell had unaccountably chosen was a West Point graduate and had served briefly in the Army, no one knew much about him or his family (it was rumored he had been born on a farm in Kentucky).

SMOKETREE and fringetree are among the few very tall shrubs big enough to be almost classed as trees. Yet they might be easy to forget in the search for distinguished ornamentals during the fall planting season.

Last week Cornell University celebrated its eightieth anniversary. The occasion was marked by a discussion of the part that radio is playing in astrophysics and the unveiling of what is described as a "radio telescope" but what is really nothing more or less than a sort of parabolic reflector.

THE fable of the camel in the Arab's tent hasn't a patch on what happened to Thidwick the moose when he kindly gave a ride to a Bingle Bug. That was a fine gesture, but the guest invited a Tree-Spider who invited a Zinn-a-zu Bird, who brought his wife, who invited . . .

Although the assigned discussion in the first NEW YORK TIMES Youth Forum of the season yesterday was, "Who Governs Our City?" the six junior high school students composing the panel showed at an early stage that their chief interest was in more playgrounds and recreational centers.

DUTCH iris used to be considered the exclusive property of the florists, but in recent years this flower's merits have been discovered by more and more gardeners. The bulbs (they are a bulbous member of the varied iris group) ought to be purchased right away, before the commercial growers take them all.

ANY fairly representative and well-selected exhibition of recent European art, and the current Museum of Modern Art print show is a worthy case in point, brings home in a striking manner the very special nature of contemporary feeling as well as certain enduring constants that relate this expression traditionally.

The current effort of the Columbia Gas System to raise $12,230,000 by the sale of new common stock is bringing into play striking innovations in the drafting and use of prospectuses and in the technique of marketing so-called stand-by offerings -- that is, issues of new stock subscribable preferentially for a limited period by the issuing company's own stockholders.

Circulation of more than 2,000,000 leaflets throughout the state to acquaint the public with a Republican "anti-labor conspiracy" was announced yesterday by Louis Hollander, president of the State CIO Council.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9 -- A vividly colored panorama of the pioneer West came to life here today with the announcement that Yale University had acquired the William Robertson Coe collection of Western Americana, described as the finest collection of such source material east of the Rocky Mountains.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 9 -- Crowd response to the New Jersey visit of President Truman has encouraged Democratic organization leaders and leading labor officials to predict that the state will "go Democratic."

HAVANA, Oct. 4 -- When Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, Cuba's new President, takes office on Sunday, he will be confronted by numerous serious problems. Spiraling inflation, labor unrest, declining revenue, financial crises in various island industries and unrestrained gang warfare, are some of these.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Chairman Fred A. Hartley Jr. said today that the House Labor Committee was preparing recommendations that thirty to forty labor union witnesses be cited for contempt of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The "sensational" public show that financial observers here have been forecasting for next Tuesday, when the Federal Reserve Board is scheduled to begin hearings in its anti-trust charges against the Transamerica Corporation might be postponed.

Gen. Jonathan N. Wainwright and Mayor O'Dwyer will plant trees in City Hall Park Thursday at 4:30 P. M. in a ceremony sponsored by the Park Association of New York an the Greater New York Civic Center Association, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Representative John McDowell, Republican, of Pennsylvania, said today he thought that Attorney General Clark and his staff were "inept" in drawing indictments against twelve Communist party leaders.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 -- Manager Lou Boudreau sang the praises of a trimly built "spot" pitcher who today gave the Indians their third straight victory in the world series for a 3-1 lead in the classic.

A good portion of American business is now convinced that establishment of uniform job evaluation techniques in each unit of companies with multi-plant operations is necessary to reduce costs and obtain more efficient over-all performance, Henry P. Kramer, secretary of the New York chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Management, declared last week.

MILWAUKEE, Oct, 9 (AP) -- Representatives Charles Kersten Republican of Wisconsin, recommended today that three top officers of the CIO United Electrical Workers Union be cited for contempt of Congress.

Price increases in aluminum, antimony, silver and quicksilver and larger demand for copper, lead and zinc marked increased activity in non-ferrous metal markets last week. The Aluminum Company of America ended the dual price level which had prevailed for aluminum pig and ingot by announcing that, beginning tomorrow, a general price increase of 1 cent a pound applying only to virgin metal becomes effective.

BECAUSE the author of this book is the successful operator of a fashion academy, it may be said that its ideas are laboratory tested. As the title indicates, the volume is concerned primarily with fundamentals. However, it is not limited to rudimentary practices.

TELEVISION had two major premieres last week. The first was the debut of the new Actors Equity-Philco Corporation dramatic series at 9 P. M. Sundays on the NBC chain. The other was the initial telecast of "Town Meeting of the Air" via the ABC network's looking and listening facilities.

Between 50,000 and 75,000 persons will parade up Fifth Avenue from forty-fourth Street to Eighty-fourth Street next Tuesday afternoon in celebration of the 456th anniversary of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus.

Retail activity continued good here last week according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports: Coat, dress and sportswear departments attracted greatest consumer response.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Navy disclosed today that it had a sea-going rocket laboratory from which fourteen-ton V-2 missiles could be sent aloft.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Asserting that the Republican Eightieth Congress was the first in history to start a long-term farm program, Gov. Earl Warren of California tonight pledged the Republican party to a still better job on farm problems after election of a Republican administration.

THE most impressive post-war development in small reflex camera design and construction, the Swedish Hasselblad Single-lens 2 1/4 by 2 1/4 reflex camera will be introduced in Cleveland tomorrow at the annual trade show of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association.

I noted with interest your feature "Celebrated Artists" concerning the paintings of distinguished folk with whom art is a hobby. I thought at once of all the other amateur artists and of the struggling unknowns whose work is never noted by the critics.

IT is a pleasure to report that Hans Habe has regained the stature he has shown in his first American success, "A Thousand Shall Fall." His "Walk in Darkness" is a tour de force in a minor key, never flagging, deftly executed, and moving with power toward its foreordained ending.

The Union News Company, whose newsstands and snack bars in railroad terminals and stations in New York, Long Island, Westchester and southern Connecticut have been closed by a strike for eight days, announced yesterday that almost half its 800 employes had returned to work.

Radio manufacturers are trying to get the Government to spread its present orders around to "educate" the industry for heavier defense demands to come. The plan is being pushed by a special committee of the Radio Manufacturers Association and has been laid before the Munitions Board in Washington.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti -- This city is busy preparing for its Bicentennial Exposition, scheduled to open in April, commemorating its founding in 1749. Concurrently there is an all-out effort to rush to completion the modernization of the shopping district before the autumn tourists arrive.
Exemption from customs duty of certain articles sent in gift parcels to persons in Greece within specified amounts has been extended to presents mailed until Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The revelation that President Truman seriously considered dispatching Chief Justice Vinson to Moscow as a special United States intermediary, after the Soviet blockade of Berlin had been submitted to the Security Council of the United Nations in Paris and after Great Britain and France had reluctantly agreed to join this nation in the move, has created great anxiety in Washington.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Cornell accorded a surprising reception to the first Harvard football team to play here since 1896 when it routed the Cantabs by 40 to 6 before an enthusiastic crowd of 25,000 at Schoellkopf field today.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Governor Dewey's decision today to talk about the labor issue at Pittsburgh, in the heart of the country's steel producing area, apparently represented a new switch in plans. Previously it had been hinted that he would talk on labor and then aides said he would not.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Although the age of American frontiersmen has long since passed, the westward trek is still on, Census Bureau figures showed this week. Also, people are still leaving the farm for life in the city.

WITHIN the next few months the permanent home of the United Nations will begin to take shape on Manhattan's East Side. Here, on a barren seventeen-acre tract once crowded with shabby tenements, breweries and slaughterhouses, workmen have begun the job of excavating tons of earth and stone in the "most significant building project of our time."

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 9 -- Ralph Durstein place kicked eight points after touchdowns in eight attempts as Lafayette College smothered Washington and Jefferson, 56 -- 15, today before 8,000. Three Lafayette touchdowns in the second period broke the game wide open after the Presidents had knotted the score.
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- This country is making haste slowly and with the utmost caution toward European federation.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Pitt's Panthers picked on somebody their own size on this sunny football day and the experience resulted in a 16-6 victory over their neighborhood rivals, the West Virginia Mountaineers.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- Business gains in the Pittsburgh district fell short of seasonal changes with the result that the seasonally adjusted index declined slightly last week. according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Your leading editorial in support of Governor Dewey was the most carefully reasoned and clearly expressed argument I have seen. Your readers are led to expect that kind of editorial thinking and writing -- rare though it is elsewhere in a political campaign.

Six important long-term expanded uses for domestic heating and plumbing equipment have increased steel requirements of the average home more than 100 pounds a unit beyond consumption requirements of 1939, Harold P. Wolf, manager of commercial research in the Rheem Manufacturing Company, San Francisco, disclosed here Friday following a conference of executives at the Princeton Club.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP) -- If the Indians win the World Series from the Braves, each member of the Tribe will receive $6,772.05, an all time record slice, according to unofficial figures. Although the Clevelanders have not given details of how they divided the money, they split thirty-four shares.
Settlement of the labor dispute involving The Journal of Commerce and its union printers and mailers was announced yesterday in a statement issued at the newspaper's offices, 63 Park Row.

Capital investment in basic industries of the Soviet economy was at a much higher rate in 1946 and 1947 than in the pre-war year of 1940 and will be increased further in 1948, the latest issue of the Soviet State Planning Commission organ, Planovoye Khozyaistvo, reports.

TOMORROW night Ray Bolger comes to the St. James Theatre in "Where's Charley?", the musical version of "Charley's Aunt," and thereby will be written another chapter in the fabulous history of the farce an obscure actor, named Brandon Thomas, wrote back in 1892.

The second and last group runs sponsored by the Public Schools Athletic League before the cross-country season gets under way were held yesterday over Van Cortlandt Park's two-and-one-quarter-mile course. Unlike last week, favorites came through in each of the three sections.

I have read with great interest your editorial of Sept. 16 entitled "How Forest Fires Start." It states that forest fires yearly burn over thirty million acres of woodland, and that 90 per cent of these fires are the result of carelessness. You come to the conclusion that "education is, of course, the only real answer * * *."

The American Merchant Marine conference, which will open on Wednesday for a three-day meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, is expected by maritime leaders to provide a sounding board for an effort to make the American public aware of their merchant fleet, its needs and its importance to the national welfare.

The authority of the late K.A. Timiryazev has been frequently invoked in support of the Soviet biological dogma associated with the name of Lysenko, which proscribes the Mendelian theory of heredity, and which resulted in a ruthless purge of Russian scientists.

Szymon Goldberg, an uncommonly sound musician and accomplished violinist, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. It was announced last week as his first in New York, but this was not Mr. Goldberg's first New York recital, unless his appearance with chamber orchestra in Carnegie Hall ten years ago, when he played, among other works, the Bach E major and the Mendelssohn concertos, the Debussy sonata and other pieces, be counted out.

Cardinal Spellman and Auxiliary Bishop Joseph P. Donahue, vicar general of the New York Archdiocese, were the principal figures in ceremonies yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral to mark the thirty-eighth anniversary of the consecration of the cathedral, which has been a Fifth Avenue landmark for seventy years.

Four and a half million school children in this country are suffering from defective eyesight, Dr. Franklin M. Foote, executive director of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, 1790 Broadway, said yesterday. Dr. Foote reported on a month's nation-wide survey in which questionnaires were submitted to school superintendents and state, county and city officials.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- The Central Committee of the Italian Communist party felt the need today to remind its followers that they must look to the Soviet Union as the "organizer and guide of the workers' progressive movement in a capitalist world."

Pointing to a new challenge to the United States by "totalitarian Russia," Senator Brian McMahon of Connecticut asserted yesterday that on the United States' "ability to remain invincibly strong may hinge the issue of war or peace and, indeed, the issue of human survival or extinction."

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- Representatives of the three Western powers conferred this morning on the suggestion by nations not directly concerned that the German question be referred to the Council of Foreign Ministers on condition that the Soviet Union raise simultaneously the blockade of Berlin.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Frank Albert put on a dazzling show of T-quarterback wizardy today to lead the unbeaten San Francisco 49ers to a 56-14 rout of the Baltimore Colts in an All-America Football Conference game.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder, Davis Cup player from Glendale, and Miss Gertrude Moran of Santa Monica, captured the men's and women's singles honors today in the first annual national hard-court tennis tournament.

Dr. Thomas D. Dublin has been appointed executive director of the National Health Council, it was announced yesterday by Philip R. Mather, president. Dr. Mather also reported that the Rockefeller Foundation had made a grant to the council of $225,000 to be used over a three-year period in its program of strengthening the public health movement throughout the United States.
BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- Convincing gains on the economic front in Western Germany are the most encouraging factors in the great political-economic struggle being waged for Germany by the Western powers.
Famous American naval engagements and personalities will be featured in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that will run from Oct. 25 to Dec. 5, it was announced yesterday by the museum.

James A. Rafferty, vice president of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation of New York, has been named to receive the Chemical Industry Medal for 1948, Archie J. Weith, chairman of the American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry, announced yesterday.

Much of the beef now arriving in the market, housewives have found, is not of the tenderest quality. Though the dry heat of roasting or broiling accentuates its toughness, the moist heat of stewing or braising softens the hard tissues. Thus beef stew becomes apropos this autumn.

In an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 5 entitled "Hospital Needs" it states that the cost of operating the voluntary hospitals of New York City in 1948 was $92,901,520.48. The deficits were quoted as being $2,845,988.30.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns, Champions of the All-America Football Conference, won their sixth straight game tonight before a crowd of 31,187 with a 30-17 victory over the Brooklyn Dodgers. It was Brooklyn's sixth loss in a row.

The greatest adventurer of all times was Jesus Christ, Who declared He came to teach men the fatherhood of God, the brotherhood of man, the forgiveness of sins and life everlasting, the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton observed yesterday in his sermon at the Broadway TempleWashington Heights Methodist Church, Broadway and 174th Street, of which he is the pastor.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct 10 -- Apparently doomed to their fifth straight defeat, the New York Football Yankees dragged themselves up by their own bootstraps to score two second-half touchdowns and turn back the Buffalo Bills, 14 -- 13, at Civic Stadium today.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 -- The arrangements had been: "If we win it is open house. If we lose, let me have five or ten minutes with my players after the game."

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Richmond Rebels, paced by the running of Halfback Jim Reynolds and the passing of Glen Knox, romped to their fourth straight American Football League triumph today, bowling over the Wilkes-Barre Bullets, 28 -- 0, before a crowd of 4,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration authorized more industrial goods than food and agricultural items in authorizing European recovery grants of $176,365,843 for the week to Oct. 6.
Five new films, including an importation from France, will arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

A slight increase in registration over that for the Presidential election in 1944 was reported last night in returns from fifty-four cities and large villages in the state outside New York City. The 1948 registration in these communities totals 1,316,920, as compared with a registration of 1,310,825 in 1944 and 1,090,639 for the state election in 1946.
GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- George Pelersky, 27-year-old farmhand of Penn Yan, paid a $50 fine yesterday for trying to shake hands with President Truman.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Concluding races for the Haebler and Godfrey trophies were held today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 10 -- The newspapers Prensa and Nacion appeared today for the first time in the sixteen-page news editions to which they have been limited by President Peron's decree. It being Sunday, each also had an eightpage rotogravure section, which all papers still are entitled to publish once a week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A plan for a world police force strong enough to keep international peace and to enforce universal disarmament was forwarded today to the governments of all United Nations members by the United States Federation of Justice.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- On the eve of the meeting of British Commonwealth Prime Ministers, opening here tomorrow, some thought is being given in London to the possibility of changes in the organization of the Commonwealth to meet new conditions.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and Dr. Nelson Glueck, president of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, will speak in a pre-Yom Kippur broadcast of the American Jewish Committee today at 5 P. M. over station WCBS and the Columbia Broadcasting System.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Sid Luckman fired two scoring passes and Johnny Lujack pitched another to help give the unbeaten Chicago Bears their third straight National Football League triumph today with a 42-21 decision over the Los Angeles Rams.

The Little Church Around the Corner at 1 East Twenty-ninth Street celebrated yesterday the 100th anniversary of the founding of its parish. The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray is rector of the church, the official name of which is the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration.

A syndicate headed by William and Bernard A. Rosenblatt has purchased the three-story building containing offices and ten stores at 709 to 715 Eighth Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-fifth Street, from the Central Hanover Bank. The group paid all cash for the property, which is 100 by 100 feet and is assessed for $470,000.

A partnership of business and labor in which owners, management and workers share both the risks and the profits was proposed yesterday by Margaret Chase Smith, Republican Senator-elect from Maine. Mrs. Smith spoke at a luncheon in the Biltmore Hotel marking the opening of National Business Women's Week.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- In the opinion of qualified observers here, European objections have overruled for the time being any inclination that the United States might have had to resume full diplomatic relations with the Franco Government in Spain.

Taffeta and velveteen are the party dress fabrics for little girls from 3 to 12, according to Martin's in Brooklyn. For children who visited the store on Saturday morning, the fairy story of "The Old Lady Who Lived in a Shoe" came to life in a presentation of holiday and snow clothes.

After two eye-to-eye conferences with Secretary of State Marshall, President Truman has definitely abandoned his amazing proposal of sending Chief Justice Vinson on a new mission to the Kremlin at a moment when the Western Powers are presenting a united front before the United Nations against the Russian threat to peace.
MONTREAL, Oct. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Montreal Royals moved to within one game of the little world series championship today with an 8-3 defeat of St. Paul of the American Association.

With the world series prolonged by the Braves' victory over the Indians yesterday, the New York Telephone Company has announced that fans may still obtain the inning-by-inning scores on the series by dialing its time bureau at MEridian 7-1212.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10 -The importance of business men in the growth of American civilization will be studied in a newly established center at Harvard University.

Proceedings of the Lambeth Conference were reviewed yesterday by one of the 329 delegates, the Right Rev. John Boyd Bentley, vice president of the national council of the Protestant Episcopal Church and former Missionary Bishop of Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Secretary of State Marshall will leave by plane about noon tomorrow for Paris. He will return to the United Nations meeting with renewed assurance that President Truman is fully backing the program respecting United States-Russian relations that he has been following there.

ON BOARD DEWEY TRAIN, Monday, Oct. 11 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey left Albany at midnight on his seventeen-car "Victory Special" train on the second tour of his Presidential campaign that will take him into nine Midwestern and border states.

The free nations of Europe must speed their plans for unity if they expect continuance of aid under the Marshall Plan, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, declared last night. He told them bluntly that they faced the "acid test" of an audit of their self-help by the next Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -Aside from the referee's whistle, the horns of the other officials and finally the umpire's gun which signalled the end of one of the worst beatings ever inflicted upon a Steve Owen-coached team, the New York Football Giants had little going for them today.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- The annual meeting of the Albany Spaniel Field Trial Club on the grounds at Feura Bush ended today with the crowning of a new field trial champion, subject to A.K.C. approval. Winner in the open all-age stake for English springers was Fireball Bess, owned by Robert Van Benschoten of Ambler, Pa., and handled by Arthur R. Eakin.

Marion Bell, soprano, who sang the leading role of Fiona in "Brigadoon" last season with marked success, was heard in her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. In addition to her experience in operetta, the young artist had appeared with the San Francisco Opera Company, the St. Louis Municipal Opera and the Opera Nacional in Mexico City.

COPPER HILL, Tenn., Oct. 10 -- A reforestation project under the Federal Government and a private corporation to reclaim denuded lands, was inspected here today by delegates to the sixty-seventh annual convention of the American Forestry Association. Sessions will end tomorrow.

Illness in every form is treated in the eighty-six non-profit voluntary hospitals of New York. Immunization services are rendered by many clinics in these hospitals. Infants get necessary strength in incubators; infection is prevented with iodine.

Despite the need for higher standards of advertising stressed early in the year by nearly a score of trade leaders, infantile and misleading campaigns have appeared to increase rather than diminish, it was stated last week by a number of well-qualified observers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- The result of ten years of research and development, an automatic color camera, which was said to put clinical photography "on a scientific basis," was demonstrated today at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology.

A touchdown in the early minutes of the third period gave Cardinal Hayes its first football victory in two tries this season yesterday when it defeated St. John's Prep, 6 -- 0, at Triborough Stadium. A crowd of 7,500 saw the Redmen absorb their second loss in three outings.

Plans for the erection of a one-story business building were announced in connection with the sale of a plot on the north side of Forty-sixth Avenue, 190 feet east of Twenty-first Street, in Long Island City, Queens, by Friedericka E. Schramm and Lizzie Schmidt to Richard J. Welsh.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week ran the gamut of strength in sterling forwards and the Canadian free dollar, to irregularity in the French franc and the South Americans. The Swiss, Belgian and Holland units were firm.

JAFFA, Palestine, Oct. 10 -- The rebellion of the Stern group terrorists at the Jaffa military prison ended at dawn today when they accepted an Israeli Army ultimatum to surrender or face military action.
A program to strengthen established regulations against dishonest or fraudulent magazine subscription solicitations was announced here last week by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc.

Members of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, who rededicated their edifice at Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street yesterday after a $25,000 rehabilitation program, were told by a visiting preacher that a congregation is judged by the appearance of its church as much as a woman is judged by her housekeeping.

Purple haze broods on the mountains. Pasture hillsides are brown and sere though river valleys cling to summer's fading green. When October comes to the land other colors are a backdrop for the shining gold. The white maples, beeches, elms and birches change their dark summer cloaks to the color that marks a season's end.

Loyalty to God, to country, and to one's fellow men must be put above desire for ease, power and fame, the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, told a congregation of 650 yesterday at the twenty-seventh annual British Harvest Festival in Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street.
OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 10 -- Twice this season Alan Corey has been involved in sudden-death overtime matches, and each time the eight-goal star has supplied the clincher that brought victory.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 -- "Little Boy Blue," a recent magazine story by Maurice Zolotow, has been acquired for the screen by Paramount as a possible Betty Hutton vehicle. The story deals with a night-club singer, who, despite the distractions of her work, struggles to bring up her young son in a normal fashion.

The "critical need" for more institutions to provide long-term care facilities for homeless children here was stressed yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard. He spoke at ceremonies held in connection with the erection of a new building for the Shield of David Home for Orphan Girls, to be located at 1800 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx.

The recent World Council of Churches in Amsterdam revealed a remarkable unity of faith and a complete understanding and brotherliness, among men and women of different races and national backgrounds, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday in his sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.
BOSTON, Oct. 10 -- Resettlement committees in thousands of Catholic parishes in the United States are busy planning to absorb displaced persons into the life of their communities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The State Department's "Voice of America" has been telling the world that President Truman is lagging behind Governor Dewey in the Presidential campaign race, it was disclosed today.

As Mrs. Fiorello H. La Guardia announced yesterday her support of George Frankenthaler, Republican-Liberal candidate for New York County Surrogate, O. John Rogge opened his American Labor party campaign for the same office with an attack on Mayor O'Dwyer.

Through a benefit concert Saturday night the Manhattanville Neighborhood Center hopes to be able to expand its settlement program in a thickly populated thirty-six-block area not far from Columbia University.
PARIS, Oct. 10 (UP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt called on the sixteen Marshall Plan nations today to insure freedom for people throughout the world.

Dunninger, mental telepathist, will have Billy Rose, the showman, as his subject for the premiere of "The Bigelow Show" Thursday night at 9:30 o'clock on NBC's East Coast television network. Co-starred with Dunninger during the weekly half-hour telecasts will be Paul Winchell, ventriloquist.

The new cargo vessel Silverplane will leave here today on her maiden voyage to India and the Philippine Islands, via the Mediterranean. The Silverplane arrived here last week in ballast after delivery to her owners, Silver Line Ltd. by Joseph L. Thompson and Sons, Ltd., Sunderland, England, builders of the ship, Kerr Steamship Company, Inc., agents, explained yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 -- A decision as to whether 25,000 long-line telephone workers will go on strike at midnight Thursday is expected to be reached in negotiations scheduled to open tomorrow at 2 P. M. between the Long-Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the general executive board of the American Union of Telephone Workers, CIO.

Recommenations for a national educational policy designed to minimize the exclusion of controversial material from the reading lists of public schools were made public here yesterday over the signatures of 107 writers, educators and other public figures.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 -- Convinced that prospects for labor unity are slimmer than ever, John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers intend to continue their "lone wolf" role in the American labor movement.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Malcolm MacDonald, British Commissioner General in Southeast Asia, said on his arrival in London tonight that it was "a matter of time only before the Communist menace in Malaya is destroyed."

Mayor O'Dwyer will lay the cornerstone for the $3,267,552 Welfare Island laundry, garage and firehouse, to service all the institutions of the Department of Hospitals on the island, at 2 P.M. on Thursday, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 10 -- The French Government is preparing to make some changes in its monetary system, according to well informed sources here.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- Fifty-eight members of the United Nations -- and possibly forty-eight American States as well -- are to be asked to take charge of the decoration of the principal conference rooms in the permanent United Nations headquarters on the East River in New York, it was revealed here today.

"The SS State," by Eugen Kogon, a study of the German concentration camp system, will be brought out in the late spring by Farrar, Straus. Mr. Kogon, a Viennese journalist and prominent Catholic anti-Nazi, was arrested when Austria capitulated in 1938 and was a prisoner in concentration camps for seven years.

After a scoreless first period in an American Soccer League fixture at Sterling Oval yesterday, the New York Americans gained their second victory in the race for the professional championship by defeating the Brookhattan-Galicia eleven, 1 to 0.
HAVANA, Oct. 10 -- Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, lawyer and revolutionary leader, was sworn in as President of Cuba at noon today in the Presidential palace.

The United States will continue to send aid to Italy under the European Recovery Program, President Truman pledged yesterday in a Columbus Day message to Generoso Pope, president of the Columbus Citizens Committee, sponsoring tomorrow's parade on Fifth Avenue.
Cardinal Spellman declared last night that nations were girding themselves for a war of annihilation and that the world was facing the "greatest crisis in the history of civilization."

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Prices of wheat have been holding within relatively narrow price limits of late on the Board of Trade without developing a definite trend. This reflects continued heavy receipts of grain at terminal markets and a belief in the grain trade that the movement will remain large, at least until the close of navigation of the Great Lakes.

Since 1892 "Charley's Aunt" has entertained legions of playgoers. Tonight the celebrated farce, written by Brandon Thomas, will be seen in a new guise. Converted into a musical called "Where's Charley?" in which Ray Bolger is starred, it will set up shop at the St. James.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 -- Allan Haywood, national director of organization for the CIO, said today he was conferring with Harry Bridges, CIO Longshoremen's Union president whose men are in the thirty-ninth day of a strike.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- A great number of incidents occurred in central Rome this evening when the police broke up a meeting called by the extreme Right Wing Italian Social Movement. It was feared that this party, which is generally regarded as the spiritual heir of fascism, would stage a protest against the trial of Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, whom former Fascists consider a national hero.
Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's address last night follows:

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- After showing remarkable resistance to the tense, dangerous situation created by the Russian blockade of Berlin, the stock market here showed quite pronounced firmness last week. The index of industrial shares touched its highest point in a month.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 -- Those docile and peaceful Braves finally got around today to taking a punch at the big bully who has been cuffing them around all week. They fetched the Indians such a clout on the whiskers that the Tribe no longer is recognizable. A record crowd came out to see Rapid Robert Feller wrap up the world series and watched him get rapped instead.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Eamon de Valera, former Prime Minister of Ireland, opening a campaign in Britain for ending the partition of Ireland, charged tonight that Northern Ireland was a police state.

There's deep mourning in the Lone Star State and flags are lowered to half staff. Southern Methodist and the fabulous Doak Walker bit the dust kicked up by Missouri's thundering running attack from the split.

Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to move within a narrow trading range last week, following the pattern in previous weeks. At the cessation of trading on Saturday, changes in active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from a net decline of 4 points to a gain of 14 on the current crop deliveries.

Fears have begun to rise in foreign trade circles that production in Japan may be permitted to "rise beyond the rehabilitation point" and not only provide renewed competition for the United States in Far East markets, but also threaten the industrialization outlook for the Philippines and China.

Plans for three large playgrounds and the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Park to be developed in connection with the Governor Smith Houses on the Lower East Side were made known yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 10 -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, Presidential candidate of the States Rights Democrats, tonight issued a statement on the Berlin situation, saying:
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 10 -- Ambassador James Bruce, aboard the liner Brazil, is expected here about Oct. 25, presumably with fresh instructions to govern his relationship, with the Peron regime.

President Harry S. Truman will get a larger share of the votes of organized labor than any other Presidential candidate, but this will not be sufficient to enable him to carry any of the more populous industrial states with large numbers of electoral votes, according to a survey made by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Joe Glamp booted a twelve-yard field goal with twenty-eight seconds to play today to give the Pittsburgh Steelers a 10-7 victory over the Washington Redskins and a tie for the Eastern Division leadership in the National Football League. Both Washington and Pittsburgh now have won two and lost one.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for the Presidency, issued tonight a seventy-four-word statement designed to reassure the friendly nations of the world that the bipartisan foreign policy of the United States still stood despite the proposal of President Truman to send Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson to Moscow in a unilateral move, by-passing the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The lumber supply improved slightly during the first half of 1948 but prices generally remained at record highs, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Seven hundred worshipers watched the laying of the cornerstone of a two-story extension at the Jewish Community Center of White Plains at 952 Soundview Avenue today.

For housekeepers and breadwinners it is no new experience these days to be caught between steadily increasing costs and not enough family income to meet them. Now we learn that several up-state New York cities, prohibited by state law from raising as much money from real estate taxes as they need, are enmeshed in their own special version of the economic squeeze.

Graduation exercises for 515 probationary policemen and twenty-four policewomen will be held tonight in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street Mayor O'Dwyer will speak and 700 delegates here for the meeting of the International Association of Chiefs of Police will be guests of honor.

An interesting question concerning the public interest is raised by the President's abortive project to send Chief Justice Vinson on a special mission to Moscow. Obviously it is the publicity attending the unfortunate incident that has done so much harm at a critical moment in international affairs.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 10 -- Douglas McCrary of Calvert, Tex., and Mrs. John R. Fell of the Meadowbrook Club scored 30, 32 -- 62 during the second round of the thirty-six-hole mixed best-ball tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today and finished with the low score of 65, 62 -- 127, three strokes ahead of the field.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A fairly steady level of economic activity in 1949 was forecast today by economists of the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said today that he was calling top industry, labor, press, education, church and professional leaders to the first of a series of ten-day closed-door conferences on national defense Nov. 8 to 18.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 -- The 1948 world series is still alive and so, quite incredibly, are the Braves. In fact, Bill Southworth's cohorts went winging eastward this evening breathing defiance in all directions.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Two Labor Government Ministers bitterly attacked Winston Churchill today for his address to the Conservative party conference at Llanduno, Wales, on Saturday.

A two-day academic freedom rally under the auspices of the National Council of the Arts, Sciences and Professions closed last night when 2,500 persons gathered at the St. Nicholas Arena to hear appeals for preservation of the right of teachers to political freedom.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 10 -- There is "an imperative need" to reopen negotiations with Russia on the problem of Germany, Henry A. Wallace told more than 2,000 persons in a speech at the armory here tonight.

The Col. David Marcus Memorial Playground at Ocean Parkway and East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday to honor the native Brooklynite who served in the United States Army in World War II and was killed fighting with Israeli forces near Jerusalem last June.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Oct. 10 -- French Foreign Minister Schuman, appearing today in Coblenz after a plane trip from Paris, gave various indications that French policy toward Germany was undergoing an important change.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals outpointed the Green Bay Packers, 17 -- 7, today in a dreary National League game before 34,369 fans, the largest crowd ever to see a football game here.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 10 -- The Israeli Provisional Government an nounced today that a census of all persons in the new state and in territory occupied by the Israeli Army would take place this month in preparation for the coming elections for the Constituent Assembly.

Reporting on operations of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., for the fiscal year ended with last July 31, Jack I. Straus, president, says sales results for the current fall season indicate a continued high rate of consumer spending. His report to stockholders is to reach them today.

A scrappy three-way contest for the House seat held for many years by Representative Vito Marcantonio has focused political attention on the Eighteenth Congressional District as one of the few lively spots in an election generally devoid of local interest.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- One of the busiest of retired men is William T. Horton, Peekskill's unsalaried historian.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- A $1,200-a-year "across-the-board" cost-of-living adjustment to all present minimum and maximum salaries of the Feinberg teacher-salary law will be sought at the next session of the State Legislature, under a resolution adopted by the Empire State Federation of Teachers Unions at the final session of its convention today.

PEIPING, China, Oct. 10 -- The Chinese Government is parachuting ammunition to its troops defending Chinhsien, West Liaoning air supply base for isolated Mukden. Chinese Air Force pilots said today that they had dropped ammunition over Government positions near Chinhsien all day yesterday.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 10 -- "Democracy thrives when men wrestle vigorously with problems of social justice and when they seek to achieve a fair balance between conflicting claims," Dr. Sumner H. Slichter, Lamont Professor of Economics at Harvard University, told Lehigh University's graduating class this afternoon.

New York's traffic problem cannot be met with any "one-shot panacea" such as installing a few more traffic lights or posting a number of one-way streets, Franklin M. Kreml, one of the country's foremost authorities on traffic management, declared here yesterday.

ON TRUMAN TRAIN, Oct. 10 -- President Truman headed westward tonight on a six-state swing, gunning for ninety-seven important electoral votes in the midwest. Upwards of forty speeches are scheduled for the tour, which will take the President into Ohio, Illinois, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Indiana and West Virginia.

NANKING, Oct. 10 -- In a pronounced psychological let-down growing out of the dark military picture and the widening economic cracks President Chiang Kai-shek apologized today for a prediction that he made to the National Assembly last April that the Communists would be driven from strategic areas south of the Yellow River in six months.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 (AP) -Cleveland's huge Municipal Stadium didn't have an inch of open space in it today, except the playing field, as the Boston Braves humiliated the Cleveland Indians and the crowd broke all attendance-receipts records in the fifth game of the world series.
The city dedicated a thirty-foot monument on Hart Island yesterday to the memory of its 450,000 unclaimed dead in potter's field.

Two recent incidents of Junk boats landing material from ships in the harbor, without the supervision and processing by customs inspectors as required by law, were reported yesterday by E.E. Conroy, executive vice president of the Security Bureau, Inc.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 -- Steel producers here and throughout the nation are looking forward to smashing production records this month.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The Soviet Army newspaper Taegliche Rundschau charged today that the State Department "openly sabotaged" President Truman's attempt to reopen negotiations with the Soviet Union by sending Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson to Moscow.

Not only does this city lack facilities to meet the current need for psychiatric and non-psychiatric community services but many of the existing agencies are failing to help those who come to them for aid. This was charged yesterday in one of the most comprehensive reports on the problem ever issued.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- Unification of all Lutheran Churches, with a combined membership of 5,000,000, was urged tonight by the Rev. Dr. P. P. Bersell, president of the Augustana Lutheran Church.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 -- There was hilarity in the clubhouse of the Braves here today. The National League champions were making the most of their first good chance to celebrate since the opening game of the world series.
PARIS, Oct. 10 -- International express trains to and from Paris were held up today by striking railmen as the Government prepared for another effort tomorrow to mediate the national coal strike.
C.W. Staacke has been appointed a technical consultant and special assistant to Thomas Robins Jr., president of Hewitt-Robins, Inc., manufacturer of rubber belting and conveyor machinery.
The City Opera Company gave its first "Carmen" of the season at the City Center last night, introducing Alberta Masiello in the name role and dancers of the new City Ballet Company.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the fifth game of the world series at Municipal Stadium today follows:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The Federal Reserve Board has received reports from all parts of the country indicating a slump in used car prices since installment buying controls went into effect.

A truck driver stole a taxicab last night and in afour-block ride smashed into another car, careened through a plate glass window and started a commotion among 600 persons in a near-by motion picture theatre.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that Americans added another $900,000,000 to their "liquid" savings from April 1 through June 30.

SECAUCUS, N.J., Oct. 10 -- A College Point (L.I.) housewife, Mrs. Dorothy Mayer, was the star this afternoon of the season's final regatta in the metropolitan area, held on the Hackensack River. The event was conducted by the New Jersey Outboard Association.

By normal standards a paltry fare of art events can be expected this week with only a score of openings listed for a period in the season that usually introduces two or three times that number of new exhibitions.

Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, in a telegram yesterday to four Presidential candidates called attention to the "self-evident fact that no organization of Jews and no individual Jew can speak for all Jews in the United States on the Bernadotte plan, or on any other issue."

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week was curtailed by observance of religious holidays, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading residentbuying offices. Out-of-town buyers attended the spring sportswear openings, and many buyers placed heavy orders for holiday ready-to-wear.
PARIS, Oct. 10 -- After an investigation dating eleven years, a huge trial will open before the Paris Assizes Court tomorrow, are calling the bitterest quarrels between the Right and Left in France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Ed J. Buhner, president of the American Trucking Associations, Inc., urged today that the trucking industry support members of Congress who voted for the Taft-Hartley Act as vigorously as some labor union leaders are trying to defeat them.

LINDEN, N.J., Oct. 10 -- The new Esso Research Center of the Standard Oil Development Company, designed to meet the company's petroleum research requirements in this area for the next thirty years, will be formally dedicated here on Thursday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Lard futures fluctuated erratically last week on the Board of Trade. They broke early under liquidation induced by a drastic decline in prices of hogs but rallied strongly on short covering, and closing trades yesterday were at net gains of 5 to 47 cents a 100 pounds.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Two brothers were killed here today when a Piper Cub in which they were stunting crashed and burned. The dead were John C. Williams, 23 years old, and Moody Williams, 19, both of Deerfield, N.J.

Leonid Hambro, young American pianist who was one of the Naumburg Award winners of 1946, inaugurated a series of twilight concerts late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. It was an auspicious start, for he held his audience enthralled with playing of rare distinction and delicacy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Supreme Court is expected to announce tomorrow whether it will hear a number of cases bearing on constitutional rights of witnesses before the House Un-American Activities Committee.

Continuation of the nine-day-old strike against the Union News Company was voted last night, 568 to 7, at a meeting of Local 906, News Distribution Employes Union, CIO, it was announced by Murray Lissak, business agent for the local.

Kenneth Gordon, violinist, gave his second New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The 18-year-old artist had prepared an extensive program consisting of the Tartini-Kreisler Fugue in A major, Brahms' Sonata in D minor, the Glazunoff Concerto, Ysaye's unaccompanied Sonata in D minor, three display-pieces by Paganini, and as novelties, a Suite by Juan Orrego, contemporary Chilean composer, and the Arensky-Piastro "Elegia."

Although Tolstoy wrote "The Power of Darkness" for Russian actors, it serves Negroes just as well. Abram Hill, the Harlem impresario, is producing it with a Negro cast at the Master Institute, where it was performed last evening.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- A long range program of diversification has been undertaken by Butler Brothers, general merchandise retail chain, with the opening of three new stores and ten additional stores scheduled to be in operation by July 1, 1949, it was announced here today by G.R. Herberger, president.

Net income of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation for the first nine months of this year was $3,266,662 after all charges including provisions of $2,025,105 for depreciation and depletion and $2,145,000 for taxes, Thomas S. Nichols, board chairman and president, announced yesterday.

The North American Rayon Corporation and the American Bemberg Corporation will hold special stockholder meetings on Nov. 8 to vote on proposed amendments to their certificates of incorporation, it was announced yesterday.

The latest Navy jet plane is being tested in California, it was announced yesterday by the Navy. The craft is the Douglas XF3D-1 Skyknight, powered by two Westinghouse turbo-jet engines. The plane can be used for fighter and bomber missions and with slight modification can be assigned to carrier duty.

A strike of 420 structural steel painters yesterday halted work on bridges and housing here and in New Jersey. The walkout resulted from demands by Local 806, Structural Steel Painters of Greater New York, AFL, for $2.90 an hour instead of $2.55.

Never before has the lack of facilities for psychiatric services in New York been so fully documented as in the report published yesterday by the New York City Committee on Mental Hygiene of the State Charities Aid Association. It describes the city's resources as "grossly inadequate" when it comes to caring not only for the men rejected or discharged from military service because of neuropsychiatric disabilities but for the city as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior who broke with President Truman in 1946 and quit his Cabinet, said today that he would support the President actively for election to a full term.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 -- "In a bankrupt world, the automobile industry could show real statesmanship by stopping assembly of automobiles now and building more farm machinery instead," said Harry Ferguson, Irish-born inventor, today.

Nelson A. Rockefeller will be chairman of the 1949 Brotherhood Week to be sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, it was announced yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company and co-chairman of the conference.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, who has been taunted by the Democrats to "come out and fight," accommodated his political opponents today with a series of distinctly barbed speeches about the Truman Administration and its foreign and labor policies.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) authorized for payment on Dec. 9 a cash dividend of $1 in addition to a dividend payable in capital stock of five shares for each 200 held. The company distributed similar cash and stock dividends in June, and in 1947 $2 each were paid in June and December.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 11 -- Saul Lantzis of Fenway and Maurice Walsh, Sunningdale, fashioned 33, 33 -- 66, four strokes under par, to win the one-day amateur-pro event of the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today.

"The Nightmare of American Foreign Policy," by Edgar Ansel Mowrer, will be brought out on Oct. 27 by Knopf. It is not only an account of American diplomacy since World War I, but also an explanation of what foreign policy is and how it affects our lives.

If Joan Field had delivered nothing but Charles Ives' First Sonata at her Town Hall recital last night she still would have left a memorable impression. As it happened the young violinist turned in a whole evening's worth of exciting performances in a well-designed program.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies increased 9.7 per cent in September, compared with the corresponding month in 1947, according to compilations covering forty-four companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. An increase of 13.1 per cent was shown for the first nine months of the year.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- As the railway strikes spread today in Alsace and Normandy, Benoit Frachon, secretary of the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor, which called the stoppage, said one aim of the organization was to put an end to "the military agreements that make of the Western bloc a war machine against the Soviet Union."
BOSTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- There wasn't a tear in the dressing room as the Braves shuffled despondently from the field where Cleveland had beaten them today for the world's baseball championship.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider two New York bankruptcy cases involving a question of paying interest on local and state tax claims.

VIENNA, Oct 11 -- Soviet authorities in Austria have issued instructions that no arrests are to be made by Austrian police in the Russian zone of occupation or in the Russian sector of Vienna without Soviet authority.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- In a White Paper issued today the British Foreign Office charged the Soviet Union with having "embarked upon a carefully prepared attempt to compel the Western occupying powers to abandon under duress their rights in Berlin."

The Arrow Linen Supply Company of 1831 Second Avenue, charging that it faced financial ruin, brought an action in Supreme Court yesterday to lift an alleged laundry ban by a labor union. Named as defendants were the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, the Laundry Workers Joint Board of Greater New York and Local 331 of the union.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At Loew's Criterion, the attraction is "Walk a Crooked Mile," a Columbia topical melodrama starring Louis Hayward and Dennis O'Keefe. Gordon Douglas directed the Edward Small production from a screen play by George Bruce and a story by Bertram Millhauser. Louise Allbritton, Carl Esmond, Onslow Stevens, Raymond Burr and Art Baker are among the supporting players.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- The Cleveland Indians today completed their task of winning the championship of Greater Boston. One week to the day after they clinched the American League pennant by vanquishing the Boston Red Sox in the post-season play-off, the Tribe polished off the Boston Braves in the sixth and, as it was to prove, deciding game of the 1948 world series.

The Salvation Army sold the three-story building at 233-237 Washington Street, southwest corner of Campbell Street, Newark, N. J., to the Jabert Operating Corporation of New York City, which plans to improve the property to contain modern stores and offices.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 9 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 2 per cent.
BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The play-by-play description of the sixth and final game of the world series at Braves Field today follows:

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 11 -- Sharp debate marked the first day's session of the National Association of Letter Carriers' convention here today when a New York delegate questioned a resolution to eliminate subversive elements from the postal service.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 98.5 per cent of ingot capacity, a gain of 1 point over last week's rate and the highest operating level since the week of May 15, 1944, when the indicated rate was 99.2 per cent under the intensified war program, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Coincident with the refusal of the Supreme Court to review its decision of last June on overtime pay for longshoremen, representatives of dock workers and employers announced jointly yesterday that they had petitioned President Truman to take special action to prevent a waterfront strike in East Coast ports.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- National Airlines, Inc., already ordered by the Civil Aeronautics Board to appear at public hearings in December to show why the line should not be dissolved, struck back today with claims that it demonstrated one of the highest marks in operating efficiency among the sixteen trunk airlines in 1947.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Admission of a Negro graduate student to the University of Oklahoma was ordered today by the University of Oklahoma board of regents, but under a "segregated basis."

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, arrived by air today to begin a four-day visit during which he will dedicate the new Roman Catholic University of Santa Maria at Ponce, the island's second city.

At the end of a four-hour-meeting here yesterday the Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it had revised upward its offer of a wage rise to 25,000 employes in forty-two states.

Columbia's scarce supply of experienced reserve backs was reduced one further when Bob Russell, replacement for Gene Rossides at quarterback and the Light Blue's chief punter, was taken from the field yesterday on a stretcher. His right leg will be X-rayed for a possible fracture.

The Brotherhood of Consolidated Edison Employes of New York served notice yesterday that it would seek a union shop clause in its new contract by filing a petition with the National Labor Relations Board asking for a union shop election for all 26,500 employes.
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 11 -- Following is the text of President Truman's campaign speech here tonight:

DALLAS, Tex., Oct 11 -- Although the Texas political cauldron is bubbling over with intraparty feuds, purges and resentment against the civil rights proposals, it seems fairly certain that traditional Democratic party pluralities will give the state's twenty-three electoral votes to President Truman by a slim margin.

BAYONNE, N. J., Oct. 11 -- The nation's entire economy can be upset by the demands for steel of the national defense program, superimposed upon domestic and export demands, unless the situation is handled "prudently." This warning was issued today to Army, Navy, and Air Force officers attending an economic mobilization course at the Navy Supply Corps School by David F. Austin, a vice president of the United States Steel Corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies announced today the purchase of Russ Meyer, 25-year-old right-handed pitcher, from the Chicago Cubs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Acting Secretary of the Interior C. Girard Davidson said today the steel industry apparently has decided to "jettison" the voluntary allocation program. Mr. Davidson charged the industry is supplying steel for "nonessential and even for frivolous purposes," and is failing to meet the essential needs of the petroleum industry.

Fifteen working mothers and their children staked a sit-down in the auditorium of Public School 235, Lenox Road and East Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday in protest against the transfer of the youngsters to different schools. The children had been cared for at the school while their mothers, some of them war widows, worked.
Cleveland's Indians, who won the world series yesterday, earned an estimated $6,772.05 each for the six days of action, a record series payment, according to The Associated Press.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 11 -- Australia turned over $1,127,000 to the United Nations today as part of her contribution to the global campaign for assistance to 230,000,000 needy children. The drive for funds, under the name of the United Nations Appeal for Children, embraces fifty-two countries and thirty territories.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Internationalization of Jerusalem and the protection of United Nations mission members in Palestine would require a force of between 5,000 and 6,000 guards, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting Mediator, said today. This, he explained, was the number that the late Count Folke Bernadotte had in mind when he drafted his last report.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A continued high level of European demand for United States grains from next year's crops was forecast today by D. A. Fitzgerald, director of the food division of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 -- Allan Haywood, national director of organization for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, continued today with his spadework looking for a possible means of ending the West Coast maritime strike, now in its sixth week.

Building an early lead, Dennis Pat Brady, Bronx lightweight, gained a unanimous decision over Solly Cantor of Paterson, N. J., in the main attraction of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Brady weighed 132 3/4, Cantor 136.

From the West Coast comes word that T. J. McGowan and Marie Marx have joined forces to produce on Broadway after Christmas a comedy entitled "Is This USPUSS?" The work is an adaptation by Samuel W. Taylor, magazine writer, of his Saturday Evening Post satire on wartime Army Air Forces public relations in England.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 11 -- Juan Manuel Galvez, Nationalist candidate, received 255,000 of the 300,000 votes cast in the Presidential election here yesterday, according to the official count announced today.

Ten thousand volunteer workers began yesterday a community-wide solicitation to raise $16,500,000 for the 116 member hospitals and welfare agencies of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York. The campaign was opened last Thursday at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The continuing debate over radio's "giveaway" craze was said by some advertising trade observers yesterday to have brought out a number of basic weaknesses in most of the leading programs. Setting aside the elements of alleged lottery and the innate transiency of fads, use of the telephone appears now as a most serious weakness, it was noted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The famous test airplane, Gulfhawk II, went into the Smithsonian Institution today alongside other historic airplanes after its sole pilot, Maj. Alford Williams, had put it through a final exhibition flight at the National Airport.
The Yugoslav consulate at 745 Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth Streets, was picketed yesterday on the second anniversary of the imprisonment of Archbishop Stepinac of Zagreb.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- British government bonds and steel shares were best in the stock market here today, but business was on the slack side because the current account ends tomorrow.

Stuart Zane Perkoff, an 18-year-old actor of iron resolution, agreed in Federal Court yesterday to try the rigors of prison life before entering a plea Friday to an indictment charging him with failure to register for the draft.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 12 -- "Lute Song," the American musical by Sidney Howard and Will Irwin, which opened at the Winter Garden Theatre here last night was damned with faint praise by critics of the leading London newspapers this morning.

The National Maritime Union is planning a conference with ship-owners in an attempt to insure proper enforcement of all provisions contained in the recent contract signed by the union and the operators, it became known yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer indicated yesterday that the office of the Corporation Counsel would complete this week its report on the establishment of a commission to set policies for solving the city's costly traffic jam. The establishment of such a commission was proposed by Mayor O'Dwyer.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- Under a leaden sky that threatened any moment to shed bitter tears on the scene, Lou Boudreau and his Indians today crowned themselves baseball champions of the universe by defeating the Braves in the sixth game of the 1948 world series.

ROME, Oct. 11 -- Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, former commander in chief of the Fascist Republican Army after Mussolini's flight from Rome to northern Italy, appeared before a special civilian court in Rome today to answer charges of "collaborating with the German invaders."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The reason for the return to the United States last week-end of Secretary of State Marshall was precisely the one given by him and the President. Mr. Truman wanted to discuss with General Marshall the agenda and programming of the United Nations and have an arm's-length conversation, for which even the miracle of the teletype is not a satisfactory substitute.

MONTREAL, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A three-run pinch triple by Oscar Grimes and tight pitching by Jack Banta and Frank Laga carried Montreal's Royals to a 7-2 victory over St. Paul today and won them the little world series, four games to one.

Cruise travel aboard transatlantic luxury liners from New York is staging a comeback, although it is still considerably below pre-war levels, advance sailing schedules indicate. Three liners will be added to the "sunshine fleet," making a seasonal carrying capacity of 18,250 to 19,700 passengers for the six large liners to be in the trade in the winter and spring.

Random notes. Although an occasional mackerel is being taken, anglers are beginning to wonder what is delaying the big schools which usually make an appearance around this time. Reports from Casco Bay indicate plenty of these fish there, and quite a few fish are being taken on the Massachusetts coast.

With an unblemished, 7-and-0 record in the All-America Football Conference, the San Francisco Forty-niners, fresh from a 56-14 rout of the Baltimore Colts, moved into town yesterday, looking forward to Sunday's clash with the Yankees at the Stadium. They will be at Bear Mountain until it is time to drop into the Stadium.
PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Russia renewed today her efforts before the United Nations Trusteeship Committee to amend several articles in the Charter.

THE NEW YORK TIMES recently reported that a cure for the occupational disease of silicosis is now in sight, due to the wonderful work of doctors of a research project. Your paper omitted a key word in the description which is of vital importance. Silicosis is not just an occupational disease: silicosis is a preventable occupational disease, and therein lies the rub.

The United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association in cooperation with the Department of Agriculture will open a vegetable merchandising course for retail grocers today at the Hinsch Produce Company, Jamaica, Bernard J. Imming, representing the Merchandising Institute of the association, told more than 1,000 retail grocers at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on whether ultimate gas consumers should get $2,764,573 deposited with a lower court by the Interstate Natural Gas Company while it fought a rate reduction order.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The National Guard tonight announced reorganization of its infantry and armored divisions to increase their fire power and mobility up to a strength equal to that of the Regular Army.

With only a sixteenth of a mile to go in the six-furlong Saxon Woods, main attraction on the racing card at Jamaica yesterday, the heavily favored Up Beat seemed on the verge of beating up eight others, and the 17,260 fans, or most of them at any rate, were rapidly calculating their gains on what appeared a certain victory for the 3-year-old son of Pharamond II.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Governor Dewey is planning to work out an arrangement with the Truman Administration under which the Republicans, if they won the election, would share the knowledge of and responsibility for national and international affairs during the transition between Election Day and Jan. 20, when a new President is inaugurated.
PARIS, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The text of the British resolution on arms limitation introduced today in the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly follows:
The legality of his deportation hearing was challenged yesterday by Michael Salerno, avowed Communist and editor of L'Unita del Popolo, Italian language newspaper here.

Complaints that ready-to-wear manufacturers are either failing to deliver on time or failing to notify when a delivery cannot be made are being received by the National Retail Dry Goods Association from retailers throughout the country, it was learned here yesterday.

Industry must start to use immediately what is available in the atomic energy field and must know what is to become available, Robert M. Hutchins, chancellor of the University of Chicago, said yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft opened a Southern campaign tour tonight with an appeal to the Democrats of Tennessee to join in support of Republican nominees for President and Senator.

The rubber futures market on the Commodity Exchange, aided by trading in a new contract designated as No. 1 R.S.S. (ribbed smoked sheets) moved generally higher in increased volume yesterday. The day's turnover in the new contract amounted to 330 long tons, while 260 long tons were handled in the standard contract. Volume was the largest in more than a week.

Various combinations of a chair frame made of laminated maple, foam rubber and webbing lead to diverse chair styles in the furniture shown yesterday by Pascoe Associates. The chairs, designed for comfort and easy cleaning, are part of a group of furniture and furnishings available to local consumers through Pascoe-New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 -- On the recommendation of its parish and church school board, the United Lutheran Church in America decided today against encouraging local congregations to establish weekday or parochial schools at this time.

The further development of the projected European federation urged by the United States and generally accepted as essential for European survival will be profoundly influenced by the decisions of about a dozen mostly non-European men now meeting in a "family gathering" in London.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that on his recent trip to North America he had been "able to dispose of some of the misunderstanding" in the United States about British and European recovery, and hoped that he had convinced the Americans that "there was no question of our dragging our feet."

The pairings of the record number of eighteen teams that will compete in the sixty-eighth international six-day bike race at the Kingsbridge Armory, Jerome Avenue and 194th Street, starting Sunday night, were announced yesterday by Promoter James A. Proscia.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 -- A symposium of international leaders on the world crisis and its solution featured the first edition of Los Angeles' new afternoon daily, The Mirror, today.

WASHINGTON, Oct 11 -- In two wage rulings today the Supreme Court refused to review a lower court decision against "merit" pay increases, and declined to reconsider its own decision that premium pay for night and odd-hour work must be included in overtime rate computations.

St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L. I., of which the Rev. Francis R. Ryan is pastor, has purchased six acres of land on the north side of Round Hill Road at East Hills, Roslyn Heights, from Joseph Wallace Hennessy as the site for a new church.

Conceding that the Democratic party was in "a hard, uphill fight" to elect its candidates, Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said yesterday that the Truman-Barkley ticket was gaining.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Under leaden skies accompanied by mist and showers, eighty-seven players closed the season of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association over the south course of the Westchester County Club today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The White House tonight disclosed that $88,275,170 has been handed over as military aid to the Chinese Central Government in its fight against Communist forces in the last six months.

ALBANY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein ordered today that the names of the American Labor party candidates be restored to the November election ballot in Albany and Rensselaer Counties.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (AP) -- "How great is the danger of another world war and how best can it be prevented?" was the question asked of the international figures.

Mental abnormalities ranging from psychopathic personality to mental deficiency caused the rejection of 52 per cent of Selective Service registrants sent by local draft boards for Army preinduction examinations in the last week, a survey by Army doctors showed yesterday.

If it were not for the ticklish international situation this country would be making encouraging progress toward full realization of the basic Constitutional guarantees. This is the conclusion one has to draw from the current report of the American Civil Liberties Union, published under the title of "Our Uncertain Liberties" and brought down through July of this year.
A mother pushed her 20-year-old son into Bronx County Court yesterday so that he could plead guilty to the crime that already had sentenced him to spend the rest of his life in a wheelchair.
A 21-year-old Brooklyn letter carrier was arraigned yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, charged with stealing from the mails cash contributions to a Catholic charitable institution in the borough.

Seeking a means to reduce manufacturing costs on wool goods in view of increased consumer resistance to prices of men's clothing, manufacturers of woolens are hopeful that the lower trend recently manifested in the Australia wool auctions will continue, it was learned yesterday.

CASPER, Wyo., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren tonight charged the Administration with exploitation and manipulation of the West solely for the purpose of "political perpetuation" of the Democratic party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that a textile mill did not violate the Labor Relations Act by granting a wage increase without notifying union officials.

Jaundice may indicate to a doctor that a patient is suffering from any of a number of ills that require use of the facilities in New York's eighty-six non-profit voluntary hospitals. Joint diseases, too, may require hospitalization or treatment in one of these institutions, which serve regardless of race, creed or ability to pay.
PARIS, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A two-day argument over the mention of the Deity in the draft United Nations Declaration on Human Rights ended today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The record production of crops forecast from American farms this season is coming close to realization. A harvest-time report issued by the Agriculture Department today said total farm output was indicated to be 8 per cent above the previous record of 1946.
The South should not be "let alone" to deal with its racial problem in its own way, Federal Judge J. Waties Waring of Charleston, S. C., said yesterday.
BERLIN, Oct. 11 (UP) -- A resourceful G. I. told today how he persuaded twenty-five Russian soldiers to let him drive his new car from Western Germany to Berlin through the Soviet blockade.
