Proper medical treatment for nutritional deficiencies depends on feeding prescribed foods during a prolonged period, Dr. Robert S. Goodhart told doctors at the "graduate fortnight" of the New York Academy of Medicine last night.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. Awni Abdul Hadi, Minister of Social Affairs in the new Arab Palestinian Government, announced tonight that Egypt had warned the United Nations truce headquarters that all Egyptians would fight if Israeli troops did not withdraw from positions seized last Thursday in a sudden attack in the northern Negeb.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks announced today they have traded Goalie Emile (The Cat) Francis and Wingman Alex Kaleta to the New York Rangers in return for Goalie Jim Henry.

For the first time, large scale group merchandising of hardware products is being undertaken jointly by four New England and New York area manufacturers, Howard C. Wilson, managing director, the Hardware Institute, disclosed yesterday. He discussed the project at a preview of the third National Hardware Show, which opens to the trade today at Grand Central Palace.

No radio station in Russia presents the arguments for and against the continuation of the regime of Mr. Stalin. No radio in Poland, Bulgaria, Hungary, Rumania or today's Czechoslovakia presents the arguments for and against the continuation of the regimes now ruling those countries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11 -- The Royal Canadian Mounted Police became a bone of contention between Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Twentieth Century-Fox today with the announcement by Metro that Sam Marx has been rushed to Ottawa by Dory Schary, studio production chief, to obtain material for a documentary-style film on the Canadian police force.
Fourth-quarter sales of cosmetics and toiletries will exceed those of last year, it was forecast yesterday by Charles A. Pennock, president of the Toilet Goods Association, Inc.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 11 -- Five conservationists were elected to honorary membership in the American Forestry Association, it was said here today by officials upon their arrival in the convention city after a two-day trip into the forest reserves of eastern Tennessee and western North Carolina.

After hiding out for fourteen years, Liberale Parrino, 48-year- old owner of a small Brooklyn grocery store, was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday and charged with violation of the Lindbergh Law in connection with the kidnapping and brutal torturing of two French seamen. The crime is punishable by death if that penalty is recommended by a jury.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Representatives of the British Commonwealth of Nations began their meetings here today in an atmosphere so friendly and cooperative that it swept away doubts of continuing strength and cohesion of this unique world-wide organization.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll returned today to the state Capitol after an absence of two and one-half months because of illness. He appeared much improved in health and immediately tackled an accumulation of state tasks.

Still concerned over his team's defense, but gratified by the outcome, Lou Little yesterday accepted congratulations for Columbia's 34-28 victory over Yale last Saturday and immediately started to worry about Pensylvania. A celebrated alumnus of Penn, Little now must prepare his charges for Saturday's Baker Field clash with George Munger's powerhouse Red and Blue.

Coverly Fischer, chairman of the administrative committee of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, said yesterday the federation was seeking the help of the Welfare Council of New York City in the establishment of a uniform accounting system for child care agencies.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art was the setting yesterday for a showing of fashions inspired by costumes by Lucinda Ballard for the motion picture, "Portrait of Jennie." A portrait by Robert Brackman of Jennifer Jones, who plays the title role in the forthcoming David O. Selznick production, was unveiled.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Joe Baksi-Ezzard Charles heavy-weight elimination bout was re-scheduled today for Dec. 10 in New York's Madison Square Garden. The winner of the fifteen-round test may meet champion Joe Louis.
TOKYO, Oct. 11 -- The Japanese Diet convened today with the hope of electing within a few days a Premier to replace Dr. Hitoski Ashida, whose coalition government resigned last week.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 11 -- John L. Lewis became today one of the world's highest-paid labor leaders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The wage-hour administrator today won his plea for a Supreme Court review of a decision which he said cast serious doubt on the enforceability of hundreds of injunctions obtained against employers under the Fair Labor Standards Act.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- John L. Lewis asked the Federal Court of Appeals today to return the $1,420,000 he and his United Mine Workers union paid in contempt of court fines as a result of the soft coal strike last spring.

Law enforcement agencies in all democratic countries were warned by various speakers yesterday at the annual conference of the International Association of Police Chiefs at the Hotel Pennsylvania to be on the alert to combat subversive elements.

LONDON, Oct 11 -- The Conservatives have dispersed from their annual conference, which has just ended at Llandudno, Wales, in a mood of confidence and even complacency. As Lord Woolton, their chairman, said in winding up the conference, they really believe their return to power is not a question of "if" but "when."
With growing realization of the need for mobility, the Police Department quietly is rebuilding one of its least known but greatly feared units, the motorcycle division.

Passenger travel on the nation's railroads is doomed unless the industry can soon organize cheaper production of cars, Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, declared yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and prices closed 10 points higher to 12 points lower than on Saturday.
BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- Pitching has dominated the world series of 1948 and today the spotlight was turned on the hurler who has been the key man in the triumph of the Indians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Secretary of State Marshall asserted today, as he departed for the United Nations General Assembly meeting in Paris, that the country was "completely united" in its foreign policy and expressed his determination to restore confidence in that policy abroad.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 (AP) -- "It should happened yesterday for that crowd:"

SHANGHAI, Oct. 4 -- Maj. Gen. Chiang Ching-kuo, economic boss of Shanghai, said in an interview here he was encountering stiff behind-the-scenes opposition from groups on which he has cracked down in his "tiger-hunting" campaign against big-time hoarders and speculators.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- President Truman is not the only Presidential candidate who has received divided counsel about the "Vinson incident." Gov. Thomas E. Dewey likewise seems to have been given somewhat divergent advice from his famous "team."

Three buildings in Broadway's "Auto Row" at Fifty-sixth Street have been sold by Frederick Brown to the newly formed 1751 Corporation, represented by Emanuel Schwartz and Arthur Loeb, brokers in the transaction. The buildings, five, four and three stories in height, are at 1751 to 1765 Broadway and 239 to 251 West Fifty-sixth Street, occupying a plot 162.4 by 211 feet at the northwest corner of the intersection.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Britain's economic recovery must take precedence over her rearmament, Albert V. Alexander. Minister of Defense, said in a speech in Bristol tonight.

Given fair weather, the installation of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as the thirteenth president of Columbia University will be held today at 2 P. M. on the university's South Court. If it rains, the university will announce, not later than noon today, that the ceremony will take place in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.

Mrs. Charles Herbert Jones of this city and Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., her brother, Livingston L. Short, and her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Hannah Jones, will sail Friday on the Nieuw Amsterdam. They will go to Paris, where the marriage of Miss Jones to James M. E. O'Grady, United States Vice Consul at Bremen, Germany, will take place on Oct. 23 in the American Church.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Baltimore locals of the CIO Shipyard Workers Union unanimously condemned today the attempt of Local 1, of Camden, N. J. to separate from the national union.

From Madison Square Garden the World's Championship Rodeo moved to Bellevue Hospital's outdoor arena yesterday in the rodeo's annual trip to entertain sick and crippled children Although the 5,000 persons on hand did not see the bronco riding and calf roping featured at the Garden, they saw something just as good and certainly a greater ratify -- a horse in a taxicab.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- United States competition is expected to play an important role in breaking the intra-European trade deadlock, according to a recent re-examination of the troublesome European trade patterns by high officials of the United States and European countries.

On May 14 the United States Government announced that it "recognizes the provisional Government as the de facto authority of the new State of Israel." In the five months which have elapsed since that date the Israeli Government has become firmly established as a stable regime in the area over which it asserts jurisdiction, unshaken by internal disorder or the determined military assault of neighboring Powers.
Following is the text of an address last night in Pittsburgh by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 11 -- President Truman dedicated himself anew to the New Deal tonight as he made a climactic bid for Ohio's twenty-five electoral votes.

Now that the World Series has come to an end, football holds the center of the stage for a run through November. With perfect timing, Columbia opens a long home stand on Saturday, taking on in succession Pennsylvania, Princeton and Cornell.

Earlier this year there were those who thought Dwight D. Eisenhower might be the next President of the United States. He has high qualities of mind and character which gave that suggestion force. He has brought those qualities to another post, in which he will be formally installed today.

Last night was an important night for the ballet hereabouts, for it marked the debut of what is in effect the first institutionalized ballet company in these parts. On this occasion Lincoln Kirstein's Ballet Society assumed a new identity as the New York City Ballet Company, correlative in its own field to the New York City Opera Company and the New York City Symphony as part of the City Center project.
PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Representatives of the big three Western powers tonight reaffirmed their determination not to negotiate with the Soviet Union until the blockade of Berlin had been lifted.

Two widely different challenges were thrown before the 350 members of the American Society of Planning Officials at their meeting in the New Yorker Hotel yesterday. Mayor O'Dwyer asked them to figure out how to build the Second Avenue Subway without the requisite half-billion dollars, and Lewis Mumford, author and lecturer, concerned himself with the practical aspects of courtship.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Picking up three birdies to offset a pair of bogeys, Miss Polly Riley nicked a stroke off par today to win medal honors in the thirteenth annual Texas women's golf tournament with a 37, 37 -- 74.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Oct. 11 -- Twenty months after their last joint inspection tour, the United States and British Military Governors of Germany returned to the Ruhr today.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- The private and voluntary child care agency is a part of the pattern of American life that is being threatened by "an alien social philosophy," the Rev. John J. Lennon, of New York today warned.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 11 -- In a week-end speech to the workers of the Bor copper mines, the biggest of their kind in Europe, Premier Marshal Tito said Yugoslavia today was short of oil and other basic commodities as a consequence of her political difficulties with the Soviet bloc.

Frantic brides-to-be, burdened by last-minute details of their approaching wedding day, will find a sympathetic friend in Miss Beatrice Loennecke, newly appointed wedding hostess for the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.

With teamsters insisting on a substantial wage rise and milk dealers warning that these demands would add to processing and distributing costs, negotiations reached an impasse yesterday and the dispute was referred to Federal, state and city mediators.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a deficit of $1,323,701 for the first eight months of this year, in contrast with a net income of $6,962,133 in the comparable 1947 period. For August, operations resulted in a net loss of $131,201, while in the same month last year, the company reported a net profit of $425,729.

For the second time in four days, Local 1250, a former unit of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, was fined yesterday for violating court orders limiting picketing before Oppenheim, Collins Co. department stores in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

The stock market had difficulty yesterday in holding its current position even in the face of a marked drop in volume. Faced with today's Columbus Day holiday, many brokers took off yesterday to stretch their week-end and, with the absence of professional interest, the market accomplished nothing outside of an irregular drift.

Ray Bolger is not the greatest man in the world. But why quibble? In "Where's Charley?", which was put on at the St. James last evening, he is great enough to make a mediocre musical show seem throughly enjoyable. An eminent hoofer of the bucolic breed, he pushes the show aside now and then to spin rhapsodically through his mocking dances, grinning like a country gawk and translating love into leaps, whirls and comic staggers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized Home Gas Company of Pittsburgh, Pa., to borrow $1,600,000 from Columbia Gas System, Inc., New York holding company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 -- A demand that the United States Government extend its trade agreements program for a "substantial period" beyond the present expiration date of June 30, was voiced today by Senator Alben W. Barkley as he campaigned in the San Francisco Bay area.

NANKING, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Chinese Government announced today the recapture of Yingkow, important Manchurian seaport. This was Nanking's greatest victory in many weeks. A Government military spokesman said the 115-mile route northward from Yingkow to Mukden is open now.

SEVILLE, Spain, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco said tonight that Spain would fight against an enemy that would attack neighboring countries in spite of "ideological differences" between those countries and Spain.

The commissioner of one of the British Virgin Islands, on holiday in New York and evidently longing for a taste of home, asked this column whether Stilton cheese could be found anywhere in the city. His question couldn't have been more apropos.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The British Treasury announced tonight that holdings of gold and dollars in the sterling area had been reduced during the third quarter of this year by 76,000,000 (about $304,000,000). This compares with a reduction in the first quarter of 147,000,000, and in the second quarter of 100,000,000.

Fred Allen has improved his Hooper popularity rating as compared with last spring but still is running behind "Stop the Music," the give-away show with which his program competes on Sunday nights, it was disclosed yesterday. Edgar Bergen, whose show also overlaps "Stop the Music," on the other hand, finished ahead of the give-away.
Further reductions yesterday in meat prices brought sirloin and porterhouse steak to 69 to 89 cents a pound in many stores, 10 to 20 cents below the prices of a month ago.

The appointment of a travel advisory committee, made up of representatives from the various segments of the travel industry, to aid in the development of international travel, has been announced by Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer.
As Jews throughout the world prepared to observe at sundown today the Day of Atonement, Yom Kippur, religious and lay leaders voiced faith in a less troubled future.
Comdr. Attilio Gatti, veteran explorer and writer, warned last night that the military power of British East Africa was "dangerously inadequate."

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Running the fastest six furlongs of the meeting -- 1:13 2/5 -- Bobanet Stable's King Midas took down the major portion of the Walter Reed Purse, feature event of Laurel race course today. In winning his second straight victory over the local course, the Heliopolis gelding took the measure of nine other three-year-olds including Tenabob, a stablemate.

Almost without exception, the winter fashions shown yesterday by Peggy Roth of 400 Park Avenue had flared skirts. The collection, including suits, daytime dresses and evening gowns, was presented during a luncheon at the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The nation's railroads, which on Oct. 1 asked for a general increase of 8 per cent in freight rates, will file with the Interstate Commerce Commission tomorrow an amended request for a 13 per cent rise in basic rates.

NOBODY born in the present century can possibly understand what the writings of George Meredith meant to his small but enthusiastic following in the Eighteen Nineties. Some inkling of the excitement and reverent admiration he inspired was revealed to me about twenty-five years ago when, having read "The Ordeal of Richard Feverel,"

The "Democratic Record Show," a new radio appeal for the votes of 1,500,000 housewives, made its debut at 3:45 P. M. yesterday over the nation-wide facilities of the American Broadcasting Company in the first of a series to be heard three times weekly to Nov. 1.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 11 -- Long Island farmers, confronted with another cut in potato acreage, this time 29 per cent under the 1948 goal, are likely to go along with the United States Department of Agriculture recommendations, but have protested reductions that do not give states equal treatment.
Uniform parkway regulations throughout the state to permit carrying skis and other winter sports equipment on the tops of automobiles was urged yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York.

The blustering type of Santa Claus who greets children with a lusty "Ho, Ho, Ho" will be out of style this Christmas, replaced by a soft-spoken Santa whose booming voice won't frighten little children.

The State of Mississippi announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Oct. 20 on an issue of $5,000,000 highway revenue bonds dated Aug. 1, 1948, due from 1953 to 1971 and callable on Feb. 1, 1958.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Traders were bearish today on an estimate by the Department of Agriculture on the 1948 corn crop. The forecast was issued after the close of markets on the Board of Trade. Including carryover, 3,683,000,000 bushels of corn were seen for the 1948-49 crop year, compared with 2,687,000,000 the previous season and 3,434,000,000 in 1946-47.
PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Britain asked the United Nations General Assembly today to find the Soviet minority responsible for the world's failure to disarm.

Urging that Italy's pre-war colonies be returned to her rule, Mayor O'Dwyer declared last night that the United States and Italy "stand side by side to see that Italy gets a square deal." He spoke at the annual dinner of the Columbus Citizens Committee, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Discussions and criticisms of religion in public school classrooms violate American traditions, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday in reply to a committee that had protested the New York public school ban on the weekly magazine The Nation.

WEST REDDING, Conn., Oct. 11 -- James Roper, 20-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmo Roper, was found dead at 6:30 A. M. today in a closet off a second-floor bedroom of his parents' home here. The young man, who was graduated last June from Williams College, was associated with his father, a public-opinion analyst, in his offices in Rockefeller Center, New York.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, declared tonight that his party was "assured of a place on the ballot" in forty-six states.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Optimists are few among the Democrats in the section of New York State that includes Oneida and Onondaga Counties and the cities of Utica, Rome and Syracuse. The question in Democratic minds is not whether Thomas E. Dewey or Harry S. Truman will carry those counties but simply the margin of victory for Mr. Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Proposed anti-trust action by the Federal Reserve Board against the Transamerica Corporation, scheduled to begin with hearings tomorrow, stumbled today over a Federal court order requiring the board to give more details of its complaint to the corporation before starting its action.

SEATTLE, Oct. 12 (UP) -- A warrant charging second degree perjury was issued today against George Hewitt of New York in connection with his testimony before a state legislative committee that investigated communism at the University of Washington.
" Steve Owen still is the coach of the football Giants and he can stay just as long as he wants to -- which I hope is as long as we're here."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12 -Swinging his campaign tour into one of the country's main centers of agriculture and industry, Senator Alben W. Barkley today charged that the Republican party had sought to "drive a wedge" between farmers and labor and was "unworthy" of the electoral support of either.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 12 -- Egypt and Iraq announced today their official recognition of the new Arab Palestine Government asserting sovereignty over all of Palestine. Syria and Lebanon are expected to follow suit within a matter of hours.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 12 -Plans to transfer the battle plaque and a steel engraving of Capt. James Lawrence, naval hero of the War of 1812, from the battleship New Jersey to the museum at the Naval Academy, Annapolis, were announced today by state military authorities.

The seven-story apartment house at 531 East Lincoln Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., accommodating 150 families, has been sold by Aaron and Jacob Shriro to Esplanade Gardens, Inc. The property, on a plot 251 by 319 feet, is assessed at $554,000 and was sold subject to two mortgages totaling $492,600.
College football's "first ten" underwent a reshuffling yesterday after an eventful Saturday as Notre Dame dropped from the top rung.

The mystery of a "five-engined" airplane, reported for weeks as flying in eastern skies, was solved yesterday. The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, with Air Force approval, admitted that the plane was not a flying saucer but a B-17 Flying Fortress actually equipped with five engines that had passed many hours of flight testing.

" The Birth of Israel: The Drama as I Saw It," by Jorge GarciaGranados, will be published by Knopf on Oct. 22. It covers the findings of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, of which Mr. Garcia-Granados was a member as chief of the Guatemalan delegation.

Warning that Communist "fifth columns" are working systematically in every country of the Western Hemisphere to excite fear and ill-will between the nations, former President Herbert Hoover urged last night that practical steps be taken to promote good-will and the mutual prosperity of the Americas.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (Reuters) -The five-foot-high "Blue Riband" trophy for which giant liners in the North Atlantic used to compete has disappeared as signs multiply that the fierce competition of pre-war years will be resumed soon.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's farm-policy address here tonight:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 -- Belief that some progress was being made toward his goal of getting West Coast maritime strikers and shipowners back into negotiation was voiced late today by Allan S. Haywood, director of organization for the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 12 -President Truman asserted tonight that the "Wall Street crowd" would not permit Governor Dewey to put his "me too" stamp of approval on the "one sane national policy for agriculture -- organized, sustained and realistic abundance."

VIENNA, Oct. 12 -- The Allied Council for Austria will deal Friday with the problem of maintaining what amounts to a twoparty system in Austria or introducing a multiple-party system. It is feared that a multiple-party system eventually could lead to the same type of political chaos as exists in various other European states such as France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board refused today to hold a bargaining election now among the Tucker Corporation's automobile workers. The reason: production of the newtype car still is in "the experimental stage."

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Oct. 12 -The calm dispassion with which upper New England views the national election three weeks from today indicates that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey already has a lead of twelve electoral votes from the three northern states of this region.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and representatives of the major phonograph record companies announced yesterday the collapse of negotiations looking toward removal of the union's ban on the manufacture of new disks.

In a market that was relatively quiet owing to Columbus Day and the eve of a religious holiday, buyers flocked to the spring and resort openings of Henry Rosenfeld, Inc., dress manufacturer. Holding only one showing in the morning at the showrooms, 498 Seventh Avenue, it was necessary to turn away over 200 persons, according to Mr. Rosenfeld, for the presentation of over 125 new styles.

WHEELING, W.Va., Oct. 12 -Gwilym A. Price, president of the Westinghouse Electric Company, speaking before a group of top utility men and manufacturers in Oglebay Park at a dinner meeting tonight, discussed details of his company's post-war reconversion program.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 12 -Harvard's football team comes to Michie Stadium Saturday for its first game with Army here since 1942, and the Military Academy is preparing to lay out the plush for a gala day.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 12 (AP) -Cleveland's world series champions received a thunderous welcome home from the baseball wars today as an estimated 200,000 persons yelled themselves hoarse in a demonstration unsurpassed in the city's history.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 -- The United Lutheran Church in America declared today its willingness to consider organic union with any or all of the other seven groups of the National Lutheran Council, which is the cooperative agency for two-thirds of American Lutheranism.

In your recent article on the death of Mrs. Edith Kermit Carew Roosevelt, the widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, you mentioned that she had chosen for her own epitaph, "Everything she did was for the happiness of others." Those who had the privilege of knowing her closely, I dare say, would regard that epitaph as deserved and fitting.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Back on July 4, Frank Hague conceded New Jersey's sixteen electoral votes to Governor Dewey if President Truman won the nomination, and the New Jersey Democratic boss has not done enough since then to warrant any revision of his forecast.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 12 (AP) -Anna M. Dursch's Ann's Lee scored her first victory of the meeting at Rockingham Park today in the $7,500 added Columbus Day Handicap, headline event of the track's annual turf doubleheader.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 12 -- The conduct of the nation's foreign policy is becoming more and more an issue in the Presidential campaign.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower added another triumph to his chain of conquests when he was installed yesterday as the thirteenth president of Columbia University. He emerged a decided victor in the perennial "battle of the echo" that has challenged many a speaker at ceremonies on South Court and South Field.
The text of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's address at his installation ceremonies yesterday at Columbia University:
After a rough flight across the Atlantic, two horses that will run in Saturday's $100,000 added Gold Cup race at Belmont Park arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The United Nations Security Council is expected to meet in the next few days to discuss several reports concerning the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, breaches of the truce and general conditions in Jerusalem, delegates interested in these questions said today.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- All of the Boston Braves, with the exceptions of Manager Billy Southworth and the club's executives, planned to "forget baseball" until next spring, today, as they drew transportation from traveling secretary Duffy Lewis and headed homeward.

Higher production costs and higher prices in many important industries in the New York area already have resulted from the Cement Institute Case and other decisions outlawing the "multiple basing point" or "delivered" prices, with small business and the consumer being hit hardest, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., declared here yesterday.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,469, compared with 743 last week and 1,567 in the corresponding week of 1947, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 448 arrivals yesterday, against 110 last Tuesday.

Representatives of the nations of the British Commonwealth are assembled in London this week for their first conference since before the war. In the eleven years since they last met changes have occurred in the structure of the Empire and the world which alter most of the things they took for granted in 1937.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The United Public Utilities Corporation, Chicago, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for the final steps in its liquidation and dissolution.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, thirteenth president of Columbia University, is the first military man to head the institution, now in its 195th year. His predecessors include four clergymen, four educators, two lawyers and two business men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The United States has lost a "major and perhaps decisive battle" in the "cold war" with the Soviet Union because the Marshall Plan is "becoming diverted from its original purpose of European recovery into a means of rearming Europe," Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The most critical problem now facing this country's schools is the increasing shortage of elementary school teachers, the ten-member National Commission on Teacher Education and Professional Standards stated today at the close of a four-day meeting at National Education Association headquarters.

ALBANY, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The State Health Department reported today that twenty of the state's seventy largest communities outside of New York City had achieved 70 per cent immunization against diphtheria among children under 5 years of age.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 12 -Federal financial assistance to states as a means of ameliorating the housing shortage and clearing slums was advocated here this evening by Herman T. Stichman, New York State Housing Commissioner. He spoke at the sixtieth annual convention of the Ohio Savings and Loan League.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12 -Yale's football team today began preparations for Wisconsin and the longest road trip in Eli history.

Paintings by 4 to 12-year-old children in the city's public schools will be displayed for two weeks beginning today in the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. These colorful and imaginative examples, the outcome of an experiment conducted by Miss Virginia Murphy.

The following is the list of official delegates who accepted invitations to the installation yesterday of Dwight D. Eisenhower as thirteenth president of Columbia University. The list was given out by the university, which pointed out that there may have been a few last-minute cancellations.

The significance of luxurious handwoven fabrics to the average homemaker who cannot pay $75 a yard for drapery material is spotlighted in the exhibit that opened yesterday in the gallery of America House, 485 Madison Avenue.

The very enthusiasm that the public and public officials have for city planning should be a warning that planners must produce "realistic, not fantastic" schemes for municipal development, Charles B. Bennett of Los Angeles, president of the American Society of Planning Officials, said yesterday.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 12 -- A warning that in case of national emergency the aircraft manufacturing industry could not increase its output of war planes in much less than two years was voiced here this afternoon by H. Mansfield Horner, president of the United Aircraft Corporation.

JALIL, Israel, Oct. 12 -- About half of the 5,000 Arab prisoners captured by the Israeli Army since May are held in a tent camp hastily thrown up on the sand and scrub of a little valley beside this former Arab village.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Britons have received more than 50,000,000 gift food parcels from the United States and the British Dominions and colonies since 1940, and today John Strachey, Minister of Food, opened a "thank you" exhibition at the Commonwealth Gift Center here to acknowledge them.

Stan Heath, Nevada's spectacular aerial artist, put on an amazing display last Saturday to hold his place as the No. 1 offensive performer of college football. The accurate war veteran connected with his target nine times in thirteen throws to account for 114 yards as Nevada trimmed North Texas by 48 -- 7.

THE world series of 1948 is completed and undoubtedly will slide unobtrusively into history as one of the less memorable of the classics. Only in the statistics department will it take on stature with record one-game attendance and receipts as well as a record winning players' share. The sum of $6,544.76, which will go to each member of the Cleveland Indians, makes them the richest group of .199 hitters that baseball ever has produced.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Port of New York Authority today urged that the entire rate scale for domestic all-rail, ocean-rail, and rail-ocean-rail class freight be revised immediately to restore relationships that have been disrupted by various rate increases since 1938.

The two outsiders in the betting, Deering Howe's Donor and Ben F. Whitaker's Carolyn A., went under the wire as a team in the $29,550 Questionnaire Handicap at Jamaica yesterday, with Donor getting the photo decision and his backers in the Columbus Day crowd of 29,677 getting $42.30, $16.80 and $10.80 for each $2 across the board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -The United States Court of Appeals today upheld the conviction of Eugene Dennis, secretary of the American Communist party, for contempt of Congress. The court, at the same time, dismissed his attack on the legality of the House Un-American Activities Committee as "sheer nonsense."
If little girls could be convinced that honest-to-goodness household equipment is as much fun to operate as toy models, a mother's lot would be a happy one.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 12 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey gave the world a new version of important current history today when he asserted (1) that he had "founded" the nonpartisan American foreign policy and (2) that the European Recovery Program had been "just another foreign relief handout" until the Republicans fixed it up.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 12 -- Western observers studying the reports of the United Nations' debate feel that a grave error has been committed by certain Western representatives in attempting to exploit, even in a timid manner, the rift between the Yugoslav Communist party and the Communist Information Bureau.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The meeting of the Commonwealth Prime Ministers passed today from economics to their most vital subject -- international affairs. Foreign Secretary Bevin, accompanied by most of the top members of the British Cabinet, spoke to the representatives from the eight visiting member states for more than an hour.

Columbia's football Lions were high-spirited and confident as they roared through a full scrimmage yesterday, but Coach Lou Little voiced a different note. The Light Blue mentor is in the difficult situation of not knowing where his next punt or extra point is coming from.

LA RABIDA, Spain, Oct. 12 -Generalissimo Francisco Franco, standing in the shadow of Larabida monastery where Columbus lived and planned his first American voyage, reasserted today Spain's claim to have discovered America.

BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- The Soviet Military Administration rejected specifically today any idea that the blockade of Berlin would be lifted without the elimination of the Western mark from Berlin and the subsequent acceptance by the Western powers of currency printed in the Soviet zone.
Charges that the Civil Aeronautics Board was impeding the Berlin airlift and the future of air defense generally were made yesterday by Raymond A. Norden, president of Seaboard Western Airlines.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- A graphic story of starvation, disease, nakedness and misery was told today in a pamphlet issued by the Arab Office in London in an attempt to call attention to the "appalling human disaster" of the Palestine Arab refugees."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -A deal for the distribution of "Shadow of Time," the projected Al Rogell-Manning Post production, by the Selznick releasing organization, is in negotiation, it was learned today, and will be concluded if a suitable cast can be found for the film by the producers or by Selznick.

Columbus Day business in local retail establishments yesterday was estimated as substantially over last year's and sales were termed "very satisfactory" by executives of leading department and specialty stores throughout the city.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Business should start planning now to find "the customers for tomorrow's goods and services," it was urged here today by Thomas D'A. Brophy, chairman of the board of directors, American Association of Advertising Agencies, at the annual meeting of the association's Pacific Council.

" Set My People Free," the Theatre Guild's initial production of the season, is on its way into the Hudson, where it will open Nov. 3. Billed as associate producer is Allyn Rice, who was instrumental in persuading the Guild's brain trust to reverse a previous decision against doing the play.

The fundamental international fact of today is that the world's potentially strongest nation, the Soviet Union, cannot be expected, for an indefinite period, to honor agreements and treaties which it may make. It will be recalled that the State Department, in a report to the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations last May, outlined no fewer than thirty-seven matters in which the Russians had broken their word.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Commanding officers were named today for the newly created Army and Air Force divisions of the National Guard Bureau.

From the vigor and persistence with which he maintains his untiring attack, it is evident that Mr. Truman believes his best issue in the campaign is the record of the Eightieth Congress. No major speech fails to dwell upon this theme. No audience fails to be reminded of the President's strong conviction that the Eightieth was the "worst" Congress in the nation's history.

DENVER, Oct. 12 -- United States District Judge J. Foster Symes today sentenced Arthur Bary, self-identified Communist party chairman in Colorado, to an indeterminate jail term for refusing to answer questions put to him by a Federal Grand Jury.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Jules Moch, Minister of the Interior, reiterated before the French Cabinet today his charges made to a Socialist party meeting that the Communist Information Bureau had instigated the French mine strike.

Richard A. Laux, president of the General Instrument Corporation, said yesterday that a sharp increase in shipments of television and FM components during the third quarter will probably enable the company to offset the consolidated net loss of $89,163 he reported for the six months ended on Aug. 31.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Some members of the United States delegation are urging Secretary of State Marshall to issue a statement emphasizing once again that the United States position on the Berlin crisis is unchanged by stressing also that once the Soviet blockade has been lifted a meeting of the Foreign Ministers Council can be called to examine the entire German problem.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- An employer must bargain on individual merit increases when a union requests him to do so, under a lower court decision which the Supreme Court, in effect, has upheld.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The International Red Cross is investigating the cases of several thousands of Greek children "who have been removed tO Yugoslavia," the United Nations said today. Red Cross headquarters in Geneva asked the Yugoslav Red Cross Society for information on the children, an announcement said.

The American Society of Travel Agents warned relatives and friends yesterday who wish to help displaced persons in entering the United States of a "bonus racket" in which an "expediter" offers to speed up the arrival of the individual in this country -- for a large fee.

A back-to-work movement initiated by the Union News Company had a setback yesterday when a group of employes who had returned to their jobs in Grand Central Terminal walked off to rejoin the strike of Local 906, News Distribution Employes Union, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -Roughly 80 per cent of the banking business involved in the European Recovery Program is being handled by New York banks, the Economic Cooperation Administration reported today. It said numerous complaints have been received from banks in every other section of the country.
The National Hockey League opens its 1948-49 season tonight with the dark horse Chicago Black Hawks clashing with the highly regarded Red Wings in Detroit.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, said today in a Columbus Day speech addressed to Italian-Americans that "the men of Wall Street and the military" who "control" both major parties "are making an American colony out of Italy."

New light is thrown on the remarkable extent to which our economy is a "rolling" economy by the latest issue of Automobile Facts and Figures, made public by the Automobile Manufacturers Association. It shows, for example, that 90 per cent of all cities and towns having local passenger transportation systems are now served by buses only.

BUTTE, Mont., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren declared tonight that under a Republican Administration the development of the West "will no longer be subordinated to political propaganda." He put his party on record for a Secretary of the Interior from one of the Far Western states.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 12 -Profit margins on the majority of drug store products are too small to carry the overhead costs of retail druggists today, John P. Tripeny, of Casper, Wyo., president of the National Association of Retail Druggists, declared tonight.

BOONTON, N.J., Oct. 12 (UP) -Judge Gerald R. Fowler tonight had under advisement the case of five-year-old Thomas Marotta, perhaps one of the youngest persons in history ever to be charged with driving an automobile without a license.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 12 -- The completed draft for the preamble of the new Western German constitution was released here this afternoon by the Committee for Fundamental Questions, which formulated it with two possible alterations it is effected to be approved by the main committee and later the plenary session of the Parliamentary Council.
America's leading educators and delegates from ancient universities abroad came to Columbia University yesterday to pay homage to its new president, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- John Santo, Rumanian-born organizer for the Transport Workers Union, CIO, was ordered deported today by Immigration Commissioner Watson B. Miller.

Meet the new manager of the Yankees: Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel, one-time hard hitting outfielder, manager of both major and minor league clubs, sage, wit and gifted raconteur as glib with the wisecrack as the late Jimmy Walker.

Pleas for serious self-examination and a vigorous positive attitude toward the eradication of hate and selfishness in mankind were made last night as Jews throughout the world began at sundown the observance of Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement and most sacred day in the Jewish religious calendar.

United States civilians and the police will be trained to combat the hazards of atomic warfare, Lieut. Col. Barnet W. Beers of the Department of Defense, said yesterday at the annual conference of the International Association of Chiefs of Police at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
NANKING, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Government announced today its second major victory in Manchuria in two days -- the capture of the Communist field base of Changwu, sixty miles northwest of Mukden.

A woman's seventeen years of effort to bring about the return of her husband caught in Poland by passport difficulties, ended in success at 5:25 A.M. yesterday when Adolf Balaban, 55 years old, stepped from a Pan American World Airways airplane at La Guardia Field.
An ingenious plan by which aliens were smuggled into this country with regularly issued but fraudulently obtained South Carolina birth certificates was reported yesterday by immigration authorities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Jess Larson, director of the War Assets Administration, recommended today that the Republic Steel Corporation make the production of its Gadsden (Ala.) blast furnace available to the foundry customers who, Republic contends, will be deprived of pig iron by the leasing of the Government-owned Cleveland blast furnace to the Kaiser-Fraser Corporation.

Introduction in Brazil's Chamber of Deputies of a bill providing heavy penalties for publication of false or malicious news items has an ominous ring. Because Brazil has had no libel law -- a fact of which certain newspapers have taken advantage -- some legal restraints may have been called for.

The United States Supreme Court has refused to review a lower court's decision that under the National Labor Relations (Wagner) Act an employer having a contract with a union must not grant pay increases for merit without bargaining first with the union having jurisdiction over the benefited employes.
Forty-five thousand persons of various religious beliefs and racial backgrounds marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in a spirit of unity to pay homage to the memory of Christopher Columbus.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 12 (AP) -Jews and Moslems celebrated holy festivals with guns in hand in this religious center tonight.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 12 -The Rev. Jonathan G. Sherman, rector of St. Thomas Church, Bellerose, Queens, was elected Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island today at a reconvening of the diocesan convention in the Cathedral of the Incarnation here.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of the address by Gov Thomas E. Dewey here today:
MEDFORD, Wis., Oct. 12 (UP) -Norman Thomas, Socialist Presidential candidate, said today he was "suspicious" of the motives of Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party nominee.

Formally installed as the thirteenth president of Columbia University yesterday afternoon, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower dedicated himself to the service of America and humanity. He pledged his administration at Columbia to support the basic concept of human freedom against the threat of the police state and internal doubts and fears regarding the future of democracy.
Four prints and a larger group of medium weight woven fabrics that can double for either draperies or upholstery comprise the fall collection presented yesterday by Brunschwig and Fils.

The American National Theatre and Academy will produce a weekly half-hour variety show this season under the sponsorship of the United States Army and the United States Air Force Recruiting Service, it was announced yesterday. The premiere is set for Armistice Day, Nov. 11, at 7:30 P.M., over a 240-station network of the American Broadcasting Company, which will donate the air time for the series.

Fifty-eight per cent of purchases authorized to be made in the United States by the Economic Cooperation Administration have been through private exporters, the National Foreign Trade Council declared yesterday in an analysis of ECA operations through Sept. 15.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 12 (AP) -- In a bitter stretch duel Honeymoon carried the W-L Ranch silks of H. M. Warner to a nose victory in the eighth running of the Queen Isabella Handicap at Laurel Park today.

The taxpayer property at the southwest corner of Linden Boulevard and 222d Street, Cambria Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Nathan Bernstein from the Dickel Construction Company for $85,000. The Cambria Heights Postoffice is among the tenants of the building, which is on a plot 100 by 115 feet.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 (AP) -Belief that the high cost of living is caused by a "fundamental weakness in the American enterprise system" is the greatest internal danger now facing this country, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers said today.
Despite dollar shortages abroad, foreign buyers who attended the Third National Hardware Show yesterday at Grand Central Palace told exhibitors they can find dollars to pay for their orders.
S. L. Nevins, formerly with the Southern Acid and Sulpher Company, has joined Mathieson Chemical Corporation as general manager of the company's newly formed ammonia department.
ROME, Oct. 12 -- Communist Leader Palmiro Togliatti again conjured up the specter of revolt today in his first speech in the Chamber of Deputies since the attempt on his life last July 14.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -The copper industry today rejected a Government suggestion for a formal agreement to set aside supplies for the nation's strategic materials stockpile.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 12 -- John L. Lewis, who opened the convention of the United Mine Workers with an attack on President Truman, closed it today with an attack on Governor Dewey. Mr. Lewis' ire against the Republican Presidential candidate was stirred by Mr. Dewey's defense of the Taft-Hartley Act in his speech at Pittsburgh last night.

Jonai, Inc., of 408 Park Avenue, presented a group of winter fashions yesterday during luncheon at the Ritz Carlton Hotel. The collection included some custom originals, distinguished for their fine details, as well as ready-to-wear suits, dresses and evening gowns.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 12 -Sails on the sizable summer racing craft were unbent and bagged today after the curtain event of the year, the "lay up" regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's labor advisers believe that some changes in the Taft-Hartley Act should be pressed if the Republican candidate is elected President, it was learned today.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 12 (AP) -The Nebraska Supreme Court ruled today that the name of Henry A. Wallace cannot appear on next month's general election ballot in the state.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Again attacking racial segregation laws in the United States, the Soviet Union told the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly here today that the practice of separating Negroes and whites in railway cars would be punished in Russia as a "crime."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12 -Harvard's head football coach, Arthur Valpey, said before a twohour contact session at Soldier Field today that Saturday's defeat by Cornell was not traceable to any one person nor to any specific section of the team and consequently planned no changes in the line-up of the first team.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- With costs of farming rising and prices of farm products falling, farm incomes are likely to be lower for the country as a whole in 1949 than they have been in 1948, the Department of Agriculture predicted today.

The Merchant Marine Veterans of America, Inc., issued an appeal yesterday to the members of all Selective Service boards, to defer from the draft all wartime seamen who have received the Certificate of Substantially Continuous Service.
South Court at Columbia University took on the rich color of some medieval quadrangle yesterday during the formal installation of Dwight D. Eisenhower as thirtieth president of Columbia University.

BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- "Operation Backtalk," the United States attempt to answer Soviet propaganda in Germany, may deteriorate to a whispering campaign because of the lack of sufficient funds, officials said today.
The windows of New York buildings, which had become increasingly opaque during the last twelve days, will gleam again tomorrow.

A Harlem industrial training program of the Y.W.C.A., which reaches 500 persons of all ages and both sexes, has stimulated better race relations in the district, officials of the Harlem Y.W.C.A. Trade School, 179 West 137th Street, declared yesterday.

The conversion of four former Navy transports to passenger liners for the Turkish Government has been started by the Todd Shipyards Corporation. John D. Reilly, president of Todd, in making the announcement yesterday, declared that this was one of the largest individual contracts obtained by his concern since the war.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Editors of liberal newspapers in eleven countries met here today for a two-day conference to consider the role of liberalism in a democratic world and the functions of the liberal press in defending and promoting it.

Several hundred alumni of St. John's University, Brooklyn, attending the sixty-eighth annual meeting of the alumni association at 75 Lewis Avenue in that borough, were told yesterday that the Communist party advocated the violent overthrow of any legitimate government, rejected "all individual, family and church rights" and was an "immoral party."
Within the "very near future" the National Security Resources Board will be prepared with an emergency economic mobilization plan, R. E. Gillmor, vice chairman of the board, said last night.
A cone-shaped crown with a small brim was selected by Keneth Hopkins of Beverly Hills as his prophetic silhouette in a showing yesterday at the Pierre Hotel by Gunther.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 12 -- The Indonesian Information Service said today Bobby Freeberg of Pittsburg, Kan., Indonesia's "one-man air force," was being held in a Dutch jail in Batavia.

Administration and anti-Administration forces hurled a barrage of diatribes at the private electric utility industry last week, but the climax to the issue over the nation's power supply is expected today, when the industry will release a counter-attack in a denial that a shortage of power exists.

A crowd of 200 neighbors, many of the women sobbing and showing other signs of strain, gathered near a dwelling at 161-30 Grand Central Parkway, Jamaica, Queens, shortly after 7:15 o'clock last night, when a high-pressure gas leak caused fear of an explosion similar to that which killed two policemen in a nearby house on Nov. 25, 1946.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 12 -- Responsibility for the Korean railroad wreck on Sept. 14 that resulted in the death of thirty-six United States soldiers has been fixed by a board of American officers on violation of three railroad operating rules by Korean Railroad employes, according to a statement issued today by Maj. Gen. John B. Coulter, commander of the United States forces in Korea.
TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 12 -Louis Rich is 85 years old, but because he wants to "stay young and keep up with the world" he enrolled today in Bergen Junior College here.

THEIR names were Vladimir Ulyanov, Lev Davidovich Bronstein and Iosif (or Yosif or Joseph) Vissarionvich Djugashvili. Their deeds were great; but their names are not known to the world, for all three were professional revolutionists who used many aliases. Each of them is known by his favorite alias, the name he used most often and continued to use after he achieved power and world-wide fame, Lenin, Trotsky and Stalin.
PARIS, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Following is the text of the speech by Warren R. Austin, United States delegate, in the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Paint brushes made from milk and a new kind of experimental candy that fortifies the consumer with vitamins and proteins, as well as satisfying his sweet tooth, were among $2,000,000 worth of exhibits placed on display at the fifth annual chemical exposition which opened today in the Coliseum.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 12 -Finland can take no part in Nordic discussions on mutual defense or politics generally, but wants to maintain and expand her present economic and cultural relations with other Scandinavian nations, Karl August Fagerholm, Finnish Premier, said in an interview today.
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The United States served notice today that it would not disarm as long as "aggressive war" was recognized by Soviet leaders as a means of achieving a world Communist society.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- By an 8-to-2 vote a United Nations Assembly subcommittee today overrode Soviet objections and approved a plan to transfer the atomic negotiations from the suspended Atomic Energy Commission to private talks among the Big Five and Canada.

PARIS Oct. 12 (AP) -- Excerpts from Soviet Delegate Andrei Y. Vishinsky's speech today in the Political Committee of the United Nations Assembly as officially Nations Assembly follows, as officially translated from Russian:

TOKYO, Oct. 12 -- The Diet's Illegal Property Transactions Committee, which brought about the downfall of Dr. Hitoshi Ashida's coalition Cabinet by bringing corruption charges against two Ministers, now is digging into the affairs of Shigeru Yoshida -- most likely candidate for Premier -- according to several indications today.

Many of us, whether we're aware of it or not, use ready-to-eat cereals other than as a breakfast food quite often. Muffins made with bran flakes are the first thing that comes to mind. Corn flakes and other cereals sometimes double for bread crumbs in meat loaves or as a casserole topping.

Officials of the New York public school system are studying a plan to reorganize the teaching of modern languages to include a six-year course culminating in a specialized high school of modern languages, it was announced yesterday.
A 6-year-old boy decided to demonstrate for four 7-year-old girls yesterday how a man hangs himself. He almost succeeded.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- After his arrival here today, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, discussed German reparations with Foreign Minister Robert Schuman and then departed for London, where he was to discuss the same subject tomorrow with Foreign Secretary Bevin.

Taking advantage of the school holiday at Fordham, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday conducted a three-hour contact scrimmage as the Rams continued preparations for Saturday's encounter with St. Francis at Johnstown, Pa.

A large-space campaign for General Electric automatic blankets was started today in New York newspapers. A simultaneous campaign is scheduled also for New Jersey newspapers. The drive is said to be the first full-scale metropolitan promotion for automatic electric blankets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Spokesmen for the leading newspapers of the United States today requested the Federal Communications Commission to facilitate public information by allocating specific wave lengths for use in maintaining local radio telephone contact with reporters and photographers.

The New York waterfowl season will open this Friday at noon, and reports from most of the better known duck guides out on Long Island indicate that they are booked solidly throughout the first split season.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- British Government bonds led the way in a firm stock market here today -- the last day of the account.
The Veterans Administration is preparing to pay millions of veterans of World War II a dividend payment on their National Service Life Insurance within the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The importance of solidarity and peace in the Americas during the present troubled world conditions was stressed today at ceremonies for the laying of the cornerstone of the Pan American Union Administration Building at Eighteenth Street and Constitution Avenue, Northwest, a block from the main Pan American Union Building.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 12 -- (AP) -- The entire Green Bay Packer squad was fined one-half of one game's salary today by Coach E. L. (Curly) Lambeau for the poor showing against the Chicago Cardinals in a National Football League game last Sunday.

Six drama groups, representing leading colleges of this city and acting through the Metropolitan Association of College Theatres, have joined with the Mayor's Committee for the commemoration of New York's Golden Anniversary to sponsor a series of period plays of this city as a collegiate salute.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- In accordance with plans announced yesterday, the nation's railroads today filed an amended petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission in which they ask that freight rates, with a few exceptions, be increased by 13 per cent, instead of by the 8 per cent asked in their petition of Oct. 1.

Going behind present Soviet maneuvers before the United Nations. Warren R. Austin, the American delegate, got down to the fundamentals of the problem yesterday when he called upon the Soviet Government to repudiate its propaganda espousing aggressive war as a means of Communist world conquest and to give some convincing evidence of its willingness to live with the rest of the world in peace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- American corporations registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission have reported sales amounting to $27,608,519,000 in the second quarter of 1948, compared with $27,204,732,000 in the first quarter, the commission announced today in its quarterly survey of American listed corporations.

Our city scout, it seems, has been absent for a longer time than often happens with him from the urban scene to which he is so firmly attached -- deprived, as he puts it, of that freedom of the city which he cherishes no less though no formal ceremony has conferred it upon him.

M. D. Clark of Woodbury, Conn., captured the 100-target 16-yard event following a shoot-off in the one-day invitation trapshooting competition conducted at Travers Island of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The event, opener of the Winged Foot club's trapshooting season, attracted 100 contestants.

" Night Has a Thousand Eyes," which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Paramount melodrama featuring Edward G. Robinson, Gail Russell, John Lund and Virginia Bruce, was directed by John Farrow and produced by Endre Boehm from a screen play by Barre Lyndon and Jonathan Latimer, and a novel by Cornell Woolrich.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday, according to The Associated Press, that the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company had bought 1,700 additional shares of common stock in the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company (Nickel Plate).

As a result of a controversy over a teacher transferred for allegedly displaying pro-Soviet bias in his classes, Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, principal of the Samuel J. Tilden High School, Brooklyn, yesterday accused the Teachers Union, CIO, of following "the Lenin line" and developing "lying to a fine art."

A three-story factory building on a plot 75 by 111 feet and two adjoining tenement houses occupying a plot 50 by 106 feet at 328 to 336 East Seventy-fifth Street, between First and Second Avenues, were sold by the 330 East Seventy-fifth Street Corporation to Philip Goldfein, who leased the property for twenty-one years to the Rockwell Baking Corporation, supplier of restaurants and stores since 1880, for its plant and executive offices.

The representatives of American and foreign universities and learned societies who heard General Eisenhower state his creed for education at the ceremonies yesterday installing him as the thirteenth president of Columbia University must know that the traditions of that great university are in safe hands and that in her new President Columbia has a valiant champion of the academic freedom that determines, in the final analysis, the stature of an institution of learning.

My experience recently in waiting in the rain almost twenty-five minutes for a Broadway bus is something that has by no means been unusual in the past few weeks, when so many, while waiting, were given plenty of time to wonder why they called the changeover from trolleys to buses "progress."

The Manhattan College basketball team will play twenty-six games during the 1948-49 season, it was announced by Brother Eusebius, director of athletics. The schedule opens Nov. 20 with the traditional Alumni game, and closes on March 3 against City College.

VIENNA, Oct. 13 -- Josef Garzuly, charge d'affaires in the Hungarian Legation in Vienna, together with his secretary and a member of the consular section, have broken with the present Hungarian Government and fled the legation.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet tomorrow to discuss several reports submitted by Secretary General Trygve Lie on the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, Mediator for Palestine, and alleged truce violations in Palestine.

The Republican National, Senatorial and Congressional Committees are still $1,500,000 short of the $4,000,000 they are permitted by law to spend, Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican National Chairman, declared here yesterday. He added that Republicans throughout the nation must be aroused from complacency and lethargy and contribute immediately to the party funds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Eleven local housing authorities awarded $26,560,000 in short-term loan notes in competitive bidding today, the Public Housing Administration announced. The successful bids were at interest rates ranging from 1.15 to 1.22 per cent.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Lord Allendale's Woodburn, 100-9 second choice, won the two and one-quarter mile Cesare-witch Stakes today by a neck in a bulky field of 32.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Asserting that the Federal Trade Commission was trying to destroy the basing-point pricing system, counsel for eight of the country's largest corn-products manufacturers asked the FTC today to drop a complaint against the companies and eight subsidiaries charging conspiracy to "fix and maintain prices."
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Richard R. Deupree was elected today chairman of the board of directors of the Procter Gamble Company. Neil H. McElroy succeeded him as president.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- After two meetings with Foreign Secretary Bevin, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, left London for Washington tonight without giving any sign that he had succeeded in overcoming British opposition to the suspension of the dismantlling of German industrial plants.
The return to duty of one regular in the Fordham backfield was offset by the loss of another back yesterday as the Rams engaged in a long dummy scrimmage.

BAYONNE, N. J., Oct. 13 -- The problems of economic mobilization in case of war require "close and realistic" liaison between the armed forces and the petroleum industry. This was emphasized today by R. T. Goodwin, manager of the aviation department of the Shell Oil Company, in a talk on the economic potential of his industry before Army, Navy and Air Force Officers attending an economic mobilization course at the Navy Supply Corps School.

Safety education is a fundamental element in the New York public school program, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, told members of the Greater New York Safety Council at a meeting in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.
Charles W. Wood has been appointed divisional merchandise manager of the home furnishings division of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, effective Nov. 1.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower lost his avowed amateur status last night when a painting he had executed for the Urban League brought $2,600 at auction. One of a hundred by celebrities to be brought under the hammer at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, the General's picture took the honors by bringing by far the highest price of the evening.

TODAY is Dwight D. Eisenhower's birthday. It will probably be spent by the new president of Columbia under slightly more tranquil circumstances than it was usually spent in recent years by the soldier Kay Summersby sketches so well in her new book, "Eisenhower Was My Boss."* It is the best book about him we have had since that broadcasting mariner Harry Butcher published "My Three Years With Eisenhower."

Columbia's Lions gave the appearance of biting at their leashes as Coach Lou Little permitted only a light contact workout at Baker Field yesterday. The Light Blue went through spirited defensive and offensive drills with no tackling allowed as the game with Penn looms two days away.

In THE TIMES of Sept. 30 I noticed a letter entitled "Hospitals as Memorials." In this connection your readers may be interested in a memorial which we received recently and which, I believe, can serve as a model for other similar gifts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that Federal marketing quotas are possible for the 1950 cotton crop
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Advertising Council, Inc., began today an all-media national advertising campaign to promote a better understanding of the American economic system.

WITH DEWEY TRAIN IN OKLAHOMA, Oct. 13 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey journeyed today through the dust bowl country of Oklahoma and promised that the Republicans would adopt "a comprehensive conservation program" to increase the security and standard of living of the nation.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Federal Judge Charles G. Briggle said today he would grant a temporary injunction restraining the Illinois Power Company from restoring a 50 per cent cutback imposed last month on deliveries of natural gas to fifteen industrial customers in Decatur, Danville and campaign.

In the course of reviewing a book the other day, on the page preceding this one, Charles Poore observed that the time of year is approaching "when nature essayists put fresh sheet of birch bark in their typewriters, head it 'Nut-Brown October,' and go to work on the pungent smell of burning leaves."

A revival of demand for pivotal issues enabled the stock market to forge ahead yesterday for the best rally since Sept. 1. The list received its spark for the day early in the trading when the steels spurted and later was buoyed by a flurry of advances as the session developed. Closing prices were up fractions to 2 points, and the composite index rose a point.

The American Merchant Marine Conference opened a three-day meeting yesterday morning on a new note, with speakers placing particular emphasis upon the necessity for a modern, balanced merchant fleet as a defense measure.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A House committee said today that gray marketeers exploiting the steel shortage are repaying "fantastic profits" running into millions of dollars.
BERLIN, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Russias have proposed that fifteen nations having military missions in Berlin close them and withdraw from the city, the official Soviet press disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Union shop election machinery in the building and construction industry has bogged down, Government sources said today.

After an absence of six seasons from the local concert stage, Margaret Speaks, soprano, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. Widely known through her appearances in radio, the musicianly artist attracted a large and enthusiastic gathering for the unhackneyed program of worthwhile offerings presented, which she sang with accuracy and poise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Federal Reserve Board said today in an answer to a show-cause order filed in the Federal District Court here that its anti-trust complaint against the Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco met all legal requirements.

The advertising trade was urged yesterday to "do its part" in translating the objectives of business management into understandable terms. The plea was made by Leo Burnett, who heads the advertising agency bearing his name, at the annual meeting of the 4-A's Central Council in Chicago.

MR. CHARLES DILLON STENGEL, an amiable whack who also is a mighty sound and shrewd baseball manager, will bring his well-advertised sense of humor into the Yankee Stadium for the next two years. He undoubtedly will need it since the Sword of Damocles now seems to be a permanent part of the Stadium equipment.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of the address by Governor Dewey, made here today:

FREMONT, Ohio, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The American Lutheran Church announced today that it was receptive to merger negotiations with four of the six other major Lutheran churches in the country. Dr. E. C. Fendt, dean of the Capital University Seminary, called the action "the strongest, most aggressive step on unity to come from any Lutheran group."
Lack of Government direction on the nation's packaging needs in the event of war was called yesterday a primary concern of producers and users of packaging materials.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today reluctantly upheld the Government's sale of a Granite City, Ill., surplus steel plant to a Koppers Coke Company subsidiary. It said the deal had a "most offensive odor of skullduggery."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The present international "tension" may already have shown that President Truman's limit of $15,000,000,000 for a defense budget in the 1950 fiscal year is too low to maintain national security, it was learned today.

The election of Lee Thompson Smith, president of the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York, as the twenty-sixth president of the Real Estate Board of New York was announced yesterday following the annual meeting of the board of governors.
BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- The last vestige of a complete city government moved today to the Western sectors of Berlin, when the City Council moved its quarters from the Soviet sector.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved over a narrow range and Closed 6 points higher to 10 points lower.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 13 -- The sixth and newest W. J. Sloane store was opened here today at the Ridgeway Shopping Center, with several thousand in attendance at a housewarming.

A dinner to honor Judge Florence E. Allen of the United States Court of Appeals will mark the climax of a campaign to raise $25,000 for a room in her name at the new law center of New York University to be erected at Washington Square South, it was announced yesterday.

The madrilene that shimmered so coolly on a sizzling August day fails to pique appetites in October. Chilly cups of jellied consomme give way, with the change in seasons, to tureens of soup fairly steaming with substance and flavor.

PEIPING, China, Oct. 13 -- Fighting was visible from the air today on three sides of Chinhsien's city wall, according to pilots returning from bombing missions over the West Liaoning battlefront. Government forces withdrew yesterday from mountain positions south of the city and are fighting a mile and a half below the city wall, these sources said.

In transactions involving three Manhattan properties assessed for a total of $2,670,000, Louis Schleifer, realty operator and active trader in hotels, has purchased a Fifth Avenue corner on the rim of the Greenwich Village area and has sold a business building on Madison Avenue and apartment hotel on the upper West Side, it was learned yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, hero of Corregidor, will be among those who will take part this afternoon in a twofold memorial tree-planting ceremony at City Hall, the Park Association of the City of New York announced yesterday.

Apparel sales by Lord Taylor on Columbus Day were greater than any other fall event in the store's history, it was reported yesterday. Women's coats led with substantial increases over Columbus Day last year, with women's suits and dresses following in that order.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 13 -- The Korean Government has installed a cordon of police across the peninsula three miles south of the 38th Parallel to reduce smuggling from North Korea, President Syngman Rhee said today.

Empire City's racing show at Jamaica had for its main act yesterday a sprint for 3-year-olds called the Garrison. No Garrison finish was required of Ted Atkinson to get Isidor Bieber's Up Beat, the favorite, under the wire a couple of lengths in advance of his most persistent pursuer in the field of ten.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

It is not by accident that the campaign itineraries of both President Truman and Governor Dewey have been also planned as to cover most of the states which will choose Senators next month. Control of the Senate, as well as of the Presidency, is at stake in the November elections.
PARIS, Oct, 13 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speech by Sir Hartley Shawcross of Britain to the United Nation General Assembly's Political Committee today:

The Israel national soccer players will be made honorary citizens of Brooklyn by Borough President John Cashmore, when the team receives an official welcome from Brooklyn fans at noon tomorrow at the Borough Hall, it was announced yesterday.

We continue, with a detailed inspection of the record, our discussion of the candidacy of Vito Marcantonio for a seventh term as member of the House of Representatives from the Eighteenth Congressional District.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Republican principles are "far more in accord" with the views of the South than "the planned economy and totalitarian regulation of the Truman New Deal," Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey's claim in Louisville yesterday that he was the founder of the bipartisan foreign policy was challenged today by Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic national chairman, who reported that Republicans should "limit themselves to the facts for the sake of national unity."
ROME, Oct. 13 -- Government employes will stage a strike throughout Italy tomorrow to protest against the regime's refusal to increase their salaries or grant them a $9 advance on future pay rises.
