WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Department of Agriculture today predicted continuing improvements for rural family living due to increased incomes of recent years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court today agreed to rule whether Henry A. Wallace's Progressive party should have a place on the Illinois election ballot. The court ordered a special hearing on the case for next Monday.

Residents of New York are daily impressed with the traffic congestion in an around our city. Officials, including Mayor O'Dwyer, and the Police Department have conducted studies, made plans, appointed commissions, imposed parking restrictions, published articles and given tickets, yet the traffic problem becomes more serious as time goes on.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 13 -- It's a long way back to the first intercollegiate football game between Princeton and Rutgers in 1869, and the students here would like to see a precedent broken in this historic series when the Scarlet plays the Tigers in Palmer Stadium Saturday.
The Economic Cooperation Administration has banned the use of cargo broker pools in the transport overseas of aid cargo, it was announced last night.

Finishing touches are being put on the new $370,000 kitchen installation at the Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn, visitors to the institution learned yesterday. The kitchen is said to be the most modern of its kind in the city.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- America's anti-trust laws have failed to prevent the continuing expansion of great industrial and commercial corporations to the point where they threaten domination over the economic life of the nation, John W. Dargavel, of Chicago, executive secretary of the National Association of Retail Druggists, charged today.

The first Pacific Coast trip by a New York college team features the thirty-one game basketball schedule announced for Long Island University yesterday by Coach Clair Bee. It will be the hardest slate in the school's history, as well as its biggest in number of games.

PLAINVIEW, L. I., Oct. 13 -- Plans for the newest educational and research center on Long Island, located during the war in Mineola as a unit of Columbia University, were submitted yesterday to the Oyster Bay Zoning Board of Appeals by H. R. Skifter, president of Airborne Instruments Laboratory, Inc.

In order to have Spec Sanders in top condition for the Football Yankees' contest with the high-scoring, undefeated San Francisco Forty-niners at the stadium on Sunday, Coach Norman (Red) Strader revealed yesterday that the star halfback had received a three-day layoff from practice.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Advance planning on a global scale to enable the world to cope with business recessions was urged by Dr. C. L. Patijn before the Economic Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today.
Seattle, Wash., announced yesterday that it will receive bids Monday on $6,000,000 of light and power revenue bonds dated Oct. 1, 1948, due Oct. 1, 1953 to 1973, and callable Oct. 1, 1958.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today received its first case testing constitutionality of the portal-to-portal act.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The National Association of Letter Carriers today nominated all but one of its officers for reelection without opposition and selected Seattle, Wash., as the site of the biennial convention in 1950.

A grave responsibility rests on the shoulders of the Premiers of the British Dominions, now in session in London. The meeting is a turning point in the history of the Commonwealth, for not only have the member states become more independent in the eventful years since the last conference, in 1937, but as a result of the war they have developed a different relationship to one another and to the rest of the world.
Douglas L. Elliman, president of Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc., will address the luncheon meeting of the Young Men's Real Estate Association of New York today at 10 Park Avenue.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 13 -- Hitting the ball with vigor and vim, Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of the home club won low gross honors in the next to the last Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament with a three-over-par 38, 39-77 at Piping Rock today.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- Count Carlo Sforza, Foreign Minister, revealed today a plan that he has elaborated and submitted to the French Government for using the Organization for European Economic Cooperation as a motive force to bring about a federation of European states.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Little if any decline in retail food prices is in sight for the next few months, Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, said today.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Reports that the United States was competing with the Soviet Union to purchase a large proportion of Ceylon's current rubber crop were substantially confirmed today by Ceylonese officials.

Fifteen thousand employes of the Westen Electric Company will have today a five-way choice of union representation or lack of representation in an election regarded as unusual in the affairs of the National Labor Relations Board.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Britain's exports in the first half of 1948 exceeded the estimate of the Government's economic survey by 26,000,000 (about $104,000,000), it was disclosed today. The figures were announced by A. G. Bottomley, Secretary for Overseas Trade.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- C. B. Baldwin, campaign director of the Progressive party, today chided President Truman on his civil rights performance, saying that the chief executive could end by a stroke of the pen economic discrimination he said prevailed in the Canal Zone against Negroes.

Development of its Convair liner program was held responsible for the net loss of $7,534,419 incurred by the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation in the six months ended May 31 in a report issued yesterday by Floyd B. Odlum, chairman of the company's board.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Oct 13 -- Car price increases have had no effect on sales because of economic and expanded market conditions, C. E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, said today. The shortage of motor vehicles will continue for another two years, and further price rises will be determined by the costs of materials and labor, he added.

The Teachers Union, CIO, charged yesterday that Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, principal of the Samuel J. Tilden High School, Brooklyn, was "attempting to ferret out progressive teachers" in a controversy involving a faculty member accused of pro-Soviet bias.
The International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, rejected yesterday an employer offer submitted last week in the current dispute over wages.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 13 -- James Kutcher, 35 years old, who lost both legs five years ago when a German shell exploded near him at San Pietro, Italy, was notified officially today of his dismissal as a $42-a-week Veterans Administration clerk here.

John Wildberg announced yesterday that he has joined forces with Frank Satenstein to produce "The Golden Touch," the new musical by Bud Burtson and Allan Sheman, and that the blueprints call for January rehearsals in anticipation of a New York opening in March.
The airlines serving New York, it was learned yesterday, have reached an agreement on coordinating winter schedules here in an effort to eliminate delays when bad weather sets in.

While the temporary economic situation in Great Britain hinders it "from playing the full role" that the country desires and that the United States wishes Britain to take in a partnership between the countries, the overseas nation has reached "the high road to recovery" Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador to the United States, declared last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Grain prices were on the downgrade on the Board of Trade today. A bearish construction placed on a Department of Agriculture estimate of a record corn crop, issued late for Monday, combined with increased country offerings and favorable weather for harvesting, dominated that grain.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- As an old grad of Pennsylvania, Lou Little will be gratified to learn that the Red and Blue will be at full strength for the first time this season when it faces Columbia at Baker Field in New York on Saturday.

Crawford Clothes, one of the largest clothing manufacturing chains, announced yesterday a 20 per cent price reduction on all of its men's clothing. The price slash, effective today, was a surprise move and will continue until further notice, Joseph Levy, president, said.

AUBURN, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Representative John Taber, whose views on many subjects have been represented as being different from those of his party's Presidential nominee, indicated here today that he expected no trouble at all whe and if Thomas E. Dewey becomes President.

Holding that the world will be divided for many years by conflicting ideologies and at best will remain in an armed truce until at least the middle Fifties, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, has put forth a public education program designed to train the nation's youth both for peace and war.

The ABC network acknowledged yesterday that it was negotiating for the television rights to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's forthcoming book, "Crusade in Europe." if the negotiations are successful, the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation would prepare a series of two-reel films especially for video.

Banking syndicates competed here yesterday for the award of new issues of public utility and railroad obligations totaling $6,500,000 and for a block of $2,493,750 of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company's common stock held by the North American Company.

The publication of Bernard Shaw's "Sixteen Self-Sketches," which had been scheduled for October by Dodd, Mead, has been postponed because of printing difficulties in England. Since publication must be simultaneous on both sides of the ocean, the book goes over to spring, 1949.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Leaders of Britain's independent motion picture theatre owners decided today to stop showing films whose scenarios were written by Ben Hecht, who is known here as the "Number one Britain hater" of the United States.
Defensive football, with its accompanying cry of "hold that line," apparently has been tossed right off the nation's gridirons as the teams concentrate solely on spectacular, wide-open attacks.

A note of opulence was reflected in the collection of Paris-designed furs presented yesterday at Jaeckel's. Hems were dipped at the back with sweeping luxury. Collars were rolled high to the throat and swept down on the shoulder. Sleeves were shaped too. being softly full and tapered to the wrist, to convey this effect of richness.

Amid conflicting claims about the strength of the strike against the Union News Company, the State Mediation Board made a new attempt yesterday to bring the company together with Local 906, News Distribution Employes, CIO.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 13 -- The journalistic success of the United Nations General Assembly in Paris shows that the peace organization would gain "excellent" publicity by holding its fourth Assembly session in Latin America, Benjamin A. Cohen, assistant secretary general in charge of the department of public information, declared here today.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Oct. 13 -- A continuing increase in the number of registered Democrats and the prospect of the largest labor vote since 1936 point today to the loss of a Republican Senate seat and a possible small increase in the number of Democrats sent to the House of Representatives from West Virginia.

The French liner De Grasse, which sailed from West Forty-eighth Street at noon yesterday, was delayed briefly off her pier while company officials arranged for a late passenger to be ferried to the liner in midstream.
A one-man poetry magazine that is absolutely free is published here once a month. The poet and the publisher is Jacob Hauser, a post-office clerk.

WASHINGTOn, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The State Department disclosed today that prominent Czechoslovaks who recently had fled their Communist - dominated country, had joined forces in a "Council for Free Czechoslovakia."

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Churches of twenty-three denominations all over the nation will join on March 20 in a one-day drive to raise $10,000,000 for the relief work of church world service. Robert J. Jordan, campaign director, reported this fact today to the national council of the Protestant Episcopal Church at its quarterly meeting in Seabury House here.

Lives are saved many times a day in New York's eighty-six non-profit voluntary hospitals through the use of ligatures, lancets and laboratories. Liver, lung, ligament and leg ills are diagnosed and treated as are innumerable other ailments.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Grandview Stables' Razzmatazz and E. P. Taylor's Illuminable qualified handsomely for the $10,000 added Spalding Lowe Jenkins Handicap next week when the two juvenile colts captured divisions of the Mount Vernon Purse.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 13 -- Anyone wanting a ceremonial elephant can get one for 200 rupees [$60] from any of numerous Indian Maharajahs who have been forced to curtail their standard of living by democratization measures in the Indian Princely States.

The refusal of all except one of the major motion-picture companies here to negotiate with two CIO unions, the Screen Publicists Guild and the Screen Office and Professional Employes Guild, will be protested by the Film Division of the New York Council of Arts, Sciences and Professions at a meeting next Thursday night in the Woodstock Hotel.

Ceramics from Athens and Rhodes, modelled after the antique and other examples of the arts and crafts, that have arrived recently from Greece were yesterday put on exhibition and sale at the House of Hellas Shop of the Friends of Greece, Inc., 37 East Forty-seventh Street.

According to the reports received to date on the activities of the archers who have turned out for the first general archery season on deer and bear now open in the Adirondack area, the bow wielders are long on shooting but short on stalking.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Despite some opposition from the floor, delegates to the convention of the United Lutheran Church in America overwhelmingly approved today a 1950-51 budget of $10,051,180, largest in the denomination's history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Joseph D. Keenan, director of Labor's League for Political Education, returned today from a tour of the Middle and Far West saying that the Senate would be captured by the Democrats in the November election.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth completed their general discussions of economic affairs here today in an atmosphere of mingled resignation and satisfaction. The eight visiting member states, taking part in these two weeks discussions all want capital goods from Britain and would like to see more going to the Commonwealth and less to Western Europe.

NANKING, Oct. 13 -- Although the State Department has transferred $88,275,000 in military aid funds to the Chinese Government, since last April, a high Defense Ministry official declared today that "not a single thing" bought with these funds had yet arrived in China.

Another battle in this year's intermittent sound - truck warfare came to an end in Lower Manhattan Court yesterday when Magistrate Harry G. Andrews dismissed charges of operating such trucks without police permits against thirty defendants.
It was encouraging to read your editorial entitled "The Spanish Problem" on Oct. 7. However, I do not think that you went sufficiently deep into the heart of the matter.

Plans for a one-story taxpayer building to occupy a vacant plot in the Dyckman section of upper Manhattan were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the southeast corner of 205th Street and Tenth Avenue by a client of the Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation to the Leckay Realty Corporation.
A solemn high requiem mass was celebrated yesterday morning for Miss Mary Gray, 80 years old, who was raped and stabbed last Saturday in her home at 17 Madison Street, Brooklyn.
Directors of Best Co. yesterday voted a dividend of 50 cents a share payable to common stockholders on Nov. 15.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 13 -- Elizabeth police have sent out a four-state alarm for a young man who has been practicing larceny on United States Route 100 under the guise of being a skilled mechanic eager to make motor adjustments for women drivers.
DETROIT, Oct. 13 (AP) -- With timely scoring help from the defense, the Red Wings beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 1, tonight in the first game of the National Hockey League season.
MADISON, Fla., Oct. 13 (UP) -- Capt. Colin Kelly, whose supreme sacrifice three days after Pearl Harbor let the world know America was not cowed, came home at last today.

A triangular plot containing 17,000 square feet of land at Park and Nassau Avenues in Manhasset, L. I., has been purchased by the North Shore Building Company from Richard Slane. The parcel fronts 196 feet on the north side of Park Avenue and 173 feet on the south side of Nassau Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 -- Two meetings of the executive committee of West Coast Ship-owners and Waterfront Employers Associations and a session sandwiched in between with Allan S. Haywood, the national CIO's chief trouble shooter, temporarily raised hopes today for a "break" in the six-week-old maritime strike.

CLAREMORE, Okla., Oct. 13 -- There are two Tom Deweys on this Presidential campaign trip: the formal Dewey, who operates before the big crowds in the cities, and the "folksy" Dewey, who appears briefly on the back platform of the train in the small towns.

Several thousand Christmas gifts, gaily wrapped and labeled for boys and girls in Europe and Asia, completed the first leg of their long journey yesterday with the arrival of a truck from Delaware County, N. Y., at headquarters of the Committee on World Friendship Among Children, 214 East Twenty-first Street.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The chief interest on the first day of the account in the stock market here today was in leading gold issues. New Pioneer rose another three shillings to a new high of just over 70s and there was steady buying of Middle Witwatersrand. Other issues generally were fractionally better where changed.

Cost savings made possible by the switch to f.o.b. mill pricing of steel are being passed on to consumers by hardware manufacturers, spokesmen revealed yesterday at the National Hardware Show at Grand Central Palace.

Proceeding rapidly with the reorganization of their dugout staff, the Yankees yesterday announced that James Riley (Milkman Jim) Turner had been signed to serve as a coach under Casey Stengel, unveiled twenty-four hours earlier as the managerial successor to Bucky Harris.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Overshadowed temporarily by the Berlin crisis, the Palestine issue remains a burning subject of discussion in corridor conversations and maneuvers of United Nations diplomats. Arab delegates have been seeking quietly to arrange for Assembly support of their views in the future from Latin-American and Greco-Turkish quarters.
ST. PAUL, Oct, 18 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of President Truman's campaign address here tonight:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Senator Owen 'Brewster, Republican, of Maine, said today that Canada was "flooding" potatoes into this country and that he had protested to the State Department.

MOUNT VERNON, Ill., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican, of Indiana, House majority leader, took an indirect dig tonight at President Truman's discarded plan to send Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson on a peace mission to Moscow.

The United States collected the first dividend under the Marshall Plan yesterday. One thousand tons of high-grade rubber, needed for the stockpile of critical materials being built up by the Munitions Board, were delivered in this port to agents of the Bureau of Supply of the Treasury Department.

The Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam arrived here yesterday with 1,213 passengers, among them Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, nuclear physicist, who returned after attending a series of meetings with European atomic scientists.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A major Republican counter-attack on the issue of control of the Senate, with Texas as the main battleground in the South, appeared to be building up tonight.

MARIANNA, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Gov. Fielding L. Wright of Mississippi said tonight that President Truman, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Henry A. Wallace were committed "to enactment of unconstitutional laws which would give the Federal Government a police force and destroy our American heritage."

SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren declared tonight that President Truman had uttered "ugly" criminal accusations and had deliberately fostered class and sectional bitterness for "political advantage."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 6:

The rubber futures market closed steady on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Prices advanced 7 to 25 points in the No. 1 contract and 30 to 45 points in the standard contract. Transactions totaled 430 long tons. London cables advanced as much as 3/16d in some deliveries.

A spirited debate over whether this country should work to reverse the trend toward centralization of population and industry enlivened the closing sessions of the three-day conference of the American Society of Planning Officials at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union offered to raise the blockade of Berlin today but only with the conditions that the complaint by the Western powers be removed from the agenda of the United Nations Security Council and that the Western powers recognize the validity of the agreement reached in Moscow Aug. 30 concerning currency problems.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Evidence so far available is deemed insufficient by the United States Attorney's office here to prosecute either Alger Hiss or Whittaker Chambers on perjury charges for their conflicting testimony before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Accenting the precarious electric power supply situation throughout the nation, the Edison Electric Institute revealed yesterday that reserve generating capacity in December is expected to be 4 per cent, compared with a margin of 5 per cent in the same month last year.
Nation-wide cooperation in passing essential highway safety laws was called for yesterday by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, general chairman of the President's Highway Safety Conference.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- Audrey Totter, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer contract actress, has been named for leading roles in two forthcoming films, it was learned today. RKO has borrowed Miss Totter for the only feminine part in "The Set-Up," which started today, and Metro has scheduled her for the role of Audrey Quail, a British Wren, in "Vespers in Vienna," which will go before the cameras about Dec. 1.

The Pennsylvania Power Light Company has been authorized to issue 150,000 new shares of $100 par value preferred stock of two series, the company announced yesterday following a special meeting of stockholders.

Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley declared last night that Governor Dewey as President would transfer to Washington the efficiency that has given New York State good government and that "the Dewey record in Washington would stand out as one of the brightest chapters in our national history."

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Mildred Zaharias set a new course record on the River Crest Country Club links for the second consecutive day as she beat Miss Beverly Hanson in the Texas Women's Open tournament today, 5 and 4.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The acceptance of an accord expected to bring about the resumption of work in the steel mills of Lorraine was a major development in the French strike situation today. In this agreement the Government made wide concessions to the workers, whose committees are expected to endorse details of the settlement tomorrow.

New York has become a "pagan city," with nearly half of its population having no organized religious affiliations, the Rev. Dr. Kenneth D. Miller, president of the New York City Mission Society, declared yesterday.

Crippled by the automobile accident which hospitalized four of their front line players last Friday, the New York Rangers inaugurate their 1948-49 National Hockey League season tonight in Montreal's Forum when they skate against the Montreal Canadiens.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Charles de Gaulle's organization, the Reunion of the French People, announced today that it had received 3,247,000 answers to a fund-raising drive.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 13 -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, States' Rights Democratic Presidential nominee, asserted here today that the civil rights program would endanger the United States Constitution and "open the doors to eventual communistic control of the Republic."

An exhibition called "Modern Wallpapers" that opened yesterday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, achieves several objectives at the same time. It represents a cross-section of the current trend in wallpaper design. It shows how the papers look on a wall and how they appear in relation to antique and modern furniture and to contemporary hand-made accessories.

William H. Hastie, Governor of the Virgin Islands, declared yesterday that Negro voters would support President Truman because of his program of civil rights and would not be misled by the civil rights program of the Progressive party into voting for Henry A. Wallace.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- France tried to find the middle of the road in the disarmament controversy today by calling for gradual and balanced arms reduction under auspices of the United Nations Security Council.

Reaffirmation of the qualities of clear perception, humility and a moral sense that would enable world statesmen to strive for a durable peace was urged yesterday as Jews throughout the world observed their most sacred day, Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.

TOKYO, Oct. 13 -- Three days after the Japanese Parliament was called into session to elect a new National Government, the situation tonight was still bogged down in a welter of conflicting politics. All parties are sparring for position in the general election that will arrive shortly.

VIENNA, Oct. 13 -- A new stream of Hungarian and Czechoslovak Jewish refugees is flowing into Vienna. The great majority of the newcomers, said to total about 3,000, were formerly business men. They have not entered the Jewish refugee camps here but have settled wherever they could find quarters privately.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Officials of the United States' Economic Cooperation Administration have been greatly heartened by a prediction by the British Government that it will be able to balance its over-all account with the rest of the world in 1952.
WASHINGTON, Oct 13 (AP) -- The American Red Cross announced today that its North Atlantic Area office in New York City would be merged next spring with Eastern Area headquarters at Alexandria, Va.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- A native of Barbados, a member of the British delegation at the United Nations, submitted an eloquent defense in the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today against Slav bloc attacks on British colonial policy. He charged that the real victims of colonialism were the human cogs in Russia's bureaucratic machine.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Red Sox announced today Coach Del Baker had resigned and a few hours later Baker said at his San Antonio, Tex., home he had been dismissed. The Sox office, which turned aside all questions, added that Hazen (Kiki) Cuyler would replace Baker.

Except for occasional brief explosive comments by a few stockholders, the forty-third annual meeting of the Electric Bond and Share Company yesterday was highlighted by the announcement that the board would declare a dividend on the common stock on Nov. 18.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Depleted by injuries, the Yale football squad completed its heavy preparation for the game with Wisconsin on Saturday in a spirited two-hour drill at Anthony Thompson Field today.
Taking the larger and more enlightened view of the present world crisis and situation, your editorial "The Problem of Spain" is as remarkable for what it says as for what it leaves unsaid.

A drive to conserve water has been undertaken by the Greater New York Taxpayers Association, it announced yesterday. Estimating that 200,000,000 gallons of water were wasted daily in the city, the association said it wanted to make property owners and tenants conscious of the part each must play in conservation.
Net earnings of the Sunray Oil Corporation in the first nine months of this year were $12,057,552, and compared with $7,332,046 earned in the comparable period of 1947, it was reported yesterday.

HAIFA, Israel, Oct. 13 (AP) -- United Nations headquarters in Haifa said tonight that the situation on the southern and northern fronts of Palestine was tense but that no major clashes had been reported. It was Atonement Day, sacred Jewish holiday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 13 (UP) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, returned tonight from Ponce, Puerto Rico's second city, where he dedicated the grounds and laid the cornerstone of the new University of Santa Maria.
Fears of a violent and immensely costly reaction from present inflationary conditions, as in 1920, were discounted yesterday by Alan H. Temple, vice president of the National City Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- It is wholly within the province of the Supreme Court of the United States, as established by Chief Justice Marshall and steadily expanded, to give or withhold reasons for its actions and decisions. Conceivably the court could render a major decision without an opinion if all the justices were willing to do so, though no such arrogant assumption of its prerogative is on record.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- A drastic decline in popular support for the Socialist Unity (Communist) party throughout the Soviet zone has been the most important development in German politics during the last six months, according to United States and British political observers here.

Throughout the nation this day is being used to take stock of the contribution which oil has made to our industrial and technical progress under a free competitive system. The petroleum industry is an outstanding example of accomplishment under this enterprise economy.

SEATTLE, Oct 13 (AP) -- President Truman reiterated his criticism of the Eightieth Congress for what he called failure to provide adequate housing legislation, in a message to the National Association of Housing Officials today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Americans for Democratic Action said in a survey made public today that there was no surface evidence to show that Henry A. Wallace would poll much more than 2,000,000 votes for President.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 13 -- In an attack on Governor Dewey, President Truman warned the country tonight of the danger of entrusting America's role in world affairs to a "recent convert" to the bipartisan policy.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 -- The Carnegie Institute's annual survey, "Painting in the United States, 1948," opened this evening in the galleries of the Carnegie Institute with a reception and preview at which the prizes were announced. Beginning tomorrow the big exhibition will be opened to the public, remaining until Dec. 12.

The program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Dimitri Mitropoulos, last night at Carnegie Hall, was so superbly performed that it was regrettable the schedule was not more worthy of the effort expended on it.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Jack Onslow, new Chicago White Sox manager, said today that the lastplace team will be rebuilt for next season that "my club will have to hustle for me."

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 15 -- Shigeru Yoshida, leader of Japan's conservative Democratic Liberal party was named Premier last night in a midnight vote of the third national Diet after a week's bitter argument over the formation of a new Japanese Government.

As reported yesterday from Washington, the National Military Establishment is now making out its budget requests for presentation to the President. For the first time it is to be a consolidated budget, with the requirements of the three services -- Army, Navy and Air -- reconciled before the matter is sent to the White House, and thence to Congress.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Eye specialists from all over the country were told today that they too often prescribe glasses for children who need merely encouragement in learning to read or treatment to correct bad reading habits.

The days of the Women's Army Corps during the war, when quantity, rather than quality was the aim, are over, Col. Mary A. Hallaren, director of the WAC, declared yesterday. On her first visit to this area to see how the Wac recruitment drive is progressing, she visited the office of Col. Francis Bacon, Military Personnel Procurement Officer for the First Army, at 39 Whitehall Street.

The Port of New York Authority awarded a contract yesterday for construction of the New Jersey Truck Terminal Building in Newark to the James J. Waters Corporation of 415 Lexington Avenue. The work was expected to start soon on what is scheduled to be the largest motor truck terminal in the world.

A designer of great ingenuity, with a flair for the dramatic, is Julio Laffitte, who created the custom order fur collection presented yesterday at Saks Fifth Avenue. One remembers his saucy Pagliacci jackets, hip length and swinging with almost circular fullness from softened shoulders, his feeling for capes, both large and small, that well reflected his Spanish heritage.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 14 -Robert E. Woodruff, president of the Erie Railroad, warned against nationalization of industry here tonight as officials of the road and the triple cities of Binghamton, Endicott and Johnson City joined in a centennial celebration.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Lord Catto, Governor of the Bank of England since 1944, will retire on Feb. 28, two weeks before his seventieth birthday, the Treasury announced today. He will be succeeded by Deputy Governor Cameron F. Cobbold.
CHICHAGO, Oct. 14 -- Two Tucker Corporation stockholders and two dealers charged today that Preston Tucker's first widely exhibited Tucker Torpedo actually was a reconstructed 1942 Oldsmobile.

The City of Cleveland, Ohio, sold yesterday an issue of $7,500,000 of electric light and power plant revenue bonds due from 1955 to 1969 to a banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. at an interest cost of 2.355 per cent. The bidding was close.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Top executives of the country's largest oil companies joined today in predicting larger supplies of petroleum products this winter than last. Speaking at meetings held throughout the United States in observance of Oil Progress Day, the oil men reviewed gains of the last year in production and refining, but warned that consumers must continue to exercise care to avoid wasting gasoline and home-heating fuels.

As though Columbia were not already facing heavy enough odds in its football battle against powerful Pennsylvania at Baker Field tomorrow, the undermanned Light Blue squad may go into the contest without big Hank O'Shaughnessy.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- John Hay, distinguished United States statesman, who, incidentally, had his own troubles with Russia, in connection with Manchuria, reached this conclusion: "There are three species of creatures who when they seem coming are going, when they seem going, they come: diplomats, women and crabs."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Mobilization of the nation's research scientists in the event of a national emergency is being studied by a new committee, the Research and Development Board disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- During the week ended Oct. 13 member bank reserve balances increased $256,000,000, The Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Intensified efforts by management to eliminate waste in packaging operations, as a sure method of cutting rising costs and a means of conserving materials for national defense, was the central theme of the Packaging Institute's tenth annual forum yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.

Higher freight rates are spurring the opening of new and larger New York plants, and facilities in Eastern states to expand supplies to Eastern wholesalers and retailers, officers of leading hardware manufacturing companies revealed at the third National Hardware Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday.

To open its eighth season the Blackfriars Guild last night presented W. A. S. Douglas' "The Minstrel Boy," a play with music about the life of Thomas Moore, the Irish writer and singer. At its best during its musical moments, the production featured the title song, "The Meeting of the Waters" and other eighteenth-century airs that have survived the years since they were composed.

A shy Negro woman with a spiritual smile sat unobtrusively yesterday at a meeting of the New York City Mission Society at which plans for a fund-raising drive for $85,000 were discussed. Then Dr. Kenneth D. Miller, Mission Society president, rose and said, "I want to congratulate Mrs. Nathaniel Kline, head of our Harlem unit, who tomorrow celebrates her twenty-fifth anniversary with us."

Three new issues of railroad equipment trust and mortgage obligations totaling $27,720,000 were sold to banking groups and placed on the market yesterday. Offerings of public securities, consisting of $5,000,000 of mortgage bonds and $1,440,000 of convertible preferred stock, will become effective today.
Operations of the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries in the quarter ended with last August, resulted in a net profit of $6,393,456 after taxes and all charges, the report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Federal Trade Commission issued a statement of policy today with respect to pricing systems in which it indicated again that it was not trying to promote f.o.b. mill pricing. It emphasized, however, that "there is nothing inherently suggestive of collusion in f.o.b. mill pricing."

Brooklyn's improved Football Dodgers, still seeking their initial victory of the All-America Conference season, will encounter the Chicago Rockets under the lights at Ebbets Field tonight. The kickoff is listed for 8:30 and some 15,000 fans are expected.

Julien H. Collins, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, declared last night that one reason why the investment banking industry has been less effective than insurance companies in attracting funds was its lack of "vigor, originality and aggressiveness."

The work of Andrea Palladio, the sixteenth-century Italian architect, has been made the subject of a study by James Reynolds, entitled "Andrea Palladio and The Winged Device." The volume, containing a long biographical sketch of the architect, discusses the influence of his work in Europe and Colonial America.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 14 -- A high Israeli source predicted today that a political settlement of Palestine's future would be reached within two months, based on the division of the Negeb desert area in the south, across a Thirty-first Parallel.
HAIFA, Israel, Oct. 14 -- The American Export liner Excalibur sailed for Beirut tonight under an agreement that arms in the cargo assigned to Lebanese merchants and Syria would not be unloaded.

At the time of the British withdrawal India had 562 Princely States, ranging in size from a medium Texas ranch to an area as large as Kansas and a population as large as that of New York State. Not all the rulers of these principalities rode on elephants but some of them did.

A STRANGER from another planet, a heavenly satellite known as Baseball, returns to earth and discovers that the most horrendous things have been happening in football since he departed. It's all very confusing. It was bad enough before he left but now it is infinitely worse. He has come back to a scene of utter desolation with most of the usual signposts removed.

The present strike in shipping on the Pacific Coast is a fight for survival of either shipping or communism, it was asserted yesterday by Frank P. Foisie, president of the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 14 -- Following a survey just completed of current attendance at 367 typical American universities and colleges, Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati, reported here today that GI students were "sticking it out in junior and senior classes in a measure exceeding all post-war non-veteran records."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -Coach Herman Hickman sent the Yale squad through its final workout here this morning before leaving for the game with Wisconsin at Madison on Saturday.

Radio programs of background material for American history courses, beamed to a potential audience of 700,000 students in New York elementary and junior high schools, will be broadcast to classrooms beginning Monday.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- As the European Council for the Marshall Plan met today to complete the first year's programs, France's fouryear recovery plan was stalled by a split within the French Government over the possibility of financing the plan, which must be done mainly from taxation.

A proposed local law to increase by 30 per cent the fares charged by the city's 11,800 taxicabs was introduced in the City Council yesterday and referred to the committee on general welfare for a public hearing at a date to be fixed later.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The radio industry cannot be expected to participate wholeheartedly in national defense procurement when the Government is "placing millions of dollars in contracts on the basis of competitive bids with all of the speculative hazards for the Government and the contractor inherent in that method of doing business," the Radio Manufacturers Association declared today.
The report in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 8 of Secretary Marshall's ban on the standard expression of politeness for concluding a diplomatic dispatch made sad reading for me.

Efforts to mediate the two-weekold strike against the Union News Company collapsed last night when the company announced that it would not sign a contract with the striking union unless its officers signed non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley law.

The first performance of Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" by the New York City Opera Company, last night in the City Center of Music and Drama was given in English, in the excellent and singable translation of da Ponte's text by Ruth and Thomas Martin.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- Four New York City election cases, involving Tammany Hall's attempt to get a second line on the voting machines for its local candidates and the American Labor party's fight for a referendum on a return to the five-cent rapid transit fare, were argued today before the Court of Appeals.

Nominations for thirty-three posts in the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, will close on Friday and balloting for the offices will begin on Nov. 1 and run through Dec. 31.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 14 -- President Truman charged tonight Governor Thomas E. Dewey's public statements left no doubt that "powerful, selfish groups within the Republican party are determined to exploit the atom for private profit."

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 14 (AP) -Rigan McKinney, former star rider, saddled the one-two horses today in the fifth and richest running of the Butler Steeplechase, first of the major jumping events on the Maryland fall circuit, in Drift and The Heir.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals ordered today that a former New York City school teacher be certified for promotion despite a Board of Education finding that his record was "insufficiently meritorious."

Hospital social service work is the most gratifying of all volunteer work, Mrs. Irving Somach, former dollar-a-year secretary to the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, declared yesterday at the end of another payless stint.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 14 (AP) -- A football referee made news today by withdrawing from his four remaining officiating assignments involving Iowa State College.

Fifty thousand children will begin receiving fluorine treatments on Monday to harden and make their teeth more resistant to decay, the Bureau of Dentistry of the Department of Health announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Officials of the American and Chicago Newspaper Publishers Associations and spokesmen for the International Typographical Union in Indianapolis and its Chicago affilite, Local 16, withheld comment tonight on Federal Judge Luther M. Swygert's holding the parent union and its top four officials in contempt of court.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- In the midst of one of the greatest diplomatic struggles of modern times, Foreign Secretary Bevin made the remarkable and disarming statement today that he was "not going to worry about our relations with Russia."
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 -- Arthur V. Davis, 81-year-old board chairman of the Aluminum Company of America, repeated a process here today which created the giant aluminum industry sixty years ago.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a call on its War Loan Accounts with the large banks requiring a total payment of $224,056,400. The call, for 12 per cent of such deposits as of the close of business on Wednesday, is payable in two instalments: half on Oct. 19 and the remainder on Oct. 21.

BAYONNE, N. J., Oct. 14 -- In an age of guided missiles, the defense of the United States may require an outer ring of radar stations connected by television with a fire control office in the middle of the country.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 15 -- Requests for more money and manpower for the Pacific's defenses may be made as a result of the high-level United States Army, Navy and Air Force conferences in Tokyo, informed sources said today.

The United States Supreme Court's ruling last March against Illinois courts, which had held that the released time program of religious education in Champaign, Ill., did not violate constitutional or statutory rights, was criticized last night by Dr. Edward S. Corwin, Professor Emeritus of Jurisprudence at Princeton University.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, hero of Corregidor, joined yesterday in a token planting of trees in City Hall Park, marking the completion of the "first mass planting project in the Park Association's Citizens Golden Anniversary Planting Program."

Rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday closed higher and steady in an active day. The No. 1 contract, on a turnover of 19 lots, or 190 tons, closed 15 to 20 points higher. The standard contract, drawing more attention, closed 18 to 25 points higher on transactions of 41 lots, or 410 tons.
ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Dr. Thornton Stearns of East Orange, who has seen a good deal of this world, is convinced it's a pretty small one after all.
Revision of Senate rules on filibustering is the first step toward enactment of civil rights legislation, Senator Irving M. Ives told the New York chapter of the American Jewish Committee yesterday.

You may not be interested in pulleys, power tools and plastic pocket rules, but if you want to find out what is new in the way of rods, reels, lures, lines and other fishing impedimenta, the National Hardware Show at Grand Central Palace has a lot to offer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 9 were 891,811 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,770 cars, or 1.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 65,051 cars, or 6.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 7,632 cars, or 0.8 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The allocation of more funds for the construction of new schools and the rehabilitation of existing ones was urged yesterday by most of the eighty-five organizations and individuals who appeared at a seven-hour public hearing on the City Planning' Commission's proposed $317,056,203 capital outlay budget for 1949.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians won't need much overhauling for defense of their world championship, President Bill Veeck said today.

Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation administrator, disclosed last night that the nineteen European nations participating in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation had reached agreement on a currency clearance arrangement.

Jerome I. Mason, assistant editor of This Week magazine, has acquired from the estate of Hiram J. Halle, millionaire collector and restorer of Revolutionary dwellings, the authentic colonial house on the west side of the highway to Poundridge Center, Westchester County.
Cotton futures closed unchanged to 15 points lower yesterday as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange became moderately active.
Audio Devices, Inc., maker of recording disks and tapes for radio, motion pictures and other uses, to Rickard Co.

The publication of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's story of the war, "Crusade in Europe," on Nov. 22 will be the largest non-fiction book publishing venture in history, Douglas M. Black, president of Doubleday Co., announced yesterday. Counting only first editions for sale here and abroad, the concern estimates that 1,500,000 copies of the book will be in print by early 1949.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The Palestine political settlement forecast in Tel Aviv today corresponds roughly to the situation as it actually exists -- with the Israeli Army holding all Galilee, the Jews in Jerusalem ruling themselves and keeping a corridor open to Tel Aviv, and Israeli forces clinging to the settlements in the northern Negeb.

Nearly eighteen months ago the United Nations General Assembly met in special session to take up the question of Palestine. Today, in Paris, its fifty-eight-nation political committee is scheduled to resume study of this stillunsolved problem. It is no longer important to debate what Mr. Balfour meant in 1917 when he said that his Government viewed with favor "the establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people."

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- The United States Military Government announced today eleven new regulations tightening the curb on trade with the Soviet zone. United States officials here prepared to enforce to the limit the restrictions on exports to that zone. These measures already have cut essential production in Eastern Germany.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Very heavy buying of steel shares was seen in the industrial section of the stock market here today on hopes that the global award method adopted when the coal mines were nationalized will be applied to the steel industry.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- Proposals for United Nations action against racial lynching and political murder brought the Russian and United States delegations into conflict in two main committees of the General Assembly today.

The buses operated by the Third Avenue Transit System are losing about $50,000 a month more under the interim fare of 6 cents recently granted by the Public Service Commission than they were losing when the fare was only a nickel, Mortimer S. Gordon, chairman of the boards of the system companies, declared yesterday.

In his indictment of Soviet policy before the United Nations, Warren R. Austin, the American delegate, described at length how Communist Fifth Columns under the direction of the Moscow-dominated Cominform are attempting to sabotage, wreck and destroy Western Europe as the homeland of Western civilization in order to pave the way for a Communist world.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- An official United States Military Government public opinion survey showed today that 51 per cent of the populace of this city supported the Russian proposal for the withdrawal of all occupation forces from Germany within a year.

An evolutionary milestone in iron foundry methods was revealed here yesterday when James H. Smith, general manager, the Central Foundry Division of General Motors Corporation, disclosed during an interview at the Marguery Hotel that for the first time on a large scale in gray iron foundries 100 per cent annealing of soft gray iron castings is being used with remarkable results.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A turbulent meeting of a trial committee hearing charges against the officers of the New York City CIO Industrial Council flared into fist fights today at national headquarters of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A warning that doctors may be missing their "golden opportunity" to treat some types of paralysis, when they follow the conventional practice of delaying therapy after an attack in the hope that the underlying cause will heal itself, was sounded last night during the program of the graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Dr. Howard E. Lamb, osteopathic surgeon, of Denver, praised early walking after surgery today, but warned that "rest in bed in the treatment of disease is still as important as it ever was."

Accused of cooperating with Nazi propaganda agencies after allegedly deserting his post, Martin James Monti, 27-year-old former lieutenant in the Army Air Forces, was indicted yesterday for treason by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.

The one-story taxpayer building containing five stores at 436 Grand Street, southwest corner of Keap Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Kate Rod Realty Company to the 436 Grand Corporation, represented by David I. Michaelson, attorney.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The United Nations Security Council will resume debate on the Berlin blockade tomorrow amid indications that the Western powers will have difficulty at this stage in getting the seven votes required for a resolution calling on the Soviet Union to raise the blockade.
The Edward C. Blum Design Laboratory in the Brooklyn Museum on Eastern Parkway, the new and professionally equipped workroom for the design industry, was formally opened last night.
WARREN, Pa., Oct. 14 -- The quick action of Lowell McCann, a baker, probably saved this city of 14,891 inhabitants from disaster today.

Manhattan Democrats, having lost all hope of victory for President Truman, are concentrating on retaining control of the office of Surrogate as the one that will keep the local organization going, George Frankenthaler declared yesterday.

Predicting that the Federal Government would again operate at a surplus in the 1949 fiscal year, John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, called last night for a four-point program of tax reduction to halt the shrinkage in risk capital available for investment.

European production is increasing slowly, but the Russian crisis has induced jitters and obscures the current industrial picture on the Continent, Bjarne Asper, vice president of the Johns-Manville International Corporation, said yesterday.

Models of freight and passenger trains, a railroad station, a town wharf and the Connecticut countryside were stymied yesterday at the east balcony of Grand Central Terminal, where they were to have joined the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's "Main Street, New England" exhibit.

Young women headed by Miss Grace Dyer are serving on the debutante committee for the performance of "As the Girls Go," on the night of Nov. 4 at the Winter Garden Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the Samaritan Home for the Aged.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The immediate withdrawal of the forces policing the strike-bound mine areas of France was demanded today in a resolution voted at a national meeting of the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor which has been directing the coal strike.
SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 14 (AP) -Ray Flaherty said today he was fired as coach of the New York Yankees professional football team after owner Dan Topping had given away four of his best players.

The first ship-load of German steel scrap for the CarnegieIllinois Steel Corporation is scheduled to arrive in Philadelphia on Oct. 25 aboard the Louis Pasteur of the Volla Transportation Company, it was announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation, parent of CarnegieIllinois Steel.

A wildcat strike cut off half of the city's beer supply yesterday. The outlook for today was even more arid, despite union efforts to get 2,687 idle drivers and brewers back to work. Off icials of the United Brewery Workers, CIO, joined with the employers in characterizing the walkout as a violation of the contract between the union and fourteen New York breweries.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 14 -- Federal Judge Luther M. Swygert held the International Typographical Union, AFL, and its four top officials in contempt of court today for insisting on maintaining closedshop conditions in contracts with newspaper publishers despite an injunction banning such practices issued by the court on March 27.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 14 -- Approval by the United States and British Military Governors of the budget adopted by the Bizonal Economic Coucil and the Council of States was announced today by the bipartite finance group.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Sharply lower prices for fresh meats and livestock and poultry were mainly responsible for a drop of 1.5 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended Saturday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- Britain and China, supported by France, strongly condemned today what they termed the Israeli Government's failure to report progress in its investigation of the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine.

Yesterday, at the end of the first month's excavation work on the site of the United Nations headquarters between First Avenue and East River Drive, from Fortysecond Street to Forty-seventh Street, progress was reported to be more than satisfactory.
The Crawford Clothes price cut of 20 per cent was watched closely in the men's clothing industry yesterday but did not lead to other immediate reductions at retail or wholesale.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14 -Football historians place the attendance at close to 100 for the first intercollegiate game in 1869 between Rutgers and Princeton, but when the rivalry enters its forty-first meeting at Palmer Stadium on Saturday some 40,000 will be in the cheering sections.
The fight in upper Manhattan for a seat in the House of Representatives may be close, experienced political observers said yesterday.
Unless the inflationary spiral is checked and the high cost of living reduced, the nation is likely to experience a wave of arson by new home owners, it was forecast yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- What to do about India has now become the chief constitutional problem facing the British Commonwealth, whose Prime Ministers have been conferring all week. As the plenary sessions will not be resumed until Monday the delegates have been holding informal bilateral talks that in many respects may prove to be as important as the full meetings.
PARIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A former United States Army war crimes prosecutor asserted today that "a complete judicial error" had prevented the presenting of proof of mass atrocities by Ilse Koch.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14 -Harvard University's 36-man football squad, rated a 19-point underdog, will entrain at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning for West Point and its game against powerful Army on Saturday afternoon.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that ten business, labor and professional men and a clergyman have agreed to serve on an advisory committee on business administration to the Commissioner of Welfare.

To those who are accustomed to your fair-mindedness, it is a shock to read your editorial of Oct. 5, in which you endorse the demand of the so-called Israeli Government that the proposals of the late United Nations Mediator, Count Bernadotte, be modified to give Israel the Negeb, the desert area south of Beersheba.
A demonstration project to aid children who are school truants has been organized by eleven voluntary agencies in cooperation with districts of the Board of Education's Bureau of Attendance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Supreme Court, after sustaining Justice Black's dismissal of a Texas Federal Court injunction as interference in the election processes of a state that no statute warrants, suddenly held a conference yesterday and agreed to hear a plea from attorneys for Henry A. Wallace that it order the names of Progressive party national candidates onto the Illinois ballot.

Your editorial, "Hospital Needs," recalls to mind the significance of our voluntary hospital system in New York City which the late ex-Governor Alfred E. Smith emphasized in 1936 when he said, "The voluntary hospital system must be preserved because the closing of these hospitals would place upon the city a burden it could not carry."

The necessity for teamwork between academic and industrial research and how its application in the oil industry constituted a major contribution to victory in World War II was recounted last night by Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 -Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino, Americanborn Japanese awaiting trial on charges of treason, failed to obtain bail in Federal Court here today.

Daily average crude oil production of the nation for last week increased 82,050 barrels to a new high record of 5,534,800 barrels, according to yesterday's report of the American Petroleum Institute. For the similar week a year ago crude oil production averaged 5,245,300 barrels daily.

Walter Davis, a 21-year-old helper on a truck, confessed late last night to the murder last Saturday of Miss Mary Gray, 80, who was stabbed in her top-floor apartment in a three-story brownstone house at 17 Madison Street, Brooklyn.

The Navy Purchasing Office announced yesterday that it had awarded a contract for 400,000 wool blankets to the Peerless Woolen Mills of Rossville, Ga. A total of 90,000 were bid in at $7.34 each by Peerless, and an additional 310,000 at $7.39.

The joint furniture market dates committee, representing retailers and manufacturers of all types of home furnishings, has reached a long-term agreement on home furnishings market dates with important Chicago interests with which it has been at odds for several months, it was announced yesterday.

A strike of script writers on most of the major network radio programs was threatened yesterday by the Radio Writers Guild, a branch of the Authors League of America, as the result of a deadlock in negotiations with the advertising agencies.

The Fulton has been booked for "The Young and Fair." Nov. 22 is the opening date for the N. Richard Nash play in which Frances Starr will be seen in one of the leading roles. Another important member of the cast probably will be Lois Wheeler.
Following is the text of the address made at Kansas City last night by Governor Dewey as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Three young boys, patients at the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital, scaled a ten-foot wire mesh fence surrounding a play pen on the roof of the eight-story building early yesterday afternoon and kept a crowd of several hundred in anxiety in the street for almost an hour as they scampered and played along an eighteen-inch ledge bordering the top of the building.

The cornerstone for the $3,267,552 Welfare Island laundry, garage and firehouse was laid yesterday afternoon in ceremonies attended by 300 persons. Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett and other city officials participated in the ceremonies for the three buildings, which will be completed in about a year.

Happiest little gent at Jamaica yesterday was Bobby Permane. The reason: When he won the fifth race with the Wheatley Stable's Grey Flight, the 9-to-10 favorite, he ended a losing streak that had extended through 127 races.

UPTON, L.I., Oct. 14 -- The board of trustees of Associated Universities, Inc., which operates the Brookhaven National Laboratory under contract with the Atomic Energy Commission, named today Dr. Leland J. Haworth as director of the laboratory.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- David Rockefeller, youngest of the five sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and one of the most erudite of the clan, is giving yeoman service here in the drafting of Westchester's first comprehensive fiveyear planning program.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 14 (UP) -- Miss Polly Riley shot a parbreaking 72 today to defeat Miss Patty Berg by 2 and 1 in a quarterfinal match of the Texas women's open golf tournament.

Choice wines, liquors and cigars were sold for less than their appraised valuations yesterday at an auction of seized and abandoned merchandise in the United States Customs Seizure Room of the Appraiser's Stores, 201 Varick Street.

CAIRO, Oct. 14 -- Egypt is harvesting a bumper crop of cotton and worriedly watching as Egyption and world cotton prices decline. The crop is estimated officially at 337,000 tons, or about 25 per cent greater than last year.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 14 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey told a capacity audience at Municipal Auditorium tonight that President Truman was running a tired and confused administration which was no longer strengthening the cause of America or of peace.
A collection of winter coats, suits, dresses and evening gowns, bearing designers' names, was shown yesterday by B. Altman Co. on the third floor of its Fifth Avenue store.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The biggest event in Britain's canine world, Crufts dog show, reopened today at Olympia Stadium for the first time since 1939. The kennel club sponsoring the show said more than 9,000 entries had been received and during the event more than 4,200 dogs of all sizes and breeds will be exhibited.

Traders on the stock market yesterday took the domestic outlook for the second day in succession as a guide for their operations, and proponents of the advance found the results gratifying. Spurred by trading of nearly a million shares, the largest thus far in the month, prices pushed forward irregularly, and, although there were a few wide gains, the increase in the price average held at 0.45 point.

GLENDALE, Calif., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Knocking six strokes off par for a 66, Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago took the lead at the end of the first 18 holes today in the inaugural $15,000 Glendale open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Two of the twelve ships still afloat after the seventy-six-vessel flotilla was used in the Bikini underwater atomic bomb tests are so dangerously radioactive that they will be sunk off the West Coast in the near future, the Navy announced today.

Edward Katz, violinist who made his Town Hall debut in 1942, appeared there for the fourth time last night. His performance left an over-all impression of lack of contrast, although he is a musician of considerable technical skill, and ability to evoke a sensuous tone quality.
I read with a great deal of interest the three articles in THE TIMES of Oct. 10 on European recovery, written by your Washington, London and Paris correspondents.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- The largest purchases of cash corn during the present crop year, 335,000 bushels being bought by local elevator interests, and a break of 2 to 10 cents in the cash market failed to have as much effect as anticipated on futures on the Board of Trade today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -The minimum wage rate for textile industry employees working on Government contracts was more than doubled today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Secret testimony by Whittaker Chambers that two underground Communist organizations were at work in the State Department in the latter Nineteen Thirties was made public today by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The bejeweled Maharajah of Morvi, a small state in northwest India, who estimated his personal fortune at "many millions of pounds," arrived here yesterday on the liner Queen Mary "without an American cent."

TACOMA, Wash., Oct. 14 (AP) -Gov. Earl Warren, coming into the strike-crippled Puget Sound shipping area in his campaign for the Vice Presidency, called tonight for a United States merchant marine able to compete for its share of the world's commerce.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 14 -- Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, raked the bipartisan policy of the Truman Administration in two speeches in downtown Milwaukee tonight, and included a personal attack on the President, who was speaking two and a half miles away at Borchert Field.
ROME, Oct. 14 -- Government employes staged a one-day strike today to protest against the Government's failure to accept their demands for increased salaries.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 14 -The strange apathy toward the November election reported from all over the country shows up particularly in Rochester. Here one can stand in the rush hour, at its busy "Four Corners," and look in vain for a single person wearing a campaign button, either for Thomas E. Dewey or President Truman, or for a campaign poster in the bright shop windows.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- The sixteenth biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America ended today after enthusiastically endorsing a program of cooperative Lutheran evangelism in 1949-50.

After learning that the defendant before him was wanted in New Jersey to serve prison terms for similar crimes, General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen ordered that Frederick Philip Train, 42 years old, who gave his address as 30 Seaview Avenue, Ocean Grove, N.J., serve the full term of a two-to-four-year sentence.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The United States will leave the defense of the European Recovery Program against attacks by pro-Russian spokesmen in the United Nations in the hands of the Western European delegates on the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee.

LONDON, Oct. l4 -- The Archbishop of York, Dr. Cyril F. Garbett, called upon the people of Britain today to support the Government's rearmament campaign and to be prepared to fight against totalitarian enslavement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -The Maritime Commission today announced results of an invitation by Standard Oil Company of New Jersey for bids on the proposed construction of a fleet of highspeed tankers.

" Angel in the Wings," last season's successful Broadway musical revue, will be reproduced on television with the original cast, according to an announcement yesterday by the "Philco Television Playhouse." Curtain time for the video presentation is set for Sunday, Oct. 24, from 9 to 10 P. M. over NBC's East Coast hook-up.
MONTREAL, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens and the New York Rangers played a 1-all tie at the Forum tonight in their opening game of the National Hockey League season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Federal Judge Luther M. Swygert's order finding the International Typographical Union, AFL, in contempt of court omitted two major restraints sought by the Government, but appeared to be more restrictive than the Government's proposal on two other points.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Great Britain has undertaken to curtail expenditures on social-improvement and betterment projects when such outlays interfere with her ability to become independent of dollar aid.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Michigan State College campus police clamped down today on what they termed student gambling in professionally operated football pools.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, said today that the Federal Trade Commission is committed to protect small business from absorption by large companies.

The greatest democratizing influence in Germany today is the Russians, Arthur Garfield Hays, general counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, declared on his arrival here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Officials at the State Department denied today reports from Paris that the United States and the United Kingdom might have arranged quietly a broad "deal" on the Mediterranean.

The harder the water, the more valuable are synthetic detergents for the family wash, David R. Byerly, Procter Gamble chemist, pointed out yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Pierre Hotel to introduce "Tide," the company's new product.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The plan of the Arnold Bernstein Line, Inc., to place two passenger liners in strong competition with the present North Atlantic trade was rebuffed today by F. J. Horan, an examiner for the United States Maritime Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- First Arctic training for the B-50 "Superbombers" of the Strategic Air Command will get under way next month when three five-plane units of the big craft are to begin rotating forty-five-day field exercises in Alaska between Nov. 1 and March 15, the Air Force said today.

The declining days of 1946 were made heavy by the statement, disagreeably reiterated, that the head of the house needed a new hat. That was not true then or now, for the old hat, purchased in 1944 -- no, 1943 -- had much life yet remaining.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -Despite Robert Mitchum's pending trial on narcotics charges, scheduled for Nov. 22, RKO is continuing preparations for his next picture, "Operation Malaya," which is slated for December or early January production, it was learned today.

BUTZBACH, Germany, Oct. 14 -The movement of Europe's homeless to the United States started today when 1,070 men, women and children left displaced persons installations in this city and Munich by train for Bremerhaven.

Prices on many pork, veal and lamb cuts are lower today, though the declines are not as radical as those that occurred a week ago. In its survey of food prices here, the City Department of Markets finds that six meats have dropped 4 cents since last Friday and four are down 2 cents.

Two new films will have local premieres in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy the attraction is "Apartment for Peggy," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic drama, filmed in Technicolor and featuring Jeanne Crain, Edmund Gwenn and William Holden.

Business loans outstanding in this area reached a new high of $5,663,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which issued the weekly statement of assets and liabilities of the reporting New York City member banks, showed an advance of $78,000,000 in commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans above the level of the previous week.

PARIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The resolution of Britain and China proposed that the Council say it: "notes with concern that the Provisional Government of Israel has to date submitted no report to the Security Council or to the acting Mediator regarding the progress of the investigation into the assassination;

Gray, from light silver to smoky taupe, was the color of the majority of costumes displayed yesterday by Rosette Pennington of 20 East Fifty-sixth Street during luncheon at the Plaza Hotel. Worsted suits, winter coats, crepe afternoon dresses, elegant evening gowns, even fur stoles, were of gray.

With the approval of Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander, the police force of the Israeli Government in Palestine will send six key men to New York within the next month for training at the Police Department Academy.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 14 (AP) -Following is the prepared text of President Truman's campaign address tonight on the atomic energy program:

United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., in its twentieth year ended on June 30, transacted the largest sales and earnings on record, J. W. Schwab, president, reported to stockholders in the annual statement issued for release today.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, requested yesterday an opinion from the Corporation Counsel on a Brooklyn highschool teacher's refusal to answer questions put to him recently by a House subcommittee investigating alleged communism in the Teachers Union, CIO.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Dairymen's League Cooperative Association called today for a "long-time, stable milk pricing formula" that would reflect the changing costs of production.
TOKYO, Oct. 14 -- Arrests continue to mark the Japanese Government's battle against the Communistcontrolled electric industry workers' union.
This year's fund drive to finance the program of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York was formally opened yesterday afternoon with the assistance of four Canadian Girl Guides.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 9 were 11 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -- William B. Given, president, American Brake Shoe Company, New York City, said today that "certainly there must be still more mechanization, less lifting, and fewer tired backs at night" in the nation's foundry industry.

The twelve-story office building at 9 and 11 East Forty-first Street which Frederick Brown bought recently from the Burroughs-Wellcome (U.S.A.), Inc., was leased yesterday by the operator to the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation for ten years from Nov. 1, 1948.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -Trans-Continental Gas Pipe Line Company asked the Federal Power Commission at a hearing today for permission to enlarge its proposed pipeline from the natural gas fields in Texas to New York City. It wants to substitute thirty-inch pipe for twenty-inch pipe on 1,210 miles of the 1,760 mile line.

Columbia will match its darting speed and offensive resourcefulness against undefeated Pennsylvania's rock-ribbed defense and crushing power at Baker Field today in the East's leading college football attraction.
Members of the Orchestre National de France were so overwhelmed by the "formidable, extraordinary" New York yesterday that they had almost nothing to say about the World of music.

Prominent laymen will preach tomorrow at the 11 A.M. worship, substituting for the pastor in some of the best known local churches in observance of seventh annual Laymen's Sunday under the sponsorship of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World.

The New York Stock Exchange and its affiliated companies, for the quarter ended Sept. 30, reported yesterday a net loss of $162,630, compared with a net loss of $97,420 in the preceding period and one of $118,497 in the like quarter of last year.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Trouble over communism appeared to be brewing today in the British trade union movement.

The Moran 'Towing and Trans~II portation Company in one ofmost unusual marine operations~has been engaged for the last sixmonths in towin~ new floating oilfie'Id equipment from New Orleansto Venezuela, it was announcedyesterday.

Declaring that the Republican party and Governor Dewey represent the only hope of American liberals, Dean Alfange, former American Labor party candidate for governor and one of the founders of the Liberal party, explained last night why he was supporting the Republican Presidential candidate.

With a highly-pleasing and purposeful performance that belied their 0 -- 6 record and cellar-position in the All-America Conference standings, the Brooklyn football Dodgers finally broke into the victory column last night. Before 8,671 fans at Ebbets Field, the Brooks defeated the Chicago Rockets, 21 -- 7, and looked good doing it.

The ninth New York Antiques Fair is to open at 1 P. M.
