Monday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street, with the most important collection of rarities the fair has ever shown. Among the 150 exhibitors will be some of the foremost antique dealers in the country, C. J. Nuttall and Dorothy Hazen, managers, said yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- An attempt under the leadership of the Soviet Union to exclude political groups from the protection of the proposed draft convention on genocide was defeated today in the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 (AP) -Building owners and managers were advised today to take five steps as protection against deflation and readjustment.

The stock market showed no inclination yesterday to test the midsummer high mark and Thursday's gains were eliminated, leaving a ragged price line at the close. Fluctuations throughout the day were narrow; only a few prices underwent changes of a point or more, and the composite rate slipped 0.56 point.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will cheer for Columbia today as the Lions engage powerful Pennsylvania before a sellout crowd at Baker Field, while Secretary of Defense James V. Forrestal and Gen. Omar Bradley, Army Chief of Staff, head the group of notables in another capacity gathering that will see Army play Harvard in Michie Stadium at West Point.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP) -Ten of the nation's largest plumbing manufacturers were accused in three anti-trust suits brought by the Federal Government today in connection with the United States investigation "into the high cost of housing."

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 15 -- Alexander W. Evans, British former director of the Steau Romana Oil Company, subsidiary of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, was sentenced here today to three years' imprisonment on a charge of having misused about $100,000 of the now nationalized company's money.

The possessors of five ferocious faces, some of them resembling those of prehistoric monsters, reluctantly posed for photographs yesterday as the most recent additions to the population of the Bronx Zoo's Reptile House.

Fifty-four of the city's leading business men have agreed to canvass their respective fields in behalf of the $425,000 campaign of the Visiting Nurse Service, it was announced yesterday by James A. Linen, publisher of Time Magazine and campaign chairman.

Calumet Farm's great 3-yearold colt Citation, who has just about earned his weight in gold this year, goes after another big pay check today. He's a 1-to-10 favorite, the pricemakers say, to collect it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The National Board of the General Federation of Women's Clubs today voted an emergency resolution making the federation the first women's organization to back a Western European military alliance.

By a vote of nearly 20 to 1, the membership of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, the largest in the international CIO union, has rejected the left-wing sponsored proposal for direct election of the international officers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The State Department denied today a Tass report of Oct. 9 that there were 10,000 United States troops and civilians in Greece, sufficient to give this country complete control over the state apparatus there.

President Truman has taken Governor Dewey to task for a speech which the Republican candidate made at Phoenix on the subject of atomic energy. Mr. Dewey remarked on that occasion: "We know what the enterprise, initiative and creative powers of our people can do.

The four-story apartment house accommodating forty-two families at 193 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, has been sold by John Piczykowski to Fortune Estates, Inc., represented by Joseph Krimsky, attorney. The building is on a plot 100 by 100 feet.

Fifty Army recruits from Camp Hood, Texas, have not been in uniform very long but they have learned a few good wrinkles about furloughs. They proved this yesterday morning by their arrival at La Guardia Field in a chartered plane.

The threatened flare-up between the League of New York Theatres and the Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers Union has been averted for the time being, at least. The dispute arose over the proposed hiring of public relation experts outside the ranks of the latter organization for the purpose of popularizing the legitimate theatre on a nation-wide scale.
LA CROSSE, Wis., Oct. 15 -Careful placement of 205,000 or more displaced persons from Europe was endorsed today by the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.

In your paper of Oct. 3 your correspondent A. M. Rosenthal reported from Paris that the Soviet Union had "shifted its political ground" and had "dropped its demand for prohibition of the atomic bomb before the imposition of international control."
The Lehigh Portland Cement Company reported yesterday for the twelve months ended with last September, a net profit of $5,093,571 after depreciation and provision for taxes.

DUBLIN, Ireland, Oct. 15 -- The Department of External Affairs and the United States Legation announced today negotiations had been resumed here for a comprehensive treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation between Ireland and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that August exports to Russia and other Eastern European countries rose to $14,000,000. The July figure was $5,300,000.

A nation-wide program for pro-irooting suitable futmiture items as j' Christmas gifts through newspaper ~advertising has been prepared for Jthe 8,000 members of the National]Retail Furniture Association, it,was announced yesterday by James~I. McMahan, the organization's.president.

With increased mechanical handling of packaged commodities certain as soon as more equipment becomes available, industry should now begin planning for suitable cases and larger unitized loads, members of the Packaging Institute were told yesterday at the closing session of their annual forum in the Commodore Hotel.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 15 -- Plans are under way for streamlining the procedures of the bizonal Joint ExportImport Agency preparatory to turning over the major part of its administration to the Germans, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, said at a press conference today.

The Thypin Steel Company has acquired for improvement with a one-story warehouse structure the vacant block comprising approximately 120,000 square feet on the south side of Hunterspoint Avenue, between Thirtieth Street and Thirtieth Place, Long Island City, Queens, from the B. L. F. Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -Assistant Secretary of the Interior C. Girard Davidson said today the steel industry has given the softcoal and mining-machinery industries the "brush off" in their requests for steel allocations.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Extension of Social Security benefits to farmers and repeal of the Taft-Hartley labor law featured a farm-labor program outlined tonight by Senator Alben W. Barkley.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- A week of debate in which only a fraction of the time was devoted to the Economic and Social Council's report to the United Nations General Assembly and the rest to heated discussion of the merits of the European Recovery Program closed here tonight.

Army draftees who are graduated from officer candidate schools will receive the chance to compete for Regular Army commissions if they desire, Maj. Gen. John E. Dahlquist, deputy director of Personnel and Administration, Department of the Army, said last night.
BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- Republican chances of regaining one Massachusetts seat in Congress and of saving another appear to hinge on the extent of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's expected sweep of the commonwealth.

On recommendation of its Committee on the Judiciary, the Board of Directors of the New York County Lawyers Association pronounced yesterday both former Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler, Republican and Liberal party candidate for Surrogate of New York County, and General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, his Democratic opponent "well qualified" for that office.

The rates for telephone service "are too low to insure for the long run the best possible service to telephone users," Leroy A. Wilson, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, declared yesterday in his quarterly letter to stockholders.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 15 -- Despite the assertion of Robert A. Lovett, United States Under-Secretary of State, in Washington on Wednesday that the allegations published here of United States complicity in the Peruvian uprising of Oct. 3 were "absurd," one Peronista paper strongly reiterated the charges yesterday and the Communists jumped on the "bandwagon" this morning.

Underwriting houses face a week of heavy new financing commitments next week. Bond issues coming up for competitive sale include $75,000,000 of forty-year debentures of the Michigan Bell Telephone Company, $25,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds of the State of California and $10,000,000 of first mortgage obligations of the Public Service Company of Colorado, all on Tuesday.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- Representative Walter H. Judd, Republican, of Minnesota, called today for a strengthening of the United Nations -- with or without Russia -- as a means to establish peace in the world.

After an intermission of more than a week devoted to a mediation effort which failed, the Security Council of the United Nations is again faced with the Western charges that the Russian blockade of Berlin has created a threat to international peace and security. The mediation effort was undertaken by the so-called "neutral" nations in the Security Council under the leadership of Foreign Minister Bramuglia of Argentina, the Acting Council President during the Berlin hearings.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 15 (AP) -The New Jersey Teamsters Joint Council has withdrawn from the State Federation of Labor, AFL, because of the federation's new per capita tax plan.

Pan American Airways announced at La Guardia Field yesterday two changes in its overseas service. Non-stop flights between New York and London, discontinued last spring "to permit the carrying of a large number of passengers destined for Gander, Nfld., and Shannon, Ireland, have been resumed and the 3,600-mile transatlantic trip is made in fourteen hours.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- Villanova came to Braves Field tonight but the visitors found Boston College an alert aggregation and after taking the lead in the opening period, the Eagles went on to win by 20 -- 13 before a crowd of 30,178.

Port officials and representatives of the city o' Newark gave a formal greeting yesterday to the Swedish-American Line freighter Braheholm, bringing in a "victory" cargo of wood pulp for distribution to users of high-grade paper in this area.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan served notice yesterday that he would not tolerate attempts by any person or groups to supersede with violence the duties of local law-enforcement agencies.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Evening up of commitments in anticipation of the week-end influenced the stock market here today and gave some sections an irregular appearance.
The twenty-seventh annual parade and ceremony of the Society of the Massing of the Colors will be held tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct 15 -- The International Typographical Union, AFL, asked the National Labor Relations Board today to "withdraw" from the General Counsel the power to seek injunctive and contempt relief under the Taft-Hartley Law.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Henry A. Wallace and Senator Glen H. Taylor, the Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates of the Progressive party, criss-crossed Chicago tonight in three meetings assailing corrupt bosses in both old parties who were charged with disfranchising "half a million voters" when the Progressive ticket was barred from the Illinois statewide ballot.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, newly inaugurated president of Columbia University, declared here tonight that he would refuse to accept Federal money for higher education if even the slightest measure of Federal control came with it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- In a ceremony today at the Canadian Embassy, Hume Wrong, the Dominion's Ambassador, awarded decorations recommended by Ottawa for particular and valuable services to Canada during World War II. Of the thirty-eight decorations that were conferred, thirtyone were bestowed on members of the United States armed forces.

Close to 1,000 American Legionnaires from New York, New Jersey and the New England states entrained yesterday from Pennsylvania Station bound for the thirtieth annual convention in Miami, Fla., Monday to Thursday.

Dr. Moshe Sneh, who headed the Jewish underground army Haganah from 1940 to 1946, charged yesterday that efforts were being made to "utilize the assassination of Count Folke Bernadotte as an excuse to attack the territorial integrity and sovereignty of the State of Israel."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reports that world sugar production regained pre-war levels this year. It predicted even more sugar next year. Much of the increase is expected in areas recovering from war damage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Supreme Court declined to act on a case involving allegations that the minimum basic agreement set up by the Dramatists Guild involves restraint under the antitrust laws, it became known today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Henry J. Kaiser, chairman of the board of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, today stirred the embers of the controversy over who should operate the Government-owned blast furnace at Cleveland when he announced that his company was prepared to "rip to pieces Republic Steel Corporation's smoke screen of hiding behind its customers."

Foreign Minister Sforza has proposed to the Italian houses of parliament approach to European unity that is less ambitious, more gradual and therefore more practical than the plans of the various organizations which are crusading for an idea as hard to down as it is to realize.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 15 (AP) -Henry L. Straus' Pilaster scored his first stakes victory of the year in the eleventh running of the transplanted Sagamore Stakes today. The fixture, formerly a sixfurlong race at Pimlico, was over the mile-and-a-half route.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -Two sparkling touchdown passes carried Kansas to a well-deserved 12-0 intersectional football victory over scrappy but outclassed George Washington University tonight.

Saying that the only way to economic prosperity is to increase production through labor and management working together, Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican candidate for United States Senator in New Jersey, declared last night that the Truman Administration was trying to take political advantage of high wages and an increased farm income and at the same time was blaming the Republican party for high prices.
The high rate of rejections among draftees continued here yesterday when only seventeen of the 114 examined were found fit for service.

ATHENS, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Minister of Justice George Melas ordered legal action today against four Athens newspapers for publishing a purported solution of the killing last May of George Polk, correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- With the listing of 590 patent awards in the Official Gazette, the United States Patent Office this week established a new post-war record, breaking the high mark of 535 set Sept. 10 of this year.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 15 -- The Unemployment Compensation Commission of New Jersey announced today that 120 of its employes would be discharged on Nov. 1 and that eight local employment service and claims offices would be closed on Dec. 1.

Mill prices of several types of low-grade hardwoods have dropped 10 to 15 per cent in the last few weeks, lumber distributors reported yesterday. All kinds of Southern hardwoods except oak in the No. 2 and 3 common grades, as well as hard maple, are affected by weakening of the market, they said.
BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- An accounting of the profits of a Boston ticket agency is sought in a suit in equity brought against New York showman J. J. Shubert by Mrs. Martha Levy of Manchester, Mass.

EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 15 (AP) -Winding up a thirty-one-day coastto-coast campaign, Earl Warren, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, asserted tonight that the Republican party alone was in a position to lead the nation after next January.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Tracey Witch, 3-year-old cocker spaniel bitch exhibited by Herbert S. Lloyd of suburban Uxbridge, was named best in show among 4,000 dogs competing at Crufts first post-war exhibition which closed in Olympia Stadium today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -The Justice Department today asked for a court order requiring Schine Chain Theatres, Inc., of New York to sell most of its motion -pictues houses in six states.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Millions of Russians are living like animals in Soviet slave labor camps, Christopher Mayhew, British UnderSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs, charged today in a broadside against Russia. His speech enlivened the United Nations committee discussion of the draft of an international declaration on human rights.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Closing its meeting here today, the General Confederation of Labor, which is the Communist-dominated union directing the coal strike, adopted its policy resolution calling on French workers "to throw off the burden of the Marshall Plan and fight against Western military accords aimed at the Soviet Union."

RIVERSIDE, L.I., Oct. 15 -- The twelve-room Georgian-colonialstyle home at Huntington, L.I., of Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, former Army Air Force supply officer, now serving a prison term for subornation of perjury, has been sold for $53,000, it was announced today.

QUONSET, R. I., Oct. 15 -- A fire that sent smoke 4,000 to 5,000 feet into the air, visible from points all over Rhode Island, destroyed the engine overhaul and repair building at the Quonset Point Naval Air Station late today. Damage was put officially at $1,000,000.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 15 (AP) -Following is the text of President Truman's campaign address as prepared for delivery here tonight:

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- The French Government is understood to have devised a plan to eliminate some if not all of the differential exchange rates for its currency that were established when the franc was devalued last January.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 15 (UP) -Communist agents from Russiandominated North Korea are infiltrating into South Korea with instructions to foment disorder, President Syngrnan Rhee said today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 15. -Led by its passing star, Bill Hoose, St. Paul's School handed Adelphi Academy its third straight setback, 20 to 6. today. Hoose connected with seven tosses in twelve attempts and scored a touchdown.

To help lower-income annuitants to meet increased living costs, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and participating domestic affiliates will pay cash allowances to these annuitants for one year to supplement income they now receive from company benefit plans and social security, it was announced yesterday.

Promise of further intelligent and unselfish service in the interest of the handicapped is implicit in the election of Bruce Barton as president of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled. He succeeds the late Walter Ewing Hope, who served the institution so well from 1924 until his death this year.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll gave his approval today to one of the major bills of the New Jersey governmental reorganization under the new state constitution. It creates a new department of law and public safety.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony Young People's Concert, Walter Hendl, conductor, Town Hall, 11 o'clock; Stella Whitman, piano, Town Hall, 3; Leo Tolstoy Memorial Concert, Eugene Istomin, piano; Ruggiero Ricci, violin; Brian Sullivan, tenor; Marina Svetlova, dancer; Alexandra Tolstoy, speaker, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

A FORTY-NINTH STREET GARDEN OF VERSES is inspired by reading Osmond P. Breland's scholarly and entertaining new book, "Animal Facts and Fallacies,"* "concerning the legends, the feats, the special habits and idiosyncrasies" of as varied a lot of birds, beasts and fishes as you could find in a tiglion's age.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 15 -- A Scandinavian defense committee was formed here today to examine possibilities for the joint defense of Norway, Sweden and Denmark against aggression, it was announced tonight. The decision was taken during a four-hour meeting of defense ministers of the three countries and their advisers.
BERLIN, Oct. 15 -- Wilhelm Pieck, aging figurehead of the Kremlin in Germany, today called for a "thorough investigation" of the leaders of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 15 -- The Israeli Army and Air Force went into action on the southern front late today in a renewal of fighting that seemed to some authoritative sources to herald the end of the truce in Palestine.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Wheat took the leadership in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, advancing 1 1/8 to 2 1/8 cents, with heavy buying by Southwestern interest, especially in May, featuring trading. Strength in wheat spread to corn and the latter finished unchanged to 1 cent a bushel higher.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- "Phooey on people," says Mrs. Rose Baron, 32. "When you're in trouble and want help, people just laugh. Phooey on people."

Brazil is planning to overhaul and re-equip her entire sugar industry with American machinery and methods, Gileno de Carli, representative of the Sugar and Alcohol Institute of Brazil, said yesterday. He pointed out at the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau that the sugar industry in that country is operating with equipment around sixteen years old.

DETROIT, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Great line play and expert quarterbacking gave an underdog University of Miami (Fla.) football team a 6 to 0 victory over the University of Detroit tonight. A crowd of 18,451 saw the Titans toppled to their first defeat in four games this season.
GENESEO, N.Y., Oct. 15 (AP) -A state-wide child guidance conference heard today that teachers should be more concerned with the effects of the educational experience on the child.
BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Industrial mobilization is more important to national security than is universal military training or the draft.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 15 -Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that the common interests of agriculture and business and industry is the maintaining of a balanced economy in which the prosperity of one segment is essential to the prosperity of the other.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee rejected by 30 to 6 today a Soviet draft resolution that would have made it compulsory for administrative powers to submit "information regarding the development of organs of self government in non-self-governing territories and the participation of the local population in the work of these organs."

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- With the small powers displaying marked reluctance to support the Western powers' complaint against the Soviet Union, at least at this stage, the United Nations Security Council postponed today consideration of the Berlin blockade until next Tuesday.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The British Government is turning the liabilities it has recently incurred in Western Europe under the European Recovery Program into a valuable asset in the home drive for economic rehabilitation.

VIENNA, Oct. 15 -- The three Western powers refused today to legalize the establishment of a fourth political party in Austria. They rejected the bid of the Democratic Union, headed by a man who is known to be pro-Soviet, at a meeting of the Allied Council for Austria.

The answers to interrogatories propounded by the Investment Bankers Association of America and seventeen corporate members who are defendants with it in a civil anti-trust suit brought by the United States Department of Justice were filed yesterday in Federal Court by the Department's anti-trust division.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 15 -- Yugoslav educational authorities have expelled 233 students "bourgeois" origin from the University of Belgrade and technic institutes of the capital on charge of hostility to the present Government, immorality and espionage.

Our visitor was an elderly man with that overlay of tan which city folk bring back from vacations and mistake, too often, for the deep-dyed bronze hue of rustic health. He produced a pipe, filled it, and consumed several matches before he got it going.

We publish on this page today a letter from the State Controller, Frank C. Moore, which discusses a problem sure to be a warm issue in the session of the New York Legislature beginning in January. This is the financial plight of municipalities caught, as all forms of government have been, in the effects of inflation.

Fire swept through a row of thirteen two-story, two-family frame houses in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn shortly before 5 A.M. yesterday, driving to the street and making homeless nearly 100 persons, including about thirty-five children. Nine persons were injured, of whom five were hospitalized.

The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation yesterday announced the programs for the two half-hour periods it has purchased on the WOR-Mutual network. Guy Lombardo will be presented on Saturday nights from 9:30 to 10 o'clock beginning Oct. 24.

The recent decision of the Department of Justice to file dissolution proceedings against the Aluminum Company of America, in view of the legal rulings handed down since the antitrust suit originally began, certainly has the odor of "election-year politics."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today ignored a demand by officers of the New York City CIO Industrial Council that two of the three members he had named to hear charges against the council's officers be removed by him.

A last minute report from the Chesapeake indicates that the stripers are schooling in the bay in numbers that many local anglers describe as "unprecedented." From Solomon' sto Rock Hall the bass, known locally as "rock," are being taken by the dozen, and although most of them are in the 6 and 7-pound class, there are quite a few big fish also.

The increased gas rates sought by the Consolidated Edison Company in its petition to the Public Service Commission would discriminate against the small home owner in favor of the commercial and industrial consumer, Harry Lesser, counsel for the Williamsbridge Taxpayers and Civic Association of the Bronx, declared yesterday at the close of the hearings at 233 Broadway.
Although the obituary for Mary Adelaide Nutting in THE TIMES of Oct. 5 contains much factual data, it fails to convey a correct impression of her true stature.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 15 -- Unification of the United States and British airlift project under the joint command of Maj. Gen. William H. Tunner, commanding general of the United States Airlift Task Force, and Air Commodore W. F. Merer of the RAF, as deputy commander, was announced this evening.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Producers Association of America, strenuously denied here today that American exhibitors were combining to limit the showing times of British pictures in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP) -Boston University's fleet football team found its running shoes in the second half tonight to whip winless but improved Temple University, 13 to 7, before 10,000 fans at Temple Stadium.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- The Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly listened today to an urgent plea by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting Mediator for Palestine, that it act on the report of the late Mediator, Count Folke Bernadotte, to end the menace to world peace presented by the Palestine situation.

As a 21-year-old trucker's helper was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court charged with the slaying of Miss Mary Gray, 80, of 17 Madison Street, Brooklyn, a former first-grade detective, who had been demoted to the ranks in 1940, won credit for having solved the crime.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -Important moves to increase the production of uranium, raw material of atomic energy, in western states were announced tonight by the Atomic Energy Commission.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 5 -- A month-long celebration commemorating the 300th anniversary of the First Presbyterian Church of this village opened tonight with the Rev. Dr. Jesse H. Baird, Presbyterian Moderator in the United States, officiating at a special service.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, in leaving La Guardia Field yesterday on his first trip to Palestine, announced that during the first nine months of 1948 a total of 73,000 refugees have entered the Jewish State.
TOKYO, Oct. 15 -- Shigeru Yoshida, newly elected Premier of Japan, today began his task of forming a conservative Cabinet to replace the defunct coalition government of Dr. Hitoshi Ashida.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 15 -- John A. Claussen, secretary, merchant pig iron committee, American Iron and Steel Institute, New York, said today indications are that imports of iron ore this year will exceed last year's record 4,900,000 gross tons.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Government today agreed to quash charges of refusal to bargain against the United Mine Workers of America.
The text of the address made last night by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey at St. Paul, Minn., as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was as follows:

Lee Sala, Pittsburgh middleweight, made his New York debut last night and gained a split decision over Reuben Jones of Norfolk, Va., in the feature bout often rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena. It was the Smoky City boxer's forty-third triumph in a row.

Hides futures prices advanced 60 to 107 points in sharply increased trading yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Of the 168 lots traded, 104 representing 4,160,000 pounds, were in the near-by December delivery.

To increase its reserves of low volatile coal required for the production of steel-making coke, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation has executed two transactions giving it an additional 36,400 acres of coal properties, E. C. Grace, chairman of the nation's second largest steel company, announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 -Shipowners met again today with Allan Haywood, national CIO vice president, in an effort to find a basis for reopening negotiations in the forty-four-day-old maritime strike.

The five-story blockfront building at 2200 Powell Avenue and 2103 Haviland Avenue, the Bronx, containing sixteen stores and 127 apartments, has been resold by Frank Slater, operator, to the Chalman Realty Corporation. The property, on a plot 201 by 180 feet, is assessed at $430,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct 15 -- Clarence Doser, the Metropolitan P.G.A. titleholder, paired with Wilson Barnes Jr., Scarsdale Golf Club champion, to win the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur oneday tournament at the Metropolis Country Club today.

THE TIMES has repeatedly indicated a thorough understanding of the principles of sound public finance, of local fiscal problems and of state-local fiscal relationships. THE TIMES has been equally fair in its news articles and editorial comment upon these important subjects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said today he had notified the British and French Foreign Ministers this week that he would insist on retention in Western Germany of certain industrial plants already marked for reparations, if a committee of American industrialists found them needed for general European recovery.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- A vigorous plea for disarmament is made today by the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano in an editorial by its editor, Count Guiseppe Dalla Torre. The ancient Roman aphorism, "If you want peace prepare for war," he says, has been the source of countless disasters and should be replaced by "If you want peace prepare for peace."
Bagoe's Pharmacy -- an integral part of old Madison Square since 1859 -- will close its doors today for the last time.

Paul Pleet, president of the Franklin Hosiery Mills, has purchased the three-story building at the corner of Main and Division Street, New Rochelle, Westchester County, from Nathan Leon Cohen through H. E. Colwell Sons, Inc., brokers.

Many of the autumnal vegetables now being featured in stores are especially good when stuffed. Cabbage, green peppers, onions, squash and eggplant, being harvested in abundance, are the varieties best suited to this treatment. The United States Department of Agriculture urges housewives to present them often while they are comparatively low in cost.

If the Giants with the toss and elect to receive the opening kickoff at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, where the champion Chicago Cardinals will help raise the season's curtain, Chuck Conerly will be in the starting line-up of the New Yorkers.

Undeterred by a sampling of prison life, Stuart Zane Perkoff, an 18-year-old actor, pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to an indictment accusing him of failure to register for the draft. The charge is a felony carrying a maximum penalty of five years in prison, a $10,000 fine, or both.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 15 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey called tonight for a "vital, realistic" foreign policy as a cornerstone of abundance and prosperity for the country's farmers.
PARIS, Oct. 15 -- In a challenge put directly to the Soviet delegation, the United States asked the Russians today to show good faith by withdrawing their "fifth column" from friendly nations.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said today that President Truman was trying to run against the Eightieth Congress, but he could not do that because "he has to run against Mr. Dewey."

Local 1250 of the Department Store Employes Union, independent, faced its third court action yesterday when the union and five persons affiliated with it were accused of criminal contempt before Supreme Court Justice Bernard Dineen and a jury.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 15 -- For the first ten miles out of New York, the proposed increases in commuter fares sought by the Central Railroad of New Jersey would be higher than regular coach fares, Corwin E. Dick of William Wyer Co., railroad consultants, conceded today during his crossexamination at the joint hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission and the State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 -Another film dealing with jet aviation, which is already a subject of cinematic competition between Paramount and RKO, has been announced by Matty Kemp and Gene Raymond, independent producers for Eagle Lion.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- City Manager Thomas C. Kennedy submitted tonight to the Common Council a proposed 1949 budget of $17,207,156. It is out of balance by $975,000 and Mr. Kennedy conceded that it could be brought into line only by the imposition of "nuisance taxes" if expenses were not pared further.

Acceptance of a wage offer that will cost the Long Lines Division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company about $4,250,000 a year was announced yesterday by the company and the American Union of Telephone Workers, CIO.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 15 -- Governor Dewey departed from his prepared text tonight to reply to former Secretary Hull. The change, as given out by the Governor's press representative, read as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The first eight women officers to enter the Regular Navy under the Women's Armed Services Integration Act of 1948 received commissions today from Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan.

Directors of the American Stove Company took no action yesterday on the dividend usually due at this time. Action, it was stated, will be considered at the January meeting. Shareholders received 40 cents each in February, May and August, this year.

Arnold Eidus is a young American violinist who made a mark as the winner of the Jacques Thibaud International Competition two winters ago. Last night he gave a recital at Carnegie Hall, a technically satisfactory performance, but musically only moderately rewarding.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- Between 1,600 and 1,800 Italian employes of six United States film renting companies called a strike today. The walkout will begin on an unspecified day next week unless an agreement is reached. The companies involved are RKO, M-G-M, Twentieth Century, Warner, and Universal Paramount.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Europe's progress toward economic recovery will make possible a significant cut in the $5,300,000,000 appropriated for the purpose this year, Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman indicated today.
Cotton futures closed 2 points higher to 6 points lower yesterday as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange quieted down after the October position expired at noon.

In your Sept. 27 edition there appeared an editorial entitled "A School S.O.S," referring to conditions at Public School 114, Queens. The editorial was apparently based on the statements made at the previous meeting of the Board of Education.

Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Commissioner of Health, declared yesterday that a shortage of professional and non-professional workers was keeping vital health services from many communities in New York and the rest of the country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Registration statements covering $60,000,000 of debentures and 835,158 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.
Denver, Col., School District 1 announced yesterday that it will receive bids Oct. 27 for $21,000,000 of bonds dated Nov. 1, 1948, due from Oct. 1, 1949 to 1967, and callable on Oct. 1, 1958.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 15 (UP) -- Mrs. Mildred Didrikson Zaharias of Denver and Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth won their semi-final matches today in the Texas women's open golf tournament and will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 15 -Members of Larchmont Yacht Club wondered whether any club, at least along this side of the Atlantic, ever had won so many cups and trophies over a year. So tonight there was a "Dinner of Champions" for all hands.

ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 15 -More than 2,500 persons gathered today for the inauguration of John Mason Kemper, graduate of the United States Military Academy in 1935, as the eleventh headmaster of the 170-year-old Phillips Academy.
A 36-year-old laborer with a record of nine arrests and five convictions was charged yesterday with felonious assault in the mugging of a 20-year-old woman on Oct. 8 on a Brooklyn street.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Leon A. Chapin, a dairy farmer of North Bangor, N.Y., was elected today president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, succeeding the late Harry H. Rathbun of New Hartford, N.Y.
GLENDALE, Calif., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Skip Alexander of Lexington, N.C., fired a seven-under-par 65 today and moved into the lead at the halfway mark of the $15,000 Glendale Open golf tournament.
ON THE DEWEY TRAIN, ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 15 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey came into Minnesota today beaming with confidence, but the local party agents and certain free-arm citizens cooled him off a bit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -The National Military Establishment said today its proposal to compile a new list of accredited reporters was intended to expedite the issuance of such credentials if they were needed in a hurry.

A versatile wallpaper is a design called "Fresco" that Inez Croom introduced yesterday in a choice of nineteen color versions. It was among new papers and fabrics shown by Arthur H. Lee Sons, Inc., at its showroom for decorators, 501 Madison Avenue.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Leaders of non-Communist French labor federations, including Leon Jouhaux, head of the Workers Force, have privately advised United States officials that if Spain is admitted to participation in the European Recovery Program they will have to withdraw their support from the Marshall Plan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- At least five former sales executives of the Tucker Corporation have been questioned by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, it was learned here today. The questioning dealt with promises made in writing by Preston Tucker and by his corporation concerning the delivery of Tucker Torpedo automobiles to dealers throughout the country.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Mrs. De Witt Alexandre of Somerset Hills and Emery Thomas of the Forest Hill Field Club won low gross honors in the Women's New Jersey pro-lady best-ball handicap tournament at the Essex County Country Club today.

In the first move of its kind by an Argentine organization, Tonsa S.A., large chain of shoe and accessory stores in Buenos Aires, will enter the United States next spring with a store to be opened at 56 West Fifty-seventh Street, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Former Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared in a statement today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's claim to have initiated through a proposal to him four years ago the bipartisan foreign policy was "incorrect."

A shortened version of "Mourning Becomes Electra," with Rosalind Russell, Raymond Massey, Michael Redgrave and Katina Paxinou, will start its first continuous -run, popular-priced engagement here today at the Mayfair. . . .

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Dr. Priscilla White, authority on diabetes from Joslin Clinic, Boston, described at a Science Service luncheon here today the as yet unpublished five-minute, mass-detection method for that disease, which she hopes will be available for wide demonstration soon.

Before Casey Stengel, new Yankee manager, left for the Pacific Coast last night after a final conference with General Manager George Weiss, a clarification of the status of Coach Charley (Chuck) Dressen came from the Bombers' front office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's expressed views on the future control of atomic energy would make "utterly impossible" any international regulation of the atomic bomb, Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut asserted today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 15 -- Drastic import restrictions imposed by decree issued by the Junta Government this morning have thrown Costa Rican business circles into near panic. The decree imposes a 50 per cent tax in the c. i. f value of goods, added to existing duties, for "luxury" merchandise, and a similar 30 per cent tax on semi-luxury goods.
BERLIN, Oct. 15 -- The Western powers in Berlin tonight announced ration increases that will raise the average value of the daily ration in their sectors of the city by 15 per cent to 2,000 calories.
MOSCOW, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Council of Ministers reported today universal over-fulfillment of the production plan for the first nine months of 1948. The 1940 prewar level was exceeded by 14 per cent.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- The European Council for the Marshall Plan expects to meet tomorrow under the chairmanship of Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium for formal submission to W. Averell Harriman, ambassador at large for the Marshall Plan, of estimates for the first year of the European Recovery Program.

The percentage increase in Soviet production as a whole reported from Moscow would indicate that the Russians valued Soviet industrial production for the first nine months of this year at 118,500,000,000 rubles in 1926-27 prices. Dr. Harry Schwartz, a specialist in Soviet economics, calculated yesterday.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 15 (AP) -- The University of Delaware turned back a rugged Bucknell University eleven before 8,000 fans tonight, 7 to 0.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Gen. Anastasio Somoza, Nicaragua's Minister of War, declared today that Cuba, Costa Rica, Guatemala and Venezuela were conniving to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The British Union of Navigators and Engineer Officers is considering boycotting ships of Panamanian registry, an official of the union said today.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 -- An Oak Ridge engineer, David M. Poole, reported today that the theory of an atom-driven airplane was 99 per cent perfected.

In the hardware trade, advance buying and "lay-aways" for Christmas delivery are from three to four times the quantities of last year, A. E. Meurer, proprietor of A A Hardware Company, Cranford, N.J., disclosed during a canvass of hardware merchants attending the third National Hardware Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday.
Distribution of beer by eight major producers in New York's $1,000,000-a-day brewing industry was cut off completely yesterday by a spreading wildcat strike of 2,800 drivers that began on Thursday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Dr. Karl T. Compton said tonight that "really serious danger" would result if public suspicion lowered the morale of scientists working for the Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Joseph E. Jacobs received a recess appointment today as Ambassador to Czechoslovakia. He succeeded Laurence A. Steinhardt, who was recently appointed Ambassador to Canada.
ALBANY, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Real estate was the most popular field for new businesses in New York State during September.

The freedom of the American people, which is the basic foundation of all of this country's institutions, is under serious threat from communism, Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, declared last night.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Six small girls have heard their own names clearly for the first time -thanks to a new sound device and an anonymous donor.

Still popular after a year's road tour through the forty-eight states before an audience estimated at 3,000,000, the Freedom Train will have a return engagement in the New York area from Thanksgiving Day through New Year's Day.

A two-volume history of Beadle Adams, the New York publishing house of dime novels, will be brought out in the spring by the University of Oklahoma Press. It has been written by Albert Johannsen, Professor Emeritus of Petrology at the University of Chicago, who worked on the compilation of the edition for fifteen years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 15 -- Republicans have been too busy playing "political checkers" to pay any attention to runaway prices, President Truman declared tonight as he warned that current inflation, if uncurbed, would lead the nation down the road to depression.

Retail trade here this week made a fair gain despite a religious holiday that had a slightly depressing effect on business. Department store sales were estimated as about 8 per cent over the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were up 10 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 -- Jean Anouilh's continental success, "Eurydice," a modern drama paralleling the Greek myth of Orpheus and Eurydice, had its American premiere at the Coronet here last night.

EASY to read, full of hilarious action, LeGrand's stories have a way of converting even reluctant young readers to literature. They are even, in a quietly deceptive way, informational, but that never spoils the gusty fun. In "Cats for Kansas" he retells for 5 to 10 year olds a choice bit of American folklore, of how old Gabe Slade brought a crateful of kittens into Kansas to brighten the hearths of his pioneer neighbors.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 16 -- The season during which the Midwest shows off its bumper crops, its sleek livestock and its intelligent farm youngsters is drawing toward a close. The conversational emphasis in rural areas and cities alike is on baby beef as strongly as it is on corn and wheat.

Scoring two touchdowns in the second half, City College's football team registered its first victory of the season last night, beating Lowell Textile Institute by 13 to 0 in Lewisohn Stadium before 3,200 spectators.

KALART led the accessories field at the Cleveland Trade Show with a new-type 3 1/4 by 4 1/4 double-sheet film holder. The first accessory made available for the Kalart camera, the holder is a foolproof device designed to prevent accidental withdrawal of the holder from the camera and featuring a new method of loading sheet film.

A 4 by 5 daylight developing tank for processing color film and color prints at home and using vane-type agitation was a feature of the Cleveland Photographic Trade Show last week. Patterned after professional models, the Kolormatic, introduced by Stapp Thrush Manufacturing Company, Inc., Oklahoma City, costs $29.50.

Efforts for peace are "being defeated by a group of men whose primary consideration is personal power" and "our greatest hope for final victory" lies in the schools, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, declared here yesterday.

Air Force and Navy Bureau of Aeronautics officers have been hard at work behind the scenes with engineers from the aeronautical industry perfecting the complicated job of military aircraft manufacture. A case in point is the new series of standards developed by the Society of Automotive Engineers at the request of the joint Army and Navy Aeronautical Standards Group for such parts as engine and propellor nuts and bolts.

Bernard Baruch and Governor Dewey were announced yesterday as the speakers scheduled to open and close the 1948 New York Herald Tribune Forum. Four sessions are to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel -- tomorrow night, Tuesday afternoon and evening, and Wednesday night.

The price of steel, a pivotal determinant in the price structure of a large segment of the nation's industry, is due for another substantial upward adjustment within the next few months unless costs take a sudden and unexpected turn downward, industry observers disclosed last week.

WE were quite upset last Sunday to read in your column a reference to the so-called "advance notification" that we're supposed to be giving contestants phoned on "Stop the Music." According to this charge, listeners who are to be telephoned are forewarned earlier on Sunday.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, who "wandered away" from his son's home in Bay Shore, L.I., at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, was found early today in a Lexington Avenue restaurant after a wide search by the police here and in several Long Island communities.
THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine has added a distinctively refreshing pen in the person ality of the versatile Tallulah Bankhead ("It's Not 'The Road' -- It's Detours").

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 16 -- Big fall sales in most department stores showed up sharply in dollar volume of sales, the Ninth District Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis showed in its report this week. Sales volume in four major cities climbed five points in the index for the four-week period ending Oct. 9.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 16 -- This region turned its attention from the bitterly debated political picture and devoted its main interests to harvest time.
In typical slow Saturday trading, stocks improved selectively in yesterday's two-hour session, closing irregularly higher for the day and generally higher on the week.

The southpaw passing of Halfback Irving Zirulnick highlighted the 18-7 triumph that Far Rockaway High scored over John Adams in football yesterday on the winner's gridiron. The home team ace flipped a 14-yard aerial to George Colton and a 37-yard pass to Bill Howe, both in the end zone, for the first-period touchdowns.
The United Nations Security Council moved closer last week to a decision on the most explosive question in the world today -- the question of the future of Germany.

ON a high plateau in the Colorado desert country 125 miles southeast of Hollywood there has lately emerged out of the sand and sage a unique village, Pioneertown, built to serve primarily as a movie set and now being developed as a permanent film-making site.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 16 -- Pre-election predictions are more difficult to make in this state this year than in any of those in the South that have threatened to break with the national Democratic party.

WITH today's great emphasis on economy, now would hardly seem the time for a pair of low-budget producers to step into the million-dollar field, but that is exactly what the erstwhile quickie firm of Pine-Thomas is doing. Actually, the move makes a great deal of sense.

IT has remained for the folks on The Daily News, of all people, to come up with television's most chichi offering. The item in question is Gloria Swanson's hour on WPIX (8 P.M. Thursday) and the elegance of the presentation is almost overwhelming.

THERE can be little quarrel with the statement of Robert Considine in his introduction to this work that "the U.S.S.R. and its direct effect on the peace and welfare of the United States and on the free peoples of the world is the most imperative problem confronting mankind today."
The old wooden sidewheel ferryboat Charles W. Galloway made her final passenger trip early yesterday morning across Staten Island Sound between Perth Amboy, N.J., and Tottenville, S.I.

When 30-year-old Ken Boen isn't wrestling with steers, he's wrestling with airplane time tables -- and thereby hangs the tale of a cowboy who is commuting twice weekly between the World's Championship Rodeo at Madison Square Garden and the Roy Roger's Rodeo at the Chicago Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- President Truman confidently predicted that there would be a lot of startled poll-takers on Nov. 3 as he returned to the White House late today from a 3,500-mile campaign swing through the Midwest that took him into six key states in as many days.

WITH DEWEY CAMPAIGN TRAIN IN MICHIGAN, Oct. 16 -- The nonpartisan American foreign policy may be working all right at the Palais de Chaillot in Paris but it is having a rugged time here in the front-porch country.

A series of lectures on the "Development of the Sciences" has been inaugurated by Yale University to bring together "the sciences and the humanities in the college curriculum and to emphasize the contribution of the sciences to liberal education." The program will feature a lecture each month, concluding in May.

FOR THIS WEEK: Prepare the soil for planting flew rose bushes, and allow to settle until they are delivered next month. . . . To naturalize bulbs effectively, scatter them by the handful and plant wherever they fall. . . . Move chrysanthemums in flower but, to avoid wilting, water them thoroughly before and after planting. . . . Gather from the plants and the ground any grapes or peaches that are diseased.
An alleged housing racket that was reported to have been operated in three states was believed smashed yesterday after a suspect in the home-building frauds had been seized in Connecticut.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Minnesota fumbled away all but one of its scoring chances today but that unmuffed opportunity was enough to give the Gophers a 6 to 0 Big Nine football triumph over fighting Illinois.

The high level of large store operating costs combined with a greatly increased "break-even" point make it inevitable that efforts will be made in the near future to develop retail outlets with lower overhead, Dr. Paul C. Olsen, director of research for the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, Inc., predicted here last week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Service unity, the subject of much high-level discussion in Washington, is a subject of low-level action far from the District line.

Early diagnosis and lifelong treatment offer the only hope of preventing blindness in glaucoma, authorities agreed recently before the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology. Glaucoma is responsible for about 30,000 of the 250,000 cases of total blindness in the United States.

WHEN Central High was closed its famous backfield was scattered to four different schools in the same city. Instead of winning a football championship for Central, as they had hoped, each found himself competing against his former mates and handicapped by having to develop a loyalty to a new school with different traditions.
TULSA, Okla., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Georgetown's Hoyas struck with two perfect fourth-quarter pass plays today to whip Tulsa's Golden Hurricane, 13 -- 7, and register their first triumph of the season.

Former associates in the United Nations and the Norwegian Navy joined in final tribute yesterday to Ole Helge Bakke, 29-year-old member of the United Nations guard detachment in Palestine who was killed while on duty in the Mount Scopus area of Jerusalem last July 13.

FOR many years now, parents of young children have been made aware, by books, pamphlets and lectures, that the child needs affection and love as much if not more than he needs his cod liver oil and vitamin C. In fact, studies have shown that, with out the security of closeness and warmth, vitamins and a balanced diet alone may fail to produce a healthy youngster.

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Dr. Fred Garrigus Holloway was installed today as the seventh president of Drew University since its founding in 1867. Nine hundred persons, including delegates from 132 American and Canadian institutions, watched the ceremony.
BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 16 -Bowdoin uncovered a passing attack to go with its powerful ground game and rolled over a bewildered Williams team, 34 -- 0, before 5,000 spectators at Whittier Field today.

There have been few Presidential campaigns in American history which have left the public as apathetic as that which will close two weeks from tomorrow night. This may be because most of the voters made up their minds long ago, or it may be because many of them simply don't care.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Wheat bogged down today on the Board of Trade in an attempt to carry its advance through with yesterday's strength. Prices were steady at the start, but selling pressure increased and the broad cereal fell back. Losses were small, however.

Opening ceremonies for United Nations Week will be held from 2:30 to 5 o'clock this afternoon at the lower plaza in Rockefeller Center. NBC broadcasts from Paris by Ambassador Warren R. Austin and in this city by George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State, and Clarence Francis, United Nations Week national chairman, will be featured.

As a native of "traditionally isolationist Minnesota," I was particularly delighted in Max Beloff's article, "The Real Purpose of the University." Mr. Beloff implies that, despite the increasing demand for mass education as a means for training more specialists for our intricate, machine-like society, the university is recapturing its original function as "a learned society."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Democratic National Committee today published the records of a unit of the Veterans of Foreign Wars as purporting to show that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey made disparaging remarks about Civil Service employes at a meeting, last spring, with veterans.

It is well that the situation of Hyderabad has been kept upon the agenda of the United Nations. Whatever the outcome of the victory of the Union of India and the future form of government, the fact remains that Hyderabad was invaded and vanquished by military force.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Tennessee thrilled a record-breaking homecoming crowd of 48,000 today by coming out of the doldrums and smashing Alabama, 21 to 6.
MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 16 -- Big Mike, a 9-year-old gelding owned by Bliss Flaccus, won the feature race today at the eighty-ninth annual fall meeting of the Rose Tree Hunt Club.

THE forces that Berlioz required for his Requiem were gigantic when he wrote the work in 1837, and even today, when large performing groups are not unexpected, his requirements could not be met by the average musical organization without considerable effort.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 16 -- The Republican drift in the New Jersey election campaign is continuing, with the Democratic high command in Jersey City failing to show the old aggressive spirit.

Seeking to hold ground in their fight to make the written contract a standard procedure in the purchase of finished rayon goods, New York fabric suppliers last week disclosed that they were intensifying their campaign to get a mandatory provision for signed orders into their trade practice rules.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- In the economics field, at least, the prophet of gloom are being put to flight. Words like depression and recession are attaining the status of blasphemy. Much of the post-war jitters seems to have evaporated, and only the most timid diagnosticians still have their fingers crossed.

As I look over Lili Rethi's drawings of the vast plant that will be the United Nations here in Manhattan ("Building a Great Workshop of Peace"), it occurs to me that the whole thing is in very poor taste. I don't mean the drawings -they're excellent -- but the idea of spending $65,000,000 to provide an elaborate meeting place for people who represent countries, many of which are war-devastated and in ruins.

With the first section of the Economic Cooperation Administration program covering subsistence items now assuming lesser importance foreign traders here last wek hailed the "second phase" of ECA activities, which they believe will come closer to the heart of the European recovery problem.

A CURRENT conflict in food circles concerns nutritiousness versus deliciousness. Can the good-for-you foods also be good to eat? Would Americans rather be told, "It's nourishing," or "It's delectable"? Is eating a science or an art?

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 16 -- With few exceptions, committee work on the drafting of the separate articles of the new Western German Constitution is being finished today at Bonn. The preamble has also been drafted in committee.
RENSSELAER, Ind., Oct. 16 -Gov. Thomas E. Dewey wound up his Midwestern campaign trip today with a 150-mile detour which indicated what he is really worrying about.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Those who have been inclined to write off the British Commonwealth as a moribund and outmoded conception must have been surprised this week when the Prime Ministers from the nine member states convened in London for what Prime Minister Attlee called "a family gathering."
THE National Chrysanthemum Society and the New York Botanical Garden will hold their fourth annual hardy chrysanthemum display and program at the Botanical Garden on Friday, Saturday and next Sunday.

Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, sounded an optimistic note on Friday when he indicated that Europe was making so much progress toward economic recovery that there might be what was described as "a significant cut" in ECA appropriations.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 16 -Taking charge in the first three minutes of play, Cornell's Big Red team scored its fourth straight triumph today, conquering a hardfighting and at times brilliant Syracuse eleven before 33,000 at Archbold Stadium. The score was 34 -- 7.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The Soviet Union seventeen days ago advised foreign missions in Moscow of new travel restrictions that further limited foreigners' movements from the capital. Western areas were among those specifically covered by the ban.

The recent assault of President Truman against Wall Street and the "gluttons for privilege" has served only to focus attention on the individuals who go to make up the financial districts of the various centers of the United States.

THOMAS JEFFERSON, our greatest philosopher-statesman, possessed an enviable capacity for absorbing knowledge from almost every field. His tireless curiosity to learn was never marred by the jealous possessiveness that afflicts the general run of the tribe of scholars.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The War Assets Administration and the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation signed the final lease today for the Government-owned blast furnace at Cleveland.

THE Children's World Theatre, which had a highly successful inaugural season here last year, will open its 1948-49 series of presentations at the Barbizon-Plaza Saturday with "King Midas and the Golden Touch."

OF the million and a half Americans who will take some active part in the competitive dog game this year about 300,000 will be novices; each the hopeful owner of his first purebred dog. It would be kindly toward them and humane toward their dogs if every breeder who sells a dog to a newcomer to the fancy could provide, along with the dog's "papers," a copy of Mrs. Larson's book.

Wallace Teed, M.D., of Ann Arbor, Mich., disposes of the old idea that the cold victim's normal attempt to get relief causes ear infection by forcing bacteria, or virus-laden material, into the tube connecting the ear and throat.

THIS is certainly one of Mrs. Mitchison's most successful historical novels. It takes place in Rome about A.D. 64, when the old patriots talked of rebellion, when a great section of the city burned (and Nero fiddled), and when the vulgar mob was entertained by the spectacles in the Circus Maximus.

THE selections in this volume include thirteen short stories, excerpts from "The House of Seven Gables," "The Marble Faun," "The Dolliver Romance," pages from Hawthorne's journals, a collection of his letters, and "The Scarlet Letter" in full.

Economists, resembling so many Kafka protagonists, are peculiarly afflicted with the anxious realization that reliable facts seem forever to elude them.

JERRY WALD, Warner Brothers' producer of all work, is not a leisurely operator. He has completed six pictures in the last year and is now supervising two more which are before the cameras. In addition, he has half a dozen projects on which writers have turned in completed scenarios.

In his article "That Midwest Power -- the Farmer's Wife," about farm wives' new leisure and how they spend it discussing world affairs, David Dempsey has hit on something big. There is a trend here the politicians had better watch.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Irving M. Engel, chairman of the administrative and immigration committees of the American Jewish Committee, opening a two-day conference of the executive branch of the AJC here today, called for immediate amendments to the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 "to eliminate its discriminating features."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- President Truman ordered the nation's military reserves immediately brought up to "appropriate strength and maximum effectiveness" today, but promptly assured the country that this sudden move did not mean the world situation had worsened.

Kennedy, in which he stated that the Memoirs of Winston Churchill "are replete with serious inaccuracies on the basis of which judgments are made that are unfair to individuals and events." It would be easy to disregard such comment from such a source were it not for a subsequent statement in the same letter, viz.:

AMERICAN cussing, according to the learned and witty Dr. Burges Johnson, who has made a well-documented study of it, has fallen on evil days. The strongest words in our vocabulary of malediction, imprecation and insult, have become, because of their relentless use by people of small talent who have little business using them, watery and innocuous.

The Brooklyn College Kingsmen defeated a fighting Wagner College football team yesterday at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, 20 -- 0, before 3,500 fans. It was the third victory in four games for Brooklyn and the first time the injury-ridden Wagner squad was shut out.

ONE of the best and easiest winter-flowering house plants in my opinion is Eucharis grandiflora, otherwise known as Amazon lily. Flowering mainly from January to March, the blooms -- like giant narcissus -- are borne in four or five clusters on straight stems.

Edward Crankshaw's article on Stalin ("The Man Who Holds the Key to War or Peace") leaves much to be desired. Both the Stalinist regime and Stalin personally are misrepresented in a dangerous direction.

SUCHOW, China, Oct. 16 -- More than 300,000 nationalists, including four first line army groups, have been concentrated in this area to handle an expected Communist offensive south across the lateral Lung-Hai railway within the next six weeks.

DON'T look now, anybody, but one of those most embarrassing things that occasionally happen in the movies as the consequence of a reckless whim is being unblushingly exhibited on the screen of the Music Hall.

DID somebody say something about a slump in dance activity? The schedule seems not to have heard the rumor. Ram Gopal and his Hindu company have canceled their scheduled return engagement, but otherwise things are humming.

THIS book does two things. First, as an account of Confucius' life it helps rectify the apparent popular vulgarization of the great teacher by the West. Second, it shows the importance of Confucianism in China's past, which is essential to an understanding of China's present.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 16 -A bronze statue of the late Man o' War was unveiled without ado today at near-by Faraway Farm.

TOKYO, Oct. 16 -- Japan, after three years of Allied occupation, has reached a turning point with a swing back toward free enterprise under a more conservative and more experienced type of political leadership.
KENT, Conn., Oct. 16 -- A few hundred city folks, most of them strangers to corn without butter, learned tonight why the corn-husking bee probably will outlast the double feature.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 (AP) -The Pitt Panthers rewrote the script between halves today and turned a drab football game into a spectacular scoring story which gave them a 21-7 victory over Marquette University. It was the first time since 1945 the Pitt has won two in a row.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 16 -- Iowa Republicans are prepared today for a victory harvest as big as the bumper corn crop now being gathered in the fields.

AGAINST the dark green, bronze and brown of autumn foliage, chrysanthemums produce one of the most dazzling displays of the garden year. Although some varieties start to flower as early as July, the majority of them are timed for a stunning climax in October.

Protein hydrolysate therapy, also known as amino-acid diet because all protein is built up from amino acids, is a comparatively new treatment for peptic ulcer. It has been developed by Dr. Frank Co Tui of the New York University College of Medicine and the New York University Division of Surgery, Bellevue Hospital, New York, and his associates.

The organizational structure of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is slated for radical revision, altering and possibly even eliminating the board of directors, it was learned yesterday. Elimination of the board, together with its body of alternate members, and secretarial staffs would result in an annual saving to the bank of more than half a million dollars.

What schoolboy trudging off to his classes of a bright October morning but has groaned at the thought that in his English class that day he will be forced to struggle again with the un-familiar cadences of one of Shakespeare's plays? Lines written for the ear come heavy to the schoolboy's eye and unless the teacher is more gifted than most of us are the classroom presentation becomes something to be endured instead of enjoyed.

LAURENCE OLIVIER'S "Hamlet" offers such a "grand experience," to quote Mr. Crowther, that unfavorable comment on any aspect of the production is to be made only with humility. It is in this spirit that I write deploring a certain lapse from Shakespeare and, in my opinion, from fitness.

George R. Hinman, member of the New York and Manhasset Bay Yacht Clubs, has been nominated to become president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound. It is tantamount to election. That will be held on Oct. 27.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- First place Portsmouth and runner-up Derby maintained their unbeaten records in the first division of the English Football League today, while Hull of the third division suffered its first defeat.

Retail activity here last week was stimulated by heavy Columbus Day business, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Sales of misses' and women's coats and suits, the survey indicated, increased sharply.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 16 -More than 3,500 boy scouts, sea scouts and members of scout bands took part this afternoon on the twenty-ninth annual pilgrimage to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Youngs Memorial Cemetery.

WHAT is the insidious nature of New England that makes nearly everyone writing about it sound like St. Nicholas' Magazine? "Rock Haven" is about two brothers, one good and ever so self-effacing, and the other naughty and pushing.

The summary of tax-reform proposals presented before the Investment Counsel Association of America last week by John Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, is regarded in financial circles as a timely contribution to current discussions of problems of the formation of private capital here and abroad.

HAVING left the Shubert Theatre last night, "High Button Shoes" opens at the Broadway tomorrow. Along with the move there is going to be an announcement that the production will give Sunday performances, that the top-price tickets will drop from the previous $6 to $4.80 (except Friday and Saturday) and that the rest of the house will be scaled proportionately downward.

WHEN his mother dies suddenly 11-year-old Mark is left alone and a stranger in a small Arizona town. But the Sheriff finds a home for him on the ranch owned by Mr. Langford, whose wife and son have been killed in an auto accident.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 16 (AP) -- The California Bears opened their bid for the Pacific Coast Conference championship today with a 42-to-0 victory over the Oregon State Beavers.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Poland told a United Nations group today that President Truman was a prisoner in the hands of "a military clique" that had prevented him from sending Chief Justice Vinson to see Premier Stalin.

Attacks upon the capital gains tax, with a viewto its elimination or to ease its impact, have brought varying reactions over the years. Such reactions, however, have resulted only in attempts to mitigate its effect, not to repeal it.

WHAT has gradually become the big fall apparelselling day, Columbus Day, registered results in this area which were called "quite satisfactory" by local merchants. It was estimated that business volume ran about 10 per cent over last year for the first two days of the week.

CLEVELAND -- Although highlighted by display items in the upper price brackets, the twenty-fourth annual convention and trade show of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association here last week revealed a genuine attempt by manufacturers to meet the demand four lower prices.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- The Western powers intend to retain supervision of the principal agencies dealing with the democratization of the people of Western Germany, when a Western German state is established. According to Joseph A. Panuch, head of the United States committee that is now planning the tri-partite military government for the Western German state, there is no intention of withdrawing control of the agencies considered vital to the political health of Germany.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 16 -Fordham University's eleven routed St. Francis College, 41 -- 0, for its second victory of the season today. The Rams scored once in each of the first three periods and then completed the one-sided fray with three tallies in the final quarter.

THE problem of a minister who realizes suddenly he no longer believes in what he is preaching furnishes the main theme for Martha Cheavens' novel, "Crosswinds." Miss Cheavens poses a stark enough dilemma for her hero, but she takes care to avoid coming to grips with reality from that point on.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Ohio State's Buckeyes ran over and around Indiana's linemen today in a 17-0 victory. The loss knocked the Hoosiers out of a tie for first place in the Western Conference.

Many members of society have subscribed to the sixtieth National Horse Show, which will open at Madison Square Garden on Election Day, Nov. 2. All boxes have been reserved for the performances of the country's pre-eminent show ring exhibition, which will maintain a run of eight days.

DALTON, Ga., Oct. 16 -- Charging that "the huge modern monopoly corporation" was keeping the "South divided against itself," Henry A. Wallace, Presidential candidate of the Progressive party, declared here today in a campaign speech that the "South will never rise out of peonage to the North" until the wage differential between the two sections of the country is wiped out.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Illinois Republicans today are favored to retain their Senate seat, but whether they can maintain their current twenty-to-six advantage in the House of Representatives depends on how well Gov. Thomas E. Dewey runs in populous Cook County.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 16 (AP) -Senator Alben W. Barkley flew into the deep South today with a bid to rebelling Southern Democrats to re-establish their "friendship and partnership" with the Democratic party.

WITH the best will in the world it's difficult to credit the recent discovery of Haitian popular painting as revealed in the current Haitian Art Center show with anything more than passing importance.

THE prize-giving season is open. A fortnight ago Pepsi-Cola's bulging prize-purse made the news; today the Carnegie awards are discussed by our colleague in his customary corner; in two weeks the Chicago prizes will be announced.

The Devil, we know, can quote Scripture for his purpose. And scripture in the broad sense, not confined to Holy Writ, is what supplies us with most of our own quotations -- since it is the recorded word of the wise and the witty.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 16 -Daniel Murphy blocked a Gettysburg try for extra point in the waning minutes of the game to give Lehigh a 14-13 victory in a stirring battle before 8,000 Lehigh Dadsday falls today.

A four-year program in "expository writing and public speaking," designed to enable students to write and think clearly on technical subjects, has been introduced this fall at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, N.Y. The program is being tried in conjunction with the college's military and naval science curriculum and, if successful, will be expanded.

THE much-discussed "crisis in the French novel" has been underlined by the death of Georges Bernanos. The French, it is said, have a tendency to find crises under every bush and in every literary magazine -- the "crisis of language," the "crisis of commitment," the "crisis of poetry," etc.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- In a report of sixty-nine closely typed pages on the program for European recovery in the year between July 1, 1948, and July 1, 1949, made public today, the Organization for European Economic Cooperation gave due weight to the positive achievements that had been made and were slated to be made by the sixteen Marshall Plan nations, the Western zones of Germany and Trieste.

AT FIRST glance, nine supine months in a t.b. sanatorium, would hardly seem a fitting subject for humor. But Betty MacDonald, who wrote "The Egg and I" and apparently can extract more downright amusement out of a nasty experience than most people can corral from a trip to the circus, has a talent for making readers enjoy her past troubles as much as they would a session with a psychiatrist.
LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 16 -Notre Dame slammed 80 yards from the opening kickoff for a touchdown today, then buried Nebraska under a vicious onslaught for a 44-to-13 victory.

The six-day bicycle race will start tonight at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx, where eighteen teams will engage in the competition that will go on without interruption until 11 P.M. on Saturday night.
