New York's Secretary of State, Thomas J. Curran, is slated to fire the pistol-shot that will send the riders on their way at exactly 9 o'clock.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Arthur Horner, Communist general secretary of the National Union of Mineworkers, brought nearer today a showdown between the British trade unions and their Communist executives.

Rabbi Julius Mark, in a sermon in Temple Emanu-El, Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday described as "hysterical" the report of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting Mediator for Palestine, that held the Jewish authorities in Jerusalem responsible for negligence in the assassination of Count Folke Bernadette.

TWO days ago Dr. Karl T. Compton ended his term as president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a position he had held for the last eighteen years. He left to head the Research and Development Board of the National Military Establishment and direct the nation's largest peacetime military-research effort.

WHEN frosts nip the annuals, most gardeners dream of owning a greenhouse to continue their hobby in defiance of winter. Unfortunately, problems of installation and expense are too much for many potential winter gardeners. Yet the fun of growing flowers from November until May is open to almost everyone.

Many parties will be given at the annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services to be held on Oct. 26 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. Mrs. Ogden L. Mills is national president of the beneficiary, and Mrs. Donald B. Tansill heads the benefit committee.

LAST summer, when Margo Jones left Texas for Europe, she took only three dresses and toted her entire traveling wardrobe in a single suitcase. During her month abroad she bought no clothes. Not even three days in Paris could tempt the theatrical director. "Why, honey," she explained recently to a puzzled acquaintance, "there just wasn't any reason for a fancy get-up.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (UP) -Stanford's downtrodden Indians, mustering up memories of the era when they were the mightiest gridiron machine on the Pacific Coast, fought back in the second half today to score a terrific 34-to-14 upset victory over the University of California at Los Angeles.

AS a foreign, correspondent covering the Fascist sore-spots of Europe before the war, Pierre Van Paassen would startle critics with his dual capacity to describe the starkest of evils and imagine the best of possible world.

WEST POINT, Oct. 16 -- Five important long-term industrial advancements in national preparedness were revealed here today by spokesmen following the closed meeting last night of more than 40 leaders of industry and national officers of the American Ordnance Association attending the annual meeting of New York post directors at the Thayer Hotel.

THE last faint echoes of our war-time efforts to bring about a sudden understanding between North and South America have died away, leaving a small enough residuum of accomplishment, but the sound scholars go quietly along with their part of the work of revealing New World neighbors to each other.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- New England went into mourning over the World Series outcome this week. After the pain had passed and the mutter of "We shoulda won the last one" died down, a few other topics edged into conversations hitherto monopolized by baseball.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- This year's Presidential election in the United States lacks reality or interest for Europeans. With American foreign policy more or less agreed upon by the two major parties, the tendency is to regard it as a popularity contest in which Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has a decided edge, all mixed up with remote issues that can be of interest only to Americans.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 16 -- Only the fact that the French representatives under Maj. Gen. Robert Noiret, conferring here this morning with Generals Lucius D. Clay and Sir Brian Robertson accidentally left in Paris the English translation of a projected agreement on a merger of the bizonal Joint Export-Import Agency with its French zone equivalent prevented the signing of the document.
LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 16 (AP) -- The University of Virginia, led by John Papit, a Philadelphian, routed Washington and Lee's Generals 41 -- 6, today.

PANAMA, Oct. 16 -- The warnings by Gen. Anastasio L. Somoza, Nicaragua's "strong man," of an alleged plot of certain Latin-American Governments to overthrow the regime in Managua, may be designed to hide domestic trouble, according to some observers of the Central American political situation.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 16 -- During the half, a group of Dartmouth students, impersonating scantilyclad Indians, put to route four "warriors" bearing the sign "Red Raiders." And the game, the first between the Hanoverians and Colgate since 1942 followed much of this pattern with Dartmouth's football aggregation turning back the foe in a smashing 41-16 triumph.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Brown's slam-banging ball-carriers nursed most of their terrific power for a second-half drive that resulted in a 14-6 victory over Holy Cross today as the New England rivals observed the fiftieth anniversary of their football competition before 20,000 spectators.
C.B. Palmer's "That American Institution -- The Handyman" calls to mind a handyman who operated some years ago in Clifton Springs, N.Y.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 16 -- The Government of Israel rejected tonight a United Nations cease fire order and its troops in the Negeb pressed on with a widening offensive intended to break the Egyptians' control of land communications into Palestine's southern desert.

The brief good-will soccer tour of the team representing the new State of Israel will be concluded this afternoon at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, with a crack American League All-Star squad providing the opposition. A crowd of 25,000 is expected to be on hand as Borough President John Cashmore boots out the first ball at 2 o'clock.

MUSEUM directors, like chessmen, constantly move from here to there. Leslie Cheek, formerly with the Baltimore Museum, has been made new director of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, while Thomas C. Colt Jr., who resigned that post last spring, has just been appointed director of the Portland (Ore.) Museum.

Employing stevedore companies in New York have appealed to the Government to defer the imposition of higher longshore overtime costs pending further attempts to settle a dispute between workers and the companies, it became known yesterday.
New York's dwindling supply of beer was shut off further yesterday when drivers for a ninth important brewery walked off their jobs to join a wildcat strike that shows no signs of being settled.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 16 -People on the country's Northwestern Frontier are wondering why this autumn is seeing a hunting season of incomparably greater magnitude than ever before. Sporting goods stores are having difficulty keeping rifles and ammunition on their shelves.

THE Alamo is associated in the minds of millions of Americans with dauntless courage, heroic death, and the epic struggle for American sovereignty and freedom. Not so many know that it was originally a mission church built by Franciscan monks.

HERE is a thrilling happenstance which occurs very rarely in the formal concert hall. But it happened here in this strongly Welsh community the other night and where the Welsh are concerned anything musical might happen, and usually does.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 16 -The Moravian College eleven of Bethlehem, Pa., downed Hofstra, 21 -- 6, today. All the scores were made in the last period.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- It will take more than a United Nations decision, the Jewish Chronicle said today, to make Jewish refugees in Israel give up the homes they had occupied after hundreds of thousands of Arabs had fled from the territory of the new state.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- With the collapse of their efforts at the U.N. to get the United States and Russia to reach a compromise over Berlin, the smaller powers have raised the question of the fundamental aims of American policy toward Russia.

THREE-QUARTERS of a century ago Mr. Hedrick moved with his farmer-parents from Iowa to newly opened Indian lands at the northwestern tip of the lower Michigan peninsula. Even today the Little Traverse Bay region, or Land of the Crooked Tree, as the early Jesuit missionaries called it, is rather off the beaten track.

SPEAKING into a microphone is quite unlike speaking into a telephone, or speaking from a platform. It's as personal as an intimate face-to-face conversation. True, millions hear you, but they never think of themselves as part of an "audience."

ASARDONIC wag along Radio Row last week maintained that it was time for the Hooper organization to forget about comparing the popularity of comedians and to start concentrating on the relative popularity of the gags.

A grass roots survey conducted by the State CIO Political Action Committee throughout New York State indicates that Henry A. Wallace will receive fewer than 200,000 votes in next month's election, it was announced yesterday.

OF the making of guide-books there is no end -- but here is a guide-book with a real, instantly-felt difference. Mrs. MacIntyre's brief, information-packed text, spaced with excellent photographs, suggests the Washington tours she herself enjoyed, afoot and by car, the restaurants and recreations she preferred, the by-ways she found most colorful, the out-of-town visits that were most rewarding.

Brooklyn Tech's powerful football team continued in the ranks of the city's unbeaten by halting James Madison High, a borough foe, 20 to 6, in the feature clash of the schoolboy double-header at Ebbets Field last night. Adam Cirillo's Engineers registered their third triumph before 8,000 spectators.

An exhibit of 230 photographs by members of the American Society of Magazine Photographers opened yesterday with a variety of subjects ranging from news-type pictures to landscape studies. The exhibit will be open to the public through Oct. 30 at the Pepsi-Cola Center, Forty-seventh Street and Broadway.

ONE of the briefest and best of the current crop of war novels is this new book by the author of "Liana." Miss Gellhorn writes in a vigorous style, suggestive at many points of ex-husband called Ernest Hemingway.
The Presidential campaign of 1948 has two weeks to go.

The Negeb (the word means "dry or parched land") is the southern third of Palestine. Much of the Negeb's land, particularly in the northern section, is good. But only a few places in the Negeb have enough water for drinking purposes -- not to speak of crops. It has been the hope of Jews that the Negeb may be made fertile (by piping water from the Jordan) and capable of supporting a large population.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 16 -- A curious mixture of cockiness and jitters pervaded the atmosphere in this capital of Israel as the United Nations reopened the discussion of the Palestine problem this week. In Tel Aviv, at least, it is evident that the second truce now early three months old is wearing thin.

MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 16 -- After being held scoreless in the first period, Tufts College's football team capitalized on two second-quarter interceptions and rolled to its third consecutive victory by defeating Rochester University, 26 -- 7, before 4,000 at the Tufts Oval today.

IN the summer of 1924, in Provincetown, Mass., a young artist named Raymond Moore, who was not a particularly good artist, became interested in the theatre. He was 26 then, fond of painting, a lover of flowers, former teacher of English and botany, and a man who could dream.

The twenty-second annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States, which closed at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Friday night after a three-day meeting, was reminiscent of the club's wartime conventions in a number of ways.

ANYONE who has tried to explain to a youngster the why, how and where of a water system or of heating and lighting systems will admire the way in which the Schneiders, with the help of the illustrator Barbara Ivins, present material on these subjects.

DR. FREEMAN, whose position as our most eminent biographer and ablest military historian no one will dispute, has undertaken the writing in six volumes of our fullest life of Washington. But if the promise of these first thousand pages is sustained, he will give us something more important even than a great biography.
LENS, France, Oct. 16 -- A majority of the coal miners in this heart of the northern French coal area appears generally unenthusiastic about the current strike.

WHEN Lord Arthur Chester, a recent and personable bridegroom, about to embark on a diplomatic mission to Germany, rented half of a villa at Dulham for the accommodation of his wife during his absence and her lying-in, Lady Blanche could scarcely endure the thought of who might be the unendurable occupants of the other half.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Football's oldest jinx was banished today when Rutgers defeated Princeton, 22 -- 6, at Palmer Stadium. This was the first success for the Scarlet in the lair of the Tiger in the seventy-nineyear history of the rivalry that gave what has become known as the great autumnal madness its start in 1869.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 16 -- Mid-October of 1948 found the high cost of living still the greatest single concern in this area. Also, complex political issues have stirred conservative Virginians to unusual interest in the pre-election campaign.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was quiet. Final prices were unchanged to 4 points higher than on Friday.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Rebounding for a touchdown in each of the last two periods after a first half in which it never advanced as far as midfield, unbeaten North Carolina defeated North Carolina State, 14 -- 0, today before 44,000 fans.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Seeded teams had no trouble today as mixed doubles competition opened the seventh Pan-American Tennis tournament.

A tree-growing project for Brooklyn, representing that borough's share in the Citizens Golden Anniversary Planting Program sponsored by the Park Association of New York City, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Tracy S. Voorhees, chairman of the association's Brooklyn committee.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- By a combination of luck, Marshall aid and extremely astute financial hocus pocus, the highest British financial authorities believe they have got the pound sterling in a position where it can shortly appear before the world as a "strong" currency.

Dr. George W. Northup of Livingston, N.J., told the New York State Osteopathic Society yesterday that the American diet through the years has been an important factor in causing functional hypoglycemia (deficiency of blood sugar).

WASHINGTON -- Travelers across the Canadian or Mexican borders or on cruises to southern climes are welcoming a short, illustrated and simple pamphlet published by the Treasury Department with the goal of taking the mystery out of customs procedures.

PARIS, Oct 16 -- By a decree of the French Exchange Control that will be officially published tomorrow the exchange rate for the dollar for export and import transactions will be practically fixed at 262 francs, which is about the rate at which exporters have changed their dollars since January.
CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 16 -- Federal aid to education is essential to meet the crisis facing the nation's schools, Mrs. Margaret Chase Smith, Senator-elect from Maine, said here today.

NEW passenger cars of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, featuring innovations designed to bring added comfort to railroad travel, were put on exhibition last week. One car, known as the "Family Coach," provides facilities for family groups, with special attention to the traveling needs of children.

ISAAC LOEB PERETZ, a lawyer by profession, was a dominant intellectual force among Polish Jews, so pre-eminent and beloved a figure in their lives that 100,000 of his compatriots attended his funeral in 1915. Neither an assimilationist nor a Zionist, Peretz constantly exhorted his people to "combine the strongest and most wholesome Jewish values with the highest achievement of the present."
BLACKSBURG, Va., Oct. 16 (AP) -- The William and Mary Indians flashed more power than Virginia Tech has seen this season as they defeated the Gobblers, 30 -- 0, today.
Three factors assumed major significance in the men's clothing industry last week, following the 20 per cent price cut announced by Crawford Clothes on men's and boys' garments.

THE United States Army is now in the souvenir business, servicing municipalities seeking captured German or Japanese weapons as trophies. Its stock of martial mementos has already been heavily drawn upon by towns and cities wishing to add a touch of grim beauty to vacant plazas and court-house lawns.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 -- If signs mean anything Americans down this way appear to have shrugged off some of their "don't care" attitude on important public questions. There is a quickening in the public pulse as the election draws near but the most important developments are on the social and economic fronts.

MUCH of the confusion and conflict in our domestic scene today has its genesis, as we now recognize, in decisions made in Washington during the war and shortly thereafter, as we moved from a peacetime to a war economy and back again.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 16 -- Stanton Griffis, United States Ambassador to Egypt, said today: "The United States has been grossly negligent in handling the humanitarian aspect of the Palestine problem. Almost for the first time in history we failed in our responsibility toward human suffering."

FOR nigh onto thirty years -- or three-fifths of his lifetime -- Steve Owen has been a part of the football scene. He's known well those two imposters, success and failure, even though his acquaintance with the latter has been a trifle on the sketchy side. But the big fellow has been around long enough to have developed a very sane philosophy.

AN almost fantastic story -- too good to be true, yet perfectly authentic -- has come from England about Nicholas Medtner, who, it will be remembered, toured this country twice some twenty years ago playing his own compositions.

A NATIONAL political campaign, whether it be for a Presidential election every four years or for a Congressional by-election every two years, offers the reporter who goes up and down and across our vast and varied country an opportunity to sense the feeling of the people, to catch their mood of the moment.

John Meader, smooth-striding harrier from Nott Terrace High School of Schenectady, showed his heels to over 500 other runners yesterday to capture the twelfth annual New York University interscholastic cross-country run over the two-and-one-quarter-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park. On the strength of Meader's victory, the up-Staters also took team laurels with a low-point total of 71 to Bishop Loughlin's runner-up 212.

IT is nice to be able to welcome the young New York City Ballet Company to that group of civic-minded if not actually civic enterprises at the City Center which includes the New York City Opera Company, the New York City Symphony and the New York City Theatre Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today for the first time that striking employes may be permanently replaced and excluded from voting in a collective-bargaining election.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The five Finance Ministers of Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg will meet here tomorrow to discuss the problem of financing the armament of Western Europe.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 16 -A strange and perhaps very grave political crisis is developing slowly in Belgium over the question of the return of King Leopold. The Communists may soon find themselves in a position to determine the fate of the Government, and with it effective Belgian participation in the European Recovery Program and in Western European defense measures.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 16 -- Teenagers of THE NEW YORK TIMES Radio Youth Forum declared here today that the United Nations needs help if it is to achieve world peace.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 16 (AP) -Vanderbilt uncorked a sharpened offensive today and crashed the victory column for the first time with a comparatively easy 26-7 football victory over Kentucky's Wildcats.

A LITTLE over two years ago a young fellow off the sidewalks of New York and built like a college football hero made a quiet arrival in Hollywood. He had coffee and cake money in his pockets and one of those option contracts which might, or might not, set him on the road to stardom.
CLARKSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Following is the Executive Order issued by President Truman providing for training of defense reserves:

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 16 -Unbeaten Trinity trounced Hobart, 52 -- 0, today for its third straight football triumph Roger Hall and Jack Corcoran got two touchdowns apiece as Trinity, leading the nation's small colleges in rushing, piled up 323 yards.

The first School of Community Relations for laymen of the United Lutheran Church in America will hold its classes starting Wednesday, at 8 P.M., under the auspices of the Long Island Conference of the New York Synod, at the Central Y.M.C.A., 55 Hanson Place, Brooklyn.
Hunter College will divert most of its relief contributions to aiding displaced persons, Prof. Eleanor Grace Clark, faculty adviser to the college's Food for Europe Committee, announced yesterday.

MISS MILLER, who already has three merit badges as a historical novelist, appears this time with one about Georgia in 1775. The craft of basket-weaving may be declining, but the craft of making up a story out of a history book continues to flourish.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 16 (AP) -- A touchdown with three minutes to play enabled the New Britain Teachers College football team to gain a 6-6 deadlock with the Merchant Marine Academy team of Kings Point, L.I., today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -Bank deposits in the Twelfth district during September totaled $9,868,386,000. This represents a gain of more than 916 million dollars, or almost 10 per cent over September, 1947. The totals for leading cities were: Los Angeles, $2,973,988,000; San Francisco, $2,457,436,000; Seattle, $713,185,000, and Portland, $594,123,000. The cumulative nine months' total reached $87,318,299,000.

DENVER, Oct. 16 -- The critical Berlin situation, the November elections and the cost of living continued this week to hold the interest of residents of Colorado and other Rocky Mountain states. The people are going to leave the Berlin situation to American diplomats and the military, but they are going to do something about the elections and the cost of living, which continues as the dominant topic of conversation among housewives.

AFTER an illness of two years Maude Adams is back again at Stephens College. Once again the young women students of this junior college in Columbia, Mo., will marvel at the seemingly tireless activity of their 75year-old Professor of Drama, dean of American actresses, as, swathed in veils, she crosses the campus.

BUFFALO, Oct. 16 -- Buffalo and its surrounding industrial towns offer in the November election an almost perfect opportunity to test the oft-argued question whether labor leaders can direct, at the polls, the political thinking of their union membership.

That distinctively American institution, the traveling salesman, is not a thing of the past, as many people believe. In fact, it is due to undergo s definite renascence within the next tweve months, according to several executives connected with organizations of traveling men.

Two thousand alumni of Columbia University were told yesterday noon by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of their alma mater, that it was important for future graduates "to be tied with affection" to the institution.

CBS this season has lured "Amos 'n' Andy" away from NBC, which on Radio Row was a surprise that will not be surpassed until David Sarnoff goes to work for Bill Paley. The bait, according to report, was a sum upward of $2,000,000, an item which will be subject to a capital gains tax rather than the much heavier income levy.

Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, took issue yesterday with liberal and labor leaders who are supporting President Truman's re-election as "the lesser evil" and dismissing his candidacy because "Thomas can't win." The obvious answer to that, the Socialist leader observed, is "neither can Truman."
The Cunard White Star liner Britannic, which doked yesterday morning at Pier 54, North River, brought 966 passengers from Liverpool and Cobb.

At the present rate of consumption, all four-year-old whisky now held by distillers will be exhausted by June of next year, according to a study completed by the Licensed Beverage Institute yesterday. The fact that some of these whiskies must be preserved and aged for use in blends gives strong indication that an increased amount of younger whiskies will be forced on the market during coming months, according to industry observers.

CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Announcement was made here today by Clark H. Minor of New York, chairman of Hamilton College's board of trustees, of the appointment of Dr. Robert Ward McEwen of Carlinville, Ill., to be the new president of Hamilton.

Buyers who visited the wholesale apparel market here last week were mainly interested in holiday ready-to-wear lines, and their response to manufacturers' offerings was good, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

With the disappearance of the Jewish centers in Europe the survival of Judaism and its musical tradition rests upon Jewish institutions in the United States and Israel, Dr.-Nelson Glueck, president of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, declared last night.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The European council for the Marshall Plan, in which foreign and finance ministers of member countries sat, formally passed to W. Averell Harriman today the joint report of those countries for the first year of the recovery program.

WITH another tire chain shortage forecast for this winter because of the steel shortage, J.R. Crossley, vice president of the Automobile Club of New York, advises motorists to do their shopping early to avoid the delays and annoyances of being snowbound.

SO far the season has yielded only one play that has the imagination and quality of a work of art. Tennessee Williams' "Summer and Smoke," acted with matchless perception by Margaret Phillips and Tod Andrews, brings again into the theatre the gifts of a poetic and creative writer for the stage.

Younger members of society are aiding in the sale of tickets for the performance of "Life With Mother," with Howard Lindsay and Dorothy Stickney in the leading roles, on the night of Oct. 26 at the Empire Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the Kips Bay Boys Club.

The Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, will sell at three auction sales this week rare old English and French clocks, 'a small but fine collection of early English silver and books formerly in the library of The Brook, a New York club.

Announcement last week of a nation-wide advertising campaign telling the American people in simple language how their economic system works has stirred an enthusiasm that promises to make it a new weapon against Communist aggression.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- One of the most disquieting developments in Germany during the past six months has been the gradual return to position commanding respect, and in some communities power, of former members of the Nazi party.
CLARKSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Truman's statement and his letter to Secretary Forrestal on organizing all reserve units necessary for national security:

THE tone would vary from the serenely Jovian to sheer circus barker, but the time was always shortly before election day and the tune was always the same. He was a great man, would save the country, was good to his mother, was true to the principles of Jefferson, Jackson, Lincoln, Rutherford B. Hayes.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 16 -The Harvard football team that had flared like a meteor to score 27 points in 30 minutes against Columbia turned Michie Stadium into a bedlam today as it held Army to a 7-7 draw in the furiously paced opening half of their first meeting since 1942.

THIRTY-EIGHT miles north of New York a Manhattan taxpayer pulled his Cadillac convertible to the side of road U.S. 9W near the Roseland tavern, walked over to a pair of the observation binoculars which invite travelers to view the scenic Hudson shores for 10 cents and put in his dime.

One section of the Labor Management Relations (Taft-Hartley) Act of 1947 defines as an unfair labor practice any attempt by a labor union to "cause an employer to discriminate against" non-union employes. The effect of this section is to outlaw "closed shop" contracts -- contracts in which an employer agrees to hire only union members.

WASHINGTON -- Two steps have recently been taken to favor the American who takes his car to Europe far pleasure driving. First, the cost of shipping an automobile overseas has been reduced, as of Jan. 1, from $600 to $500 round trip, and from $400 to $375 one way.

EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 16 (AP) -The United States Immigration Service, in an unprecedented move, abandoned efforts today to halt illegal entry of Mexican farm workers into this country. Instead, the agency opened the border to thousands of "braceros" and turned them over to American farmer employers for jobs in southwestern beet and cotton fields.

Seward Park and De Witt Clinton brought their football records for the season above the .500 mark yesterday when they defeated Stuyvesant and Christopher Columbus, respectively, in a scholastic bargain bill before 4,000 spectators at Triborough Stadium.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 16 (AP) -Oregon's Norm Van Brocklin helped keep the Duck's Rose Bowl hopes alive today by sparking an 8-7 Pacific Coast Conference victory over the Southern California Trojans.

OF late years the big national annual exhibitions have tended to become more and more alike in the roster of artists represented. The Carnegie annuals, from year to year, bear a particularly close family resemblance.
Twenty-five handicapped children, many of them with crutches and braces, visited the Bronx Zoo yesterday and for two exciting hours seemed to forget their handicaps.

INTIMATE observers of the political scene have always been aware, in a general way, that Sol Bloom was a rather unusual person. "Quite a guy" is a phrase used reasonably often about him. But it takes Mr. Bloom himself, in a frank and charming autobiography reviewing his seventy-eight years of life, and seventy-one years of work, to really bring it home.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States defended institutional advertising in emergency periods in a brief filed with Secretary of Defense James V. Forrestal today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- High registration figures from many states are causing party researchers to revise their earlier ideas on the size of next month's Presidential vote.

By several implied and direct warnings, the utility industry and underwriters of its securities should have concluded during the last week or so that an expansion of the already un balanced ratio of debt and equity financing may severely jeopardize the success of its $9,000,000,000 construction program -- $6,000,000,000 electric, $3,000,000,000 gas.

THE idea of the perfect hand has a widespread appeal; bridge players don't expect to hold one, but they like to dream. A recent report in this column of an honestly dealt hand with ten solid spades and the other three aces inspired numerous letters from other bridge players who have held, or seen, such hands.

Citation, who certainly is the horse of the year, probably is the horse of the decade and may be the horse of the century, did it again at Belmont Park yesterday. He won the $111,700 Gold Cup race in a romp.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The abandonment of security measures in the French mines as a protest against the presence of police in the mining area today caused the Government threaten sanctions in reprisal. This action is expected to bring the coal strike situation to a climax.

A YOUNG American citizen of Japanese ancestry was applying for a job in Honolulu soon after the attack on Pearl Harbor, Mr. Smith relates. He was asked if he was a Japanese "No, I'm an American of Japanese ancestry," was his answer.

Although overpowered throughout the last three periods, the Columbia football team was within three yards and thirty-two seconds of a remarkable 1-point conquest of favored Pennsylvania yesterday at Baker Field.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Purdue's Boilermakers shook off their football miseries today with a 20-13 victory over Iowa.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York presented its first concert of the season for children "up to nine" yesterday morning at Town Hall. Almost a thousand youngsters were on hand and they joined the proceedings in singing "The Farmer in the Dell."

"Every thirty minutes someone in the United States commits suicide," Dr. Carleton Simon told the International Association of Chiefs of Police at last week's meeting in New York. Dr. Simon is the criminologist of the association. He must have startled even his hardened hearers with the announcement that in ten years 167,624 persons have done away with themselves in this country.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 16 -While awaiting the outcome of the expected talks in London on the new form of the British Commonwealth relationship, possibly dissolving the crown as a common link, Indian editorialists insist that continued close relationship with the United Kingdom and the other Dominions must not impair this country's position as a neutral in the political struggle between Russia and the West.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Duke's Blue Devils ended Maryland's perfect football record today with two precision plays that carried them to a 13-to-12 victory before 21,914 fans.

ITHACA, N.Y. -- Cornell University's Department of Hotel Administration will soon have a home of its own -- $2,500,000 Statler Hall -- which will contain a complete "practice hotel" with thirty-six guest rooms, lounges and dining facilities.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 16 (AP) -- A pair of halfbacks, Elwood Petchel and Wally Triplett, sparked the Penn State football team to a 37-7 victory over West Virginia today before 18,000 fans.

TORONTO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The surprising Boston Bruins soundly whipped the world champion Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 1, tonight in the opening National Hockey League game for both teams. The Bruins, knocked out of the Stanley Cup play-offs by the Leafs last spring, were never behind. The contest attracted 14,065 fans.

INTERESTING item of literary intelligence: this department was yesterday informed by Elliott Graham, at E.P. Dutton Co., that his firm had recently, for the first time, been able to sell a book of poetry in Detroit.

WINCHESTER, Va., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft said here tonight that he had found "a determined and enthusiastic Republican party looking forward to carrying the Southern States for Dewey and Warren" in the election.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- The battle for Congress took on new interest this week over the Presidential campaign, which all public-opinion polls indicate will end in a victory for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey over President Truman.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week were 138,734, as against 150,985 a year ago, a decrease of 8.1 per cent, and for 1948 to date totaled 5,308,882, in contrast with 5,696,693 last year, a decrease of 6.8 per cent.

THE hard battle of reasonable man against the Zeitgeist, the spirit of the age, is carried to many active fronts in this book, with flowing vigor and evident enthusiasm. The attack starts against the spirit of an older age, when Rationalism was lyricized.

AMHERST, Oct. 16 -- A powerful Amherst College eleven, held to a 7 -- 7 halftime score by the stubborn Colby Mules, roared back with three touchdowns in the last two quarters to win their fourth straight, 27 -- 14, on the victor's Pratt Field.

For the first time, a complete intracompany training program for purchasing personnel has been designed and made available to industry and educational groups, officials of the National Association of Purchasing Agents disclosed here yesterday.

Preliminary plans for the Dewey-Warren rally in Madison Square Garden on Oct. 30, the Saturday night before election, were announced yesterday by New York Republican County leader Thomas J. Curran, the general chairman.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 16 -- Yale's bulldog tenacity overcame the jolt of a Wisconsin touchdown in the first two and a half minutes of play today and brought a 17-7 victory for the Eiis.
ATHENS, Oct. 16 -- Secretary of State Marshall arrived by air today to see for himself why, even with the help of American millions, the Greek Government has failed to wipe out its guerrilla enemies.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- A Russian-supported amendment that attempted to establish a permanent committories was rejected today when seventeen nations voted for it and seventeen against with seventeen abstaining at a meeting of the trusteeship committee of the United Nations Assembly.
I MUST protest against the review of my book, "Mirror for Americans -- Japan," written by Foster Hailey, and published in THE TIMES book section for Sept. 19.

Reports from Maine to the Carolinas indicate that this should be an unusually productive deer season, and in many parts of this wide area the deer herds have increased to a degree that has put the animals in the pest classification.

THE full details of the Metropolitan Opera's new season are expected to be forthcoming this week. The word, though, is that they'll be sent to the papers in a straight news release. If so, it means that, for the time being, one of the institutions of New York's musical life is being suspended.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, urged today a continuance of a "firm" policy toward Soviet Russia and warned that nation not to underestimate American willingness to fight to preserve its integrity.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The note that Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said he expected from the British yesterday on proposals for modifying the program of dismantling German industry still had not gone to the United States tonight, according to Foreign Office sources.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 16 -Lafayette halted Muhlenberg's twelve-game streak tonight before 21,000 persons, the largest football crowd in this town's history, with a strong display of power. The score was 46 -- 13.
BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- The Soviet zone failed to meet by approximately 50 per cent Russian demands for reparations from current production during the first half of this year, German sources said today.

IT is difficult to describe "All Hallows' Eve" without making it sound like a pulp thriller. There are comings and goings from the spirit world; a dead wife telephones her living husband; a diabolic magician sticks pins in the image of the person he wishes to murder.

BURTONWOOD (By Wireless). THE Yanks are back -- some 4,000 of them -- in the familiar olive drab uniform with the Air Force patch on the left shoulder. About half of them are attached to B-29 groups stationed at Scampton and Waddington near the old cathedral city of Lincoln and at Marham and Lakenbeath, old wartime Royal Air Force bases.

THE post-war boom has now been running three years. During this time industrial production has increased 17 per cent, personal incomes about 28 per cent, expenditures for goods about 25 per cent, wholesale prices about 53 per cent, the cost of living about 33 per cent, total corporate profits over 100 per cent.
In the article "The Real Purpose of the University" author Max Beloff asks if the right to higher education necessitates a lowering of educational standards in American universities.

NASHVILLE, IND. -- Tourists in increasing numbers are stopping in this picturesque little village in the heart of scenic Brown County attracted by the charm of the landscape and by the active artists' colony which flourishes here.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 16 (UP) -A rocky line and a rampaging backfield enabled Tulane to smash Mississippi's defending Southeastern Conference champions, 20 to 7, today before 43,000 spectators.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 -- A crescendo of variegated propaganda as the November election approaches has shifted much California attention from the national contest to eighteen state constitutional amendments and initiative proposals, the judgment of which will put voters in the dual role of legislators.

To meet the needs of today's complex society, American teachers should have a wide range of knowledge and a broad background of general education, according to a report just completed by the American Association of Teachers Colleges.
OWOSSO, Mich., Oct. 16 -- The Republican Presidential nominee, Thomas E. Dewey, came home tonight to this place of his birth and a rousing welcome from old neighbors.

Although Argentina exported a total of 5,179,000 cattle hides and kips during the first eight months of this year, against 3,469,000 in the same period last year, it is still credited with stocks ranging between 3,000,000 and 4,000,000, according to trade advices here yesterday.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 16 -Finland's Social Democrat Government struck two telling blows today against the Communists.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Spokesmen for the Western powers emphasized today that they did not plan any effort to resume direct negotiations with the Soviet Union on the Berlin blockade as proposed yesterday by Faris el-Khouri, Syrian representative on the United Nations Security Council.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Stung by British accusations yesterday that Russia was maintaining vast slave labor camps in which millions of human beings were treated like animals, Byelorussian and Soviet spokesmen replied hotly in the United Nations General Assembly's Committee on Human Rights today to the allegations.

HAWTHORNE'S portrait, framed in, fumed oak, used to hang on the wall just above the blackboard, and Miss Fletcher, the love-light gleaming through her pince-nez, told us all about him. He was pure, gentle, very fond of children, and so shy and ethereal that his friends called him Oberon, after the king of the fairies.

SHRUBS with bright berries in autumn contribute showy color to plantings that might otherwise have settled into October doldrums. Two that combine strikingly, or prove effective even when grown alone, are beautyberry and snowberry.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 16 -Mighty Michigan mauled Northwestern by 28 to 0 in a bruising struggle today before 85,938 to take undisputed recognition as the greatest football team in the Big Nine, if not in the nation.

Mrs. Donald Geddes is chairman of the volunteer committee in charge of sales at the Opportunity Shop booth at the New York Antiques Fair which opens tomorrow at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street.

Re Colonel Frunke's letter, in which he says, "In my career in the service I found that too heavy rank among the EM tended to set up a caste system between them and the commissioned ranks. Sergeants always seemed an independent group to me.

Mrs. Donald Geddes is chairman of the volunteer committee in charge of sales at the Opportunity Shop booth at the New York Antiques Fair which opens tomorrow at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street.

Re Colonel Frunke's letter, in which he says, "In my career in the service I found that too heavy rank among the EM tended to set up a caste system between them and the commissioned ranks. Sergeants always seemed an independent group to me.
GLENDALE, Calif., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago, playing the steadiest sort of golf, shot back into the lead in the $15,000 Glendale Open Golf Tournament at the 54-hole mark today.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 16 (AP) -Frank Frankel's Quarter Pole, 11-to-10 favorite, circled the field and raced in a three-length winner today of the $15,000 added Maryland Handicap.

THERE is more than meets the eye in the visit that the New York City Opera Company will make to Chicago next December and the proposals, hinging upon this visit, for the establishment in Chicago of a municipally conceived opera company similar to New York's, and the collaboration of the two lyric theatres.

AN old technique in visual education -- the "turnover talk" -- has been enlisted to help fight discrimination. A kind of illustrated lecture, the "turnover" utilizes a series of bound posters placed on an easel, to be turned back like the pages of a stenographer's notebook as the leader tells the story from an accompanying script.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -Failing in week-long efforts to get negotiations resumed as a step toward ending the West Coast maritime strike Allan S. Haywood, director of organization for the national CIO, said today he was returning East. He added that he saw no way at this time of ending the deadlock between the shipowners and striking unions but asserted that the door was "not closed" and that he might return.

Richard Farrell, 21-year-old pianist from New Zealand, made his American debut at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, and a rewarding performance it was. His program listed the Bach-Busoni Chaconne, the Schubert Sonata in A minor, Op. 143, Copland's Sonata (1941), Chopin's Scherzo in C sharp minor and Liszt's Sonetto del Petrarca, No. 104, and his Hungarian Rhapsody, No. 6.

IF the makers of the Treaty of Versailles had had access to the scholarly researches of the late Professor Cross -- or what is more important had they been seriously interested in the interplay of ethnic and racial historical forces in Europe -- there is some chance that Adolf Hitler would have failed in his mission of galvanizing Germany behind his propaganda for a Greater Reich.
An extract from the diary's foreword, written in 1943, two years before her death.

The President's order to Defense Secretary Forrestal to proceed forth-with to strengthen the military reserves of the United States should not be taken as an alarm. The President merely doffed his campaign sombrero and put on the hat of Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Services to order a needed strengthening of the reserve organization -- especially that of Army Ground Forces and the Air Force -- at the top levels of command.

In a hard-fought contest which ended in a stalemate after each team appeared to have victory in its grasp, the Erasmus Hall and Midwood High School elevens battled to a 20-all tie at Ebbets Field yesterday afternoon. The game, feature of a double-header, was witnessed by 5,000.

ATLANTA, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A 300-man battle royal among players and spectators was the big moment on Grant Field today as Georgia Tech defeated Auburn, 27 -- 0. It was Tech's fourth straight football victory.

THE Day family, of the flaming red hair, is packing its belongings this week-end and is preparing to go home to New York for the winter. The winter? The last time the Days moved on New York they stayed somewhat over seven years, until it was not clear whether the Empire Theatre had not been built for "Life With Father," and whether the play ever would give up tenancy.

MASSIVE, brilliant and terrible in its relentless detailing of an army's destruction, Theodore Plievier's "Stalingrad" is the most impressive novel of the second World War yet to appear in Europe. There, we are told, it sold over a million copies in various languages.

FRANCOIS MAURIAC is a member of the French Academy and one of the major figures, along with Peguy, Claudel and Bernanos, of the Catholic literary revival in France in the early part of this century. Mauriac's increasingly intense spiritual concerns have remained in vital harmony with his admiration for writers as diverse as Valery, Malraux, Proust and Gide, and with a courageous personal devotion to political liberty and liberty of conscience.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Hard-hitting Texas overpowered stubborn Arkansas, 14 to 6, today to grab its Southwest Conference opener before 46,000 football fans.

If the nation's critical need for psychiatric services is to be met, it is vital that there be more coordination among groups interested in psychiatry and "more consolidation on their points of similarity, rather than accent on their differences," Dr. Lewis Wolberg, president of the Institute for Research in Psychotherapy, declared yesterday.

DURING fall planning, beautiful visions of the gardens we'd like loom large in our minds. So dominant in these mental pictures are the prima donnas -- spring bulbs, iris, roses, lilies, phlox and chrysanthemums -- that we are likely to forget to order those plants which are the supporting chorus, until their absence is felt the following year.

One out of every seven persons in New York without ability to pay will go to one of eighty-six voluntary hospitals this coming year. Whether he needs an operation or an oxygen tent he will be treated regardless of race or creed by one of the non-profit institutions.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Almost everyone in the United States knows that elections will be held Nov. 2, and it would be hard to get up a dispute about the matter. In France, however, no one knows when the next French general elections will be held.

Great Britain's economic future depends on an increase in her exports, this increase in turn on her industrial development, and her industrial development on scientific and engineering research. Here science and politics interlock. Parliament therefore created a Parliamentary and Scientific Committee which gives it advice and which consists of some two hundred peers and M.P.'s and the representatives of about eighty scientific bodies.

While numerous communities in the United States have been struggling the last few years to organize rehabilitation centers to meet the needs of their handicapped residents, there opened last June, on the outskirts of Nanking, China, a modern rehabilitation center of which any American city might be justly proud.

Back in home surroundings after disastrous experiences on the road, New York's competing professional football teams -- the Giants and the Yankees -- today will resume their three-year battle for prestige and patronage. Both will encounter topflight opposition.

ONLY one startlingly new weapon was displayed last week during the recent "war" in which a non-aggressive democracy called Nomora got the jump on and trounced a militaristic, totalitarian state called Deluvia.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The once mighty Liberal party, now near extinction, is making a bid to come back in the British general election next year. The party, which once provided Britain with ten Prime Ministers but now has only ten seats in the House of Commons, has launched a campaign to recapture the political bastions it once held.

WHEN Vladimir Horowitz made his American debut twenty years ago, he was desperately fearful of his future here. Friends in Europe had bid him bon voyage with the lugubrious warning that there was no place in the United States for another pianist at the top.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The seven-month struggle of the Slav bloc to oust Dr. Jan Papanek of Czechoslovakia from his two United Nations jobs was decisively defeated here today when the General Assembly voted in full session to retain the foe of Prague's Communist Government.

Although activity in financial markets was somewhat circumscribed because of the holidays, an improved tone was again in evidence last week. For the second successive week share prices edged higher to within the levels of early September as traders centered their attention on domestic problems rather than the foreign situation.

Futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange continued to hold within a narrow range last week, showing net declines of 3 to 23 points at the close of trading on Saturday. In the preceding week, the market registered net changes ranging from an advance of 14 points to a decline of 23 points.

Men and women throughout the city may learn a wide variety of skills -- to dance or sew, sketch or repair household equipment -- in evening community centers opening this week in 185 schools in the five boroughs. Most of the centers will open tonight, the others tomorrow or Wednesday, Mark A. McCloskey, director of community education of the Board of Education, announced.

In its first issue, published today, The National Guardian, a "progressive newsweekly," announces its support of Henry A. Wallace, expressing the conviction that Mr. Wallace represents the "progressive tradition set in our time by Franklin D. Roosevelt."

YONKERS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Bishop Charles K. Gilbert rededicated St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church on Underhill Street here at a special service in the restored colonial edifice this morning, as part of the 150th anniversary observance of the church.
On sales of $34,839,863 Sharp Dohme, Inc. had a net profit of $3,933,678 after taxes and all charges in the twelve months ended with last September, it was reported yesterday.

The New York City Opera Company's presentation of Richard Strauss' "Salome" is one of its best all-round productions, and the company gave it again last night at the City Center after omitting it from its season last spring.

A special fleet reconversion program for the Department of the Army, involving nine ships with a peacetime capacity of 14,000 passengers, compared with a wartime capacity of 40,000 troops, is nearing completion.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- The United States and Britain plan to introduce a joint resolution this week calling on the United Nations General Assembly to sponsor a relief program in behalf of several hundred thousand Arabs who had fled from Israeli-controlled areas of Palestine, it was learned today.
The Football Yankees gave their best performance of the season yesterday but it wasn't quite good enough to carry the day against Frankie Albert and the fleet-footed backs of the Forty-Niners.

If family counseling services had been used in the early stages, many of today's psychiatric "casualties" could have been avoided, Miss Frances Taussig, executive director of the Jewish Family Service, declared yesterday.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings took sole possession of the National Hockey League lead tonight, scoring at least twice in each period to plaster the undermanned New York Rangers, 7 to 0, before 12,716 fans. It was Detroit's second triumph in as many starts and moved the Red Wings into first place ahead of the Montreal Canadiens.

I cannot refrain from correcting the impression conveyed by Pablo Merry del Val of the Spanish Embassy, in his letter published Oct. 6, that during the Second World War the Spanish Government's principal preoccupation was rescue of Jews from the Nazis.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A new South American haven for refugee money from any place in the world has been created in Uruguay under protection of a recently passed investment law.

Following a survey made by the National Association of Leather Glove Manufacturers it was shown that only 68 per cent of retailers' normal requirements for leather gloves have been purchased for 1948, it was announced over the week-end by James H. Casey Jr., secretary of the association.

The "woeful lack of appreciation on the part of several nations" that the authority they exercise derives from God and is subject to His laws is retarding establishment of world peace, the Rev. William T. Greene declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

With only a few exceptions retailers' stocks on hand of ready-to-wear are sufficient for the season's needs, according to reports on activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week, which were prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A torrent of wages and corporate revenue sent state income tax collections to the highest peak in history in the fiscal year 1948, the Federation of Tax Adnimistrators reports.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Claude Harmon of Winged Foot, the Masters champion, and Jack Patroni, home-club pro, defeated Willie Turnesa of Knollwood, the National amateur champion, and Ray Billows of the Dutchess Club, Poughkeepsie, 4 and 2, in a pro vs. amateur best-ball event at the Apawamis Club today for the benefit of the United Hospital Fund.

The extension of "Break the Bank to television will begin Friday night at 9 o'clock, when the quiz, over which Bert Parks presides, will become a simultaneous offering over both the video and audio facilities of ABC.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 17 -- A statistically optimistic picture of the resettlement of Europe's homeless throughout the world during the current fiscal year was drawn today in figures obtained here from the International Refugee Organization and other sources.

Samuel Kovenetsky, president of the Macy Department Store Employes Union, Local A-S, unaffiliated, announced yesterday that he had resigned as secretary of the newly-organized Distributive Trades Council. The council was set up by the Macy union and seven other left-wing store unions that have seceded from the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 17 -- Sparked by the fine individual play of Alan Corey, the Jericho poloists staged a strong second half drive to defeat Bostwick Field, 8 -- 4, in the weekly high goal match at Bostwick Field today.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The mentality displayed by the stock markets, or at least by those who shape their course, continues to be a constant source of surprise to financial observers in London. Ordinary as well as professional investors have in the past week flouted even more outrageously than before facts that in more normal circumstances would have caused and maintained something like dismay.

Reflecting the recent increase in reserve requirements on both demand and time deposits, ordered by the Federal Reserve Board, the statements of conditions of the fifteen largest banks here for Sept. 30 disclosed substantial shifts in assets since June.

OWOSSO, Mich., Oct. 17 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, rested by a week-end at his mother's Michigan home and reassured of victory by political prophets, is leaving here early tomorrow for Albany to plan the final phase of his Presidential campaign.

The new home of the Hope Day Nursery, one of the oldest child care centers for working mothers in New York, was dedicated yesterday. At the same time the need for other such agencies was stressed by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein and Dr. Alice Keliher, Professor of Education at New York University.

It is rather the thing, when a concert is given by a distinguished organization from a great and friendly nation overseas, for reviewers of the occasion to express themselves in complimentary, diplomatic, and, if necessary, guarded terms.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Several hundred residents of Tarrytown, North Tarrytown and Irvington-on-Hudson visited Sunnyside, Washington Irving's "elegant little snuggery" overlooking the Hudson River here, and 265-year-old Philipse Castle at North Tarrytown today on the second and last of 1948's "Sleepy Hollow Folk Days" at the two shrines.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The undefeated Chicago Bears fell below their 38-point average but still registered a 28-0 triumph over the victoryless Detroit Lions for their fourth-straight National Football League decision today.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- The Finance Ministry today revised its rates of exchange between the franc and a number of other currencies. This in effect devaluates the franc by 22 per cent in relation to some currencies. The relationship between the dollar and the franc remained

In the United Nations committee which is attempting at Paris to draft an international declaration of human rights it is the practice of the Soviet delegates to goad the Western Powers from time to time about their failure to achieve a full protection of the civil liberties of all of their people.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 -- The steed industry reached a new high mark for output last week when the rate was raised 1 point to 98.5 per cent of rated capacity. This was considered also a special record in view of the shortage of scrap metal and pig iron.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Truman's sudden order to Secretary Forrestal to build up the nation's reserve components to "maximum effectiveness" means nothing without the money to put it into effect and the legislation to implement it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported tonight that business picked up nicely as it moved into the fall season, giving promise of a "sustained high aggregate volume."

"For a great country like the United States, your Customs Service is a very poor advertisement," said Dr. P. J. Mijksenaar, secretary-treasurer of the American Businessmen's Club of Amsterdam, Holland, following his arrival in New York yesterday with eleven other members of the club for a seven-day good-will tour.

Nine customers and the proprietor of a bar and grill at 520 East sixth Street were taken to the East Fifth Street police station yesterday afternoon, when two patrolmen, answering a robbery alarm, found six of the customers and the proprietor manhandling a seventh, accused of robbing the proprietor of $37.50.

THE maestro had been thrilling crowds for years with an act at which he was admittedly without a peer. By the use of his strange powers of magic and prestidigitation he'd always left them numb and gasping by whipping out of his hat a rabbit they'd never suspected was even there. The rabbit wasn't named Harvey. It was named Upset.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The directors of the United States Chamber of Commerce today urged arms trading with friendly nations and standardized military equipment for joint defense.

The Communist-dominated bloc in the United Nations was accused of "sterile isolationism" by Warren Austin, United States Ambassador to the United Nations, in a transcribed address from Paris here yesterday at the opening of United Nations Week.

Chinatown's only all-night mission, which for thirty-seven years has fed, sheltered and helped to rehabilitate derelicts, has closed its doors, it was learned yesterday. The mission was founded in a venerable three-story building at 8 Bowery by Dudley Tyng Upjohn, grandson of the designer of Trinity Church.

PARIS, Monday, Oct. 18 -- A slight decline in the strength of France's Communists was reflected in the early returns from the election held yesterday by the municipal and departmental Councils to select the electors [delegates] of the electoral colleges.

Sharply contrasting personalities, campaign techniques and issues are emerging in the Congressional fight in Brooklyn's sprawling Fourteenth District, where the American Labor party is campaigning vigorously to unseat Representative Abraham J. Multer, the Democratic candidate whose campaign is being buttressed by Republican and Liberal party support.

An old holding in the Greenwich Village area has passed to new control with the sale of the five-story brick dwelling at 343 West Twelfth Street for the first time since 1878. The property, which includes a separate two-story brick building on a lot 22 by 80 feet in the rear, was used by the great-grandfather of the sellers for his home and dairy business.

Paintings by the late Marsden Hartley, selected from the period 1934-42, at the Rosenberg Galleries, heads the art attractions in local galleries this week. Prints and drawings by the tragic anti-Nazi German artist, Kaethe Kollwitz, will be shown at Galerie St. Etienne.

Mack Harrel, Metropolitan Opera baritone, gave the first of a series of three recitals yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His program was devoted to the complete cycle of Brahms' "Romanzen aus Magelone," which is seldom offered in its entirety.
Recently there have appeared in your columns letters from persons representing the landlords' point of view, criticizing the City Rent Commission.

Defense, in so far as the New York Giants and Chicago Cardinals were concerned yesterday at the Polo Grounds, was merely a word to be found in the dictionary. For these National Football League rivals, before 35,342 fans, played a game in which nearly 100 points were scored and nearly 1,000 yards gained. At the end the champion Chicagoans had an eye-opening, record-smashing 63-35 victory.

The Girl Scout Council of New York has opened its 1948 drive for $350,000 with a report on its achievements and program that should win enough enthusiastic contributors to exceed its goal by many thousands of dollars. The amount sought is a modest one, when one realizes that it will aid 37,556

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 -- President Peron received an expected ovation this evening from a great throng gathered to hear him speak from the balcony of Casa Rosada on the third anniversary of his return from brief exile and his emergence as a potential President.

President Truman's order to Defense Secretary Forrestal to move immediately to strengthen the reserve units of the armed services and to report progress to him within sixty days is well within the realities of national security whether or not the international situation improves or deteriorates. Mr. Truman says it is improving.
There seems to me a basic incomprehension in all our talk about communism and our ballot. May I suggest a broader perspective?

A parade of 3,000 members of military and naval units and patriotic societies preceded the twenty-seventh annual massing of the colors in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon.

The eleventh novel by Lloyd C. Douglas, a fictionalized biography of Simon Peter, entitled "The Big Fisherman," has been scheduled for Nov. 16 publication by Houghton Mifflin. This will be the third novel about early Christians to be issued in about a month.

Half of the 1,347 vessels that entered or left the port of New York in September flew the American flag, the monthly report of Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs, said yesterday. Of the 679 entering the port 346 were of American registry, and of the 668 that sailed from here 326 were American.

Medical, hospital and industrial equipment and miscellaneous items of surplus property, acquired by the Government at a cost of $13,000,000, will be offered for sale in the New York metropolitan area by the War Assets Administration during the next thirty days, it was announced over the week-end by Walter F. Downey, regional director.

A statement of the Population Reference Bureau that our national IQ is endangered by the low college birth rate appeared in your issue of Oct. 3. My scrutiny of all the material published by the PRB College Project in the last three years indicates that this claim is scientifically fallacious and surreptitiously reactionary.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- One of the most critical problems of France is that of increasing industrial production for the export markets. Another is to stabilize the purchasing power of the wage earners. To date no French post-war Government has been able to settle either of these problems.

Filled to the brim with Broadway's nostalgic memories of the fin de siecle era, "The Leading Lady" -- Ruth Gordon is the author-star and her husband, Garson Kanin, is the director -- will be introduced at 8 o'clock this evening at the National by the producing team of Victor Samrock and William Fields after a tryout fraught with forebodings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 -- With national CIO representatives unsuccessful in bringing about a resumption of negotiations in the West Coast maritime strike, Harry R Bridges, the CIO longshore union's head, notified the Waterfront Employers Association over the week-end of his willingness to recommend election of a rank-and- file committee to negotiate a settlement.

A museum of "living art" for Queens, to serve also as a cultural center for the borough, would be one means of keeping for future generations reminders of the great part Long Island has played in this country's history. A committee has been formed to bring about the creation of such an

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 17 -- The help of the European Recovery Program is exerting gradually a favorable influence on the ecomony of the Netherlands. In well-informed quarters it is said that it is expected that the gap in the balance of international payments will be covered by 1952 and that within a year and a half scarcity in the Netherlands will be ended.

It is a dramatic fact, according to newly published figures, that the almost 18,000,000 Americans admitted into the 6,173 hospitals of the United States in 1947 represent nearly a 100 per cent increase over the 9,221,517 patients admitted to hospitals in 1937, ten years ago.

The greatest tragedy about human nature is that real living is often postponed indefinitely, Dale Carnegie, lecturer and author of "How to Win Friends and Influence People," declared yesterday. He spoke at the Layman's Sunday morning service of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.

MILLBROOK, N. Y., Oct. 17 -The twenty-fourth annual meeting of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America ended today with the open all-age event for English springers. Splendid work marked the stake, held on the grounds of the Sandanona pheasantry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has purchased "Tension," a screen melodrama by John Klorer, as a possible vehicle for Robert Taylor and Van Heflin, the studio has announced. Robert Sisk will produce the film, which will have a Los Angeles background and will deal with an unjustified accusation of murder.

Some of the Christmas cards that well-wishers will send out before too long probably will become permanent wall decorations instead of being merely used as bright touches of holiday color on mantel and table. The American Artists Group, which since 1935 has been printing cards designed by the foremost artists of the day, has now turned out a collection of them in frames that will outlast the shedding Christmas tree.

John Haynes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, led his congregation in a special service yesterday morning dedicating the church's new home. The modernistic structure has been open for worship since Sept. 26.

Concentrating all its scoring in the first half, the Cardinal Hayes eleven scored a 19-6 triumph over the Chaminade High School of Mineola, L. I, yesterday at Triborough Stadium before 7,000 spectators. It was the winner's second straight victory in three outings, while the Flyers now have dropped three or four games.

Danny Kaye used to sing a hilarious song about the dismal reactions of a GI forced to do kitchen police. Perhaps he would have changed his tune had the kitchen been more on the model lines of those now on view at Lewis Conger. Almost anyone would find even potato-peeling pleasant in one of the cheerful and convenient culinary centers set up in the store by Cox, American Central and General Electric.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct 17 -- An American Legion, swelled by World War II veterans to 3,000,000 members, will open its thirtieth annual convention here tomorrow, with President Truman delivering an address which has been described in advance as non-political.

A man identified through his fingerprints as Lawrence Sullivan, 33-year-old convict, was shot dead at 9:25 o'clock last night in or at the door of Joe's Four-Leaf Bar and Grill at 322 Henry Street, where a man was slain last year Sullivan was killed by a single bullet fired from an automatic pistol of' 380-caliber, a weapon of unusually high power.

Mlle. Olga Colin, principal of a small public school for girls at Vecoux, France, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday and went on to Richmond, Va., where she will marry Simon Damiani Jr., a grocer, whom she had never seen.
The 1949 Frazer and Frazer Manhattan four-door sedan cars will go on display tomorrow in dealer showrooms.
A construction program for Fordham University requiring $3,000,000 during the next few years was outlined yesterday by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has informed the Republican leaders of New York State that, if elected President on Nov. 2, he will continue as Chief Executive at Albany until just before his inauguration in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Air Force wants 10,000 former service men to help it keep the Berlin airlift and the B-29s in Europe running.

Continued Republican control of the next House of Representatives is indicated by a survey by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in twenty-four states, in which the Congressional campaign committees of the two major parties look for changes in the present partisan alignment.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Manufacturers Trading Corporation, which has loans of $10,400,000 out to industries in thirteen states, has petitioned the United States District Court here for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Law.

SALONIKA, Greece, Oct. 17 -- Coinciding with Secretary of State Marshall's visit to Athens, Greek Minister of Justice George Melas and Minister of Public Order Constantin Rentis made a joint announcement here today of "the facts thus far ascertained" concerning the murder of George Polk, correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The development of a united Protestant church in this country is not as "complicated" as it might appear, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, said yesterday morning in his sermon.

Six-day bicycle racing returned to the local scene last night when the sixty - eighth International competition began at the Kingsbridge Armory, Bronx. New York Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran fired the gun promptly at 9 o'clock to start on its way a representative field of eighteen teams, consisting of the best foreign and American riders.
New York State will receive a "windfall" of $9,534,052 in additional payments from Federal social security funds in the year that began Oct. 1.

If the entire population of the United States sees red before the day is out the National Cranberry Week Committee will be responsible. In an effort to get the second largest cranberry crop in history put to good use the group has established National Cranberry Week, starting today, with the approval of Governors in thirty-five states.

An electroencephalograph is a device for measuring brain impulses, and a Birmingham hospital owns one. According to The United Press, the machine was attached to a patient the other day and the physician in charge sat back to await developments.

With fall dress business going into its final production phase, suppliers of rayon fabrics indicated yesterday that a dull period of at least four weeks' duration may be expected in their trade. Most mills and converters, they said, will hold to current price levels on the theory that price, as such, is not too great a factor in stimulating business at this time.

There was an air of quiet strength in the major foreign currencies last week but a softness ruled in some South Americans. Business was in good volume, considering that Canada recessed on Monday for its Thanksgiving Day holiday, and here observance of Columbus Day on Tuesday closed the banks and stilled trading interest.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -- The maritime commission is investigating charges that Latin-American countries are discriminating against United States shipping, it was revealed today.

Synagogues throughout the city marked the beginning last night of the thanksgiving festival of Succoth, or the Jewish Feast of the Tabernacles. The ancient harvest celebration is observed for seven days by Reform Jews and for eight days by Conservative Jews.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- An open-air meeting of 3,000 trade unionists in Manchester today overwhelmingly adopted a resolution calling upon the British Cabinet and the General Council of the Trades Union Congress to "take all necessary steps to remove Communist control from the trade-union movement.''
Senator Robert F. Wagner was reported in "fine shape" and resting comfortably yesterday in his son's home at Bay Shore, L. I., after his ten-hour disappearance on Saturday.

Reduction of the United States Department of Labor in two years from a personnel of 7,000 employes to 3,300 and halving of its annual appropriation by the Eightieth Congress was assailed yesterday by John W. Gibson, Assistant Secretary of Labor, as a deliberate move to cripple further the wage-earners of the country.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Trouble appeared to be imminent on the strike front in the northern French coal area today as safety workers of the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor began to walk off their jobs in strikebound pits and mineheads, while the anti-

O. John Rogge, American Labor party candidate for Surrogate, charged last night that Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan, and Frank Costello, racketeer, were working together in the current political campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Retailers are getting a 69-cent share of each dollar of income left to consumers after taxes, the Department of Commerce reported tonight. That's nearly a dime-size bigger chunk than in pre-war 1939. The retailer got about 60 cents of each dollar of consumer income after taxes in those days, the Department said.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Boston Yanks handled the Pittsburgh Steelers with the greatest of ease while winning their first National League home game, 13-7, today before 7,208 at Fenway Park. The Steelers, who drubbed the Yanks, 28-14, two weeks ago, were helpless until the last minute of play, when a pass interference ruling set up their touchdown.
I should like to add a few further details in the shocking case of Ilse Koch.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- The Finance Ministers of Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg today agreed on the immediate financing of their common military staff for the defense of Western Europe and prepared suggestions for the Five-Power meeting to be held in Paris on Oct. 25.

WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Oct. 17 -- Memorial High School swamped Demarest of Hoboken 55 -- 0 at Miller Stadium today before a crowd of 9,000. It was the fifth straight victory for the Orange and Black. Emil Sacher's 60-yard run for a touchdown and Bobble Aiello's 40-yard dash on an intercepted pass for another score featured.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- A broad demand for cash lard from Government agencies featured the market last week, and with rapidly decreasing stocks prices swung sharply upward. October took the lead, going to a premium of over 1 cent a pound over November at one time, owing to lifting of hedges by warehouse interests and short covering.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Details of a carbon black plant to be built in Britain as the first guaranteed investment project under the European Recovery Program was announced here tonight. Half of the capital for the venture will be supplied by an American company and the rest by British investors.
