GLENDALE, Calif., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Routing the opposition with a last round eight-under-par 64, Ben Hogan captured the inaugural $15,000 Glendale Open golf tournament today with a 72-hole score of 275.

Elmer F. Quinn, minority leader in the State Senate, was not endorsed but neither were his two opponents in the Eighteenth Distant, in recommendations to voters in Manhattan and the Bronx made public yesterday by the Citizens Union.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 17 -- The current espionage trial in the Belgrade District Court involves three self-confessed agents of former King Peter, who is alleged to have instructed them to make contact with those Chetnik commanders who have survived

Two Maritime Commission emergency -type passenger liners, the Marine Falcon and Marine Swallow, were towed up the river last week to the Government's temporary reserve-fleet base at Tompkins Cove, near Haverstraw, N. Y.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Oct. 17 -- The land and the farmer were themes here today at pontifical mass and in a series of special services to mark a formal opening of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday urged support of the $16,500,000 campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York. He declared that failure of the drive would force the federation's 116 affiliated hospitals and welfare agencies "to operate at paralyzing deficits or to curtail vitally-needed services."

ROME, Oct. 17 -- The Italian Communist party today began celebrating a "month of friendship for the Soviet Union," designed to convince the Italians that the only way they could avoid being involved in a third world war would be to abandon the Western democracies and throw themselves into Russia's arms.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 (AP) -Automatic Otto Graham pitched two touchdown passes and figured in another scoring dive as the champion Cleveland Browns notched their seventh straight All-America Conference triumph today with a 31-to-14 victory over the Buffalo Bills.

Federation Employment Service shortly will recommend early establishment of a joint committee comprising top local industrial, labor and Governmental leaders to begin an all-out drive to persuade industry to employ more middle-aged and older workers, Roland Baxt, executive director, disclosed last week.
ATLANTA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Will Hill, handyman, wise man and Negro, was borne to his grave yesterday by his "boys" -- all white.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- President Truman, who returned late yesterday from a six-day midwest campaign trip, spent a busy Sunday at the White House receiving reports on conditions abroad and planning speeches for the coming week.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury who was passing through Paris on his way to Palestine, said today that the "United Nations must act promptly to establish peace in Palestine with the Nov. 29, 1947, resolution of the General Assembly as a minimum basis."
Fred J. Urban has been appointed sales manager of Hermann Spielmann Sons, Inc., manufacturer of tie fabrics and men's neckwear. He joined the company in 1940.

At least once at every rehearsal the company of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo can expect emotional fireworks from Rachel Chapman, their rehearsal pianist, who also frequently plays in the pit during performances. What form this explosion will take no one can guess.

Oven J. Roberts, former Justice of the Supreme Court, declared yesterday that the United States had wasted $15,000,000,000 on aid to Europe in the past three years. He added that the nation must join in federal union with Western Europe to make the Economic Cooperation Administration effective enough to combat Russia.

The old power plants supplying electric current to the IRT division of the city subway system are in such poor condition that "there is a likelihood of serious failure at any time at either or both of these plants," according to William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- While emphasizing that there can be no political identification between American Jews and Israel, Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, asserted here today that Jewish people in this country should manifest "a patient, benevolent and utterly sincere approach to the problems of Israel."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Mass picketing, even though peacefully conducted, violates the Taft-Hartley Law, Irving Rogosin, a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, ruled today.

OWOSSO, Mich., Oct. 17 -- Governor Dewey's relations with Senator Vandenberg and Harold Stassen have undergone an interesting transition during the Presidential campaign and, in view of what Mr. Dewey has been saying on his current trip, one or both of them may vet figure in his cabinet plans if the Republicans win.

With Ben Watman tallying twice, the All-Star team composed of players picked from the American Soccer League defeated the eleven representing the State of Israel in a well-played battle at Ebbets Field yesterday. A crowd of 25,000 saw the local athletes turn back their eager foes by the score of 3 to 2.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- There is considerable feeling in British official quarters concerned with the European Recovery Program that Greece, Turkey and bizonal Germany should be excluded from the work in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation on the allocation of next year's United States financial aid to Europe.

DOUGLAS SOUTHALL FREEMAN, distinguished Richmond newspaper editor, tireless military historian and celebrated biographer of Robert E. Lee, writes his monumental books in much the same spirit as that of the Pharaohs who built the pyramids, to leave on the flat desert of contemporary biography structures of such vast size and magnificent construction that posterity in ages yet to come will regard them with awe.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 17 -- Walter Eytan, director general of the Israeli Foreign Office, declared today that the Provisional Government of Israel "stands by its claim to the whole of the Negeb," desert area in the south of Palestine, as provided for by the United Nations partition plan.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Foreign Minister Shertok tonight asked the Israeli Government to submit to a request by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, for a temporary cease fire in the Negeb area.

Municipal bond offerings this week will be highlighted by the marketing of $37,500,000 of Chesapeake Bay Bridge revenue bonds and by the State of California's issue of $25,000,000 veterans' welfare bonds. The Chesapeake Bay issue, in the form of $18,500,000 serials maturing from 1952 to 1967 and $19,000,000 3.20 per cent term bonds maturing in 1973, is expected to reach the market Monday or Tuesday. The California offering is slated for Tuesday.
ATHENS, Oct. 17 (AP) -Secretary of State Marshall conferred with top Greek officials today against a background of growing concern over Greece's military campaign against the Communist guerrillas.

ROME, Oct. 17 -- A nation-wide strike of street car employes, scheduled for midnight, was postponed late this evening. No agreement has yet been reached in negotiations between the representatives of the employers and the workers, but their viewpoints have come together closely enough to hold out a reasonable hope that some satisfactory settlement may be reached.

Surface transportation in the Bronx was thrown into confusion yesterday, when bus drivers on twenty-nine lines of the Surface Transportation Corporation refused to sell passengers any transfers to the city's subway and elevated lines.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles could not do anything wrong today, and the Redskins could not do anything.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- John Foster Dulles, Republican representative on the United States delegation to the United Nations, declared today that the American share in the airlift into Berlin was "above partisan politics."

The annual convention of the National Audubon Society, now being held here, serves to focus attention on the work this organization has been doing in fostering the protection of the country's remaining natural resources, not only birds, but also the soil of this continent, its range lands and forests, aquatic life, water supply and wild animals.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 17 -Israeli forces fought their way with bayonets on to an important height in the Negeb battle today, and held the hill against repeated heavy Egyptian counter-attacks that were supported by tanks, armored cars and artillery, an Israeli Army communique reported tonight.

At the top policy level, industrial executives concentrated last week upon bringing into balance the advantages and benefits of Public Law 395, governing industrial allocations of materials, which expires Feb. 28, 1949, and is due to be either continued, overhauled or discarded by the next Congress.

DETROIT, Oct. 17 -- After a lukewarm reception in a swing through the industrial section, Henry A. Wallace ended his second visit to this state tonight by declaring that he would fight to preserve the Progressive party and describing Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, as the greatest single obstacle to this ambition.
Whatever college football team may deserve top ranking in the nation, the Maize and Blue of Michigan flies on high in any appraisal of defensive strength.

Development of too many special promotional campaigns by organized retailers is likely to lessen effectiveness of those already well established, it was observed over the week-end by a number of advertising men in this field. This reaction was prompted by the recent proposals for a new "special event" campaign in February.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- Urging the major parties to unite in the struggle against communism and for German unity, Jacob Kaiser, Christian Democratic party leader, today assailed the Social Democrats for their "aggressive policy in a time of trial."

The gas utility industry will need $3,300,000,000 to complete its construction program through 1952, it was disclosed yesterday in the first comprehensive study of the industry's capital requirements just issued by the committee on economics of the American Gas Association.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- A surprise meeting of British, Irish, Canadian, Australian and New Zealand Ministers was held today at the country home of Prime Minister Clement Attlee for the purpose of considering the consequences of Ireland's decision to sever her last link with the British Crown.

Many of the custom-made furniture pieces and built-in bookcases that local decorators use in rooms are made by Kagan Woodcraft. To offer its services to homemakers, as well as to show furniture of its own design, the company has just opened Kagan Designs, Inc., at 130 1/2 East Sixty- fifth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Some of the problems of boosting British industrial output that will face the Anglo-American Productivity Council are the subject of a critical analysis of British methods published in the newsletter of the European Bureau of the American Federation of Labor.
Lieut. Gen. John C. H. Lee, retired, called yesterday in a Laymen's Sunday address for a revival of evangelism with the accent on youth.

The Rev. Robert F. Lindemann, pastor of the Lutheran Chapel of the Redeemer, Queens Village, Queens, laid the cornerstone yesterday afternoon at the Christian Day School building being erected by the church at Union Turnpike and 221st Street, Queens Village. The structure, to cost $130,000, will serve as a place of worship as well as a school.
Beer taps ran dry in many neighborhood taverns last night, but the amber brew still gushed abundantly in most large midtown bars, restaurants and hotels.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 17 -The Federation of American Scientists has set up a scientists' committee on loyalty problems, Prof. Henry De Wolf Smyth, chairman of the department of physics at Princeton University, announced today.
The formation of a Fire Department Gold Star Society, with membership open to widows and orphans of firemen killed in line of duty, was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- A surprise meeting of British, Irish, Canadian, Australian and New Zealand Ministers was held today at the country home of Prime Minister Clement Attlee for the purpose of considering the consequences of Ireland's decision to sever her last link with the British Crown.

Many of the custom-made furniture pieces and built-in bookcases that local decorators use in rooms are made by Kagan Woodcraft. To offer its services to homemakers, as well as to show furniture of its own design, the company has just opened Kagan Designs, Inc., at 130 1/2 East Sixty- fifth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Some of the problems of boosting British industrial output that will face the Anglo-American Productivity Council are the subject of a critical analysis of British methods published in the newsletter of the European Bureau of the American Federation of Labor.

In the largest single day's trading since the war, cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange advanced 46 to 108 points yesterday. A heavy demand led by December contracts advanced prices throughout the day. The market closed near the high in a turnover of 393 lots.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- The United Nations Security Council will hold a special meeting tomorrow to debate a call from Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting Mediator for Palestine, for "prompt intervention by the Security Council" to end the renewed fighting in the Negeb area of Palestine.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The knotty problem of reconciling Ireland's future status with continued Commonwealth cooperation was today turned over here to the best legal brains that could be summoned. It is hoped that a report can be made back to the Commonwealth Prime Ministers before their London conference ends early next week.

The domestic shipping industry has ceased to be a factor in the development or maintenance of the American Merchant Marine and only immediate and drastic relief can rescue it from its present state of decadence, Ralph Keating, president of the Refrigerated Steamship Line, declared yesterday.

Announcing the declaration of a 5 per cent stock dividend on the common stock of Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., Hyman P. Kuchai, president, reported yesterday a new high in sales and earnings for the first nine months this year.

Jeff Davis Milton, cowboy, Texas Ranger and United States Marshal, has been made the subject of a biography by J. Evetts Haley. It is an account of almost seventy years of adventure along the frontiers of Texas, Arizona, and Old and New Mexico.

A musical adaptation of Edward Sheldon's well-known play, "Romance," originally put on by the Messrs. Shubert in 1913 with Doris Keane starred, will be presented this evening at the Shubert Theatre under the same producing auspices.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Oct. 18 -- In a reconditioned old bus that has been their home for the last two weeks, Alvin Behr, his wife and two youngsters expect to start tomorrow on a tour of the United States.

The Board of Education expects New York's public school children to have sound teeth as well as alert minds as a result of two new programs that were started yesterday. It is also seeking to improve their training in art.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- A determined group of small countries insisted today that the United Nations push ahead with the task of controlling atomic energy along the lines put forth by this country more than two years ago. Warren R. Austin, United States delegate, however, bluntly served notice that Russia was the stumbling block and that the United States would not give up atomic bombs until a fool-proof control system had been devised.

Samuel Margolis, who was suspended on April 22, 1941, from a $2,100 a year position as a library assistant at City College on charges resulting from the Rapp-Coudert Committee's legislative investigation, was discharged last night by the Board of Higher Education at a closed meeting in Hunter College.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 18 -- The city of New Brunswick was ordered in Federal district court today to permit Sidney Stolberg, Progressive party candidate for Congress, to use a sound truck in his campaigning.

ROME, Oct. 18 -- Secretary of State Marshall arrived in Rome by air from Athens at 3:50 this afternoon and three hours later he had already had conferences with President Luigi Einaudi, Premier Alcide de Gasperi and Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 12 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 3 per cent.

Until yesterday it appeared that the New York Football Giants might bob up with offensive and defensive help in the person of Bruce Smith, one-time Minnesota and Navy ace and recently a member of the Green Bay Packers. But Smith, a hard-running, alert back, has made up his mind to remain out of football.

Schoellkopf Crescent at Ithaca will stage the big college game in the East on Saturday -- the only one between undefeated entries -- as Army makes its first upstate football trip on record to play Cornell. Michigan and Minnesota will hold the spotlight in the middle West in their battle for the Little Brown Jug at Minneapolis.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18 -- In an editorial marking its seventy-ninth anniversary, this mornings' Prensa recalled that in the early days of Argentine journalism papers had been organs of party propaganda, and that news itself had been twisted to fit political ends.

Plans for a twelve-story and penthouse apartment building to contain 223 suites on the west side of Eighth Avenue between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Cost of the structure is estimated at $2,450,000.

Victory through air power will be Fordham's goal against Georgetown, according to Coach Ed Danowski, who yesterday sent the Rams through a light drill in preparation for Friday night's contest at Washington's Griffith Stadium.

Having fallen in love with the theatre many years ago, Ruth Gordon has posted a nice, sentimental valentine to it. "The Leading Lady," she calls it; it was produced at the National last evening. When Miss Gordon became a playwright about five years ago, she virtuously renounced the stage, which requires a good deal of personal attendance.
Two Netherlands steamship companies announced here yesterday the formation of a new shipping line to enter the highly competitive service between New York and east coast ports of South America.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein began court action yesterday to halt the "grimmest kind of profiteering on sorrow" by operators of so-called "non-profit" cemeteries who he said had made millions of dollars illegally for themselves.

The United States Postoffice Department will show a deficit of $550,000,000 at the end of its fiscal year next June, a figure totaling "more than postal receipts of fifteen years ago," Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Younkers Brothers, Inc., Des Moines, Iowa, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 34,000 shares of 5 per cent, $50 par value, cumulative, sinking fund, preferred stock, and 70,000 shares of no-par value common stock.
By word of mouth advertising the Bureau of the Census has become a large-scale supplier of a personal service. It provides proofs-of-age for persons who have no birth certificates.

On the first day of Succoth, or the Feast of the Tabernacles, many sermons at special synagogue services here yesterday emphasized the rebuilding of Israel as a Jewish homeland. The holiday, is symbolic of a joyous festival, is observed for seven days by Reform Jews and for eight days by Orthodox and Conservative Jews.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- Labor strife flared again over the week-end. The Communist - dominated All Japan Electric Industry Workers' Union met a hastily contrived interim wage award from the Central Labor Relations Board with an order that each chapter should "engage in every possible strike action in keeping with regional conditions."

The Marshall Plan is taking hold in France, and that country's general level of production is now equal to that of 1938, or higher in some industrial lines, Etienne de Lassus, chairman and president of the Compagnie Francaise Thomson-Houston and head of a group of companies associated with the International General Electric Company, Inc., in France, said yesterday.

Columbia's basketball team will play twenty contests this season, including twelve in defense of the Eastern Intercollegiate championship which the Lion five has won the past two years, it was announced yesterday by Director of Athletics Ralph Furey.

The Roaring Brook Purse, for 3-year-olds, chief item of entertainment in the Empire City-back-at-Jamaica proceedings yesterday, provided a roaring finish in which Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Loser Weeper bagged the photo decision over Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Lex.
PARIS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the statement by the United States delegate Warren R. Austin in the United Nations Political Committee:

A syndicate including Henry Morgenthau Jr., I. Jerome Riker and Harry C. McClarity has purchased the Town House Hotel and six adjoining buildings at the southeast corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street from the National Union Corporation of Baltimore, Md.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Otis Co., Cleveland investment banking concern, and its largest stockholder, Cyrus S. Eaton, won a round today in their fight with the Securities and Exchange Commission over the collapse of the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- A general business downturn does not seem imminent, Clifford S. Young, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, said today. But, he added in an address before the annual convention of the Institute of Internal Auditors, "unless further positive steps are taken to check inflationary pressures, we cannot hope to minimize the eventual repercussions to be faced in business and employment."

The birth of quadruplets is not a frequent occurrence, but the voluntary hospitals in this city are always prepared for even such an emergency. The quota of $2,854,988 the United Hospital Fund is seeking is not for phenomenal events, however, but for actual deficits incurred by inflationary costs in 1947.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 18 -- Although Alabama strongly supports the States'-Rights Democrats in this year's Presidential contest, there is a situation developing in the state which promises to produce one of the strangest political results in the country's history.

" I FEEL like a pig," said Jimmy Conzelman mournfully. The droll and witty coach of the Chicago Cardinals was in the grip of twin emotions yesterday. He was delighted, naturally enough, by his 63-35 cross-country victory over the New York Giants the day before but he also was terribly embarrassed that he'd rubbed it in on his old pal, Steve Owen.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- The newly formed United Laborite party, created by Tammany Hall in an attempt to bolster its local candidates by obtaining for them a second line on the voting machines, was barred from the Nov. 2 ballot today by uninamous decision of the Court of Appeals.

The New York City Housing Authority executed yesterday the first financing of its projected $200,000,000 program of non-subsidy housing by selling $48,256,000 of bonds maturing in three to fifty years to a syndicate of 126 banks and investment houses at an interest cost of 3.213 per cent.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The enormous financing operation by the Shell group in the United States is part of a world-wide development scheme for a vast increase in output of petroleum from British-controlled sources which is designed to relieve Western Europe's need for oil from dollar areas, earn dollars for Britain and thereby contribute to the European Recovery Program.
PARIS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The following is a partial text of the emergency report by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, on the fighting in the Negeb:
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Invariably, it seems, these pro-amateur one-day tournaments are won by the last team to finish. Today was no exception.

FLINT, Mich., Oct. 18 --As a contribution toward easing of country-wide parking and traffic congestion problems, the 1949 Buick cars are reduced in length. Three inches have been lopped off the new series as compared with 1948 models, but what has been discarded on exterior dimensions has been compensated by augmented space in the interior construction.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- The Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor called all safety and maintenance crews out of the strike-bound coal mines tonight for an indefinite period. The step was taken purportedly in protest against alleged violence by Government troops who were protecting anti-Communist workers returning to a mine near St.-Etienne, Loire, in Central France.

Cites Trade Show Techniques Manufacturers' decisions to participate in trade shows should be based on the same "yard-stick" used in the selection of other advertising media, Meade Johnson, general sales manager of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company's Stamford division, told the Industrial Advertisers Association yesterday at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

REHOVOTH, Israel, Oct. 18 -- The war in Palestine has delayed the opening of the Weizmann Institute of Science, but, barring unforeseen circumstances, this monument to the famous chemist-states-man will be completed and in full operation by next spring.

Democratic officials had a preview yesterday of "The Truman Story," a ten-minute visualization of the life of the President for movie theatres. The private showing was in the Universal Pictures Building, 445 Park Avenue.

Seeking a solution to the transfer dispute that has snarled traffic on twenty-nine Bronx bus lines since Sunday morning, Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday called a meeting of all participants in the controversy.

PRAGUE, Oct. 18 (UP) -- An emissary of Greek Guerrilla Gen. Markos Vafiades asserted today that Adam Mouzenides, Greek Communist, accused by the Greek Government of murdering George Polk, died before Mr. Polk did.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- The strategic interest of the United States in Spain and the British coolness toward proposals for either customs unions or European political unions are expected to be prominent among the subjects that will be discussed by the Foreign Ministers of the five Western European states when they meet in Paris next Monday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 - Accident prevention has failed to keep pace with medicine and other sciences in preventing death and suffering, and never will achieve comparative results until the American public is aroused to fight accidents as it has fought disease and epidemics.

An analysis of the defense budget figures for the current fiscal year gives one very good reason why the Organized Reserve program of the Army Ground Forces and the Army Air Force has not achieved post-war expectations -- a condition which President Truman has ordered Defense Secretary Forrestal to correct forthwith.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 18 -A snow-white felt hat, utilized as a symbol of "clean government," is the biggest news in Indiana politics today. The drawing power of that symbol, coupled with other factors, may have important national as well as state-wide repercussions, including the possible retirement from office of the prospective chairman of the House Labor Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 - Despite the great ideological differences that exist, it would be a mistake for this country to exclude exchange students from the Communist-dominated lands in Europe, the Government's Advisory Commission on Educational Exchange said today.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- Shigeru Yoshida, leader of Japan's conservative Democratic Liberal party, tonight completed his Cabinet, four days after his election by the Diet. The new Ministers will be installed tomorrow, subject to approval by Allied headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Great differences still exist between the lowest and highest rates for home electricity in cities, the Federal Power Commission reported today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association of New York, testified today in the association's suit to bar the Metropolitan Opera Company of Chicago from using that name.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 18 -With victory secured in the battle for communications in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, the Israeli Government proposed tonight an immediate meeting with Egyptian representatives to "settle peacefully" the differences between Israel and Egypt in regard to this area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Illinois politics became mixed in a dispute over state law today, when a spokesman for Gov. Dwight H. Green, and other Republican state officials, appeared before the Supreme Court to help Wallace Progressives get a place on the Illinois ballot in the Nov. 2 election, by having the Illinois election statutes declared unconstitutional.
Substantial revisions in a proposed local law to increase taxicab fares here by 30 per cent have been suggested by the Police Department, it was learned yesterday.

DUBLIN, Oct. 18 -- It was stated authoritatively here tonight that the repeal of Ireland's External Relations Act would be proceeded with and that when the last tie with the British Crown had been severed Ireland would be prepared to accord existing citizenship and trading privileges to the British Commonwealth.
ALBANY, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The heat wave last August caused the New York death rate to climb to its highest point for the month in twenty years, the State Health Department said today.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 18 -- Philip F. La Follette, former Progressive Governor of Wisconsin, today endorsed Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for President.

The tendency of the public to "pity" the psychologically and physically handicapped and to think of them as stereotypes such as "crippled" or "sick," was deplored yesterday by Dr. Luther E. Woodward of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene.

Pre-fight fireworks were in evidence yesterday as Charley Fusari of Irvington, N. J., and Tippy Larkin, Garfield, N. J., welterweight, went through a preliminary examination at the Jersey City Armory for their ten-round battle there Thursday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The Waterfront Employers Asciation flatly rejected today the CIO longshoremen's latest offer to resume negotiations as the West Coast maritime strike went into its 47th day with no sign of a break.

With reports of excellent waterfowl shooting coming from Canada and several northern states, and with thousands of broadbill already feeidng on Long Island Sound, it seems safe to prophesy a fairly good season, although the prospects for the late season hunting are best.

The Shell Caribbean Petroleum Company, recently incorporated in New Jersey to take over certain assets of the Royal Dutch-Shell group in the Western Hemisphere, announced yesterday that it has concluded an agreement for the sale to a group of United States and Canadian insurance companies an issue of $250,000,000 of its bonds bearing interest at 4 per cent and maturing in 1968.

Argentina, under the Government of President Juan Peron, is seeking fully reciprocal juridicial and economic cooperation with the United States, Dr. Jeronimo Remorino, the Argentine Ambassador, told 200 persons at a luncheon of the Pan-American Society in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
OTTAWA, Oct. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Trade Minister C.D. Howe announced today an 18-per-cent voluntary reduction in the import of iron and steel products from the United States.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau predicted today his world champion Cleveland Indians will run one-two in the American League race for at least three seasons and maybe five.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Senator Alben W. Barkley said here tonight that a Democratic defeat in November might hang a question mark over further development of the Tennessee Valley Authority and atomic energy.
ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey returned to the state capital tonight from his second Presidential campaign trip convinced that it's all over but the voting.

Among the things falling yesterday in Madison Square Garden were cowboys from their horses, popcorn from the balcony -- and the wild West from the high place it once had in the affections of city youngsters.

More than two-third of the General Electric Company's employes, by actual test, regard their plant newspapers as the most honest and reliable news sources on company operations and policies, Fred N. Neal, of the executive department employe relations division, declared yesterday.

SUCCASUNNA, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Four men returning home from a wedding party, including two brothers of the bridegroom, were injured fatally here early today when their automobile struck a tree. Three other occupants of the car -- among them a brother of the bride -- were injured.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A long-range economic and military aid program for China, involving annual appropriations substantially in excess of the $400,000,000 provided by Congress this year, was urged today by Roger Lapham, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission to that country.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 18 (AP) -Maximos V. resigned tonight as spiritual head of 140,000,000 members of the Greek Orthodox Church.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 18 (AP) -Following is the prepared text of President Truman's address today to the American Legion convention:

While the police were searching for the slayer of Lawrence Sullivan, an ex-convict shot down Sunday night in a Lower East Side bar and grill, the victim's older brother, George, was found guilty yesterday in General Sessions of second-degree murder.

NANKING, Oct. 18 -- A week of disaster for the Chinese Government's armies in Manchuria, during which an estimated 100,000 troops were lost through Communist action, was brought to a climax tonight with a Communist radio announcement that the 60th Army of the Government's Changchun garrison had surrendered yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Fifteen German editors visiting the United States to study freedom of the press heard Justice Robert H. Jackson of the Supreme Court declare tonight that even dictators could benefit by permitting that freedom.

A warning that failure to prevent bonfires in the twelve hours before and after the voting on Election Day would result in disciplinary action against commanding officers was issued yesterday in special orders by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Indications that the United States is considering active steps to equip an Austrian army as well as the forces of Western European democracies emerged today as the neutral powers continued their efforts to bring about a compromise settlement of the Soviet blockade of Berlin.

When Patrolman Charles H. Cordes of Borough Headquarters, Queens, arrested a mail handler in the post office at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon on a charge of bookmaking, a mail clerk in charge of the depot drew a pistol and tried to prevent the arrest, according to testimony last night in the Brooklyn Queens Night Court.

The newly-formed Independent Television Producers Association will hold its first general membership meeting at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. Reports to the membership will be read by Martin A. Gosch, president; Irvin Sulds, vice president, Nathan M. Rudish, secretary, and Henry White, treasurer.

Cautious buying marked the twenty-second annual Shoe Manufacturers' Spring Opening, comprising popular-priced lines, yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel. The current situation in which retail inventories have risen faster than retail sales was advanced as the reason.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- The Paris stock market had already discounted the revaluation of the franc, so it showed no marked change today. South African stocks had risen before the week-end in anticipation of the reduced value of the franc in terms of other soft currencies.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called upon the city's leading department stores yesterday to ignore left-wing store locals that recently seceded from the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, and set up their own unaffiliated Distributive Trades Council.

Stevedoring employers last night submitted to longshoremen employes another wage offer in a last-hour attempt to settle differences that threaten an Atlantic Coast dock strike on Nov. 9. The parties to the dispute are scheduled to appear this afternoon before the Presidential inquiry board assigned to the case, and the board will then make its report to the White House.

The report of Pacific Mills, issued yesterday for the wine months ended on Oct. 2, showed a net profit estimated at $7,818,000 after all deductions, including $7,110,000 for taxes and $2,000,000 provision for contingencies.

ATHENS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Minister of Public Order Constantin Rentis said tonight that the family of George Polk was welcome to come to Greece to participate in the trial of the persons charged with Mr. Polk's murder.
Words flowed more freely than beer yesterday as hours of conversation failed to produce any break in the five-day-old tie-up of deliveries from New York's breweries.

The stock market faltered yesterday in an attempt to push forward for substantial gains. Selling which developed late in the session cut back the morning's advances so that the composite rate only rose 0.21 point on the day. On balance, the number of stocks to show gains far outnumbered the losses, as 498 out of the 1,004 issues dealt in ended higher while 260 lost ground.

Bernard Baruch said last night that he did not believe another war was imminent, but that fear of war remained. He blamed Soviet leaders for vetoing "the American dream of a world free of the threat of atomic destruction" and advised that the United States "strike a wise balance between peaceful and military development of atomic energy."

The five-story apartment building accommodating twenty families at 299 Mount Eden Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Rex Housing Corporation to Clara Spinner. The attorneys were James J. Leibman for the seller and Erdheim Armstrong for the buyer.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- The Soviet military administration began to arm the "Peoples Police" of the Russian zone today as unrest and defiance of the Russians spread in an area known to the Germans as "the Zone of Silence."

True to its tradition, established successfully in a single season, the Little Orchestra Society, Thomas K. Scherman, conductor, opened its second season last night in Town Hall with a program containing works, novel to the ears of this generation, by masters of the past and the present.

Would you like to sample Chinese style velvet cake? Javanese shrimp wafers? Spiced apple jelly? Ming Cha tea? Macy's bids its customers to a tasting party this week. A Fine Food Festival opened yesterday on its eighth floor; it continues through Saturday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18 -- The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund will be called on to extend its current two-month emergency program in Palestine and to continue to help Arab and Israeli refugee children, Maurice Pate, executive director of the fund, said today.

With all major airlines showing huge increases in air freight volume, American Airlines announced yesterday sweeping reductions in air freight rates, R. E. S. Deichler, vice president for sales, said the new rates would bring savings up to 20 per cent for shippers in the New York area.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 2, Anne O'Hare McCormick pointed up a possible problem when she suggested that it may be that top Soviet leaders are unaware of the facts as they exist, not because of dishonest reporting, but because their information is derived from Soviet sources perhaps incapable of objective reporting and interpretation.

SOME 2,500 years ago the Chou Dynasty was in such a state of collapse that the Empire of China had broken up into ten independent dukedoms which were continually at war with each other. Times were bad. Moral standards were degenerating. Civilization seemed in peril. Intelligent people longed for the unity and peace which China had once known under the sainted emperors of legendary antiquity.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- A "Train of Gratitude" will soon roll through France collecting items typically French in design and manufacture. Their eventual destination is the United States and they are France's way of saying thank you for the "Friendship Train" that brought food and supplies from the United States to the French people last wnter and for all the help given by the American people since 1939.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Represenative F. Edward Hebert, Democrat, of Louisiana, called on Governor Dewey today to declare before Nov. 2 whether he would or would not, if elected President, order Government officials to withhold information concerning the loyalty of Government officials and employes from Congressional investigating committees.

Shift of emphasis from fall to spring and resort wear was evident yesterday in the New York garment market as additional companies opened their new lines. Manufacturers reported a steady stream of buyers who have begun writing for the new season, and on the basis of initial orders, all indications point to volume equaling or exceeding that of last year.

A syndicate of eighty-four underwriting houses headed by Alex. Brown Sons of Baltimore placed on the market yesterday $37,500,000 of State of Maryland bridge revenue bonds for financing the construction of the proposed Chesapeake Bay Bridge.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- The political cliche has made a startling comeback in the Presidential campaign. For a time, when Robert Sherwood, Samuel Rosenman, Russell Davenport and Archibald MacLeish were constructing Presidential addresses, the shining verb gave the exhausted adjective some competition, but the well-battered phrase is now back in all its tarnished glory.

The basement of Hearns, where the annual housewares fair opened yesterday, has been turned into a three-ring circus where equipment to save time and temper are the attractions. Salespeople and demonstrators have turned "barkers" for a variety of household aids from a mop that can slither under low furniture to small clips to seal opened cereal boxes.

Ban on use of the terms "tropicals" and "gabardines" without designation of their fiber content was recommended yesterday at a joint meeting between representatives of the Clothing Manufacturers of the U. S. A. and the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the Aldine Club.
CHICAGO, Oct 18 -- Grain futures developed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade today, corn closing at the top with net gains of 3/4 cent to 1 1/2 cents, December leading.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 18 -- President Truman asserted today that the United States would continue the search for peace in a spirit of "mutual conciliation," but he served notice on Russia that we would do so without faltering and without appeasing her.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- The foreign trade of the French zone of occupation of Germany has been fused with that of the combined United States and British zone in an agreement signed by the three Military Governors, it was announced here today.

Your issue of Oct. 15 contained a letter from Mary Garvin arguing against including the Negeb in the State of Israel. It is perfectly in order to argue this rather complicated question back and forth. Geographically, politically and financially it is not so simple a problem as it would appear to some.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Oct. 18 -Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, and Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, spoke at today's session of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference here. Both defended Administration programs and policies and criticized Congress and political opponents.

The money market was somewhat easier yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 1/4 to 3/8 per cent, compared with one-half of 1 per cent on Friday. The member banks here which reported excess reserves of $193,000,000 on Wednesday, showed a decline to $76,000,000 by Friday night.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 -- Henry A. Wallace deferred his main speech -- an attack on the Taft-Hartley Law -- here tonight until after he had delivered a nationwide radio address based on the theme of civil liberties.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Commercialization of Sunday, promotion of legalized gambling and the sale of intoxicating beverages were attacked in committee reports submitted today at the opening session of the 126th annual meeting of the Synod of New Jersey of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- One of the most drastic sections of the Taft-Hartley Act affecting unions was invoked for the first time today by a trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board. He directed a union to reimburse an employe who had been illegally laid off at the union's request.

Although the complete results of such an inquiry could not be available before the next Legislative session adjourns, the impartial study of fiscal relations between New York State and New York City suggested by two state Legislators deserves earnest consideration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- As the President heads from Miami into North Carolina, one of the former Confederate states in which his so-called civil rights message to Congress on Feb. 2, 1948, aroused strong opposition in the local Democratic party, the question recurs whether he will make any mention of the positive federal program he proposed on that date.
The field of seventeen teams in the sixty-eighth international 6-day bicycle race continued the mad whirl at Kingsbridge Armory last night before a crowd of 4,500.

Robert E. Strawbridge Jr. has been re-elected chairman of the United States Polo Association, it was announced yesterday. Devereux Milburn Jr. and George C. Sherman Jr. were re-elected vice-chairman and secretary-treasurer, respectively. Sherman is also president of the Indoor Polo Association of America.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 (AP) -Charles J. McLennan today announced that he had given up his positions with New Jersey racing and hereafter will devote his time to the three Maryland tracks with which he is connected. He also will continue his winter post as racing secretary at Hialeah.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- United States Circuit Judges Sherman Minton and J. Earl Major in this city late today stayed the Federal contempt-of-court order outstanding against the International Typographical Union, AFL. They ruled a few hours after Federal District Judge Luther M. Swygert, in South Bend, Ind., had refused to take similar action.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 - The Supreme Court agreed today to hear another case involving attacks on the "quickie" divorces granted by some states.

A clock is little more than a train of wheels, or gears, firmly grinding out pieces of time in the shapes of hours and minutes. Writers of books and of poems assign a number of qualities to clocks: they are solemn of face, reminding man of his mortality; they glower, their midnight chimes preceding the appearance of ghosts; or their hands may be represented in connection with actions heavily charged with suspense.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -The first Assembly of the World Council of Churches, recently held in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, took issue with both communism and capitalism mainly at those points where the two systems diverge from "basic Christian concepts of morality," Prof. John C. Bennett of Union Theological Seminary said here tonight.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens announced yesterday a "wholesale" inquiry into complaints of rent gouging, in which payments of as much as $1,500 for an apartment have been reported. At the same time District Attorney Herman Methfessel in Richmond opened a grand jury investigation of possible rent violations.

HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 18 -Prof. Ralph A. Burns, head of the Education Department at Dartmouth College, has been granted a special leave of absence to become chief education specialist officer for the United States Military Government in Occupied Germany, it was announced here today by Dr. John Sloan Dickey, president of the college.

Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, has accepted the chairmanship of the American Social Hygiene Association's "Stamp Out VD Drive" here, it was announced yesterday by the association. Mr. Cullman, who headed the same drive last year, expressed his deep concern about the large proportion of teen-agers among the venereal disease cases reported in this city this year.
The season's first cold snap was moving in on New York last night.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 18 -- The reciprocal trade agreement program of former Secretary of State Hull would be scrapped for the "old-fashioned log rolling, back - scratching" tariff - writing plan if the Republicans won full control of the Federal government in the Nov. 2 election, Senator Alben W. Barkley, the Democratic candidate for Vice President, warned here today.

Great things were expected of Eunice Podis at her Carnegie Hall recital last night after her unusually fine debut last year, and indeed she again proved herself an unusually talented pianist. But, for reasons which one ascribes to the peculiar acoustics and to her choice of music, our enthusiasm is tempered.

" A Song Is Born." the Samuel Goldwyn production, starring Danny Kaye, which arrives at the Astor, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The comedy with music, which was filmed in Technicolor and which is being released by RKO, was directed by Howard Hawks, and features Virginia Mayo, Hugh Herbert, J. Edward Bromberg, Felix Bressart, Benny Goodman and Ludwig Stossel.
Michigan's unbeaten-untied Wolverines took over the No. 1 spot in college football ranks yesterday in the weekly Associated Press poll of the nation's sports writers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Robert W. Wolcott, a spokesman for the American steel industry, charged today that the recent agreement between the United States and Great Britain for allocation of German scrap metal was "pitifully and stupidly handled."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady with gains of 14 to 24 points net after a session of more active trading than had been the rule recently.

Mayor O'Dwyer endorsed yesterday the candidacy of his brother, Paul O'Dwyer, Democratic-American Labor party candidate for the House of Representatives in the Twenty-first District, in upper Manhattan.

We are heartily in favor of spending as much city money as can be spared to modernize, improve and extend the city's rapid transit system. At the same time transit needs and other city needs are so great and urgent that we think the value of the city's "yardstick" operation of municipal power plants to furnish electricity to IRT trains should now be restudied objectively by Mayor O'Dwyer.
The 240,000 collective farms in the Soviet Union, which employ more than 41,000,000 persons, have received a new order from the Soviet Council of Ministers to purge their payrolls of bureaucrats.
OMAHA, Oct. 18 -- Nebraska is so sure-fire Republican that both major parties' national campaigners are shunning it as through it had the plague.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- A plea to the United States to condemn Generalissimo Francesco Franco is contained in an open letter to Secretary of State Marshall by Salvador de Madariaga, former Spanish Ambassador to the United States, published this morning by The Manchester Guardian as an article on its editorial page.

A gracious loser, Lou Little yesterday declined to protest Saturday's pass-interference ruling by Field Judge Fred Wallace in the closing stages of the Columbia-Penn game at Baker Field. That it was a costly, possible disputable decision, the coach of the Lions agreed, but, as he told the Football Writers Association at its weekly luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's, "whatever I might say would not change the result."

A. Cardani, Inc., ice cream manufacturer, in an expansion move, has leased the new one-story industrial building at the southwest corner of Thirty-seventh Avenue and Ninth Street, Long Island City, Queens, from Samuel Stahlman for ten years. The structure is 50 by 100 feet. G. Irving Huber was the broker.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18 -Spanish Foreign Minister Alberto Martin Artajo departed for Madrid by air this afternoon after an eight-day visit that culminated this morning in the signing of four new accords between Spain and Argentina.

William L. Standard, attorney retained by the Federation of Greek Maritime Unions to defend thirty-six of the organization's officials and members being held for trial in Greece on treason charges, announced yesterday that a visa had been denied to him by the Greek Consulate in New York and the Greek Embassy in Washington.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 18 -- The Belgrade district court will impose sentences tomorrow on three self-confessed agents of former King Peter who sought and failed to carry out their assignment to make contact with former Chetnik commanders and resurrect the Chetnik underground movement.

LAUREL, Md., Oct 18 (AP) -- Miss Margie Fisher's Shivaree, a mud-loving son of Swashbuckler and Swing Music, raced to a clear one-length victory in the Halethorpe Purse, sixth and top event on today's racing program here.

Rugged Charley Zivic, Pittsburgh middleweight, halted Gene Boland's string of victories at twenty-nine last night when he knocked out the Scranton, Pa., boxer in the third round of the main bout scheduled for ten sessions at the St. Nicholas arena.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Employes of the Trust Company of New Jersey have withdrawn as members of Local 17, United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO, and organized a new, independent union, the American Bank Employes, Inc., Sylvester Garfield, general counsel of the near group, announced here today.

Amalie Sophie Pedersen, 66 years old, will make her first visit to the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday night -- but not to see the show. She will be the honored guest at a special performance to mark the opening of Hospital Week, a performance arranged for 4,000 volunteer workers in the United Hospital Campaign.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- President Truman today specifically provided for the outright exemption from registration and service under the Selective Service Act of six classes of aliens.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Students who unfurled a ten-foot "Good-Bye Harry" banner at Saturday's Yale-Wisconsin football game were denounced today by the Badger team, student leaders and the university president.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The American League, spurred by Cleveland Indians fans and an unprecedented flag battle, played before an all-time record paid attendance of 11,150,099 fans this year.
Dan Towler, who totes the football for little Washington and Jefferson College of Washington, Pa., is the nation's leading college scorer, Associated Press statistics revealed yesterday.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania National Horse Show, sparked by the dash and color of international competition, opened today for a six-day run in the farm show arena.

MEXICO CITY, Oct 18 (UP) -Mexico tonight ended the migrant labor agreement between this country and the United States because of what it called the tacit approval by Washington of recent mass illegal entries or Mexican farm workers into Texas.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Larry Doby, center fielder for the world champion Cleveland Indians, got a royal welcome home today, especially from the pupils of East Side High School, who were given half a day off for the purpose.

The New York City Ballet Company last night offered its first change of program in its weekly series of performances at the City Center. The story is not a very happy one. After its brilliant beginning last week, it let us down sharply on this occasion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Declaring that "it looks as though we never had so much business near the front of the stove," John J. McCloy, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said today that the bank might use up in the next six month the $478,000,000 that it has available for lending.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- No decided trend was seen in a generally quiet stock market here today.

Featuring an unusual number of rarities in furniture, silver, china and glass, the New York Antiques Fair opened its doors yesterday afternoon at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, for a six-day run.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Government experts made these winter fuel forecasts today:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Receiving a rousing reception at Union Station last night after returning from its surprising 17-7 triumph over the University of Wisconsin, the Yale eleven began preparations today for the game with Vanderbilt University scheduled for the Yale Bowl on Saturday.

I would like to make the following correction of a reference to me in a story in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 10 of the Conference on Academic Freedom held under the auspices of the National Council of the Arts, Sciences and Professions on Oct. 9 at Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Board of Examiners of the New York public school system may have to revise its procedures for evaluating the records of candidates applying for teaching or supervising licenses, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Emergence of a large number of moderates among the electors for the Council of the Republic, chosen yesterday by municipal councils, was interpreted by former Premier Paul Reynaud today as a sign the French had desired to get away from dogmatic parties and internal division.

General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan refused yesterday to grant a new trial for two men convicted of slaying Anthony Hintz, West Side boss stevedore, on Jan. 3, 1947. A retrial has been sought on the basis of the uncorroborated testimony of a third defendant, Andrew Sheridan, who confessed in the Sing Sing death house that he had plotted the crime.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The fitness of Winston Churchill to continue as active leader of the Conservative party has been questioned by two sober, influential British newspapers.
The National League drew 9,822,502 baseball fans during the 1948 season, a decrease of 5 per cent from last year's high, according to unofficial figures compiled by The Associated Press.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 -Nine short stories from the public domain will serve as the basis for the first nine television films to be made by Marshall Grant-Realm Productions, it was learned today. The stories will be Guy de Maupassant's "The Necklace" and "Mademoiselle Fifi," Robert Louis Stevenson's "The Sieur de Malatroit's Door,"
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The top four players in the Pan-American tennis tournament advanced easily today into the third round.
ATHENS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Newly trained Greek commandos went into action for the first time last night, capturing two mountains in Communist Leader Markos Vafiades' "Free Greece."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- President Truman said today that he was creating an emergency fact-finding board to investigate the controversy between the Class I railroads and sixteen non-operating unions. The members of the panel will be named soon.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 18 -The first cold rains and autumn chills of the last few days have started a fear-stricken cry of "blankets" among Arab Palestinian refugees. There are about 500,000 of them, most of them huddled under trees in tents, shanty towns and slums of Arab lands surrounding Israeli-held parts of Palestine.

RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 18 -- President Truman arrived here tonight, the first President to visit Raleigh since Theodore Roosevelt came here in 1905, to make a major appeal to the South to support him on election day.

PHILADELPHIA Oct. 18 -- A strong plea for making Government contracts "a fair business deal," was advanced here today by Vice Admiral George F. Hussey Jr. (USN retired), secretary, American Standards Association, New York City.

The present Selective Service Act does injustice to a small group of veterans whose corps, during the war, suffered a higher percentage of fatalities, to the best of my knowledge, than any other service. This group is made up of former cadet-midshipmen of the United States Merchant Marine Academy who served in the war.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 8 - The "hospital of tomorrow" will probably need Federal and state grants, as well as augmented private contributoins, but should remain free of governmental controls and should give patients fuller service than at present, the American College of Surgeons was told today.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 18 -- Declaring that an "actual war" lacking only arms was now going on, Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, wartime head of the Manhattan (atomic bomb) Project, said tonight in effect that the Baruch Plan for international control of atomic energy was outmoded in the light of the Soviet's policy of deception.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, back from a long European tour, today advocated a greater non-governmental exchange of visits by labor leaders and professional people between Europe and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Representatives of seventeen Negro land-grant colleges who opened today the twenty-sixth annual session on the theme "Federal Relationship to Education," were told that education in the South can be improved by approaching the state Legislatures with a program and proof that money obtained would be spent wisely for education.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that wool production next year will be only 272,000,000 pounds, the smallest on record.

A new plastic used by the Navy during the war to construct radar and other special electrical equipment has been found to be "the most satisfactory substitute" for human cartilage and bone in plastic surgery, it was announced yesterday in The Journal of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- According to Lloyd's Register of Shipbuilding returns for the third quarter of the year, issued today, out of the 4,203,875 gross tons of steamers and motorships under construction in the world, 52.6 per cent is being built in Britain and Northern Ireland.

The daily double will be back on the New York horse racing scene next season. Officials of the five tracks operating in this state -- Belmont Park, Jamaica, Saratoga, Empire City and Aqueduct -- announced yesterday their decision to restore this form of betting which was discontinued here on the final day of the 1945 season.
The outlook for settlement of a wage dispute between Atlantic longshoremen and their employers, threatening to result in a strike on Nov. 9, brightened yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- The battle to save lives on the streets and highways is being won, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, administrator of the Federal Works Agency and general chairman of the President's Highway Safety Conference, reported today. He spoke before a traffic session of the National Safety Council's annual convention.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 -- The Soviet sector police confiscated today more than a score of vehicles whose owners were attempting to break the intensified blockade ring the Russians have ordered around the Western sectors of the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The White House released today the letter written by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt from Paris on Oct. 4 in which she pledged her support for the election of President Truman. The letter read:
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Oct. 20 (AP) -A Korean Army detachment battled police in southern Korea today in what Government authorities here termed a Communist-inspired insurrection.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 19 --A new minimum salary scale of $2,200 a year for Presbyterian clergymen throughout the state was unanimously adopted here today by the Presbyterian (USA) Synod of New York. This represents an annual increase of $200.
The Bureau of Records and Statistics of the Department of Health is helping to combat vote frauds, it became known yesterday.

The transfer snarl that has plagued 40,000 Bronx bus riders since Sunday will begin to unravel at 6 o'clock tomorrow morning, under an agreement reached yesterday in the office of William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

John D. Morse, formerly editor of the Magazine of Art, has been appointed director of publications for the Art Students League and will be in charge of preparations for the exhibition and catalogue planned in celebration of the league's diamond jubilee in 1950.

RED BANK, N. J., Oct. 19 -- From several Eastern states show-ring and horse-racing enthusiasts among members of society will gather Saturday on Amory L. Haskell's estate near here for the eighteenth meeting of the annual Monmouth County Hunt race meet and the various festivities arranged to complement the day's program.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The eight seeded players in the Pan-American tennis tournament moved into the quarter-finals today.

Many business organizations covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 continue to violate both minimum wage and overtime provisions of the act. William S. Tyson, labor solicitor, Department of Labor, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- An eleventh witness in the House's investigation into alleged Communist activities in the United Public Workers Union, CIO, in the New York area risked citation for contempt today by refusing to say whether he was, or ever had been, a member of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, attacked the International Typographical Union's competency test demands today as "simply sham" and said the real objective was the closed shop.

A first novel by James K. Feibleman, "The Long Habit," will be published on Oct. 29 by Duell, Sloan Pearce. It is a story about life on an island along the Louisiana coast. Mr. Feibleman is the author of thirteen books of nonfiction, among them "An Introduction to Peirce's Philosophy" and "The Theory of Human Culture," both of which were published in 1946.

A warning that recent rulings on price systems by the Federal Trade Commission, supported by the Supreme Court decision, may have "catastrophic" results, if they limit or completely outlaw freight absorption and quotation of delivered prices, was given to more than 300 members of the Sales Executives Club at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday.
RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The prepared text of President Truman's address at the dedication here today of a monument to Presidents Jackson, Polk and Johnson follows:

Margaret Johnson, 5 years old, was burned to death yesterday afternoon in a fire in the ground-floor apartment of an old three-story brick tenement at 110 Second Street in South Brooklyn. Three younger sisters were burned badly at the same time.
Local 1250, Department Store Employes, independent, won its first battle yesterday in a long series of legal skirmishes with Oppenheim Collins Co.
YOU published on Aug. 21, an article from your London office dealing with The Sons of Liberty who are endeavoring to create an anti-British boycott in the United States.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 --Current hospital accomplishments in the treatment of cancer indicate that about 50 per cent of cancer cases, averaging all types, are definitely curable, the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons was told today.
RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 19 -- From the vantage of this friendly Southern state, President Truman today addressed a conciliatory appeal for unity to the sundered Southern Democracy.

The infant mortality rate in New York City has declined in the last fifty years from 140.9 for 1,000 live births in 1898 to 26.4 in 1947, Dr. Helen Wallace of the Department of Health announced yesterday during the United Hospital Fund campaign.

Six men were arrested here last night as suspected members of an automobile theft ring that had stolen forty to fifty late model cars valued at $200,000 in the last six months. Detectives of the Automobile and Forgery Squad said the cars had been sold in legitimate markets at prices as high as 40 per cent above their listed value.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Albert DeCourville's presentation of "Lute Song" will be withdrawn from the Winter Garden on Oct. 30 after a run of only three weeks.

TOKYO, Oct. 19 -- The conservative Cabinet of newly - elected Premier Shigeru Yoshida was installed in office this evening by Emperor Hirohito. There were some minor changes since the Government list was announced last night.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 19 -- President Truman, by all the standard political omens, is safe in Kentucky.

The gallery will greatly outnumber the shooters at the National Rifle and Pistol Championships to be held on Oct. 25 to 27 at Quantico, Va., when fifty-four regional rifle and pistol champions will shoot it out for the National Crowns.
Twenty "political favorites" received almost 40 per cent of all the guardianship appointments made last year by the New York County Surrogates' Court, O. John Rogge asserted yesterday.

A tale of a key was among the reports made to investigators of the Queens District Attorney's office yesterday by eleven tenants who said they had been forced to pay large amounts for apartments. The eleven were among 200 who are to be interviewed concerning charges of "rent gouging."

PRAGUE, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Miltiades Porphyrogenis, Justice Minister in the [Communist] "Free Greece Government" of Gen. Markos Vafiades, said tonight that he had a complete record of the killers of George Polk and that they were not Communists.

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Bernard Deforge took the stand today to tell a Forsyth Superior Court jury of plans leading up to the "throwing" of a Carolina League baseball game here last May 14.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- A group of the Tucker Corporations distributors and dealers, claiming to represent about one-fourth of its 2,076 sales outlets, announced tonight formation of a special committee to protect their investment and issued a general appeal for other dealers to join them.

A 48-year-old Bronx landlord, who gave a tenant a bad check in returning $1,192 paid for a bonus, painting and furnishings expense, was sentenced yesterday to a three-month term in the workhouse by a two-to-one vote of the three justices in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- The improvement in loan rates already experienced by New York banks is inadequate to offset the contraction in earning assets resulting from decreased deposits and higher reserves, Morris A. Schapiro, bank stock analyst, asserted here tonight.

The Tri-Continental Corporation, in the first quarterly report since its merger with the General Shareholding Corporation on Oct. 1, reported yesterday net assets of $64,085,858 as of Sept. 30. The figure was before deducting the funded debt and was equivalent to $11.06 a common share, compared with $10.28 on Sept. 30, 1947, and $11.94 on June 30, this year.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Mexico took the lead tonight in the first of three team jumping events for the Pennsylvania National Horse Show's international competition challenge trophy.
CAMBRIDGE,. Mass., Oct. 19 -- Harvard's football team polished its offensive and defensive formations for Saturday's game with Dartmouth during a controlled scrimmage on Soldiers' Field today.

As usual in disputes between labor and management on our city transportation system, the riding public has been taking the rap in the transfer controversy in the Bronx. Thousands of bus passengers on the Third Avenue system have had to pay more for their daily transportation and suffered other inconvenience because drivers have taken it upon themselves to refuse to sell the transfers that were ordered by the city government.

The theft of jewelry valued at more than $60,000 from the vault of the Croydon Hotel, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street, in a carefully planned attempt to throw off suspicion, was solved quickly yesterday by the police.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The forward pass, practically a forgotten weapon in Army's four straight victories this season, was emphasized throughout today's scrimmage as the cadets made earnest preparation for the "game of the week" at Cornell on Saturday.

Miss Elizabeth W. Baker will give a tea this afternoon at the headquarters of the Smith College Club of New York at the Weylin for a group of women serving with her on the committee for the performance of "Carmen" on Dec. 14 at the Metropolitan Opera House in behalf of the club's scholarship fund.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -Federal Security Administrator Oscar R. Ewing regretfully gave up his government-paid cook today, but he is going to ask Congress to pass a law so he can get the man back.

ROME, Oct. 19 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall left for Paris, accompanied by his wife, at 3:15 this afternoon after he had had an audience with the Pope in the summer palace of Castel Gandolfo and after laying a wreath on the tomb of his stepson, Lieut. Allen Tupper Brown, in the military cemetery of Nettuno.

Despite the fact that Carnegie Hall was sold out to within 93 2/5 per cent of its capacity during the 1947-48 season of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, the orchestra ended the season with a total operating deficit of $109,190.48.

Plans for a modern office building to replace the former home of Cathedral College on Madison Avenue, in the block north of St. Patrick's Cathedral, were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property to Uris Brothers, builders.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The international Communist propaganda apparatus has begun to make it plainly evident that a powerful new campaign is either under way or about to get under way to further "socialize" those nations that are now within the Soviet Union's sphere of influence.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- With damage to the French coal mines fast becoming a threat to the whole of the French economy, the Government today prepared to force safety measures in the extensive mining region of the north with the prospect of increasing resistance from the strikers.

Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican national chairman, said yesterday that after the election the party would be built up in the South so there would be a two-party system all over the country.

Harry and Sydney Waxman, builders, have purchased a tract of about eighty lots in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn for improvement with one and two-family houses. The Stromkill Valley Corporation was the seller and the Neptune Brokerage Corporation was the broker.

Historic Occasion: "Life With Mother," heralded as an eminent successor to its predecessor, "Life With Father," settles down at the Empire tonight, with Howard Lindsay and his wife, Dorothy Stickney, occupying the roles made famous by them in "Father." First nighters are urged to be in their seats on time as the overture will start at 8 and the curtain will go up promptly at 8:12.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Grain markets were firm in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, but liberal profit-taking developed in wheat, corn and soy beans and the finish was easy.

The Metropolitan Opera's sixteen-week 1948-49 season will open on Nov. 29 with Verdi's "Otello," it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager. The cast will be headed by Ramon Vinay as Otello, Leonard Warren as Iago and Licia Albanese as Desdemona, with Fritz Pusch conducting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Camera-bearing rockets soaring to sixty and seventy miles above the earth have recorded pictures of more than 800,000 square miles of Western United States, probably the largest land area ever to be photographed at one time, the Navy disclosed today.

Regardless of race, creed or ability to pay, New Yorkers requiring medical aid are cared for in one of the eighty-six voluntary hospitals in the metropolitan area. One out of every seven persons in this community seeks help each year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's projected musical version of "The Shop Around the Corner" has been scheduled for the cameras early next month, with Judy Garland, Van Johnson and Marcia Van Dyke heading the cast, it was learned today.

Crosley Motors, Inc., will start two extensive campaigns next month, it was learned yesterday. One, using newspapers and magazines, will feature as the central theme a statement that the company which builds the smallest cars is now the world's largest producer of station wagons.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 19 -- Delegates to the thirtieth annual American Legion convention will put aside fun-making tomorrow to take up some 700 resolutions which will shape policy for the coming year throughout the 3,000,000-member organization.

Sentiment for the advance improved considerably yesterday on the stock market, although the going proved to be laborious at times. The improvement was selective, with interest rotating from one group to another throughout the session.

This is the anguished cry of an IRT straphanger. Through the years he has kept his silence when jostled, pushed, squeezed, and has never shouted Eureka! upon sucking in a breath of fresh air when emerging from the labyrinth on a hot summer day.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 19 - Salaries of public purchasing agents should be raised almost $2,000 above present levels, which average $5,185, because of the importance of their responsibilities in buying, David Joseph, New York certified public accountant, asserted here today in reporting on the first national survey of tasks and compensations in local, state and Federal procurement.

There is "no apparent possibility of any reductions in shoe prices," in view of the high total cost of producing and distributing shoes, Lawrence B. Sheppard, president of the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- In a world turned upside down, the plea made to the Supreme Court yesterday by the Governor and Attorney General of Illinois to have a section of that state's election laws declared unconstitutional may not seem extraordinary.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 19 -- The United Nations received today -- in pidgin English -- an account of how the local peoples of the South Pacific have joined the global campaign of the United Nations Appeal for Children.

NANKING, Oct. 19 -- The North Manchurian Communist radio claimed the complete occupation tonight of Changchun, former Manchurian capital, following the capitulation of the Government's Sixtieth Army on Sunday and the surrender of the remaining New Seventh Army at noon today.

Spills took their toll in rapid-fire fashion as the original field of eighteen teams was reduced to thirteen in the sixty-eighth international six-day bicycle race at the Kingsbridge Armory last night. A gathering of 9,000 watched the feverish action.
