SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 19 -- Newell Grinnell of Rochester, N. Y., was named president of the American Society of Travel Agents at the eighteenth annual convention today. He succeeds Harry M. Paulsen of Summit, N. J.

In Paris the other day, the United Nations got on with a serious and important bit of legislation. The Social Committee was drafting a Declaration of Human Rights, and an orator continued a speech a good half hour beyond 1 o'clock, which was lunch time.

Central Park and the Riverside Park are perhaps the most decorative parts of our beautiful city. Since spring, those of us who enjoy our leisure outdoors have noted with sorrow the steady and increasing deterioration of the park facilities.

Lower prices can do much to reverse the downward trend of men's clothing sales, Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Co., makers of Gramercy Park Clothes, declared yesterday in the company's "open letter" sent to 5,000 retailers throughout the country. He called on retailers, clothing manufacturers and mills to do everything possible to "drive men's clothing prices down."

California sold yesterday at auction bidding $25,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds due Feb. 1, 950 to 1969, to a banking syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., on a bid of 106.54 for interest of 2 1/2 per cent, the rate designated by the state.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 19 -- A laymen's committee to study the problem of increasing ministers' salaries was appointed today at the 126th annual meeting of the Synod of New Jersey of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

ASHLAND, Ky., Oct. 19 (AP) -- In his first home-state speech of the campaign, Senator Alben W. Barkley urged Kentuckians tonight to cast a record vote next month to prevent a return to Republican "shortsightedness."

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Before retiring as Governor of the Bank of England Lord Catto issued a warning tonight that Britain's ambitious capital investment programs were "still running at a rate in excess of our available resources" and might lead to further inflation.

THERE are tricks in all trades, they say, except basket-making. One of the tricks of public relations is to reveal disagreeable news at a time when there is a surfeit of news so that the distasteful item cannot get the play it deserves. Favorable releases, of course, are always held up until the space is available for a splash display.

Lovers of the dramatic unities should study "My Romance," which was put on at the Shubert last evening. It is standard operetta with standard routines and situations that have not changed through the years. At one time the authors and composers may have believed in those ritualized gestures toward stock romance.

Walter Hoving, president of the Commerce and Industry Association and chairman of the board of the Fifth Avenue Association, accepted yesterday the post of campaign treasurer of the Citizens Committee for the election of George Frankenthaler, Republican candidate for Surrogate.
The Air Force still must be considered capable of quickly and victoriously ending a war with the atomic bomb, Lieut. Gen. Elwood R. Quesada of the Air Force declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, said tonight his Senate investigating committee would give President Truman a complete record of its hearings in the Ilse Koch case.
John A. McGarry has been appointed divisional sales manager, hotels and clubs, in the metropolitan area for the Jacob Ruppert Brewery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- The executive board of the Communication Workers of America, independent, today approved a 9.9 cents an hour wage increase as a pattern for third round pay rises in the telephone industry.

Hide futures prices advanced 15 to 40 points yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. It marked the eighth consecutive trading day in which this market has registered gains. Transactions aggregated 4,520,000 pounds.

PARIS, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the addresses on the Berlin crisis to the United Nations Security Council today by Sir Alexander Cadogan of Britain and Dr. Philip C. Jessup of the United States:

The New York State Conference on Social Work holds its forty-ninth annual meeting at a time when it becomes ever more important to define more exactly, if that is possible, the role that government and private agencies shall play in meeting the world's and the individual's needs.

OF all the now-it-can-be-told war memoirs which have yet appeared only Winston Churchill's "The Gathering Storm" is as important and interesting as "Roosevelt and Hopkins,"* by Robert E. Sherwood. The two books are very different, but they are alike in the fact that they are both written by men who are masters of words and they both interpret recent history from the vantage point of the most intimate sources of power.

A blind veteran will appear today in Midtown Court to test the recently enacted state law that forbids exclusion of blind persons accompanied by Seeing Eye dogs from restaurants and other places, except where they would create a dangerous situation.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. S. G. Steckler's Coyote, a consistent performer on the New Jersey circuit, gained a hard-earned nose victory in the Hyattsville Purse, a six-furlong dash for 3-year-olds that topped today's card at Laurel Park. Grant Thorn's Superb Donna, odds-on favorite, was second, with Dutel third.

Customer complaints are the barometer of retailing, George G. Nichols, president and general manager of the G. M. McKelvey Company of Youngstown, Ohio, told members of the Store Management Group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Coincident with release of its earnings report for the third quarter of this year showing sharply higher net income, the Republic Steel Corporation declared yesterday an extra cash dividend and a stock dividend on its common stock in addition to the regular disbursements on both the preferred and the common stocks.

It was a color story that Laddie Northridge offered yesterday in the showing of his mid-season millinery collection at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. He brought forth pastels in soft glowing tones of lime and gold, a moonstone blue and mauvish pink to complement furs by day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 -- Pcaific Coast shipowners and the striking CIO longshore unions exchanged verbal broadsides today as the owners rejected a proposal from Harry Bridges for resumption of negotiations.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The University of Wisconsin Student Board tonight asked wholehearted support for the Badger football team and censured "certain members" of the student body for "unsportsmanlike conduct" at Saturday's Yale-Wisconsin game.

A criticism of the time -- and by inference the money --wasted on Presidential elections, made by Rutherford B. Hayes three days before his name was placed in nomination at the Republican Convention of 1876, is one of the autographed items by former Presidents that go on display today to the public in the Pierpont Morgan Library, 33 East Thirty-sixth Street.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard, chairman of the recently appointed Commission for Displaced Persons, announced yesterday that the commission was planning for the arrival of the first group of displaced persons who will pass through this port during the end of this month or early November.

A survey by the industrial relations department of the National Urban League showed that last spring 7,400 Negroes were employed in white-collar jobs in businesses owned by whites and in industries in white neighborhoods in twenty-five cities, it was announced yesterday by Leroy W. Jeffries, assistant director of the department.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- An assertion that "the fire chiefs of our port cities have established a rather miserable record in the handling of ship fires" was made here today by Edward J. Kehoe, fire prevention and safety engineer of the United States Atomic Energy Commission in New York.
Joe Louis, heavyweight boxing champion of the world, has canceled his retirement and will defend his crown again in June of next year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The strength of the armed forces, Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force, reached 1,531,881 Oct. 1, the National Military Establishment reported today. This was an increase of nearly 38,000 over the Sept. 1 strength.
ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- Optimism among supporters of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey reached new heights tonight with the publication of official registration totals for New York State.

The transcontinental migration of a century ago to the gold fields of California will today be marked at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, with a special exhibition of mementos of the gold rush days.
Three thousand persons are expected to attend Brooklyn College's fifth annual Honors Day exercises to be held on the quadrangle at 11 A. M. today. An open house program will be held from 1 to 5 P. M.

The cakes that caterer Robert Day-Dean decorates for parties here also may be served by out-of-town hostesses. Mail orders for petit fours, cookies and Danish pastry as well as for the cakes are filled at the retail shop, 6 East Fifty-seventh Street.

HARRISON, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Cancellation of plans for a $7,000,000 suburban shopping center on property owned by Mrs. Ogden Reid in the Purchase estate area here was announced today by Boston promoters of the project and the Harrison Planning Board.

A plea for the strengthening of democratic processes within our borders and wherever the United States has influence was voiced yesterday by Rabbi David H. Panitz to the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, at services for the second day of Succoth, the Feast of the Tabernacles.
Tea-Maker, the 5-year-old owned by Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark, persists in upsetting the dope.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The Royal Dutch Shell group's 62,500,000 bond issue in New York to finance development in hard-currency countries brought in buyers for selected issues in the oil section of the stock market here today.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Over Russian objections the United Nations Joint Economic and Social Committee decided today to recommend to the General Assembly that an agreement be concluded between the United Nations and the International Refugee Organization. The vote was twenty-eight in favor and six against, with eight abstentions.

Marguerite Mallen has sold the vacant plot, about 40 by 110 feet, at the southeast corner of Queens Boulevard and Sixty-seventh Drive, Forest Hills, Queens, to the Showroom Realty Corporation, an affiliate of the Cunningham Pontiac Corporation of Richmond Hill. E. G. Minner of Great Neck and T. J. Hart of Forest Hills were the brokers.
I should like to express my opinion On the subject of inflation. A born European, I had more first-hand experience with it in the Twenties and Thirties than I cared for.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The United Nations Security Council in an emergency meeting this morning voted unanimously to order an immediate cease-fire in Palestine, where renewed fighting between Arabs and Israelis has gone on since Friday in the Negeb area.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,769, against 1,469 last week and 1,385 in the similar week of last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,075 arrivals yesterday compared with 448 last Tuesday.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's State the attraction is "The Three Musketeers," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's Technicolor screen version of the Dumas romantic adventure, with Gene Kelly as D'Artagnan and Lana Turner as Lady de Winter.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States representative, told the United Nations Security Council today that the Soviet blockade of Berlin "is being intensified" and that "the duress of which we complained and which is a bar to negotiations is being increased even as the Security Council deliberates."

W. E. S. Griswold Jr., president of W J Sloane, yesterday urged carpet manufacturers to step up research to bring out lower-priced merchandise. In an address before the annual meeting of the Carpet Institute in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel he said that retailers now have a real problem in controlling carpet stocks and getting satisfactory volume because current prices are forcing more and more consumers out of the market.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed somewhat irregular, 6 points higher to 3 points lower than the day before, with near months showing the most strength.

Reflecting its increased emphasis on the fitness of judiciary candidates, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York resolved last night that former Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler, Republican, and General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, Democrat, were qualified for the office of Surrogate.

Another page in Columbia's record books was rewritten last Saturday, the athletic office revealed yesterday as Coach Lou Little put his squad through a light contact session at Baker Field. An offensive drill by the first and second teams highlighted the day's activities.
Steve Owen hasn't tossed out the T, despite the fact that his football Giants used only the old. A system in the record scoring game against the Cardinals last Sunday.

The social work profession was called on last night by Miss Ollie A. Randall, president of the New York State Conference of Social Work, to make a unified effort to restore public confidence shaken by the recent "crisis in the state and city's social welfare program."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 19 -- Israel would accept the United Nations Security Council's cease-fire order, it was learned tonight, and the Government was awaiting official notification of the order before telling its victorious army in the south to stop fighting.

Tomorrow the Department of Sanitation, which this month was reorganized by Mayor O'Dwyer, will open complaint bureaus in each borough. For the men who are streamlining the department into a modern, scientifically operated unit, this marks the end of the long warfare between city dwellers and the department.

The Greek Government's long-awaited report on its investigation of the murder of George Polk, Middle East correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, asserts that Mr. Polk was murdered by Greek Communists with the apparent intent thus to discredit the Government by arousing the American public against it.

The board of directors of the American National Theatre and Academy, holding its first fall meeting yesterday, approved the signing of the International Theatre Institute Charter, which will establish ANTA as the United States Centre of the International Theatre Institute. The action followed the recent appointment of ANTA to membership on the United States National Commission for UNESCO.

Communism is no current threat to the internal security of this country, Attorney General Tom Clark declared yesterday at the forty-fourth annual convention of the National Association of Postmasters of the United States.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- France improved a deficit trade balance in September, her imports amounting to 49 per cent of her exports, figures obtained here today disclosed. A year ago her exports were 35 per cent of imports. In 1938 the percentage was 83.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Israel will accept the Bernadotte report on Palestine as a basis for discussing a settlement, Representative Emanuel Celler declared here tonight, but he said she would insist on changes.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19 -- Henry J. Allison, of Charlotte, N.C., president of the National Wholesale Hardware Association, said today that the trend in the hardware business is toward "normalcy" in addressing the opening session of the fifty-fourth annual convention at the Marlborough-Blenheim Hotel.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The Soviet delegation, while maintaining its silence at today's Security Council meeting on Germany, distributed to delegates and correspondents a booklet entitled "The Soviet Union and the Berlin Question" as its reply to the White Papers previously issued by the United States and Britain.

MIAMI, Oct. 19 -- The Women's Auxiliary of the American Legion, in convention here concurrently with the parent organization, today broadened the scope of its activities to include international affairs.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth agreed here today that they must not only strive to maintain democracy in Western Europe but should seek to revive it behind the Iron Curtain.

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, said yesterday that national security and world peace required American leadership and national unity to convince Soviet leaders of the strength and vigor of American democracy as a rival of world communism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Following labor protests against holding the third general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in Beirut, Lebanon, it was reported today that the time and place of the meeting might be changed.

VIENNA, Oct. 19 -- Austria's two major parties, upon whose cooperation depends the existing high degree of political stability here, have clashed over the school issue which has embittered Austrian political life since the foundation of the republic.

A warning that the parking of baby carriages or the storage of household effects and furniture in public halls of multiple dwellings is prohibited by the Department of Housing and Buildings was issued yesterday by Commissioner Bernard J. Gillroy.

Pierpont Estates, Inc., of 36 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday filed plans for the erection of an eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 40 to 44 Park Avenue and 37-39 East Thirty-sixth Street. The proposed structure will house 156 families and will cost $1,700,000, according to an estimate with the plans made by Emery Roth Sons, architects.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 19 -- Carl E. Bolton, former union official, today was ordered held for trial on a charge of attempting to kill Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations United Automobile Workers' Union at his examination before Recorder's Judge Christopher E. Stein.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 - Approximately $100,000,000 of new financing was proposed today in registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs, characterized yesterday as "unfair" charges of inefficiency and slowness on the part of customs examiners at La Guardia Field.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 19 -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have consolidated their long-term economic programs into a single plan extending to the fiscal year of 1952-53. They have submitted this plan to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A recommendation urging the United States to maintain an "open-door" policy, with proper safeguards, for the interchange of persons between this country and eastern Europe was adopted today by the Government's Advisory Commission on Educational Exchange.

Six new issues of public utility securities, running to more than $100,000,000 worth of debentures, bonds and preferred and common stocks, were priced yesterday for marketing by underwriting syndicates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The proposal that the Federal Communications Commission regulate the broadcasting of "give-away" programs by means of rules under which many of them would be outlawed as lotteries was challenged at a hearing today. Representatives of the radio industry from one end of the country to the other, with one exception, opposed such control.

Offering what he termed a "natural conclusion," Raymond Rodgers, professor of banking at New York University's Graduate School of Business, told savings bankers yesterday that regardless of the outcome of the election, there will be "little change, if any, in our monetary credit controls and debt policies in the near future."

Alexander Koral, a sanitary engineer, who was dismissed by the Board of Education because of his refusal to testify before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, began an action in Supreme Court yesterday for reinstatement.

Immediate formation of a Joint Chinese - United States Economic Planning Board to do "some real down-to-earth" planning for China, not only for this year but for the next three to ten years, was urged yesterday by Liang-Fu Chen.

Maj. Gen. David N. W. Grant (retired), who was Air Surgeon during the war, demanded last night a unified system of Government general hospitals for all persons entitled to such medical treatment from the Federal Government.

As community-conscious citizens we are aware in a general way that New York City, with its vast population, has thousands of sick persons who are constantly in distress and require expert care. We cannot, individually, do much to bring direct aid to the ill, but we can most certainly support to the limit of our means those organizations that do such work with a high degree of professional skill and efficiency.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, in its statement for the first nine months of 1948, to be released today, showed net earnings of $9,787,417, equal to $3.83 a share. In the corresponding period last year the company earned $8,727,826 or $3.42 a share.
The cold spell in the metropolitan area played a one-night stand yesterday. Today the weather is due to be more mild.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP) Coffee gets a clean bill of health as a nutritious beverage in experiments with white rats made public today at Cornell University. Rats which all their lives ha nothing to drink except coffee -- not even water -lived as long and well as animals that never tasted the stimulant.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- The Air Force and civilian airlines are working on mobilization plans which would give the Government virtual control of the 1,354-plane commercial fleet in event of war.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Oct. 19 -- After hearing of many phases of rural social and national agricultural problems, the National Catholic Rural Life Conference spoke its convictions today in a series of resolutions.
Counter - measures against the Georgetown spread formation were the aim of a long defensive scrimmage staged at Fordham yesterday.

New York's vanishing beer reserve, down near the bottom of the barrel as the result of a six-day wildcat walkout by 3,000 drivers, was dried up even more yesterday when strikers acted to cut the lone supply line from New Jersey.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 19 -- "We'll score against Columbia Saturday at Baker Field."

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Cornell got into the rough part of the week's work for Army today with offensive dummy scrimmage against a Jayvee group. Coach Lefty James had various combinations working as a first unit and the the Big Red squad went through the repertoire of ground and aerial plays.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The British Labor party asserted, in a pamphlet published here today, that Britain, under the Socialist administration, was the prime mover in the trend toward a united Europe but that progress was hampered by the economic backwardness of some countries, including France and Italy.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The Western powers bowed today to pressure from small countries and agreed to revive the suspended United Nations Atomic Energy Commission. Faced with the clear danger that their campaign to continue the suspension would not get two-thirds support in the General Assembly, the big Western delegations met in the small hours of this morning and decided to give way.
With the season approaching the halfway point, forty-seven college football teams, including eleven major squads, still can boast of perfect records, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Increases in railroad less-than-carload rates that would have cost Eastern shippers about $29,000,000 a year were turned down today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, told meetings in two Pennsylvania cities tonight that President Truman should have dismissed Secretary of State George C. Marshall for seeking to sidetrack his proposed "peace negotiations" with Joseph Stalin.

Every now and then an artist will give a recital that, for all its excellent features, will seem a less-rewarding musical experience than it should be, considering the gifts of the artist. It was thus with Gunnar Johansen's third New York recital last night at Carnegie Hall.
Martin James Monti, former lieutenant in the Army Air Forces, who will be tried Jan. 17 for treason in Federal Court, Brooklyn, was denied bail yesterday by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Great Britain and France have accepted the proposal of Economic Cooperation Administrator Paul G. Hoffman that further transfers of industrial plants from Western Germany for reparations payments be postponed pending a determination of their need there under the European Recovery Program.

Many well-known members of society are aiding in the 1948 New York Seeing Eye enrollment campaign, which will open today and will continue until Nov. 17. Two hundred volunteer workers will seek to enroll one thousand new members in the organization, a national philanthropy which provides dog guides for the blind. At its school in Morristown, N. J., the Seeing Eye has trained more than 1,500 dogs to be guides for blind men and women.

HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Field Marshal Gen. Walther von Brauchitsch, commander in chief of the German armies until Adolf Hitler dismissed him after reverses in Russia, died at a British Army hospital last night while awaiting trial on war crimes charges.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Thirty of the Cleveland Indians, who had to play an extra game after the regular schedule was completed in the American League to get into the world series with Boston, will collect a record $6,772.07 apiece for becoming the champions of baseball, it was announced today by Commissioner A. B. Chandler.

Postmaster Gustavus A. Latham of Marshall Pass, Col., was the most popular man yesterday at the National Association of Postmasters convention in the Pennsylvania Hotel. A bachelor, 64 years old, he was surrounded by every postmistress there.

Eight principles and standards for proper use of testimonials in advertising were announced yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau, Inc. A bureau spokesman noted that there had been little numerical increase in their use, but that new types and users made necessary a statement of standards.
BERLIN, Oct. 19 -- The Soviet Military Administration appears to be preparing to transfer over control of the Soviet zone to Communist officials backed by a police army.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Accusing Secretary of State Marshall of planning a "test of force" with the Soviet Union next spring, an editorial in the Communist newspaper Humanite today concluded that the resistance of the French to participation in a war against Russia "will not be passive."

Representative Jacob K. Javits objected strenuously yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer's endorsement of his brother, Paul O'Dwyer, for the Twenty-first Congressional District seat and condemned the action as one of "pure nepotism" with "no basis in fact or principle."

In presenting three new coiffures yesterday at the Salon Lentheric, Guillaume of Paris advocated neither all short nor all long hair but a variety of lengths. A triangular motif was followed in the hair styling. It was particularly evident at the nape of the neck, where the hair was either trimmed into a neat V or gathered by means of new spiral combs that resembled coils.

The council of the Authors League of America will meet at 12:30 P. M. today at the Hotel New Weston to authorize a strike by the Radio Writers Guild against a number of advertising agencies. The membership of the Guild, which is a branch of the league, voted last week in favor of a walkout.

While many college football coaches are faced with the task of selecting defensive and offensive units in the fielding of their teams, no such problem exists at N. Y. U. And, in many ways, the Violet coach, E. E. (Hook) Mylin holds a unique, if not an enviable, position.

Signing of a contract between Iran and Overseas Consultants, Inc., under which this foreign-advisory group of eleven engineering companies will undertake a study of economic and social conditions in Iran and make recommendations for planning of that country's projected $650,000,000 development program, was announced here yesterday and in Washington.

Sinclair Lewis, the novelist, was among the 404 passengers who sailed for Italy yesterday aboard the liner Saturnia. Mr. Lewis said he was going to Italy and France for six months and while there would write a series of nonpolitical articles, based on personal observation, for the North American Newspaper Alliance.

Mayor O'Dwyer accepted yesterday from Jacques de Thier, Belgian Consul General, a bronze plaque from the Belgian Government, to be placed eventually in the American memorial to the 6,000,000 European Jews slain in World War II.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 -- The increasing incidence of endometriosis, one of the commonest ailments of women which leads to sterility and many other disorders, is a social rather than a medical phenomenon foreshadowing a decline in our civilization, the American College of Surgeons was told tonight.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The second fatal tug accident just outside Baltimore Harbor within a month was believed today to have claimed the lives of seven men.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday a zoning regulation prohibiting the creation of new airports or seaplane bases or the extension of existing installations unless authorized by the commission.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 20 -- The American Legion pledged itself today to carry its fight against communism into the schoolrooms of the country by "aiding" the teaching profession so that the republican form of government does not suffer but is "exalted."
CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 -- The final Ohio political story will be written in the figures of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's majority for President in that state.
TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 20 (AP) -Marshall Field 3d said tonight that the mental health of children was "by far the most serious long-term problem" now facing the world.
PARIS, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The text of the Canadian resolution on atomic energy adopted by the United Nations Assembly's Political Committee today follows:

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 20 -- There is virtually unanimous agreement in Florida political circles that at this time President Truman and Governor Dewey are running neck-and-neck in the race to capture the state's eight electoral votes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Opposition to the sales tax as a means of financing education, appeals to citizens to take more part in community affairs and proposed formation of a county council for mcouragement of such participation marked the second annual Westchester conference on community development here today.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 20 -- Railroad lines that perform car-floatage or lighterage service in New York Harbor are due to receive an increased share of the joint linehaul rail rates beginning in January under a report issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Net income of the Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries for the first nine months this year rose to $26,181,000 from $10,837,000 earned in the corresponding three-quarter of 1947, according to a report for release today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20 -- Inflation could be ended very easily by drying up the monetary supply, United States Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, said here today, but that would cause widespread unemployment.

GREENWOOD, S.C., Oct. 20 -Depressed textile markets will spur modernization and expansion of plant equipment in this manufacturing community rather than cause any contraction of output, it was asserted here today by J. C. Self, president of Greenwood Mills.

Pending Congressional clarification of problems raised by recent United States Supreme Court decisions affecting industry-wide pricing systems, producers of standardized products should make "independent competitive determination" of their prices, company member representatives were told yesterday at the opening conference of the American Standards Association's three-day annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -Coke Stevenson, former Governor of Texas, today formally requested a Senate committee to investigate the Democratic run-off primary elections in which he lost the Senatorial nomination to Representative Lyndon Johnson, Democrat, of Texas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 13:

Frozen foods have no uniformity of quality in any brand, Elizabeth Sweeney, household equipment editor of McCall's magazine, said yesterday. She spoke at the first open fall meeting of the Eastern Frosted Foods Association, Inc., in the Biltmore Hotel.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The French Government today confirmed that it had agreed to delay the dismantling of German factories in accordance with the request from Paul G. Hoffman, ERP Administrator. A spokesman for the Foreign Office carefully pointed out, however, that this agreement did not cover a number of factories now being dismantled in the French zone.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- Hector McNeil predicted this evening that the success of the Marshall Plan might force the Soviet Union to cooperate with the Western European powers through pressure caused by the eventual dissatisfaction felt in the Eastern European countries that had been excluded from its benefits.
SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- "Folks, come up as close as you can. I'm no politician and I don't speak very loud."

MEADVILLE, Pa., Oct. 20 -- Five major developments of national industrial importance marked the opening of the new four-and-a-half acres plant here today, of the National Bearing Division of the American Brake Shoe Company.

Because of certain limitations placed on its initial stock offering of 20,000,000 shares, the Playboy Motor Car Corporation, which intends to place in production a new small automobile, announced yesterday withdrawal of the offering and said that new financing is being arranged.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20 (AP) -Fireman Hugh Casey today joined Fireman Kirby Higbe in the Pirates' baseball family and the question immediately arose:

The voters of the Twenty-fourth Congressional District in the Bronx are being asked to decide on Nov. 2 whether Representative Leo Isacson, who went to Congress last February after a special election, or State Senator Isidore Dollinger, is the greater exponent of Zionism and the greater champion of the underprivileged.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The British Commonwealth, through its Prime Ministers' meeting here, agreed today to build up its armed forces. This was announced in a communique at the end of secret discussions lasting all morning and afternoon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, who recently returned from commanding the Eighth Army occupation troops in Japan for three years, solemnly warned tonight that the United States faced "potential defeat" in any future Pacific war if Russian Communists gained control of the Japanese islands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Miss Evelyn Hersey, former assistant to the United States Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, will depart on Nov. 2 to serve as Social Welfare Attache to the United States Embassy in New Delhi, India.

In the seven years since his debut here as a Leventritt Award winner the young American pianist. Sidney Foster, has won a considerable following and last night more than 2,000 persons turned out to hear his recital at Carnegie Hall.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 20 -Christopher P. Mayhew, UnderSecretary of the British Foreign Office, arrived here today and informed correspondents that he had been commissioned to examine at first hand various aspects of the dismantling problem.
BOSTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Miss Adelia Beeuwkes, University of Michigan nutritionist, said today that men were "more businesslike" about reducing than women.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 20 (UP) -- W. C. McWaters today denied the testimony of a former minor league baseball manager that he had been bribed by McWaters to "throw" a game here last spring.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 20 -Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of Treasury, declared here today that the "overwhelming majority" of the American people were genuinely sympathetic to the new state of Israel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, declared this evening that the rebuilding of United States military strength was an affirmation, not a rejection of this country's "loyal support of the United Nations."

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- By a unanimous vote today the United Nations Joint Economic and Social Committee recommended that greater consideration be given to the geographical distribution of members of the Economic and Social Council as well as subsidiary groups.

The stock market gathered momentum on the recovery side yesterday and pushed ahead to new highs for the current movement. Accompanied by a further expansion in business, prices were enlarged more than a point in some of the key issues while the composite rate rose 0.60 point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The National Labor Relations Board, by a 3-to-2 vote, refused to set aside a union representation election today on grounds of employer interference. The decision overruled a regional director who held that the action of two officers of an employer who called in the employees individually and advised them of the employer's views was interference.

SEATTLE, Oct. 20 -- There are several "iffy" factors this fall in the political picture of Washington State, where various forms of "liberalism" and "radicalism" have been manifested for several decades.

Ten thousand commuters of the Staten Island muncipal ferry between the Battery and St. George, S.I., were more than a half-hour late in reaching Manhattan yesterday morning when a ferryboat broke down at the peak of the rush hours and had to be taken out of service.

CHARLOTTESVILLE. Va.. Oct. 20 (AP) -- Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican National Chairman, said tonight, "Our entire constitutional system rests upon the fundamental right of the states to determine for themselves all policies of local home rule.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Oct. 21 -- The Korean Cabinet met early this morning in emergency session under President Syngman Rhee to widen plans for the suppression of the Communist uprising on the southern coast of Korea, spearheaded by revolting Korean army forces.

Like many other scientists, I have read a number of technical papers by W. C. Lowdermilk and have developed a profound respect for his scientific ability. Also, like many others, I have read his book, "Palestine, Land of Promise," and was greatly disappointed at his highly emotinal approach to this important problem -- a stark contrast to the splendid objectivity which characterizes his technical papers.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee decisively rejected Russian atomic proposals today and gave strong approval to a resolution ordering the Atomic Energy Commission to continue work on the basis of the Western control plan.

ATHENS, Oct. 20 -- Minister of Justice George Melas said tonight that he had read American newspaper comment on the reported solution of the murder of George Polk, American news commentator, as transmitted to the local press, and made the following statement:
The first twelve titles of a new series of illustrated books for boys and girls 10 to 16 years old will be brought out next month by Pocket Books, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

The last remaining passenger ships in the regular American coastal services have been withdrawn in the face of heavy competition from modern American and foreign Atlantic liners scheduled to enter the cruise trades, it became known yesterday.

Columbia's football team took time off from their continual offensive maneuvering long enough to undergo a concentrated defensive drill against Princeton's single wing attack at Baker Field yesterday. Furnishing the opposition for Coach Lou Little's charges was the Lion freshman eleven.

A frequent cause of disastrous aircraft fires has been eliminated with the development of a nonflammable fluid to actuate landing gear and other airplane controls, the Douglas Aircraft Company and the Monsanto Chemical Company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Presidents of the seventeen Negro land grant colleges in the Southern and border states were advised by legal counsel today that the best interests of Negroes as well as the country dictated that they should oppose race segregation in education.

The council of the Authors League of America voted yesterday to approve and support the decision of the Radio Writers Guild to strike against those advertising agencies and radio-package producing firms refusing to subscribe to the agreement now in effect with the major radio networks.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The six member countries that are not directly concerned in the Berlin dispute are preparing to submit a resolution to the United Nations Security Council that will omit any specific condemnation of Soviet action.
Two proposals to make the United Nations a more effective instrument for international cooperation were made last night at the closing session of The New York Herald Tribune's annual forum.

Women of the Democratic State Committee who have spent the last three weeks touring the provinces to dramatize high prices," parked their 16-foot trailer truck outside the Biltmore Hotel yesterday and put on their act at a press luncheon in a ninth floor suite.
Aronowicz of 19 West Fifty-seventh Street presented some novelty fur designs along with his lavish collection of coats, stoles and capes, during luncheon yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The National Military Establishment is considering replacing its controversial "loyalty" questionnaire for military accreditation of news correspondents in the event of an emergency with the much shorter, less detailed form used during the last war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The question whether the Federal District Court has the right to intervene in the Federal Reserve Board's anti-trust case against the Transamerica Corporation of San Francisco was taken under advisement today by Judge James W. Morris.

Aptitude and temperament tests given in the past year to a group of men and women prior to their employment in thirty-nine advertising agencies were termed successful yesterday by Gwynne A. Prosser, personnel director of McCann-Erickson, Inc., in a report at the National Conference on Personnel Measurement in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins opened their National Hockey League home season tonight by routing the Chicago Black Hawks, 8 -- 3, before a near capacity crowd of 13,000 at the Boston Garden. Ed Sandford and Grant Warwick each scored twice as the Bruins kept Goalie Sugar Jim Henry under heavy fire from start to finish.

TEX RICKARD was wont to say "I never seed so many nice people." Uncle Mike Jacobs would have phrased it, "I never seen so many nice people." But Harry Markson would be more inclined to pluck a line from Ovid and intone, "They come to see: they come that they themselves may be seen." It isn't that Markson is particularly partial to Ovid.

Madison Square Garden stands squarely behind the Twentieth Century Sporting Club in the struggle of Mike Jacobs' organization to maintain its position of leadership in boxing promotion against the growing challenge of the Tournament of Champions.
A third political party in power could lead to the death of liberalism, Prof. T. V. Smith of the Maxwell Graduate School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University, asserted yesterday.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Two resolutions urging Congress to adopt an American Legion plan for universal military training were approved today by the American Legion Auxiliary.

Action was fast and furious last night in the sixty-eighth international six-day bike race as the field of thirteen teams reached the halfway mark of the marathon. The Kingsbridge Armory reverberated with the cheering of 12,000 persons as the speedsters stole twelve laps within a ninety-minute span.

Because design has become an increasingly important factor in competitive selling, the men who make the designs have become a necessity rather than an industrial luxury, it was declared last night by Stanley Marcus, executive vice president of the Neiman-Marcus store, Dallas.

A group of heroic dogs from leading medical research centers will mingle with their pedigreed cousins when the Brooklyn Kennel Club presents the borough's first all-breed dog show in twenty-five years at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, 1322 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, beginning Saturday.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The Russian bloc representatives in the United Nations General Assembly's Political Committee accused the United States today of deliberate delay on the Palestine question because of the impending American elections. Debate on Palestine in the Political Committee was postponed by vote of 34 to 11, with 10 nations abstaining.

We suppose there is no city department which, day after day, and in all seasons, is subject to such steady criticism as the Department of Sanitation. There are occasional outbursts of indignation against the subways, against the Police Department, against the Welfare Department, against the school system. But none of these is such fair game as Sanitation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 20 -- Both sides threw reinforcements today into the battle for the Negeb, an Egyptian Government source stated tonight. Aerial activity was intense, with the Egyptian Air Force attacking Israeli concentrations of armored vehicles and bases of operations in the desert settlements, it was said.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Commissioner Catherine Bramwell-Booth retired today after forty-five years of service with the salvation Army.

BREMEN, Germany, Oct. 20 -The first displaced persons to leave Europe for the United States under the terms of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 will sail tomorrow from Bremerhaven for New York aboard the United States Army transport General Black.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -Franklin Medals, highest awards of the Franklin Institute, were presented today to Dr. Wendell Meredith Stanley, biochemist, and Dr. Theodore Von Karman, aeronautical engineer, at the institute's 1948 Medal Day ceremonies.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- A two-hour discussion on limitation of debate in the United Nations Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee, considering the International Declaration on Human Rights, resulted today in a vote to curb the speakers.

Creation of a special advisory committee on store adjustments and merchandise returns, designed to function within the store management group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, was approved unanimously yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel by executives attending the first nationwide clinic on these problems.

DALLAS, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight the battle between President Truman and the Eightieth Congress "is the same battle between freedom and totalitarian government which is going on today throughout the world."

The Transport Workers Union will call a strike against seven privately owned bus lines in the city effective at 9 A.M. Tuesday. The union's aim is to focus the attention of the Public Service Commission on its demand for an increased permanent fare sufficient to pay $5,000,000 in retroactive wages to bus line employes.

Fears that the Government of India is moving toward nationalization or socialization were allayed yesterday by Sir Benegal Rama Rau, Indian Ambassador to the United States. He spoke at the annual meeting of the American Asiatic Association at India House, marking the fiftieth anniversary of the organization.

The Zionist Organization of America announced yesterday that it had started a ninety-day campaign for a food collection "to alleviate the serious shortage confronting the civilian population of Israel."

The advisory board of manufacturers of the New York Furniture Exchange yesterday changed the dates of the local winter furniture market from Jan. 24 through Jan. 29 to Jan. 17 through 22. J. J. Melniker, exchange president, said that the change was because of the revision in the Chicago market dates now set for Jan. 3 through 15.

Simultaneously with the report of operating results for the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30, the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company announced yesterday an extra dividend of $1 a share in addition to the regular quarterly of $1 payable to common stockholders on Dec. 1.

For the second successive week, crude-oil production last week established a new peak. According to the American Petroleum Institute production averaged 5,586,350 barrels daily, an increase of 51,550 barrels over the preceding week. A year ago, the nation's output averaged 5,268,400 barrels daily.

VIENNA, Oct. 20 -- Two Soviet air force lieutenants deserted their post in the Ukraine and crash landed their two engine bomber Oct. 9 at the Camp McCauley airport near Linz the United States zone. United States headquarters disclosed today.
COVINGTON, Ky., Oct. 20 (AP) -Senator Alben W. Barkley stumped his home state today with a plea for labor to vote Democratic and prevent a "return to hopelessness and despair."

The management of R. H. Macy Co. informed its employes yesterday that no dispute existed between the store and its workers and accused the president of a union representing its personnel of attempting to "create a strike."

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (UP) -- Hawthorne Race Track officials today announced a final toll of twentyseven races horses killed as the result of a fire that swept a wooden stable last night. The horses were valued in excess of $100,000.

A new cold reduction sheet and tinplate mill having an annual productive capacity of 300,000 net tons of steel items will be opened today at the Pittsburg (Calif.) plant of the Columbia Steel Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

Magistrate Charles F. Murphy ordered a complaint drawn yesterday against William Gwon, a headwaiter at the Ruby Foo restaurant, 240 West Fifty-second Street, after a preliminary hearing in Midtown Court on charges that Mr. Gwon had barred a blinded Army veteran and his Seeing-Eye dog from the restaurant's main dining room on Oct. 9.

During a six-hour hearing on the proposal of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company, witnesses of both utilities testified before Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, yesterday that such a move would be in the public interest.

In its report on candidates for the State Senate in Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond, the Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsement of six candidates. They are Senator Seymour Halpern and Senator Frederic E. Hammer, Queens Republicans; Senator Samuel I. Greenberg, Senator Louis L. Friedman and Senator William Rosenblatt.
Fordham drilled in the sunshine and twilight yesterday for its night game tomorrow at Griffith Stadium, Washington, D.C., where the Rams will meet Georgetown for the twenty-first time.

Arnold (Allie) Romano, described as "the biggest seller of narcotics in the United States," was held without bail in Felony Court yesterday on charges that he sold heroin to a Federal narcotics agent posing as a West Coast distributor.
Banking syndicates competed yesterday in a variety of underwriting transactions involving more than $35,000,000 worth of public utility and railroad securities.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -The Economic Cooperation Administration today authorized its first foreign aid to Ireland, tentatively allocating $4,498,200, for corn purchases in the United States.

The first indoor boxing promotion of the Tournament of Champions will present Charlie Fusari of Irvington, N.J., against the veteran Tippy Larkin of Garfield, N.J., in a ten-round welterweight contest at the Jersey City Armory tonight.

The Federal Mogul Corporation announced yesterday the declaration of a 15-cent extra dividend and a 40-cent regular dividend payable to common stockholders on Dec. 10. Payments for the current year amount to $1.75 against $1.55 paid in 1947 on the present capitalization basis.

The discovery in Labrador of high-grade iron ore deposits, which may rival the Mesabi range in extent and quality of ore, is among subjects discussed in a study, "America's Mineral Resource Position," released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Three apartment houses occupying a plot 50 by 100 feet at 404-06 West Fifty-first Street have been sold by Farwil Estates, Inc., to Michael J. Freeman for cash over mortgages of $25,500 in a transaction negotiated by Earl Douglas Hansen, Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -The Economic Cooperation Administration announced today that the American members of the AngloAmerican Council on Productivity were en route to London where the council will hold its first meeting on Oct. 25.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -Lester Cowan's next production for United Artists will be "The Customer Is Always Right," in which Ilona Massey, Marion Hutton and Vera Ellen will play the leading feminine roles, Cowan disclosed today.

Your editorial "Fractional Electorate" of Oct. 11, relying on recent Census Bureau figures, stated that on this coming election day there would be 95,000,000 men and women of voting age in the country, but estimated that no more than 53,580,000 would vote.

The Government, in seeking an injunction against maritime strikes on the West Coast last June, called the walkouts inimical to the nation's best interests but since the ban was vacated on Sept. 2 it has done nothing to force a settlement of the dispute, Edward M. Tangen, secretary-treasurer of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, declared yesterday.

Surgery saves lives and needless suffering, and is one of the vital services offered by New York's eighty-six voluntary hospitals. Severe shock brought about by injury or emotion is treated daily in the nonprofit institutions. Signs and symptoms are diagnosed each year for one out of seven persons in the metropolitan area who otherwise could not afford medical aid.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Thursday, Oct. 21 -- The Israeli Cabinet, after having accepted the order of the United Nations Security Council for a cease-fire, was still in session early today without having reached a decision on when to call a halt in the renewed Palestine warfare.

George Feld, 38 years old, who was described by detectives as an ex-convict, a known jewel thief and an expert in the use of celluloid strips to open spring locks, was arrested early today by policemen of the East Sixty-seventh Street station after he had been questioned about a recent series of jewel burglaries in East Eide apartments.

A vacant industrial plot, 125 by 100 feet, on the north side of Forty-fifth Avenue, 200 feet east of Eleventh Street, in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Mrs. Jennie Johnson to the Calamosa Realty Corporation, which plans to improve it with a onestory office and warehouse building.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- A shift in the management and control of Tucker Corporation appeared in the making today as distributors and dealers planned steps to bail the company out of financial difficulties that have brought operations to a virtual standstill.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, arrived in Paris this morning and spent the day in conference with W. Averell Harriman, roving Ambassador for the Economic Cooperation Administration, and the chiefs of its missions in fourteen countries and regions of Europe.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 20 -- Jamal Husseini, Foreign Minister of the Arab Provisional Palestine Government at Gaza, is here negotiating with Egyptian authorities to have the administration in Egyptian-held parts of Palestine gradually transferred from the military to the civil authorities of the Gaza Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -The Army has prepared regulations for paying inactive duty training pay to members of the Organized Reserve Corps, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Registration statements covering $11,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 180,000 shares of preferred and 95,000 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 20 -Close to 2,000 Turkish Jews have received authorization during the last three days to emigrate to Israel, as compared with 500 exit visas issued to Jews in the five months from last May 15.

Endorsement of Hyman N. Glickstein and Robert V. Santangelo by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York as qualified for the Supreme Court was welcomed yesterday by both candidates. Both are nominees of the American Labor party.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 20 -- One more determined campaign for the return of exiled King Leopold III to Belgium was crushed here this afternoon in the Senate when the Socialists, Liberals and Communists defeated a bill to hold a plebescite on the issue presented by the Catholic party.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The outstanding feature in the stock markets here today was fluctuation in British Government bonds following the terms of the new 100,000,000 ($400,000,000) British Electricity Loan.
The 1948 campaign of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York City for $425,000 was opened late yesterday afternoon with a reception given by James A. Linen, chairman of the drive.

Trading in cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange established a post-war record yesterday. In a turnover of 520 lots, prices closeed 45 to 90 points higher than the previous levels. The figure compared with the previous post-war high of 399 lots on Monday of this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Republicans can attribute their worry over retaining control of the Senate this year to the wholly accidental operation of Section 3, Article I, of the Constitution. This divided the members of the Senate into three classes so that, beginning with the second year of its existence, one-third of its membership would stand for re-election every two years.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 20 (AP) -Miss Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., and Armando Vega of Mexico upset the highly favored European team of Mrs. Nelly Landry of France and Jaroslav Drobny of Czechoslovakia today to win the mixed doubles championship of the Pan-American Tennis Tournament.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 20 -The Presbyterian Synod of New York voted unanimously today to oppose a "get tough" policy as the sole means of dealing with the Soviet Union.

Mayor O'Dwyer commended yesterday at City Hall two police officers and three detectives for their "excellent police work" in connection with the arrest on Tuesday of three men charged with the theft of $60,000 worth of jewelry from a safe deposit box in the Croydon Hotel, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Reports from Maine on the woodcock and grouse shooting have been excellent, and prospects for the deer season, which opens in six northern counties today, are better than they have been in several years.

ROME, Oct. 20 -- Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, denied categorically today insinuations made by the left-wing Rome press that Pope Pius XII offered the Vatican's services for mediation between East and West to Secretary of State Marshall.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- At the fifteenth annual convention of the National Association of Food Chains, Franklin J. Lunding, president of the Jewel Tea Company of Chicago, and president of the association's executive committee, today told the 300 chain stores executives:

TARBOLTON, Scotland, Thursday, Oct. 21 -- A KLM Dutch airlines Constellation en route to New York crashed into a slope one mile from Prestwick airfield early today, reportedly killing thirty-four of the forty persons aboard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -The House Campaign Expenditures Committee said today its investigation of Democratic fund raising in Michigan "indicates clearly the possibility of violation of Federal statutes."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -Senate campaign investigators put off until tomorrow plans to report on campaign spending by former Oklahoma Gov. Robert S. Kerr, Democratic Senatorial candidate in his home state.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- Reorganization of the United Nations commissions dealing with economic development and with economic stability will be demanded by a number of nations when the Economic and Social Council meets in Lake Success in February.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -The Government, seeking to smooth over a controversy with Mexico, declared today that it had not issued any "blanket" order permitting uncontrolled entry of Mexican farm workers to the Southwest.

Gonzalo Restrepo-Jaramillo, theColombian Ambassador, and Senora ~de Restrepo-Jaram~!lo have cometo the Waldorf-Astoria, aceom-Ipartied by their son and daughter-{in-law, Sen~r and Senora Juan G.Restrepo.

I was very much interested in your editorial of Oct. 20 entitled "French Election," in which you speak of the splinter parties. What you say, of course, is true that the process "has been a substantial contribution to the instability of French governments, since each government must be built upon a coalition of minority groups none of which has sufficient power to rule in its own name."

The five-story building at 135145 West Kingsbridge Road, northeast corner of Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, containing twelve stores and fifty-seven apartments, has been sold by Morton Rosenfeld, Lawrence Herring and others to the Kingsbridge Realty, Inc., represented by Bernard Friedman, attorney.

Government cannot operate as cheaply as private business, Harry B. Mitchell, president of the United States Civil Service Commission, declared yesterday. The amount of checking, inspecting and paper work involved makes it impossible, he told 2,500 postmasters at the National Association of Postmasters convention in the Pennsylvania Hotel, which will end today.

Substantial agreement that the House Un-American Activities Committee had operated at times along lines that merited public disapproval was reached last night by four experts on the "What's On Your Mind?" forum who considered whether civil rights needed more protection.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The plan for taxing secretariat employes of the United Nations, who at the present time do not lose part of their salaries in income taxes, was approved here today by the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee.

The State of Mississippi sold yesterday two issues of highway revenue bonds totaling $5,000,000. One issue of $1,000,000, maturing from 1953 to 1961, was sold to John Nuveen Co. and associates at an interest cost of 2.5849 per cent. The other issue, consisting of $4,000,000 of bonds due from 1961 to 1971, was sold to Ira Haupt Co. and associates at an interest cost of 3.0367 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- President Truman will make a sevenminute speech tomorrow night from the White House in a radio broadcast sponsored by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Robert S. Johnson of Garden City, L.I., one of the top Air Force aces of the last war, was appointed yesterday commanding officer of the Thirty-third Night Photo Reconnaissance Squadron, a First Air Force Reserve Unit at Mitchel Air Force Base Reserve Training Center.

More and more old automobiles are becoming instruments of death on our highways. If we had any doubt of this fact, we need not look any further than the New York State Motor Vehicle Bureau report on automobile accidents for the first seven months of 1948.

WASHINGTON, Oct 20 -- The Secretary of Agriculture today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to deny a request of the railroads for an immediate 8 per cent emergency increase in freight rates while holding hearings on a long-term increase of 13 per cent.

SEOUL, Thursday, Oct. 21 (AP) -Army headquarters received an unconfirmed report today that fighting had extended as far as Namwon, fifty miles north of Yosu. This information said only a few insurgents had reached Namwon.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein started actions yesterday in Supreme Court against twenty-five persons, including eight women, on charges of illegal registration for the coming election.

Even the child too young to have learned to read and hence presumably unaware how huge is the accumulation of words written in praise of man's best friend will recognize when confronted by a dog -- especially a small dog -- that a dog appears to be a praiseworthy creature.
A deliveryman, a school girl and a truck driver were waiting yesterday in the hand clinic at St. John's Episcopal Hospital.

Considering that the Football Yankees, even at the peak of their power in 1946 and 1947, never have beaten the Cleveland Browns, Coach Norman (Red) Strader climbed far out on a limb yesterday in essaying his team's prospects against the undefeated champions of the All-America Conference at Cleveland on Sunday.

The Foreign Commerce Club of New York opened its fall series of monthly dinner-meetings last night in the Commodore Hotel, with "Sixth Annual Steamship Night," honoring the lines serving the Port of New York. Fifty shipping company executives were the club's guests.
The Doctors Orchestral Society of New York, under Ignace Strasfogel, will give a concert next Sunday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the United Hospital Fund.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Representatives of the National Retail Dry Goods Association met here today with officials of the Treasury Department and the Bureau of Internal Revenue to discuss the possibility of allowing retailers to adopt retroactively the LIFO methods of valuing inventories.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 (AP) -Miss Ann Curtis, champion 400meter Olympic swimmer, said today she may turn professional this week.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- A French proposal to give the United Nations the right to intercede in future cases of mass murders of populations only when such acts of wholesale killings are sanctioned by States raised a series of strong protests here today.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 20 (AP) -Police saved a Negro from possible lynching by members of his own race last night after he had assaulted and robbed an elderly white druggist, Detective Chief John C. McCarthy reported.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Contract policies of the International Typographical Union, AFL, which in the last year have caused scores of strikes in the newspaper and commercial printing industry, have given impetus to "a revolution" in printing organization and methods, the opening convention session of the Printing Industry of America, Inc., was told today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -Payments to the New York Stock Exchange Maturity Fund can be deducted from Federal income tax as ordinary and necessary business expenses, the Internal Revenue Bureau said today. The fund is maintained for the benefit of families of deceased members of the Exchange.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20 (AP) -E. P. Taylor's Illuminable, a game son of Sun Again and Flaming Top, acquired for $7,500 as a yearling, carried the Canadian's silks to a neck victory in the twentyfirst running of the $10,000 added Spalding Lowe Jenkins Stakes at Laurel Park today.

The internal controversy over the management of New Stages, Inc., the downtown producing group which successfully brought "The Respectful Prostitute" to Broadway, reached a climax yesterday when Norman Rose and David Heilweil, its managing directors, resigned their posts.

Demanding that partisanship be kept out of foreign policy, Governor Dewey urged last night that the United States act decisively to "arouse and strengthen and solidify the free world" against the threat of totalitarian aggression.
Campaigns against rent gougers continued yesterday in three boroughs. In the Bronx and Brooklyn the accused were brought into court but in Queens the investigation appeared to lag.

Despite police protection for New Jersey beer trucks coming through the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels, New York's dwindling beer supply improved little if at all yesterday as a wildcat strike by 3,000 local drivers passed its seventh day.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 20 -Brazil partly lifted the bars on immigration today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -The Wisconsin honeymoon was over and, in a steady downpour, the Yale football squad went through a stiff, vigorous workout today on Thompson Field.

SHANGCHIU, China, Oct. 18 -The pattern of repeated Government military defeats, capped by the disastrous loss of Chinhsien, Manchuria, emerged in sharp perspective here today following talks with Nationalist officers, soldiers, officials and peasants along the troop-infested Lung-Hai railway.

Foreign-language courses in New York's public junior high schools showed an increase of 10,000 student enrollments this semester, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Theodore Huebener, director of foreign-language study for the Board of Education.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- The Soviet Military Administration agreed tonight to elections in Berlin so long as the elections followed the Communist pattern and all antiCommunist or non-Communist parties were erased from the ballot.

Dekor, a city shop devoted entirely to the countrified home accessories that the Maxeys of Bucks County, Pa., decorate with gay peasant motifs, opened yesterday at 300 East Fifty-sixth Street. The products enlivened by Pennsylvania Dutch, French Provincial or Early American designs in bright colors and metallics, range from tin pots for serving coffee to candle sconces.

Persons encountering Negro sales clerks in New York department stores are more likely to react to democratic than to prejudicial attitudes, according to a recent study sponsored by the Research Committee on Intergroup Relations and the Commission on Community Interrelations of the American Jewish Congress.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 20 (UP) --The color issue threatened today to bench two Nevada backfield aces for the Tulsa game on Saturday. The Negro players involved are Sherman Howard, fullback, and Alva Tabor, who handles the passminded Wolfpack's T-formation plays when Quarterback Stan Heath is out.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 10 points higher to 5 points lower than the day before.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- After intermittent investigations stretching back to 1939, a Government-appointed committee reported today that the basic principles of the defamation laws of the United Kingdom "are not amiss."
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 20 -Premier Paul-Henri Spaak was called upon tonight to allay the fears of his fellow countrymen that he favored war with the Soviet Union.

The Great Books Foundation, 246 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday the opening on Oct. 29 of nine seminars to train discussion leaders in its program to promote the reading and discussion of great books. The meetings will be held at Freedom House.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Organized labor's political groups are unanimous in predicting the election of Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat, to the United States Senate and the defeat of Republican Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota.
DETROIT, Oct. 20 -- Lieut. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer, head of the Air Defense Command, declared here today that "human flight at 1,000 miles an hour is no longer hangar day dream."

MANILA, Oct. 20 -- The Philippine House of Representatives today opened committee hearings on Un-Filipino activities, the counterpart of Washington's Thomas Committee, with testimony from Engracio Fabre, Commissioner of Immigration, naming fifty Chinese and several Russian Communist leaders.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Air Chief Marshal Sir Roderic Hill, who commanded Britain's air defenses during the flying bomb and rocket campaign of 1944-1945, declared in a report published today that the German rocket "foreshadowed further developments which still loom ahead of us."
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 20 -Henry A. Wallace made his bid tonight for support from the country's coal miners and, in the same speech, delivered an attack on the Marshall Plan.

Between some of the reactionary elements that have followed the trail of the "Dixiecrats" in their rebellion against the civil rights program of President Truman, and the idea of a South advancing toward the twoparty system, there may be a sevenleague non sequitur.

The restaurant buffet does for the printed menu what television performs for radio; the eyes accomplish in a glance what it takes the mind minutes to imagine. Proof, if such is needed, is the thirty-foot long buffet that David S. Cowles has just set up at the Ambassador Hotel, Park Avenue at Fifty-first Street.

In a card game named piquet, the winning of all tricks is called a capot. In the $17,850 Wakefield Stakes at Jamaica yesterday, the 19-to-20 favorite was Greentree Stable's 2-year-old colt Capot, named for his dam Piquet. With Ted Atkinson playing the hand, he swept the board.

The fame of Aksel Schiotz, Danish tenor, who made his American debut at Town Hall last night, preceded him. His imported records had established that he was an artist of stature, and his services to the resistance movement of his country during the Nazi occupation had won many more admirers for him at home and abroad.

ON Broadway -- or thereabouts -- the theatre may be laying palpable eggs these days as enthusiastically as a Rhode Island Red. But in the bookstalls you will find plenty of entertaining new books celebrating various fields of the sock-and-buskin set. In fact, we have quite a theatrical trend going on in literature (and its more or less distant suburbs) at the moment.

A new experiment in public welfare -- an attempt to rehabilitate in a medical clinic persons with chronic illness "who look like permanent relief cases" -- was announced yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard.

Since Father and Mother Day are lovable people, it is wonderful to have them back. Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, who wrote the fabulous "Life With Father," have followed it with "Life With Mother," which they installed in the Empire last evening.

The United States Maritime Commission approved yesterday in principle an application of the Pacific Argentine Brazil Line, Inc., for an operating differential subsidy between United States Pacific ports and the east coast of South America.

Every once in a while it seems desirable to point out, at least for the record, that football is only a game. That it is an excitingly good game we are prepared to admit. We still cling to the old-fashioned view that how you play it is more important than whether you win or lose.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- British exports for September showed an almost imperceptible recovery from August lows while September imports dropped about 2 1/2 per cent, the Board of Trade reported today.

Delivery of milk and other dairy products to 11,000,000 consumers in New York and suburban areas beginning next Monday was endangered yesterday when talks between drivers and milk distributors reached a stalemate.

A case testing the constitutionality of the Department of Parks regulation forbidding public speaking on park property without a permit ended its first round yesterday with a victory for the department. Magistrate Simon Silver in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, found Eric Hass, 43-year-old editor of the Socialist Labor publication, The Weekly People, guilty of having spoken without a permit on Oct. 1 on the mall on Eastern Parkway near Utica Avenue, Brooklyn, and suspended sentence.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 20 -- A $1,124,720 benevolence budget for 1949 was adopted today by the Synod of New Jersey of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. The action was taken at the Synod's 126th annual meeting at the First Presbyterian Church here.

The Daily Worker announced last night that it would publish in today's issue a statement by George Bernard Shaw criticizing the arrest of twelve Communist leaders here. The statement, in which the nonagenarian playwright remarked that Christ was a Communist, was made exclusively to the Communist newspaper and cabled from London by its correspondent there, The Worker said.

A United Nations official reported yesterday that, in the midst of bitter fighting in Greece, a "gentleman's agreement" had been reached and observed for more than a year by both sides. The agreement covers the nation-wide campaign to eliminate malaria, a campaign carried out with the full blessings of the rebel forces of Gen. Markos Vafiades.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Mexican team continued to build up its lead today in the international team jumping event at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show. The three-day low score race ends tomorrow.

" Tragic Hunt," a new importation from Italy, begins its initial engagement today at the Ambassador. Giuseppe de Santis directed the topical drama, which features Vivi Gioi, Andrea Checchi, Carla del Poggio and Massimo Girotti. Produced by Lux Films and released here by Films International of America, the picture has Italian dialogue and English titles.

Yesterday's announcement that a new issue of $150,000,000 of debentures of the American Telephone Telegraph Company would be on the way to market this year came as a surprise to the financial district. All outstanding issues of the company's bonds were affected adversely.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 20 -- The Right Rev. Dr. Malcolm E. Peabody of Syracuse, Bishop of central New York, was elected president of the Protestant Episcopal Synod of the Province of New York and New Jersey today. Bishop Peabody, who will serve for three years, was elected after the Right Rev. Barrel H. Reinheimer, Bishop of Rochester, submitted his resignation because of ill health.

The Government shortly may offer "phantom" or stand-by war contracts already contemplated for general purpose machine tools to producers of other heavy industrial equipment and affiliated metal trades items, Frank M. Shields, deputy director for production, National Security Resources Board, disclosed yesterday.

Hats must twinkle at night, even as the stars in a southern sky, according to Walter Florell, who showed a midseason evening collection in his establishment, 29 East Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon. He called the collection "Top hat -- white tie."

TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- Unless conditions at the time are far better than they are at present, Allied troops should not leave Japan following the signing of a peace treaty, Premier Shigeru Yoshida said at a press conference today.
Mrs. Lena Gabarini, a New York Travelers Aid worker for thirtyseven years, received yesterday a citation for loyal and faithful service from Edward E. Watts Jr., president of the society.
