Attorney General Tom Clark and his predecessor, Francis Biddle, were named as defendants in a $250,000 damage suit filed in Federal court yesterday by Armand Gregoire, a former French attorney, who charged that he had been interned unjustly for nearly five years.

Two hundred Masons, representing the first fraternal organization to join the local Red Cross Blood Donor Program on a citywide scale, donated pints of blood yesterday at three points in the city. The donations will continue until the Masons have built up a credit of at least 1,000 pints in the Red Cross blood bank.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The British people were told today that if the European Recovery Program worked as it should, the best they could hope for in the coming year would be a continuation of the present basic rations.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Britons in positions of responsibility are waiting patiently and with no outward show of great concern for the outcome of the United States Presidential election. The ordinary people are manifesting no perceptible interest in the campaign.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Mexican Army jumping team soared to an easy victory today in international competition at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show. With third straight triumph, the Mexicans captured the three-day low-score championship event.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -Col. Clarence E. Barnes, a Republican leader who heads the Reserve Officers Association, said today that President Truman's order to speed up the military reserve training program was a defense necessity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Truman told a country-wide radio audience tonight that the Republicans were intent on destroying the New Deal while the Democrats proposed to "build upon it a better way of life."

SHANGCHIU, China, Oct. 21 -Emblazoned in large Chinese characters on the city wall of Shangchiu are two fiery slogans, painted by the Political Department of the Nationalist Army, "Down with Soviet Red Imperialism" and "Eliminate the Communists who threaten the nation and ruin the people's lives."

Members of the American Standards Association were warned yesterday that there is danger of "Government assuming a proprietary interest in standardization," by extension of which industry was said to be increasing production and strengthening the nation's security.

Edith Weiss Mann, harpsichordist, and Ernest White, musical director of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, presented an elaborate program of eighteenth-century chamber music last night at Town Hall. They were assisted by Mildred Hunt Wummer, flutist; Felix Galimir, violinist, and a string ensemble composed of Louis Graeber, Ann Purcell, Henry Siegel and Annie Steiger, violins; Karl Doktor and Alfred Mann, violas; Hermann Busch, 'cello, and George Koukly, double bass.

ABOARD THE GENERAL BLACK, Oct. 21 -- The large-scale emigration of Europe's homeless to the United States started today, when this ship sailed from Bremerhaven with 813 displaced persons aboard. They will arrive in New York Oct. 31 and will spread out to all parts of the country, where homes and jobs await them.

The stock market made an unsuccessful bid yesterday to materially further its recovery beyond the high points of August and September. The list on the Stock Exchange came within a few cents of last month's peak but recoiled under moderate selling.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Despite numerous reorganizations and disappointing post-war business, the aviation industry today embraces twenty-five companies offering a range of fifty-five models of airplanes designed for civilian use, according to a compilation made public today by the Aircraft Industries Associates.

Slowed up orders for textiles have pushed gray goods storage in the Paterson, N.J. area up about 100 per cent over a year ago, and placed industrial warehouse space at a premium, it was learned yesterday. Finished goods storage of both rayon and cotton goods, according to trade sources, has increased about 50 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- During the week ended Oct. 20, member bank reserve balances increased $70,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

John Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, continued his inquiry into milk-pricing practices yesterday by issuing subpoenas to three officials of milk distributing concerns for questioning next Wednesday on the handling of bids for the supply of city agencies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A union may obtain some advantage from the Taft-Hartley Act despite refusal of its officers to sign the non-Communist affidavits, according to a ruling by a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 21 -Up until the last few days, Connecticut's 1948 election campaign has revolved around a single issue, "How far will Chester Bowles run ahead of President Truman?"

The City Council committee on general welfare closed yesterday a public hearing on proposed legislation to prevent or control air pollution in the city. Representatives of twenty-five organizations urged approval of such legislation while spokesmen for twenty groups opposed it, mainly on the ground that better enforcement of existing regulations would accomplish the same result.

The immediate need for blankets, piece goods for clothing, milk powder and cereals by refugees from the Holy Land will be met by a joint appeal of organizations engaged in that area, it was announced yesterday.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a $25,000 contract under which the Public Administration Service, an Illinois corporation with headquarters in Chicago, will make a study and analyze the organization and operation of the Department of Welfare.

Trade interest broadened yesterday in the new No. 1 rubber futures contract on the Commodity Exchange in a turnover of 640 long tons. Trading began in this contract in Monday, Oct. 11. Market observers pointed out that one large rubber interest made heavy offers in both the March and May deliveries, which were readily absorbed by the trade.
Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn arrived at LaGuardia Field yesterday after a four-week trip to Israel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- American corporations reported cash dividend payments of $679,300,000 in September, or 19 per cent more than the $573,200,000 paid during the corresponding month of last year, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce announced today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 21 -- The lovely Venetian gondola in which Robert Browning spent golden hours with Elizabeth Barrett in Italy 100 years ago rested tonight back of the old saltbox barn on the seventeenth-century Mulford place here.

A new wrinkle in illegal entry was revealed yesterday in Felony Court as George Feld. 38-year-old ex-convict was held without bail on charges that he had stolen an estimated $500,000 in jewelry and other valuables from East Side apartments in the last sixty days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Progressive party and the National Wallace for President Committee, major sponsors of Henry A. Wallace's Presidential bid, reported today that they had spent $1,092,377 from the first of the year to Oct. 18 in their national campaign.

If we had in this country the British system of awarding titles to our military men and allowing them to pick their own, a British example being Viscount Montgomery of Alamein, it is possible our commander in Germany would be known to history as Viscount Clay of Berlin.

The state's entire post - war building program is at a standstill despite the fact that $13,000,000 has been spent on plans and three years have elapsed since the end of World War II, Democratic State Chairman Paul E. Fitzpatrick charged here yesterday.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 21 (AP) -Unbeaten Clemson turned a fumble and a blocked punt into a pair of last-period touchdowns to gain a hard-fought 13-7 victory over South Carolina today in their forty-sixth annual State Fair Grounds classic.

A dance entitled the Red Shoes Ball was given last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza after the benefit preview of the motion picture, "The Red Shoes," at the Bijou Theatre. The beneficiary of both events was the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club at 283 Lexington Avenue, a haven for service men which was established during the first World War.

Henry A. Wallace declared last night in a nationwide broadcast that the time had come for Americans to achieve abundance for all the people or "admit our failure and abdicate in favor of a new kind of government."

William C. MacLaren, whose probation report said he was as "meticulous in opening a safe as a fussy housewife in her kitchen," weighed an old and proved adage with philosophical overtones yesterday in General Sessions.
FLINT, Mich., Oct. 21 -- In a normally Democratic tier of industrial counties in Southern Michigan, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey now appears to have a good chance to forge ahead of President Truman.

Large areas of solid color and smooth woodwork replace the carved laurel wreaths and ornate fixtures that once abounded in the town house that Robert Heller, industrial designer, has converted into living quarters and studio. The new offices for his concern open today at 161 East Sixty-first Street.

In a sweeping condemnation of the Administration's "horrible botch of our bipartisan foreign policy," Senator Eugene D. Millikin, Republican, of Colorado, charged last night that it could be "gutted by a Chief Executive who does not understand it," and urged the election of Governor Dewey as President on Nov. 2.

An unlisted and unpaid pavementripper who could give cards and spades -- spades, anyway -- to the wandering city crews that have the city looking bombpocked, was belatedly discovered yesterday in The Bronx Zoo.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 21 (AP) -Some 2,000 cheering students heard the University of Wisconsin football captain promise tonight that "things are going to happen Saturday," when Wisconsin meets Ohio State.
The text of Senator Alben W. Barkley's address at Carnegie Hall last night follows:
ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- The conviction of Julius Lobel, alias Jimmy Collins, and Irving Cohen in the $784,000 Mergenthaler swindle in Brooklyn was upheld today by the Court of Appeals in split decisions.
CAIRO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, said today that the Egyptian Army had "emerged victorious" from the current fighting in southern Palestine.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc., will ask the Government to "stick by" its former Palestine policy by insisting that the Negeb area remain in Israel. Mrs. Samuel W. Halprin, Hadassah president, predicted here yesterday.

After deliberating nearly four hours yesterday a jury found two members of Local 1250, a former unit of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, guilty of criminal contempt of court for violating an injunction limiting picketing before Oppenheim, Collins Co., department stores in Manhattan and Brooklyn last month.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21 (AP) -United States Champion Richard Gonzales and veteran Frank Parker, both of Los Angeles, stroked their way into the singles semifinals of the Pan-American Tennis Tournament today, along with the defending titleholder, Jaroslav Drobny of Czechoslovakia, and Eric Sturgess of South Africa.
Following is the text of President Truman's radio speech last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Military Governor in Germany, predicted last night that countries behind the Iron Curtain soon would begin to free themselves from Soviet domination as an outgrowth of the European Recovery Program.

The passing of the era of coastal ship travel is a loss to the nation on two counts. Today the only American ships remaining in passenger liner service are the Evangeline and the Yarmouth, and the current voyage of the Yarmouth is the last on schedule books that have been kept well over a hundred years.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 21 -- Swiftly and unexpectedly reversing a longstanding policy, the American Legion adopted here today a sweeping demand for payment of Federal pensions of $60 monthly to all veterans of World Wars I and II upon their reaching the age of 55.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Army today offered to qualified one-year veterans and men on active duty a plan for obtaining a commissioned rank which it described as "perhaps the easiest method ever provided."

Earning assets of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System were raised $160,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday by heavy acquisition of short-term Treasury obligations, although business loans decreased from the new high mark set last week.

The General Foods Corporation established a new high record for sales and earnings in the first nine months of this year, according to the report issued to stockholders yesterday by Clarence Francis, chairman, and Austin S. Iglehart, president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Fordham's green team, although boasting a 41-0 victory over St. Francis, is conceded little chance against Georgetown's powerful eleven in a night game at Griffith Stadium tomorrow.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21 -Already hampered by injuries, the Yale eleven received another serious blow today when it was learned that John Setear, regular end from New Britain, Conn., was order observation in the Yale infirmary for a back ailment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Oct. 16 were 913,832 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 22,021 cars, or 2.5 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 40,317 cars, or 4.2 per cent fewer, than for the corresponding week last year, and 17,934 cars, or 1.9 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Two leaders of the left-wing faction of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, charged yesterday that there had been widespread fraud in the recent union referendum in which the membership rejected a proposed constitutional amendment calling for direct election of international officers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- In exactly two minutes and twenty-one seconds today, the entire text of the novel "Gone With the Wind" -475,000 words on 1,047 pages -- was flashed, page by page, across this city by television and reproduced by high-speed photography methods before an audience of several hundred persons in the Library of Congress.

" Gyp" activities of some private personnel consultants are making it difficult for personnel executives to "sell" top management on all scientific personnel selection and measurement tests, Hiram S. Hall, personnel administration director, Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, declared yesterday.

If Columbia and Princeton throw passes around at Baker Field tomorrow with the prodigality with which their coaches tossed compliments at each other yesterday, somebody is going to score a lot of touchdowns.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The State Department disclosed today that the case against Robert C. Alexander, assistant chief of its Visa Division, had been closed with a formal reprimand by John E. Peurifoy, Assistant Secretary of State for Administration.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -The Christian church was chided here today for passing weighty resolutions looking toward the improvement of mankind while neglecting the confused and frustrated individual on its doorstep.
It was interesting to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES an article referring to the increase of taxi fares as introduced in the City Council.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- The Russian campaign to establish in the Soviet zone a Communist-controlled government of "all Germany" will move into a key phase tomorrow when a draft constitution for a German republic will be presented at the opening session of the People's Council's fourth plenary session.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A congressional sub-committee looking for Communists in maritime labor groups, tonight issued subpoenas for Harry Bridges, Congress of Industrial Organization Longshore chief, Hugh Bryson, head of the CIO Marine Cooks and Stewards, and fifteen others.
PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Britain accused the United Nations Trusteeship Council of incompetence today and was sternly rebuked by China for having expressed "superficial, premature and unjust criticism."

The Italian duo of Antonio Bevilaqua and Severino Rigoni put on a thrilling burst early this morning to tie the Belgian pair of Louis Saen and Emile Bruneau for the lead in the six-day bike race at the Kingsbridge Armory, the Bronx.

Marking an innovation in its program, the State Department of Mental Hygiene will give funds to help set up a mental health research clinic in Buffalo for the study of alcoholism, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene.

Reporting an enrollment of 2,648 students, most of whom are men, Dr. Frederick D. Patterson, president, Tuskegee Institute, Tuskegee, Ala., told the institute's board of trustees at the annual meeting here yesterday that the presence of the GIs in the student body gave the school "campus maturity and seriousness of purpose."

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 21 -- Charlie Fusari, Irvington (N.J.) welterweight, made it two in a row over Tippy Larkin by stopping the Garfield veteran in the sixth of a scheduled ten-round bout at the Armory tonight.
Navy Day Week will start tomorrow with a full schedule of parades, speeches, exhibits and "open house" on various ships and at shore installations.

In an auction sale yesterday of old English silver from the collection of Richard C. Paine of Boston, a rare Charles I perfume burner made in London in 1628 brought $2,800. The one-day sale at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, realized $34,502 from the silver that was sold together with Continental porcelain and other decorations from various owners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -The petroleum industry has grafted a streamlined "national oil policy" which it hopes the Federal Government will adopt. The proposal still is incomplete, however, and it probably will not reach the Administration until next January.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Molyneux inaugurates the midseason with forty models designed to help rather than hamper busy lives. Wearable, chic, without fuss and feathers, they are for the woman who appreciates simplicity with well-studied detail including accessories.

Councilman Michael J. Quill, who, as a sworn officer of government, has the responsibility of upholding the sovereignty and dignity of the state and all its agencies, has once more used the strike threat as a coercive weapon against government. In this case he has threatened to halt service on seven major bus lines carrying several million passengers daily.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended Oct. 16, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's comprehensive index advanced to 164.8 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 16 were 11 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor for Germany, in Washington for less than twenty-four hours, won an authorization from President Truman and his topmost security advisers today to draw upon an additional sixty-six big C-54 transports for use on the vital airlift into Berlin.

Consolidated net sales of the General Electric Company and its affiliates were 24 per cent higher in the first nine months of 1948 than in the corresponding period of last year and net income in the 1948 period was 34 per cent higher, Charles E. Wilson, president, announced yesterday.

The threat of a nation-wide strike of longshoremen when the present Federal injunction against longshore walkouts expires on Nov. 9 was renewed yesterday morning by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, before a Presidential board of inquiry, which is seeking to settle a dispute between the union and the New York Shipping Association.

THROUGH the thick darkness strange voices whispered ultimate truths, but he never could quite catch what they said. He tossed restlessly, half-bored by the cloudy obscurity of the lunatic world in which he found himself, halffascinated by its sinister charm. Nothing was familiar here and all former boundaries could be crossed.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth arrived last night with 2,246 passengers at Pier 90, West Fiftieth Street. She docked at 7:50 o'clock, twelve hours late because of rough weather.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct 21 -William Cagney disclosed today that his next independent production with his brother James as his star will be a murder film of the kind in which James made his early mark on the screen. "The Stray Lamb" and "A Lion Is in the Streets," two properties which the Cagneys own, will be put on the shelf until after the murder film is completed.

An announcement was made yesterday afternoon by the New York Yacht Club of an ocean race next summer that may eclipse in size any one of the kind ever held. A check-up afterward of likely entries gave indication of as many as fifty starting craft, more than ever set sail in one of the events to Bermuda.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 21 -- Government troops appeared to have the Communist-led rebellion under control tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Supreme Court, voting 6 to 3, refused today to interfere with the operation of an Illinois law which has barred Henry Wallace's Progressive party from the ballot in that state.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Richard C. Patterson Jr., recently appointed Ambassador to Guatemala, called at the White House today to say goodbye to President Truman. He will depart for his post the first week in November.

The United States Treasury issued yesterday a call on its War Loan accounts with the B banks requiring 15 per cent of such deposits as of Oct. 20, to be paid in two installments on Oct. 26 and 28. For banks in this area the amount payable each day is $42,057,200, and the daily payments by banks throughout the nation will total $133,334,200.

Eight judicial candidates of the American Labor party joined yesterday in issuing a statement attacking the reports on judicial candidates made by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the New York County Lawyers Association as "piously phrased but politically motivated" and designed to perpetuate machine politics and bi-partisan patronage.
TULSA, Okla., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The University of Tulsa put it up to Nevada today whether Nevada uses two Negro members of its football squad in the game here Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- As recounted in this space today, control of the Senate -- its committee chairmenships and majorities, its officers and its procedures -- is one of the high stakes in the contests throughout the United States this year for thirty-two (of ninety-six) seats in that body which are to be filled by the voters on Nov. 2.
A new type of baby bottle that is meant to be disposed of after a single use was shown yesterday to a group of women editors.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 21 -Army completed preparations for Saturday's meeting with Cornell by staging a brisk ninety-minute drill on the Plain today. The forty-oneman cadet traveling squad will entrain for Ithaca at 7 A.M. tomorrow.

PRESTWICK, Scotland, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Thirty-nine persons were dead tonight from the wreck of the Dutch airliner that crashed near here in an early morning fog today. The plane had forty aboard. Nine of the dead were Americans.

The performances given under Dimitri Mitropoulos by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall were exciting and challenging and uneven. But he had a program and a soloist to reckon with. The soloist was Joseph Szigeti, playing the Brahms violin concerto.

" The Red Shoes," a British-made romantic drama written, produced and directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger and filmed in Technicolor, will have its local premiere today at the Bijou. Anton Walbrook, Moira Shearer, Leonide Massine, Marius Goring, Albert Basserman, Robert Helpmann, Ludmilla Tcherina and Esmond Knight head the cast of the ballet drama, which is being presented by J. Arthur Rank and released here by Eagle Lion.

The Rev. Wilfred F. Penny, who will be 31 years old on Nov. 27, announced yesterday acceptance of the rectorship of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Ignatius, West End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street. He comes from St. James Church, Franklin Square, L.I., where he has been the priestin-charge for the last seven and a half years.

James A. Farley, former Post master General and Democratic National Chairman, declared yesterday that the present United States policy toward Spain is "short-sighted" and urged this country "in its own interest" to reestablish full diplomatic relations.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Lists for the Government's 100,000,000 3 per cent electricity issue closed this afternoon, and the strength of giltedge stocks, which recorded allround gains up to 1/4 point, indicated confidence in the loan in the stock market here today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 -- A chemical test for cancer with a high rate of accuracy in a limited number of test cases was reported today to the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

Allowance for adequate parking space in the planning of shopping centers in outlying districts was stressed by Seward H. Mott, executive director of the Urban Land Institute, in a talk last night at the monthly dinner meeting of the New York Metropolitan District Chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers in the Advertising Club.

A new situation comedy, "The George O'Hanlon Show," which will draw on the doings of family life, is planned to receive its premiere on WOR at 8 P.M. Thursday, Nov. 4. Featured in the program will be Mr. O'Hanlon and his wife, Lurene Tuttle.

The elegance of the Nineties with its stiff rich fabrics, its jewel-like colors and portraits of ladies in low-necked gowns was recalled by Russeks yesterday in a showing at the Plaza Hotel of festive fashions for after five. Taffeta rustled with the same sibilant swish of that bygone era, pretty throats were again set off by the low decolletages of deep garnet, green and gold brocades.

The retirement of Miss Belle de Costa Greene as director of the Pierpont Morgan Library and the appointment to that position of Frederick B. Adams Jr. of the Air Reduction Company, Inc., were made known yesterday. The change will become effective Dec. 1.
Paris, Oct. 21 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

BOSTON UNIVERSITY vs. N.Y.U. (Tonight) -- The Terriers are on the march toward top-ranking in the East within the next few seasons. The Violet is marking time at best. Certainly it is going nowhere in particular, least of all in this game. B.U. by whatever score it pleases.

Tammany "wheel-horses" and two politician-lawyers who hold important positions in the city administration received lucrative guardianship appointments last year from New York County Surrogates' Court, O. John Rogge, American Labor party candidate for Surrogate, charged yesterday.

Plans for converting the Whitelaw Reid mansion at 451-53 Madison Avenue, at Fiftieth Street, into an office building to house various Catholic agencies were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by the Archdiocese of New York.

A Newspaper Advisory Committee, headed by Stuart Peabody, assistant vice president in charge of advertising for the Borden Company, has been appointed to assist the Advertising Council, Inc., in preparing the newspaper program on the campaign to improve public understanding of the American economic system, it was announced yesterday.

ATLANTA, Oct. 21 -- Although standard political indices give Georgia's twelve electoral votes to President Truman this year, there is a growing feeling locally that certain "imponderables" could still turn the national election into a closely contested three-way race in this state.

Further Congressional action for upward revision of postal rates to meet mounting operating costs and deficits of the postal service was called for here yesterday by Post Office officials. Even increased postal rates effective next January were deemed inadequate at closing sessions of the four-day convention of the National Association of Postmasters of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -The Internal Revenue Bureau disclosed today that eight organizations listed by Attorney General Tom Clark as "subversive" had been stripped of their tax-free status.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Negotiations are reported virtually completed for the purchase of the Edgewater Beach Hotel here for $6,000,000 by a Boston hotel syndicate headed by A. M. Sonnaband, it was learned today.
CASPER, Wyo., Oct. 21 -- On the football odds board in the Arcade Bar here is chalked: "$1,000 on Hunt." It has been there two weeks. There have been no takers.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- Russian authorities permitted today the release of twenty German policemen and guards from the Western sectors, arrested Sept. 6 during Communistled disorders in the City Hall. The disclosure of the Russian move was made by Acting Mayor Dr. Ferdinand Friedensburg, who told members of the City Assembly that arrangements were being made for the early release of forty other Western sector employes of the city government still held.
At least 2,000 persons who registered for the November election may be challenged on their residence qualifications if they appear at the voting polls here, it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Memorial busts of Admirals of the Fleet Earl Jellicoe and Earl Beatty, British naval heroes of World War I, were unveiled in Trafalgar Square today in a Navy Day ceremony marking the 143d anniversary of Britain's greatest naval victory -- the Battle of Trafalgar.

Operations of the Continental Can Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, last, resulted in a net profit of $14,420,743 after taxes and all charges, Hans A. Eggers, president, reported yesterday.

Entry of insurance company credit into the financing of purchases of truck-trailers was revealed here yesterday in the announced terms for a $30,000,000 credit for the Fruehauf Trailer Sales, Inc., a new company formed to take over installment receivables of the Fruehauf Trailer Company for periods up to five years.

In an unusual action, the Board of Superintendents has approved for New York public high school reading lists the best selling novel "Gentleman's Agreement," which last winter was banned because of passages that were considered immoral.

" Japan Diary," by Mark Gayn, has been scheduled for Nov. 15 publication by William Sloane Associates. It is a day-by-day account of his experiences in Japan and Korea from December, 1945, to May, 1947, and a story of the forces that are shaping our occupation of the countries.

The end of the eight-day beer truck driver strike appeared to be in sight late last night after an announcement that brewers and union leaders had reached an agreement under which par ticipants in the "wildcat" walkout would start returning to work on Monday. Observers noted, however, that the time schedule issue, the crux of the dispute, did not appear to have been settled.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 21 -- The Liberation Front of the Slovene Peoples Republic, one of the constituent republics of Yugoslavia, acknowledged for the public record several days ago that segments of the Communist party in Trieste and Gorizia supporting the Communist Information Bureau and the pro-Cominform Austrian Communist party in Carinthia had organized strong opposition to Yugoslavia's claims to those territories.

Fines totaling $50,000 were imposed by Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday on the Rubber Manufacturers Association, Inc., of New York, two of its officers and eight corporate members after their plea of nolo contendere to a criminal information charging violation of the Sherman Anti-trust Act.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 9 points lower to 3 points higher.

Knickerbocker Brands, Inc., manufacturer and distributor of dental gold, has purchased the newly completed one-story building at 1221-1223 Utica Avenue, Brooklyn, from the G. F. Construction Corporation. The building, on a plot 60 by 100 feet, will be used by the new owner for manufacturing purposes.

As Mr. Krock pointed out on this page yesterday, it is a chance turn of the wheel of fortune that puts in doubt the political complexion of the next Senate. Thirty-two places in that Senate will be filled by the voters on Nov. 2 (Maine has already voted). Fifteen of these places are now occupied by Democrats.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan issued a statement yesterday in support of General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, the Democratic nominee for Surrogate, who is running against George Frankenthaler, Republican-Liberal candidate, and O. John Rogge, American Labor party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Army and Air Force disclosed today plans to build 1,933 additional family housing units in a joint effort to relieve the acute lack of housing for service personnel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A proposal that steel producers set aside 20,380 tons of steel plates and shapes for shipbuilders next January and February was endorsed today by the Navy and Maritime Commission.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 21 -- Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, in a message to the American Society of Travel Agents in a convention here, declared today that the ECA fully recognized the importance of tourist travel abroad as a factor in promoting peace and prosperity.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 21 -Richard Bemporad, 59 years old, a retired business man, saved his life here today by clinging, while said to be unconscious, to an overturned dinghy in the waters of Long Island Sound.

Title to the Jensen Building at 665 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-third Street, was acquired yesterday by David A. Schulte, who signed a contract for the purchase of the property last summer from the City Investing Company, Robert W. Dowling, president Clark T. Chambers, Inc., was the broker in the sale of the property, which at the time was reported to have brought more than $2,200,000, its assessed valuation.

Up at Squadron A Armory, police trainers are schooling green horses to nudge pedestrians out of the way without kicking, to catch runaways on bridle paths, to look smart leading a parade, and even to jump in competition at Madison Square Garden.

Representative Leo Isacson and Arthur Schutzer, state executive secretary of the American Labor party, were at the head of forty pickets marching in front of the Lexington Avenue entrance to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night demanding the removal of Gen. Lucius D. Clay from his European command.

New York hunters seem to be displaying considerable interest in what is going to happen during the Rhode Island waterfowl season this year, for that state is the only one in this area having late dates. They will open there on Dec. 10 and close of Jan. 8, which should insure good broadbill shooting on the open water and possibly much better black duck shooting than New York, Connecticut or New Jersey.

Three group shows by out-oftown and local exhibitors are on view this week in the art galleries. At the Riverside Museum, the Northwest Water-Color Society is holding its first New York exhibition with something more than a hundred items listed.

Plans for an information and advisory clearing house to help the borough's industries meet the rapidly stepped-up defense program were announced yesterday by the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce to its 1,200 members. Changed military science and materiel as well as production shortages have created unprecedented problems in the nation's rearmament program, the chamber emphasized.

Chickens weighing under four pounds are being featured at Bohack stores today for 49 cents a pound. Throughout the city, 51 cents is the most general price for these birds, according to the City Department of Markets. The tariff, 2 cents under last week's average, is the lowest for several months.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain and France gave their approval in general tonight to a compromise resolution on the Berlin issue presented by the six members of the United Nations Security Council not directly concerned in the dispute.
James F. Loughlin's letter in THE TIMES of Oct. 14 calls for some comment.

Following are the speeches delivered last night by Governor Dewey and Gen. Lucius D. Clay, American Military Governor in Germany, at the annual dinner of the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The Court of Appeals reserved decision today on the plea of Long Island University to use the property it acquired recently at Oyster Bay, L.I., to provide facilities for about 500 students.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) -Chairman J. Parnell Thomas said tonight that the House Committee on Un-American Activities had information indicating that the Communist party had secretly registered 75,000 members in this country.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 21 -- Extension of the bizonal Joint Export-Import Agency to include its equivalent in the French zone will expand the present scope of the unit by about $125,000,000 a year, according to an analysis presented this afternoon by the directing head of the organization.
DETROIT, Oct. 21 -- The Chrysler Corporation attributed the lay-off today of 8,000 employes in its Dodge main plant to one man's rush to a time clock. A company spokesman gave the following account:

Improved visibility and increased riding comfort are among the automotive advances reported for the "Nash Airflyte for 1949" line presented yesterday by the Nash Motors division, Nash-Kelvinator Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- With Republican control of the Senate at stake in the election, the Republican Senatorial campaign committee, which has raised $167,578 since Sept. 1, sent most of it back to states where key contests are being waged.
Anne O'Hare McCormick's column about German women in THE TIMES of Sept. 13 is of the greatest interest, especially to those who, like myself, have been recently in Germany.

Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, Democratic candidate for Vice President, appealed last night to labor union members to turn out a heavy vote and not to waste their votes on "diversionary" candidates.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- In a discussion of this country's achievements at the recent safety-of-life sea conference in London, Admiral Joseph Farley, commandant of the United States Coast Guard, Washington, D.C., asserted today that "we were generally satisfied with the progress we were able to make," but that "there is room for further advances without unduly burdening any foreign shipping."

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- An inventory to determine the limits of the dismantling of German factories will be completed as rapidly as possible -- it is hoped within ninety days -Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said today.

Approximately 1,500 top banking executives, representing the management of 15,000 banks throughout the country, are scheduled to attend the National Credit Conference in Chicago Dec. 13 to 15, it was announced yesterday by Evans Woollen Jr., president of the American Bankers Association.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- One person killed and 200 injured was the toll today in three new riots in French mining areas that increased tension and the difficulties of a settlement of the coal strike. A statement by the Communist party had the result of bringing out into the open its objective of defeating the European Recovery Program.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 (AP) -Paul Brown, coach and general manager of the Cleveland Browns, will resign as chief of the AllAmerica football conference champions and return to the intercollegiate field in 1949.

MANILA, Friday, Oct. 22 (AP) -An Indonesian Republic official said today he had new evidence that Bobby Freeberg, United States flier known as the Republic's "oneman air force," was captured by the Dutch.
Vice Admiral Jules James, USN, and Mrs. James of Baltimore are at the St. Regis.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The third session of the United Nations General Assembly got its first glimpse of Big Five unanimity today when all the major powers announced their support of a Mexican resolution calling on them to try harder to settle their differences.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Negro youth must be encouraged to go into industrial and agricultural occupations which require trained technicians if they are to be turned away from "a craze" for whitecollar jobs, the seventeen presidents of Negro land grant colleges were told today.
Good news and bad news came from the New York Football Giants yesterday.

Prices on the spring line of men's shirts and sports wear which Marlboro Shirt Company, Inc., will show to retailers beginning next Monday will be priced about 10 per cent under last year. The opening price on dress shirts will be $22.50 against $25.50 last year, and range to $48 per dozen.

Citing a need for enlarging American Red Cross activities in the armed forces as well as among civilians, Brig. Gen. E. F. Jeffe, retired, chairman of the 1949 fundraising committee of the New York Chapter, declared yesterday that democracy was at stake.
PARIS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Mexican peace resolution approved today by the Big Five members of a United Nations subcommittee:

LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The new edition of Jane's Fighting Ships, authoritative publication on world navies, said today the United States was building up anti-submarine vessels and preparing ships for special duty in the Arctic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Truman received today from Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, the first copy of a History of the Congressional Medal of Honor and the 2,116 Army heroes who have received it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -Good times for the next six years are foreseen by Agriculture Department economists. Even if a moderate recession should come, they regard living standards as sure to remain far above the 193539 pre-war level.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -Counsel for New York County (Manhattan) made a one-minute defense before the Supreme Court today of the state's ban of the book "Memoirs of Hecate County."

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The fight to remove Communist influence and leaders from the British Labor movement has extended to the Cooperative party, it became known today. The party, whose representative in the Cabinet is Defense Minister A. V. Alexander, is a constituent of the National Council of Labor, in which it is represented along with the Labor party and the Trades Union Congress.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Straight votes for the Progressive party will be sought in Cook County (Chicago) to get evidence of the sentiment for Henry A. Wallace for President, whose name will not be printed on Illinois ballots as a result of today's Supreme Court decision.
Mayor O'Dwyer placed primary responsibility for keeping the city clean on the "people" as he officially opened yesterday the Sanitation Department's five borough complaint bureaus.

For a few ticket-buyers in the crowd of 17,126, the race of the season was run at Jamaica yesterday. It was a claimer, fourth on the program, and there wasn't a reasonable facsimile of Citation in it. But the winner, Harry L. Carr's 3-year-old Glenwood Kid, accounted for the fattest mutuel pay-off of the 1948 campaign in New York, and those who had asked for his number won't soon forget the happy occasion.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 21 -- With 125 denominational representatives of more than forty groups in the Protestant church in attendance, a special meeting of the Church World Service was opened here today. It will take up plans for the enlarged program which the world organization will carry out in caring for displaced persons under the new United States Government edict permitting 205,000 DP's to enter this country in the next two years.

BERLIN, Oct. 21. -- Construction of a powerful United States radio station in the vicinity of Hof, near the Czechoslovak frontier in northern Bavaria, has been abandoned by the United States Military Government because of the lack of funds.

Eight men set fire to a fivestory Harlem tenement last night after an argument in which they stabbed two superintendents' helpers, the police reported. One man was burned fatally in the fire, and a woman and a fireman were hurt seriously.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha, Neb., had registered $6,000,000 of serial debentures, due 1966-69, that are to be sold at competitive bidding.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- An order for a cease-fire in the Negeb at noon tomorrow. Greenwich Mean Time [7 A.M., Friday, Eastern standard time], was sent tonight to the Egyptian and Israeli Governments by the Acting Mediator on Palestine, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Commonwealth good-will and cooperation were in fullest flower tonight when all the Prime Ministers and delegates attending the Dominions' conference were guests of Prime Minister Attlee at a banquet at 10 Downing Street.

Instead of staging "He and She," the Ken Englund-Ogden Nash-Vernon Duke revue dealing with the actions and thoughts of a man and woman, Agnes de Mille yesterday was announced by the Ewings and Giovanni Cardelli to direct "The Rape of Lucretia."

LINZ, Austria, Oct. 21 -- Lieut. Anatalya Barsof, pilot of the twin engine Soviet bomber that he flew into Hoersching airfield here ten days ago, joined his navigator, Guard Lieut. Piotr Pirogov, today, in telling a group of press and radio representatives that they had fled from the Soviet Union in a search for freedom.

Five Government mediators, who have been attempting to bring about an agreement by 15,000 milk drivers with several hundred milk dealers, issued a joint statement early today asserting it had become apparent that the dispute "cannot be settled or adjusted by direct negotiation."

John Ellis, Republican candidate for Congress in the Eighteenth District, charged yesterday that as the result of a "deal" by Democrats in his district had virtually abandoned their work on behalf of their candidate, John P. Morrissey.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The grain markets were firm today in the early trading on the Board of Trade. Corn led, but failure of outside buying to broaden led to profit-taking and a sharp reaction, December corn breaking 1 1/4 cents a bushel from the top.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21 (AP) -Miss Judy Johnson, who has experienced marked success with steeplechasers during the current meeting, saddled her fourth and most notable winner today, the Auburn Farm's Homogenize, in the $10,000 added Governor Ogle Steeplechase Handicap.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- A proposal by France that mass extermination of populations may be punished as acts of genocide under a proposed international convention only when such acts were sanctioned by the states involved was rejected today by a vote of 40 to 2 in the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

The New York City Opera Company presented its first "Don Giovanni" of the season at City Center last night. It was a performance marked by neat ensemble singing, expert orchestral playing under the direction of Laszlo Halasz, some pretty voices and an atmosphere which was good-humored but at least partially helter-skelter.

The Bronx transfer revolt that had spread confusion among 40,000 passengers and city and bus company officials since Sunday ended at 6 A.M. yesterday when 250 special employes of the Board of Transportation began the sale of six-cent transfers at thirty-one rapid transit stations throughout the borough.

MIAMI, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Hubert A. Goode of Portland, Ore., was named national president of the American Legion Auxiliary today. Her only opponent, Mrs. Archie W. Miller of New Cumberland, Pa., withdrew as a candidate.
PARIS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The text of remarks by John Foster Dulles, United States delegate, to the United Nations Political Committee today:

Looking in retrospect to the early days of its existence, the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn opened yesterday a week's exhibition of relics of a half-century ago and their modern counterparts with a preview for friends and old alumni.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Tax refunds totaling $32,036,353 have been given 5,169 corporations during the last six years for overpayments on their wartime "excess profits," the Internal Revenue Bureau reported today. More than half -- $16,672,162 -was paid out in the year ended on June 30.
MONTREAL, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens took over first place in the National Hockey League tonight by blanking the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 0.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The French Government has sent to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation a statement of French objectives for the end of the first year after the Marshall Plan, the year from July 1, 1952, to July 1, 1953, when beneficiaries of the plan will be expected to be able to get on without United States aid.

Eight specific questions have been raised by the basing point controversy stirred by the recent Supreme Court and Federal Trade Commission decisions, according to an extensive research study presented yesterday by Raymond E. Bell, management and marketing consultant, Corbin, Va.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -Interhandel of Basle, Switzerland, today filed suit against the United States Government for return of about $103,000,000 worth of stock and cash seized during the war under the Trading with the Enemy Act.

Flouting police orders to keep off Broadway as theatre-goers started homeward, 800 teen-age supporters of Henry A. Wallace marched down that thoroughfare late last night disrupting the normal heavy flow of traffic.

A business associate came over to my desk the other morning and showed me an airmail envelope mailed in China with postage stamps on it amounting to $250,000. I asked him what made this letter so valuable as to require such a sum for postage, and his answer was: "The inflation in China makes the postage cost that much."

TRENTON, N.J.; Oct. 21 (AP) -A fall season for New Jersey race tracks has been proposed by Gov. Alfred Driscoll as a means of boosting state revenue. The plan, embodied in a memorandum to the State Racing Commission, would have the season open later and last longer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Gen. Lucius D Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, described Ilse Koch today as "a woman of depraved character and ill repute" but against whom war crimes charges for which she had originally been sentenced to life imprisonment were supported only by "hearsay."

TEL AVIV, Oct. 21 -- Determined to fight to the last minute before the imposed cease-fire halted the campaign, the Israeli Army captured Beersheba today and posed a serious threat to all Egyptian arms in the war in Palestine.

A Gibson Girl Ball will be given on Dec. 20 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza in honor of Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, who is completing her twenty-fifth year as chairman of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee. Proceeds of the dance will be devoted to the committee, which was founded fifty years ago by the State Charities Aid Association as a placement agency for homeless children, regardless of race, creed or color.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 22 -- With the Communist-led insurgents surrounded in three small areas of Cholla Namdo Province, the Government announced tonight that final mopping up operations were under way.

Jeffery J. Keating, 56 years old, of 152 East Sixty-first Street, manager of a four-story, seven-apartment building at 119 East Sixtieth Street, was arrested yesterday at the East Fifty-first Street Police Station on a charge of grand larceny.

Governor Dewey told political adherents here yesterday that he expected "increasing vituperation and abuse" from opponents in the closing week of the Presidential campaign. He asked his followers not to respond in kind, because it would have the end result of destroying national unity and would delay world peace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A Presidential board of inquiry, in a report made public by the White House today, expressed confidence that East Coast longshoremen and their employers could reach an agreement before an anti-strike injunction expires about three weeks hence.

A part of the immense debt that man owes to his friend, the dog, will be suggested today at the show of the Brooklyn Kennel Club. A group of dogs described as the "most valuable" ever shown, although they have no title whatever to show prizes, will be on exhibition.
Most of the major industrial concerns that sponsor network radio programs have decided not to make further effort to forestall the strike threatened by the Radio Writers Guild, it was said yesterday.

Ice cream sales during the coming year can be regarded with "optimism," Charles F. Cook, president of the National Association of Retail Ice Cream Manufacturers, stated yesterday at the fifteenth annual convention in the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company, Chicago, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for simplification of the capital structure of a subsidiary, the Philadelphia Company of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Export-Import Bank has decided to consider granting loans on specific projects for the State of Israel, in view of a recent State Department report that in the department's opinion such action would now be warranted.

Limited finishing capacity for rayon goods in local dye houses will result in a serious production bottleneck in the event of any sudden rush of textile orders, it was pointed out yesterday in the trade. Dyers in the New Jersey area, textile men said, have enough goods on hand to utilize their full capacity for a minimum of ten weeks.

No matter what the provocation, I doubt if the average person in the United States, remembering the tragedy of Hiroshima, would approve of dropping atomic bombs on the helpless populations of Leningrad, Moscow, Kiev and Stalingrad.
Dr. Frederick W. Maroney, Dean of Students at Brooklyn College, announced yesterday that he would take disciplinary action against fifteen executives of the college chapter of Students for Wallace.

Legendra, bred and owned by William L. Brann and trained by Large Edward Christmas, poured it on in the stretch at Jamaica yesterday to win the best of the afternoon's races. It was a mile-and-a-sixteenth Class C Handicap called the Cherryola, and Legendra, with Young Bill Passmore at the controls, tucked it away in the last fifty yards by little more than a yard.

Plans for converting a former church on the lower East Side into a dance hall were revealed yesterday when the City Title Insurance Company announced that it had insured title to the five-story building at 105-09 East Houston Street, following its purchase by East Side Chateau, Inc., Hilda Kaye, president.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert declined yesterday to dismiss the indictments accusing twelve Communist leaders of conspiracy to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government and of being members of the Communist party "well knowing" that it advocated that doctrine.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio the British amateur title-holder, led five United States players today into the quarter-final of the Mexican amateur golf championship.

Elizabeth Coatsworth, author of two books about Maine, "Country Neighborhood" and "Maine Ways," has turned her attention to Massachusetts in her forthcoming book, entitled "South Shore Town." It is a description of the town of Hingham, which "still retains an eighteenth century flavor."
LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The text of the final communique of the meetings of British Commonwealth Prime Ministers follows:

A parcel of 180 lots in the Rosewood tract at Bayside, Queens, has been sold by Realty Associates, Inc., according to H.D. Burchell, vice president, to Lana Homes, Inc., builders. The new owners plan to improve the property with one-family dwellings.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Military Observers are of the opinion that the Western Union defense arrangements cannot really begin to advance beyond the initial planning stage until after the United States Presidential and Congressional elections.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 2 points lower to 12 points higher than Thursday's final prices.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 -- A new high-efficiency engine, the culmination of more than ten years of experimentation, will be a feature of the 1949 Cadillac line, it was announced today. This power plant offers a new scale of economy, speed and compression, according to the company, and is said to reduce fuel consumption by about 20 per cent.
BUTTE, Mont., Oct. 21 -- There appears to be more than a little confusion in the Montana political scene.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 -- Five Detroit-area auto agencies and four individuals were indicted today by a Federal grand jury for alleged illegal contributions totaling $2.915 to the Republican Party campaign chest in the 1946 and the current 1948 campaigns.

Asserting that there must be no return to the reactionary record made by the Republican party in the Nineteen Twenties, former Governor Herbert H. Lehman urged last night the election of President Truman and a Democratic Congress to preserve the social and democratic gains made under the Administrations of the late Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mr. Truman.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 22 -- The production of new cars for the American public could be speeded up if a good percentage of the scrap steel now available in Germany was allocated to United States steel manufacturers for assignment to the production of sheet steel for automobiles, Ben T. Wright of Evanston, Ill., president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said today.

In the absence of any progress toward a settlement, the Transport Workers Union, CIO, accelerated yesterday its preparations for the strike of 8,500 members employed by seven privately owned bus lines in the city on Tuesday.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 23 -- A Federal Court of Appeals has ruled today that the Government expropriation of 10 per cent of all newsprint imported by the newspaper Prensa since early 1946 is not only legal but "reasonable and just," according to a decision of the court first made known by the Government radio last night.
Alex Thompson, the young sportsman who owns the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League, yesterday declared war to the death of the rival All-America Conference.

Men's wear retailers were urged yesterday by M.M. Lebensburger, business analyst, to return speedily to normal merchandising and not to fall into the "seemingly panicky pitfalls of cut-price sales." He spoke at a sales convention of F. Jacobson Sons, Inc., makers of Jayson shirts, pajamas and sportswear and Excello shirts, in the St. Moritz Hotel.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- The United Nations Security Council and General Assembly held special morning and night sessions today to re-elect five judges to nine-year terms on the International Court of Justice.
SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Oct. 22 -- Republicans in Michigan are counting upon the "cracker-barrel vote" to offset a possible ballot deficit in Detroit.

Beginning today nearly seventy paintings by contemporary French and American artists will be shown at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. They will be auctioned on Wednesday evening at the galleries for the benefit of the United Hospital Fund.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 22 -- Jose Arrieta, news editor of Reuters' Buenos Aires bureau, was arrested by two plainclothes men as he emerged from a restaurant early this afternoon.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt took time from a crowded United Nations schedule here today to visit the Paris school of the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, where Jewish youths receive vocational training, and to address the students.

HARVEY, Ill., Oct. 22 -- Three thousand scientists, engineers, industrialists, chemists, bankers and other persons from all parts of the country toured the nine buildings comprising the new research and development laboratories of the Sinclair Refining Company, opened here officially today.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- The Japanese press and public was eagerly discussing tonight reports published here of a "new American policy for Japan." The policy is reportedly being framed by the Army and State Departments on the basis of reports by George F. Kennan, the State Department's planning expert who visited Tokyo briefly last spring.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Records in sales and profits in the meat packing industry last year "probably will not be equaled this year," the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said today.

POLAND SPRING, Me., Oct. 22 (AP) -- There is "growing danger of socialization of the railroad industry," William H. Day, general chairman of the New England Shippers Advisory Board, said today. "Government ownership and operation of our railroads would be a national calamity," he added.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- The administration of trusts and estates by banks is becoming a mass-production operation, Aurie I. Johnson, newly elected chairman of the trust division, New York State Bankers Association, declared here today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 -- A bold and revolutionary operation for repairing human arteries clogged by disease or injury was reported today by one of France's leading surgeons, Dr. Louis Bazy, to an audience of doctors at the American College of Surgeons' Annual Clinical Congress.

Lloyd Paul Stryker, chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the New York County Lawyers Association, denounced yesterday as "a malicious falsehood" the charge of eight judicial candidates of the American Labor party that the recommendations on judicial candidates of his committee and that of the Bar Association of the City of New York had been "piously phrased but politically motivated" and "designed to perpetuate machine politics and bipartisan patronage.

Robert Thompson and William Norman, respectively chairman and secretary of the State Committee of the Communist party, appealed yesterday to organized labor to work and vote for the election of Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, and Simon W. Gerson, Communist and American Labor party candidate for City Councilman in Brooklyn.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Col. Humberto Mariles, the Mexican Army team's brilliant leader, tonight added the Governor's Challenge Trophy to his growing list of Pennsylvania National Horse Show awards. The Olympic jumping champion was in perfect form as he twice rode his chestnut mount, Arete, faultlessly over the difficult eight-jump course.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The confidence with which the city is awaiting the result of the 100,000,000 British Electricity Loan, for which allotments will be out during the week-end, was demonstrated today by the strength of gilt-edge issues in the stock markets here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported tonight that industrial production held in September to the same level as in August, slightly below the peacetime record high of last February.

At a conference last night with Waiter Maggioli, Federal mediator, milk dealers and the American Federation of Labor Teamsters Union decided that except for a single issue, they were willing to submit to impartial arbitration their wage dispute affecting milk deliveries to 11,000,000 persons in the New York-New Jersey Metropolitan Area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- President Truman appointed today the three members of an emergency board that will make recommendations on the pay demands of more than 1,000,000 "non-operating" railroad workers. Hearings will start on Tuesday in Chicago.

With regard to your editorial on the case of George Polk, permit me to say how deeply all Greeks share your opinion, i.e. that this case is a matter which "for the sake of United States-Greek relations" should be thoroughly examined. The definite charges which the Greek Government made on the basis of conclusive evidence against Communist officials is, I think, a decisive step towards the solution of the crime.
I wish to call your attention to an instance of thought control and of the infringement of academic freedom in the State of Michigan which demands national attention.

Production of a new type of streptomycin for use in the treatment of tuberculosis, after "highly encouraging reports" had been received from various groups of clinical investigators, was announced yesterday by Merck Co., manufacturing chemists at Rahway, N.J.

In the pamphlet, "Understand Your Child -- Ages 6 to 12," to be issued today by the Public Affairs Committee, Inc., 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, Mrs. Clara Lambert writes: "Knowing what to expect, but not expecting the impossible, is the best general guide for parents."
The Texas Company had a consolidated net income of $45,350,232 after charges, taxes and reserves in the three months ended on Sept. 30, W.S.S. Rodgers, chairman, reported yesterday.

At its recent meeting in Washington the United States Advisory Commission on Educational Exchange warned against closing our doors to students of other lands with whose ideologies we may differ. There is a growing tendency, the educators found, to bar all kinds of cultural exchange between this country and Eastern Europe.

Stalled on the ground by Columbia's line play, Pennsylvania's freshman eleven took to the air to defeat the Lion cubs, 13 -- 12, at Baker Field yesterday. The Quaker yearlings scored both their touchdowns in the third period.

A former fellow employe of a payroll messenger-guard company was arrested last night by the police, accused of having kidnapped a friend, shooting him three times, stealing a $2,773 payroll and then abandoning him among weeds in an empty lot in Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 -- A House subcommittee investigating communism in the West Coast maritime strike tried vainly to get direct answers today from several witnesses at a tumultuous hearing to the question: "Are you or have you ever been a member of the Communist party?"

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy struck from the voting lists yesterday the names of twenty persons on motions made by State Atty. Gen. Nathaniel L. Goldstein on the ground that they were registered illegally. The Court also denied one motion, and two others were withdrawn.

After a series of escapades that would rival the plot of a Hollywood script writer, three men were booked yesterday afternoon at the East 104th Street station house on charges of blackmail and attempted extortion of $100,000 from Edward F. Luckenbach Jr., 23-year-old vice president of the Luckenbach Line.
Sunken treasure to the amount of $15,000 probably lies somewhere in the Hudson River as the result of a $5,000,000 fire last year that destroyed Pier 57, Fifteenth Street and the North River.

First shipments of British mass produced portable electric tools for distribution in American markets are here and will continue to arrive at the rate of 400 units a month. Fred L. Stuart, importer, 33 West Forty-second Street, reported yesterday. Shipped by S. Wolf Co., Ltd., London, the tools use American standard parts and will be marketed exclusively through distributors, Mr. Stuart emphasized.

Although most of the fishermen have put their rods away in favor of a rifle or shotgun, there are still a few surfcasters who consider that the season is really just getting under way. Those of the brotherhood who have been anxious to get a few channel bass from the beach at Hatteras or Ocracoke can leave right now, for the reports from both areas are excellent.

Mayor O'Dwyer made a face-to-face appeal to members of the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to reverse their ban on granting the city's station, WNYC, special permission to broadcast returns on election night. His plea, however, failed to produce any immediate results.

FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 22 -- When the first batch of post-war draftees arrives here on Nov. 3 they will find a "new" Army in which the non-coms say "please" and "thank you," and in which they virtually are begged to become officers.
PEIPING, Saturday, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Troops defending Taiyuan routed two Chinese Communist brigades northeast of the capital of Shansi Province, pro-Government reports said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Among other accomplishments Georgetown intercepted two passes, recovered a fumble and blocked a kick against Fordham tonight at Griffith Stadium. Following each of these commendable defensive plays, the Hoyas exploded with a resourceful offense that fashioned a touchdown and proceeded to rout the Rams, 35 -- 0.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Wheat showed strength and corn was heavy on the Board of Trade today. Buying of wheat by mills and cash interests resulted in advances of 1/2 to 7/8 cent a bushel and the close was at the top. Corn lost 1/8 to 1 1/8 cents, December leading.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has signed Edward G. Robinson to play the leading role in "East Side Story," the screen adaptation of Jerome Weidman's 1941 novel, "I'll Never Go There Anymore," which Fox bought in August for production by Sol C. Siegel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- New and improved devices of all-purpose utility, ranging from rocket projectors to life preservers, from aircraft construction to a power-driven surfboard and from an automobile headlight dimmer to toys, were among the 569 inventions patented this week by the United States Patent Office.

At least twenty freighters, owned by exiled Yugoslav shipping companies and manned exclusively by Yugoslav crews, are plying the ocean commerce routes today, Ivan S. Ivanovic, shipping executive said yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- Russian athletes will compete in the 1952 Olympic Games at Helsinki, the United Press learned authoritatively today. As a prelude to participating in Finland, the Soviets, who did not enter the 1948 meet in London, have applied for affiliation with ten international athletic federations.

Because tomorrow is both "Navy Day Sunday" and "United Nations Day," a special addition to the ceremonies will be made when, for the seventh year, a Navy vessel strews flowers on the waters of the outer harbor, in memory of America's fighting men who died at sea.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The CIO's Political Action Committee reported to Congress today that it was $71,788 in the red.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Four prominent educators speaking at the Catholic University forum here joined today in criticizing the potential effect on religious educational institutions of recommendations made recently by the President's Commission on Higher Education.

Emulating the method used by the Pied Piper in ridding the ancient town of Hamelin of rats, 250 boys and girls from twenty schools in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx marched through the streets yesterday to awaken the community to the current menace from rodents.

"Many women college graduates, unable to find jobs that effectively utilize their talents, are forced to waste years in unrewarding clerical jobs," Miss Ruth Houghton, director of the Barnard College Occupation Bureau, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A grand jury investigation of the payroll in the office of Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey and chairman of the Committee on Un-American Activities, was started today, officials of the Justice Department disclosed today.

On Oct. 20 last year near Kennebunkport, Me., began one of the worst forest fires in this section of the country. For six days it burned and devastated, causing damage estimated at $10,000,000. Two thousand people had to be rescued from Mount Desert Island. When the smoke cleared, 100, 000 acres of woodland and eight communities had been wiped from the face of the land.

With the original field of eighteen teams reduced to nine, the six-day bicycle race at the Kings-bridge Armory in the Bronx moved into its final twenty-four hours late last night. Despite the comparatively shallow field, the riding brought out its fair share of thrills, and the fans, some 10,000 in number, maintained an interest all through the evening program.

Central New York State puts on its prize football show of many long years today. In Cornell's Schoellkopf Crescent, the Big Red and Army will meet in the only game of the day the country over between major teams with spotless records.

Hugo E. Rogers, Manhattan Borough President and leader of Tammany, repudiated yesterday a letter reported to have been sent by him to Assemblyman John P. Morrissey, Democratic candidate for Representative in the Eighteenth Congressional District, which said that "the Eighteenth Congressional District fight is second in importance only to the effort to elect our President."

The Anheuser-Busch warehouse on Lincoln Highway in South Kearny, N.J., has been sold by the Viaduct Terminal Corporation to an investment group organized as the 31 Ward Street Corporation. The David T. Houston Company and the Louis Schlesinger Company were the brokers.
YORK, Pa., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Gen. Jacob L. Devers told the mothers of America tonight that every youth drafted into the Army "will be treated as a human being, never a raw recruit."

An object lesson in the contribution that civil rights make to community welfare was given last night at the Town Hall Club when the sudden birth of a baby to a woman visitor created an emergency that was met only when a Negro physician was discovered among seventy civic leaders attending an institute of the National Citizens Council on Civil Rights.

The Columbia Steel Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, announced yesterday plans for a new sheet mill to be constructed in the area of Los Angeles, and the McLouth Steel Corporation of Detroit reported details of an $18,500,000 expansion program to make it a completely integrated mill.

WE are in the great third wave of books about the war -- and may soon need lifelines or be looking for a likely desert island. At first there were the quick reminiscences and the even quicker novels. Then came the parade of Hemingwayfarers and the revelations in the tradition of Sir Philip Gibbs' "Now It Can Be Told."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic candidate for Vice President, predicted tonight that if the Republicans won in November "inflation will be allowed to move forward without check.'

A revolutionary process of inkless printing has been developed that might completely change all the operations of the printing and publishing industry. This was announced yeserday by Joseph C. Wilson, president of the Haloid Company, Rochester, and officials of the Batelle Memorial Institute, Columbus, Ohio.

Margaret Sullavan wil make her television debut as featured player in the first of a new series of one-hour dramatic shows scheduled to begin over the CBS-TV network on Sunday, Nov. 7. The programs are to be carried twice monthly under the over-all title of "Studio One."

Senator Glen H. Taylor, Vice-Presidential candidate of the Progressive party, called last night on President Truman to suspend operation of the draft as harmful to the cause of peace. The Senator from Idaho said that the President had the power to do so under the Selective Service Act.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau of the world champion Cleveland Indians got a rousing welcome today from admirers at the University of Illinois, his alma mater.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Trans-Continental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, Dallas, Tex., a Delaware corporation, asked the Federal Power Commission today for authority to acquire, build and operate proposed facilities of Trans-Continental Gas Pipe Line Company, Inc., incorporated in Texas.

QUEBEC, Oct. 22 -- Unforeseen circumstances are the only thing which will permit increases in the output of pulp and paper mills in Quebec Province for many, many years, it was stated today by Prime Minister M. Duplessis.

LONDON, Oct 22 -- A strong protest against the "infiltration" of foreign artists into British opera companies was registered here today by 200 opera singers at a meeting called by the British Actors Equity Association.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 22 (AP) -- The mighty University of Georgia Bulldogs tonight overpowered the University of Miami Hurricanes, 42 to 21, before 46,127 fans in the Orange Bowl -- the largest crowd ever to attend a regular season football game in Florida.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 22 -- When municipal officials from New Jersey and New York met in Spring Valley, N.Y., last week to map out a campaign for ragweed extermination in this area they forgot to consult the beekeepers who today, through the North Jersey Beekeepers Association, entered a stiff protest complaining that it's either ragweed or the bees that must go.
H. R. Mack, Eastern division manager, has been promoted to merchandising manager in the U. S. Tires division of the United States Rubber Company.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- After police had used firearms for the first time today in the coal strike riots, the French Cabinet ordered drastic measures to put an end to the violence that in many quarters was described as "insurrectionary."

Commercial users of electricity in a score of Nassau County communities were voluntary participants in a peacetime "dimout" last night, for periods ranging up to three hours, after the Long Island Lighting Company had suffered a sudden cut in power output.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Part restoration of the cotton trade to private industry channels was announced today by the British Government.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 22 -- Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha and a spokesman of the Ministry of National Defense charged tonight that the Israelis had violated the cease-fire by attacking and shelling Beersheba.

Prices of securities rushed upward yesterday on the Stock Exchange. In the share market all standards of recent months were exceeded as prices pushed forward to the best levels since July and scored the widest increases since mid-May.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Thirty-three of the New York City high school students who were guides at the atomic energy exhibit during the recent Golden Jubilee exposition at Grand Central Palace eagerly toured the General Electric Research Laboratory here today.
A helping hand by more fortunate citizens to the boys and girls of "Mousetown, U.S.A.," was urged yesterday by Bradford Chambers, author and director of the East Harlem Gang Survey.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Four more years of intense production and restrained consumption, with Britain paying her way at the end, were forecast in the four-year economic program for the United Kingdom submitted to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation here.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 22 (AP) -- A United States Department of Labor spokesman said today that young persons should be trained to become more adaptable so they could "switch careers" to meet changing conditions.
