WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- About three dozen persons who held prominent New Deal positions or were closely associated with President Roosevelt denounced today the Presidential candidacy of Henry A. Wallace as opposed to "the humane impulse of American progressivism and to the spirit" of Mr. Roosevelt.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 22 -- Although no United States goods were among permitted imports recently scheduled for next year, the Government, it was announced today, has authorized expenditure of $5,500,000 for purchase of specialized American farm tractors, spare parts and implements which are unobtainable from Britain.

NIR AM, Palestine, Oct. 22 -- The uneasy peace of the third United Nations cease-fire of the Palestine war settled over the country today, and the 100 members of this Jewish settlement in the Negeb desert had their first moment of repose in more than a week.
Public agencies were called on yesterday by Mrs. Helen L. Buttenwieser, chairman of the New York City Committee on Adoptions, to help solve the problem of adoptions.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The United States Navy public information office announced today that the 14,000-ton cruiser Tone, last of Japan's large warships, had been scrapped. This makes destruction of the Japanese fleet 98 per cent complete, the announcement added.

NANKING, Oct. 22 -- The frantic buying sprees that spread throughout Nationalist China several weeks ago as part of the panicky flight from the gold yuan have abated -- because most of the merchants either cannot or will not put up enough goods for sale a the Government's ceiling prices.

A Princeton team that has yet to score a victory this season will invade Baker Field today, determined to rehabilitate its tattered fortunes against Columbia. The twenty-second meeting between these Ivy League rivals is expected to attract a crowd of 30,000.
PARIS, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The text of the resolution submitted by the six powers not directly connected with the Berlin crisis offered today in the United Nations Security Council follows:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 22 -- President Truman, having already lost two and probably three of Tennessee's twelve electoral votes, will require good fortune and the strong, full operation of a normally Democratic tradition if he is not to lose all the others.

BOSTON, Oct. 22 -- Outnumbered and outplayed, New York University's football team was slapped down to another defeat, 28 -- 7, tonight under the Fenway Park lights by Boston University, which chalked up its fourth straight triumph.

Your editorial on the George Polk case suggests that the case "should not be left unsolved." You indicate that the Greek Government's long awaited report on its investigation asserts that Polk was murdered by the Communists to discredit the Government and that to an independent group of newspaper men that has raised funds "to promote an independent investigation," "it had seemed that the official investigation was not very thorough."

There are two more weeks to Election Day, and most people I know are not aware of the names or qualifications of the candidates for local, state, or national office except for the Presidency. About two days before Election Day, most newspapers will publish the names of candidates whom they recommend. Many citizens may take a quick look at these names and vote accordingly.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange advanced yesterday 40 to 15 points above the levels of the previous day. A strong trade demand and short covering of the near-by delivery positions advanced prices as much as 62 points at one stage of the day's trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Army gave without explanation today a restricted showing of several official motion-picture films depicting the mass murders and atrocities of the Nazi concentration camps, in the course of one of which an Army narrator stated that Ilse Koch had ordered lampshades made from human skin.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 22 -- The Rockingham Park stewards today imposed fines totaling $500 on four jockeys for improper riding. George Hettinger was assessed $200 and Charles Mullins, Bill Harris and James Boucher $100 each.

The board of trustees of Hampton Institute, 80-year-old college for Negroes at Hampton, Va., named Alonzo G. Moron, college business manager, acting president yesterday, pending the selection of a successor to Dr. Ralph P. Bridgman, former Brooklyn educator, who was relieved of his post Feb. 20.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Russia's reported all-out effort to smother the "Voice of America" radio broadcasts may be boomeranging.

There once was a man who bought an hourglass in a New York antique shop. In addition to being an unnecessary indulgence of a whim, the purchase cost him valuable hours of sleep. He set the glass on his bureau and fell to watching the sand running from top to bottom.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- India Edwards, director of the Women's Division of the Democratic National Committee, today attacked the social welfare record of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in New York State as "not what he says it is."
Tony Pellone, Greenwich Village welterweight, left no question as to superiority over, Roman Alvarez, East Sider, in their return bout of ten rounds last night at the St. Nicholas arena.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The State Department and the Air Force agreed today to permit other American republics to buy three types of the nation's swiftest fighter planes, two of them jets, and a two-engined transport.

Israeli's need and plans for obtaining radio and telephonic equipment to modernize its communications system were outlined here yesterday by Zvi Prihar, first Israeli director general of communications.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin greeted United Nations Day today with a proclamation of faith in the principles underlying the world organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- An American Federation of Labor Union, two of its officers and the business manager of a distributors' group were convicted today in Federal District Court here in what was said to be the first test of the Hobbs Anti-Racketeering Act.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- The Palestine question comes again before the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly tomorrow morning, and general opinion in the United Nations circles tonight was that it would be postponed again, and the Greek situation probably debated first.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 22 -- Governor Earl Warren opened the final phase of his personal campaign to insure a Republican victory in California with a speech this evening in which he charged that because of "incompatibility" between President Truman and the majority of Democrats in Congress no program offered by the President had a chance of passage.
ATHENS, Oct. 22 -- The Government has ordered martial law in the Peloponnesus from tonight until conditions in that troubled area improve.

Coaches Hank Gowdy and Travis Jackson have been unconditionally released by the New York Giants, it was announced yesterday by Secretary Eddie Brannick. No action to replace them is expected until after Manager Leo Durocher confers with President Horace Stoneham at the time of the winter major league meetings.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- American teenagers in 17,000 high schools in the United States were told today by top United Nations leaders that their best hope of living in a lasting peace lay in their supporting the world organization.
Municipal Court Justice Charles A. Loreto was back in circulation yesterday after a brief incarceration brought on by working overtime.

The committee appointed by the Board of Transportation to study Bronx surface transport is to be commended for its straightforwardness in recommending, among other things, that the Third Avenue Transit System "restore street car operation on its Southern Boulevard and Boston Road lines, making available for use elsewhere the sixty buses now used on those routes."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Wisconsin's thrice-beaten but "very mad" football team flew in today for tomorrow's Big Nine clash with Ohio State, and a capacity crowd of 76,677 was due to the fray.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration authorized today a grant of $4,000,000 to the United Kingdom for the purchase of 40,000 tons of Canadian newsprint. It said the grant was to reimburse Great Britain for dollars already spent for the Canadian product.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Despite its measure of "restraint in the credit field" during the last fifteen months, the Federal Reserve Board conceded today that inflationary pressures have continued dominant in the American economy.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 22 -- The New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers urged today that all state teachers' schools make sex education a required subject.

The "Winged Words" so often mentioned by the blind Homer more than two thousand years ago have now become literal images. In the halls of the Library of Congress on Thursday men seated before one of our modern electronic-photographic marvels saw treasures from the library's archives projected on a large screen, after having arrived only a few seconds before through space at the speed of light by means of a new electronic marvel called "Ultrafax."

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- In its first unanimous vote of the session, the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today the resolution urging Big Five cooperation and a speedier settlement of peace treaties not yet concluded.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The meeting of the Commonwealth Prime Ministers ended today with a statement of full approval for the Western European Union and Britain's association with Western Europe. There were pledges to work for democratic peace and to resist aggression.

The Western democracies took their Berlin story to the United Nations because they found it intolerable that Soviet Russia should resort to force for the purpose of compelling them to negotiate a settlement of German questions on which Soviet opposition alone had hitherto blocked agreement.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Oct. 22 -- The Burlington County Board of Freeholders authorized today a $12,400,000 bond issue for the purchase and operation of two privately owned bridges across the Delaware River.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Carl E. Dunnagan of Chicago, president of Inland Press, Inc., was elected president of the Printing Industry of America, Inc., by the association's convention today.

The Meva Realty Corporation, of which Eva Wehnes is vice president, has sold the one-story taxpayer on a plot 100 by 105 feet at 204-220 West 238th Street, the Bronx, to the B.F. V. Realty Corporation, operators. The property is assessed at $47,000.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation will substantially increase its appliance production in 1949, J.H. Ashbaugh, vice president in charge of the appliance division, disclosed yesterday. He did not indicate extent of the increase.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- It would be difficult to find better working spaniels than those that competed today as the twenty-fifth meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Association opened with three stakes. The judges, William H. Kirkland Jr. and Francis J. Squires made their decisions only after sharp reviews of the close competition, held under fine conditions.

Chrysanthemums lent their autumn brilliance to a three-day show that opened yesterday afternoon at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park. Two flower borders near the conservatories are the outdoor feature; a conventional show was staged in the museum building by the National Chrysanthemum Society.

Lumber production during the week ended Oct. 16 rose 2.1 per cent above the preceding week, but dropped 1.9 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Shipments were up 1.7 per cent over a year ago while orders declined 0.8 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.
ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Oct. 22 -- The New Jersey Women's Golf Association closed its season today with one of the finest turnouts of the year.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Delegates of the six member countries not directly involved in the Berlin dispute submitted to the United Nations Security Council today a proposal providing for a compromise settlement of the dispute.

International cooperation of the type that prevailed in wartime will solve the much more difficult problems of the peace, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told 150 members of the Fellowship of United States-British Comrades at their first annual convention last night in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Peacetime uses of atomic energy are now important in magnitude, Dr. Lyle B. Borst, chairman of the Nuclear Reactor Project at the Atomic Energy Commission's Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, told 150 women today at the fall conference of the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Belgium called upon the United Nations today to set up a special investigation committee to ferret out the full story on slavery and slave traffic and clear the way for possible corrective action by the world organization.

Bids designating interest rates ranging from 1.13 per cent to 1.18 per cent were submitted yesterday for $13,817,000 of temporary loan notes of the New York City Housing Authority. The obligations, which are to cover temporary financing of the Gowanus Houses and the Albany Houses in Brooklyn and the Bronx River Houses in the Bronx, are dated Nov. 10, 1948, and will come due May 10, 1949.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22 -- Mechanization in foundries is proceeding rapidly, with approximately one-half of the total present equipment less than five years old, J.S. Vanick, research metallurgist for the International Nickel Company, New York, asserted here today.

Sponsored by the Bronx County Council of the Jewish War Veterans and the Bronx Zionist Emergency Council, a parade of veterans and other groups will be held from Fordham Road down Grand Concourse to the Bronx County Courthouse at 61st Street tomorrow morning to mark "Support Israel Day."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The creation of a microbiological institute in the Public Health Service to bring research on several important diseases up to the same intensive level as now obtains for cancer and heart ailments, was announced today by the Federal Security Agency.

Donald Dame, tenor, gave his fourth New York recital last night at Town Hall. With George Schick at the piano, Mr. Dame was heard in a program composed of the complete "Liederkreis" of Schumann, the aria "Constanze, dich Wiederzusehen," from Mozart's "Die Entfuehrung aus dem Serail," Poulenc's "Air champetre,' Debussy's "Colloque sentimental" and "Chevaux de bois," a group of folksongs and a final group of English lyrics by Walmer, Maltzman, Silberta and others.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The legal requirement of equal opportunity on the air for political candidates applied only to those who were candidates for the same office in the same election, the Federal Communications Commission ruled today.

Striking rank-and-file beer truck drivers rejected flatly yesterday a union-brewers' formula for settling the nine-day-old strike. The men announced they would stay away from their jobs until they won their full demands.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 (AP) --Fines totaling $42,500 were levied today against five major paint and varnish companies and six officers after they pleaded no contest of Federal charges of conspiracy to fix prices.

New Offerings of Securities Distribution of new issues of securities will be on the slow side next week, compared to the heavy concentration of offerings that have just come to market. The major offering will consist of $21,000,000 of school bonds which the Denver, Col., School District will put up for sale on Wednesday.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The United States' brightest stars were sent to the sidelines today as Czechoslovakia's Jaroslav Drobny and South Africa's Eric Sturgess stroked their way into the singles final of the Pan-American tennis tournament.

In "Tell the West," an account by Jerzy Gliksman of his sufferings in Soviet prisons, occurs this passage, page 120: "'* * * The prisoner never even knows when his case appears before the Council. And this procedure will also apply in your cases. You, too, will receive a ready-made sentence from OSSO.'

BERLIN, Oct. 22 -- Communist Germany demanded today the establishment of a "sovereign, unified" German state and proclaimed a Constitution ghost-written by Soviet officials, that would place that state under the control of Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Former Gov. Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma, now the Democratic Senatorial nominee from that state, was accused in an investigator's report to a Senate elections subcommittee today of having had spent on his behalf in the primaries of last July $61,140 more than he reported and $59,500 more than the state law allowed.

To promote efficiency in helping the 4,000 "non-residence" cases of the Welfare Department, a reorganization was announced last night by Acting Welfare Commissioner Crystal M. Potter, effective Nov. 1, that concentrates the work on all "non-residence" causes in one center instead of in fifteen different ones as at present.

The three principal suburban counties of New York State, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk, have furnished constantly increasing Republican majorities in recent years, even when the Republicans were not carrying the state as a whole.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 22 -- The possibility that direct talks between Israeli and Arab leaders for a final settlement of the Palestine problem might be started soon was being discussed here again today as a result of the Israeli victory in the battle of the Negeb, desert area in the south of the Holy Land.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- Hungary's Communist-dominated Cabinet today accused Joseph Cardinal Mindzenty of having aided "foreign imperialists" by meddling in official matters, and warned that "the Government will not tolerate" such actions.

Frank McHugh, who forsook the local stage almost twenty years ago for the greener fields of Hollywood, is coming back to Broadway. The screen star has informed Morris Green, producer of the forthcoming comedy, "It Still Happens," written by Lewis Nemerson, that he is prepared to return East "to do the show on forty-eight hours' notice," which gives rough idea of what he thinks of the script.
Settlement houses and day nurseries are needed even more today than they were during the war, Mrs. Rich W. Hollaman, president of the board of managers of East Side House, declared yesterday.

The most charitable interpretation of the vote of the American Legion Convention delegates for a resolution proposing a pension of $60 a month for all armed services veterans at the age of 55 (to be raised to $75 a month at the age of 65) is that those who cast the 2,025 votes in favor didn't realize what they were doing.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Approximately 67 per cent of draft registrants have been rejected as physically unfit, the State Director of Selective Service said today.

A long-brewing controversy centering around the right of the Department of Marine and Aviation to grant a permit for two veterans to operate a fish-packing barge at bayside docks on Sheepshead Bay finally came into the open yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration disclosed today that ten persons formerly in its employ had failed to pass the agency's security investigations and were no longer on the payroll. One official refused to say whether the ten employes were dismissed or were permitted to resign but explained that "their permanent appointments were not confirmed."

The evening performance of "Life With Mother" on Nov. 10 at the Empire Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Speedwell Society. The organization cares for convalescent children from two weeks to 12 years of age, who have been referred to it by various hospitals in the city.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The University of Oklahoma does not have to admit another Negro student just because it enrolled one, Oklahoma's Attorney General held today.

DISCUSSION, dialogue, is the life of France. It contrasts with the practice of monologue by its disrespect for the rules, by its traditional anarchy and by its individualism which has almost become a disease.

Reports from Washington that the recent decline in prices of used automobiles is a result of the reimposition of Regulation W, which controlled consumers' credit, have aroused resentment in banking circles, it was learned yesterday.

WHILE it would be incorrect to say that American interest in Norway and its people stems primarily from the years of World War II, it is a fact that our awareness of this progressive and democratic Scandinavian nation has grown markedly since 1939

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23 -Coach Herman Hickman received little solace today from the visit paid by his "kinfolk" from Tennessee as Vanderbilt administered a 35-0 setback to Yale before 30,000 in the Bowl.
MONTREAL, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The league leading Montreal Canadiens and the runner-up Detroit Red Wings battled to a 0-0 tie tonight in their first meeting of the 1948-49 National Hockey League season.

EXPRESSIONISM, which bulks so large in contemporary American art, was much in evidence in the newly opened shows last week. With Max Beckmann -- who next to Rouault, is perhaps the outstanding living exponent of expressionism -- now teaching in the Middle West, this influence may be expected to grow even more important in the next few years.

In his piece "Wanted: A New Type of Cabinet," Edward S. Corwin proposes to solve the century-old conflict between Congress and the President by having the President "construct his Cabinet from the membership of a Joint Legislature Council of the two Houses," plus some heads of departments and agencies.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Fireball Bess, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Van Benschoten of Ambler, Pa., and handled by Arthur Eakin, won the springer open all-age stake, feature event in the annual meet of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association today.

HERE is an immensely satisfying book for mothers of any age or state of mind. Possibly fathers will read it too and find their experiences well matched by the F.P.'s (Family Provider's) lot in this hilarious household. But this is primarily a book about the job of being a mother.

When the current Presidential campaign began there must have been, in certain parts of the world, a lively hope that it would reveal disunion and confusion among the American people. Indeed, such a hope was rather clearly expressed here and there. Obviously the campaign need not have taken place at all if the American people had been in precise agreement on all points of policy.

Large retailers are holding their advance orders for men's spring suits and topcoats about 70 per cent of requirements, while clothing manufacturers are limiting their spring fabric purchases in many instances to 50 to 70 per cent of their estimated needs, it was reported here last week.

A complete realignment of sales quotas in national markets has been made by tool and machinery manufacturers because research reports have disclosed that total dollar potentials of Eastern states now exceed similar potentials of Middle Western states in these lines, executives said yesterday when interviewed on 1949 prospects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The progress of non-Communist Europe toward economic recovery will be hastened in the months ahead by inclusion in the Marshall Plan of a recognized practice of United States management in plowing income back into business.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Recent dedicatory ceremonies at Mullet Key. V-shaped island of 840 acres at the northern approach to Tampa Bay, were the first steps in a multi-million-dollar development program which will provide Florida's west coast with a new playground.

LATE in the evening of Tuesday of next week, probably around midnight, one of three middle-aged New Yorkers will be informed that he has been chosen to fill a job that pays $28,000 a year, that ordinarily lasts for at least fourteen years, and that shares control of something more than half a billion dollars annually.

Procedures set up to process 5,000 displaced persons a month will have to be stepped up to 10,000 a month if the 205,000 DP's in Europe are to obtain visas by the deadline on June 30, 1950, Ugo Carusi, chairman of the Displaced Persons Commission, reported last night at La Guardia Field.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 23 -- The University of Vermont scored a 14-to-0 upset victory over the University of New Hampshire today.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey declared today that the American Navy must remain the world's strongest so that "no aggressor nation will ever be deluded by the belief that our free society cannot defend itself."

TOMORROW evening John Kriza of the Ballet Theatre company will make a guest appearance with the New York City Ballet at the City Center, dancing with Maria Tallchief in Balanchine's "Symphony in C." The City Ballet will also add "Four Temperaments" to its repertoire in the same performance, and on Tuesday will present "Orpheus" with major cast changes.

IT would seem that the whole country is having a love affair with San Francisco. Old San Franciscans smile indulgently. Tirelessly they guide new residents and visitors into the cable-cars that climb the plunging streets to the Top O' The Mark.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 -- Following is the text of an address by Norman Thomas as prepared for delivery here tonight:

Impetus of good consumer response to women's apparel lines presented this fall will be carried over into the spring, it was predicted last week by New York garment manufacturers. Buyers are making an early start for the new season, they said, and are placing larger orders than they did a year ago.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- The Palestine question appears as far as ever from a genuine settlement after five weeks of the United Nations sessions that, it was hoped, would settle it.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The main lines of organization of Britain's nationalized coal industry have been approved by a special committee established to study the matter, Lord Hyndley, chairman of the National Coal Board, said today.
NEXT to gardening itself, a property owner will enjoy building walks, terraces, fences and walls. As they grow under his hands, they satisfy an innate desire to design and build.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 23 -- A powerful Wesleyan University eleven unleashed a savage ground attack to swamp unbeaten Amherst by a score of 27 -- 0 before 8,000 on Andrus Field today. The victory extended Wesleyan's unbeaten, untied Streak to three for the season and nineteen over a three-year stretch.

There are two methods by which the Kremlin carries on its contest with the West One is the campaign of words, the battle of propaganda. The other is the campaign of action. These two methods make up the formula the Russians have been using, particularly since the U.N. convened at Paris five weeks ago.

SECOND only to our relationship with the Soviet in the field of United States foreign policy is the job we undertook in Japan and have been carrying out, almost alone, since late August, 1945, when General MacArthur and the Eleventh Airborne Division moved in to begin one of the strangest occupations of a defeated country that has been recorded.

IN the near future the scientists on Palomar Mountain, California, using the fabulous 200-inch Hale telescope, will begin to reveal the secrets of the universe. A highly trained little astronomical and astrophysical community has been installed on the mountain at a cost of $6,550,000 donated by various Rockefeller philanthropies to plumb space for a distance of a billion light years, twice as far as man has ever peered.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's address prepared for delivery here tonight.

THE fourth postman, we are happy to state, does not share the fate of the three who have preceded him. He is saved by the intervention of an Australian deerhound belonging, for the time being, to John J. Malone, Chicago's celebrated criminal lawyer and sleuth.

THIS handsome brochure is, in effect, a printed introduction and guidebook to the Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I.,. the oldest synagogue in the United States and since 1946 a national historic shrine. It is, as well, a building rich in historical associations.

The American Management Association last week recommended more careful selection of office supervisors as the essential first step in achieving much needed improvement in human relations. The recommendation was made by the planning council of the office management division.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The country's defense chiefs joined today in a resounding "well done!" for the Navy on the occasion of its 173rd anniversary Wednesday.

Despite Bill Berger's sparkling forty-five-yard triumph, Pennsylvania's cross-country team won a triangular meet at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, defeating Columbia and Princeton. Penn's winning score was 38, while Columbia and Princeton registered 42 and 53, respectively.

Placing five men in the first twenty-three positions, Bishop Loughlin High School of Brooklyn gaining an upset victory in the twenty-third annual Manhattan College interscholastic cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Last week a dispatch from London announced that Nikolai Sinitsin, a Soviet biologist whose work has been reported in this department, had successfully transplanted hearts in both cold-and warm-blooded animals. Sinitsin carries on research in the Gorky Medical Institute, Moscow.

In a pair of thrill-packed schoolboy football games before 4,000 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday, New Utrecht won its first game of the season by conquering Midwood, 13 -- 0, and Erasmus Hill upset favored Lafayette, 7 -- 6.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- With United States support, the United Nations postponed action today on the Palestine question one more week despite new official reports of continued fighting in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, and in northern Palestine.

FOR a great many years now have been reading angry pronunciamentos by producers, playwrights and actors, denouncing George Jean Nathan as a destructive critic, menacing the otherwise bright future of the American stage.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 (AP) -Shibe Park -- baseball home of Philadelphia's Athletics and Phillies -- is getting a face-lifting.

HAVING more than sixty conductors under its management, Columbia Artists still dominates the field. But the handling of conductors is no longer as much a one-management affair as it used to be. National Concert and Artists Corporation, which had only seven conductors under its wings a year and a half ago, now has twenty-six.

With the advent of high personal income tax rates, there has been a noticeable tendency toward the more conservative investment of savings. Statistics show that not only current savings, but vast amounts of capital, have been used to buy annuity contracts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -Defense officials revealed tonight that Russia attempted to get from the Radio Corporation of America rights to Ultrafax, the new system for transmitting words with the speed of light.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Republican National Committee, appealing for campaign funds, advised: "Don't Throw Peanuts to the Elephant:" When contributions fell below expectations, the committee followed up with this: "It's the Early Buck That Catches the Ballot."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 23 -- An experienced Brown football team that has lost only to Yale in its opening game showed power, precision and deception in abundance today as it smothered Connecticut by 49 -- 6.

THIS new book of Mr. Ernst's (his twelfth, if one counts five collaborations and a symposium) is so much like good conversation that one is sure Mr. Ernst wrote it because he had been told he talked so well he ought to write more.

Anthony Ferrari, 25 years old, of 35-21 Ninety-fourth Street, Corona, Queens, was held yesterday without bail for grand jury action on charges of kidnaping, robbery and assault. He was accused of taking William Ward, 39, a payroll guard, of 1440 West Avenue, the Bronx, from Manhattan to Bayside, Queens, shooting him and leaving him for dead in a lot there Friday.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- Soviet authorities announced officially tonight that they considered the six leading anti-Communist officials of the city administration Fascist warmongers and asked Berlin's City Council to take unspecified "measures."

MEXICO CITY -- The motorist planning a vacation in Mexico will find highway conditions generally excellent. Immeasurable progress has been made on Mexican roads during the last ten years and today all important parts of Mexico except three -- Yucatan, Tehuantepec and the Gulf of California coast -can be reached on paved highways.

A great deal of Beethoven is going to be played here this season, The New York Philharmonic-Symphony is giving an orchestral cycle of his works and at least five smaller groups have announced cycles of his chamber music. One of the first of those ensembles, the sonata team of Benno and Sylvia Rabinof, launched their series at Town Hall yesterday.

ONCE upon a time football was an orderly, conservative game where the points were made by tortuous, grinding process. A "scoring" play was a carefully husbanded maneuver which was saved until a team rumbled within the 10-yard line. Up to that stage the gridiron heroes were shooting exclusively for first downs in accordance with the time-honored and proved Rockne and Warner formulas.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 23 -- The Midwest This week appeared more divided over the weather than over the rushing climax of the political campaign. To many, the opalescent Indian summer haze was just about perfect but duck hunters prayed for rain to put more water in the ditches and lure the birds from the sky.
SELDOM does anyone have a good word to say for a kibitzer. If in the report of a bridge hand the kibitzer is mentioned at all it is usually as the villain of the piece.

HOMEMADE bread is many things to many men. It is the fragrance in a farmhouse kitchen; it is a small boy asking for some bread mind Jam; it is a checkered tablecloth and a bottle of wine and some aged cheese. In fact, what is it not? It means everything that is comfortable and homelike, solid and flavorful.

JEAN ISABEY, the famous French portraitist, arrives in a gilded carriage at the gates of Vienna in 1814 for the Congress which followed Napoleon's banishment to Elba. Prince Razumovsky. Beethoven's celebrated patron, watches while his magnificent palace, touched off by the new-fangled pipe-heating system laid under the floors, goes up in flames -- a catastrophe attended by all the visiting and local notables of Vienna.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 23 -- The first congress of the United Trade Unions of Yugoslavia will convene tomorrow in Belgrade to face the difficult task of utilizing and spurring greater production efforts on behalf of the current five-year plan, which has been subjected to stresses and strains through the decline of trade with the countries of the Communist Information Bureau bloc.

A new type of public-revenue bond backed by unconditional municipal guarantees is making its first appearance in the public market for tax-exempt obligations as a result of the decision of the New York City Housing Authority to build $200,000,000 worth of housing for the so-called "forgotten families" of the post-war period.

MR. WILLIAMS starts off by apologizing for his article -- in fact, almost half the piece consists of an attempt to forestall criticism. This is a very handy device but not altogether effective. The article was intended as an explanatory one, yet a good play needs no explanation.

Three hundred years ago today a great peace celebration began in Germany. It started with salvos of cannon from the walls of the old city of Muenster, where the Peace of Westphalia had just been signed.

IOWA CITY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Notre Dame's green-clad football legions slashed to 27-12 victory over stubborn Iowa today. The Irish, swinging through their twenty-third game without a defeat, used their ground forces almost exclusively against a team fired with a determination to repeat Hawkeye triumphs here in 1921 and 1939.

The United States is now engaged in a full-scale program of student exchange with other countries. During the present academic year more than 20,000 men and women from abroad will be studying in our colleges and universities. A large number of Americans will, in turn, study at foreign institutions.
Theatre parties continue as a popular means of raising funds to further the work of charitable organizations with several arranged for the forthcoming weeks.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 23 (UP) -- North Carolina roared on unbeaten and untied today, routing Louisiana State's Tigers, 34 to 7, as Charlie Justice ran for one touchdown and passed for two more.

ANGELA THIRKELL is a delight and an institution, but this reviewer has never felt unqualified admiration for her teeming world under glass. Her people, unlike Trollope's placid Barsetshire gentry, have always seemed to spend too much time worrying about possible threats to the gentility and sanctity of the county and in congratulating one another, sometimes even in words, on their superiority and ineffable good breeding.
NANKING, Oct. 23 -- The loss of two more important Government centers -- Chengchow, strategic Honan rail junction, and Paotow, western terminus of the Peiping-Suiyuan line -- was reported tonight

IN your issue of Oct. 3, in an article entitled "The Video 'Freeze,' Mr. Jack Gould comments on the cause of the freeze and its probable effect on the industry. Mr. Gould correctly attributes the freeze to interference between stations and continues:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, charged today that a Department of Justice investigation of his alleged payroll misrepresentations was "cheap Pendergast politics."

A WEEK of recent typical abstract productions by an Englishman and three Americans provides some interesting contrasts. John Minton's oils, gouaches, water-colors and drawings at the Durlacher Gallery might stand as a useful corrective to some of the excesses of local abstract work.

THIS, the second published volume of the Army's tremendous ninety-nine-volume World War II history project, follows closely in physical and literary style, format and method the notable first volume. It is detailed and thorough -- almost to the point of boredom.

One hundred educators in the city have formed a non-partisan committee to work for the election of George Frankenthaler, Republican and Liberal party candidate for Surrogate of New York County, it was announced yesterday.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 23 -Former Gov. Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma denied today that excessive sums had been spent on his behalf in the Senatorial primaries.

The great fact that comes from the two weeks' conference in London of the Prime Ministers of states representing 500,000,000 persons who still swear allegiance to the British Crown is that the Commonwealth remains. It not only remains; it emerges from the conference stronger, if anything, than it was before.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 23 -- Political leaders in this region, divided though they are on other questions, concur unanimously that this is the dullest, most lethargic Presidential campaign ever waged in the Pacific Northwest.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The recovery of Western Europe with American help is threatened by Soviet-inspired Communist political and economic sabotage. Under the direction of the Cominform the campaign to nullify the progress made under the ERP recently has gained considerable momentum.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly active yesterday. Final prices were from 5 points lower to 4 points higher than the day before.

Answering the charge that the schools are not paying so much attention to reading as they used to, the New York State Department of Education asserted last week that "today's children read better and understand more of what they are reading."

NEW DELHI, India. Oct. 23 -- India is keeping a suspicious eye on municipal elections that are scheduled to be held tomorrow in the small French colonies in India. This voting is prelude to a referendum on whether these small territories -- Pondicherry, Mahe, Karikal.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 -- Lafayette College scored two touchdowns in the third period to beat Bucknell University, 19-7, on a muddy gridiron today. Approximately 5,000 Homecoming Day fans braved the rain to attend.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 23 -- There were bitter dregs for Minnesota but there was a potion of joy for Michigan in the Little Brown Jug tonight as the Wolverines came from behind twice to score their nineteenth straight football victory, 27 to 14.

THE recent plea by Bosley Crowther for a place where silent films might be seen with regularity finds no echo in Hollywood, where such a place exists and prospers. Called simply The Movie, it is a one-story white stucco building on Fairfax Avenue dedicated to the proposition that there is still entertainment and stimulation in the art of the silent motion picture, especially if the old films are approached neither with scorn nor excessive adoration.
Your review on the motion picture, "Walk a Crooked Mile," which appeared in THE TIMES on Oct. 13, has been called to my attention.

"OTELLO," announced for the opening performance of the Metropolitan Opera season, Nov. 29, is an opera long considered above the heads of the great public -- caviare to the general. With American public taste developed as it has in late decades, the selection is wise and appropriate.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 23 -After getting away to a two-touchdown lead in the first quarter, Rutgers was held in check by Lehigh in Taylor Stadium, the Scarlet emerging on top by 20 -- 6 for its fourth consecutive victory.

IN this plain-spoken book President Conant of Harvard University proposes that the American public-school system recognize the controlling importance of foreign policy for our era. The fundamental problem of foreign policy is the conflict between the totalitarian Soviet Union and the Western democracies.

THE "I" of this narrative went into combat as an infantry replacement in a rifle company. Like others in the group with which he was moved to the front, he had received a minimum of training. Much of his equipment confused and hampered him.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 23 -Scoring in every period, and compiling 381 yards rushing from scrimmage, Brooklyn College's Kingsmen registered a 33-0 victory over an outweighed Northeastern eleven today before 1,800 fans at Huntington Field.
ROME, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The official English text of the Papal Encyclical made public today follows:

PARIS. THIS is a picture of the children of Europe three years after a war that showed them no mercy and has brought them no peace. For the past three months I have toured countries on both sides of the Iron Curtain, and I have seen children suffering as children were never meant to suffer.

Ch. Blakeen Osprey, the 4-year-old white standard poodle that Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt has been campaigning around the circuits with considerable success, gained another best-in-show and a big, handsome piece of silver at the first all-breed event of the new Brooklyn Kennel Club last night.

IT is a long way from the medieval Hotel Dieu, dirty and crowded with the sick and dead (often in the same beds) to the towering, aseptic colossi that are the medical centers of a proud, latter-day America. And in fashioning volumes on two singularly important institutions, Dr. Bertram M. Bernheim and Page Cooper have limned "stories" that redound to America's credit and are as native as baseball and streptomycin.

REMEMBERING the felicitous ode to Princess Elizabeth on her wedding, admirers of John Masefield, Poet Laureate of England, are waiting breathlessly to hear in what terms he will congratulate her when she becomes a mother.

Henry Wallace's Progressive party is on the ballot in every state except Nebraska, Oklahoma and Illinois. Of these states, only Illinois is vitally important to Wallacites. Illinois is regarded as one of Mr. Wallace's three strong states (the other two are New York and California).

Fifty persons were injured when one trolley car rammed another last night on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn opposite the Prospect Park Zoo. The accident tied up traffic for more than an hour at the height of Saturday night congestion.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Strong-armed Dick Gilman threw three touchdown passes today as Kansas surged to a 27-7 Big Seven Conference football victory over Nebraska.

FOR THIS WEEK: Plant all kinds of spring flowering bulbs as soon as possible, with the exception of tulips. They may be postponed until November. . . . Cut down the tops of asparagus and peonis and of plants that have turned black and limp because of frost. . . . Weeding flower beds and borders saves time in the spring.
The seventh edition of the style pageant, "Fashions of the Times," will be presented this week by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

With the Yankees and the Dodgers of the All-America Conference engaged in Cleveland and Chicago, respectively, the Giants will have the local field to themselves in professional football today. Opposing Steve Owen's young team in a National League contest at the Polo Grounds will be the rough, tough Pittsburgh Steelers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- America is feeding Europeans while the Soviets poison their minds. Carleton Smith, management consultant of business firms and director of the National Arts Foundation, said today in reporting on a three-month trip to every country in Europe, including Russia.

GREGG TALLAS, film editor and occasional director, has started a new venture in Hollywood, a cooperative repertory theatre involving twenty-five recruits from the Pasadena Community Playhouse. He and his young colleagues have rented an old estate across from the Hollywood police station and have set up housekeeping and play-acting there, their initial ventures being "The Alchemist" and "The Seagull."

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Yugoslavia made her first move today in the dispute over the Balkans by demanding a United Nations hearing for a representative of General Markos Vafiades, chief of the Greek guerrilla forces.

SO many Americans have come to the London Palladium it is not surprising to hear of plans to take the Palladium to America. The great music hall ends an astonishing season to the sound of Hollywood stars blowing its trumpet.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Entering its third week, the Communist-led French coal strike had become tonight an avowed revolt against the Government. It was assuming rapidly all the characteristics of the conflict between the East and the West for the control of Berlin.

Thorium has long been recognized as a potential source of bomb material. Like uranium, it was therefore placed under the control of the Atomic Energy Commission by the Atomic Energy Act of 1946. Solving the many complex research problems in the way of the large-scale utilization of thorium may take a decade or two.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 23 -- Fullback Johnny Corbisiero scored three touchdowns to spark the undefeated Middlebury College football team to a 24-13 upset victory over a previously unbeaten Trinity eleven today at Porter Field before 3,200.

Alan Mandel, 13-year-old pianist-composer of this city, gave his first local recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The decidedly gifted child, who looked even younger than he is, disclosed, abilities at the keyboard and in his compositions, auguring well for his future in both fields of the art.

GASPARCOLOR Prints, a process developed during the war and still being used extensively by the Armed Forces, are now being offered as a regular service by the West Coast Studios of Gasparcolor, Inc. The announcement was made last week by the company's Eastern agent, the Thirty-fourth Street Camera Exchange, 150 East Thirty-fourth Street.

Witch hazel is in bloom now, the tufted yellow petals straggling like the unkempt hair of some blonde young witch. It is one of the few trees on which one can find leaves, flowers and ripening seed pods all together in the autumn. The leaves are now a rusty gold and ready to drift away, their year's work done.

ROME, Oct. 23 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, and W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador in Europe for the Marshall Plan, respectively, have just completed a twenty-four-hour survey of the European Recovery Program operations in Italy.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- Under brilliant autumn skies thousands of cheering soccer fans saw Portsmouth and Derby play important games in Britain's first division, and thousands more crowded into Cardiff for the soccer international in which Scotland beat Wales by three hard-won goals to one.
The milk strike threatened for today was averted yesterday afternoon by an agreement to arbitrate.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Although everyone was aware of its dangers, scarcely anyone in France expected the coal strike to provoke the major national crisis that it has assumed today.
Your layout on "Jet Propulsion" cleared up a lot of questions in my mind. Tell me, though, hasn't there been at least one case where a man was killed on the ground by a jet?

AWRYLY humorous and soft-spoken gentleman named Luigi is one of the very few new characters to make their appearance on the air this fall, and from all present indications he should be around a while.

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Little St. Bonaventure College served notice of approaching football greatness today by upsetting the Southern Conference champions from William and Mary, 7 to 6, before an estimated crowd of 12,000 in Forness Stadium.

LONDON Oct. 23 -- An official statement was issued tonight about the British-Danish talks held here this 5 week on "problems affecting the Danish-minded part of the population in South Schleswig." It shows that the discussions were friendly and comprehensive. But did not lead to much real agreement.

THOSE who seek to set their troubled hearts and our troubled world at peace by repeating some incantation like "abolition of power politics," "disarmament," or "world government," would be well advised never to lift the cover of Hans Morgenthau's "Politics Among Nations," "International politics," they will find on the very first page, "is, of necessity, power politics.

The New York City Rent Commission is auditing the financial records of city hotels to ascertain whether they owe refunds to permanent guests whose rentals were increased above the 12 per cent maximum authorized by the commission as of Oct. 1, it became known yesterday.

Navy Day Week here got under way yesterday with open house at various Navy installations and ships and with a ceremony at the equestrian statue of Theodore Roosevelt, "father of the modern American Navy," on the steps of the American Museum of Natural History.

There were strong indications yesterday that the strike threatened for next Tuesday against the city's seven privately-owned bus lines by the Transport Workers Union, CIO, would be modified to take the form of a work stoppage for only a few hours.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 23 -- Michigan States battle-toughened Spartans gave unbeaten Penn State the scare of the season and a banner home-coming crowd an incurable taste of jitters today. The final score was 14 to 14, preserving Penn State's unbeaten record for fourteen consecutive games.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 23 -- Paced by Stu Duffield, Williams College topped a favored Tufts team in a see-saw contest today, 14 -- 13, before 4,000.

THE lure of the bulb catalogues and of the baskets and bins in the seed stores prove so irresistible that all the family, and even an occasional unwary guest, are likely to be pressed into service each autumn week-end as the gardener succumbs to new temptations.

THE problem of how to transport their skis if they cannot carry them atop their cars is taking some of the anticipatory joy out of the coming winter sports season for thousands of New York skiers. The puzzle results from restrictions imposed by some parkways on carrying anything -- including skis -- on the outside of automobiles.
Henry A. Wallace spent yesterday at his farm at South Salem in Westchester County, working on speeches for the last lap of his race for the Presidency as the candidate of the Progressive party.
It's a good idea to leave 'em smiling, and that's what Eddie Arcaro did at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday -- with the aid of the Woodvale Farm's 2-year-old colt Sport Page.

The vanguard of the new American settlers -- 813 persons from the displaced persons camps of Europe -- are now on the high seas, their dream of new homes in the land of their choice almost a reality. Almost -- because not until they pass the Statue of Liberty, not until they walk down the gangplanks and set foot and worldly belongings on American soil, will they really believe that it has happened for them.

WHEN a young man forsakes a steady living for a career in music it may be inferred he expects to succeed. He also expects to undergo the vicissitudes of that hazardous profession. But Aksel Schiotz, the Danish tenor who made his American debut last Wednesday, could never have foreseen the calamitous events involved in his musical career.

THE death by poison of Simon Redding casts suspicion upon his wife, the former Amy Sayers, and upon Nellie Osgood, Amy's housekeeper and companion. As the inquest proceeds, it seems evident to all who hear the testimony that one of these two administered the poison and that the other was an accessory before or after the act.

IF justification were needed for the small, exquisitely selected Rembrandt exhibition now at the Fogg Museum. Harvard University, it could be found in the publication of a new book on Rembrandt by Jakob Rosenberg, who also arranged the show.
The popular view that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's election as President is a foregone conclusion has intensified speculation on the selections he will make for his Cabinet.

Since the U.N. General Assembly convened in Paris on Sept. 21 the delegates at the Palais de Chaillot have spoken about three million nine hundred thousand words. These words have been spoken before the various U.N. organs at 218 meetings taking up about 455 hours.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 -- Probably the paramount matter of regional concern in this area as the election approaches is the question of water -- both salt water and the complex man-made fresh water supply on which much of the region is perpetually dependent for salvation from desertdom.

AUGUSTA, Me. -- By 1950 Maine will have a new artificial lake as large as any of the lakes in the Rangely Chain. The lake, which will be about twenty-six miles long and three miles wide and will cover approximately 15,000 acres, is expected to become a special lure for fishermen.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23 (AP) Coach Wesley E. Fesler of Ohio State lashed out tonight at the critics of Harry Stuhldreher, mentor of Wisconsin's football squad.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- The Rev. Osborne Budd, rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, on Underhill Street here, played an unusual role today when he performed the ceremony at the marriage of his mother, Mrs. Roberta LeMon, to Harry Leggatt, which took place in the church this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock.

A REVOLUTIONARY new method of picture-making, called Xerography, or "dry writing," was announced here last week. Prints on practically any surface, including ordinary paper, wood, glass, cloth, metal and ceramic, are produced electronically by Xerography within forty-five seconds after exposure in and ordinary camera.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today that the Republicans not only would hold their 51-to-45 majority in the Senate but also probably would gain several seats.
Twenty-five communities in the New York area are considering making local audits of the status of civil rights based on the report of the President's Committee on Civil Rights.

IN the past twenty years no type of man has changed more strikingly than the autobiographical author. Aforetime it was the fashion for such a person to display a self-confidence which amounted to self-love, to tell how through the vicissitudes of life he had never failed but honorably.

Better values at lower price in ready-to-wear lines stimulated activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

A joint committee composed of three members of the Garment Salesmen's Guild and a like number from the Association of Buying Offices will be set up on a permanent basis to examine and adjust frictions and differences between salesmen and resident buyers.

Yet, the combination of scientist-inventor-industrialist has emerged in the person of the only living man whose name today is synonymous with television. He is the accepted technical leader in a billion-dollar industry which bids fair to become within five years one of the nation's ten largest.

Britain, for a century the dominant foreign power in China and the principal architect of the pattern of Western relationships with that country, today has almost totally abdicated her responsibilities there into American hands. From the viewpoint of the British Foreign Office, the entire map of China would today appear colored as an American "sphere of influence." from which the British are excluded because of Britain's retreat following her European war exertions.

For many years a number of individuals, characterized as "Gloomy Gus" or some equally scornful title by their fellow sportsmen, have prophesied that preserve shooting for upland game birds eventually will replace public shooting in many of the Eastern states.

ROBERT RUARK'S work must surely give the lie both to those who mourn the passing of good American invective as a work of art as well as to those who claim it as the exclusive property of Mencken and Pegler. Ruark lacks some of their spite, but possesses most of their vocabulary, and a youthful vigor -- not to mention good humor and a sense of proportion -- that they now seem to lack.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 23 -- Interest in the Presidential campaign mounted heavily in this area during the week, with President Truman's speeches at the American Legion convention at Miami and before Democrats at Raleigh, N.C., providing much of the stimulus.

Contracts for badly needed repairs to the Prison Ship Martyrs Monument in Fort Greene Park, Brooklyn, where lie the bones of hundreds of Revolutionary patriots who died on British prison ships, will be submitted next month to the Board of Estimate for approval, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- An unlucky Navy eleven succumbed to Pennsylvania's superior manpower before 75,000 persons at Franklin Field today. The score was 20 -- 14 and the story of the game is the story of a long and losing Navy gamble for a short gain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Fiscal officials of the national military establishment were grappling this week with the vast and complex question of the military budget.
Engineers must be prepared to administer and to direct the resources that they have harnessed. Dean Thorndike Saville of New York University's College of Engineering declared yesterday.

WITH this, his sixth book of poems, one feels justified in saying that Kenneth Fearing has sought and found his permanent level in the range of modern verse, and that it lies somewhere between Auden and Ogden Nash. With something of the former's surrealist imagination and a good deal of the latter's urban ability to pillory suburban mediocrity, Fearing does not, of course, derive his style from either.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Competition for new home-appliance sales has been heavily weighed in favor of the lumber dealer and against the appliance retailer, the National Electrical Retailers Association charged today as the organization announced that it would appeal to the Federal Reserve Board for relief from the hardship of tightened credit curbs under the new Regulation W.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 -- While pleading for his own election on the record of the New Deal and his own administration, President Truman tonight hammered Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, as a man of "gall" who he said was given to "double-talk" and "misrepresentation."
Visiting talent delivered the curtain punch-line again yesterday in another of those thrilling football melodramas that have become routine at Baker Field.

Columbia University will award its Kemp Medal for "distinguished service in geology" to Dr. Charles P. Berkey, Newberry Professor Emeritus of Geology at the university, it was announced yesterday. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia, will present the medal to Dr. Berkey at a dinner in his honor this Tuesday at the Faculty House, 400 West 117th Street.

TALKS and demonstrations by more than forty nationally known speakers, the largest roster ever to address a meeting of amateur photographers, will feature the 1948 convention of the Photographic Society of America, Nov. 3-6 at the Netherlands-Plaza Hotel, Cincinnati.

THE recent concerted action by English film exhibitors to boycott motion pictures written by Ben Hecht because of his intemperate utterances on the Palestine problem began last week to have repercussions in Hollywood.

THE Nassau County Horticultural Society's annual fall flower show will be held at Burrwood, the estate of Mrs. Walter Jennings in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., Friday through Tuesday, Oct. 29 to Nov. 2. This marks the third successive year it has been held in this setting.

ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 23 (UP) -Unbeaten Duke, rocked all afternoon by slashing Virginia Tech defensive play, shook Wingback Tommy Hughes loose for a 45-yard touchdown run today to score a 7-to-0 victory before 12,700 fans.

The business office remains virtually the "last frontier" in which American industry can pioneer mass producing equipment, and rapid progress is being made in development of new machines, Frank E. Tupper, managing director of the fortieth National Business Show, said yesterday in announcing opening of the 1948 exposition at Grand Central Palace tomorrow at 1 P.M.

THE years between childhood and adolescence have been called "the forgotten years of childhood." In a Public Affairs Pamphlet just published, called "Understand Your Child -- Ages Six to Twelve," Clara Lambert gives a year-by-year description of the behavior of the youngsters of these "forgotten years."

Two years ago, a painter in one of New York's large industrial plants stood atop a 20-foot ladder painting a ceiling. He was a careful workman, but that morning something happened, something that happens once every 15 seconds, or 5,700 times each day, an industrial accident.

Five week-end fishermen, three of them boys were rescued from possible drowning yesterday morning at the coney island by a combined airr-sea operation that brought into emergecny use for the first time the Police Departments new helicopter.

Stressing the benefits derived from their studies in elementary and junior high schools, the participants in the Youth Forum, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, showed little interest in "playing hookey" in their discussion yesterday.

Bewildered, travel-weary and with mixed feelings about the air age, a Puerto Rican woman who on Thursday boarded the wrong plane at La Guardia Field and wound up in London instead of Puerto Rico, was finally speeding in the right direction last night.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- A record vote is looked for in at least two and possibly three New England States.
DENVER, Oct. 23 -- National and state elections, the Berlin crisis and recent decreases in the cost of living held the interest of Rocky Mountain residents this week.

LITTLE SAL and Little Bear went with their respective mothers to pick blueberries on either side of Blueberry Hill. The little girl and her mother picked for canning for the winter, and the little bear and his mother ate their blueberries on the spot, preparing for winter in their own way.

MARCEL PAGNOL, France's master of comedy, comes from Marseille, where men are fond of exaggerating the truth until it assumes the appearance of a grotesque and humorous lie; but he is deadly serious about the importance of his new movie "La Belle Meuniere," which will show in Paris next month -and in New York shortly thereafter.

Buoyed by an improvement in the world situation, stock prices last week developed the strongest upturn seen in several months. Reassurances by Gen. Lucius D. Clay that he can see a change in trend against the communistic tide abroad, coupled with an improvement in domestic conditions, contributed to the improved sentiment.

THIS is an outstanding book a field where angels might well fear to tread. TULSA, Okla., Oct. 23 -- Nevada University's Wolfpack, led by its ace passer, Stan Heath, overwhelmed the University of Tulsa's sputtering Hurricane, 65 -- 15 today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Chicago Railroad Fair, which attracted more than 2,500,000 persons in a seventy-six-day run last summer, will be repeated in 1949 "as a still greater exposition," Maj. Lenox Lohr, president of the fair, said yesterday.

THERE is one clear reason for not placing Ben Riker's book on the endless shelf of gayly tender remembrances of family life and enterprise in a mellower America -- and letting it go at that. The reason is that "Pony Wagon Town" is fit to start a section of its own. It not only has style; it is distinguished by particular content.

ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Neil S. McCarthy's Shannon II today won the $75,000-added Golden Gate Handicap in 1:59 4/5 at Golden Gate Fields to equal the world record and set a new standard for American tracks for one mile and a quarter. Two lengths behind the Australian Importation, See-Tee-See ran second, a half length ahead of Stepfather. On Trust was fourth.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Mississippi's resourceful Rebels used the hot Southern sun as an ally to beat down the Boston College Eagles, 32 to 13, today before 23,000.

Ford Motor Company is now solving problems in materials handling for its suppliers when bottlenecks hold up delivery of parts needed for new cars. These facts were brought out during a recent interview with M.L. Gusler, Ford's materials-handling expert from Dearborn, Mich., while he attended an industrial conference in New York.

MARKING the spots where seeds, bulbs and plants have been set in fall is well worth the trouble, for few of us remember by spring exactly where we put the plants in autumn. Markers need not be the conventional labels obtainable in seed stores; there are other devices.

In a crowded week of sales, the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, will begin tomorrow to auction the second and final part of the distinguished collection of western Americana formed by the late Herbert S. Auerbach.

THE English excel at pricking the foibles and crotchets of their countrymen, and Winifred Lear, in her first novel, "The Causeway," has not fumbled the ball. She has written an amusing and keen-edged little satire on the desperate and pathetic plight of a 36-year-old spinster in search of love.

Early revival of consideration by the city to purchase electric power for the IRT and BMT divisions of the transit system from the Consolidated Edison Company was indicated last week in the disclosure by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, that the rundown condition of city-owned plants supplying transit power threatens "serious failure at any time."

O. John Rogge, American Labor party candidate for Surrogate, suggested yesterday that the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the deans of the local law schools draw up a "nonpolitical" panel of lawyers to serve as guardians in the Surrogates Court.

The University of New Hampshire's unique course in "Survey of Music in America," first introduced last year, is being offered again this semester in response to high student interest. According to an announcement from the university, the study of American music is just as important as the study of American literature, but more often overlooked.

Retail trade forged ahead here last week, with strong consumer buying of seasonal apparel, accessories and homewares. Department store volume was estimated at about 15 per cent ahead of the like week last year.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23 -With 46,000 highly partisan spectators, including virtually the entire student body from Hanover, as witnesses, Dartmouth today scored a decisive 14 -- 7 victory over Harvard in the fifty-second game of this ancient Ivy League rivalry.

STARKVILLE, Miss., Oct. 23 (UP) -- Sailin' Ed Salem won a football game for Alabama with his toe instead of his arm today, booting a field goal that provided the 10 -- 7 margin over Mississippi State in a bruising battle before 28,000.

OTTAWA -- Two major problems confronting Canada's tourist industry -- providing enough suitable accommodations for the millions of Americans who visit Canada each year, and the completion of the Trans-Canada Highway -- occupied most of the discussion at the third Dominion-Provincial Tourist Conference held at the House of Commons here last week.

Domestic industries in general and the steel industry in particular are hoping for some important revisions in corporate and individual tax requirements by the Eighty-first Congress, which convenes in January. Many industrialists consider the tax changes even more to be desired than clarification of pricing regulations, on which the Capehart committee already has started work.

Charging that President Truman has protected Communists and members of other leftist groups holding high positions in the Federal Government, Archibald B. Roosevelt, only surviving son of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, offered his services yesterday in support of Governor Dewey and Gov. Earl Warren to Alger B. Chapman, New York State Republican campaign manager.

New Jersey and other out-of-state beer flooded into a nearly brew-parched city yesterday on the tenth day of a walkout by 3,000 beer drivers that has been labeled a wildcat strike by their international union.

Letchworth Village, the largest state institution for care of the mentally defective, is so over- crowded that 500 children are sleeping on mattresses because there is no room for beds, Dr. Harry C. Storrs, senior director of Letchworth, reported yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Paul Ramadier, Minister of Defense, has told a committee of newspaper reporters that publication of any news on national defense except what is officially announced, is illegal if it is accurate and will be punished. If it were inaccurate it would not be punished, he said, according to the committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Corn slipped around 2 cents a bushel at times on the Board of Trade today under the weight of record-breaking yields. The easiness of corn gave the entire market a nervous undertone, although during early dealings wheat moved to the highest prices since late July.
PARIS, Oct, 23 -- Herbert Vere Evatt, Australia's Minister of External Affairs, gave the United Nations credit today for saving peace time and again during its three years of life.

The annual board of directors meeting of the Conference of Christians and Jews will be held tomorrow and Tuesday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the conference, said the board would hear reports from leaders in industry, labor, religion and education.

THE 520 members of the American Society of Travel Agents, who sold $300,000,000 worth of travel and transportation facilities to the American public in 1947, expect to equal, perhaps to exceed, that total this year. Newell Grinnell, Rochester, newly elected president of the society, made this prediction last week in an address to the ASTA annual meeting in the General Oglethorpe Hotel, Savannah, Ga.

USING the same locale and approximately the same period of time -- the Louisiana low country from ante-bellum days to the present -- that were the setting for his "The Lawd Sayin' the Same," Dr. Ballowe's new book tells nineteen folk tales of the Creoles of the Louisiana Delta.

Chester Bowles in his article entitled "Challenge to the Conservatives" failed to mention the greatest challenge existing here in America, viz., Connecticut state legislative rotten-boroughism, which permits as few as 9 per cent of the voters of Connecticut to elect a majority in the Connecticut House of Representatives.

At the annual joint meeting of the Riverside Discussion Group and the League of Women Voters to be held at the Riverside Branch Library, 190 Amsterdam Avenue, on Tuesday at 8:15 P.M., the topic will be "Politics -- Whose Job Is It?" The meeting is open to the public.

The Communist party will launch in November and December a nation-wide drive to recruit 5,000 industrial workers to its ranks. This is reported today in The Sunday Worker, party organ, which makes public the text of a letter sent by the national committee to all party organizations and members.

ALTHOUGH the Play House here, with its two modern side-by-side theatres, has just opened its thirty-third season, its period of expansion continues with a new and third theatre now under construction.

The celebrated critic of the American system wrote this sixty years ago. And he was referring to the popular election by which the United States chooses its Presidents.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- In a frenzied nerve-jabbing football game, Ohio State surged from behind today to score a 34-to-32 victory over Wisconsin's Badgers, who had been stirred to a super-pitch because of criticism of their coach, Harry Stuhldreher.

THE United States has often been called the most wasteful nation on earth, and in few other respects are we more vulnerable to the charge than in the prodigal waste of our resources through needless accidents.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Rumanian Government rejected tonight a protest by Vatican representatives to a resolution by several Greek Catholic Church priests breaking all ties with Rome and reuniting with the Greek Orthodox Church.

The performance of "Life With Mother" on the night of Nov. 3 at the Empire Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Seamen's Church Institute of New York. Proceeds will be used to further the educational, social welfare, recreational and health facilities at the institute's headquarters, 25 South Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- A plan for the leasing of city-owned lands to private enterprise for the erection of apartment houses was forwarded today to Mayor Vincent J. Murphy and members of the Newark City Commission by Meyer C. Ellenstein, former Mayor and present Director of Public Works.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 23 (AP) -Mrs. Sheila Summers, the South African champion, won the women's singles title in the seventh Pan-American tennis tournament today, defeating Miss Dorothy Head of Alameda, Calif., 11 -- 9, 6 -- 2.

DESPITE a grim specter of doubt which rose recently, "The Night Watch" definitely will go before the cameras, probably in March, Robert Buckner, author and potential producer-director of the picture about the embattled Holy Land, asserted last week.

LEVELING off of the boom seemed to be the business diagnosis made by the Federal Reserve Board index of industrial production which was issued late last week. The index number stayed at 191 for no change from August. The February index number represented the high of the year at 194 on the 1935-39 base.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Frank Frankel, a Texas oil man, struck one gusher today and came, mighty close to another in Laurel's double stakes offering.

THE subtitle calls this "A Tale Old Carolina," and a fantastic tale it is. As an "event" book, that is, one which reports occurrences rather than causes, it has everything, history, mystery, blistering romance. Mr. Marshall knows his business, but there are times when he seems to know too much, when the stage becomes positively jammed with giant blacks, lame violinists, sadistic half-brothers, and enough Spanish moss to smother the whole lot of them.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Royal Mission, a grandson of the former Kentucky Derby winner Burgoo King, jumped expertly considering the miry underfooting, to capture the eighteenth running of the Monmouth County Hunt Cup over a rolling three-mile timber course on the spacious estate of Amory L. Haskell today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 23 -- Serious fighting broke out on the long dormant northern front in Palestine today, and with renewed hostilities in the south, both the general truce and the newly imposed cease-fire in the Negeb appeared to be endangered.

THE importance to highway safety of uniform traffic control devices and the need for improvement of those now in use are emphasized in a manual prepared by a joint committee of the American Association of State Highway Official, the Institute of Traffic Engineers and the National Conference on Street and Highway Safety.

ROME, Oct. 23 -- Proposals to internationalize Jerusalem and surrounding territory were supported by Pope Pius XII in an encyclical letter addressed today to the Catholic episcopacy throughout the world that urged all the faithful to pray for the cessation of hostilities in Palestine. At the same time the Pope said that freedom of access to the holy places in Palestine and freedom of religion should be assured by international guarantees.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- In an effort to gain political domination over the whole of Germany, the Soviet Union is determined "to attempt to force an issue in the near future," the International Committee for the Study of European Questions asserted today in its ninth report.

PAUL DRAPER has just ended a few weeks of wonderful dancing in the Persian Room. Entertaining as his annual Christmas seasons are with Larry Adler at the City Center, it is good once in a while to see him under night club conditions, which, though tense and trying, have their compensations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- The Democratic National Committee charged today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey "used hundreds of thousands of dollars in New York State funds" to further his Presidential ambitions.

THE gradual emancipation of women in China, the slow shifting of age-old customs and thought are reflected in this story of one girl's quiet rebellion. Shulan, daughter of a small farmer, is loath to give up her happy life teaching in a mission school to marry. Although there are evil rumors about the village lout to whom she had been betrothed as a baby her tradition-bound family refuses to break the contract.

THIS third book, following "Animal Tracks" and "Animal Homes," carries us another step toward genuine understanding of the non-human neighbors who share our planet.
