Dr. Mason writes of birds and animals and insects without sentimentality or whimsey, sticking to observed facts. His facts are more fascinating than fiction.

WATER is a crucial element in the Far West. This year the West has suffered from not enough water -- and from too much water. Two months after California was seared by a crippling drought, Oregon and Washington and the Idaho "panhandle" wallowed in a disastrous flood.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Several delegations, including that of the United States, were today studying means to oppose what they termed Britain's attempt to weaken the authority of the United Nations Trusteeship Council by limiting its field of activity.
About 200 million years ago, even before dinosaurs dominated the world, chirotherium left its footprints on the mudflats of the world, even to the scaly soles.

The finding of a Maritime Commission trial examiner that the Government agency was not empowered to order carriers in the export trade to incorporate freight charges in bills of lading received general approval yesterday from steamship lines and freight forwarders.
THE theory that films will be the foundation for television programming received what appears to be a serious setback last week.

HIS department, at this moment, is in a mild tizzy as a result of a too rapid shuttling back and forth between the Connecticut hills, flamboyant as they now are, even after an unpropitious summer, and the more subtle and deeply insinuating charms of the Vineyard, muted but strangely effective in its autumnal coloring.

The 532 mutual savings banks of the nation increased deposits by $45,000,000 during September to a new high total of $18,272,000,000, but alongside last year and the first half of this year the gain was only "moderate," according to William L. Maude, president of the National Association of Savings Banks.

IN those curious early days after we "liberated" Rome, copies of the articles that Mussolini was writing for the Corriere della Sera of Milan filtered through the lines and we could see them at the OWI, PWB and other alphabetical offices.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 23 (AP) -- A St. Louis newspaper man investigating the slaying of gangster Bernie Shelton was indicted with three members of the Shelton gang today on charges of kidnapping, intimidation and conspiracy.

Mrs. Vincent Astor heads the executive committee for the world premiere-preview of the motion picture, "Joan of Arc," with Ingrid Bergman in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 10 at the Victoria Theatre. Mrs. Astor has enlisted the aid of many prominent women of society in furthering the success of the event.
KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 23 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy eleven vanquished Hofstra, 28 -- 7, today before 3,000 fans.

William A. Wadhams, in his letter of Oct. 17, brushes aside -- as he is fully entitled to do -- all considerations relating to the geographic situation, ethnic background, cultural affinity, and political reality of Hyderabad, to confine himself to a purely legalistic examination of its claim to nationhood.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Former Secretary of State Cordell Hull took the Soviet Union sternly to task in a statement issued tonight on the eve of United Nations Day for the "tragic example" it had given in its international behavior since the end of World War II.

STILL seems to be some muddlement on the matter of book prices. Not so long ago the sad if obvious fact was noted here that they were, by and large, still rising. Where upon one contemporary came out with the news that no, they really weren't, that fiction prices particularly had been held down; and only the other day another chimed in with cheering words to the same effect.

THE perennial Tradescantia virginiana, one of the spiderworts, seems to have been created especially for difficult conditions or for people with little time or inclination to garden. Its amenable qualities appeal even to those who like to grow more difficult plants in their borders.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- A provision to bar the abduction of children from one community of people to another was inserted today, at the behest of the Greek Government, in the proposed United Nations convention against the mass extermination of populations.

FALLEN leaves from deciduous shrubs are the signal that planting time for the majority of these valuable plants is at hand. The list of possible choices for use in this area is long, and even confusing, unless approached with some definite ideas about what effects of flower, form or fruit are wanted.

PONDICHERRY, French India, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The French administration of Mahe has collapsed and the Indian Government has been asked by the local Mayor to assume control of that Malabar Coast city, advices received here today said.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Union College routed the Hobart College eleven today, 25 -- 0, before a homecoming crowd of 3,000. The Dutchmen scored two touchdowns on the ground and took to the air for another pair.

Thomas F. Gilligan writes in to your column (in reply to "Why People Vote -- And Why They Don't," by W. Phillips Davison) to tell why he hasn't voted for years. The clerk at the polling place embarrasses him, says Mr. Gilligan, by talking in a loud voice.

THE writing of history is frequently an ideological weapon -- and, in recent years, scholars as well as popular authors have begun to break a long-standing monopoly of historiography, the genteel, paternal and genially vicious interpretation of the Negro in American history that was advanced at virtually every level of learning and writing.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Top United States sources said today that soon after the American elections the United States and Canada would draft a sweeping North Atlantic alliance for full military aid to the five-nation Western European Union.
Rallying for three touchdowns in the second half, the Wagner College football team tied City College, 19 to 19, at Lewisohn Stadium last night.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Russia opposed today a demand of Western powers that information on armed forces be made available to the United Nations before actual disarmament took place.

TORONTO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Stanley Cup champion Toronto Maple Leafs scored their first victory of the National Hockey League season tonight by trouncing tail-end Chicago, 6 -- 1. It was the Black Hawks' fourth straight loss.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Colgate ended two losing streaks today by shading Holy Cross, 14 -- 13, as 12,00 fans turned out to honor the Crusaders' coach on "Dr. Bill Osmanski Day."

WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE, a dramatist of some pre-science and considerable current appeal to the motion picture industry, undoubtedly did not have Hollywood in mind when he cautioned, "Neither a borrower nor a lender be." This advice is all wrong, according to the movies' modus operandi.

WITH the Christmas-giving season not too far away a spate of records for children has been made ready for the market. As usual, they vary in quality. A few are done with imagination and good taste and may be recommended unhesitatingly. A good many others are run-of-the-mill stuff, and in at least one case a well-meant experiment does not come off.

POTOSI, Bolivia, Oct. 23 (UP) -Two Argentine automobile racers were killed today during the third lap of the grand prix $60,000,6,000-mile race between Buenos Aires, Argentina, and Caracas, Venezuela.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- German Communists and their Soviet zone allies suddenly reopened the question of a Russian share in the control of the Ruhr at today's meeting of the Communist-sponsored People's Council.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Fear that the suspension of the dismantling of German factories, sought by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, may mean the end of German reparations has been expressed by both French and British officials since Mr. Hoffman's visit to French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman yesterday.

During the past week the boards of trustees of Hampton Institute, Va., and Tuskegee Institute, Ala., have held meetings in New York, and the heads of the seventeen Negro land-grant colleges of the Southern and Border States have convened in Washington, presumably about finances and the aims and purposes of these worthy schools in the present-day world.

THE two-week vacation in Europe is not only possible; a good many Americans are already taking it. More are arranging for it later in the winter. And, perhaps more surprising, a considerable number of Europeans are now taking short vacations in the United States.
TRENTON, Oct. 23 -- The concern of the Republican party over continued control of the United States Senate is influencing the campaign in New Jersey.
The Belgian team of Louis Saen and Emile Bruneau won the six-day bicycle race which ended at the Kingsbridge Armory last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The consumers' price index halted its rising on Sept. 15 after a continuous advance of five months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

ALTHOUGH the years of her life were roughly the same as Queen Victoria's (both spanning fairly well the nineteenth century), Fanny Kemble -- actress, author, divorcee, vocal feminist and active opponent of Negro slavery -- was singularly un-Victorian.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Members of the faculty of Bloomfield College and Seminary here must be "zealously pro-American" and "definitely anti-communistic," Dr. Frederick Schweitzer, president of the college, stipulated today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 23 -- In the face of the unimproved dollar situation, President Juan D. Peron's regime has tightened controls on credit operations and exchange allowances with a view to curbing domestic inflation and slowing the exodus of what few dollars have heretofore been available.

Department store activity here last week centered on main floor and ready-to-wear sections, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Homefurnishings sales were good.

HISTORY, which has the pernickety habit of repeating itself, ran true to form last week with the announcement that David Heilweil and Norman Rose had resigned as managing directors of New Stages. The Messrs. Heilweil and Rose said they found it impossible to function under the control of a seven-member board to which they belonged, that so large a board led only to inefficiency and dissipation of purpose.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 23 -- The American Legion, noted for its pranks and capers at convention time, got an "A" in deportment from both Miami and Miami Beach for its recent national convention here.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 23 -- Dr. Mildred McAfee Horton has resigned as president of Wellesley College to join her husband in New York. He is the Rev. Dr. Douglas Horton, minister of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches and chairman of the American Committee for the World Council of Churches.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate to the United Nations Security Council, will not accept the compromise proposal for a settlement of the Berlin dispute as it now stands, usually reliable sources said today.

ONE of the gravest criticisms fired at our Hollywood films is that they furnish the young with false values in their trumped-up fabrications of pseudo-life. All sorts of perilous notions about the nature of the world in which we live are alleged to derive from the movies -- and that's a charge with which we're prone to agree.

IN the same manner that a progressive business man makes a critical survey of the previous year's activities, so the good gardener takes stock of his successes and failures. October is a prime month in which to do this, for there is still time to remake borders, divide perennials and move plants into new locations.
HERE are three first novels, all written by young women, as dissimilar in style and content as they could be.

The Presidential election of 1948 is nine days off. Last week the general public attitude toward the Presidential race continued to be one of apathy. In many places the contest for the White House was overshadowed by more spirited contests for lesser offices.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 23 -- For five days this week Savannah was the world capital of the multi-billion-dollar travel industry as more than 600 representatives of travel agencies, domestic and overseas carriers, hotel operators and resort areas throughout the United States and twenty-seven foreign countries gathered for the annual convention of the American Society of Travel Agents.

AS one of the first volumes in the new American Men of Letters Series, Emery Neff's "Edwin Arlington Robinson" is a disappointment. Professor Neff knew Robinson at the McDowell colony, and values Robinson's poetry deeply, but what he writes is conventional academic appreciation at its minimum of intensity or speculativeness.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 -- Calling for universal disarmament under international controls, Norman Thomas, Socialist party candidate for President, urged tonight that the United States adopt a new approach in its efforts to establish lasting peace.

IN examining the future of the United Nations it is first of all important to determine what the United Nations is and what it is not. Many think that the United Nations is a piece of machinery which ought to work automatically to assure the Charter objectives of peace and justice.

STUTTGART, Germany, Oct. 23 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt addressed a crowd of 1,000 Germans, mostly women, in their own language today and warned them against letting "Sovietism" take the place of nazism.

IN 1943, the nation was jarred by the outbreak of zoot-suit riots between sundry groups of soldiers, sailors and civilians on the one hand, and on the other, gangs of youths from the Mexican-American section of Los Angeles.

OTTAWA, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Arrangements have been completed for redemption or refunding of three issues of Dominion securities which are maturing or have been called for payment in the next few weeks, Finance Minister D.C. Abbott announced yesterday. Redemption of the bonds was announced last week.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican Chairman, announced yesterday that next Saturday night's rally in Madison Square Garden would be preceded by an old-fashioned torchlight parade.

THIS good tempered, sensible little novel, complete with an old-fashioned happy ending, is welcome today in the face of the doubt and turmoil which prevail even in popular fiction. In "The Family Members" Mr. Yoseloff rings a change on the immemorial theme of the erring daughter and the "never darken this door again" tag line.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Action in Harvard Stadium today wasn't confined to the football game between Dartmouth and Harvard.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 23 -- Jack Greenstein, 48 years old, owner of several local taxicabs, was shot fatally tonight in the lobby of his apartment house at 109 Johnson Avenue here by a man who accosted him just as he stepped inside the front door.
President Truman will deliver four major addresses on nationwide radio networks this week, the Democratic National Committee announced yesterday.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 23 (AP) -An alert and scrappy Illinois team upset luckless Purdue, 10-6, today to win its first Big Nine football game in three starts this season.

ANYONE who cherishes among his schoolday memories a hero-worship for Sir Richard Grenville whose little Revenge fought like a demon against fifty-three Spanish ships of war, to Tennyson's delight -- should enjoy "Roanoke Hundred."
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 23 (UP) -- California will continue on daylight-saving time, at least "for the present," Gov. Earl Warren has ruled.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 23 -- Korean Army observation planes today dropped leaflets to the Communist-led rebel forces in Cholla Namdo Province urging them to surrender.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Two policemen were injured today in a street battle with about 700 Communist-led pickets outside the strike-crippled Arabia porcelain factory.

The stock market yesterday had its most active Saturday session since May. The turnover in the Stock Exchange reached 680,000 shares, compared with 390,000 on the previous Saturday, a volume common to the short session since Saturday trading was resumed recently.

FOR any boy or girl who has a yearning to become a writer. reading this latest Howard Pease book will be a rewarding experience. The author has not only combined a first-rate dog story with a tale of adventure on the high seas, but has employed an interesting device which enables the reader to observe just how a young writer should properly go about the task of weaving a successful piece of fiction.

THE question of whether vaudeville ever actually died or whether it simply lapsed into a moribund state is still a debatable one. But fortunately for legions of bicyclists, dog owners, jugglers, acrobats and comedians the question is rapidly becoming academic.
The Kings County Grand Jurors Association called yesterday for legislation to make parents and guardians responsible financially for defacement of property by minors.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Southern California battled to a 7-to-6 victory over a fighting Stanford team today in a Pacific Coast conference football game decided by the accuracy of a kicking toe.

Four national Negro organizations have pledged financial aid to a project sponsored by the United States Office of Education to wipe out illiteracy among adult Negroes, Dr. Ambrose Caliver, a Federal Security Agency specialist for higher education among Negroes, announced yesterday.

South Africa has yielded another fossil human-like skull fragment from its ancient cave deposits, along with signs of fire and animal bones that were broken by clubs. This new find has been given the scientific name Australopithecus Prometheus -- the first name an indication of its relationship to the other proto-humans already found in this region, and Prometheus a tribute to the Olympian hero who taught men the use of fire.

LOS ANGELES -- There is a way to get to the Caribbean Islands and Mexico for $140.15 if you happen to be flying from New York to Los Angeles and you're not in a hurry about getting there. At least, $140.15 is the difference between the direct transcontinental fare of $157.85 and the $298 cost of a Pan American Airways ticket for the long way round.

The state committee of the Liberal party announced yesterday that virtually all tickets had been sold for its Thursday night's rally at Madison Square Garden and that the party would give an enthusiastic welcome to President Truman, who will be the principal speaker.

LET'S not underestimate the value of what Ray Bolger is doing in "Where's Charley?" He is a matchless hoofer who has developed through the years into a dancing clown in a broad style, ideal for the stage. As show business is now organized, with night clubs replacing vaudeville, it is difficult to see where a successor can come from.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Mexican Army team completed a grand slam conquest of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight with the capture of the International Military Challenge Trophy. Col. Humberto Mariles, riding Aretes: Capt. Raul Campero, up on Chihuahua, and Capt. Ruben Uriza, astride Hatuey, gave a faultless performance.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- With the $80,000,000 intra-European payments scheme scheduled to go into effect Nov.1 among the participants in the European Recovery Program, the British, the largest creditors under the program, are still in the dark as to the meaning of a vital part of the agreement.

Hunter College's large Assembly Hall was well filled with children yesterday morning when Thomas K. Scherman's Little Orchestra gave its first Young People's Concert. The hour-long program, "Meet the Instruments," featured Milton Cross as narrator and Blanche H. Burton, 15-year-old Negro pianist.

For the first time, two experienced typists were assigned jobs in an engineering research laboratory to recommend major points of design of an electric typewriter, and two of their suggestions were actually used, it was reported at a preview of the new machine in the offices of International Business Machines Corporation, 590 Madison Avenue, last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Truman declared tonight that he would approve no change in the United Nations partition of Palestine, effected last fall, that in turn was not acceptable to the State of Israel.

Blanche Thebom, the Metropolitan mezzo-soprano, gave her third New York recital yesterday afternoon. Blessed with a handsome stage presence and a gorgeous voice, Miss Thebom evoked unstinted enthusiasm in Town Hall after each of the offerings of her carefully-devised schedule.
Turn your clocks and watches back an hour. You are back on standard time. Get that extra hour's sleep, ah-h-hm.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- There will be peace because "we are not willing to submit to extortion as the price of peace," Warren R. Austin, permanent United States delegate to the United Nations, told a United Nations meeting tonight at Central Hall, Westminster.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Britain's four year economic program, submitted to the Marshall Plan Council here is regarded as a major element in the forthcoming four-year plan for Europe that the council will seek to frame next month.

The Rev. Dr. Harold C. DeWindt, pastor of West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, said in his morning sermon yesterday that good politics, like real religion, "can't be bought at bargain counters."

ROME, Oct. 24 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi, in an interview published today by the Rome newspaper Messaggero, quoted Secretary of State Marshall as having said during last week's visit to Rome that "military action is not probable" in the worldwide struggle between the Western democracies and the Soviet Union.

What was bruited about recently concerning the possibility of Irving Berlin and Robert E. Sherwood collaborating on a musical comedy turns out to be correct. Yesterday the Playwrights Company, of which Mr. Sherwood is a member, confirmed the report in an announcement, saying that he and Mr. Berlin would actually start work today on "Miss Liberty," a project close to their hearts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- William C. Bullitt a lifelong Democrat who served as a trouble shooter as Ambassador under Democratic Presidents Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt, announced his support today of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's candidacy for President.
ON TRUMAN TRAIN, Oct. 24 -- President Truman departed on a last intensive drive for election tonight, with a schedule calling for about forty appearances in eight states.

When a recitalist lists an entire program of interesting music it is worthy of note. When she also proves herself equal to the task of putting it across before a Town Hall audience it is enough to daze a reviewer. Nell Tangeman, soprano, did both last night, and it was indeed stunning.

Fifty leading surgeons, physicians and general practitioners put down their tools of healing and took up musical instruments last night while nurses from six voluntary hospitals formed a 250-voice chorus. They appeared on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House and welcomed 3,000 volunteer workers in the audience who are helping to keep open New York's eighty-six non-profit hospitals by doorbell ringing for the United Hospital Fund.

NANKING, Oct. 24 -- Government troops in South Manchuria recaptured Yingkow, Liaotung Peninsula port today, thus restoring highway communications between Mukden and the sea. The Central News agency said that Government forces had entered the port city at 9 A.M. after having taken Tashihchiao, twelve miles to the east on the old South Manchurian Railway.

New York has a "pitiful dearth" of gallery space for art exhibitions, Albert T. Reld, national vice president of the American Artists Professional League, declared yesterday. He charged that "New York goes in largely for muscles and legs and cheesecake, and rather forgets there is a cultural side to art and opera.
A Brooklyn Good Samaritan answered a feminine call of distress yesterday morning and was ill paid for his gallantry.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 -- Purchasing agents for the district's major steel mills disclosed late last week that their stock piles of steel-making scrap are excellent and well above what they had hoped for some months ago. At the same time it was indicated that every ton of scrap would be urgently needed to meet a demand that shows no signs of falling off.

A full discussion of the system of overtime wages for customs employes, paid by steamship and airlines for after-hour inspections and examinations of certain kinds, is expected early in the next session of Congress, according to shipping men and customs officials here.

Michigan, Notre Dame, North Carolina, Army, California and Georgia Tech drew away from the field as the big six of intercollegiate football Saturday as Penn State was tied, Pennsylvania had its second narrow escape and Cornell's quest for the bubble of fame ended in the cannon's mouth of West Point.

In your editorial of Oct. 14 "Oil Progress Day" you state that the petroleum industry has been an important contributor to our national defense. Might it not be well to emphasize the essential role petroleum must take if our civilization is to survive?

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The amateur gunner-handler stake, held under adverse weather conditions, concluded the twenty-fifth meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association today. Dogs, handlers and the judges, Frances J. Squires and William R. Kirkland Jr., worked in a sharp wind and soaking rain.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins ran the opening kick-off back 97 yards to a touchdown today and then rolled on to beat the Green Bay Packers, 23--7, in a National League football game before a small crowd of 13,433 fans.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Patience and the talented toe of Cliff Patton paid off for the Philadelphia Eagles today as they accomplished their first triumph over the Chicago Bears in fifteen years of National Football League rivalry. In a damp and dreary setting at Shibe Park, they upset the hitherto unbeaten Midway Monsters, 12--7.

The third anniversary of the founding of the United Nations comes in the midst of a creeping crisis which both overshadows its many genuine accomplishments and provides a supreme test of its ability to fulfill the chief function for which it was created. This is to safeguard international peace and security.

The missionary's function is to build up the visible church of Christ in every corner of the earth, the Rev. T. Xavier Lewis declared yesterday at the Mission Day solemn mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street. A former parishoner of the church, Father Lewis soon will become a missionary in the Marshall Islands.

An unfavorable trade balance for Brazil of $1,100,000, causing a drain on that country's dollar resources, was shown by a report on trade during August between Brazil and the United States, issued over the week-end by the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, 551 Fifth Avenue.

A two-year task of compiling 40,000 biographies of artists, educators, scientists, jurists, and military, business and political leaders in sixty-five countries ends today with the publication of "World Photography," a two-volume book of 1,170 pages, by the Institute for Research in Biography.

Declaring that everything these days is streamlined except our souls, Bishop Christopher E. Storrs of Grafton, Australia, yesterday characterized the English-speaking peoples as "too busy and too practical to get down on their knees and pray."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The Navy spelled out its post-war shipbuilding program today in a statement that emphasized anew the increasing importance assigned to underwater and air warfare, including consideration of possible air attacks across the Arctic.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Parliament reassembles briefly tomorrow to wind up its present session, and then on Tuesday the last full session of this Parliament will begin. Its biggest issue by far will be the nationalization of the iron and steel industry, which threatens to provide the bitterest political battle in years.

The city administration was defended yesterday against charges that it had failed to take adequate action in combating traffic congestion. Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan, in a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer, gave a resume of accomplishments that, he asserted, countered "the impressions offered by 'cure-all' dreams and fancy brochures of publicity-seeking committees that the city is doing nothing about the traffic problem."

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 24 -- The Belgian, Netherlands and Luxembourg Governments are endeavoring to achieve the economic union of those countries as early as possible to show that by exertion and sacrifice the goal can be reached within a limited time.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Wheat and corn parted company last week on the Board of Trade. December wheat was strong and sold yesterday at $2.29 3/8 a bushel, the first time that it has been above the Government loan level of $2.29 since late last July.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals, erupting for 35 points in the third quarter, smashed the Boston Yanks, 49--27, today to move into a tie with the Chicago Bears for the Western Division lead of the National Football League.

Communist "fellow-travelers" were described yesterday by the Rev. Dr. L. Wendell Fifield, pastor of the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, as individuals who help promote communism by "advancing a materialistic philosophy and defeating a spiritual philosophy."

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 24 (UP) -- President Enrique Hertzog declared today that the nation-wide "state of siege" proclaimed last night was "a warning to agitators that the Government and the people will resist any violence they might provoke."

With only eight days to go before the election on Nov. 2, Thomas E. Dewey and Earl Warren, Republican nominees for President and Vice President, respectively, appear certain to defeat President Harry S. Truman and Senator Alben W. Barkley, their Democratic opponents, by a large plurality in the Electoral College.

For the first time in its sixty-four-year history the Metropolitan Opera Company has taken a member of its clerical staff to be one of its performers. Singled out for the distinction is Yvonne Andlauer, 23-year-old mezzo-soprano of this city, who starts singing in the opera chorus when it begins rehearsals today.
Two days of the most intensive campaigning in New York and the metropolitan area will mark President Truman's final Eastern swing later this week.
The familiar pattern of last-minute governmental action to avert threatened strikes by Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union began repeating itself yesterday.

Activity in the foreign exchange market during the past week continued quiet. While there was a fair demand, mostly from commercial interests, business transacted was limited and price movements were for the most part very narrow.
The efforts of the United Brewery Workers, CIO, to end the wildcat strike of beer drivers in this city met a new series of rebuffs yesterday.
William S. Begg has been appointed vice president and secretary of the American Steel and Pump Corporation.

HAIFA, Israel, Oct. 24 -- Israeli and Syrian troops were still locked today in a fierce battle on the northern front of the Palestine war. In the Negeb desert area in the south, however, peace was restored as the United Nations opened negotiations with Israel and Egypt on the cease-fire ordered by the Security Council.

NEWARK, Oct. 24 -- Henry A. Wallace proposed tonight that Great Britain, Russia and the United States agree to remove all their troops from Germany and put its policing in the hands of France, Belgium, The Netherlands, Luxembourg, Poland, and Czechoslovakia.

For a number of weeks he had been seen going about -- when he was not shouting to contemporaries at the top of his voice or, in more quiet moods, finding the range of a puzzling subject by popping questions all around it -- with his lips pursed and cheeks puffing in and out.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce has analyzed the operations of the Tennessee Valley Authority, and found an "enormous difference" between the system's computed costs and those a private operator would incur.

Supplementary information to show the necessity for retaining out of profits amounts sufficient to replace productive facilities at current prices should be provided in corporation annual reports, according to a statement issued over the week-end by the committee on accounting procedure of the American Institute of Accountants.

American business men are finding it difficult to consummate purchases of European textiles owing to price and delivery uncertainties, it was pointed out last week by Herbert Miskend, president of Yolande Corporation, manufacturer of lingerie and blouses.

THE Benedictine Priory of Oby, situated among the fens and swamps by the Waxle River somewhere in the North of England, was founded in the twelfth century. A small convent in an isolated region, it just managed to keep in existence for two centuries. Its income was poor and uneven. Few noble novices with rich dowries were enrolled.

Europe's 15,000,000 uprooted persons should be resettled speedily in useful work and satisfactory living conditions for economic as well as humane reasons, the committee on international policy of the National Planning Association declared yesterday.

CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Maynard L. Cassady, educational leader in the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, who trained 2,000 USO workers during the recent war, died yesterday after a brief illness. His age was 50.

The cornerstone of a new $1,100,000 building at Hillside Hospital, which will increase the capacity of the hospital from 88 to 172 beds, was laid yesterday by Leon Lowenstein, a vice president of the hospital, on its grounds at Bellerose, Queens.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct 24 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll said today he would receive a preliminary report tomorrow on sale of two privately owned toll bridges over the Delaware River to Burlington County for $12,000,000, more than twice their estimated value.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 24 -- Yugoslavia has asked the United Nations to annul the adherence of Trieste to the Marshall Plan organization because it "endangers" the "political and economic freedom" of the international territory, the Yugoslav news agency, Tanjug, reported today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- Two Pacific Coast steamship offices are closing for at least the duration of the maritime strike, according to an announcement here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- A representative of 5,000,000 American clubwomen said today that feminine voters were determined to elect a Congress which would do something next year about high prices and the housing shortage.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- "The complete recovery of Western Europe can be expected by 1952, even if the Soviet satellites of central and southeastern Europe continue to block trade between Eastern and Western Europe," Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, declared here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Labor Department said yesterday that in a decade under the wage-hour laws employers had paid $112,000,000 in back wages to workers.

The White Cross is the symbol of the United Hospital Fund to aid the sick with will to live but without ability to pay. Last year one out of seven New Yorkers wounded in wrecks or weak with acute or chronic disease was treated in this area's eighty-six voluntary hospitals.
The wind cut capers with the rain yesterday and at times produced the illusion that snow was falling.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Prices of cash corn were sharply lower lastI week as the result of increasedI recepits and liberal tenders onI previous contracts which had made l industries 'independent for the time being. Elevator interests were the best buyers of cash corn late in the week.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Trafalgar Square was more crowded and festive tonight than in any night since the armistice of World War II. It was proof of how starved the Britons were for light and color and how little they asked by way of amusement, for these many thousands came from near and far merely to see the new brightly lit fountains.

If New Yorkers gave less thought to private gain and more to the "common good" their city would be a happier place to live in, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122nd Street, said yesterday.
Seven new films, including importations from France and Italy, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Brooklyn's Dodgers easily scored their second straight victory over the Chicago Rockets, 35 to 14, today in a battle between the two cellar-dwellers of each division of the All-America Football Conference. A scant gathering of 5,964 attended.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings skipped ahead of Montreal into first place in the National Hockey League tonight by downing the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 1, on a pair of big goals by Defensemen Jack Stewart and Len (Red) Kelly before a record Olympia crowd of 15,336.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- For the second time within a week the United States and Britain are running into opposition from the smaller powers on pivotal points in the United Nations disarmament controversy.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -- The first purely modern buildings for Harvard University were reaching their final stage of design here today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Chicago, the market center for grains live stock, furniture and many other products, has become a leading market for shoes, industry spokesmen said today.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Harry Pollitt, secretary of the British Communist party, called upon British coal miners to show more "international solidarity" in a speech in South Wales today. He made it clear that the British Communists were hostile to the Labor Government's conduct of the nationalized coal industry.
The World Council of Churches has demonstrated the absurdity of the belief that war is inevitable, Spencer Miller Jr., State Highway Commissioner of New Jersey, declared yesterday.

Billed as one of the immortals, with only the last name given, the Polish pianist Mieczyslaw Horszowski, gave a recital Saturday night at Town Hall. It was not as memorable an event as such advertising might lead the unwary to expect, but there was much distinguished piano playing nevertheless.

The first volume of a two-volume history of India by Gertrude Emerson Sen will be brought out by Longmans, Green on Wednesday. "The Pageant of India's History" recounts the subcontinent's story up to the crumbling of unity in the thirteenth century.

Warning flags are posted and autumn seems to gather momentum as it slides downhill into November. Oaks still cling to many of their bronze-brown leaves, but the glowing wine-red color of the sumacs is draining away to thin brown-red and the rich cardinal of the Virginia creeper is changed to dull bronze on the trunks of meadow elms.

Since storage space for dishes is usually limited in today's small homes and apartments, dinnerware that can be used equally well for informal meals or formal entertaining is favored by contemporary designers. They usually prefer simple shapes that go with either delicate stemware or sturdy glasses, and a combination of muted and dramatic colors in a stylized design.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- In what was perhaps the most brilliant performance of his illustrious career, Otto Graham passed for four touchdowns and ran for a fifth today as the mighty Cleveland Browns routed the New York Yankees, 35 to 7, before 46.912 enthralled onlookers at Municipal Stadium.

Owing to retail demand, orders and reorders for fall and winter apparel received by apparel manufacturers here last week continued heavy, particularly in the coat and suit divisions of the market, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Manufacturers were also busy with the preparation of their spring lines, which are scheduled to open soon.

Federal aid to higher education in this country may mean the destruction of the independent college or university, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University, declared in his annual report, to be made public today.

Heading a list of twenty new exhibitions this week is a pictorial chronicle in paintings, prints and models of naval history from the revolutionary period to World War II, opening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art today. Prominent among new one-man shows today are paintings by Jon Corbino at the Rehn Gallery and recent paintings by Fletcher Martin at the Associated American Artists Gallery.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board issued its first rulings on strike activities under the Taft-Hartley Law today.

A stirring pictorial chronicle of the Navy's history is presented in an exhibition opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, following a private viewing last night. Paintings and prints unfold the story of battles and heroic deeds and show the faces of our naval fighting men.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- To finance Great Britain's four-year industrial plan very large amounts of capital will be required. A start on this plan was made last week when the British Electricity Board, which is an outcome of nationalization of the electrical industry, publicly issued a loan for 100,000,000 on an interest basis of slightly more than 3 per cent.

Representative Vito Marcantonio opened his "Morrissey file" yesterday to indicate that his Democratic opponent for Congress, John P. Morrissey, had cultivated friendship and support as late as August, 1946. Mr. Morrissey has said that he did not support Mr. Marcantonio for public office when the latter had the Democratic nomination.

Deletion of the name of God from the United Nations Bill of Human Rights was "an unchallenged sacrilege and a retreat in the United Nations' quest for unity and peace," the Rev. Edwin B. Broderick of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared at solemn mass there yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- France's long-term economic program just submitted to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation marks the crossroads in French planning policy, according to experts here.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of Tennessee Williams' new play, "Summer and Smoke," next Monday night at the Music Box Theatre for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

Having recently returned from Europe, where I directed the vocational training operations of World ORT Union in the Jewish DP camps in Germany and Austria, and where I lived in intimate professional and social contact with Jewish DP's, I should like to support fully the views expressed by Kurt Grossman in his recent letter.
A memorial service at sea and a Navy art preview attended by John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, marked yesterday the Sunday celebration of Navy Day Week in the New York area.

Following are the texts of addresses delivered yesterday in Paris by Secretary of State Marshall and John Foster Dulles, member of the United States delegation to the United Nations, as recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System:

The O'Dwyer administration was reported yesterday to be toying with the idea of asking the 1949 Legislature for a permissive enabling act under which the city could purchase the remaining private bus lines without cutting into its borrowing power within the constitutional debt limit.

Prices for cotton registered here last week some improvement over recent levels. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange on Saturday showed net gains of 23 to 39 points, in contrast with declines of 3 to 13 points in the previous week.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics has just released its monthly index of consumer prices for the period ended Sept. 15. This reveals that for the first time in six months living costs as a whole ceased to advance, while retail food prices actually showed a modest decline.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- San Francisco's Forty-niners, coming from behind with a second-half rally, defeated the Baltimore Colts, 21--10, today to protect an unblemished record in the AllAmerica Football Conference.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Driving 69 yards for the deciding touchdown in the final minute of play, the Los Angeles Rams came back to take a 34-to-27 National Football League decision from the Detroit Lions today after trailing, 21-0, at half-time.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's complex reclamation plan is meant to defend the richest agricultural regions from effects of the dread "sukhoveyi" -- hot dry winds from the Caspian and Central Asian deserts. The plan calls for:

BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The unbeaten Boston Bruins reeled off their third straight National Hockey League triumph by overpowering the New York Rangers, 4--1, tonight before 13,000 at the Boston Garden. The victors made half of their tallies while the Rangers were shorthanded because of penalties.

The plight in which virtually all of our charitable institutions find themselves as the result of the constantly rising price spiral is nowhere better illustrated than in the case of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York. What with rising prices, increased costs of care and an increase in the number of persons served, this organization has found the deficits of its member organizations jumping from $66,000 in 1945 to $2,100,000 in 1947.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The proceedings of the United Nations General Assembly have come to a virtual halt so far as all critical issues are concerned pending the results of the Presidential election in the United States.
MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet newspapers Pravda and Izvestia said today the third anniversary of the United Nations saw the organization menaced by United States policies.

A prayer in honor of the third anniversary of the United Nations was authorized for use yesterday at all religious services in the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Long Island. The prayer, written by Bishop James P. DeWolfe, follows:

PARIS, Oct 24 -- British and American concepts of their security interests extend around the peripheries of the Soviet Union from Spitsbergen and Scandinavia through Germany and central Europe, across central Asia to the Far East and over China, Korea and the Kurile Islands to the Aleutians and Alaska.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament opened a week-long celebration of its one hundredth anniversary this morning with a pontifical mass of thanksgiving at which Cardinal Spellman presided.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- "Communist infiltration into maritime unions," is to be the subject of further hearings by a subcommittee of the House Committee on Labor and Education, it was announced yesterday by Representative Charles J. Kersten, Republican, of Wisconsin, as he left for home.

Despite the hampering effects of "plenty of red tape," the Italian Government is showing a spirit of cooperation in encouraging United States investments and enterprise in Italy, Leo J. Wollemborg, director of Italian Publishers Representatives, Inc., said here last week.

Ice skaters officially opened the rink at Rockefeller Center yesterday, but were forced to give up after skating in the rain for more than an hour. The ice still was hard, but the water was more than two inches deep in some places.

Union of all major branches of Lutheranism in this country, based on Bible teachings, "which we together teach and confess," was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Thaddeus F. Gullixson, president of Luther Theological Seminary, St. Paul, Minn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- David O. Selznick has acquired "The Lion Tamer's Husband," a screen comedy by Frank Gill Jr. and Albert J. Cohen, for filming next spring, the Sleznick Production Company here has announced. Joseph Cotten or Gregory Peck will play the leading male role, according to the announcement, which described "The Lion Tamer's Husband" as a completed photoplay, ready for the cameras.

Soil conservation experts in the United States have been advocating for many years the planting of trees on a large scale as a means of combating drought conditions. Their efforts were rewarded dramatically during the "dust bowl" era of the 1930's in the Middle West when the late President Roosevelt sponsored the shelter-belt plan.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The first full meeting of the Anglo-American Productivity Council will be held in London tomorrow.

In tackling the extremely testy problem of the financial plight of the municipalities and communities in New York State, Frank C. Moore has unquestionably acted with honesty and integrity. However, I believe that his letter to THE TIMES omitted a few facts that deserve a public airing.

The public assistance caseload declined in September for the fourth month in succession, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday. He also said that he was ordering a reinvestigation of each of the 137,161 cases on the relief rolls "to be sure that the usual pattern of increasing caseloads during the fall and winter months does not necessarily follow this year."

I strongly urge that the United Nations not allow the situation to drift on in this way any longer. It is two years since the Assembly first asked for a genocide convention, and I feel that the Assembly at its meeting in Paris should * * * adopt a final convention.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 24 -- Boris Kidrich, chairman of the State Planning Commission and a member of the Yugoslav Political Bureau, said today in the opening address to the first Congress of United Trade Unions that the Communist Information Bureau states had not established an economic blockade of Yugoslavia, but he added that moral pressure upon this country was having its effects upon the five-year plan.
CYPRUS, Oct. 24 -- A big ear is nearly ready to "eavesdrop" in Eastern Europe.

There is semi-discrimination against adults at the performances of "King Midas and the Golden Touch," being staged these Saturdays and Sundays by the Children's World Theatre at the Barbizon-Plaza playhouse. Since reviewers are not immune from the terms of an edict that bars oldsters from the play, unless they are accompanied by children, three young escorts convoyed this department's representative to his place at the opening matinee performance.

Sales of Sano cigarettes, made by Fleming-Hall Tobacco Company, Inc., increased 80 per cent since the opening of its national newspaper campaign in August, Arnold R. Deutsch, president of Deutsch Rhea, Inc., the agency which handles the Sano account announced over the week-end.

PARIS, Monday, Oct. 25 -- The Egyptian delegation to the United Nations has asked for an emergency session of the Security Council on the ground that Israeli forces still were carrying on an of fensive in the Negeb, but no action has been taken.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet Government and the Communist party announced jointly today a gigantic fifteen-year reclamation and development project covering nearly 300,000,000 acres of land on which "millions and millions" of men are to be employed.

The strike threatened by the Radio Writers Guild against advertising agencies and program producing firms refusing to accept the terms of the contract now in force with the four major radio networks has been set for 12:01 A.M., tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- That "problem children" also have their problems -- with parents -- was indicated here today at Children's Village.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Buildings and pavements on the Carnegie Tech campus today were splattered with painted signs protesting the school's losing football ways.

Bonraye Fo Yu of Orchard Hill, a Pekingese imported by Mrs. Richard S. Quigley of Lock Haven, Pa., made a stride toward greatness yesterday by getting best in show in the all-breed fixture of the Queensboro Kennel Club at the Fourth Regiment Armory, Jamaica.

The Composer's Forum series, which Ashley Pettis presents annually at Columbia University's McMillin Theatre, got off to a mixed start Saturday night. The composers presented were Peggy Glanville-Hicks and Irwin A. Bazelon.

ABOARD THE ARMY TRANSPORT GENERAL BLACK, Oct. 24 -- This ship, carrying 813 displaced persons to the United States, turned slightly off course this afternoon to pick up a critically ill woman from another Army transport.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement tonight on his position in regard to Palestine:

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 24 -- Declaring that there are few countries in the world where the milk supply is sufficient to meet human needs, Sir Herbert Broadley of England, deputy director general of the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations, said tonight that milk production must be doubled before adequate supplies are available for world nutrition needs.

The carpet industry probably will end allocations of most nine-foot merchandise early next year, an executive of a well known mill predicted last week. He said his organization is gearing its sales staff to free acceptance of orders after Jan. 1 and added that other manufacturers are counting on termination of nine-foot quotas by the end of the first quarter of 1949.

The Football Giants yesterday emerged from a rain-soaked battle with the Pittsburgh Steelers with their second triumph of the season, 34--27. After being tied twice the Giants made the deciding touchdown three seconds after the final quarter began.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas said tonight that he would "insist" on appearing before the grand jury looking into his payroll records. His statement was a reply to an invitation issued late this afternoon by the Justice Department.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 24 -- Meeting generally stiff resistance, Government troops today continued scattered battles with Communist-led insurgent forces in Cholla Namdo Province.

James A. Farley yesterday pledged his own support to the Truman-Barkley ticket, and predicted its election if the American people supported the Democratic ticket the way they did in the preceding four national elections.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 24 -- Edward B. Yancey, a vice president and member of the board of directors and of the executive committee of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., died of a heart attack here today at the age of 60.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., campaign manager for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, the GOP Presidential candidate, today urged the voters in Tennessee to elect Carroll Reece to the United States Senate to insure "unity of action between the White House and Congress."

More than 350 varieties of natural and processed cheese, representing types characteristic of forty-seven countries, are being presented for the first time in Abraham Straus' food shop. The A. S. boast is that no other department store in the United States carries an array of cheese so big that one could enjoy a different kind almost every day in the year without any duplication.

A considerable degree of optimism with regard to the chances of averting an East Coast longshoremen's strike on Nov. 9 continues despite strike threats and the fact that negotiations are about to enter the final two weeks. The present 80-day Federal injunction against a walkout expires on Nov. 9.

PARIS, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Secretary of State Marshall said tonight that the "obstructive attitude" of certain nations was the greatest blight on the record of the United Nations. He made his declaration in a prepared broadcast on the third anniversary of the world organization.

ST.-ETIENNE, France, Oct. 24 -- The Government on the one side and the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor on the other spent today lining up their forces for tomorrow's expected showdown of authority in this coal district.

Sir Lawrence Bragg, Nobel Prize winner and head of the Cavendish Laboratory at Cambridge University, arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Media. He came to the United States for a lecture tour and to accept the Roebling Medal of the Mineralogical Society of America on Nov. 12 at the society's annual meeting in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Something happened to the U.N. when it moved to Paris. Over here it is again the UNO -- ONU in French -- and still as new to the French as it was to Americans who assisted at its birth in San Francisco. France deliberately adjourned its turbulent Parliament in order to present a semblance of government to this international assembly.
CAIRO, Oct. 24 -- Egypt postponed today, at the request of Dr. Bunche, an ultimatum issued yesterday that threatened military action unless Israel ceased attacks in the Negeb by 6 P.M. today.

Last night saw the third annual dance festival at the Ziegfeld Theatre for the benefit of the Spanish Refugee Appeal, an affair which has rapidly grown to be one of the outstanding events of the dance season each year. The theatre had been completely sold out for the last two weeks, and many well-known dancers were reported to have volunteered their services far beyond the capacity of a single evening's performance.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's speech in Chicago on Tuesday night will stress the interdependence of labor, business and agriculture and develop a theme on how governmental policies favorable to each group "will help build a healthy and vigorous America," it was announced today.

Irene Dunne's performance in the title role of RKO's "I Remember Mama," and Ronald Colman's characterization in Universal-International's "A Double Life," were judged the top starring portrayals of 1947-48 in the seventh annual national poll of newspaper, magazine and radio screen reviewers conducted by the trade journal, The Film Daily.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- A recital of concrete past difficulties and abstract future triumphs by Heinrich Rau, chief of the German Economic Commission of the Soviet Zone, concluded a three-day meeting of the Communist-sponsored People's Council today.

Most New Yorkers dropped their dimes in the subway turnstiles with less reluctance, last July 1, when they learned that a $2,500,000 home medical care program to relieve the acute bed shortage in city hospitals would be established with funds available from increased rapid transit fares.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP) -- George Ratterman and the Buffalo Bills overcame a 14-point handicap and flew on to a 35-to-21 victory over the Los Angeles Dons in an All-America Conference football game today before 26,818 fans.
The twenty-third annual World Championship Rodeo came to a rip-roaring wind-up with 10,000 persons watching at Madison Square Garden last night.

College courses for students who chose business as a future neglect those qualities necessary for successful business management, according to a two-year study completed by the Society for the Advancement of Management, released over the week-end.

Despite sharp cold winds and a heavy rainstorm, 5,000 persons marched down the Grand Concourse in the Bronx yesterday in a "Support Israel" Day parade sponsored by the Bronx Zionist Emergency Council and the Bronx County Council of the Jewish War Veterans.

The Gourmet Society was back in business yesterday with its first dinner since 1942. To mark the end of its austerity period, the president of the organization, J. George Frederick, showed up for a Chinese feast attired in a mandarin coat and skull cap and well-briefed with interesting items about Chinese table manners.

The Budd Company reported yesterday for the first nine months of 1948 a net income of $7,843,046 after charges and taxes, equal to $2.10 a common share. This compares with $4,658,501, or $1.23 a common share in the similar period of 1947.

Mischa Elman will celebrate the fortieth anniversary of his New York debut on Dec. 10. The audience that gathered to hear his annual recital at Carnegie Hall last night clearly included many admirers he has gained during those four decades, for his first appearance was greeted with the prolonged applause of old friends.

Two men held up an Italian pastry shop at 218 Grand Street, within a few blocks of Police Headquarters, yesterday afternoon. After a zigzag chase through the lower East Side one of the men was caught in a basement at 152 Mulberry Street and the $140 loot was recovered. His older companion escaped.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- In a statement issued here today, the French Communist party, as a party, acknowledged and proclaimed for the first time that it considered the French miners' strike a part of the struggle between Russia and the West.

Two works new to the repertoire of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra were featured at its concert given Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, under Dimitri Mitropoulos. These consisted of the Passacaglia, Op. 1, by Anton von Webern, and Bloch's Suite for Viola and Orchestra.

GENEVA, Oct. 24 -- The number of European workers available for emigration from their respective countries is enormously in excess of the requirements of European countries for foreign labor. Such is the conclusion to be drawn from the figures issued here today by the International Labor Organization, based on replies furnished by twenty-five European member countries of the organization.
TOKYO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur reported today that Japan's industrial production index was 32 per cent higher in July, 1948, than for the same month a year ago.

Registration for the Adult Education programs at the four municipal colleges -- City, Brooklyn, Hunter and Queens -- shows a slight increase of 449 men and women for an over-all total of 9,763 students, compared with 9,314 for the fall semester of 1947, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Dow Chemical Company of Midland, Mich., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 105,176 shares of common stock that the company proposes to offer to its employes and seven subsidiaries and associated companies.

A cigar-smoker from way back, Admiral Jonas Ingram, All-America Football Conference Commissioner, yesterday said he was willing to switch to a pipe -- a peace pipe. In an eloquent speech at the weekly luncheon-meeting of The Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's, Ingram deplored the "war" that exists between his circuit and the old-established National Football League.

With such Wallace strength as existed six months ago waning visibly, it is strange to find President Truman swinging more and more to the Wallace line -- so far as domestic issues are concerned -- as the campaign nears its end. His speech last night at Chicago set a new high mark in this direction.

Gradually but surely the rights of labor and management, respectively, under the Taft-Hartley Act are being brought into clearer definition and focus through the decisions of the National Labor Relations Board. One of the most important group of decisions of this kind to emerge thus far was published in yesterday's newspapers.

QUANTICO, Va., Oct. 25 (AP) -Defending national pistol champion Heulet Benner of Ft. Knox, Ky., was tied for the lead at the one-third point today as a field of 24 hand-gun champions from every section of the country opened the Sixty-fourth National Rifle Association matches.

A raging sea, swept by gales ranging at times up to seventy miles an hour, gave New York-bound passengers a foretaste of Atlantic winter weather over the week-end and delayed shipping from eight to twenty-four hours.
DETROIT, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A three-for-two player trade with the Chicago Black Hawks was announced today by the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Campaign Manager, indicated here yesterday that campaign fraud charges would be pressed against three Democratic candidates for United States Senator who are generally considered to have better than even chances of election.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended to that body today that it approve a debt readjustment plan of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company and its subsidiaries, that will hold back any maturities of $129,708,000 of outstanding bonds until 1969, with maturities spaced thereafter at five-year intervals until 1994.

Mayor O'Dwyer and a group of city officials broke ground yesterday for Todt Hill Houses, the first project in the New York City Housing Authority's $200,000,000 program without cash subsidy to be started on Staten Island.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The question of Kashmir and the partition of Ireland were put forward today as weak spots in British Commonwealth unity.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Organized Reserves within supporting units of the eighteen-division Army will have first priority on drill pay presently available, the Army announces.

Federal funds were quoted at 3/4 of 1 per cent to 1 per cent yesterday, compared with 1 3/8 per cent on Friday, reflecting somewhat easier conditions in the money market. The member banks here, after reporting excess reserves of $174,000,000 on Wednesday night, ended the week on Friday with a deficiency of $26,000,000, which was their position at the start of business yesterday.

Despite a serious power shortage and interruption of production caused by floods in the Northwest, earnings of the Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly-owned subsidiaries reached a new high record for the first nine months of this year, Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president, reported yesterday.

We Americans should not be so wrapped up in present European troubles as to fail to note the anniversary of a great diplomatic settlement of the past, the three hundredth anniversary of the Peace of Westphalia. On Oct. 24, 1648, after some years of tedious negotiation, there were signed the Treaties of Muenster and of Osnabruck, thus bringing to an end the Thirty Years' War of Germany.

The appointment of James V. Gurge as manager of the Holland America Line's newly establisled South American department was announced yesterday by Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager of the line in the United States, Canada and Mexico.

A rebellion was set off on the morning of Oct. 20 by the South Korean constabulary garrisoned at Yosu, a port town about 130 miles south of Seoul and eighty miles west of Pusan. Whether the uprising is Communist-inspired, or is a manifestation of long-standing resentment against the parties in power, or is a combination of both, it is the beginning of tragedy for the Korean nation.

Walter R. Kraeuter, 35-year-old son of a South Orange, N.J., foundry owner, was sent to prison for four years when he pleaded guilty before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert yesterday to a four-count indictment charging draft evasion and attempted bribery of a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The stock market here was rather subdued today by international news, while the last week of the long account kept speculative business down to a minimum.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The United Nations Security Council was summoned to meet in an emergency session tomorrow morning to consider Egyptian charges that "Zionist forces in Palestine are constantly and increasingly violating the truce and defying the ceasefire orders given by the Security Council."
Tangible signs of the Metropolitan Opera Company's forthcoming season appeared yesterday at noon, when the chorus convened for the first time.
The cotton futures market turned easier on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed 14 to 19 points net lower.

Sir Osbert Sitwell, fifth Baronet of Renishaw, novelist, essayist and biographer, and his sister, Dr. Edith Sitwell, considered one of the world's greatest living poets, met the New York press yesterday for an hour of talk that raced from foreign policy to fountain pens, by way of literature, philosophy and the economic difficulties of artists in Britain today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- Except for the problem of high prices, there is "very little evidence of weakness in the economic structure of the nation," Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said today.
A "decentralization" program to move idle dentists from this city into upstate towns where their talents could be used more fully was recommended yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25 (AP) -- With more than two weeks to think it over, Bill Stewart, national league umpire, mused tonight that it would have been a "dull world series if I didn't catch a little hell."

"IT gets a bit discouraging some times," remarked Red Strader of the Yankees. "I don't think we ever did a better job of covering the Cleveland ends than we did yesterday. Yet Lavelli and Speedie still caught those passes."

J.R. Mandelbaum, assistant regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, intervened yesterday to avert the threatened strike of the Radio Writers Guild. At his request, the Guild agreed to suspend plans for picketing of programs, thus in effect putting off an immediate strike.

From Boston yesterday, where his production of "Bravo!" will be testing its wings for at least a fortnight, Max Gordon confirmed a report that the George S. Kaufman-Edna Ferber play will arrive here at the Lyceum Theatre on Monday evening, Nov. 15.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 18 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 7 per cent.

The hunting season, for certain divisions of small game, opened a few days ago. To say that the opening came as an anti-climax is to understate everything about it. To begin with, the current holder of the license -- and it is on remarkably cheap pink paper -- never had desired to be a hunter, but was pressured into it by another male in the house.
It was during a tense moment in the Columbia-Princeton game, The United Press reports.
Carl Liscombe, high-scoring left wing of the Providence Reds, continues to set the pace in the American Hockey League's individual scoring race, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP) -Beau Jack quit the lightweight ranks for good today and signed for a match he hopes to use as a springboard toward the welter- weight championship.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- In a ruling handed down today the Tribunal of the Seine declared admissible the libel suit filed against the Communist-connected newspaper les Lettres Francaises by Victor Kravchenko, author of "I Chose Freedom," who is now in New York.

The closing services of the Succoth Festival season were held yesterday in temples and synagogues by Jews throughout the city. Pleas were made in sermons for the world to conserve its good things, whether they be men and women or the fruits of the earth.
In the News of the Week in Review section of the June 13 NEW YORK TIMES there appeared this paragraph:
TORONTO, Oct. 25 -- Canada's defenses are being coordinated with those of the other Western powers so they will fit into a North Atlantic security pact, Defense Minister Brooke Claxton said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UP) -The Displaced Persons Commission tonight published the names of the first group of the 205,000 homeless Europeans who will enter the United States under a two-year resettlement program.

EN ROUTE WITH GOVERNOR WARREN, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Gov. Earl Warren pledged the Republican party today to development of the Western region and struck back at Democratic campaigners for calling his party "saboteurs of the West."

ST.-ETIENNE, France, Oct. 25 -- Tense calm prevailed in strike-bound St.-Etienne today as the General Confederation of Labor's twenty-four-hour general strike halted all but essential utilities. While there was no violence, the confederation made an impressive show of strength as some 30,000 persons turned out to mourn Antonin Barbier, the striking miner who was fatally shot during Friday's clash with Government forces.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Eighteen leading stainless steel companies, involved in a civil anti-trust suit, have reached an agreement with the Government under which the producers are enjoined from price-fixing and employing other restraints of trade.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Consideration is being given to a proposal to send substantial numbers of British, workingmen and production managers to the United States for training in American production methods, Philip Reed, chairman of the United States delegation to the Anglo-American Productivity Council, said today.

The high cost of living should no longer present a problem to Gustina E. Scaglia of Glastonbury, Conn. She returned to the United States this month after spending fourteen months in Europe on a total outlay of $550.
BOSTON, Oct. 25 -- Strong confidence in future business prospects marked the opening here today of the twentieth annual Boston Conference on Distribution at the Statler Hotel.

Brooklyn may be a state of mind but it seems to know its own mind politically. Bounded on one side by the Atlantic Ocean and on the others by Manhattan, Queens and Staten Island, it has its blind spots that vote Republican and even Communist on occasion.

The Florida Improvement Commission will offer on Nov. 10, $3,600,000 of Palm Beach City road and bridge revenue improvement bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1948, and due Oct. 1, 1949 to 1968, with bidders to name the rate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Army today requested the Selective Service System to induct 20,000 men in January. This monthly allotment compared with 10,000 men requested in November, and 15,000 in December.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 25 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, has halted the execution of forty-five persons now in Landsberg prison, all of whom were Hitler bodyguards. The order apparent came in response to a barrage of messages from German prelates, both Catholic and Protestants.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Dan Galgano, Woodway Country Club professional, and George Brundage, his amateur partner from Westchester Hills, topped a field of twenty-two teams with a best ball of 36, 33 -- 69 in the final Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur tournament today at Whippoorwill.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 25 -Benjamin Brown of New Orleans, president of the International Association of Ice Cream Manufacturers, called today on the nation's ice-cream business not to put its efforts in a competitive struggle within the industry but to compete with other products that seek the same share of the American food dollar.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 25 -- The commander of the Syrian forces on the northern Palestine front accepted today a United Nations order to cease fire, and for the first time in weeks there was something resembling peace in Palestine.

Mayor O'Dwyer endorsed yesterday Proposition No. 1, which calls for a decision by the voters as to whether the present system of working hours in the Fire Department shall be made permanent. The proposition will appear on the voting machines in the general election.
Record activity by both sellers and buyers marked the opening session of the fortieth National Business Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday. An estimated 8,000 visitors attended.

Fog, wind and rain harassed the field in the Long Island P.G.A. championship tournament at the Pomonok Country Club yesterday, and after thirty-six holes Jack Mallon of Cold Spring Harbor with 75, 74 -- 149, and Pat Cici of Nassau County, who reversed the procedure with 74, 75, were tied for the honors.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., operator of a chain of retail food stores extending from New York to Florida, attained a new high sales record of $105,814,563 in the forty weeks ended on Oct. 2, its report, to be issued today, says. This represents an increase of 14.08 per cent over the $92,751,034 volume shown for the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- School children should be made familiar with the basic facts of atomic energy so that they will know that it has hazards but can be handled safely, Dr. Paul Aebersold, Oak Ridge, Tenn., isotope expert, told an Office of Education conference today.
Satisfied that Fordham, in losing to Georgetown Friday night, had turned in its best performance of the season, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday canceled practice for the Ram eleven.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- In Western European military circles the belief was expressed today that Norway was planning to join the United States, Canada and the Brussels Treaty powers in an Atlantic defense pact next spring, thus withdrawing from a Scandinavian "neutrality bloc."

The relationship between Governor Dewey and Senator Chapman Revercomb of West Virginia, a Republican candidate for re-election, was made a campaign issue here yesterday by the Democratic high command.

Strong north winds that lashed the city and metropolitan area late Sunday night and yesterday, causing extensive power failures in outlying sections, were abating last night and expected to diminish markedly today.

Notre Dame heads East this week for its only appearance on the Atlantic seaboard, and even though Navy does not appear to be a match for the Fighting Irish, the game in Baltimore Saturday takes precedence over all others in this section.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Corn was weak and other grains were firm on the Board of Trade today, wheat closing 7/8 to 1 1/4 cents higher with December at a new high since late last July. Corn was under pressure early, with December off 1 1/2 cents at one time and only 1 cent above the seasonal low, but the market rallied later with other grains and closed 1/4 cent lower to 3/8 cent higher.

Rejecting all efforts to compromise the Berlin crisis, Russia has again misused its veto power to block the legal adoption of a conciliatory resolution in the Security Council which would have enabled it to end the illegal blockade of the German capital in return for Western concessions without receiving outright condemnation for violating the Charter by using force to attain its ends.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -Election experts in the forty-eight states predict that 51,035,256 persons will vote for President on Nov. 2.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Today's veto of the joint resolution on the Berlin crisis, the twenty-eighth in United Nations Security Council history, was the twenty-seventh exercised by the Soviet Union. France used the veto once in connection with the Indonesian problem and in addition joined with Russia in voting no on a procedural point in connection with the Spanish case in 1946.

One man's forgetfulness can become another man's business. That would seem the explanation for the existence of the Ajax Business and Collection Bureau, which has been feeding on absent-mindedness for seven years.

A "one-year moratorium" on minor controversies between clergymen of different faiths was proposed yesterday by the Rev. Joseph Cantillon, chairman of the Department of Religion at St. Peter's College, Jersey City, N.J.
