The Jesuit priest addressed the opening session of the two-day annual meeting of the board of directors of the National Conference of Christians and Jews at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 15 carried a box headlined "Council resolution asks 9 P.M. curfew for youths" that discussed a resolution introduced in the City Council to keep persons under 18 years of age "off the streets, places of amusement, and other places of assembly between 9 P.M. and 8 A.M."

Hide futures prices continued to advance yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. However, pressure on the near-by December delivery was relieved by large offerings. At the close of the day's trading distant deliveries were 55 to 80 points higher while December advanced only 10 points.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that 8,149,278 running bales of cotton from this year's crop were ginned prior to Oct. 18.

The Association of National Advertisers yesterday took a collective look at next year and found prospects generally bright for higher advertising budgets. Optimism on sales and profits was tempered by a feeling that the uptrend is likely to taper off from the pace of the past year or two.

Theodore Lettvin, pianist and Naumburg Foundation prize winner, gave the debut which that Foundation bestows as a prize upon young artists of exceptional talent, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Mr. Lettvin has come fast as a performer, having played as soloist with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra at the age of 12.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Democratic National Committee filed a report with Congress today showing that it had gone $10,755 in the red while spending $1,503,709 in the drive to elect President Truman.

HOULTON, Me., Oct. 25 -- The deer season seems to be in full swing in northern Maine and if the number of deer you see lashed to it he mudguards and tops of passing cars is any indication, the increase in the herds must be as great as reported.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 25 (AP) -Continuing on gamely after relinquishing the lead in midstretch, Edward B. Townsend's Harold Harter was returned a neck victor in the Smithsonian Handicap, a $10,000 claiming affair which topped today's program at Laurel Park.

Two stowaways, one of whom attempted to steal ashore in a white steward's coat, were caught yesterday aboard the American Export passenger ship Marine Perch, which docked at Pier 84, North River. The incident led to a ruling by the ship's master, Capt. John V. Redmond, forbidding stewards to wear their uniform coats ashore in the future.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- South Africa was forced today to withdraw a proposed amendment to Article 6 of the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights that in the opinion of many delegates would have prevented the organization from opposing all forms of discrimination.

Forty-four names were stricken from the voting lists yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan after Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein had challenged them for violation of the Election Law. Two others who had been challenged submitted proof and the motions to strike their names from the polling lists were withdrawn.

Dr. George W. Taylor, former chairman of the National War Labor Board, declared last night that the Taft-Hartley Act was forcing government, rather than management or labor, to fix terms and conditions of employment.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- A Russian plan for the withdrawal of the Soviet occupation forces from Germany, except for the Berlin garrison, and for the establishment of a Communist-controlled government in the Eastern zone of occupation was discussed at last week's meeting of the Executive Committee of the Socialist Unity [Communist] party in Berlin.

BORDEAUX, France, Oct. 25 -- Once again the life of the Fourth French Republic, governed by a coalition of political parties of the center, is being tested by left and right millstones that are grinding the middle between them. The Upper Loire Valley is verging on chaos as Communist-led strikers exploit economic woes.

By working hard as a porter and bootblack while he lived frugally on the lower East Side, David Feldman has managed to save $6,410 in the last seven years. Of course it has helped a little also to have been on home relief all that time as he admitted to Magistrate Hyman Bushel yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 25 -- The Korean Government announced today that the Communist-led rebellion in Cholla Namdo Province on the south coast of the peninsula had been put down. Operations are now in the "stage of mopping up separated bands of insurgents in the affected area."

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- G.W. McLaurin, the first Negro to enroll at the University of Oklahoma, said today he was under "strain and humiliating conditions" in his segregated classwork. He is seeking a Federal Court order to end his status.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 -- Senator Robert A. Taft predicted today that the Republicans would win a majority in the Senate Nov. 2 and might "even gain a seat or two."

Emphasizing diversity of ownership in the billion-dollar General Electric Company, more than 25 per cent of the 248,850 stockholders are "small" holders, owning one to ten shares each. Brokers and bankers represent less than 2 per cent of the owners, while trustees and other fiduciaries number about 10 per cent and institutional holders -- colleges, hospitals, etc. -- comprise about one-half of 1 per cent, according to a G-E survey released yesterday.

American-flag steamship companies, unhampered by "Government interference," could transport at least 50 per cent of the foreign trade of this country, it was contended yesterday by Commodore Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of Moore-McCormack Lines.

Universal-International has acquired "Sing Your Way Out," an original musical comedy by Maxwell Shane. The yarn, described as being set "within the walls of a penitentiary," deals humorously with "prison pictures and the radio.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Mrs. Ann Powers, 39-year-old redheaded waitress, who a week ago today went on trial here charged with the second-degree murder of Police Capt. Thomas J. Rowe in his precinct station office May 21, today changed her plea from not guilty to guilty of manslaughter.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee predicted here tonight that the Democratic party would win the election and gain control of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

FRANKFORT ON TI4E MAIN, Germany, Oct. 25 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Marshall Plan Administrator, indicated this afternoon that German hopes for extensive revision of the dismantling program would be dashed in an announcement on the matter, scheduled for tomorrow in London.

Consumers often complain that they are overcharged for fresh fruits and vegetables in small grocery stores. Question the retailer and he quickly replies that he must sell at a high price if he is to survive. Much of the produce he has on hand spoils before he can dispose of it.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 25 -- Arizona, the country's baby state, is headed for a break with one of its newer political traditions if Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is elected President. It has never failed to give a margin to the winner of the nine Presidential campaigns during its thirty-six years of statehood.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25 -Princeton's varsity eleven was confined to a short signal drill on rain-soaked University Field today in preparation for the Virginia game Saturday. Coach Charlie Caldwell eliminated contact work and scrimmage for his squad in the wake of the upset victory over Columbia.

The Bon Ami Company announced yesterday addition to its line of "Glass Gloss," a new wax-like cleaner, which it will introduce this fall on the Pacific Coast and in Texas with strong newspaper and radio advertising. Opening of other markets is scheduled to follow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Navy showed today its "new look" for women officers and enlisted personnel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A closer integration of immigrants with their adopted countries was advocated here today by the Rev. Dr. J.J. Stam of the Netherlands Reformed Church, who has just completed a six months' church-merger mission to Dutch immigrants in Canada.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Gen. Markos Vafiades, leader of the Greek guerrilla army, was denounced by the West as a brigand and defended by the East as a champion of democracy as the United Nations debate on the Balkan fighting began here today.

TOKYO, Oct. 25 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters today for the second time challenged the Soviet Union to make good on its promise under the Potsdam Declaration to provide for a continuous return of Japanese war prisoners to their homes.

Profit-taking was encountered yesterday by the stock market in the wake of the sharp rally of last week. The steels were the target of the realizing and widest inroads appeared in this division, with losses of approximately 2 points. Comparable declines were sustained by some individual units in other sections, but the composite rate decreased by only 0.49 point on the day.

Just before Indian Summer sets in, Maurice Schwartz invariably blows the dust out of the Yiddish Art Theatre in Second Avenue and opens for business. Usually he begins with a literary play with beards and costumes, many romantic scenes and some vocal music.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- James M. McNabb, 40 years old, a yachtsman and an insurance executive, was killed today when his automobile left the boulevard, crashed through a guard rail, sheared off a power pole and overturned in a ditch. His body was pinned in the wreckage.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 25 -Mrs. Fannie Rockwell, Danbury's oldest resident, observed today her 104th birthday with an announcement that her vote in the Nov. 2 election would be cast for Governor Dewey for President.

A gain of 20 per cent in investment commitments for building and engineering projects in metropolitan New York and northern New Jersey during the first nine months of this year as compared with a similar period last year is reported by the F.W. Dodge Corporation.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Reorganization of the New Jersey Governmental administration was "98 per cent" complete today when Governor Alfred E. Driscoll signed two departmental bills.
Following is the text of President Truman's campaign speech in Chicago last night, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- The anti-Communist parties of the City Assembly refused today to take any action against six of their leaders whom Soviet authorities had described as fascist war-mongers.
Pete Anderson, the swashbuckling caballero from the pampas of Yorkville, really showed 'em how to ride in the Empire-at-Jamaica program yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 25 (UP) -Whittaker Chambers told the Federal District Court here today that when he called Alger Hiss "a Communist and a member of the Communist party" he meant it. Chambers, a former Communist and now senior editor of Time magazine, replied to Hiss' $50,000 damage suit against him.

"The Liberal Presidents," by J. C. Long, to be issued on Thursday by Crowell, is an account of how Jefferson, Monroe, Jackson, Lincoln, Cleveland, Theodore Roosevelt, Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt were sources of change reform and new power.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review the trial of thirty-five pickets who were arrested during a strike at the Columbia studios in Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Supreme Court in a 4-4 split upheld today the New York obscenity ban of Edmund Wilson's novel, "Memoirs of Hecate County."

Danny Ahearn, 45-year-old ex-convict and author of "How to Commit Murder and Get Away With It," "took his life in his hands" yesterday in General Sessions Court. Facing life imprisonment as a fourth offender if convicted, Ahearn informed the court he would act as his own lawyer.

The Union News Company announced yesterday that a twenty-three-day strike by its newsstand agents and soft-drink bar clerks had ended and that 750 employes were back at work. Local 906 of the News Distribution Employes Union, CIO, declared in rebuttal that "the strike is not over regardless of how many returned to work; the strike will continue."

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- When parliament was prorogued today, it took only eleven sentences to summarize the accomplishments of the recent special session, which was one of the shortest in all British history. The summary was given in the traditional King's speech prepared by the Cabinet and read by the Lord Chancellor.

Montefiore Hospital became the first voluntary institution in this city yesterday to provide for doctors in a group practice plan a special center for diagnosing and treating the ills of health insurance holders.

Harry Greenburg, president of the Diana Stores Corporation, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday that sales for the two months ended on Sept. 30, last, reached a new high of $2,853,658, increasing 26 per cent over the $2,625,042 shown in the corresponding period a year ago.

NAZARETH, Israel, Oct. 25 -About 50,000 Arabs are living peacefully in Israel, about half of them in this Biblical town and in the villages surrounding it. Their spokesmen say that they are satisfied to be part of the new state.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 25 -- The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund has appointed a United States Army medical officer temporarily to head its new relief program for young victims of the fighting in Indonesia between the forces of the Netherlands Government and the Indonesian Republic.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Export-Import Bank said today it was without sufficiently detailed information on which to base a decision on the proposed $100,000,000 loan to the Israeli Government.
VIENNA, Oct. 25 -- The Austrian Government confiscated today Vienna's Communist afternoon newspaper, the Abend.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A German trade union delegation today volunteered to supply former German war pilots to fly the airlift into Berlin in grateful appreciation of the succor afforded the population of the city's western Allied sector by air since the Soviet blockade.
An increase in the number of young riders has made it necessary for two matinees to be devoted to their competition at the National Horse Show, which begins in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday.

A victim of the city's plans to build an underpass connecting the East and West Side drives at the Battery, the old Barge Office at South Ferry, through which thousands of immigrants have entered the country, is soon to feel the impact of the wrecker's sledge.

Willie Pep, world featherweight champion, and challenger Sandy Saddler of Harlem went through preliminary physical examinations yesterday for their fifteen-round title bout at Madison Square Garden Friday night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- R.L. Williams, president of the Chicago North Western Railroad, predicted today that atomic energy would be "playing a vital role" in transportation 100 years from now and that trains would someday shoot along at 800 miles or more an hour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UP) -- The State Department disclosed today that Mexico had accepted as "satisfactory" the United States Government's apology for allowing several thousand Mexican farm laborers to stream across the Texas border recently in violation of an agreement between the two countries.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The Executive of the Scottish area of the National Union of Mine Workers decided in Edinburgh today to send 1,000 ($4,000) to French coal miners now on strike.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The story behind President Truman's extraordinary speech here tonight illustrates what the electorate may expect from the President's board of strategy during the last week of the campaign.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Governor Alfred E. Driscoll today studied ways to set aside Burlington County's purchase of two privately owned Delaware River bridges for $12,000,000. He was advised that the bridges were worth not more than $4,900,000.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 25 -- The Dartmouth Indians will go to the Yale Bowl on Saturday in search of their first victory in five years over the Bulldog.
The Citizens Union made public yesterday its endorsements of eight Assembly contestants in Manhattan and twelve in Brooklyn.

A back-to-work movement sponsored by the Brewers Board of Trade and the United Brewery Workers, CIO, failed yesterday as 3,000 striking beer drivers continued to tie up all truck deliveries from twelve major New York breweries.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The Cook County (Chicago) Democratic organization, of which Jacob Arvey is chairman, gave president Harry Truman and his family a party tonight that they should long remember.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky tonight vetoed a compromise resolution on Berlin presented to the Security Council last Friday by six representatives of countries not directly concerned in the question.

Lou Kusserow, Columbia University fullback, scored a touchdown against Princeton Saturday to gain on Washington and Jefferson's Dan Towler as the nation's leading college point-maker, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- In a sudden reversal of an earlier decision made by the special committee on genocide, the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted today by 25 to 16 to exclude cultural genocide fro the proposed convention to outlaw mass extermination of populations.

Franz Lehar's "Merry Widow" came out of a city, a Europe, indeed a civilization, now forever changed. Perhaps there was no Paris, no Vienna, such as Lehar's music suggests. The old Austrian Empire, of which Vienna was the capital, was corrupt, incompetent, frequently unjust.

Pete Mead of Grand Rapids, Mich., stopped Sal Richie of the East Side in 2:06 of the fifth of the main event listed for ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, Mead weighed 160 1/2, Richie 151.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Staff employes of the United Nations got the good news today that their expatriation allowances, originally scheduled for discontinuance after two years, would be maintained for at least another year.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct 25 -A wall of fear and secrecy has been built around atomic energy in this country, Henry A. Wallace charged tonight, to "protect oil, gas, coal and electric power investments against the competition of this cheap universal atomic power."

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The possibility of linking the existing Western European Union defensive alliance with a pact or understanding with the United States and Canada was discussed at today's meeting here of the Foreign Ministers of the five Brussels pact nations, Britain, France, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 25 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said here today that the AFL "definitely will do something about starting a third major United States political party in its national convention here Nov. 15."

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 25 -Appropriations totaling $5,083,515 are included in the Suffolk County budget for the fiscal year begining Nov. 1. This is an increase of $402,562 over the total in the budget adopted in 1947.

In a spirited debate last night that brought shouts from some of the 400 persons in the audience, Representative Jacob K. Javits and Paul O'Dwyer replied to charges that each has made against the other in the course of the campaign for Congress in the Twenty-third District.
Last-minute touches were given yesterday to the seventh edition of "Fashions of the Times," the fashion production presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES that will open this afternoon for a four-day run.

X-ray, the short-wave light radiation that permits doctors to penetrate the mysteries of the human body and learn the source of pain, is an essential service offered by the eighty-six voluntary hospitals in New York. X-ray therapy, treatment by controlled application of X-rays for diseases such as cancer, is given at nine of the non-profit institutions in the metropolitan area.

GENEVA, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Forty cowboys and cowgirls of a American rodeo company were ordered expelled from Switzerland today after a free-for-all fight last night at the Palais des Expositions that was somewhat in the tradition of the old Wild West.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 25 -- Duncan Sandys, son-in-law of Winston Churchill and honorary secretary of the Movement for United Europe, announced here today that various federalist organizations had decided to set up a new movement to lead the publicity campaign for European unity.

The use of the room to be decorated, its architecture and traffic lanes, are fundamental considerations in planning a room. William Pahlmann, interior decorator, advised last night. Only after these are analyzed can color, texture and all the rest of the decorating aspects be considered, he told members of the Home Fashions League training course held at Town Hall.

A program to improve the quality and quantity of medical care in the United States was presented last night by Dr. William B. Rawls in his inaugural address as president of the Medical Society of the County of New York. He spoke at a stated meeting of the society at the New York Academy of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Arthur J. Goldberg, general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared today that he would promptly appeal the National Labor Relations Board's decision outlawing mass picketing and broadening union responsibility.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 25 -Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya, prominent crusader for the democratization of the Indian Princely States, will be the next president of the Congress party, the dominant body in the Dominion Government, latest returns from the Congress party election indicated tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the question of what price should be paid for preferred stock in the liquidation of the Engineers Public Service Company, a New York holding company.

Opening day retail attendance and order volume at the first separate summer and casual furniture market was described as "disappointing" yesterday by leading manufacturers. The market, sponsored by the newly organized National Association of Summer Furniture Manufacturers, will run through Friday in widely scattered producers' showrooms in New York, Philadelphia and Chicago.
Room settings indicating how furniture often associated with terraces and lawns may be used effectively indoors all year 'round were displayed yesterday by two companies.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Russia's omnibus resolution for the prohibition of the atomic bomb and a one-third reduction of armed forces of the Big Five was rejected today by a special subcommittee of the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The National Paper Trade Association, Inc., 220 East Forty-second Street, New York, twenty-three regional paper trade associations and approximately 100 paper distributors were charged today in a Federal Trade Commission complaint with engaging in an unlawful combination to fix prices and otherwise eliminate competition in the sale of fine and wrapping paper.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Citation probably will never race at his peak as a 3-year-old.

TOKYO, Oct. 25 -- Forty Japanese publishers, whose competitive bids on royalties ranged from 5 to 35.5 per cent and averaged 13.9 per cent, today obtained from occupation headquarters permission to publish fifty-eight foreign books. American, British, French and Soviet authors are represented.
ATLANTA, Oct. 25 -- Georgia's refusal to put the Progressive party candidates on the Nov. 2 ballot for state offices was upheld here today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Two hundred and four eye doctors were dismissed today as defendants in the Federal Government's anti-trust suit against six large spectacle manufacturers and 3,324 oculists.

The Navy speeded preparations yesterday for its big Navy Day celebration tomorrow. In berths throughout the area ships were being prepared for boarding parties of civilians. And up from Norfolk, Va., the battleship Misrouri, last of the class to remain commissioned, was steaming for Pier 90, Fiftieth Street, North River, to join the fleet that will be inspected by these civilians.

Despite the stimulating effect of the Marshall Plan on food production, the world still is facing a difficult supply problem because of increased population, Viscount Bruce, chairman of the World Food Council, a branch of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization, declared yesterday.

ON THE DEWEY TRAIN, Tuesday, Oct. 26 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey left Albany at midnight on his final vote roundup of 1948, as well-informed quarters suggested that the program proposed for his Administration was to be found as much in his campaign speeches of 1944 as in what he has said this year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- A Republican victory on election day will bring a Fascistic threat to American freedom that is even more dangerous than the perils from communism and extreme right "crackpots," President Truman asserted here tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -- Henry and Phoebe Ephron, Warner Brothers scenarists, will go to New York this week to begin work on "Broadway Revisited," a musical photoplay which they had been assigned to write for production by Jerry Wald.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Blood and fire stained the portals of the Stoke Newington Town Hall in London tonight when sixty to seventy persons, said to be followers of Sir Oswald Mosley, chief of Britain's one-time Fascists, stormed a peace meeting organized by trade unionists.
PARIS, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the official texts of speeches in the Security Council today by representatives of the Big Four Powers:

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The police, security guards and troops, reported to number 30,000, opened today a large-scale military operation for occupation of the strikebound coal mines in the north of France. The first day's movements were successful and met virtually no resistance, Jules Moch, Minister of the Interior, reported to the Cabinet tonight.

BILLINGS, Mont., Oct. 25 -- The battle of public power versus private power in connection with the $25,000,000 Canyon Ferry dam on the Missouri River, east of Helena, has been postponed for at least a year, but it is a political campaign subject of considerable interest in western states.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 (UP) -Victory-starved Carnegie Tech students staged their second "We-want-better-football" demonstration of the week today, and this time they were joined by 3,000 University of Pittsburgh students who didn't have anything at home to cry over.

With coaches crowded and trait service curtailed 50 per cent, railway transportation on Staten Island today is inferior to what it was forty years ago, Cornelius A. Hall, Borough President of Richmond, declared yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 25 -- Wisconsin, which appears to be in the midst of a political change from the Progressive era of the LaFollettes to an era of actual two-party politics, is expected on Nov. 2 to give the Dewey-Warren ticket a majority substantially exceeding the slim 24,119 votes by which Mr. Dewey won the state's twelve electoral votes in 1944.

The recitals of Bernardo Segall, Brazilian pianist, have received mixed welcomes over the last few years. Last night, when he played in Carnegie Hall, was one of his off-nights. His playing was monochromatic and mostly objective, the more noticeably because his program included such introspective works as Beethoven's Sonata. Op. 109, and Brahms' rarely-heard Variations on a Theme of Schumann.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Representative Hugh Scott, chairman of the Republican National Committee, contended today that he had "chapter-and-verse evidence" of illegal political activity by employes of three Federal departments in the New Mexico election.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond charged tonight that an FEPC law "would be carried out by a national police force, already being trained" by President Truman.

PANAMA, Oct. 25 -- An abortive attempt to overthrow the Government of President Domingo Diaz Arosemena failed last night. The coup led to the arrest of former President Harmodio Arias and the Liberal Reform party's Presidential candidate, Dr. Jose Joaquin Vallarino, former Ambassador to Washington, together with twentyfive others charged with participation in the plot.

Net income of the Shell Union Oil Corporation in the first nine months of 1948 rose to $82,333,090, or $6.11 a share, from $38,676,876, or $2.87 a share, earned in the corresponding period a year before, according to the report to stockholders for issuance today.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 25 -- Pro-French candidates appeared tonight to have won majorities in the municipal elections in the three small French colonies of Pondicherry, Karikal and Yanaon. Municipal authorities elected in yesterday's voting will determine the time and conditions of a referendum on whether these tiny French territories on India's coasts shall join the Dominion or remain in the French Union.

Persons who sell pinball machines on credit cannot expect the New York courts to help collect for them, according to a ruling of City Court Justice Frank A. Carlin, which came to light yesterday. Pinball machines, the court pointed out, are outlawed as gambling devices under Section 982 of the Penal Law, according to a decision by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 -Fighting was going on in Paraguay tonight after a limited Army uprising that the Government radio said was centered in the military academy. Police in Asuncion, the capital, sought to put down the rebels, who apparently had been joined by other but unspecified, military elements.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, completed plans last night to stop work at 9 A.M. today on the buses and trolley cars that carry 3,500,000 riders a day in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and lower Westchester County.

Nine shipping clerks and truck-men of Michaels Brothers, Inc., 10 Congress Street, Brooklyn, ware arrested last night after questioning yesterday afternoon in the offices of the Kings County District Attorney in connection with the theft of merchandise valued at $95,000. The company operates furniture and home appliance stores in the metropolitan area.

"Diary of Independence Hall," a history of the major events that took place there from 1733 to 1824, will be brought out by Lippincott on Nov. 15. The authors, Harold Donaldson Eberlein and Cortlandt Van Dyke Hubbard, have drawn their material from contemporary newspapers, letters, documents and official records and have written the story in the present tense.

Nothing has seemed quite as naive during the many years I've been reading THE TIMES as that suggestion of a gentleman writing from a college town, Bryn Mawr, that the "formula" for making the atomic bomb should be "permanently and utterly destroyed."

Autumn harvests from gardens and orchards are now supplying the markets with an abundance of vegetables and fruit. Apples from up-state, New England and the Pacific Northwest and sweet potatoes from New Jersey and the South are just two of the foods in excellent supply.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Official dispatches to the State Department described the Communist-led uprising in southern Korea as "unbelievably barbaric," with the rebels murdering 500 in cold blood in the city of Sunchon alone.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26 -- United States Ambassador James Bruce returned to his post here this morning aboard the steamship Brazil. While still on shipboard, he had received a radiogram from President Juan Peron welcoming him back with "a warm embrace."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Gov. James E. Folsom of Alabama, reaffirming his intention of forcing Alabama's Democratic electors to vote for the Truman-Barkley ticket, said today he would return to his home state tomorrow to institute court proceedings.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- John Foster Dulles, closely watched here as possibly the next United States Secretary of State, accused the Soviet Union today of deliberately inciting trouble in Europe, Africa, Asia and the Americas in a campaign to spread communism throughout the world.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- A new university to be known as Freie Universitaet [Free University] will begin its first semester with 2,000 students on Nov. 8, Prof. Edwin Redslob announced today. The school will open its doors to students not only from the Western sectors but also from the surrounding Soviet zone.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Israel refuses to give up positions taken in recent Negeb fighting, as "requested" by the United Nations truce staff, Aubrey S. Eban, representing Israel, told the Security Council today.

The meeting of the Transport Workers Union membership, scheduled originally for Manhattan Center but held finally at Transport Hall, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street, resembled a comedy of errors de spite its turbulence before it was ultimately over last night.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 26 -- On grounds that there is nothing in the New Jersey Civil Rights Statutes that refers expressly to "swimming pools," Judge John Lynn in First District Civil Court here dismissed today a suit against the owners of the Palisade Amusement Park Swimming Pool for allegedly refusing Negroes admittance to the pool.

The chaos in surface transportation which developed yesterday with its consequent inconvenience and danger to the public of New York City is the responsibility of one man, Michael J. Quill, City Councilman and international president of the Transport Workers Union.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 26 -- The Israeli Government rejected tonight a request of Dr. Bunche, acting Mediator, to restore the battlelines in the Negeb in the positions held by both sides before the recent Israeli campaign in Palestine's southern desert.

The largest collection of modern furniture ever presented by W.A. Hathaway Company, 51 West Forty-fifth Street, has been arranged in several rooms planned to show how Drexel's Precedent group may be adapted to different settings.

Dr. George D. Thorne of 852 St. Nicholas Avenue, a Negro physician who was admitted this month to the American College of Surgeons at the thirty-fourth clinical conference of the college at Los Angeles, said that the question of the right of the Negro physician to be rated according to his excellence in his field had apparently been settled once and for all.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 26 -- The police rammed two Army tanks through the doors of the old Colonial Building at San Marcos University today and ejected eighty-three students who had barricaded themselves inside the building.

The liner Exochorda, rebuilt by Bethlehem Steel Company's Hoboken yard into a modern passenger vessel, was formally delivered yesterday to her owners, the American Export Lines, which will operate the ship on its Four Aces Mediterranean route.

Events today: New York Youth Concert, Wheeler Beckett, conductor, Ruggiero Ricci, violin, Carnegie Hall, 3 P.M.; Byrd Elliot, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Ana Maria Relano, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Adeline Candido, soprano, James Eliot Ferry, baritone, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 165 West Fifty-seventh Street, 8:30; Andor Foldes, piano, Lexington Avenue Y.M. and Y.W.H.A., 8:40.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Political cross-currents in the labor movement appear to augur well for a closer rapprochement between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations after the national election next week, according to views expressed here today by representatives of both organizations.

Preparations for Saturday's clash with Lehigh continued at Ohio Field yesterday for the New York University football squad. Coach Edward E. (Hook) Mylin sent his team through a long workout with the emphasis on improving the Violet aerial attack and pass defense.

IN many respects "Wilding Graft,"* a first novel by a young English writer, Jack R. Clemo, seems like a survival from an earlier age. In technique, in material and in point of view it resembles the fiction of the Eighteen Seventies and Eighteen Eighties far more than it does that of today. Unfortunately, it does not resemble the great novels of that time but rather the undistinguished ones which have long since been forgotten.
Harry P. Smith, formerly New York district sales manager of Mathieson Chemical Corporation, has been appointed assistant general manager of sales of the company.

Len Younce, captain and veteran guard of the football Giants, has been relased from the hospital, along with Emlen Tunnell, and will be ready to play against the Bears in Chicago next Sunday. Tunnell, Negro back, will not be available then.

The French-made "Cesar," a drama written, produced and directed by Marcel Pagnol, will have its local premiere today at the Elysee. The offering, one of a trilogy including the previously shown "Marius" and "Fanny," stars the late Raimu, Pierre Fresnay, Orane Demazis and Charpin.

Henry A. Wallace will speak on street corners and indoors in thirty-three parts of this city tomorrow, Friday and on Sunday, following his return from New Haven where he makes a campaign address tonight.

SANTIAGO Chile, Oct 26 (UP) -- Representatives of banks and stock exchanges in the United States and five South American countries met today in the second Inter-American Congress of Stock Exchanges. The first was held in New York last year.

Johnny Neun, who was dropped as manager of the Reds before the National League season ended, yesterday returned to the Yankee organization, with which he has been associated during much of his baseball career.

New medical evidence that the amount of meat eaten daily may be a factor of far-reaching importance in determining a child's susceptibility to tooth decay was presented yesterday before the dental health conference in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Norman Thomas, perennial Socialist candidate for president, was the 100th "fall guy" of the Circus Saints and Sinners yesterday, but he gave as much as he received in making "fall guys" of his fellow Presidential candidates and his non-Socialist audience.

Full endorsement of the legislative records of three Democratic Assemblymen in the Bronx was given yesterday by the Citizens Union. The group approved the careers of Julius J. Gans in the Sixth Assembly District; Louis Peck in the Seventh, and Nathan A. Lashin in the Twelfth.

New York's Rangers will show many new faces tonight when they usher in their home National Hockey League season against the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden. The game will start at 8:30 o'clock.

Now entering its tenth year of service, the Institute for Religious and Social Studies is performing a unique function in this city. A scholarly and scientific fellowship of educators and religious leaders, the Institute brings together serious-minded men and women of different faiths and creeds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Two squadrons of Navy transport planes, twenty-four big C-54's, are being assigned to the Berlin airlift to provide added cargo capacity through the crucial winter months ahead, the Air Force announced tonight.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- There is no four-power agreement on air safety rules in the corridors leading to Berlin and the responsibility for any accidents suffered by United States and British planes in airlift operations rests "entirely" with their pilots, Soviet authorities declared tonight.

The Cardinal Hayes' eleven registered its third straight victory yesterday at Triborough Stadium by defeating St. Francis Prep, 16 -- 0. The contest originally was scheduled for last Sunday, but postponed because of inclement weather.

Stung by recent newspaper articles, editorials and photographs picturing the unsanitary conditions prevailing in East Harlem, fifty members of Youthbuilders, a group of 12 to 14-year-old students at James Otis Junior High School, East Harlem, yesterday joined the Sanitation Department in its attempt to clean up the area.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Oct. 26 -- The National Association of Independent Tire Dealers was told at the twenty-eighth annual convention here today that litigation recently brought by the association against the Rubber Manufacturers Association and the so-called "big five" was initiated to restore the "economic freedom" of the independent merchant.

QUANTICO, Va., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The wind took command on the firing ranges today and wrecked riflemen's scores in the National rifle and pistol championships, dropping the top man to 1,556 out of a possible 1,600.

The first member of the Brewers Board of Trade to break the solid ranks of that organization acceded yesterday to demands by striking rank and file beer drivers that a delivery time schedule be scrapped.

Bus strikes, such as the one yesterday, have rapidly replaced subway walkouts as the major threat to the city's transportation lifelines. While the last major strike of subways occurred in 1926, it was in 1941 that an effective walkout by the Transit Workers Union, CIO, tied up the Fifth Avenue Coach Company's 1,305 buses for eleven days.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey charged tonight that his Democratic opponents had reached "a new low in mud-slinging" and, in a desperate effort to win another term in office, were spreading "fantastic fears among our people."

Jacqueline Drucker, young American pianist, who played at Carnegie Hall last night, won the $1,000 North American Prize in a competition held in San Francisco last August. One must assume that there were good reasons for her victory at that time. Not many of them were in evidence at Carnegie Hall last night.
BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 26 (AP) -- A municipal crackdown today struck scalpers who were selling tickets to the Navy-Notre Dame football game Saturday.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- A sharp divergence of opinion exists between United States and British authorities over the extent to which foreign property interests in Germany are to be protected by the military governments.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 26 -- H. R. Leonard of St. Paul, Minn., board chairman of the American Dry Milk Institute, said today that the United States produces three times the volume of dry milk made in the rest of the world combined.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the San Jose Waterworks, San Jose, Calif., had filed a registration statement covering a proposed public offering of 15,913 shares of $25 par value common stock.

WHEN Frank Boucher was approaching the end of his brilliant career as the star center on the New York Rangers he noticed that Phil Watson was always staring enviously at the Boucher jersey every time he doffed his uniform and hung it up in his locker. The big No. 7 held a fascination for M'sieu Philippe. "
Coach Ted Rosequist is a confident football director and the twenty-three men who comprise the Brooklyn College squad also brim with optimism.

Nathan Wilson, operator, yesterday purchased 254-60 Canal Street, southwest corner of Lafayette Street, a five-story manufacturing loft building with nine stores, from a corporation controlled by Moe Levy Son and represented by Max Greenfield.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- "Mr. Baseball" accepted graciously today the plaudits of the nation's forty-eight Governors.
A fist fight in Times Square last night between service men and some of 2,000 young men and women who had marched down Broadway in a demonstration for Henry A. Wallace, was broken up by the police.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, operator of the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines since May 1, 1947, reported yesterday that net income for the third quarter amounted to $1,380,364, equal to 30 cents a share.

Changes in methods of regulating business are the only ones likely to be made by a new Administration in the vast body of law built for that purpose, members of the Association of National Advertisers were told yesterday at their annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,764 compared with 1,769 last week and 1,311 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today ordered four airlines to suspend for ninety days beginning Nov. 1 their practice of giving reduced rates to parties of ten or more persons.
Following is the text of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's address delivered in Chicago last night, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

A campaign to raise $250,000 to cause only the income from the continue and expand the work of fund will be used to make tickets available to students at reduced providing students of the city's public schools and colleges with prices.
A banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., placed on the market yesterday an issue of 350,000 new common shares of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company at $13.50 a share.
AREQUIPA, Peru, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- Oscar Galvez of Argentina today won the fifth lap of the $60,000 Grand Prix automobile race between Buenos Aires, Argentina and Caracas, Venezuela.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26 -- The Paraguayan Government announced in Asuncion today that the revolt centered in the military academy had been completely suppressed after ninteen hours of intense fighting.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 26 -- The congress of the Federation of Coffee Growers of Central America and Mexico, at sessions here yesterday and at a dinner given last night by the National Bank of Nicaragua, stressed the high cost of production and the low price for coffee in the United States.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Oct. 26 -- The late President Roosevelt's "Little White House," where he died April 12, 1945, was dedicated as a national shrine today.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- Royal Little, president of Textron, Inc., defended today the practice of "speculating" with funds set up as charitable trusts by the corporation. This, he told a Senate subcommittee, was a method of obtaining venture capital which in five years had built the corporation's business from $8,000,000 to $125,000,000.
PARIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The text of the five-power Western European Union communique on a North Atlantic pact follows:

BEIT HANUN, Palestine, Oct. 26 -- A 25-year-old Israeli Army brigade commander stood on a hill outside this occupied Arab village today and, looking toward the near-by Egyptian headquarters of Gaza, said simply: "The Egyptian Army in Palestine has been destroyed as an effective fighting force."

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Soviet Russia's veto of the compromise plan in the United Nations for settlement of the difficulties at Berlin and opening of the new Parliamentary session subdued the stock markets here today, and easier trends were seen in several directions.

The inside union strategy that provided for a token bus strike only was disclosed yesterday by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, before he knew that the strategy had missed fire.

The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering issues of common and preferred stock, which, with the concurrent private sale of $193,000,000 of bonds, are proposed to finance, construction of a pipe-line to bring natural gas from Texas to New York City.

Mapping an intensive study of Fordham's pass defenses, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday conducted the inaugural drill for the Rams' contest with Boston University by sending backs and line-backers through a long dummy scrimmage.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 -- A new major expansion program for works here and at Aliquippa, Pa., to cost $70,000,000, was reported today by the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation. Most of this amount is to be spent at Pittsburgh.
City dwellers and commuters left without surface transportation by the bus and trolley strike yesterday reacted with traditional resignation. There were exceptions but these were few and far apart.

Columbia's thrice-beaten Lions buckled down to the task of preparing for the Big Red of Cornell with a long afternoon of offensive and defensive drills at Baker Field yesterday. A full-scale tackling scrimmage in which the first two teams played strictly on the defense highlighted the day's proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The United Kingdom borrowed $310,000,000 today from the Economic Cooperation Administration to buy capital equipment and industrial raw materials needed in its recovery effort. It agreed to repay the amount in thirty-five years unless prevented by adverse economic conditions.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Fortunate to secure racing room on the inside, E.A. Nicodemus' Laran, under a daring ride by Apprentice Willie Gilbert, took the featured Patuxent Purse at Laurel Park today.

Concerned over the inadequacy of legal depreciation reserves in covering replacement costs, the United States Steel Corporation for the third quarter of 1948 increased its special quarterly depreciation reserve to $13,500,000 from the $7,100,000 set aside a year before, Irving S. Olds, chairman, reported yesterday.

Newspaper advertising in fiftytwo cities rose x3.5 per 'cent in September t6' l7,31LS,246 lines from 17~,871,40 in the corresponding month last ydar, Media Reeordd announced yesterday. .All classifications showed' .gains as follows: Automotive. 27.3 per centL retail, 15.1 per cent; total display, 1~.6 per cent; department stores, 12.2 'per cent; general, 10.8 per cent; classified, 10.1 per cent. and financial 2.2 per cent.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation attained a new peacetime high in sales which totaled $711,275,535 for the first nine months of 1948, compared with $583,342,409 for last year's period, Gwilym A. Price, president, reported yesterday.

The 1948 Roosevelt Medals of Honor have been awarded to Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, and Mrs. Millicent Carey McIntosh, dean of Barnard College, Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevelt Memorial Association.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., in the first nine months of this year had consolidated net earnings of $103,000,000 after charges and taxes, equal to $3.30 a share on the capital stock, according to an estimate made yesterday by B. Brewster Jennings, president.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Grain markets were somewhat unsettled in trading featured by operations against the cash article on the Board of Trade today. Wheat closed unchanged to 5/8 cent higher, December selling at a new high since late last July.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Nationalization of the iron and steel industry jumped to the forefront as Britain's greatest internal controversy when Parliament was reopened this morning. King George VI in his speech from the throne referred to the Labor Government's measure, which would "bring under public ownership those companies extensively engaged in the production of iron ore or of pig iron or steel or in the shaping of steel by a rolling process."

The personnel of the Fire Department was augmented "to relieve the arduous working hours of officers" with the swearing in yesterday of 216 lieutenants and probationary firemen by Commissioner Frank J. Quayle at a brief ceremony in the quarters of Engine Company 31, Lafayette and White Streets.

Small and medium-sized businesses should find a place for themselves in the rearmament program to offset possible losses of existing markets, it was pointed out last night by Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War. Small business will find the procuring branches in the Army, Navy and Air Forces interested and cooperative, he said, and advance payments will be available in proper cases and in permissible amounts.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Still holding together after taking a terrific beating in the Atlantic, a Navy amphibious ship sailed through moderating seas tonight toward the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- Walter Schreiber, once a major general in the German Army Medical Corps, and until recently a member of the Soviet-sponsored Free Germany Committee and faithful adherent of Soviet policy in Germany, has escaped from the Russians and at present is a political refugee under the guardianship of the Western powers, authoritative sources said today.

Milk distributors will make consumers dig half a cent deeper into their pockets tomorrow to pay for the wage increase of $4 to $5 a week an arbitrator awarded yesterday to 15,000 drivers and plant employes of metropolitan and suburban milk companies.
Mrs. Margaret Fernandez, 52-year-old breeder of Mexican chihuahua dogs, of 647 Eighth Avenue, believes in sharing her wealth to "spread happiness around the world."
Henry A. Wallace asserted last night that the Progressive party, whose Presidential candidate he is, had "stopped the cold war in its tracks."
ATLANTA, Oct. 26 -- The Atlanta Journal announced today that it would support President Truman as the Democratic party's nominee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- James Mason will make his second Hollywood screen appearance as Gustave Flaubert in "Madame Bovary," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today. Mason will be seen in a prologue and epilogue to the actual story and will serve as narrator throughout the film, the screen adaptation of the novel requiring the actual appearance of the author, although the original work was written in the third person.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 26 -- President Truman should win the fifteen electoral votes of his native Missouri, even though the race is likely to be a rather close one. Casualties, however, in the state's Republican Congressional delegation are so strongly foreshadowed as almost to be certain.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Independent stores must adopt scientific business methods to meet the needs of their markets in order to exist in competition with mail order houses and chain stores, Walter H. Lowy, vice president of the Formfit Company, warned today at the opening session of the company's clinic on new scientific merchandising techniques.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Another shooting encounter between troops and miners today resulted in the killing of one miner and the wounding of eight other persons. The clash stimulated the resistance that had been thought to be waning among the striking coat miners of France.

Public schools in the Harlem area were defended yesterday by Dr. J.J. Osuna, educational consultant of the Employment and Migration Bureau of the Puerto Rican Department of Labor, against charges that they are "breeding places for delinquency."

One hundred American Airlines employes, members of Local 501 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, engaged in a "sit-down" strike yesterday at the airlines' hangars at La Guardia Field and at a warehouse at 43-02 Ditmars Boulevard, Astoria, Queens.

PEIPING, Oct. 26 -- The professorial strike at the National Peiping University spread this morning to the entire campus as assistant instructors, students and even campus policemen struck in sympathy in protest against the disparity between the fixed salaries and unbridled inflation that has defied the theoretically frozen prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Navy reviewed today the last year in naval aviation, found it making "unparalleled progress," and promised a force of 14,500 planes and new jet fighters to support its sea power by July of next year.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 26 -- President Truman is getting the crowds--warm, sympathetic, admiring crowds--but he is leaving them vaguely dissatisfied.

GAGETOWN, N.B., Oct. 26 -- We will not be able to report on the actual shooting situation in this area until tomorrow night at this time, but never have we seen a section where the prospects seemed brighter.

The Appellate Division, by a four-to-one vote, ruled yesterday that the dispute between two union groups as to which should act as bargaining agent for the 7,000 R. H. Macy Co. employes must be determined by trial.
The seventh edition of "Fashions of the Times" came to life yesterday on the stage of Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

The first show of paintings by patients in the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx opened yesterday for a two-week run in Building D of the combination of infirmary and rehabilitation center.
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Oct. 26 (AP) -- States' rights are "the only guarantee we have that a kind of Kremlin will not be established in Washington," Gov. J. Strom Thurmond said tonight.
World War I veterans, with their talk of forty and eight, have nothing on the eighteen soldiers who virtually ran a trans-Atlantic kennel -- with a sulky cat thrown in for good measure.
PARIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The text of the statement by United States Delegate John Foster Dulles today in the United Nations Assembly Political Committee on the Balkan question follows:

The 1949 line of wallpapers introduced yesterday by Wall Trends, Inc., 509 Madison Avenue, includes both modern designs that are fresh looking, but not too extreme, and soft patterns composed of traditional motifs worked out in a fresh manner.

PANAMA CITY, Oct. 26 (UP) -- The twenty-five-day-old government of President Domingo Diaz was in full control of the country today after a terrorist outbreak Sunday night that police described as an abortive revolutionary plot.

ABOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S CAMPAIGN TRAIN, Oct. 26 -- Miles apart on political issues, President Truman and his Republican opponent, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, met at ten paces today but only for a hail-and-farewell salute of their train engineers.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Following is the prepared text of the address here tonight by President Truman:

Coffee futures broke sharply in the early morning trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices dropped 36 to 63 points below the levels of the previous close. Observers attributed the decline to cable information to the Exchange that the Liquidating Committee of the National Coffee Department of Brazil had been authorized to export coffee under conditions assuring price and shipment control.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26 -- Heartened by the return of Vic Frank, regular guard to the line-up, the Yale football squad held a brisk two-and-a-half-hour workout today in preparation for the important game with Dartmouth in Yale Bowl Saturday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Third-round wage and hour demands of the sixteen non-operating railroad unions threaten the solvency of the country's railroad system, Guy W. Knight, counsel for the carriers, said today.

Next Tuesday the voters of New York City will elect twenty-four members of the House of Representatives. In all but one case -- the Sixteenth District (Richmond) -- a present member of the House is a candidate for re-election. The voters, therefore, will have before them in most cases a record of performance to help shape their judgment at the polls.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, heard progress reports today from members of his staff who are following the development of Britain's recovery program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, accused his two Republican fellow-members of the Senate Campaign Investigating subcommittee today of conducting their inquiries for partisan election gains.

GENEVA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A broncho-busting cowgirl, one of a rodeo troupe ordered out of Switzerland by police, identified herself today as Mrs. Katherine Carnegie, estranged wife of socially prominent Thomas M. Carnegie Jr.

A 1949 budget of $3,500,000 was approved yesterday by the board of directors of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, meeting in annual session at the Waldof-Astoria Hotel. The new budget is the largest in the twenty-year history of the interfaith organization.

Trunk line railroads serving the port of New York are reconsidering restrictive measures imposed years ago on rail-ship cargo routed through the Port of New York Authority's Union Inland Terminal in the Chelsea district between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, it was reported here yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- A decision to propose to the United States the opening of negotiations for a North Atlantic security pact embracing North America and parts of Western Europe was taken today by the Foreign Ministers of five Brussels Treaty powers, according to officials of those countries.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Earl Blaik was in the projection room of the football office here today. He was watching moving pictures of a game but, since it would not have been cricket to "sneak a peek" at the feature film of the matinee, it could not be ascertained which team the Army head coach was studying.
In commending your fine editorial entitled "Russia's Slave Labor," published Oct. 18, I should like to draw your attention to another aspect of this same tragic problem.
PARIS, Oct. 26 -- The possibility developed today that several members of the United Nations Security Council might go to Berlin in the next few days to inspect conditions under the Soviet blockade.

An investigation by the Civil Aeronautics Board into price-cutting practices of airlines on the busy New York-Puerto Rico run resulted yesterday in the indictment by a Federal grand jury of the Ultramar Skyway Service, Inc., a travel agency at 53 East 109th Street, and its 24-year-old treasurer, Humerto Tormos.

Dennis James, announcer and specialist in reporting wrestling matches on television, will inaugurate his own show at 8:30 P.M. Sunday over CBS video. It will be a variety turn with a carnival background, the supporting acts including Leonardo and Zola, described as fire dancers; Dagmar, billed as a mystic, and Risko, a juggler.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- In a strongly worded protest sent to the United Nations Security Council today Yugoslavia accused the United States and Britain of "fresh flagrant violations of the provisions of the peace treaty with Italy" regarding Trieste.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 26 -- President Truman asserted tonight that the Republicans, in failing to act on his omnibus program in the extra session of Congress last summer, had confessed to a governmental philosophy that was inimical to the people.

A trust fund of $48,431 has been established from the residue of the estate of the late Clifford B. Harmon, Westchester real estate operator and aviation enthusiast, for continuation of the annual award of the Harmon International Air Trophies, according to an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, chief Philippine delegate to the U.N., praised the United States administration of nonself-supporting territories today. He also deplored what he said was Britain's effort to weaken the authority of the United Nations Trusteeship Council as well as the Soviet efforts to use the United Nations as a springboard for "biased criticism."

With Michigan and Notre Dame running one, two among the nation's college gridiron leaders for the second straight year, other all-victorious outfits probably are wondering what they have to do to convince the experts that their records are just as good.

Beer wholesalers will be forced to operate with shorter mark-ups and will become more and more dependent on brewers if the trend toward monopoly in the industry continues, William H. Jacobus, general sales manager and director of the George F. Stein Brewery, Inc., Buffalo, warned yesterday. He addressed the sixteenth annual convention of the New York State Wholesale Beer Distributors Association, Inc., in the New Yorker Hotel.

As a native of New York City I have followed with interest the question of transportation fares therein. The traditional five-cent fare was maintained throughout the life or era of the privately owned transportation companies, notwithstanding increased operating expenses and taxes in the late Nineteen Twenties.

In reporting a $3,574,781 increase in earnings, Thomas J. Watson, president of International Business Machines, announced yesterday a quarterly cash dividend of $1 a share in addition to a 5 per cent stock dividend.

The Cosmopolitan Line's new cargo-passenger vessel Ronda will leave here tomorrow afternoon on the second leg of her maiden voyage, company officials announced yesterday. Built in Goeteborg, Sweden, by the Lindholmens Varv., the vessel will operate on the line's service between United States Atlantic ports and France, Belgium and the Netherlands.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration can now begin to see the first fruits of its endeavors to rehabilitate Western Europe, Representative Everett M. Dirksen, Illinois, told the concluding session here today of the Boston Conference on distribution at the Statler Hotel.

A new furniture delivery organization, the United Distributors Furniture Service, has been set up by managements of thirteen local home furnishings establishments operating approximately thirty-five stores, it was learned yesterday. A spokesman for the store managements said the new organization will work with regular store delivery facilities to ease current consumer delivery and store receiving jams and will assume part of delivery loads during peak seasons like Christmas.

The share market on the Stock Exchange found the recovery trail highly difficult to negotiate yesterday, although individual issues responded to corporate developments. The composite rate showed a rise of 0.33 point on the day and gains ranged to approximately 2 points in some stocks, but the share list on balance leaned to the lower side.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 -- Overconfidence is causing the greatest worry among Republican leaders of Southern California in the final week of the Presidential campaign.

In another week it will be over, it will have joined the World Series in history. The votes will have been counted, a congratulatory telegram will have been sent and the housing problem of someone will have been settled for the next four years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- The Government sought today to force the International Typographical Union, AFL, to comply immediately with a contempt order issued in Indianapolis twelve days ago.

The Indians and Braves, rivals in the last world series, each gained two berths on The Associated Press' 1948 major league all-star team. The remainder of the dream squad is composed of two players each from the Cardinals and Red Sox and one each from the Yankees and Giants.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- It is by boat, from this suburban Westchester community, that one visits the administrative headquarters of the First Air Force. The headquarters is on eighty-acre Davids Island, known today as Fort Slocum, and lies one half mile off shore in Long Island Sound.

Twenty-seven leading American writers, including a Nobel prize winner and five Pulitzer Prize winners, have endorsed President Truman's candidacy and sent the President a statement of their reasons, the Democratic National Committee announced yesterday.

Under the title of "Alice in Videoland," "Fashions of the Times," Seventh Edition, was presented in Times Hall yesterday. Prophetic fashions, encompassing resort and spring, took their course through a travelogue developed as if in a television studio where a rehearsal is taking place.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 26 -- North Carolina, which has been politically "courted" this year by all major parties on a scale that is without precedent in its history, seems more certain than any other old-line Southern state to remain faithful to its Democratic party suitor.

The Washington Toll Bridge Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids Nov. 4 on $10,500,000 Puget Sound Toll Bridge and Ferry revenue bonds dated Oct. 1, 1948, due Oct. 1, 1968, and callable in 1951.

Directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway will take action on Friday on a proposal to sell $40,000,000 of a new series of refunding and improvement mortgage bonds, Walter J. Tuohy, first vice president, said yesterday at an interim meeting of stockholders in Cleveland.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, brought suit yesterday against the General Electric Company and members of the Atomic Energy Commission, asking $1,000,000 damages and a Federal injunction against the blacklisting of the union in atomic plants.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 26 -- The battle for control of the South Korean port city of Yosu continued through its second day, according to reports reaching headquarters of the Korean Army here today.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 26 -- Appealing for return of a Democratic Administration on the basis of its sixteen-year record of labor and social legislation, Senator Alben W. Barkley, candidate for Vice President, carried his campaign into two of his party's industrial strongholds in this normally Republican state today.

Reflecting a substantial increase in sales of electricity, and a $1,000,000 annual rate increase by the New York Steam Corporation, a subsidiary, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday that net income for the twelve months to Sept. 30 amounted to. $36,893,821.

Players of favorites extracted no enjoyment from the main bout at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday, for Isidor Bieber's Up Beat ran wide on the first turn, ran wider later and finished a pulled-up last.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 1 to 11 points net lower, led by the weakness in the December position.

An analysis of current political campaigns by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith has shown "a marked decrease in the use of anti-Semitism" compared with 1940 and 1944, it was reported in the findings of a nation-wide survey made public yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, national chairman of the league.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Malcolm MacDonald, British Commissioner General for Southeast Asia, declared here today that an overwhelming majority of Malayan trade union officials and members were firmly backing Government measures against Communist-inspired terrorism in Malaya.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- No air conditioning regulates the temperature in the handsome modern theatre of the Palais de Chaillot where the United Nations plenary sessions are held. But a palpable chill cooled the warm air of yesterday's tense and crowded meeting when Vishinsky announced his veto of the resolution so softly worded by six "neutral" members of the Security Council in the hope of compromising the Berlin dispute.
ST. ETIENNE, France, Oct. 26 -- Government troops were expected to attack the Couriot mine here soon and start what may be another bloody clash.

VIENNA, Oct. 26 -- In the first Russian reaction to the flight to freedom by two Soviet airmen on Oct. 9, the official news agency Tass declared today the United States had violated "valid" four-power "regulations" by having failed to return the men.

The ensemble emerged as an important feature of "Fashions of The Times." Spectacular were eight costumes forming the color theme of the scene called "Colorscope." Cooperating with the plan for the general presentation, each of the designers worked out a specific arrangement which, with one exception, resulted in a startlingly beautiful color duo.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 26 -- The Communist challenge to Finland's Social Democratic government appears to have failed for the moment. The strike wave aimed at ousting the Cabinet now is tending to subside but the Communists are preparing for a new attack in the form of a general transport walkout in about two weeks.

Citing three basic reasons for his conclusion, Prof. Joseph L. Snider of the School of Business Administration, Harvard University, declared last night that "inflation is about over." He spoke at a dinner meeting of the ready-to-wear group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The Russian veto of any compromise on the Berlin crisis has again emphasized that the masters of the Kremlin are pursuing a long-range plan in what John Foster Dulles has characterized as a general effort to extend the power of Soviet communism throughout the world.

Reflecting a rise in net sales to $278,098,505 in the first nine months of this year from $186,228,231 for the 1947 period, earnings of the Studebaker Corporation and its subsidiaries were more than double those of a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday.

An improved model of an electronic device that enables the blind to "read" by the invisible light of electrons was demonstrated for the first time last night at a meeting of the New York Electrical Society at the Engineering Auditorium, 229 West Thirty-ninth Street.

The American Red Cross provided the nation's physicians and hospitals in the last year with about $15,000,000 worth of plasma and other derivatives processed from surplus wartime blood donations, Edward J. Quigley, chairman of the Brooklyn chapter, said yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, called today for a "moderate breaking" of the machinery of inflation to prevent an abrupt halt later.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 26 (AP) -- General Manager Lee MacPhail of Kansas City in the American Association announced today that the contract of Dick Bartell, 1948 manager, would not be renewed. The Blues finished sixth last season.

Women from ten clubs affiliated with the Eastern Ski Association met last night at Tramer's Restaurant to discuss the possibility of forming a Women's Ski Association of New York. The group decided to convene again Nov. 16 to draw up a constitution and elect officers.

After a miscarriage in union strategy had turned a planned four-hour work stoppage into the biggest bus strike in the city's history, 1,000 of the 8,500 drivers involved voted overwhelmingly last night to end the wildcat tie-up and restore normal service to 3,500,000 riders this morning.

Sol Bloom, who has been representing the Twentieth Congressional District on Manhattan's West Side for twenty-six years, is now engaged in one of the most intensive campaigns of his long political career. He will not admit that he is in danger -- and impartial political observers agree that he probably will win -- but he is, nevertheless, taking more than a casual interest in the campaign.

The revolt of allegedly Communist-led troops in Cholla-Namdo Province in southwest Korea apparently has been put down by the loyal Constabulary of Syngman Rhee's Government. Eyewitness reports are, however, that it was a bloody business. The revolting troops killed those who opposed them or who they believed might oppose them.

Negotiation attempts by the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service to bring about a settlement of the dispute between the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the New York Shipping Association continued yesterday, but no progress was reported.

With the sun bathing her peacetime coat of light gray, the Missouri glided into the North River yesterday. Soon afterward the only active battleship in the United States Fleet was berthed and most of the 1,500 officers and men were at liberty in the city.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 26 -- The general management of Yugoslav state railroads has announced without explanation an immediate and drastic curtailment of passenger and freight movements. As of today a large number of passenger trains are scheduled to be suspended temporarily.

The Young Composers Group, which was organized in August, 1945, presented its second public concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The program consisted of works by six members, most of them decidedly on the conservative side.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was informed last night in the presence of 200 scientists and industrialists that ignorance of geology had led to many serious mistakes during the last war.

It is pleasant to hear that at long last the city is about to make needed repairs to the Prison Ship Martyrs' Monument in Fort Greene Park, Brooklyn, site of the common grave of hundreds of Revolutionary patriots who died on British prison ships. For the last few years the condition of this tall memorial shaft and the somewhat shabby appearance of Fort Greene Park itself have been of increasing concern to park lovers.
Henry A. Wallace charged at a luncheon yesterday that President Truman "has done more than any man since Hitler to promote dictatorship in this world".

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 -- After Jan. 1, individuals who earn less than $5,000 a year no longer will have the choice between Form 1040 or Form W-2 in making income-tax returns for the Treasury Department, according to an announcement made here today by the Secretary of the Treasury, John W. Snyder.

The controversy over the work of Academician Eugen S. Varga, one of the top economists of the Soviet Union, and his school, stimulated by economic spokesmen for the official viewpoint on Stalinist ideology, is still going on in Russia.

A young veteran who "blew his top" when he found that he could not get into the leather business because he had not been approved by a trade association was credited by the Department of Justice with instigating an investigation that led to the indictment yesterday of the association, twelve corporations and thirty-five individuals.

Wall Street prophets flushed in embarrassment soon after 3 P.M. yesterday when the dividend action of United States Steel was announced. The "extra" dividends that they had been predicting -- and which had imparted great strength to steel stocks last week -- did not materialize.

Annual savings amounting to as much as 200 per cent or more of the amount of the actual cost of new equipment have been obtained by analyzing new methods of office procedure. This was emphasized to more than 800 executives attending the conference on office management problems, of the American Management Association, which opened yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
Leaders of every branch of the fashion industry joined yesterday in a chorus of praise for the seventh edition of "Fashions of the Times."
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The supreme leadership of the British labor movement urged its 8,000,000 followers today "to counteract every manifestation of Communist influences within their unions."

MILAN, Oct. 26 -- An explanation why the business depression prevailing in Italy for several months past has become more noticeable since Sept. 3 when J.D. Zellerbach, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission to Italy, declared that drastic and painful rearrangement of the economy of the country was imperative if the Marshall Plan was to succeed in Italy has been given by D. Robert Ricciardi, director of the ECA's activities in northern Italy.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Secretary of State Marshall, Foreign Secretary Bevin and French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, after an hour's conference this afternoon, decided to leave the Berlin question before the United Nations Security Council for the time being.

GAGETOWN, N.B., Oct. 27 -The man who said duck shooting was good only when the weather was so bad a sensible man stayed at home would have found everything to confirm his opinion had he been with us today.

Reaching the market at a time when tax-exempt obligations showed signs of losing some of their recent buoyancy, the $21,000,000 school borrowing of Denver yesterday turned out to be quite a feat of credit appraisal and pricing.
