MOSCOW, Oct. 27 (UP) -- A stagehand with a high Government decoration raised the curtain tonight on the fiftieth anniversary performance of the world-famed Moscow Art Theatre -- the playhouse that in 23,300 performances has never had an empty seat.

Net income of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company for the nine months to Sept. 30 amounted to $295,045, or 40 cents a share, in contrast to a net deficit of $393,051 reported for the comparable 1947 period, it was announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27 -- Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, said here tonight that the third party would eventually force Government ownership upon the country's banks, railroads, gas and power utilities, and atomic energy.

Due to the drop in retail grocery dollar volume that is expected to accompany the decline in food prices, the New York State Food Merchants Association is researching a number of more profitable non-food items to boost profits, it was learned here yesterday.
Navy Day visitors to the Bayonne, N.J., Naval Base were treated yesterday to the sight of student divers accomplishing, under water, tasks that many people have trouble doing right out in the opera.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The election is still six days away and the joint Congressional committee handling arrangements for the Presidential inauguration has not even begun to allocate tickets, but there is hardly a room to be had in a major Washington hotel for the big Jan. 20 event.

A resolution urging Congress not to ratify the Havana Charter for an International Trade Organization but to seek its renegotiation was adopted yesterday by the American Tariff League at its sixty-third anniversary meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27 -- Leaders of the Congregational and Unitarian churches in the United States observed the 300th anniversary of the Cambridge platform of church discipline today with pointed reference to present events, including the coming national election.

TORONTO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored two goals in the final period tonight to hand Montreal's Canadiens their first setback in the National Hockey League, 3 -- 2. It was the second victory for the defending champions against three defeats.

Officials of the International Longshoremen's Association. AFL, devoted most of yesterday to discussion of the forthcoming vote by the union's membership on the final offer of the New York Shipping Association. This offer was submitted to the special Presidential board of inquiry last Thursday.

Norman (Red) Strader was informed publicly yesterday that he would be retained as coach of the New York Football Yankees next year and he promptly made it known that for the remainder of the present season he would concentrate on developing the new talent on the club's roster.

Regardless of the sympathy that the American people may feel for Jews in Europe, the diplomatic policies of the United States "must hang together in some coherent pattern that makes sense from the standpoint of the national interest of America as a whole, including the interest of Americans of Jewish faith," Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, told the New York chapter of the American Council for Judaism Inc., yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- John L. Lewis demanded today that President Truman intervene in the French Government's handling of the miners' strike by using the power placed in his hands "in the control of the Marshall fund" to have France "cease making war on its own citizens."

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week set a new peak for the third successive seven-day period. According to the American Petroleum Institute, output averaged 5,595,950 barrels daily, an increase of 9,600 over the previous week.

The Douglas Aircraft Company highe figure excludes $70,000,000 had a net income of $1,950,795, no equal to $3.25 a share of capital in the first nine months this year, contrasted to the net of $1,170,037 after income tax cdit a year before, Donald W. Douglas, the president, announced yesterday.
RENO, Nev., Oct. 27 -- Mrs. Porfirio Rubirosa, the former Doris Duke, obtained her second Nevada divorce today. The court permitted her to resume her maiden name.

A complaint against a New York restaurant, charged with barring a blind veteran because he was accompanied by his Seeing Eye dog, was withdrawn yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court after the head-waiter the restaurant publicly apologized for the incident.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 27 -- The Republicans are likely to lose a sorely needed Senate seat in Minnesota next Tuesday while the disposition of the state's eleven electoral votes as between President Truman and Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is a toss-up, according to political observers.

The difficulty of getting along with the Soviet Union so long as her leaders continue thinking of "inevitable" war with capitalistic nations was explored last night by four speakers on the fourth of the current series of "What's On Your Mind" programs.

MORGENTHAU, Palestine, Oct. 27 -- Morgenthau is not yet on the map but its Hebrew equivalent soon will be. It is another Jewish settlement, founded today just inside the "Burma Road" corridor that the Israelis carved through Arab territory from Israel proper to Jerusalem.
Seven recommendations for improving dental health in New York State were adopted by the Dental Health Conference at the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday after a three-day discussion.

Probably from his youngest days in California, and most certainly since his young manhood, Judah L. Magnes, Palestine's greatest educator, held to the creed that if you believed sincerely in an ideal you must live by it, and that there can be no compromise with one's conscience. Time has proved him right more often than wrong in the stands he took.

Observance of Navy Day should not pass without some mention of the gallant role played by the American merchant marine in support of the Armed Forces during World War II, Arthur M. Tode, honorary president of the Propeller Club of the United States, declared yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, left London for Washington tonight after having expressed confidence that the European Recovery Program was making good progress.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The United Nations General Assembly will be asked to recognize the Government of South Korea and approve the continuation of the United States occupation until conditions are stabilized, it was reported here today.
Striking rank and file beer drivers drove their second wedge into the ranks of the Brewers Board of Trade yesterday amid growing signs that the wildcat walkout might be over in a matter of days.

Charles W. Schwefel, managing director of the Hotel Gramercy Park, was elected president of the Twenty-third Street Association at the annual meeting of the association yesterday at Cavanagh's Restaurant. He succeeds John F. Morgan.

The stock market indicated yesterday its disappointment over the failure of the United States Steel Corporation on Tuesday to join the procession of companies declaring higher or extra dividends. Although there was again a long list of favorable payments to stockholders by a wide variety of corporations, the reaction in Big Steel was the dominant factor in the day's, proceedings on the Stock Exchange.

Two years after its purchase from the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation the triangular block formed by the intersection of Thirty-fourth Street, Thirty-eighth Avenue and Northern Boulevard, in Long Island City, Queens, has been resold by Simon Bros., builders, to the Reichman Realty Corporation, Joseph Reichman, president.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- A report of soaring profits and announcement of a bigger dividend by Roan Antelope Copper Mines, Ltd., sent all Rhodesian copper shares up in the stock markets here today. Elsewhere lack of fresh international news, coupled with the prospect of a lively Parliamentary session, put the brake on any fresh buying.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Danish Government announced today that prospecting and mining concessions given to American interests in 1936 no longer could be considered valid. Minister of Public Works Carl Petersen told a news conference that Government experts had reported the Government was tricked into granting the concessions.

Joseph M. Mazer, president of the Hudson Paper and Pulp Corporation and well-known Zionist, has been elected president of the newly organized American Kereth Corporation. This group, which has opened offices at 55 West Forty-second Street, will endeavor to help solve the housing problem in Israel.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Yugoslavia accused the United States today of transforming Greece into a giant military base -- complete with airfields for heavy bombers -- as a bridgehead for use against the Soviet Union.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27 -- Herman Hickman looked up from a pile of mail as high as his native Smokies and he was grinning from ear to ear. The Yale football coach was feeling good on two counts, despite the 35-0 licking the Bulldog took from Vanderbilt.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 27 -- A New Jersey turnpike authority was created today with Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll designating as its first project an express toll road from Pennsville on the Delaware River to a junction with main routes at Woodbridge, near Elizabeth.

Byrd Elliot, Seattle violinist, who last played here six years ago, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. She showed once more the attributes that have stamped her previous appearances: seriousness of purpose, technical competence and an interest in contemporary music.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Aubrey H. Harwood, director of ECA operations, said today that the ECA had offered to help United States mining companies expand in foreign fields in efforts to build up the nation's strategic defense stockpiles.
Bill Dickey, one of baseball's all-time great catchers, yesterday was named a coach of the Yankees, the club with which he was connected as player -- and briefly as manager -- for nineteen years.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- Invoking the name of Alfred E. Smith, President Truman asserted here tonight that the Republicans were using against him tactics like the anti-Catholic whispering campaign that decisively contributed to the defeat of "the Happy Warrior" in his race for the Presidency in 1928.

Jack Nork, tailback for Columbia's football team, was named game captain for Saturday's encounter with Cornell by Coach Lou Little as the Light Blue's mentor put his squad and a group of freshmen through the most extensive tackling scrimmage of the season at Baker Field yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander commended yesterday at a City Hall ceremony eleven members of the Police Department who were active in the "breaking" of two recent cases involving attempted extortion and kidnaping.

There is no task more difficult in the way of theatrical production than the successful presentation of black and white. This is being achieved in "Fashions of the Times" because of the skill in handling lights demonstrated by Nat Karson, who has lighted and directed the performance.

A collection dignified clothes for women was shown yesterday at a fashion show on the third floor of B. Altman Co. It included daytime and evening dresses, coats, suits and millinery for the mature women.
City College football continues to be unique in many ways by contrast with other college camps.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A special subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee urged today that the proposed International Trade Organization be supported by the Eighty-first Congress as a part of the bipartisan foreign policy.

John E. (Bing) Miller, Violet football star of the Twenties, was appointed Graduate Manager of Athletics at New York University last night by Professor John F. Sullivan. Professor Sullivan made the announcement twenty-four hours after he had been selected as chairman of the Board of Athletic Control by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Several popular British cars appeared with a modified American look and a "dollar grin" when the thirty-third International Motor Exhibition, the first in ten years, opened here today.
The following is the text of President Truman's campaign speech at Boston last night as recorded and transcribe by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Jack Kroll, director of the CIO-Political Action Committe, predicts a maximum vote in the election Tuesday. With 80,000 PAC workers active in thousands of precincts Mr. Kroll said today that his organization's reports indicated that a vote of approximately 56,000,000 was indicated.

To carry the war to the enemy in any future conflict the Navy must maintain an up-to-date, efficient fleet, Vice Admiral Harry W. Hill, commandant of the National War College, declared last night. Admiral Hill addressed 500 persons at the annual Navy Day dinner, sponsored by the Navy League of the United States, at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The project for a defensive pact for the North Atlantic by the Brussels Pact countries of the Western Union on the one hand and the United States and Canada on the other is expected to be pressed through negotiations here after the Presidential elections, though a considerable time will be required before it can be completed and put into force.

Freshman Jack Kramer of Los Angeles heads United States professional tennis rankings for 1948. The United States Professional Tennis Association placed the hard-hitting Californian on top yesterday in announcing its "big ten" of the year.

At the first annual meeting yesterday of the Federation of Women Shareholders in American Business, Inc., Mrs. Wilma Soss, founer of the federation, was elected president and Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde was elected vice president.

Full cooperation between communities and agencies of all denominations dealing with incoming displaced persons is essential to make the new Displaced persons Act effective, Mrs. Louis Broido, chairman of a conference on displaced persons sponsored by the United Service for New Americans, declared yesterday.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., is in complete agreement with the opinion expressed in the editorial "To Fight City Smoke" that "it is generally recognized by the people of New York City that a much better job needs to be done on air pollution control."

NANKING, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Competent military sources said today that Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's armies had "a golden opportunity" to crush 60,000 Communist troops in the Manchurian corridor with a pulverizing blow.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 27 -- Speaking here tonight, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey accused President Truman of helping communism at home and abroad.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Britain envisages the necessity of continuing some form of European payments agreement beyond July, 1949, as a supplement to United States recovery aid, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today.

The American Steel Foundries declared yesterday an extra of 50 cents and a regular dividend of 60 cents a common share, both payable on Dec. 15. Previous payments have been 50 cents quarterly for several years.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Sterope, 25-to-1 shot ridden by an 18-year-old apprentice, galloped to victory in the Cambridgeshire Stakes today and landed a betting fortune for his owner, J.B. Townley.

ATHENS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Greek High Command was authoritatively reported today to have ordered a shake-up in the leadership of army units that lost two important heights to Communist rebels in the Mount Vitsi area last week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- An agreement by the British and French Governments to delay distribution of about 300 industrial units as reparations payments from Western Germany pending a decision on their retention under the European Recovery Program was announced today by the State Department.

Without attempting to submit an all-inclusive list of qualified candidates for the New York Legislature, we do offer here for the consideration of voters next Tuesday the names of a considerable number of present members of Senate and Assembly (and one former member) from New York City and upstate counties who have in general made a good record and whose services at Albany would be missed if they were not returned.
Following is the text of Gov Thomas E. Dewey's campaign address at Cleveland last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Bids on the first contract for the six-lane Major Deegan Expressway to be constructed in the Bronx will be received in November, and work on the $40,000,000 project will get undere way by the beginning of next year, it was learned yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 27 -- The Israeli chief of operations made clear today the Israeli Army's opposition to restoring the Oct. 14 battlelines in Palestine and suggested instead the withdrawal of all sides to positions held on May 14 -- roughly the boundaries proposed in the United Nations partition plan.

Representatives of business, labor unions and churches told volunteer workers and board members of 144 Protestant welfare agencies yesterday that cooperation between a private welfare agency and the rest of the community headed a list of standards by which they decided what charities to support.

A complete three-room apartment as well as numerous setting mark the winter conversion of the Mayhew Shop at 603 Madison Avenue from headquarters for summer furniture and accessories to a center for coordinated home furnishings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration clamped a temporary lid today on grants to nine Marshall Plan nations in an effort to spur the negotiation of loan agreements. All countries eligible for loans except Great Britain and Iceland were affected.
BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- The Nashua New Hampshire Foundation, an organization of Nashua citizens, completed today negotiations for purchase of all property owned by Textron, Inc., in their city.

Wholesale butter prices dropped slightly yesterday for the third successive day, and some chain stores announced still further reductions in the retail cost. The price now averages 69 to 71 cents a pound. Whatever the housewife saves at the butter counter, however, she may lose-on the milk bill, for the same stores will put 'up that price 1/2 cent a quart today.

A first mortgage loan of $965,000 at 4 per cent for ten years was made by the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston. Mass., to Parkholme, Inc., Eli Ellis, president, on the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 430 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Bids were received in Albany yesterday on another contract advancing construction of the Cross-Bronx Expressway, City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses announced last evening. The latest job to be let concerned clearing the site in Highbridge Park for a huge traffic interchange.

DETROIT, Oct. 27 -- Until atomic power can be devised for use in airplanes, the Navy will have to continue to maintain the nautical caravan for the transportation of men and supplies in case of war, Admiral W.H.P. Blandy, commander of the Atlantic Fleet, said here today in a Navy Day address.

Retailers pressing for quick deliveries of children's coats, snow suits and legging sets have created a shortage of these items in the garment market, according to New York manufacturers. Demand exceeding that of any season in the experience of manufacturers, including the war years, has cleared all available stock, they said yesterday, and production is at least three weeks behind.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Radio Moscow has conceded the Presidential election to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, although it still thinks Henry A. Wallace is the best candidate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 120: A decrease...

Two students from Queens, who spent five hours hitch-hiking across the Triborough Bridge and two boroughs to get to their school in the Bronx, were among thousands of high school pupils affected yesterday by the bus tie-up. Many high schools in the Bronx reported many latecomers and absentees, but schools in Manhattan appeared to have suffered little.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The production of the bizonal area of Germany "must not only reach pre-war levels, but rise above them" and its exports must be expanded to four times their present volume, it is contended in a four-year economic program for that area just submitted to the European organization under the Marshall Plan.

Since last month when they combined their resources for the purpose of bringing to Broadway Arthur Miller's new play, "Death of a Salesman," Kermit Bloomgarden and Walter Fried have been confronted by the problem of casting the leading feminine and masculine roles.

THE pleasure of reading other people's mail -- which is lavishly deplored, ordinarily -- becomes enormously respectable when the letters belong to celebrities and are published in book form. In fact, a good deal of righteous indignation is expressed by scholars and the laity if the private papers of great men are too long withheld from the Peeping Tom called posterity.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, will observe today the nineteenth anniversary of his consecration to the episcopate, and the Right Rev. Horace William B. Donegan, his suffragan, will observe the first anniversary of his consecration.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Ivor Thomas, journalist, author and former Parliamentary Secretary for Civil Aviation and Colonial Under-Secretary, who resigned yesterday from the Labor party, explained his reasons to the House of Commons today by means of a detailed attack on the Labor Government.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler today wiped ten players off the Detroit American League baseball team's farm rosters and said "beyond any doubt these players were covered and handled contrary to baseball law and procedure." The club was not fined.

TOKYO, Oct. 27 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Headquarters now is instructing the Japanese to discount strongly reports from Washington that major changes may be made in occupation economic and labor policies. The reports have been the subject of widespread discussion here in the last few days.

DES MOINES, Oct. 27 (AP) -Marriner S. Eccles of the Federal Reserve Board said today it was necessary for economic security to "bring about a condition of world peace at an early date, even at the risk of war."
Shoes and stockings played important roles as complements to the 140 costumes seen in "Fashions of the Times," showing this week at Times Hall.

Despite dollar restrictions in foreign markets, export sales of the Monroe Calculating Machine Company in 1948 are at the rate of 238 per cent of the company's best pre-war year, W. G. Zaenglein, president, announced yesterday at the National Business Show in Grand Central Palace.

Regardless of whether President Truman or Governor Dewey is elected President next Tuesday, big business will be the winner and the American working people the losers," Farrell Dobbs, Presidential candidate of the Socialist Workers party, declared here last night.

Pursuant to their policy of seeking peaceful solutions of international disputes in keeping with the United Nations Charter, the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France have decided to stand for the present on the Berlin resolution voted by the great majority of the Security Council, but vetoed by Russia, and have declared their continued willingness to carry it out in good faith.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The application of Station WNYC supported by a request from Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York for special temporary authority to broadcast the election returns from 10 P.M. on Tuesday through the early hours of Wednesday morning was denied today by the Federal Communications Commission under a rule recently adopted terminating the issuance of such special authorizations of night hours to daytime stations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 -Omar Hoskins, a federal conciliator, had another meeting today with officers of the Marine Engineers Benefical Association, an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in connection with the possible resumption of negotiations with West Coast shipowners.
MELBOURNE, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A prominent racehorse owner and his trainer were cleared of charges of improper practice today by a committee of the Victorian Racing Club.

Under an improved rate of production, particularly in its automotive operations, net sales and net income of the General Motors Corporation for both the third quarter and the first nine months of 1948 were sharply higher than the respective totals for the similar periods of last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Republican Congressional Campaign Committee was shown in preliminary reports today to have put $16,500 into New York City and State to hold or strengthen its twenty-eight member delegation in the House, which now also has fifteen Democrats and two members of the American Labor Party from New York.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 27 -- While railroad men still commented on Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's rear platform remark on Oct. 12 that the engineer of his train was "a lunatic" for backing into a crowd at Beacoup, Ill., Alvanley Johnston, grand chief engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, announced today his support of the Republican nominee for President.

Accepting the springtime theme of the seventh edition of "Fashions of the Times" are the silken rustle of taffeta and the swish of other crisp fabrics that whisper through many of the scenes of this presentation at Times Hall. Indicative of the fashion excitement in store are the varied treatments given to taffeta.

More than $350,000,000 will have been spent by the 3,300 members of the National Industrial Advertisers Association for that type of advertising alone by the end of this year, it was predicted yesterday by William A. Marsteller, chairman of the association and vice president, Edward Valves, Inc., East Chicago.

Completing a two-week tour of this country, during which he had long talks with President Truman, Governor Dewey and other political figures, Robert G. Menzies, former Prime Minister of Australia, sailed for home by way of England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania.

There is no prospect of a major business recession, Edwin B. George, economist, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., told more than 600 industrial executives who attended the American Management Association luncheon yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

CHARLEY JOHNSTON is the brother of the late Jimmy Johnston, boxing's famed Boy Bandit. No label hinting at larceny ever has been attached to Charley's name. He hasn't Jimmy's colossal nerve, boundless imagination nor belligerent mein. He doesn't even wear a derby hat. But he does have the eternal Johnston hustle and much of the Johnston skill at space-grabbing.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 27 -- A Yugoslav trade mission headed by Melenaje Popovitch, Minister of Foreign Trade, whose arrival in Moscow was reported yesterday by the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug, is seeking to renegotiate a short-term annual trade agreement with the Soviet Union that has already expired or will expire soon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Removal of hedges against sales of cash corn to exporters and the Government and lighter country offerings resulted today in higher prices for that grain on the Board of Trade. The close was at the top with gains of 1 1/4 to 2 cents a bushel, December leading.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 27 -- The Capital National Bank in Jackson and the Jackson State National Bank of this city are slated for consolidation to form the largest bank in the state of Mississippi, it was learned here today. The proposed consolidated institution, to be known as the First National Bank of Jackson, will hold resources totaling about $70,000,000.

The New York Youth Concerts Association, Inc., opened its fifth season of symphonic concerts for school children of the New York area, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The program, performed by an orchestra of sixty-five pieces, under Wheeler Beckett, with Ruggiero Ricci, violinist, as guest artist, was heard by a capacity audience of 2,900, the largest in the association's annals to date, with more than 100 seated on the stage and many standees.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- The Russian campaign of protest against the United States and British airlift into blockaded Berlin was strengthened tonight by an announcement by the Soviet news bureau that Lieut. Gen. G.S. Lukantchenko, Chief of Staff of the Soviet Military Administration, had sent a new letter to United States and British authorities protesting against alleged violations of air safety in the corridors leading to Berlin and over the city itself.
The stollen is so good it seemed a shame to wait till Christmas to discuss it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- With the plea for "peace through preparedness" echoing across the country in more than 150 formal Navy Day addresses, the Navy itself gave emphasis to these statements today by announcing the commissioning next month of the U.S.S. Des Moines, heaviest of the "heavy" cruisers, armed with the most deadly power weapons these vessels have ever carried.

With few exceptions, purchasing at the Jamestown furniture market has been limited to essential fill-ins, according to an executive of an interstate furniture store chain who returned from the market yesterday.

Plans for a new colony of forty-one homes at North Street and Theall Road, Rye, in Westchester County, have been announced as the result of the sale of twenty-three acres of land there by the Miriam Osborn Memorial Home to J. Eric Wideberg.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 27 -- Five regiments of army troops revolted in Peru's second city of Arequipa today and asserted tonight that they controlled the southern half of the country.

For 155 young persons who aspire to places behind Broadway footlights and radio microphones, yesterday was "audition day" at the city's new High School of Performing Arts, 120 West Forty-sixth Street. For some, it was "just another audition"; for others it was their first, but for all it was a big moment.

The three-family brownstone dwelling at 82 Lexington Avenue, Brooklyn, was resold by the Dansker Realty and Securities Corporation to Laura Artie Jacobs through the Active Realty Company, broker. A purchase money mortgage of $4,400 was executed at the closing.

Employment on new ship construction in this country is far below that considered absolutely necessary to maintain an adequate and healthy merchant marine, H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, declared last night.

Both President Truman and Governor Dewey have devoted much of their time and emphasis in this campaign to the discussion of economic issues. It seems to us that in this field Mr. Dewey has shown less tendency to play to the gallery than his principal opponent and has demonstrated a consistency in his point of view that has been decidedly alien to the addresses of the President.

Accelerated subway service, pooled riding in taxicabs that swarmed the bus routes and the generosity of private car owners minimized bus-strike effects yesterday. Clear weather helped, too. Short-haul bus users walked to the subways.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A United States war crimes court acquitted thirteen high German military commanders of having plotted war today but convicted at least three of them of war crimes.

New orders booked by furniture factories in September were "somewhat lower" than in the preceding month and the comparable month last year, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading furniture manufacturers.

Mrs. Frothingham Wagstaff and her aides will meet this afternoon at the Colony Club to complete plans for furthering the sale of tickets for the pre-opening performance of "As the Girls Go" on the night of Nov. 12 at the Winter Garden Theatre for the benefit of the Samaritan Home for the Aged.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 27 -- Korean Government forces captured Yosu, southern port city and last stronghold of the rebels, at 1 o'clock this afternoon, according to Korean Army headquarters.

Garrulous Danny Ahearn, wellknown hoodlum of the roaring Twenties, kept right on talking yesterday in General Sessions Court after a jury had convicted him of robbery in the second degree. It was his fourth felony conviction and he faces life imprisonment.

Some smaller mills are offering twelve-foot axminster carpets in quantity for immediate delivery, retailers reported yesterday. They emphasized that offerings are limited to hard-to-sell patterns and added that none of the top mills are making them.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 8 to 14 points net higher yesterday.

Declaring that he could not explain why he did it, except that he "felt lucky," John Marrison, 54-year-old cashier at one of the $5 payoff windows at Jamaica racetrack, told detectives yesterday that he had bet $5,250 of the track's money during the afternoon, and lost it.

Tones of pink and mauve were the dominant colors in Eve Tartar's collection of midwinter hats seen yesterday at luncheon at the Pierre Hotel. Small, side-draped felts were among the most flattering in this group of well-defined shapes.

Billy Meyer, freshman pilot of the Pirates, is the major leagues' "manager of the year." The popular Pittsburgh skipper won in an Associated Press poll of 220 baseball writers throughout the country, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Excerpts from the Yugoslav delegation's English text of a speech today by Ales Bebler in the United Nations Political Committee follow:

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Life With Mother," on the night of Nov. 5 at the Empire Theatre which has been taken over for the benefit of the Episcopal Actors Guild. Mrs. Charles Manton Richter is chairman of the committee in charge of the sale of tickets for the benefit.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 27 -- It was a rough afternoon for the Navy football players today as they prepared for an even rougher afternoon against the Irish of Notre Dame on Saturday at Baltimore.
Five men were under arrest yesterday because a man walking along the Bowery with fifteen boxes stumbled and dropped them in front of three detectives of the Safe and Loft Squad.

In its report on Assembly candidates in Queens the Citizens Union yesterday endorsed Assemblyman William E. Clancy, Democratic and Liberal party candidate for re-election in the Second District, and Fred W. Preller, Republican candidate for re-election in the Ninth District.

An active demand for crude cotton oil from packers and refiners, advancing prices in the South a cent a pound or more, made for an active day in the futures market on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein obtained show-cause orders late yesterday afternoon in the Supreme Courts of Manhattan and Brooklyn against 132 persons on charges of having registered illegally for the November election.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Truman named today a committee on religious and moral welfare and character guidance in the armed forces to help provide a healthy, spiritual and recreational life for service men while they are not on duty.

Net sales of Standard Brands. Inc., and its United States subsidiaries reached a new record of $214,034,858 in the first nine months of this year, increasing 5.6 per cent over the $202,702,880 volume for the 1947 period, according to the report to be released today by Joel S. Mitchell, president.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor, gave cautious and qualified approval today to the idea of withdrawing the occupation armies "under satisfactory conditions" as a means of solving the German problem.

The Richmond county grand jury, which is investigating complaints of rent gouging by owners of apartment houses on Staten Island handed up twelve informations yesterday against five defendants and a corporation.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 27 -- A wild and wooly finish to New Mexico's election campaign was indicated today, but the Democrats were riding toward victory in the important Senate contest.

Candidates for admission to the ninety-four colleges and universities associated with the College Entrance Examination Board may indicate three "first choices" among the institutions they desire to attend, under a rule adopted yesterday at the board's ninetyeighth regular meeting.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- A letter from the Earl of Halifax in today's Times, London, replied to what he held to be an implication in Winston Churchill's book. "The Gathering Storm," that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain did not have any faith in his Munich settlement with Hitler and sought to deceive the British public into a contrary belief.

Stewart H. I-Iolbrook, author of "Lost Men of American History," present.q more interesting facts about people and places in "Little Annie Oakley and Other Rugged i People," which will be issued by l lVacmillian on Nov. 19. It is a collection }f twenty-eight short stories, some of which have appeared in magazines and news. papers.
The insurgent bus strike ended last night when the last group of hold-outs voted overwhelmingly to return to work.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The uneasiness felt by many nations over what they regard as Britain's attempt to weaken the authority of the United Nations Trusteeship Council crystallized today in a draft resolution introduced jointly by the United States, Brazil, India, Norway and Pakistan before the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee.

School District No. 1 of the city and county of Denver, Col., sold yesterday a new issue of $21,000,000 of bonds maturing serially Oct. 1, 1949 to 1967, to a banking syndicate headed by Harris Trust and Savings Bank and Bankers Trust Company, at an interest cost of 2.045 per cent.

A new high of $8,438,043 in earnings was shown by the Lion Oil Company in the nine months ended on Sept. 30, almost doubling the $4,856,321 income shown for the corresponding period of 1947, according to the report of T. M. Martin, president, issued yesterday.
The zenith of the seventieth annual campaign of the United Hospital Fund has been reached, and expanded public solicitation gives every New Yorker an opportunity to help meet its $2,845,988 goal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Department of Labor reported today that more working time was lost in September because of strikes than during any month since May.
Philip Wylie, the novelist, announced last night his resignation from the Authors League of America, the independent organization embracing the majority of the country's prominent writers.

After a conference with the chairmen of the eight counties in the metropolitan district, Alger B. Chapman, state campaign manager, and Glen R. Bedenkapp, state chairman, joined yesterday in a statement predicting that the Republican national candidates, Governor Dewey and Gov. Earl Warren, would carry Queens, Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties by a total plurality of 400,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 -- Four sharp Congressional contests in northern and central California, in districts represented now by two Republicans and two Democrats, are putting life into a campaign notable for its apathy.

Pat Cici of the Nassau County Park course in Westbury won the 18-hole play-off for the Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship when he fired a 2-over-par 39, 35 -- 74 to defeat Jack Mallon of Cold Spring Harbor by 1 stroke.

The public opinion polls, and other seers, now say for there is to be a new Administration. When he gets to the White House for lunch on that inaugural day, Mr. Dewey should dictate two important memoranda. The first should be to ask the proper bureau to do something about highway historical signs and the second to ask the packers of cranberry jelly to do something constructive about their tins.

ST.-ETIENNE, France, Oct. 27 -- This morning Government forces walked into the important Pigeot mine and took it over without opposition from the striking miners. The strikers at Pigeot and three smaller neighboring pits stood by with their hands in their pockets as a small detachment of security police pushed aside barriers and marched into the mine areas.

Notices of termination of tenancy were sent yesterday to residents of the block on the southwest corner of Washington Square. The property has been the subject of a controversy since the announcement earlier this year that buildings there would be razed to establish a $3,000,000 law center of the New York University School of Law.

Two new films will be open in midtown theatres today. At the Capitol the attraction is "One Touch of Venus," the adaptation of the Kurt Weill-Ogden Nash S.J. Perelman musical play featuring Ava Gardner in the title role, Robert Walker and Dick Haymes.

The New York Federation of Post Office Clerks declared yesterday that it had requested two hours off on Election Day for voting, but that the request had been denied. Otto Gottlieb, president of Local 10 of the group, said such time off was customary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Senator William E. Jenner of Indiana, chairman of the Senate Campaign Investigating subcommittee, ordered today the impounding of ballot boxes in eight more Texas counties figuring in the nip-and-tuck Senatorial run-off in which Representative Lyndon B. Johnson defeated former Gov. Coke Stevenson in the Democratic primaries.

ABOARD PICCARD-COSYNSEXPEDITION MOTHERSHIP SCALDIS, Off Cape Verde Islands, Oct. 27 -- In the flat glare of Navy searchlights on black water, the bathyscaphe heaved dripping from the depths at 10:18 o'clock last night to complete the first man-carrying dive of the strange underwater balloon.
Advertisers and business men were told yesterday to prepare for a "total war on totalitarian ideas," and to end complacency in the belief that a new Administration will halt "the march of communism."

Democratic and Liberal party leaders estimated yesterday that at least 2,000,000 persons would see President Truman during his two-day campaign visit to New York today and tomorrow. During his stay, the President is scheduled to make nine speeches in the city and two in Yonkers. He also is scheduled to attend a reception and a conference, at each of which he probably will speak informally.

Harry La Montagne's Conniver, back in the form that clinched the most-improved-filly-of-the-year title for her earlier in the campaign, ran over the opposition in the stretch at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday to win $20,200 of the $29,250 at stake in the Comely Handicap.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Several influential United Nations delegates have proposed that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, in the event he is elected President next Tuesday, issue a statement affirming his position on the main policies being followed by the United States delegation at this session of the General Assembly.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The Arab States are studying an "ultimatum" for presentation to the Security Council unless action is taken at tomorrow's emergency session to halt the shooting in Palestine, a particularly well-informed Arab source stated tonight.

Spencer Drayton told The United Press yesterday that his Thoroughbred Racing Protective Bureau had uncovered a "ringer" case in which the horse Don't Delay ran under the name "Lid" at Blue Bonnets, Montreal, on Aug. 28.

The State Committee of the American Labor party charged yesterday that the Citizens Union, although posing as a nonpartisan group, had been actuated by anti-Communist bias in making public its recommendations on candidates for the Legislature.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie told the Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today that the costs to date for the mission of the United Nations Mediator in Palestine totaled $2,497,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Since the compilers of the "sleeping polls" are generally agreed that the only doubtful outcome of next Tuesday's elections is whether the Republicans or the Democrats will have a Senate majority in the Eighty-first Congress, it may be serviceable to give the names of the 28 individual contestants on whose showing at the polls this outcome will depend.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The Government's motion to establish a tribunal to consider allegations of bribery and corruption in the Board of Trade was approved unanimously today by the House of Commons. Winston Churchill expressed the Conservative Opposition's entire accord with the methods and terms of reference proposed by Prime Minister Attlee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -Reports that Howard Hughes, controlling stockholder of RKO, favors a two-for-one split of the company's shares to separate wholly owned theatres from other RKO operations, were confirmed today by a source close to Hughes.
The Todd Shipyards Corporation is converting six LST's [Landing Ship, Tanks] into crude-oil carriers for the Shell Caribbean Petroleum Company, it was made known yesterday.

Heading a list of 150 Navy Day Speakers throughout the country, John L. Sullivan, Secretary of the Navy, declared in Chicago that the United States "must give free people everywhere unmistakable evidence of our intention to support them in their struggle so that the unsteady truce of today may become the stable peace of tomorrow."

As an aftermath of the conviction of a tenant selector on charges of rent gouging, permission to move in will be denied thirty-two doctors and dentists, who had obtained leases for offices in Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, pending a further investigation, it became known last night.

George R. Hinman of the New York and Manhasset Bay Yacht Clubs last night was elected president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound. The action was taken at the annual meeting of the organization held in the New York clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 27 (AP) -- M.S. Szymczak, of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, said today that "it would be dangerous to assume that inflationary forces have run their course." He spoke also of "the continued threat of further deterioration in the international situation'' in a talk at a luncheon of the Buffalo Chamber of Commerce.

I have been a resident of the Village for the past thirty years and never have I seen such flagrant violations of law and order as outside the taverns of West Eighth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Whole gangs of terrorists and hoodlums from the Bleecker Street and Carmine section have descended upon the Saturday night crowds seeking entertainment.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (AP) -The courage of fifty-nine naval reservists, many of them 17 and 18 years old, who were making their first sea voyage, helped a small landing craft survive a three-day Atlantic storm, her officers reported today.

The home town debut of the Rangers proved exasperatingly unsuccessful for the New York representatives in the National Hockey League. Opposing the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night, the Blue Shirts struck for the first goal only forty seconds after the beginning of the game, and things augured well for a happy introduction to the 13,224 fans on hand.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Oscar L. Nyberg's Irisen, a 5 -- 2 shot, proved her gameness in taking the six-furlong Georgetown Purse at Laurel Park today. The filly scored by two lengths despite drifting out at the head of the stretch.
LEESBURG, Fla., Oct. 27 (UP) The long-dormant Florida Ku Klux Klan announced plans today to ride again on Monday, the eve of the general elections.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Oscar L. Nyberg's Irisen, a 5 -- 2 shot, proved her gameness in taking the six-furlong Georgetown Purse at Laurel Park today. The filly scored by two lengths despite drifting out at the head of the stretch.
LEESBURG, Fla., Oct. 27 (UP) The long-dormant Florida Ku Klux Klan announced plans today to ride again on Monday, the eve of the general elections.

WASHINGTON, Oct 27 -- American travel agencies will advance a program later this fall designed to end many of the travel restrictions in Latin America, the Committee on Facilitation of Inter-American Transportation said today.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Fifty-two foreigners arrested for activities in the French coal strike have been expelled from France, the Government announced today as the miners' conflict appeared to be nearing an end.

The first major feature under the new $17,000 television research project of the Department of Agriculture will be the Thanksgiving Day presentation from New York of "The Miracle Harvest," Kenneth M. Gapen, in charge of radio information for the department, announced yesterday in Washington.

Percy Brassett, a 32-year-old truck driver whole probation report showed that he had stolen from a poor box in his own church when he was a youth, was sentenced by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert yesterday to three years in prison for theft from the mails.
QUANTICO, Va., Oct. 27 (AP) -A husky Detroit policeman and a slight, freckled 20-year-old Maryland University junior today were found to be the nation's No. 1 pistol and rifle shots.

While office furniture sales this year may average 10 per cent ahead of last year, profit margins are narrowing because of rising costs and the time is fast approaching when aggressive sales promotion will be vital, Moe Turman, president of the National Office Furniture Association, said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Joseph J. O'Connell Jr., chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, declared tonight that the airlines should stop blaming the Government for their bad financial situation.
Willie Pep will defend the featherweight championship of the world tonight when the Hartford clashes with Sandy Saddler, Harlem challenger, in a 15-round bout at Madison Square Garden.

President Truman made his strongest pro-Israel declaration last night. Speaking at Madison Square Garden to more than 16,000 persons brought there under the auspices of the Liberal party, the President ignored the Bernadotte Report and pledged himself to see that the new State of Israel be "large enough, free enough and strong enough to make its people self-supporting and secure."

New Orleans with its iron-grilled balconies offers the romantic background for organdies, laces, nets, in fact all of those fragile materials that one associates with the Southern belle and moonlit nights in Scene Eight of "Fashions of the Times."

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Peruvian Government tonight ordered its air force to start operations against an Army garrison that had revolted at Arequipa, main city of southern Peru. The Government said peace prevailed in all other parts of the country.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Through Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, the Delaware River Joint Bridge Commission started an inquiry today into the purchase of the two private toll bridges over the Delaware River by Burlington County.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of Mr. Panyuskin's statement:

Two new films will open in Broadway houses this morning. At the Strand the new arrival is "June Bride," a romantic comedy produced by Warner Brothers starring Bette Davis and Robert Montgomery. Bretaigne Windust directed and Henry Blanke produced from a screen play by Ranald MacDougall and a play by Eileen Tighe and Graeme Lorimer.

Although the reviewers meted out nothing but praise for Josephine Hull and Eddie Dowling, stars of "Minnie and Mr. Williams," the critical reaction to Richard Hughes' 25-year-old religious fantasy, which came to the Morosco on Wednesday night, was the direct opposite.

Sponsors of the programs affected by the strike of the Radio Writers Guild will meet at 1 P.M. Sunday with J.R. Mandelbaum, assistant regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, it was announced yesterday.

Effective Monday the name of Charles M. Storm, Inc., will be changed to Storm Klein, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Allston E. Storm, president of both the old and new corporations. Charles M. Storm will continue as chairman of the executive committee.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -- With most of its injured players back in uniform, the Yale eleven completed its preparation for Saturday's game with Dartmouth at a long practice session today.
The cotton futures market yesterday closed 1 to 11 points net lower, as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange slowed up somewhat.
Following is the text of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's address in Boston last night, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

For voters in different parts of this city there are fourteen judicial offices to be filled on election day. Following our usual practice, we present as a trustworthy guide to the merits of candidates for these fourteen offices a list based as a sifting of recommendations made by the city's leading bar associations and the Citizens Union.
Jacob Carpenter Semple, 65 years old, conductor of Pennsylvania Railroad crack trains between New York and Washington, retired last night after 45 years of service.

It was Hedley Woodhouse's turn to rise and shine in the Empire City-at-Jamaica show yesterday. The energetic young gentleman from Vancouver had five mounts, four winners. He lost his chance for a perfect day -- and the first quintuple of the New York campaign -- when Isidor Bieber's filly, Joan's Robin, was unable to provide sufficiently fast transportation in the final race.
Bullet Bill Daley, star fullback for Minnesota and Michigan in his college and V-12 training days, has severed connections with his third professional club since 1946.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Justice Department lawyers appeared before a federal grand jury today in connection with an inquiry into activities of former Rep. Roger C. Slaughter, Democrat, of Missouri.
Following is the text of President Truman's speech in Madison Square Garden last night, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Dimitri Mitropoulos, who is alert to the world he is living in, is giving a contemporary tang to his concerts with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Last night at Carnegie Hall he directed the first performance of Morton Gould's Symphony No. 3 in its revised version.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 (AP) -- They closed the entry box for the Pimlico Special today and, as expected, the name of only one horse was in it -- Citation. The Calumet Farm flier is going to breeze a mile and three-sixteenths at Pimlico tomorrow all by himself except for Jockey Eddie Arcaro.

OTTAWA, Oct. 28 -- The Canadian Government has informed the other Governments concerned that it was ready to enter into negotiation of a treaty of collective security with them and other North Atlantic states, Lester B. Pearson, Secretary for External Affairs, said this morning.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -- Yale University has a new proton accelerator which smashes atoms at an increased rate of speed.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28 -- After a three-hour talk with United States Ambassador James Bruce this morning, President Juan D. Peron declared United States-Argentine relations would steadily improve and would reach a new high level in the future.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 28 -- An elderly sister and brother who apparently had lived for three days in their littered home at 38 Leslie Street while the body of the sister's husband remained in debris there, were committed today to hospitals near here.

A plan for the consolidation of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary and the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, two of the city's oldest institutions, under the name New York-Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital, was announced yesterday in a joint statement by Hugh E. Paine and Walter C. Baker, presidents, respectively, of the two hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national campaign manager, predicted today a smashing victory for the Dewey-Warren ticket next Tuesday that would carry with it continued Republican control of both houses of Congress.

Identifying himself with the New Deal, President Truman declared last night that business leaders owe as much to its architects as do the working people. "The New Deal benefited all the citizens of this great nation of ours, the rich as well as the poor, all of us," he said.

So confident are the Republicans of a landslide victory on election day that many of them look on the Presidential campaign as a mere ritual that must be followed because of custom and precedent. They do not give President Truman a chance and consider his defeat a foregone conclusion.
In the art galleries this week Victor Tischler's one-man show at Joseph Luyber's and the twenty-fourth annual of the New York Society of Women Artists at the Demotte Gallery are of special interest.

VIENNA, Oct. 28 -- The Soviet demand for the delivery by Nov. 30 of 540 locomotives and 5,575 cars from the Austrian railroads is not likely to be opposed by the Western powers' representatives here. The Americans seem to be taking the view that the Russian claim that this equipment is war booty is largely legal under the Hague Convention definitions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized today the sale to two insurance companies of $66,000,000 of 3 5/8 per cent first mortgage pipeline bonds, due 1968, of the Michigan-Wisconsin Pipe Line Company of Detroit, and exempted the sale from competitive bidding.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- John L. Lewis' intervention by letter in the French miners' strike created domestic and international labor repercussions today.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has been informed of the general feeling here that, if he is elected President, he should make clear his views on the policies being followed by the United States delegation at the United Nations General Assembly, usually reliable sources reported today.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 28 -- Lee Bum Suk, Prime Minister and-Minister of National Defense, in a statement today, placed responsibility for the revolt that began among Government troops in Yosu, south Korean port city, on Oct. 20, on careless recruitment for the constabulary under the United States Military Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that the ICC approve a plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific system with a total capitalization of $608,942,000.
A third member of the Brewers Board of Trade, the Metropolis Brewery, 501 First Avenue, broke the ranks of the employers yesterday and came to agreement with striking rank and file beer drivers.
The four-story brick residence of Sinclair Hatch, attorney, at 162 East Ninety-third Street was purchased by a client of Culver, Hollyday Co., brokers in the deal.

"The Battle for North America," edited by John Tebbel, has been scheduled for Nov. 26 publication by Doubleday. It is a one-volume abridgment of a thirteen-volume work by "America's great historian," Francis Parkman, which he called "France and England in North America."

The Progressive party candidates, Henry Wallace and Senator Glen Taylor, apparently have decided that there is a better way of serving up politics to the public than straight speeches. As a result the two have cut a record -- one of narration and singing -- that will be heard for the first time tonight at 11:30 o'clock over Station WMCA, it was learned yesterday.

President Truman was likened last night to Lady Macbeth by former Vice President Henry A. Wallace, who told the American Jewish Congress that Mr. Truman was trying unsuccessfully to cleanse his hands of the blood of Israel.

STUTTGART, Germany, Oct. 28 (AP) -- United States Army constabulary forces used tanks and cavalry against Germans today to break up a riot that had started when thousands had demonstrated against the high cost of living in this United States zone city.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Oct. 28 -- Eleven high ranking officers of the German Army and Navy received prison sentences today for war crimes and crimes against humanity.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 28 (UP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg lashed out at the Democratic Administration tonight for what he called "a sullen lack of cooperation" with the Republican Eightieth Congress.

Medical research may discover that the manifestations of old age are caused by the failure of some chemical process in the body, speakers told the fifty-seventh annual meeting of the Association of Life Insurance Medical Directors of America in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

Large quantities of falsely labeled anti-freeze solutions, many containing high percentages of corrosive salts, are "flooding" the market here and in at least six other Northern cities, it was reported yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau.

The Dormil Realty Corporation, represented by Hymen Bettigole, attorney, bought for investment from the Easter States Lien Corporation the store and apartment building and one-story taxpayer at 1415-17 Amsterdam Avenue, southeast corner of 130th Street, through Herman I. Steinholz, broker.

Mayor O'Dwyer received last night the gold medal award of the One Hundred Year Association. He was honored for his achievement in the "advancement of New York" and in particular for his efforts in forwarding the Golden Anniversary celebration.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 28 (AP) -- An estimated 2,300 delegates attending the opening session of the Cooperative Grange League Federation's annual meeting were told today that "to keep GLF effective it must be well financed."
DETROIT, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The estate of the late Henry Ford would have a total valuation of about $70,000,000 if figures used for tax payment purposes finally are approved.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 28 -- Anthony Eden, former Foreign Secretary of Britain's wartime Government, issued a two-fold warning today against the misuse of the United Nations and its machinery for settling world disputes.

Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, wartime head of the Office of Strategic Services, called yesterday for extension of the Monroe Doctrine to embrace western Europe and urged that the United States and other democracies impose economic sanctions on Russia to bring about "peace by compulsion."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- During the week ended Oct. 27, member bank reserve balances increased $50,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., obtained from Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday an order temporarily restraining the United States Government and two groups of shipping lines in the North Atlantic trade from putting into effect two Maritime Commission orders that it said would result in illegal and discriminatory freight rates in that trade.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Union moved into the Balkan debate today with a formal demand that the United Nations General Assembly dissolve its on-the-spot observation committee and order the withdrawal of all United States troops in Greece.

ABOARD, PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S CAMPAIGN TRAIN, EN ROUTE TO NEW YORK, Oct. 28 -- President Truman declared today that 60,000,000 voters would go to the ballot boxes to rout Governor Dewey, his opponent, and other Republican candidates next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The State Department rejected today Premier Stalin's charge of warmongering against the West with a brief statement on his interview.
Henry A. Wallace and his motorcade had to halt yesterday and then make three left turns to avoid merging with President Truman's entourage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The State Department reacted sharply today to a demand of Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, that the Far Eastern Commission call upon the United States to inform it of "the substance" of a reported "secret military conference" that Gen. Douglas MacArthur was said to have held in Tokyo from Oct. 12 to 14.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Military Administration in Germany is preparing its "own dissolution" in favor of the German people, an article in the Neues Deutschland, official newspaper of the Socialist Unity [Communist] party, said today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Senator Albert W. Barkley, Democratic candidate for Vice President, accused the Republicans today of waging a campaign of "evasion and hypocrisy."

A total of 138 hunters, the largest number in many years, has been entered for the thirty-one hunter contests to be held during the National Horse Show that begins in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 28 (AP) -- John L. Lewis suffered a decisive setback today in a battle for survival in New York State's major utility system.

Simultaneous with the report of record sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended on Sept. 30, the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation announced the declaration of an extra dividend of 50 cents in addition to a 25-cent quarterly dividend payable to stockholders on Dec. 24.

Stations WOV and WEVD announced yesterday that they would broadcast on Tuesday night the election returns heretofore carried by WNYC. When WNYC leaves the air at 10 P.M., the stations will cut in on the lines running to Police Headquarters, where the city's vote is tabulated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Despite the income tax cut, Government tax receipts were $322,523,000 higher for the first quarter of this fiscal year than in the same period last year.

The coal strike in France is a last-minute attempt on the part of Communist-dominated elements to stop that country's recovery program, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said yesterday on his arrival here after a ten-day trip to France, Britain, Western Germany and Italy.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct, 28 -- The voting trend in Virginia definitely indicates that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is favored over President Truman, but by a margin so narrow that many believe a mild shift in sentiment among the "silent votes" could keep the state in the traditional Democratic column.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Some Soviet experts here suggested that in view of the tight Government control over the press in
HAVANA, Oct. 28 -- Fresh and jorked beef may be imported free of duty. according to a Cabinet deeisian announced tonight. This is in line with the Oovernment'. effort to lower the cost of living.
A drastic revision of the grading system now used in America's schools and colleges was proposed yesterday by Dr. Maurice E. Troyer, Professor of Education at Syracuse University.

WE might as well start off with one sure winner. It supplies a feeling of confidence, buoys up the morale and eliminates all tendency to fumble. Gather closer, chum. This will have to be whispered. Today's surest shot is Citation in the Pimlico Special. Alas and alack! Would that they were all that simple.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union here today of having attempted to muzzle the world press by proposing that the United Nations convention on genocide includes a provision to punish all forms of public propaganda aimed at inciting racial, national or religious hatreds.

New records in steel production and net earnings were set by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in the third quarter of 1948, E.G. Grace, chairman, reported yesterday. Present indications point to a betterment of those achievements in the final three months of this year, he said.
A plan to improve and extend the public psychiatric services of this city will be presented to Mayor O'Dwyer within the next few weeks, it was learned yesterday.
BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- United States and British authorities are studying plans to set new limits on German merchant shipping and shipbuilding activities, maritime officials said today.

In reviewing all applications by physicians and dentists for office space in Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is seeking to assure the presence there of fully qualified practitioners, according to a statement yesterday by Churchill Rodgers, general counsel.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Del Bissonette, one of the all-time Brooklyn greats and manager of the Boston Braves for a brief period, today was named manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the International League.
Gene Bearden, the tall southpaw of the Cleveland Indians, was voted yesterday the American League's rookie of the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- The House Campaign Expenditures Committee reported today that fourteen Michigan witnesses, "mostly postmasters or acting postmasters from various sections of Michigan," testified at a hearing in Detroit that they had been solicited for campaign contributions by John R. Franco.

Juniors and teen-agers, including the small sophisticate and the tres jeune fille, are receiving many a hand on the stage of Times Hall this week during the performances of "Fashions of the Times." Interpretations of Paris designs, gay youthful cottons, and chic taffetas and failles are among the portrayals by designers for the young market.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28 -- It is not in the public interest to increase commuter fares on the Central Railroad of New Jersey, nor in the ultimate interest of the state, as well as the railroad itself, Charles R. Erdman Jr., commissioner of the Department of Economic Development of New Jersey, testified today at the joint hearing on the railroad's application for a commuter fare increase.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent during the week ended Oct. 23, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's comprehensive index increased to 165.3 per cent of the 1926 average as the result of moderate price increases for fresh meats and livestock.

The City Council referred yesterday to its committee on parks and thoroughfares a resolution by Councilman S. Samuel Di Falco, Manhattan Democrat, proposing that the United Nations name a main thoroughfare within its official area in mid-Manhattan "Avenue of the Americas" or "Boulevard of the Americas."

War-torn Sherman tanks now are battling for peanuts in East Africa. Stripped of formidable armor and fitted with reconstructed machinery, these war dogs have been tamed into heavy tractor-type vehicles for service on the mottled fields of Tanganyika Territory where Great Britain seeks to obtain a new source to augment a dwindling fat supply.

The National Security Act makes the United States Marine Corps responsible for meeting every new development science may produce, Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, former commandant of the Marine Corps, declared yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.
Mounting to a grand climax of opulence, one entire scene of "Fashions of the Times" is devoted to a luxurious display of mink wraps in the natural wild tone and several models of handsome mutations.

Three thousand persons heard last night representatives of the various political parties discuss the Israeli question at a nonpartisan forum in Manhattan Center under the sponsorship of the American Jewish Congress.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The boys from Princeton University roar into New Brunswick tomorrow for a rip-snortin' game of field hockey with the girls of the New Jersey College for Women.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 28 -- Two men with criminal records and a woman were convicted by a Nassau County Grand Jury tonight of robbery, burglary and assault in the beating and robbing of Mrs. Alwine Kebel, wife of Harry G. Kebel, an advertising executive, in her home in Garden City, L.I., June 6.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration completed loan agreements today calling for thirty-five-year advances of $60,000,000 to Ireland, $25,000,000 to Denmark and $10,000,000 to Sweden.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- The rapid deterioration of financial activity in the Western sectors may soon lead to the establishment of the Western Deutsche mark as the only valid currency in those sectors, military government officials said today.

Reflecting the improvement in sales, due largely to military orders, the Republic Aviation Corporation showed a net income of $2,274,870 after taxes and all charges for the first nine months of this year, Mundy I. Peale, president, reported for publication today.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A demand for Federal laws limiting the nation's charitable trust funds was in the making today after a New England Senator blasted what he called "the hocus pocus" of building such funds from modest sums to millions.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 28 -- The Netherlands Government moved today to slice through the red tape hampering the Indonesian negotiations by sending Foreign Minister Derek U. Stikker by plane to Java. He left tonight and will stay there about ten days.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The strike in the mining regions of France seemed to be waning slowly, with the center of conflict shifting to the ports and the Belgian frontier, where coal imports were being received.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Oct. 23, 1948, totaled 927,532 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 13,700 cars, or 1.5 per cent more than for the preceding week, 27,095 cars, or 2.8 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 14,725 cars, or 1.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
PARIS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The text of the British-Chinese resolution on Palestine submitted today to the United Nations Security Council:

The stock market completely slipped off the recovery trail yesterday and suffered the worst reversal in a month. The retreat carried prices back from fractions to approximately 3 points in a few sensitive issues and left the composite rate lower by 0.94 point.

The United States Rubber Company realized net earnings of $15,216,798 on a sales volume of $431,930,181 in the first nine months of this year, according to the report of F.B. Davis, chairman, and Herbert E. Smith, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday.

The construction cost index of the American Appraisal Company rose 16 points during the third quarter of 1948 and now stands at 502, a new high mark which is two and one-half times the 1939 index figure and more than five times the base figure of 100 for the year 1913.

The Radio Corporation of America reported yesterday that net income for the nine months to Sept. 30, amounted to $15,128,783, equal to 92 cents a common share, compared with $12,233,758, or 71 cents a share in the comparable 1947 period.

Apparently stung by the condemnation of his policy of force by the great majority of the Security Council, Premier Stalin has struck back with a statement in which he attempts to shift blame for the international crisis from the shoulders of his own Government to those of the Western Powers.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Msgr. George Hakim, Catholic Archbishop of Galilee, in an address here today, declared that the only solution for the refugee question in Palestine was an agreement for the return of all refugees to their places of origin.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 27 (AP) The Pennsylvania State Banking Board has refused to raise legal reserve requirements for state banks in line with recent action of the Federal Reserve Board.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- "Democratic socialism, which consistently fights for civil liberties, even for those with whom it violently disagrees," is the one hope of protecting liberty, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, declared here tonight.

Some critics opposing the New York public school ban on The Nation are guilty of misrepresentations and evasions, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, charged yesterday in a final report dealing with the Board of Superintendents' action against the weekly magazine.
PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Britain and China asked the Security Council today to plan sanctions against either party in Palestine that continued to defy its orders.

A Soviet diplomat can be a gentleman, even when he is a member of a United Nations commission. This was one of the few clear messages conveyed last night in "Partition," by C. Hart Schaaf, presented by Modern Play Productions at the Provincetown Playhouse.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28- A value of $43,183,624.91 was placed today on the estate of the late Charles W. Nash, an early automobile manufacturer, in an official appraisal filed in superior court. Mr. Nash died June 6 at the age of 84.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The unconditional releases of first baseman Frank McCormick and left-hand pitcher Ernie White were announced tonight by General Manager John Quinn of the Boston Braves.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Winston Churchill made a fervent defense in the House of Commons today of what is left of the Commonwealth and declared that the Conservatives would never agree to eliminating the word and the sentiment "British" from the title.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Spokesmen for the United States, British and French delegations tonight denied Premier Stalin's assertion that any agreement existed with the Soviet Union regarding a last-minute Soviet proposal on the Berlin blockade.

The cornerstone of a modern, air-conditioned two-story-and-basement building at Flatbush and Tilden Avenues, Brooklyn, housing the newest Macy's branch store, was laid yesterday morning by Mayor O'Dwyer and Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Premier Stalin charged today that the Western powers had backed out of two agreements on Berlin because their leaders were pursuing a policy of "unleashing a new war."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- Universal-International announced today that William Powell will play the leading role in "Take One False Step," a photoplay which Irwin Shaw is writing for production by Chester Erskine in January. In the film, Powell will be seen as a college professor who becomes scandalously involved with a girl.

Mayor O'Dwyer, former Postmaster General James A. Farley and Manhattan Borough President Hugo E. Rogers united yesterday in urging the election of General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen to the Surrogate's bench in New York County.

Equipment-trust investment circles were quick to note yesterday that the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's return to the orthodoxy of margined borrowing on equipment-trust obligations netted the road an interest cost about 0.40 per cent lower on $4,200,000 borrowed this week than on $5,500,000 borrowed last August.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 23 were 12 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Home politics was blamed by brokers for the quietness prevailing in the stock markets here today.

A mortgage loan of $2,077,500 has been arranged by the Underwood Mortgage and Title Company for a rental housing development in North Bergen, N.J., for which construction will begin immediately. Known as Floral Gardens, Inc., the project will contain 263 dwelling units and will be erected on a site at Twenty-sixth Street, extending from the Boulevard to Grand Avenue and to a new street to be opened in the rear of the plot.
