Like a housewife checking on the maid, Raymond C. Cruthers, superintendent of the Holland Tunnel, ran a finger over some white tile and inspected the smudge. Then he hopped from the narrow catwalk to a closed-off lane of the eastbound tube.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- Plans for modernization of Westchester's 23-year-old medical examiner system hit a snag today when county officials and Dr. Frank Dutra of Cincinnati, who was to have taken office on Jan. 1 as the new medical examiner and head of county laboratories, failed to agree.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 -- A local trade promotion office, designed to help Cleveland industry expedite consumer goods through New York Harbor to world trade centers, was opened here today by the Port of New York Authority.

David H. Hausman, an attorney, announced last night that he was negotiating with several large movie producers in an attempt to bring the movie making back East from California. Mr. Hausman said he had been the successful bidder for the Wheeler Shipbuilding Corporation's yard in Whitestone, Queens, at an auction conducted in Brooklyn yesterday at the direction of the Federal Court, which is supervising the Wheeler concern's proceedings in bankruptcy. Mr. Hausman's bid was $405,000.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 28 -- The will of Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt, was filed in Surrogate's Court here today. Mrs. Roosevelt died Sept. 30 in her home at Sagamore Hill, Oyster Bay, at the age of 87.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 28 -- The Yugoslav newspaper Politika accused Hungarian authorities today of gangsterism and the revival of Nazi methods of violence in an attempt to force Yugoslav diplomatic officials in Budapest to betray their Government to the Communist Information Bureau.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 28 -- As the two Egyptian pockets on the northern Negeb, Palestine desert area, began to crumble today. Israel opened a major political offensive to come to peace with Egypt.

A dividend of 25 cents on common, payable Dee. 15, was voted ;by the Avco Manufacturing :orporation. This brings to 40 cents [the amount declared payable to Istockholders of common stock with ;respect to the 1948 fiscal year. A previous payment of 15 cents was made in May.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Philco Corporation reported today sales of $194,156,000 for the first nine months of 1948, a new high for the company and 23 per cent above last year's $157,209,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Truman's sudden moves recently in the areas of foreign and military policy, and the move in foreign policy he almost made, seem to have been widely accepted as likely though unfortunate consequences of his effort to reverse the odds against his election.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren, GOP Vice Presidential nominee, campaigned in the agricultural San Joaquin Valley today, speaking in parks and from courthouse steps in the role of neighbor and old resident.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Paul Mueller of Basle, Switzerland, received the 1948 Nobel Prize in medicine tonight for having discovered the strong insect-killing powers of DDT.

Holding that "there can be no Christian sanction for one-sided support of either economic individualism or economic collectivism," the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America called yesterday for a perpetual Christian struggle for whatever values are most neglected in the predominant economic institutions.

Columbia and Cornell meet on the football field tomorrow for the thirty-sixth time and there is every indication that this is going to be one of the best shows they have put on since the business between these Ivy League rivals started back in the hair-pulling days of 1889.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, threw down the gantlet yesterday to left-wing leaders of New York's department store unions and announced he would fight them to the finish for control of 30,000 workers.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell modified yesterday one section of the ruling he handed down last July finding the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers guilty of violating the antitrust laws by exacting fees from theatres exhibiting motion-pictures containing ASCAP music.

For the first time in more than twenty-five years Manhattan voters are showing unusually keen interest in the election of a Surrogate in New York County, the most important local elective office at stake, and one for which three candidates are competing.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 28 (AP) -- West Virginia's 120,000 coal miners, who will take the day off to vote next Tuesday, were asked by their leaders today to support Gov. Thomas E. Dewey as "the lesser of two evils."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to defer beyond Nov. 1 the assessment of charges by railroads for unloading fresh fruit and vegetables at New York and Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Formation of a new international labor organization to succeed the three-year-old World Federation of Trade Unions depends partly on the possibility of agreement between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations that they both will join the new organization, it was reported here today.

Although few were aware of it at the time, 1,700 Bronx students have found themselves featured in a school-produced technicolor film. The idea of student leaders and faculty members at Morris High School, 166th Street and Boston Road, the Bronx, the picture will receive its public premiere at an open-house parents association meeting on the evening of Nov. 9.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 28 (AP) -- American Way, owned by Paul Mellon of the Rokeby Stables, scored his most impressive victory today when he clipped a full six and three-fifths seconds off the course record in winning the thirty-fifth running of the Chevy Chase Steeplechase Handicap.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The Public Service Commission today authorized the Surface Transportation Company, the largest bus company operating in New York City, to borrow $150,000 from Westchester Transportation Company to meet claims of its employes for back pay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Immediate recall of primary election investigators from Texas was demanded today of Senator William E. Jenner of Indiana, Republican chairman of the Senate Campaign Investigating subcommittee, by Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, minority member of the inquiry group.

A schoolboy's snack of 'bread 'n' butter and milk" had shrunken further yesterday. There was not much butter on the bread -- although the price of the spread had dropped to a new low mark for the year -- and less milk in a no longer "tall glass," because the price of milk had risen for the second time in a month.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Although the possibility of war with the Soviet Union is a matter of grave concern, Gen. Omar N. Bradley asserted tonight that there was an even greater probability that America and Russia would live in a state of tension for a generation or more.

Representatives of real estate groups opposed yesterday, at a public hearing before the City Council's committee on general welfare, a bill to require twentyfour-hour doorman service in multiple dwellings equipped with self-service elevators.

The Board of Estimate established yesterday morning a new record for brevity. Disposing of a three-item calendar in jig time, it adjourned exactly sixty-one seconds after it was called to order by Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri, who presided in the absence of Mayor O'Dwyer.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- The New Haven Railroad will take the stump for industrial expansion in southeastern Massachusetts next month, Laurence F. Whittemore, president, announced today.

Long years of waiting will end at noon tomorrow for 813 displaced persons aboard the Army Transport General Black, scheduled to dock at Pier 61, Hudson River. The group is the first of 205,000 homeless persons destined to come to the United States in the next two years under the Displaced Persons Act.

A few days ago you printed a letter from David Konopolsky deploring the ignorance of the voting public on the personalities and qualifications of candidates running for local and state office. We agree with the writer that this ignorance is deplorable, though we do not necessarily agree with his suggestions for a solution.

Voting by approximately 15,000 certified members of the Atlantic Coast District of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, on the final offer of the New York Shipping Association will take place Thursday and Friday, Benjamin Naumoff, chief of elections of the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday.
What the man will wear gets more attention in this year's edition of "Fashions of the Times" than in any of the six previous style reviews sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Past the little spotted deer, the towering elephants and the menacing rhinoceri of the man-made Asiatic jungle of the American Museum of Natural History, a large group of portraits of natives from the same distant lands were placed on a month's exhibition yesterday in the adjacent Corner Gallery.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 -- As the West Coast maritime strike entered its ninth week, Omar Hoskins, a Federal Conciliation Commissioner, announced today that the Pacific American Shipowners Association and the Congress of Industrial Organizations Marine Engineers Beneficial Association had "reached a basis of settlement subject to ratification of their respective memberships."

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The Italian Government has given satisfactory assurances to Secretary of State Marshall that it would collaborate to the limit of its possibilities with the five signatories of the Brussels Pact for a Western European union, well-informed sources said today.
Although a lifelong Democrat I recently announced my intention of voting for Governor Dewey.
MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The text of a question and answer interview by a Pravda correspondent with Premier Stalin:

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $117,073,083 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $9 a share on the capital stock.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee listed today total contributions of $1,883,516 and expenses of $2,007,287 through yesterday, leaving a deficit of $123,771.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- Rails were placed, switches were set, locomotives were polished and Pullmans greased tonight for the opening tomorrow of the biggest show of the world's largest miniature railroad -- the "Eastern Lines" operated here by fifty-five New York and Westchester bankers, lawyers, engineers and business men.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin asserted tonight that "the day is rapidly coming" when the Western democracies would be so united and strong as to "make attack impossible" and end any threat of attack.

The well-groomed foot, according to the I. Miller fall showing of shoes by David Evins seen yesterday at the Plaza Hotel, will wear a closed shoe by day and by night a simple one that relies upon its fabric rather than ornamentation for elegance.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Coach George Munger was in the training house addressing Pennsylvania's football squad today, so interviewers waiting in his office whiled away the time by reading press releases from Washington and Lee, opponent that figures to be the fifth 1948 victim of the unbeaten Quakers at Franklin Field on Saturday.

The cottonseed oil futures market continued active yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. On light offerings and scattered buying the market opened firm 10 to 15 points above the previous levels. Weakness in lard, soy beans land grain, due partly to the placing of an embargo of shipments of corn and soy beans to New Orleans, carried prices as much as 85 points below the early highs.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 28 -- The Swedish Cabinet was reconstructed today at a meeting presided over by King Gustaf, who is nearly recovered from his illness.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 28 -- The Yugoslav Government issued a statement tonight accusing regular Greek Army troops of murdering in cold blood nine wounded Yugoslav soldiers captured in a Kaimakhchala border incident the night of Sept. 6-7 and concluded its statement with announcement that it "will take most energetic steps."

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- Plans have been completed for the annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball to be held Saturday night in the Tuxedo Club. Nearly all the prominent debutantes in the New York area are expected to attend. Mrs. David Wagstaff, chairman of the ball committee, has announced that almost 300 reservations have been made.

Predicting an enthusiastic demonstration for Governor Dewey, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, made public yesterday the detailed program for tomorrow night's Republican rally in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Truman has released another $154,817,000 of Air Force funds for the purchase of 125 planes of various types, including bombers, and the modernization of those now in production, it was announced tonight.

Formation of a committee to negotiate more favorable debt adjustment terms for war-defaulted Italian corporate dollar bonds than those proposed last December by the Italian Republic was made known yesterday in a communication directed to bondholders by Thatcher C. Jones, a professor of finance at New York University.

Formation of a committee to negotiate more favorable debt adjustment terms for war-defaulted Italian corporate dollar bonds than those proposed last December by the Italian Republic was made known yesterday in a communication directed to bondholders by Thatcher C. Jones, a professor of finance at New York University.

Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, emphasized on his arrival at La Guardia Field yesterday that the Marshall Plan was working in Europe despite Communist opposition. Mr. Hoffman was returning from his recent survey in Europe.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins won their fourth straight National Hockey League game tonight as they defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 1, before 16,312 at Chicago's home opener.

The Republican National Committee made public yesterday a letter from the Brooklyn Council, Veterans of Foreign Wars, repudiating a report allegedly made to the council by James V. Mackin, one of its members, in which he had described Governor Dewey as a critic of Civil Service employes.

Mrs. Leo Freed of Rye, N.Y., heads the committee in charge of the sale of tickets for the performance of "Life With Mother" on the night of Nov. 8 at the Empire Theatre for the benefit of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver.

Austria has spent $3,194,037 of the $10,000,000 credit granted by the Export-Import Bank for purchases of surplus goods from the War Assets Administration, E. R. Wachner, representative here of the Austrian Government, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it would proceed with a previously postponed hearing to determine whether it should revoke or suspend the broker-dealer registration of Otis Co., Cleveland investment banking firm, as a result of its participation in the recent $10,000,000 common stock offering of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.
Formation of a new men's wear group which will develop and establish style trends and coordinate their promotion within member stores was announced here yesterday.

Willis J. Ballinger, economic consultant to the House Small Business Committee, denied yesterday that he had made the statement purportedly attributed to him by Marshall J. Mantler, managing director of the Bureau of Salesmen's National Associations, to the effect that the threat of Federal investigation and potential prosecution which hung over salesmen's markets in the men's wear, women's and children's apparel and footwear fields had been removed.

The sixth annual home inspection sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council with the cooperation of the Police Department and the Board of Education got under way yesterday when policemen distributed 1,050,000 home inspection questionnaire forms designed to test the safety of the home for the people living in it.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 (UP) -- A Baltimore court was told today that scalpers had "connived" with some midshipmen of the United States Naval Academy to obtain "large numbers" of tickets for the Navy-Notre Dame football game at Municipal Stadium Saturday.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 28 -- The pro-lady Scotch foursome tournament sponsored by a group from the Baltusrol and Essex County Country Clubs was won today by Harold Sanderson of Canoe Brook playing selected drives and alternate shots with Mrs. C.A. Foehl of Essex County. They carded 73 -- 5 -- 68.

With meat supplies more than adequate for the demand in wholesale markets, retail stores have dropped prices on several cuts today. Steer beef is particularly plentiful and six cuts are down 2 to .8 cents since last Friday. Loin lamb chops, 95 cents a pound, and shoulder lamb chops, 79 cents, both are 4 cents less than they were a week ago.

George Nelson, architect and furniture designer, declared yesterday that the trend in houses is toward an industrially produced shell, and that nothing short of the cessation of building itself will stop the development. The designer visualized that the shell will some day include the functions of many types of furniture and will assume most of the burden of illumination.

Japanese textile producers have cut prices on cottons for the Far Eastern market, apparently with the consent of the Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers (SCAP), it was learned yesterday from New York exporters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Representative John Taber of New York, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said today that he expects to get along all right with Thomas E. Dewey if the latter is elected President.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Robert E. Doherty, beleaguered president of Carnegie Tech, today had some support from another college president with football troubles.

The first full-scale experiment in one-way avenue traffic through congested mid-Manhattan will start on Nov. 6 on Ninth and Tenth Avenues, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, making his first major effort in behalf of the Truman candidacy last night, vigorously attacked Governor Dewey's claims of social progress in New York State during the six years of the Dewey state regime.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The French Government may ask Parliament in January to approve a customs union with Italy and to authorize the drafting of a plan for unifying tariffs and fiscal legislation of the two countries, according to officials dealing with this question.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Calling for "a complete and frank showdown" with Russia, the fundamentalist American Council of Christian Churches, representing fifteen self-styled "Bible-believing" Protestant denominations, opened its seventh annual convention here today.

GAGETOWN, N.B., Oct. 28 -- One of the interesting features of the shooting in this area is its variety, and this morning we moved up the Saint John River to the mouth of the Jemseg and for the first time in our experience shot from what they call a "canoe blind."

The sun was shining in London last Tuesday and also over large areas of the United States. In London the bright rays were reflected from the silver breastplates of the household cavalry escorting King George and Queen Elizabeth to the opening of Parliament.

With buses rolling normally in all parts of the city, leaders of the rival union factions in the "stoppage that turned into a strike" made conflicting claims yesterday as to the impact of the two-day bus tie-up on the battle between right and left-wing groups for control of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University announced yesterday that the University Council has confirmed the appointment of Dr. Samuel A. Brown, past president of the New York Academy of Medicine, and dean emeritus of the New York University College of Medicine, as acting chairman of the board of trustees of the New York University -Bellevue Medical Center.

President Truman toured nine miles of city streets through twilight and early dark yesterday. It was a campaign visit. He got the traditional greeting -- spiraling ticker tape, storms of con fetti, lanes of red fire to light his way. The populace's cheers, by all local standards, were restrained.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey advocated tonight a broad expansion of Federal social benefits and promised the program would have "the enthusiastic support" of a Republican Congress, which, up to now, has turned down similar recommendations by President Truman.

The general housing situation, the trend toward smaller apartments and overcrowding, has resulted in more foster homes being lost each month than are being replaced. Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard said yesterday.

ATLANTA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, leader in the Southern fight against President Truman's civil rights program, pledged today to vote for Mr. Truman in the general election. The Georgian, who received 263 Southern votes for the nomination for President at the Democratic National Convention, said he would vote a straight Democratic ticket.

Homemakers who have always loved blue and have mourned its absence from most recent furnishings displays will be happy to find it back again in the leading interior at Loeser's new Modern Galleries, which opened yesterday.

Rushing in where bigger organizations and proprietors of bigger stages fear to tread, the New York City Opera Company gave its first production of "Aida" last night in the City Center, performing the opera with so much intelligence and spirit and so many good if not great voices in the cast, that it got away with it in an exceptionally communicative and exciting fashion.

The general housing situation, the trend toward smaller apartments and overcrowding, has resulted in more foster homes being lost each month than are being replaced. Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard said yesterday.

ATLANTA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, leader in the Southern fight against President Truman's civil rights program, pledged today to vote for Mr. Truman in the general election. The Georgian, who received 263 Southern votes for the nomination for President at the Democratic National Convention, said he would vote a straight Democratic ticket.

Homemakers who have always loved blue and have mourned its absence from most recent furnishings displays will be happy to find it back again in the leading interior at Loeser's new Modern Galleries, which opened yesterday.

Rushing in where bigger organizations and proprietors of bigger stages fear to tread, the New York City Opera Company gave its first production of "Aida" last night in the City Center, performing the opera with so much intelligence and spirit and so many good if not great voices in the cast, that it got away with it in an exceptionally communicative and exciting fashion.

Production of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in the first nine months of this year "reached the highest level for a comparable peacetime period in the company's history," Walter S. Carpenter Jr., board chairman, declared in the report of operation mailed to stockholders today.

Office management executives responsible for planning work loads are partially to blame for current high office operating costs, H.T. Whitley, systems engineer, Arthur Andersen Company, declared yesterday. He spoke at opening sessions of a two-day convention of the Office Executives Association of New York, Inc., in the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

The authority given the Legislature by constitutional amendment to provide a Tenth Judicial District was another instance of the warping of the fundamental law for partisan political purposes. The up-state Republicans in New York have been doing that sort of thing for at least a century.
NEW LEXINGTON, Ohio, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Sunnyhill Coal Company has developed a giant mechanical coal digger which may triple the output of today's mechanized mines.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled here today that the Pittsburgh Railways Company is not now subject to the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Louis Tartaglione, 33 years old, of 297 Avenue X, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to an indictment charging him with stealing, forging and cashing a United States Treasury check for $76.50.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- City governments took in and spent more money last year than ever before, the census bureau reported today.

The largest shipment of cement mill machinery ever loaded for transportation in one consignment will leave tonight on the S.S. Pierre de Saurel, from pier 28, East River, bound for a new $6,000,000 public works cement plant of the French Government at Ben Arous, Tunis, North Africa.

A collection of the best stories, poems and pictures selected from St. Nicholas magazine has been edited by Henry Steele Commager, who is better known as the editor of two histories: "America in Perspective: The United States Through Foreign Eyes" and "Tocqueville's Democracy in America."

The City Planning Commission adopted yesterday a proposed capital outlay budget of $308,857,199 for 1949, the largest in its ten years of existence. The proposed budget, covering the calendar year beginning Jan. 1, 1949, consists of recommendations on sums to be spent on permanent improvements to be financed by city bonds or other municipal securities.

Asserting that there is no hope for adequate housing under a Republican Federal administration, former Governor Herbert H. Lehman last night assailed Governor Dewey for failure to use his position as leader of the Republican party to insist upon tile Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress passing the Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill at the special session called by President Truman.

Sandy Saddler became the featherweight champion of the world last night by knocking out Willie Pep of Hartford, Conn., in four rounds. In one of the biggest ring upsets of the year, the spindly Negro from Harlem stretched the defending titleholder on the canvas for the full count with a left hook to the jaw after the round had gone 2 minutes 38 seconds.

A feast for the eyes were the colorful print frocks seen this week in their springtime hues in "Fashions of the Times" Illustrating how colors filter through each field of fashion, they were displayed in a novel manner in the Colorscope scene with coats and suits, each print following a coat or suit and echoing its tone.

When old-timers complain vaguely that things aren't what they used to be, members of the younger generation within earshot are inclined to assume an air of patience -- or impatience, if they be ill-mannered -- and hope that the inevitable reminiscence will be brief.

With only two of the nation's seven major unbeaten-and-untied elevens facing foemen worthy of their steel, second-flight powers will supply most of the competitive wallop in today's campus football. In its number of prospectively close matches between good, if not great, teams, October's final Saturday offers by far the best program of the season.
MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Despite protests by German churchmen the United States Army went ahead today with the execution of Nazis convicted of war atrocities.

President Truman urges the observance of "Universal Bible Sunday," on Dec. 12 in a statement released at the White House and made public yesterday by the American Bible Society at its headquarters, 450 Park Avenue. The Chief Executive also endorsed the promotion of the world-wide Bible reading of identical passages daily from Thanksgiving to Christmas Both movements are under the sponsorship of the Bible Society President Truman said:

Mrs. William C. Breed will give reception Wednesday afternoon at River House for members of committees actively interested in plans for the Bal des Symphonies, which will be held Nov. 16 at the Plaza to augment the pension fund of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Industrial supply and equipment manufacturers and distributors have increased their combined national sales goal $1,000,000,000 for 1949, aiming at a target of $6,000,000,000, compared with $5,000,000,000 last year.

DUBLIN, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Ireland, soon to become an independent republic, will not enter any defense arrangement with Great Britain until the six counties of Northern Ireland are joined to it, Minister for External Affairs Sean MacBride announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- The "solid front" presented by West Coast maritime unions since the start of their strike on Sept. 2 was broken today with the ratification and signing of an agreement by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and the Pacific American Shipowners Association.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The Burmese Foreign Minister, U Kyaw Nyein, who is on a private visit to London after attending the United Nations General Assembly in Paris, said here today that Burma was receiving arms and technical military advice from Britain under the terms of the Anglo-Burmese defense agreement.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 29 (UP) -- A spokesman for United Nations headquarters said in Haifa tonight that Israeli forces were attacking the Arabs over a wide front in northern Palestine, between Tarbicha and Lake Hule.
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Britain told the United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today that it could count on her full collaboration for the successful attainment of all its tasks.

John Haynes Holmes, minister of the Community Church, urged last night the support of George Frankenthaler, Republican candidate for Surrogate in New York County, Speaking over station WMCA, Mr. Holmes said a Surrogate should be learned in the law and of such integrity as to command the confidence of the community.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The French non-Communist unions today ended their participation in the coal strike. The Workers Force and the Christian Workers have accented the Government's terms and ordered their members to return to the pits on Tuesday or as soon as they can be protected.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll urged tonight the election of Thomas E. Dewey as a move to start "operation unsnarl" over what he called a bureaucracy-mad National Administration.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- It was made obvious here today that if Premier Stalin, with his Socratic dialogue yesterday, sought to bewilder Britain and Western Europe, he had succeeded; if he sought to shake them, he had failed. Even the highest officials frankly agreed that they could not divine Mr. Stalin's motives, but the firmest reaffirmations were made that Berlin would be held.
NORTH ATTLEBORO, Mass., Oct. 29 -- A lot of unusual things happened in this southern Massachusetts town of 12,500 today.

Coffee futures were firm on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. New highs were established in the distant delivery positions. Prices at the close were 15 to 33 points above the previous levels.

Freedom has ended in Czechoslovakia, eighteen families from that country agreed yesterday on their arrival by plane from Paris at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The families were brought here under the auspices of the Joint Distribution Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today denounced the French coal miners' strike as Communist-inspired, directed by the "Communist Fifth Column" to overthrow the French Government and establish Communist control.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- How much comic magazines affect crime was debated here today by James V. Bennett, Director of Prisons, and Henry E. Schultz, executive director of the Association of Comic Magazine publishers.

The hazards of lighthouse tending extended into New York Harbor yesterday when two lightkeepers were overcome by coal gas fumes at the tiny tower called West Bank Light on the border of Ambrose Channel. They were rescued speedily by boat, raft and amphibious airplane.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- President Truman asked Americans today to renew "their devotion to the cause of enduring peace" on Nov. 11, the thirtieth anniversary of the armistice ending World War I.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Developments of significance in the field of television are reflected in the new and improved technical devices included among the 504 inventions approved this week by the United States Patent Office.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress, sent a telegram yesterday to President Truman suggesting that his statement on Israel in Madison square Garden on Thursday night should be made a directive to the United States delegation in the United Nations.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund voted $6,000,000 today for aid to Palestine refugees, but the question of direct and immediate United Nations aid was postponed by the United Nations Social Affairs Committee until tomorrow after a three-and-a-half-hour session.
The New York City Federation of Women's Clubs decided yesterday that landlords must be curbed from taking advantage of tenants during the housing shortage.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 29 -- Tension between the United States and Russia prevents the United Nations from freeing and unifying Korea, the organization's Korean Commission will report to the General Assembly in Paris.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Remnants of grandeur in the home of Charles R. Thomas were found by police today in a search of the house at 38 Leslie Street here where Mr. Thomas's body was found Wednesday by a neighbor three days after his death.
ATHENS, Oct. 29 -- A decree signed and issued by the Cabinet tonight extended martial law over all of Greece.

The United States Government has avoided a delicate situation resulting from the dispute between Israel and the Arab states by ordering calls of the emergency class passenger ship Marine Carp at Beirut and Alexandria canceled, it was learned yesterday. The vessel is scheduled to leave here on Nov. 3.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Registration statements covering $27,000,000 of bonds, 136,000 shares of preferred stock and 20,000 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by five companies.

A crowning feature of "Fashions of the Times," which closed last night, was the millinery. It is prophetic of brims to come. Inasmuch as it is possible to anticipate what will be worn in the sun-drenched days of spring and in tropical climates before the first snow flurry has hit New York, leading designers stitched straw braids and molded felts into 1949 silhouettes.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Citation and Jockey Eddie Arcaro went for a $10,000 stroll today in the Pimlico Special.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The Municipal Council of Paris tonight canceled the reception it had scheduled to give tomorrow night in the City Hall in honor of the delegates to the United Nations General Assembly.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 29 -- An Israeli Government spokesman said tonight that the United Nations Security Council's discussion of the war in Palestine was being conducted with a "complete lack of reality."

A man who lost his American citizenship by joining the Nazi party and serving in the German Army during the war arrived here yesterday to press a court suit through which he hopes to regain his citizenship.

The revolt of a part of the Army in southern Peru was the third armed up-rising in that country in five months. This and a previous abortive revolt by an Army garrison led by Lieut. Col. Llosa in June were revolutionary actions by the Right. That at Callao earlier this month, in which some Peruvian Navy units joined, was led by the Leftist Apra party.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- The fundamentalist American Council of Christian Churches today denounced the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America and the recently formed World Council of Churches as "cooperating fronts for world socialism." The council also called on its adherents to oppose the appointment of John Foster Dulles to "either the position of Secretary of State or representative of the United States in the United Nations."
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Maryland Terps routed the University of Miami football team, 27 -- 13, in the Orange Bowl tonight before 35,304 fans.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 29 -- A remarkable salvage feat was completed today when the Huddard Parker liner Wanganella, 9,875 tons, which was wrecked on Barrett's Reef at the entrance to Wellington harbor in January, 1947, underwent successful flotation tests after having nearly one-third of her bottom renewed in a floating dock.

President Truman bore down hard on "Republican high prices" in his metropolitan appearances yesterday and told a night gathering of 700 in Lost Battalion Hall, Queens, that housewives understood very well the issues of the campaign.
MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Youth organizations representing more than 33,000,000 members promised Premier Stalin today to defend the interests of the Soviet state "under any conditions and at any cost."
The futures market closed 4 to 8 points lower on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday under rather light trading.

Afternoon and evening fashions figured prominently in the showing of twenty-five original models from the winter collection of the house of Caller Soeurs of Paris and 230 Park Avenue, seen yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.
Halloween this year may be remembered with shudders by many adults as an exhausting three-day unofficial holiday, but by some youngsters as a prolonged gleeful one.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 -- Navy and Notre Dame meet tomorrow in Babe Ruth Stadium with the Irish heavily favored to maintain their invincibility against all comers through their twenty-fourth successive football game. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 o'clock.

Reaffirming his hope that the joint Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati and Jewish Institute of Religion of New York "will become the equivalent of a great university of American Judaism," Dr. Nelson Glueck was installed last night as president of the institute. He was named to head both schools when they were combined on June 16.

Max Ausnit, former Rumanian industrialist who is currently being tried at Bucharest in absentia on treason charges, yesterday branded the trial as a farce and denied he had ever plotted to overthrow the Government of Rumania.

President Truman covered thirty-six sunlit miles on the second day of his New York campaign tour yesterday. The route took him from midtown Manhattan to Yonkers and back and almost every foot of it was a kind of triumphal journey. He covered another thirty-odd miles to Brooklyn and Queens in the night phase of his campaign.

A unique show of the week is of work by the "primitive" painter, Victor Joseph Gatto, at the Charles Barzansky Gallery, 644 Madison Avenue. This self-taught artist delights in lush jungle scenes, turning from them occasionally to do widespread panoramas of countryside in painstaking detail.

Buying interest dwindled further yesterday on the stock market, and although a faint firmness crept into the proceedings, the list on the Stock Exchange closed lower on balance. The continued hesitancy of traders to assume a position comparable to that of last week was translated into a further contraction in volume with transfers on the Exchange at 860,000 shares, against 970,000 shares on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, announced today that his department would go on a "peace-or-war" basis on Nov. 15, when a major reorganization would prepare the service for any eventuality.

The civil rights promises given by President Truman in Harlem yesterday afternoon were called "hollow and worthless" last night by Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, at a rally in the same district.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Theodore C. Link, St. Louis newspaper man, asserted today that indictments returned against him were the "product of the prejudicial, personal domination of Attorney General George F. Barrett." He asked that they be quashed.

Issuance of a commitment by the Federal Housing Administration for insurance of a $425,000 mortgage for construction of a six-story fireproof apartment house at 21 Hamilton Terrace, near City College in upper Manhattan, was announced yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, New York State director of the FHA.
DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production in the United States and Canada this week will total 116,413 units, Ward's automotive reports estimated today.

Two of the one-man art exhibitions this week offer the work of a traditionalist, Ernest Lawson, and a young abstract painter, John Grillo. At the Milch Gallery twenty-three oils by Lawson, the well-known American impressionist who died in 1939, are on view.
DETROIT, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Nine Michigan postmasters told a Congressional subcommittee today that John R. Franco, State Democratic Chairman, solicited campaign contributions from them.
Warring left and right wing factions within the Transport Workers Union, CIO, battled again yesterday, this time with the leftists taking the offensive in a suit filed in Supreme Court.

Not for a long time had this writer heard such a talent allied with the musicianship, the feeling, the intelligence and artistic balance shown by the 20-year-old pianist, Byron Janis, who made his New York debut last night in Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Hewlett Johnson, the "Red Dean" of Canterbury, has left Britain for a coast-to-coast American speaking tour.

LAWFIELD, N.B., Oct. 29 -- For some years we had heard of the deer hunting on the Otnabog Barrens and after a very full day of tramping over bogs, high hills, hardack, burns and blowdowns we know a lot more about the Otnabog hunting but not a bit more about the Otnabog deer.

NANKING, Oct. 29 -- Private advices from Mukden said today that Manchuria's leading city, cold, bleak and unprotected by any large holding force, was now at the virtual mercy of the Communists and that the Government's whole plan for evacuating the northeast had gone awry as a result of the difficulties encountered by the Nationalist troops in the Tahushan area.

VIENNA, Oct. 29 -- The Allied council for Austria was the scene today of another disagreement between the three Western delegates and the Soviet representative over the training and control of the Austrian police.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- A poll of college students last week showed that 73.9 per cent favor Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican, for President, according to the National Institute of College Opinion Surveys. The study covered 3,200 young men and women in colleges with a total enrollment of 28.000. President Truman won only 10.7 per cent of the votes.

Rabbi Israel Goldstein will observe his thirtieth anniversary as the spiritual head of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun at the service this morning in the 123-year-old synagogue on Eighty-eighth Street, west of Broadway.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- With this city's 270-man police force mobilized for the occasion of President Truman's visit, three thugs invaded a private residence this morning and at the point of a pistol robbed the wife of a jeweler of an estimated $6,500 in gems.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- The special grand jury reported today that "disgraceful laxity" on the part of W. Frank Marshall, receiver of taxes, and other city officials was largely responsible for amusement tax embezzlements exceeding $203,000.

Lumber production during the week ended Oct. 23 rose 3 per cent above the preceding week and was practically above the corresponding week last year. Shipments were 5.8 per cent below a year ago and orders 7.9 per cent lower, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A Texas rancher's rescue of a child and aid to others trapped in a blizzard won the highest award today among twenty-four Carnegie Hero Fund recipients in seventeen states.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 29 -- Secretary of State Fred M. Alger Jr. late today waived technicalities and agreed to accept a certified party list of the nineteen Democratic party electors tomorrow, twenty days after the deadline for qualifying electors.

In the wake of the police decision to make Ninth and Tenth Avenues one-way thoroughfares the Surface Transportation Company has decided to abandon bus operation on Tenth and Amsterdam Avenues, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Truman underscored the importance of Turkish political independence and territorial integrity to the security of the United States "and of all freedom-loving peoples" in a statement recorded by the Voice of America and broadcast over its facilities to Turkey and other countries today.

There are, according to the Census Bureau, about 95,000,000 persons of voting age in this country. Of these a little more than two-thirds, or nearly 67,000,000, have registered or otherwise qualified for voting next Tuesday. Of these again, the best estimates we can get are that about 51,000,000 will actually vote.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 29 -- A superbly balanced Dartmouth eleven will invade Yale Bowl tomorrow, seeking its first victory over the Eli since 1943. A sellout crowd of 65,000 will attend the thirty-second meeting of the Ivy League rivals in a series which began in 1884.

Senator Brien McMahon proposed yesterday that the United Nations operate its own radio stations and newspapers in all the Big Five countries. This might enable the organization to fulfill its primary purpose as "town meeting of the world," he asserted.
Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Nov. 16 on bond issues totaling $4,000,000. Dated Dec. 1, 1948, the bonds will come due Dec. 1 from 1949 to 1978.

When Dr. Paul Mueller was in this country three years ago he gave a simple account of the researches which he directed and which led to the synthesis of dichloro-diphenyl-trichloro-ethane, mercifully shortened to DDT, and to field tests on crops that were threatened with destruction by the Colorado potato beetle and other pests.

Harold E. Stassen, chairman of the American Heart Association 1949 national campaign, announced yesterday that William E. Cotter, general counsel of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, had been appointed executive vice chairman of the drive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Democratic National Committee reported today that its campaign receipts through last Wednesday had been $1.683,193 and disbursements had totaled $1,674,760. It reported also that it had $95,000 of loans receivable and $151,414 in unpaid bills.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Reportedly on direct intervention of President Truman, the United States delegation withdrew support today of the Anglo-Chinese resolution asking for consideration of sanctions against either party in Palestine that ignored the United Nations Security Council's order for restoration of the Negeb truce line.

Independent Producers of Giveaway Show to Discuss 'Sniping' Independent producers of giveaway shows will meet at 12:30 P.M. on Monday at the Hotel Biltmore to decide what steps may be taken to defend such programs from attacks in many quarters.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The Government's steel nationalization bill, published today, carries the Socialist administration into entirely new fields. For the first time the Government will take over a manufacturing industry -- or most of it -- and will compete with private concerns within that industry.

Five or six minutes prior to the start of the chief bit of business before the house at Jamaica yesterday -- it was a run for sub-junior varsity 3-year-olds -- five of the ten contestants had 9-to-2 listings on the odds board. Then C.V. Whitney's Ghost Run became the clear-cut favorite, and Grant Thorn's Andy Handy was made the second choice.

Teachers must respect the de-I sires of parents not to have their[ children turned against them orI their cherished ideals, Dr. WoolfI Colvin, principal of Seward Park High School, declared last night

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- William C. Bullitt, appointed earlier today as a special Congressional agent to Nationalist China, told The United Press tonight that he would investigate "all phases" of American aid to the Chiang Kai-shek Government.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 29 -- The army tonight deposed Jose Luis Bustamante y Rivero as President of Peru as a three-day revolt in the south spread to the nation's capital.

Reporting on operations of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, Robert V. White, president, informed shareholders yesterday that the final quarter of the year is expected to be highly profitable and that "everything indicates our consolidated net income for 1948 will be greater than any year since 1926."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that Mrs. Dorothy S. Thackrey has a right to offer her West Coast radio properties for sale on an all-or-none basis.

FAIRCHILD, Wis., Oct. 29 -This village of about 700 persons plans to fight hard against a ruling of the State Board of Medical Examiners which will prevent a refugee Polish doctor on his way to this country from a German displaced persons camp from practicing medicine in Wisconsin.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The overshadowing concern of American policymakers in Paris is the interregnum between the election and the inauguration. It is assumed on all sides that the Republicans will be voted in and that international tension will heighten in the next two months.

Joseph Froggatt Co., consulting actuaries, has developed a new "yardstick" for employe benefit plans set up on the understanding that increased employe productivity will enable employers to defray their cost, Paul A. Turner, assistant chief actuary, disclosed yesterday.

If your child has trouble in learning to read or has difficulty with his other school subjects, it is likely that he lacks emotional security or feels that he is unwanted. Poor readers, as a rule, are unhappy children and are badly maladjusted.

With the three major Presidential candidates in New York yesterday more than 50 per cent of the city's 17,850 police were on special political details for the first time in the recent history of the department.
A 24-year-old father pleaded guilty yesterday before County Judge James M. Barrett in the Bronx, to a ten-count indictment of grand larceny. He faces a possible sentence of 100 years in prison.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- In a direct attack upon the Truman administration for "gyrations" and blunders, Gov. Earl Warren took the President to task tonight for campaign methods involving use of terms such as "pitchforkers, gluttons and saboteurs."

The three-story apartment building also containing a store at 4023 Thirteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Louis Shilin to Rose Mirsky. The property is assessed at $42,000. Harry Dworkin was the broker in the transaction, in which a purchase money mortgage of $25,000 was executed at the closing.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- The United States, British and French commandants of Berlin authorized the City Council today to distribute 22,000 tons of coal for home heating. [The ration will average about twenty pounds a person, The Associated Press said.]

The problem of placing Negro children in foster homes has grown more acute with the tearing down of old-time large family houses in areas given to Negro occupancy, officials of the Riverdale Children's Association of 223 East Thirtieth Street declared yesterday.

ON DEWEY TRAIN, EN ROUTE TO NEW YORK, Oct. 29 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey brought his campaign travels to a close today with a declaration that "Europe must federate or perish" and he held out the hope that a united Europe, given American aid, could roll back the Iron Curtain.

Election day referendums on local government bond issues totaling more than $1,200,000,000 hold out more interest to bond houses than the week's schedule of new issues of securities, a scanty one compared with those of recent weeks.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has seen fit to devote three editorial columns -- in the issues of Oct. 12, 14 and 15 -- to urging my defeat as the member of Congress from the Eighteenth Congressional District, New York, an office I have held for six terms.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The country had a small cut in traffic deaths from last year as it began the last and most dangerous quarter of 1948 in terms of driving hazards, according to the National Safety Council. It reported today that September's death toll was up 4 per cent, the second month this year to show an increase over 1947.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 29. -- Soviet-Finnish relations as exemplified by the attitude of Lieut. Gen. G.M. Savonenkov, Soviet envoy, toward the Finnish Government have cooled lately.
Brightly colored necklaces and dangling earrings illuminated the fashions seen on the stage of Times Hall in the production of "Alice in Videoland," which closed last evening.
Today 813 displaced persons will arrive in the land of their dreams.

Housewives interested in cutting down to a minimum the time they spend in the kitchen are finding food manufacturers most cooperative. This is the impression we received during a tour of grocery stores yesterday. Three of the new items we saw are prepared products that may be whipped up in a short time with very little effort.

While still subject to governmental review on its legality under the TaftHartley law, the agreement between the American Federation of Musicians and the record companies offers an interesting commentary on James C. Petrillo's concept of union leadership.
The Los Angeles Dons went through a two-hour workout at Ebbets Field yesterday in preparation for the clash with the Brooklyn Dodgers tomorrow at the Brooklyn ball park.

Representatives of the International Nickel Company's sales organizations and distributers were urged last night to prepare for an increasing number of buyers' markets. The occasion was a dinner closing the company's twenty-fifth annual sales conference, attended by more than 300 persons in the Commodore Hotel.

The performance of Jean-Paul Sartre's play "Red Gloves," starring Charles Boyer, at the Mansfield Theatre on Dee. 14 has been taken over by the Homemaker Service of the Children's Aid Society. Mrs. John B. Marsh is chairman of the committee for the event, and Mrs. Louis G. Bissell, Mrs. Basil B. Elmer and Mrs. K. Tod Martin are vice chairmen.

The Department of Housing and Buildings is being overwhelmed with a record volume of tenant complaints and charges of multiple-dwelling violations, it became known yesterday. Bernard J. Gillroy, head of the department, estimated that the complaints would reach the new high mark of 150,000 this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Early abandonment of Communist attempts to sabotage the European Recovery Program by strikes in basic Continental industries was forecast today by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The anti-Communist Workers Force and Christian Workers wrote today to John L. Lewis asking him to refrain from helping the Communists in a battle against France. They told Mr. Lewis he was helping to break down the Marshall Plan.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Reorganization of the Mexican Baseball League was announced today as a step toward forming a new circuit next season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Four-fifths of employers who are subject to the Wage-Hour Law will have to rearrange wage schedules as a result of the Supreme Court's recent overtime-pay decision, a spokesman for the United States Chamber of Commerce said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Los Angeles police, pursuing their campaign against the traffic in marijuana, last night arrested Huntz Hall, 28, film and stage actor and member of the original New York "Dead End Kids." He was the second film figure taken into custody in the drive, his arrest following by just two months that of Robert Mitchum.

The finest blooms from gardens and greenhouses on Long Island were sent to the fall flower show which opened yesterday afternoon at Burrwood, the estate of Mrs. Walter Jennings, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. This annual event is presented by the Nassau County Horticultural Society with the cooperation of local garden clubs, the Westbury Horticultural Society, the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society and many volunteer workers.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Danish Parliament today granted the Danish-American Prospecting Company the right to continue exploration and exploitation of raw materials in Denmark's subsoil for six months.

The officers composing the international military jumping teams of Mexico, France and Canada began arriving in New York yesterday for the National Horse Show that starts its eight-day run in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The eleventh quarterly report of overseas disposals of surplus United States Government wartime property of the Foreign Liquidation Commission was submitted to Congress today showing that it has practically completed its work.

Expressing complete confidence in his election, President Truman again criticized Governor Dewey, his Republican opponent, last night for dragging American foreign policy into the campaign, attacked the Republican party as a force of isolationism and reaction and asserted that continuance of a Democratic Administration in Washington offered the best hope for world peace.

Walter Russell, sculptor and president-emeritus of the Society of Arts and Sciences, has bought a rundown mansion and 500-acre estate in the Blue Ridge section of Virginia and will convert the house into a museum of his own work for "posterity," it was learned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 -- John McDowell, Republican member of the Congressional Committee on Un-American Affairs and a candidate for re-election from the Twenty-ninth District of Pennsylvania, was denounced today by a citizens committee of Pittsburgh which included six nationally known scientists.

Buyers seeking replacement of fast-moving stocks of women's fall and winter coats have found the market almost entirely cleaned out, it was learned yesterday. Prime resource houses have no merchandise in stock and coats in production are already accounted for, they said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Responses to a questionnaire, submitted to Democratic Senators and candidates for the Senate from the South, suggest that the Democratic party may not be able to organize the Senate in the event it wrests control in point of numbers, from the Republicans next Tuesday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Herbert L. Forest, assistant director of the Dairy Branch, United States Department of Agriculture, said today that "it is totally destructive" for the various groups in the nation's milk industry to blame the Government for increases in the price of milk.

Governor Dewey returned to New York late yesterday afternoon following a day of back-platform appearances in New England, prepared to make the climactic speech of his campaign for President at a Republican rally tonight in Madison Square Garden.
Governor Dewey, Republican nominee, has the support of 771 newspapers, or 65.17 per cent of the nation's dailies in hid bid for the Presidency, Editor and Publisher said yesterday.

Alexander Kontorowicz, violinist, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall before an enthusiastic audience. After studying in Poland, Russia and Germany Mr. Kontorowicz toured Europe. Later he became concert violinist to the King of Egypt, and for the last four years has been court violinist to the Emperor of Ethiopia.

Magistrate Hyman Bushel in Lower Manhattan Court issued summonses yesterday for David Feldman, 34 years old, of 19 Pitt Street, and his wife, Mrs. Zelda Feldman, 75, to face charges of receiving home relief by fraud. On Monday Feldman had been found guilty of disorderly conduct by the same magistrate.

The parcel 20 by 50 feet at 1177 Sixth Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-sixth Street, formerly owned by the Board of Transportation, has been leased by the Avamer Realty Corporation consisting of Ralph Kirsh and Joseph Stutz, operators of the Economy Sandwich Shops, to a syndicate composed of Charles Linksman and Max Rector.
ROME, Oct. 29 -- Premier Stalin's interview produced widely divergent reactions in Italian public opinion.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Stock exchange officials of seven American countries today urged their Government to "assure absolute freedom for financial operations as soon as possible."

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Friends of John Foster Dulles, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's principal adviser on foreign affairs, said today he had not taken part in the formulation of the United States policy regarding possible imposition of sanctions against Israel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Emery J. Woodall, an examiner for the Federal Power Commission, recommended today that the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation of Houston, Tex., owner of the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines, be authorized to increase its gas delivery capacity by 75,000,000 cubic feet a day.

After a second taste of prison life, Stuart Zane Perkoff, an 18-year-old actor who was the first person arrested in this area for evasion of the 1948 Selective Service Act, changed his mind yesterday about refusing to register.

A small black and white spitz named Princess starred in yesterday's Halloween Hazing ceremony at Hunter College. The upper classmen gave Princess, who is owned by Vigee Lester. a junior, to the freshman class as the official class mascot.

Nathan Katz, 43-year-old Brownsville hoodlum, a one-time inmate of San Quentin, felt yesterday the full impact of Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald's determination to break the underworld code that forbids even the victim of an armed assault to inform on his gangland assailant.

Warning his charges that it would be "a serious mistake" to underestimate the Chicago Rockets, whom they meet in an All-America Conference game at the Stadium tomorrow, Coach Red Strader sent the football Yankees through a long defensive drill yesterday.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Moscow radio, following up Premier Stalin's attack on the Western powers Thursday, broadcast the text of a Berlin agreement he said had been submitted by the Soviet Union but had been rejected by the United States, French and British delegates.

Nine "town meetings," at which "sharp and constructive criticism" is to be invited on every phase of the advertising trade, will feature the 4-A's Eastern Annual Conference Nov. 15 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday. Gordon E. Hyde of Federal Advertising Agency, Inc., who heads the conference-sponsoring New York Council, described the plan as "breaking sharply with tradition."

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- About 210,000 railway clerks and freight handlers could be put on a Monday-through Friday forty-hour week with no dislocation in railroad operations, George M. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, said today.
ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A statewide building code to set up standards for all construction was proposed today at the convention of the New York State Association of Architects.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- Sparked by Bobby Gage, who put on a one-man aerial show, Clemson College remained one of the nation's undefeated and untied football teams tonight by beating Boston College, 26 -- 19, before 25,169 persons at Braves Field.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- More than 100 representatives of little theatres throughout the state registered tonight for the third annual Community Theatre Conference at Cornell, sponsored by the Departments of Rural Sociology, Speech and Drama.

For all the gloomy forebodings of the last few months, Broadway should have reason for optimism so far as the next four weeks are concerned, at least. A glance at the theatrical schedule for November discloses eight likely candidates ready and willing to chance the collective appraisal or disapproval of the critical fraternity.

Wesley Clair Mitchell, who died here yesterday in his seventy-fifth year, rated by common consent and by any conceivable test the appellation of dean of American economists. For many years before his retirement in 1944 his lectures at Columbia University attracted graduate students from all parts of the world.

Two new pictures will open locally today. "The Plunderers," a Western from the Republic studio, will be shown at tile Gotham. Rod Cameron, Ilona Massey and Adrian Booth head the cast. . . . Arriving at the Stanley is "The Spirit of the Flesh." an Italian drama based on the Alessandro Manzoni novel.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway yesterday elected Walter J. Tuohy president to succeed Robert J. Bowman, who was named chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Tuohy, who was named first vice president on July 20, joined the C. in 1943 as vice president in charge of coal traffic and development.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was inquiring into alleged irregularities in the Texas Democratic primary contest between Representative Lyndon B. Johnson and former Gov. Coke Stevenson.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, who as acting chairman of the United Nations Security Council has been in charge of the efforts to bring about a compromise settlement of the East-West Berlin dispute, said today he thought the Council should reconsider the question "after a prudent delay."

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Heavy dealings in steel shares were seen in the stock markets here today before and after publication of the Government's proposals for nationalizing the steel industry. Buyers rushed prices up in early trading, and adjustments had to be made, once the Government's terms were available, to bring prices into line with the official estimates.
The seventh edition of "Fashions of the Times" ended its four-day run last evening with a resounding tribute from a leading spokesman for the city's fashion industry.

The once-abandoned British freighter Leicester is still afloat, but she was threatened anew yesterday when her battered plates started leaking as salvage workers attempted to tow her to a New York repair yard. Under tow of the tug Kevin Moran of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company of New York, the battered ship was moving slowly toward Cape Henry last night, with 14 feet of water in one of her holds.
The Public Service Commission charged yesterday that New York's combination 12-cent subway-bus fare discriminated against privately owned surface lines.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Prices of grains were on the down grade on the Board of Trade again today, although the deferred deliveries of corn managed to rally to around the previous close in the final trading. December corn finished at the bottom for a net loss of 1 1/2 cents a bushel, with the distant positions unchanged to 1/8 cent down.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 29 -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Turkish Republic was celebrated today. In Ankara troops of scouts and other organizations paraded past Ismet Inonu, the second President of the Republic. The main attraction of the parade was a fully motorized division, equipped with United States materiel.

The custodians of the public's treasures in the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been keeping their fingers crossed during the last ten years whenever there has been a heavy blow. By late next spring ,the cause for worry -- the outworn and corroded steel trusses and girders of the building's huge roof -- will have been removed in the completion of one of the biggest repair jobs the museum has had to undergo.
Following are the texts of President Truman's address at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night and of his talk in the afternoon in Harlem:

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 29 -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Turkish Republic was celebrated today. In Ankara troops of scouts and other organizations paraded past Ismet Inonu, the second President of the Republic. The main attraction of the parade was a fully motorized division, equipped with United States materiel.

The custodians of the public's treasures in the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been keeping their fingers crossed during the last ten years whenever there has been a heavy blow. By late next spring ,the cause for worry -- the outworn and corroded steel trusses and girders of the building's huge roof -- will have been removed in the completion of one of the biggest repair jobs the museum has had to undergo.
Following are the texts of President Truman's address at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night and of his talk in the afternoon in Harlem:

Skiers from the Atlantic seaboard started to converge on the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday as the advance guard of the record crowd that is expected to attend the twenty-seventh annual convention of the United States Eastern Ski Association today and tomorrow.

THE American College Dictionary defines a novel as "a fictitious prose narrative of considerable length, portraying characters, actions and scenes representative of real life in a plot of more or less intricacy." That certainly makes Samuel Spewack's knockabout, informed and exuberantly entertaining new book, "The Busy Busy People,"* a novel.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Brig. Gen. Frank E. Stoner, chief United Nations telecommunications engineer, told the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee today that steps had to be taken immediately if the international organization were to secure broadcasting frequencies for its own radio system.

The Army's newest transport, the converted troopship Admiral R.E. Coontz, was officially renamed yesterday the Gen. Alexander M. Patch, in memory of the commander of the Seventh Army in Europe. The ceremonies were held aboard the vessel at Pier 4, Brooklyn Army Base.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Almost 11,000 jobs for non-agricultural workers are open to displaced persons in New York State, a report submitted to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey by Industrial Commissioner Edward R. Corsi disclosed today.

STE. ETIENNE, France, Oct. 29 -- Early this morning Government troops quietly infiltrated the huge Couriot mine here and took it over without resistance on the part of the confused strikers. By this skillful operation the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor miners were driven out of their last stronghold in the Loire basin.

Retail trade here this week made a good increase, due mainly to very favorable fall shopping weather during the first three days. Department stores sales were estimated as about 11 per cent over the corresponding week last year.

The first detailed public announcement of a clerical job standards plan "that will reduce the number of employes necessary to do this type of work by 20 per cent" and result in savings of millions of dollars was made yesterday at the annual convention of the Office Executives Association of New York, Inc., in the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 29 -- It was learned today that President Syngman Rhee's plan, announced yesterday, to ask the Korean National Assembly to authorize the formation of a National Guard of 50,000 was regarded favorably by top-ranking officers of the United States forces here.

CLINTON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Amwell Sue, white and black pointer from the Amwell Kennels of Lambertville, N.J., took the open derby stake as the three-day meeting of the JocKey Hollow Field Trial Club opened today. It was the fifth victory of the season for Sue, who was guided by George Stymist.

Declaring that the office of today is in reality a "business machine," Morris Lapidus, architect and designer, said yesterday that "office furniture must reflect the same scientific approach that is used in designing an automobile or a piece of factory equipment."

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, today urged before 750 Chicago business men that the next Congress extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for "a substantial period" as the best hope for world trade recovery and as an alternative to depression, dictatorships and possible war.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The gentlemen of Princeton University broke a tie in the second half to defeat the ladies of the New Jersey College for Women, 5 -- 2, at field hockey today.

The national committee of the Progressive party will meet Nov. 13 and 14 in Chicago to chart post-election political activity and to adopt a legislative program, C.B. Baldwin, secretary and campaign manager for the party's Presidential nominee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the National Pressure Cooker Company, Eau Claire, Wis., and five of its officers to stop using "exclusive-dealing contracts in the sale of pressure cookers and canners."
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Russia would take over Greece in a day if United States military aid were withdrawn, Canada warned here today.

With the big resort season just around the corner, "Fashions of The Time" turned it attention to cottons and play clothes and those fashions that are worn at the cocktail hour in patios and on club terraces for dancing after dark.
LIMA, Oct. 20 (UP) -- The Government was overthrown today by a coalition of Army officers who named Gen. Manuel Odria as President of Peru. General Odria is to reach here tomorrow to take office.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Wearing their everyday clothes, King George, Queen Elizabeth and Princess Margaret paid their first visit tonight to the popular theatre recently opened in the People's Palace in London's East End.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (Science Service) -- Uranium deuteride, which is the compound formed by the union of uranium and deuterium, or double-weight hydrogen, can be produced with greater efficiency and safety by a method on which Patent 2,452,139 has just been issued.
President Truman re-committed himself yesterday to the full measure of his ten-point civil rights program, pledging to work for it "with every ounce of strength and determination I have."
COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 29 (AP) -- J. Howard McGrath, national Democratic chairman, today recognized the pro-Truman Democratic group in this state as the "official Democratic party of South Carolina."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- George Marshall, who was borrowed from Paramount by Columbia to direct "Bonanza." has withdrawn from the assignment after four days of shooting because of disagreement with S. Sylvan Simon, producer of the picture, the studio disclosed today.

Usually, when the armed forces receive a request for a photograph of some young man in service, the letter is filed along with thousands of similar notes. However, the Navy violated this principle yesterday, having spent more than a month in breaking the rule.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (Science Service) -- Uranium deuteride, which is the compound formed by the union of uranium and deuterium, or double-weight hydrogen, can be produced with greater efficiency and safety by a method on which Patent 2,452,139 has just been issued.
President Truman re-committed himself yesterday to the full measure of his ten-point civil rights program, pledging to work for it "with every ounce of strength and determination I have."
COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 29 (AP) -- J. Howard McGrath, national Democratic chairman, today recognized the pro-Truman Democratic group in this state as the "official Democratic party of South Carolina."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- George Marshall, who was borrowed from Paramount by Columbia to direct "Bonanza." has withdrawn from the assignment after four days of shooting because of disagreement with S. Sylvan Simon, producer of the picture, the studio disclosed today.

ABOARD ARMY TRANSPORT GENERAL BLACK, Oct. 29 -- Originally scheduled to arrive Sunday, this ship speeded up after the transfer at sea of the critically ill German child born to the war bride of Pfc. John J. Miller of Cedar, Mich., from another transport. Mrs. Miller now is recovering.

AFTER some years as an actor in radio I have reached the conclusion that studio audiences at dramatic broadcasts are an unnecessary evil. Who benefits from having an audience? The show? The actors? The audience itself? None of these.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 30 -- WFMO, a frequency modulation station with studios at 880 Bergen Avenue and a transmitter atop the seventeen-story Labor Bank Building at 26 Journal Square, suspended service at 11 o'clock tonight after being in operation since Sept. 25, 1947.

Governor Dewey took a walk in Central Park and on Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon, seeking relaxation from the rigors of four weeks on a campaign train. He was alone, except for his bodyguard of three State Troopers and more than a score of reporters and camera men. He paused at times to shake hands with children and others who recognized him.
All but one of the several agencies responsible for traffic in Westchester County have taken steps to end the confusion that has plagued motorists on main highways there, it was disclosed yesterday.

HAVING helped Eagle Lion to conduct a small-scale film vendetta against crime and large-budget pictures, Director Anthony Mann apparently is not deviating from this format. Hereabouts last week to show Producer Walter Wanger a rough print of his latest effort, "Reign of Terror," Mann disclosed that, like "T-Men," his forthcoming projects, "Border Incident" and "Twelve Against the Underworld," will be made for approximately $450,000 each.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 30 -- Two outstanding facts, both of a military nature, emerged from Israel's successful Negeb campaign. The first was that the Israeli Army had carved out a much larger territory for the new state than the United Nations partition plan awarded it.

THE murder is served in Tony Mott's private office at the Restaurant Maillaux. Tony is there with a steak knife in his neck. The chief suspect is Peggy Mott, who is known to have hated her playboy husband and with good reason.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- With the coal strike nearly a month old, the Communists of France have had their innings; and, regardless of the outcome of the strike now, they have, in the estimate of many observers, gained their ends. Yet many signs point to the party's strength being on the wane.

ATHENS, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Premier Sophoulis said today that United States Secretary of State Marshall turned down his request for an incrase of 30,000 men in the Greek Army during Secretary Marshall's recent visit to Athens.
Retail activity here last week was stimulated by pre-Christmas buying in toy, stationery and accessory departments, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

NANKING, Oct. 30 -- The loss to the Chinese Communists of all Manchuria, a rich industrial area and a leading incubator for World War II, became a recognized fact tonight as President Chiang Kai-shek returned unexpectedly from North China and marked his sixty-second birthday while Mukden lay prostrate before the advancing Communist columns.
