SUNCOOK, N.H. -- For the second year in succession the 5,000-acre game preserve at Bear Brook, near here, will be open this fall to hunters -- but only to those armed with bows and arrows.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The political effects of prices in relation to purchasing power will be tested again on Tuesday.

CUMBERLAND CENTER, Me., Oct. 30 -- Miss Norball Foster, a song writer, said today she had received a "brief but to the point" refusal from James C. Petrillo, head of the Federation of Musicians, to lift his ban on recordings so that her song, "God Bless All Nations," could be recorded and presented to the United Nations, to which it is dedicated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Russia defined much of her present or projected sphere of control in Eastern Europe as early as 1939, it was shsown in a document released by the Army tonight.

Basic naval training for civilians without military experience and refresher and training courses for demobilized veterans of the Soviet Fleet are being given to "millions" of workers and peasants in the Soviet Union under the reorganized civilian national defense program, it became known yesterday.

The 813 displaced persons coming to waiting jobs, homes and eventual citizenship in the United States were happy but inarticulate when the General Black docked here yesterday. Many of them could not speak English, but those who did repeated phrases such as "It's wonderful," "It's beautiful" and simply, "I'm glad to be here."

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (UP) -- California's Golden Bears barely escaped with their perfect record untarnished today, beating the inspired Southern California Trojans, 13 to 7, before 90,890 fans, the largest football crowd anywhere this season.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie's progress report on the United Nations world capital project in the heart of New York City came up in the General Assembly's Administrative and budgetary Committee today, and not a single country had any complaint to make.
The Wagner College football squad ran up its highest score of the season yesterday at Grymes Hill, S.I., in routing the Ursinus College Bears, 23 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- American farm leaders flatly contradict Soviet claims that the soil-use program the Russians have announced will be bigger and better than anything a capitalist nation could do.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -Kenneth Matthews, British Broadcasting Corporation correspondent, visited the Greek guerrillas' Pelopannesean headquarters after a week's journey over mountains on muleback during his recent seventeen-day detention by the "Free Greek" force, the BBC disclosed today.

TOKYO, Oct. 30 -- The occupation officials are impatiently awaiting the Japanese Government's decision on what should constitute a reasonable return on foreign investments here and how investors should be permitted to obtain foreign exchange for it.

Every employer in light manufacturing industries can use blind and physically handicapped workers, R.P.M. Davis, 74-year-old manufacturer of a haircutting device, declared yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.

NOTWITHSTANDING that we are in the midst of the motor age, the National Horse Show will be back in town this week for its sixtieth annual appearance. And when it opens at Madison Square Garden on election day even though the United States Army has put cavalry in the discard, there will be military riders again.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 30 -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, declared here tonight the Socialist party has campaigned "vigorously in the United States to teach the theory and ideal of democratic socialism, to outline a Socialist program for our troubled times, and to make more likely the rapid emergence of a great mass party of the people as an essential instrument for winning plenty, peace and freedom."

In preparation for the return to the New York area of the Freedom Train, the American Heritage Foundation, the sponsoring agency, announced yesterday the appointment of nine civic leaders as chairmen of local committees to organize patriotic ceremonies and good-citizenship programs and to supervise arrangements for the visit of the Freedom Train to variout metropolitan communities.

UP in Boston the other day Elinor Hughes, drama critic of the Hub's Herald, told her readers that this season's moral may turn out to be that "never have so many expected so much of so many and been disappointed." Doleful words, those, and at this point in time only too true.
In your issue of Oct. 17, you published a letter from William H. Wadhams on the status of Hyderabad, replete with errors of fact and law.

The Rev. Carl A. Hansen will take office tomorrow as the Director of Youth Work for the Board of Christian Education of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, with headquarters at 71 West Twenty-third Street.

Owing to the continued strong demand for women's fall and winter apparel, manufacturers here last week delayed production of many ready-to-wear spring lines, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 30 -- President Truman and the Democratic Senatorial candidate, Robert S. Kerr. seem fairly well ahead in Oklahoma.

A new three-cent postage stamp will bear a picture of the late Will Rogers. This is the first time in the history of our nation that an actor has been honored in such a manner. Who is more entitled to this honor than the lovable Will Rogers, who was America's ambassador of good-will?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- There are now, according to the headlines, only three days left in which to protect the Republic from the perils of disunity and incompetence, avoid the terrors of fascism and communism, confound the malevolence of the "gluttons of privilege" and, of course, save the American way of life.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- By a decree of the Supreme Congregation of the Holy Office all of Jean Paul Sartre's works have been placed in the Vatican's index of forbidden books. The decree, which bears yesterday's date, was approved today by the Pope and ordered published.

LOS ANGELES -- County authorities have announced plans for the development of a leading tourist attraction here and one of the nation's great natural curiosities, which goes under the unprepossessing name of the La Brea Tar Pits.
The first group of homeless Europeans to arrive under the Displaced Persons Law came up New York harbor yesterday past the Statue of Liberty amid the thunder of welcoming whistles.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Westchester, the "most Republican county in the nation" in some elections, may take a firmer grip on its record next Tuesday in rolling up a Presidential plurality for Governor Dewey.

Dr. C. Anderson Aldrich, director of the Rochester Child Health Institute of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., has won the Lasker Awards of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene for 1948, Dr. George S. Stevenson, medical director of the committee, announced yesterday.
Three thousand persons paid tribute yesterday to Dr. Israel Goldstein in a special service honoring his thirtieth anniversary as rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The undefeated, untied White Plains eleven romped to a 20 -- 6 victory over Salem (Mass.) High today before 4,500 fans at the high school stadium. It was the fourth straight triumph for the Tigers.

JUST how much Abraham Lincoln read of the letters that arrived after he was nominated for President is not known. John Hay, in charge of incoming mail after Lincoln reached the White House, said that the President didn't read one letter in fifty, but Hay had a fondness for sweeping statements tinged with cynicism, and this may have been one of them.

PANAMA, R.P. -- Until recently the closest contact that the average traveler to tropical America has had with the jungle was a bird's-eye view from an airplane or a glimpse driving along a concrete highway in an automobile. That is now changed for visitors to Panama.

ON a shifting day in August, 1374, in the English convent of Oby, a blind nun named Dame Cecily lay waving away flies with an elder branch and imagining Saint Lucy's eyes on a platter. It was just before a great storm and the visitation of the Bishop.

BERTIE PODDLE, the fat boy with imagination and intelligence, will be welcomed back by those who have read "Bertie Comes Through." Bertie is still solacing himself with the gooier concoctions of Frubbler's drug store.

The Citizens Union in a statement prepared by its sub-committee on candidates for the higher courts, of which former Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick is chairman, deplored yesterday the caliber of most of the candidates for Supreme Court.

Harry Markson, new managing director of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, announced yesterday that he planned a Feb. 11 return match between featherweight titleholder Sandy Saddler and former champion Willie Pep at Madison Square Garden.

INSTALLATION of a built-in mechanical synchronization in the Automatic Rolleiflex, Ikoflex III and all models of the Contax camera is a new service announced by A.C. Muller, camera repair expert of 421 Seventh Avenue.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Although they insisted that the projected Atlantic security pact was an American proposal, officials of the Brussels treaty powers said today they did not expect negotiations regarding it to take any conclusive form until after the inauguration of the new administration in Washington in January.

ANY Cecil B. DeMille production is an event in Hollywood, but the Technicolor "Samson and Delilah," which DeMille is filming at Paramount with Victor Mature and Hedy Lamarr in the title roles, is attracting more than its share of attention because the producer-director has returned to his favorite story source, the Bible.

ONE of the few women to see the war from the innermost sanctum of the Allied armies was a young, good-looking Irish girl. Kay Summersby, who joined SHAEF as a volunteer chauffeur in the days when London was still reeling from the Blitz.

Retail trade continued active here last week, but the percentage of gain over a year ago was somewhat smaller. Department store sales were estimated as about 10 to 11 per cent above 1947, against an 18 per cent rise the week before.

THE inspiration of a fine teacher of literature and the "Collected Poems" of T.S. Eliot led Doug Harris to choose English teaching as his profession. There followed years of disenchantment and with them the test of Doug's integrity.
VIGNETTES of the year's last two commemoratives, the twenty-ninth and thirtieth stamps on the 1948 program arranged at Washington, have been made available by the Postoffice Department.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- Erich Gniffke, a leading member of the Socialist Unity [Communist] party, has been ejected from the party because he fled to the Western sector, ADN Soviet-licensed news service, announced tonight.

REPRESENTATIVE work by American women photographers features the Women's Invitation Exhibition, which opens tomorrow for a month at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street. The more than 100 prints shown were made by thirty-eight exhibitors from thirteen states.

After an absence of fourteen years, the London String Quartet made a triumphant return to the local concert stage yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The celebrated organization, which is marking its fortieth anniversary this season, was heard in the first of a series of four programs of a two-day Beethoven Festival, devoted to the last ten quartets of the composer and the Grosse Fugue, which closes tonight.

BEGINNING Friday people will be able to say once more that they have seen repertory at Boston's Copley Theatre without confessing to hardening arteries. For on that day the theatre that was once among the most famous in America under Henry Jewett, will be back in repertory.

QUEEN VICTORIA was more than a monarch: before her long reign ended she had become the tutelary deity of her age and the symbol of imperial Britain at its most expansive moment. That makes the task of any biographer, particularly if he is English, an exceedingly difficult one.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 -- New Englanders showed a reasonable amount of curiosity over personal visits by President Truman and Governor Dewey on successive days this week. Over back fences, however, talk turned to local issues whipped up by closing bursts of oratory at state levels.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Burlington County's $12,000,000 purchase of two private toll bridges over the Delaware River was publicly repudiated before the State Senate today by the county's Senator, Arthur W. Lewis, Republican. The Senator, in a brief statement to the Senate during a special legislative meeting to receive executive vetoes, asserted, "The good, decent, respectable people of Burlington County resent the whole thing."

IN structure, this book is a portrait of a man linked to an analysis of a poet and novelist as he developed through the years. It is simply and lightly written as an introduction, or a reappraisal, addressed to a popular audience. The idea is excellent and useful: the actual result is almost unique among biographies.
Drives aimed at lower costs have been started in three industry-wide movements: (1) office administration, (2) sales administration, and (3) materials handling methods.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Lincoln High scored the biggest upset in the Hudson County Interscholastic Athletic Association's championship race today by defeating previously unbeaten St. Peter's Prep, 13 -- 8. A crowd of 9,000 saw the thrilling contest.
JOLIET, Ill., Oct. 30 (AP) -- A convict due for release from Stateville Prison next Thursday has begged the warden to keep him at least six months longer.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 30 -Showing a clear-cut edge over the home team in the statistical department as well as in the final score, Brooklyn College swamped Hofstra, 40 to 0, today.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -Many of the first 499 may have been hard, but Penn's 500th football victory since 1876, scored on Franklin Field today before 50,000 fans, was just a breeze.

One hundred years ago German liberals met and dreamt there of a German republic; most of them were intellectuals and professors.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Tulane called on all its power today to gain a 9-0 victory over a Mississippi State team that was still struggling dangerously when the game ended.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Politics -- international politics, not the domestic variety -- is rapidly becoming, in the eyes of many Washington observers, a contest in solvency.

GAGETOWN, N.B., Oct. 30 -- Thick fog in the morning and a flat calm with a bright sun in the afternoon made this the worst possible day for duck shooting, so we returned with only eight ducks between the two of us.

Governor Dewey will carry New York State, and its forty-seven electoral votes, on Tuesday by a substantial margin, according to all pre-election signs. The Republican landslide in the state, which once seemed possible, now seems unlikely, and a Dewey victory should be by a plurality from 300,000 to 400,000 votes out of a total of about 6,000,000 recorded for the principal nominees, himself, President Truman, or Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party nominee.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Oct. 30 (AP) -- About one ounce is the total weight of all the radioactive atoms shipped from here in one year by the Atomic Energy Commission.
NANKING, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Today some unofficial quarters said that the Communists had completely occupied Mukden, swollen to nearly 2,000,000 population by refugees.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 138,996, as against 152,021 a year ago. decrease of 8.6 per cent; and for this year to date totaled 5,588,431, to compare with 6,002,641 last year, decrease of 6.9 per cent.

TIENTSIN, China, Oct 29 -- Mukden is ominously tense tonight [Friday] waiting for the Communists to walk in. That was the situation when this correspondent left the once great Manchurian industrial center in one of the last planes to take off before its south airfield was cleared at 6 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Navy has a new aluminum "prefab" designed for 65-below-zero weather which a dozen men can assemble in less than two hours with their mittens on.

ANDRE MAUROIS has come to history by way of biography. "Ariel," the fictionalized life of Shelley, launched him on his career just a quarter of a century ago, and a steady stream of biographies have come from his atelier in the years since.

THE feasting on and around Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's may be fun for the family but it takes a lot out of the cook. She'll come through the culinary capers demanded of her at this season more easily if she has the right tool for each job.

IT WAS Hal Sims who once remarked that the perfect system for bidding grand slams can be expressed in one word: Don't, Mr. Sims made an exception, in those days, for his famous three-bid, which led infallibly to grand slams -- but, unfortunately, only on hands that almost never showed up, so that the bid fell into desuetude and eventual oblivion.

THE Negeb, scene of major fighting between Israelis and Arabs in Palestine, is a land so dry that even cactus has to be cultivated. Yet this 3,000,000-acre stretch of barren hills and sandy plains a total area almost equal to the combined Arab and Jewish holdings in the rest of Palestine -- is a prime factor in Israeli plans.

IN "A Streetcar Named Desire" Jessica Tandy, the rueful heroine, insists on telling her troubled sister. Kim Hunter, that the latter's tempestuous husband, Marlon Brando, is a throwback to primitive man. Brando, overhearing the tirade in a back room, casually walks in on the girls holding a bottle of a much-publicized brand of cola.

BLOWING ROCK, N. C. IN last Sunday's column this department made mention of the contrast between the glowing colors of the Connecticut hills at this season and the more subdued yet lovely tints of the Vineyard.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 -- All the emotion and partisan feeling with which, in former times, Canadians took a vicarious part in every Presidential election in the United States seems to have vanished entirely this year.
MARTINSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 30 -- Income from the West Virginia tourist and vacation industry has broken all records in 1948, the Industrial and Publicity Commission reports.

SOME day Sir Henry Merrivale (H.M. to his intimates) is going to drive Chief Inspector Masters mad. He almost does it when he prods Masters into reopening the Fleet ease twenty years after it has been written off as death by accident.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Those grim old specters, the steel barons, the international cartels and the munitions makers, are driving British socialism to a logical but controversial step -- nationalization of the iron and steel industry. The bitterest political battle since the war is going to be fought over this measure.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- An iron curtain has been thrown around the Indian princely state of Hyderabad, behind which a reign of terror is being conducted, Liaqat Ali Khan, Prime Minister of Pakistan charged here today. He called on the United Nations Security Council to send out observers immediately to escertain the true state of affairs.
President Truman was described last night as a "man with a persecution complex" and the inventor of a new dance step consisting of one step forward, two backward and then a sidestep.

TORONTO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Ted Kennedy scored twice to lead the National Hockey League champion Toronto Maple Leafs to a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight. The loss was the Wings' first of the season.

All of today's local entertainment in professional football will be provided by the All-America Conference. The Giants of the National League are in Chicago to meet the Bears, so the Yankees and the Dodgers, playing at home, will have the field to themselves.

Scoring three touchdowns, running, kicking, passing and calling plays, Leo Wagner led the City College football team to a 33 -- 12 upset over the New Britain Teachers College in Lewisohn Stadium last night.

Several thousand persons gathered in Times Square late last night to watch firemen extinguish a smoky blaze in a defective flue in Rosoff's Restaurant, 152 West Forty-fourth Street. Thirty-five patrons in the restaurant, which extends through to Forty-third Street, were asked to leave when the fire was discovered.

EVERY time there is a new moon, poor, lonely Mr. Jeremiah Topple looks at it over his left shoulder and makes a certain wish. Mr. Topple, who works hard selling vegetables from a pushcart, isn't one just to sit and wait for this special wish to come true, either.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Continuing the domestic labor feud over the French coal mine strike, John L. Lewis, the president of the United Mine Workers, asserted today that William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, was a victim of "Truman axemen and your personal enemies in your own office."

Here is a report on the people, the activities, the daily drama of the clinics in a New York voluntary hospital. The hospital -- New York Polyclinic -- is typical of the city's eighty-six voluntary hospitals, all non-profit, non-tax-supported institutions, serving public. Among their great services are these clinics. where visit cost an average of $1.45 to the patient,$3.05 to the hospital.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 30 -It was just another field day for Earl Blaik's horde of Black Knights at Michie Stadium today as Army romped over Virginia Tech, 49 -- 7, before a capacity crowd of 26,921, including 10,000 Boy Scouts.

WAKE FOREST, N.C., Oct. 30 (AP) -- North Carolina State spotted the Wake Forest football team three touchdowns in the first eleven minutes of play today, and although fighting gamely, was never able to recover.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30 -- President Truman scrapped a prepared address tonight to make the angriest speech of his campaign in which he made his most bitter attacks on Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Wage increases ranging from $2 to $5 a week for approximately 8,500 up-state telephone workers are provided in new contracts signed by the New York Telephone Company and three independent unions.

HE starry-eyed youngsters who axe all set to become writers, singers and artists are often helped by advice from. women who have achieved success in their chosen fields of endeavor. Such advice we found in a booklet entitled "Vocationally Yours," just issued by the Camp Fire Oirls. Inc.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- While the Republican candidates will sweep Rockland on Tuesday, the lack of interest in the campaign may cut Governor Dewey's plurality below the 11,036 he had over James M. Mead in 1946. Political experts here believe, however, he will run ahead of his 6,034 plurality over Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1944.
ROME, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Vatican newspaper, Osservatore Romano, criticized a United Nations committee today for not having included a mention of God in a draft declaration on the rights of man.
The Boston Bruins will move into Madison Square Garden tonight to tackle the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game.

IT would be folly to expect, even though it is being held at the Metropolitan Museum, that the exhibition showing the Navy's development in paintings, prints and ship-models is of special artistic concern. Its primary interest is historic.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 30 -- The pass combination of Edward Finn and Robert Searles paced Brown to a 20-6 victory over Rutgers today.

WHEN 17-year-old Danielle, her little brother and her grandmother returned, after four years of wandering, to their little French village from which they had fled to escape the Nazis, they found their fortunes at a low ebb. Danielle's father, her mother and her fiance had not been heard of in many months; a greedy villager had cheated them of their best acres and their other vineyards were untended and unproductive.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Oct. 22 -- Described by Opposition members as "a retreat from socialism" and "a Tory measure," the Government has introduced a bill giving the farmer tenants of Crown land the right to purchase the freehold. Hitherto the Government has resisted all arguments for the sale of the freehold of Crown lands, not already provided for in the leases.

GETTYSBURG, Pa. -- The eighty-fifth anniversary of the dedication of the national cemetery here, and of Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg Address, will be observed Friday, Nov. 19, and this historic town of 6,000 is preparing for a great throng of visitors for the anniversary ceremony.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 30 -- The spluttering northern front in the war in Palestine burst into flames today as the Israeli Army launched what appeared to have been a full-scale offensive to eliminate the Arab-held bulge descending into Galilee from Lebanon.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Gen. Manuel Odria, head of a military junta, announced today that Peru is to be "reconstructed on a new basis" as a result of the triumphant right-wing revolution that ousted President Jose Luis Bustamante y Rivera yesterday.

THE short novel, by its very size, makes an exciting book. It is an exciting form as well. Longer than a story, it incorporates (when the work is "right") the compactness and texture of the one genre and the richness and structure of the other. There are many examples.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A fighting band of Iowa Hawks bounded back from apparent defeat today to down Wisconsin, 19 -- 13, in a Big Nine football thriller.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Princeton feared a tough struggle with the University of Virginia today, with the Tigers figured to be "let down" after their dramatic triumph over Columbia last week. The Cavaliers were thought to be primed to outdo themselves in their invasion of the north, and the expectation among the 23,000 fans in Palmer Stadium was for a tight struggle.
EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Oregon Webfoots finally shook off an old hex in the final three minutes today and chalked up a 14-13 victory over St. Mary's Gaels.

ATLANTA, Oct. 30 -- The Presidential campaign and the Berlin crisis continued to hold top interest this week, but county fairs, harvesting of crops and a variety of other sectional events served to divert attention.

The sixtieth National Horse Show will begin in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday for eight days of matinee and evening performances. It is one of New York's older sports events as well as a social fixture of considerable importance.

IN the season's kaleidoscopic variety, last week brought forth one notable background exhibition and several one-man shows of work by American contemporaries who clearly demonstrate that they are still developing if not actually undergoing deep sea changes.

THE case history of a comparative newcomer to films named Macdonald Carey is apt to be disturbing to persons who are deeply concerned with hammering out a positive philosophy on what goes into the making of a screen star.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 30 -- Trailing by 20 points in the third period, New York University's eleven struck for two quick touchdowns, picked up another in the fourth and converted all three times to beat Lehigh, 21 to 20, before 8,000 fans at Taylor Stadium today.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Royal Mission, Lee L. Chandler 3d's 5-year-old brown gelding from Ligonier, Pa., came with a rush on the closing flat to take the twenty-seventh running of the four-mile New Jersey Hunt Cup over the rolling terrain of E.B. Schley's estate today.

FORTUNATELY for the well-being of the nation, "Life With Mother" has turned out to be a worthy mate to "Life With Father." We all came from the opening performance in a glow of good humor, feeling very amiable about the human race and convinced that all is for the best in the best of all possible worlds.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Oct. 30 -- A curfew has been imposed on Stuttgart from 9 o'clock in the evening until 4 A.M. as a result of the riot there Thursday, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, announced today.

Campaign oratory is improving, according to speech experts reporting in the Quarterly Journal of Speech, edited by Prof. Harold P. Harding of Ohio State University. The journal says that President Truman has shown remarkable progress such as displayed by few men in American official life.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (UP) -Fullback Bob Becker drove the improving University of Pittsburgh eleven to an easy 20-to-0 victory today over Western Reserve University before 12,000 fans at League Park.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 30 -- Lafayette College scored its fifth victory in six starts by defeating George Washington University, 33 -- 14, today before a Founders' Day crowd of 13,000. Danny Kovacs, Lafayette captain, caught two touchdown passes to share the spotlight with Andy Davis of the visitors, who put on one of the greatest passing exhibitions ever seen here.
LOUDON, Tenn., Oct. 20 (UP) -- National Guard air and ground units moved on this East Tennessee town today under executive orders to quell threatened mob violence.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 -- Notre Dame's swift couriers and blockers blew Navy down today as the fighting Irish recorded their most crushing victory in the history of this intersectional rivalry dating back to 1427.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Asserting that the entire Truman doctrine was imperiled by the latest events in Manchuria and Greece, Henry A. Wallace said today that the United States would have to find a new foreign policy.

Opening night of the sixtieth National Horse Show on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden will draw to that arena hundreds of members of society who regard the premiere of this notable exhibition as the formal opening of the winter social season in New York.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Bulldogs of Georgia handed Alabama its worst defeat since 1910 today, burying the Crimson Tide by 35 to 0 Before a crowd of 45,000.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Purdue was good enough early and late today to gain its second football victory of the year by defeating Marquette 14 to 9. Although the Hilltoppers for a time enjoyed a 9-to-7 lead that made Milwaukee fans forget four previous defeats, they fumbled away the game in the last eight minutes.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 30 -- One stop in a 2,000-mile journey may seem infinitesimal to the layman, but to the Wildcats of Northwestern today it was a gigantic stride in the direction of the Rose Bowl.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Scoring two touchdowns in the opening quarter, Boston University's Terriers won their fifth consecutive football game today by downing an injury weakened Syracuse eleven, 12 -- 7.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky said tonight that "the fundamental issue in the election is whether the gains made by the people during the last sixteen years are to be preserved or lost."

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 30 -- It's a lot easier to get a drink in Kansas than it is to get the names of Democratic candidates for public office. The Democrats are regarded as token opposition to the nearly omnipotent Republicans in this Sahara of the Middle West, where liquor is "the burning question."

NEWBURY, Vt., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Two Boston-Montreal trains traveling on a single fog-shrouded track along the Connecticut River crashed head-on at 3:15 A.M. today, killing the engineer and fireman on each express, injuring five mail clerks and shaking more than 250 passengers.

The domestic steel industry now is operating in its best post-war stride, with distribution improving and destined to become better, with earnings at record levels, production close to all-time peaks, and the industry's huge expansion program progressing very satisfactorily, according to financial reports for the third quarter released last week by the leading steel companies.

Cornell left nothing to the last minute at Baker Field yesterday. By that time the Ithacans had completed the job of overtaking the Lions, who had led by 13 -- 7 in the fourth quarter, to beat Columbia, 20 -- 13.

HARALD KREUTZBERG will give his only New York performance of the season this evening at the Ziegfeld Theatre with seven new numbers on his program. At the City Center the new City Ballet, in its fourth pair of performances, will present three works that have not been seen before in its season thus far.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Coasting under a strong grip at the end, Henry L. Straus' Pilaster added the thirty-fifth running of the Governor Bowie Handicap to his growing list of 1948 successes before 16,434 racegoers at Pimlico today.
DONORA, Pa., Oct. 30 -- Eighteen persons died in this steel mill town of 15,000 today and health authorities said their deaths apparently were the indirect result of a smothering "smog."

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Through their own corps of special representatives at the United Nations General Assembly meeting here, several million United States farmers, union members, professional workers and men and women engaged in scores of other fields are maintaining a watchful lobby that helps shape the official United States position.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Fomer Mayor Frank Hague, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee and New Jersey's Democratic boss, will wind up the campaign locally with a rally tomorrow afternoon at Dickinson High School at which he will make his usual pre-election prediction.

STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 30 (UP) -- A long-dormant Stanford passing attack clicked for two touchdowns today to prove the major factor in a 20-0 upset of the Washington Huskies in a Pacific Coast Conference game.

THIS is the first book for children by the distinguished English novelist and critic. LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters) Unbeaten Derby County scored a 1-0 victory at Birmingham today to take undisputed lead in the first division of the English Football League.

THE Civil Aeronautics Board received one of the heaviest attacks in its eleven-year history last week when W.A Patterson, president of the United Air Lines, charged it with having a record of "outstanding failure."

THE autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York will be held in the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House, Thursday to Saturday. This is the first large show to be held in the society's new enlarged headquarters.
VIENNA, Oct. 30 -- Erwin Scharf, left-wing Socialist leader, will be expelled from the Austrian Social Democratic party, it is now learned definitely.

LEE HALL, Va., Oct. 30 -- The largest reserve fleet of merchant ships in the country has been "shaken down" through sales and transfers to 439 vessels and probably will not vary greatly in size in the future, according to Maritime Commission representatives here.

A RECORD total of 29,608,318 persons visited the National Parks, National Monuments and other areas administered by the National Park Service during the year that ended Sept. 30, according to a report made to Secretary of the Interior J.A. Krug last week by Newton B. Drury, director of the National Park Service. The figure surpassed last year's record numbers by 4,464,198 visitors, or 17 per cent.

OUT-OF-TOWN openings of Broadway productions used to be considered something that could well be left for the yokels and a few professionals who had a finger, a dollar or a relative in the production. But lately a number of non-professional New Yorkers -- plain cash customers -- have been going far afield for first nights.

United States announcement of "notice of intent" to negotiate new trade agreements with eleven countries and issuance of the "bargaining" list of commodities for proposed tariff cuts is expected soon in foreign-trade circles here. It would not be surprising, it was said, if both announcements were made immediately after election day, and certainly within the next ten days.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Georgia Tech's Engineers, finally solving a difficult Duke defensive pattern, rambled from behind to score a 19-to-7 victory over the Blue Devils today and remain among the unbeaten and untied elite.

A NEW ballet company which may possibly have more than ordinary significance has just come into being in Cuba, and was scheduled to make its world bow last Thursday in Havana. It is called the Ballet Alicia Alonso and its personnel of thirty dancers is drawn largely from the Ballet Theatre company.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- British correspondents were informed from London tonight that Secretary of State Marshall, during his visit there today, had been trying to persuade Foreign Secretary Bevin to help postpone the entire Palestine issue not only until after the United States elections but until next year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- The West Coast maritime strike has caused wage losses of nearly $20,000,000, including some $9,000,000 to striking longshoremen alone, it was estimated today by the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast.

Small businesses, which cannot afford to waste money on inefficient selling techniques, are setting the pace in packaging progress, it was declared yesterday by Martin Ullman, veteran New York industrial designer.

Observers feel that reimposition of import controls by the Union of South Africa is probable "sooner or later" inasmuch as voluntary selective and restrictive buying of consumer goods has not been sufficiently effective in curtailing exchange expeditures, according to an analysis by the National Foreign Trade Council.

The life of the traveling salesman today is no bed of roses, according to several veterans of that profession interviewed last week following their return from their first selling trips since the pre-war shutdown in traveling activities.

Announcement by Senator Cordon that the scheduled trip of a Joint Congressional Committee to Guam, Samoa and the Trusteed Territories in the Pacific is being postponed indefinitely will come as discouraging news to the island people and to those Americans who have been trying to stimulate Congressional action on this important aspect of our colonial problem.

Some of the resiliency went out of the financial markets last week as hopes for an early settlement of the Berlin crisis were blocked by another veto. The possibility of an extra dividend by United States Steel, which failed of fruition, did not help sentiment.

RENO, Nev., Oct. 30 -- Quarterback Stan Heath, the nation's top passer, pitched five touchdown passes and completed eigth others for an amazing total of 327 yards and a new intercollegiate record today as he led Nevada to a 79 -- 13 victory over Oklahoma City Universtiy.

The Household Finance Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net income of $7,955,290 in the first nine months of this year, according to a report issued yesterday by B.E. Henderson, president. After deducting dividends on the preferred stock, the balance of net income was equivalent to $3.14 each on 2,445,498 common shares.

Ancient Chinese bronzes collected by the late James Monroe McAdams, and Chinese sculptures, jades and Japanese works of art, the property of Efrem Zimbalist, will be auctioned on Thursday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The recent death of one of the screen's most proficient camera men, Gregg Toland, probably went unnoticed by most filmgoers. Unlike directors, whose efforts are given copious publicity, those in charge of photography receive little credit for painstaking labors.

IN 1841 Dorothea Lynde Dix, visiting the women in the East Cambridge, Mass., jail, saw for the first time a lunatic, saw, too, her icy cell, the jailer's blows, the convicts' callous contempt. Thus began a crusade which was to take her into dark corners of utter horror all over the United States and Europe as she strove for humane treatment for the insane who were starved, frozen and beaten.

Voters in the city next Tuesday will cast ballots for President of the United States, Representatives in Congress, State Senators and Assemblymen, justices of the Supreme Court and, in a few areas, other judicial offices. In addition they will pass on one question being submitted to a referendum.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Air Force announced tonight that its new Northrop B-49 jet bomber had flown more than 3,400 miles, surpassing the range performance of the B-29 in its early days.

SAN MIGUEL DE ALLENDE -- South-of-the-border tourists are finding pleasure this season in a few days' stay at this quaint old hill village in the heart of Mexico's Guanajuato state. This interesting town of stone towers and narrow streets is 264 miles northwest of Mexico City, and is accessible also from San Luis Potosi, after turning off the Pan-American highway at Antiguo Morelos, on the way south from San Antonio and Laredo, Tex.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The New York State Community Theatre Conference organized on a permanent basis today as 131 delegates from twenty-eight little theatres adopted a constitution and elected a board of nine directors.

The man who singly had more to do with the establishment of commercial aviation and the forerunners of America's giant sky networks is back in the saddle. His is a story that challenges those who say there is no romance in Wall Street.

To the Drama Editor: BEFORE the opening of "Summer and Smoke" at the Music Box Theatre, I wrote in for two good orchestra seats for the Tennessee Williams play, giving a choice of six evenings. I received two seats in the fifteenth row orchestra -- the last row -- for the third evening performance, Friday, Oct. 8.

Fashions of the Times -- the title was never more appropriate. The fashions displayed last week in the annual style show sponsored by The New York Times are genuinely of our day. In the free swinging flare of coat and skirt of capelet and veil, designers have caught the ease and grace of movement of the air age at its best.

Jean Walter, a French architect, thinks that because "the literature on medical architecture is so scanty" designers of hospitals have to travel from city to city to acquaint themselves with the ideas of others. As the result of his own wanderings in quest of knowledge, Walter notes a trend toward economy in ground space at the expense of height.

Competitive ports such as New Orleans, Boston and Philadelphia are "making a noticeable inroad into the volume of goods handled through the Port of New York" because of outmoded piers and traffic delays here, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, said yesterday.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that by early 1949 it would have gathered all the engineering data necessary to lay out the new runways and locate the additional buildings called for at Newark Airport under the Authority's long-term plans for expanding the New Jersey air terminal.

Mrs. Harold C. Richard will give the annual card party and tea for the benefit of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service on Dec. 7 at her home, 1060 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Richard is vice president of the board of directors of the beneficiary, located at 122 East Twenty-ninth Street, which is celebrating this year the 125th anniversary of its founding.

PROVINCETON, Mass., Oct. 30 -- Preliminary plans were announced today for the rededication, no Armistice Day, of a tablet near the spot where the Pilgrims first landed on American soil here on Nov. 11, 1620.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Following is the text of Henry A. Wallace's speech as prepared for delivery here tonight:

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 30 -- The Democratic party completed certification of its nineteen electors in Michigan here this afternoon when John R. Franco, state Democratic chairman, and Mrs. Violet Patterson, vice chairman, filed the list with the Secretary of State, Fred M. Alger Jr.

NO weeks in the garden are looked forward to with greater anticipation than tulip time, and when all the work of fall planting ends in failure there is naturally keen disappointment. Dissatisfaction was expressed last spring in many parts of the country.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Union College registered its third straight victory today by defeating Williams College 19 -- 7, before a crowd of 4,500.

REASONABLY good color reproductions of great paintings have been produced for several decades, but expensive methods of printing have priced them immoderately high. Tedious and careful plate and proof making. vari-colored inks, and skilled supervision all have combined to delay the availability of fine reproductive art over cheap chromos.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- There is "no evidence that the Russians desire to reach an agreement on the Berlin question and end the threat to peace," Dr. Philip C. Jessup, deputy United States delegate to the Security Council, declared tonight.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- The food supply of the Western zones is "seriously threatened" by the resurgence of the black market in the German economy, official United States Military Government reports disclosed today.

IN football, one is either pro-Notre Dame or anti-Notre Dame! Nobody is satisfied to perch on the fence. If a fan is pro-Rambler, he doesn't care whom Notre Dame beats, and if he feels the other way he doesn't care who beats Notre Dame.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Seasonal gains brought mid-September non-farm employment to a record high of 45,864,000, a rise of 377,000 over August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Revival of the USO program which provided recreation for service men in World War II is being completed rapidly, Secretary of Defense James Forrestal said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, 1896, are the place and time. Linda, an attractive girl, is saddled to a fanatical evangelist who wants to convert a rat-infested tannery into a dormitory for sinners, but, much to the reader's relief, she leaves with her two children and gets a divorce.

Prices of shares drifted in a narrow range during yesterday's abbreviated session on the Stock Exchange, closing the final period of the week and month on a firmer note, with selected issues strongest. Trading volume dropped to 350,000 shares, the smallest for a two-hour session in a fortnight.

THE powers, problems and responsibilities of the American Presidency are so enormous that nobody except the candidates themselves -- and they only briefly -- have ever had the nerve to suggest that the job could really be mastered by anybody but prophets, angels and warriors.

For the third year in succession it was "pay to the order of the King Ranch" at the end of yesterday's edition of the Westchester Handicap at Empire City-at-Jamaica. It's getting to be a habit -- and Trainer Max Hirsch hopes he doesn't soon break himself of it.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Production was resumed in the French coal mines today for the first time since Oct. 3 with a back-to-work movement that was variously reported at from 25 to 50 per cent. In the Lorraine district 80 per cent of the miners were reported back.

Statements printed in Pravda, the Communist party paper of Russia, are tantamount to official Soviet doctrine. Usually the statements are made by Premier Stalin's subordinates in the various echelons of the Soviet hierarchy. Only rarely does Stalin himself "grant" an interview to Pravda.
WHEN Charles Warwick Evans, founder of the 40-year-old London String Quartet, walks into a hotel room and pulls his 'cello in after him there is hardly room left for a small boy to turn pages.

TOLEDO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- An out-of-court settlement of the flat glass anti-trust suit leaving the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company intact, but containing severe injunctions against practices alleged to be in restraint of trade, was approved today by Federal Judge Frank L. Kloeb.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 3 points higher to 7 points lower than on Friday. The market was quiet and lacked a definite trend. There was a fair amount of hedge selling, mostly in small lots. Trade buying was fair but on the scale down.

THE scene of this story is Wrightsville, the same town which served as the setting for Ellery Queen's best novel, "Calamity Town." Ellery goes to Wrightsville to ride herd on young Howard Van Horn, who is subject to spells of amnesia and is worried about what he may have done or may do during his periodical blackouts.

NANKING, Oct. 30 -- The position of Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's Government -- militarily, economically and psychologically -- has deteriorated to the point where diplomatic missions here are informing their home capitals of the possibility of a Nationalist collapse within the next few months.

Senator Irving M. Ives, speaking at the closing Republican campaign rally in Madison Square Garden last night, accused President Truman of engaging in "double talk" on the Palestine issue and undermining the prestige of the United States in the United Nations.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The French miners' strike has resulted in both a victory and a defeat for the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor. The labor organization has won a sound victory against France's recovery effort but has lost a number of miners who are reaching a stage of physical hunger in which it is difficult for them to reconcile the Confederation's use of their strike power for political reasons.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 30 -- Private sources reported today the arrest of Kotchi Drodze, until recently Albania's Minister of the Interior, chief of the Albanian secret police, and secretary of the Central Committee of the Albanian Communist Party on charges of supporting Yugoslavia against the Communist Information Bureau.

When Dr. Joe Vincent Meigs of Harvard rises to tell the American College of Surgeons that women should have children early in married life to avoid endometriosis, an affliction which is still a mystery after sixty years of study and which sterilizes from 20 to 70 per cent of childless women, he must be listened to with respect as an experienced gynecologist.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The teeth in the Taft-Hartley Labor Management Relations Act are starting to bite, just as its proponents had hoped and its opponents had feared.

A Dewey-Warren "victory parade" passed along sixteen Manhattan blocks early last evening, including the heart of the theatrical district. Possibly because it lacked "star" attraction and because torchlight made a feeble showing against the high candlepower of theatre marquees the procession drew a crowd of only about 30,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -The board of directors of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation today announced plans for separating the motion-picture production and distribution section of the company from its theatre properties along the lines of the "divorcement" action long pressed by the Department of Justice on antitrust grounds.

A blonde policewoman, with only two months' experience on the force, aided in the arrest of three men in the subway early yesterday morning by rapping one of them over the knuckles with a blackjack and causing him to drop a knife he had drawn.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 30 -- With registration at record high, traditionally Republican Suffolk County may return a Dewey-Warren plurality of 50,000 next Tuesday, according to Representative W. Kingsland Macy, himself a candidate for re-election in the First Congressional District, comprising all of Suffolk and a part of Nassau County.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 -- Gov. Earl Warren wound up six weeks of intensive campaigning tonight with pleas for national unity and that "every citizen" cast his or her vote.

THE last lingering days of autumn weather are an excellent time to sow seeds of several choice hardy annual flowers. There is no need to hurry about getting these seeds into the ground, as long as they are sown before the earth freezes.
KINGS POINT, L.I. Oct. 30 -Bridgeport U. stormed back to defeat the U. S. Merchant Marine Academy, 25---20, in a thriller today.

In George Barrett's article "The Real Word Wizards -- the U.N. Interpreters" mention is made of Jose Baquero as permanent delegate and chief of the Ecuadorean delegation to the U.N. Assembly at Paris. Actually Dr. Baquero is neither delegate nor is he in Paris.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- Loss suffered through car thefts was attributed today to negligence of state agencies by Charles D. Henderson, executive vice president of the New York State Automobile Dealers. There is definite need for a car title law which will assure purchasers that their vehicles are free from any encumbrances, he asserted.

NORTH ATTLEBORO, Mass., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House and publisher of The Daily Chronicle, said today that an editorial in his paper saying Governor Dewey's speeches were "designed for tonal effect" and had matter which "sounds good and brings applause, but promises nothing" was a syndicate editorial.

ONE of the most painful and disquieting murder stories in the whole history of crime in Britain, the Thompson-Bywaters case of 1923, has an echo in the new tale by the English writer Shelley Smith, whose ability to turn the screws of tension increases with each book she writes.

EVERY day except Sunday, eight hours a day without let-up, queues shuffle along the pavements of Britain's main streets, Oxford Street in London, Corporation Street in Birmingham, Deansgate in Manchester.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Wheat and corn futures moved lower today on the Board of Trade and closed near their bottoms for the session. Both at times were off around a cent a bushel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Monroe Goldwater, head of the reconstruction division of the Joint Distribution Committee, major American agency aiding distressed Jews abroad, emphasized tonight the immediate need for an expanded program of rehabilitation in behalf of "tens of thousands" of the 700,000 Jews in Eastern Europe who have become "economically displaced" because of nationalization of industry in that area.

WITH so many escapist painters preferring man's works to man himself, art to life, this book on the greatest realist of all time should be read and seen by everybody. Its author is a lifelong Rembrandt scholar, former Curator of the Print Room of the Berlin State Museum, and now Professor of Fine Arts and Curator of the Print Department at the Fogg Museum at Harvard University.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- The Soviet press published today what it said was the text of a Paris draft agreement on Berlin that Premier Stalin stated in his published interview had been broken by Britain and the United States.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Penn State's Nittany Lions, bouncing back from a tie with Michigan State, preserved their unbeaten record here this afternoon by grinding out a methodical, power-driven triumph over Colgate, 32 -- 13.

THERE is a growing complaint in England, too, that our radio programs suffer from staleness, a lack of new ideas. "Irma," the Tommy Handley show, is, for example, coming back for the tenth successive year.

THE story of Shylock has become one of the world's notable legends and therefore it is just as legitimate for anyone to recast it in his own terms as it was for Tennyson to retell the Arthurian story or for Benet to write poems about Helen of Troy.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- Despite the assurance and confidence of recent Russian pronouncements on policy in Germany and despite the steps taken toward acceptance of a Constitution for "all Germany," it is evident that the Soviet Military Administration and its henchmen in the Socialist Unity [Communist] party are encountering difficulties in the Soviet zone.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization will hold its fourth annual conference here beginning Nov. 15 to discuss, among other subjects, plans for making increased food production "truly international," it was announced today.

ON the eve of an election which the political experts maintain is still "in the bag" there is not much excitement in business quarters over the result. The popular vote may turn out to be much closer than was imagined earlier in the campaign, and the Senate result is still marked as "doubtful."

MIAMI -- An unusual welcome for visitors to Florida is being planned for the coming tourist season. Free citrus juice will be dispensed while attendants at "Welcome Stations" give tourists information and literature about the section they intend to visit.

The current furore over the case of Ilse Koch accentuates the need for consideration of the effects of victory in our plans and preparations for a possible World War III. Planes and bombs should not monopolize the planning boards of our military strategists and tacticians.
Annuities are neither investments in securities nor life insurance contracts. Nor are they treated like either for income tax purposes. The present formula for taxing annuities is purely arbitrary.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 30 -- Nassau County, the home community of J. Russel Sprague, one of Governor Dewey's principal advisers, will roll up a whopping plurality on Tuesday for the Republican Presidential candidate.

ATHENS, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Premier Sophoulis, who said tonight that a Cabinet crisis was "unavoidable," may submit his resignation at any time in the next forty-eight hours, political quarters believed.

TO be a gaucho in the year 1875 was to know the greatness of a vanishing era. The ranch owner was also the feudal chief, or caudillo, to whom the cattle hands owed a fierce tribal loyalty. In return he protected them from army conscription, from thieving Government officials, from the un-Christian alien influences of Buenos Aires.

Skiing, whose growth the past decade has been unprecedented in sports annals, was thoroughly explored and examined yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania in the opening half of the twenty-seventh meeting of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association.

LESLIE ROBERTS is a Canadian journalist who visited the Soviet Union and seven other European countries last spring to see for himself how the common people of these nations regard the Cold War. He has returned home, satisfied that the Russian people -- and the Kremlin -- do not want war, and that the other European peoples are sick and tired of the power politics of both Russia and the United States.
New Utrecht and James Madison battled to an 18-18 tie and Lafayette defeated Abraham Lincoln, 14 to 6, in a football doubleheader before 6,500 at Ebbets Field yesterday.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 30 -- Undefeated Middlebury College had little trouble today scoring its sixth consecutive football victory of the season by routing Norwich, 40 -- 0, before 3,000 fans. The Panthers scored in every period, with two of their six touchdowns being made by second and third stringers.

A three-point program to overcome the educational problems of young children has been started at the University of Minnesota with the opening of its child-study center. The program will offer special assistance annually to between 400 and 500 Minnesota children with school problems; prepare regular classroom teachers, supervisors and administrators for remedial work, and initiate research into various educational problems for which satisfactory solutions are not yet known.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has assembled 560 special assistant and special deputy attorneys general to watch for fraud at polling places throughout the five boroughs on election day, he announced yesterday after swearing in 327 of the volunteers in a mass ceremony at 80 Centre Street. The others have taken their oath of office and received their location of their assignments.

High school students representing a cross-section of public, private and parochial schools in the metropolitan area expressed widely divergent views yesterday on the outcome of the Presidential election. They gave their views at the Youth Forum, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast from the studio of WQXR at 730 Fifth Avenue.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The losing streak of the University of California at Los Angeles ended at three games today and Nebraska's went to five as the Pacific Coast Conference team grabbed a 27-to-15 victory over its Big Seven football rival.

IN the recent Town Meeting discussion of television's future, Rouben Mamoulian the Hollywood and Broadway director, advanced the thesis that television could not be considered a new art form. Rather, Mr. Mamoulian held, television was merely a new medium of communication which drew its techniques from already well-established arts.

TOKYO, Oct. 30 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur sharply informed Soviet authorities today that they had no justified claim against the Japanese Government for expenses involved in the repatriation of Japanese war prisoners and civilians from Russian-held territory, as has been asserted by the Russian delegation here.

To the tune of tumultuous cheers, Governor Dewey brought his campaign for President to a formal close at a Republican rally Madison Square Garden last night, pledging an administration devoted to promoting unity among the American people and furthering the cause of world peace.

Several dinner parties will be given tomorrow before the performance of Tennessee Williams' play, "Summer and Smoke," at the Music Box Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The United Nations International Emergency Children's Fund tonight gave details of the aid being sent beyond the Iron Curtain to 400,000 underfed children and nursing or pregnant women in Rumania.

WHILE the focus of attention has been on the conflict between Russia and the West in Europe, another fateful clash has been joined on the other side of the world. Communism is bidding, just as it did after the first World War, for ascendancy in Asia and under conditions more favorable than after 1919.

PRINT shows by John Marin and Paul Klee fall in the same week by a happy coincidence. It may be history will install them as minor talents. Be that as it may, there are few contemporaries who surpass the individuality, legibility or astonishing completeness of utterance of these two giants of sensibility.

Auxiliary Bishop Vincent Brizgys of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Kaunas, Lithuania, announced here yesterday he would explain the workings of the Communist regime in Lithuania during a series of lectures being arranged primarily for more than 1,000,000 Lithuanian Americans in this country.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 30 -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond said tonight that "the millions who are going to vote for States Rights Democrats will succeed in preventing either Truman or Dewey" from enacting a Federal Fair Employment Practices Commission.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The professor-scientist-administrator known as "the man who built the atom bomb" has come home from Europe, fearful for the future.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- It is the conviction of some of European officials charged with making the European Recovery Program work that basic changes in United States policy toward the use of dollar aid must be made in the subsequent years of the program if failure is to be avoided.

After carefully going over all the news of the campaign in his daily paper, a seeker after light on the mysteries of American politics opened "Ordeal of the Union," by Allan Nevins, and began to read:
This Tuesday the United States of America holds its forty-first Presidential election.

ATHENS, Oct. 30 -- Strong indications came to the fore today that a Greek Cabinet crisis would occur early next week, despite the cautioning of the United States Embassy and aid mission that the present coalition Government under Premier Themistocles Sophoulis, Liberal, had best remain in office, at least until some satisfactory alternative appeared.

ERIC JOHNSTON has long been a successful salesman for the products of industry, both tangible and ideological. In his own thriving brick enterprise, as president of the United States Chamber of Commerce and now as the head of the motion-picture producers association, he has done an outstanding job of merchandising.

BABY kissing is fading from the political scene hut children have continued to play an important part in the American Presidential election circus now reaching its finale. They turned out by hundreds and thousands when one of the candidates came to town.

The trend toward larger sales gains in basement stores than main stores has strengthened, it was learned here yesterday. A survey of leading department stores disclosed that basement sales, generally, have been making better gains in comparison with main stores during recent weeks than at any time during the year.

CHAMPIONS of the underdog will rejoice to find him holding his own so ably in these contests with powerful adversaries. In each story the hero successfully matches a nimble wit against superior strength, wealth or power, winning in each case a victory for the weak and oppressed the world over.

IT is four hundred years since a classical scholar named Georg Faust (sometimes confused with an early printer named Johann Fust) disappeared under mysterious circumstances. Posthumous rumors, attaching his name to the escapades and unorthodoxies of a period teeming with both, increased the confusion and deepened the mystery.

An increase in the present statutory limit of $7,500 for individual savings accounts to a new top of $10,000 is being advocated by savings bank leaders, it was learned yesterday. The proposal is part of an over-all program, now in process of development by the bankers, to broaden their activities and services under current conditions of declining deposit growth.

THE general and strong enthusiasm aroused by the British film, "The Red Shoes," which is a picture about ballet people, is thrilling and refreshing to observe because it obviously isn't peculiar to the pure "balletomanes." It is the natural, spontaneous reaction of the audience to enchantments of a sort which derive not alone from the ballet but from the treatment of ballet on the screen.

BABYLON, L.I. Oct. 30 -- Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, assisted this morning in planting the first of 52,000 tulip bulbs on public grounds in the village of Babylon in preparation for the second annual tulip festival sponsored by the service organizations of the village.

ELECTION news will take precedence over the usually scheduled programs on Tuesday night. The four networks plan to scrap all regular offerings and devote their time to analyses of trends, commentators' reports and actual returns.

Finding themselves again in a highly competitive market, rayon goods suppliers are re-examining quality standards to ease their selling burden, it was pointed out last week. Yarn producers, weavers and converters were agreed that stabilization of the industry depends on their ability to produce goods which will evoke less consumer criticism by measuring up to the claims made for them.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (UP) -- An editorial in the American Medical Association Journal say that no adequate tests have been developed to measure throat irritation caused by cigarettes. The journal adds that from a psychological point of view, smoking may have its points.
HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 30 -- Following is the prepared text of the address delivered here tonight by Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina:

THIS "fictional reportage" was first announced as "The Hoffmanns of Berlin." It also might have been called "That Was Berlin," the heading under which the series has been running in The New Yorker. The Hoffmanns are a German anti-Nazi family which miraculously survived the Third Reich, the war and the bombings, with their minds and characters still intact.

WITH winter's approach motoring organizations are advising drivers to recondition their automobiles for inclement weather. The advice is given added emphasis in a warning from the National Safety Council that winter death rates are from 24 to 53 per cent higher than summer rates in the northern half of the country and from 5 per cent to 33 per cent in southern tiers.

CLINTON, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Scoring an unprecedented victory for a Brittany spaniel in the annals of major circuit pointing breed competition, Ivy of Loufel, owned and handled by Alan R. Stuyvesant of Allamuchy, N.J., today defeated leading pointers and English setters in the amateur shooting dog stake at the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club's annual fall meet.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Premier Stalin's attack Thursday on the Western powers is taken here as proof that the Soviet Union has lost at least one battle in the propaganda war with the United States.

THE recent announcement in your columns that Hollywood would award an "Oscar" annually to the foreign film its Academy Committee considered best, makes it manifest that this decision was reached with the greatest reluctance -- and with little desire to implement it in fact.

Reports received by the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine of the United States Department of Agriculture early this summer indicated that while DDT was satisfactorily controlling house flies generally, it was failing in some areas. Similar reports came from Egypt and Greece.

The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee by the State Charities Aid Association will be marked on the afternoon of Nov. 18 by the tenth annual White Elephant Cocktail Party and Tea Dance in the grand ballroom and adjoining foyers of the Plaza.

The disappearance of thousands of dollars' worth of linens from the Consolidated Laundry Corporation's plant at 311 East Ninety-fourth Street was believed to have been solved yesterday when the police charged four men with the theft of $600 worth of linens.

Tom Voorhees of Paterson, N.J., East Side High, notched his second individual triumph of the season in interscholastic competition yesterday when he finished first in Fordham University's first interscholastic cross-country meet. Voorhees' time over the two-and-a-quarter mile course at Van Cortlandt Park was 13:31.6.

Proceeds1 will be used to furnish the hospital] with linen, blankets and other articles essential for the personal comfort of patients.

The news has been full recently of important names -- heads of states, diplomats and candidates for office. There is always a temptation to exaggerate the significance of outstanding individuals. In addition to balloting for a long list of candidates, residents of the city will be asked to pass on a proposal to amend the City's Administrative Code to legalize the working hours of firemen, now in operation experimentally.

AT a time when so many homes are being built and new gardens planted, the desire of the home owner to have roses growing in the garden is almost inevitable. Yet he hesitates, concerned with the conventional idea that roses can be grown only in full sunshine.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The "help-wanted" sign is back in America's front window. There is a job for every person willing and able to work, or soon will be.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 30 -- Amherst spotted Tufts two touchdowns in the first period, then rallied in the next two to win by 14-13 today.
I was interested to notice in S.J. Woolf's "Then and Now -- Maude Adams," a reference to "a nunnery in Aurora, New York." According to the article, Miss Adams retired there when she left the stage.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 -- A California encyclopedia salesman this week encountered at nearly every call the reaction, "Come back after the election." People did not seem to feel that the election would leave them particularly better or worse off, regardless of its outcome, but appeared to have adopted it as a pretext for postponing consideration of problems generally.

LILY-FLOWERED tulips are comparative newcomers to the tulip world, and are as yet seen in gardens all too infrequently. This is the time to consider some of the outstanding varieties, and plant them for spring bloom.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Oct. 30 (AP) -- United Nations relief officials said today that the recent fighting in southern Palestine between Jews and Egyptians had driven [about 30,000 more Arabs from their lands and homes.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Reiterating its contention that "historic Protestantism rests its final authority on the infallible, inerrant word of God, the Bible," the fundamentalist American Council of Christian Churches today challenged representatives of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America to "open debate" on the validity of the "social gospel" as opposed to fundamentalism.

In your issue of Oct. 17 Godfrey Nelson again points out how the capital gains tax interferes with the flow of savings into industry. It might be added that under present monetary conditions it has the effect of reducing the value of the savings themselves.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Southern Methodist, paced by dazzling Doak Walker, today overpowered the University of Texas, 21 to 6, in Memorial Stadium, before 68,750 fans, biggest crowd in Southwestern football history.

" THIS book is a study of the foreign policy of the United States in recent years." It is moreover -- as the opening sentence does not go on to say -- incomparably the best study of American foreign policy for this period that has yet been written.
Despite public concentration on the two major parties and the current third-party movement, there are actually eleven political parties with Presidential candidates in the present election.

WITH an eye cocked to the Christmas trade, the record companies are putting out an unusually large number of new recordings in November this year. Many of these releases deal with matters operatic, probably because opera is in the news, with the Metropolitan soon to open, the City Center under way and the San Francisco company's season winding up.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 30 -- As election day approaches, New Jersey appears to be safely Republican, except for one or two Congressional races.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Kansas Jayhawks pulled one out of the fire today as Halfback Charlie Moffett returned a pass interception 45 yards for a last quarter touchdown and a 13-to-7 victory over Oklahoma A. and M.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Twelve delegates spent more than three hours today in the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly debating whether Spain should be included in the transfer of the League of Nations Statistical Convention to the United Nations before discovering that Spain never was a party to the original convention.

MONTREAL, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Pete Babando's goal with less than two minutes to play enabled the Boston Bruins to tie the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 3, tonight in their first meeting of the National Hockey League season. Grant Warwick scored Boston's two other goals.

When Henry Clay proposed his Compromise Measure on slavery in 1850, a friend warned him that he was hurting his Presidential candidacy. Mr. Clay replied: "Sir, I would rather be right than be President." Historians do not agree on whether he was right, but he never was President.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 -- Maryland, in which the Democratic politicians were very low in spirit a month ago, now looks like a doubtful state with Gov. Thomas E. Dewey just a shade ahead of President Truman. As to Congress, there is a good chance for some shifting about in the state's delegation in the House of Representatives, with three new situations that appear about equally possible.

On Tuesday, as 60,000,000 Americans go to the polls, attention will be focused on the outcome of the contests for the Presidency, Congress and major state offices. In the State of New Jersey, however, equal attention will be paid by the patients, residents and students of New Jersey's state institutions and their families to a welfare education bond issue of $50,000,000 for state buildings for medical, welfare and educational use.
WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The University of Delaware upset a favored Muhlenberg College eleven today, 12 -- 0, before 8,400.
IN the Lincoln Memorial in Washington are the words, "In this temple as in the hearts of the people for whom he saved the union the memory of Abraham Lincoln is enshrined forever."
The Fifth Avenue corridor of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will display tomorrow the latest "Technical Books of the Month" covering a wide range of topics.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif, Oct. 30 -- The Marine Corps' wartime airbase at Goleta, seven miles north of here, is about to be transformed lock, stock and barrel, into a college.

WASHINGTON, Oct.30 (UP) -- Three Congressional committees promised tonight to keep close tabs on Tuesday's balloting in several states to guard against voting irregularities. They also are inquiring into complaints about election law violations in some primary elections.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Minnesota's football team came to life in the second period today and went on to defeat an under-manned Indiana team, 30 to 7.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 30 - Thomas E. Dewey's election on Tuesday would please Argentina. At least Foreign Minister Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia is on record as having said that he had detected in the Republican campaign speeches a critical attitude toward the "vacillating policy" of the Democratic Administration toward Argentina.

The unique laboratory of the Army-Navy Medical Procurement Office, 84 Sands Street, Brooklyn, has tested nearly 25,000 items of medical equipment destined for all United States Armed Forces throughout the world, according to figures released here yesterday.

Colleges and universities in this country are neglecting the important field of American literature and culture, according to a three-year study sponsored by the National Council of Teachers of English. Less than 5 per cent of the nation's institutions of higher learning require even one course in American literature.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The Soviet Union charged today in the Economic and Financial Committee of the United Nations General Assembly that industrial powers of the world were "imposing a yoke" on underdeveloped countries by drawing off all the raw materials needed in home industries.

Governors Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Earl Warren of California, Republican candidates for President and Vice President, will win over their Democratic opponents, President Harry S. Truman and Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, in the election next Tuesday, according to reports from correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in each of the forty-eight states.

Rabbi William F. Rosenblum, in a sermon yesterday in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, denounced refusal by the State Department to urge a change in the place of the meeting of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and cultural Organization on Nov. 17 from Beirut, Lebanon, as a "flagrant" example of "Arab appeasement within that department."

Blaming the nation's professional schools for indoctrinating their students against collaboration with other professional groups, Lawrence K. Frank, director of the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development, urged closer cooperation yesterday among all those concerned with the mental and physical development of the child.

On these two pages there appears a compilation of the candidacies, issues and forecasts of Tuesday's elections, based on dispatches from correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in the forty-eight states. The data on the Presidential race are confined to the Truman, Dewey, Thurmond and Wallace tickets.
