Business organizations are breaking with long-established traditions of office management to reduce clerical costs, R.L. Forster, president of the Office Executives Association of New York, said last week. The group is one of the 500 local chapters of the National Office Management Association.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The so-called Soviet compromise offer on the Berlin question was looked upon by the British today simply as a trick to get the Western powers to agree to currency talks under the duress of the blockade. Authoritative sources said its publication would not deter the British stand.

TWENTY-SIX stories up, overlooking the open expanse of Central Park, the wind howled last week-end with a ferocity that was not nearly as impressive at street level. Bette Davis, just in from her farm in New England, tarrying long enough to renew some old acquaintances before setting out by automobile for California, didn't like the wind one bit.
THIRTY-FOUR days and thirty performances after it opened last September, the twenty-sixth local season of the San Francisco Opera Company came to an end the other day.

THE name "Modern Wallpapers" seems like a curious understatement of the exhibition at the Architectural League of New York which the American Federation of Arts will presently circulate among several museums throughout the country. A more descriptive title, we should think, would be something like "Today's Spirit in Decoration" -- a spirit which might be defined as the freedom to do anything you please as long as you do it pleasingly.
WHEN considering a deciduous ground cover, silver-edge goutweed is often overlooked by the gardener. It is a pretty green and white foliage plant.
LILIES can be planted in November. Since some kinds come into the stores very late in the year, it may even be necessary to wait until December to put them into the ground.
A 2-year-old girl virtually was boss of the Trans-World Airlines hangar at La Guardia Field yesterday.
Governor Dewey's speech last night at Madison Square Garden, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct 30 -- The Israeli Government has decided that its proposed election and citizenship laws shall apply to any territory within Palestine that was under Israeli Army control, it was learned today.

ANNAPOLIS, MD. -- The dream of a faster city-less and ferry-less north-south coastal highway route is closer to reality now following approval by Army engineers of construction of a highway bridge over Chesapeake Bay near Maryland's capital.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 30 -- Problems of politics, prosperity and public finance held top attention in the Upper South this week.
CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Hamilton College's football team entered the winning column today after four losses by downing Hobart, 13 -- 0, in a hard-fought game.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Cyrus S. Ching, national director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, described today a "preventive" program, under development for the last several months, designed to avert crises between labor and management, "before tempers begin to run high."
BOSTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- State Representative John Brown yesterday joined the ranks of those who want a new kind of money.

FOR THIS WEEK: Prune raspberries and rambler roses, if they have not been done yet. . . . Rake leaves off the lawn to prevent yellowed spots next spring. The hard oak leaves, now starting to fall, are better for mulching under shrubs than for compost. . . . Add to the fruit supply by setting out trees or grape vines this fall. . . .

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 30 -- Charlie Justice's two first-quarter touchdown passes kept North Carolina in the list of major undefeated college football teams today by defeating Tennessee, 14 to 7. It was the Tarheels' thirteenth consecutive victory, over two seasons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Representative Leonard W. Hall of New York, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, predicted today that the Republicans would carry both the Senate and the House on Tuesday, as well as the Presidency, and that in the House they would make a net gain of eleven to twenty-three seats.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 30 -- Despite forecasts of record vote turnouts on next Tuesday, expected because of many hotly contested Senate races and highly controversial regional issues, the Midwest had time this week to discuss many significant nonpolitical developments.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The University of Rochester football team, scoring all its points in the last quarter, defeated Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 14 -- 7, today before 5,000.
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Sunday school superintendent whose idea brought culture to millions of Americans will be honored here tomorrow in the church where Chautauqua was invented.
THE Society for Forgotten Music makes its first public appearance this evening in the New York Public Library.

TAFFETAS, stiff and rustling, are swirling into the spring. They lend themselves as no other fabric to the flyaway look that characterizes the skirts with their winglike side drapes, their backward floating panels and their over-drapes. Not only is the fabric interesting in itself, but it is treated in such manner that it gains in surface value.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin's views regarding President Truman's policies and statements on Palestine make plain what he said today in a conversation with Secretary Marshall and how he felt. Secretary Marshall and Mr.Bevin hardly could have avoided talking about Mr. Truman's recent statements on Palestine, which are regarded here as a repudiation of the Secretary of State's stand on the issue.

TUXEDO PARK, N,Y., Oct. 30 -- More than a hundred of the debutantes from the New York area and some from Maryland and Delaware attended the annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball tonight in the Tuxedo Club. Mrs. David Wagstaff was chairman of the ball committee.
Forty-two thousand workers in the women's cloak and suit industry in this city, up-state and in New Jersey have voted almost unanimously for the union shop, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The Israeli declaration accused Britain tonight of having tried to use the United Nations Security Council for a "political maneuver" to "sever the Negeb [desert area in southern Palestine] from Israel."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -Bank loans, already at a high record, increased more in September than in the two preceding months combined, according to reports by the Federal Reserve Board, and installment sale credit, along with consumer credit generally, hit to new peaks despite the return of Federal controls on Sept. 20 after a lapse of eleven months.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Dr. Bramuglia declined to comment tonight on the assertion by Tass that he had agreed with Mr. Vishinsky on a substitute resolution.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 -- Although the West Coast aircraft industry has staged a pronounced resurgence from its post-war slump, with a current backlog of nearly $1,500,000,000 in orders, a conspicuous fly in the ointment, in the view of manufacturers, is a new low ebb in export business.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt, Thomas E. Dewey and Grover Cleveland are descendants of Thomas Ford and Elizabeth Cooke, early settlers of Dorchester, Mass., according to James A. Hayes of Utica, who traces his wife and children back to the same ancestry.

UNDER plans now being worked out here, French and Japanese motion picture interests will combine efforts for the production of films in both languages. Francois Chevallier, representative for a French film syndicate, said the project is well under way, with Andre Paulve, president of the Societe Distribution Cinematagraphique, planning to arrive in Japan toward the end of the year to complete final agreements with the Toho Motion Picture Company.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Australia called today for a new United Nations Balkans Committee with instructions to crop investigating and concentrate on conciliating quarrels between Greece and her three northern neighbors.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 30 -- The Netherlands has set Nov. 8 as the deadline for ending subsidies, which have been a prominent feature of the nation's trim and tight economy since the end of the war.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 30 -- Mighty Michigan had to do it the hard way today, but it was equal to the test.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- The elections were paramount in the interests of people of the Central States this week. But enthusiasm was generally low, except in local contests which bear on controversial issues or personalities.

ONCE upon a time the Giant-Cub rivalry in baseball was the most bristling in sports. Irate fans not only stoned the ballplayers in their open barouches but also fired away at the sportswriters, which is a perfectly indecent and scandalous thing for anyone to do. Then came a renewal of that rivalry in football with the mighty Chicago Bears clashing with the then-feared Football Giants.
NO praise is too high for Veltheimia viridifolia as a house plant for winter flowering. It is only unfortunate that it has no common name.
William Saroyan ("Formula for the Theatre -- By Saroyan") writes of audiences with some (Continued on Page 4) asperity but considerable truth.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 30 -- Despite the imminence of a Presidential election, local and regional issues are holding greatest interest in the Pacific Northwest this autumn. The most intently watched struggle is the one between Mon Wallgren, 57-year-old Democratic incumbent, and Arthur B. Langlie, 48-year-old Republican challenger, for the Governorship of Washington.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Following is a stenographic text of President Truman's address here tonight:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30 -- Harvard got back on the victory trail after three straight defeats today and did so in an impressive manner as it turned back the Purple of Holy Cross, 20 -- 13, before 35,000 at Harvard Stadium. It was the first triumph for the Crimson players since they upset Columbia in their season's opener.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30 -- A growing suspicion that Tuss McLaughry is fashioning a real football powerhouse in the seclusion of the Hanover Hills was confirmed today when Dartmouth rode rough shod over Yale to score a smashing 41-14 triumph.

Plans are being completed for the bridge party to be given by the Women's Auxiliary of the Church of the Ascension on Thursday in the Roof of the St. Regis for the benefit of the St. Mark's Mission of Alaska. Mrs. Louis Guerineau Myers is chairman of the committee for the event and Miss Susan Alfreda Coxe is vice chairman.

" Today," said President Truman in a speech in Chicago last week, "there is a growing, and dangerous, concentration of economic power in the hands of a few men.*** great corporations have been expanding their power steadily. They have been squeezing small business further and further out of the picture.***"

DETROIT, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the CIO United Auto Workers, today accused the Republican party of "practicing the same kind of up-side-down economies that led to the crash of 1929."
The Police Department will use all its available men -- even rookies without uniforms -- to assure lawful and orderly voting tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Appointment of Ralph Wright, a union official who has been a linotype operator for several New York newspapers, as Assistant Secretary of Labor was announced today by the White House.

Asking laymen's support of the All-Diocesan Mission scheduled to start next Sunday, the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday that the job of evangelizing this city's millions of "on-the-fringe and nominal Christians" was too big for clergymen alone.

The revolt of the States' Rights Democrats against President Harry S. Truman on the civil-rights issue not only will cost him the thirty-eight electoral votes of Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi and South Carolina, but probably will enable Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to win the eleven electoral votes of Virginia and give the Republican Presidential candidate a fair, though possibly not an even, chance to carry Florida with eight electoral votes and Tennessee with twelve electoral votes.

DONORA, Pa., Oct. 31 -- Several hundred asthma and cardiac sufferers remaining in this stricken town were evacuated to other areas tonight as a welcome rain helped to clear the air of a smog believed to have contributed to the deaths of twenty residents.
MANILA, Monday, Nov. 1 -- (AP) -- The United States confirmed today that the Philippine Scouts, a part of the United States Army since 1901, would be gradually disbanded in the next eleven months.

The Rev. Joseph Szczepkowski, a member of the executive committee of the Methodist Church in Poland and for twenty-five years a minister in Warsaw, asserted yesterday that "there is absolute freedom of worship" in his country.

The Third Order of St. Francis, a religious order of men and women "living in the world," held its twenty-fourth annual communion breakfast yesterday in the Pennsylvania Hotel, after mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West Thirty-first Street.
Output of plastics materials this year will probably set a new record for volume, despite somewhat lessened activity in the molding field.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 31 -- The fatal "smog" which blanketed Donora, Pa., for two days recalled for many Belgians today the mysterious Meuse Valley fog which caused more than seventy deaths in 1930.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The importance of Cleveland as a world port is described in an article in the current issue of Foreign Commerce Weekly, a Department of Commerce publication.

A journalist, four occupational therapists, two civic leaders and a licturer on the cure of alcoholism will be honored as the 1948 Women of Achievement at the Women's International Exposition, which will open at noon today in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills elevated themselves into a tie for first place in the Eastern Division of the All- America Football Conference today by trimming the Baltimore Colts, 35 to 17, before a crowd of 23,694 in Civic Stadium.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has asked for bids to be received on Nov. 16 for $14,518,000 of first mortgage bonds of the New York Bay Railroad. The bonds will be dated Oct. 1, 1948, and will mature on Oct. 1, 1973. They contain a provision for an annual sinking fund of $300,000 and will be guaranteed by the Pennsylvania Railroad as to principal, interest and sinking fund.

In the South sweet potatoes aren't just a vegetable that's fried, baked or candied to accompany a main dish. The versatile tuber also is the feature ingredient in puddings, pies and pone. Now, from the Louisiana yam growers, comes a suggestion for another way to use their product.

A 3-year-old Doberman pinscher, Ch. Wittland's Black King, belonging to Leo Wittenberg of Hollis, L.I., took the best-in-show award of the twenty-seventh all-breed event of the Bronx County Kennel Club in cavernous Kingsbridge Armory, the Bronx, yesterday.

With borrowed money costing local governments about 1 per cent more in interest than at the end of the war, voters in all parts of the nation will be called upon tomorrow to give their say-so on a third billion-dollar round of proposed post-war bond issues for state and local governments.

The Teachers Union reported yesterday that it had received hundreds of telegrams and letters from educators, parents, authors, artists and trade unionists commending the statement "in defense of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights" made by Samuel Wallach, former president of the Teachers Union, before a Congressional subcommittee on education and labor.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Lanvin favors clear tones in a midseason collection very much in the Christmas party mood. Violet, cinnamon, Chestnut, bright apple green stand out midst black, pewter and dove grays.
At the top of the slate tomorrow the voter will find a single Proposition. On that Proposition we recommend that he vote Yes.

DETROIT, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Coming from behind after spotting Green Bay a 7-0 lead, the Detroit Lions cracked an eight-game losing streak by beating the Packers, 24 to 20, today for their initial National Football League victory under Coach Bo McMillin.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 31 -- Competent authorities in Berne have decided to prohibit by Federal decree traffic in gold passing through the free zones of Geneva and Basle. The decision is a result of deliberations held last week by the Swiss National Bank and representatives of the great commerical banks in Switzerland.

At the National Business Show in this city more than a hundred exhibitors of office machinery have been out to convince businessmen that the road to success is paved with high-speed computing gadgets, work flows and time-study engineering. From IBM in New York to Marchant in California, these fabricators of efficiency dazzle the eye with the advantages of capacity carry-overs and electronic solvers that outthink man, eleven to one.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Five members of the Silvers family were dead tonight and three surviving children were in critical condition from coal gas poisoning in a tragedy that has not been explained fully.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Plans listing the number of infantry and armored divisions plus the number of jet fighter squadrons necessary for defense of the Brussels Treaty powers now have been drawn up at Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery's headquarters here.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October expanded to the largest total since July, but it was the smallest for an October since 1944, the last Presidential election year. Sales crossed the million-share mark in seven sessions, the heaviest of which was 1,801,600 shares on Oct. 22.

In his article of Oct. 2 on Justice Black and the Supreme Court, Arthur Krock by implication and direct statement presents a view of the Supreme Court before and after 1937 that the facts do not support.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 31 -- With the approval of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is planning to expand the field of its work to include Japan.

With Pete Layden setting a team record for total offense, the Football Yankees reinstated themselves as a contender for the All-America Conference's Eastern Division title by routing the Chicago Rockets, 42 -- 7, at the Stadium yesterday.

Bernard M. Baruch acknowledged yesterday that he had received a letter from President Truman some months ago, but he declined to discuss its contents. Published reports have been that the President, in such a letter, criticized Mr. Baruch for not accepting a post on the Democratic National Finance Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- "The Red Badge of Courage," Stephen Crane's notable novel of a day of battle during the Civil War, published in 1895, will be brought to the screen by Paul Short, independent producer, if current negotiations with the estate of the author are concluded.

DONORA, Pa., Oct. 31 -- Solemn groups stood outside churches and hospitals here today to discuss the silent death that struck down residents here yesterday in a low-lying smog that had enveloped the community since Wednesday.

New York's new residents who arrived Saturday from Europe in the first group admitted under the Displaced Persons Law spent their first day in America doing as they pleased -- something new for most of them.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Nearly 875,000 Puerto Rican voters will elect their own Governor for the first time Tuesday.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- -Russia described today as "false" and "malicious" United States and British reports that the Russians had increased the German police force in their occupation zone by 200,000 to 300,000 men.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Oct. 31 -- President Truman returned home today as a "country boy," believing, after an unprecedented political campaign, that he has developed a hidden groundswell which will sweep him into the Presidency for four years in his own right.

The report of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, shows net earnings of $12,244,926, or $3.31 a share on the outstanding common stock. In the corresponding nine months of last year, earnings amounted to $5,197,934, or $1.45 a share.

CLINTON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- In a hard slashing ground race topped by one find, Reaction, a 4-year-old pointer, owned and handled by Carl W. Shattuck of Mountain Lakes, N.J., won the amateur all-age stake of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club's annual fall meeting today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 31 -- The Israeli Army claimed today the complete rout of Fawzi el-Kawukji's forces in the Galilee bulge, thus knocking the second Arab army out of the Palestine war in little more than two weeks. "The entire Galilee area has been cleared," an Israeli Army spokesman declared.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The story of the stock markets here in the last week has been much the same as in many weeks past. Their behavior still suggests that Britain's cares, if they have not altogether vanished, are not such as to dampen the quietly bullish sentiment that exists and which has carried security prices as a whole up a little further.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Recovery authorizations for Western Europe and China during the week ending Oct. 27 totaled $179, 032,075, and brought a small-scale revival of East-West trade, the Economic Cooperation Administration reported today.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Gen. Manuel Odria took office as provisional President of Peru today and named a new, all-military Cabinet.

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police indicated yesterday that they were less punctual than persistent. There was some head-shaking when thirty-three Mounties came riding down Fifth Avenue on their storied steeds, looking very dashing in their scarlet uniforms -- but an hour late.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The canning industry has undergone a major change in the pattern of merchandising this year as a result of drastically conservative buying practices on the part of the retailer and wholesaler, a trade leader said today in outlining industry difficulties which have led to some curtailment in the amount of food products packed.
Twenty oils and water-colors of ships painted by a seagoing engineer, Comdr. Lauren S. McReady, USMS, will be placed on exhibition this afternoon at the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street.
Mayor O'Dwyer attacked Governor Dewey's labor record last night in a radio appeal for the re-election of President Truman.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 31 -- A warning was sounded today from the pulpits of Roman Catholic churches here and in neighboring communities against the support in Tuesday's election of local candidates who have endorsed a proposal to legalize in this state the dissemination of birth control information by physicians.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Selective Service officials in the nation's ten largest cities reported today that an average of 72 per cent of the 24 and 25-year-olds called up for pre-induction physical examinations were unfit for military service.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Defensively weak and offensively weaker, the New York Football Giants suffered a 35-14 setback at the hands of the Chicago Bears in their National Football League encounter at Wrigley Field today.

Many lawyers are not the leaders of public opinion that they should be, Arthur T. Vanderbilt, Chief Justice of New Jersey, asserted yesterday in his last annual report as dean of the New York University School of Law.

Predicting a victory for President Truman and the Democratic party at the polls on Tuesday, United States Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared last night that the Senate would go Democratic by three to five seats.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The British Government opposes any unnecessary postponement of the Palestine issue at the United Nations, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.
Signaling the first round of Yuletide spending, $166,758,636 will be withdrawn from mutual savings banks throughout the nation by more than 2,131,530 Christmas Club members during the next few weeks.

John Haynes Holmes, in his sermon yesterday at the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, characterized the current presidential campaign as "trivial, inane, the worst I have ever known." He declared that there was no fundamental difference between the Democratic and Republican parties "in anything that matters," and held that as far as the destiny of humankind was concerned it would not make the "slightest bit of difference" which nominee was elected.

The annual election of officers for the Atlantic and Gulf district of the Seafarers International Union, AFD, begins today, with sixty-one candidates contesting for thirty-three positions. The elections will run through Dec. 31.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- (AP) -- The Paterson Panthers took over undisputed possession of first place in the American Football League today by defeating the Richmond Rebels, 20 -- 14, before 9,862 in Hinchliffe Stadium.
Miss Celeste Jedel, writer and former secretary to Raymond Moley, died last night in a fire in her three-room apartment at 333 West Eighty-sixth Street.

The largest local in the Barbers and Beauty Culturists Union, CIO, disaffiliated yesterday in a move paralleling the recent secession of eight left-wing store locals from the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Nothing is more certain in Tuesday's national election than that the Senate is to have a big turnover in membership.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- The Blind Brook four, led by Walter Nicholls, who made three goals from his No. 3 spot, defeated the Fairfield (Conn.) polo team, 5 to 4, before 4,000 at the Blind Brook Club today.

A three-man arbitration board awarded yesterday a 10 per cent cost-of-living wage increase to 15,000 drivers and laundry workers employed by thirty-five major linen supply houses in the metropolitan area.

A proposal seeking to pave the way for settlement of the strike of the Radio Writers Guild was accepted yesterday by representatives of advertising agencies and sponsors of radio programs. It was advanced during a five-hour meeting by J.R. Mandelbaum, assistant regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

For the first time in three seasons of All-America Conference competition, the Brooklyn Dodgers were shut out yesterday, the Los Angeles Dons blanking the Dodgers 17 -- 0, before 12,825, including Gov. Millard Caldwell of Florida, and 125 members of the Orange Bowl committee.
Three clergymen in this city preached sermons yesterday in behalf of greater Christian unity and of a rapprochement of Protestants and Catholics.

Sales of women's coats here last week were estimated from 50 to 100 per cent above sales in the comparable period last year, according to reports on conditions in the wholesale apparel market here, prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

MADRID, Oct. 31 -- Information has been received that the split between Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union has now become so wide that in the event of a world war it is by no means certain that Marshal Tito would activate his military alliance with the Soviet Union.

Scoring three times in the first period, Cardinal Hayes went on to an easy 34-14 victory over Fordham Prep yesterday at Triborough Stadium before 6,000. It was the fourth straight triumph for Hayes after dropping its opener to Brooklyn Prep.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- An advance in December wheat to above the Government loan level and heavy receipts of cash corn featured the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week. However, prices held within comparatively narrow limits and liberal hedging sales in both wheat and corn were offset by increased Government buying.

A trend toward a stable and constructive labor relationship in the mass-production industries is indicated in a report issued over the week-end by the National Planning Association's committee on the causes of industrial peace under collective bargaining.

The eighth anniversary of the Axis attack against Greece was commemorated yesterday in the Greek Orthodox Cathedral at 319 East Seventy-fourth Street under the auspices of the Federation of American Hellenic Societies of Greater New York, the American Legion and the Greek War Veterans.
A.E. Halberstadt has been appointed general manager of the A.B.C. Freight Forwarding Corporation.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 -- For the second successive period the steel industry wound up last week at 99 per cent of rated capacity. Salespeople in this area believe there will be little chance of missing a peacetime record in steel ingot output this year and believe the figure will be close to 88,000,000 tons.
With one week to go before the opening of his one-man show of paintings at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, Walt Kuhn announced yesterday that the exhibition would be a farewell appearance.

An invitation to parents and others interested in public education to inspect the city's schools during Open School Week, which will begin a week from today and continue through Nov. 12, was issued yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking last night from Paris where she is attending United Nations sessions as an American delegate, appealed for the election of President Truman and a Democratic Congress. It was Mrs. Roosevelt's first speech of the 1948 political campaign.

The New Friends of Music opened their thirteenth season of concerts of chamber music yesterday afternoon before an audience which packed Town Hall, testifying anew to the firm place that this concert series has won in the musical life of this city.

State, municipal, public-utility and railroad bonds offered in October amounted to $416,652,000 for forty-seven issues, against $297,462,000 for forty-nine issues in September. In October, last year, offerings were $393,939,000 for thirty-six issues.
Henry A. Wallace made peace the major issue yesterday in talks to 100,000 persons at sixteen campaign rallies in Brooklyn, stronghold of the American Labor party.

NANKING, Oct. 31 -- The Chinese Government scuttle its Aug. 19 price control program today as an unsuccessful venture and announced a new series of economic regulations based on accepting inflation as a recognized fact. The Government lifted price ceilings on all foodstuffs, rehitched Government salaries to the rising cost-of-living index and restored to municipalities the power to deal locally with prices, many daily necessities and industrial raw materials.

Foam rubber, introduced in train and bus seats and since used for mattresses, is going into pillows and ready-made studio coaches. At least four makes of pillows are available, ranging from extra soft to thick styles, since the latex can be foamed to degrees of softness.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Eleven Rumanians pleaded guilty today to charges of plotting with American and British representatives to overthrow the Government. A verdict will be handed down on Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Tommy Thompson's passes seemed radar-directed and Steven Van Buren ran like a berserk bull today as the Philadelphia Eagles rolled over the Pittsburgh Steelers, 34 -- 7, before about 30,000 fans in the haze of Forbes Field.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 31 (AP) -- One passenger was killed and three were injured, none seriously, at 7:30 o'clock this morning in a collision of the passenger steamer District of Columbia and the tanker Georgia in a fog in Hampton Roads.

Regarding the complaint of a Frustrated Father, permit me to add that this frustrated farmer is in a worse boat. Farmers may set clocks back, and may have babies change their waking and feeding hours. But has any city man ever tried to change the time a rooster starts to crow, and thus wake the farmyard?

There were some interesting price changes in the foreign-exchange market last week which were in the main only reflecting special conditions and not at all symptomatic of general unsteadiness. There was the sudden break in the pound sterling; a softer tone in the Canadian free dollar and a sharp decline in the Swiss free franc.

After a week of studying the habits of their prospective victim, two armed robbers held up Miss Eleanore Moore, a restaurant owner, in her suite at the Winthrop Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, early yesterday.

The Explorers Club flag No. 127, carried by Capt. Hassoldt Davis and his wife, Ruth, on their recent expedition to the unexplored hinterland of French Guiana, will be returned to the club's headquarters at 10 West Seventy-second Street on Nov. 9, when Captain Davis is scheduled to report on his findings and present 2,000 feet of color film.
ATHENS, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- Fighting against guerrilla forces in the southernmost peninsula of Greece, jutting south from the Peloponnesus, was reported in tonight's Greek General Staff Communique.

The Flatlands Post of the American Legion received a special citation yesterday from the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross for contributing 5,000 pints of blood during World War II. At the ceremonies at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, before the football game between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Los Angeles Dons, an honor guard of veterans whose lives were saved with plasma stood by.

GROSSE ISLE, Mich., Oct. 31 (UP) -- A high Navy official today brought into the open again the long-smouldering Navy-Air Force fight over which should do the chief long-range bombing job in the event of war.
Wartime seamen and non-veteran officers and men in active posts at sea are being called for induction by local draft boards, it was reported yesterday.

With their stores shut down by a jurisdictional strike, the owners of 100 Harlem pharmacies decided yesterday to sign contracts with both rival unions and let the courts decide which was legally entitled to represent their employes.

For the first time, permanent peacetime uses for large quantities of silver in machinery bearings have appeared, with a rapidly growing trend of consumption indicating that silver may displace tin to a large extent in engines and many industrial services.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Sammy Baugh's aerial lightning bolts flashed with devastating fury today as the Washington Redskins massacred the Boston Yanks, 59 to 21, in the highest total ever run up by the Tribe in a National Football League game.

Most of forty-one passengers for the Pacific Coast stranded here Saturday night, when none of them could find the officials of a travel agency from which they had bought "air coach" tickets for $88 each, were on their way to Los Angeles and San Francisco last night.

The Rangers had it last night. The New York entry in the National Hockey League turned in a sparkling exhibition in upsetting the previously undefeated Boston Bruins, 2 -- 0, in a slashing battle that kept a crowd of 14,768 tense with excitement at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, disagreed sharply today with those who felt that the atomic bomb was the greatest threat to the future of man. He maintained that the "menacing state of mind of the dogmatist and extremist" was the chief danger facing the world.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 31 -- Jose Luis Bustamante y Rivera, deposed President of Peru, declared here today that there was no justification for the Rightist military coup that had ousted him Friday without forcing him to resign.

In the event of a war between Soviet Russia and the Western powers neither side can gain, Dr. Goodwin Watson, professor of education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday in an address before the New York Metropolitan Section of the National Jewish Welfare Board.

A veteran city fireman and a housewife paired up yesterday to deliver twin girls to Mrs. Edward F. Sullivan of 402 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. It was their second joint obstetrical venture. Two years ago they had helped Mrs. Stella Rodriquez of 406 Fourth Avenue bring her son Robert into the world.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- The appointment of Dr. Milton J.E. Senn, of Cornell University Medical College, as director of the new Yale Child Study Center was announced today.

Experiments in the use of television for the mass instruction of trainees will be conducted in the near future by the Office of Naval Research at the Special Devices Center at Sands Point, L.I., it was announced yesterday.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- In the largest opening dinghy session on record here twenty-six craft hoisted sail today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

PHILADEPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Urgent need for prompt approval of further freight-rate increases was asserted today by M.W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in a special message to the company's stockholders.

ATHENS, Oct. 31 -- Greece's coalition government of Populists and Liberals under Premier Themistocles Sophoulis, which assumed power some thirteen months, ago with American backing, was still in the saddle tonight. However, the crisis was considered perhaps only to have been postponed.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The parents of Irving Ross said tonight his wife and three daughters were to leave for Austria tomorrow to make their home with him there. The eldest of the daughters is 12.

The Government of Chiang Kai-shek has suffered the worst blow since the darkest days of the war as a result of the forced evacuation of Mukden, which has fallen or is about to fall into the hands of the Chinese Communists. For the fall of Mukden signifies the fall of Manchuria, which means that China has lost the great industrial center which was to be the economic basis of its recovery.
Students from Metropolitan Vocational High School who are studying for sea careers aboard the John W. Brown, Pier 4, East River, held "open ship" yesterday for 400 parents, teachers and friends.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- French Communist labor's second line of defense in the ports and on the railways in the battle for coal seemed to be crumbling today as troops unloaded ships and insured the passage of coal trains from the Belgian frontier.

PARIS, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Police I cleared strikers out of two more coal mines in central France to-{ day as the Govermnent announcedI new price cuts in its program to] {bring prices znd wages in line. ] At Aontceau - lex - 1W_ines, Corn-

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 31 -- The Security Committee of the Israeli Provisional Parliament has confirmed a decision of the Army General Staff dissolving the separate headquarters of the Palmach, Socialist-inspired elite corps of the Army, and the headquarters' affiliated services, it was learned today.

VIENNA, Oct. 31 -- The expulsion of strongly Communist-inclined Socialist leader Erwin Scharf from the Austrian Social Democratic party has become for the moment a leading political issue here. A serious split in the so-far solidly unified Socialist party would be calculated better any other development to place Austria on the possible road to eventual absorption into the Soviet satellite system along with her neighbors, Czechoslovakia and Hungary.

Controller Lazarus Joseph made public yesterday his annual report covering the fiscal year ended June 30. The 434-page volume, crammed with figures dealing with every aspect of the city's finances, showed that the 1948-49 fiscal year opened on July 1 with $75,060,282 in the general fund.
PAWLING, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Wearied by his long Presidential campaign, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey decided to spend this perfect autumn day relaxing on his farm here. In the morning he went to church.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- The Weather Bureau said tonight that voters in most parts of the country would have fair weather Tuesday, but it forecast some rain for the more populous states east of the Mississippi.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 -- Max Schmeling, 43-year-old former world's heavyweight champion, lost a slow ten-round decision today to Richard Vogt of Hamburg, German light-heavyweight champion, and then announced: "This is my last fight."

A strike intended to cut off the supply of fish for hotels and restaurants was voted yesterday by 300 members of the United Sea Food Workers, AFL. The strike was scheduled to become effective at midnight.

Outplayed for the most part, the New York Rovers' 1948-49 debut on Madison Square Garden is yesterday afternoon was an unhappy one. Unable to cope with the speed and slick stick-handling of the visitors, Phil Watson's Red Shirts dropped a 4-2 decision to the Montreal Royals in a Quebec Senior Hockey League tussle that featured a double-header.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 -- In one of the least acrimonious contests that New Jersey has experienced in many years, Archibald S. Alexander, Democrat, and State Treasurer Robert C. Hendrickson, Republican, will end their campaigns tomorrow for the United States Senate.

Prices for cotton registered here last week were generally lower despite the improvement of the preceding week. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 23 to 39 points, in contrast with net gains of 23 to 39 points in the previous week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- President Truman said today that the world's hopes for peace put "a grave responsibility upon our schools" in training future generations of American citizens.

DETROIT, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Steady Teddy Lindsay slapped in his fifth goal of the season and three other Detroiters caged their first as the Red Wings downed Montreal, 4 to 1, tonight before 13,712 fans to regain the undisputed lead in the National Hockey League.

The American branch of the Society for Forgotten Music gave its first concert last night at the New York Public Library, with the cooperation of that institution. An unusually provocative program was presented, consisting entirely of neglected instrumental and vocal compositions of the Eighteenth and Nineteenth Centuries deemed worthy of revival for audiences of today.

Competitive skiing in this part of the country will reach record heights during the 1948-49 season, judging by the comprehensive schedule of 125 tournaments sanctioned yesterday by the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association as its twenty-seventh meeting came to an end at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The annual James J. Hoey Awards for Interracial Justice were presented yesterday by Cardinal Spellman to Mrs. Anna McGarry, vice president of the Catholic Interracial Council of Philadelphia, and Ferdinand L. Rousseve, Negro architect, formerly of New Orleans.

Norman Thomas made his final major address yesterday in his sixth campaign for the Presidency. The Socialist candidate called it his valedictory but pledged all his energies to formation of a new party to which he said all the forces of economic and political democracy could rally.
Any one who saw Notre Dame trample Navy will find it difficult to believe that there is a better football team than the one Frank Leahy has under his command.

Tempering the widely held belief that the price decline in farm products last month meant an end of inflation, the National City Bank of New York, in its November letter released today, warned that it was "too early to write off further inflationary dangers."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland,: Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- The Rev. Dr. A. W. Neill of Armagh, [oderator of the Presbyterian Church in Ireland, died hero tonight at the age of 61. Dr. Neill, who was appointed Wroderator irL June, collapsed shortly before he was scheduled to 'broadcast a sermon for the British Broadcasting Corporation's Overseas Program.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- In an interview published this morning in the official Soviet German-language newspaper, Taegliche Rundschau, the deputy Soviet commandant in Berlin, Col. Alexis Yelisarov, warned the Berlin City Administration against carrying out the municipal elections, scheduled for Dec. 5, in the three Western sectors.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Doug Bentley hammered through a goal in the last eleven seconds of play tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 2-to-1 National Hockey League triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs before 16,206.

Students at New York City schools and colleges and other persons interested are being especially urged this year to contribute to the World Student Service Fund drive for $50,000 being held from Nov. 1 through Nov. 14. Money raised each year by this organization goes to aid needy professors and students in Europe, China and other parts of Asia.

Just about a year ago Bar Harbor was swept by a fire that reduced a large area of Mount Desert Island to ashes. In that disaster the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory was destroyed, and with it precious records and at least 50,000 pedigreed mice and other animals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Directors of the United States Chamber of Commerce declared today that the country's $250,000,000,000 public debt and $40,000,000,000 annual budget made a thorough review of our currency and credit system necessary.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams staged a belated three-touchdown splurge in the last half today, but failed to overhaul the National Football League champion Chicago Cardinals and were beaten, 27 to 22, before 32,149 fans.
Five new pictures are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Mary Nolan, who danced her way to world fame as Imogene (Bubbles) Wilson in the Ziegfeld Follies, died today.

PEIPING, Oct. 31 -- Nationalists in Hopeh Province seem to be attempting to take eleventh-hour military initiative before the Communists, obviously winning Manchuria, have time to move full force into North China.
Spokesmen for nine strikebound breweries announced yesterday that they had agreed to put off efforts to resume deliveries until Wednesday to permit new attempts at settlement of the wildcat tie-up.

LOUDON, Tenn., Oct. 31 (AP) -- National Guard troops, who were ordered here yesterday when a sheriff reported possible mob violence stemming from the death of a hillbilly singer, were withdrawn today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Royall balked at calling President Truman's election either "necessary" or "essential" to national defense today, but declared it "desirable.''

Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, and Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican Senate leader, debated the campaign issues yesterday over the Columbia Broadcasting System, with Senator Taft speaking from Cincinnati and Senator McGrath from New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Vitamin B-12, recently isolated and still available only in small quantities, unquestionably has a beneficial effect not offered by any other chemical substance on one of the most difficult complications of pernicious anemia, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, Dr. Tom Spies of Northwestern University Medical School reported today.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- United Nations and French political circles here have been much interested the last two days in rumors that President Truman had instructed Secretary Marshall to stall off action on Palestine not only until after the Presidential elections but also until after the end of the current General Assembly session.

Some two dozen new art exhibitions will open in the local galleries and museums this week. Prominent among today's openings is the Miller Company's collection of abstract paintings and sculpture at the Knoedler Galleries, with proceeds of the twenty-five cent admission charge earmarked for the Scholarship Fund of the New York University School of Fine Arts.

Seekers after the kingdom of heaven we reminded yesterday by the Rev. Michael J. Deacy of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff that they would be judged by the "mercy, compassion and love they showed their fellow men."
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Recent developments in the dairy industry prompted spokesmen and market analysts today to predict that more butter would become available for consumers.

Bernard M. Baruch declared yesterday that unless we in this country thought less of our "rights and privileges" and more of our "duties and obligations" toward individuals, groups and nations, America would "not have freedom."

LOUDON, Tenn., Oct. 31 (AP) -- National Guard troops, who were ordered here yesterday when a sheriff reported possible mob violence stemming from the death of a hillbilly singer, were withdrawn today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Royall balked at calling President Truman's election either "necessary" or "essential" to national defense today, but declared it "desirable.''

Offerings of municipal bonds in this week's market will be topped by three issues of obligations of Harris County, Texas, on Thursday, totaling $17,500,000. On the same day, the Washington Toll Bridge Authority will open bids on $10,000,000 of Puget Sound Bridge and Ferry revenue bonds due in twenty years.

The Belasco Theatre, 115 West Forty-fourth Street, passed into the hands of new owners on Friday, it became known yesterday. That much is bona fide. But the identity of the purchaser, the amount paid or the agent who figured in the transaction is supposed to be a dark secret.

POUaHEPm. Y., 31 -- Joseph Bernhart of 114Innis' i Avenue, retired member of the New York Fire Department, died Thursday in his home at the age of 77. He had lived here for fifteen years. He was born and educated in New York. He retired from the fire department several years ago. He leaves his wife, Elizabeth ]3ernlus-t: son, Henry Bernhsrt: a daughter, Mrs. George Stangel, and three sisters.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- On this gray afternoon the wide trottoirs of the Champs Elysees and the sere allees of the Luxembourg Gardens are uncomfortably crowded with sedate family groups enjoying their Sunday promenade. The families are larger than they were -- the most striking social change in postwar France -- but on this dress-up occasion the many children are as quiet as the few used to be.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 -Former Mayor Frank Hague late this afternoon predicted overwhelming victory on election day for President Truman -- in Hudson County.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Armstrong Tire and Rubber Company has filed a $500,000 suit in the United States District Court against the United Rubber, Cork, Plastic and Linoleum Workers of America (CIO), its Local 303 and eight members, W.A. Murphy, company secretary-treasurer, has announced.

The first piloted airplane flights in which ram-jet engines furnished the power to keep the plane aloft were announced yesterday by the United States Air Force and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation of Burbank, Calif.

Harald Kreutzberg gave his only New York recital of the season last night at the Ziegfeld Theatre in a program consisting principally of new numbers. That they are very similar to the old ones is only further testimony to the fact that there is a distinctive Kreutzbergian style.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., after a ten-day visit to Palestine today, declared he felt it was "high time" for the United States to develop its own policy on the Palestine question -- a policy "which would consider the interest of our own citizens first and lead toward a lasting peace."

Books about two countries under Soviet dominance will be brought out by two concerns next week. Whittlesey House has set "The Rape of Poland," by Stanislaw Mikolajczk, former Prime Minister of the Polish Government-in-Exile, for publication next Monday.

One year ago the state opened one of its five experimental Institutes of Applied Arts and Sciences in a rented schoolhouse at White Plains. Like its counterparts in Binghamton, Utica, Buffalo and Brooklyn, the institute was designed to provide two-year concentrated technical training for young men and women who could not attend regular colleges because of lack of finances, time or entrance opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The House Committee on Campaign expenditures announced tonight that it had begun an inves- tigation of alleged registration irregularities in the Eighteenth District of New York.

A campaign to enlist women's support behind legislation seeking repeal of the 20 per cent Federal excise tax on cosmetics and some toiletry articles was reported here last week to be receiving "tremendous response," as well as additional backing.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 31 -- Israeli authorities disclosed today that a "great industrial center" for the manufacture of a wide variety of consumer goods was being planned for Rehoboth, a town near Tel Aviv. Construction of the first plant, which will employ several thousand persons, already has begun.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- A record $4,000,000,000 was spent on new homes, apartments, industrial plants and other privately financed construction projects during the three months ended Sept 30, the Federal Works Agency reported today.

A VISITOR to Baltimore over the past week-end discovered that the sports offerings there were more educational than exciting. First of all, there was Citation in his walkover Pimlico. Then there was Notre Dame in another walkover. That last one, however, hadn't been advertised as such.

Books about two countries under Soviet dominance will be brought out by two concerns next week. Whittlesey House has set "The Rape of Poland," by Stanislaw Mikolajczk, former Prime Minister of the Polish Government-in-Exile, for publication next Monday.

One year ago the state opened one of its five experimental Institutes of Applied Arts and Sciences in a rented schoolhouse at White Plains. Like its counterparts in Binghamton, Utica, Buffalo and Brooklyn, the institute was designed to provide two-year concentrated technical training for young men and women who could not attend regular colleges because of lack of finances, time or entrance opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The House Committee on Campaign expenditures announced tonight that it had begun an inves- tigation of alleged registration irregularities in the Eighteenth District of New York.

A campaign to enlist women's support behind legislation seeking repeal of the 20 per cent Federal excise tax on cosmetics and some toiletry articles was reported here last week to be receiving "tremendous response," as well as additional backing.

NANKING, Nov. 1 -- Nationalist planes bombed Mukden at 4 P.M. today, one hour after the Communists had completed their occupation of Manchuria's leading city An authoritative report from Mukden said that the Communists entered this thriving industrial center this morning, started disarming scattered Government troops and were in full control by 3 P.M.

DONORA, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP) -- A state health official reported tonight that he had found "small quantities" of poison gas in the air over this industrial town where nineteen sufferers from asthmatic and cardiac afflictions died suddenly over the week-end.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1 (AP) -The possibility of a record turnout of New Jersey voters in tomorrow's Presidential election was indicated today when statewide registration figures showed a new high of 2,399,780 persons eligible to cast ballots.
Governor Dewey declared last night that the paramount issue of the campaign was whether the United States would be a strong, united nation, able to meet "the challenge of a dangerous world."

Outcome of voting today on issues involving legalization of liquor in Kansas and California will be closely studied by distilled beverage producers for effects on proposed Federal legislation restricting liquor advertising, which "dry" groups are expected to reintroduce at the next Congress, it was learned here yesterday.

Launching the second week of Fordham's preparations for Saturday's encounter with Boston University at the Polo Grounds, Coach Ed Danowski staged a three-hour drill yesterday, highlighted by an intra-squad scrimmage. A slightly revamped first team engaged the second-string eleven in a long workout under game conditions.

With regard to your editorial of Oct. 22 "The Coastal Ships," it has needed neither a prophet, nor the son of a prophet, to point out that our coastal commerce was going to vanish from the water, and become part and parcel of the commerce of the hinterland.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 1 -The Holy Synod of Archbishops elevated Archbishop Spyrou Athenagoras of New York today to Patriarch of the Greek Orthodox Church.
There will be little available on radio and television tonight other than election news and music.
Voters all over the nation will go to the polls today in generally fair weather, according to a forecast late yesterday by the Weather Bureau at Washington.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1 -Princeton's varsity eleven, decidedly elated over its powerful showing against Virginia Saturday, ran through a short and spirited scrimmage today in preparation for its defense of the "Big Three" title against Art Valpey's invading Harvard team in Palmer Stadium this week-end.

Build-up of mill inventories of women's full-fashioned hosiery in the last few weeks has resulted in special reductions on unbranded lines, it was learned yesterday. The distressed goods were mainly sheer types offered by secondary producers, buyers said, but some weakness has developed among all categories of hose.

One of Broadway's most distinctive landmarks, THE NEW YORK TIMES' moving electric news sign, will be in service tonight for its sixth Presidential election. And four days hence -- on Saturday -the sign will observe its twentieth birthday.

The City Planning Commission's report accompanying the proposed capital budget for 1949 raises some interesting questions of policy. The Commission as a whole expresses agreement with the Board of Estimate's decision to keep control of waterfront rehabilitation in the city's Department of Marine and Aviation.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- There is mounting resistence in the Soviet zone of occupation to the new semi-military police force and the elimination of all but fanatical Communists from positions of authority, Western intelligence reports show.

The feature race at the Empire-at-Jamaica meeting yesterday attracted only three runners, and it was generally believed before post-time that the event would be the nearest thing to a walkover for Safe Arrival of the King Ranch. He was in there against Three Rings, owned by Mrs. Evelyn L. Hopkins, and Silver Drift, running in the colors of Mrs. Richard J. Maloney Jr.

Robert White, a 22-year-old stage and radio actor, was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn on the charge of violating the Selective Service Act of 1948 by failing to register for the draft. Arraigned before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein, in Federal Court, Brooklyn, he waived examination and was held in $1,000 bail for the grand jury.

Although forecasting a victory for President Truman today, Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, expressed his belief last night that the election would be "exceedingly close."
Notre Dame was elected No. 1 football team in the nation yesterday in the weekly Associated Press poll of sports writers, barely nosing out Michigan by a margin of 3 points.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Two Democratic members today accused a GOP-controlled House Expenditures subcommittee of going out of bounds in ordering an investigation of the New Mexico Senate race.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- In morning coats, instead of the usual wigs and gowns a special tribunal began an inquiry today into possible graft in Government departments. The session, held in a packed chamber in London's famed Law Courts Building, was devoted only to formalities.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 1 -- From a Midwest living room overflowing with relatives, President Truman asked his fellow citizens tonight to decide his political future according to their convictions. He told them, however, that he believed the Democrats would govern them more equitably than the Republicans.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 1 -- With the arrest of retired Gen. Carlos Ibanez, former President of the republic, and retired Gen. Ramon Vergara, former Governor of the Province of Santiago, it is reported in informed circles that a conspiracy against the Government has been discovered, although the extent, inspiration, objective, and the persons involved have not yet been made known.

The Association of Catholic Trade Unionists charged last night that three Bronx building superintendents had been ordered ousted from their jobs and their homes because they opposed the leadership of Local 32-E of the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Although on a reduced scale, principally owing to today's celebration of All Saints' Day, labor trouble continued to affect the French coal pits.

A detail of 643 policemen and detectives, only half the number assigned in 1944, will be on duty tonight in the Times Square area, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

Twenty thousand dollars' worth of jewelry was stolen early yesterday from the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel suite of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Luce by a thief who was not afraid to wander around Mrs. Luce's bedroom while she slept a few feet away.

MULDROW, Okla., Nov. 1 (AP) -Eleven Air Force fliers died in the crash of a twin-engined transport plane on the outskirts of this eastern Oklahoma today today. The plane, flying low in a driving rainstorm, broke into three pieces and plunged into a rain-covered cornfield at about 11 A.M.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- John Strachey, Minister of Food, announced in the House of Commons today the easing of the rationing of several food items as proof of the "undoubted improvement in our exchange position."
OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Gov. Earl Warren was welcomed to his home town of Oakland tonight in a rally closing his campaign.

PIMLICO, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Al Sabath's Alsab's Day, a daughter of Alsab, the 1942 Preakness winner, came through with a strong stretch run today and won the $15,000 added Marguerite, annual stake test for 2-year-old fillies.

The twelve Communist leaders accused of conspiring to teach the forcible overthrow of the Government asked in Federal Court yesterday that the trial be put off indefinitely because "the present state of hysteria" over communism made a fair trial impossible.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 1 -Thirteen destroyers and three aircraft carriers left Narragansett Bay today to join almost sixty other ships for three weeks of Navy maneuvers in the North Atlantic. The exercise force will comprise more than 30,000 men.

Henry A. Wallace continued last night to stump for the Progressive party, telling street and indoor audiences that their votes today would determine whether there would be "one world at peace or two worlds in conflict."

A limited edition of a facsimile reproduction of the entire manuscript of "The Book of Kells," the "most beautiful illuminated book of the Middle Ages," is offered for subscription by Urs Graf Verlag, Ltd., of Bern, Switzerland. The edition, each copy numbered, will contain all the "great pages" and a selection of the less famous pages in color.

CASTLE HAYNE, N.C., Nov. 1 -- The mailman stopped at a small gray cottage in this community today and delivered a package from the Navy to Mrs. Clyde Covington, whose 18-year-old son, Richard, is at sea aboard the cruiser Little Rock.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, States Rights Presidential candidate, ended his campaign tonight with a final broadside at President Truman's civil rights stand.

Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett declared yesterday that television should consider the opportunities for service in visual education, as well as in providing entertainment, at WABD's inauguration yesterday of daytime programming. He represented Mayor O'Dwyer, who was prevented from attending by the pressure of his duties.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 1 -- The annual Fall Antique Show opened today at the Garden City Hotel with dealers' booths comfortably filling three ballrooms. Hours will be from 1 to 10 P.M. daily except Friday, the last day, when the closing time will be 9 P.M.

Scrap industry members wondered yesterday why they could not get copies of the Department of Commerce plan for a single corporation to handle all German scrap, presented to an industry advisory committee orally last Thursday, at the Department of Commerce Building, Washington.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, returned yesterday from Israel declaring that the new state would ultimately become a "hard core of resistance" against communism in the Mediterranean. At the same time he called on the State Department to "adopt a policy of its own toward Israel and not follow the lead of the English Foreign Office."
The recent letter of F. Tennyson Jesse, relative to the effect of the comics in their portraiture of England, reminds me of a personal experience of some years ago.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Answering inquiries about steel shares kept brokers busy in the stock market here today. Otherwise they would have had a quiet day, for interest elsewhere was at a low ebb.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday that his department had started its home-care program for patients who can be treated at home. The program was undertaken to ease the overcrowding in the city hospitals.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Nov. 1 -Water in New York's vast Kensico reservoir was at the lowest level today in the reservoir's thirty-year history. It had receded so far that remnants of the villages that lay in the valley before Kensico dam created a lake were exposed to view again.

HAVANA, Oct. 26 -- The possibility of an attack on the Dominican Republic by Dominican exiles and their revolutionary friends is remote at present, according to well-informed sources, despite the continual accusations made by President Raefel L. Trujillo of that country.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Connecticut for the first time, has more than 1,000,000 citizens eligible to vote in this year's election. The state's eight electoral votes, by all indications, will be cast for the Dewey-Warren ticket.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -Government officials appealed tonight to the American people to step in with voluntary contributions to help save the lives of 500,000 Arab refugees from the Palestine fighting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -CARE, the overseas relief organization, today promised a traditional "turkey and trimmin's" Christmas dinner package for hungry families of Britain and Europe. Cost of each special package will be $15.00.

Marked progress in the nationwide campaign of the National Association of Manufacturers and the United States Chamber of Commerce for jobs for older and physically handicapped workers, which began a month ago, was reported yesterday by Morris Sayre, president of the NAM. Mr. Sayre said that employers in all parts of the nation were rallying behind the drive.

The exhibition of abstract art which opens today at the Knoedler Galleries (for the benefit of the Scholarship Fund of the Institute of Fine Arts, New York University) represents a unique collection. In the first place, it is company-owned, and in the second, its purpose is to emphasize the direct and indirect applications to which abstract art can be put.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Cornell's football ranks were thinner than ever today in the first practice for the annual game with Colgate. There were many absences but Coach Lefty James was the least alarmed as he accounted for them with the one word "exams."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The giant strength of the United States at home and abroad will be vitally sapped -- according to President Truman -- if he is voted out of office tomorrow, particularly with a Republican Congress. The essential measure and impact of that strength cannot be achieved -- according to Governor Dewey -- if the Democrats tomorrow are retained in executive, and restored to legislative, power.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 1 -- The United Nations ordered the Israeli Army today to withdraw those forces which, observers said, had crossed the Lebanese frontier to a depth of two to three miles along most of the northern front. The Israeli Government refused, it was understood.

Because of the sharp upward swing in national draft requirements for January, this city has been called upon to provide 1,206 men for induction during that month, Col. Candler Cobb, selective service director for the city area, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- On the eve of polling in the United States, Britons woke up to the American election today. Their morning newspapers gave them column after column of summaries, explanation and comment.
FOSTER, R.I., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The contest for the double office of Town Treasurer and Tax Collector in tomorrow's election is a friendly family fight -- between a husband and wife.

"Sealed Verdict," a topical drama produced by Paramount starring Ray Milland, will have its local premiere this morning at the Paramount. Lewis Allen directed and Robert Fellows produced the offering from a screen play by Jonathan Latimer and a novel by Lionel Shapiro.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -George Munger won't have any trouble getting his undefeated Penn squad "up" for Saturday's meeting here with Penn State's Nittany Lions.

Following is the text of President Truman's radio address as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES as it was broadcast from Independence, Mo., following the introduction of the President by Senator Barkley speaking at Paducah, Ky., last night:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -Twentieth Century-Fox has purchased "Remember, Oh Remember," a screen story by Millard Kaufman, as a probable vehicle for Dana Andrews, it was learned today. The story deals with the postwar consequences of wartime desertion and presents the loyalty conflict in a girl who loves a deserter.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The British Government repudiated today a suggestion put forward last Wednesday in Berlin by Gen. Sir Brian Robertson that all occupation armies might be withdrawn from Germany as a possible means of solving the German problem.
LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Adverse weather conditions in some parts of the Southern Hemisphere today hampered scientists observing an eclipse of the sun.

When the Republican party captured control of both Houses of Congress by a landslide vote in November, 1946, it dealt a shattering blow to American political tradition. In the case of earlier decisive interim revolts against the party in power the economic climate had usually favored the opposition.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Limitation of the use of three Westchester County parks to Westchester residents on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays next year was recommended to the Board of Supervisors here today by its committee on county officers and departments.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- While Federal negotiators sought to bring about further peace meetings in the West Coast maritime strike, the Sailors Union of the Pacific, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, announced that it had reached a new agreement with the Standard Oil Company of California covering unlicensed personnel on the company's tanker.

"The City College football team will have a new outlook in its preparations for this week's game," Coach Harold Parker said yesterday, reviewing the Beavers' 33-12 upset of New Britain Teachers Saturday night. "The victory gave the squad the confidence it will need against Brooklyn."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, ordered the three armed services today to adjudicate in his office differences over proposed legislation and not to carry them to Congress.

With buying held to a sixty-day basis by retailers, prices of women's shoes remained firm yesterday at the main spring opening of the members of the Guild of Better Shoe Manufacurers at their showrooms here.

RIO DE JANIERO, Nov. 1 -- The possibility of building up a form of barter trade between the United States and Brazil is being studied here as a consequence of the increasingly unfavorable balance for Brazil in her commerce with North America.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- The unexpected purchase by the Burlington County Bridge Commission of two Delaware River bridges for $12,000,000 will be under state investigation at Mount Holly on Wednesday and a subject of court action at Jersey City on Thursday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Notre Dame still is ready to play Michigan any time, any place and the professional All-America Conference will operate again next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Entry of a proposed decree that would divorce the exhibition business of Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation from its production and distribution business within one year has been approved by the Department of Justice, it was announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Five hundred Communists gathered outside the United States Embassy in Grosvenor Square tonight and chanted slogans while a deputation went inside to protest the trial of twelve American Communist officials in New York.

Two National Labor Relations Board elections next week will give New York store workers their first opportunity to record their allegiance in the contest between the Congress of Industrial Organizations and eight left-wing locals that recently seceded from the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Gov. Fielding L. Wright, Vice-Presidential candidate, declared tonight that strength shown tomorrow by States Rights Democrats would govern their success four years hence.

Representatives of more than 600 publicly owned electric utilities in thirty states released yesterday statistics purporting to show that the publicly owned systems pay proportionately more taxes and are better managed, than the private systems.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 1 (UP) -Capt. Edward H. Eaton of the passenger steamer District of Columbia, told a Coast Guard board of inquiry today how his ship rammed the tanker Georgia on Sunday in what his employers said was his first accident in his twenty-five-year career.
Financial and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will be closed today, Election Day, but European and Canadian markets will operate as usual.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 5 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 11 per cent.

Since Feodor Vassilevsky, refugee from a Russian coal mine, landed here from the Army transport General Black last Saturday in the first shipment of displaced persons immigrating to this country he has been "living like a king."

Jimmy Phelan, coach of the Los Angeles Dons, started it when he remarked that "something should be done about the substitution rule." Thereafter the main topic of the weekly luncheon meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday was the current vogue of wholesale switching of offensive and defensive players.

We heartily concur with Dr. John B. Pastore, executive director of the Hospital Council of Greater New York, in his belief that the merger of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary with the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital is a step forward in providing better service to the people of New York City.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 1 -- Despite the friendly conspiracy of the rest of Western Europe against her, Belgium continues to soak up dollars from the dollar poor of Europe at a rate that makes this small country the No. 1 headache for financial experts of the European Recovery Program.

Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, hero of Bataan, was announced yesterday as the man who would receive the salute of the international military teams at the formal opening of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden tonight.
We were glad to note your editorial of Oct. 18 on Russia's slave labor. This is a subject that has been too long neglected and often deliberately ignored.

Radio producers have begun to ship the bulk of limited production of twelve-inch cathode ray direct view television receivers to dealers who maintain list prices, buyers reported yesterday. The move, according to retailers, is "the first effective action taken by some manufacturers against dealers who persist in cutting prices."

After a hard day with the "three R's," New York's public school children may be expected to return home with nerves relaxed and appetites improved as a result of the Board of Education's plan to paint classrooms a soothing blue-green and lunchrooms a mouth-watering peach color.

ATHENS, Nov. 1 -- Efforts were made today by Michael Mavrogortatos, Minister without portfolio, and other Liberal party members to heal the breach between Premier Themistocles Sophoulis, the leader of the party, and Sophocles Venizelos, deputy leader who two days ago sought the resignation of Mr. Sophoulis' Cabinet.

THE sixtieth National Horse Show will open in all its splendor in the quiet elegance of Madison Square Garden today. But 'twas not always thus. The original presentation in 1883 was made in an abandoned car-barn which was to gain an enduring fame of sorts under the label of Gilmore's Gardens. That sumptuous (?) site endured for four years until the show was called off temporarily.
The lives of hundreds of babies may be saved annually in New York because of a new joint plan put into operation yesterday by the Departments of Health and Hospitals.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- The Soviet Union has made a new move to open the doors of the United Nations membership to all countries whose applications have been turned down.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- All signs indicate that Governor Dewey will capture Pennsylvania's thirty-five electoral votes tomorrow. His margin is put by impartial analysts at 200,000. The figure of Republican leaders is more than 500,000.

Edward Everett Horton and Arthur Treacher, the report goes, are seriously considering a Broadway appearance this season in that old war horse, "Springtime for Henry." If the deal materializes, Theron Bamberger, an occasional venturer in the managerial field, and Guy Palmerton, summer theatre impresario, would serve as the sponsors.

ROME, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Pope Pius XII, speaking yesterday at his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo to 1,000 workers from the Fiat automobile plant in Rome and Milan, said "the Church rejects state totalitarianism" and the "superstitious worship of technology."

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Gen. Sir William Slim, commander of Britain's Fourteenth Army in Burma, took up his duties as Chief of the Imperial General Staff today. It is believed that General Slim will be soon appointed Field Marshal, the rank normally associated with his new position.

The Judwill Realty Corporation acquired the two-story factory structure at 19-27 Clay Street, Brooklyn, from 19 Clay Street, Inc. The property, which occupies an irregular plot 75 by 105 feet, is assessed at $35,000. Title was insured by the Lawyers Title Corporation.
Kenneth Prince Lord is with Hirsch Co., members of the Stock Exchange, in their main office. He is a retired brigadier general of the United States Army.
