More than fifty million American citizens, the largest number ever to vote in a national election, will go the polls today to elect a President and Vice President of the United States and 435 members of the House of Representatives.

Fifteen hundred members of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, adopted a resolution last night attacking Austin Hogan, left-wing president of Local 100, for bringing a suit in the Supreme Court against Gustav Faber, the local's treasurer, and Paul Lerman, a printer.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Three virtual strangers to the tournament trail served notice to the big-name players today that it won't be all fun playing for the forty-sixth North and South open golf title.

TOKYO, Nov. 1 -- Contemplated changes by the Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers in the method of buying raw wool for Japanese industry -- reported prematurely and perhaps inaccurately -- have stirred American and Japanese business communities.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The submarine U.S.S. Tigrone, in some respects the Navy's most modern fighting craft, went into commission today at the Portsmouth Navy Yard.

It was another election night, Nov. 6, 1928, when the first words rode in electric lights around the moving sign that belts the Times Building in Times Square. From that night, twenty years ago, to this time a ribbon of news has unfolded history to millions of eyes raised by Broadway throngs.
The New York Football Giants, unhappy after their defeat by the Bears, returned from Chicago yesterday with a hospital list that was longer than their faces.

Action on proposed uniform minimum standards for export packaging will be taken soon at a mass meeting in the Maritime Exchange, it was learned yesterday. Authorization has been given for the meeting, and it is expected that a date will be set some time this month.

Coffee futures prices eased slightly after small advances in the early part of yesterday's session on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc. Trade hedge selling lowered prices 19 to 5 points under the levels of the previous session. Sales for the day totaled 6,500 bags.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -Maj. Gen. James P. Hodges, formerly commanding general of the flying division, Air Training Command, at Randolph Air Force Base, San Antonio, Tex., has been assigned to Berlin, the Air Force announced today.

The striking Radio Writers Guild attached a reservation yesterday to its acceptance of a proposal for opening negotiations with the committee representing agencies and sponsors of radio programs. The proposal, advanced by J.R. Mandelbaum, assistant regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, had been accepted by the committee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- All grains were lower in the early trading today, but there was a strong close in all pits, as short covering became active, traders wishing to even up for over the holiday. Corn did not break as much as many expected, and commission and local buying firmed the market.
CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 1 -- The wind-up of the United States Presidential election campaign has brought United States prestige in the Arab Middle East to a new low.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1 -- A panel appointed by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll awarded today a payment rise of 13 cents an hour to 6,000 employes of the Public Service Coordinated Transport Company.

Employers, public officials and directors of social and religious groups are rallying behind industry's campaign to find jobs for older and physically handicapped workers, it was disclosed yesterday by Morris Sayre, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, co-sponsor of the drive with the United States Chamber of Commerce.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- The latest cease-fire order in Palestine, where the Israelis had been fighting the Lebanese, seems finally to have been effective, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, the acting United Nations Mediator, said tonight.

Local 333 of the United Marine Division served notice yesterday on the Employers Wage Adjustment Committee, which represents a majority of the New York Harbor towing concerns, that it intends to terminate the present labor contract, it was learned yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Something new in football penalties -- a $75 fine for each of the officials if one of them doesn't know the rules and the others don't call him on it -- was advocated today by a 29-year veteran of college coaching.

Analysis of a great many aspects of the Soviet economy is going forward at a number of the country's research centers, a survey showed yesterday. This work by American scholars will help to fill the gaps in the country's knowledge of the Soviet Union left by the Soviet decree banning the publication of economic information considered essential to security.
The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday an increase of $4,409,680 in its nine months' earnings over last year, declared two dividends of $1 each and also announced the election of a new officer.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Nov. 1 (AP) -Newfoundlanders pressed the Government today for settlement of the three-weeks-old railway strike that had left them short of food and supplies.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 -- No major revision will be made in the TaftHartley Labor Law regardless of which party wins control of the United States Senate tomorrow, Representative Fred A. Hartley of New Jersey said today in an address before the Detroit Economic Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- A reshaping of United States policy in China was recommended today by Roger D. Lapham, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration in that country. He said that "our middle-of-the-road policy" was "not getting us anywhere," and he advised that we "stick our neck out," give affirmative aid and "take full responsibility for that aid, control it, and see how it is spent, both economically and militarily."

FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, Oct. 30 -- The French West Indies, only point in the Western Hemisphere where the Communist party is the dominant political organization, is the scene of a bitter tug-of-war between right and left that may erupt any day into large-scale violence.

Charging that funds raised in the United States were being used "as a lever with which to change or dominate the social structure of Palestine," Henry Montor, executive vice chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, has resigned his post, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas is returning to Washington tomorrow for a brief consultation, the United States Embassy announced this afternoon. He will take the opportunity to visit his father in Montreal before going to Washington, and expects to return to London early next week.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather quiet yesterday and final prices were 3 to 6 points net higher.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The net working capital of American corporations, exclusive of banks and insurance companies, reached a new record level of $63,900,000,000 in the second quarter of this year, compared with $59,500,000,000 in second quarter of 1947 the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today in its regular quarterly analysis of working capital.

The game that the East wanted to see above all others in 1947 but was not in the book is finally coming to pass. Pennsylvania and Penn State, after a six-year interlude, are resuming relations on the gridiron Saturday in the only meeting of the week between teams that remain unscathed.

Some time within the next twenty-four hours one of our leading Presidential candidates will probably send a message of congratulations and best wishes to the other leading Presidential candidate. The message may be delayed if there is any lingering uncertainty, but it will be sent and it will carry an honest good-will.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Mrs. Minna Geddes of Brookfield, Democratic candidate for State Senator, today reaffirmed her support of the program of the Planned Parenthood League of Connecticut. The group is seeking a state law sanctioning birth control advice.

TOKYO, Nov. 1 -- The Japanese press and public are anxiously canvassing the potentialities of the United States Presidential election in the belief that the outcome might settle the American attitude toward Far Eastern problems for the next four years.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 1 -- Dismissal of the Government's anti-trust action against the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, Owens-Illinois Glass Company and Corning Glass Works was asked in a consolidated answer flied in United States District Court here today.
Optimistic views on the future of Scandinavian shipping were presented yesterday by two shipping officials who arrived on the Swedish American liner Gripsholm.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's final campaign, address as broadcast last night:
FRANKFORT ON MAIN, Germany, Oct. 30 -- Having flown nearly 1,000,000,000 pounds of supplies into Berlin on 67,162 flights, "Operation Vittles" has outgrown its name, according to airmen here.

As wary of possible damage suits as any individual property owner, the city, through its real estate bureau director, yesterday requested the police to shoo away motorists attempting to leave their automobiles at a projected parking lot on the site of the old Criminal Courts Building and Tombs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Senator-elect Margaret Chase Smith of Maine called upon women of the nation today to vote for Republican candidates for the Senate and the House "to make the team in Washington complete."

PEIPING, Nov. 1 -- Americans living in the five provinces of north China were advised today by the United States Consulates in Peiping and Tientsin to consider the desirability of evacuation. They have been asked to leave between Nov. 15 and Dec. 1 if they wish to take baggage.

AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, Nov. 1 (AP) -- King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan declared today that he was "determined to bring peace" to Palestine's Arabs and to avoid disagreement and disunity among the Arab nations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -Plans for the first through transcontinental air service between the Southeast and the Pacific Coast were announced today by American Airlines and Delta Air Lines.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- Ten Los Angeles residents held in contempt and sent to jail last week for refusing to reply to questions in a Federal grand jury investigation of Communist activities were ordered freed by the Ninth Federal Circuit Court here today.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican County Chairman, in a bitter attack yesterday on the rival Tammany organization, accused it of being willing to "sell down the river" any and all other candidates in order to elect General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, its candidate for Surrogate of New York County.

The General Motors Corporation resumed yesterday management control of Adam Opel, A. G., its German manufacturing subsidiary at Russelsheim, near Frankfort lain Main, Germany. Control was lost during the war and, upon conclusion of hostilities, the German company was under control of the United States Office of Military Government in the Reich.

About 6,000,000 New Yorkers will go to the polls throughout the state today to cast their votes in the Presidential election. For the first time in memory no state-wide officials are simultaneously up for election.

The Horse Show is back in town. It is the same after sixty-five years of history, going back even of the old Madison Square Garden with the golden Diana shooting at the stars from the top of her tower.
Well satisfied with his team's 21-20 defeat of Lehigh last Saturday, Coach Edward E. (Hook) Mylin held a light workout yesterday at Ohio Field for New York University's football squad.

Columbia's second team bore the brunt of yesterday's practice session at Baker Field as Coach Lou Little continued his attempts to develop capable reserves for the Lions, who dropped their third straight game to Cornell last Saturday.
POCATELLO, Idaho, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Senator Glen H. Taylor accused "Wall Street" tonight of plotting to plunge the United States into war.

Supreme Court Justice Felix A. Benvenga refused yesterday to order an immediate halt to a strike of 300 fish handlers. He directed the striking union, the United Sea Food Workers, Local 359, AFL, to show cause at a hearing next Tuesday why the court should not order arbitration of the wage dispute between the union and the Associated Fish Purveyors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Central and South West Corporation, Wilmington, Del., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a statement covering 659,606 additional shares of $5 par value common stock.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The cases of two United States Olympic team ice skaters accused of unsportsmanlike conduct were under consideration today by a special Committee of the Amateur Skating Union.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Minister for Economic Affairs, drew cheers from both sides of Commons tonight when he called for European economic cooperation as the only means to combat "chaos-producing tactics" of the Communist Information Bureau.

As the result of an inquiry into 1,638 complaints of false registration, a challenge list of 1,501 names has been supplied to the Board of Elections, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- A full program of eleven committee meetings is scheduled for the United Nations tomorrow in spite of the fact that all delegations to the third General Assembly here have their eyes turned toward the United States elections.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Veterans will bid on surplus Army barracks and buildings in the occupied area of Shanks Village, Robert Flood, Public Housing Administration manager here, announced today. Any service veteran is eligible to enter a bid on one or more of the barracks and twenty-four large miscellaneous buildings from Wednesday until Nov. 17.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander welcomed 337 new men into the department yesterday at a brief ceremony at Police Headquarters. The appointments leave the patrol force still short 459 of the authorized budget quota of 16,706 members.
The Swedish people are in accord with this country's handling of the recent international developments in Europe. Ake Bonnier, Swedish publisher, declared here yesterday.

A gold medallion of honor was presented to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey last night at the twenty-fifth anniversary celebration of the Women's International Exposition, which was opened yesterday in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP) -A United States District Judge rejected today a plea to order Warner Brothers Pictures and ten other major film companies to relinquish ownership of motion picture houses in this district.

FORT DIX, N.J., Nov. 1 -When the first draft of Selective Service recruits arrives here next Wednesday, they will come under the direction of officers specially trained to handle them human beings as well as teach them to be soldiers.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- Industrial production in the Western zones of Germany established another post-war record during September when the output index rose to 70 per cent of the 1936 level, the Military Governor announced today.
department stores showed an increase of 5 per cent in October, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Plans for a $1,000,000 development of 150 one-family dwellings in New Jersey were announced yesterday by Melvin Cohen, counsel for the Fellsway Corporation of Newark which has purchased a tract of land in New Providence Borough bounded by Livingston and South Streets and Maple and Central Avenues.

Declaring that "fully 40,000,000 persons" in this country were not being served by adequate public health facilities, Dr. Thomas D. Dublin, newly appointed executive director of the National Health Council, appealed yesterday for community awareness of "the huge stockpile" of public health skills and resources.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 1 -- The General Electric Company today publicly withdrew its recent statement that every Communist party member in America takes an oath to overthrow the United States Government by force and violence.

Among the newly arrived items on grocery shelves now are many delicacies from abroad. From England, for example, there is a marmalade that is aged like wine for several seasons. It is available again in this country after a wartime absence.

The stock market enjoyed yesterday a pre-election rally that carried prices to within easy range of the October high level. The comeback in the steel shares, after last week's reaction, which was due to disappointment over the lack of any extra disbursement to stockholders by the two big producing companies, was primarily responsible for the fresh recovery.
BATAVIA, Java, Nov. 1 (AP) -The Moscow-trained Indonesian Communist leader Muso was reported today to have been killed in a skirmish with Indonesian Republican forces.

Typhoid has been wiped out almost completely in Israel, Dr. Eli Davis, deputy director for the Hadassah Medical organization in the Holy Land, reported yesterday. Because the water supply and plumbing still are serious problems, he ascribed the disappearance of the disease since the partition of Palestine to inoculation of all citizens and the end of vegetable purchases from the Arabs, who used disease-bearing fertilizer.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 1 (AP) -- An accounting of Textron profits was sought today in a suit filed against present and past officers in Federal court here by Lillian Berger, a stockholder.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company announced yesterday that its backlog of work (estimated balance of major contracts unbilled) amounted to $212,746,668 on Sept. 27, last, compared with $67,943,262 on June 28 and $61,154,393 on Sept. 29, 1947.
PEIPING, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The capture of Mukden frees Chinese Communist troops for a massive assault against North China.

A vacant irregular plot about 112 by 139 feet at the northeast corner of Mineola Avenue and Elm Street, near Roslyn Heights, in North Hempstead, L.I., has been purchased for improvement with a taxpayer building. The Vicfred Realty Corporation, of which Henry M. Weitzner is president and Fred Sinderband is secretary, was the buyer, and the sellers were Margaret Docherty and Charles J. Velders, doing business as the Roslyn Heights Home and Auto Supply Company.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 1 -- The Navy football team got a look at what it may have missed Saturday afternoon as the middies reviewed movies of the game with Notre Dame in which the Irish submerged Navy by a 41-7 count.

SAINT JOHN, N.B., Nov. 1 -One glance at the map of Queens County, in this province, will illustrate why this is a great country for waterfowl, and after several days of moving up and down the Saint John River, from the Jemseg to the mouth, we are satisfied that no visiting hunter would be disappointed.

Changes in airplane schedules for November, usually bringing a reduction in service to meet seasonal declines in traffic, show no such results this year. With new rates of fare to counteract the general increase of two months ago and with load factors keeping up beyond expectations, most of the lines are providing new services rather than reducing flights, it was reported yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1 -- The Garden State Antiques Show, the first large exposition of the kind to be held here since before the war, was opened this afternoon in the Terrace Room of the Mosque Theater by Mayor Vincent J. Murphy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -Vincent C. Burke, first assistant postmaster general, disclosed today that the Post Office Department was investigating complaints that Senator Chapman Revercomb, Republican, of West Virginia, mailed large quantities of campaign material under his special free mailing privilege as a United States Senator.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Plans to press for a National Child Research Institute in the Children's Bureau, with an initial $5,000,000 annual authorization, were revealed here today by the American Parents Committee.
VIENNA, Nov. 1 -- Russia has let down the Iron Curtain on investigation of the brutal murder early Sunday morning of Irving Ross, a member of the Economic Cooperation Administration-mission here.
ATLANTA, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Government today cut off road funds to Georgia until the state solves its $17,000,000 highway contract tie-up.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Danny Kaye, who came all the way from Hollywood to play a one-night stand before Britain's King and Queen, held the stage of the Palladium Theatre for thirty minutes tonight, twice as long as any of the other 300 performers in the royal command variety show.

A member of the House of Representatives since 1923, Representative Sol Bloom is the ranking Democratic member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. He headed the committee before and during the war when the Democratic party controlled the House and helped frame legislation on Lend-Lease, relief and rehabilitation.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, asserted yesterday that funds raised in this country for Palestine "are not allocated here but remitted to head offices in Jerusalem to be disbursed in accordance with the budgets of the World Zionist Organization and the Jewish Agency for Palestine."

No signs of the 10,000,000 vote that the Progressive party leaders were counting upon for their Presidential candidate, Henry A. Wallace, appeared in returns early today from roughly half the country's projected popular vote in yesterday's election.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- London's leading newspapers said today that the man who was elected President of the United States would hold the immediate fate of the world in his hands. They gave thanks that on foreign policy the Republican and Democratic parties were united.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- The Moscow radio said today that Premier Stalin had caused "obvious confusion" among Western diplomats when he had charged they were pursuing a "policy of unleashing a new war."

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- As the outgrowth of events connected with the coal strike, it was learned today, the Cabinet will discuss tomorrow the amending of some laws to prevent Communist obstruction in the future.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2 -- Ships of the United States Navy began a second courtesy visit to Argentina when the light cruiser Huntington and the destroyer Douglas H. Fox tied up in Buenos Aires Harbor this morning. Last January the heavy cruiser Albany and the destroyer George K. Mackenzie paid a similar call.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 3 (Wednesday) -- Wisconsin's twelve electoral votes went to President Truman in yesterday's election in a complete upset of pre-election anticipations.

The Mayor of New York took his place in line early yesterday afternoon like any other citizen and waited patiently for twenty minutes to cast his vote. He chatted amiably with his fellow voters in the line and smiled jovially for newspaper and news reel photographers.

Popular price dress manufacturers have been successful in stimulating business after a dull October by early showings of cotton, silk, and novelty rayon lines for spring, it was indicated in a survey of the market yesterday. Showrooms were well filled on election day and buying activity centered on goods for both this month and next, according to manufacturers.

For New Yorkers who are able to put politics out of their minds for a few minutes a visit to one of the several mass plantings of chrysanthemums is highly recommended as good for the eyes and the soul. The blooms are at their peak this week, and one place convenient for many to see them is Bryant Park, west of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2 -- The dwellings and churches in Virginia of the first permanent English settlers in North America were medieval in appearance and in the architectural style of the Tower of London and Westminster Abbey, an art historian has reported.

PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Three of the longest drivers in the golfing business and two comparative strangers to the weekly tournament trail -- one of them an amateur -- took the honors today in the first round of the forty-sixth North and South open golf tournament.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 2 -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have been asked by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation to produce a more concrete four-year recovery plan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Treasury reported today the budget for the current fiscal year had slipped into the red again after a long period in the black.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Ed (Sandy) Sandford and Grant (Nobby) Warwick, two front-line bulwarks with the Boston Bruins, shared first place today in the National Hockey League's scoring race with a total of ten points each.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission reports a sharp decline in imports of furs since December, 1946.
Proposition No. 1 to legalize firemen's woorking hours now in operation experimentally was carried yesterday by an overwhelming margin, substantial returns showed last night.

Election day crowds, stimulated by clear skies and brisk weather, jammed retail stores here yesterday and sent sales gains up to 25 per cent over the corresponding day last year, according to estimates of leading retailers throughout the city.

AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 2 -- A small "shoulder" cannon constructed on the Bofors principle is being manufactured to augment the firing power of the regulation infantry rifle for the United States armed forces in event of emergency.
SALT LAKE CITY, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Utah voters gave their four electoral votes to President Truman in yesterday's general election.
Your editorial on Oct. 20 dealing with the investigation of the murder of my brother, George Polk, was splendid. Your summary of the case seemed to me to be the fairest I have yet read.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 2 -- President Truman piled up a good lead tonight as returns came in to state headquarters here. Thomas E. Dewey was trailing in Dade (Miami), Hillsborough (Tampa) and Duval (Jacksonville) counties.

New York automobilists would do well to take to themselves the advice given by New Jersey State Highway Commissioner Spencer Miller Jr. to car owners in his state to prepare their vehicles for the winter. Inadequate traction and reduced visibility, as Mr. Miller correctly says, are the two major threats faced by drivers.

Capitalizing on its rival's mistakes, the St. John's Prep football team turned back John Adams High, 26 to 6, in the twelfth annual battle between the schools at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday. A crowd of 8,000 was on hand.

INDIANAPOLIS, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey overcame President Truman's lead in Indiana's election and pulled ahead by 1,377 votes today. Returns from 2,550 of the state's 4,056 precincts gave Mr. Dewey 552,251 and Mr. Truman 550,874.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 -- West Coast waterfronts were almost deserted today, the end of the first two months of the maritime strike, as pickets took two hours off to vote. In this port trucks equipped with loudspeakers moved along the Embarcadero with a message urging all strikers to go to the polls.

Governor Dewey, Republican nominee for President, carried his home state of New York in yesterday's election by a plurality of about 37,000 over President Truman, his Democratic opponent, and won New York's important forty-seven electoral votes.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 2 -- Hour exams kept both Quarterback Johnnie Clayton and Halfback Hal Fitkin out of today's scrimmage, but their replacements more than carried the offensive burden for Dartmouth. With diminutive Gil Mueller calling the signals, the backfield of Sullivan, Dey and Ed Isbey continually racked up sizable gains.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- President Truman jumped into the lead in the contest for Ohio's twenty-five electoral votes early today, and the Democrats captured the Governorship in a surprise display of strength.

NANKING, Nov. 2 -- Dr. Wong Wen-hao, whose Cabinet failed to ameliorate China's runaway inflation with a new currency system, explained to the Legislative Yuan today why he had submitted his resignation as Premier to President Chiang Kai-shek yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- A pedigreed dog, owned by a woman in Port Chester, N. Y., has given the Westchester County Republican Committee a problem they do not know how to solve.

Sixty-two youngsters representing sixteen nationalities "stole the show" yesterday at the Silver Jubilee Women's International Exposition in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
With only 101 out of 3,707 election districts unreported at 6 o'clock this morning, New Jersey's sixteen electoral votes went to Governor Dewey by an indicated plurality of about 70,000.
NANKING, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Chinese Communists called today for quick surrender of President Chiang Kai-shek's beaten armies in Manchuria and openly boasted that they would conquer all of China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today indirectly to permit the railroads of the country to make an immediate, emergency increase of 8 per cent in freight rates by assigning the matter for hearing here beginning on Nov. 30.

Constantin Fotitch, former Minster and then Ambassador from Yugoslavia to the United States rom 1935 to 1944, presents his opinions of the relations between Yugoslavia and the Western Powers in his forthcoming book, "The War We Lost: Yugoslavia's Tragedy and the Failure of the West."

New York's wealth and fashion and a large number of plain citizens divided their interest between the election returns and the annual visitations of the horse as a medium for sport and the exchange of social amenities last night. The occasion was the formal opening of the Sixtieth National Horse Show, launched again on an election afternoon for a run of eight days of matinee and evening performances in Madison Square Garden.

The latest developments in France demonstrate that the French sector of the Communist International is mobilizing its full resources in both manpower and brutality in an effort to wreck French economy as one way of wrecking the European Recovery Program. It has begun to arm Communist strikers and to throw them into pitched battles with French troops and police.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- A photographic system of typesetting that dispenses with cast metal type has been demonstrated in the recently-opened laboratories of the Printing, Packaging and Allied Trades Research Association in Leatherhead Surrey.
The Democrats had recaptured the House of Representatives early today on the showing of unofficial and incomplete returns.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 2 -- United States industrialists have been complaining that scarcely any American investment under the European Cooperation Administration's gurantee is possible owing to the unhelpful attitude of European Governments.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The three German generals still being held prisoners by the British will be tried next March, Lord Chancellor Viscount Jowitt told the House of Lords today. The Lord Chancellor was answering a barrage of criticism such as the Labor Government already has faced several times in the House of Commons where only last Thursday Winston Churchill expressed shock and bitterness over the delay in trying these men.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Decrees nationalizing the motion picture industry and hospitals were approved by the Rumanian Cabinet today.

Blond, curly haired Bill Berger, Columbia captain, won the twenty-second annual metropolitan intercollegiate varsity cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, accounting for a mild upset by outrunning Armand Osterberg, New York University's individual defending titleholder.

WINNIPEG, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Outside interest in the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today was confined, due to the election holiday in the United States. The United Kingdom received an allocation of 260,000 bushels of wheat under the Anglo-Canadian wheat agreement.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov, 3 -- Dry Kansas was waging a touch- and-go battle over repeal of its time-honored prohibition amendment early today with the drys holding a slim 6,509 lead at the quarter-point and many city wet precincts still to report.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2 -- With only one town unreported, Chester A. Bowles, Democrat, leading by 1,322 votes, is certain of election as Governor of Connecticut over the incumbent, James C. Shannon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2 -- Head Coach Arthur Valpey sent the Harvard football squad through a long and intensive passing drill before having two 30-minute scrimmages today as the Crimson prepared for the Princeton game Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Government tentatively ordered American millers today to stop using nitrogen trichloride as an agent for bleaching bread flour.

Representative Abraham J. Multer, re-elected as a member of the House of Representatives from Brooklyn's Fourteenth Congressional District, is a Brooklyn Democrat whose campaign was aided by Republican and Liberal party support. He represents one of the most populous Congressional districts in the nation.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 2 -- A plan of restrictions on imports from dollar areas was outlined broadly here today to nineteen leading representatives of South African commerce and industry by Finance Minister Nicholaas C. Havenga.

Motivated by broad-minded principles, the Theatre Guild abhors hard and fast rules. For instance, back in 1941 it was seriously thinking of doing "Set My People Free." Written by Dorothy Heyward, co-author with her late husband of such Negro shows as "Porgy," "Porgy and Bess" and "Mamba's Daughters," "Set My People Free" deals with Denmark Vesey's abortive slave uprising of 1822 in Charleston.
PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky was ordered sharply today to stop "insulting other delegates" -- and he refused just as sharply.

The thief who stole $20,000 in jewels early Monday from the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel suite of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Luce's overlooked a leather case in Mrs. Luce's room that contained gems valued at more than $100,000, it was learned last night.

BISMARCK, N. D., Nov. 3 (Wednesday) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey was slowly increasing a narrow lead over President Truman in early returns this morning on North Dakota's balloting yesterday. Other Republican candidates also were forging ahead of their Democratic opponents.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 2 -- Fairfield County supported both Thomas E. Dewey and James C. Shannon, Republican Presidential and Gubernatorial candidates, although state-wide tallies showed that Chester Bowles, Democratic candidate for Governor, held an unbeatable position.

Governor Dewey received election returns by radio and television with his family and a few old friends until an early hour this morning in his suite at the Hotel Roosevelt, Madison Avenue at Forty-fifth Street.

MINEOLA, L. I., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Governor Dewey won 70.6 per cent of a record vote of 262,935 in Nassau County as residents turned in the expected Republican majorities in the Presidential and local election contests.
GENEVA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Inland Transport Committee of the Economic Commission for Europe has called for action on an old project to modernize European freight cars with automatic coupling devices.

The five-story store and apartment building at 2377-79 Creston Avenue, northwest corner of East 184th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased for investment by David Kohl and another from David Green and others. The building, on a plot 116 by 95 feet, contains fifty-two apartments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman is the only one of eight Presidential and Vice Presidential contenders who will lose his job unless he wins today's election.

The National Association of Bedding Manufacturers will ask the Government soon to withdraw its invitation to bid on 408,000 cotton mattresses, J. Paul Fanning, managing director, disclosed yesterday. The mattresses will go to the Army Quartermaster Corps and are being procured through the Army-Navy Purchasing Office in New York.

The Italian-made topical melodrama, "Tragic Hunt," now at the Ambassador Theatre, has been re-titled, "Woman Hunt," it was reported by a spokesman for Lux Films, the producers. The change was made because the new title "more adequately" fits the theme of the picture, it was stated. "
GUATEMALA, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- The Government today placed squarely on Britain the responsibility for the tension prevailing in Anglo-Guatemalan relations.

Charles D. Starks and others have sold the two-story apartment house with stores on the north side of Far Rockaway Boulevard, 99 feet west of Foam Place, Far Rockaway, Queens, to Henry M. Voehl for cash above a mortgage of $20,000.

The Amott-Baker realty bond price averages gained a full 1 per cent during October to score the strongest advance in real estate bond prices of any thirty-day period since the first of the year. The previous high gain for 1948 was 1/2 per cent in January.

ATLANTA, Nov. 2 (NANA) -- The late President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Little White House, at Warm Springs, Ga., was opened to the public last week for the first time. There, at the time of his death in April, 1945, the President was working on plans for the Charter meeting of the United Nations in San Francisco.

The Chrysler Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries in the United States earned $52,568,683 during the first nine months of this year, establishing a new high record for the period, according to the report of K. T. Keller, president, to be mailed today to stockholders. Net earnings for the first three quarters of 1947 were $46,863,476.

In a game that must be placed high on the list of thrillers staged between the schools since the rivalry was begun forty-seven years ago, Manual Training High School's unbeaten eleven turned back a battling Erasmus Hall squad, 20-to-13, in Brooklyn's annual Election Day schoolboy classic yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Don de Fore was named today for leading roles in two films, "House of Cards," which Lester Cutler and Marty Martyn will produce with Laraine Day as the feminine star, and "The Furies," which Hal Wallis will produce, with Barbara Stanwyck as the leading woman.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 2 -- The Bucharest Military Court passed sentences today ranging from fifteen years to life imprisonment on twelve prominent Rumanians found guilty of treason and economic sabotage.

Chester Bliss Bowles, former administrator of the Office of Price Administration, based part of his campaign for the Governorship of Connecticut on opposition to the state's 1 per cent sales tax, which he characterized as a "soak the poor" levy.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- In the face of the greatest outpouring of voters in Massachusett's history, President Truman appeared early today seemed certain to win this state with its sixteenth electoral votes by a plurality in excess of 100,000.
Three youthful members of an alleged gang from the Park Slope section of Brooklyn were held yesterday in $5,000 bail each for a hearing Friday in Adolescents Court on charges of disorderly conduct.
NANKING, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Chinese Communist troops, racing southward from Mukden, occupied three more important cities today and trapped two Nationalist divisions at the Gulf of Chinli port of Yingkow.
NEW DELHI, India, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- V. N. Godse, 35-year-old Brahmin, said in court today he had killed Mohandas K. Gandhi 'purely for the benefit of humanity."

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The Labor Government has provided an overwhelming case against the nationalization of the steel industry by the record it has made in the enterprises it is already running, R. S. Hudson, Conservative of Southport, told the House of Commons today.

Final figures in Senate and Assembly districts of the state showed today that the Democratic party had made a net gain of at least nineteen seats in the Assembly. and ten seats in the upper house. In only one district was an incumbent Democrat defeated.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Poland called upon the United Nations General Assembly today to take action against the United States for allegedly seeking to control other governments by applying economic sanctions under the Marshall Plan.

S. Samuel Di Falco, Manhattan Democrat and a City Councilman since 1941, is 42 years old, married and lives with his wife and two children at 170 Second Avenue. He has been a resident of New York since 1907. In his political and legal career of many years he has been concerned largely with American-Italian civic and legal affairs.

Firemen of Engine Company 57 -- that is, the captain and crew of Firefighter -- will celebrate on Nov. 16 the tenth birthday of their shiny "wagon," proud flagship of the city's fleet of nine fireboats, largest and most powerful fireboat in the world.

MACHIAS, Me., Nov. 2 -- The opening of the deer season in this part of Washington County is an event that not even an election could disturb, and while most of the local hunters paused long enough to race for a polling place, they raced just as rapidly to return to the woods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The farmer's future as sketched by recent forecasts of the Department of Agriculture appears likely to be less rosy than the boom times he has known since the start of World War II. Step by step, the department has been scanning prospects in the various phases of the nation's farm economy.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The visits of Secretary Marshall to London, John Foster Dulles to Stockholm and Copenhagen and Philip Jessup to Berlin during last week-end aroused more interest and curiosity over here than what happens within the General Assembly. In forty-odd days of talk this session has produced no important decision.

The Security Bureau, Inc., an organization of maritime industry companies formed to combat theft on the city's waterfront, has completed a survey of an inland warehouse that has a practically perfect loss record during the last three years of operation, it was made known yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- President Truman pulled the entire Democratic ticket in his home state to victory today. The landslide was so complete that it left only one of the state's nine Republican members of Congress sure of being re-elected.

All the glamour and military pomp of the greatest of all equestrian spectacles in this country flashed before a distinguished audience in Madison Square Garden last night for the formal opening of the sixtieth National Horse Show: In the huge assemblage were many leading figures in society, diplomatic, military and civic civic circles.

The New York City Ballet Company at the City Center last night gave its first performance of "Divertimento," created for the Ballet Society originally by George Balanchine to music of Alexei Haieff and performed in January of last year for the first time.

A salty spray of seafaring phrases and customs remains on the desk after reviewing the various activities of Navy Week. But before the desk is swabbed down and squared away, some of these traditional terms are worth considering for transfer ashore.

Wallace M. True, vice president of the Lincoln Savings Bank, will be the principal speaker at the dinner meeting of the Society of Residential Appraisers on Tuesday in the Hotel Shelton. J. Harold Sparkman of Seattle, Wash., national president of the society, will also address the meeting.

A 40 per cent reduction in advertising rates for Norte-Revista Continental, Latin-American magazine, will be made effective with the January, 1949, issue, it was announced here yesterday by American International Publications, Inc.

George Frankenthaler, a Republican, entered the campaign for the office of Surrogate of New York County armed not only with the background of a long and varied practice of law, but with the coalition support of his own party and the Liberal party.

A touchdown in the final period enabled the Stuyvesant eleven to tie favored De Witt Clinton, 13 -- 13, in the feature game of the election day twin bill at Triborough Stadium yesterday. A crowd of 6,000 saw Monroe come from behind in the second half of the opening contest to conquer Seward Park, 18 -- 7.
An aptitude for legislative duties impelled New Jersey State Treasurer Robert C. Hendrickson to run for the United States Senate.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond, the States' Rights Democratic Presidential candidate, won Alabama's eleven electoral votes in today's election.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- A rumor that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and some other United States delegates to the United Nations were calling for a showdown on the delegation's Palestine policy was widely circulated here tonight. United States delegation sources denied that there was a split but declined to say what, if anything, had been said on the subject.

At 6 A. M. today, after a night in which his political fortunes waxed and waned with every passing hour, President Harry S. Truman took an impressive lead over his Republican opponent, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, in both the popular and electoral vote of the nation which went to the polls yesterday in the forty-eight states of the Union to choose a President, a Vice President, the Eeighty-first Congress and thirty-two Governors.

FOUR years ago a curious book appeared that was in essence the eloquent expression of its author's fourfold love affair with the Christian religion, medieval civilization, the country of France and the Cathedral of Notre Dame. "The Biography of a Cathedral," by Robert Gordon Anderson, was a learned, sprawling, formless, emotional, appealing and informative book.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Voting machines were being used by about thirty out of every 100 voters in the election today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 2 -- Persistent reports that Trans-Jordanian and Israeli representatives have been meeting in Jerusalem for the last two days drew a Governmental denial here tonight that peace talks had begun.
Despite its size, the election yesterday was one of the quietest and most orderly in the city's history, enforcement officials said after visiting all boroughs and checking polling places.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, with a backlog of orders amounting to more than $212,000,000, is embarking on the final stage of a plant-modernization program to make it one of the great production plants in the nation, it was reported yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Governor Dewey carried Westchester County in today's Presidential election by a plurality of 80,966. In 1946 he received 113,977 over James M. Mead for Governor, and in 1944 he was 67,044 ahead of President Franklin D. Roosevelt in the White House contest.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A woman who bills herself as America's only woman candidate for President spent $5 out of her own pocket last night to come to Philadelphia for a last-hour appeal for votes.

The general situation around New York yesterday was arid as election laws forced the cutomary visitors to local bars and taverns to put down their beers in favor of ballots. So it was with some surprise that passersby stopped, sniffed and smelled the fragrant aroma of Scotch whisky coming from 37 West Forty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- With 1,783 of the state's precincts unreported at 5:15 A. M., President Truman led Governor Dewey by 81,867 ballots in their race for Illinois' twenty-eight electoral college votes, while incomplete returns from more than two-thirds of the state's precincts recorded a Democratic sweep of state offices, which unseated Senator C. Wayland Brooks and Gov. Dwight H. Green.

George C. Sherman Jr. of New York was re-elected president of the Indoor Polo Association of America, it was announced yesterday. Son of the founder and first head of the organization formed in 1915, he is also secretary-treasurer of the United States Polo Association.

The two six-story buildings at 167-71 Radford Street, northeast corner of Riverdale Avenue, in Yonkers, N. Y., containing five stores and forty-five apartments, have been purchased for investment by Joseph Molnar and William Landsberry from the Century Federal Savings and Loan Association.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Under an easterly wind that piped up at 18 knots when they went out and kindly dropped to 12, twenty sailing dinghies competed in eight races today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 2 (AP) -- Races for the governorship were tight in a score or more states today.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Guifford Bonslog, 25 years old, a deckhand from Hammond, Ind., was killed today in a collision between two lake freighters during a fog on Lake Erie. Two shipmates were injured.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Returns from 7,779 of Pennsylvania's 8,292 election divisions gave Gov. Thomas E. Dewey an advantage of 154,767 over President Truman. The vote for Mr. Dewey was 1,784,051; for President Truman 1,629,286, and for Henry A. Wallace 49,545.

"I don't have much to say," was the opening remark of Steve Owen, coach of the football Giants, as he pulled himself to his feet at the weekly Polo Grounds luncheon yesterday. "Philadelphia has a fine team."

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 2 (UP) -- The new police force in the Soviet zone of Germany is really a Red army, consisting of German war veterans, equipped with tanks, artillery and other heavy weapons, it was charged today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Arthur R. Cahill was elected treasurer of Montgomery Ward Co, at a meeting of directors today. Third to occupy the post this year, he succeeds Arthur C. Romer, who is also a vice president and a director of the company.

New York, the most important source of late yellow and white onions, now expects a crop that will be twice as great as that a year ago. The total yield will be only 6 per cent less than that for the bumper year of 1946. As for national production of this vegetable, the United States Department of Agriculture estimates that it will add up to 41,000,000 fifty-pound sacks, 4,000,000 more than in 1947.

DONORA, Pa., Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Borough of Donora today asked the United States Public Health Service to survey the air above the town in an effort to solve the mystery malady which took nineteen lives last week-end.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (NANA) -- First precise measurements of the strength of human bones, determined in the same manner as applied to structural steel or wooden rafters, have just been reported by scientists of the United States Bureau of Standards.

DETROIT, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Governor Dewey was ahead in unofficial returns from his native State of Michigan early today, but President Truman's labor followers waited for full reports from Wayne (Detroit) County before conceding the State's nineteen electoral votes.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly, who have been following the United States election with at least the same amount of attention as they have been giving to the Assembly meetings, expressed hope tonight that if Governor Dewey was elected he would promptly make known his views on the crucial issues before the Assembly.
OMAHA, Nov. 3 (Wednesday) (AP) -- With only one Nebraska race still in doubt, Republicans today had scored another across-the-board victory in Nebraska's 1948 general election.

VIENNA, Nov. 2 -- The Communist newspaper Tagblatt am Montag implied today that the murder of Irving Ross, a member of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission here, could have been premeditated, referring to the slaying as "the end of an espionage affair."

Net income of the Continental Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the nine months ended with last September increased to $41,8 1,005 from $24,889,113 earned in the corresponding three quarters of 1947, according to a report to be made public today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Gov. Earl Warren came smiling out of his suite in the St. Francis Hotel here just before mid-night to say that the nation-wide returns from yesterday's Presidential election were still too close for him to "make any estimate" of the final result at that hour.

Running with Republican and Liberal party endorsement, George Frankenthaler became this morning the first non-Democrat in fifty-four years to win the rich jupdicial prize of a post on the Surrogate's Court in New York County, when he nosed out John A. Mullen by 664 votes.

Isidore Dollinger, Representative-elect in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District in the Bronx, will go to Congress with a background of experience in legislative affairs attained during the last twelve years in the State Legislature.

Dean Jagger has been signed to co-star with Margaret Sullavan in McKnight Malmar's "The Storm," for the television premiere of "Studio One" at 7:30 o'clock Sunday night over the CBS video network. Supporting roles in the one-hour adaptation will be filled by Harry Bellaver, Alan MacAteer, Maurice Manson, Mary Wickes, John Forsythe and Leslie Litomy. Worthington C. Minor will direct.

Campaign Issues, Working of Electoral College and Data on Candidates Also Sent Short wave radio listeners in almost every part of the world were treated last night by the State Department's "Voice of America" broadcast to a round-the-clock report on how the United States elects a President.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Argentina won today the support of a majority of the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly for a move to delete a reference to barring Franco Spain from all action under the League of Nations Convention on Economic Statistics, in spite of the fact that Spain never had been a party to the convention.

Payments for war damage and other purposes by the United States to the Philippines, averaging more than $500,000 a day, will stimulate the economy of the islands for the next two years, Frank A. Waring, chairman of the United States-Philippine War Damage Commission, said in an interview released for publication today. He indicated that the flow of dollars from the United States will offset the import deficit of the new republic.

The American Export liner Exochorda sailed on her maiden voyage to the Mediterranean at 4 P. M. yesterday from Jersey City, with ninety passengers. Among them was Miss Amice M. Calverley, Egyptologist, who is returning to Baliana, Egypt, to continue her twenty-year study of the Temple of King Seti I.

Born of poor parents near Orchard and Stanton Streets on May 18, 1904, Jacob K. Javits' earliest memories include the cries of the pushcart peddlers of Manhattan's lower East Side. His father was a janitor who never made more than $40 a month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- Directors of the Matson Navigation Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Oceanic Steamship Company, have been made defendants in a suit filed in the State Superior Court here by a group of stockholders seeking recovery of $40,359,000 alleged to have been wasted in ship reconversion since the end of the war.

Times Square saw the death of a tradition yesterday. For the first time on a national election night, the Square was comparatively thinly populated. Such crowds as did assemble were voiceless, and without spirit.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Mexico will reserve the right to exclude states suspected of discrimination against Mexicans from participation in any new migrant labor treaty between this country and the United States, a Government spokesman said today.

Vito Marcantonio was born forty-five years ago in the polyglot Upper East Side district he has represented in Congress for six terms. In the past he has had major party support; this year he went it alone, winning a voting line only on the American Labor party ticket.

During all next week parents and other visitors will have an opportunity to see at first hand what the schools of this community are doing. Each year American Education Week is set aside to focus special attention on the nation's schools. Here in this city the doors will be open to all who wish to visit the classrooms and see the school system in action.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A union seeking bargaining rights may go directly to the National Labor Relations Board for certification without first requesting recognition of the employer, the board stated today.
Your excellent editorial of Oct. 2 placed a deserved spotlight on the home medical care program at Montefiore Hospital.

OAKDALE, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Jim Lappin of Bishop Loughlin set a new record for 2.4-mile course here today in winning the fifteenth annual interscholastic cross-country run sponsored by the La Salle Military Academy. Lappin toured the flat but difficult course in 12 minutes 39.5 seconds to lower the standard of 12:46.6 set by Ed Keating of Curtis in 1931.

Furs, satins and lace shared honors last night at the starting signal of the social season, the Sixtieth National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. It was a big night for mink and ermine, with wraps ranging from the briefest capelets and wrapped boleros to full length sweeping capes and coats.

WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Nov. 2 (AP) -- The names of eleven men who lost their lives in the crash of an Air Force C-47 near Muldrow, Okla., yesterday were released today by the commanding officer of the Sheppard Air Force Base, where the men were stationed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- National Selective Service headquarters recommended today that qualified students in the professional schools for the "healing arts" of medicine, dentistry, veterinary medicine and osteopathy be deferred from the draft until their graduation.

A "mechanical mole" that digs and loads coal at a rate of three tons a minute has entered, or soon will enter, the war against the high cost of mining soft coal. This particular twenty-six-ton contraption has just been unveiled for the edification of the press at New Lexington, Ohio, by a Pittsburgh coal company, but other concerns are reported to have their own versions under development.

The States Rights Democratic ticket, headed by Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, was romping off this morning with forty electoral votes in five Southern states, an electoral total that had been as good as conceded to it even before the balloting began.

Hal Price Headley's Lithe received comparatively few votes in the balloting at the mutuel windows, but she was the star of the election day show before 36,179 Empire City-at-Jamaica customers yesterday.
The choice of a President by the House of Representatives in the event that no candidate receives a majority of the electoral votes is provided for in the Constitution.

Representative Vito Marcantonio last night squeaked through to a narrow victory for re-election to Congress over John P. Morrissey, Tammany Democrat, and John Ellis, Republican, in his first contest as a candidate on the American Labor party line alone.
A radical departure from the present methods of nursing education in this nation was recommended yesterday in a report by the Committee on the Function of Nursing after a six-month study.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- With a heavier vote than had been expected, despite the record registration of 48,000, Governor Dewey carried Rockland County today by 7,847 votes, 1,813 more than his plurality of 6,034 over Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1944.

Secretary Forrestal's directive to the three services to clear all matters of defense legislation through his office instead of fighting it out before Congressional committees is another step in his effort to bring about real unification in the military establishment.

MOSCOW, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Pravda, Izvestia and Trud devoted special stories today on the closing campaign speeches of President Truman and Progressive party candidate Henry A. Wallace, but ignored that of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 2 -- An incipient revolt by 731 girl students of the East Orange High School on North Walnut Street was checked temporarily today when nine new mirrors were ordered by the Board of Education to supplement inadequate facilities for glamour.

NANKING, Nov. 2 -- Nationalist planes continued bombing Mukden today and the city is now without water and electricity, according to a report received tonight from Angus Ward, United States Consul General. The Communists are already in full control of the Manchurian industrial center.
Non-Communist elements in eight seceding store locals were invited yesterday to return to the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

In a surprise move yesterday, Vacuum Foods Corporation, maker f Minute-Maid concentrated frozen orange juice, began processing for the 1948-49 season in its $2,500,000 plant at Plymouth, Fla. General production of concentrated juices was not expected to start for another thirty days, according to industry observers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- A spokesman for the Arabian American Oil Company disclosed today that the concern had decided to give up its option on oil concessions in the Saudi Arabian-Kuweit "neutral" zone on the Persian Gulf.
PEIPING, Nov. 2 -- Chinese scientists have begun a new search for fossils of the "Peking man" to replace those that disappeared shortly after the outbreak of the Pacific War.

HELENA, Mont., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Light rain and snow apparently had little effect on the Montana election today as the state voted for one Senator, a Governor, two Representatives and state and county officers.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The United Nations Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee rejected today a Russian amendment that would have sanctioned restrictions imposed upon freedom of movement of Russian nationals by the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The inactive National Guard was reestablished today to enable both officers and enlisted men no longer able to continue active training with their regular National Guard units to retain their Guard status.

The, vast Pacific Northwest is about to experience a shortage of electric power so severe that it threatens to undermine the very industrial growth that cheap electric rates made possible in the area, according to a private utility executive.

Brooklyn College's hopes of extending its winning streak to eight straight against City College Saturday received a severe jolt yesterday when it was learned that Marv Schrier, varsity center, will miss the encounter. Schrier suffered an ankle injury against Hofstra last week and has failed to respond to treatment.

OTTAWA, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Statistics Bureau estimated today that the world had more bread grain for export than at any time in nearly twenty years and that over-all supplies were higher than in any year since 1939.

The Navy announced yesterday that construction work had started on new buildings for the Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens, under the largest hospital contract ever awarded by the Bureau of Yards and Docks.
Although the team played its opening game on Sept. 25, Fordham will be "at home" Saturday for the first time this season in the football meeting with Boston University at the Polo Grounds.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The United Nations Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee rejected today a Russian amendment that would have sanctioned restrictions imposed upon freedom of movement of Russian nationals by the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The inactive National Guard was reestablished today to enable both officers and enlisted men no longer able to continue active training with their regular National Guard units to retain their Guard status.

The, vast Pacific Northwest is about to experience a shortage of electric power so severe that it threatens to undermine the very industrial growth that cheap electric rates made possible in the area, according to a private utility executive.

Nearly 1,000 party workers and their guests, many of them holders of important posts, gathered at Republican headquarters in the Roosevelt Hotel early last evening to receive returns and participate in an expected victory celebration. Two hundred were still there at 5 o'clock this morning. They were receiving returns. But there had been no noticeable jubilation.

Led by Bill Matthews, a hard-hitting left halfback from Cartaret, N. J., New York University's freshman football team battled to a 6-6 tie with a favored Fordham yearling squad before 4,000 persons yesterday at Fordham Field.
Jack Kranis, Democratic-Liberal candidate, won a seat in the City Council from Brooklyn in a sweeping victory today that saw him poll more votes than his two opponents combined.
SEATTLE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Returns from normally Democratic western Washington cities sent President Truman into a comfortable lead over Governor Dewey tonight in Washington State's elections.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The weather had a hand in today's heavy vote -- mild and clear almost everywhere in the country.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- President Truman was keeping himself incommunicado early this morning as a historic and startling election upset teetered in the balance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated that net railroad income in September was $82,000,000, compared with $20,700,000 in September, 1947. The estimate was based on reports filed by the Class 1 roads.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 2 (AP) -- On the basis of returns from more than half of Wyoming's 680 precincts, President Truman and Democratic Gov. Lester C. Hunt were out in front late tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- The fifty-ninth annual American exhibition opens tomorrow in the Art Institute with a preview for exhibiting artists and members of the museum. From Thursday through Jan. 2 the exhibition will be open to the public.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Postoffice Department reports that there will be no change in regular postmasters if Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is elected President today. All such postmasters are protected in their jobs by Civil Service law.

Frank L. Steinbauer has been appointed sales manager of the Philadelphia territory by A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., carpets. He formerly was sales manager in Seattle, where he has been succeeded by Carl Holmer of the Atlanta office.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- Russian-controlled radio propagandists in Berlin are today "talking largely into a vacuum," according to Col. Gordon Textor, director of the American Military Government's information services division.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Thomas Goldberg, a Republican committeeman, was held in $500 bail by United States Commissioner Ethan Allen Doty on charges that he purchased a vote in yesterday's election in violation of the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.

Democratic control of both the Senate and House of the Eighty-first Congress was probable if not a certainty on the basis of returns at 6 A. M. today from yesterday's dramatic and surprise-laden election.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Although the last day of the long account kept business down in the stock markets here today, most sections were firm.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- If Thomas E. Dewey is elected President of the United States today, he and his family will cease to be "free" from the moment the returns are in.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Governor Dewey defeated President Truman today in traditional Republican Suffolk County by a vote of 75,481 to 29,129. Henry A. Wallace polled 2,679 votes. The Dewey-Warren margin of victory approached closely the 50,000 plurality predicted by Representative W. Kingsland Macy Republican county chairman, although the total number of votes cast was below expectations based on a record registration of 154,077.

The accent was on offense at Baker Field yesterday as Coach Lou Little sent his Columbia Lions through a three-hour practice session in preparation for Saturday's game with Dartmouth. A defensive drill for the regulars preceded the work on the Lions' attack.

I find my T-square raised in high horror at "Topics of The Times" Oct. 22 and its folksy, anonymous architectural adviser. "* * * what distinguishes architecture from me building * * * is an element of add beauty," and "beauty in architecture * * * is always something somehow added."
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 2 -- Genial and smiling as ever, President Harry S. Truman went to the ballot box with his family today. He said he expected nothing but victory.

Still confident at 2:30 o'clock this morning that President Truman and Alben Barkley would be elected as a result of yesterday's heavy voting, Senator J. Howard McGrath, National Democratic Chairman, predicted a total of 300 Democratic votes in the electoral college.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Governor Dewey defeated President Truman today in traditional Republican Suffolk County by a vote of 75,481 to 29,129. Henry A. Wallace polled 2,679 votes. The Dewey-Warren margin of victory approached closely the 50,000 plurality predicted by Representative W. Kingsland Macy Republican county chairman, although the total number of votes cast was below expectations based on a record registration of 154,077.

The accent was on offense at Baker Field yesterday as Coach Lou Little sent his Columbia Lions through a three-hour practice session in preparation for Saturday's game with Dartmouth. A defensive drill for the regulars preceded the work on the Lions' attack.
