INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 2 -- Genial and smiling as ever, President Harry S. Truman went to the ballot box with his family today. He said he expected nothing but victory.

Still confident at 2:30 o'clock this morning that President Truman and Alben Barkley would be elected as a result of yesterday's heavy voting, Senator J. Howard McGrath, National Democratic Chairman, predicted a total of 300 Democratic votes in the electoral college.

In the early hours of the morning the outcome of one of the closest elections in the history of the American people was still undecided. What was clear was that the electorate had turned out in great numbers to register its choice. This pilgrimage to the precinct schoolhouse, to a lamp-lit private home in the New Hampshire White Mountains, to a tobacco store in Manhattan is more than an expression of choice for President.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Brookfield Farm's Istan survived a foul claim and won the twenty-second running of the $7,500 added Janney Handicap before an election day crowd of 14,000 at Pimlico today.

THERE was a story floating around Baltimore last week-end that they didn't even bother to give Citation a rubdown after his walkover in the Pimlico Special on Friday but that Eddie Arcaro desperately needed a rubdown. He'd strained every muscle in his arms while trying to hold back the explosive Calumet Comet in his majestic solo flight around the historic old track.

ITHACA, N, Y., Nov. 2 (AP) -- A suggestion that substitutions in college football be limited was pooh-poohed today by Cornell University's head coach, George K. (Lefty) James, who is credited with making 296 line-up changes in defeating Columbia last Saturday.
SOUTH SALEM, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Henry A. Wallace, Progressive party candidate for President, and Mrs. Wallace, left Farvue Farm, their home near here, early this morning to cast their ballots.

SAN FRANCISCO, Wednesday, Nov. 3 -- Only a few thousand votes separated President Truman and Governor Dewey early today as the tabulation of California's votes in the Presidential election of yesterday neared the half-way mark.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- President Truman's victory was interpreted in France tonight as marking the persistence throughout the United States of the New Deal sentiment that long sustained Franklin D. Roosevelt. It also was regarded as a clear mandate from the American people for continuance of the foreign policy that had crystallized in the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The Government-sponsored mission investigating the labor and trade union situation in Malaya reported tonight that Communists had planned to undermine the Malayan trade-union movement and substitute organizations aimed at setting up a Communist republic.

The election of President Truman vitrually assures the retention of title in the tidelands off the coast of California. In a Supreme Court decision almost eighteen months ago, it was held that the United States Government had paramount rights in these lands, which contain large petroleum resources.

AND now we interrupt this lavish broadcast of the recapitulation of the recapitulations of the recapitulations of the election returns to bring you a review of a new book by Ludwig Bemelmans, "The Best of Times,"* which even Mr. Roper or Mr. Gallup could have told you is a sure winner in any anti-political sweepstakes and a wise and witty and generous example of his bemelmaniacal talents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Congress' second organizational upheaval in two years will find seasoned legislators, including many Southern conservatives and former committee chairmen, in key posts when the Democrats reassume control next January.

Henry A. Wallace, whose Progressive party candidacy has been credited with approximately one million votes, called yesterday upon President Truman to redeem his campaign promises and bring about controls to reduce prices, repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act, full civil rights for Negroes, and full recognition and assistance to Israel.

VIENNA, Nov. 3 -- United States authorities here are preparing official action to overcome the difficulties encountered in investigating the murder of Irving Ross, a member of the Marshall ECA Mission Plan here in the Soviet sector of the city early Sunday.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- The United States and British Military Governments announced today they had ordered the retention of rationing and price controls on basic food commodities in western Germany to prevent German profiteering in United States and British food shipments.

Four children were suffocated by smoke yesterday evening in a Harlem flat while their mother, unaware that fire had broken out in the apartment, was singing a spiritual for friends in an apartment below.

Of the estimated 12,000 cerebral palsy victims in the metropolitan area, 1,000 children now are receiving medical care and about 100 of these are being cared for by the Brooklyn Visiting Nurses Association, Marie Knowles said yesterday.

Failure to apply known methods to control infectious diseases results in 100,000 preventable deaths annually, Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, United States Surgeon General, declared yesterday. At the same time he urged the National Committee for Mental Hygiene to add to public understanding of mental illness.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Britain welcomes the initiative taken by the United States in seeking an international solution to the problem of Antarctica, Foreign Secretary Bevin told the House of Commons today during the traditional Wednesday period for replies to questions on foreign affairs.

Although Governor Dewey carried the normally Republican state of New Jersey, hard-fighting Democrats in the industrial areas held his plurality to 30 per cent of the forecasts and made significant gains in many parts of the state, a complete count showed yesterday.

The "100 per cent" promotion plan under which New York public school pupils are advanced in grade on the basis of their age rather than on academic accomplishment is up for review by city education officials, it became known yesterday.

The most important international chess masters' tournament to be held in this country since the six-cornered contest here in 1927, which was won by the late Jose R. Capablanca and preceded his world championship match with the late Dr. Alexander Alekhine, is listed for Dec. 24 to Jan 2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Atomic Energy Commission directed the General Electric Company today to withdraw and withhold recognition from the United Electrical Workers, CIO, in respect to any employes engaged on atomic work of a restricted nature.

Hundreds of books recently published and illustrations of the various processes that go into the making of a book from the manuscript stage to the time it appears on the bookseller's shelf, went on exhibition yesterday in the Museum of Science and Industry in the RCA Building of Rockefeller Center.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3. -- A few hours after being apprised by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of the Republican ticket's defeat, Earl Warren went back to Sacramento today to tackle his California Governor's job from which he had "been away too long." He wanted, he said, to put in some work during the afternoon on his budget message for 1949-50.

Furniture retailers will boycott bedroom suite manufacturers who increase wholesale prices, buyers declared yesterday. They said case goods are in good supply and they will be able to absorb lines of producers who intend to hold the price line.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Baltimore sports were thrown for a loss at the polls yesterday.

Continuing the department drive for cleaner streets, William J. Powell, Sanitation Commissioner, announced yesterday that his inspectors had issued 404 more summonses to alleged violators of the sanitary code. The summonses are returnable today in the Magistrates Court.

Horlacher Brewing Company, Allentown, Pa., producers of Perfection and Pilsner Beers, will make extensive use of newspapers to introduce these brews in the New York market area by the end of this year. Deglin Wood, Inc., is the agency.

MADRID, Nov. 3 -- As an immediate result of President Truman's astonishing electoral victory, many major foreign political developments that had been halted until after the voting in the United States almost certainly will be activated now more swiftly than had been expected.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- President Truman was urged today by Vincent Malone, president of the Independent Marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers, one of the striking maritime unions on the West Coast, to call a conference of labor leaders to map a four-year plan for labor peace.
The first sixty-three children to enter the United States under the displaced persons act of 1948 celebrated here yesterday the election of President Truman as "the man who brought us to America."
THE NEW YORK TIMES starts printing tomorrow Joe Louis' own story of his life. It will iron in seven installments, daily except Sunday.

The Maritime Commission is expected to decide in the next two weeks on a proposed downward adjustment of American-flag cargo rates for carrying Marshall Plan commodities to European ports, it was reported here yesterday.

With inclement weather forcing Fordham to divide its practice session between field and gym, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday turned his attention to the study of defensive measures against Boston University's winged T-formation.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Prime Minister Attlee promised tonight to investigate complaints that the procedure of the Government's purge of Communists and Fascists from the civil service was unfair.
Laundry products experts at General Foods Corporation opened a new home laundry center at 383 Madison Avenue yesterday with demonstrations of a new and improved La France flake bluing.

Officials of the country's three nation-wide public opinion polls, all of which forecast a Dewey victory, were studying election returns yesterday to find out why President Truman was right when he said their faces would be red after Election Day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Few changes in the Cabinet are expected when President Truman starts his new term of office on Jan. 20, and for at least some time later. Mr. Truman is represented as well satisfied with his departmental advisers, and they, in return, are pictured as equally happy.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The examination by experts of the four-year national programs submitted to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation has brought severe French criticism of the British plan on the ground that its austerity involves importing as little as possible, while flooding Europe with British products.
The Democrats were assured by election returns or concessions last night of a numerical majority of twelve in the Senate of the Eighty-first Congress.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 3 -- Pre-election warnings in the country's big Farm Belt that farmers, faced with falling prices and growing surpluses, were uneasy over the Republican campaign pronouncements apparently were borne out in yesterday's returns.
With indications that the pre-election slowdown noted in some lines is ending, many business quarters reacted favorably yesterday to the unexpected re-election of President Truman.
Reversing a ten-year trend, the Democratic party in Tuesday's election gained a total of twenty-nine seats in the State Legislature, including nineteen seats in the Assembly and ten in the Senate.

Glenn Dobbs, who spoiled Red Strader's debut as coach of the Football Yankees by passing and running to three touchdowns for the Dons in the last five minutes of their previous encounter on the Coast, is not likely to see much service in the New York-Los Angeles return match at the Stadium Sunday.

Eight pressing problems now confront production executives in their attempt to lower costs and increase output and quality, according to a survey of 1,000 companies by the American Management Association, released yesterday. They are:
John F. Bales has resigned as executive vice president of Tek Hughes, Inc., effective Dec. 3 and after that date will assume an executive position with Yardley Co., Ltd.
Still stunned at national election figures that failed to match the fat votes they gave Governor Dewey, strongly Republican suburban counties here tallied the score yesterday on local issues.

Any liberal American, of any party, may be content with some of the results of Tuesday's elections to the United States Senate. In Illinois Prof. Paul H. Douglas, a "liberal progressive" with an international point of view, defeated the incumbent Republican, C. Wayland Brooks, an outspoken isolationist.

A special committee will begin this afternoon the counting of 26,000 votes cast by members of the National Maritime Union in a referendum to decide whether the union's officers should sign the Taft-Hartley Law non-Communist affidavits, Neal Hanley, NMU national secretary, said yesterday.

Horse players stayed away from the Empire City-at-Jamaica proceedings in unprecented numbers yesterday. Only 12,700 checked in, that being the smallest turnstile count of the down-state New York racing season.

Balloting by local members of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, on acceptance or rejection of the final offer of the New York Shipping Association will begin at 6 o'clock this morning, John J. Carmody, field examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, said yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 3 -- The fact that President Truman's victory was unexpected in Italy does not mean that it was unwelcome. On the contrary most Italians feel that Mr. Truman's re-election removes any doubt as to what might have been the fate of the Marshall Plan under a Republican administration.
An author, a critic, an actor, and a producer tangled in debate last night over station WQXR on the question of why better films were not being made today.

PEIPING, Nov. 3 -- Nationalist B-24 and B-25 bombers based here bombed Mukden today for the third successive day. The bombers are trying to blast the industrial targets and the large munitions dumps that fell into Communist hands.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 3 -- President Truman accepted this day of supreme triumph in a spirit of humility and with a simple pledge to serve the American people for prosperity and peace. The fire-breathing campaigner, who "passed a miracle" unsurpassed in American political history, today was more like the man who appeared so overawed when he assumed the succession to the late Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The Albatross III, only Federal marine fishery research vessel, tied up at the East River and Fulton Street yesterday after a week of study into underwater conditions along the continental shelf "between a line south from Marthas Vineyard and the Hudson Canyon."
ALBANY, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Governor Dewey came home to a friendly, sympathetic welcome here tonight.
Results of the Presidential election will have little effect on automobile sales, Don E. Ahrens, general sales manager of the Cadillac division, General Motors Corporation, declared yesterday.

Two new films will open in first- run theatres this morning. At the Rivoli, the -attraction is "The nake Pit," TwentieJ CenturyFox's adaptation of the novel by Mary Jane Ward, starring Olivia de Havilland. The drama was directed by Anatole Litvak who coproduced with Robert Bassler from a sdreen play by Frank Partos and Millen Brand.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., completed its fiscal year last July 31 with the highest sales and earnings in its twenty-year history, according to the annual report of Samuel Bronfman, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday.
DENVER, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The biggest football upset in the country last week did not happen to a football team. It happened to Harry Bitman, Denver tailor.

President Truman's stunning victory over Governor Dewey was interpreted yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer as a rebuke to the Eightieth Congress and a warning to Russia that "the people of the United States do not like to be pushed around."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said today that the election of President Truman shows "it is almost impossible to put an administration out of office at the very peak of a prosperity boom."
The executive board of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, dropped any immediate move yesterday to expel Austin Hogan, left-wing president of the local.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 4 -- Astonishment and relief were mingled in Britain yesterday as the certainty of President Truman's victory grew and both these emotions were reflected in this morning's newspapers.

The first "tourist class" service by a scheduled airline began last night when Capital Airlines sent from La Guardia Field a DC-4 airplane with fifteen passengers for Chicago at $29.60 each and another ten for Pittsburgh. The rest of the four-engined plane's pay load was taken up by air cargo.

Before we in the newspaper business spend all our time and energy analyzing Governor Dewey's failure in the election, maybe we ought to try to analyze our own failure. For that failure is almost as spectacular as the President's victory, and the quicker we admit it the better off we'll be.
The residential property at 262 Purchase Street in Rye, N. Y., has just been sold for the third time this year. Blakeman Quintard Meyer was the broker in each of the transactions.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Over the objections of the Soviet Union and its satellites, the United Nations General Assembly approved today five resolutions to enable the Trusteeship Council to participate more actively in the social and economic development of non-self-governing territories.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 3 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers dampened Fort Wayne's entry into the Basketball Association of America by taking an 80-76 victory in the season opener tonight.

For the first time in some years foreign handicrafts have arrived here in quantities reminiscent of pre-war days. Despite the shortages abroad, the Women's International Exposition, which ended last night its third day of exhibition and program activity in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, had many of the aspects of an international bazaar.

The capital of the National City Bank of New York would be restored to $124,000,000 under a proposal adopted yesterday by the board of directors. The plan will be submitted to stockholders for their approval at the annual meeting on Jan. 11.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- John Foster Dulles, principal adviser to Governor Dewey on foreign affairs, issued a statement here tonight expressing disappointment over Mr. Dewey's defeat but declaring the election of President Truman "will, no doubt, mean the continuance of the bipartisan foreign policies that have proved their worth."
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A twenty-six-game basketball schedule for Rutgers University was announced today by George E. Little, director of athletics.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- In a strict party vote the Labor Government in the House of Commons tonight defeated by 359 votes to 195 a Conservative motion condemning the Government's proposal to nationalize the iron and steel industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Federal Trade Commission filed separate complaints today against twenty-four candy and confectionary manufacturing companies in Eastern and Central States charting them with violating the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.

A property in the midtown millinery district that was sold last year for the benefit of bondholders passed to new control yesterday when David S. Meister, operator, resold the seventeen-story loft building on a plot 103 by 100 feet at 49 to 57 West Thirty-seventh Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.
Despite a mud-covered gridiron, City College's football team yesterday continued to drill intensively for Saturday night's encounter with Brooklyn College, the "big game" of the C.C.N.Y. campaign.

Charles P. Taft, who served in the State Department from 1943 to 1945, has turned in to Farrar, Strauss the manuscript of a book on the State Department. Mr. Taft, a brother of Senator Robert A. Taft, served as Director of the Office of Economic Affairs and later as Director of the Office of Transport and Communication Policy.
The common man walked, or rode, to work yesterday a little stunned by the miracle he passed when he r'ared up on Tuesday and re-elected President Truman.

Asserting that the results of Tuesday's election opened a new era for American labor politically, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, described yesterday "President Truman's triple victory," his election and winning Democratic control of both Houses of Congress, as "the greatest victory ever achieved under the New Deal banner."

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The British, who are a nation of sportsmen and bettors, were delighted today to see a long shot win in a neck and neck race for the United States Presidency. They did not get really interested in the election until it became a sporting proposition.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 3 -- Israeli Army patrols repulsed the first effort of the Egyptians to break out of the beleaguered police fortress of Iraq Suweidan last night, an Army spokesman announced today.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, President of the United Nations Assembly, was one of the first persons here to offer public congratulations to President Truman today. Dr. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs and chief of the Australian Delegation, called Mr. Truman "a magnificent fighter" and said that the people of all lands owed him tribute for his work for human welfare.

It is in these first post-election days that one gets an adequate idea of the disruptive and devastating effect, once every four years, of the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November on the continuity of American thought.

The radio voice which used to announce that it was "time to stump the experts" was not on the air, with that program, Tuesday night. But it might have been. The experts were indeed stumped when a predicted landslide for Governor Dewey turned into a victory for President Truman.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra returned to London today for the first time since the war. All was forgiven in truly Christian spirit, for the tour of Britain that began tonight is under the auspices of the European religious movement, Christian Action.
Should anyone still believe in polls, here are the election-night computations of G.E. Hooper, Inc., which reports that NBC on that occasion won the largest audiences in both radio and television.

WESLEY, Me., Nov. 3 -- This was a perfect day for deer hunting, and although we did not get a shot, there are worse things than failing to get a deer the first day. Spending the rest of the time in the woods as camp cook is one of them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, has told President Truman and his National Security Council that the present state of uncoordinated internal security controls constitutes a threat of the utmost gravity to the whole national security and that this threat can best be met by creation of an over-all central authority for all domestic protective efforts.

Over the objection of Commissioner Robert Moses, the City Planning Commission, voted yesterday to hold a public hearing at 2 P.M. on Nov. 17 on a proposed zoning amendment that would permit construction of parking garages, as a matter of right, on any property zoned for business or retail use in any part of the city.

Mr. Truman has confounded the prophets and won in his own right the great office of the Presidency, to which he succeeded in 1945. His victory is a personal triumph, accomplished in the face of apparently heavy odds and despite the fact that both the left wing and the right wing of his own party deserted him.

Dipping back into Negro lore of more than a century ago, Dorothy Heyward has come up with an interesting revolutionary drama, "Set My People Free," put on by the Theatre Guild at the Hudson last evening. Mrs. Heyward is telling the story of Denmark Vesey, who almost led his people up to a rebellion in Charleston in 1826.

Frankie Frisch and Freddy Fitzsimmons, whose feats of derringdo on the diamond contributed many a glowing page to the glamorous history of the Polo Grounds, will be back in the uniform of the New York Giants next season as coaches, it was announced yesterday by President Horace Stoneham.
BERLIN, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- Germans followed the returns of the United States Presidential election with mounting excitement as President Truman swept to his dramatic victory.

Four changes in bus routes stemming from the police decision to try full-scale experimental operation of one-way traffic on Ninth and Tenth Avenues were announced yesterday. The shifts will go into effect Saturday when the new plan starts a sixty-day trial.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, asked last night for public support of the university's principles of freedom of inquiry. He stressed in an address to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York the value to the whole community of an institution that builds "a solid wall of defense against isms" by creating individual responsibility.
PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Britain already has shipped 15,200 tons of narrow-gauge steel rails to the Soviet Union and the remainder of 25,000 tons promised under the trade agreement of last December is ready for shipment, it was learned officially today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 3 -- While the United States election results reached Belgrade too late for publication, there can be no doubt that editorial offices have been profoundly shocked by Henry A. Wallace's dismal showing.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Army completed its hevay contact work for Stanford in the rain today. Coach Earl Blaik sent his charges through a tough defensive drill that included pass defense.

Lieut. W. R. Ballard of the Canadian Army team won the Dakota Trophy in the international military jumping last night for the Dominion's first victory of the glittering National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.

FORT DIX, N. J., Nov. 3 -- "Welcome to the United States Army." With these words, Lieut. Col. Charles F. Arny, commanding the initial receiving point at Fort Dix, greeted this afternoon the first seven recruits to arrive here under the Selective Service Act of 1948. Hundreds more are expected to follow in the coming weeks.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 3 -- The most immediate effect of President Truman's victory on Latin America is likely to be the maintenance of the status quo of the United States diplomatic corps. Although few South Americans thought Governor Dewey would clean out all Ambassadors on the Continent if elected, it was considered that political appointees such as James Bruce in Argentina and Claude G. Bowers here would be replaced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Organized labor was jubilant today over the election of President Truman. Labor spokesmen asserted that it was a mandate to Congress to repeal the Taft-Hartley Act "and enact a program of progressive labor legislation."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- Ewing Scott, director of such Arctic films as "Mala" and the recent "Harpoon," has closed a deal with Universal-International for the production of a new picture, "Arctic Manhunt," for which he already has photographed 60 per cent of the scenes in Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- In the general election voters of several states were called upon to decide upon bonuses for veterans of World War II, increased old age pensions, labor issues and various tax and bond proposals.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, declared yesterday that a gain of eight New York seats in the House of Representatives was a mandate to the Democratic majority in the State's next Congressional delegation to go forward with the program so vigorously advocated by President Truman during the campaign.
The cotton futures market turned strong and active yesterday as a result of the elections, and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 3 to 42 points net higher.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 -- Advocates of restricting the sale of intoxicating beverages were rebuffed in California and Washington in yesterday's election, but held their ground in Oregon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- The Pennsylvania coaches went down the line on the virtues of the Penn State football team today and the sum total added up to a combination of Notre Dame, Michigan and the Chicago Bears. Apparently Bob Higgins' Nittany Lions were as good as elected and it wouldn't be necessary to wait until the final returns to know the winner of the game here Saturday at Franklin Field.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- President Truman's vote-getting power pulled the Democrats into solid control in thirty of the country's forty-eight governorships today.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- A steady decrease in the number of railway passengers contrasted sharply with a growth in British airlines traffic recorded today in the Government's Monthly Digest of Statistics.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The Presidente Peron, 14,500-ton combination passenger and cargo vessel built by Vickers-Armstrongs for the Argentine Government, was launched at Barrow-in-Furness to- day.
The cottonseed oil futures market on the New York Produce Exchange was active and irregular yesterday with a turnover of 283 lots.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Federal District Court here declared today that it "does not have the power" to direct the Federal Reserve Board to clarify further its complaint charging that the Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco, had violated the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.

Net income of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in the first nine months of this year rose to $8,869,512 after taxes and all charges from $2,680,567 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday.

Although President Truman lost New York State and its forty-seven electoral votes to Governor Dewey, his Republican opponent, by a plurality of 42,777 in Tuesday's election, Democratic and labor leaders, after analyzing the returns yesterday, expressed complete satisfaction with the result.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 3 -- With virtually a third of the squad absent from practice because of examinations, the remainder of the Dartmouth football team underwent a sketchy workout in preparation for Saturday's clash with the unpredictable Lions of Columbia.

Russia and Hungary have signed a $150,000,000 "goods exchange" agreement that will regulate trade between the two countries until Dec. 31, 1949, according to details available in foreign trade circles here yesterday.

The Democrats swept all of Congress yesterday, recapturing the supposedly impregnable Republican House by a landslide and seizing firm control of the Senate in one of the great political revolutions of American history.

Lavish, handwoven silks from Siam that may do much to alter current trends in interior color schemes were introduced yesterday by Thaibok Fabrics at a special showing at the Pierre Hotel. They are the products of native weavers in remote Siamese provinces and represent traditional designs and techniques that are said, however, to have been almost unknown outside the country.

Except by Mr. Wallace, national defense was not made an issue, even by inference, in the campaign just concluded. Mr. Truman and Mr. Dewey showed no division there. Both were unqualifiedly in favor of as strong a military establishment as is needed to help keep the peace.
Harry S. Truman showed in his recent campaign the tough fighting qualities that are his natural inheritance as a descendant of the American pioneer stock on both his father's and his mother's sides.
Joseph Clark Grew, former United States Ambassador to Japan, and Mrs. Grew have come to the ,Savoy-Plaza from Washington.

Third parties have often played a useful part in the past. Many times their programs have been taken over by the major parties and enacted into law. But the abysmal failure of Henry A. Wallace in Tuesday's election proves once and for all time that this country has no room for a third party allied with those whose roots are in foreign soil.

CAIRO, Nov. 3 -- Although the attitude of most Arab spokesmen had been "a plague on both their houses -- they are both against us" President Truman's unexpected triumph caused a sensation in Cairo that was a measure of the tremendous importance of American politics to the Middle East.

CLEMSON, S.C., Nov. 3 -- The Clemson American Legion Post will award a plaque for "courageous and distinguished service in battle and baseball" to Leland V. (Lou) Brissie at an Armistice Day meeting the night of Nov. 11.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Charles de Gaulle is Premier Stalin's candidate for power in France and would be his instrument if he gained power, Leon Blum, veteran Socialist leader, asserts in an article to appear tomorrow in the Socialist newspaper Le Populaire.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 4 -- The court returned to session in the paneled hall of the former Japanese War Ministry where, for the last two and one-half years, approximately 9,000,000 words of evidence had been presented covering the activities of seventeen Japanese Governments in the thirteen years preceding the attack on Pearl Harbor.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- While placing the blame on the French Communist party for its attempt to wreck the nation's economy, Premier Henri Queuille said tonight that the Government had surmounted the attack. He warned, though, it could not fulfill "its republican mission" if the nation should divide itself into two opposing blocs.

After conceding defeat and sending congratulations to President Truman yesterday, Governor Dewey announced he did not intend to seek a third Presidential nomination. He said he had "no plans" about a third term as Governor and denied a reported intention of resigning. His term has two years to run.

Joseph Fuchs is the kind of musician who never lets you down. His violin recital at Carnegie Hall last night was an occasion rich in musical values. It was also rich in virtuosity, but technical exploits were something that Mr. Fuchs -- and his listeners -- took for granted.

While business activity in the Second Federal Reserve District has been continuing at high levels, the district is nevertheless accounting for a smaller proportion of the national income than before both the war and the depression. This is pointed out in a survey published today by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The first seven men conscripted here under the nation's first peacetime draft were inducted yesterday at the Army recruiting and induction center at 39 Whitehall Street, where 1,823 young men enlisted last month.

Vito Marcantonio goes back to Congress for the seventh time, but it is clear that he no longer represents his constituents: Of 98,603 votes cast for the three contenders in the Eighteenth Congressional District he received 35,937, or 36 per cent; 62,666 voters were against him.

I was deeply impressed by the editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 24 entitled "Negro Education." It moves me to tell you about our Catholic Scholarships for Negroes, Inc., which was incorporated here in Massachusetts in the spring of 1947.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Dr. Manley O. Hudson, United States pioneer in the advancement of international law, was one of fifteen jurists elected by the General Assembly today to the United Nations International Law Commission.

After questioning two officials of the Sheffield Farms Company, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday that he had received "no satisfactory explanation" for the alleged fixing of milk prices in city contracts. The city official previously had examined officials of the Borden Milk Company and the Dairymen's League on the subject of collusion among the milk companies.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 3 -- Kansas voted repeal of its sixty-eight-year-old constitutional prohibition amendment. Wet forces piled up an apparent 46,000-vote majority in yesterday's voting.

NANKING, Thursday, Nov. 4 -- Manifestly hoping for a Republican victory in the United States elections, high Chinese officials were unable to conceal their disappointment today as the balloting returns, broadcast by American shortwave radio, showed President Truman's re-election.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Attempts to introduce a mechanical loading machine on one of London's wharfs started a walkout Monday of 400 dockworkers who were still on strike tonight. The machine, which was on trial at Butler's wharf, is said to do the work of twelve men.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, is going to trade punches again with Billy Conn, who has emerged from a retirement forced by Louis two years ago.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 3 -- Neighbor Harry S. Truman put together his home state's farm and labor vote to win a tremendous victory and lead the Democrats in a clean sweep of yesterday's general election.

Merrill A. Watson, president, Carpet Institute, yesterday outlined a five-point program to increase 1949 carpet sales at the manufacturing level during an institute meeting with top executives of local carpet specialty stores in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A Federal statutory, court reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., for an injunction barring the United States Government and two groups of shipping lines in the North Atlantic trade from implementing two recent Maritime Commission orders.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio declared yesterday a quarterly cash dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock plus a 2 per cent stock dividend on the common, both payable on Dec. 10.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Mexico's West Point football team, Colegio Militar, expects to defeat the University of Tampa at Tampa, Fla., next Sunday. The team leaves Friday in a military transport plane.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 27:
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 3 -- The word from Coach Charlie Caldwell is that the Tigers will go "all out" to beat Harvard in the forty-first game of their series at Palmer Stadium Saturday.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The tense election struggle in the United States gripped attention in the stock markets here today. Although it was the start of the new account, the neck-and-neck voting excluded all other topics.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- A United States B-29 Superfortress, on a routine flight between Scampton airfield in Lincolnshire and the Burtonwood air depot in Lancashire, crashed today with its crew of three officers and seven enlisted men.

When Jean Dalrymple and Gabriel Pascal corralled last spring the American rights to Jean-Paul Sartre's Parisian hit, "Les Mains Sales" (called "Red Gloves" for Broadway purposes), the deal was enviously regarded as one of the best staged coups of show business.
MASTIC, L. I., Nov. 3 -- A 12-year-old boy bicyclist was killed and the motorist who ran him down was injured in a double accident on Montauk Highway, at Park Avenue, here, at 5 P.M. today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Big Nine will learn whether its members favor new scholarship legislation affecting athletes and perhaps vote on Michigan State's membership bid at its annual winter meeting here, Dec. 10-13.

The Long Island Rail Road displayed at Jamaica yesterday the first ten of fifty new double-deck cars that are to add something new in comfort to the line. The ten will be put into service today, and more will be added as they arrive from the Pennsylvania Railroad's construction works in Altoona, Pa.
His team didn't win, but the play of Al Derogatis, Duke tackle, against Georgia Tech brought him the award as the "lineman of the week" yesterday in The Associated Press Poll.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The grain market's reaction to the sweeping Democratic victory at the polls was an early brisk rally in all pits on the Board of Trade, the theory being that there would be no change in the price-support regulations or in the policy of exporting surpluses.
The stock market reacted violently yesterday to the results of the national election.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 4 -- The International Military Tribunal held today that Japan was guilty of waging wars of aggression against China and planning similar hostilities against the United States, Britain, Russia and other allied powers.

A lend-lease armaments program for Western Europe will start even before the beginning of President Truman's second term if pre-election plans of the State Department and the National Military Establishment receive final approval.
Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader and Presidential candidate, asserted yesterday that President Truman's victory had temporarily dashed Socialist hopes for a new mass party.
PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru of India told the United Nations General Assembly today that an awakening Asia would demand a complete end of the "yoke of colonial rule."

ARCADIA, Calif., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Freddy Fitzsimmons, heading his car into the driveway of his home here on the tail-end of a long haul from New York, heard the telephone ring and scurried inside the house.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The American elections were watched closely by all those here with an interest in Palestine, and an Egyptian delegate made an angry charge this afternoon in committee that power politics had obscured the interests of small countries.

Mrs. Lytle Hull will give a reception this afternoon in her apartment at Hampshire House for several young women concerned with the organization of a junior committee for the Bal de Tete, a benefit dance to be given Dec. 9 at the Plaza under the sponsorship of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service.

Army will be back on Columbia's gridiron schedule in 1949 after a year's absence, Ralph Furey, director of athletics, announced yesterday in releasing the Lions' nine-game card for next fall. Earl Blaik's cadets replace Princeton on Columbia's slate in a game to be played at West Point's Michie Stadium.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 3 -- If the United States is looking for anyone to take the place of its red-faced poll takers, it may consider a couple of gentlemen from Argentina, though it is doubtful that they would be interested.

From press reports on events in China, appearing day by day, it is clearly evident that affairs in that unhappy country are not going too well. The Communist forces are winning the war -- thus far, in any event. So the cry is now being raised that the United States must take drastic action immediately to save the present Chinese Government from collapse.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- It appeared dubious tonight that Gov. Earl Warren had saved his own state and its twenty-five electoral votes for the Republican national ticket. Despite the Vice-Presidential nominee's unusual successes as a vote-getter, a tabulation of more than four-fifths of California's ballots from yesterday's election gave a growing lead to President Truman.

Production of crude oil in the United States last week established a new peak and crossed an average of 5,600,000 barrels a day for the first time. According to the American Petroleum Institute, production averaged 5,604,100 barrels daily, an increase of 8,150 over the previous week.

Like the early settlers, Mrs. Cecilia M. Wallace of Walker, Minn., learned from the Chippewa Indians how to cook wild rice. She has submitted to this column some interesting facts about this food that the Indians have been cultivating since before Columbus covered America.
Monroe, Mich., announced yesterday that it will receive bids Monday on $2,200,000 of water revenue bonds dated Sept. 1, 1948, due July 1 from 1953 to 1978 and callable July 1, 1952.

The Surface Transportation Corporation opened yesterday its case for an interim emergency seven-cent bus fare in an all-day hearing before the Public Service Commission. The company contended that current passenger revenues did not cover the cost of recent wage increases.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Dr. Amazasp A. Arutiunian, delegate of the Soviet Union, told the Economic and Financial Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today during an attack on United States foreign investment policies that "the real lord of Chile" was the Bethlehem Steel Company.
A great deal has been written, said and done about beautifying our city. The eagerness with which we go about it makes us forget that we are starting at the wrong end. How about cleaning first?

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The executive councils of both major and minor leagues will meet with Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler here tomorrow and Friday. At that time plans will be made for the annual meeting of baseball clubs in Chicago next month, according to Walter Mulbry, secretary-treasurer of baseball.

The musical season gained further momentum last night when Times Hall was opened for musical events. The first of the performers to appear there was Ilse Sass, German pianist who came here before the war. She has played for the Red Cross and the USO, but this was her local concert debut.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The problem of devising a constitutional formula by which Ireland can remain within the Commonwealth after breaking her last link with the British Crown has stumped legal experts, it was learned in official quarters here today.

In the stock market yesterday the immediate effect of the news of Mr. Truman's re-election to the Presidency was fairly large-scale selling and declining prices. Turnover for the day was 3,230,000 shares, making it the most active trading session since May 14, and leading issues closed 1 to 3 points lower.

Turnover for the day was 3,230,000 shares, making it the most active trading session since May 14, and leading issues closed 1 to 3 points lower.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Democratic women leaders at party headquarters here said today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's alleged attack on the "teacher lobby" was a factor in his defeat.

THE national elections have been getting all the space, naturally enough, but baseball has been having a few voting contests of its own recently and this undoubtedly is the proper time to discuss them. TORONTO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Frank Filchock, barred from professional football in the United States, received the Imperial Oil Trophy today as the outstanding player in the Ontario Rugby Football Union.

On the night of Dec. 10 the Gridiron Club of Washington will hold its winter dinner, and on these occasions the quality of the provender is almost as famous as the entertainment and the guest-list. But, whatever may be printed on the menu card, the principal entree for the members of this club, who are the correspondents for American newspapers in the capital city, will be not beefsteak, not terrapin, but crow.

The European economy is suffering from lack of productive labor, Joseph W. Frazer, president of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, said yesterday on his arrival on the Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam after a six-week business trip to Europe.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Rokeby Stables' Genancoke won the eleventh running of the $10,000 added Battleship Steeplechase Handicap by three lengths at Pimlico today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- All the scoring was crammed into the second period as the National Hockey League All-Stars defeated the champion Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1, before 15,681 at Chicago Stadium tonight.

A man and his wife, who were said to have enriched themselves to the amount of $500,000 by acting as "fiduciary agents" for European refugees, were held yesterday without bail on a grand larceny charge by Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in Flatbush Court.

Analysis of the vote cast Tuesday in New York City showed voting trends as amazing, in their implications, as the national vote that sent President Truman back to the White House for a full term in his own right.
A grateful mother voiced her appreciation yesterday to the Navy and THE NEW YORK TIMES, two organizations that cooperated recently to get for her a picture of her 18-year-old sailor son.
NORTH ATTLEBORO, Mass., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. said today that the election results were a "sensational surprise," then promised cooperation with President Truman.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Although President Truman's election reaffirmed the belief here that the United States would soon join in a North Atlantic defense pact, British officials do not think that a new alliance necessarily will be concluded immediately.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov.4 (AP) -The American Friends Service Committee said today that it had received a cablegram from the Russian Red Cross thanking the Quaker organization for a gift of streptomycin valued at $25,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- National banks in the United States and possessions reported net earnings of $355,307,000 for the six months ended June 30 of this year, an increase of $36,125,000 over the first half of 1947, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

Communists of "all countries" have been warned by Bolshevik, organ of the Central Committee of the Communist party of the Soviet Union, that the path of mass struggles, general strikes and "armed revolution" was the only one that would lead to the lasting success of the Communist cause, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Formation of a non-profit research corporation to apply "the nation's best scientific abilities and achievements" to the national defense was announced today by the Air Force.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 30 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

GALWAY, Ireland, Nov. 4 (UP) -- The ten striking sailors of the ferry boat Dun Aengus took mercy tonight on the 2,000 hungry persons on the isles of Aran and agreed to make a single crossing of Galway Bay with supblies for the primitive islanders.

The longest trial in history is at last drawing to a close. In Tokyo the presiding judge of the International Military Tribunal which has been trying former Premier Tojo and other Japanese war leaders for the last two and a half years has begun to read the court's judgment.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 4 -- Ambassador James Bruce, who came here fifteen months ago as President Truman's envoy, intimated today that the President was concerned about communism in South America, and especially in Argentina.
A movement to form an international organization of citizen groups to work for peace was announced yesterday by the One World Congress, Inc., at a reception in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 4 -- Apart from the fact that there is very little direct benefit to the Belgian economy in the form of dollar aid, three things about the European Recovery Program particularly worry the Belgians.

I read with interest the letter of Thomas Jefferson Miley, Executive Vice President of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, dealing with the smoke problem, published Oct. 28. Unquestionably "a much better job needs to be done on air pollution control."

SHANGHAI, Friday, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The Government's official news agency today announced completion of "Operation Dunkerque" by Nationalist armies from the south Manchurian port of Yingkow in three days and nights involving "hundreds of thousands of tons" of shipping.

In the State Assembly the Democrats have gained nineteen seats as a result of Tuesday's election; the Republicans will now hold eighty-nine and the Democrats sixty-one. In the Senate the Democrats have gained ten seats and will now hold twenty-five, while the Republicans will have thirty-one.

CAIRO, Nov. 4 -- Substantial quantities of food and other supplies have been distributed to Arab refugees from Palestine through the United Nations Disaster Relief Organization, George Frederick Beard, representative of the organization in Cairo, disclosed today.

Reverting to a fund-raising method that was popular in the early days of the utility industry, the Virginia Electric and Power Company seeks to sell 750,000 additional common shares, $10 par value, on an installment basis during 1948 and 1949.

October housewares dollar volume in home furnishings and department stores was approximately 5 per cent greater than in the corresponding month last year, buyers reported yesterday. They said that gains were registered primarily as a result of consistent promotion.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 (AP) -Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican national chairman, said today that he was going on a vacation, but "it's not going to be a permanent vacation."

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- In its first major decision of this session, the United Nations General Assembly approved tonight, 40 to 6, the United States sponsored atomic energy control plan and rejected the Soviet Union's counter-proposals by exactly the same vote.

A rayon pulp mill designed to employ a new process for producing dissolving woodpulp used in the manufacture of rayon and other synthetic products will be built in the South by International Paper Company, it was announced yesterday by John H. Hinman, president.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 4 -- Control of imports into South Africa is foreshadowed for many weeks, Finance Minister Nicholaas C. Havenga said today. He estimated that the measure will reduce imports from the United States by about $100,000,000 yearly if supplementary quotas for producer goods are freely granted.

The first public appearance of the Very Rev. Dr. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury Cathedral, in the United States on his forthcoming coast-to-coast speaking tour will be made at a dinner in his honor on Nov. 14 at the Pierre Hotel, it was announced yesterday by Olin Downes, chairman of the New York Committee of Welcome to Dean Johnson.

ROME, Nov. 4 -- While the greater part of Italian newspapers applauded President Truman's election today, the Left-Wing press tried to hide its discomfiture by claiming that United States voters had preferred him to Governor Dewey because he had shown greater willingness to come to terms with the Soviet Union.

The strike of the Radio Writers Guild was suspended yesterday as joint meetings were opened with the committee representing advertising agencies and sponsors of radio programs and the flow of writing and literary material to struck programs was resumed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat, of Louisiana, started the ball rolling today toward fulfillment of President Truman's campaign promise of more low-cost housing for low-income families.

Although it is as a British subject that T. S. Eliot has received the Nobel Prize for Literature, America too can claim that it has contributed to the making of the man. For this patrician poet and critic was born in St. Louis, was graduated from Harvard and became a British subject only in 1927.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -The heavy control of Congress which the Democrats won in Tuesday's elections raised the possibility today of a renewal in the House of the Republican-Southern Democrat coalition.

ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, tired from his long campaign but outwardly unruffled by his defeat in his bid for the Presidency, returned to his Capitol office today to attend to state business.
IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, Nov. 4 -- The world's most powerful magnet was demonstrated here today publicly for the first time.

The Football Giants' hopes of holding Steve Van Buren and Company in check on Sunday at the Polo Grounds received a big boost yesterday. Captain Len Younce has been pronounced fit for action and definitely will play against the Philadelphia Eagles, the mighty leaders of the National League's Eastern Division.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Oct. 30, 1948, totaled 931,750 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 4,218 cars, or 0.5 per cent more than for the preceding week, 8,996 cars, or 1.0 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 9,438 cars, or 1.0 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

New flowers and old ones in greater numbers than have been seen for many years were displayed in a new setting yesterday afternoon when the Horticultural Society of New York opened its threeday flower snow. The exhibition is being held this year in the Colonnades Ball Room of the Essex House.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- A long list of controls that have shackled British manufacturers in the acquisition, use and distribution of raw and semi-finished materials were lifted today by the Board of Trade. In a companion action the Ministry of Supply disclosed its intention of easing many of its licensing and permit regulations effective Dec. 1.

Justice Michel F. Walsh granted yesterday in Supreme Court in Brooklyn a temporary injunction restraining Local 1, Barbers and Beauty Culturists Union, CIO, from disaffiliating itself from the parent union. The order is effective pending the outcome of an action brought by the national to take control of the local's funds and contracts.

Merger of Protestant city churches where necessary to meet changing urban needs as well as the expanding of missionary work into the suburbs was recommended yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Alfred Grant Walton of the Flatbush-Tompkins Congregational Church, Brooklyn.

TOKYO, Nov. 4 -- Before the court adjourned this afternoon thirteen of the twenty-five defendants -- besides two who are already dead and one, a propagandist named Shumei Okawa who is in a mental institution -- had been named in the tribunal's opinion.

ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- State Controller Frank C. Moore reported today that state financial assistance to local governments during the fiscal year ending March 31 reached an all-time peak of $416,124,026. Payments to New York City during the same period totalled $218,755,302.

Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, and John G. Munson, vice president in charge of raw materials for the United States Steel Corporation of Delaware, will leave today for Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, to inspect ore deposits in that country and in Venezuela.
FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The standards of three squadrons of the 102-year-old Third Cavalry Group, after numerous Indian scrapes and six wars, will be retired permanently at a review tomorrow.

Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn told a group of more than 100 representatives of Brooklyn women's organizations, rallying yesterday to raise funds for the Colonel David Marcus bloodprocessing station in Israel, that among the fledgling state's greatest needs were blood plasma and vaccines.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Washington's biggest industry will take time off tomorrow to welcome home the Boss.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 4 -- The United States has secretly revitalized three French divisions with new military equipment to help boost Western Europe's armed strength, unimpeachable sources said today.
The nation's public schools have failed largely in the task of instilling in youth loyalty to American ideals, Dr. Edmund E. Day, president of Cornell University, warned last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today revoked the operating authority of two overseas radio transmitters owned by the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company at Brentwood, L.I. The order said the transmitters had been put into operation prior to FCC consent.
WESLEY, Me., Nov. 4 -- Never tell a Maine guide you want to "move over a lot of the country," that is, unless you have rubber legs and cast iron lungs, for he is apt to take you at your word.
ON BOARD PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S TRAIN, Nov. 4 -- President Truman does not want a third term, it was learned authoritatively today.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 4. (AP) -- Nine men were killed in a B-29 crash in the Azores yesterday. There was one known survivor among the twenty United States Air Force men aboard the plane.
Control of air pollution, including smoke nuisance, should be vested in the Board of Health rather than the Department of Housing and Buildings, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin said today that a new labor law, "fair to both workers and management," would be one of the first pieces of business put before the Eighty-first Congress.
PARIS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Anglo-Chinese resolution on Palestine as amended by the United States and approved tonight by the United Nations Security Council:

Jack Kramer of Los Angeles, former national amateur champion and Davis Cup star, has been named to the No. 1 spot in the 1948 official ranking of the Professional Lawn Tennis Association, it was announced yesterday. He holds the national pro title, too.

The police began yesterday the round-up of twenty teen-age boys who, after instruction by a 13year-old prodigy in crime, had stolen at least 200 Government checks totaling $50,000 from apartment house mailboxes in Brooklyn in the last two years.

At the second hearing before the Public Service Commission on the petition of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company, witnesses of both utilities testified yesterday before the chairman, Milo R. Maltbie, with evidence designed to show that the merger would be in the public interest, as the result of operating efficiencies inherent in a consolidation of the two systems.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4 Westchester County officials took preliminary steps today toward relaxing the county parkway ban on the carrying of skis atop automobiles. At a conference here they agreed to recommend to the County Park Commission a new ordinance that would permit motorists to transport skis, ski poles and perhaps some other athletic equipment on the outside of cars.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -Promptly upon his return to Washington tomorrow President Truman will begin arranging a series of conferences looking toward early repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act. This was pledged by the Democratic platform and reiterated by Mr. Truman in the course of his nation-wide speaking tour.

James Hodes, a vice president of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, predicted yesterday a general strike on the system's bus and trolley car lines if the Public Service Commission's conditions for a $150,000 loan between two Third Avenue subsidiaries were carried out.

Mary Jane Ward's powerful novel, "The Snake Pit," is hardly one which Hollywood might have been expected to choose for transcription to the screen. For it puts forth fully and frankly the case history of a young woman in a mental institute, wherein she proceeds through experiences which are not of the most beguiling sort.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 4 -- Fifty-four southern cities now have 279 Negro law-enforcement officers, according to an annual report released today by the Southern Regional Council.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -Twenty-one states have so far ratified the proposed constitutional amendment under which a President would be limited to two terms in office.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- In the best physical shape of the season, Army went through its final workout today preparatory to its departure to play Stanford at the Yankee Stadium Saturday in the first of what Coach Earl Blaik terms "three tough final games."

Coach Lou Little and the Columbia football squad will leave this morning for Hanover, N. H., and the game there tomorrow with Dartmouth, expecting one of the sternest tests of their current football campaign.

Numbers of cancer patients are alive today as the result of new facts being discovered through cancer research, the annual meeting of the American Cancer Society was informed yesterday by Prof. Edwin P. Lehman of the University of Virginia and president of the Society.

A civil anti-trust suit by the Screen Writers Guild that charged the motion-picture producers with conspiring to govern the political views and associations of persons engaged in the production of pictures, was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman on technical grounds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A man identified by Detective Sergeant W. V. Christian as Jake Powell, former big league baseball star, shot himself to death in police headquarters here today.

Up to now, the stage version of "The Happy Time" has been a figment of the imagination. Since Robert Fontaine's delightful autobiographical novel of a quaint Canadian family was published in 1945, various producers have done their utmost to get a proper adaptation.
Georg Jensen, Inc., 667 Fifth Avenue, silversmith, to Anderson, Davis Platte, Inc.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 4 -- A survey of recent design in contemporary home furnishings was presented this afternoon in an exhibition, "Decorative-Arts Today," by the Newark Museum at a preview for members and exhibitors.

Local voting on the final offer made by employers to the members of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, started yesterday morning at twenty-five union polling points and will continue today. Polls are open from 6 A.M. to 10 P.M.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The United States served blunt notice on the Soviet Union here today that security provisions of the Marshall Plan would be maintained rigidly as long as Eastern European countries continued their "aggressive actions."

Pessimistic all week, Sid Morett, Brooklyn College football trainer, announced yesterday that Marv Schrier, the center, over whose injury there has been so much concern on the Flatbush campus, will definitely see action against City College tomorrow night.

The New York City Rent Advisory Board will meet on Nov. 22 to consider action on the petition of landlords for an increase in residential rents, and that of tenants for a decrease, Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Lower prices for fresh meats, dairy products and livestock were chiefly responsible for a decline of 0.9 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended Oct. 30, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange for the second day in succession were strong yesterday, closing 26 to 77 points net higher. The far months were relatively stronger than near months.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 4 -- The flight of Communist and non-Communist citizens from states in the Communist Information Bureau bloc to Yugoslavia has accelerated the underground political struggle between the Yugoslav Communist party and the Cominform.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Walter Reuther, whose million-member Congress of Industrial Organizations United Auto Workers Union contributed cash and leg work to the Democratic campaign, today hailed President Truman's victory as a "staggering defeat to the forces of special privilege."

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Lester Pearson, Canadian Minister of External Affairs, proposed today that Iceland, Ireland and the three Scandinavian countries be requested to join with the United States, Canada and the five members of the Western Union in forming a North Atlantic pact for mutual defense against aggression.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Penn tapered off today in its next-tolast tune-up for the game with undefeated but once tied Penn State here on Saturday.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- Wilhelm Pieck, Communist boss in Germany, advised Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, today to abandon "his fatal policy" in Europe and ask for his recall in view of the "decision of the American people," against war in Tuesday's election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley hopes to escape political oblivion, the fate of many previous Vice Presidents, by continuing in an active though informal way as Democratic leader of the Senate, associates said today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Six men and a woman, all white, were convicted on conspiracy charges today in connection with disorders which broke out in July when police stopped some negro-white tennis matches in a public park.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Registration statements covering $9,744,500 of new financing were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

Ida Krehm, pianist, was heard in a recital last night at Town Hall. The program she presented contained the Sonata in C major of Brahms; a group of pieces by Daquin, Rossi and Soler; the Nocturne in B flat minor, Ballade in F major and two Preludes by Chopin; Scriabin's Three Etudes, Op. 65; Vianna's "Corta jaca," and excerpts from Ginastera's "Doce Preludios Americanos" and from Sam Raphling's "American Album."

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin confirmed today that officers of the regular British Army were still serving with Trans-Jordan's forces, a fact about which there has been confusion in the United States and elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Swiss Government has refused to sign a bilateral agreement with the United States qualifying it for aid under the European Recovery Program or to permit the establishment of an American economic mission in that country.
The college scholarship contest sponsored nationally since 1945 by the Pepsi-Cola Company will not be held in 1948-49, it became known here yesterday.

To Colonel C. V. Whitney, horsebreeder, horse-owner and, incidentally, assistant secretary of the Air Force, went all but $750 of the $5,000 purse put up for the chief item of entertainment in yesterday's Empire City-at-Jamaica show.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor; Leonard Rose, 'cello, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Busch Quartet, assisted by Maryjane Thomas, 'cello, Town Hall, 8:30; "Aida," City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; Compositions of Elmo Russ, assisting artists, Lois McCauley, Lucyle Harmantas, Paul Gavert, Keith Andes, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

ABOARD SHIP SCALDIS of Piccard-Cosyns Expedition, at Sea off St. Jago, Cape Verde Islands, Nov. 4 -- A dream of forty years fizzled and died today when Profs. Auguste Piccard and Max Cosyns decided to abandon their attempt to ride the weird underwater balloon they had created down to ocean depths of perhaps two and a half miles.

Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn, vice chairman of the City Council, introduced yesterday a proposed local law designed to protect hotel tenants against excessive rent increases either by "unconscionable practices of landlords" or rulings of the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission.
It was Mexico twice yesterday in the military jumping competition of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.

The 20 per cent Federal excise tax is having a "catastrophic" effect upon the fur industry, officials of the American Fur Merchants Association said last night at the fiftieth anniversary meeting of the organization at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- Reports of important, behind-thescenes developments that will shortly bring the sixty-four-dayold West Coast shipping strike to an end persisted on the local waterfront today.

The eleven-story building at 18-20 East Fiftieth Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, has been purchased for investment by the A.M. Corporation, Harry Forsyth, president, from the Drake America Corporation, British exporters and importers, who leased back three upper floors for their own occupancy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, stood on his constitutional rights today and refused to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating charges that he padded his Congressional payroll.

People ask me, "Joe, when you were a kid in Alabama, living sharecrop in a cotton patch, did you dream to be a millionaire and have rich things like cars, and pockets stuffed with money, and fine clothes and all that?" I say to them: "I couldn't dream that big."

The new vogue in hockey, the use of four forward lines in a game, will likely be adopted by Frank Boucher, manager of the New York Rangers. The pilot of the local entry in the National Hockey League indicated his willingness to try the plan in a talk at the weekly meeting of the New York Hockey Writers Association yesterday at Leone's.

VIENNA, Nov. 4 -- The Communists' evening newspaper, Der Abend, published today a statement to the effect that Irving Ross, official of the Marshall Plan mission here, was under suspicion by the American authorities and was under American observation and that at the time he was slain early Sunday he was on his way from "an American social function."

With the forecast of damp winter weather ahead, Lane Bryant offered fashions for sunny climates yesterday morning at a show presented on the stage of the Park Avenue Theatre. Clothes for chubby children had their place on the runway along with styles for size 18 and over.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The phenomenal foreign markets for United States food products are receding, but the world remains in urgent need of more and better food, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations said today.

An eccentric shack-dweller in the New Lots district of Brooklyn, who had been complaining of being annoyed by youthful trespassers, bought a shotgun yesterday and a few hours later killed a boy who had been playing at the rear of his property at 878 Ashford Street, the police said.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -Gar Moore, the American actor who went to Italy to make his first screen appearances in "Paisan" and "To Live in Peace," has been signed to a term contract by UniversalInternational and will make his American film debut in "Illegal Entry," the studio announced today.

A possible solution for the longstanding deadlock between the Port of New York Authority and the airlines over leases and terms at New York International Airport, La Guardia Field and Newark Airport was in the making yesterday.
In a new shop opened yesterday on Gimbels third floor, girls of 5 feet 7 inches and taller will find clothes proportioned to their height.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The suggestion that as a result of his electoral victory President Truman might revive his project to send Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson as his personal envoy to see Premier Stalin was made in three morning and three afternoon newspapers in Paris today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Despite an impost of 124 pounds, Mrs. H. K. Haggerty's Rampart drove to a two-length victory in the twelfth running of the $7,500 added Lady Baltimore Handicap at Pimlico today.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that net income for the twelve months to Sept. 30 amounted to $32,723,848, a drop of $3,125,231 below the $35,849,079 reported for the preceding twelve months.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 4 -- A United States Army board comprising Cols. James L. Harbaugh Jr. and John M. Raymond opened today an inquiry into charges that the Criminal Investigation Department had utilized third-degree methods to obtain confessions in a post exchange scandal.
Political antagonisms between left and right-wing factions within the Transport Workers Union, CIO, erupted into brief physical violence last night at Transport Hall, 153 West Sixty-fourth Street.

Wage increases of $2 to $5 weekly for 60,000 employes were announced yesterday by the New York Telephone Company. They are incorporated in agreements finally ratified with eight independent unions representing commercial, plant, traffic, accounting and general departments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Barbershop owners who work in their own shops complained to the National Labor Relations Board today that they faced a demand that they join the barbers' union under threat of strikes and boycotts. They requested the NLRB general counsel to issue a complaint and to ask the Federal Court for an injunction.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 4 (UP) -- The executive committee of baseball's major and minor leagues proposed today a uniform ceiling of $6,000 on all bonus payments to players starting their first year of professional baseball.

Disposal of short-term Government securities accounted for a drop in the earning assets position of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City for the week ended last Wednesday. The weekly combined statement issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed a decrease of $204,000,000 in loans and investments.

Sweden is preparing to export $750,000 worth of modern furniture annually to the United States, Goesta H. Sandstedt, president of the Swedish Furniture Manufacturers Export Association, disclosed yesterday. He estimated the value of Swedish furniture shipments to this country in the last three years at only $1,500,000 and added that total annual output of Sweden's thirty furniture factories exceeds $75,000,000.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Dean Acheson, former Under-Secretary of State, and W. Averell Harriman, representative at large for the European Recovery Administration, are regarded by delegates to the United Nations General Assembly as the most likely possibilities to succeed Secretary of State Marshall.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Partial recovery in dollar stocks was seen in the stock markets here today after the weakness yesterday on the results of the Presidential election in the United States. Under the lead of General Motors, which scored a 2-point gain, prices were as much as 1 point better throughout.

Predicting that popular-price sportswear for women will enjoy widespread favor for a long time, Henry J. Perahia, president of the National Skirt and Sportswear Association, called upon the industry to meet the demand for better styling and well-made merchandise.

The Commercial Credit Company had a consolidated net income of $12,547,789 after all deductions in the first nine months this year, contrasted with $5,411,956 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the report to be released today.

A fund which is expected to total $250,000 has been established in the name of Serge Koussevitzky by the trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, it was announced yesterday. The sum is to be used without restriction for cultural and educational development by the orchestra and as a cushion against emergencies.

Most of the northern New Jersey counties, impervious to national trends, emerged from Tuesday's elections without significant change in their political complexions. As was expected. Republicans were swept into office in Bergen County while the Democrats ran up substantial pluralities in Hudson County.

Probably little noticed amid the pages of election news in yesterday's papers was a little story from San Juan, Puerto Rico, announcing the election of Senor Luis Munoz Marin as Governor of that United States territorial possession. It was a big day in Puerto Rico, though, and marked a forward step in this country's colonial policy.

A history of New York under British Military Government, from September, 1776, to November, 1783, by Thomas Jefferson Wertenbaker, has been scheduled for Nov. 15 publication by Scribner. It is entitled "Father Knickerbocker Rebels: New York City During the Revolution."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -The Post Office Department today urged suspension of All American aviation's mail pick-up service as a too costly luxury.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. (AP) -- Wilfred Sykes, president of the Inland Steel Company, said today that "the supply of iron ore in the Great Lakes region will probably last for hundreds of years."
