Addressing the seventeenth mid continent trust conference of the American Bankers Association, he said the steel industry "is not in danger due to the shortage of its main raw materials."

A fashion show of what the welldressed girl will wear to complete her resort and spring clothes was presented yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group, Inc., at the Astor Hotel. Betty Held, chairman of the accessory division of the Fashion Group, spoke on accessory trends for spring.
The Central Illinois Public Service Company declared a dividend of 30 cents on common, payable Nov. 30. Previous payments this year were 25 cents each in March, May, and August.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today adopted a joint British-Saudi Arabian amendment to Article 12 of the draft declaration on human rights that leaves nations free to decide whether they should grant or refuse admission to political refugees.
Amateurs have so much more fun than professionals when it comes to sampling wines.

Dr. Louis J. Paradiso, former head of the business statistics section of the Department of Commerce, called yesterday on the poll-takers who missed the election forecasts to disclose the size of their samples, the sampling error indicated and other technical data.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Good weather and consistent golf returned today, leaving two of the favorites tied for the lead in the forty-sixth North and South open golf championship. Right behind them at the halfway mark of the tournament, running a day late because of Wednesday's heavy rains, were players figured as serious contenders and first-day flashes who had slipped back.

Federal Grand Jury in Brooklyn handed up yesterday a twentytwo-count indictment charging Julius Rose, 39 years old, with using the mails to defraud automobile dealers or $49,000. Mr. Rose, who lives at 5406 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, will appear for pleading on Monday.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution tonight calling upon Egypt and Israel to withdraw their troops to positions occupied in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, before the fighting broke out there on Oct. 14.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Alexander S. Panyushkin, the Soviet Ambassador, pressed the Far Eastern Commission at a meeting today to act upon a Russian proposal for international controls to prevent a revival of Japan's war industry.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4 -- Gov. Earle C. Clements, a Democrat, will name the successor of Alben W. Barkley, vice-president-elect, in the Senate, but who Kentucky's junior senator in the Eighty-first Congress will be is very much in the dark, political observers asserted today.

Housewives doing their weekend shopping today will find that the downward price trend on many foods is continuing. Various meats, poultry, eggs, vegetables and fruits are from 2 to 10 cents lower than they were last Friday. In fact, the only tariff increases that the City Department of Markets found in its weekly survey of retail stores yesterday were on a few vegetables.

An effort to create the unusual in fur designs was reflected in the showing of Ritter originals yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. Typical was the treatment of ocelot in knee-length coat, slim through the bodice and with a slight flare to the skirt.

The recent New Orleans Public Service Company bond issue took its place yesterday alongside the many miscues that underwriters have made since the end of the bull bond market in attempting to price new issues of corporate bonds of fixed term under the compulsory sealed-bid-and-deadline bidding system.
Efforts of city authorities and shipping officials to agree on a formula for future pier rental costs have failed, and further discussions are necessary, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States distributed to local chambers today "a program for community anti-Communist action" with a warning that American Communists have now been instructed to work more directly on the masses of people at the community level.
Patrolman Thomas J. Long of the West Forty-seventh Street police station was suspended from duty yesterday after the shooting of a taxi driver at Forty-third Street and Tenth Avenue.

Fearful that Government priorities and allocations on steel may be put into effect early next year following expiration of the voluntary program under Public Law 395, the Independent Merchant Exporters Association, with headquarters in Washington, made known yesterday it has renewed its appeal to Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer for elimination of "letters of commitment" in the export licensing of steel.

Daniel F. Hulgrave has been appointed director of the purchasing and salvage section of the procurement and schedules staff of General Motors Corporation. Formerly manager of purchases of the Cadillac Motor Car division, he succeeds H. L. Dingler, who has resigned.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- The result of the election was again the main factor today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, being especially effective in sparking the buying demand for new crop wheat deliveries, which were strong throughout the session.

The liner Exeter, third unit of American Export Lines new "Four Aces", was formally delivered to her owners here yesterday by officials of the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company. The vessel, which was rebuilt at Bethlehem's Staten Island yard, successfully completed her trial run on Monday.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 4 -The demands made upon Negro institutions for training in the higher skills of industry and agriculture require a revamping of courses in all Negro industrial colleges, Luther H. Foster, president of Virginia State College, said today.

A warning that teachers' strikes may spread to the college level unless salaries are increased and the attitude of the American public improved, was issued yesterday by Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University. This "substitution of power for reason" by professors, he declared, would result in a "jaundiced" program of education.
A sizable group of oils by Anna E. Meltzer at the galleries of French Co. heads a list of three one-man shows of considerable interest this week in local exhibition places.

Gracie Mansion was the scene yesterday afternoon of the presentation of the sixth annual award of the American Fashion Critics Award to Miss Hattie Carnegie. Other recipients of honors for outstanding work in the field of fashion were Esther Dorothy, Joseph de Leo and Maximilian.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- The military governors of the United States, Britain and France will insure the observance of the new German Constitution, now in preparation in Bonn, under the occupation statute, reliable sources said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 4 -Weary United Nations workers had a chance today to own a restful island retreat where they can swim, fish and temporarily forget international politics. The island, located off Stony Creek, Conn., is seventeen acres in extent and is about two hours by car or train from New York.

Columbia University's American Press Institute will begin its program for the 1948-49 academic year on Monday when a two-week seminar for eleven newspaper picture editors opens. The program's first regular seminar follows a special six-weeks seminar for German editors that ended Oct. 23.

TIe quirks Of esday's vot-! g produced freak results all over the nation, but particularly: in the ten c.ounties of the Sixt Judicial District of New York State..comm.only regarded as one political unit and known as ['the "southeril tier.'

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Nov. 4 -The Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company was absolved today of criminal negligence in the electrocution of an employe, Peter Curran, at its transmitting plant south of here on Oct. 15.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 4 -- P. A. White, director of sales promotion, Cities Service Oil Company, New York City, said today that the oil supply situation is easier now than it has been for many months, but warned, however, that the margin over requirements is small.

BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- Trade agreements between the bizonal area and Uruguay and Egypt, calling for the exchange of approximately $60,000,000 worth of goods, have been approved by Generals Lucius D. Clay and Sir Brian Robertson, United States and British Military Governors.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 4 -- Nobel Prizes for 1948 were awarded today to the Americanborn British poet, Thomas Stearns Eliot; the British physicist, Patrick M. S. Blackett, and the Swedish chemist, Arne Tiselius.

This week the first members of our new draft Army are unloading from the trains and moving into their new home at Fort Dix, N.J. As they come off they will be lined up and their last names will be called.
Despite President Truman's campaign promise to repeal the TaftHartley Act, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, declared yesterday that he doubted the measure would be repealed.

Despite some disturbing prospects, President Truman's election will bring no drastic changes for business, according to Raymond Moley, Professor of Public Law, Columbia University, and former assistant Secretary of State. Speaking at the annual meeting of the Corset and Brassiere Association of American in the Biltmore Hotel last night, Mr. Moley said the Taft-Hartley Act will be amended but not repealed by the new Congress.

It was gratifying to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the warm welcome given to the first displaced persons who arrived on the Genera Black. I am concerned, however, that no mention was made of Protestant participation in that reception other than the mere mention of Church World Service.

Gov. Thomas E. Dewey carried New York State by a plurality of 55.293 in his unsuccessful try for the Presidency, according to a revised tabulation of the upstate county returns by The Associated Press yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Britain feels a double cause for pride. Although Mr. Eliot was born and reared in the United States he is honored here as the world's greatest living poet who has chosen to make Britain his country. On his sixtieth birthday last September, worldwide tributes such as rarely had been paid to living artists were showered on him here in tribute to his place and influence in modern literature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The State Department urged United States voluntary organizations today to continue their relief work for war refugees in the Near East in view of the "critical" plight of these refugees. At the same time the department expressed the hope that the United Nations General Assembly would adopt a pending resolution to provide a relief program.

Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, leader of Tammany, said yesterday that he would not concede the election of George Frankenthaler, Republican and Liberal party candidate, as Surrogate of New York County, but would await completion of official canvass of the vote by the Board of Elections.

An active and strong market continued in cottonseed oil futures yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. The buying was considered a carryover from the bullish sentiment stimulated by the election results. Prices advanced 40 to 92 points on a turnover of 248 lots.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- After Franklin D. Roosevelt was elected for the fourth time, a devoted friend of his drew up a chart for the President's desk. He believed that no man ever created was proof against all the dangers to democracy which this doubly unprecedented tribute might evoke.

New corporate financing transactions totaling $14,000,000 were announced yesterday. Contributing to the total were three private placements -- $10,000,000 of 3 5/8 per cent fifteen-year debentures of St. Regis Paper Company, $3,000,000, of fifteen-year 3 1/4 per cent notes of Black Decker Manufacturing Company and $1,000,000 of tenyear 3.75 per cent sinking fund debentures of Thor Corporation.

The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday the leasing of the site of the old Tombs and Criminal Courts Building by public auction for use as a 540-car parking lot. The auction will be held at 11 A.M. on Nov. 29 in Room 1013 of the Municipal Building, under the direction of William L. Ellard, the board's real estate director.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- A test of the constitutionality of the White Plains police practice of forbidding political meetings on streets and sidewalks was begun in City Court today before Judge William McKinley, when two leaders of the American Labor party were tried on disorderly conduct charges for conducting such a meeting.

The city's drive against dirt in the streets reached a high mark yesterday when 394 persons were fined in four courts in Manhattan and the Bronx for Sanitary Code violations ranging from neglect to curb dogs to burning refuse on the pavements.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 4 -- Savings banks are not satisfying the needs of their depositors and "are not doing the job the public wants," John Adikes, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, told the group's fifty-fifth annual convention, which opened here today.

" Unfaithfully Yours," which arrives at the Roxy, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The romantic comedy-drama, which was written, produced and directed by Preston Sturges for Twentieth Century-Fox, stars Rex Harrison and Linda Darnell.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 4 -A 14-year-old Boy Scout, whose good deed last Dec. 22 involved the risk of his life so that a fellowScout might live, will receive on Nov. 18 the Gold Honor Medal for Life Saving, the highest award of the Boy Scouts of America, the Suffolk County Boy Scout Council announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The White House and the Selective Service System jointly announced today the appointment of five committees of scientists and educators to make draft deferment recommendations for students of science and draft-age scientists.

I have read with interest in THE TIMES, Oct. 18, Arthur K. Davis' letter headed "Our National I.Q.," in which he criticized "a statement of the Population Reference Bureau that our national I.Q. is endangered by the low college birth rate."

DOES the first Saturday in November mean anything to you? It should, because it's the traditional date for the Army-Notre Dame classic, now in so deep a state of suspended animation that South Bend diagnosticians are beginning to wonder whether rigor mortis has started to set in. Instead of it we find...

Belated or corrected returns from Tuesday's election indicated yesterday that the Democrats had picked up three more seats in the House of Representatives, now held by Republicans, and that the House in the Eighty-first Congress would be composed of 263 Democrats, 171 Republicans and one member of the American Labor party.
The Timken Roller Bearing Company, in its statement of operations covering the nine months ended on Sept. 30, last, reported yesterday a net profit of $11,177,441 after taxes and all charges.
The Daily Worker, official organ of the Communist party, said yesterday that Henry A. Wallace had disappointed it by small size of his vote.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -Organized labor scored two major victories Tuesday when voters in Massachusetts and New Mexico rejected closed shop bans. These were partly offset by a new setback in Arizona.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Charles de Gaulle issued a statement to the press tonight in which he referred to "anarchy in France and a threat from without." He made his announcement as the Government was declaring that the coal strike would be ended and production on a normal basis would resume next week.

ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- As a result of increased enrollment and insufficient school buildings, many districts in this state are conducting substandard school programs this fall, Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education asserted today.

Louis Kotler and Saul Schechter bought the two bungalows and nine stores at 25-04022 Sea Girt Avenue, Edgemere, Queens, from Julia Lenrow. Charles Streimer was the broker. A purchase money mortgage of $15,000 was executed at the closing of title to the property, which is assessed at $47,700 Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 5 -- The International Military Tribunal of the Far East today blamed the Japanese Army for starting the nation on the road to aggressive war.

Intending to use Fordham's "infantry" to turn back Boston University tomorrow at the Polo Grounds, Coach Ed Danowski concentrated on the perfection of the Rams' running attack in yesterday's semi-contact scrimmage.

The stock market quickly emerged from its surprised state over the outcome of the national election and proceeded yesterday to regain approximately one-half of the serious damage of Wednesday. Prices were bid up in fairly fast fashion on the Stock Exchange and gains of around 2 points were frequent at the close, while the composite rate showed a recovery of 1.68 points.

Parents should not make their children regard policemen as "bogymen," Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander declared yesterday. He pleaded for "more parent relationship with the police" at a forum on juvenile delinquency sponsored by the Permanent Committee for the Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency and the Women's International Exposition, in exposition headquarters at the Seventyfirst Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

The methods of "big business" were recommended for the field of public health administration yesterday by State Commissioner of Health Herman E. Hilleboe before a meeting of the New York State Association for Crippled Children at Lenox Hill Hospital.

In recognition of the leading role assumed by the United States in world affairs, the Presidential election this year was an event which other nations watched with deep interest and concern. For days the wheels of diplomacy stood almost still awaiting the outcome.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- It was the turn today of Britain's weeklies to comment on President Truman's election and they echoed in more restrained and thoughtful language the excited judgments of British newspapers.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Malcolm MacDonald, Commissioner General in Southeast Asia, will return to Singapore tomorrow after having convinced his own and the Commonwealth governments that communism is being kept under control in that vital part of the world.
Bids designating interest costs ranging from 2.766 per cent to 2.8867 per cent were the best received yesterday for three separate issues of bonds of Harris County, Texas, totaling $17,500,000.

Community responsibility for the improvement of the mental health of the nation was emphasized yesterday at the closing session of the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
At a late hour last night, with not much more than a handful of election districts still missing, the popular vote of the four principal candidates for President stood as follows:

A pair of favorites took the honors -- and the cash -- in the co-features of the Empire City-at- Jamaica racing program yesterday. In the order in which they went into the winner's enclosure, they were George D. Widener's 2-year-old colt Reveille and the King Ranch's 3-year-old colt Fire Point.

Max Kleinberg, in a purchase investment, has acquired the four-story store anti-apartment building at 145 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, from O. William Schindler. L. L. Yearsley, broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the four-story dwelling at 821 Carroll Street for Elizabeth J. Mahoney to David Erenhalt, and the three story house at 491 Fourth Street for George Marks to George Stuart for occupancy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Aluminum Company of America will buy the Government-owned aluminum plant at Massena, N.Y., for $5,000,000 and will make available to the industry all of its alloy patents and its most important process and fabricating patents without any reciprocal obligations, the War Assets Administration announced today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 5 -- The Yugoslav Government announced tonight that Karlo Mrazovitch, Yugoslav Minister to Hungary, had been relieved of his duties in that country and appointed Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP) -- August Scholle said today that the CIO might attempt to keep Republican Senator Homer Ferguson from taking his seat in the Eighty-first Congress. Mr. Scholle is head of the CIO's Political Action Committee in Michigan.

Consolidated net profit of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation in the first nine months of 1948 amounted to $8,253,451 after deducting $5,900,000 for Federal tax requirements, Edgar F. Kaiser, vice president and general manager, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Representative Adolph Sabath, Democrat, of Illinois, said today he thought "professional short sellers" were knocking stock prices down "to create an unjust impression that a recession is impending."
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Two British heroes, Winston Churchill and Danny Kaye, shared the limelight tonight in celebration of Guy Fawkes Day.

PRETORIA, Union of South Africa, Nov. 5 -- A list of goods from non-sterling areas prohibited under the import restrictions announced yesterday by Finance Minister Nicholass C. Havenga appeared in the Government Gazette today. It is so comprehensive that it will change the appearance of every store window in the country.

The American Zionist Emergency Council issued a statement yesterday calling on President Truman to undo "the great injustice perpetrated by the American delegation to the United Nations which brought about passage by the Security Council of a British-conceived resolution aimed at the imposition of sanctions against Israel."

Forty frightened men, women and children were escorted by firemen down a ladder from the first-floor fire escape of a six-story old-law tenement at 100 Columbia Street last night after a fire had broken out in a ground floor flat.

Churches and Synagogues in the New York area have been asked devote part of their services today and tomorrow to an appeal for support of the Red Cross Blood Program of the Greater New York Chapters, it was announced yesterday. This week-end has been chosen because Thursday is Armistice Day.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 5 -- An intensive comb-out of Communists in Hyderabad is planned by the Military Government of the former independent princely state that was taken over by the Indian Army in September.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- During the week ended Nov. 3, member bank reserve balances decreased $114,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Under an order signed by Superior Court Judge William A. Smith, the Essex County Democratic Committee deposited today $2,730 for a recount of the Essex County vote involving the Twelfth Congressional District, the offices of County Supervisor and three Freeholders.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has acquired an option on "The Yellow Cab Driver," a screen comedy by Devery Freeman, as a possible vehicle for Red Skelton, it was learned today. The studio has engaged Freeman to expand his story into a scenario, and if the prospective photoplay develops suitably, the company will exercise its option.

The ,nual Horse Show Ball given by the National Horse Show Association officials each year in conjunction with the exhibition in Madison Square Garden took place l last night in its customary locale, the Grand Ballroom of the WaI-i dorf-Astoria.

ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 5 -- In its leading editorial, "The South and Truman," today's Athens Banner-Herald, a Democratic paper since 1832, called for an end to the "cold war" on the civil rights issue "before this question eventually destroys unity at a time of national peril."

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The United Nations took its first really concrete step today toward getting relief soon to the hundreds of thousands of hungry and homeless Arab refugees from Palestine when the Budget Committee of the General Assembly approved a proposal to advance $5,000,000 from the United Nations working capital for immediate aid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Florida Power Corporation, St. Petersburg, Fla., filed a registration statement with the SEC covering $8,500,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds that are to be offered publicly. The underwriters and other terms of the offering are to be filed by amendment. Florida Power proposes to use the proceeds for construction.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- John Foster Dulles carried the United States policy of talking bluntly to the Soviet in the United Nations a step further today by announcing that universal fear of Russia had forced the United States to stop disarming.

The theatrical firm of James Russo, Michael Ellis and Alexander H. Cohen has acquired another partner in the production of the forthcoming comedy, "Jenny Kissed Me." He is Clarence M. Shapiro, who, until recently, saw service as an M-G-M talent scout in the Midwest and produced Walter Kerr's "Stardust" in Chicago.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Toney Penna, smiling, happy-go-lucky little Cincinnati professional, came from nowhere to win the $1,500 top prize money in the forty-sixth North and South open golf tournament today.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey granted today a respite, until the week of Dec. 6, to stay the execution of three men convicted of slaying Anthony Hintz, West Side boss stevedore, on Jan. 8, 1948.

The increase in the wholesale price of butter, amounting in three days to 3 3/4 cents on a pound brick of Grade A in the New York market, began to be reflected yesterday on counters of the retail stores.

Increased governmental attention to the nation's housing problems was forecast yesterday as city and state officials announced the early opening of one public housing project in Brooklyn, and broke ground for the construction of another.

A program to bring the history of freedom and good citizenship before New York school children has been designed to coincide with the return visit to the New York area Nov. 25 to Jan. 1 of the Freedom Train, J. Edward Shugrue, national director of the American Heritage Foundation, 17 East Forty-fifth Street, announced here yesterday.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind warned yesterday that the whole system of orderly, democratic unionism might collapse and democratic government be destroyed if unions failed to enforce discipline and contract observance among their members.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A study of the membership of the new Congress shows that any proposal to repeal or substantially change the Taft-Hartley Act may be due for tough sledding because of the following reasons:

The Busch Quartet presented the first of a series of three concerts last night at Town Hall. This ensemble composed of Adolf Busch, first violin; Bruno Straumann second violin; Hugo Gottesmann viola, and Hermann Busch, 'cello were heard in a noble program made up of Beethoven's Quartet in E minor, Op. 59, No. 2, and Schubert's Quintet in C major, in the latter of which works Maryjane Thomas, 'cellist, appeared as assistant artist.
Two men, one of them a priest, were rescued last night when a home-owner at East Chester Bay, the Bronx, heard their cries for help after they had become lost in the fog while fishing from a rowboat.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Princeton's varsity eleven will open its defense of the "Big Three" title here tomorrow, meeting the Crimson of Harvard in an Ivy League contest that will see the winning team finally succeed in bringing its record for the season up to the 500 mark.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Federal Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit rejected today an appeal by the Dana group of common stockholders of North American Light and Power Company to upset approval by the Delaware Federal District Court of the company's amended liquidation plan.

Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., yesterday introduced four new television receivers with fifteen-inch metal cathode ray direct viewing tubes at a dealer showing in the Pierre Hotel. The company is the first major producer to place television sets with metal tubes on the market.

For the first time since the end of the war four factors have combined to improve the supply outlook for malleable iron products, used as parts for machines, cars, trucks and heavy equipment, James H. Lansing, research director, Malleable Founder's Society, Cleveland, declared yesterday. He addressed more than thirty-five industry members at a meeting of the Eastern section of the association at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Five sentences from Buckingham Palace ended one more ancient British custom tonight. It was announced that the Home Secretary would not be present for the birth of Princess Elizabeth's baby this month.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 5 -- The New Jersey Board of Education formally revoked today authority of John Marshall Law School in Jersey City to confer the degree of bachelor of laws, but made the order fully effective Oct. 15, 1950.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 5 -- Still in search of a victory, Navy's football squad arrived in the rain today for the game tomorrow with Michigan, winner of its last twenty contests.

Fog-bound in the outer harbor, the French liner De Grasse docked yesterday five hours behind schedule at Pier 88, North River and Forty-eighth Street, with a consignment of silver from the ruins of Pompeii.

New regulations limiting the length of low-flight rake-offs and approaches of planes for La Guardia Field and the New York International, Airport at Idlewild in Queens, will go into effect within the next few weeks, Civil Aeronautics Authority officials indicated yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- One after another, the countries of Western Europe came to the defense of the United States today in reply to Polish charges in the United Nations that the Marshall Plan enabled Washington to control the trade policies of participating countries.

Ten weather-beaten health inspectors, who daily pilot their rowboats to isolated coves and sandbars in the waters surrounding New York City, have apprehended 619 shellfish "bootleggers" since the beginning of the year and condemned 9,474 pounds of clams, mussels and oysters in their possession, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- For more than two weeks before Tuesday's election upset the handwriting was right there on the wall for all to see.

"TOWARD AN UNKNOWN STATION,"* by Allan Lyon, is a good book. It is the story of some young Americans who were traveling (at the expense of the patriotic taxpayers) around France and Luxembourg and the edges of Germany not more than forty or fifty months ago. Their adventures were full of incident and variety, and Mr. Lyon describes them with a kind of sardonic disenchantment and a wonderful clarity.

New equipment for making scientific drawings and reproductions of microscope slides have enabled Hannah Seidenfeld to be the first blind student at Hunter College to complete laboratory 'courses in physiology.

A rehearing of the interim increase in gas rates granted the Westchester Lighting Company last August was demanded of the Public Service Commission yesterday when some twenty representatives of various Westchester localities appeared before the commission at 233 Broadway.

David Feldman, the casual bootblack and porter who saved $6,400 with the help of home relief in thirteen years, began to see daylight yesterday through the threatening clouds of trouble the law had gathered over him.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- No event since the war's end caused such a sensation in Europe as the triumph of Mr. Truman. The completely unexpected denouement of the American campaign diverted Parisians from their own troubles and excited the United Nations delegates more than any vote cast in the General Assembly.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The Soviet bloc rose in protest today against a United Nations Secretariat ruling forbidding the Yugoslav delegation to show a documentary film in the Palais de Chaillot.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Judge L. Paul Burke of the Probate Court announced today that on Nov. 15 he would hear three petitions in the contest for the custody of Eligio Del Guercio Jr., 16- year-old heir to part of the fortune of the Timken Roller Bearing family.

VIENNA, Nov. 5 -- The Franz Josef Hospital in the Soviet sector of the city, in which Dana Superina, principal witness in the murder Sunday of Irving Ross, is lying now, is overrun with Soviet plainclothes guards.

The Brooklyn College eleven puts a three-game winning streak on the line at Ebbets Field tonight against its arch rival, City College, in the twenty-first renewal of an interborough series dating back to 1932. Some 20,000 fans are expected to be in the stands at the 8:30 kick-off.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 5 -- The Israeli Cabinet will meet Sunday night to discuss the United Nations Security Council's resolution ordering Israel and Egypt to return to the battlelines occupied in southern Palestine before fighting broke out there on Oct. 14.
NEW BERN, N.C., Nov. 5 (AP) -- A preacher's casual invitation to "come down and worship with us some time" led to its acceptance by President Truman.

Franklin Field, Philadelphia, provides the big show of the East on today's football program. Pennsylvania and Penn State, both undefeated since 1946, will meet there for the first time since 1942 before a sell-out crowd of 78.205.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Dollar stocks recovered further today in the stock markets here, which were cheerful throughout.

President Truman's victory and the recapture of Congress by the Democrats were seen as mandates for the repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act by Jacob S. Potofsky, in a speech last night at a victory celebration and dinner of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, at the Commodore Hotel.
The "prophet without honor" adage does not hold true for the latest $1,000 Lasker Award winner, Dr. C. Anderson Aldrich. For it was his students at the Mayo Clinic who nominated him for the honor.
Following are the texts of the speeches by President Truman and Vice President-Elect Barkley from the White House yesterday, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Seventy - four per cent of the members of the Communist-led Federation of Railway Workers who voted on the issue today, backed a call for a nations railway strike of twenty-four hours' duration to press the demand for an upward revision of wages, the union reported.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Maritime employers were reported today to have accepted a proposal aimed at settling the shipping strike. Th plan, which seeks a basis for a resumption of negotiations, was understood to include these key points:

So Freedom Train is coming back to New York City. And, it is hoped, with the inaccuracies corrected which were noted in the train, and in the film story shown when the train was here a year ago, both of which were brought to the Heritage Foundation's attention at that time.

WESLEY, Me., Nov. 5 -- In states where only bucks may be killed the hunter usually finds does by the dozen, but here in Maine deer of either sex may be killed, and the does seem just as elusive as their antlered consorts.

If Mr. Truman had lost the election he could now be looking forward to sitting on his own front porch, when spring came smiling down the streets of Independence, Mo., and going here and there without being followed by reporters, photographers, office seekers, secret service men and brass bands.

When Murray Levitz, 44 years old, of 175 Tapscott Street, Brooklyn, received a summons on Sept. 23 for smoking in the subway, he decided not to give his own name to a transit patrolman but that of a former business partner with whom he had had a disagreement.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The three-to-two "New Deal" majority on the National Labor Relations Board seemed assured today.

Heavy fog closed in upon the city yesterday to disrupt ferry, plane, shipping and vehicular traffic as the mercury climbed to 70.6, a little more than one degree under the record temperature of 72 for the date.

PEIPING, Nov. 5 -- The rush to get out of North China has started. Two commercial passenger airlines flying out of Peiping are booked three to four months ahead and a mad scramble is now going on at the docks and the steamship ticket offices in Tientsin.

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, said yesterday that a bill providing for air pollution control throughout the city along the lines suggested by Mayor O'Dwyer probably would be introduced in the Council before Nov. 30.
SEATTLE, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Thirty-eight persons were listed as missing today in three planes along the rugged North Pacific rim.
Michael J. Quill challenged the left-wing majority of the international executive board of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, yesterday to remove him as international president of the union.

Steamship operators made feverish plans yesterday to get their vessels loaded and out of this port before the Tuesday night deadline for a longshoremen's strike, despite scattered optimistic predictions that the walkout may be averted.

The New Jersey Zinc Company announced yesterday a net profit of $6,361,542 after all charges, equal to $3.25 a share, for the nine months ended with September. In the corresponding period last year the net was $6,213,848, or $3.17 a share.

NANKING, Nov. 5 -- The evacuation of 1,100 families and dependents of the United States military personnel, hitherto on a voluntary basis, was placed on a compulsory basis today and the United States Embassy advised all non-essential Americans in the Nanking-Shanghai area to leave China "while normal transportation facilities remain available."

"Road House," a melodrama from Twentieth Century-Fox, will open today at the Mayfair. Ida Lupino, Cornel Wilde, Celeste Holm and Richard Widmark are the principals. . . . A new Trans-Lux Theatre, at 345 East Seventy-second Street, will open at noon today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a recapitalization plan of the Kansas Power and Light Company, Topeka, Kan., and the Missouri Power and Light Company, Jefferson City, Mo., that would increase the voting power of their parent, the North American Light and Power Company, Wilmington, Del., and permit the filing of a consolidated tax return by the three companies.

TORONTO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A plan of the Ontario Hydroelectric Power Commission that may cost $150,000,000 -- to develop enough additional power from Niagara Falls to assure a permanent solution for southern Ontario's power shortage -- will start immediately, Robert Saunders, chairman of the commission, said today.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5 (UP) -- Parke Carroll, general manager of the Newark Bears of the International League, said today that no decision had been reached on reported plans to transfer the club franchise to another city for the 1949 season.

In the case of Ilse Koch it has been stated that the conversion of the life sentence became necessary because of lack of evidence against her. This statement is astonishing in view of the evidence published in eight volumes by the Office of United States Chief of Counsel for Prosecution of Axis Criminality under the title "Nazi Conspiracy and Aggression."
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 5 -Egyptian troops isolated near El Majdal have withdrawn toward Gaza, it was announced today.

Competitive bidding transactions are likely to dominate next week's market for new securities. Sales of tax-exempt obligations of local governments are scheduled in large number and variety, but not in great volume. Among the major tax-exempts expected are $10,500, 000 of Washington Toll Bridge Authority Puget Sound Bridge and Ferry 4 per cent bonds which were acquired last week by a syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and A.C. Allyn Co., Inc.

Pete Mead of Grand Rapids, Mich., defeated Charley (Affif) Zivic, Pittsburgh middleweight, in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 2,365 paid $6,004 to see Mead gain the unanimous vote of Referee Harry Ebbets and Judges Artie Schwartz and Frank Forbes.

The finest of greenhouse flower may be seen at the annual autumn show of the Horticultural Society of New York in the Colonnades Ball Room of the Essex House. The exhibition will be open today from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

Advertising in the eight major New York daily newspapers during October totaled 15,109,192 lines, a gain of 10.21 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. All categories recorded gains, with automotive up 12.78 per cent, retail 10.94 per cent, classified, 10.88 per cent, general 8.98 per cent, and financial 3.55 per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Grain markets closed decidedly strong today after a decline early in the session. Commission absorption took the slack out of the pits on the Board of Trade on the decline, and short covering disclosed a scarcity of offerings in the late trade.

"Horsecars and Cobblestones," a buok of reminiscences of a Jewish childhood, by Sophie B. Ruskay, will be published next month by the Beechhurst Press. The story deals with the author's immigrant parents and their family at the turn of the century in New York.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- The forty-two-story Civic Opera Building at the northwest corner of Madison Street and Wacker Drive was bought today by the Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company of Chicago for $10,735,000. The buyer paid $3,215,000 cash and assumed a $7,520,000 mortgage held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York.

NANKING, Nov. 5 -- With the civil war crisis still continuing, Premier Wont Wen-hao, who resigned this week had returned to his desk today after Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek urged him to carry on in this "most critical time."
PARIS, Nov. 5 -The proceedings of the United Nations:

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 -- United States Ambassador James Bruce, who recently returned to his post here after nearly three months in the United States, announced today he had been able to assure that President Juan D. Peron that the Economic Cooperation Administration intended to treat Argentina "most equitably in every way."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 5 -- New Jersey will not face any critical shortage of water supply for the immediate future as the result of above-normal rainfall during the last year, the New Jersey section of the American Water Works Association was told today.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina rejected yesterday a petition of the twelve Communist leaders accused of conspiring to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government that he disqualify himself from presiding when their trial begins on Nov. 15.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Lessons are more difficult for 75 per cent of school children because classroom construction prevents proper hearing, Lyle F. Yerges, Chicago sound engineer, believes.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Freer circulation of the productive "know how" of Britain's more efficient plants is one of the first requisites in increasing the country's productivity, the Anglo-American Council on Productivity said today.
The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that it intended to ask the Public Service Commission for increased rates in view of rising operating costs and a decline in net earnings.

Ray Lev is a young lady of uncommon dexterity at the piano keyboard and, to judge by her recital at Carnegie Hall last night, one who is charged with musical intensity. These facts worked both ways on the quality of her performance.

Today's music events: Young People's Concert, Little Orchestra, Thomas K. Scherman, conductor, Hunter College Auditorium, 11 A.M.; Marie Rondahl and Frances Paige, sopranos; Conchita Gaston, mezzo-soprano; Simons Bermanis, tenor; Gerald and Wilfred Beal, violins, Town Hall, 3; Edna Ricks, mezzo-soprano, Times Hall, 2:30; Rae Muscanto, soprano, assisted by Simeon Bellison, clarinet, Town Hall, 5:30.

The Pullman Company announced yesterday that ticket agents would be permitted to redeem tickets this winter for the Florida resort service only if returned for cancellation not later than the third day preceding the departure of the train for which sold.

After testing and counseling 200 children from 4 to 17 years old, and an equal number of non-veteran adults, the Brooklyn College Testing and Advisement Center will start its second year of public service this month.

Retail trade here this week declined despite an increase shown on election day. Department store sales were estimated as down 10 per cent under the corresponding week last year. A switch to warm wet weather during the latter part of the week was blamed by retailers for the decline.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The $225,000 champion French racehorse, Djelal, killed himself today in panic while being flown from France to a stud farm in Kentucky.

In THE TIMES of Oct. 27 the Filipino delegate to the United Nations, Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, is quoted as saying in Paris that Britain, Belgium, Australia and other countries are not exerting more effort to improve the educational standards of the nonself- governing territories under their respective responsibilities.
HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 5 -- Dartmouth and Columbia will meet on Memorial Field tomorrow in the nineteenth contest of their gridiron rivalry. Rain is forecast.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly rejected today a Soviet suggestion that the draft convention on genocide include a provision stipulating that a command by legal authorities or superior orders would not excuse persons from punishment for any crimes of wholesale extermination of people or races.

A Queens veteran who moved his wife and two infants into a house purchased by the city for condemnation along the route of the Van Wyck Express Highway must move out by next Friday or face a disorderly conduct charge, he was told when he appeared yesterday in Flushing Magistrates Court.

A dividend of 90 cents, payable Dec. 10, was voted by the Creole Petroleum Corporation. A like amount was disbursed in the three previous quarters bringing the total for the year to $3.60, compared with $2.85 last year.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 5 -- A broken leg, suffered by a homeless, underfed mongrel pup this afternoon when it was struck by a car on Central Avenue here was the dog's introduction to a succession of honors and a future that only the Robbins Athletic Club can predict.

Colombia has withdrawn its discrimination against merchant exporters of iron and steel products and has modified its ruling to permit mark-ups by such exporters of not more than 10 per cent over prices granted by manufacturing exporters, it was learned here yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- A C-54 Sky-master swept out of the rainy skies today and landed on the 6,000-foot runway of the new Tegel airfield in the French sector to inaugurate a third airfield in Western Berlin and insure a sizable increase in the flow of supplies into this blockaded city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The number of Americans with jobs stayed above 60,000,000 in October for the fifth month, the Census Bureau reported today. The total was 60,134,000. Although this was a drop of 178,000 from September, it was 930,000 higher than in October last year.
Basil O'Connor declared here yesterday that the nation's health was being threatened by the "machinations" of short-sighted individuals working for national health legislation.

ROME, Nov. 5 -- An Italo-Greek treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation was signed in San Remo today by Foreign Ministers Carlo Sforza for Italy and Constantin Tsaldaris for Greece. The first of its thirty articles lays down that "there shall be perpetual peace and friendship between Italy and Greece."

Continuation of the current world shortage of cocoa and chocolate for the next five years was predicted yesterday by industry representatives who just returned from a world conference of producers and users in London. Their report was made at a meeting of the National Confectioners Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Hew York Knickerbockers shot the works in the second half to defeat the Indianapolis Jets tonight, 87 -- 71, before 6,932 fans.

Army and Stanford went through final tune-ups at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, after which the rival coaches, Earl Blaik and Marchy Schwartz, said their charges were ready for today's battle at the Stadium.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Liberal party, which has stood behind the Labor Government on previous nationalization measures, served notice tonight that it would fight the Government's proposed acquisition of the iron and steel industry.

Reports from Indonesia now are that the three principal leaders of the Communist revolt against the Republic are dead or in prison. Muso was captured and killed a few days ago. A story yesterday said Alimin, who had been the Communist leader before Muso's arrival from Moscow, had been executed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- With the count still incomplete, the vote for President tonight stood as follows: Truman, 23,079,060, Dewey, 21,094,756; Wallace, 1,094,877; Thurmond, 925,226; total, 46,193,919.

TOKYO, Nov. 5 -- The Japanese tonight expect the conviction of all the nation's former leaders on trial with Gen. Hideki Tojo as accused war criminals before the International Military Tribunal for the Far East.
Wallace York, 51-year-old Brooklyn eccentric, who fatally wounded a 15-year-old boy on Thursday with a newly purchased shotgun, was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of murder.

Samuel Falk, campaign manager for former Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler, Republican and Liberal party candidate for Surrogate of New York County, announced yesterday that a recheck of the tabulation of election returns gave Mr. Frankenthaler a larger plurality over General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, his Democratic opponent, than the election night figure of 664.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The National Military Establishment reminded today men of the 19-to-26 draft age who wish to enlist that they must volunteer before they get notice from their Selective Service boards to report for their pre-induction physical examinations.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Brig. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States Marine Corps, Chief of Staff of the United Nations truce observation force, who arrived by air today from Haifa, went into consultation immediately with Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, the acting Mediator, on the report that he has been asked to present to the Security Council on the recent fighting in Palestine in violation of the truce imposed by the Council.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Approaching Sunday's French elections, Leon Blum, veteran Socialist leader, conferred today with Premier Henri Queuille about the prospects of a reinvigoration of the "Third Force," which has, it is thought, drawn strength from President Truman's victory Tuesday.
BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- American comic books, detective stories and true love novelettes will be made available to the Germans with funds guaranteed by the Economic Cooperation Act, it was learned today.

Cottonseed oil futures continued active yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. Early in the day prices moved irregularly, but rallied sharply under commission house buying, scattered short covering and catching of stop-loss orders.

The award of the Nobel prize in physics to Prof. P.M.S. Blackett and to Prof. Arne Tiselius in chemistry will be endorsed by scientists who have followed the work of both men. To Professor Blackett goes the credit for having been the first man to photograph the transmutation of an atom and for investigating the clusters of cosmic rays to which he gave the name of "showers."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -The Economic Cooperation Administration gave effect today to a complex intra-European payments plan designed to end the "dollar standard" of settlements among Marshall Plan countries by requiring the creditor nations among them to make loans in their own currencies to debtor members participating in the European Recovery Program.

The De Florez Engineering Company bought the three-story dwelling on a lot 17 by 98 feet at 116 East Thirtieth Street from Whit Burnett and Mrs. Hallie Burnett and will alter and occupy it for business. Ruland Benjamin were the brokers.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- An Air Force B-29 bomber crash-landed in flames near a Colorado Springs golf course today a few minutes after taking off. Two of the crew of ten suffered minor injuries.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander demoted nineteen detectives and rewarded twenty-four others with promotions or extra compensation yesterday in the biggest shake-up in the Detective Division this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Interdepartmental Trade Agreements Committee today issued formal notice of the intention of the United States to participate in negotiations with eleven countries for reciprocal reduction of tariff and other trade barriers looking to their accession to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade concluded at Geneva on Oct. 30, 1947, by the United States and twenty-two other countries.

The Huie Kin Memorial Presbyterian Church, 225 East Thirty-first Street, the only Chinese conregation of that denomination in the city, will erect a building on a site at 472 Pearl Street, south of Columbus Park, at Cardinal Hayes Place.

In appraising the results of Tuesday's election most thoughtful persons will probably agree that an important cause for gratification is to be found in the emergence of a unified National Government. For the past two years President Truman has had to administer his office under a twofold handicap.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- After holding Georgetown scoreless in surprising fashion during the first half, New York University's defenses wilted considerably and the Hoyas went on to a 13-to-6 victory over the Violet tonight. A crowd of 5,892 was on hand at Griffith Stadium.
When I was 19 years old I trained for the international light heavyweight golden gloves in Chicago. I wanted to take that title.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A forecast of party harmony in Congress between Northern and Southern Democrats came today from two Senators in the heretofore opposed camps.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Housing and Home Finance Agency said today it will offer to sell 400 units in the Hilltop Manor war housing project at Wichita, Kan., to the Hilltop Manor Mutual Ownership Association. The association is composed of present occupants of the project.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- A possible new approach by the six "neutrals" to the Berlin controversy is being discussed by members of the United Nations Security Council.

Ralph Edward Barrows, 19 years old, of 317 West Fifty-sixth Street, a men's residence hotel, confessed last night, according to the police, that he killed Colin Cameron MacKellar, 56, a Canadian textile corporation executive, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel early yesterday morning.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The executive council of the major baseball leagues today approved a change in the rules to permit the option of first-year bonus players if waivers are obtained. They. cannot be optioned now.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 5 -- Tennessee, which has twelve Presidential electors, was assured tonight that all but one of its twelve votes would be cast for President Truman.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 5 -- To Negro youth of this state greater educational opportunities were promised today by spokesmen for the state's white majority population. With their assurances was a message telephoned here by the Secretary of the Army, Kenneth C. Royall, a North Carolinian by birth, who said that "the broadening of education is the best answer to intolerance."

A self-styled "big-time politician" from Brooklyn was paroled in mid-Manhattan court yesterday to await a hearing Monday on disorderly conduct charges. The police said he had passed three red traffic lights, told two patrolmen he would have them "broken" through his political connections, threatened to have a police lieutenant "out digging ditches," and ripped the coat of one of the patrolmen early yesterday morning.

We believe that the determined efforts of Mayor O'Dwyer's reorganized Sanitation Department to do a better job on street cleaning are having an effect and -- what is equally important -- that the public is becoming aware of its responsibility for partnership in these efforts.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 5 -- The possibility of a state-wide recount of the votes cast in Tuesday's election was seen today when the State Board of Election Canvassers obtained a Superior Court injunction impounding all voting machines indefinitely.

As an alternative way of showing honor to the dead and expressing sympathy for the bereaved, thereby avoiding lavish expenditures for flowers at funerals, a memorial fund is being established at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

Transatlantic airline flights into the giant airfield at Gander, Nfld., were put on an emergency footing at midnight last night to prevent depletion of the aviation gasoline supply there while the railway workers of Newfoundland are on strike.
One-way avenue traffic on Ninth and Tenth Avenues, designed to speed truck traffic through the congested midtown area, will become effective at 8 A.M. today for a sixty-day experimental period.

In their final heavy workouts of the week, the football Giants, Yankees and Dodgers yesterday devoted their chief attention to special defensive measures against the redoubtable stars of their visiting opponents.

The monthly report of the United States Maritime Commission on the status of the reserve fleet lists an increase of eighty-three vessels during the month of October, with the total fleet, as of Nov. 1, 1,901 ships.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Mrs. Samuel W. Halprin, national president of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, appealed to President Truman today to curb "two or three wilfull men" in the United States delegation to the United Nations for supporting the British resolution on Palestine in defiance of his clear-cut statements reaffirming the Democratic platform on Israel."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- This city, ordinarily notable for its apathy toward celebrities in the streets, turned full about-face today to give President Truman a "homecoming" demonstration for which it was hard to find a parallel.

LANDSBERG, Germany, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Fourteen war criminals, including severe minor Nazi leaders, were hanged here today for the "cold-blooded and inhuman" murder of United States fliers and concentration camp prisoners.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- When officials at the Ministry of Defense were asked today about a report from Frankfort on the Main, Germany that the United States Army had equipped three French divisions in Germany, they replied that a denial was about to be issued.

A tract of about sixteen acres of land at the northwest corner of Horace Harding Boulevard and Lakeville Road in the village of Lake Success, L. I., has been sold by the Wyckoff Trading Corporation to the Bellingham Realty Company, Inc., headed by Harry Berger.
James A. Rafferty, vice president of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, urged America's chemical industry last night to take the lead in modernizing housing.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Eight persons were killed and sixty-seven injured when small tornadoes and heavy windstorms ripped through sections of Louisiana, Mississippi, Kentucky, Tennessee and Georgia early today and tonight.

Lumber production for the week ended Oct. 30 was 3.6 per cent below the previous week but 1.5 per cent above the like week last year. Shipments were down 9.3 per cent compared with a year ago, and orders were down 17.1 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

On Nov. 17 the New York Academy of Medicine will inaugurate the fourteenth of its series of lectures on medicine for the laity. This years' program testifies to the many ramifications of medicine. Law is represented in the Linsly R. Williams memorial lecture on "Some Problems in Law and Medicine for the Laity."

The ginger remaining in the 18-year-old heels of Resorte, glorious star of the Mexican string, completed a military jumping sweep for the second straight day for the riders of the republic in the West Point Challenge Trophy event at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

Fresh apprehension was expressed yesterday by holders of securities over the all-inclusive Democratic victory in the national elections. This expression in the Stock Exchange took the form of another selling wave, comparable with that of Wednesday, with Thursday's recovery wiped out and prices reduced from fractions to as much as 8 points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- When 114 employes out of 115 quit individually within thirty-six hours their action is "a work stoppage in the nature of a strike," a trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board concluded today. He held the union responsible, too.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, 4 points higher to 8 points lower.

The Edgar Bergen show, featuring the impish ways of Charlie McCarthy, is reported to have been purchased by the Coca-Cola Company for sponsorship on a network still to be decided. The program's present sponsor, Standard Brands, previously had indicated a desire to relinquish the offering because of a change in advertising plans.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, Argentine Foreign Minister, started a series of informal talks with Cabinet Ministers this afternoon when he called on Foreign Secretary Bevin at the Foreign Office.

A dignified appearing, middle-aged landlady of two furnished apartment buildings in the Chelsea area was arrested yesterday on the basis of charges that she had mulcted tenants of $10,000 in rental bonuses, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Religion in the life of a child cannot be thought of in terms of a half-hour or an hour a week but must be considered as a continuing seven-day-a-week experience, delegates attending the regional conference on the International Council of Religious Education warned here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -At least one year more of high grain export to the Marshall Plan countries was predicted today by Dr. D.A. FitzGerald, director of food and agriculture of the Economic Cooperation Administration, on his return from Europe.

Three years ago next month the Foreign Secretaries of the United States, Great Britain and Russia, meeting in Moscow, agreed on a resolution setting up an Atomic Energy Commission under the United Nations. In January, 1946, this resolution was unanimously adopted by the United Nations General Assembly, holding its first meeting in London.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Marcel Rochas presents a collection of thirty models, comprising winter sports outfits and clothes for all city-wear occasions. Following his guepierre line, the models are based on the corselet, whether it be by cut or shaped belts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Revision of the social security system, including broadened coverage and increased benefits, appeared likely today to take precedence in the new Democratic Congress over all other bills in the field of taxation and related matters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley predicted today that the Democrat-controlled Eighty-first Congress would give President Truman the power to establish selective price controls which the Eightieth Congress has denied him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Industry's reaction today to President Truman's plan for labor-management discussions to prepare a new labor relations bill to supplant the Taft-Hartley Act was surprise, pleasure and healthy skepticism as to the possibility of a favorable result.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The right of the National Theatre to refuse admittance to Negroes has been sustained by the Municipal Court of Appeals in a unanimous opinion made available today. The controversy will presumably be taken on upward to the Supreme Court even though the National has been converted from a legitimate playhouse to a motion-picture theatre.

The foreign exchange market here was notified yesterday of the terms of rationing which the South African Reserve Bank is imposing on non-sterling exchange available to importers in an effort to halt the heavy drain on the gold reserves of the South African banking system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Life may be made a little easier for fliers checking on target airplanes in case the military authorities adopt a control system designed by Charles L. Paulus of Dayton, Ohio, and Howard A. Klein of Oakdale, Pa., for use on such planes, which won Patent 2,452,599 on the list of 573 issued this week by the United States Patent Office.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and Lloyd B. Marsh, Republican State Chairman, began today to reorganize and "revitalize" the New Jersey Republican organization and its policies.

Stumpp Walter, 132 Church Street, has been selling seeds, garden equipment and food delicacies for more than fifty years. The store's grocery department, however, seems no older than yesterday. Fresh green paint, gracefully curving display counters and hanging pots of ivy give this recently renovated spot a spic-and-span, modern air.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A total of eighty-four leaders of virtually all segments of public and civic affairs will take part in joint "orientation" conferences to be conducted by the national military establishment, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, announced today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 5 -- Cancellation of the recent decision of the denazification tribunal in Ludwigsburg to free Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, ordered by a German court of appeals, was announced today by Walter Kuransky, Commissioner for Denazification in Wuerttemberg-Baden.

Still confident that Fordham can overcome a favored Boston University eleven, Coach Ed Danowski will send the Rams into their first home game of the season at the Polo Grounds today. A crowd of 7,500 is expected to be on hand for the kick-off at 2 P.M.

Representatives of three major polling organizations that erred in their forecasts of last Tuesday's election said yesterday that they would release full technical data for statistical evaluation of their results when they finish analyses of the polls.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 5 -- Mounting Communist pressure against the Korean Government prompted the Korean authorities today to crack down on subversive groups. Home Minister T.Y. Yun ordered arrests of known and suspected Communists and sympathizers throughout south Korea's nine provinces in an effort to forestall further uprisings.

Women's coat and suit manufacturers who have heavy fabrics available are taking orders for women's garments for December and January delivery, it was learned yesterday. Few orders can be placed for delivery in less than six weeks, resident buyers reported, and some lines are closed tight for the fall season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -The Czechoslovak Government has in effect turned down a State Department protest against arms shipments to the Palestine fighting areas, officials disclosed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- The Waterfront Employers and Pacific American Shipowners Associations announced today that they have accepted Almon E. Roth's proposal for reopening negotiations in the sixty-four-day-old West Coast shipping strike.

HONOLULU, Nov. 6 -- Hawaii's gloom as the squeeze of the West Coast maritime strike continues to strangle its economy is tinged with hope as word from the West Coast indicates optimism for a quick settlement of the two-month tie-up of Pacific shipping.

THAT stern look in publishers' eyes is due mainly, of course, to high thinking, pure living and eyestrain. Even so, the prevailing state of the trade is not likely to mellow anyone up. Contrary reports here and there, but the chorus, midway in this autumn season, is that costs have risen, profits have fallen and sales have slumped.

Efforts to bring about public realization that venereal diseases are serious infections but that most cases "may be cured quickly and painlessly with newer methods of treatment" were urged last night by Dr. Harry S. Mustard Commissioner of Health, in an address on his department's control program scheduled to begin tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The National Education Association called upon the incoming Eighty-first Congress today to give prompt attention to Federal-aid-to-education legislation which was declared necessary "to remove the threat to our nation's security caused by millions of children who today are denied a fair chance to get a basic education."

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Wake Forest won a spine-tingling 27-20 decision over Duke today, the Deacons' second victory over the Blue Devils in twenty-one years. A crowd of 20,000 saw the Deacons score in every period.

ROME -- The Italian bus tours, know as CIAT Pullman, made such a hit with tourists this summer that they will be continued through the winter for the benefit of off-season travelers. Three new itineraries are offered for the winter months: a tour between Rome and Genoa; a hill town excursion out of Rome, both already available; and a six-day tour of Sicily, beginning Dec. 20.
Solving an eighty-year-old problem of the pulp industry, a new process in the manufacture of sulphite wood pulp was announced yesterday in Tacoma, Wash., by the Weyerhaeuser Timber Company.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 6 -- The Yugoslav press published today a series of telegrams from Marshal Tito and other Yugoslav leaders to Marshal Stalin, Foreign Minister Molotov and President Shvernik of the Soviet Union, wishing them on the occasion of the thirty-first anniversary of the October revolution continued successes at home and abroad.

AS is pretty well known by now, Billy Rose is something more than the figure in a Broadway press agent's dream. Press agents must stick fairly close to possibility, and the actual Billy is far too improbable to be believed.

Seventeen persons were injured, of them critically, in the Bronx last night when a Surface Transportation Company bus went out of control and caromed for a block before crashing into a bar and grill at the northwest corner of 149th Street and Gerard Avenue.

DETROIT, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Net income of $9,488,336, or 63 cents a share, was reported today by Packard Motor Car Company for the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1948. This compares with a net loss of $131,478 in the like period of 1947.

COMPARATIVELY little touched in American school rooms, Iceland, as this travel book proves, is worthy of greater attention. The author reminds us this island is now of strategic importance because of its accessibility as an air base between the United States, Europe and Russia.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- The only measuring stick for a good university is whether or not it is a center of independent thought for the improvement of society and advancement of knowledge, Chancellor Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago, said this week.

SO it wasn't a "Republican Year" after all! It seems the farmers were quite prosperous and a little skeptical of what might happen under another Administration; that labor really didn't like the Taft-Hartley law, and that various and sundry of the citizenry were concerned about the high cost of living and also the lack of housing.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Soviet efforts to make the recognition of human rights subject to the will of the state were defeated today, when the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations approved by a vote of 38 to 0, with seven abstentions, Article 13 of the draft Declaration on Human Rights.

Professional football fans will have their choice of three local attractions today. The Giants meet the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds in a National League contest an dthe Yankees oppose the Los Angeles Dons at the Stadium and the Dodgers tackle the Buffalo Bills at Ebbets Field in All-America Conference games.
Boston University did the expected yesterday, defeating Fordham 33 -- 7, in the Rams' first home game of the season.

The session of the United Nations General Assembly in Paris is a little more than half over. The meetings began in the Paris of Charllot last Sept. 21. They are expected to end around Dec. 10 in time for the delegates to get home for Christmas. The delegates have been reminded of the passing of time by the changing appearance of Paris.

Stan Waterman, Dartmouth junior, captured the individual title and Army won team honors yesterday in the tenth annual cross-country championships of the Heptagonal Games Association over the five-mile course of Van Cortlandt Park. Sixty-three runners from nine colleges faced the starter's gun but only fifty-five finished.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A substantial increase in the strength and fire power of the National Guard's non-divisional field artillery battalions will result from a partial reorganization which went into effect on Nov. 1, Maj. Gen. Kenneth F. Cramer, chief of the National Guard Bureau, reports.

EARLY last summer, as the Economic Cooperation Administration was being organized, representatives of the sixteen nations at Paris appealed to American authorities for a brief moratorium on requests for information to justify and guide the Marshall aid. They -- and their governments -- were being demoralized by the apparently insatiable American appetite for statistics.

The recommendation that the next Congress establish selective price controls, made by Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley in Washington on Friday, was endorsed yesterday by junior high school students participating in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

THE trend noted in recent years in the big National Ceramic annuals held at the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts is verified in the thirteenth suen show which opens to the public today. That is: the medium which was once used primarily for pottery is becoming more and more popular with sculptors.
MYSTERIOUS Japan should be now an open secret -- if Americans have digested the thousands of English language books on Japan they have carted out of this country in three years of occupation.
