RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 6 --The official canvass by the Suffolk County Board of Elections showed that Governor Dewey and Gov. Earl Warren, the Republican nominees for President and Vice President, received a plurality of 46,449 over President Truman and Senator Alben W. Barkley, the Democratic and Liberal party nominees in the election in Suffolk County on Tuesday.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- With the United States elections out of the way, hope is reviving here that the United Nations General Assembly can complete is work before Christmas and that a special ses- can complete its work before sion next February or March will not be necessary.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 6 -- Although Tuesday may have marked a turning point in American history, the people of this region seem concerned about the same problems now as they were before the election took place.
DETROIT, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Most of the 1949 model automobiles will have quieter, smoother performing and more powerful engines.

While Election day retail trade was active, warm and rainy weather during the latter part of the week slowed up sales here considerably. Department store volume was estimated at about 10 per cent under the like week of 1947.
NANKING, Nov. 6 -- The Government claimed a modest victory in Central China tonight, but rumors spread through Nanking that an effort to negotiate a peace with the Communists was in the wind.

DOING the weekly wash, the job that was once considered the most menial and tedious brand of housework, is beginning to acquire a certain social prestige. Now that automatic laundry equipment has removed the sweat and backache from washday, even the mistresses of two-maid households have been heard boasting of their skill in laundering blankets.

Patrick Brennan, one of the best known officers in the American merchant marine, is retiring from the sea. Chief engineer of the luxury liner America since that vessel was commissioned, he has served as a top ranking engineer for the United states Lines, operators of the ship, since 1920.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 6 (UP) -- William and Mary's stolid Indians brought to an end one of football's outstanding victory strings today when they scored early and held North Carolina to a 7-7 tie before 43,000 unbelieving fans.

Brooklyn Tech, boasting the second best record in City P.S.A.L. football competition, gained its fifth victory in six starts by defeating Thomas Jefferson, 28 -- 6, in the feature game of the Ebbets Field scholastic double-header yesterday.

IN the coverage of the election results on Tuesday night and early Wednesday morning, radio had much the best of it over television, the video art fumbling rather badly in its first full-dress effort to cover the outcome of a Presidential campaign.

THE train was humming over the rails from Boston to St. Louis for the final lap of the 1946 world series. Frank Frisch, an unemployed baseball manager, had just finished a complete, unexpurgated and off-the-record recital of his troubles with the maddening Pittsburgh Pirates who had given him all those gray hairs.

If there was any doubt whether industrial prosperity would continue, regardless of the outcome of the national election, it was removed last week by actions taken by leading industrialists after President Truman's election. In leading industries, ranging from automobiles and steel to public utilities and chemicals, top executives took steps to push multi-billion dollar expansion programs which are now scheduled to continue past 1949.

FOR THIS WEEK: Finish planting bulbs as soon as. possible. . . . Plant all kinds of shrubs, rose bushes, apple and pear trees this month. Order shade trees to be set out next month. Then water regularly until the earth freezes. . . . Start bulbs of paperwhite narcissus in bowls of water and pebbles to flower for the Christmas holidays. . . .
NOW that the election suspense is over, it would be wise to look around a bit and size up the situation.

There are those who ask whether the Soviet system of government can be studied effectively with materials available in American libraries. Julian Towster (he is Assistant Professor of Political Science at the University of Chicago) has presented the most extensive study yet to appear in proof that it can.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were rather quiet, and final prices were unchanged for one contract to 10 points lower than the day before for others.

LAURENCE OLIVIER'S "Hamlet" has been showing at the Park Avenue Theatre for just one month, and already it has fired as much comment as exploded after the opening of "Gone With the Wind." This corner has received more letters discussing it, pro and con, than we've had on any picture in the memory of current personnel.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Trinity College piled up unexpected 464-to-0 margin over Amherst before a crowd of 4,500 at Trinity Field today as two of New England's top small college passers collided and Trinity's Whitey Kunkiewicz came out on top.

IT was a wrench for Skid to leave his home and friends in Georgia when his parents moved up North especially as he had just been elected captain of his baseball team. Nor had he counted on being the only Negro boy in the little Connecticut community.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- The American Public Health Association will honor next week the memory of Lemuel Shattuck of Boston, who nearly a century ago wrote a report that still is considered "the bible of public health in America."

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- More than 2,000 persons packed Central Hall to overflowing here tonight to attend a meeting arranged by the British-Soviet Society in celebration of the thirty-first anniversary of the Russian revolution. The guest of honor was the Soviet Ambassador, Georgi N. Zarubin, who was accompanied by several members of the Soviet Embassy staff in diplomatic and military uniforms.

NUTS have been gathered this autumn in record-breaking quantities. The total crop of pecans, almonds, walnuts and filberts is 63,000,000 pounds greater than a year ago. From South America, Brazil nuts are arriving in shipments described as fully adequate to meet the demand.

THE general autumn clean-up around the home grounds results in more of a benefit than the neatness which meets the eye. It also helps spell the end for many common pests and diseases which otherwise would spend a comfortable winter in the garden readying for renewed attacks next year.

BEST known for her plays ("Autumn Crocus." "Call It a Day"), Miss Smith has carried over into "I Capture the Castle" the humor, sentiment and tempered poignancy that have characterized her work for the theatre.
AS someone who is interested in television, I want to tell you how excellent I thought your article of last Sunday was. "Matter of Form" hits the nail right on the head.

THIS is a novel dedicated to east Texas -- land of pines, post oaks and willlows, of winding creeks, possum hollows and sand. Because this region hasn't been ballyhooed in movies and Westerns as have Texas plains and cowboys, it will seem new territory to many.

W. Va., Nov. 6 (By Science Service) -- Synthetic, oil from coal, with a total of 1,000,000 barrels daily, was given as the objective of a program outlined to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers here by J.D. Doherty of the United States Bureau of Mines.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Dazzling Doak Walker, practically everybody's candidate for All-America, amazed the fans and dazed his opponents today as he personally accounted for every touchdown in Southern Methodist's 20-to-14 triumph over Texas A.

Measures for increasing the efficiency of the Police Department, including the acquisition of new mobile equipment and the decentralization of some of the department's functions, were outlined yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- Foreign Minister Molotov said tonight the voters of the United States had rejected a program of aggression and reaction when they had defeated Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for President.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Brown's alert football team enjoyed a tune-up for its Harvard game next week by outclassing Western Reserve, 36 -- 0, today before 8,000 fans.
HAVING produced twenty plays in the last three years in England. I found the adventure of co-producing "Edward, My Son" in New York very much more fun than I had thought possible.

September shipments of hosiery totaled 12,593,608 dozen pairs compared to 13,169,815 dozen pairs in September, 1947, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. Women's full-fashioned shipments during September amounted to 3,989,937 dozen pairs compared to 3,530,979 dozen pairs in the corresponding period last year.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 6 -- The end of a turbulent week found the Upper South a little apprehensive about the region's political future, but all in all ready to forget about politics and concentrate on getting bills paid up before Christmas.

Assistant Secretary of Labor Ralph Wright declared yesterday that the Taft-Hartley law was a "vicious, anti-labor law" and that its repeal would be "among the first pieces of legislation, placed before the Eighty-first Congress." He said that a new law, "fair to both workers and employers," was the goal of President Truman.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 6 -- Idaho farmers, Wyoming ranchers, Utah mining executives and Colorado business men are throwing off election-induced headaches in traditional fashion this week-end. They are hunting duck, geese, pheasant and quail, with the blast of shotguns echoing along lake-shore flyways and upland pastures.

THIS is the first of two volumes of an attempt to sum marize that part of mankind's heritage which is native to India. It is an engrossing story rather than formal history, and it sets out, in a vaguely Wellsian manner, to highlight the consistent unity of Indian civilization against the uncommonly chequered backdrop of dynastic history, to expound rather than quibble, and to aim at the lay reader, not the specialist.

Eight major breweries, strike-bound by a "wildcat" walkout of 3,500 beer drivers since Oct. 14, have filed suit for $8,275,000 in damages against five striking locals of the United Brewery Workers, CIO, it was made known yesterday.

A MARKED sensitivity to the quality of sunlight characterizes the exhibition of pictorial documentary photographs by Forman Hanna, internationally known salon exhibitor, on display at the Brooklyn Museum through Nov. 28.

DR. LIBERTY HYDE BAILEY, dean emeritus of the New York State College of Agriculture, will be presented with the bronze medallion of the Women's International Exposition at the opening of National Flower Week tonight.

THIS department's recent brief foray into the literature of the dog has quite naturally evoked some rather passionate reactions from both dog and cat lovers. The subject touched upon is one on which convictions run deep and strong.

Retail store buyers were advised by top buying office executives here last week, to "continue with spring buying plans as though the election had not taken place." One qualification added to this suggestion, however, was to urge that buyers use more caution in purchasing merchandise which is in plentiful supply in relation to demand.

Nathaniel Peffer is to be congratulated for his sane report on Communist tactics in the Far East ("Communism Bids for Dominance in Asia"). He overlooks Korea, however. If one is to believe the news of the past week, Korea may well be the scene of Stalin's first complete victory in Asia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The price index theory of election forecasting won new prestige in Tuesday's debacle of the pollsters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The public opinion polls have collided at last with the inexorable reality that people are not digits and percentage points. That tardy realization is having drastic repercussions. For the polls had won great influence in national affairs.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Notre Dame's football team skipped lightly over a muddy field in a 42-6 victory today against Indiana University's five-times beaten Hoosiers. Economic Commission for Europe, and after five days of consultations, the fifteen experts decided that frontier formalities are seriously handicapping tourist travel on the continent.

Tying in with the return visit of the Freedom Train to New York for the Nov. 25-Jan. 1 exhibition, the American Heritage Foundation, sponsor of the tour, has given to Superintendent of Schools William Jansen for school use 33,000 of the foundation's teachers' study guides, "Your Heritage of Freedom" and twenty-five copies of the foundation's documentary sound film "Our American Heritage," J. Edward Shugrue, national director of the foundation, announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Balked in the air and fought on fairly even terms on the ground, Holy Cross reached in the bag for a third-quarter field goal and a 16-13 victory over Duquesne at Forbes Field today. A slim crowd of 4,568 that flouted threatening skies was repaid by the Dukes' unexpected strength.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Temple's football Owls lived up to pre-season predictions they would be a November team by trouncing Syracuse, 20 to 0, today for their second straight triumph.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- Cornell's football forces, hitting with great power inside the tackles, defeated Colgate by 14 -- 6 in a driving rain on Schoelellkopf Field today.

The aristocrat of American industry has finally been humanized: not by a public relations organization nor a blustering, colorful and public-appeal citizen, but by the man who tops the organization as chairman of its board of directors.

The United States delegation prepared here yesterday to leave for the Third General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization opening Nov. 17 in Beirut, Lebanon.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- For the first time in United Nations history a committee of the General Assembly took action today to look into a case concerning men condemned to death by their Government.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- One way or another, the present negative Communist hold on France will be broken. That much can be taken for granted -- and that we shall soon have seen the last of those "combat groups" that have engaged troops and police sent to quell Communist-led strikes in the coal fields.

Times Square farmers are funny people. Last Sunday in "Olympics, Farm Style," one of them wrote that "farm carts" are used in corn-husking contests. Farm carts are something the Midwestern farmer never heard of, much less used for corn picking.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Although Washington is speculating about a successor to Secretary of State Marshall, who desires to retire from public life, there is ample authority for saying that he has not closed his mind to the possibility of continuing in office at least for part of President Truman's new term.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 6 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration faces one of its toughest problems in the Netherlands.

ROCKLAND, Me., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Coast Guard craft from the Burnt Island lifeboat station and Rockland early today rescued the captain and a crew of nine from a tug which ran aground on the southeastern tip of Monhegan Island.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 6 -- Lou Little almost strained the ancient friendship between himself and Tuss McLaughry as darkness was falling on Memorial Field today, but justice, or a reasonable facsimile thereof, triumphed in the end and Dartmouth won the football game from Columbia, 26 -- 21.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The non-Communist affidavit provision of the Taft-Hartley Law today was credited by some officials with breaking the back of a threatened union boycott of the National Labor Relations Board.

IF ever anyone deserved a rainbow it was Ruey Sarvis, as nice a little girl as ever yearned for a $2.98 genuine ruby ring like Cousin Essie's. Ruey, an orphan, lived with a civic-minded aunt who couldn't remember what little girls really needed but Gramma did.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- Pairing touchdowns in the second and final quarters, Rensselaer Poly today defeated Clarkson College, 27 -- 14, on its windswept home field.

THE delegates of the United Nations have found many grounds for disunity at their meeting here, but at least one small area of agreement -- the "Marche aux Puces." This famous turn-of-the-century "Flea Market" squats several hops, skips and jumps past the Butte Montmartre on waste ground at the Porte de Clignancourt, on the northern rim of the city.
SEAN O'FAOLAIN sent you an "Unhappy Report" on Irish letters, which appeared in your Oct. 10 issue. It need not have been so unhappy, as I will try to show.

Jack Warner, 38 years old, of 48 Ridgewood Avenue, Newark, was brought here from Baltimore yesterday for arraignment as one of the three men who worked a $4,000 "switch game" on an elderly man in the Bronx two years ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The White House social season was called off by the President and Mrs. Truman today because the building is being closed indefinitely for repairs.

NANKING, Nov. 6 -- Battered by military defeats, oppressed by indescribable inflationary woes and newly disappointed by the results of the United States elections. Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's government is now hanging suspended by the narrowest thread.

Thirty-seven of fifty-four of the nation's medical schools, in answer to a recent questionnaire of the National Society for Medical Research, said that their medical research or medical teaching was handicapped because of "antivivisection obstructionism," the society announced here yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Two cavalry regiments were moved into Santiago today from Vina del Mar and Los Andes as military authorities continued to arrest army officers and civilians suspected of implication in a widespread conspiracy to overthrow the Government.
Further research in arthritis and the other rheumatic diseases was urged yesterday by Dr. Currier McEwen, dean of the New York University College of Medicine.

One is an old-fashioned and highly academic volume of exegesis, of the type that used to be devoted to such subjects as the women of Dickens.

Future world prosperity and peace depends to a great extent on increased American productivity, Charles Luckman, president of the Lever Brothers Company and former chairman of President Truman's Citizens Food Committee, declared yesterday.

BOYS of my sort in England were at the earliest age, in spite of -- or perhaps because of -- worldly advantages they enjoyed, taught the dignity of man, their equality before God, and to treat everyone with a consideration which nowadays is not so much in evidence.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 6 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today that the Eighty-first Congress should quickly repeal the Taft-Hartley Act and vote new labor statutes "fairly acceptable to all.

The League of Women Shoppers called yesterday for prompt action by President Truman on a stronger rent control law and pledged its support to him and the new Congress in reinstatement of price and rent controls and repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law.

A MUSIC critic before he was a drama critic and playwright. G.B. Shaw has never lost his affection for the tonal art. Nor, for that matter, his capacity for strong opinions trenchantly expressed. In the British press recently there has been a discussion of the texture of orchestral bass, and Mr. Shaw has been taking part in the debate.

RECOGNIZED authorities on American folksongs concede that although men usually are the known folk singers, in nine cases out of ten it has been the women who have kept the old ballads alive in this country, humming them over their work and singing them over and over again to their children.

Chroniclers of the Presidential election have not failed to call attention to the fact that the election of last week was the forty-first such election for the nation. That is, forty Administrations of four years each will have passed into history when President Truman begins his new term on Jan. 20 and 160 years will have passed on next April 30 since George Washington took the oath as first President of the United States.

Instead of a perfunctory congratulatory message Henry Wallace has sent President Truman a warning that the campaign promises must be kept. In so doing he was well within his rights. For though Truman won the Presidency, Wallace won the election.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration released to the French Government this week 25,000,000,000 francs more from the counterpart fund under the Marshall Plan. It has now released 90,000,000,000 francs in all from this fund and its predecessor created in conjunction with interim aid.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Vice President-Elect Barkley has less than one chance in four of becoming President through the death of Mr. Truman. Seven of the thirty-two Presidents have died in office.

HERE, in pictures, is the history of the West and its wars from 1862 and the Sioux War in Minnesota to the Ghost Dance rebellion and the death of Sitting Bull at Pine Ridge in 1891, the three decades which Bancroft has called "the history of aboriginal extermination."

Mrs. Hollister Sturges Jr. heads the committee in charge of the sale of tickets for the performance of "Life With Mother" on Thursday night at the Empire Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Child Education Foundation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, has canvassed his Secretaries of the Army, Navy and Air Force for their views on the handling of statements by prominent retired officers which might be considered inflammatory or embarrassing to a unified national defense program, it was learned today.

JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Freddie Mills, world light heavyweight boxing champion, knocked out Johnny Ralph, South African heavyweight king, in the eighth round of a scheduled twelve-round non-title bout tonight.
Ralph Edward Barrows heard himself accused yesterday of having caused the death of Colin Cameron MacKellar, Canadian textile executive, by "striking, punching and kicking about the head and body."
ALBANY, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A joint legislative committee today scheduled a hearing Nov. 22 and 23 in New York City to investigate the advisability of limiting the size of life insurance companies.

A role much larger and more difficult than the one it played in World War II has been assigned to the Civil Air Patrol by the United States Air Force in the event of another war, it was announced here yesterday.
Radar equipment aboard merchant vessels may be expected to fail five times per unit over a ten-month period, the National Federation of American Shipping reported yesterday on the basis of a survey.

THERE is an old refrain that goes something like, "Any rags, any bones, any bottles today?" Heralding the approach of the so-called "junk" wagon of the early Nineties, which was loaded with a fascinating collection of metal objects, bottles and boxes, it was an irresistible magnet to children.
It would be interesting to know to what extent the stay-at-home voters and those who, though eligible to vote, failed to register, were responsible for the outcome of Tuesday's election.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 6 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development "necessarily" looks to the large savings banks in New York as one of the principal outlets for the sale of its bonds, John J. McCloy, the institution's president, told the New York State savings bankers here today.

For most observers, last week's "wrong-way" experting by some public opinion pollsters was funny. But marketing research technicians -- the business world's pollsters -- detected in the strong note of ridicule the beginnings of increased prejudice against all methods of measuring consumer demand and advertising results.

More meat, more milk and more eggs are promised American consumers under estimates made public yesterday by the Department of Agriculture. If the law of supply and demand still holds, this should mean lower prices, but in this field, as in the political, prophecy is a risky business.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The United States and British airlift will be able to maintain an average supply load of 4,000 tons a day for the Western sectors of Berlin in bad weather "without difficulty," Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States military governor, declared today.

APPOMATTOX brought a formal end to the Civil War, but it left so many unresolved questions between the North and the South that we are still trying to solve them. Similarly, the election of a President leaves unresolved the central dilemma of the American people: where does national security lie and how do we achieve it?

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- The most heartening basic development in Germany this year has been the dramatic spurt in industrial production of the American and British zones of occupation following the introduction in June of currency reform.
ATHENS, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis said tonight his coalition Greek Government would resign Monday.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 6 -- A $6,000,000 underground bus terminal will be built, at a date to be determined, beneath Government and Fountain Squares in downtown here, the City Planning Commission has announced.

LIST as one of our more industrious citizens Eddie Albert, whose interests in the movies, both Hollywood and commercial, and the radio and television, have just brought him winging from the Coast. Of immediate concern, of course, is the reception accorded "You Gotta Stay Happy," newly arrived at the Music Hall and his "first decent acting job in some time."

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- Governor Dewey today blamed Republican over-confidence for his defeat in the Presidential election. At the same time, he served notice that he intended to continue in an active role as titular leader of his party.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- There has been a frank discussion here between Foreign Secretary Bevin and Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, Argentine Foreign Minister, about the dispute between the two countries over ownership of Antarctic territories.

THE sesquicentennial of the abortive insurrection by Irish revolutionaries led by Theobald Wolfe Tone (1763-1798) is being commemorated this month with 2 1/2-pence ruby and 3p blue-violet stamps, according to word received by New York Stamp Company from Eire's Minister for Posts and Telegraphs.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- One week ago Pennsylvania celebrated its 500th victory on the football field, but today the Red and Blue suffered its first defeat since 1946.

DETROIT, Nov. 6 -- Steve O'Neill, who gave Detroit one world championship and three American League runner-up clubs in his six-year stay here, was fired today as manager of the Tigers. He was the seventh major league pilot to lose his job this year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Science has developed a new operation to destroy frequent hallucinations of "ghost" hands and feet by patients after amputations, according to a Washington surgeon.

Scientists have been blowing soap bubbles to find out what makes metals strong, Sir Lawrence Bragg of Cambridge University, England, Nobel Prize winner in physics in 1915, reported last week in an address at a joint meeting of the Rochester Sections of the American Chemical Society and the Optical Society of America.

More than ten million persons are expected to visit the nation's schools during American Education Week, which officially opens today. Now in its twenty-eighth year, the open-school program will focus attention this week on the teachers' responsibility for "strengthening the foundations of our freedom."

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today adopted a resolution that gives the Trusteeship Council the right to be consulted by administering powers prior to any union between trust territories and colonial areas.

THE author explains that this is a book to be read, not studied. Her point is well taken. She has made a glowingly romantic story of French history, highlighting the scenes that interest her, skipping nimbly past connecting stretches and making small use of dates.

A blond Hamlet on the stage might prove a worth-while innovation if he could wear down the long tradition of dark Hamlets, but the blond locks in a black and white film appear snowy much of the time and make the young prince seem old.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Cecil Wright, who learned enough about law in prison to get out, was freed from Alcatraz today on a writ he obtained himself.

Art connoisseurs showed a preference for modern American painting over that of the early nineteenth century at an auction sale yesterday of valuable works from the collection of Ralph Blum of Beverley Hills, Calif., in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Greece and her problems were put aside for more than an hour today while the delegates of the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee talked about the movies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Use of atomic power for rocket propulsion is one of the more fantastic possibilities of the future.
The mortgage that has hung over the Seventy-seventh Division Association for twenty years was disposed of last night in an unusual ceremony on the main ballroom floor of the Roosevelt Hotel.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Russia won her fight here today to tighten the national implementation clause of the convention against genocide.
The first ship carrying Europe's homeless to the United States under the provisions of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 arrived in New York a few days ago.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Brig. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States Marine Corps, truce supervision Chief of Staff in Palestine, in a three-hour meeting with Arab leaders here this afternoon, told them that the Israeli Army dominated the military situation in Palestine, it was learned here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- In the aftermath of President Truman's smashing victory there is much fruitless speculation whether the outcome would have been different had Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, instead of Thomas E. Dewey, been the Republican nominee.

As an important phase of its industrialization program, India plans to double and possibly triple its production of plastics within the next three to four years, according to spokesmen for the delegation representing the All India Plastics Manufacturers Association.

His hero (a combination of his inarticulate giant, Jencic in "Hunky" and the ambitious Daniel Patterson of "Stride of Man") is Faljan the drover.

MADRID, Nov. 6 -- Indications of a new major shake-up in the Falange party came today with Gen. Francisco Franco's announcement that Carlos Ruiz, Civil Governor of Madrid, had been named provisional lieutenant general of Franco's personal bodyguard.

GENERAL EISENHOWER has taken Columbia the way he took the Normandy beach. By now, four months after his "landing," the entire university population of 35,000 -- students, professors, officers, trustees and janitors -- has happily surrendered and adores its conqueror.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 6 -- The American Jewish Comunity is on the threshold of a Jewish cultural renaissance, Philip Klutznick, of Chicago, said here today at the annual meeting of the National Finance Council of the National Jewish Welfare Board.

The red-hot intra-city football rivalry between Brooklyn College and C.C.N.Y. was resumed at Ebbets Field last night but the continuation of the series brought nothing but woe and discomfiture to the supporters of the Beavers.

One of two hold-up men who had robbed a Bronx gasoline station of $90 yesterday morning was injured and subsequently captured when the car in which the two were escaping hit a pillar of the IRT elevated structure on White Plains Avenue, the police reported.

A device that looks like an oversized radio tube has been developed to study magnetic lines of force. Dean Thorndike Saville of New York University's College of Engineering announced Yesterday that Dr. Samuel G. Lutz, chairman of the Electrical Engineering Department, and S.J. Tetenbaum, a graduate student, worked jointly on the project.

NEWARK, Del., Nov. 6 -- The value of non-professional theatres in the decentralization policy of the American National Theatre and Academy was emphasized here today at sessions of the ninth Delaware Dramatic Conference.

Seventy-four city veterans, former "permanently bed-ridden, chronic patients" of the Veterans Administration Hospital at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, are now at home caring for themselves, the Veterans Administration reported yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The Czech Communist party acted today to transform i-{ self into a tightly knit "elite" or-[ ganization, amid growing indica- { tions of a serious split in the{ party's high command.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 -- Californians, whose vote favored President Truman by a narrow margin, not only were as surprised as the rest of the nation at the election outcome, but reserved some particular bewilderment for their own state situation.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 6 -- President Peron sees President Truman's election as a victory for "those who know how to evaluate the effort of the working classes," according to a letter sent to Ambassador James Bruce today.

WHILE the comprehensive Bonnard exhibition at the Museum of Modern is still fresh in our memories, the Jacques Seligmann, Gallery has rendered a real service by opening a loan exhibition of early paintings by Vuillard.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 6 -- What is believed to be the world's thinnest paper has been put to use by chemists of the General Electric Works Laboratory here. The paper is used in electric capacitors, described by engineers as devices which store electricity for future use.

PROBABLY the best known type of lavender is the English variety, Lavendula officinalis. Its sweet-smelling flower spikes may be dried for sachets and its gray foliage provides accent in the herb or flower garden.
WASHINGTON, Nov 6 (AP) -- The Navy today issued the first pictures of the launching of its heavy long-range patrol plane, the Neptune P2V, from an aircraft carrier.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 6 -- Before another sellout crowd of 85,938, Michigan's football team rolled on to a 35-0 victory over Navy today, thereby registering the twenty-first consecutive triumph for the Wolverines.

FIELD AND STREAM is a magazine devoted to outdoor life and its issues contain a wide variety of stories on hunting, fishing and woods adventures. From among them Robeson Bailey has compiled a number devoted to hunting experiences in various parts of America.

A LEAK of confidential information from the office of Floyd Evans, a lumber magnate, threatens the business he has built up by hard work and by methods that have not always been strictly ethical. Evans calls in his trouble shooter, Steve Rourke, to stop the leak.

" CREOLE DUSK" is the third book W. Adolphe Roberts has written about the history and romance of New Orleans. This latest novel depicts the colorful period of the city after Reconstruction and, in particular, is concerned with the lively adventures of Yvon Olivier, a young doctor from an old and illustrious Creole family.

ON each of their anniversaries a message is read to marines everywhere that begins: "In November 10, 1775, a Corps of Marines was created by resolution of Continental Congress. Since that date many thousands of men have borne the name 'Marine.'"

A YOUNG couple with a gift of curiosity about primitive people can get into some queer situations. It was not enough for the Helmericks, Bud and Connie, to live with Indians and then to spend a year in the interior of Alaska far from civilization; they had to push on to the north shore of Alaska, 240 miles east of Point Barrow, at the mouth of Colville River, and settle there for a time.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Hadassah, women's Zionist organization of America, will build a $300,000 hospital in the Negeb. It will have fifty to sixty beds and will be the first in Israel's southern desert. It will be named in memory of Dr. Haim Yassky, Hadassah medical director who was slain by Arabs last April.

Of the various educational techniques used by the military services to speed wartime training, one of the most effective was the widespread use of films, film-strips and other visual aids. During 1943-1945 the military services had more than twice as many film showings as the motion picture industry had had for the entire country in all the years before the war.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The new polaroid land camera which will produce a photograph in one minute was demonstrated this week at the annual convention of the Photographic Society of America.

NELLIE LUTCHER is a living example of the phenomenon which provides a talent to suit the times. She is both performer and composer with an impetuous style which neatly splits the difference between old-time blues shouting and avant guard bop.

THIS useful reference book, prepared by and published for the Department of Information of the United Nations, is designed to explain the machinery of the organization and to show how it has been and is being used by the fifty-eight member Governments.

Bishop Loughlin placed four of its runners in the first five yesterday to take the team title in the Catholic high schools city-wide cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park William Berggren, Fordham Prep, was the individual winner with a slow 14:02.4 clocking for the two and one-quarter miles.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 6 -- The United Nations Appeal for Children raised only $1,235,391 of its $20,000,000 goal in the United States, because of impractical campaign arrangements, the national office reported today.

Before he performs an operation a surgeon scrubs his hands and arms for ten minutes at least. A liquid soap which contains hexachlorophene (phenol and chlorine compound) insures sterile hands in three minutes. The soap has been used for a year or so in the University of Michigan's hospital.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Chinese Communist radio today broadcast a statement of unity with Soviet Russia for world revolution. It bitterly attacked the United States.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The grain market on the Board of Trade was not very successful today in trying to extend its post-election advance into the fourth straight session. All cereals opened strong, July and September wheat hitting new seasonal highs, but prices slumped later.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- A $200,000 housing project for faculty and administration has been completed for the campus of Elmira College. Containing sixteen apartments, divided among four units, the development follows a policy of maintaining close student-faculty relationships.

HERE are three books which undertake to show three phases of American life, a rural community, a Midwestern small town, and a metropolitan suburb. They are not equally readable, but each in its own way shows not only a differing kind of life but a sharply differing approach to life.

OTTAWA, Nov. 6 -- Some time within the next few days W.L. Mackenzie King, who has been Prime Minister of Canada for more than twenty-one out of the last twenty-seven years, will hand in his resignation from that office to the Governor General, Viscount Alexander, and recommended the appointment of Louis S. St. Laurent as his successor.

THE film version of "Hamlet" is execrable in almost every way. It is hard to see how it could be worse. Its sins * * * begin by conceiving "Hamlet" as a series of pictorial effects, picturesque poses by a nineteenth-century melancholic, who, ascending and descending innumerable stairs, nurses a nameless sorrow whose cause we never know and about whose outcome we cannot care.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 6 -- Lehigh's eleven, rebounding from last week's loss to N.Y.U., toppled a favored Muhlenberg team, 35 -- 20, before 10,000 in Taylor Stadium today.

A blue-bannered booth at the Women's International Exposition ending tonight in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, has proved a veritable toyland for children and "lovers of little things."

The basing-point system, zoning prices and other methods used by American business and industry in computing uniform delivered prices for their products, are docketed for public trial this week in Washington before Senator Homer E. Capehart's trade policies subcommittee.

The fall series of free art lectures sponsored by the New York Public Library starts Tuesday at 6 P.M. with a lecture on "The Modern Approach to Interior Decoration." The lectures will be held each Tuesday at the same time through Jam 25 in Room 213.

The white-porticoed colonial mansion at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, Washington, D.C., has housed thirty-one tenants since John Adams moved in during October, 1800. The average tenancy has lasted four years and six months. Last week the thirty-first tenant -- the thirty-second President of the United States -- won a renewal of his lease in circumstances extraordinary in American history.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- French prophets after the debacle of their colleagues in the United States were somewhat diffident tonight about predicting the outcome of the elections that will be held tomorrow for a complete renewal of the Council of the Republic, the advisory body that has replaced the old French Senate.

TOWARD the end of his forty-three-year pastorate at Blue Hill, Maine, in 1837, the Rev. Jonathan Fisher humbled himself with an interior admonition: "My attachment to the world has been, and still is, too strong." Our secular age, taking stock of his prodigious activity, would be apt to conclude that a man who so loved the world as to accomplish in it all that he did ought to be proud of his attachment.

SCRIPT writer Bill Tracy has a wonderful idea for a new radio serial. He has been writing soap opera so long that he is completely fed up with it, and he thinks it would be more fun to do a serial about and detection.

AN unusual portrait of Jesus is the surprise in Mr. Blythe's novel about the beginnings of Christianity. With Christ's active, roving life as proof of endurance, he sees not a gentle Nazarene but a "bold Galilean" -- Nazareth was in Galilee -- deeply tanned by wanderings in the sun, toughly muscled from work as a carpenter.

Awesome power carried Army's unbeaten football forces to a one-sided victory over Stanford yesterday at the Yankee Stadium. Exploding in every period, the mighty men of Earl Blaik notched their seventh straight triumph of the campaign, this time by a 43-0 margin.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Plans for expansion of the campus of the University of Pennsylvania and construction of a number of new buildings were announced tonight by Harold E. Stassen, president of the university.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- A plan to give greater authority to the European organization under the Marshall Plan will be considered soon by a committee composed of men of Cabinet rank from nine participating countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- To attract the country's best managerial talent, salaries of Cabinet members and other high-ranking Federal officials would be increased by as much as $5,000 annually under a bipartisan bill proposed today for early consideration by the Democratic Congress.

" SWEET AND SOUR" is a collection of humorous short stories which not only survives the stern test of collection but actually seems to benefit from it. In its first story, the author is a boy in eastern Czechoslovakia with a powerful, though never to be realized, ambition to own a first-rate delicatessen.

ATHENS, Nov. 6 -- A latent governmental crisis was brought to a head last week-end when a deputy chief of the Liberal party, Sophocles Venizelos, suddenly declared that he and the greater portion of the party no longer had confidence in the leadership of their fellow party-member, Premier Themistocles Sophoulis.
WOMEN'S influence on car design and construction will be, perhaps, the outstanding development in the new models to be presented this fall and winter.

In their hours of relaxation they drink vast quantities of moonshine whisky. One of them, a man named Sullivan, talks wildly of a scheme for using the bacilli to prevent war by killing off a large portion of the earth's population and frightening, the survivors into fighting the plague instead of each other.
In all the explanations I have read of the failure to correctly forecast the Presidential election, it seems to me the outstanding reason for Republican party failure has been overlooked.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week was unaffected by the election results, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office. Business as usual included substantial reorders for women's outerwear and orders for January sales merchandise.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 6 -- A recheck of Passaic County's 310 voting machines here today resulted in verification of the 150-vote victory of Representative Gordon Canfield, Republican incumbent from the Eighth Congressional Disrict, over his Democratic opponent, Charles S. Joelson, in last Tuesday's general election.

LAST week's decision by the directors of RKO Radio Pictures to accede to the Government's persistent demand for divorcement of theatre ownership and operation from the production and distribution of motion pictures has set a precedent which is expected to affect the entire film industry.

The stock market was unable yesterday to make up its mind as to a definite direction. Prices started on a recovery theme, but soon bogged down under the weight of fresh selling which left final quotations highly ragged. Holders of securities were obviously searching for a clue to guide them out of the mental hazards that resulted from the unexpected victory of President Truman.

WHAT everyone knows about the "oldest living democracy," is, according to Mr. J. Christopher Herold, largely wrong. That it is vigorously alive, he does not question, but all other propositions and cliches concerning this sturdy nation he subjects to penetrating analysis in his charming new book. "The Swiss Without Halos."
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The threat of a French railway strike was still an unsettled prospect tonight as the coal strike, while declining in effect, approached its fifth week.

Rate of Army quartermaster spending in the first three months of the current fiscal year has shown an increase of 20 per cent over last year, according to a compilation of awards released by the New York quartermaster purchasing office.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Ohio State neatly trimmed an ambitious but inept band of Pittsburgh Panthers today, 41 to 0, to continue its football renaissance under Wes Fesler with its fifth victory of the year.

A TREK up to the Ninety-second Street "Y" is indicated for this afternoon, for the Dance Theatre Series opens with a performance by Nine Fonaroff and her company. Miss Fonaroff, who has expressed herself eloquently on the relationship between theatre and dance, has assembled a company of men and women, dancers and actors, for her program of three "choreographed plays."

PARIS -- L'ete de la Saint-Martin is Indian Summer to the French. It starts about Nov. 11, Saint Martin's Day, and rarely fails to bring warm, sunny days, a matter of prime importance in this period of limited coal. The autumn so far has been delightful and Paris is full of visitors.

MR. KOUWENHOVEN'S study of the arts in modern civilization explores the argument that where American culture has been partly shaped by western European traditions, its more enduring and expansive forms are indigenous.

THOUGH the latest, the fifteenth, of Walter R. Brooks' funny and wise stories about Freddy the pig and the Bean farm is called "Freddy Goes Camping," camping forms only the start and close of this wonderfully involved chronicle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Truman approved at a long conference this afternoon with James E. Webb, Director of the Budget, a policy of holding down expenditures to the lowest possible level which will meet the needs of the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The National Federation of Small Business, Inc., asked President Truman today to consider no candidate for appointment as Federal Trade Commissioner who would not give "full, complete, vigorous and impartial" support of the country's trade laws.

A change in strategy for medical scientists in command of the fight against cancer was indicated here yesterday when leading figures in the research field called for new studies on the puzzling relationships between a man's environment and the statistical chance that he will have a cancer.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- Pieces of pottery among the relics pumped two months ago from an old wreck lying in the Delaware River beneath eighteen feet of sand and silt have been identified as English ware of the last quarter of the Eighteenth Century.

In behalf of the Goddard Neighborhood Center, the performance of "Life With Mother" on the night of lqlov. 16 at the Ernipre Theatre has been taken over by persons interested ctively in the work of the organization. Mrs. John Nields is president of the institution's board of directors.

FLOWERING almond is, in my opinion, one of the loveliest of the old-fashioned shrubs. Yet today it receives little attention and only meager representation in our gardens. Planted in fall, this shrub blooms in spring and has vigorous growth, grace and beauty of bloom to recommend it.

A strong, free and economically sound state of Israel was predicted by James G. McDonald, representative of the United States to the new Jewish state, in a message read last night at the opening session of the second annual convention of the Labor Zionist Committee for Relief and Rehabilitation, Inc., at the New School for Social Research, 66 West, Twelfth Street.

The precarious orientation of the financial market place with worldwide inflation is lost momentarily in a welter of confused reactions to the Truman Administration's unexpected recapture of the executive and legislative branches of the Federal Government.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- A stunned silence that settled over this region after Tuesday's election began lifting rapidly toward week's end as voters of Massachusetts and Connecticut, especially, discussed the probable effects of the election results.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Nov. 6 -- An interesting visitor in Charles Town recently was Mrs. Anton Lang, widow of Anton Lang, who portrayed the part of Christ in the Passion Play, normally presented in Oberammergau, Germany, every ten years.

TOKYO, Nov. 6 -- The fear of carpet-bagging and of having their nation become an "economic colony" are conditioning Japanese thinking about foreign investments. From present indications the Cabinet's plan for "encouraging" such investments will incude a sharp limitation on profits convertible into foreign currencies and supervision over the terms of prospective deals.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 6 -- E.O. Jewell, well known port authority and general manager of the dock board here since March, 1942, has resigned as of Dec. 1, E.S. Binnings, dock board presdent, announced this week.

ANATOLE LITVAK, director-producer of "The Snake Pit," is momentarily running a dead heat with that unabashed idolater, George Jessel, in the Darryl F. Zanuck Admiration Sweepstakes. Mr. Litvak's enthusiasm is understandable.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Oct. 6 -- Thirty-two of the country's leading industrial scientists are attending a one-month course here on the fundamental techniques of using radiosotopes -- or "tracer atoms" -- in research work, it was announced today.

DURING the past five weeks Tallulah Bankhead has been straining the walls and foundations of the Plymouth Theatre by dragging audiences in for a whirl at Noel Coward's "Private Lives." Since Miss Bankhead of the Alabama clan is a vary determined lady it is probably a good thing that people come voluntarily without having their heads knocked together.

The left-wing international executive board of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, set up two committees yesterday to investigate a number of charges brought against Michael J. Quill, international president, and other members of his rightist bloc.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The sensational Chicago Cardinals, led by Charlie Trippi and Elmer Angsman with three touchdowns apiece, punched 21 points in both the second and fourth quarters today to rout the Detroit Lions, 56 -- 20, in a National Football League game.

It was a leisurely Sunday in Brooklyn Week-End Court. A few minor incidents came before Magistrate Abner C. Surpless and then the case of three men and eight women, who had been arrested early yesterday morning in a card game raid.

The people of the Netherlands are "welcoming" the Marshall Plan and believe that American aid will "help them regain their economic independence," Miss Marguerite A. Salomon, chairman of "Brooklyn Adopts Breukelen," said yesterday on her arrival by plane from the adopted Dutch town.

The regional director of the Northeast section of the United States Weather Bureau, which includes thirteen Northeastern states, is a modest husky man with blue eyes and a small neat mustache who is very pleased that his last name spelled backward or forward comes out the same way.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- All over Eastern Germany today soldiers of a new Germany army heard the urgings of Communist speakers to prepare to defend the new "People's Government" the Russian political experts were preparing for the Soviet zone.

Wearing the light blue and white uniform of their organization, 1,000 Catholic War Veterans and members of their women's auxiliary attended yesterday their thirteenth annual Armistice Day Memorial Mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Francis Poulenc, the eminent composer, made his first New York appearance last night at Town Hall, as accompanist for Pierre Bernac, baritone, who also had not been heard here previously, but at once established himself as a highly distinguished purveyor of song.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Greece has advised the United States that 1,951 persons, 885 of them this year, have been legally executed since the Communist-led guerrillas tried to win control of the country.

Marking the start today of an extensive month-long campaign against venereal disease, 45,000,000,000 units of penicillin will be distributed free to physicians and hospital out-patient department in this city for treatment of early syphilis and gonorrhea, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Business men and manufacturers here saw no reason to become excited over the lifting of Government controls on manufacture and supply covering a considerable range of industries. The Ministers responsible for the action describe it as designed to assist Britain's industrial efficiency and its power to export, but it is not expected that the results will be either immediate or spectacular, at least so far as the public is concerned.
Resignation of Theodore W. Kheel from his $15,000-a-year post as director of the City Division of Labor Relations was announced-yesterday at City Hall.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers ran a dogged jinx out of Forbes Field today and overwhelmed the Green Bay Packers, 38 -- 7, in the process. A crowd of 26,058 saw the Steelers end a three-game losing streak in a burst of scoring which tied the Pittsburgh all-time National Football League point total.

Stephen S. Tolk, a professional gambler, was seized yesterday in Philadelphia in connection with the so-called Park Avenue charity gambling party, it was announced here by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

The Budapest Quartet made its first New York appearance of the season in yesterday's New Friends of Music program at Town Hall. It played Mozart's Quartet in D minor (K. 421) and was joined by Milton Katims, viola, in the same composer's Quintet in C (K. 515).

Infantile paralysis cases in this city dropped sharply last month, the Health Department reported yesterday. In October, 140 eases and five deaths were reported, compared with 265 cases and nine deaths in September. Cases for the year to Nov. 1 totaled 620 with twenty-five deaths.
The General Telephone Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $2,175,878 in the nine months ended with September, Harold V. Bozell, president, says in his report today.

The recent national elections have convincingly demonstrated that the state "is not an end in itself but exists for the person," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, said yesterday.

VIENNA, Nov. 7 -- Investigation has established that Russian soldiers arrested Irving Ross, member of the Economic Cooperation Administration, took him to the Soviet Kommandatura and held him in temporary custody some time before he was murdered by assailants who, according to a witness, attacked him in his automobile.

The acquisition by Lieut. Col. Ralph H. Isham of two great additional portions of the archives of James Boswell -- the papers found at Fettercairn House and a further cache from Malahide Castle -- is an event of the first importance to literary and historical scholarship.
When James Boswell was writing his "Life of Johnson," he applied, among many other friends of Samuel Johnson, to Sir Joshua Reynolds for material.

ROME, Nov. 7 -- Foreign Minister Karl Gruber of Austria arrived in Rome today for a stay of three days during which he will sign two conventions. One is to facilitate the interchange of goods and persons between the Austrian and the Italian Tyrol and the other to prepare for negotiations to strengthen the political and economic ties between Italy and Austria.

Democracy should be more than just a word. That is the feeling of the parents who founded the new Experimental School at 31 West 110th Street to succeed the famed Horace Mann-Lincoln School, which went out of existence last spring after a prolonged court battle.

"I would fain write to you in my own hand, but really cannot. * * *" Having thus begun a letter to his faithful friend Temple in April, 1785, James Boswell, strange mixture of the good and bad, the great and small, laid down forever the pen which had been idle hardly a moment in nearly forty years, which death alone could still.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 7 -- The Open All-Age Stake of the Connecticut Field Trial Association was won by Earlsmoor Patina, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank and handled by Willie Witte today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 7 -- Something like a panic has seized thousands of persons, mostly French, who, fearing that the United States might again block all dollar balances belonging to Europeans, had sought safety by putting their capital into Swiss francs when they heard in mid-October that the Swiss Government thought of reforming coinage.

Reflecting the substantially larger sales and other income of the Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries in the first nine months of 1948 over the similar period last year, net income rose to $38,035,151 from $21,403,035, according to the report issued for publication today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Trade in grain futures last week was considerably smaller than the preceding week but nearly as broad as a year ago.

Declaring that too many persons felt they must do everything "on their own," Bishop Charles K. Gilbert of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York said yesterday that churchgoers would find it difficult to be good Christians unless willing to accept aid from the Lord.

The Rev. Brother Thomas Austin, director of St. Ann's Academy, 153 East Seventy-sixth Street, has been appointed Provincial of the Marist Brothers in the United States, a Catholic order, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Brother Louis Omer, who had held the position for the last six years.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Considerable information about an alleged supply line by which men and arms have been transported from Czechoslovakia to Israel was reported tonight to have been supplied by the British Government to Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The Schiaparelli story this midseason is in spectacular necklines, especially for evening. By standing away from the bust, necklines emphasize its contours.

Prices for cotton for future delivery turned firm last week following the election. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange at the end of the week showed advances of 29 to 104 points in contrast to declines of 25 to 39 points in the previous week.

A diocesan-wide Protestant Episcopal mission was opened yesterday morning with a sermon by the Rev. Bryan Green, rector of St Martin's Church, Birmingham, England, in which he reluctantly observed that most people go to churches only for "matching, hatching and dispatching."

The inability of the Eightieth Congress to get together on a liberal program, overconfidence and a vigorous campaign by President Truman were the three main factors responsible for the Republican defeat in the recent elections, in the opinion of Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York.

A movement to organize a special national chapter of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States for amputee and paraplegic patients in veterans hospitals was started here yesterday by the Fort Tryon Post, No. 3037, VFW.

The improving Football Yankees ran up a 38-6 score on the Los Angeles Dons yesterday at the Stadium to keep in the chase for the All-America Conference Eastern Division title. The triumph put the Bombers in a second-place tie with Baltimore, just one game behind Buffalo.
HONOLULU, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, the Memphis dentist, won the $10,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament today.

Dr. J.J. Osuna, former Commisisoner of Education in Puerto Rico, appear to have misinterpreted the finding and conclusions of the Harlem Project Report in his recent statement of Harlem schoools. In doing so, he had badly served the sincere and conscientious guidance experts, psychologist social workers and other skilled personnel who worked on this project and more important, the very children whom he is interested.

A new series of programs from Hollywood, Calif., starring Don Ameche, is scheduled to be heard on a Monday-through-Friday basis over the CBS network, with the American Tobacco Company meeting the cost of sponsorship. While neither the exact format nor starting date could be immediately ascertained, the program was expected to be in the nature of a "showcase" for varied talents.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- France and the three Western zones of occupation in Germany are about to sign an important commercial and payments pact, according to informed sources here. Only a few details of agreement remain to be settled.

Headed by Col. Hurnberto Mariles, who came through with a faultless performance aboard the veteran chestnut gelding Resorte, the Mexican Army team annexed the $1,000 International Military Stake as the sixth day of the Sixtieth National Horse Show closed last night at Madison Square Garden.

Confronted with the hopeless task of upsetting the high-flying Philadelphia Eagles, the New York Football Giants tried their best to accomplish the feat yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Their best, as the saying goes, was not nearly good enough, and the Eagles won with comparative ease, 35 -- 14.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Satchel Paige made a spectacular effort today but his Kansas City Royals dropped the first game of a baseball double-header to Gene Bearden's All-Stars, 8 -- 7, before 10,000 fans at Wrigley Field.
Reduction of Federal spending in the fiscal year 1949-1950 by $2,300,000,000 to $3,400,000,000 was recommended yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

Results in the fourth round of the annual championship finals at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday left Carl Pilnick in the lead with a score of 3 -- 0 and one game, with H.M. Phillips, postponed. Pilnick's tie with Larry Evans, club champion, was broken when the latter was defeated in his fourth round match by Theodore A. Dunst.
The reassembling in this country, after the most extraordinary vicissitudes, of the precious archives of the eighteenth-century English biographer James Boswell was disclosed over the week-end.

Robert H. Baxter Jr., formerly chief process engineer in the chemicals departments of the Ansco division, General Aniline and Film Corporation, has been appointed chief design engineer of Sharp Dohme, Inc., Philadelphia. He succeeds J.M. Waligora, who resigned.

Industrial and materials handling equipment valued at $8,800,000 will be offered for sale in New York and New Jersey during November by the War Assets Administration, Walter F. Downey, WAA regional director, announced over the week-end.

The discovery of a new type of infectious mouse cancer that apparently can be passed from one animal to another by injection of a milky fluid produced by malignant growth was announced to leading cancer experts yesterday by the president of the Japanese Cancer Society.
TOKYO, Nov. 7 -- Joseph B. Keenen, Chief Prosecutor in the Tojo trial, said today that General MacArthur last July had predicted Truman's election and had so informed the White House.

In his review of my novel "Doctor Faustus" in Books of the Times, Oct. 29, Orville Prescott has introduced a political remark which stands in near of correction. He says of me: "He cannot take public notice of the Nazis in his native country until they had come to power.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 7 -- After listening for two days to criticism of the United Nations handling of the Palestine problem, representatives of 250,000 members of Hadassah, women's Zionist Organization of America, voted this morning for direct peace negotiations between Israel and the Arab states.

Leading from the start, Earl Foster of the New York Pioneer Club took individual honors in the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior cross-country championship, run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. He paced the field of forty-three competitors over the four-mile course in 21:08.5.

Dr. Lillian Gilbreth, 70 years old, mother of eleven children and president of a firm of consulting engineers, received yesterday the eighteenth annual Woman's Association Award for Eminent Achievement at the twenty-second yearly friendship dinner of women's groups in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 7 -- An Israeli Government spokesman said today that "Israel has received no military assistance whatsoever from Russia." The statement was provoked, according to the spokesman, by newspaper reports about a "Russian-sponsored supply line to Israel alleged to have been 'revealed' in Paris to Dr. Bunche."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 -- The election returns may have dampened the spirit of steel people but it had no effect on output. Steel ingot production last week stayed at 99 per cent of rated capacity and is not expected to drop below that point until the Christmas holiday season.
That little yarn in the papers recently about how a citizen of Nyack, N.Y., had been impelled to call his home community the "most honest town in the world" has had results.

Seven technical papers have been prepared for presentation and discussion at the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, which opens a three-day session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Wednesday.

Three new exhibitions of primary interest this week include the 1948 Annual Exhibition of Contemporary American Painting at the Whitney Museum, opening on Saturday; the show of the veteran American painter, Walt Kuhn, "Fifty Years a Painter," opening today at the Durand-Ruel Gallery, and a retrospective exhibition of paintings by Kandinsky, covering the period 1908-44, opening tomorrow at the Sidney Janis Gallery.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- An "amazing" deterioration in the morale of the soldiers and officers in the Soviet Army of occupation has developed during the last six months, according to a senior United States official in Germany.

Mayor O'Dwyer has moved to create within his office, subject to his supervision, a Division of Radio Broadcasting to handle the activities of radio stations WNYC and WNYC-FM, constituting the Municipal Broadcasting System, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, Monday, Nov. 8 -- Charles de Gaulle's Reunion of the French People was swept into a leading position in the advisory Council of the Republic, almost complete returns from yesterday's indirect elections revealed. The Communists lost heavily.

A tug-of-war for control of the New York City schools is taking place between officers of the Boar dof Education and officials of the municipal government, a monograph issued today by Teachers College, Columbia University, charges.

The total revenue of the city-owned transit system for July, the first month of operation with an increased fare, was $261,633 more than total operating costs, it became known yesterday. It was the first time in two years that the network of municipal subway, elevated, street car and bus lines escaped an operating deficit.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Berl Locker, chairman of the Jerusalem section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, warned in a cablegram today against any fund-raising campaign for Israel "apart from the United Palestine appeal."

The unexpected result of Tuesday's balloting brought but minor disturbance in the foreign exchange market last week. It appeared only to affect the Swiss free franc; pound sterling was steady and the Canadian free dollar turned up at the close from mid-week heaviness.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 7 -- The Israeli Government will await the receipt of proposals for new military lines in the Negeb before taking action on the United Nations Security Council's order to restore the positions of Oct. 14 in the southern desert.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- With seven men knocking in a goal apiece, the Detroit Red Wings tightened their National Hockey League lead tonight by swamping the second plate Boston Bruins, 7 to 3, before 13 580 fans.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko called on the Soviet Army today to remain in complete military preparedness but said the growing forces of peace "will not allow a new war."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett and Henry Wallace, the defeated Progressive party candidate for President, tonight attended a big reception at the Soviet Embassy. They were among hundreds of guests who feasted on sturgeon, caviar and vodka in celebration of the thirty-first anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

ROME, Nov. 7 -- Speaking in Milan this evening at a commemoration of the Bolshevik revolution, Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti made a strong plea in favor of peace between the Soviet Union and the West. "I can assure you," he said fervently, "that it is quite possible for Socialist and capitalist nations to live together in peace."

NANKING, Nov. 7 -- For the second time this week Gen. Pai Chung-hsi, who is regarded here as one of the most capable of Nationalist military men, has rejected Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's request that he assume field command of the vital Suchow battle area, it was learned tonight.
Four new films, including importations from Germany and Austria, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 7 -- A colorful and boisterous welcome, befitting his dual role of election day miracle man and this town's No. 1 vacationer, was accorded to President Truman here this afternoon.
Dwellings and small apartment buildings formed the bulk of realty passing to new control in transactions reported in three boroughs of the city over the week-end.

On Oct. 28 you published a letter from Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president of the Commerce and Industry Association, on the subject of air pollution and the Sharkey bill. On behalf of the Committee on Smoke Abatement of the Citizens Union, which helped to prepare that bill as a means of achieving real progress toward making this a clean city, I would like to comment.
Thirty-nine Jewish refugees, mostly survivors of Nazi concentration camps, arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on their way to new homes and jobs in this country.

Tchaikovsky's "Eugen Onegin" was revived by the City Opera Company at City Center last night, after a season's absence from the company's repertory. As in its previous performances, the work was performed in Russian.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Homage was paid to the dead of two World Wars at memorial services today throughout Britain and the Commonwealth. Here in London 5,000 persons stood bareheaded in drenching rain around the Cenotaph in Whitehall at a service attended by King George.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks defeated the New York Rangers in a fiercely contested National Hockey League game before 16,780 tonight, 4 -- 2, a result that put the teams into a tie for fifth place.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The first United Nations "interne" program held entirely for government civil servants has been successful beyond the fondest hopes held for it, G.N.T. Widdrington, in charge of the program, declared today.

Bendix Home Appliances, Ltd., will use twenty periodicals for an extensive advertising campaign in Great Britain on the Bendix automatic washer, it was announced over the week-end. Sixty separate advertisements have been prepared for the drive, it was added.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Bethlehem's Bulldogs pounded out a 16-7 victory over the Wilkes-Barre Bullets today in an American League football game. Billy Kline uncorked the circuit's longest run of the year as he raced 95 yards with a punt to score for the Bulldogs.
The re-election of President Truman, Senator Robert A. Taft declared last week, shows that it is almost impossible to put an Administration out of office at the very peak of a prosperity boom."

Eighteen manuscripts that are being insured for $700,000 will be lent by the New York Public Library for an exhibit at the Baltimore Museum of Art from Jan. 27 to March 13, it was announced yesterday by Ralph A. Beals, director of the library.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Cleveland' s champion Browns rolled to their ninth straight All-America Conference triumph of the season today, spanking the Baltimore Colts, 28 to 7, before 32,314.

SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 7 -- The four-engine Boeing Stratocruiser, world's largest commercial transport, has been approved by the Civil Aeronautics Administration for use at a gross weight of 142,400 pounds, Wellwood E. Beall, vice president of the Boeing Airplane Company, announced here today.
The weather turned more seasonal yesterday, with a sparkling, though mild, autumn atmosphere succeeding the summery and foggy spell of the preceding twenty-four hours.

The aristocrat of Southern football, Georgia Tech and North Carolina joined the Dixiecrats in the miseries as the returns came in Saturday. And for Pennsylvania, Missouri and Baylor, too, it was a day of lamentation, not to overlook the impressarios of the bowl games.

A greater share of Federal funds for early use in harbor improvement here was asked yesterday by the Port of New York Authority, which cited a backlog of about $20,000,000 of work authorized for this port but held up for lack of money.
PRETORIA, Union of South Africa, Nov. 7 -- Full seriousness of the new currency regulations in so far as they affect imports from the United States is coming home to South African merchants.

Persons who resent the mention of money in the pulpit overlook the fact that "the amount and spirit of their giving constitute the acid test of their religious profession," the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122nd Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Most of the talk in the City and particularly in the stock markets in the past week has been about the plans for nationalization of the British steel industry and the results of the American Presidential election.

In his last annual report a dean of the New York University School of Law, Arthur T. Vanderbilt, now Chief Justice of New Jersey, strikes a note that should be heard by thoughtful men everywhere. In urging that law schools become centers for "legal scholars" the jurist suggests that such centers should "welcome the cooperation of laymen who are interested in the law."

Openings of spring ready-to-wear lines attracted many buyers to the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Although some spring orders were placed, many buyers planned to shop thoroughly before placing future commitments.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Something like a revolution in British trade union policy was proposed today by the General Council of the Trades Union Congress in a report on methods of increasing the productivity of British labor for the benefit of the nation's economic recovery campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- With the convening of the Eighty-first Congress still two months away, the broad outlines of the inevitable showdown between liberal and standpat Republican members of the Senate already were taking shape today.

DONORA, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Twenty-one residents who became ill in the smothering smog which resulted in nineteen deaths last week in this mill town will soon leave for a week's rest in North Carolina.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Jack Sutphen, in his boat Rum Dum, swept the annual three-session pre-winter dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

The second half of the program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Dimitri Mitropoulos, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, was devoted to two display-works for violin, with Isaac Stern as soloist. Before these offerings which consisted of Bartok's "Rhapsody," No. 2, and Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole," came the Prelude to Wagner's "Lohengrin" and Chausson's Symphony in B flat major, carried over from last week's schedules.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7 -- A 1949 budget of $1,491,955 for the National Jewish Welfare Board was endorsed by the board's national finance council here today.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 7 -- The result of the Presidential election in the United States had no influence on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange. Dull conditions rule there on the expectation that the era of large industrial profits has come to an end.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- The Democratic victory of last Tuesday was construed immediately as bullish on the grain markets and was the signal for a general buying wave that carried cereals and soy beans to sharply higher levels.

QUEBEC, Nov. 7 -- More than 50 per cent of Canada's newsprint production is threatened with shortages if present drought conditions continue in Quebec Province, it is learned here. At least ten big companies will be among those affected, these including Consolidated Paper, E.B. Eddy Company, Canadian International Paper, Howard Smith Paper Mills, Donnacona Paper, Anglo Canadian Pulp and Paper Mills, Quebec North Shore, Price Brothers, Lake St. John Paper, and St. Lawrence Paper Mills.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears scored on a 64-yard aerial strike on the first play from scrimmage and rolled on to defeat the Los Angeles Rams, 21 to 6, in a National Football League battle before 56,263 fans today.
