Richard Dyer-Bennet, who presented a program on Saturday night at Town Hall, is a unique performer. In addition to being a singer, he is an excellent guitarist, and besides being an entertainer, he is a composer and a musicologist.

There has been a lot of talk about Mike Jacobs using me for a sucker, but that's all wrong. If it wasn't for Mike Jacobs I would never have got to be champion. He fixed it for me to get a crack at the title, and he never once asked me to do anything wrong or phony in the ring.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 7 (AP) -- The end of the string came today for Hugh Devore's Brown Indians from St. Bonaventure as the vastly under-rated Canisius Golden Griffins ground out a 14-6 victory.

LEWES, Del., Nov. 7 -- The harried three-day career of Mr. and Mrs. I.W. Tarburton as nurses to a brood of 300 baby sea horses was closed here today when the tiny fishes died, despite frantic efforts to keep the family together. Mrs. Tarburton is general manager of the Delbay Seafood plant.

LAUREL SPRINGS, N.C., Nov. 7 (UP) -- Representative Robert L. Doughton, Democrat, of North Carolina, who will head the Ways and Means Committee in the Eighty-first Congress, said today that it might be difficult to raise enough money through taxes to carry out fully the program laid down in President Truman's campaign platform.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Nov. 7 -- To passers-by along Newbridge Road this morning it looked as if some of the seven sons of the late Michael F. Dwyer, veteran farmer of this community, who carry on the farm for their mother, were throwing away thousands of bushels of potatoes.

The annual County Fair under the auspices of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will be held all day Wednesday and in the evening at the church parish house, 2 East Ninetieth Street.

A second book of pictures of George Bernard Shaw this year will be distributed next week. Oxford University Press brought out in July Feliks Topolski's "Portrait of G.B.S.," a collection of drawings in pen, brush, charcoal, pencil and oil, depicting Mr. Shaw in many moods.

ATHENS, Nov. 7 -- The Greek Government announced tonight it had postponed the execution of ten merchant marine labor unionists scheduled for tomorrow. They had been convicted by a military tribunal last week of subversive activity.

Expansion of the use of vending machines, particularly in the soft drink "cup machine" field, were predicted last week as being "practically limitless," by Sam Kresberg, executive vice president of Drink-O-Mat Industries Corporation, one of the largest vending machine producing companies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 7 -- Yugoslav Communist party leaders celebrated the Russian anniversary last night with a public affirmation of their unreserved support for Soviet foreign policy against the "American-led imperialist front" and an equally strong and unequivocal reaffirmation of their fidelity to the views of Premier Marshal Tito.

Completely renovated and refurbished, the 22,500-ton Queen of Bermuda will return to the New York-Bermuda service on Feb. 12, John Walsh, General Manager of Furness, Withy Co. in this country, announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Employers and maritime unions, deadlocked since Sept. 2, announced agreement tonight on a formula for possible settlement of the long West Coast strike.

HARRISVILLE, N.H., Nov. 7. -- Edwin H. Cooper of Brookline, Mass., writer, lecturer and World War I hero, was drowned in Silver Lake yesterday, apparently in a fall from his motorboat. He was at the lake closing the family cottage. He was 67.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 7 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and his wife and two sons arrived here late this afternoon for a two-week rest in the Arizona sun after his strenuous political campaign.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Eliahu Epstein, special representative of Israel to the United States, asserted here today that within the past few days a major Arab country had made "significant" peace overtures to Israel.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The striking French miners' union today invited representatives of the Parisian labor unions to visit the strike-bound northern mine fields and to give the lie to Government reports that up to 50 per cent of the miners were back on the job after five weeks of striking.

THAT was a real good football team which Penn State brought out of its mountain fastness on Saturday and put on public display before 80,000 Franklin Field witnesses, most of whom were singularly unappreciative of the class and power of the Nittany Lions. In the main they were rabid rooters for unbeaten Penn with a long standing and deeply ingrained feeling of superiority over the pretenders from the central part of the Commonwealth.

Although Marian Anderson has become almost a national institution, she sings as if her life depended on giving her very best. And so it was again last night at Carnegie Hall in her first New York recital of the season.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Ch. Magic of Mardormere, greyhound belonging to the Mardormere Kennels of Glen Head, L.I., gained the best-in-show award today in the tenth annual all-breed event of the Union County Kennel Club at the Elizabeth Armory.

Representative Jacob K. Javits declared last night that the American people immediately should call on President Truman to honor campaign pledges by granting a $100,000,000 loan to Israel, extending full recognition and exchange of ambassadors and lifting the arms embargo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Farm income reached a post-war peak in September and took a downturn in October. A Department of Agriculture report showed today that receipts from sale of farm products dropped 3 per cent below those of October last year.

Archbishop Athenagoras of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America and Patriarch-elect of Constantinople, was honored yesterday at a liturgical service in the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 8 -- The Tripartite Pact of 1940 between Germany, Italy and Japan was "a compact made between aggressor nations in furtherance of their aggressive purposes," said a ruling today by the International Military Tribunal trying former Premier Hideki Tojo and twenty-four other Japanese leaders as war criminals.

Ralph Staiger of 240 East 124th Street, an 18-year-old who is on parole from Elmira Reformatory, was arrested yesterday on a charge of felonious assault after he had fired five shots at short range, but without a hit, at two detectives in the New York Central Railroad yards at West 225th Street and the Hudson River.

Probably one of the most carefully worded theatrical announcements was issued yesterday. Conceived by top men in their field, the notice, sent out on stationery of the Playwrights Company, briefly said:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Errol Flynn will play Soames Forsyte opposite Greer Garson in "The Forsyte Saga," which will go before the cameras at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in December, the studio has announced.

Bob Chappuis, the Brooklyn Dodgers' pitcher from Michigan, yesterday cracked an all-America Conference passing mark set by Glen Dobbs two years ago by completing twenty-six of fifty-one aerials against the Buffalo Bills at Ebbets Field.

The Rev. Dr. Raymond S. Haupert, president of Moravian College and Theological Seminary, Bethlehem, Pa., spoke at a "Moravian College Day" service yesterday morning in the First Moravian Episcopal Church, Lexington Avenue and Thirtieth Street.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- T e text of Marshal Bulganin's Order of the Day today, the thirty-first anniversary of the Russian revolution, as broadcast by the Moscow radio, follows:

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the General Assembly, set a United Nations precedent today by appealing direct to the Greek rulers to suspend execution of death sentences upon ten trade unionists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- With increased production still the dominant theme in world food planning, high producing countries face serious marketing troubles unless a program of orderly distribution is worked out, the director of the Food and Agriculture Organization said today.

Elmo Roper, public opinion analyst, declared in his weekly broadcast yesterday over the Columbia Broadcasting network that the scientific sampling poll had proved its worth beyond any doubt and was not at fault when it came up with the wrong answer in the recent election.
BOSTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- With Sammy Baugh passing for two touchdowns, the Washington Redskins today defeated the Boston Yanks, 23 -- 7, before 13,659 fans at Fenway Park.

An organized movement to bring about a closer balance of costs with prices and sales volume will be started next week by the National Wholesale Druggists Association, it was made known over the weekend by E. Allen Newcomb, the group's executive secretary.
HERFORD, Germany, Nov. 7 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery tonight began the first of a series of military talks designed to weld the armies of Western Europe into a unified force.

It now appears that there was another pre-election miscalculation. This was that the voters were selecting a candidate who, with his family, would spend the next four years in the White House. The successful candidate, a Mr. Truman, will not do precisely this. The ceiling of the East Room is sagging, that of the Blue Room is shaky.

Mayor O'Dwyer's recent conference at Gracie Mansion to discuss the Sharkey bill and his later remarks last week about air-pollution control seem to imply a willingness to consider changes in organization to combat smoke. The Mayor will find, we think, that no one will be disposed to quibble with him about details as long as he finds some way to get the anti-smoke job done effectively.

Five years ago, on Nov. 20, 1943. the United States threw its pride and hope on the beaches of a narrow island here, no larger than Central Park. Three days later 6,000 men lay dead on its coral rubble.

In the full pride of its power, Soviet Russia yesterday celebrated the thirty-first anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution with a display of military might equaled in times of ostensible peace only by the military parades which Hitler used to stage to intimidate the world.

The names of more than 500 members of Air Force Reserve units in the 2230th Air Force Reserve Training Center have been removed from the roster for non-attendance at training meetings, it was announced yesterday by the Air Force Reserve Training Center at Mitchel Air Force Base.

Inventory headaches continue, but except in the textile industry they are less severe than a few months ago, according to the opinions garnered from a "How's Business?" survey simultaneously conducted among members of the New York Credit Men's Association, the Chicago Association of Credit Men and the Los Angeles Credit Managers Association.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 7 -- The latest analyses of the economic position of the Netherlands and Belgium have convinced top-financial authorities in both countries that realization of the Benelux Economic Union by 1950 will be impossible unless the project is underwritten by the United States.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The San Francisco 49ers scored their tenth consecutive All-America Conference victory today at the expense of the Chicago Rockets, beating Coach Ed McKeever's team, 44 -- 21, before 25,306, at Kezar Stadium.

Carrot and escarole are two plentiful and thriftily priced vegetables that aren't used as often as they deserve to be. Families are apt to rebel if carrots appear too frequently on the menu, but that's probably because they're always prepared in the same way.

Organized labor in New England has joined with industrial management to protect the industrial prosperity of that region by demanding legislative action in the next Congress to clarify recent legal decisions regarding price formulas, Arthur Keating, president of the Trimont Manufacturing Company, Roxbury, Mass., disclosed in an interview at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here last week.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Nov. 8 -- Officials of the Korean Government here said today they had received reports of mass uprisings in Soviet-occupied North Korea in which 6,000 or more Koreans had been killed. There was no confirmation from other sources.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda said today that President Truman's surprise election may force him to carry out "the program of international cooperation put forward by [Henry A.] Wallace.''

Because the United Nations failed to implement its own resolution, the part that it plays with regard to the state of Israel has changed fundamentally in the last year, Dr. Nahum Goldman, political representative of Israel to the United Nations, said here last night.

Dr. Nelson P. Mead, former acting president of City College and for forty-five years a member of its History Department, will retire on Feb. 1, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Morton Gottschall, Dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 7 -- Hamid Frangie, Lebanese Foreign Minister, predicted today in an interview that Israel would refuse to comply with the Security Council's order to withdraw to the positions of Oct. 14 in the Negeb or with any similar order that might be issued regarding Galilee. He was convinced that the imposition of sanctions against the Israelis would be vetoed by the Soviet Union.

PEIPING, Nov. 7 -- Sixty-four of 120 students at the College of Chinese Studies, which has been famous in China thirty years, have definitely decided to leave Peiping before Dec. 1 as a result of civil war developments. The college, popularly known as "the Peiping Language School," is closely allied both in personnel and curriculum with Yale University's Institute of Far Eastern Languages.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Preparatory work on the proposed North Atlantic defense pact between the United States and Canada and five nations of Western Europe was reported today to have been undertaken by the permanent commission of the Brussels Treaty powers in London.

Shades of the recent election extended right into the Jamaica Race Track yesterday. As is always the case, every one of the eight races on the program had its favorite, and every favorite was played with reasonable confidence. But, as is not always the case, every horse selected by the "pollsters" ran according to form, according to the form followed by the G.O.P. ticket last week, that is.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 8 (AP) -The Arab countries have rejected an Iraqui proposal for a united Arab military command in Palestine, Premier Muzahim Amin elPachachi said today.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The underground network of pipelines that fed aviation fuel to the major fighter and bomber airfields of Britain during the war is to be put back into service, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican of New Jersey, chairman of the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities, was indicted today on charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government of the United States and of filing false claims against it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- A prediction that the United States might exhaust its present reserve of uranium in thirty years, if the mineral's present assumed rate for use for making atomic bombs is continued, was made public tonight from a paper to be delivered at the annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute.

Mounting interest in adult education throughout New York State was reported yesterday by Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, at a conference sponsored by the New York Adult Education Council.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Appointment of Norman Collins, a controller of the state-owned British Broadcasting Corporation's television service, to the new board of governors of the British Film Institute, announced today, was taken in film and broadcasting circles here as confirming reports of plans for a close link between the film industry and the BBC's television services.

The outlook for settlement of the twenty-five-day-old strike of 3,000 New York beer drivers improved last night with an announcement that the rank-and-file committee representing the strikers had made peace with international officers of the United Brewery Workers, CIO.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 8 -This city's first antiques show was formally opened this afternoon by Mayor Flank Eggers at the Jersey City Woman's Club, 375 Fairmount Avenue, to the strains of old songs played by a music box made in Rahway in 1865.

Retail stores here are lagging behind the rest of the nation in launching holiday promotions, Howard P. Abrahams, director of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, disclosed yesterday. This conclusion is based on a mail survey just completed of department and specialty stores throughout the country, he stated.

Dr. William B. Rawls, as incoming president of the New York County Medical Society, devoted much of his recent inaugural address to an attack on "compulsory health insurance." Unfortunately, the method of his assault was largely misrepresentation and name-calling.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Unofficial calculations tonight gave Charles de Gaulle's party, the Reunion of the French People, 107 of the 264 seats so far filled in the second Chamber, the Council of the Republic. Fiftysix other seats are to be filled by the overseas territories, next Sunday and later.

Concern over apparent contradictions in United States policy in Palestine was expressed yesterday by Michael S. Comay, head of the British Commonwealth Division of the Israeli Foreign Office and a member of the Israeli mission to the United Nations. He was interviewed in the Israeli Consulate, 16 East Sixty-sixth Street.

The new 9,200-ton Ivaran Line freighter Borgholt, Norway's most modern contribution to the world's express cargo routes, will make her maiden voyage from New York today, bound for the Philippine Islands, Hongkong and Shanghai.

Responding to "Open School Week" invitations issued by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, the United Parents Associations and the city's public school teachers and principals, thousands of parents visited classrooms throughout the city yesterday to see for themselves how their children were faring with the "three R's."

AVALON, Calif., Nov. 8 (UP) -Jerome Cady, aged 40, a screen writer, was found dead today on board his yacht off Catalina Island. An overdose of sleeping pills caused the death, a preliminary investigation showed.

PARIS, Nov. 8 Russia and Yugoslavia working as a team conducted the United Nations longest filibuster today in an attempt to block final action on the Balkan dispute until the expected resignation of the Greek Government.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 8 -Optimism grows here that the election of President Truman and a Democratic Congress in the United States enhances Brazil's chances to obtain financial help to develop mining, transportation, manufacturing and agriculture.
Shipping officials in Washington and members of the maritime industry expect last week's Democratic victory to mean smoother sailing for the post-war Merchant Marine program.
PARIS, Nov. 8 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet twice tomorrow, once behind closed doors and once publicly, to discuss the Palestine problem, now at a critical stage.

They did not know precisely what nor how, but speakers for literature, music, drama and the plastic arts expressed confidence yesterday that something valuable and lasting would come out of the confusion of the contemporary age.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, the Democratic National Chairman, disclosed today that he intended to bar from positions of party leadership those who bolted the ranks to take an active part in founding the States' Rights Democratic party.

The Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Nov. 17 on an issue of $9,000,000 of electric plant revenue bonds dated Nov. 1, 1948, and due on Nov. 1 front 1949 to 1988.

Marking the inspired riding of the Mexican Army, one of its officers, Col. Humberto Mariles, took the international individual military championship challenge trophy at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night, but a Canadian, Lieut. W. R. Ballard, gave the team pause during the matinee.

Carey Transportation, Inc., has purchased the garage building at 417-21 East Ninety-fourth Street, extending through to Ninety-fifth Street and fronting 180 feet on the East River Drive, from Henry Herman and will use it as a bus terminal.

Dr. Ryojun Kinoshita's announcement that in Japan "a new kind of malignant growth" had been discovered, which does not occur spontaneously but which can be induced in mice by injecting abdominal fluid from a victim, is of importance. Though Dr. Kinoshita does not regard this discovery as another proof that cancer is caused by a virus, some of the specialists who heard him at the American Cancer Society's meeting were of a different mind.

NANKING, Nov. 8 -- The Kuomintang's civil war effort became more than ever today the battle of one man as the uncompromising Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, surrounded by a host of his despondent followers, called on the party to rally around him for "another eight long years" of war against the Communists.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The most important baby in the world -- at least so regarded by every Briton -- is due to be born in a week or so to Princess Elizabeth.

John Kriza last night made his postponed guest appearance with the New York City Ballet Company at the City Center, dancing opposite Marie-Jeane in the third movement of the Balanchine-Bizet "Symphony in C." He was to have appeared two weeks ago but was prevented from doing so by an accident to his foot.

The flood tide of communism, now sweeping through Asia, has undermined the flimsy foundations of Nationalist China and is threatening to topple into dissolution the weak structure of Chiang Kaishek's Government.

Five members of Fordham's regular football team will be missing from the starting line-up when the Rams encounter Holy Cross Saturday, Coach Ed Danowski announced yesterday. The changes mean the transfer of four regulars to reserve status because of poor performances in the 33-7 defeat by Boston University and an injury incurred by one lineman in the same contest.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- A new compromise proposal for settling the Berlin dispute, which has been dormant since the Soviet Union vetoed the previous compromise proposal in the United Nations Security Council, is being prepared by Secretary General Trygve Lie, it was learned today.

Five hundred delegates representing 400 organizations in the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs arrived by special train yesterday for the fifty-fourth annual convention of the federation in the New Yorker Hotel.

Two men, after posing as kindhearted strangers willing to assist an 80-year-old woman whose crutch was broken, were booked later last night at the West Twentieth Street police station on charges of snatching $87 from her in the hallway of her home.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations announced today that it was joining in the $1,000,000 suit filed by the United Electrical, Radio and Machines Workers Union against the Atomic Energy Commission.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 8 (UP) -- German officials searched in vain tonight for Hjalmar Schacht so they could Serve the pre-war Finance Minister with a warrant for retrial as a major Nazi offender.

TOKYO, Nov. 8 -- Government financing is running into what looks like a temporary impasse. The Cabinet is working out a new supplementary budget, variously estimated at 80,000,000,000 to 300,000,000,000 yen. General MacArthur, the Allied Supreme Commander, insists there must not be any deficit financing -- that every expenditure be balanced by income -- yet tax revenues are beginning to peter out despite frantic efforts to collect them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -The 1948 cotton crop was estimated today by the Department of Agriculture at 15,168,000 bales -87,000 larger than forecast a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Fuller Brush Company, Hartford, Conn., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 11,606 shares of its 4 1/2 per cent cumulative non-voting first preferred stock, $100 par value, that will be offered publicly at $100 a share.
A plan to expedite relief case work in the Department of Welfare was announced yesterday, by Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard. He said the changes would increase efficiency and decrease cost.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Among the good business principles on which the United States is assisting the recovery of Western Europe is the so-called "counterpart fund," which has been much in the news lately. The words have a dull sound, even in the phraseology of banking, and doubtless many American readers shy away from informing themselves on a subject with such a name.

With the industry's production constantly improving, the monthly payroll of the nation's iron and steel companies has also been moving higher each month. In September the payroll reached a new all-time high of almost $200,000,000, with the average hourly earnings of production workers rising to a new peak of $1.718 according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- Grain markets continued on the upgrade on the Board of Trade today, with December wheat and oats selling at new highs since late last July. December corn sold at a new high for about a month. July and September wheat and September corn and May soy beans went to a new seasonal high.

TOKYO, Nov. 8 -- From July, 1940, onward, Japan negotiated with the United States, not to find a solution of international problems, but "solely for the purpose of furthering her own aims in conjunction with those of Germany and Italy," the International Military Tribunal decided today.

Twentieth Century-Fox is pointing with pride to the business done over the week-end by its three new Broadway film entries, "The Snake Pit," "Unfaithfully Yours" and "Road House." According to the company announcement, the pictures, which opened at the Rivoli, Roxy and Mayfair, respectively, were seen by "a total of 146,500 people at the three theatres from Friday through Sunday," and the combined business at the three houses "reached a six-figure take."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 8 -- An industrial training program for young immigrants to help the state of Israel achieve prosperity in peace was mapped today by delegates from forty-seven states to the thirty-fourth annual convention of Hadassah, Women's Zionist Organization of America.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -The National Labor Relations Board ruled unanimously today that a union-shop contract not made in accordance with provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law was illegal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The continued use of three voluntary steel allocation programs after the scheduled expiration date of Feb. 28, 1949, virtually was assured today when the Department of Commerce announced that it had set Nov. 15 for hearings on the matter.

When the Yankees launch spring training at St. Petersburg, Fla., Casey Stengel, the new manager, will have an opportunity to look over five aspirants for the firstbase job, for yesterday, it was announced, the Yankees signed Norman (Babe) Young, recently cut loose by the Cardinals.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP) -Illegal trade practices that eliminated competition in the shoe repair business were charged in Federal indictments returned today against a Philadelphia Trade Association and twelve individuals and companies.
The absence of a United States Army team has thrown the National Horse Show Association as well as that of Harrisburg and Toronto's Royal Winter Fair into a quandary for next year.

Probably nowhere in the world is the horror of war as vividly preserved as on this island. It lies close beneath the surface and the brittle volcanic crust holds the promise that from time to time a forgetful civilization will break through.

Costs of waging a "cold war" and the possibility of a "hot war" are the principal factors disturbing the present general tendency toward stability of prices and production. Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.

Subject to approval by stockholders of American Investment Company of Illinois on Nov. 23, it is proposed that American Investment will offer to shareholders of the Ohio Finance Company 236,610 shares of its preference stock as follows:

Once again Franklin Field will house one of the chief football attractions of the week in the meeting Saturday between Pennsylvania and Army. From the start of the season this is the game in the East that has been looked forward to almost more than any other.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 8 -- Gov. Millard F. Caldwell of Florida called today on newspaper publishers in the South to "castigate unmercifully" any persons who attempt to inject racial or religious prejudice into the public affairs of the country.

The United States Court of Appeals unanimously upheld yesterday the sweeping anti-strike injunction issued under the TaftHartley Law to prevent picketing of the New York and Brooklyn stores of Oppenheim Collins Co.

With the Democratic and Republican parties committed to governmental support of prices of farm products, no relief appears in sight for the consumer -- which means every man, woman and child in the United States -from the inflated prices of food and such articles of clothing as are made of cotton or wool.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 8 -- The Netherland contribution to the defense of Western Europe will be discussed here tomorrow by Field Marshal Montgomery in his first visit to this country as chairman of the joint military committee. It is expected the Netherlanders will inform him that no troops can be furnished by them until at least 1952.

Two thousand chemical engineers, who had spent much of the day at discussions of scientific and industrial problems, were chalenged last night to apply the courageous methods of scientific approach to the problem of world peace.

Since last Tuesday there has been some talk about regulating publicopinion polls. Apparently this would be done to punish the opinion-testers for predicting wrongly. But what is a public opinion poll? The answer is that it is a composite expression of opinion, obtained and interpreted by specialists.

T. S. Eliot, to whom the Nobel Prize in Literature was awarded last week, will have a new book brought out by Harcourt, Brace in February. The author says, in his introduction, that its purpose "is not to outline a social or political philosophy, but to help to define a word, the word culture."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- After studying scouting reports of Army's offense, Coach George Munger showed his Penn football team some new defenses to use against the West Pointers' "Three S. Men" here on Saturday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 (AP) -California's move to stamp out horse race bookies by denying Western Union facilities to a racing information service was challenged today in the Ninth United States Circuit Court of Appeals

Miss Alene Burr has been appointed stylist and director of publicity of Security Mills, Inc., manufacturer of woven and knitted coatings and wool jersey dress fabrics. She formerly was with Bonwit Teller and the Associated Dry Goods Corporation.

The recent suggestion by Frank Murray, Marquette coach, that a football official who errs on a rule be fined, does not strike Asa S. Bushnell, Eastern commissioner, as being fair or feasible. Speaking before the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday, Bushnell flatly rejected Murray's revolutionary proposal, stressing that he is opposed to a system of fines.

VIENNA, Nov. 8 -- The Socialist party congress opens tomorrow with evidence in hand indicating that the Communists have lost for the moment a chance to disrupt the party through Erwin Scharf, disident former Socialist Left Wing leader.
TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 8 -- A special state study commission offered three simplified forms of municipal government today for adoption by New Jersey communities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Truman today asked all Government agencies to let him know by Nov. 29 what new laws they thought were needed in their fields.

The cornerstone of the first permanent building of New York International Airport at Idlewild Queens, was laid yesterday afternoon. The $4,500,000 three-story brick structure will house the regional offices of the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the United States Weather Bureau.
Kings County Court. started yesterday, a new system of calender practice designed to prevent handpicking of judges by the District Attorney for certain cases.
A Federal statutory court approved yesterday a decree that within a year would divorce the exhibition business of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation from its production and distribution business.

Only one major obstacle to an "express ride" on Ninth and Tenth Avenues, now converted to oneway traffic operation, was apparent yesterday as the plan to speed traffic around congested mid-Manhattan had its first workday test.

The General Motors Corporation, which recently reported sharply higher net earnings for 1948, announced yesterday an increased year-end special dividend of $2 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 10. In the preceding quarter the automotive company paid $1 a share, previous to which a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share was paid on the stock.

A selection of Austrian wines from vineyards highly prized by the Viennese for centuries but little known in other countries was introduced in New York yesterday afternoon at a tasting in the Tyrolian Room of the Restuarant Crillon, 277 Park Avenue.

Frederick Spillmann, 46 years old, who was sentenced in 1936 to life imprisonment as a fourth offender but later was freed, was arrested again last night on a felony charge in Queens and will face a life term once more, according to the police of the Richmond Hill station.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- After giving an impressive demonstration of his famed two-fisted punching power. Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis came out of the exhibition boxing bout with Johnny Shkor of Baltimore with a slightly scraped upper left eyelid tonight at the Arena.

" Should the Federal Government Help Finance Our Schools?" will be discussed in the radio forum "What's On Your Mind?" to be presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES and heard over station WQXR at 9:30 P.M. tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.
BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- The Soviet Military Administration has completed the democratic facade for its sector of Berlin with establishment of a new Socialist party.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- A 50,000,000 ($220,000,000) trade agreement between Japan and five countries of the British Commonwealth, including the United Kingdom, was announced tonight by the Board of Trade.
Residential properties dominated the sales on Long Island reported yesterday by brokers and title companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The War Assets Administration announced today that the Republic Steel Corporation, Cleveland, had signed a ten-year lease to operate the government-owned blast furnace and facilities at Gadsden, Ala.

A Swedish scientist who has come close to defining life in terms of a well-ordered sequence of chemical events described the basic concepts behind his incredibly sensitive measuring instruments to doctors at the New York Academy of Medicine last night.

Mrs. Phyllis Walshon, 24-yearold wife of Irving Walshon, a veteran of World War II, killed their 3 1/2-year-old son, Clifford, by smothering him with a pillow about noon yesterday at their home at 59-03 Ninety-seventh Place, Rego Park, Queens.

Once more, Hezekiah Cobb, unterrified foxhunter, has paid a visit to our big city. What brought him here, naturally, was the Horse Show. There is little opportunity in his part of the country for elderly gentlemen to take part in the exercise which first lifted men's feet off the ground.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Domingo Marimon of Argentina today won the 100,000-peso ($20,700) first prize in the Buenos Aires-Caracas Grand Prix automobile race when a freak accident cheated Oscar Galvez, Argentine driver, of victory by four minutes.

A threatened strike of East Coast longshoremen at midnight tonight was averted early today when union and management committees reached a settlement after a six-and-one-half-hour meeting in the offices of the New York Shipping Association at 80 Broad Street.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 8 -- This man President Truman is so unpredictable. On election day he fooled everybody, except 23,000,000 voters. Today he was supposed to be staying in his own back yard on the naval base here, but did he?

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Nov. 8 -- The presidents of the seventeen Negro land-grant colleges in the border and Southern states "believe" that a financial crisis now faced by private colleges in the South will force them to become state colleges, Dr. John W. Davis, president of the West Virginia State College, said today.

Economies and the automobile have scuttled the Hudson River Day Line after eighty-five years. The four squat steamboats, as constant on the Hudson during the summer months as harried canoeists, are up for sale, it was announced yesterday.

The first four civil service merchant marine hearing examiners, appointed under authority of the Administrative Procedure Act of 1947, were sworn in yesterday morning at the headquarters of the Third Coast Guard District, 42 Broadway.

Thrifty housewives will do well to include cheese often in their meal-planning now. The very good reason for this is that prices on a number of domestic varieties are considerably lower than they have been. Recently the Safeway. A. P., and Bohack chains reduced tariffs on mild cheddar, processed American and Swisstype cheeses 6 cents a pound.

Strong optimism for spring trade in boys' wear was voiced yesterday by manufacturers and buyers alike at the second day's showing of the five-day market week of the Boys Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association in the New Yorker Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP) -Ike Williams, 140, lightweight champion, let loose with a knockout blow as the bell ended the first round to score a quick nontitle victory over Buddy Garcia, 136, of Galveston, Tex., at the Arena tonight.
Scott Watson, composer-pianist, made his Town Hall debut yesterday afternoon. As a pianist he proved himself able, if a bit wanting in nuance. As a composer he was exceptionally interesting.

The experiment of making heavily traveled Ninth and Tenth Avenues one-way streets in midtown will be watched with interest. This test by the Police Department is to last for sixty days. It began auspiciously last weekend, but will receive its real test only on business days when traffic is at full flow.

George Frankenthaler, RepublicanLiberal candidate for New York County Surrogate, increased his plurality to 1,201 votes, according to the final tabulation of the election inspectors' tally sheets as made public yesterday by the Board of Elections.

Likening the present period in world history to that preceding the Constitutional Convention in American history, Judge Florence E. Allen called on lawyers last night to guide public opinion in favor of world government.
Hollingsworth Whitney, paper manufacturers, reported yesterday for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Sept. 26 consolidated net income after taxes of $2,722,866.

Negotiations are under way for the purchase of the 800-acre Rockland County estate of Adolph Zukor at New City by a syndicate of New York business men, it was learned yesterday. The property, in the town of Clerkstown, also includes the golf course of the Mountain View Golf and Country Club.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Louis M. Hacker, Associate Professor of economics at Columbia University and noted lecturer on United States history delivered tonight at Oxford University his inaugural address as Harmsworth Professor of American History, a post he will fill during 1948-49.

IT was the annual meeting Admiration Society as Steve Owen shook hands warmly with Mel Hein, his old captain and center, who now serves as line coach for the Los Angeles Dons of the rival; All-America Conference. Their deep affection for each other has increased rather than diminished with the passing of time.

Declaring that sanitary conditions in subway stations were "deplorable," directors of the Broadway Association called upon the Board of Transportation yesterday for a "Clean Up -- Spruce Up" drive in the city transit system.

With buyers apparently willing to place orders for both near-by and end-of-year deliveries, corset and brassiere manufacturers who opened spring lines yesterday said that prospects for the industry were "very encouraging."

More than half of the post-war refurnishing of hotels and restaurants throughout the country remains to be completed and active buying for this purpose is continuing at a record-breaking pace. Particularly in better lines of textiles, carpets, furniture, glassware and china, supplies are still scarce and demand is strong.

Max Schmeling set me back almost to where I started when he beat me in our first fight in the Yankee Stadium in June in 1936. I wasn't but 22 then. I guess that night was the worst I ever had, counting before and since.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt urged yesterday the permanent ousting of Southern Dixiecrats from the Democratic party, since President Truman won without their help and over their opposition.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 8 -With high hopes that the game on Saturday may break Navy's losing streak, the Middies today set their sights on Columbia's Lions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Maurice Tobin, Secretary of Labor, said at a press conference today that he would prepare recommendations on labor legislation for submission to President Truman.

The table settings now on display at Altman's are numerous and diverse enough to help homemakers plan appropriate backgrounds for anything from a tea party to a banquet in the coming holiday season. The display on the fourth floor will continue throughout the week.

Plans for the new three-story Children's Museum in Brooklyn at the southwest corner of Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue were among those filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The cost is put at $1,600,000.
Twenty-one ambulances and five trucks sped a floral cargo of cheer yesterday to 20,240 patients in city, Army and Navy and veterans' hospitals to open National Flower Week.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (AP) -Jockey Carson Kirk called for a hard stretch bid today and drove War Trophy home first in the $25,000 added Riggs Handicap as the big gelding set a new Pimlico track record for the mile and a half.

The Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly was the scene yesterday of a filibuster that succeeded in preventing a strong majority from registering its will. The question at issue was a proposal that the U.N. condemn Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania for helping the Greek guerrilla forces to make war on the Greek Government.

The international executive board of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO, transmitted to the union membership yesterday a recommendation that the union comply with the non-Communist affidavit requirement of the Taft-Hartley Law.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 3 per cent last week under the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that it would begin hearings here on Dec. 7 on its anti-trust proceedings against the TransAmerica Corporation, San Francisco. The Reserve Board's action will force the huge bank holding company to appeal the matter, if it intends to do so, within the next thirty days.

The stock market lapsed back yesterday into a more normal state, with a lessening of activity and prices irregularly higher on the day. A firm tone prevailed throughout the session and the list gave evidence of attempting to find a new equilibrium at or around the current levels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The vital question whether individuals can be forced to admit or deny membership in the Communist party will be decided by the Supreme Court, as a consequence of orders handed down by the tribunal today.

Affiliates of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies are saving at least 12 1/2% per cent on food and commodities in the face of inflationary prices by means of group buying, Rudolph Havelka, director of the federation's institutional marketing service, said yesterday at a meeting of its administrative committee in the Bankers Club.

Paris, Nov. 8 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Social Committee voted 37 to 3, with 3 abstentions, today in favor of equal rights for men and women "both during marriage and at its dissolution."

First of the yacht racing associations to toss overboard the ageold practice of timing the finishes of yachts, which has been conceded to be a waste of effort, and to adopt dates for its important events next year was the Great South Bay one, which held its annual winter meeting last night in the New York Yacht Club.

A divorced couple, parents of a husky 19-year-old youth charged with slaying a Canadian business man in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last Friday, pledged yesterday they "would stick with him until this is over."

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- The five Brussels Treaty powers, now exchanging ideas about a projected Atlantic security pact, will not invite Scandanavian or other Western European nations into the discussions until the question of the scope of the pact has been put up to the United States, officials of those powers said today.

Increased Federal funds can be used to support an expanded program of higher education without injecting "undesirable controls," John Dale Russell, director of the Division of Higher Education, Office of Education, Federal Security Agency, declared yesterday.

When a Presidential train glides into the railroad tunnel under the Hudson River, a bell with a flat, almost asthmatic wheeze goes off in Alex Milano's control tower at the western end of Pennsylvania Station.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 8 -Nathuram Vinayak Godse detailed in court today his ideological disagreements with Mohandas K. Gandhi, whose murder he confessed in the course of his reading of a 30,000-word statement. The 36-year-old Hindu Brahmin editor is on trial in a special tribunal with seven others for murder, for conspiracy and for security violations.

A discussion of proposed legislation to control garage rents and service charges was held yesterday in the office of Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, its sponsor. He met with representatives of the garage business and directors of the Automobile Club of New York.

A blood test will become a routine part of every examination of a new patient in a physician's office if a suggestion by Dr. Theodore Rosenthal, director of the Bureau of Social Hygiene in the Department of Health, is carried out.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -The International Typographical Union. AFL. took another step today in its effort to overthrow a contempt of court finding.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 8 Shortly after noon today, Wilhelm Shreck, his wife, and his two grown children -son and daughter -- sat down in their little flat in the Sachsenhausen area of Frankfort to their usual midday meal.

The National Orchestral Association is an organization that provides training and practical experience for young instrumentalists, but this major objective does not prevent it from giving a lively series of concerts each season. Leon Barzin, the musical director, is no doubt responsible for the adventurousness of the programs.

December hide futures trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday was the center of interest, and at the close of the session December delivery showed an advance of 75 points, a new high for the current movement, that was within 37 points of the peak for life of the contract established in July.

ATHENS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Members of the Greek Parliament threw one of their colleagues out bodily tonight for supporting an Australian proposal for peace talks between Greece and her three northern neighbors.
The upland game season will get under way in New Jersey at 9 A.M. tomorrow, and the waterfowl season opens in that state at noon on Friday.
DETROIT, Nov. 8 -- Nonprofessional employes of Harper Hospital went on strike today to press for recognition of the newly organized Hospital Employees Union, AFL, as bargaining agent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Republican-controlled Senate Campaign Investigating Subcommittee voted today to let the Democratic Senate of the Eighty-first Congress decide whether two of its new Democratic members and one hold-over Democrat were nominated without the taint of fraud or excessive expenditures.

The most important feature of the Christian Dior ready-to-wear collection, presented yesterday in the Paris couturier's new New York salon at 730 Fifth Avenue, is that it is strictly Dior. If those invited to see it expected something startlingly different, something to put the fashion world on this side of the Atlantic into a tailspin, they were disappointed.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were 12 to 46 points net higher.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- President Truman has expressed his appreciation of the "splendid work" being done by John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser on foreign affairs, as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, it was learned today.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- French representatives in Germany are protesting vigorously against what theyh)0*0*0*icall the too-rapid political and economic growth of Western Germany, it was learned authoritatively today.
The New York Appellate division upheld unanimously yesterday the action of state racing officials in refusing a license to Daniel Lamont, Altoona, Pa., race horse owner.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Harry G. Hunter, assistant commissioner of the Public Buildings Administration, said today that with the Truman family out of the White House, his agency soon "will do some more digging and cut some more holes" to help in making a final decision on what to recommend to Congress with regard to reconstruction of the Executive Mansion's second floor.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- The revolutionary type of Schmidt camera now used by astronomers to discover hitherto hidden secrets of the heavens has opened the way for discovering hidden cancers of the digestive tract in their early pre-symptomatic stages, when they are still in the operable and curable stage.

MELLE, Germany, Nov. 8 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, chairman of the commanders-in-chief of the Western European Union, outlined to the British, United States and French military governors in Germany today his preliminary plan for the defense of Western Europe.
Leo Milito, rugged East Side lightweight, won a split decision over Jimmy Warren of Brooklyn in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Milito weighed 132, Warren 135 1/2.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 8 -- Reports of continuing Chinese Communist successes and the announcement of the hasty withdrawal of Americans from the Nanking and Shanghai areas are having a disquieting effect on the South Korean Government and on private circles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Fundamental investigations into economic and social problems of the family group by home economics departments of the land grant colleges was urged today as part of research under the Agricultural Marketing Act by Agnes Fay Morgan of the University of California.

The Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association held its annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore and re-elected Mrs. John T. Lawless of Greenwich, president. There were only a few changes made in the officers and the board of directors for the coming year.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- The strike of French railroad workers showed no immediate sign of materializing today as the Federation of Railroad Workers, a branch of the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor, announced that the final count of a strike vote would not be completed for about fortyeight hours.

Attorneys for the twelve Communist leaders accused of conspiring to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government charged in Federal Court yesterday that a "barrage" of anti-Communist propaganda by Government and private agencies had whipped up such a state of hysteria that it was impossible for the defendants to get a fair trial now.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP) -The advisability of limiting the size of life insurance companies will be considered by a joint legislative committee at a hearing on Nov. 22 and 23.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Economic Cooperation Administration officials headed by Chief Paul G. Hoffman conferred for nearly an hour today with Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett on the future of United States aid to the Government of Chiang Kai-shek in view of Communist gains in North China.

It is definite that the Playwrights' Company will undertake the Broadway presentation of Garson Kanin's new play, "The Smile of the World." The deal apparently was clinched when the Playwrights' agreed to an immediate production, as requested by the author.

Through two depressions, disabled or homeless war veterans were housed and fed for $1 a day in the Veterans Club of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross. Founded in 1921, the organization was disbanded last night with a farewell party at club headquarters, 323 Lexington Avenue.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 8 -The Israeli Government started the first census of its about 800,000 citizens tonight by putting all under house arrest to make sure they held still to be counted.

Jack Benny has accepted new contract terms proposed by the National Broadcasting Company, with the result that he will continue to be heard on the NBC network at 7 P.M. Sundays, it was made known yesterday. The network submitted the proposals after the Columbia Broadcasting System sought to induce the comedian to shift the base of his activities to the CBS network on Sundays.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A report to Congress today on the $577,000,000 interim aid program said the relief supplies had probably saved Italy from "economic bondage," prevented a collapse of the French economy and enabled Austria to reap her best harvest since the War.
Domestic steel mills this week will set a new high production record of 1,791,700 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 8 -Samuel Moskowitz of North Bergen, general counsel of the New Jersey Retail Liquor Stores Association, said tonight that liquor prices are too high and as a result are restricting sales and causing antagonism among consumers.
TORONTO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Very Rev. Dr. Hewlett Johnson, "Red Dean" of Canterbury, has his reasons for believing that Premier Stalin is not a dictator.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 8 -- The Hungarian and Bulgarian Governments have assured the Yugoslav Government that they have no designs on Yugoslav territory. The assurances were contained in an official note to Belgrade's Ministry of Foreign Affairs protesting against a speech made in the Yugoslav Parliament on Sept. 30 by Peter Stambolitch, Premier of Serbia, a constituent republic of Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -Senator-elect Russell Long, Democrat, of Louisiana, said today he believed that most States' Rights Democrats "are ready to return to the regular party."

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 8 (AP) -The Amherst College chapter of Phi Kappa Psi announced today that Tom Gibbs, a Negro sophomore and athlete, would be initiated as a member despite some opposition within the fraternity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The retiring leader of the Republican House, Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr., asserted today that the opposition in the new Congress would be unable to deny to President Truman any proposal "that he really wants."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -Prompt resumption of contract negotiations was assured today by striking maritime unions and West Coast shipowners, with both sides showing eagerness to end the costly strike which has kept seaborne shipping idle for more than nine weeks.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 8 -- India's future relationship to the British Commonwealth may be considered in the current session of the Indian Constituent Assembly, Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru told the Assembly today. It was his first address to that body since returning from the London conference of Commonwealth Prime Ministers.

American history classes in all New York public junior high schools will emphasize this nation's heritage of freedom as contrasted to the practices of totalitarian states, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Elias Lieberman, associate superintendent in charge of the junior high school division.

Hirshon-Garfield, Inc., has been appointed to handle all advertising for Burlington Mills, it was announced yesterday by Kenneth Collins, vice president in charge of advertising and public relations of Burlington Mills Corporation. The agency has been handling Burlington advertising for men's wear suitings, shirting division, Galey Lord Men's Wear Fabrics and Burlington Mills' institutional campaign.

HARTFORD, Nov. 8 -- SageAllen Co., Inc., a department store, today demonstrated for the first time an electronically controlled detection and ventilation system designed to minimize smoke and panic hazards in case of fire.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Dollar stocks made a poor showing in an otherwise cheerful stock market here today. The biggest loss was that of United States Steel, which finished 6 1/2 points down. Other falls ranged up to the 3 1/2 points recorded by General Motors.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- If President Truman returns to his proposal to make a direct approach to Moscow, the British Government should report him, Emrys Hughes, Labor member, said in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Leading newspaper, radio and motionpicture spokesmen took up today the question of whether gangbuster radio dramas and crime-story movies and comics have an unwholesome effect on the public, particularly children.

PALISADES, N.Y., Nov. 8 -Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont, widow of the former chairman of the board of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc. plans to donate her estate here to the Presbyterian Hospital, New York, it was announced today.

ERIC JOHNSTON, who calls himself "a small business man from Spokane" and "strictly a product of Main Street," is one of the most personable and persuasive men in American Public life. When he was president of the American Chamber of Commerce he made his job seem several times as important as it ever had before.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -Warner Brothers today named Patricia Neal to play the leading feminine role opposite Ronald Reagan in the screen version of John Patrick's 1945 play, "The Hasty Heart," which will go before the cameras in England about Dec. 1.

A system permitting first offender parking violators to pay their fines by mail will be instituted next Monday, Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger announced yesterday. Stressing that the mail-payment method would be rigidly restricted to first offenders, the Chief Magistrate warned that if the experiment proved unsatisfactory the Court would again require the personal appearance of such violators.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 An effecive world-wide peace cannot be achieved unless the present SovietAmerican armament race is halted, and this objective cannot be attained without the establishment of a supra-authority -- or world government, James P. Warburg, New York banker and author, said tonight.

One of the largest French bone china dinnerware producers has raised prices to American importers from 16 to 20 per cent, Meyer Fireman, president, Crownford China Company, Inc., disclosed yesterday. He said that the factory is one of the most important of French bone china manufacturers and added that other French exporters in the Limoges area are certain to follow suit.

PARIS, NOV. 8 -- Attempts by the Soviet bloc to seek passage of a resolution that, in the opinion of the administering powers and of the United States, was tantamount to a "vote of nonconfidence" for the United Nations Trusteeship Council, were frustrated today through an amendment that virtually deprived it of all controversial points.

The Associated Press has just polled the members of the new Congress to ascertain where they stand on some of the more important and controversial issues expected to come up for legislative action in 1949. Answers to all or some of the questions were received from about half the total membership of the two Houses.

The Government expects to invite sealed bids in about a month in the proposed sale of its majority stock holdings in the American Bemberg Corporation and the North American Rayon Corporation, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -Bennett E. Meyers, former Army Air Force general, today lost his appeal from the conviction that sent him to jail.

A four-day festival of French music, dedicated "to the greatness of France, through the musicians who share in its expression," will be presented from Nov. 30 to Dec. 3 by the Juilliard School, under the honorary patronage of Henri Bonnet, Ambassador of France.

A program of slum clearance in which public ownership of housing would play no part was advocated yesterday by the United States Saving and Loan League's committee on Government housing as the league opened a five-day convention in the Commodore Hotel.

The stock market was subjected yesterday to a renewal of the post-election selling which carried prices on the Stock Exchange down to the lowest marks since last March. It was the third assault on the market since the Democratic victory in the national elections and left prices further reduced by 2 to 5 points in the key issues.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 9 (AP) -- A total of 154 harness horses were sold for $161,850 here today, setting a new opening-day record for the annual standard bred horse auction.
Hail the "Big Four" of college football -- Michigan, Notre Dame, Army and California.

Miss Cynthia McDonald heads a group of debutantes of this season aiding in the sale of tickets for the performance of the Ice Follies on the night of Nov. 18 at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. Frequent meetings of the group are being held at the Ritz- Carlton to perfect plans for the benefit.

ROME, Nov. 9 -- The Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano publishes an editorial by its editor, Count Giuseppe Dalla Torre, this evening appealing to President Truman and Premier Stalin to put an end to the troubled world situation by direct negotiation. The present, says Count Della Torre, is "one of those fleeting instants that never return if not seized immediately.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Sentiment in labor circles and some government quarters appeared today to favor returning the Wagner Act to its former status as the first step if the Taft-Hartley law was repealed.

The relative dearth of new equity financing and the "substantial reliance on debt instruments characteristic of corporate financial practice in the post-war years have thus far had no serious consequence for corporate financial positions," according to Stanley L. Miller, economist of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

On the fourth floor of the Brooklyn Museum, against a crimson background, fashions representing a decade of designing by Charles James, the American who has made a name for himself in Paris, London and New York, now are on exhibition.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 2,483, compared with 1,254 last week and 1,924 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,393 arrivals yesterday against 440 last Tuesday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Miss Margarie Fisher's Shivaree, often a quitter during his early career, showed that his recent staying form was not a flash in the pan when he won the $5,000 Heiser Handicap at Pimlico today.

Directors of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad Company declared a special dividend of 75 cents and a dividend of 75 cents on common, both payable Dee. 30, J. D. Farrington, president, announced yesterday. Previously a payment of 75 cents was made on Sept. 30 and an initial of a like amount was disbursed July 15.

Today this is the Navy's most important anchorage west of Pearl Harbor. The heavy fighting that led to its capture four and a half years ago might have seemed far away were it not for a Japanese with a close haircut. He was literally unearthed by natives on an isolated island of the atoll last spring and the islanders are still wondering about his coiffure.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, warned last night that every tendency leading to the centralization of responsibility in the national Government carried with it the danger that authority would be centralized.

With the opening of the Jewelry Dealers Exchange, this city's largest jewelry mart, last week in West Forty-seventh Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, veterans in the business agreed yesterday that the Bowery district had lost one more aspect of its claim to fame and that the balance of the trade had swung northward to the crowded midtown street.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 9 -- Preliminary analysis of the four-year recovery plans of European nations has shown wide inconsistencies in assumptions the countries participating in the European Recovery Program are making about each other's trade.

The merger and consolidation of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital into the New York University - Bellevue Medical Center was formally completed yesterday as representatives of both institutions signed the agreement for the union in the offices of Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University at 100 Washington Square East.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The search for truthful news in a propaganda-beset world, and what the facts mean in terms understandable to the average reader or listener, are keynote topics for this week's meetings of The Associated Press Managing Editors Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Continued administrative "tinkering" with a country's economy inevitably leads to tyranny, John M. Hancock, a member of the Secretary of Commerce's Advisory Council, said today as he urged that the Government's "foggy" policy, with respect to the pricing systems of American business, be clarified to encourage a free interplay of economic forces.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The proposed North Atlantic security pact will be confined to the five Western European union nations plus the United States and Canada, even though it is believed by Europeans drafting it that the United States will insist upon broadening its geographical scope, it is understood here.
William H. Dennler, assistant manager of the General Electric Company's vacuum cleaner division, has been appointed manage of the division.

VIENNA, Nov. 9 -- The Austrian Cabinet voted today to file a formal protest against the arrest of Dr. Margarethe Ottillinger by Russian officials. The Cabinet hopes to get the protest before next Friday's meeting of the Allied Council for Austria. Dr. Ottillinger is the leading Austrian specialist concerned with the implementation of the Marshall Plan here, the Ministry of Economic Planning said.
The people of Nigeria have donated $4,000 toward the appeal of the African Academy of Arts and Research and Africa House, 459 West 140th Street, it was announced yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company of Ohio had a net income of $18,922,947 in the first nine months of this year, of which $1,508,000 was non-recurrent income, W. T. Holliday, president, reported yesterday to stockholders and employes.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 9 -- Mustafa Nahas Pasha, former Premier and leader of the opposition Wafd party, narrowly escaped assassination last night. Two of his guards who were injured in the attempt died today.

LONDON Nov. 9 -- The British Government is planning to create a comprehensive and flexible civil defense organization throughout the British Isles, it was announced today with publication of the text of the Civil Defense Bill.

We heard Alexander Brailowsky, pianist, play last night in Carnegie Hall with less regard for minutae of performance and more of passion, a big line, free impulse, and variety of tone than at any previous recital of his that we remember.
Four resolutions proposing the establishment of a ceiling on executive salaries and annual compensation were voted down at the annual stockholder meeting yesterday of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

The end of competition in the National Horse Show saw Mexico's great riders winners for the third straight year of the International Military Perpetual Challenge Trophy last night. A crowd of 12,000 in Madison Square Garden applauded, then stood as the anthem of the republic rang out a tenth time for victory.

Present estimates indicate that the population in the United States in 1950 will total 150,000,000, an increase of about 18,500,000 over the census in 1940, J. C. Capt, director of the Census Bureau, said at the Cooper Union Forum last night.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today that "as part of his duty to keep himself informed of all matters before the United Nations" he was "making a study of the currency problem in Berlin."

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- It was confirmed here today that Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, had gone back to India from the recent Commonwealth Conference with a clear idea of the kind of formula that might keep India within the Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Far Eastern Commission announced today that Japanese business men now would be permitted to go to other countries to sell their products under a directive sent to Gen. Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Commander Allied Powers in Japan, for implementation.

Sidney G. Deneau has been named general manager of domestic distribution of the Selznick Releasing Organization, it was announced yesterday after a special meeting of the board of directors of SRO here attended by David O. Selznick and Daniel T. O'Shea.

In the belief that something good an happen because much of the worst already has assailed his foot-all Giants, Steve Owen is looking quite hopefully toward next Sunday's game with the Los Angeles Rams at the Polo Grounds.

Rating Alfred on a par with N. Y. U., the only team to defeat Brooklyn College this season, Coach Ted Rosequist guarded against any possible let-down from his squad this week-end, after their rousing performance against C. C. N. Y., by delivering a short talk before yesterday's practice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The United States and Canada today took limited action toward possibly reviving at a later date the Passamaquoddy tidal power project by referring certain matters in connection with it to their international joint commission.

President Truman's major campaign speeches and his most significant messages to Congress are being put into book form by Public Affairs Press of Washington. The material will be arranged to provide an over-all view of the President's plans and policies concerning civil rights, labor, housing, inflation, agriculture and international affairs.
Regular and reserve organizations of the Marine Corps will observe tonight its 173d anniversary. Two celebrations are to be held in the Astor Hotel, and others in Brooklyn and the Bronx.
An expanded recovery program for Japan, to enable that country to pay its own way, was urged yesterday by William H. Draper Jr., Under-Secretary of the Army.

The Government's effort to scatter industrial plants as a safeguard against possible atom bombing will not be limited to new facilities but envisions the relocating of some existing units, it was reported yesterday by Ralph F. Dimmitt, consultant to the National Securities Resources Board.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A better rounded education to balance the threats to civilization inherent in technical discoveries was urged before the Association of Land Grant Colleges today by national leaders.

A requiem mass was celebrated yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral for George E. Ruppert, chairman of the board of directors of the Jacob Ruppert Brewery, who died on Friday at the age of 73. Two thousand persons were present.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Plans to ask Congress for some wartime rent powers, extended "at least one year" beyond March 31, were reported today by a spokesman for the Housing Expediter, Tighe E. Woods.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- National income might be doubled if sharing of profits with the workers were universally adopted, William Loeb. vice chairman of the Council of Profit Sharing Industries, said today in closing the first annual mee%ing of %he council.

YONKERS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- A woman suspected of being a typhoid carrier, who may have infected two members of a household for whom she worked as cook, has undergone an operation at St. Joseph's Hospital, which it is hoped will remove the hidden infection, Dr. John A. Faiella, deputy health commissioner, announced today.

The Democratic platform of 1948 called unequivocally for the outright repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act, and Mr. Truman hammered relentlessly on this theme throughout his campaign. But even the platform adopted at Philadelphia, bristling as it was -- and as party platforms invariably are -- with promises of something for everybody.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Broad agreement on the number of combat units that each nation of the Western European union will provide initially toward the common defense pool has now been reached, it is reported here. It is understood this was one of the two principal topics discussed yesterday at a meeting in Germany between Marshal Montgomery and the three military governors of Western Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Landlords have the right to evict tenants simply by withdrawing the houses or apartments from the rental market, the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 9 -- The South Hempstead Community Church, now nearing completion here, has been built in the last two years by community effort.

First of a new line of bonded "Monocord" threads made of extruded nylon yarns, was announced yesterday by Richard T. Kropf, research director of Belding Corticelli Company. Welded instead of twisted, the thread has no spirals or ridges found in the conventional product, Mr. Kropf pointed out, and tests show that it will not kink, snarl, split, ravel or catch as it goes through a machine.
With a moderate volume of business, trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday resulted in a mixed close, 2 points net higher to 6 points net lower.

The mediators who make a career of settling big and little strikes for the Federal and state Governments worked out a precedent-making agreement yesterday to keep from getting into jurisdictional disputes with one another.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 9 -- When a United States cruiser and a destroyer steamed out of the harbor for their home bases early this morning, they apparently were ending a routine courtesy visit. In reality, however, they were leaving behind what observers here regarded as proof that relations between the United States and Argentina were back on a friendly basis.

The reports from the Adirondacks on the deer season are far from glowing, and several groups which lease hunting tracts each year report that they have had approximately a 30 per cent decrease in the success ratio this fall.

The proposal that all voluntary welfare and health agencies in the country unite in one federated fund to eliminate the multiplicity of campaigns now found in almost every community was offered yesterday by Robert S. Miller, vice-president of the United Health and Welfare Fund of Michigan.

The New York Rangers anticipate another rugged battle tonight when they skate against the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. It marks the second meeting within four days between the clubs, now tied for fifth place.
" The Taft-Hartley Law must be repealed." This is the report headlined on the front pages of the papers after the election. "The people have given a mandate," so it is said.

St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, will receive $2,000,000 for the charities and general purposes of the church, according to the petition for probate of the will of Mrs. Henrietta Porter Lippincott, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court by Seth T. Cole, Albany attorney.

Sales and earnings of the Celanese Corporation of America for the first nine months of this year exceeded any corresponding period in the history of the company, according to the operating statement issued for release today by Harold Blancke, president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- United States exports dropped in September to the lowest point in nearly two years despite heavier shipments under the Marshall Plan. It was the third straight month of decline.

A new surgical operation for shaking palsy, also known as Parkinson's disease or paralysis agitans, was described for the first time last night before a combined meeting of the Section on Neurology and Psychiatry and the New York Neurological Society at the New York Academy of Medicine.

An oil industry information program for next year budgeted at $1,850,000 has been approved by the board of directors of the American Petroleum Institute, it was announced yesterday by Ralph C. Champlin, chairman of the Oil Industry Information Committee.

Science also is wondering what happened to the election forecasts, the Social Science Research Council indicated yesterday by an announcement that it is forming a committee, the members to be announced today to study public opinion polls.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- The French desire to establish a completely internationalized Ruhr is believed to be behind the present agitation in Paris and Germany against the swift political and economic growth of Western Germany.

King Gustav V of Sweden, the world's oldest reigning monarch, has embroidered an altar-cloth for the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Bethlehem Evangelical Lutheran Church of Brooklyn, it was learned here yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- Clear skies today enabled United. States and British airlift fliers to recover somewhat from the effects of bad weather during the first week of the month. In the twenty-four hours ended at noon 619 planes carried 4,583.3 tons of supplies into blockaded Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Thousands of school teachers have a stake in a new question laid today before the United States Tax Court, whether teachers may deduct from their incomes the expenses of attending summer schools to improve their capabilities.

NANKING, Nov. 9 -- The Chinese Communists, striking at the economic entrails of the Lower Yangtze Valley, broke the southern section of the Tientsin-Pukow railway today and cut China's capital off from its primary source of coal.
