WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- India Edwards, director of the women's division of the Democratic National Committee, said at a press conference today that on the basis of reports from women in key states she was confident that women cast the decisive vote in the election a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Diplomatic circles forecast today that the Ambassadors of the five Western European union nations would begin exploratory conversations at the State Department next week on the projected North Atlantic defense alliance.

TOKYO, Nov. 9 -- The International Military Tribunal trying former dictator Hideki Tojo and twenty-four others accused as war criminals today upheld almost in their entirety the Russian charges that Japan had plotted and on occasion had carried out aggressive warfare against the Soviet Union.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that operations during the first nine months of this year resulted in a deficit of $1,256,230, in contrast to a net income of $7,577,395 in the comparable 1947 period.

The Shuberts have purchased from the William Waldorf Astor estate the plots on which four of the choicest Broadway theatres (all abutting each other) -- Shubert, Broadhurst, Booth and Plymouth -- are located, it was announced late last night by the Shuberts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, stands a good chance of being seated by the new Democratic House, at least temporarily, despite his indictment yesterday on fraud and false-claims charges, according to those familiar with precedents and procedures in such matters.

The thirtieth anniversary of Armistice Day will be observed in this city and throughout the country tomorrow. Special exercises paying homage to the war dead will be held by veterans' organizations, patriotic associations and churches.
BAY CITY, Mich., Nov. 9 (AP) -- A Federal Court jury today acquitted a Flint automobile sales agency and two of its officials on charges of contributing money illegally to the Republican party.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 9 -- The Israeli Government asked the United Nations today to investigate whether regular British troops had returned to Palestine on the Arab side. It declared that it would take the "most serious view of so bold an intervention by a foreign power" if the reports were substantiated.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 9 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, executive vice president of The Houston (Tex.) Post and wartime director of the Women's Army Corps, today was unanimously elected president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Governor Dewey's defeat for the Presidency, coupled with his announcement that he has no intention of again being a candidate, has served to focus national attention upon Senator Irving M. Ives of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The situation confronting the Chinese Central Government "is becoming more desperate by the hour," a participant said today after a meeting of the Public Advisory Committee on the Economic Cooperation Administration's China aid program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration is going ahead with plans for a "scientific poll" to find out how much the people of Europe know about the European Recovery Program.

Santa Monica, Calif., sold yesterday $3,020,000 of bonds due from 1949 to 1973 to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.279 for 2 1/2s, an interest cost of 2.4785 per cent.
PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

Among the proposals that will be considered by the Amateur Athletic Union at its sixtieth convention in New York on Dec. 3, 4 and 5 will be one that the United States lend its support to the projected biennial Europe vs. the Americas track meet. This was made known yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the National A. A. U.

LEO DUROCHER once was roundly condemned for saying that nice guys finish last. His specific reference, ironically enough, was to Master Melvin Ott, the man he later was to succeed as manager of the Giants. But the sports journalists leaped all over him with spiked shoes and recited a long list of managers who were nice guys and who didn't finish last.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 9 -- A funeral service for Mrs. Mary Kerr Duguid of 783 Lake Street, former field secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., was held here in the Forest Hills Presbyterian Church this afternoon by the pastor, the Rev. Frederick Jenkins.
MONTREAL, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Official National Hockey League statistics released today show the Bruins' high-production unit still running one-two-three in the scoring parade.

The months-old threat of an Atlantic and Gulf waterfront strike has been settled and the new agreement reached late Monday night is expected to be ratified by the membership of the International Longshoremen's Association. Yesterday was the deadline for the walkout, which would have brought total immobilization to the nation's shipping and crippled foreign lines with major services to American ports.

About the only way in which pancake mixes are used in this country is for making those great favorites, breakfast flapjacks. The preparation can serve as a basis for a variety of other dishes, too. Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, home economist in THE TIMES' test kitchen, has devised recipes in which the mix is the basis for several main luncheon dishes and some delectable desserts.

Immediate increases of 20.97 and 34.41 per cent in commutation fares on the Long Island Rail Road were sought by the line yesterday in a supplemental petition to the Public Service Commission. The smaller increase would apply to those using the railroad Mondays through Fridays, while the bigger rise would affect those who travel on Saturdays, Sundays or holidays as well as during the ordinary five-day work week.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- An attempt to increase by 20,000,000 (about $80,000,000) annual two-way trade between Britain and Sweden will be made in negotiations due to open here tomorrow with the Swedish trade mission. Under the current trade agreement, which expires at the end of the year, Britain has bought goods to the value of about 41,000,000 from Sweden and sold about 30,000,000 worth.

A resolution calling upon the Mayor's Committee for the Commemoration of the City's Golden Anniversary to furnish the City Council with a detailed financial report was introduced in the Council yesterday. It was referred to the Committee on Rules.
A heavy fog closed in on New York last night, hampering air and sea traffic.
SAN FRANCISCO. Nov. 9 -- A new complication was introduced into the West Coast strike picture today on the eve of a resumption of negotiations between striking maritime unions and shipowners.

MIAMI, Nov. 9 (AP) -- An unusual November hurricane moved over the Atlantic toward the North Carolina coast tonight. The surprise storm, which reached hurricane force early today, was centered at 10 P. M. about 380 miles east of Daytona Beach, Fla., moving northwestward at eighteen miles an hour.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 9 -- The West Virginia State College reported today a successful project which was set up three years ago to train by Army and Navy wartime instruction methods, men and women in the fundamentals of twelve construction trades and personal services.
Chappie and me watched Max Schmeling fight Harry Thomas in Madison Square Garden in December in 1937. I studied him good. We were matched for June 22 in 1938 in Yankee Stadium.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 9 -- U. S. aid to the newly created Korean Government under the Economic Cooperation Administration is being held up pending the decisions of the United Nations General Assembly, United States Ambassador John J. Muccio said today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 9 -- In evaluating the weight of evidence submitted against the twenty-one defendants, Mr. Kempner emphasized that the masses of documents uncovered since the original war crimes trial for major war criminals would have ranked the current defendants with Hermann Goering, Joachim von Ribbentrop, Rudolf Hess and others convicted then if they had been available.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- A memorial plaque to President Roosevelt will be unveiled in Westminster Abbey, Britain's national shrine, on Friday by Prime Minister Attlee and Winston Churchill, wartime Prime Minister, in the presence of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The initial step toward recognition of the Chief Rabbinate of Israel as the supreme religious authority for Jews has been taken by the Rabbinical Council of America, which says it represents between 2,000,000 and 3,000,000 Orthodox Jews in the United States and Canada.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Indefinite delay of a $13,000,000 IdeepeninK and improvement projest for Buffalo harbor was indiI eated today.

In concluding its eight-day run at Madison Square Garden last night, the National Horse Show drew a capacity audience including many persons prominent in society, industry, the arts and circles. When the notes of "Taps" sounded from the "yard of tin" (as the ringmaster's coaching horn is called in show-ring circles) the sixtieth exhibition of the National Horse Show Association was brought to a close.
state-owned British European Airways. Eighty airliners were affected and a thousand passengers had to cancel their journeys or travel on a foreign line.

Hide futures prices continued to advance yesterday on the Commodity Exchange with the near-by December delivery closing 33 points higher. The spread between December and March at the market's close was 390 points but it had been well over 400 points several times during the day.

During the first three months under increased fares, the city's transit lines carried 10.91 per cent fewer passengers than during the corresponding period last year, but took in 56.95 per cent more money, the Board of Transportation reported yesterday.

American business prosperity will continue as long as this country is selling its products abroad and supporting the Marshall Plan foreign aid program, Leonard Hicks, managing director of the Morrison Hotel, Chicago, and owner of Case Narina, Key West, Fla., declared yesterday at the thirty-third National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 9 -- Britain formally charged Albania today in the International Court of Justice with having mined Corfu Channel on Oct. 22, 1946, as a result of which the destroyers Saumarez and Volage were heavily damaged and forty-four sailors killed.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The Slav filibuster in the United Nations Balkan debate ended its second day today with the United States warning that the delaying tactics would hamstring the Assembly more than the veto "frustrates" the Security Council.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Quiet conditions ruled in the stock markets today and prices tended to ease in almost every section.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- In emphatic and categorical terms the British War Office denied today that there were any British troops in Trans-Jordan or that any had entered Palestine.

How a few well-chosen accessories may enliven a room is indicated in the forty-fifth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Craftsmen, which opens today at the Barbizon-Plaza Galleries, 1O1 West Fifty - eighth Street.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The South African Government will resist all attempts by the United Nations to interfere with its administration of the trust territory of south-west Africa, E. H. Louw, South African Minister of Mines, said today.

WAR and violence, looting, rape and massacre, have one common origin in fear. Conquerors sacking a town may not seem to be motivated by fear, but all unwittingly they are. This was the philosophy of Ibrahim, the passively fatalistic proprietor of fourteen houseboats which he rented to the British tourists who vacationed in his native mountain Province of Kandahar.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 9 -- Mrs. Helen Weiss, 35 years old, drew $1,000 in $100 bills from a savings bank here today and tried to distribute it to persons who struck her fancy. When She attempted to give one to Kenneth Erwin, special officer in Ohrbach's department store at Market and Halsey Streets, he turned her over to the police.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Business conditions appeared to have stabilized during October, according to a report issued today by W. B. Cressy, chairman of the business survey committee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago. Changes in some basic economic conditions were the smallest recorded in a number of months, he added.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 (AP) -- The most beautiful comet since Halley's paid an earthly visit thirty-eight years ago is sweeping through the skies tonight -- and giving astronomers a merry chase in trying to chart its course.

Rouben Mamoulian declared yesterday that television will not exert a harmful effect on motion pictures, but, instead, will depend upon films for its material. He also told a luncheon meeting of the American Television Society in the Hotel Astor that video's adverse influence will fall on radio whose "destiny is going downhill."

Members of the Committee of St. Johnland Auxiliary of Women have taken over the performance of "Bravo!" a new play by Edna Ferber and George S. Kaufman, on the night of Nov. 30 at the Lyceum Theatre to raise funds for the Society of St. Johnland.

United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey announced yesterday that 300 men and women had been ordered to report next Monday to the Federal Court House, Foley Square, for possible service as jurors in the trial of the twelve Communist leaders accused of conspiring to advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

Production by domestic steel mills during October established a high record of 7,973,416 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. On the preceding day the Institute reported that steel mill output this week would be the highest in history.

ROME, Nov. 9 -- Foreign Ministers Count Carlo Sforza for Italy and Karl Gruber for Austria this morning signed two conventions to facilitate the transit of Austrian persons and goods by road and railroad over the Italian territory between the frontier stations of Brenner and San Candido. The conventions are purely technical in character.

The airlines' dream of all-weather flying took another step toward realization last night when an inspection of the radar ground controlled approach system at La Guardia Field was completed and the equipment found ready for routine use in bad weather rather than solely as an emergency aid.

British ship production is still at a high level but certain types of construction work are nearing completion, with no new orders in sight, Sir Amos L. Ayre, chairman of the Shipbuilding Conference, a British shipyard association, said yesterday.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 9 (AP) -- United States Prosecutor Robert W. Kempner demanded today that twenty-one members of Hitler s wartime Foreign Office receive the death penalty for war crimes.

A 1918 living room, complete with golden oak woodwork, muddy buff wallpaper, chenile portieres and unclassifiable furniture, greets visitors to a new display that opened yesterday at the Sylvania Lighting Center, 500 Fifth Avenue. This dreary spectacle is quickly left behind, however, for scenes of lively light and color showing how the interior of a thirty-year-old house might be rejuvenated without too much in the way of architectural changes.

Those leaves are back again, those miserable leaves. All summer they hung properly on trees, pretty, if you like, but at least out of the way. All summer they formed a cool shade in which relaxing poets searched similes for nature's canopy and, finding no better, wrote "stet" to the original and went on to flower garlands.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Negotiations are going on secretly between Egyptian and Israeli representatives for peace in Palestine, a usually well-informed Egyptian source insisted today as the Security Council in a closed session prepared to seek the means of achieving a peace settlement to replace the present Palestine truce.

ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- Qualified New York State employers will receive $126,665,306 this year in tax credits against unemployment insurance taxes payable in 1949, the State Labor Department reported today.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The City of London's traditional Lord Mayor's show proved a brave but unhappy sight today. It was devoted entirely to recruiting for a possible third world war and was disturbed by three attempts of good-natured but mischievous students to break into the ranks.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade were under pressure early today in sympathy with a decline in securities, but turned strong later under the leadership of December corn, and the latter sold at a new high since Aug. 17 and December wheat and oats went to a new high since mid-July.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- This week it is France's turn to demonstrate the fallibility of political prophets. The success of the Gaullist bloc in last Sunday's election for the Council of the Republic was a surprise to everybody, including the leaders of the Rally of the French People, now represented for the first time as a political party in a national body.

The Board of Higher Education defended yesterday its recent exoneration of Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, chairman of the City College Romance Languages Department, who is accused of anti-Semitic practices.
VIENNA, Nov. 9 -- Chancellor Leopold Figl, speaking tonight at memorial exercises for the Austrian Jews murdered by the Nazis, declared:

A higher interest rate on GI home loans is needed to give a fillip to the lagging residential realty market and to attract adequate financing for prospective building operations, the United States Savings and Loan League was told yesterday at its annual convention in the Hotel Commodore.
THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial of Nov. 4 makes the false and malicious charge that in the recent campaign I accepted the support offered me "by the spokesmen of a foreign Power."

The United States Court of Appeals affirmed yesterday the right of insurance companies to sue the Federal Government for reimbursement of payments to persons who had claims against the Government for injuries but who had not brought suit.
The annual exhibition of useful objects at the Museum of Modern Art, which was expanded last year to 100 items costing from $100 downward, has resumed its former price level of $10 or less.

While Theodore W. Kheel, director of the City Labor Relations Division, renewed yesterday his efforts to settle the four-week-old strike of 3,000 beer drivers, a fifth brewery signed an individual pact with the strikers.

President Truman is reported to have said, or to have intimated, to his associates after the election that henceforward the foreign policy of this country is going to be determined in the White House, where law and custom say that it should be. As a corollary, that policy presumably then would be interpreted to other governments only through accredited representatives.

No indication that a supernatural force is at work controlling the fundamental life processes of cell reproduction, growth and function has ever been detected by the delicate instruments of modern biological physics and chemistry, Dr. Torbjoern Oskar Caspersson said yesterday.

A special investigating committee appointed by the left-wing international executive board of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, recommended yesterday that a recent referendum victory by supporters of Michael J. Quill, the union's president, be set aside on the ground that the results had been obtained by "very obvious fraud."

The Museum of Modern Art will put on exhibition today an arresting group of recent acquisitions. The eight objects are all of European origin, as the American accessions are being withheld for a debut presentation in the forthcoming show of American art from the museum's permanent collection.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Personal income in September continued at the record annual rate of $214,600,000,000, but it failed to show a gain for the first time in three months, the Commerce Department said today.

In a far-reaching move to improve the quality of New York's public education system, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, has recommended to the Board of Education a complete reorganization of its curriculum and statistical research division.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Louis De Rochemont and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer are negotiating a settlement of De Rochemont's producing contract, it was learned today from the studio. Negotiations are being carried on in New York, according to Metro, although the reason given for the termination of the contract is the company's decision not to make "Lost Boundaries,'' De Rochemont's projected film about "passing" from the Negro race to the white race.

The detailed procedure by which city officials are battling to stamp out venereal disease in New York was outlined here yesterday by Mrs. Katherine C. Nye, who supervises the activities of fifteen investigators working for the Bureau of Social Hygiene.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 10 (AP) -Japan was convicted today by the International Military Tribunal of waging "aggressive war" against the United States, the British Commonwealth Nations, the Netherlands and France.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Middle East experts in London expressed the opinion today that the protracted campaign in Palestine was imposing a severe financial strain on some of the Arab states whose budgets already are small and unsteady.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The United Nations Security Council will remain in session in Paris until Dec. 16, though the General Assembly hopes to adjourn on the 8th, it was decided at this morning's private session of the Council members.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Dapper Bruce Dudley of Louisville, former sports writer, today became the seventh-president of the American Association.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 9 -- Mrs. Samuel W. Halprin of New York was unanimously reelected national president of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization of America, by delegates of 265,000 Hadassah members at the final session of their thirty-fourth annual convention today.

The latex carrier St. Paul, converted by the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division from an LCT for the Farrell Lines West African coastal feeder service, is scheduled to leave in tow today on a 4,000-mile trip to Monrovia, Liberia.

Two Fordham linemen who had been marked "doubtful" for Saturday's contest with Holy Cross, yesterday were declared unavailable for the game, and one of them will be out of action for the remainder of the season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -The House Committee on Un-American Activities is going into hibernation for the rest of this year.
The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation announced yesterday that it had modified its registration statement, filed last week with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Although hopes run high here that Army's unbeaten team will continue in high gear against Penn in Philadelphia on Saturday as well as in the traditional game with Navy on Nov. 27, it became certain today that the football season would end against the midshipmen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, authorized the Air Force today to commission limited percentages of Annapolis and West Point graduates next June as an "interim" step toward possible future creation of a separate Air Force academy.

Sol Wand, 31-year-old wholesale meat dealer at 426 East Seventy-third Street, was fined a total of $600 with the alternative of 120 days in jail and received an extra thirty days' suspended sentence, when he pleaded guilty yesterday in Municipal Term Court to selling adulterated horse meat to restaurants.

The New York City Ski Council, with a membership of twenty-six clubs and 5,000 individuals, met last night at the Dartmouth Club to make plans for the 1948-49 winter season. John Claire, Long Island Ski Club, chairman, told the representatives that the council will hold its annual interclub races at the new Jiminy Peak ski area in Hancock, Mass., on Feb. 12 and 13.

A new high-speed continuous process for spinning viscose filament yarns has been developed by the American Viscose Corporation, it was announced yesterday. The company plans to install new machines for an initial 20,000,000 pounds of annual capacity with first deliveries of the new product scheduled for about January, 1951.

Columbia began defensive work for Saturday's game with Navy in a light contact workout at Baker Field yesterday. Emphasis was placed on defensive maneuvers to combat the middies' passing attack, but Coach Lou Little's squad went through an offensive workout as well.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Princess Elizabeth's baby, expected within the next four or five days, will be a prince or princess with the title or attribute of "royal highness." This was decreed tonight by King George and published in The London Gazette.
NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Newark Eagles, this city's representative in the Negro National Baseball League since 1935, is disbanding, Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Manley, co-owners, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A plan designed to end log-jams of legislation and appropriations and make generally for more orderly legislating is ready for presentation to the new Congress.

A resolution advocating Federal aid to education was defeated almost unanimously yesterday at the opening business session of the four-day fifty-fourth annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs. Only a few faint "ayes" opposed the vigorous "no's" echoing through the New Yorker Hotel grand ballroom.

The New York Women's League for Animals has broken with a past that goes back to 1910 and is now seeking male members. The women's organization, which runs the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital, one of the most famous animal hospitals in the country, has sent out letters to men, inviting them to become members, it was learned yesterday.

Manufacturing wage rates in New York City rose between April, 1943, and April, 1948, at a rate that outstripped the rise in the cost of living here, according to preliminary data on straight-time hourly earnings released yesterday by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The new November 1948, Manhattan telephone directories, alphabetical and classified (Red Book), are being delivered by carrier to subscribers, the New York Telephone Company announced yesterday. They are the "fattest" volumes yet, in this borough, and distribution and the collection of the old ones will require the services of 500 to 600 men putting in fifteen working days.

Since the time, three years ago, when last we heard Bernard Weiser in recital, he has grown conspicuously. This was shown at his recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, when he played a variously assorted program of old and of recent music, topping off with the Chopin B minor sonata which brought the printed list of the concert to an end.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Detailing his Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation's plan for leasing its new forty-passenger Convairliner to airlines, Floyd B. Odlum, chairman of the board, today told a news conference that he hoped for favorable action within thirty days on his company's application to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of about $43,000,000 that would comprise 73 per cent of the capitalization of the leasing subsidiary, the Convair Equipment Corporation.
For the first time in the history of the city's schools, kindergarten and first-grade pupils will wash and dry their hands under the aegis of the Board of Education.
Magistrate James A. Blanchfield denounced yesterday a practice of the police of sending complaint affidavits to the courts rather than have the patrolmen appear in person against minor offenders.

A dock tie-up here today was threatened late last night when it was reported that most of the locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, in this port had voted against a proposed new contract and that police precinct heads had ordered out radio patrol cars along the North River waterfront early this morning.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 9 -- The Navy varsity today got a firsthand look at the winged-T attack they will try to ground Saturday at Baker Field.

The Department of the Army has just published a large, handsome volume dedicated to the men of the Army who have been awarded the Medal of Honor. This medal is given to those who distinguish themselves in actual combat "by gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of life above and beyond the call of duty."

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Alexei P. Pavlov, Soviet delegate to the United Nations General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee, charged today that the United States press was only a tool of "magnates" and did not represent the "view of the people."

A tentative agreement between Press Wireless, Inc., and the Commercial Telegraphers Union, AFL, on terms of a new contract was announced yesterday by J. R. Mandelbaum, assistant regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly took the first steps today toward trying to return Greek children living in Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria to their parents in Greece.

The Packard-Federal Corporation, of which Robert D. King is president, has purchased the one and two story industrial building at 351 Grand Concourse, extending through to 350 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, from the Universal Metal Products Company. Joseph P. Day, Inc., and the James H. Burns Company were the brokers.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- The twin evils of fee-splitting and kickbacks in the medical profession can be eliminated only by a system of group practice in which specialists pool their knowledge to provide the patient with all the benefits of modern medicine, it was declared today at the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 9 -- Reorganization of Congress under Democratic leadership and Cabinet changes were put at the top of President Truman's vacation agenda tonight after he was joined here by Vice President-Elect Alben W. Barkley and Leslie Biffle, staff director of the Minority Policy Committee of the Senate.

Egon Bernath, president of Bernath Co., has purchased the five-story building at 28 East Fifty-sixth Street, southwest corner of Madison Avenue, as the new location for his sportswear store. William and Carl Oestreicher were the sellers and Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 9 (AP) -- President Juan D. Peron of Argentina was asked today to intervene in a controversy now raging over who won the $60,000 grand prize automobile race between Buenos Aires, the Argentine capital, and Caracas.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 9 -- Reorganization of Congress under Democratic leadership and Cabinet changes were put at the top of President Truman's vacation agenda tonight after he was joined here by Vice President-Elect Alben W. Barkley and Leslie Biffle, staff director of the Minority Policy Committee of the Senate.

Egon Bernath, president of Bernath Co., has purchased the five-story building at 28 East Fifty-sixth Street, southwest corner of Madison Avenue, as the new location for his sportswear store. William and Carl Oestreicher were the sellers and Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 9 (AP) -- President Juan D. Peron of Argentina was asked today to intervene in a controversy now raging over who won the $60,000 grand prize automobile race between Buenos Aires, the Argentine capital, and Caracas.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, said today that the charitable trusts in the textile empire of Textron, Inc., were like a "shell game." He asserted the public had to pay a higher share of taxes because the trusts, "by questionable devices," escaped payment of income taxes.

Jockey Ted Atkinson and a colt named Royal Blood went to the rescue of players of favorites in yesterday's fifth race at Jamaica. They combined their talents for a front-running triumph that was the first scored by a favorite at the Empire City meeting since last Saturday's seventh event.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Dr. Amazasp A. Arutiunian of the Soviet Union today took up Poland's attack in the United Nations against the Marshall Plan, describing the latter scornfully as "a Marshallizing process to make Western Europe fully dependent on Yankees."

A set of White House autographs by the thirty-one Presidents from George Washington to Franklin D. Roosevelt brought $750 at auction yesterday in the sale of the library of Mrs. G. J. Guthrie Nicholson of Newport, R. I. The two-session sale yesterday and Monday was held at the Parks-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, and realized $16.324.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Two Russian-born Jews, once persecuted for their faith in the land of their birth, quietly affirmed today that they were "proud" to give their war hero son in service to their adopted country.

The Thorobred Company, Inc., Cincinnati, manufacturer of the Thorobred line of dog foods, to the Cincinnati office of Roy S. Durstine, Inc., for consumer media advertising. An initial newspaper campaign in the Cincinnati area will be extended to other key cities in Ohio, Indiana and Kentucky.
The development of atomic energy -- for war and for peace -- will be one of the host of problems with which the Federal Government must cope during the next four years.

Dividend disbursements on the common stock of the United States Gypsum Company will amount to $6 this year, an increase of $2 over 1947 payments, with the declaration yesterday of an extra of $1.50 and the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents voted payable on Dec. 31.

The third season of professional basketball at Madison Square Garden will get under way tonight, with the Minneapolis Lakers, headed by the great George Mikan and Jim Pollard, opposing the New York Knickerbockers. A crowd of 12,000 is expected at this Basketball Association of America contest, which will be preceded by an American League preliminary between Wilkes-Barre and Bridgeport at 7:30 P.M.
Construction of the first hall in the Museum of Natural History designed exclusively for exhibition of plant life is expected to begin next year, it was learned yesterday.

The Greenpoint People's Regular Democratic Club has lost some of its regularity, it was disclosed yesterday, after the members found they had been locked out of their own clubhouse at 119 Norman Avenue, Brooklyn. This is the organization that made the late Peter J. McGuinness famous as the "Democratic boss of Greenpoint."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- George Munger gazed out of the window of his office at Franklin Field, lost in stygian reflection. Outside, the falling rain and drab skies were in harmony with the somberness of his mood.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted today to give state courts rather than an international tribunal the power to try any persons accused of the crime of mass extermination, a decision believed by many here to sound the death knell for the proposed international pact on genocide.

The conclusion reached by your editorial of Nov. 5 that Mr. Truman's election by a relatively small popular vote margin is by no means a "smashing endorsement" of his entire legislative program is certainly warranted. One fact should be kept in mind, however. While this election has shown that a bandwagon psychology sways few voters, a bandwagon tendency does appear after the election.

G. William Rasch, former vice president of the Brooklyn Savings Bank, has sold his twelve-acre estate on Sag Harbor Cove, North Haven, L.I., to Herman M. Brown of Des Moines, Iowa, manufacturer of highway construction machinery.

Charles L. Wagner's touring production of Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette," now in its seventh week on the road, played last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, squeezing the borough in between Springfield, Mass., where it played Tuesday, and Jamestown, N.Y., where it will repeat the opera tonight.

The sentence of Alexander D.L. Thiel, 62-year-old forger who in 1945 admitted a crime for which the late Bertram M. Campbell served a prison term, was reduced by four years yesterday when the defendant, broken and emaciated, appeared before General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen.

Under the terms of the recently signed Port Watchmen's agreement, pier guards caught stealing are faced not only with the loss of their jobs, but also with permanent expulsion from their union, Edward E. Conroy, executive vice president of the Security Bureau, Inc., explained yesterday.

Both radio and television versions of "On Trial" will be put on the air when the program is resumed by ABC on Monday, Nov. 22. The telecast is scheduled for 8 to 8:30 P.M., the broadcast for 10:30 to 11 P.M. The series, taking its format from courtroom procedure, is devoted to examination of present controversial questions, nationally and internationally.

A review of the activities of the Foreign Policy Association during its thirty years of existence was made public by the association yesterday. The Foreign Policy Association was founded Nov. 11, 1918, by a group of New York men and women who believed that the United States had entered World War I without sufficient widespread knowledge of the issues at stake.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The National Security Council has reviewed the China situation in the light of its rapid deterioration and has submitted recommendations to President Truman, it was learned today.

Msgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, who has been Administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral for the last nine years, has been appointed an Auxiliary Bishop of the New York Archdiocese, according to word received here early today. He will be the Titular Bishop of Metelis.

Relatively normal weather was expected today as a cold air mass moved into the metropolitan area last night to dispel recurrent fog and mild temperatures and a tropical storm veered out to sea instead of battering New York.

Huge pumpkins pointed the way up Carnegie Hill yesterday to the third annual country fair in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. But not a drop of the good country rain that fell outside of 2 East Ninetieth Street splashed on the wares set up under a canopy of orange paper sunshine in the parish-house auditorium.

Six had been entered, but only three started in the chief item of business at misty, sloppy, showery Jamaica yesterday. It was a Class C contest with the strange name of the Tragedy Handicap and C.V. Whitney's gray 4-year-old filly Silver Fog took it with a most estimable run around the last turn and through the stretch.
Mrs. Amelia Marie Propper, a church deaconess, had to have two cakes yesterday to hold all of her birthday candles. One hundred years old, Mrs. Propper blew out twenty of the candles in one breath.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 10 (AP) -- The seventy-five-acre Brookline, Mass., estate of Mrs. Isabel Weld Perkins Anderson, widow of the late diplomat, Larz Anderson, was bequeathed to the town of Brookline today in a will disposing of $7,000,000 of property.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- In his speech of acceptance to the Democratic National Convention last July, President Truman spread his nets in every pool that teems with voters. But he added special bait for the support of farmers and labor unionists, and the election returns are even more impressive of his catch in the first-named waters than the second.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Article Seventeen of the United Nations draft Declaration of Human Rights upholding freedom of speech and of the press was approved today by 36 to 6 with no abstentions as drafted by the Commission on Human Rights.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Wage rates in manufacturing rose 8.7 per cent, or almost 11 cents, in the year ended in September, preliminary estimates released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed today. In the three years since V-J Day, the increase in wage rates was about 43 per cent.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- Italy and Turkey signed today a trade agreement containing the novel feature that any eventual balance in favor of either signatory may be transferred to any country participating in the European Recovery Program and used for the purchase of goods there.

The Israel Corporation of America, which last month entered into a partnership agreement with the Jewish Agency for Palestine to further the economic development of essential industries and a vast program of housing in Israel, announced yesterday' authorization by the Securities and Exchange Commission for issuance of stock.
Does a dullard described as a "high grade moron", make the safest automobile driver? This question was interpolated yesterday into the discussion of country-wide traffic problems.

Coffee futures advanced 45 to 48 points on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices were at the best levels of the day in a firm close. Sales aggregated 6,750 bags. Buying by producer interests and scattered short covering of the near-by positions, coupled with the uncertainty over the longshoremen's strike, aided the advance.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 10 -- Full support to solidarity of the Western Hemisphere, forest conservation in the South and encouragement to schools of journalism was pledged today by members of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Determined efforts to kill the House Committee on Un-American Activities in the Eighty-first Congress assembling next January were signaled today.

There is no use to claim infallibility. It may be unconscious favoritism toward an orchestra with which we grew up. But it is the inescapable conclusion, and to the best of this deponent's knowledge and belief, after hearing brilliant performances in preceding weeks by other symphonic ensembles, that there is no other orchestra in the country which for finish, glow of tone and distinction of style equals the Boston Symphony.
PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 10 (AP) -The National Grange convention heard a plea today that organized labor hold off on demands for a new round of wage increases.

As the result of an order issued yesterday by the Public Service Commission, 3,800 employes of the Surface Transportation Corporation and its subsidiaries probably will receive next Thursday the first installment on their retroactive wage payments, a spokesman for the Third Avenue Transit Corporation announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The predicament in which American business pictures itself as a result of recent court decisions on pricing policies is "greatly overstated," Herbert A. Bergson, assistant attorney general, declared today.

Although the United States retains its great industrial potential, there is no certainty that the months is prepared to win a six-months or one-year war, Maj. Gen. W.H. Middleswart, assistant Quartermaster General, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The American Federation of Labor is determined to unite its forces quickly on a program to win the next Congress to new labor legislation as a substitute for the Taft-Hartley Act, it was disclosed today.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The expected battle between the Union of South Africa and many non-administering powers led by India began at today's meeting of the United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee, when Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Indian delegate, denounced what she said were the miserable conditions of non-European populations in South-West Africa, a trust territory administered by the South African Government.

Low-cost public housing stands at or near the head of the list in most forecasts of the measures which President Truman will propose to the new (Eighty-first) Congress when it meets. Surely this reflects a proper emphasis. There is a crying need of effective action in this area.

There is a definite flaw in the reasoning of your editorial, "The Nineteenth Man," in THE TIMES of Nov. 5. You point out that President Truman's plurality appears to be only "about 2 million" and his electoral total 304, and go on to comment:

Many an angler who has been opposing his wife's pleas for a Bermuda vacation probably will change his tune when he learns that two big bonefish, both crowding the world record for this fish, have been taken at the island.

En route ot the steamer De Grasse, Christian Dior, who sailed yesterday for France, gave a special interview to Virginia Pope, fashion editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, on the WQXR program, "Keeping Up With the Times." It was the French couturier's first American venture on the radio.

TOKYO, Nov. 10 -- A final decision on the exchange rate for the yen now rests with Washington. The recommendations and supporting arguments of the Supreme Command Allied Powers in the Pacific were submitted some time ago. Since the acceptable rate would depend upon the time when it was made effective it was understood that the recommendations were not specific about a precise figure but indicated the factors that should be considered when setting it.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Army's badly battered warriors continued their preparations for Penn in a heavy rain on the Plain today. The two platoon system never was more clearly defined as Coach Earl Blaik kept the defensive units scrimmaging on a very muddy field while the offensive squads enjoyed the comparative comfort of the huge field house.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Traders placed a bearish construction on a Department of Agriculture estimate on the corn crop issued late today, showing an increase in the yield of 82,000,000 bushels as compared with Oct. 1. Including carry-over, there is a total of 3,768,000,000 bushels available for use during the 1948-49 crop year, compared with 2,687,000,000 bushels the previous season and 3,423,000,000 bushels in 1946-47.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 -- The elements, not Princeton, pushed Yale's football team around today. For the first time this year, Coach Herman Hickman had to retreat indoors to complete part of the practice session.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- William L. Clayton, a top administration official for the last eight years, resigned as economic assistant to the Secretary of State, it was disclosed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 -- William N. Margolis, assistant director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, announced tonight that he was calling a peace meeting of the disputants in the West Coast maritime strike for tomorrow morning.

Inquiries for machine tools for industrial installations have increased substantially throughout the country, and many of these are expected to be converted to orders, machine tool builders reported here yesterday.

Mention Wiggins Country Store to a Smith College alumna and she probably will exclaim about the old-fashioned candies she used to buy there when she was an under-graduate. Many a student has spent a goodly part of her allowance on the rock candies, peppermint pillows and other now-rare sweets offered in this shop at Northampton, Mass.
First steps have been taken to start the largest American development of the highest grade chrome ore deposits on this continent, it was disclosed yesterday.

A hold-up man with a troubled conscience, who on Tuesday had made off with $427 from the offices of the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, Local 65, at 13 Astor Place, gave himself up for arrest yesterday after refunding the money to union officials.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Army opened files marked "top secret" today to dispute charges of incompetence leveled by Lieut. Gen. Holland M. Smith of the Marine Corps against the leadership of the Army in general and the Twenty-seventh Infantry Division in particular, during the crucial battle of Saipan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Two of the nation's defense leaders paid solemn Armistice Day tribute to American dead of two World Wars today and pledged to work for future peace through a strong, united America and international cooperation.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- The second annual Congress of the European Union of Federalists, who are working for creation of federation of European states, came to a close tonight in Rome where it had been sitting since Sunday. The Congress approved a motion in favor of bringing about the unification of all groups and institutions that are striving towards same objective in all Western European countries.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Quiet conditions ruled in the Stock Markets here today.

The United States Court of Appeals was asked yesterday by attorneys for the twelve Communist leaders accused of conspiring to advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government to issue a writ of mandamus directing the disqualification of Federal Judge Harold R. Medina as presiding judge.

Knowledge of the broad inquiry into rent gouging in Queens has prompted landlords there to return at least $100,000 obtained from tenants in the form of bonuses and illegal payments, J. Irwin Shapiro, chief assistant District Attorney, said yesterday.
The United States Marine Corps throughout the nation and in many emplacements all over the world celebrated yesterday the 173d anniversary of its birth as the oldest American fighting force.

The possibility that one of the many camera portraits of Abraham Lincoln may become the means of bringing a little luxury to a 12-year-old Bronx boy was revealed yesterday by Miss Caroline Nathan, principal of Public School 39.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 (UP) -- A wartime law enabling the Government to reduce or suspend royalty payments made by private industry to patent owners to prevent "excessive profits" was upheld as constitutional today.

At the best, a commuter is a bundle of taut nerves held together by baling wire, binder twine and the necessity of somehow bringing up the children. Nature is against him, nature in the form of ice, snow, rain and sleet, and constantly he is meeting new and contrived hurdles.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 10 -- The United Nations Truce Supervisory Board sent a strong protest today to the Israeli Army over the arrest of two military observers present during the action involving Iraq Suweidan in the Negeb yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 3:

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- A six-power conference on the Ruhr opens here tomorrow under the shadow of French hostility to the United States and British plan to transfer control of Ruhr industries to German trustees.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- Sanitation conditions in the United States are in a number of major respects considerably worse than they were a hundred years ago, Prof. Abel Wolman of Johns Hopkins University reported today at the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The reports in Moscow received no official support here today.
Jay Thorpe held the first of a series of teas for brides and their mothers yesterday afternoon in the bridal shop.

Forced indoors yesterday by a muddy field, City College's football team was restricted to a signal drill and a blackboard session in which several new plays were taught. Saturday's encounter with Hofstra College will be the last game for City this year and Coach Harold Parker expects to test the new maneuvers, especially designed for use against single-wing elevens, under game conditions.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- A United Nations subcommittee dealing with urgent measures for aid to 500,000 Arab refugees from Palestine completed its work today and approved a draft resolution for submission to the United Nations Social Committee Friday afternoon.

When the snows start falling and the air is crisp, a hardy and comparatively new breed of sports folks, the skiers, flee by the thousands from the city for retreats in upper New York State and New England. Every Friday toward sundown these snowbirds start rolling northward by automobiles for their favorite slopes and trails.

The International Paper Company and its subsidiaries transacted the largest net sales for any nine-month period in its history and with the exception of 1947, exceeded the annual volume for every year on record, according to the report issued jointly yesterday by John H. Hinman, president, and Richard J. Cullen, chairman.
There was lots of fights I didn't feel too good. In my first fight with Arturo Godoy in New York on Feb. 9 in 1940, I really dogged it. I didn't feel peppy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- In spite of increased world food supplies, lower income groups in most countries have not been able to obtain as good a diet in 1947-48 as in 1946-47, due to rising costs of living, the Food and Agriculture Organization reported today.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Miss Ella A. Widener's Adaptable found three miles and twenty-two jumps right up his alley at Pimlico today and ran off with the $15,000 added Manly Steeplechase Handicap.

The stock market took another plunge yesterday, but steadying influences which developed during the last hour tended to repair some of the extreme damage. The list in the Stock Exchange was forced to absorb again some heavy liquidation in the prime industrial issues, but the offerings were taken readily.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The state has reached the end of its lush years, when revenues ran far ahead of expenditures, and is confronted with the probability of a deficit of as much as $50,000,000 for the current fiscal year.

PEDRO DE VALDIVIA, Chile, Nov. 10 -- The extraction of natural sodium nitrate by solar evaporation is being attempted here experimentally. Experts say that the process, if successful, will bring the nitrate industry to a revolutionary new phase.

The Social Science Research Council announced yesterday the appointment of seven research authorities to study the methods and records used by polling agencies in making forecasts on the Presidential election.
VIENNA, Nov. 10 -- Growing apprehension was spreading through Vienna today.

Another of the first questions to face the Eighty-first Congress when it convenes will be what to do about the House Un-American Activities Committee, which has certainly been the most controversial committee of the last few years and possibly of all time. Since it is a standing committee of the House, it will continue unless it is abolished.

European economic cooperation, "a hope six months ago, is today a fact," Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, said last night at the World Trade Dinner closing the thirty-fifth annual convention of the National Foreign Trade Council in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 10 -- A split-up of stock on the basis of two shares for one, subject to approval of the annual meeting of stockholders on Feb. 16, 1949 was recommended today by the board of directors of the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland, coincident with the declaration of a stock dividend of $600,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- American buyers of new automobiles were mulcted to the extent of an estimated $450,000,00 during the first seven months of this year, a Congressional inves tigating subcommittee charged today.

The New York Athletic Club celebrated its eightieth anniversary last night with a dinner at the city club house, that was attended by more than 1,000 members and guests. Five former presidents of the New York A.C., George J. Corbett, William A. Dalton, Orie Kelly, Col. Henry W. Ryan and Gilbert B.J. Frawley, all of whom served between 1920 and 1944, were present.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Dr. Cyril F. Garbett, Archbishop of York, denouncing Marxist Communism said today that there was another form of Communism consistent with Christianity.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Robert Piguet proves anew the elegance of all black in a small but significant collection for the Christmas holidays. The ideal black faille suit for wear under a fur coat is stem skirted. The gracious tuxeudo front front on the jacket gathers at the throat onto a standing collar, but below the waistline it becomes a standaway cuff bordering the cut-away.

"Bravo!", the sixth collaborative effort by Edna Ferber and George S. Kaufman, the writing partnership that contrived such hits as "Dinner at Eight," "Stage Door" and "The Royal Family," will be unfolded this evening at the Lyceum Theatre.

In memory of a friend who died of cancer, twenty New York women have raised enough money for the Hospital for Joint Diseases, Madison Avenue and 123d Street, to purchase a 2,000,000-volt X-ray machine for cancer research and treatment.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- A final decision by trade union leaders to carry through the twenty-four-hour work stoppage in the bizonal area beginning at midnight tomorrow was made this evening. The strike is planned as a protest demonstration against the high living costs.

A pretty, 20-year-old nun had her sight restored after complete blindness. The eyes of a young woman, closed since girlhood, were opened so she might see the man she had married and the two babies she had borne. An aging news vender, condemned to fumble at his street corner in perpetual darkness, regained the sunlight with the cornea of a child who died in infancy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Otis Co. of Cleveland, investment bankers, asked the Federal District Court here today to enjoin the Securities and Exchange Commission from holding a hearing to determine whether to revoke or suspend the broker-dealer registration of the banking house.

What started as an easy job for the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night turned into a mighty tough task. Off to a two-goal lead in the first period of their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks, the Blue Shirts seemed about to have things their own way, especially since the score halfway through the third period read 4 to 1 in their favor.

NANKING, Nov. 10 -- Martial law was proclaimed in Nanking and Shanghai tonight and the central broadcasting station announced the establishment of a midnight curfew. These steps were taken following another day of large-scale rice rioting here in which three persons were trampled to death and eleven injured by policemen's pistol butts in the course of food raids on at least forty rice shops, bakeries and restaurants.

PROFESSIONAL football isn't the only sport which has had a "cold war" waged between rival leagues. Basketball had one of its own until last spring and it was settled by an Anschluss, which probably is the identical way the gridiron battle for supremacy will be determined. The stronger circuit absorbed the most attractive teams of the weaker one and thus put itself on an infinitely more solid footing.

Crowds jammed the Thirty-third National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace for the third successive day yesterday and exhibitors reported that a three-phase trend of color, fashion and comfort has appeared in active buying by hotels.

"HERE'S a pretty kettle of fish," said Walgrove Snood, the literary banker, as he encountered his friend Kim Carruthers, the benevolent bookman, on the 5:58 for Niblickdale. "Have you seen John Chamberlain's piece in the November issue of Fortune?"

BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- The Russians declared today their intention of forcing down all United States and British planes flying outside the corridors leading to blockaded Berlin and all aircraft without identification flying over the Soviet zone.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed unchanged to 11 points lower.

A plan through which American business concerns can use their regular advertising in foreign countries to combat communism and correct misconceptions about the United States was announced here yesterday by the Advertising Council.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- President Truman's controversial White House balcony is going to appear on the country's money.

A year's fellowship for the study of rehabilitation in the Hospital for Special Surgery has been granted to Dr. Jack Lovelock, assistant director of physical medicine at the hospital, it was announced yesterday.

"The Book of Great Conversations," a collection of selected dialogues by world figures, edited by Louis Biancolli, will be published by Simon Schuster on Nov. 23. The dialogues range from Socrates to Joseph Stalin. They are presented in a dramatic form, with stage directions to indicate the action, and each is preceded by a short biographical essay.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- Jeffrey Lynn and Martha Scott have been signed by RKO to play the leading roles in "Sam Wynne," which Will Price will direct from a novel by J.M. Wallis described as a melodrama about a New York bookkeeper.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Newark Star-Ledger tomorrow will quote Dan Topping, co-owner of the Yankee baseball empire and president of the Newark Bears, as saying that the local International League club definitely is for sale.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 10 -- Netherland authorities are seriously considering a modification of their highly efficient exchange control to encourage exports to the United States.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- A highly qualified observer who recently returned from Palestine, where he conferred with Israeli military leaders, expressed doubt today of Tel Aviv reports that British troops had entered Palestine on the Arab side.

Renewed conflict between the moderate and left wing elements of the American Veterans Committee came into the open yesterday when it was learned that forty AVC chapters in the New York area face possible suspension three weeks before the national convention.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff, told a Boston Chamber of Commerce luncheon today that America's greatest weapon in the East-West conflict is the proof by its citizens of Democracy's ability to provide economic progress as well as human freedom.
Half of the city waterfront was immobilized yesterday by a wildcat walkout of American Federation of Labor longshoremen.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Competition primarily, and cooperation and conservation by all concerned, have won the battle against the recent "superdemand" for petroleum and its products, Dr. Robert E. Wilson, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company (Ind.), declared here today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Informed that the broken ankle suffered by Ken O'Donnell, Harvard football player, had resulted from contact with a plastic helmet, Athletic Director William J. Bingham today advised the Crimson coaching staff that such equipment would be illegal after the 1949 season.

Fear that Federal grants for education would result in a regimented, standardized type of education inimical to democracy was expressed last night by Dr. Claybrook Cottingham, president of Louisiana Polytechnic Institute.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 10 -- The President of the United States is growing chin whiskers.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 10 -- Lieut. Comdr. Karel Kovacitch, 34-year-old former Yugoslav naval officer, will be Britain's star witness in the Corfu Channel case against Albania before the International Court of Justice. He will testify that Yugoslavia laid the mines in Albanian waters that blew up two British destroyers with the loss of forty-four lives on Oct. 22, 1946.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Branding recent increases in bank reserve requirements and rediscount rates as "puny gestures" against inflation, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, today called on the rest of the insurance industry to join in his campaign to halt pegging of the Government bond market.
PARIS, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The text of the Balkan resolution by the United States, France, Britain and China, as approved today by the Political Committee of the United Nations Assembly:

At 7 A.M. yesterday William Schnepel, the superintendent of a modern apartment house at 306 Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx, was startled by a loud commotion above him. It sounded as if each of the sixty-five families was beating a metallic concerto on the house's water pipes.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the newly rebuilt Victoria, the attraction is "Joan of Arc," the picturization of the French martyr's life, starring Ingrid Bergman in the title role. Victor Fleming directed and Walter Wanger produced the Sierra Pictures presentation, which is being released by RKO, from a screen play by Maxwell Anderson and Andrew Solt based on the play "Joan of Lorraine," by Mr. Anderson.

The Florida State Improvement Commission sold yesterday an issue of $3,600,000 of Palm Beach County road and bridge revenue bonds due from 1949 to 1968 and callable from 1959 on to a banking syndicate headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., at a bid of 100 for 3 1/4s.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 10 -- Bobby Jones, the great golfer, is still in the University Hospital here where he underwent an operation on Oct. 30 which proved to be more serious than anticipated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Farm income in October dropped about 3 per cent below the high record of October, 1947, the Department of Agriculture reported today. It was the first month this year in which farmers' cash receipts have fallen below the corresponding month of last year.
The right-wing executive board of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, CIO, suspended yesterday its leftist president, Austin Hogan, and two other officers of the local.
The fifty-sixth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers opened yesterday afternoon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for a three-day session.
"The Vision of Saint Thomas," a painting by Botticini (1446-1498) never before exhibited in this country or abroad, is now on view in the west transept of the Fordham University Church.
ATHENS, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis said tonight that any compromise with the Communist-led guerrillas would mean "submission to a force unworthy of the Greek people."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- By common definition and political tradition a "rascal" in Washington is a person appointed to office by the party that has just lost an election. And in accordance with this tradition, of course, this is the time "to kick the rascals out."

New Yorkers hardened to the ways of Forty-second Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues can now announce that they have seen just about everything there. In the past they have seen bright lights, side shows, cheap movies, chestnut venders' stands, flea circuses.

Bill Olson, Columbia's dependable wingback, has been selected captain for this Saturday's game with Navy, Coach Lou Little announced yesterday. The Garden City, L.I., senior will lead the Lions before Columbia's third capacity crowd of the year.

The United States Court of Appeals reversed yesterday the ruling of a Federal Court judge who last June dismissed a stockholders' suit to enjoin the American Woolen Company from putting into effect a retirement pension plan for salaried employes.

The forced feeding of vital chemical substances to cells misfunctioning in a diseased or crippled human body holds great promise for the solution of baffling medical problems ranging from cancer to treatment of the insane, Dr. Torbjoern O. Caspersson said last night.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company yesterday introduced what it claims is an entirely new type of carpeting during formal opening of its remodeled New York show-rooms and headquarters at 140 Madison Avenue. The new product features an integrated wool face sponge rubber back construction and first orders will be taken at the January homefurnishings market, according to G.C. Denebrink, vice president for sales.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- What will probably be the most effective weapon against strikers was announced today by the French Government. The family allowance paid to some workers and notably miners, will not be paid in future to men who have worked fewer than eighteen days in a month.

It was a dull and dripping day outside yesterday and the general oppressiveness even made itself felt within the cheery confines of the Stadium Club, where a gathering was assembled for the weekly luncheon of the New York Football Yankees.
CAMP HOOD, Tex., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, is serving a two-week tour of active duty in the organized reserve here as a lieutenant colonel.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The British Government's Film Finance Company, which is authorized to lend up to 5,000,000 ($20,000,000), has granted its first loans to help British movie production.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 10 -- Eben Ayers, assistant White House press officer, denied tonight that there was any truth to a Washington report, broadcast without comment by Tass, the Russian official news agency, from Moscow, suggesting that President Truman and Premier Stalin might meet, either in Washington or Moscow.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Ben Hogan, a native Texan who plays his golf as a representative of Hershey, Pa., has been named "golfer of the year" by the Professional Golfers' Association.

Aiming to capitalize on Fordham's speed and what he believes a more polished T-formation against Holy Cross Saturday, Coach Ed Danowski conducted a ninety-minute practice yesterday as rain curtailed activities.

Financial and commodity markets throughout the country will be shut today in observance of Armistice Day. Banks in most states also will observe the holiday. Canadian exchanges will be closed for the Dominion's Remembrance Day, but European markets will operate as usual.
Hermon More, curator of the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, since its founding in 1930, has been appointed director, it was announced yesterday.

Civic organizations interested in comprehensive rezoning of the city have been asked to submit specific suggestions for rezoning of their communities to the City Planning Commission. Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the commission, said yesterday that these organizations had received maps upon which they could indicate their views.

December 15, the day of World Christmas Festival and World Chanukah Festival, should be made happier this year for children of sixteen foreign countries who will receive gifts from hundreds of school children in this country. Thousands of holiday gifts, all gaily wrapped and marked "For a boy, aged 9," "For a 15-year-old girl," or otherwise as appropriate, have arrived here en route to Europe and Asia from children all over the United States.

October rayon yarn and staple fiber shipments totaled 94,400,000 pounds, an increase of 7 per cent over the corresponding month last year, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. For the first ten months of the year, shipments totaled 913,700,000 pounds, a gain of 16 1/2 per cent above shipments in the corresponding period of 1947 and 30 per cent over those in the first ten months of 1946.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Cooper Hanover topped the second day of bidding at the tenth annual standard bred horse sale today with a $15,000 price tag.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- American women have come to the realization that the United States must remain prepared, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told a French press conference here tonight.

A three-day supply of bread, untouched on the doorstep where it had been delivered, led yesterday at Dongan Hills, S.I., to the discovery that an elderly caretaker had died in a disused mansion overlooking the lower bay and that a disabled companion, dependent on the other for food, was starving inside the locked house while the bread accumulated.

Comic books should be placed under censorship similar to that over the movies, Mrs. George C. Porter, historian of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, declared yesterday at the organization's convention in the New Yorker Hotel.

A community of the nations that are founded upon recognition of the worth of the individual in democracy is growing on both shores of the Atlantic out of the Marshall Plan and the Brussels Pact, Sir Oliver Shewell Franks, British Ambassador to the United States, declared last night.

Making available American crime comic books to Germans with ECA funds does not seem the soundest way to demonstrate the advantages of our democratic society. In the critical propaganda struggle nosy going on between the Soviet Union and the Western democracies to win the allegiance of the German people, does it make sense to send publications that present the worst and most distorted aspect of American life?

An art exhibition minus art works had its preview yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. The show, "Art in the Neighborhood," was sponsored by the United Neighborhood Houses and the museum's committee on art education.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 -- Automobile production at the Chrysler Corporation dropped sharply today as a strike at the company's Jefferson plant made more than 9,000 employes idle.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Saburo Kurusu, Japan's special pre-Pearl Harbor "peace" envoy to Washington, was aware of Hideki Tojo's plan in using his negotiators to mask a surprise attack on the United States, the International Military Tribunal for the Far East ruled today.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Andrew N. Winslow Jr., director of one of the charitable trusts set up by Textron, Inc., testified today that he and officials of other trusts set up by the textile corporation were instructed to ignore Federal tax demands.

TOKYO, Nov. 10 -- The International Military Tribunal trying Hideki Tojo and other accused war criminals ruled today that atrocities were committed by the Japanese armed forces on so vast a scale and with so common a pattern that the actions must have been either secretly ordered or "willfully permitted" by the Japanese Government.

Long Island community officials, business men and civic organizations will be asked to help organize public opinion and marshal evidence for a fight against the Long Island Railroad's move for increases in commutation fares, it was announced yesterday.
Citizens of New York will join the rest of the nation today in solemn observance of the thirtieth anniversary of the signing of the Armistice in World War I.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A record corn crop of 3,649,510,000 bushels -- 82,000,000 bushels more than forecast a month ago -- was estimated today by the Department of Agriculture in its semifinal crop report.

Beatrice Ficaro, soprano, and Beatrice Eppinelle, pianist, gave a program, yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, in the Recitals in Miniature series. Miss Ficaro, a lyric coloratura, who presented florid arias and several songs, disclosed a voice rich in possibilities not yet realized.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King, wartime Chief of Naval Operations, has decided he was too harsh with Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Admiral Harold R. Stark in the Pearl Harbor case.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Lou Hoitsma raised up from his end position and just sort of grinned. The William and Mary flankman, who once played center had just been told he'd been selected today as the lineman of the week in The Associated Press poll.

This is a holiday of the dead and of the living -- of dead men and dead hopes, of living men and hopes that will not die. The dictionary defines an armistice as "a brief cessation of arms * * * a temporary suspension of hostilities * * * a truce." In the case of the Armistice of 1918, for which this holiday was created, the definition was accurate.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- After more than two weeks' debate the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly today found Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria guilty of endangering peace in the Balkans and decided to keep the United Nations on-the-spot observation committee at work in Greece for another year.

Declaring that a settlement was "in process," Theodore W. Kheel, director of the City Labor Relations Division, said early today that he hoped to make "an announcement" regarding the beer strike after a meeting scheduled for 11 A.M. at City Hall.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Those talent-tagged kids known as bonus players were ignored today as the major leagues staged their annual baseball draft. Although the minors are studded with 270 youngsters good enough to get $6,000 or more for penning their names to contracts, not one was drafted for a big league trial.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The acting Palestine Mediator, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, asked Israeli representatives tonight to explain the arrest of two truce observation officers, which had been characterized by the senior officer in Haifa as "a deliberate attempt to thwart effective supervision of the truce and a flagrant violation of the Security Council resolution of Oct. 19."

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies increased 8 per cent in October, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to compilations of forty-three companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. An increase of 12.2 per cent was shown for the first ten months of the year.

Crude oil production in the United States last week again reached a new peak, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Output averaged 5,626,700 barrels a day, an increase of 22,600 over the previous week. A year ago, production averaged 5,239,550 barrels daily.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Another right of intrusion on the privacy of an Englishman's home, which he still regards as his castle, was recognized by Parliament tonight in the interest of improving British radio and television reception.

Periodic re-examination, second in importance only to early initial treatment, was stressed yesterday as an integral part of the current war against venereal disease in New York. Dr. Evans Thomas, director of the Rapid Treatment Center at Bellevue Hospital, pointed out that neglect of the follow-up treatment by the patient might permit a relapse as long as eighteen months after treatment began.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, president of the United Nations General Assembly, called on the Big Four tonight to settle their dispute over Berlin. He insisted that the area of disagreement between the Soviet Union and the Western powers had been reduced to that "between tweedledum and tweedledee."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 -- With Navy authorization from Washington, a Mars flying boat was to take off soon after midnight tonight with two tons of hay and 2,500 worms to appease the hunger of eight baby elephants, a number of exotic birds and other live cargo aboard a "Noah's ark" inbound from the Far East.
The Spanish liner Habana, bound for New York from Cadiz, Spain, was damaged Tuesday night when she collided with the Italian freighter Punta Mesco in a fog off Ambrose Lightship.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A number of Navy air and surface search craft swept the Pacific nine miles from this big Hawaiian naval base tonight in an attempt to locate a mysterious submarine. Pacific fleet submarine force headquarters said:

MOSCOW, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Moscow newspapers, from the smallest to the largest, printed the Tass dispatch today that quoted The Washington Times Herald as saying President Truman might come to Russia for a personal conference with Premier Stalin.
