In the face of a continued high rate of residential building, purchases of homes by war veterans with GI loans are declining sharply throughout the nation, T.B. King, head of the loan guaranty division of the Veterans Administration, reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Fog and unsafe playing conditions tonight forced a twenty-four-hour postponement of the Boston Bruins-Detroit Red Wings National Hockey League game at Boston Garden. The halt was called after nine minutes and one second of very slow action.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here today vacated a stay of District Judge Luther M. Swygert's contempt of court citation against the International Typographical Union which it issued on Oct. 18.

Colleges must place more emphasis on training students to deal with others, Dean Charles M. Edwards of New York University's School of Retailing declared yesterday. In his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase, he said that this aspect of education had been "woefully neglected" by most schools.
ROGURON ISLAND, Majuro Atoll, Marshall Islands -- The heavy drone of landing craft has not faded forever from the atoll lagoons of the Pacific.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- The United States and British Military Governments turned over to German trustees today temporary and limited control of the administration of the Ruhr coal, iron and steel industries.

Dedication of a new headquarters for the American Field Service at 113 East Thirtieth Street yesterday will enable that organization to provide additional facilities for its members and for foreign students who will be invited here under a scholarship program.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman formally protested to the United States and British Ambassadors today against an order issued by the United States and British Military Government indicating that final decision regarding the ownership of the Ruhr coal mines and steel industry would be left to a freely chosen German government.
The Pittston Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income in the nine months ended with last September of $4,183,969 after all deductions, including $2,891,516 provided for taxes.

One of the pleasures of an otherwise dismal summer in Britain has been contact with numerous students from the United States. Their visits are an important contribution to Anglo-American friendship, the need for which grows more important every day, and British hostesses, within the limitations imposed by shortages of household equipment, have given what they could of hospitality and have enjoyed their coming and been richly rewarded by their stay.

Barring unforeseen difficulties, the oil industry is confident that the oil transportation problem, which was so acute during, the winter of 1947-1948, has been solved, according to reports made public yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- A few hours before leaving for New York, Jacques Fath delighted his clients and the press with his mid-season collection, especially his glamourous evening gowns, enchanting in coloring.

Reactions in the automotive field were caustic and varied yesterday in the face of charges by a Congressional investigating subcommittee that buyers of new cars in this country have been mulcted of an estimated $450,000,000 in the first seven months of this year.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia held meetings this evening with the United States, British and French delegates in what was described as a new attempt to break the Big Four deadlock over Berlin dispute.

MADRID, Nov. 11 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco said today that he and the Spanish people desired an improvement in relations between Spain and the Unitedh)0*0*0*iStates. He also expressed the hope that this country could receive a United States loan to finance the replacement of outmoded industrial and transportation equipment.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, stalked from a hearing yesterday held by a committee of his left-wing opponents in the union on the ground that Armistice Day was no time for such a meeting.

A dispatch from Paris in THE TIMES of Nov. 6 states that the Legal Committee of the U.N. General Assembly has rejected a Soviet proposal that the convention on genocide exclude the defense of superior orders on the part of persons accused of extermination of peoples and races.

Commodore Siebe Vlietstra, master of the liner Nieuw Amsterdam and senior commander and commodore of the Holland-America Line fleet, has been retired after fortytwo years' service with the company. Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager of the line in the United States, Canada and Mexico, in making this announcement yesterday, said Commodore Vlietstra would be succeeded by Capt. Cornelis van Beek, until recently master of the Veendam.

Pointing to the nation's serious need for naval auxiliaries, Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, USN (Ret.), president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, asserted yesterday that the recent placing of orders for five new passenger ships was a most encouraging sign, even after two years of delay.

News of President Truman's election came as a surprise in Brazil but "we are satisfied with President Truman and we like his policies," Orlando Dantas, publisher of The Rio de Janeiro Diario de Noticias, said yesterday at La Guardia Field.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11 -The Big Three championship is supposed to be signed, sealed and ready for delivery to Princeton Saturday. By general consent, all that remains is for the Tiger to show up in the Yale Bowl and go through the formality of tying a bow knot in the Bulldog's tail.
FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP) -The Nevada Wolfpack returned to the winning column today by beating Fresno State, 53 to 7, before 13,500 football fans in Ratcliff Stadium.
NORRISTOWN, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A 30-year-old ex-convict admitted that he caused a fatal train wreck intending to loot the bodies of the victims, District Attorney W. Arnold Forrest reported today.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 11 -Heartened by a thunderous sendoff from the student body, Dartmouth's thirty-eight-man football squad entrained for Ithaca tonight for its big battle with once-beaten Cornell at Schoellkopf Field Saturday.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Seattle Hanover went for top money at the standard-bred horse sale here today as the auction's total reached a three-day high of $871,400.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Counsel for the railroads and for the sixteen non-operating unions have signed a stipulation which provides that the emergency board hearing the railroad wage dispute will have until Dec. 17 to file a report with President Truman.

WILMINGTON, Ohio, Nov. 11 -America's colleges and universities have the responsibility of developing "uncommon men and women who can undertake leadership in this nation," Herbert Hoover declared here this evening.

Festive after-dark fashions for the holidays, picturesque in their stiff fabrics of brocade and satin, taffeta and flowing chiffon, were shown yesterday by Rosette Pennington at the Plaza Hotel. Bodices curved prettily below white shoulders or were dramatically covered with long sleeves and high necklines.

The commercial airlines of the nation expect that the coming winter flying season will be the best in history from the standpoint of safety and the number of scheduled flights completed, Milton W. Arnold, vice president of the Air Transport Association, announced here yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Prime Minister Attlee rejected today a proposal that he approach President Truman and Premier Stalin to arrange an early meeting with them "for a discussion of presentday problems."

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The executive committee of the European organization under the Marshall Plan discussed today the interim report that must be made to W. Averell Harriman by Monday on the uncompleted European four-year economic plan.

James A. Roe was called upon yesterday by County Judge Thomas Downs of Queens to resign as Democratic leader of Queens County because of his outspoken criticism of President Truman before, during and since the Democratic National Convention at Philadelphia last June.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 -President Juan D. Peron said last night that he was looking forward to the day when all men in Argentina would be equal. He added that he was less interested in material gains than in the dignity that, "day by day," his regime was achieving for the working man.
The suburban areas around New York are growing three times as fast as the metropolis itself, the Regional Plan Association, Inc., 205 East Forty-second Street, reported yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- By unanimous vote the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee tonight asked the aid of the International Red Cross and of national Red Cross organizations in returning to their homeland some of the Greek children now living in Yugoslavia, Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and Poland.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- President Harry S. Truman declares that separation of church and state and the support of religious organizations by individuals has answered a problem which has "plagued humanity" at various times in other countries.
New York was playing host yesterday to more than 100 Argentine airmen, here on a sightseeing tour before starting out on a crosscountry inspection of flying fields and airplane factories.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 11 -Senator J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the Democratic national committee, said this evening that the Democrats would welcome cooperation from Republican Liberals in Congress and expressed the belief that President Truman would be lenient with minor offenders among the party's unfaithful.

Airline aeronautical engineers and mechanics at La Guardia Field were surprised at the technical knowledge displayed by a 12year-old boy who visited their facilities yesterday. They were even more surprised when they learned the young visitor to the field had been blind since birth.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 12 (UP) -The International Military Tribunal based its verdicts and sentences on the following ten of the fifty-five counts of the original indictment in the war crimes trial. It held these counts had been proved by the prosecution.

Kid Gavilan, holder of the welterweight championship of Cuba, will tackle Tony Pellone, willing battler from Greenwich Village, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Pellone was named as Gavilan's opponent a few days ago after Tony Janiro, the Cuban's original foe, had to withdraw because of a back injury.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- News stories which suggest what is going to happen should not "leave what has happened out of sight," J. R. Wiggins of The Washington Post told a meeting of the Associated Press Managing Editors Association today.

I was supposed to fight Billy Conn when we were in the service, but the fight never came off. When we went into the Army Billy and me had no way to make money to pay tax on the income we made before we got into the service.

Robert C. Richardson Jr., a retired lieutenant general of the Army, in a statement yesterday denounced recent magazine articles by Holland M. Smith, a retired lieutenant general of the Marines, as "distorted, malicious and misleading."

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- In unequivocal terms, the French delegation to the six-power conference that opened here today made clear its opposition to the United States and British plan for German trusteeship and control of the Ruhr coal, iron and steel industries.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- State Senator Thomas C. Desmond today termed "objectionable" three changes he said had been proposed for his newspaper confidence bill. He said "appeasement proposals" that would make "a mockery of one of the basic freedoms" had been advanced by foes of the bill.
If to be forewarned is to be forearmed Steve Owen and his Football Giants should be prepared for any eventuality when they tangle with the Los Angeles Rams at the Polo Grounds Sunday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- A warning that American housewives, who will spend about $4,000,000,000 for more than 20,000,000,000 cans of food in the next twelve months, "will pour millions of dollars worth of food-value down the kitchen sink" during that period unless they benefit from recent scientific findings, was issued here today by the National Canners Association.

The need for greater effort on the part of private builders and financing agencies to meet the backlog of demand for small homes throughout the nation was emphasized at yesterday's sessions of the fifty-sixth annual convention of the United States Savings and Loan League in the Hotel Commodore.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Stone Age came out of the pack and won the 42nd running of the $15,000 added Walden Stakes, historic test for 2-year-olds, at Pimlico today. It was the third victory of the program for Vanderbilt.
The average American city home gives its inhabitants a greater sense of insecurity than a Hottentot krall. At least in Africa the lions seldom venture into the village.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Friday, Nov. 12 -- Ten o'clock whistles at the Ruhr mines last night brought scores of thousands of men up from pits, to pour through the gates at Essen, Dortmund, Bochum and other communities. As they made for home no replacements came to the shafts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Former President Herbert Hoover disclosed today that the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government very likely would recommend an increase in Federal pay as a first step in obtaining more efficient, less costly government.

After weighing all factors of attraction of sites closer to steel producing areas, Purolater Products, Inc., Newark, N.J., decided to locate its new plant in the North Jersey portion of the Greater New York industrial area and has started drawing plans and specifications for facilities estimated to cost $1,000,000 to $2,000,000, officials disclosed in an interview yesterday.

The Wright brothers' original flying machine, prototype of the planes that altered the design of the world's navies, will return to this country on the flight deck of a United States Navy light carrier.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -Victor Mature, who is playing Samson in Cecil B. de Mille's "Samson and Delilah" at Paramount, will remain at the studio for a second picture under a loanout extension from Twentieth CenturyFox, it was learned today.

As a result of jacklighting and other forms of illegal hunting carried on prior to the opening of the deer season, many hunters who travel several hundred miles to try their luck in a much publicized deer area are finding only disappointment.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11 -- New Jersey teachers repeated tonight their request for a $2,500 minimum yearly salary and asked that retirement pensions be liberalized by the state.
LARCHMONT, N.Y. Nov. 11 -Corny Shields won the holiday dinghy regatta today off the Larchmont Yacht Club by two points.

Mrs. William H. Golding of Cobleskill, N.Y., was elected president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs yesterday at the final business session of its fifty-fourth annual four-day convention in the New Yorker Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 -- The seventeenth Marques of Camarasa, whose title of the Spanish nobility originated in the sixteenth century, died unexpectedly yesterday in his suite at the Biltmore Hotel. Cause of death was a mystery.

A long-term leasehold on the one-story taxpayer containing six stores at the northeast corner of Second Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street has been sold by Jacob L. Rosenthal through his Delaware Manor Apartments, Inc., to the Bilkay Realty Company.

Celebrating both Armistice Day and his thirtieth birthday, Ovie Scurlock rode Ben F. Whitaker's 2-year-old colt Prince Quest to victory in the $23,750 Ardsley Handicap at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday. Joining in the celebration were players of favorites in the crowd of 30,750, for Prince Quest was the people's choice at 11 to 10.

Improved train operation on the Fulton Street line of the Independent subway division in Brooklyn is expected to result from the new $2,000,000 push-button signal system that goes into effect at the end of this month, the Board of Transportation said yesterday.

Century Furniture Associates, Inc., a central buying organization serving thirty-nine independent furniture stores in twelve states, will work under a new policy approved by member stores to strengthen group buying power, Lewis W. Parker, executive vice president, disclosed yesterday.
MUAR, Federation of Malaya, Nov. 11 (AP) -- About 3,000 rag-tag fanatics hiding in the jungle are all that is left of Communist dreams of a Soviet Malaya.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The United States opposed today before the Far Eastern Commission the recent Soviet proposal for international controls to prevent a revival of Japan's war industry.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- In an unexpected victory for the Soviet point of view, the principle that no one may be compelled to join an association was adopted as part of the International Declaration on Human Rights by the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today.

Another of those suspenseful masterpieces of gridiron drama that have marked this Columbia football season appears to be shaping up for tomorrow, when the frustrated Light Blue eleven clashes with Navy's ill-starred team before a capacity gathering of 35,000 at Baker Field.

FRANKFORT on the Main, Germany, Friday, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A oneday strike by millions of German workers in protest against the high cost of living hit the United States and British zones at Thursday midnight.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 -Gladys Swarthout, Metropolitan Opera star, singing the title role in "Carmen" before an audience of 3,800 tonight in Syria Mosque, accidentally stabbed Raoul Jobin, the Canadian lyric tenor singing the role of Don Jose, in the third act of the opera.

QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 11 (UP) -A Congressional resolution empowering the Executive to grant oil exploration and exploitation concessions to the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Shell Oil Company was promulgated today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -Sir Oliver Franks, the British Ambassador, will present tomorrow fifty-eight awards to military and civilian nationals of four countries. The awards, to be made in the name of King George VI, will be given at the British Embassy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -Full-scale negotiations looking to settlement of the West Coast maritime strike, which has immobilized ports and tied up most waterborne shipping since Sept. 2, were put under way today by the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, and the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast.

THE football season has come roaring into the homestretch where games between traditional foes make this weekly guessing contest a greater occupational hazard than usual. Irregardless (ahem!) of that, though, here goes:

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A country-wide operating organization of cooperatives to put producers in command of dairy prices was recommended to the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation today.

WITH THE FIRST TASK FLEET, Nov. 10 (AP) (Delayed) -Twelve thousand men and $1,000,000,000 worth of assorted naval ships and planes sank the veteran heavy cruiser Pensacola today after pounding it for six and a half hours.

Mayor O'Dwyer will ask Congress when it reconvenes next year to restore many former powers of the Federal rent control agency, and to give primary attention to the maintenance services that many landlords have been neglecting here, it was announced yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:
The Newark Baseball Club of the International League, in other and better years the outstanding farm property of the Yankees, is for sale, presumably to the highest bidder.

ATHENS, Nov. 1 -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis said today that Vice Premier-Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris would return to Athens at once from the United Nations sessions in Paris, now that the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee had finished its discussion on Greece.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- As a result of an increase in domestic production of newsprint, Britons will read newspapers that are 25 per cent larger next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a strike for union recognition during the term of another union's contract was not in itself an unfair labor practice where the contracting union had not been certified by the board as bargaining agent.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 11 -- Representatives of eight Arab states concluded a meeting of the Arab League's Political Committee tonight after having taken a decision, widely reported to be to resume joint military operations if the Israelis refuse to comply with the United Nations Security Council's order to withdraw to the positions in the Negeb that they held Oct. 14.

The New York City Opera Company gave its third performance of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" last night at the City Center with a cast including three artists who had not appeared previously in the new production. Leona Scheuneman made her debut with the organization as the Countess, while Adelaide Bishop and Norman Young assumed the respective roles of Susanna and the Count for the first time.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Nov. 11 -- On a wind-swept beach at the easternmost end of town, the people of Provincetown paid tribute today to the "faith, hope and courage" of the Pilgrims, who first set foot on American soil here 328 years ago.

Dimitri Mitropoulos was assisted at the concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall by the composerpianist Francis Poulenc in the performance of his "Concert Champetre" for harpsichord (or piano). Mr. Poulenc was fortunate in the placing of his work (played for the first time by this orchestra) between Mendelssohn's overture to "Ruy Blas" and Mahler's Seventh Symphony.

Ground was broken yesterday for the Bell Park Gardens veterans' housing project, New York State's first cooperative, non-profit home development that will provide apartments for 800 former servicemen and their families by next spring.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Labor relations experts foresee a period of uncertainty and some confusion in the next six to eight months while the country's national labor policy is being revised.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The first domestic shipment of monazite sand, a substance from which the fissionable element thorium is obtained, was claimed today by a West Chicago refiner. Thorium and uranium are used in atomic energy production.

Citing "phenomenal success" of two previous special campaigns in newspapers, Park Tilford announced yesterday that it will run full-page and 1,000-line holiday season ads featuring its "honor roll" of wines and liquors in sixty metropolitan newspapers.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Led by Joe Carveth, who scored twice, the Canadiens defeated the Black Hawks, 4 -- 1, tonight in a rough and tumble National Hockey League game. Adam Brown scored for Chicago late in the third period to spoil Goalie Bill Durnan's bid for his fourth shut-out of the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Civilian payrolls in the executive branch of the Federal Government maintained a level of more than $1,000,000,000 for the first two months of the new fiscal year, the Joint (Byrd) Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures reported today.

No matter how busy Jed Harris is, he always finds time to weigh the merits of a script. Reports from New Haven, where the master is polishing off "Red Gloves," indicate that he has become so enamored of a play by Robert and Mignon McLaughlin, temporarily called "Gaden," that he intends to have it ready for his constituents by February.

There was not stopping George Mikan until the 6-foot-10 inch erstwhile De Paul ace stopped himself last night at Madison Square Garden. In a nutshell, this explains the sorry home debut of the New York Knickerbockers, who fell behind at the outset and wound up on the wrong end of a 77-68 count in their Basketball Association of America contest with the Minneapolis Lakers before 15,162 fans.

ARLINGTON, Va., Nov. 11 (AP) -- "The draft is shot full of deferments," the American Legion's new national commander told an Armistice Day crowd in front of the tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery today.

Large-scale purchases of new equipment are enabling leading hotels to stabilize their cost and profit ratios on a high level of earnings, hotel executives said yesterday during the fourth active day of the thirty-third National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace.

A sudden return to good seasonal shopping weather, a legal holiday and longer Thursday hours for most retail stores combined yesterday to indicate one of the largest business days of the year for retailers here.
There is a memorial here to the 3,214 Americans who died to capture this island in 1944. It is not of stone or bronze, but of water and life. It is Lake Susupe.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Petroleum liquids produced in this country will be available in "substantially increased amounts as the years pass" through 1953 and thereafter, it was reported today to the American Petroleum Institute.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Bruins outroughed top-place Detroit for a 4-1 victory in the replay of the National Hockey League's first fog postponement tonight before a capacity crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden. There were three fist fights and Red Wings Ted Lindsay and Gordie Howe had to retire with accidental injuries.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Judge Luther M. Swygert of Federal District Court today gave the International Typographical Union, AFL, until Monday to purge itself of contempt of court by showing that it had halted illegal efforts to force employers to make contracts containing closed-shop conditions.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- In a strongly worded warning to Russia, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg declared here tonight that it was unrealistic for Soviet statesmen "to dangerously miscalculate the impact of last week's election on American foreign policy."

Activity on the television front continues unabated, the Columbia Broadcasting System announcing a number of new programs for early presentation. A quiz program entitled "The Eyes Have It," with the questions based on excerpts from newsreels of the last twenty years, will have its premiere on CBS video at 8:30 P. M. this Sunday.

Like the ground hog who, it is said, sometimes gives a forecast of spring, thirty members of the Millinery Designers League, Inc., presented advance spring hats yesterday at the sixth annual meeting of the organization at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
The four-week-old strike of New York beer drivers ended at midnight last night when 3,000 striking drivers voted to approve an agreement worked out earlier in the day at City Hall.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- China told the United Nations today that former Japanese prisoners of war had been armed by the Soviet Union and were being sent into battle on the side of Chinese Communist armies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 11 -- In a speech to the Academy of Sciences of Serbia, Marshal Tito today warned his conservative enemies on the Right that they were doomed to destruction and at the same time served notice on his Communist Information Bureau enemies on the Left that the Yugoslav Communist party would continue along its own chosen path toward socialism.

Butter, large Grade A eggs and some types of poultry, foods that have been declining in price recently, now are going up. All these items, which included broilers, fryers and roasters, are 2 cents higher today than they were last Friday. The temporary downward trend has come to an end because wholesale supplies are no longer large enough to meet the demand from retailers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) -In a rough and tumble game which saw the spectators shower the floor with paper, the Rochester Royals whipped the Philadelphia Warriors, 83 -- 75, in a Basketball Association of America contest tonight.

When an election shifts the party control in Congress the control of the committees which do so much of the work of each House naturally shifts also. The minority leader in each committee thereupon becomes, almost always, the chairman. This minority leader will have worked his way up, session by session, from last on the list to first on the list, by the mere passage of time.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- Fifty-five C-54's of the United States Air Force will move to the enlarged airfield at Celle in the British zone next month to increase the airlift tonnages for blockaded Berlin, reliable United States Military Government sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The "growing obligation" of the Extension Service of the Agriculture Department and land-grant colleges "to help rural people understand complex economic and social problems" was stressed in a report adopted at today's final session of the Association of Land-Grant Colleges and Universities.

Tentative plans for the threeday national credit conference sponsored by the American Bankers Association in Chicago, beginning on Dec. 13, were announced yesterday. According to Kenton R. Cravens, chairman of the ABA's Credit Policy Commission and vice president of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company, St. Louis, Mo., a nation-wide antiinflation program will be worked out at the meeting.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Paris Communists today held a bloody street fight with the police along the city's main thoroughfare, the Champs-Elysees. Sixteen were arrested and well over fifty were injured, many seriously, by flying paving stones, nightsticks and gunfire before the police ruthlessly put down the brawl that the Communists had evidently instigated as their way to mark the thirtieth anniversary of the World War I Armistice.

Since Edna Ferber and George S. Kaufman wear their hearts in the right place, "Bravo!" which was acted at the Lyceum last evening, is warm and sympathetic. With the assistance of Oscar Homolka and Lili Darvas, they have written a drama about the poignant plight of some Eastern Europeans in New York.

The one-story taxpayer building at 393-97 Bedford Park Boulevard, northwest corner of Webster Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Chase National Bank, as trustee, to Joseph Donahue. This is the first sale in forty-seven years of the property, which was held at $65,000.

A young robber made off with an Eighth Avenue bus Wednesday night and apparently operated it for hours over its regular route until it crashed into a taxicab at Fiftieth Street. He then stepped into the subway near by and disappeared, with all the six-cent fares he had collected.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Strong protests against the United StatesBritish policy toward the Ruhr were voiced in Armistice Day speeches today by Vincent Auriol, President of the Republic, and by Edouard Herriot, President of the National Assembly.

Efforts of Atlantic Coast port officials to ease competitive factors that have been causing their foreign trade to decrease while that of Gulf ports rises were brought to light yesterday aboard the New York Central Railroad's ferryboat Niagara.

Shoe production this year will hit 465,000,000 pairs, according to an estimate yesterday by the Tanners Council of America. The figure is based on ten months' production and allows for the usual let-down this month and in December.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly in the end will accept modification of the Bernadotte Plan along lines more acceptable to Israel, a usually well-informed source predicted today.

American Federation of Labor maritime unions in this port, including both shoreside and seagoing labor, are constantly on guard against the inroads of Communist party influence in shipping activity along this coast. Unmistakable evidences of communistic participation are usually to be seen in a maritime strike, either before it comes off or as it develops.

The biggest Armistice Day parade in the metropolitan area yesterday was Newark's with 30,000 marchers passing the City Hall reviewing stand in the two-hour march along Broad Street between Lincoln and Washington Parks. The police, who called it the biggest Armistice Day procession in more than a dozen years, estimated that 100,000 spectators lined its path.
If the current campaign by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies for $16,500,000 is permitted to fail, the entire community will suffer, Hospitals Commissioner Edward M. Bernecker warned yesterday.

CONSTANTIN FOTITCH, Yugoslav Minister and Ambassador to the United States from 1935 to 1944, believes that his countrymen have as good cause to feel betrayed by the Teheran Conference as do the Poles. It was at Teheran that the United States and Great Britain agreed to Russia's annexation of nearly half of Poland, thus making mincemeat of the Atlantic Charter's noble sentiments against territorial changes.

GREENSBURG, Pa., Nov. 11 -With more than 190 religious and secular educators in attendance, the Rev. William Granger Ryan, a priest from the Diocese of Brooklyn, was seated as the sixth president of Seton Hill College here today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, the hero of Corregidor and national commander of the Disabled American Veterans, handed a check for $33,000 today to James E. Nickerson, 42 years old, of Port Washington, L.I., as the winner of a puzzle contest sponsored by the DAV service foundation.

Two one-man shows and a group exhibition by American and French contemporaries are notable additions to this week of art gallery activity. These exhibitors include Romare Bearden at the Niveau Gallery, Joseph Gerard at the Weyhe and the Feigl Gallery group show.

Herman L. Weisman, acting chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, has forwarded an invitation to 103 Jewish welfare funds throughout the country requesting that each designate two representatives to meet with the appeal for implementing a decision to include one-third representation of Jewish communities on the governing bodies of the appeal.

ATHENS, Nov. 11 -- National Guard and gendarmerie units in the Tripolis area of the Peloponnesus were today seaching for an American civilian engineer, who was reported to have been abducted by four armed guerrillas. He is Francis L. McShane, 43, of Newburgh, N.Y., assistant superintendent of roadbuilding for the New York contracting firm of Atkinson-Drake, engaged on the American aid program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A Democratic purge of Federal job holders who bolted has claimed its first victim, with many more expected, and successors are being sought among Southern Democrats who actively supported the Truman-Barkley ticket.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- In a heated defense of his Government's treatment of natives in South-West Africa, Eric H. Louw of the Union of South Africa was reprimanded tonight by the chairman of the United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee for making personal remarks about one of his Government's most per sistent accusers -- Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 11 (UP) -- A New Hampshire nag named Big Red plodded his way to a lengthand-a-half victory over a Kentucky plow horse at Rockingham Park today to win what was billed as the world's richest race for plugs. Big Red, encouraged by the cheers of 23,000 spectators, covered the half-mile course in 1:03 to earn $1,000 and a chance for a college education for his owner.

ON FLYING BOAT MARSHALL MARS, AT SEA, Nov. 11 -- The Navy carried succor to a floating menagerie of hungry elephants today, 1140 miles west of San Francisco. In doing so, it did something which Navy officers said had never been done before.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- The Pope underlined today the urgency of achieving a federation of European states in an audience he granted at his summer residence of Castel Gandolfo to delegates of the fourteen nations who participated in the second congress of the European Union of Federalists.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Heavy oversubscription of the Trinidad 3,000,000 3 per cent loan, for which 80,000,000 was offered, started a buying movement of gilt-edge issues in the stock markets here today. The movement found jobbers none too well supplied with stock, and by the close of trading prices had improved up to 1/4 point all around.

Effective immobilization of the entire Atlantic Coast by striking dock workers was forecast here yesterday as locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, prepared to complete balloting on a proposed new agreement. They were expected to vote against acceptance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Economic Outlook, publication of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that millions of American families had been forced to use all their savings and that the "ability to save and the ownership of accumulated savings" was being confined to fewer families.

Increased salaries for top administrators in Government service were advocated yesterday by Prof. William J. Ronan, director of the New York University Graduate Division of Public Service. The suggestion was a part of Professor Ronan's annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

The origin of mysterious imprints strangely resembling fossilized dinosaur skin in the rock on the left side of United States Highway 9-W three miles north of the traffic light at West Coxsackie, N.Y., confounded experts at the Geological Society of America's meeting at the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.
As a foreign correspondent stationed in New York, I venture to make a suggestion for the consideration of American publishers.

According to figures just released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, hourly wage rates in the country's manufacturing industries are now running 43 per cent higher than they were on V-J Day when the fighting war came to an end. Average hourly earnings, however, are only 33 per cent higher and average weekly earnings are up only 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Purges and ousters are being executed or threatened by both the Democrats and the Republicans as a result of the general election, but there is a growing prospect that the largest disturbance along these lines will be among the Republicans in the Eighty-first Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- To the surprise of fellow passengers, Mrs. Harry S. Truman and her daughter, Miss Margaret Truman, boarded a southbound passenger train at 3:40 P.M. today to join the President vacationing at Key West.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 11 -Army took advantage of Armistice Day recess to get in its first double practice session of the year today. The cadets gathered for a half-hour skull practice in the morning in addition to their regular ninety-minute stint on the playing field in the afternoon.

The Arabian American Oil Company plans to spend $320,000,000 for producing and supporting facilities in the period 1948-53, W. F. Moore, president, said yesterday. He declared that the company's present production in Arabia was about 450,000 barrels a day and that it was proposed to increase it to 700,000 daily by 1951.
On Armistice Day yesterday, hospitalized veterans of World War I took stock of their compensations for the sacrifices they made in their country's name thirty years ago and found them good.

Sparked by Don Zimmer, a spirited Stuyvesant eleven yesterday defeated James Monroe, 27 -- 19, in a thrilling contest, feature of the last scholastic twin bill of the season at Triborough Stadium. In the other half, De Witt Clinton registered its fifth success with a 14-0 triumph over Evander Childs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -Citizens of the United States will be admitted to Great Britain after tomorrow without visas. The elimination of the visa requirement will be announced at 7 P.M. tomorrow by the British Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Walter B. Wooden, associate general counsel of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that "we all are in danger of becoming mired in a morass of semantics," when attempts are made to interpret the effects of recent court decisions on the pricing policies of American business.

Frank Boucher, manager of the New York Rangers, has several plans calculated to add to the effectiveness of his charges in the current National Hockey League race. Addressing the New York Hockey Writers Association at a dinner at Leone's yesterday, the Blue Shirts' mentor said that he was seriously considering the use of complete five-man units when all of his injured players return to top shape.
The thirtieth anniversary of the armistice that failed to bring a lasting peace was observed yesterday in a world disordered from World War II and torn by new battles in far-flung areas.

The World Health Organization has accepted the newly-formed World Federation of Mental Health on an official consultative basis, it was learned yesterday from Dr. Nina Ridenour, executive officer of the International Committee for Mental Hygiene.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- The presence in wheat germ of an unidentified factor, believed to be a new vitamin, found in experiments on mice to increase their natural resistance to bacterial infection, was reported here today at the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal spent a busy day in Paris today conferring with Secretary of State Marshall, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, President of the United Nations Assembly; W. Averell Harriman of the Economic Cooperation Administration; Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador, and Paul Ramadier, French Minister of Defense.
Show business, concerned over falling box-office receipts and attendant unemployment in its ranks, held preliminary talks yesterday on ways and means of encouraging national interest in the theatre.

Industrial mergers which speed goods into distribution will find approval in the Federal Trade Commission, according to Lowell B. Mason, FTC commissioner. Mergers, he held, have sparked "luxury" production which contributes to the high standard of living in America and generally they do not constitute permanent monopolies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -In spite of the administration's pledge to seek repeal of the TaftHartley Law, its chief agent, Robern N. Denham, intends to follow a "business as usual" policy. Mr. Denham said in an interview today that he would keep on administering the Republican-sponsored labor law "as if nothing had happened," so long as it was on the books.
Gordon P. Lovell, assistant to the general sales manager of the International Business Machines Corporation, has been appointed manager of electric accounting machine division.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 12 -- Hideki Tojo, the little man who led Japan into the war, and his twenty-four co-defendants were convicted today by the International Military Tribunal, which sentenced Tojo to hang.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 11 -Territorial readjustments between the dominions of India and Pakistan may be sought from both sides as a result of the migrations following the partition of the subcontinent into two nations.

In the interest of the European Recovery Program, which calls for the greatest possible production in all participating countries, the American and British Military Governments in Germany are returning the coal, iron and steel industries of the Ruhr, the industrial heart of the continent, to German ownership, and are appointing German trustees to administer these properties under continued Allied supervision.

Your leading editorial of Nov. 7 says: "Tuesday's vote showed that approximately half of the voting population is still in what might be called the New Deal mood." Several letters to the editor in the same issue ascribe the Republican defeat to -- as one writer puts it -- "the strength which the appeal of F.D.R.'s New Deal has in the hearts of the American people."

Thirty-five representatives of leading Jewish organizations in New York City, who next week will leave on a survey flight to Europe and Israel, were guests of honor last night at a reception given by the Council of Organizations of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York at the Biltmore Hotel.

NANKING, Nov. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Teng Wen-yi, official Government military spokesman, said at a press conference today that the battle for Suchow was developing on an unprecedented scale, surpassing that of any battle that took place during the Japanese war.

Your leading editorial of Nov. 7 says: "Tuesday's vote showed that approximately half of the voting population is still in what might be called the New Deal mood." Several letters to the editor in the same issue ascribe the Republican defeat to -- as one writer puts it -- "the strength which the appeal of F.D.R.'s New Deal has in the hearts of the American people."

Don't blame the oven if the cake you are baking turns out poorly. This admonition is the theme of a booklet that the General Electric Company has just issued. It is graphically illustrated to prove that failures in cake making often are the fault of the cook or of the utensils she uses.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation plans to increase 1949 refrigerator unit production 25 to 30 per cent compared with 1948, George H. Meilinger, household-refrigeration division manager, disclosed yesterday. He said that no bar exists at the moment to attainment of the goal, but added that the company feels procurement of necessary steel may not be possible because of developments in the first quarter of 1949.

With 450 naval reserve seamen and officers aboard, the light cruiser Portsmouth docked yesterday afternoon at Pier 26, North River, after a fourteen-day training cruise to the Caribbean. Bad weather precluded gunnery practice on the return trip from San Juan, P.R., but the reservists underwent rigid training in other naval requirements.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Crowds are beginning to gather during the daytime outside of Buckingham Palace as the public awaits news of the birth of Princess Elizabeth's baby. Nothing has yet transpired, however, to indicate that the great event is imminent.

One hundred and fifty men and women picketed the Spanish Consulate, Fifty-third Street and Madison Avenue, for an hour yesterday to protest death sentences of thirteen persons scheduled to die this month in Spain.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The European Council under the Marshall Plan decided today that a unified European recovery program could not be made now and that in its place the council would send to Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, by Dec. 7 an interim report showing both the progress made and the difficulties encountered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -America gave its highest honor today to two men who played a part in winning the second World War, S/Sgts. John W. Minick of Mechanicsburg, Pa., and Gus Kefurt of Sharon, Pa. Both died in action in Germany.

Anna Feldman has sold the dwelling at 612 Avenue K, Brooklyn, to Emanuel Dash. A purchase money mortgage of $18,000 was executed at the closing of title to the property, which is assessed at $32,500. McCormick Swingard were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The prospects of an American loan to Spain appeared dim today, though officials read with deep interest the Madrid dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES quoting Generalissimo Francisco Franco as saying that Spain desired a loan of $200,000,000 for the purchase of industrial and transportation equipment.

WE got as far as page 14 of Angela Thirkell's "Love Among the Ruins"* and in that book that day we read no more. We were, we realized, intruding. Miss Thirkell had just murmured something about "as any of our readers who were at the Deanery dinnerparty in the dreadful cold summer of 1946 will know."

This island is largely a vine buried wilderness today. Its six great B-29 airstrips, aimed at Tokyo, are deserted. The two pits from which atomic bombs for Hiroshima and Nagasaki were loaded are water-filled and resound with the croaking of bufo toads.

Austin Hogan, suspended president of the New York local of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, asserted yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer had bribed Michael J. Quill, international president, with a dues check-off system to turn TWU into a "company union."

BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Planned Parenthood League which unsuccessfully sponsored a birthcontrol referendum on the recent Massachusetts ballot, today asserted Catholic opponents should report for tax purposes the amount spent fighting the measure.

ROME, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII congratulated President Truman on his election victory and the President, replying, said he was humbly seeking Divine guidance in the quest for peace, the Vatican announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (AP) -Hal Hibbard, a leading aircraft engineer, said today that a jet transport of transatlantic range and twice the speed of present airliners could be put into service within six years.

A statement by Anthony A. Antona kakis of the Greek Government Office of Information, published Nov. 1, challenges the validity of some of the observations contained in my letter of Oct. 20 on the George Polk case.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 12 -State engineering experts were brought in today as possible aids in the search for the body of a 64year-old worker buried in a rock slide at the Lambertville quarry. The engineer arrived after the man's four sons had asked that highway department equipment be supplied.

The New York Rangers will skate against the Canadiens of Montreal in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. A crowd of 15,000 is expected to witness the clash, which will be the only Saturday night one of the local season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.7 per cent during the week ended Nov. 6, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP) -- More than 56,000 ballots cast by Ohioans for Presidential candidates in the Nov. 2 election were thrown out, a survey showed today.

The best handicap horses still in training in this theatre of turf operations -- a dozen of them -- have been entered in today's $75,000 added Butler Handicap, feature of the penultimate program of the Empire City Racing Association's session at Jamaica.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- A tribute unique in the long history of Westminster Abbey was paid today to the memory of Franklin D. Roosevelt in the presence of his widow. A plaque was unveiled by Winston Churchill and Prime Minister Attlee in the last remaining niche under the great windown at the west entrance.

Because "a temporary situation of scarcity" has developed in veterans' home-loan funds in some communities, the Government is justified in purchasing GI loans to help keep adequate financing available, the United States Savings and Loan League declared yesterday in a resolution adopted at the closing session of its fifty-sixth annual convention in the Hotel Commodore.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Assertions that "there is grave danger of Government ownership of transportation in the United States" and that "outmoded Federal policies, class legislation and 'horseand-buggy' regulation have promoted disintegration within the industry" were made today by Donald D. Conn, executive vice president of the Transportation Association of America.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 -Yale and Princeton, two of intercollegiate football's oldest rivals, will clash in the Bowl tomorrow with the Tigers favored to capture the Big Three title for the second consecutive year.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 12 (AP) -Maryland's last thirteen days of the major Eastern horse-racing season will start here tomorrow with fourteen overnight entries for the $10,000 added Thomas K. Lynch Memorial Handicap. The mile and a sixteenth race, named in honor of Bowie's first general manager, will be run for the twelfth time.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Nov. 12 -- Shuttered windows and locked doors on shops large and small symbolized the extent to which the twenty-four-hour work stoppage called by the labor unions was observed today everywhere in this area as well as throughout the bizonalh) 0*0*0*iarea.
Columbia University's freshman football team displayed a strong ground attack to register a 20-6 victory over Cheshire Academy of Connecticut yesterday at Baker Field.
Wichita, Kan., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Nov. 16 on $1,297,914 of improvement bonds dated Nov. 1, 1948, and due Nov. 1 from 1949 to 1958.

Three major unions in the television field have agreed to a division of employes of The Daily News station, WPIX, into seven separate bargaining units. The agreement was seen as auguring for amicable settlement of jurisdictional problems in the video labor field.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 12 -- Col. Gen. Ivan Gosnyak, member of the Politburo of the Yugoslav Communist party and one of Premier Marshal Tito's closest associates, told the second congress of the Slovene Communist party yesterday in Ljubljana that Yugoslavia would never renounce her territorial claims to those areas in Austria, Italy and the Free Territory of Trieste inhabited by Slovene communities.

At the conclusion of its hundredth year, upon which the books were closed Sept. 30, the Community Service Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, New York 10, continues to deserve in full measure the gratitude of New York City for its health and welfare work in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Higher pay for top Federal officials, advocated by the Hoover Commission and a Senate subcommittee, received the conditional endorsement today of an influential Senator, Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, who had been regarded as a possible stumbling block.

With the election over, we are settling down to an assured continuity of policy in many fields. We do not believe that there would have been any real change in our atomic energy program if Governor Dewey had been elected, despite some doubt raised by a possibly careless statement in one of his campaign speeches.

Michael Todd will ring up the curtain at the Winter Garden this evening on his new musical, "As the Girls Go." It will star the redoubtable Bobby Clark, cast as the husband of the nation's first woman President, and feature Irene Rich, playing the first lady to be elected President of the United States in the year 1953.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 -President Juan D. Peron and his wife will be invited to the New Orleans Mardi Gras in March "if necessary arrangements" can be made, Mayor Delesseps Morrison of New Orleans said today. The Mayor is spending ten days here as the official guest of Buenos Aires.

A 33-Year-old father of ten children was sentenced yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to one year and one day in Federal prison and fined $10 for stealing and cashing a $76 pension check belonging to a wounded veteran of World War II.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 12 -- At a time when a fresh outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease [Aftosa] has made it necessary to move the quarantine line twelve miles closer to the United States border, four members of the United States Senate Appropriations subcommittee began discussing today with officials of the joint Mexican-American Commission future financial aid from the United States to eradicate the disease from Mexico.

Untamed wolves and domesticated dogs have a similar basic behavior pattern, and both have many patterns of behavior similar to those of human beings, it was brought out here yesterday in the opening session of a two-day conference on the methodology and techniques for studying animal "societies."

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- British and United States representatives on the one hand and the French delegation on the other reached a clearer understanding of their conflicting views on maintaining international control of the Ruhr's war potential in the six-power Ruhr conference here today.

An account of life in the North in the Eighties and Nineties, entitled "The Trail Led North: Mont Hawthorne's Story," by Martha Ferguson McKeown, will be published by Macmillan on Tuesday. Mr. Hawthorne went North in the Eighties for the silver salmon fishing and moved to the Klondike in the Nineties to prospect for gold.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (AP) -Ralph Pasquariello, hard-hitting fullback from Everett, Mass., scored three touchdowns as he led Villanova to a 36-7 victory over Georgetown before 16,500 fans at Shibe Park tonight.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 12 -- Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley confirmed today reports that the Commonwealth Government received representations from the United States Government seeking a taxation convention between the two countries designed to eliminate taxation on income from investments made by residents of one country in the other.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Grain markets fluctuated nervously on the Board of Trade today. Reports regarding the Atlantic seaboard longshoremen's strike were the dominating influence in shaping the course of the markets.

Any time someone says "if" too loudly Don Davis comes up with half a dozen inventions, to hear him tell it. To prove it he held forth for the better part of yesterday afternoon spreading gadgets, fruits and vegetables over most of the table space of a panelled office in the Chrysler Building.

Many persons are going into the psychiatric divisions of Bellevue and Kings County Hospitals "who don't necessarily belong there," Edward M. Bernecker, City Commissioner of Hospitals, declared yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The Communistled General Confederation of Labor has ordered its members in the Paris region out on a twenty four-hour general strike tomorrow to protest an alleged police attack on a "peaceful" Armistice Day parade here yesterday.

With a parade of midshipmen -some 800 strong -- adding color to what promises to be a highly exciting gridiron battle, Navy's victory starved eleven will tangle with Columbia before a capacity crowd of 35,000 at Baker Field today.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The Worldh)0*0*0*iJewish Congress notified the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today that its decision to hold the third general UNESCO conference in Beirut, Lebanon, made it impossible for the Congress to participate.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Paper Container Manufacturing Company, Chicago, today sued the Dixie Cup Company, Easton, Pa., for treble damages of $5,400,000.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 12 -Dr. George O'Hanlon, medical director of the Jersey City Medical Center for the last twenty-four years, was honored today in a ceremony at which the 15-story doctors' staff house at the hospital was officially named O'Hanlon Hall.

An eager 4-year-old boy whose afternoon was brightened daily by a reunion with his 8-year-old sister when she returned from school was crushed under the wheel of a school bus yesterday afternoon seconds after his sister had alighted.

The priority to be given to various nuclear energy projects -- including the development of atomicpowered airplanes -- will be among the problems the Atomic Energy Commission and the Administration must face.

A 42-year-old woman proprietor of an East Harlem grocery store, described in Municipal Term Court as "the dirtiest in the city," began yesterday serving a thirty-day workhouse sentence on her plea of guilty to a sanitary code violation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- An authoritative statement by all fifty-seven Governments belonging to the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations as to the present status of their food supply is the principal objective of the organization's conference starting here next week.
Two T-2 type United States Navy tankers have received their annual inspection, a complete overhaul and repainting at the Hoboken yard of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The weekly newspaper Labor quoted Charles J. MacGowan, an American Federation of Labor leader, today as saying that unions would have to accept certain legislative provisions over and above the original Wagner Act.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Secretary of State Marshall said today that the Soviet Union was conducting a propaganda peace offensive designed to play upon the general desire for peace with the real purpose of weakening the position of the United States.

Donizetti's "L'Elisir D'Amore" will be the Metropolitan Opera Company's second bill, the evening of Nov. 30, it was announced yesterday. Ferruccio Tagliavini, Bidu Sayao, Salvatore Baccaloni, Guiseppe Valdengo and Inge Manski will sing leading roles, and Guiseppe Antonicelli will conduct.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Nov. 6, 1948, totaled 843,166 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 88,584 cars, or 9.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 67,004 cars, or 7.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 70,179 cars, or 7.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- United States Secretary of Defense James Forrestal arrived here by air this afternoon and drove immediately to 10 Downing Street to confer with Prime Minister Attlee and Defense Minister A. V. Alexander.
MIAMA, Fla., Nov. 12 (AP) -The University of Miami Hurricanes defeated the University of Chattanooga Moccasins, 19 -- 0 tonight in the Orange Bowl before 28,548 football fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan of the Public Service and Gas Company, Newark, N.J., to sell $50,000,000 in debentures. The proceeds will retire $30,000,000 in bank loans and will finance construction and improvements.

The former Worms estate in Bay Shore, L.I., has been purchased by the South Shore Reform Temple of Bay Shore, which will convert the main residence into a chapel, classrooms and community building. The property comprises two and three-quarters acres and, in addition to the main residence of eighteen rooms, includes garages, kennels and greenhouses.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Notified today that they had been suspended indefinitely by the national executive council for pledging a Negro, members of the Amherst College Alpha chapter of Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity said they would proceed with plans to initiate the student, Thomas W. Gibbs of Evanston, Ill., on Nov. 23.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The big success of the Trinidad loan continued to have a stimulating effect on British Government bonds in the stock market here today when prices rose up to 1/4 point all around on investment buying.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Tigers cleaned house today for the manager who will succeed deposed Steve O'Neill, releasing the last two of three coaches who worked under O'Neill with the fifth-place club of 1948.
It seems to me that the editorial "The Dixiecrat Vote," in your issue of Nov. 7, rests upon an unwarranted assumption of fact.

Consolidated net profit of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation for the nine months ended Sept. 30 amounted to $3,244,231, equal to 24 cents a common share, contrasted with a net deficit of $465,315 in the corresponding period of 1947, Guy W. Vaughan, president, reported yesterday.

Foreclosure conveyances of property in Manhattan set the lowest mark since the depression last month when only four parcels were transferred as the result of forced actions taken to satisfy liens amounting to $94,937. In reporting the figures yesterday the Real Estate Board of New York pointed out that during 1937, the year in which it began compiling the data, the foreclosure actions averaged 103 monthly, with the monthly average liens amounting to $14,011,070.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- Unreasoning psychological fears of the possible effects of radioactivity released in an atomic explosion have developed to such a magnitude that "it could well interfere with an important military mission in time of war," the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association was told here today.
Notre Dame and Army, two of the intercollegiate football triumvirate, come up to possibly their most exacting tests of the season today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 12 -Fourteen suitcases which, the police said, contained stolen merchandise and jewelry were found today in an automobile of a married couple who were being questioned in the passing of a quantity of stolen travelers checks.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday and closed 3 to 27 points net higher, with old-crop months showing relatively greater strength than new-crop months.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Three railroad operating unions representing about 150,000 engineers, firemen and switchmen settled their third-round wage dispute with the railroads today by accept ing a pay increase of 10 cents an hour, retroactive to Oct. 16.

The land is filled with stone that's cropped and weathered in the image of man or his works -- the granite-bold Great Stone Face, Chimney Rock on the Oregon Trail, The Mittens, Shiprock Butte, Rainbow Bridge. Named by pioneers hungry for landmarks, they have come down to us by their natureh)0*0*0*ichangeless and austere.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 12 -Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion disclosed today that talks looking toward a Palestine settlement were proceeding with two Arab Governments. He declared that Israel would not surrender any part of the Negeb "unless we are physically forced" by United Nations troops.

h)0*0*0*iThe people of the world today and the historians of tomorrow will agree, we believe, with the verdicts of guilt and the sentences handed down yesterday in Tokyo by the International War Crimes Tribunal against the twentyfive Japanese war leaders. If ever men waged a cruel and barbarous war of aggression, these did.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -The national board of the League of Women Voters announced today the league would seek passage of a nine-point program in the Eighty-first Congress.

Ann Bomar, a young mezzo-soprano with a future, made her Town Hall debut yesterday afternoon. Gifted with a naturally opulent voice, good looks and showing sympathy for the music on her program, she elicited prolonged applause and shouts of "Brava!" from the audience.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- It was announcedh)0*0*0*itonight that King George, on the recommendation of the Pakistani Government, had approved the appointment of Khwaja Nazimuddin, present acting Governor General of Pakistan, as the Governor General of the country.

This is the time of year when people seriously consider throwing the highly efficient telephone out of the window. Summer's unpunctuated days, when whole hours passed without the ringing of the telephone bell, are now of dim memory.

Today's events: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor; Jesus Maria Sanroma, piano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Pierre Fournier, 'cello, Town Hall, 2:30; Loewenguthh)0*0*0*iQuartet, Times Hall, 3; Benno and Sylvia Rabinof, piano and violin.

TOKYO, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Justice Sir William Webb of Australia, the presiding judge who read the sentences on twenty-five major Japanese war criminals today, himself, in a separate opinion, denounced Emperor Hirohito as the real "leader of the crime."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -With the conclusion of filming tomorrow of "Colorado Territory," Warner Brothers will suspend production activities, except for one picture, until sometime after Jan. 1, it was learned today. The only film that will be in production during the next six weeks is "Task Force," a naval film with Gary Cooper.

Any drive by the Department of Sanitation against littering the narrow, congested streets in the Washington Market district, center of Manhattan's huge and feverishly busy wholesale produce business, is up against so many handicaps that it would seem to be doomed before it starts.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A group of Australian editors is asking support for a move to halt ratification of a proposal they fear threatens the free exchange of news.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 12 -Brig. Gen. Edgar Erskine Hume, the first to use DDT on a mass scale to halt Naples' wartime typhus epidemic, received the Gorgas Award at the annual dinner of the Association of Military Surgeons here tonight.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) -Miss Grillo set a new world record for two and a half miles in winning her second straight Pimlico Cup Handicap today and two other track marks were bettered in a rousing finish to the meeting.
TOKYO, Nov. 12 (UP) -- The judgment of the International Tribunal against former Premier Hideki Tojo follows:
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, said today that "the trouble with the American Government is that its efficiency has been allowed to slip away."
The three-day-old wildcat waterfront strike took on new proportions last night when it was declared official by the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL.

Under the square clock that juts out over the sidewalk at the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, a stocky, pink-cheeked young man looked intently yesterday at midday passersby. Spotting a hatless fellow who seemed also to be studying faces in the crowd, he walked over and pressed the man's arm.
I was very much interested to read your editorial "The Nineteenth Man." In this you have certainly packed in some very useful and, I feel, significant information.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The article of the international Declaration of Human Rights covering the people's right to free elections and to participation in their governments was adopted today by the United Nations General Assembly's Social Committee after three meetings devoted to its discussion.

ROME, Nov. 12 -- A wave of Communist-instigated strikes and agitation was spreading over Italy today just when initial expenditures under the Marshall Plan were about to begin. The strikes range from one of twentyfour hours scheduled for next week by all state employes, including railroad men, to the policy of "non collaboration" begun three weeks ago by the workers of the Fiat Motorcar Works.

Cecil B. Fishbein bought the four-story twenty-seven-family apartment building at 3030 Health Avenue, northeast corner of Albany Crescent, the Bronx, from Harvey Estates, Inc. Nehring Brothers were the brokers. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 6 were 8 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, acting chairman of the Security Council, sounded out Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate, late tonight as to the terms of a new formula that might be the basis for the eventual solution of the Berlin dispute.

ATHENS, Nov. 12 (AP) -- After Premier Sophoulis' resignation King Paul promptly summoned home Mr. Tsaldaris, who was Premier during 1946 following the election victory of his Populist (monarchist) party.
TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- The Japanese press and public tonight were deeply impressed by the verdict of the Allied Tribunal sentencing Hideki Tojo and twenty-four others as war criminals.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 12 -- The greatest explosion in Cairo's history demolished today a publishing house in which three English and French-language daily newspapers were printed and, according to a police estimate made tonight, killed eleven persons and injured seventy-one.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Public understanding of canned food nutritional values will tend to increase further United States consumption of canned foods even beyond the estimated 1948 figure of more than 20,000,000,000 cans, it was declared here today by Howard T. Cumming, president of the National Canners Institute.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -The Civil Service Commission disclaimed today the job of hiring Federal employes.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Separated lines of shirring scattered all over moires and lustrous faconne satins for cocktail hours form a new technique adopted by Maggy Rouff. Though not quite the same as tufting, the effect is somewhat like it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- A wage increase of 15 cents an hour for West Coast longshoremen was proposed by their negotiating committee, headed by Harry R. Bridges, at a meeting today with representatives of the Waterfront Employers Association.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Poland's charge in the United Nations that the United States was practicing economic discrimination against nations not participating in the Marshall Plan, was laid aside today in the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee by a decisive vote of 28 to 6.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 -- Six corporations and seven of their officials today were charged by a Federal grand jury with monopolizing the $10,000,000 a year street lighting industry.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- More than 1,000 special education teachers were told today that schools "have missed the boat completely" by grading pupils according to age and intelligence, and that this system was largely to blame for juvenile delinquency.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 12 (AP) -Officers of the International Typographical Union will file sworn statements Monday with the Federal court in Indianapolis that they are complying with the TaftHartley law, Don Hurd, secretarytreasurer of ITU, said today.

A revised and expanded version of "The Mozart Story," with dubbed-in English dialogue, will begin an engagement today at the Little Carnegie. Hans Holt plays the composer and Winnie Markus appears as his wife.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The condition of the Federal Reserve Banks as announced by the Federal Reserve Board today follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 Although long suspicious of the arbitration process, workers in this country are gradually becoming convinced of its usefulness, T. A. Johnstone, director of the General Motors Division, United Auto Workers, CIO, said here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. Nov. 12 -- Dr. John H. Bosshart, New Jersey Commissioner of Education, urged his state today to concern itself with the national program of education because "it is ridiculous to teach democracy in high school if only two-thirds of our boys and girls are there."

A Saint Bernard dog, the traditional helper of the traveler in distress, will symbolize the efforts of the Travelers Aid Society of New York next Saturday when the society begins its annual Thanksgiving Week campaign to solicit funds to carry on its work.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The thirty-yearold Armistice Day of 1918 is the last victory the French have to celebrate. That is why it is observed here with more ceremoniousness than elsewhere. Yesterday Paris shut up shop far more completely than on Sunday and throughout the country people put aside everything else to concentrate on the memories of a war they won.

Hide futures prices closed strong on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Strength was gathered from the continued high spot prices in Western markets, unexpectedly small cattle slaughter in the latest reported week, and a firmer trend in the securities market.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -About 200 delegates from western Europe, Canada and this country attended today's sessions of the first World Congress of Ukrainian Women, which was called to unite and coordinate the work of Ukrainian women's organizations.
PEIPING, China, Nov. 12 -Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's commander in North China declared today the Government had been beaten in Manchuria by corruption and inefficiency.

The successful administration of workmen's compensation laws is seriously hampered by extended controversy over medical features of claims filed under these statutes, speakers agreed yesterday at the first symposium of the American Academy of Compensation Medicine in the New York Academy of Medicine Building, Fifth Avenue and 103 Street.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 (AP) -Every cargo of iron ore loaded into a Great Lakes freighter at Upper Lakes docks since Wednesday has set a new season record for a peacetime year. On that date, the 1947 mark of 77,898,087 gross tons was passed and the Great Lakes fleet set its sights on the gross ton mark of 80,000,000 never achieved before except in time of war.

ATHENS, Nov. 12 -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis called on King Paul early this afternoon and handed in his resignation. Thus foundered the Populist-Liberal Coalition Government that had weathered many a storm in its fourteen months' duration.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Dartmouth's football squad arrived from Hanover today, worked out briefly on Schoellkopf Field and left to spend the night at Watkins Glen, N.Y. The Indians will meet Cornell tomorrow in the thirtysecond game of a series begun in 1900.

New-money borrowing in substantial amount is in store for the primary market for bonds next week, with the likelihood, too, that some new stock may be floated. Holding chief interest in the new bond issues is the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company's offering of $60,000,000 of thirty-one-year debentures on Tuesday.

Retail trade here this week showed a decline due to unseasonal and poor shopping weather, despite extremely good sales on Armistice Day. Department store sales were estimated as about 10 per cent under the corresponding week last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -A manufacturer said today that New England's great industrial centers will suffer a drastic loss of mills and factories unless Congress legalizes present pricing systems.

VIENNA, Nov. 12 -- All three Western High Commissioners protested today against the "abduction" of high Austrian officials by Soviet occupation authorities. The protests were based on a letter from the Austrian Cabinet to the Allied Council asking that action be taken in the seizure of Dr. Margarethe Ottillinger, Austrian Marshall Plan specialist.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -With its spirit rekindled, Pennsylvania will meet the undefeated Army team on Franklin Field tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (UP) -Threats of violence from supporters of Compton College unless their team was picked for the Little Rose Bowl game today led the Southern California Board of Football to toss in the towel.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- In a decision announced today, the Black River District Regulating Board approved construction of Panther Mountain Reservoir on the headwaters of the south branch of Moose River in Herkimer County to improve control of the Moose and Black Rivers.

The Committee of Contributors and Workers -- the group that is opposed to the administration of the United Palestine Appeal on various matters of policy -- announced yesterday that it would hold a conference of fund-raising leaders of Jewish communities throughout the country in Atlantic City, N.J., on Dec. 11 and 12.

Westchester town and county officials appeared in force yesterday to oppose fare increases sought by the Westchester Electric Railroad Company and the Westchester Street Transportation Company, affiliates of the Third Avenue Transit System, at a public hearing before Public Service Commission Examiner Harold A. Olmsted.

The entire blockfront on the north side of West Fourth Street, between Broadway and Mercer Street, has been purchased for investment by Daniel Cikeresvale from the Broadway Control Corporation, Morris Fein, president, for cash over mortgages amounting to $230,000.
