NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The name of Governor-elect Chester Bowles was stricken today from a list of sponsors for a lecture here by the Very Rev. Dr. Hewlett Johnson, the so-called "red dean" of Canterbury Cathedral.

A tale of members of one family scattered among five widely separated cities developed yesterday when a 15-year-old French boy was taken to Ellis Island because no relative met him on his arrival at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- At the outset, recounting the initial appearance of Victor de Sabata as guest conductor of the Pittsburgh Symphony in Syria Mosque this evening, it is to be said that he electrified his audience, received a reception of unprecedented enthusiasm and quickly proved that he is a foremost virtuoso conductor of today.

A new theory of how mountains are formed while oceans collapse and earth surfaces bulge into islands or volcanoes, will be presented today at the final sessions of the Geological Society of America meeting at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Clarification of Governmental regulations affecting the textile industry would aid in the stabilization of trade under current economic conditions, it was pointed out yesterday at the textile trade coordination conference in the Plaza Hotel.

EAST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Skilfully maneuvering his powerless jet fighter this afternoon when it developed trouble on a take-off from Mitchel Field, the pilot narrowly averted crashing into a row of brick bungalows near Hempstead Turnpike and Duncan Road here.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 12 (AP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said tonight that the long-range farm price support program adopted by the Republicancontrolled Eightieth Congress needed to be revised.

The Football Yankees harbor no special grudge against the Football Dodgers, whom they have beaten five straight times in All-America Conference matches over the past three years and whom they figure to defeat again tomorrow at the Yankee Stadium.

A cargo of gold bullion valued at $11,000,000 was unloaded yesterday from a freighter at Pier 51, North River, and transferred to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, despite the longshoremen's strike that has virtually tied up the waterfront, according to a spokesman for the States Marine Corporation.

Kid Gavilan, fast punching welterweight from Havana, gained the decision over Tony Pellone of Greenwich Village in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. In a savagely fought, bristling battle, the Cuban managed to gain the unanimous vote of the officials, although Pellone, it seemed, made matters a little closer than the ballots would indicate.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Fifteen former guards at the Mauthausen concentration camp were hanged at Landsberg prison today. A United States war crimes court had convicted them of slaying more than 4,600 wartime inmates of the camp, including forty-seven American and British airmen.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Without any expectation that the United States would reciprocate fully, the British Government announced today that United States citizens entering this country would no longer need British visas in their passports.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- United States pilots of the airlift will follow the orders of Soviet air patrols to land on near-by airfields if they are flying outside the Berlin corridors and if they judge that the C-54's they are flying can be landed on airfields without damage, United States Air Force sources said today.
A furnished apartment in 104 West Ninetieth Street has been leased by Florida Reid to Elizabeth Batchelder, Helen Planvet Batchelder and Francis J. Batchelder through the Houghton Company.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- All the gain in business recorded in the Pittsburgh district in the second half of October was cancelled in the first week of November, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

Business lending by banks in this area spurted $65,000,000 last week to a new high mark of $5,671,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday. Reporting on the operations of the twenty-five New York City member banks during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed that the new total of commercial, industrial and agricultural loans outstanding compares with the previous record level of $5,663,000,000 established on Oct. 13.

A newspaper campaign in New England that produced a large increase of sales for Lestoil, synthetic detergent, will be extended by the Adell Chemical Company, it was announced yesterday. The original drive, using half and fullpage space in eleven papers, began early in September.

The ill-health of William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, caused a further postponement yesterday of his trial and that of eleven other members of the party's national board on charges of conspiracy to advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

A statement by the New Jersey Department of Motor Vehicles suggests that if both motorists and pedestrians do not develop a greater awareness of the imminent possibility of danger, injury and sudden death on the highways, the situation "will undoubtedly provoke legislators to enact stringent measures in an attempt to curtail accidents."

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The British motion-picture industry will be investigated by a "powerful and well-staffed committee" appointed by the Government, which will review current distribution and exhibition practices "against a background of economics of the industry."
Miss Peggy McLean of New York, the national titleholder, swept all her seven matches in winning the New York City open table tennis championship last night at the Western Union gymnasium.

One hundred leading citizens of the East Harlem neighborhood took part last night in a community conference on mobilizing the churches, clubs and other agencies of the neighborhood behind the campaign against venereal disease.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission tonight postponed indefinitely its hearings on revocation of its license to Otis Co. of Cleveland, investment bankers.

STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 12--The opening day of the duck season usually is more exciting in prospect than retrospect, for usually the waterfowl that have excited the impatient gunners for a week or more prior to the season mysteriously disappear shortly after daybreak of the first day.

NANKING, Nov. 12 -- The battle for Suchow, the all-important north Kiangsu railway junction guarding the approaches to Nanking, developed into full swing tonight with both sides claiming successes in a fight that is expected to determine the fate of the Central Government.

The importance of capital formation to all groups in any kind of economy, free or planned, is stressed in a study of the subject, "Capital Formation Under Free Enterprise," released yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

The Knickerbockers will make their second home start of the campaign tonight, when they meet the Baltimore Bullets, last season's champions of the Basketball Association of America at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

An appeal for funds for food for the hungry on Thanksgiving will be made through a letter from Cardinal Spellman to be read at all masses tomorrow and on Sunday, Nov. 21, in the Roman Catholic Archiocese of New York. Collections will be made in all churches of the archdiocese a week from tomorrow.
Reductions in employment by five Northeastern manufacturers, affecting upward of 1,000 workers, were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The question of whether some topflight radio and screen performers are paying their full share of income taxes was raised today by Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire.

Post-election strength in Treasury bonds was extended yesterday from obligations open to commercial bank ownership to bonds which only non-bank investors may acquire. As a result the Government's so-called bank-ineligible bonds moved upward from the Federal Reserve System's buying pegs for the first time since last July.

The long nonpartisan study of ways to make our Federal Government simpler and more economical, which began with enactment of a law on July 7, 1947, setting up a commission for this purpose, is nearing an end. Herbert Hoover, who undertook to lead this study as his "last public service," has given us a glimpse of some of the proposals, tentatively approved, which will be reported to Congress in January.

In an effort to work out a longrange program of naval and merchant ship construction, steps are being taken to set up under the National Security Resources Board a permanent Ship Facilities Committee, it was announced last night by W. John Kenney, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

The stock market continued to flounder yesterday in its post-election state of indecision. From a firm to improved opening on the Stock Exchange, the list lapsed into an irregular course and, while some individual stocks managed to recover approximately a point, the best that the composite rate could show on the day was a rise of 0.13 point.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The United States is advancing the dates of shipment of munitions to China in view of the situation confronting the Nationalist Government in the face of the southward drive of the Chinese Communist armies.

Lumber production for the week ended Nov. 6 was 4.4 per cent below the like week last year. Shipments were down 21.0 per cent and orders 27.8 per cent, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 12 (AP) -Appeals from Federal District Court approval of reorganization of the $780,000,000 American and Foreign Power Company were filed here today. The action will take the case to the United States Court of Appeals in Boston.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 12 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, coauthor of the Taft-Hartley Act will be defeated "decisively" in 1950 and the American Federation of Labor will bring about repeal of that law, William Green, president of the AFL, predicted here today.

The concepts of the East and West are complementary rather than antagonistic and peace may be achieved through the mutual acquaintance of the common peoples of the world, the Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury, declared yesterday.

Three of the art exhibitions which opened this week are to be credited to the distaff side. The three women painters having shows are Irina Blaine at Ward Eggleston Galleries, Nuala at Kleemann and Maud Morgan at Betty Parsons Galleries.

Richard G. Green, attorney for William W. Remington, suspendedh)0*0*0*iDepartment of Commerce official who was accused by Elizabeth T. Bentley of being a Communist, asserted in an affidavit filed in Federal Court yesterday that she had dropped out of sight and that United States marshals had been unable to serve her in Mr. Remington's $100,000 libel suit.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 12 -- The Nassau County Transit Commission went on record as opposed to another increase for the Long Island Rail Road, it was reported at the commission's office in the Old County Courthouse here today.
John A. Campbell, formerly assistant to the director of traffic procedures for Eastern Air Lines, has been promoted to assistant traffic and sales manager for the New York area.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 12 -- In an act of compassion inspired by a newspaper article, President Truman today directed James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, and Carl R. Gray, Veterans' Administrator, to clear up the red-tape snarl of the widow of a civilian economist for the Army.

Needing a victory to better last year's won-lost record, the City College football team will visit Hofstra College at Hempstead, L.I., today for its 1948 finale. The Beavers won two, lost five and tied one in 1947 and they will duplicate that record if they lose today.

Mary Canberg, violinist, gave her second New York recital last night at Times Hall. The program included Bach's Concerto in A minor, the infrequently played Rondo in C major (K. 373) of Mozart, the Delius Concerto, VillaLobos' Sonata-Fantasia, No. 1, and offerings by Bartok-Szigeti, L. Dubensky, Paganini and Ravel.

Release by the Economic Cooperation Administration of 250,000,000,000 lire ($440,000,000) in the Italian counterpart fund, required to be set aside under ECA regulations, will permit immediate start of a program already drawn up by the Italian Government, according to advices here last week.

Making its first home appearance of the year, New York University's injury-riddled football squad will face a powerful Rutgers eleven at Yankee Stadium today. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 P.M. and a crowd of 10,000 is expected.

A spokesman for the Department of Justice charged in Federal court yesterday that business men seemed to believe that a fine imposed for violation of the antitrust acts was merely a license fee that could be charged off as the cost of doing illegal business acts.

SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The crew of a B-29 bomber reported missing early today has been sighted beside the crashed plane on a Pacific atoll, Col. James E. Briggs, Spokane Air Force base commander, said tonight.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Managing editors were told today they could get more readers and create more understanding by making their newspapers easier to read.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- New and improved devices ranging from periscopes to prosthetics punctuated the list of 580 inventions approved this week by the United States Patent Office.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The United States and Britain joined today in denouncing Russia's "one-third" disarmament proposal as a political trick, a propaganda maneuver and an attempt to profit from the fact that the Soviet Union had more men under arms than any country in the world.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Secretary of State Marshall declined comment today when asked whether the United States still supported the plan of the late Count Folke Bernadotte for the settlement of the Palestine question. He based his refusal on the ground that the United States' position would be fully expressed when the General Assembly takes up the question.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Penn State's third and fourth-string backfields turned on the steam today to swamp an outclassed Temple University football team, 47 -- 0, before 16,000 at Beaver Field.

THE juxtaposition of Mr. Day Lewis' "Poems" and Miss Sitwell's "The Song of the Cold" generates a curious distortion which affects one's judgment of both books. The comparison is unkind to the former, of course, since even the most accomplished minor poetry -- and Mr. Lewis' is skillful, beautifully articulated, lucid, sensitive -- must suffer when it is read in the light of a major work.

New York machine shops and metal-working plants have felt a sharp upturn in business, Alexander Berger, president and chief engineer of Automotive and Aircraft Hydraulics, Inc., 507 West Fifty-sixth Street, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

In the evolution of Federal income tax law there has been a tendency on the part of the taxing authority and the courts to broaden allowances for deductions of personal losses -- as distinguished from business losses and those sustained in transactions entered into for profit.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- The exhibition in Germany of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," with funds guaranteed by the Economic Cooperation Administration Act, has been proposed by a Walt Disney agency, the Bookfilm International Cooperation, it was learned today.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Continuing his swift survey of Western European defense problems and United States forces in Europe, Secretary of Defense James Forrestal concluded a twenty-hour visit to Britain today with a luncheon conversation with the chiefs of all the British armed services.

RARELY do a series of isolated gallery events conspire to make the stimulating and rounded survey of old and new that falls to our lot this week. One-man shows by Chase, Kandinsky, Graves, and an exhibition of old master drawings are calculated to appease the wish for sentiment, accommodate the formalists, gratify the modern-archaic taste and sustain our sense of the past.

DAVY, a boy used to taking care of himself, goes to live in a houseboat which bounces agreeably all the time. In other houseboats on the moorage live Helen and Ellen Llewellen, the highly articulate twins. Rancid Weeks, older than the others, is given a workout by the twins without losing his temper and comes in handy when Davy sets out in a home-made raft and lands on an island in the river.

AFTER seven lean years of storage in the granary, Dorothy Heyward's Negro drama, "Set My People Free," has reached the stage. It has been on the verge of production every season; little quivers of excitement about it have been passing up and down Broadway all this long time.
Mervyn Jones in "King's Versifier" calls Ben Jonson the first Poet Laureate. The World Almanac says Chaucer was. * * *

The football Yankees and the football Giants will buck each other for patronage again today. However, the big attraction on the professional gridiron is out in Cleveland, where more than 80,000 will witness the clash between the Cleveland Browns and the San Francisco Forty-Niners, both undefeated in All-America Conference play.

GUAM, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Ten Air Force fliers whose B-29 crash-landed on lonely Fais Island, 130 miles east of Yap Island, while searching for another Superfortress were picked up and were on their way to Guam today. They had not been injured.
The boat train, that nuisance to travelers abroad, arrived last night at the world's greatest and ordinarily most convenient port.

NO mistake about it, it's Howdy Doody time. With a platform favoring double ice cream sodas for a dime, school once a year and plenty of movies, the earnest young boy who is the favorite of the Peanut Gallery finished third behind Truman and Dewey, racking up ten times the number of votes accorded Wallace.

IN simple repetitive phrases that suggest the traditional fairy-tale style, Miss Lattimore tells the story of three little girls, Jade, Pearl and Jasmine. Familiar daily doings, though set in a Chinese home with details of local color, reaffirm kinship of children everywhere.

A WOMAN is shot down at the Sang Froid night club, which gives Bagby an opportunity for accusing Inspector Schmidt of punning when he refers to the killing as murder in cold blood. Schmidt doesn't get it, because he doesn't know French.

CISSIE, who had been an orphan for most of her nine years, "had been passed around to quite a few places in her life but never to an island," until she came to visit Uncle Eben on Peachtree Island in Lake Erie. By the end of her first day, however, she knows that she wants to live there.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 (AP) -After a year's hearings, Special Master Charles I. Russo has ruled that the Van Sweringen Corporation is solvent.

ATLANTA, Nov. 13 -- Alabama's Crimson Tide turned a fumble and a pass interception into a 14-12 upset victory over Georgia Tech today to all but end the once high hopes of the Yellow Jackets for a bowl bid. The thrice-beaten Tide was a two-to-three touchdown underdog.

Exceptionally favorable harvesting condition in October, according to the Department of Agriculture, have resulted in adding 82 million bushels to earlier estimates of the 1948 corn crop. The nation's number one feed crop is now placed at 3,649,510,000 bushels. That would make it 400,000,000 bushels larger than any previous harvest on record.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The impact of the election upon the Hoover commission studying the reorganization of the executive branch of the Government may have been ever so subtle, but it was apparently felt none the less. From a number of well-informed sources comes the word that the final report, which is to be submitted to Congress in January, will be affected to some degree by what happened on Nov. 2.

People who are tempted to lament the good old days should consider some facts and figures that were presented Friday at a meeting of the American Public Health Association in Boston. The Association was celebrating the centenary of the first American public health law and the establishment of the first American board of health, for which the Commonwealth of Massachusetts may take proud credit.

CLINTON, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- A favored Union College eleven recorded a 25-7 victory over Hamilton College today in the fifty-third meeting of the two teams before a Hamilton homecoming crowd of over 3,000.

The value of the Netherlands East Indies guilder, and of the Dutch guilder itself, is being undermined by the policies of the Netherlands toward the Republic of Indonesia, Dr. Alexander A. Maramis, the republic's Minister of Finance, asserted here yesterday.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 13 -- Bob Gardner's 75-yard touchdown run for Ohio Welseyan accounted for the visitors' only score as Lafayette College romped to a 27-7 victory today. All the scoring came in the first half.

Donor, as game a thoroughbred as there is in the business, drew out in the last sixteenth of a mile to hit the jackpot in the Butler Handicap at Jamaica yesterday' on the penultimate afternoon of the New York racing season. It was the richest horse race ever run in November, and to the winner went $58,850 of the $85,950 gross.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (NANA) -- This is an age of comets. Last year broke all records with twenty-one reported from observatories all over the world. So far this year, with reports not nearly complete, twelve have been recorded.

An exhibition schedule of thirty-six games, all against major-league opposition, has been arranged to help Leo Durocher whip his Giants into shape for the 1949 pennant campaign, according to an announcement yesterday.
AS modestly as the night-blooming cereus opens its petals to the Hawaiian moonlight, a new and surprising chorus has blossomed forth almost over night in Honolulu.

FOR the first time in the history of commercial air transport the airline people in the United States are able to look forward to winter operations without reaching for the red ink and aspirin bottles. As a matter of fact, they expect the coming winter to be the best in their history.

THIS novel, which begins as a study of an individualist and returns to that study as the book closes, is also a view of Australian society of twenty-five years ago and an affectionate exposition of the lives of an Australian family.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- The possibility that the United States and the Soviet Union may succeed in arriving at some sort of modus vivendi in the next few months is now almost the sole topic of conversation among delegates to the United Nations General Assembly.

Publication of the fifth volume in a seventy-two-volume series of translations of the Fathers of the Church done in the United States -- a gigantic work of Catholic scholarship first projected in 1946 -- was announced yesterday by Dr. Ludwig Schopp of 229 East Forty-ninth Street, editorial director and initiator of the undertaking.

A CAMERA that is worn like a wrist watch, weighs 8-1/16 ounces and takes 400 pictures on a roll of 35mm. film, has been designed by Dr. Rudolf Steinbeck, a Munich scientist. The camera will be in production next month after two years' work on the first model.

A long-range university-wide program to "redefine the basic elements of the American tradition" will be offered this year at Cornell University, with a symposium on "America's Freedom and Responsibility in the Contemporary Crisis." Supported by a $10,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation, the project will cover urgent contemporary problems.

ALTHOUGH it is impossible to forecast the fate of Moss Hart's "Light Up the Sky," which opens at the Royale Thursday, one thing can be put down for certain -- it'll make this the week of Broadway's Burning Ears, not to mention a couple of threatened lawsuits.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- The International Court of Justice was named today by the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly as the final arbiter in disputes concerning the interpretation and application of the proposed pact on genocide.

IT is fortuitous that Mr. Berg's very fine survey of the question of poliomyelitis, commonly called "polio," and until recently "infantile paralysis," should come when we are witnessing the wane of one of the most severe epidemics of this most dreaded of all diseases.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Unbeaten Clemson threw back stubborn Wake Forest today in a 21-14 thriller to register its seventh straight victory.

Well-known women of society, young matrons and debutantes of this season are interested in the success of the Christmas sale, entertainment and tea for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society to be held on Tuesday and Wednesday in the Embassy ballroom and Garden Room of the Ambassador, under the auspices of the Woman's Branch of the society.

THE picture which Anatole Litvak and Twentieth Century-Fox have made from the novel "The Snake Pit" is a fine and mature piece of work, as much of a credit to the movies as any such film could be. That is an estimation which we want, right away, to nail down, before anyone gets the notion that we are challenging it as a film.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Cyrus S. Eaton, largest stockholder in the Cleveland investment banking firm of Otis Co. and a veteran advocate of competitive bidding for publicly offered securities, breathed new life into his campaign against negotiated public offerings during the last two months.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Streptomycin has proved to be a valuable aid in treating selected patients with severe pulmonary tuberculosis, three Chicago physicians reported yesterday.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Unbeaten Michigan opened up a land and air attack here today that pulverized defeat-groggy Indiana, 54 -- 0, the Hoosiers' worst beating since Michigan rocked them, 63 -- 0, in 1925. In the process Michigan clinched at least a tie for the Big Nine football title.
TIME was when the fighter plane pilot and his epic adventures were the staples of moviedom. That time was farther back than you may think.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 13 (AP) -The axe is expected to fall on Monday on Texas crude oil production. That is the day the State Railroad Commission has indicated orders will be signed shutting down seventeen fields producing approximately 400,000 barrels of crude daily.

WITH Dr. Serge Koussevitzky on the podium, the National Broadcasting Company will broadcast rehearsals of the Boston Symphony Orchestra starting Monday, Nov. 22. The program will be heard over the NBC network from 1 to 1:30 in the afternoon with WNBC carrying the music locally from 11:30 P.M. to midnight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The National Planning Committee of the American Veterans Committee today expelled Morris Pottish of New York, a member of the national committee. He was ousted for presiding at a meeting on Sept. 27 of the New York Area Council which voted to seat a delegate then under suspension from AVC.

ARTIST and author of this book appreciate the fact that the young man of 2 is fast growing away from the straight picture book of his baby days and is ready for a simple story with simple pictures. In "Hello Peter" these are about 2-year-old Peter, Peter's things and Peter's doings.
Princeton University has introduced this fall a new academic program which measures student effort on the basis of over-all ability, thus disregarding deficiencies in minor subjects.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Declaring that "only the ignorant" were in danger of being swept away by Communist propaganda, Walter E. Myer, director of the Civic Education Service, Washington, said today this nation need not fear to teach its students facts about communism.

The annual Thanksgiving bridge party of the New York Society of Kentucky Women will be held on Tuesday in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. The proceeds will be devoted to the support of Berea College and other mountain schools providing educational opportunities for underprivileged children.

FAITH is an age-long and worldwide phenomenon, of which the expressions, never more numerous than today, are bewilderingly diverse, witness these two characteristic volumes. In the first of them we see a great faith working on the moral and intellectual plane.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 (AP) -- European freighters will have a total of fifty-seven sailings into the Great Lakes for the season ending next week, compared with thirty-seven last season.

THE conflicts and sharp challenges of our times have stimulated a fresh interest in the fundamental issues of government. Political philosophy has had a rebirth on this continent, after a long period in which few if any contributions of note were made.
PARIS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The text of the joint communication that Dr. Herbert V. Evatt and Trygve Lie sent to the four great powers today follows:

THESE essays and lectures by the foremost historian of science in America have a chaste and illumined quality anomalous in our times. They bring to mind Chaucer's description of the Knight of "The Canterbury Tales," who "in all his life to no man had said, a word but what was courteous and right."

Finally finding the scoring combination in the third period, Boys High triumphed, 7 -- 0, to make it four in a row over Erasmus Hall in the forty-fourth game of their fifty-year-old football fixture before 6,000 fans at Boys High Field yesterday.

Rutgers University, instigator of the autumn madness that besets the nation each fall, played its six hundredth football game at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, but so far as N.Y.U. was concerned it was a historic occasion in which the local school would rather not have had a part.

Brooklyn College assured itself of matching its best football season in history yesterday by defeating Alfred University, 31 -- 7, before 5,000 at Brooklyn Field. The Kingsmen, in recording their fifth straight and seventh victory of the campaign, shattered the eleven-year scoring mark of 209 points by bringing their season's total to 221 points, with one game still to be played.

AS a last flourish to fall planting, some parrot tulips might be set in the ground during November. These flamboyant relatives of the prim Dutch bulbs provide special effects in locations that suit their highly individual blossoms.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 13 -- Denmark is preparing her answer to the inevitable question of the United States: "What have you done with Marshall Plan money?"
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -The Army wants it known that the "occasions of ceremony" at which its uniform may be worn do not include Communist affairs.

Is easy money receiving a new lease on life? Next to the trend of the stock market, this is the most absorbing question in the financial district today. Related to it are two subsidiary questions: If money stays cheap, will it be because of impending business recession? Or will it be at the insistence of public money managers armed with newly fashioned credit-control tools that still have to be cleared by Congress ?

LAST week the business advisory services, after getting over the election shock, started to figure out what was likely under a Democratic Administration for the next four years. It was agreed that labor and the farmers would have a large say in the legislation coming up.

ONLY in dreams do fragmentary pictures from his past life come back to William Smith, but they are not definite enough to help him establish his true identity. He knows that his name is not William Smith, despite the identity tag he has brought back from the war.

IN November, when the outdoor garden wanes, the greenhouse owner fully appreciates his good fortune. Then he can have a profusion of bloom under glass, heedless of the cold that settles inexorably over the grounds outside.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 13 -- The Amherst Lord Jeffs came from behind today to defeat Williams, 13 -- 7, before 7,800 Alumni Day fans.

OTTAWA, Nov. 13 -- Canadian shipowners are being so hard pressed by decreasing cargo offerings, increasing operation costs and the complications of foreign currency exchanges that they are near the point of seeking a decision from the Government as to whether or not Canada needs and wants a merchant marine, and, if the answer is yes, how it is to be maintained.

THE Godolphin Arabian, a golden-red stallion who became the founder of a line of thoroughbred horses, Man o' War among them, is the most romantic horse to appear in literature for youth for some time. His shining coat was marked with the symbols (to Moroccans) of speed and of misfortune, and the stallion's story did seesaw between good fortune and near disaster.

Permit me to comment briefly on the article, "Why Russia's Young Diplomats Act That Way," in which Jack Winocour writes: "At the hour scheduled on the gilded invitation the (Russian) Embassy lights will be dimmed to hasten the departure of the lingering guests, and the food and drink will mysteriously disappear from the tables." What amuses me is the word "mysteriously.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A plan for mobilizing the civilian populace and minimizing alarm, panic, destruction and death should an enemy attack this country was set forth by the National Military Establishment today to supply "the missing link" in the nation's security.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The Labor party continued today its impressive record in parliamentary by-elections by holding the seat for Edmonton, London. With the election of its candidate there, it has retained twenty-nine and lost only one in forty-five by-elections since the general election in 1945.

THE mask-faced puppy was born in the Northern wilderness. When his mother, a runaway husky, was slain by the black wolf, the young dog outwitted the killer and proceeded to shift for himself -- until the day that he stepped into Link Stevens' fox trap. In the powerful, untamed husky the youthful trapper saw a future leader for his sled dogs, and he determined to win his captive's confidence.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- The period of United States pressure on Marshall Plan countries appears to have come to an end as leaders of those countries, while attaining a large measure of cooperation, have run into long-range difficulties that no pressure can remove.

TO one who, like myself, makes an annual visit to the United States, the first impression of power remains overwhelming. In the dazzling light of this country's productive record it is easy now to forget the apprehensions of economic collapse that figured so largely in reconversion plans during the late summer and fall of 1945.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- New Englanders appear to be settling down to a two-month struggle against the high cost of living until the new political administrations can start living up to their campaign promises in January.

A plan for establishing now, while the lessons of the war are still fresh in mind, a Civil Defense Organization to mitigate the consequences of any possible enemy attack on this country, or other widespread calamity, is presented today by the National Military Establishment for official and public study.

Dr. Fine's article on the educational page of Oct. 24, regarding the recommendation of the United States Advisory Commission on Educational Exchange with respect to cultural exchange with Eastern Europe, is most timely. We who are daily engaged in student interchange activities cannot fail to agree with the Commission's conclusions and appreciate the extensive analysis of the situation made by Dr. Fine.
DUBLIN, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Ireland will cut her last formal tie with the British Crown and will have "complete independence" before Christmas, Prime Minister John A. Costello predicted today.

THE Hudson River Day Line's announcement last week that it was going to sell its white steamers and go out of business occasioned nostalgic sighs among the thousands of New Yorkers who traditionally have taken a holiday trip on one of the line's stately, flag-decked river queens.

TO some readers of this autobiography it may appear that novelist Phyllis Bottome's childhood was just this side of idyllic. She was born sixty-six years ago in a peaceful world to parents who never failed to love, understand and reassure her.

A threefold increase in production with consequent savings of overhead and other manufacturing costs will permit an immediate reduction of 22 per cent on its 54-gauge full-fashioned hosiery, it was announced yesterday by the Gotham Hosiery Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Dr. William Haber, adviser on Jewish affairs to the United States Army commanders in Germany and Austria, believes "there is little doubt that the Jewish displaced persons problem has entered into the liquidation phase."

THE American reading public loves a success story. It can find none more colorful and dynamic than this biography of Booker T. Washington, the Negro educator, who rose from slavery and poverty to leader of his race. Basil Mathews has written a calm, definitive biography of Washington against the background of conditions during his era.

Gray November skies last week lent a dour aspect to beleaguered Berlin. The trees that still stand in the battered capital -- many have been cut down for firewood -- have been stripped of their leaves by wind and rain. The chief concern of the people is the airlift on which they are dependent for food and fuel.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- So far as the British Government is concerned the lifting of the Soviet blockade of Berlin must precede four-power discussions on Berlin any other German questions.

MUSIC publishers know what is being played because they keep close tabs on performances of works from their catalogues. And this fall three of the principal publishers of American compositions -- G. Schirmer, Carl Fischer and Boosey and Hawkes -- are telling the same story.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Truman today proclaimed through executive order a new coat of arms, seal and flag for the Vice President as a present for Senator Alben W. Barkley when he takes office in January.

I want to add my appreciation to Murray Schumach's comprehensive appraisal of Margo Jones' great ability ("A Texas Tornado Hits Broadway"). Mr. Schumach is incorrect, however, in stating: "The lady director-producer has confounded business men with her capacity for making a paying proposition out of her art in a city that has virtually forgotten what it was to have a theatre."

A bazaar will be held at the William I. Sirovich Home, 203 Second Avenue, between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets, from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. tomorrow through Friday by the Rose Sirovich Relief Society, Inc. The proceeds will go to the home's building fund, Mrs. Jack J. Colm, president of the society, announced yesterday.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 13 (UP) -- Little Jerry Tiblier dashed eighty yards on a punt return today for the decisive touchdown in Mississippi's 16-13 victory over Tennessee.

LAST week furnished perfect illustrations of the old Hindu fable about the blind men and the elephant. One had felt the body, another the tusks, another the tail, another the trunk, another the legs, and they all came to very different conclusions as to the nature of the beast.

Nothing but moral force stands behind the appeal made to the Big Four yesterday by the Australian Foreign Minister, Herbert V. Evatt, President of the United Nations Assembly, and U.N. Secretary-General Trygve Lie to settle the Berlin dispute "without delay." Dr. Evatt and Mr. Lie can do nothing except to point out, as they do, "the danger to the peace and security of all nations" which this controversy has produced.

The Loewenguth String Quartet of Paris made an extraordinarily fine start yesterday afternoon in its six-concert series, which will include all the quartets of Beethoven. The Times Hall series comes only two weeks after another top-drawer outfit, the London Quartet, played the last ten of these works, and promises to make memorable the next two week-ends.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Sagging stockyard prices for hogs and many kinds of pork was a leading topic of conversation this week among the populace in metropolitan centers of the Central States.

La Salle Academy made a sweep of honors in the fifteenth annual Bronx-Manhattan-Westchester Catholic High Schools Athletic Association cross-country championships yesterday when it captured both the individual and team titles. Lawrence Paturzo, in winning, registered a 13:48 clocking over the two-and-one-quarter-mile Van Cortlandt Park.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, tonight called on the Government of Israel to withdraw its forces in the Negeb to the positions they occupied on Oct. 14, before the recent fighting.

NANKING, Nov. 13 -- The eastern flank of the Government forces defending Suchow, key northern Kiangsu rail junction, has started to crumble, it was reported tonight. Government military sources said that Gen. Tu Yu-ming, field leader under the Suchow command, was directing a mass re-shifting of his available forces in an attempt to re-establish the line above Nanking.

Speared on a triple pronged dilemma -- strike, short supply and heavy Government demand -- the copper industry fears that the outcome of current industry-Government meetings may culminate in allocations and price controls.

WHILE the accent is largely on television in Chicago broadcasting this season, the Chicago Industrial Health Association, in cooperation with some 300 health and welfare agencies, has come up with an unusually effective radio documentary series titled "It's Your Life."

TEL AVIV, Nov. 13 -- With each day of delay in settling the Palestine problem, the basis for settlement becomes increasingly favorable to Israel. This is why it is believed here that two of the Arab states have sought contact with Israeli officials looking toward some kind of agreement that would not be too obvious a defeat in the eyes of the Arabs.

Renewal of Government controls on exports promises to be one of the first international trade matters to come before the new Congress, inasmuch as authority for existing controls under Public Law 395 expires on Feb. 28 next.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Joseph P. Ryan, chief of the striking longshoremen, will meet at 10 o'clock this morning in Gracie Mansion soon after the Mayor's return from the West Coast, it became known last night.

INTRODUCTION of the Polaroid Land Camera, which utilizes the one-step picture-making principle first announced last year, was the highlight of the 1948 convention of the Photographic Society of America in Cincinnati recently.

A CHANCE remark about the settlement in the Ramapos long ago of "Jackson's Whites" led Theda Kenyon to write this story of the American War for Independence. It is her sixth historical romance, of which the last was "That Skipper From Stonington."

AS an immediate novelty in books about New Orleans, it is pleasant to note that Miss Robinson has put ht some hard hours of research; and that she shows herself unwilling to skim over and rehash, slightly, the same old things that go into the same old books about the yeasty, zesty Creole town.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- The British high command in Germany will view any forcing down of British aircraft by Soviet fighters as a matter of "utmost gravity," the Soviet Military Administration was informed today.

Members of Chapter Number One of the Berkshire Industrial Farm have taken over the performance of "Red Gloves," a new play by Jean-Paul Sartre, with Charles Boyer in the leading role, on the night of Dec. 21 at the Mansfield Theatre to raise funds for the institution.

A NOVEL of adolescence in a rural setting can make easy use of what nature provides in symbolism, and to do so has become almost a rule of fiction. In "The Wild Country," Mr. Bromfield grabs with both hands at the Missouri countryside for the symbols of his hero's awakening.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 13 (UP) -An official spokesman said today that martial law had been clamped on one-fourth of United States-occupied South Korea to deal with reported new "plots" against the Government.

November rain is traditionally chill and dismal; but the tradition is no more than half right. Save in summer, rain is always chill, and he who gets soaked is going to be cold until he dries off, whether it is November or April. And as for the dismal aspect, that is a matter of time and place and mood.

The Marshall Plan should serve to unite the nations of Europe for peace and prevent them from falling under Communist domination without imposing our form of government upon any of them, in the opinion of high school students who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- The American Consul General in Shanghai announced today that the United States armed forces were prepared to divert ships to Shanghai to evacuate Americans wanting to leave.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 13 -- The chapel bell at Wesleyan University rang out today to signal another Cardinal victory, the twenty-second in a row, this time over a highly touted Trinity eleven. The score was 16 -- 0.

Foundation garment manufacturers wound up their spring market week in New York last week with a greater buyer attendance and volume of orders than was anticipated, according to Fletcher D. Dodge, executive vice president of the Corset and Brassiere Association of America.

The annual forecast of approaching economic crisis in the United States by Soviet Government economists arrived in New York last week. It contained a grudging excuse for the three previous forecasts, which missed the level of business activity in this country by a wider margin than the pollsters missed the 1948 elections.

HERE is a rousing historical tale of the French and Indian War, with the high point that fierce but unsuccessful attack on Fort Ticonderoga by the English forces under Abercrombie and Howe. Specifically, it tells the story of Phil Dearborn, homeless orphan, who slips into the Army and becomes both assistant to Lord Howe and a member of Rogers' Rangers.

SOME things are easy for Ann to do and hard for Tim, but Tim can do lots of things that Ann can't. Ann admires the way that he can tie knots. Tim marvels when Ann jumps rope. Some things are hard for both of them and some are easy when they do them together.

THE longest running story in the history of the motion picture industry -- the Government's ten-year-old anti-trust action to divest producer-distributor companies of their theatre holdings -- continues to be the biggest trade news of the moment.

The thirty-eighth annual exhibition of juvenile literature, "Children's Books Suggested as Holiday Gifts," opens on Tuesday in the Central Children's Room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. It has been prepared by Mrs. Frances Clarke Sayers, Superintendent of Work with Children, and a special committee of children's librarians.
Thomas D. Campbell of Hardin, Mont., one of the world's largest wheat growers, will leave by Air France today to help the French Government increase wheat production in North Africa.

Mrs. Richard Kennon Hines and Mrs. Henry Steeger head the general committee for the annual Christmas fair of the Brick Presbyterian Church to be held on Friday in the recreation hall of the church under the auspices of the Woman's Association.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- Residents of California, Oregon and Washington are thinking of the possible effects on their pocketbooks of new pension plans adopted by all three West Coast states on Election Day.

WHEN 15-year-old Tim Yoder's older brothers go off to war and bid him look after their mother and sister, Rosy, and their happy home on the Isle of Que, in the lovely Susquehanna River, Tim feels he is being asked to be too much of a man all at once.

FROM her aunt, Anne Parrish heard the story of Harriet Tubman, escaped Negro slave, abolitionist, Union nurse, spy and stalwart of the underground railway. In this last activity Harriet became exceedingly adroit and successful, leading more than 300 slaves to freedom before the Civil War and was dubbed "Moses" by those who heard of her exploits.

ANTHROPOLIGIST William Howells, whose first book, "Mankind So Far," demonstrated his skill in handling scientific data for popular use -- minus technical jargon, minus collateral opinions and with occasional humor -- has now come forth with a volume on primitive man and his religions.

With the arrest of a Mexican-born cartoonist and his wife in Los Angeles on Friday, postal authorities here announced yesterday they had rounded up the last members of a group that allegedly had attempted to use a new version of the old "Spanish prisoner" swindle scheme.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, accused the United States today of preparing a Pearl Harbor sneak attack against Moscow and of making concrete plans to wage war on Soviet soil.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Democrats on Capitol Hill this week were preparing with manifest pleasure to take over from the Republican-dominated Joint Inaugural Committee appointed by the Eightieth Congress for the job of organizing President Truman's inaugural.

IN her first story about contemporary children, Pamela Bianco has combined her rare artistic and literary gifts, and created characters whom young readers will recognize and remember. They will cherish this chronicle of childish experiences for its imagination, insight and quiet humor, as well as for the exquisite design and detail of the stylized drawings and decorations.

WHO is the girl with the smoking pistol in her hand who stands over the body of the dead psychiatrist Ozzie Fenwick? Barry Barlow, who has heard the shot, does not recognize her, but he does recognize her shoes. He should, because he designed them.

Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger gave assurances yesterday that magistrates would support the Department of Sanitation in its efforts to control littering of the streets in the Washington Market district.

AESOP used to write them, as did the Brothers Grimm and Queen Marie of Rumania Apparently the first American to try was the Rev. John Cotton, grandfather of Cotton Mather. Later Americans have included practically every conceivable brand and breed, from Nathaniel Hawthorne of Salem to Christy Mathewson of baseball.

IRAN across a statement made by Mr. Anatole Litvak and reported in last Sunday's edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Nov. 7, which I consider an unwarranted and flagrant violation of the existing credit agreement between the motion picture com-companies and the Screen Writers Guild.

It is difficult to piece together the varied forms of illogic that your correspondent, Ernest T. Nash, pursued in his letter of Oct. 24 regarding England and the United States, and their past and present in Chinese affairs.
In the Sunday Times (Oct. 31), Bette Davis said that censorship stifles honest expression in American pictures.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 13 -- Halifax is the busiest shipping port in Canada as a result of the strike of stevedores at United States Atlantic ports. The waterfront here is the scene of the greatest activity since the war years, and railroads are taxed to capacity to handle the sudden influx of passengers from ocean liners bound to United States ports.

THE inconclusive and tantalizing data extant on that notable queen of the Ptolemy dynasty in Egypt, Cleopatra -- data not only fragmentary, but all webbed in legend -- have made her (most reasonably) an infinite source of literary speculation.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- As the week drew to a close, Britons were almost universally speculating on whether it would be a boy or a girl and how King George would like being a grandfather.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 -- The American Federation of Labor today decided upon a double-barreled offensive to rid its affiliates in Canada of Communists and to purge Communists from the Canadian Trades and Labor Congress.
WITH the relaxation of restrictions on arms and ammunitions for use in game hunting in the West Indies, there are indications that the islands will have their biggest hunting season this winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Representative Wright Patman of Texas predicted today that the special House Small Business Committee would be retained in the new Democratic Congress. The former chairman of the group said investigations started under Republican control would be continued.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The University of Buffalo wound up its most successful football season in years today, walloping Bucknell, 47 -- 13, for its sixth victory against one loss and a tie.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A top secret "M-Day" plan is being developed for the American merchant fleet.

Among the big losers in the election two weeks ago were the Gallup, Roper and Crossley national public opinion polls -- President Truman's "red-faced pollsters." From all sides there was strong criticism of the polls. One Republican Congressman said he would introduce a bill in the next session to deny the use of the mails to election polls.

TO the Vienna-born philosopher Martin Buber goes the credit for collecting and presenting to the Western world all of the striking fables, parables and aphorisms produced by the Hasidic sect of Eastern European Jewry. Considering Hasidic truth "vitally important," not only for Jews but for adherents of other faiths as well, he challengingly promises to carry it to the non-Jews: "

NOT many of the ballet books which stream from the London presses to meet the apparently insatiable thirst of the British public are of any great moment except to the balletomanes, but A.H. Franks has written a very simple one that has a certain value.
ONEONTA, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Hartwick College pushed three touchdowns across in the fourth quarter to defeat Wagner College, 25-12, today as rain and wind swept Hartwick Field.

THE iron eagle liked his job telling which way the wind blew, but years of watching the crops grow and seeing the children on the New England farm make snow candy at "sugaring off" time wearied him. He longed to flap his iron wings and fly somewhere.

In the course of a Sigma Xi lecture delivered at the University of Chicago, Prof. H.J. Muller of the University of Indiana, Nobel laureate of 1946, yearned that X-rays, whether used in treating cancer or for diagnostic examinations of the abdomen, may cause hereditary body changes if the reproductive organs are in the irradiated field.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Sigma Delta Chi, national journalism fraternity, approved today a committee recommendation that it abandon proposals to establish a code of journalistic ethics.

BECAUSE Luke Baldwin's father had been an easy-going, idealistic doctor, the boy found it hard to adjust himself to living with his practical and businesslike Uncle Henry. The conflict between the two centered around a once-beautiful collie, now old and useless and about to be destroyed.
With Joe Carveth blasting home a pair of goals to lead in the attack, the Canadiens of Montreal defeated the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

FOR a long time now, a favored cause among industrial designers has been a plea for the same kind of efficiency at home as we have in our offices. Homemakers don't always see eye to eye with them on this point, but any woman who has ever worked in an office knows a few items of office equipment she would like to see translated for home use.

LONDON. IN the last year the Western powers have been offered every possible opportunity of watching Soviet Russia at work. In Europe it has been the year of the Cominform, of the coup d'etat in Prague, in Germany of the Berlin crisis. In the Far East the summer saw the development of a full-scale Communist offensive in Burma, Malaya and Indonesia and the year has brought territorial gains to communism in North China.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- In as thrilling a finish as has marked the forty-eight-year-old series between the schools. Cornell staged a gallant last-period rally to turn back Dartmouth's eleven, 27 -- 26, before 30,000 at Schoellkopf Field today.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Taking to the air when its overland advance was unexpectedly halted. Holy Cross turned back a surprisingly strong Fordham eleven, 13 -- 6, today before a crowd of 5,000 at Fitton Field.

ALBERT DEUTSCH is a violent man with words. Again and again he has pointed out in his articles the shame of our care -- or, rather, our lack of care -- for the mentally ill. Beginning with the Veteran's Administration, he exposed the inadequacies, the outright failure to provide decent care for the veterans of previous wars, in spite of the millions appropriated for that purpose.

TEL VIV, Israel, Nov. 13 -- The Israeli Government will launch shortly a fun-scale colonization plan for the Negeb desert area of southern Palestine, centered on Beersheba as an Israeli town, it was learned today.

THE complexities of the postal system are simplified in this story of the postman, and that stalwart public servant is represented in four countries, France, England, Brazil and the United States, giving this book an international flavor.

LONDON'S Central Music Library was opened to the public last month. Among the speakers were Ralph Vaughan Williams, Sir Steuart Wilson, Eric Blom and Mrs. Winifred Christie Moor, whose gift in memory of her husband, Emanuel Moor, made the establishment of the library possible.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Describing the Progressive party as "far more important now than it ever was," Henry A. Wallace, its Presidential candidate in the recent elections, asserted here today that he had "just begun to fight" for the party's "liberal program."

A VISITOR straying into the radio studio when "Boston Blackie" goes on the air might be slightly startled at what he saw. A petite young lady, giving herself a stiff right to the jaw -- a left to the solar plexus, and a series of short jabs to the nose followed by a conclusive uppercut with a fist that held a stopwatch.

THE eleven pieces of fiction in this volume are variable in length, from the short novel, "The Little Town," to the very short story, "The Finger." The novel, appearing in English for the first time, is the work which in its original form first gained for its author European recognition.

IF we make use of De Quincey's distinction between "literature of knowledge" and "literature of power" -- that the one merely teaches while the other moves the spirit of man -- we are bound to include Sartre's fervent and brilliant challenge to anti-Semitism in the second category.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A new peak in college enrollment for the third successive year, a total of 2,408,307 students in 1,800 colleges, was reported today by the Federal Office of Education.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 13 (UP) -- An Air Force C-47 transport crashed into a B-50 bomber in taking off at Eielson Field last night, killing six men and injured fifteen, the air base commander reported today.

Bernardo Ibanez of Chile, president of the Inter-American Confederation of Workers, declared yesterday that the workers of Latin America have "an incipient and still weak organization" and are compelled to "wage a war against selfish exploiters, on the economic plane, and against feudalistic reactionaries, Fascists and Communists, on the social and political plane."

HERE are two books that tell -- each in its own fashion -- of a nation's hope for independence, and how that hope crumbled piecemeal under the Soviet steam roller. One is by the Yugoslav Ambassador to Washington in the war years; the other is by Hungary's former Prime Minister.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Massive Minnesota bruised its way to a 28-21 victory over Iowa today in a sizzling flurry of touchdowns.

While admitting to "a certain inevitable disappointment" about "the low Wallace vote," Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party, asserted yesterday that the Progressive party emerged from the election "as an influential force in the political life of the country today."
A CAMPAIGN for Governmentendowed drama in the United States is being formulated by a group of theatre leaders and is expected to get under way here early next year.

The Catskill deer hunters should find conditions about right when they go into the woods tomorrow morning for the opening of the season, and while not all of the leaves are off the brush the woods are fairly open and the recent rains have wet down the leaves enough to insure quiet hunting.

THE complete suspension of production operations by Eagle Lion "until some time in January" came last week as a surprising and drastic climax to economy measures begun by the studio six weeks ago. This latest development served to point up the difficulties of film producing and distributing companies which do not control exhibition outlets.

ELIZABETH YATES' new novel, "Beloved Bondage," opens on the day that John Bennet, a furniture salesman from unfashionable Riverton, marries Althea Trainer, the enchantingly beautiful daughter of a family living across the river in fashionable Highlands. Only on his wedding night does John discover that part of Althea's air of enchantment is due to an unfortunate mental quirk which makes her, among other things, unwilling to consummate their marriage.

More than 1,000 emotionally disturbed children have been deprived of help in the last year because the staff of the Jewish Board of Guardians, one of the largest child-guidance groups in the country, has been reduced by almost a third, it was learned yesterday from Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, president.

THE picture which Mrs. Parker O. Griffith, founder of the Griffith Music Foundation, paints of Newark, N.J., in 1907, the year she and Mr. Griffith settled there, is one that would put the heart and ambitions of a less determined woman permanently in the deep freeze.

DR. STANLEY JONES, the now venerable missionary who discerned the Christ of the Indian Road, is one with whom it is impossible to quarrel. He is horrified by the predicament of civilization menaced by force. In escapist mood he is hypnotized by Mahatma Gandhi, that wise man from the East whose only force was influence -- it should be added organized influence -- over others.

ALEKO and his goat, Lesbia, live on a Greek island with Aleko's grandmother. Aleko, like most of the people on the island, is always a little hungry since the war, and life is difficult. One day he finds -- with Lesbia's help -- a bronze statuette of a shepherd lad.

THE Scotland to which Mary the Queen returned from France in 1561 was a den of thieves and murderers, according to this novel. Poison was a matter-of-fact instrument to the gang of lords around Mary, which included her illegitimate half-brother.

Today will mark the joint opening of Nursing Progress Week, proclaimed as such by twenty-seven governors and sixty-three mayors, including Mayor O'Dwyer, and celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of American nursing.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 14 -- Sir William Gilliatt, the gynecologist who will attend Princess Elizabeth at the birth of her child, decided late last evening to spend the night at Buckingham Palace. A room there had previously been prepared for him.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Wisconsin punched over four touchdowns against a weak Marquette squad today to defeat the Hilltoppers 26 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A House investigating subcommittee will start Monday public hearings designed to prove up its conclusions that American buyers of new automobiles were mulcted to a tune of $450,000,000 by dealers during the first seven months of this year.

ONE of the most popular forms of historical writing in recent decades has been practiced by authors who are unhampered by the facts, or at least unworried by their interpretation. It is related that when someone objected to Andre Maurois that from his "Ariel" one would scarcely divine that Shelley was a poet, the author queried: "Was Shelley a poet?"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The shape of the new four-year era of President Truman is being hammered out now in relaxed, almost carefree conferences on the white sands at Key West, Fla., but no one in Washington expects drastic changes.

Leading from start to finish, the New York Knickerbockers regained their winning ways with a 91-87 triumph over the Baltimore Bullets in a Basketball Association of America contest at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. A crowd of 4,123 saw the Knicks snap a two-game losing streak and go into a tie for first place in the Eastern Division at the same time that Boston lost to Rochester.

Carpet mills will substantially increase store modernization services to small carpet specialty stores immediately, Merrill A. Watson, president of the Carpet Institute, disclosed in an interview last week. He said that plans for more extensive service to such outlets are being made as a result of vigorous complaints by small retailers that mills limit store modernization services almost entirely to department and furniture stores and similar large establishments.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 13 -- State and local tax problems have been the chief discussion topic at ranch-house talkfests and big-city Rotary luncheons this past week. Every state and virtually every city throughout the mountain region is badly in need of new schools and hospital facilities; and tax funds, already drained by road and waterworks construction projects, are woefully short.

Pierre Fournier, who gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, must be reckoned among the foremost 'cellists of the time. The artist from France provided his large audience with a series of performances which disclosed remarkable interpretive powers as well as an extraordinary technical equipment, and he scored an immediate success.

LONDON. HAS humor, as it used to be known in Europe, dried up somewhat under the pressure of post-war hardships and uneasiness about the future? Some correspondents, searching for the leaven of wit in press and word-of-mouth anecdote, are inclined to think so -- although part of the answer may be simply the newsprint shortage, which doesn't leave much room for frivolities and asides.

A CAMERA hospital staffed by New York repair experts will be a feature of the National Photographic Show of 1949, to be held Feb. 19-22 at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities, as it is now known and as it has proceeded for two embittered years, was stricken, probably mortally, in the election returns.

The Austrian people believe they could make greater economic progress if the four occupying powers withdrew their troops, Otto Sagmeister, Minister of Food in the Austrian Cabinet, declared yesterday. He arrived last week with the Austrian delegation to the forthcoming United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization conference in Washington.

The wearing qualities of synthetic paints and varnishes can now be tested in less than one second with a new machine that utilizes supersonic energy. According to Saul Moses of the Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C., the coating is smeared on a metal cap, which is screwed on the end of a duraluminum cylinder attached to an electronic source of high-frequency sound waves.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The cornerstone of a new University of Caen, whose buildings were destroyed along with a great part of the city of Caen in 1944 fighting, was laid today by Yvon Delbos, Minister of Education, in the presence of government officials, representatives of foreign countries and of educational institutions.

Britain now has joined eight other European nations in abolishing that bane of travel, the visa, for Americans wishing to go to those countries for short periods. Belgium, Italy, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, Luxembourg and the Netherlands are the others.

AN unusual way of life and an uncommon setting enrich this mystery to the extent that it can be called good regional fiction for both boys and girls of 10 to 14. But the story of the odd happenings to the large Pennyweather family and their neighbors along the levee and on both sides of the river in New Orleans during one winter and spring is never lost in the richness of its background.

AT the wine judging at the California State Fair (reported here recently), the gold medal in the dry sherry class went to Solera Cellars for a wine described as "soft and well-balanced." Now this prize winner is coming East.

THIS novel was written as the basis for a scenario for a film recently produced in France. This fact may be partial justification for M. Sartre's use of dizzying flash-backs, deus ex machina, newsreel style, and shock devices of a kind not usually associated with the novel per se.
OMAHA, Nov. 13 -- Corn, which is never far from the thoughts of the Midwest, loomed large in the region's conversation and plans this week.

Supplies of scrap metal available to the domestic steel industry have improved so much in recent months that the danger of curtailment of steel production this winter, which had been feared earlier, virtually has been eliminated, the scrap trade feels.

THIS collection of eighteen stories and fourteen poems, with Santa Claus as hero, will prove useful for storytellers seeking new material, and enjoyable for young readers of the Santa Claus age. Although some of the selections will be familiar ("The Night Before Christmas," "Is There a Santa Claus?" for instance), many of them are less well known.

PIRATES have always held a fascination for young people -- especially these buccaneers who eventually became respectable. Such a pirate was Scarface, cabin boy to the capable but cruel Captain Cheap. The story centers around the West Indies, Tortuga, the pirate lair, and Bridgetown, home of the Royal Governor.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- President Truman's choice of this city, the nation's southernmost, for winter vacations has already brought it wide recognition. And his presence here at this time has brought renewed tourist interest, evidenced by a record number of advance reservations for the coming season.

Weathering another sharp selling attack -- the third major assault since the national elections -- stock prices closed lower for the second successive week. Trading ended on a rallying note, after THE NEW YORK TIMES averages had come within striking distance of the year's low point, which was recorded in March.

Two major atomic energy problems, which transcend the philosophy and organization of the Atomic Energy Commission, or the priorities to be accorded various nuclear energy projects, overshadow all other similar problems.

PARIS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from a speech on disarmament proposals made before the United Nations Assembly's Political Committee by Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky:
The first sheet of 1948 Carver IIn'c., a non-profit organizati.o?, zation was founded by the late seals for the $2,000,000 endowment'

The Ice Follies of 1949, starring Roy Shipstad, Hazel Franklin, Betty Schalow, Mae Ross, Frick and Frack and others, will open a fifteen-performance run at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night. The extravaganza, which has proved highly popular in the past, has a cast of 200 this year, including many newcomers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13 -- Only after Yale had fought with the tenacity of its traditional bulldog mascot did Princeton leave the field today carrying off the Big Three title. The Tigers won the game by 20 -- 14.

Another six-day bike race arrives in New York starting tonight at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory, Broadway and 168th Street, with thirty outstanding competitors entered. Acting Mayor Vincent Impellitteri is scheduled to fire the starting gun that will send the fifteen teams off on the mad whirl for glory and money.

THREE stage works not often performed hereabouts receive a measure of their due in new recordings. They are Richard Strauss' Elektra, Ravel's L'Enfant et les Sortileges and Saint-Saens' Samson et Dalila. The latter two are done in full, while almost all of the final scene of the Strauss opera has been recorded.

Despite heavy Armistice Day sales last week, retail trade here for the entire period was held back by unseasonally warm and rainy weather. Estimates put department store volume at about 10 per cent under last year.

OF these three books of biography and memoir, "Main Line" is the most interesting. Mr. King, a Californian and not to be confused with the admiral, began his career at 15 as a Western Union messenger. He became a telegrapher and went to work for the S.P., which assigned him to a succession of stations in the wild country where the main line from San Francisco to Reno crosses the Sierras.

"MAN and His Works," by Professor Herskovits of Northwestern University, is a testament to the scientific engineering principles of present-day anthropology. For more than fifty years anthropology has shared the burden of most infant sciences in affirming and reaffirming its claim to being a scientific discipline with a manageable frame of reference, specific methods and a critical approach to problems.

Plans for a new building to replace the present French Evangelical Church at 126 West Sixteenth Street will be announced at the one-hundredth anniversary of the establishment of that parish next Sunday. The new structure will cost approximately $200,000.

LIEUT. John Reardon, Cavalry, U.S.A., fought the Apache chieftain Deesohay for four years. Some day, the young officer swore, he would decoy the wily Indian into a position where B Company could annihilate the red outlaws with charge and counter-charge.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. -- Once known only for its legalized gambling and easy divorce laws, this so-called "desert sea" resort town -- fortuitously situated in the heart of some of the West's most scenic playgrounds -- currently is preparing for the winter season.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- Three out of four Berliners are convinced the situation in this city "is serious enough to cause a war within the near future," a Military Government survey of public opinion showed today.

NILS lives on a farm, has a dog, a cat and a pony, and his chief ambition is to be a cowboy. His mother and father had come from Norway, and sometimes he brags so much his mother calls him Peer Gynt, after the Norwegian lad who "liked to tell tales as tall as the mountains of Norway."

FOURTEEN-YEAR-OLD Ab Carmody tells his own story in blunt, boylike language that is exactly right for the suspense-filled tale. He runs away from a California school to his Guatemalan great-uncle, only to find the old general dying on his ruined plantation.

A BLOCK of marble in the London studio of Lewis Quinton forms what might well be called the leitmotif of this novel. Quinton plans to carve from it a group to be titled "Resurrection," and as the work proceeds something like a resurrection takes place within the sculptor.

TOKYO, Nov. 13 -- No appeal for clemency will be made by former Japanese Army and Navy officers convicted with former Premier Hideki Tojo's war criminals and sentenced to hanging or life imprisonment, it was announced today by defense counsel.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of "Carmen," with Rise Stevens, Licia Albanese, Kurt Baum and Frank Guarrera in the leading roles, on the night of Dec. 14 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- The Russian drive for a settlement of the Berlin impasse, on grounds favorable to the Soviet Union's policy of ejecting the Western powers from Berlin, received new impetus today when an editorial in the Taegliche Rundschau, organ of the Soviet Military Administration, declared "the Berlin question can be settled at any time on the basis of the two agreements reached earlier."

BABAR fans, young and old, need no longer ask wistfully, "Isn't there another Babar story?" for here are the adventures of mischievous Arthur, the very same Arthur of the other Babar books. Arthur has an idea, and in following it through is just as surprised as everyone else on the airfield to find himself on the tail of a plane which has just taken off.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A proposed civil defense plan made public by the National Military Establismhent "assumed" today the use of the atomic bomb by "a theoretical enemy" and estimated that casualties would total 40,000 killed and 60,000 injured for every bomb burst over a densely populated area.

The immortal Bobby Clark may be a scream, as you imply ("Bobby Clark -- 'First Spouse of the Land!"), without his grease-paint glasses, but to me it just doesn't seem right. * * * Bobby made his place in the hearts of theatregoers with those improbable spectacles adorning his comical physiognomy.

Has Jean Cocteau, who so justly praises (in "Focus on Miracles") the 16 mm. film, heard of Cinema 16? More than his article, the films I have seen at Cinema 16 have opened my eyes to the 16 mm. field.

LENS (By Wireless). THE whole region of Pas-de-Calais was in a state of siege. Two hundred thousand Communist-led miners sulked idly in their houses. About 30,000 troops had been sent into the region to seize the mines from the strikers and to protect a handful of men still willing to work.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Four men were killed and five were injured this morning in a collision between a fire engine and a passenger car.

A disturbing aspect of the Presidential election was the strong indication that, despite a plurality in excess of one million popular votes for President Truman, a failure to obtain a majority in the Electoral College might throw the Presidential election into the House of Representatives, with a real possibility of private deals there which might frustrate the expressed will of the people and elect a minority President.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 13 -- Still somewhat surprised but apparently pleased with the results of the election, most residents of the Southwest are watching with added interest developments in Washington.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 13 -- Alfred Loritz, accused black marketer recently recaptured by the Munich police after many months, said today he had fled from jail because he had been arrested on false charges and "would have died" for the lack of medical treatment for a stomach ailment.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., stoutly straddles a picturesque bluff, one foot planted firmly in the silt-heavy Missouri River, and the other thrust deep into the loam-rich prairie. Compared to the great seaboard cities it is a runt; but as wheat-and-corn-belt cities go, it is a giant.

The famous collection of rare Americana belonging to the Rev. Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes, formerly Canon of the Episcopal Cathedral in Washington and before that the long-term secretary of Yale University, will be auctioned tomorrow and Tuesday evenings at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

TO place climbing or pillar roses against a fence or wall, and then face them down with smaller kinds of roses, is a most effective planting scheme. Some beautiful combinations can be worked out, either all in one color or in contrasting shades.
