SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- A trio of plunging Red Raiders, Alan Egler, Armand (Frenchy) Allaire and Paul Mulligan, tore Syracuse's Orangemen asunder today, 20 to 13, in the forty-ninth meeting between these time-honored neighborhood foes, as 36,232 football fans shivered in Archbold Stadium to see if Bernie Custis' aerial raid could tie the battle in the dying minutes of action.

Buyers continued to check spring ready-to-wear lines shown here last week in the wholesale apparel market and also looked over merchandise offered for January clearance and white sales, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

THE thirty-eighth volume of the popular Rivers of America series covers the Mohawk, a tributary of the Hudson that branches westward at Cohoes, near Troy, and cuts through the plateau of central New York State. As a watery spectacle the Mohawk is not impressive.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 13 (UP) -- Quarterback Joe McCary, his face twisted from the pain of a broken right hand, intercepted a West Virginia lateral and ran forty-five yards in the fourth period today for Virginia's only touchdown, which beat West Virginia, 7 to 0.

TWINS have always been of peculiar interest to mankind because of their relative rarity. In primitive times twins were often regarded as omens of good or bad fortune -- mostly bad. If looked upon as signs of ill fortune, twins were usually destroyed. In civilized society twins, besides being cherished by the family circle, are in a sense laboratory material for scientists, medical men and educators.

A new service expected to open a wide field for transparent plastic boxes and containers was disclosed here last week by officials of Plastic Molded Arts, Inc., Long Island City, manufacturer specializing in plastic packaging.
"That American Disease, 'Electionitis,'" by Leopold Schwarzschild, is an amazing document -- amazing because it deliberately presents the principle of free speech as a wasteful, vicious thing.

IN the bridge dogma, one of the standard tenets is: When one of equal honors is led, cover the second, not the first. If dummy has Q-J-6 and you are sitting over dummy with K-7-4, you do not cover if the queen is led; you play low, and cover the jack if it is led next.

Anyone who saw Gertrude Samuels' pictures of "The Lost and Forgotten Children of Europe," and read of them in your Magazine came away with a sickish feeling. It makes one feel guilty about our own comfortable homes and well-fed stomachs to see ragged children living in caves and in desperate need of food.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- By thirty seconds Army won a race with the clock again today and with it a football game, 26 -- 20, as Pennsylvania just failed to provide the shock of the year.

ON a Sunday afternoon in Quito, time is apt to move slowly for the visiting American. Through the day he has observed the life of this Ecuadorian capital, 9,000 feet up in the Andes, a city old when the Incas came. He has been to church, has watched the boys and girls at the noontime dance, has lunched, sat in the sun, had tea.

THE life stories of a financial wizard (and gambler), a promoter (and crackpot) and a hardbitten Yankee trader (and family bully), are individually of ephemeral interest; collectively they call attention to the diverse elements that contribute to the growth of a nation.
TOKYO, Nov. 13 -- Japan's new Government is taking a tough attitude toward the coal mining and electric power wage disputes.

THIS is one of the most interesting books written so far for the teenage girl who has outgrown most "girl's books" and is ready to graduate to more adult fiction. Novels of this sort are the bridge between the younger books and the distorted and puzzling picture of life and love that so much of modern fiction presents.

CHICAGO, Nov 13 (AP) -- Corn met selling pressure on the Board of Trade today, largely because of nervousness created by the strike of longshoremen at northern Atlantic Coast ports. Other cereals were mostly lower, but wheat showed relative steadiness.

ONE day a big pelican, blown North by a storm wind, finds himself far from his home off the Florida coast. He doesn't know that he is flying over Canada, and he doesn't notice much of what he is flying over, but the 3-to-6-year-old will find many objects in the brilliantly colored and detailed pictures that Pelican does not see.

SOMEONE is sending anonymous letters to Katy Meredith. She finds them, unstamped and bearing no postmark, at the door of her Greenwich Village apartment, and each consists of only three words, "You pushed her." Katy knows that they refer to an accident which occurred thirteen years earlier when her foster-sister Monica fell through the ice while skating.

HONOLULU, Nov. 13 -- Gov. Ingram M. Stainback was on the island of Hawaii today for an inspection of the Waiamea reclamation project. He apparently was ignoring the latest attempt by dissident territorial Democrats to have him removed from office.

The belief that foreign-flag steamship companies had deliberately depressed their rates to take away Economic Cooperation Administration cargoes from American ships was expressed here last week by Grenville Mellen, member of the Maritime Commission.

FOR about twenty-five years the movement known as the Scottish Renaissance has conditioned the intellectual climate of Scottish letters. As happened with various European countries in the nineteenth century, the revival of national culture in Scotland was originally, and is now more or less loosely, connected with a political nationalism.

CHICAGO -- The nation's railroads, seriously concerned with airline and bus competition and with a downward trend in passenger traffic volume, are studying ways of taking the thumps and bumps and sidesway out of their passenger cars in order to achieve the smooth ride on "ribbons of steel" that both the traveling public and the railroads have been looking for.

The tenth annual card party and tea at the home of Mrs. Harold C. Richard, 1060 Fifth Avenue, for the Sheltering Arms Children's Service will be given on Dec. 7. The proceeds will be used to provide foster home care for 110 new children who are included this year in the group the beneficiary aids.
WILMINGTON, Ohio, Nov. 13 -- America's liberal arts colleges have the difficult responsibility of developing citizens who understand how to eliminate the war spirit and build peaceful attitudes.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Gerald H. Salisbury, chairman of the State Freedom Train Commission, said today that the New York State Freedom Train would be ready to visit every community in the state by early January.

JOE LITTLEFIELD'S father died as they were crossing the plains and the boy went to live with an old scout. At near-by Fort Bridget lived Dick Praisewater, son of an Army officer. When news of the Civil War reached Fort Bridger, Dick's father deserted to join the Rebel army and all of the loyal troops were ordered East.

THE sir and brother of this novel's title is an international labor union vice president idealistically involved in his work and hopelessly entangled with a rich-type woman who doesn't necessarily believe in one big union.

In the colorful setting of a country fair, favorite children's books will come to life as one of the features of the second annual Boys' and Girls' Book Fair, which will open Friday at the American Museum of Natural History for a four-day run under the sponsorship of the museum, THE NEW YORK TIMES and the Children's Book Council.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 13 -- Boris Kidritch, chairman of the State Planning Commission and a member of the Yugoslav Politburo, today ordered the Slovene Communist party congress, which is meeting in Ljubljana, to intensify the drive against the Kulaks [wealthy peasants] by speeding up the establishment of agricultural cooperatives on the collective model.
PARIS, Nov. 13 -- The delegations of Denmark, Norway and Uruguay submitted today a draft resolution that invited South Africa to collaborate more closely with the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

THERE is a great deal more to this book than the story of the secret of the bog near Killieslaw. Killieslaw was an Irish village whose last able-bodied man was impressed by the English to go to America to fight -- the time is 1812 -- and Mickey, a medium-sized boy was left to care for the village.

BACK in those days (if you got enough subscriptions). The Youth's Companion would give you a pair of skates, a magic lantern, an air rifle, and -- but I never got enough subscriptions to find out what the big prizes were. Or, if you weren't a Youth's Companion boy, and had the itch to write, you were probably a member of the St. Nicholas League.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 10 points net lower.
One of Hollywood's leading writer-producers explains why Richard Haydn, an actor, was handpicked to direct the latest Brackett comedy, "Miss Tatlock's Millions," for Paramount.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- Russia has protested to Gen. Douglas MacArthur, Supreme Allied Commander in Japan, against measures said to have been carried out by the occupation authorities against Japanese workers and alleged that mass arrests were taking place in Japan, the Moscow radio announced tonight.

Plans have been completed for the annual luncheon and sale for the benefit of St. Luke's Home for Aged Women, to be held on Wednesday and Thursday at the headquarters of the home, Broadway at 114th Street. A luncheon will be served on Wednesday and a tea will be given on Thursday, and on both days there will be a sale of useful and decorative articles suitable for gifts at the forthcoming holiday season.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Mrs. Bernice Brown Cronkhite, vice president of Radcliffe College and dean of its Graduate School, will be honored here next Thursday at a reception marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of her association with the college, it was announced today by Mrs. S. Burt Wolbach, a member of the school's board of trustees.

WE have never been able to resist peeking into prams and this summer in England we were especially keen about the baby carriage brigade. We admired the red cheeks, bright eyes, chubby legs and generally fine appearance of the babies and pre-schoolers.

ONLY a few people, and those few but infrequently, know ecstasy. It is a big word; it means a state of being outside one's self and outside time, caught up in an overwhelming emotion, it implies a high occasion and a greatness of response to it.

A loss in land area of approximately 6,400 acres is suffered annually by the United States as a result of erosion and the action of other shore processes, Martin A. Mason of the War Department's Beach Erosion Board declared yesterday at the closing session of the sixty-first annual meeting of the Geological Society of America in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

COUNT FOLKE BERNADOTTE finished these auto-biographical notes only a few weeks before his tragic death. He penned the final lines while flying over the Mediterranean from Rhodes to Rome, on a mission connected with his role as United Nations Mediator in Palestine.

CAPTAIN DIGGORY of the Fair Adventure, Walter Blake, owner's son, and Prosper Grange, dispossessed gentleman, come together in a maze of plot when they take a mysterious ring from a sinister stranger. Shipwrecked, they make their way to the north of England, where Prosper's daughter enters the tale.

GROTON, Mass., Nov. 13 -- A favored St. Mark's football team just barely earned a 13-all tie with Groton, traditional rival of long standing, in their annual classic today. The host school, which bowed last year, was ahead 13-6 in the last half when Barnard of St. Mark's, a fleet back all afternoon, scored a touchdown, then swept the end for the extra point, which tied the game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Mrs. John S. Power, widowed mother of three small children, said today she was "flabbergasted" that "in the midst of all the world's troubles the President should bother with mine."

THE historical novels by Zofia Kossak previously published in English -- "Blessed Are the Meek," "The Leper King," and "Angels in the Dust" -- were crowded, violent, episodic chronicles of the Crusades. They took place chiefly in the Near East between the eleventh and thirteenth centuries, and were concerned only incidentally with Mme. Kossak's native Poland.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 13 -- Cooler weather dipped into the Deep South this week and Southerners found something to talk about other than politics.
PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Secretary of State Marshall today reiterated that he would not decide whether to resign from the Cabinet until he had discussed the question with President Truman.

THIS story-biography of Thomas Jefferson's eldest daughter has warmth and liveliness as well as authenticity and dignity. Martha Jefferson's childhood at Monticello, her years in France with her father and her romance with young Tom Randolph, provide the framework for a colorful story.

JOHN BAKELESS' "Daniel Boone" is a full, authoritative adult biography. This volume is an extremely skillfully edited (not rewritten) version of that work with the documentation and duller details omitted and all of the sparkle and liveliness retained.

NEITHER of these little volumes should be tossed aside as the blood and thunder fiction which their titles would indicate. The first, especially, fills a long empty niche on the shelf of frontier history.

Approaching a break-even point on ratio of sales to costs, the cotton textile industry will find itself sliding into a loss position unless it can take more positive action in merchandising its output, it was pointed out last week.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Nov. 13 -- Tip your hat to Notre Dame and pat the Fighting Irish on the back for a glorious comeback that fashioned a thrilling 12-7 victory over Northwestern today in Notre Dame Stadium. At the same time, similar courtesies must be extended a gallant group of Wildcats who almost achieved the upset of the year.
The old practice of family succession in the banking field has gone into the discard.

PERHAPS believing that "children should be seen and not heard," the New York Historical Society will show paintings of American youngsters by American artists in an exhibition opening next Wednesday. The fifty oils cover the period from 1660 to 1860, by which time the photographer began to compete with the painter.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 13 (AP) -Johnny Rauch furthered his bid for All-America recognition and Georgia's chances for the Southeastern Conference championship today by riddling Auburn's defenses with his thread-needle passes in a 42-14 Georgia victory.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Boston College outrushed and outpassed William and Mary today but the home Eagles were forced to settle for a 14-14 tie in a bruising football game witnessed by 15,112 Braves Field fans.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- Ch. Snow Boy of Fircot, an English-bred miniature poodle belonging to the Blakeen kennels of Mrs. Sherman man R. Hoyt, Stamford, Conn., became best in show at the fifty-fourth all-breed event of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia tonight.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Archbishop Richard J. Cushing of the Catholic archdiocese of Boston will bring the greetings of the Boston Catholic Community tomorrow to the seventy-fifth anniversary convention of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which will open its four-day meeting here.

THE author of these essays, John Emerich Edward Dalberg-Acton, was born in Naples in 1834. His grandfather, a scion of one of the more adventurous families of old English nobility, was Prime Minister of the South Italian kingdom.

ALL the best features of an old-fashioned Christmas in the country adorn this thoroughly contemporary story of the Clark family, those nice New Englanders first met in "Windy Foot at the County Fair." As in that story, there is a wonderful sense of affection and shared experience in the bustle of preparations for company, the last-minute shopping, bringing in the Christmas trees, carol singing in the village.

SOME months ago in "Rocket Ship Galileo" Mr. Heinlein got his characters operating safely on the Moon, but now in "Space Cadet," in the year 2075, Matt, his hero, is attempting a sort of interplanetary West Point to become an officer in an interstellar patrol force.

THE life of a saint is an adventure in lands and among perils beyond the ken of average people; its telling requires a particular approach -- observant of normal phenomena but aware that the tale itself walks the boundary between natural and supernatural life.

After a meal there is more sugar in the blood of a diabetic than in the blood of a normal person. When diabetes is suspected, the doctor has the blood analyzed for sugar (usually on an empty stomach) to determine the blood sugar level. If the level is too high, the case is one of diabetes.

WHAT may be the best football game of the current season is scheduled for this afternoon when the San Francisco Forty-Niners drop in for a spot of T with the Cleveland Browns before some 80,000 wild-eyed fanatics on the lakefront at Cleveland. It brings together two unbeaten teams and, unfortunately, revives that ancient cliche about the irresistible force meeting the immovable object.

THE incredible Ruth St. Denis is at it again. In spite of being substantially along into her seventies, she refuses to relax into even moderate passivity. Now she has established the Ruth St. Denis Theatre Intime out in Hollywood, as the latest activity of the Ruth St. Denis Foundation, Inc., a non-profit corporation which sponsors also her Church of the Divine Dance and has recently found itself going in for movie production.

Because of increased enrollment, the city's elementary schools will need at least 1,000 new teachers each year for the next seven years, Dr. William Jansen, superintendent of schools, disclosed yesterday.

HERE are the stars and constellations our forefathers knew and named. These are the stories from many eras and from many cultures that they devised to explain the presence of the beasts, gods and heroes they saw in the night sky. The stars were their clocks and their calendars; they controlled the planting of the crops, the days of their festivals, their very fates.

THE books of this series are particularly refreshing because they show the life of foreign lands, not through American eyes but through those of their own young nationals. This does away with the elementary explanations that burden most travel books, and leaves more space for incident.

CONGRESS has been urged repeatedly to broaden and change the Federal Social Security program. During the Presidential campaign just ended leaders of both political parties added their voices to this plea. And there can be no doubting the need.

THE thirty-third National Hotel Exposition, held at the Grand Central Palace last week, offered a preview of new furnishings, materials and decorative effects designed to provide new concepts of attractive and comfortable hotel living.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Christiana Stables' 3-2 favorite, Service Pilot, won the Thomas K. Lynch Memorial Handicap by a nose from R.E. Carter's Oriols with a strong finish at the opening of a thirteen-day meeting today. Brookmeade Stable's Insertarable was third in the field on nine.

In the shipping industry longshoremen are the link between sea and land. They load and unload every piece of cargo -- freight and passenger luggage alike. They push the cargo around on the docks, hoist it up onto the decks in giant "slings" and haul it into the holds.

FRANCISCO PIZARRO, cousin to Cortes, companion of Balboa and de Soto, began life humbly, tending pigs on a Spanish farm. In this colorful little book for 8-to-12-year-olds, Mr. Duvoisin gives us a glimpse of Pizarro's boyhood and of the restless ambition that led him to the New World.

The Yankees, who have been doing considerable shifting in their vast baseball Organization since the close of the season, revealed another shake-up yesterday when Bill Skiff, who managed the Newark Bears last summer, was named to pilot the Kansas City Blues farm club in 1949.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Harvard found the Achilles' heel of Brown's vaunted pass defense today and pierced it for a 30-19 victory. It was Brown's first defeat in seven games.

George Helfenstein, Fort Hamilton harrier, took the individual title and Andrew Jackson captured team honors yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League city-wide cross-country championships over the two-and-one-quarter-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park.
WALTER KERR'S eloquent defense of the drama critics is a welcome relief from the many articles one reads attacking "The Nine Cold Men." One remark of his does puzzle me, though.

Retail activity here last week was stimulated by Armistice Day sales, which almost reached Christmas rush proportions, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Company.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange moved along at a slow pace yesterday with prices closing irregularly higher. Volume for the abbreviated session aggregated 380,000 shares, compared with 880,000 shares on the preceding Saturday. It was also the narrowest market in two weeks with only 770 individual issues changing hands.

OF Eugene Delacroix, the first of the French Impressionists and the masthead of the Romantics, Charles Baudelaire wrote: "The tiger, intent on his prey, has less light in his eyes than was seen in Delacroix when all his powers willed to seize a dream."

THE little girls who enjoyed "Tagalong Tooloo" will adore Sally Tait and the story of the very exciting ninth year of her life. There was school, with new school books and geography lessons with her father along the wharves in Texas, new friends, and Mr. Scratch, the cat with personality all his own.

PROPER Bostonians and those who just live there are beginning to develop a sleepwalk sort of boredom toward the appearance of another book about their city. Especially when it is a bit of cherrystone carving worthy of the artisans who used to engrave the Lord's Prayer on the head of a common pin.
GENEVA, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Hobart College closed its football season today by crushing Sampson College, 24 to 0. The victory was the Statesmen's third against five defeats.

In critical industrial areas, steel shortages are being eased by the installation of electrical conversion equipment to enable steel foundries to cast ingots suitable for rolling scarce sheet and strip, T. Starling Winters, consulting electrical engineer of Englewood, N.J., disclosed here yesterday.

ALTA, UTAH -- Early snowfalls have covered the local skiing slopes with thirty inches of powder, and both the Rustler lift here and the Mt. Millicent lift at Brighton are in operation. Winter sports enthusiasts describe the skiing as good.

Edward Adams, veteran Pennsylvania Railroad locomotive engineer, recorded yesterday his "Voice of America" broadcast to be heard in Germany this week in the bitter radio battle to win the German workers for Western democracy.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Winston Churchill has criticized Prime Minister Attlee's intention to have an all-Socialist delegation representing Britain in the five-power talks on European unity. This was revealed in correspondence published today between the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition.
GREAT BRITAIN last week abolished visa requirements for American travelers, bringing to nine the number of European countries that have recently waived visas for short-term visitors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -A band of opportunists, North Carolina's Tarheels climbed back into a prominent post-season bowl position today by setting down Maryland, 49--20, before 34,588 fans in Griffith Stadium.

There come days in November when both time and the river seem to stand still. The urgency of spring and the bustle of summer have vanished from the shore under the towering rocks of the Palisades and the river lies a gray and listless mass.

The performance of the Ice Follies on the night of Nov. 23 at the Madison Square Garden has been taken over to raise funds for the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys in Millington, N.J., and an encouraging subscription has been reported.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

NEWS dispatches from India since the war has shocked the world with their accounts of the tragic labor pains Mother India has experienced in giving birth to her latest national reincarnation. These journalistic observations have provided a potent source of background for novelists as Alan Moorehead demonstrates in "The Rage of the Vulture."

TOWARD the end of October, 1947, the late Joshua Loth Liebman, author of that extraordinary little volume, "Peace of Mind," which continues to make literary and publishing history, gathered together at the Temple Israel in Boston certain religious and psychiatrical authorities of New England for a two-day conference on the subject of Religion and Psychiatry.

READERS from 12 up will find interest in this story of modern China. It tells of a group of students who traveled, by whatever means available, from Japanese-occupied sections of their country to free territory. South of Chungking they established schools and dormitories, making with their own hands whatever they couldn't bring or borrow or buy.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Charles de Gaulle's electoral success last Sunday was indecisive and cannot directly force events in France. But it is, in the view of most observers, one more step in a process that may lead in a short time to a showdown on the problem of M. de Gaulle in a general election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The rapid deterioration of the military and economic position of the National Government in China has confronted the United States with a problem of grave moment.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Tulane's Green Wave stayed in the Bowl picture and just about knocked Baylor out of it today by thoroughly trouncing the Bears, 35 to 13.

FOR the past three years Stuart Chase has been running a chart-and-compass line across the whole front of the sciences devoted to human relations. He has been looking for better ways of dealing with human affairs and reports that he has found them.

"Work or fight" national legislation should be adopted in the event of another war without delay, to compel all Americans to share the burden, former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson told 600 veterans of the Forty-fifth Infantry Division last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Two great imponderables -- the minimum requirements of foreign aid, economic and military, and national defense -- hold the answer to whether President Truman will be able to present a balanced budget to Congress next January. The 1950 budget, covering the fiscal year to begin next July 1, is now in the final stages of preparation.

The practices of employers who balk at hiring qualified disabled persons was assailed, yesterday at the fall conference of the Business Education Association of the State of New York at the Roosevelt Hotel.

NEW hotels, motels and guest houses being rushed to completion for the opening of the season will offer visitors to both Florida's East and West Coast a wide choice of accommodating and will substantially relief the space shortage of the past few seasons.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 13 -- Mid-November found the Upper South this week relatively fat and prosperous, critical of its Government, but no more so than usual.

FOR thirty-eight years my wife and I have made annual pilgrimages to Broadway, traveling 1,100 miles exclusively for the purpose of play-going. Since the great reduction in the theatre roster, we have remained each time long enough to include every dramatic offering in Manhattan.

Many parties will be given at the luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Judson Health Center on Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The benefit has been arranged by members of the Center's Women's Committee, of which Mrs. John Williams Morgan is president. Mrs. Morgan is executive chairman of the benefit committee, and Mrs. J.G. Phelps Stokes heads the patroness committee.
BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- The French Government has a stronger hold over the German industry in its zone than it has ever had since the occupation, German financiers and industrialists asserted today.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 13 (UP) -- Jimmy Joe Robinson, fleet-footed halfback, broke through for a 100-yard touchdown sprint today and added another tally later to give Pittsburgh a 20-to-13 victory over Purdue.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 13 -- President Truman laid business aside today and took his own and his official family on a sightseeing cruise to historic Fort Jefferson in the Dry Tortugas Islands.

American systems of management and industrial "know-how" for the first time since the war are now scheduled for worldwide use. These activities have started to point toward long-term industrial prosperity based on systematic upgrading of industrial production standards throughout Europe and South America, Mrs. Wallace Clark, head of Wallace Clark Co., management consultant service, 521 Fifth Avenue, disclosed in an interview at the company offices yesterday.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 13 -- Leo Wagner was the whole show as City College completed its most successful season since 1941 by trouncing Hofstra, 47 to 6, today.

ON a camping trip in the Rockies Joe and Harry Phelps are trapped by a winter blizzard. Old Bill, an experienced woodsman, tells them they are locked in until spring. Here begins a fast-changing series of adventures as the trio battles the hazards of nature.

WEATHER rhymes and saws are a lot of fun, but when a child asks why it rains or what is frost he expects a serious answer. In the same simple terms in which he previously explained atoms and astronomy Mr. Meyer shows how the seeming vagaries of the weather are produced by scientific laws.

Heavy industrial equipment business is continuing to hold steadily on a high level, although some spotty conditions are appearing in a few lines due to seasonal declines. But for Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation gross dollar shipments for 1948 will be above last year, Clarence E. Searle, president, disclosed in an interview at his office at 2 Park Avenue last week.

LAU SHAW will be well remembered by many American readers as the author of "Rickshaw Boy," a successful novel of modern China that managed to make the plight of the Chinese slum-dweller both real and vivid to Western readers.

New experiments in the social behavior of rats, preliminary to applying the findings to an increased knowledge of the behavior patterns and population growths of humans and other animals, were reported on yesterday in the final session of a two-day conference on the methodology and techniques for the study of animal "societies."

HARRISON FORMAN has attempted here a difficult feat of compilation -- to present most of the facts about China, excluding politics, within a single not too large volume. Considering the magnitude of the job, he has succeeded remarkably well.

THERE is a mushrooming of "pictures" on art. Already stimulated by the prospect of television distribution, the production of art films received further impetus from the enthusiasm which greeted the short film on Matisse at the new Paris Theatre.

THE Long Island Horticultural Society will hold its annual meeting and dinner at the clubhouse in Bethpage State Park, Farmingdale, on Tuesday. A talk, two motion pictures, an exhibit and a business meeting are included in the program.

NOT much in the way of novelty graces the week's list of events. In fact, nothing that falls strictly under that designation until next Sunday. Then an up-and-coming set of young choreographers will introduce some new works up at the Ninety-second Street "Y", and that evening the Ziegfeld Theatre will house the first recital by Jose Torres.

A DANGEROUS truth is loose among minor novelists: that they are all moral philosophers. Once they were scientists; now, if they are at all serious about their craft, they write parables. The old Zola still lingers in most of them, but John Bunyan has entered into their hearts.

Arturo Toscanini went before the television cameras for the third time yesterday when his regular Saturday concert With the NBC Symphony was both telecast and broadcast from studio 8-H in Radio City. The program was the fourth of eight he is devoting to the works of Brahms.

HORSE thieves stole the pony from the ranch one night, and the dog who looked after the pony followed the truck. When the thieves discovered that the pony was blind, they turned dog and pony loose in the fenced-in badlands. The dog could have got home easily, going under or over all the closed gates, but he stuck to the pony.
ATHENS, Nov. 13 -- King Paul called upon Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris today to form a new Government following the resignation yesterday of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis.

THIS is a series of autobiographical sketches in the English manner of reminiscence -- intense affection for geography and people and the small, dear things of living; gentle shyness mixed with sudden shafts of frank and casual confession; wonder and delight in the simple, small-town tangents to routine existence; well-mannered restraint when such ill-bred things as native fascism or a foreign country's bureaucracy cast snares at mental comfort.

The appointment of Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, former acting president of Columbia University, as president of Associated Universities, Inc., which operates Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, L.I., will be confirmed on Friday at a meeting of the Associated Univirsities executive committee, officials of the laboratory said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Truman today proclaimed Thursday, Nov. 25, as Thanksgiving Day. He called upon Americans to give thanks for the bounties bestowed upon the nation and to resolve "to render generous assistance to the hungry and homeless in other lands."

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Rampaging Ohio State, lone obstacle between Michigan and an undefeated season, today plastered its worst defeat on favored Illinois, 34 -- 7, and kept the Buckeyes' faint Rose Bowl hopes alive.

ALTHOUGH organized only a year ago, the Philadelphia Experimental Theatre today is credited not only with giving the non-commercial stage a healthy boost in this area but also with setting the pace in a national plan to decentralize the legitimate theatre from New York.

The impact of inflation on retirement income and the failure of many pension plans to adequately recognize employe progress during tenure of employment is causing some business organizations to review bases for arriving at retirement benefits, E.C. Gardiner, vice president of the Chase National Bank, disclosed last week.

THE best way to read this book is to have a large-scale map of southern California at hand. Then you will be able to follow Tommy Dancer as he dashes hither and yon on his lawful and unlawful occasions, chiefly the latter.

COOKING is fun, especially when you have a handy guide like this one to help you build up a repertoire of dishes for any occasion. Teen-agers, both boys and girls, will really use this book. The high school quarterback will feel as much at home with it as his girl would and be as justly proud of his tasty pot of hot slumgullion.

HOLLYWOOD'S newest fair-haired boy with the halo of dollar signs is writer-director George Seaton, erstwhile gag man, stock company juvenile, Lone Ranger, playwright, and, to future historians, perhaps, the man who started all the noncommercial gemuetlichkeit at Christmas.

THE realistic and folk stories of this collection fit rather uncomfortably into the framing story of a father telling tales to his dears and his darlings. The realistic narratives are concerned with the small incidents in the lives of children in the Irish countryside.

Miss Janne Martineau, daughter of Mrs. Hubert Martineau of the Pierre, heads a junior committee aiding plans for a dance to be held on the night of Dec. 3 in the home of Mrs. Aubrey Cartwright at 820 Fifth Avenue for the benefit of the Camp des Alpes-Maritimes at Cots deCagnes, France.

MULCHING is a subject which occupies the minds of gardeners as the cold weather approaches. A protective covering is especially recommended for perennials, roses and shrubs which have been set out this fall.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 13-Lehigh plodded its way to two first-half touchdowns and exploded in the final half-minute of play for another to win as it pleased against Carnegie Tech, 20 to 0, today on pre-game rain-soaked Taylor Stadium.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Andover Academy completed its second undefeated season since 1931 by beating its traditional rival, Exeter, 28 -- 7, before a crowd of 4,500 at Brother's Field today. It was the seventh successive victory for the Blue and White, which scored at least two touchdowns in every game.

WITH the announcement yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association that the one hundred millionth motor vehicle had been manufactured in the United States, emphasis was given to the manufacturing contributions by New York State which made possible this achievement.

We listened yesterday afternoon, at the Boston Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall, to one great work and three magnificent performances. For the Fifth symphony of Prokofieff looms the larger in the literature of contemporaneous music as one becomes familiar with it, and the reading of yesterday further clarified its significance.

Last spring, a young man who had not yet reached his thirtieth birthday, lay in bed in one of New York's large hospitals for chronic disease. He had been there for six years, disabled by the Marie Strumpl type of arthritis, one of its most crippling forms. His feet, knees, lower back and hips were fixed and rigid, but, fortunately, his arms, shoulders and hands were unaffected.

THIS is the first biography in English of the famous Russian chemist, Dmitri Ivanovitch Mendeleyev, who is remembered today for his work on the periodic table of the elements. The periodic law relating chemical properties according to atomic weight was formulated by Newlands, Lothar Meyer and finally by Mendeleyev.

THIS is the thirty-fifth volume in a distinguished series and especially noteworthy because it is the first of the collection to concern itself with a river outside the continental United States. The move beyond our boundaries does not mean that our own rivers have been covered.

LIMA, Nov. 13 -- The 2 1/2-year-old "Sechura" contract, which would give Standard Oil interests the right to explore and develop an additional 5,000,000 acres of Peruvian coastal desert, is regarded both by oilmen and independent experts as indefinitely stalled as a result of the recent governmental overthrow.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 13 -Storming from behind, the United States Merohant Marine Academy registered twice in the final period to defeat Adelphi College, 27--19, and thereby clinch Nassau County's "Little Three" football crown today.

THE Puff-Tails are a congenial family. There's father, stern and sometimes short-tempered; mother who is patient and protective, and the five bunny rabbits who have a lot to learn. One of them upon seeing the snow for the first time exclaims, "The clouds have fallen down all around us."

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt and Trygve Lie appealed directly to the heads of the United States, British, French and Soviet Governments today to undertake "immediate conversations" to settle the Berlin dispute. Failure to reach an agreement, they said in a letter, would be "a danger to the peace and security of all nations" and would undermine the work of the United Nations.
A TREE trunk can be used as a picturesque support for climbing plants. There is still time to work out such a scheme this fall.

HALF a century of the American labor movement is wrapped up in this memoir package -- left side, right side, seasoned with the personality of an intense and gaily adventurous woman. Born of two well-to-do Jewish families in the Russian Ukraine, Lucy Lang remembers the Czarist anti-Semitic persecutions of the late Eighteen Eighties which drove her parents to America.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Trough Hill, 6-year-old bay gelding from the stable of Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr. of Middleburg, easily won the Mary Mellon Steeplechase, a two-and-a-half-mile brush race that featured the fall meet of the Middleburg Hunt Race Association today at the Glenwood Race course.

At the week's end the majority of larger retail stores here were beginning Christmas promotions. Windows trimmed with holly and other traditional backgrounds appeared here and there on side streets, some stores had Christmas catalogues in the mail, and Christmas advertising was placed for its first substantial appearance in newspapers today.

WE have skipped chapters not easy to skip of Louis Biancolli's "Book of Great Conversations," now published by Simon and Schuster, in order to get to the account of the talk that Wagner and Rossini had together in Paris in 1860.

PROFESSOR BUTLER of Cambridge is quite too clear-headed a scholar and writer not to be a good judge of her own book, and she describes it as "vulnerable." An essay on the meaning of magic might have been instructive as well as fascinating, but in this case even the fascination is frustrated somewhat by futilities.
"WHAT are you doing, Dr. Weizmann?" asked Lord Peel.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 13 (AP) -- After penalties and fumbles kept it scoreless for the first twenty-five minutes, Oklahoma bowled over Nebraska, 41 -- 14, in a Big Seven Conference football game today.

MATILDA, the one girl among the four children of the Fosters of Indianapolis, was a happy giver. Her heart sometimes ran away with her head so that she gave what was not hers, including baby brother Waldo, whom a neighbor incautiously admired.

"OH, you wanted the old grandfather tales, * * * them old impossibilities," said his host when Richard Chase was searching for stories in the Southern mountains. As in his earlier collection, "The Jack Tales," many of these had their origin across the sea, but handed down for generations, have taken on a robust American flavor.

VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Passenger service on the West Shore Railroad is being maintained by bus shuttle service as the result of a seventeen-car derailment from a ninety-one-car fast freight at 6 A.M. today 300 yards north of the Valley Cottage station.

SEVENTEEN centuries ago Dura Europos was a thriving garrison town in Syria, where people of various nationalities mingled, and where worshippers of the Persian god Mithra rubbed elbows with worshippers of Zeus, Jehovah and Christ.

AS recently as the Thirties, Harvard's Professor Harris reminds us, the appointment of an economic adviser to the State Department was a newsworthy event. Today the department swarms with economists, for economic issues have become of paramount importance in the foreign relations of the United States.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 13 (AP) -- After penalties and fumbles kept it scoreless for the first twenty-five minutes, Oklahoma bowled over Nebraska, 41 -- 14, in a Big Seven Conference football game today.

MATILDA, the one girl among the four children of the Fosters of Indianapolis, was a happy giver. Her heart sometimes ran away with her head so that she gave what was not hers, including baby brother Waldo, whom a neighbor incautiously admired.

"OH, you wanted the old grandfather tales, * * * them old impossibilities," said his host when Richard Chase was searching for stories in the Southern mountains. As in his earlier collection, "The Jack Tales," many of these had their origin across the sea, but handed down for generations, have taken on a robust American flavor.

A WORLD-WIDE stamp collection which was assembled by Harold L. Ickes, who was Franklin D. Roosevelt's Secretary of the Interior and for a time held the same post under President Truman, will be publicly sold this week and next week by Edson J. Fifield, dealer, at 500 Fifth Avenue.

LIVING in Chicago in 1860 meant high adventure for 13-year-old David Morgan. There were the novelties of the raw, young city and a Presidential campaign; but especially thrilling was hearing about a mysterious underground railway that flourished in the tense atmosphere arising from the bitter sectional differences.

The commandant's house at the Key West Naval Submarine Base is a rambling, white, West Indian style cottage with five bedrooms, living room, dining room and kitchen, and a large enclosed porch. Last week this cottage was the temporary White House.

THE story of the Holy Wolf of Gubbio is one that should please equally young readers and old. For young readers it is an easily understood account of a dangerous beast made gentle by the power of St. Francis, that lover of animals; of how the wolf came to live in the town of Gubbio and used the seven miracles granted him by the saint, and what was the outcome of it all.
Two explosive scoring drives by Columbia snapped the four-game losing streak of the Lions and sank gallant Navy for the thirteenth successive time yesterday.

DES MOINES, Nov. 13 -- There's a new worry in the farm belt since the election. Although Iowa farmers along with thousands of others helped the Democrats to victory, they are paying close attention to Washington reports of possible rationing and price control legislation.

MANCHURIA has fallen to the Chinese Communists. All of North China must almost inevitably follow. That the Chiang Kai-shek government can long stand as the national government of China is almost inconceivable. More is involved, however, than victory and defeat in a Far Eastern civil war.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- Derby County was beaten for the first time this season in the English Football League today, losing to Newcastle United, 3 -- 0. Derby held the first division lead by a two-point margin as United tied for second place with Portsmouth which played a 1 -- 1 draw with Blackpool.

Society and musical circles are collaborating in final plans for one of the new season's first large benefit fetes, the Bal des Symphonies, which will be given Tuesday night at the Plaza. A full evening's entertainment has been arranged by the committees in charge.

BETWEEN the cumbersome machinery of the United Nations and the peoples of Palestine whose troubles it is trying to solve, the one connecting link is Ralph Johnson Bunche, who became Acting U.N. Mediator for Palestine with the murder of Count Folke Bernadotte.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Rioting in several Paris suburbs, with shooting by the police, accompanied the general strike in which Communist-led workers only partly succeeded today in halting Saturday activities around the capital.
AS the season for flowers draws to a close, the gardener becomes more conscious than ever of trees on the landscape. If signs of ailments are evident, he begins to search for their causes and cures.

THIS novel, from an author already published as a poet, has an essentially simple story to tell of time and man. The descendants of Gamaliel Potter, a Vermont dairy farmer, are the principal characters, the countryside is the setting.

LIKE a good many people connected with the theatre, Crosby Gaige would be regarded by a sedentary world as being just a little fantastic. For all of that, even a good many people connected with the theatre regard him as being just a little fantastic.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 13 -- California's Bears, generating the same tremendous power that has kept them unbeaten and untied, scored a crushing 44-14 victory over the Washington State Cougars today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- Agreement that the hiring hall, with its registration and dispatching features, would be preserved in a new coastwise waterfront contract was reached today by negotiating committees of waterfront employers and striking longshoremen of the West Coast.

JUST as Betty Smith has staked out the borough of Brooklyn as her particular province, Arthemise Goertz has concentrated on the neighboring borough of Queens. From the Sunnyside of her first novel, "Give Us Our Dream," which was well received last year, Miss Goertz moves on to Astoria in "The Moon Is Mine."

BETWEEN the cumbersome machinery of the United Nations and the peoples of Palestine whose troubles it is trying to solve, the one connecting link is Ralph Johnson Bunche, who became Acting U.N. Mediator for Palestine with the murder of Count Folke Bernadotte.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Rioting in several Paris suburbs, with shooting by the police, accompanied the general strike in which Communist-led workers only partly succeeded today in halting Saturday activities around the capital.

The dock strike which began last Wednesday and has been gathering momentum since that date has tied up more than 200 ships in Eastern seaboard ports and may take as many as 45,000 men off their jobs. So far its chief effect has been to halt overseas shipments, including ECA cargoes to Marshall Plan countries.

The Sabbath brought no truce yesterday in the "hot war" between Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and his left-wing opponents in control of the union's international executive board.

Chester Barris, an American pianist of considerable musical understanding, gave a recital last night at Times Hall. It was his first appearance in this city since his debut ten years ago, and he selected a straightforward program of established classics for his return.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 14 -Universal-International has announced an out-of-court settlement of its $87,083 suit against Deanna Durbin for money advanced to her and a revision of her contract, reducing the number of pictures she will make for the studio from five to three.

The Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Sr., pastor emeritus of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, declared yesterday that "the Negro church, because it has provided a doctrine of meekness, has saved the race from annihilation in the United States."

A contract for altering the former Feigenspan brewery in Newark, N.J., has been awarded by P. Ballantine Sons, who recently acquired the property, to the Turner Construction Company. The changes will cost about $500,000 and will be from plans by Fred Immen, architect.

No one can be a good Catholic unless he is a militant Catholic willing to share his faith with others, the Most Rev. Thomas J. McDonnell, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, declared yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins, limited to only 16 shots, defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 2, to tighten up the National Hockey League race tonight before 13,900 fans at the Boston Garden.

In these times when autonomy is so carefully guarded by many organizations, the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society and the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service are to be commended for their decision to merge, as announced in today's news columns. By coordinating services to families and children under one roof, in line with a current trend, they will be able to avoid duplication and overlapping.

The possibility of food price controls being put into effect in the near future was regarded as "very unlikely" by industry leaders here last week. Of much more concern to them, however, was the question of whether or not farm price supports will be eased under the terms of the Hope-Aiken Law in 1950.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- In one of his rare press conferences, Secretary of State Marshall remarked that Soviet propaganda had not been successful in this year's General Assembly. That is an understatement of a widely noted fact.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- While awaiting the royal birth Prince Philip, wearing old flannel trousers, an open-necked shirt and sweater, paced up and down a long palace corridor outside the delivery room.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears and Green Bay Packers staged one of their traditional bruising battles, with the hard-pressed bears finally taking a 7-6 National Football League triumph before 48,113 fans today.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 14 -- The national board of the United Council of Church Women, meeting here on the eve of the organization's fourth biennial assembly, named Mrs. W. Murdoch MacLeod of Atlanta, Ga., executive secretary today to succeed Mrs. Ruth Mougey Worrell of Columbus, Ohio.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- Declaring that a "staggering" number of people in this country are racially and religiously prejudiced, Archbishop Richard J. Cushing of the Catholic Archdiocese of Boston said today that no true Christian should support or participate in any such activity.

On returning to New York, after several years in the hinterland, I expected to find this great city in the year 1948 cosmopolitan, sophisticated and free from provincial prejudices. My pride as a cosmopolitan New Yorker has had some rude jolts.

NANKING, Nov. 14 -- First-hand accounts portrayed Suchow today as an isolated city, with its east flank almost gone, with its airfield in peril, and with Communist elements operating within a ten-mile radius of that strategic northern Kiangsu rail junction.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- On the basis of returns for twenty-four of the thirty-four seats that were filled today in the French African colonies, Charles de Gaulle had increased his representation in the advisory Council of the Republic by eight more members.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 14 -- Delegates to the convention of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, which opened here today, will consider a proposal to bar communists from holding office in the union.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 14 -- In a brief but formal message dedicated to Pan-American amity, President Truman tonight expressed the hope that cooperation among the American republics would be intensified by practical measures.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 (AP) -Chicago Cardinals struck quickly for two touchdowns before a 33,364 crowd was seated today and went on from there to a 24-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers. Missed scoring opportunities deprived the Steelers of a chance to make it closer.

Yvonne Lefebure, French pianist, made her American debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The first half of her program was devoted to Mozart's Fantasy in D minor, the Bach-Liszt Prelude and Fugue in A minor, and Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 110.

The voluntary consolidation of two historic private social service agencies, the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society, into one nonsectarian agency, was announced yesterday.

The threatened passing of the Hudson River Day Line will leave the river a lonely body of water next summer. For those who cannot afford, or do not choose, to own an automobile the opportunity of enjoying some of our country's most magnificent scenery will be forever gone.

Six members of the Fire Department were overcome by smoke poisoning yesterday in an eighthour battle against flame and fumes in the holds of the 6,000-ton Panamanian freighter Centauro, moored at Pike Slip in the East River.

Prices for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week moved in relatively narrow range but closed the period in a firmer tone. Active futures contracts showed net gains of 25 to 36 points, following gains of 29 to 104 points the week previous.

Union of the Northern Baptist and Disciples of Christ denominations would create a body of 3,200,000 communicants and would form the fourth largest Protestant group in the United States, the Rev. Dr. Hillyer H. Straton, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Malden, Mass., said yesterday in a sermon at the Park Avenue Christian Church, 1010 Park Avenue.

The church is losing its power in fundamental education when the need for its educational services is greater than ever, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, told the congregation of the Brick Presbyterian Church at Ninety-first Street and Park Avenue yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The first big event in the new royal baby's life -- the christening -- will be private. It may take place at Sandringham, the King's favorite country home. If so, it is likely to be next month. The royal family usually spends Christmas at Sandringham.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 -- If there was any doubt early last week that the steel industry would make a new peacetime output record this year, it was dispelled by the week-end.

Reports of a recession in the men's wear retail trade appear to be greatly exaggerated and the average business volume in October equalled that of October last year, one of the record months in the trade's history, according to the monthly survey of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, issued over the week-end.

Acquisition of a new four-story building at 305 Henry Street, the gift of former Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Lehman, will more than double the welfare activities of the Henry Street Settlement, it was announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The government newspaper, Izvestia, announced today the death of Prof. A. Vishnevsky, Soviet medical expert.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The new Democratic leadership of the Senate, it was indicated today, will rule out headline-hunting by the special Senate investigating subcommittee that Republicans of the Eightieth Congress started off with a $170,000 appropriation.

The New Friends of Music are introducing their audiences to the music of Arnold Schoenberg in easy stages. The first Town Hall concert had none, the second contained the semi-popular "Verklaerte Nacht" and yesterday five songs of that composer's Op. 6, composed in 1905, were heard.
BUTLER, Pa., Nov. 14 (AP) -- The parable of the talents paid off better than twofold today for the Rev. Hudson M. Clements and his little parish.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 15 -- A son who may one day be the King of England was born to Princess Elizabeth last night in her room at Buckingham Palace. The mother and her son are doing well and all Britain is rejoicing.

It seems probable that when State Legislatures next convene there will be a vigorous effort to enact laws requiring periodic inspection of motor vehicles. Both New York and Missouri considered legislation to this effect this year. The New York bills failed of passage, but the legislation in Missouri is still pending.

A Brooklyn man, who the police say seemed to have been bent on exterminating five relatives and some neighbors against whom he also had a grudge, was captured last night after he had shot his son and a woman neighbor in Brooklyn.

Buyers' activities in the wholesale apparel market here last week centered on orders for spring ready-to-wear, holiday fill-ins and opening orders for January sales merchandise, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading residents buying offices.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today the newly elected directors of the eleven district Federal Home Loan Banks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Gifts of $164,039 for the Young Women's Christian Association World Fellowship fund were presented by a procession of fifty-one girls from the forty-eight states and three Territories at vesper services held today in Washington Cathedral.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -Santa Clara's Broncos, with a field goal and touchdown, defeated the St. Mary's Gaels, 10 -- 7, in the annual football clash between these two old rivals here today. A crowd estimated at 35,000 saw the renewal of the series, started in 1896.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Authoritative sources predicted today that neither the United Nations Security Council nor the General Assembly would succeed at this session in reaching a definite solution of the Palestine question. In particular it was said that the question of what boundaries are to be assigned to Israel, and to whatever government makes good its control over Arab areas of the Holy Land, would be left over until next year.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 14 -- The United Nations today ordered establishment of a vast No Man's Land in the Negeb desert of Southern Palestine by Nov. 19 and an Israeli Government spokesman, foreshadowing its rejection, labeled the order as a "shameful document which finds no favor with us."

A definite pick-up in sales was noted last week among distributors of finished rayon textiles. Garment manufacturers have been active in the market for dress fabrics, suitings, sportswear materials and linings, distributors said, indicating that the need to cover requirements for new lines can no longer be delayed.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 14 (AP) -Cord Meyer Jr. of New York was reelected president of the United World Federalists today as the group started a $550,000 expansion program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -The United States today invited ten nations to a conference here to establish international control over commercial fishing in the Northwest Atlantic.

Mayor O'Dwyer returned yesterday morning from his curtailed vacation in California and plunged immediately into efforts to bring about a settlement of the longshoremen's strike that has tied up the city's entire waterfront and shipping industry.
QUEBEC, Nov. 14 -- On a basis of figures for the first nine months of 1948, Canadian pulp and paper exports will exceed $650,000,000 this year, it is reported in newsprint and paper circles.
Dorothy Dix and her advice to the lovelorn will become a regular feature of the American Broadcasting Company network with Jan. 3 set as the starting date for the Monday through Friday series.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 14 -Thirty-nine sailing dinghies, the largest local fleet since before the war, were out today in the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club. There have been more only in the joint events with other clubs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Lard futures averaged lower on the Board of Trade last week, although November rallied to close 5 cents higher while the distant months were off 17 to 40 cents a 100 pounds. Trading in November lard will cease at the close next Saturday.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 14 (AP) -A proposal that the Government stop supporting farm prices and thereby allow food prices to fall when supplies are plentiful was advanced today at the convention of the National Grange.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- David Nelson, European Chief of American Overseas Airways, criticized today as "surprising and insulting" a statement made here yesternight by Whitney Straight, Chief Executive of the British Overseas Airways Corporation.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- Billed as the gridiron battle of the century, today's All-America Football Conference clash between the Cleveland Browns and the San Francisco Forty-Niners was hardly that. Actually it was, for the greater part, a dull affair, in which the champion Browns outscored the Forty-Niners, 14 -- 7.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 14 -- The Dutch Cabinet will meet tomorrow to consider one more final and far-reaching decision on Indonesia. A report will be submitted to it by the Foreign Minister, Dr. Derek U. Stikker, who returned from Java last night.

The establishment of a limited ship passenger service between New York, Florida and Gulf ports, the first since the start of World War II, was announced yesterday by the Pan Atlantic Steamship Corporation, a subsidiary of the Waterman Steamship Corporation.

Another of the eight store locals that seceded from the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, announced yesterday its intention of filing non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Law.

A Lutheran Unity Day address yesterday morning by the Rev. Thomas B. Kline warned against the possibility of Christianity's becoming "a Currier Ives religion, always hanging on the wall as a reminder of things past."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14 -Deploring the trend among college students away from the humanities in favor of the social sciences, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced in his annual report to the trustees, parts of which were released today, that Princeton would do all in its power to modify the "flight from the humanities."

PRETORIA, Union of South Africa, Nov. 14 -- Recent conferences between importers and merchants, on one hand, and officials of the Department of Commerce and Industry, on the other, results of which were made known today, point to a period of austerity for South Africa.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Grain prices moved upward on the Board of Trade last week, with December wheat and oats selling at new highs since mid-July and December corn at the highest since Aug. 17.

New York, with its great port brought to a standstill by the longshoremen's strike, became an inland city yesterday to hundreds of trans-Atlantic travelers forced to take the boat trains shuttling between here and Halifax, N.S.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- In the midst of the postwar prosperity boom, the nation's relief load has gone sharply upward.

Scoring touchdowns in the first, second and fourth periods and holding the Dodgers in check until eight seconds before the end, the Yankees won, 21 -- 7, at the Stadium yesterday and moved into a triple tie for first place in the Eastern division of the All-America Conference.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Prizes were awarded in five media this afternoon prior to the opening tomorrow of the eighteenth annual exhibition of the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild at the Westchester County Center here.

The Board of Transportation has given the Loft Candy Corporation a ten-year lease of mezzanine space at four stations of the IND division of the city subway system, with the right to set up stores for the sale of "packaged candies and related novelties attached thereto," it was made known yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts staged a 28-point second-half rally to whip the Chicago Rockets, 38 -- 24, today and stay in contention for Eastern Division honors in the All-America Football Conference.

Three last-period scores by the Los Angeles Rams topped off one of the wildest touchdown jamborees the Polo Grounds has ever seen and sent the Giants down to their third straight defeat yesterday. The final count was 52 -- 37, after the New Yorkers had come from behind twice to seize the lead.
Two new museum exhibitions and a benefit show of contemporary and nineteenth-century masters are leading attractions of another full exhibition week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -The Washington Redskins roared from behind to score four fourth-period touchdowns today -- three of them on passes from Sammy Baugh -- to roll over the Detroit Lions, 46 to 21, in a National Football League game.

ATHENS, Nov. 14 -- Constantin Tsaldaris, who was asked by King Paul yesterday to form a new government to succeed that of Themistocles Sophoulis, today called upon leaders of the various parliamentary groups for their cooperation.

ROME, Nov. 14 -- In a proclamation made public this morning the directorate of the Italian Communist party blamed the Marshall Plan and "American reactionaries" working through the present Christian Democratic Government for the ills that plague Italy.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 14 -- The Israeli Government is considering an appeal to the United Nations to relieve the plight of Jews in Arab countries at war with Israel, it was learned today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dons threw a block into the Buffalo Bills' Eastern Division title hopes in the AllAmerica Football Conference today, beating the Bills, 27 -- 20, before 23,725 persons in Civic Stadium.

Dr. Donal Sheehan has been named chairman of the Scientific Committee of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, Edwin A. Salmon, director of the center, announced over the week-end. Dr. Sheehan was formerly director of the Commonwealth Fund.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (AP) -The Philadelphia Eagles' one-two punch -- Tossin' Tommy Thompson and Weavin' Steve Van Buren -combined to lead the National League's Eastern Division pace setters to a 45-0 victory over the Boston Yanks today before 22,958 at Shibe Park.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Henry A. Wallace indicated today he would run for President in 1952 on the Progressive party ticket if that seemed "the best thing" for the party.
With a terrific pace being set from the opening gun, twelve teams started in the six-day bicycle race that opened last night before 5,000 fans at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 14 -- One year ago, a simple meal of milk and bread was placed before a Polish youngster in a Warsaw orphanage by a field worker of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

The paralyzing effect of the longshoremen's strike was experienced at first hand yesterday by 1,669 passengers from Mediterranean ports who arrived on the Italian liner Saturnia. She was the first large foreign-flag vessel to dock here since the walkout began last Wednesday.

With all the trouble fathers and farmers seem to have with the changeover from standard to daylight time, and vice versa, according to some recent letters, may I suggest a solution along lines laid down by the farmer and unconsciously adhered to by the infants' parents?
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The total of recovery grants to Western Europe and China will top $3,000,000,000 this week, the weekly report of the Economic Cooperation Administration indicated today.

In a cool November evening the crowd standing before Buckingham Palace saw a royal page walk from a palace doorway. He spoke to a constable who is always on duty at the gates. The policeman walked to the iron railing that withstood the crowd.
LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Britain's joy at the birth of a new Prince was not without a tiny overtone of sadness tonight -- the announcement came after the pubs closed.

Although the incidence of syphilis among persons arrested in vice cases has been increasing slightly since 1943, the control of venereal disease among prostitutes is one aspect of the campaign to eradicate such diseases that presents no problem to public health authorities, Dr. Theodore Rosenthal said yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer's recent reorganization of the Department of Sanitation is expected to weld the city's 8,000 rubbish collectors and truck drivers into a more streamlined, scientifically operated unit, but who is to help the individual New Yorker in the solution of his trash problems? Trash when viewed in the aggregate as just so many tons of matter to be disposed of may be approached scientifically by our sanitation engineers.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Although the weight of money influence continues to maintain the firm trend in the Stock Exchange, a quieter phase has developed in the markets recently.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -The nation's public health officials are fighting today to prevent any increase in venereal diseases as a result of the new draft.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 14 -Commuters and representatives of the Long Island Rail Road engaged here today in their first public debate on the fare increase of 25 per cent sought by the line, with the company declaring that still another might be sought later.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -Seven members of the House, six of them from the Armed Services Committee, will leave tomorrow for a study of the Berlin airlift and other military problems in the occupied zones of Europe.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings took undisputed possession of the lead in the National Hockey League tonight with a 3-to-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 16,984 fans.

The action of the National Planning Committee of the American Veterans Committee in suspending the charter of the New York Area Council of the AVC was termed "illegal" yesterday by Morris Pottish, chairman of the New York Area Council.
Three new films, including an importation from France, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

A last-period goal by Eddie Kullman squared matters for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. The Leafs enjoyed a scoring edge through most of the battle, but Kullman's shot in 6:12 of the final session enabled the home outfit to settle for a 4-4 tie with the holders of the Stanley Cup.

THOSE experts who do their experting by remote control undoubtedly will be inclined to drop Army down near the bottom of the class as a result of its narrow escape against Penn on Saturday. They will be wrong. It really took an eye-witness to appreciate the magnitude of the job the Kaydets did in whisking victory away from the aroused Quakers in the final seconds.

Tuberculosis can be wiped out in this country if the people take the necessary action to find all unreported cases and insist on adequate facilities for care of the tuberculous, Dr. James E. Perkins, managing director of the National Tuberculosis Association, declares in his 1947-48 annual report, made public over the week-end.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 (AP) -Consolidated net income of the Alleghany Corporation for the first nine months of 1948 was $3,031,232, exclusive of profits and losses on security transactions, the holding company reported today. This compared with $907,252 for the first nine months of last year.

Sidney Weinberger, formerly of the Cavendish Buying Corporation, has been appointed buyer of china and glassware of the Associated Merchandising Corporation. Lillian Bedrick has been appointed buyer of moderate millinery and Robert Murback was named buyer of inexpensive and budget millinery.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -Tighe E. Woods, the Housing Expediter, said tonight that he would ask Congress to reinstate Federal rent controls over some 1,000,000 housing units in apartment hotels.

The number of men interested in studying for the Protestant Episcopal priesthood has markedly increased in the past year, the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday in a statement issued at his ofifce in the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and ll0th Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -Federal conciliators succeeded late tonight in averting the strike of Greyhound bus drivers scheduled to begin at one minute after midnight in seven western states.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 14 (UP) -- American and British planes roared over the air bridge to Berlin tonight after fog had paralyzed operations for more than eighteen hours.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -The Hoover Commission on Government Reorganization will recommend shifting some of the President's burdens to his Cabinet, a commission member said today.

Wage increases of $11.52 to $17.80 a week and a welfare fund amounting to 2 per cent of rentals are being sought by representatives of 30,000 unionized elevator operators and other classes of service workers in Manhattan office, loft and apartment buildings, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- French and American experts will start this week a series of negotiations that will lay down principles for deblocking and utilization of the counterpart of gift deliveries under the European Recovery Program to France for 1949.

The dispute between the landlord and a tenant of a building at 536 East 134th Street, the Bronx, which began last July when the latter accused the landlord of barring him three times from his apartment, was revived yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court.

A special two-year technical training program designed to develop future leadership from among its employes has been started by the Bethlehem Steel Company's New York district shipyards, Arthur Hiltebrant, general manager of the district, announced yesterday.

Two and a half billion dollars of capital investment will be required in Israel to place 1,000,000 immigrants on a self-sustaining basis within the next ten years, it was reported yesterday at the first national economic affairs conference of the Zionist Organization of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

On Monday, Nov. 1, the day before the Presidential election, share prices on the New York Stock Exchange, as measured by the combined industrial and rail averages of THE NEW YORK TIMES, reached a high, in round figures, of 123.3 and closed the day at 122.8.

The officers who served the United States Golf Association this year have been nominated for re-election in 1949, according to the report of the nominating committee, of which George W. Blossom Jr. of Chicago is chairman. Heading the slate is Fielding Wallace of Augusta, Ga., as president.
Representative Jacob K. Javits urged last night the extension of federal aid to education so that young men and women could receive scholarships for technical and professional training.

Eschewing art for the moment, the headmen of "As the Girls Go" have come up with a bountiful and uproarious musical show, which opened in the hospitable Winter Garden on Saturday evening. Almost anything with Bobby Clark bouncing through it is likely to seem mighty enjoyable and Bobby gives the cap and bells a merry shaking in this carnival.
Eight hundred miles apart, two scourges of college football were fighting for their lives.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 14 -- Gen. Manuel A. Odria, who has been provisional President of Peru for sixteen days, declared in an interview this morning that general elections would be held in about "a year," by which time he hoped that a "new democratic basis" would have been established in the republic.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 15 -- The crowds that had waited outside Buckingham Palace for many patient hours to hear the news of the birth of the royal heir had their reward and their thrill last night as a page came out to tell them the tidings. Buckingham Palace by then was exploding the good news in all directions.

MARK GAYN has lived much of his life in the Far East. For many years he has written about it with more than the usual reportorial authority. From December, 1945, until December, 1946, he served as the Tokyo correspondent of The Chicago Sun and during that time wrote his wife a series of nearly daily letters in journal form which he kept up after she joined him in Japan.
News of the birth of a baby son to Princess Elizabeth, received here at 5:15 P.M. yesterday, evoked expressions of delight from individual Britons and members of Commonwealth organizations alike.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 14 (AP) -A P-51 fighter plane with a dead pilot in the cockpit roared out of control on a Stout Field runway today until a state policeman blasted its tires with a riot gun.

Bishop Clarence H. Shawe of the British province of the Moravian Episcopal Church, London, in a sermon here yesterday morning held up the "unity" of the Moravian Church as an example for international organizations.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 14 -- Despite the disappearance of inflationary dangers, Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck told the Lower Chamber last week that he was not prepared to accelerate the thawing of accounts frozen under the monetary purge.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 14 -- Profound changes in the Swiss capital money market were plainly shown when the 300,000,000-franc 3 1/4 per cent conversion loan at par, offered by the Confederation in October and redeemable at par on Nov. 1, 1958, proved a failure.
