Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale, duo-pianists, gave their second New York recital last night at Town Hall. With the exception of the Mozart Sonata in D major, the program was given over to five works specially written for the gifted team, which were splendidly performed.

VIENNA, Nov. 14 -- Fear that the Soviet military government plans to abolish the authority of the Austrian police in the eastern, Russian-occupied zone and place in power a force of its own, recruited possibly from Communist "factory guard" units, is growing here.

James E. Webb, director of the Bureau of the Budget, has been urged by Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, to give "full consideration" to improvement of virtually all the navigation channels on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, it was made known yesterday.

An undertone of strength in sterling forwards dominated the trading in the foreign exchange market last week. Also contributing to the improvement was a steady market for the Canadian free dollar, and a good-size gain in the Swiss free franc.

The reaction to the joint communication addressed to the Big Four Powers by President Evatt of the General Assembly of the United Nations and Secretary General Lie indicates that this well-meaning effort has produced a certain amount of confusion which threatens to play into the hands of Soviet propagandists and therewith defeat its purposes.

Ralph Tropiano, 36 years old, was arraigned yesterday on a charge of having killed Alfred Loffreto, a bookmaker, last year. It was this murder, one of a series of gang killings in the Bath Beach section, that set off a drastic shake-up among Brooklyn detectives.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Most States having the higher percentage of veteran population in relation to the total population of voting age gave President Truman a majority in the recent election, an analysis shows.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 14 -- Leno Lazzari, sculptor by commission to the Duke of Windsor and other world notables, and his wife were slain in their studio home early today by precise shots fired into their stomachs.

Plans of the Park Department to place equestrian statues of two Latin-American heroes on landscaped sites at each end of the Avenue of the Americas were announced yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer. The plans have been approved by the United States State Department, which regards them as appropriate steps to stress the function of the thoroughfare as an emblem of Pan-American good-will.

Vegetable receipts were moderate last week in the wholesale fruit and vegetable market, the State Department of Agriculture and Markets announced yesterday. The market was steady on potatoes and onions and slightly weaker on cauliflower, brussels sprouts and cabbage.
BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal said today that he had informed President Truman that he would be unable to remain in his present post throughout the new Administration.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Ch. Try Cob's Success, the New York City black cocker spaniel that was thwarted in his effort to repeat best in show at Philadelphia's fixture last night, came through in the smaller seventeenth annual Camden County Kennel Club all-breed event today.

Controller Lazarus Joseph expressed yesterday his general approval of the 1949 capital budget of $308,857,199 recently adopted by the City Planning Commission, but reminded members of the Board of Estimate that they were not precluded from disapproving any of its items when they come up for authorization.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 14 -The birth of the State of Israel "will help sustain, indeed regenerate Jewish religious and educational work in all countries," Dr. Salo W. Baron, Professor of Jewish History, Literature and Institutions at Columbia University, declared here today.

The premiere of "Anne of the Thousand Days," co-starring Rex Harrison and Joyce Redman, has been delayed a week. Instead of arriving Dec. 3 at the Shubert, the Maxwell Anderson play is now scheduled to make its debut Dec. 10.

NANKING, Nov. 14 -- The Communist radio declared tonight that peace with the present leaders of the Kuomintang in Nanking [Chinese Government party] was "contrary to the purpose of the Chinese Communists." This statement came as an abrupt answer to at least two members of the Kuomintang who are known to have advocated a resumption of peace negotiations with the Reds.

PEIPING, China, Nov. 14 -- Government forces are evacuating Paoting, Hopeh provincial capital ninety miles southwest of Peiping, according to Chinese Press reports today. Regular troops have been withdrawn, leaving only a local garrison to defend the city.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -Waterfront strike negotiators moved steadily toward a new contract today as the West Coast maritime walkout went into its seventy-fourth day.

The Amherst College football team beat Williams on Saturday by a score of 13 to 7, but it may be that another sort of victory, won on the Amherst campus on Friday, will be longer remembered. Until Friday, Amherst had a chapter of the national Phi Kappa Psi fraternity. On Friday that chapter was suspended by the national executive committee for "unfraternal conduct."

Duke Ellington brought his virtuoso band to a well-filled Carnegie Hall Saturday night for the sixth of his annual appearances there. The program listed much famous Ellingtonia of yesteryear as well as some new pieces in his latest "concert" medium.
WILMINGTON, Ohio, Nov. 14 -An unusual venture in higher education is under way at the 77-year-old Quaker college situated in this Southern Ohio community.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 14 -- European business men feel they are the forgotten men of the European Recovery Program.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 14 -- The American Federation of Labor will urge Congress to repeal the Taft-Hartley Act as soon as possible, to substitute the former Wagner Act for it and then to take up possible amendments to the old labor law.

An accurate writer, who always strove for full coverage of his assignments, Henry R. Ilsley, member of THE TIMES sports staff since February, 1922, died Saturday with more than fifty years of newspaper work behind him. "Harry," as Mr. Ilsley was known to his legion of friends and co-workers, had both an eventful and varied career.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -Navy vessels have begun the shipment of arms and munitions from the United States to the hard-pressed Chinese Government, military sources disclosed tonight.

Despite a sharp decline in sales, the Schenley Distillers Corporation's net income for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 rose to $29,524,365 from $26,844,733 reported for the preceding twelve months, according to the annual report to stockholders, issued for publication today.

Union and management representatives in the men's clothing industry announced yesterday the first fruits of the $1,000,000 "living memorial" they have set up to carry forward the principles and aspirations of the late Sidney Hillman, founder and first president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO.

OTTAWA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Weary and ailing, Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King will lay aside the cares of office tomorrow. His resignation will mark the end of an era in Canada and set a record that may never be surpassed.

MADRID, Nov. 14 -- Candidates were announced throughout Spain today for the first section of the municipal election, which will be held next Sunday. It will be the first municipal election held under the Franco regime.

OTTAWA, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press) -- An attack on Communists in Canadian unions by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, was regarded today as having strengthened the hand of international union officials bent on cleaning reds out of the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada, an AFL affiliate.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 14 -- The Mizrachi Women's Organization of America called upon President Truman today to send "clear instructions" to Secretary of State George C. Marshall to support Israel's demands for direct peace negotiations with the Arab states.

The Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, the "Red" Dean of Canterbury, declared last night his belief that peace would be achieved between Russia and the Western powers despite economic forces in the United States and Britain that he said led to "production for warlike purposes."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -The United States will ship less goods abroad this year than last despite the $7,000,000,000 a year foreign aid program. Thomas C. Blaisdell, director of the Department of Commerce Office of International Trade, said tonight 1948 exports may drop 15 per cent from the peak of $15,300,000,000 established in 1947.

Annual salaries of $3,500 or more for City College graduates "or any other college men" can come only from "graduate work or job experience," John F. X. Ryan, undergraduate placement director at the college said yesterday. Mr. Ryan has just completed a survey of salaries and positions held by 46.8 per cent of the 1,100 June, 1947, graduates from City College.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- When the majority or plurality of those American voters who went to the polls on Nov. 2 supported President Truman and a Democratic Congress they were not only returning to power a much older group of committee chairmen than theh) 0*0*0*iRepublicans who held those positions in the Eightieth Congress.
Mayor O'Dwyer served notice yesterday that he would renew his demand that the State Legislature expand the city's borrowing capacity.

Intercollegiate football offers its last full program of the season Saturday. The curtain falls for all but a few teams of the East and Middle West, though there remain for next week such perennial favorites as the Army-Navy, Penn-Cornell, Boston College-Holy Cross, FordhamN.Y.U. and Colgate-Brown games.

The gay spirit that will prevail in the new Jo Hughes shop, at 10 East Fifty-sixth Street, is indicated upon entering. At the right of the door a cut-out figure of a haloed Christmas angel hangs,h)0*0*0*iwearing a diaphanous colored chiffon nightie.

Details of the operation of the clinic system of the Bureau of Social Hygiene, which is said to have been longer in operation than any other municipal venereal disease h) 0*0*0* icontrol program in the country, were discussed here yesterday by Dr. Theodore Rosenthal, director of the Bureau.

The setting of a trial date for the twelve Communists accused of conspiring to advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government was postponed by Federal Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday until tomorrow.

Reflecting sharply lower prices in the London and Singapore markets, rubber futures declined 55 to 75 points in the No. 1 contract and 60 to 75 points in the standard contract on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Transactions were 1,280 long tons, with trade interests finding difficulty in absorbing offerings.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 15 About one-tenth of the nation's farmers now have come up through the ranks of the Future Farmers of America and the group's educational program has been a distinct leavening force in agricultural development in the United States.

Raymond M. Hilliard, city Welfare Commissioner, began yesterday an investigation of relief cases that promises to last indefinitely. His staff started a thorough reinvestigation of all 137,000 cases on the city relief rolls with the primary purpose of determining whether the relief clients were strictly eligible for public aid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The post-election campaign of liberal Republicans of the Senate to oust the "Old Guard" party leadership has all but broken down because of the inability of its participants to agree on leadership candidates of their own.

Considerable optimism with regard to sales prospects abroad despite import handicaps by foreign nations and dollar shortages was reported yesterday at the meeting of eighteen foreign managers from sixteen countries held by theh)0*0*0*iWestrex Corporation at its offices at 111 Eighth Avenue.

Dr. George Cannon, national secretary of the Physicians Forum, charged last night that efforts were being made within the Medical Society of the County of New York "to impose thought control on medical thinking, as part of organized medicine's efforts to defeat the movement for national health insurance."

I have read with some concern the editorial "Hospital Service," which appeared in the NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 7. It seems to me that many conclusionsh)0*0*0*iwere drawn without giving due consideration to the facts available.
PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Canada, France and Belgium introduced a joint resolution in the United Nations Security Council today calling for an armistice throughout Palestine.

The reports from several sections of the Catskill area at the end of the first day of the deer season indicate that conditions were about normal; in other words, most of the bucks that had been located prior to the season found some remote and secure hiding place a few minutes after the first of the hunters crashed through the brush.

BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- The airlift into blockaded Berlin, cut by fog in recent days to below the average of deliveries was impeded tonight by the crashing and burning of a United States Navy C-54 on the runway at Templehof.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- In a divergence from policies that had been in effect ever since the Westchester park system was established a quarter-century ago, the County Board of Supervisors voted today to bar non-residents from two parks on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays next year so that local residents might have greater use of the facilities.

NANKING, Nov. 15 -- A new major battle has developed on the Tientsin-Pukow railway line south of Suchow, according to both Government and Communist reports. Fighting continued to rage today along the Lung-Hai Railway east of Suchow.

There is urgent need for prompt dispersal of population and industry in the United States as a protective measure against a possible atomic attack, Gayle W. Arnold, assistant director of production of the National Security Resources Board, warned the real estate men of the nation as they gathered yesterday for their forty-first annual convention.

Five of the top executives of the United Palestine Appeal resigned yesterday, widening the split in the agency that collects millions of dollars annually from American Jews for the new State of Israel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- By refusing to examine a lower court opinion, the Supreme Court in effect today sustained the 1947 law passed by Congress repudiating claims for retroactive "portal-toportal" pay, reaching perhaps $6,000,000,000.
The blockade of East Coast shipping grew tighter yesterday as striking longshoremen moved to close "escape hatches" in Canadian and Gulf ports.

Michigan's mighty Wolverines continued to lead the nation's football teams in the weekly Associated Press poll of sports writers yesterday, bettering their first-place margin of last week considerably.

Parents should beware of new drugs offered as "wonder cures" for poliomyelitis, Dr. Hart E. Van Riper, medical director of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, warned yesterday. He spoke at the opening session of the foundation's four-day conference of of state advisers at the Pierre Hotel.

Rhode Island State's Robert Black scored a smashing repeat triumph over Horace Ashenfelter of Penn State, and Michigan State ran off with team honors in the fortieth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. varsity cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

A benefit exhibition to aid the Public Education Association opened with a preview last evening at the galleries of Paul Rosenberg. The carefully selected exhibition is made up of three paintings each by Cezanne, Renoir, Degas, Van Gogh, Matisse, Braque and Picasso, the inclusions representing early, middle and late work by each of the seven artists.

The United States Maritime Commission is sure to request extension of its authority to operate ships under general agency agreements at the forthcoming session of Congress, it was learned yesterday. The present, authority is scheduled to expire on March 1, 1949.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -Six baby elephants, their hunger appeased by choice red at hayflown to them at sea by a Navy relief mission, arrived here today on a modern Noah's Ark which brought in the largest menagerie of wild animals and birds to come from the Far East since before the war.
Fireman Jeremiah Dennis Murphy, 29 years old, received the Paddy Reilly Hero Medal and Scroll yesterday for his rescue of a mongrel dog in a Brooklyn fire last Wednesday.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- An embattled Opposition today opened what appeared to be a futile struggle against nationalization of Britain's iron and steel industry.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 -- The "audacity, stupidity and insolence" of post-war Russia has goaded the United States into an acceptance of its responsibilities in world leadership, it was asserted today by James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

If it did no more, that recent cold snap slowed the picnic season to all but a dead stop. Indian summer will be along presently, to be sure, and there will be a brief recurrence then, but to all intents and purposes the meadow year of 1948 has ended.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15 -Nugent Fallon, president, Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, said today that "all signs point toward a somewhat reduced standard of living, voluntary or compulsory," in this country.

Operating revenues of the Greyhound Corporation for the first nine months of this year were 7 per cent higher than a year ago, but higher operating expenses resulted in a decline in earnings, according to the report of Orville S. Caesar, president, released today.
BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- Unable to open a new "free market" food shop the Russians today presented Eastern sector residents with a circus instead of bread.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Nov. 15 -- A new coal technology which is now in the pilot plant stage was demonstrated near the heart of the nation's vast underground wealth of soft coal here today by Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 (AP) -Sites for possible play-offs were selected at an otherwise secret meeting of the National Football League today.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Close finishes, stock equipment on today's program, carried right into the featured Belair Purse. Brookmeade Stable's Chains withstood a long stretch drive to win by a head margin from Mrs. J. V. Stewart's Dr. Almac.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15 -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, told the American Federation of Labor today that the Taft-Hartley Act would be repealed and the Democratic platform pledges to labor would be fulfilled in thirty days after the new Congress convened.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15 - Ninety per cent of the soft drink bottlers in Pennsylvania have suffered losses in sales volume averaging 35 per cent since the enactment of the 20 per cent tax on carbonated beverages in that state in June, 1947.

Pointing out that the weakest link in the Army's preparedness program was the soldier's vulnerability to cold, Dr. Paul Siple,h) 0*0*0*idirector of the Research and Development Group, General Staff, U.S. Army, appealed yesterday to manufacturers of heavy outerwear for aid in applying research findings on cold-weather clothing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -The Federal Communications Commission today announced it would hold public hearings on the manner in which news broadcasts had been handled by three large radio stations controlled by G. A. Richards of Los Angeles.

BLOOMSBURG, Pa., Nov. 15 (UP) -- Bloomsburg State Teachers College charged today that California (Pa) Teacher is a "Penn State football farm" and therefore should be deprived of the State Teachers' College Conference championship.

0*0*0*iOLAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 15 -Delegates from twelve nations, all members of the Preparatory Committee of the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization, will meet here for their second session on Nov. 30.

A fiery private diary kept by Theodore Roosevelt for a short time in 1882 and never before seen by historians was put on exhibition yesterday at Theodore Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street. Written in a youthful scrawl with occasional orthographical lapses, the document throws a vivid light on "T.R.'s" early political appearance in Albany as a 23year-old Assemblyman from New York City's "silk stocking district."

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 15 -- Affiliation of the United Council of Church Women with the proposed all-inclusive National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America will be postponed for at least one year, a member of the women's organizaton's national board said here today.

Msgr. Nicholas H. Wegner, director of Boys Town, Neb., famed home and school for homeless and underprivileged boys, was guest of honor last night at a dinner of the Long Island Boys Town Advisory Board in the New York Athletic Club.

California manufacturers of women's and children's outerwear will have combined showings in New York at least twice a year to build up their Eastern market, according to Harold Gudnason, president of the Manufacturers and Wholesalers Association of San Francisco.

Wendell Phillips, leader of the University of California's African Expedition that has been exploring Africa for the last fourteen months, returned yesterday to this country tv rep6rt to the university the expedition's progress thus far. He will return to Africa shortly and remain with the expedition until it completes its work, which is expected to take another five months.

Plans are being completed for the Children's Party on Saturday afternoon in the Hunter College Playhouse for the benefit of the Frontier Nursing Service, which maintains a hospital, six nursing centers and a graduate school of midwifery in the Kentucky mountain regions.

The Republican party lost its Presidential campaign because it conducted a "smug, supercilious and arrogant campaign" under the domination of the "Albany group," it was charged yesterday by Clarence Budington Kelland, author, and Republican National Committeeman from Arizona.
Charles Abrams, attorney and authority on housing, will speak on "Housing in Scandinavia" at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, tonight at 8:30 o'clock.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- It seems Fullback Art Murakowski signed Northwestern's death warrant when he ran that stolen Notre Dame pass 91 yards for a touchdown at South Bend, Ind., last Saturday.

VIENNA, Nov. 15 -- Irving Ross, member of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission, who was murdered Oct. 31, had been appointed shortly, before that to a position that required him to investigate the operation of some of the hundreds of industrial establishments operated here by the Soviet as well as other Russian economic activities, it was learned today.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will produceh)0*0*0*itwenty-one new "major productions" in the "coming months," twelve of which will be photographed in Technicolor, it was announced by the company. Of the twenty pictures on the studio's schedule -- sixteen of which are completed and four of which are before the cameras -- ten have been lot in Technicolor.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 15 -- After an hour's legal wrangling the guardianship contest over Eligio del Guercio Jr., 16-year-old son of the late Frederica Fry del Guercio Hale of this place, was adjourned for two weeks in the Greenwich Probate Court.
Thomas P. Brophy quit as a newspaper reporter forty-one years ago because he did not like the long hours. He became a deputy marshal in the New York Fire Department.

Franklin Street Loft Property and West 84th St. Suites in Other City Dealsh)0*0*0*iOThe fifteen-story office structure at 17-23 John Street, known as the Tyler Building, has been purchased in an all-cash transaction by Frederick Brown from the Tyler Building Corporation, of which Sidney A. Shaskan is president.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Secretary of State Marshall's reply to the appeal by Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, President of the General Assembly, and Secretary General Trygve Lie for four-power conversations to settle the Berlin dispute will place on the Soviet Union responsibility for the present crisis, well-informed sources said this evening.

" Make Your Kitchen Modern" is the kind of manual that anyone involved in such a project will refer to constantly. Prepared by Iowa State College's home economics department and the Iowa Agricultural Experiment Station, the booklet is intended primarily for farm home owners.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 15 - Dr. James G. McDonald, head of the United States Mission to Israel, was was called to Paris today for consultations with Secretary of State Marshall on the Palestine situation. Dr. McDonald will leave during the next few days.

Representatives of seventeen of the twenty-four steamship companies that have filed exceptions to the Maritime Commission's new policy on bareboat chartering of Government-owned vessels to American-flag operators, presented oral arguments before the commission yesterday in Washington.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Expenditures of $25,600,735 by Westchester in 1949 and a record tax rate that would increase by $4 the annual tax bill on a $10,000 home were proposed today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach in a 160-page annual budget message and compilation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15 -- Foreign Minister Edvard Kardelj disclosed yesterday at the second congress of the Slovene Communist party, now meeting in Ljpbljana, that the Communist party and Yugoslav authorities were encountering strong economic resistance to the establishment of socialism in Slovenia from rich peasants and clerical groups.

LONDON, Nov. 15 - Steady progress in drafting a North Atlantic Defense Pact is being made here by a permanent commission of five Western European Union powers, authoritative sources said today. Provided that no major divergencies of opinion arise in the next few days the draft should be ready for transmission to Washington by the end of this week or the beginning of next.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 15 -- An outbreak of shenanigans caused a most un-Navy-like deterioration of order and decorum at the naval base here this evening. The press was responsible, and got away with it only with the tacit consent of the Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces.

The field in the international sixday bicycle race being held in the spacious Twenty-second Engineers Armory was cut to ten yesterday when Andrew Pousse, a member of the French team, and Brooklyn's Benny Mangano were forced to withdraw because of injuries.

WHEN the contract of Steve O'Neill was not renewed as the manager of the Detroit Tigers there was not the slightest bit of mystery as to his successor. He would be, naturally enough, Bucky Harris. The exboss of the Yankees always has been a prime favorite of young Spike Briggs, heir to the Tiger baseball empire and the Briggs automobile fortune.

The New York Academy of Sciences, 131-year-old scientific society, opened yesterday a campaign for a $1,000,000 fund to finance the erection and maintenance of a permanent Academy building and science center in New York.

The reasonableness of the milk prices in the metropolitan area is "open to question," Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare said last night at a meeting in the Russell Sage auditorium, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- A crowd in raincoats stood on the drenched pavement in front of Buckingham Palace tonight singing lullabies for Princess Elizabeth's infant son and calling for the baby's father, the Duke of Edinburgh.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Madame Carven shows a collection of ski togs overflowing with novel ideas inspired by her recent visit to Finland. Not the least of these is a "kiss-not" hood, so called by the Finns because it covers the face completely except for a round opening for the eyes and nose.

Al Hersh of the East Side knocked out Ross Anzalone, Bronx boxer, in the scheduled feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The fight ended in 2:26 of the fifth, Referee Eddie Joseph halting proceedings when Hersh's superiority was apparent.
PARIS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of a resolution on Palestine placed before the United Nations Security Council today by Canada, France and Belgium:

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 15 "Clocking" of meteoric showers speeding at 133,000 miles an hour, some fifty miles above the earth's surface, by using sky-directed radio waves as a "stopwatch" was reported to the fall meeting of the National Academy of Sciences here today.

Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., declared yesterday a year-end dividend of $3.75 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 14. The company paid $2 each in the three previous quarters, making a total of $9.75 for the year against $8 disbursed in 1947.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Robert A. (Red) Rolfe, former Yankee third base star, came back to the major leagues today as the new manager of the Tigers. He never before has managed a professional baseball team.

The stock market enjoyed yesterday its best recovery since the post-election plunge and fractions to as much as 2 points were restored after the successive retreats of the last two weeks. Generally credited for the furtherance of the mild rally of late last week were a long list of favorable earnings reports and dividend actions.

TOKYO, Nov. 15 -- Alfred W. Brooks of Kansas City, Mo., attorney for two of the convicted Japanese war lords, said todayh)0*0*0*ihe planned to appeal the Allied Tribunal's verdict to the United Nations and to the International Court of Justice.

Although the privilege that permits first offender parking violators to pay their fines by mail was scheduled to become effective yesterday, 750 personsh)0*0*0*i"jumped the gun" by sending in remittances over the week-end, Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger announced yesterday.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 15 -- The birth of the British Prince was hailed by President and Mrs. Truman today. The President sent the following message to Princess Elizabeth at Buckingham Palace:

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 15 -- The diversion of United States Army transports in the Pacific to the emergency evacuation of Americans in China has sharply pointed up the vulnerability of the American position in Korea in the event of an all-out Communist bid for control of this country.
OTTAWA, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Canada's new Prime Minister is a courtly French Canadian whose greatest immediate desire is a North Atlantic security league.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 15 -- Administration forces in the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, won their first major test of strength today against a well-organized bloc of extreme right-wing delegates.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The pilot of the future may safely escape from a disabled supersonic craft at high altitudes where an ordinary parachute would be useless. He would be enclosed in a bullet-shaped metal "capsule" with a propeller on its tip.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -Plans to turn over the vast Marshall Plan grain-purchase program to private industry ran into a White House blockade today.

Canadians today are paying honor to William Lyon Mackenzie King, who has resigned as Prime Minister of Canada after serving longer in a democratically elective post than any other man in history. Mr. Mackenzie King's only rival, so far as political longevity goes, is Sir Robert Walpole, who was Prime Minister of England from 1721 to 1742.

Tonight's events: Philadelphia orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor; William Kapell, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Helen Le aire, contralto, Times Hall, 8:30; Ruth Klingman, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Little Orchestra Society, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30.

In a letter to THE TIMES published Nov. 10, your correspondent, Elisha Friedman, out-Gallups Roper in postelection double talk. He solemnly says that the election returns demonstrate no mandate for repeal of the TaftHartley Law because Dewey carried a number of the Northeastern industrial states, whereas Truman carried many rural states.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The lack of national plans for The Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg and Greece, as well as the incompatibilities of major plans submitted, has delayed the projected four-year European program toward which the European Council under the Marshall Plan is working.

Nearly everyone who attended the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday, took aim and fired away at the controversial free-substitution rule. Coaches, press-agents and casual visitors kicked it around more than a bit.

Television advertisers were urged yesterday to place greater weight on effects of increasing receiver sales on their own product sales. The suggestion, made by a research official in an interview at the 4-A's Annual Eastern Conference, noted also that the popular conception of TV as a luxury market is decreasing in validity.
For the second time in a week Bronx residents learned that when an eel is frustrated by the intricacies of modern plumbing a lot of people can go thirsty. Twentyfive families were affected yesterday.

Miss Elizabeth T. Bentley, selfconfessed former Communist spy, who was a key witness at the recent hearings of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, has been received into the Roman Catholic faith, it was made known last night.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- A minor problem arising from the birth of the new Royal Prince -- but one profoundly important to the Heralds and Pursuivants of the College of Arms -- is the question of what armorial bearings the latest member of the royal family should have.

Mrs. Edwin J. Carey gave a tea yesterday in her home, 1115 Park Avenue, for committee members in charge of arrangements for the tea dance in behalf of St. Joseph's Day Nursery, to be held Nov. 28 at the Stork Club. Mrs. Charles R. Barrett is chairman and Mrs. James J. Waters, co-chairman, of the arrangements committee.
MADRID, Nov. 15 -- The police today painted out anti-Franco signs displayed in two prominent Madrid sites. They bore the Spanish Falange signature.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The feature in the stock market here today was the strength of British Government bonds, with the treasury 2 1/2 per cent loan leading the way with a 5/8-point rise. Other gains throughout the list ranged up to 7/16 point.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 15 -The Syracuse squad will be in its best share of the last four weeks when the Orange takes on Columbia at Baker Field. Syracuse suffered no serious injuries against Colgate and Lee Buchsbaum, fullback, and Jim Pepper, tackle, are expected to see at least limited action against the Lions.
MT. HOLLY, N.J., Nov. 15 Mark A. Sullivan Sr. of Jersey City was named custodial receiver today for two bistate bridges that have been in litigation since their recent purchase by Burlington County.
Accorded an enthusiastic reception in Los Angeles and Chicago, the Ice Follies of 1949 will present a star-studded array of skaters when it opens a 13-day run in Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Mrs. Madeleine duPont Ruoff, daughter of the late Alfred I. duPont, today sued the United States Government for the return of more than $1,000,000 in property seized last Sept. 23 on the ground that she is a German citizen.

Consolidated net income of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., for the twelve months ended Sept. 30 amounted to $13,347,856, equal to $1.09 a common share, Stuart M. Crocker, the president, reported yesterday. The net compared with $16,628,570, or $1.36 a share in the preceding twelve months.

The New York City Ballet Company last night opened its sixth pair of weekly performances at the City Center with a program consisting of repetitions of three ballets by George Balanchine. These were the Bach "Concerto Barocco," the Rieti "Triumph of Bacchus and Ariadne" and the Mozart "Symphonie Concertante."

Urban redevelopment in this country is making satisfactory progress despite statements to the contrary, according to Seward H.h) 0*0*0*iMott, director of the Urban Land Institute of Washington, D.C., writing in the current issue of Urban Land, a publication of the institute.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Guatemala's Foreign Minister, Dr. Enrique Munoz Meany charged here today that new British troop landing in British Honduras threatened his country's sovereignty and disturbed the peace of the American Continent.

Nancy Carroll, Hollywood alumna, and Molly Picon, the darling of the Yiddish stage, will share stellar billing in tonight's opening, "For Heaven's Sake, Mother!", which David Kay will unveil at the Belasco Theatre. Miss Carroll, who of recent years has spent her time in the movie capital, was last seen on the New York stage in 1939 in "I Must Love Someone."

DUBLIN, Nov. 15 -- Dublin is aglow today with flags, bunting, floral decorations and floodlights at night -- not as some English visitors innocently assumed to mark the birth of Princess Elizabeth's son, but in commemoration of the Irish rising of 1798 against the British.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 15 -- Albania opened its defense in the Corfu Channel case before the International Court of Justice here today with the charge that Britain was more interested in the political aspects of the case than its legal side.

Pleased with Fordham's performance against Holy Cross, Coach Ed Danowski limited the Rams' practice to an hour yesterday, concentrating on pass defense. The Maroon will engage Rutgers at New Brunswick on Saturday.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The French have asked the United States and Britain to supplement the London agreement of last May by agreeing that, when the Allied control of Western Germany ends, the control over the management of coal and steel industries be transferred not to the Germans but to an international authority.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -James M. Dillon, Eire's Secretary of Agriculture, offered today a plan to end wars, saying that it "could be put into effect in 48 hours." A single step can solve the problem, he said in an interview.

The two-family dwelling at 31-38 Ninety-eighth Street, Elmhurst, Queens, has been sold to Margaret Mimnaugh by Lawrence Martin, trustee of the estate of Margaret Kirk. Jungerman Chambers were the brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

A new book by Dr. William Beebe, naturalist and explorer, has been scheduled for publication in May by Duell, Sloan Pearce, entitled "High Jungle." His first book since 1942, it is an account of three explorations of the Venezuelan jungle, where he directed scientific projects for the New York Zoological Society.

The left-wingcontrolled international executive board of the Transport Workers Union voted yesterday to condemn the suspension of Austin Hogan, president, and two other officers of Local 100, by the local's executive board last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The death of competition in automobile financing was assured through a Supreme Court decision today, a three-man minority charged in a sharp criticism of a four-man majority.

Assurances that there would be no interference with the movement of food and fuel by tug and barge from New Jersey to New York were given yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer by the International Longshoremen's Association. AFL.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has made new overtures to Jack Benny after the collapse of negotiations between the comedian and the National Broadcasting Company, it was disclosed yesterday. A CBS spokesman said last night, however, that no contract had been signed as yet.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Faced with a top-heavy political agenda, theh)0*0*0*iUnited Nations General Assembly set up a special committee today to handle expected debates on the veto, the Little Assembly, membership and the creation of an international armed guard.

EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 15 (UP) -California has refused to meet Oregon in a postseason play-off for the Pacific Coast Conference championship and the Rose Bowl berth, Oregon Athletic Director Leo Harris said today.

Your editorial of Nov. 12 failed to dispel the fears which many of us, American and French, feel at the recent move returning the Ruhr industries to German ownership. This move, which has not been discussed adequately by public opinion, is one of the most far-reaching decisions taken since the war and may determine the future of Europe for decades.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper, who is investigating the Burlington County bridge purchase for Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, said today that he would go to Philadelphia to interview Theodore Hanff, who, like the family of Maj. Gen. Clifford R. Powell, owns 25 per cent of the stock of the Burlington Bridge Company.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 15 (AP) -The International Typographical Union, AFL, today filed a statement saying that it was obeying a Federal Court order against violating the Taft-Hartley Act.

The United States Maritime Commission is encouraging steamship operators to file application for operating differential subsidies on trade routes already subsidized if the need for additional services appears warranted, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- A tribunal of inquiry into allegations of bribery and corruption in the Board of Trade and other Government departments opened this morning under a lurid glare of publicity, but without having provided as yet any grave evidence.

The Little Orchestra Society, conducted by Thomas K. Scherman, continued its present series at Town Hall last night. The program included Brahms' early Serenade in D; the Riposta from Pergolese's cantata, "Contrasti Crudeli"; "Distressful Nature," from Haydn's "The Seasons," and "Sound and "Alarm," from Handel's "Judas Maccabaeus," all sung by Richard Tucker, and the first performance of Sol Kaplan's Violin Concerto in G major, the solo played by Philip Frank.

A thousand musicians, technicians and entertainers representing every phase of show business took over in Madison Square Garden last night as the United Jewish Appeal's fifteenth annual "Night of Stars" benefit show held the spotlight.

Congress must determine the pricing system to be used by industry and state clearly under what circumstances a seller is to be denied the right to compete for any business, in any market, with any competitor. Current confusion over Supreme Court basing point price decisions has resulted in unprecedented discussion and disagreement among lawyers, business men and economists as to what is legal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company of New York and Kansas City, Mo., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $30,000,000 of twenty-five year sinking fund debentures to be offered publicly.

President Truman spoke truly in the message he sent to the opening session of FAO's fourth annual conference yesterday in Washington: "The work which FAO does or leaves undone will have a great bearing on the history of the world." The Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations, to give this agency its full title, is not an emergency venture in relief work.

h)0*0*0*iOne of the important tasks confronting the next Congress will be to review the progress of the European Recovery Program and to appropriate further funds for it in keeping with the moral pledge assumed by the United States to continue it for four years. That the Program will be continued and that the necessary funds will be forthcoming, has been assured by the whole election campaign and its results.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Dissatisfaction with the showing of the Syracuse University football team this season has led to a double-barreled investigation of the situation, it was learned today.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- New York's system of releasing public school children from classroom attendance to receive religious instruction does not violate the Constitution, Justice Roscoe V. Elsworth of the State Supreme Court ruled here today.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Despite constant exhortations from the Communist party to hold out against the Government, miners continued their back-to-work movement today, according to production figures reported from the mining areas.
It seems strange that the Freedom Train is returning to New York City for a second visit and then will be broken up.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury today subpoenaed twenty-two executives of some of the country's largest corporations to testify in a giant anti-trust investigation which includes the du Pont empire.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 15 -- Progress made by the working committees assigned to handle adjustments of the divergent points of view of the Western powers on an occupation statute for Western Germany is sufficiently advanced that it is possible tomorrow's conference of the three Western Military Governors may bring a final agreement, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States commander, said tonight.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores dropped 13 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 1 per cent.

The probable forerunner of a vigorous public-versus-private power contest early in the Eightyfirst Congress was indicated yesterday when Ernest R. Acker, president of the Edison Electric Institute, reopened the industry's attack on the proposed addition of an $84,000,000 steam plant to the Tennessee Valley Authority.

TOKYO, Nov. 15 -- The Japanese Cabinet crisis that has been brewing since the Conservative Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida was installed less than a month ago came to a climax tonight with the probability that Parliament may be dissolved this month and a general election ordered.

Traffic accidents, deaths and injuries were down sharply in the city last week, as compared with the same period a year ago, the Safety Bureau at Police Headquarters reported yesterday. The figures were:

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Representatives of the four Balkan countries that were called upon by the United Nations General Assembly to meet in direct negotiations to iron out their differences held their first informal discussion here today in an atmosphere described as one of practical conciliation.

Cotton is continuing to move into the Government's 1948 loan at a heavy rate. In the week ended on Nov. 14, 315,182 bales entered the loan, bringing the total from this crop to 1,969,786 bales. If entries have continued at the pace of recent weeks, the total in the loan now is about 2,400,000 bales.

QUINCY, Mass., Nov. 15 -- The United States Navy cruiser Des Moines, rated as the world's most powerful, put out to sea today in Massachusetts Bay on a builder's final trial. The 17,000-ton vessel will be commissioned tomorrow.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Assurances were expressed in the House of Commons today that the gradual transfer of authority from the Military Governments in Germany to the hands of the Germans would be carried out in a manner that would safeguard the security of Britain and Western Europe.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Taft Wright, 35, an outfielder, today was sold by the White Sox to the Athletics. The Chicago club described the sale as the opener in other deals with the Mackmen.

BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- The Soviet army of occupation in Germany, twenty-six divisions and more than 300,000 men, is breaking up and its component parts are marching into winter quarters after six months' concentration in army corps, according to an unimpeachable United States source.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 15 - America's railroads are the "weak link" in the national defense setup, Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, said today while touring this infantry center with fifty-four industrial, labor and other leaders.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Aspinook Corporation has been called for Dec. 15 to vote on an agreement of consolidation between Aspinook and its affiliated companies, Lawrence Print Works, Inc., and Arnold Print Works, Inc.

A protest "strike" by wholesale buyers of fruit who spontaneously rebelled yesterday against paying a new unloading charge imposed by shippers at Hudson River auction piers collapsed when prices fell and brokers finally started buying.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15 Frank Capra, who directed a screen adaptation of Mark Helinger's race track story. "Broadway Bill," at Columbia in 1934, with Warner Baxter as the leading man, will do a new version of the yarn early next year at Paramount, with Bing Crosby as the star, it was learned today.

A few flips of a coin at Cleveland yesterday determined the sites and dates of whatever play-offs may be necessary in the All-America Football Conference. Joe Petritz, public relations man for the Conference, announced the developments.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- A contract to run two and a half years, to June 15, 1951, was sought by the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards today as it began negotiations with the Pacific American Shipowners Association looking to an end of the West Coast maritime strike, now seventy-five days old.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 15 -Only an injection of new inflationary pressures at this time will prevent a continued trend of downward price adjustments, it was declared here today by B. Earl Puckette, president of the Allied Stores Corporation. He spoke at the annual fall conference of the Florida State Retailers Association.

Stockmarket operators who followed the financial forecasts of 82year-old Frederick N. Goldsmith and profited by it showed little if any concern as to the origin of the information so long as they made a profit. This was disclosed yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber in a suit brought by the State to enjoin the Goldsmith Financial Service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -The cost of workers' social insurance should be part of the sales price of their procduct and not charged to Federal taxes, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, stated today in the current issue of United States News and World Report, a weekly publication.
OTTAWA, Nov. 15 -- Louis Stephen St. Laurent today took office as Prime Minister of Canada, replacing William Lyon Mackenzie King.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 15 -- Private industry's voluntary method of allocating critical materials and the attendant rise in black market activities should be the subject of a Congressional investigation, the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners was told today in the annual report of its president, Walter R. McDonald.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 15 -- Private industry's voluntary method of allocating critical materials and the attendant rise in black market activities should be the subject of a Congressional investigation, the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners was told today in the annual report of its president, Walter R. McDonald.

YIRKA, Palestine, Nov. 15 -- Ash if the new state of Israel did not have enough troubles about its frontiers, the Druses have popped up with the proposition that their 4,000 square miles in southern Syria should be joined to the new state when peace is made.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Agriculture Committee of the non profit, nonpolitical National Planning Association today issued ah)0*0*0*istatement which it termed "good news to consumers" that food prices are starting to come down.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley flew here today for a reunion with John H. Perry, an old friend and fellow Kentuckian, at the latter's Palm Beach home.

After considerable wrangling, the Board of Elections and its staff failed to reach an official final count yesterday in the Surrogate contest between George D. Frankenthaler, Republican-Liberal, and General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, Democrat.
A 51-year-old Brooklyn mail carrier faces possible dismissal from the postal service on the grounds of disloyalty, it was made known yesterday.

A public hearing was held yesterday morning at the State Building, 80 Center Street, on revision of schedules for computing hotel and restaurant employers' payroll contributions to the State Unemployment Insurance Fund.
Youngsters confronted with their idols are apt to exhibit a bit of awe, a bit of reluctance and a bit of the show-off that is in every energetic child.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP)--Despite the American-Russian cold war, the Soviet Union continues to ship to the United States raw materials which can build up this country's war machine.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Nov. 16 -- All Americans in China today were warned by United States consular officials to "get out immediately" as Chinese Communist armies in a surprise flanking movement threatened vital Suchow with isolation.

The first complete cruise to Israel and the first to Palestine since 1938 will start from New York in March, it was announced here yesterday by William Roth, chairman of the board of the Polio Institute of Palestine.
SINGAPORE, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Britain today summoned senior diplomatic and Colonial officials to a two-day conference here Thursday and Friday on Communist-plagued Southeast Asia.

Two hundred sheets of unused United States stamps bearing the autograph of Franklin D. Roosevelt and presented by the latePresident to Harold L. Ickes, then Secretary of the Interior, brought $8,800 yesterday at a sale conducted by Edson J. Fifield at 500 Fifth Avenue.
WHITE PLANES, N.Y,, Nov. 15 -- With 200 persons waiting in line to enter, the twenty-seventh Eastern States Antiques Fair opened this afternoon at the Westchester County Center here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -Most installment credit companies must register with a Federal Reserve Bank by Nov. 19, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 -- A camera by which the inside of the human body may be photographed in color will be demonstrated to the United States chapter of the International College of Surgeons, which opened its thirteenth annual assembly here today.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- The failure of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to convince the American electorate that the Republican party possessed "a human spiritual foundation" cost him the Presidential election, according to Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati, president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

The European Recovery Program is making progress, despite "relatively minor setbacks" such as the coal strike in France, and probably will not be extended beyond the four years planned, W. Averell Harriman, special United States representative in Europe for the Economic Cooperation Administration, declared yesterday at La Guardia Field.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 Three uncomplaining customers told a House investigating subcommittee today that they had paid premiums of $500 each for the privilege of buying new automobiles this year.

The Empire City Philharmonic -- also known as the Seventh Regiment Band -- played "Auld Lang Syne" and the covers went on the tote board at the Jamaica track yesterday. It was the 196th and last day of New York's longest racing campaign.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and closed fifteen points higher to four points lower, with the March position showing the most strength.

The Port of New York Authority released yesterday a letter from its chairman, Howard S. Cullman, expressing to George W. Whiteside, attorney for several airlines, the determination of the commissioners to insist not only on new rates but on a new system of computing rates at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -Representative J. Parnell Thomas pleaded innocent today to charges of conspiracy growing out of alleged padding of his office payrolls.

ONE of the most popular authors in the world today is a former Lutheran minister who still describes himself in "Who's Who" as a clergyman. Lloyd C. Douglas, who is 71 years old, is known from Nome to Zanzibar as the author of "The Robe," one of the most sensational fictional successes of this century. Since "The Robe" never appeared in a cheap reprint edition, comparisons are difficult.

The third annual Regional Plan Conference, being held today at the Hotel Roosevelt under leadership of the Regional Plan Association, will bring together more than four hundred officials and citizens of the New JerseyNew York-Connecticut metropolitan region.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 15 -With an estimated gain of at least 20 per cent in gasoline stations where intoxicating liquors are sold during the last year a countrywide drive is under way to curb this procedure, Lou E. Holland of Kansas City, Mo., said today at the opening session of the forty-sixth annual meeting of the American Automobile Association here.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad declared today a dividend of $1 a share on its preferred stock, the first dividend it has paid since 1932. President Roy B. White announced the action of the Board of Directors at the opening of the 122d annual meeting of stockholders.

The Public Service Commission finished hearing testimony yesterday on applications of two more private bus lines for a 7-cent interim fare. They are the Avenue B and East Broadway Transit Company, Inc., and the Queens-Nassau Lines, now operating under a 6-h)0*0*0*icent interim fare granted by the commission.

Home and fashion accessoriesh)0*0*0*ithat an interior decorator suggests as holiday gifts to bring the arts into everyday life are being shown until Dec. 4 at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. Many of the ceramic vases and bowls on display are closely related in simplicity of shape and earthly colorings to primitive wares.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American Red Cross and president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, today criticized as fallacies the arguments of those who advocate merging into one joint fund-raising campaign the appeals of national private health and welfare agencies.

The Giants, having outbid eight other major-league clubs, announced yesterday the signing of Oswald Kolwe, 21-year-old righthanded pitcher. Kolwe, who hails from Hammond, La., is one of the Detroit group declared free-agents recently by Commissioner A. B. Chandler.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Truman in a message to the Food and Agriculture Organization conference today, put food at the top of the list of factors counting for world peace.

Advertising agencies were urged yesterday to take long forward steps in virtually all areas of their operations. Recommendations centered on solving the agencies' and clients' cost problems, increasing individual workers' understanding of overall operations, and developing a wider scope of client services.

A hearing on the Federal Trade Commission's complaint against the Book-of-the-Month Club and two of its officers for "deceptive use of the word 'free' in their advertising"h)0*0*0*iwas held yesterday at the commission's local office at 45 Broadway.

Jo Weidin of Vienna, Austria, Jack Dempsey's heavyweight prospect, made his local debut last night at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, by hammering out a decision over Don Mogard, formerly of Toronto and now a resident of Paterson, N. J., in the main event of ten rounds.

TOKYO, Nov. 16 -- Labor officials attached to the occupation have asked one week in which in they hope to settle the present coal strike. If they fail it is almost a foregone conclusion that Gen. Douglas MacArthur will move in and crush the movement that is already cutting Japan's critical coal supply and therefore interfering with the occupation's objectives.

Encouraging results in the treatment of heart and kidney disease and of high blood pressure, the three major killers of civilized man, by means of a diet consisting entirely of rice and fruit, with a highly restricted intake of salt, were reported last night at a meeting of the New York Heart Association at the New York Academy of Medicine.

Events tonight: Frances Magnes, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Rosalyn Tureck, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Compositions by Isadore Freed, Leonard Rose, 'cello, Karen Tuttle, viola, Leonard Seeber and Mr. Freed, piano, WQXR String Quartet, Times Hall, 8:30; Jan De Man, piano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8; Annette Royak, soprano, Stanley W. Drucker, clarinet, Max Weiner, violin, Hunter College Auditorium, 8:30.
Former United States Senator Hiram Bingham and Mrs. Bingham have come to the Ritz-Carlton from Washington.
Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault said last night he had no plans for reorganizing his "Flying Tigers" to aid the Chinese Nationalists against the Communists.

Reporting on operations of the St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., David Van Alstyne Jr., chairman, informed stockholders yesterday that the consolidated gross business for the first nine months of this year reached $10,051,231.

Following a wild session of jamming that took place after the 9 o'clock sprints, the team of Henri Surbatis of Greece and Rene Cyr of Montreal surged ahead of the ten-team field as the international six-day bicycle race continued at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night.

A colorful picture of holiday fashions, with ready-made and original models, was offered by Jay Thorpe yesterday at the Ritz Carlton, Hotel. A wedding party opened the show, introducing a bridal gown of the Empire trend fashioned of the palest pink satin with a low-cut guimpe of pearl-embroidered point Venise lace.
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- A campaign to extend the life of the United Nations Little Assembly for another year began here today against the opposition of the Soviet bloc.

Phil Silvers, the comedian lately engaged in Broadwafs "High But-ton Shoes," will bring a new tele-vision revue to the air next week, which NBO win carry over its EastCoast network on Wednesdays a/c 8:30 P. 1 Appearing regularly will be a ten-piece orchestra under the direction of Harry Salter, Con-hie Sawyer, in song and comedy; Jerry Hausner, as a straight man, and 10-year-old Len Hale, actor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Representatives of two of the country's large steel producers condemned the f.o.b. mill pricing system today and urged the Eighty-first Congress to adopt remedial legislation to clarify the pricing "muddle," promote competition and prevent monopoly.
Establishment of a three-state commission to plan the development of the metropolitan area was proposed yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner.

Although buyers have become more selective and the frantic pressure for shelter has been relieved in most sections of the country, the market for well-built new homes continues to hold up well in nearly all communities, brokers representing various areas reported yesterday at the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- The Yeshiva Farm Settlement, Inc., a nonprofit organization, obtained legal permission tonight to continue operating in New Castle an Orthodox Talmudic Rabbinical Seminary for Young Men, in which seventy-five youthful refugees from Czechoslovakia are learning to become rabbis "with a taste for rural atmosphere."

An unusual and, we believe welcome, opportunity to use its spacious facilities for the study of nature has been offered by Palisades Interstate Park through its governing commission to 400 high and junior high schools within a radius of a hundred miles. The offer includes not only use of the 48,000-acre park area, but also use of free lecture texts motion-picture films and slides.
Belatedly, it becomes apparent that the Michigan State Spartans, 1948 model, are one of the nation's great offensive football units.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Storm center of a controversy between the State and Burlington County over two Delaware River bridges, Maj. Gen. Clifford R. Powell formally retired today as commander of the New Jersey National Guard.

The Congressional Country Club, Washington, D.C., was chosen yesterday as the site for the 1949 United States junior amateur golf championships. The dates are July 27-30. The contestants will qualify for the tournament proper on July 19.

In a world beset by fears of war, communism and the atomic bomb, the United States must be prepared to live up to its obligation as the chief hope and guide for peace and security among freedom-loving people everywhere, James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, declared here last night.

Venereal diseases represented 56.9 per cent of all cases of infectious diseases reported in New York City in 1947, according to figures released yesterday by the Department of Health. This was four times as many as for any other single infectious ailment.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Repudiating its own work, the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly rejected tonight an article of the rights of workers -- a part of the international Declaration on Human Rights the Committee is drafting -- which it had spent three meetings amending.

Boston sold yesterday $4,000,000 of bonds due Dec. 1, 1949 to 1978, to a banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., at an interest cost of 1.886 per cent. The bid was 101.599 for 4s, l 1/2s and 2s. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield 0.85 to 2.60 per cent.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 16 (AP) -- A record wage dividend, estimated at $13,000,000, was voted today by the Eastman Kodak Company for 51,500 employes in the Western Hemisphere.

The other day, as tardy atonement for earlier slothful sins of omission, there finally were purchased several tickets to a football game. It was thought that a day in the air would do no one lasting harm and, in addition, it was felt the time had come to introduce some of the less-world-weary members of the family to an agreeable way of spending an afternoon.

Gene Rossides and Lou Kusserow, who between them have practically rewritten Columbia's record books, will have their last opportunity to shatter another pair of Lion marks Saturday at Baker Field when Coach Lou Little's eleven encounters Syracuse in the final game of the season for the Light Blue.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 16 -- President Truman today gave his post-election blessing to the aims of the commission headed by former President Herbert Hoover to streamline the Federal Government for efficiency and economy.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Rochester Royals made accuracy at the foul line count heavily tonight as they defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 75 to 63, in a Basketball Association of America game.
ALBANY, Nov. 16 (AP) -- John A. Lyons, State Correction Commissioner, said today that contrary to predictions of some criminologists there had been no post-war increase in New York's crime rate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Nearly four hundred manufacturers and distributors of industrial supplies discussed more efficient distribution of their products here today, at one of a series of industrial distribution forums. A similar discussion was held at Rye, N.Y., late in October, and another is scheduled for Biloxi, Miss., early in January.

The New Jersey waterfowl season is now under way and the reports on the first few days have been encouraging, with an unusually large number of limit shoots reported from Barnegat Bay as well as from the marshes fringing Delaware Bay.

Fashion may change from season to season, but where cookery is concerned the opposite is true; a certain changelessness becomes pleasing. Each fall we eat with happy appetite the same foods -- such things as oysters, sweet potatoes, nuts, sausage.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Moving the last 70 yards as if they were drawing a chariot, William Ziegler Jr.'s Curtain's Up, E. A. Nicodemus' Laran and Brookmeade Stable's Lucky Devil finished in the order named and noses apart in the feature here today.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- The New York State Council of Churches is asking every affiliated church to arrange for the resettlement in the next year of at least one displaced person or family, the council announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 16 -- Dr. Julian Huxley, world renowned zoologist, declared today that the cultural barriers between the satellite states and the Soviet Union were at least as great as those that separated the Iron Curtain countries from Western Europe.

BEIRUT, Nov. 16 -- The road to Damascus is a well-traveled highway. Saul of Tarsus saw the light on this road. Once it led to the Street Called Straight. Then it was a Roman road, but for 3,000 years before the Roman Empire it was traversed by Phoenicians, Assyrians, Egyptians, Persians, all the ruling peoples of the ancient world.

Mrs. Eva Stein has sold the five-story building at 1905 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, containing ten five-room apartments, to Joseph Pollack. Nehring Brothers were the brokers and the attorneys were Burgh Heller for the seller and Bregman Bregman for the buyer.
Firefighter, the powerful flagship of the city's fleet of fireboats celebrated yesterday her tenth birthday at her berth at Pier 1 the Battery.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 16 -- A six-hour conference today among the Western Military Governors substantially advanced the formulation of an occupation statute but failed to resolve several points that must be submitted to respective governments.

Dr. Eugene Ayres has been quoted in THE TIMES as fearing that America's supply of uranium might be exhausted in 1978, if used at the present rate in manufacture of atomic bombs, and "there is little likelihood of extending our uranium reserve by large discoveries." This is an unduly pessimistic view.
M. W. Lightcap has been appointed director of sales for the Nielsen Television Corporation. His headquarters will be in New York at 11 East Thirty-first Street.

Miss Joan Schuyler Leeming and Miss Joan Herbert Lloyd, debutantes of this season, not only will be guests of honor at their formal "coming-out" parties and other festive events but also are cooperating with many other debutantes as members of committees working for various charitable enterprises.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, Washington, D.C., today forecast eventual "real relief" from high food costs as a result of this year's bumper farm crops. He predicted that this would make any demands by labor for new wage increases "less compelling."

Most private employment agencies are far behind business organization personnel departments in screening and general interviewing of job applicants, William C. Harding, personnel director, P. Lorillard Company, declared yesterday. He urged agencies to begin immediate training of interviewers in techniques now standard in many companies.

The Democratic majority of the Eighty-first Congress will have an opportunity when it organizes after Jan. 3 to set a precedent in confirmation of committee staffs that will have important consequences. If it uses discrimination in winnowing the crop of expert assistants that were appointed by Republican majorities two years ago to serve Congressional committees, it will set an excellent example.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Military Administration has closed the border control point of Herleshausen and the Thuringian town of Eisenach, a road center near the border between the Russian and the United States zones of occupation, according to Russian and United States reports.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The aviation industry, far from being overloaded with military orders, desires and needs greater export business for civilian types of planes, a spokesman said here today.
Independent theatre owners will resist the city's 2 per cent tax on the assessed valuation of equipment included in theatre leases, it became known yesterday.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Evidence of a factor in heredity not before recognized as such was presented today to the fall meeting of the National Academy of Sciences by Dr. Richard B. Goldschmidt, Professor of Zoology at the University of California.

The various and sometimes contradictory impulses that are at work to produce dispersal of population are sure to be the subject of continued analysis, but they are a fact to be accepted by New York City as a basis for future policy. Some interesting ideas as to this decentralization process were developed yesterday at the third annual Regional Plan Conference.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The tribunal of inquiry into allegations of corruption in the Board of Trade heard a confused account today of efforts to get a license to import amusement machinery. After four hours of testimony and questioning of the second witness in this sensational scandal, there was no doubt either of the confusion or the incredulity of the tribunal.

DOWNSVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- With the thunderous roar of 2,000 pounds of dynamite at 2:45 o'clock this afternoon, this tiny Delaware County community saw the holing-through of a new water tunnel that will help to bring Delaware River water 120 miles by aqueduct to New York.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 16 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York area of the Methodist Church today deplored any inclination in this country to "make a deal with dictatorship" as a defense against communism and called on American policy-makers to cease "flirting" with the Franco regime in Spain.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- The Union of American Hebrew Congregations, founded seventy-five years ago in Cincinnati by the late Dr. Isaac M. Wise, voted today at its biennial assembly to move its national headquarters from that city to New York.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Lively bidding for breeding stock pushed prices upward today at the Keeneland fall thoroughbred sales. The increased tempo was noticeable, but to a lesser degree, in prices paid for yearlings.
The March of Dimes is no longer adequate to meet the expanded needs for fighting poliomyelitis, Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, declared yesterday.

While fruit auctions at Hudson River piers returned to normal yesterday after Monday's protest "strike" by wholesale buyers who objected to paying new unloading fees, Mayor O'Dwyer announced at City Hall that the city would seek relief for the produce merchants.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 16 -- The end of a system whereby Western Germany has received dollars partly from the Army and partly from the Economic Cooperation Administration will be urged by the Washington aid organization for the future.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Union suggested today a meeting with the heads of the United States, British and French Governments to discuss a settlement of the Berlin dispute as well as peace treaties for Germany, Austria and Japan.

Two hundred and eighty feathered visitors from Japan were safely quartered yesterday at 36 Cooper Square, the first shipment since the war of roller and chopper canaries. They had been flown from Tokyo in the belly compartment of a Pan American Clipper. Special batteries were installed for light and heat.

A wave of promotions and clearances of men's clothing is expected to mark retail merchandising between now and the end of January, unless sales improve with colder weather, it was indicated in the men's clothing industry yesterday.

Savings banks can meet present expenses and combat the rising trend of costs without radically changing the composition of their earning assets, August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Banks Trust Company, asserted last night. Speaking before the Savings Banks Officers Forum, Group IV, in the Hotel Astor, Mr. Ihlefeld declared that excessive reliance upon bond, rather than equity, financing by corporations "has become recognized more and more as a threat to future economic stability."

If somebody had thought to measure the owl's ears yesterday when it flew into the sixty-seventh floor window of the RCA Building, it might be easier to say what kind of owl it was and what it was doing in the skyscraper.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- A tribute to the retiring librarian of New York's Morgan Library, Miss Belle de Costa Greene, is printed in this week's London Times Literary Supplement.

Natural crude rubber sold yesterday on the Commodity Exchange at nine points below the Government's price for general-purpose synthetic rubber. It was the first time since March that the natural had undersold the domestic manufactured substitute.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- "The Judas Kiss," a screen story by Irving Revetch, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a possible vehicle for Van Heflin or Robert Taylor, the studio disclosed today. The story deals with a Confederate soldier sent to New Mexico to hold up a northern bullion train. "

ONE of the more interesting aspects of the ascension of Red Rolfe to the managerial throne at Detroit is that he has only one sure-shot regular in his outfield, Johnny Groth in center. What? You never heard of Johnny Groth? That's strange, because Groth is slated to be the regular Tiger center fielder for the next ten or fifteen years.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 16 -- The highly successful use of radioactive isotope tracers to diagnose cancer of the thyroid gland was reported today to the United States Chapter of the International College of Surgeons.

A rather disarming group of children's portraits assembled in an exhibition, "Up From the Cradle," opens today at the New York Historical Society after a preview last evening. Some fifty oils, water-colors, ivory and wax miniatures and silhouettes are included in this 200 years -- 1660 to 1860 -- survey of childhood depictations, solicited from private sources, dealers, museums and the society's own collection.

After a session with a king-sized abacus or two, the State Racing Commission yesterday provided the official figures on the 196-day New York turf campaign which ended with Monday's show at the Jamaica track.

Seven men and three women were arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions Court, accused of "shaking down" apartment seekers for $8,985 in illegal rental bonuses. The group, which included four attorneys, represented the largest round-up of alleged rent gougers since District Attorney Frank S. Hogan opened a drive last spring on "widespread extortion practices" in the granting of leases.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 16 -- An advocate for Albania suggested today that Greece might have been implicated in the mining of two British destroyers in the Corfu Channel in October, 1946.

Archie Binns, author of "You Rolling River," is at work on a biography of Minnie Maddern Fiske, the actress. The book is being written in collaboration with Olive Kooken, sculptress friend of the actress, who inherited from Harrison Grey Fiske, 3,000 pounds of letters, diaries, papers, scrapbooks, photographs and costumes.

David S. Meister has purchased the property at the southwest corner of Jefferson Street and Hoover Avenue in Passaic, N. J., from the Jefferson-Hoover Corporation. The parcel, 56 by 150 feet, is vacant except for a corner building, 16 by 66 feet, which is leased to the College Hill Company for fifteen years.

Several criticisms of the immigration and naturalization laws and procedures, including the charge that present immigration quotas add to the high cost of living, were read yesterday into the record of a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee.
