Curbs on high interest rates and other abuses in the financing of automobiles and other goods bought under conditional sales contracts will be pressed at the next session of the state Legislature in January, Senator J. Raymond McGovern, Republican, of New Rochelle, announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- Reports that Dr. Otto Strasser is backing an extreme Right-Wing party aimed at "Germany's reorganization" have reached Berlin recently and are causing lively anxiety among democratic politicans already disquieted by the rebirth of a number of extreme Right-Wing groups in Western Germany.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16 -- All members of the secular and regular clergy in Argentina from now on must carry special ecclesiastical credentials, to be presented whenever required by Government officials. A decree to this effect by the Executive power has just been published by the Foreign Office, whose full title is the Ministry of Foreign Relations and Worship.

The American press generally speaking is the most responsible and honest in the world, David Marshall, Patterson Professor of Journalism at Fordham University, declared last night at a forum on American freedoms.

Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, urged last night that a ceiling be placed on expenditures for the rearmament of Western Europe and other extraordinary demands on the American economy.

Mrs. John Williams Morgan, president of the Women's Committee of the Judson Health Center, headed the committee for the annual luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the Center held yesterday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

ATHENS, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis and Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris announced jointly tonight that a new Government had been formed with Mr. Sophoulis retaining the post of Premier.
New York University's football squad devoted the greater part of yesterday's practice session at Ohio Field to polishing its offensive for Kings Point Saturday.

Officers of the National Maritime Union, CIO, under a dictate of the union's membership, will comply with that part of the Labor Management Relations Act of 1947 that calls for their signing non-Communist affidavits, it was made known yesterday afternoon.
MANILA, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A Flying Fortress, missing on a flight from New Guinea, was found downed today in the north central Philippines with all twelve aboard safe. Two suffered minor injuries.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- In an oratorical broadside that veteran House of Commons observers believed rarely equaled, Winston Churchill, leader of the Conservative opposition, today assailed the Government's bill to nationalize the iron and steel industry as "a burglar's jimmy to crack the capitalist crib."

Madeleine Carroll, glamorous screen star, will make her first Broadway appearance at 8:15 tonight at the Morosco in "Goodbye, My Fancy." Also to be introduced are Fay Kanin, scenarist, who wrote the play, and her husband, Michael Kanin, film producer-writer, who is sponsoring the attraction in association with Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Delegates of three nations, Lebanon, Pakistan and Iraq, today protested consideration of Israel as a member of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

Competitive bidding yesterday for more than $90,000,000 worth of public utility and railroad securities generated interest costs ranging from 3.215 per cent for $60,000,000 of thirty-one-year debentures of Northwestern Bell Telephone Company to 3.75 per cent for $14,518,000 of bonds of New York Bay Railroad, an affiliate of the Pennsylvania system.

A plea for intensive community campaigning to assure the success of the 1949 campaign for $2,000,000 of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, was made yesterday before 300 campaign chairmen at a conference in the Roosevelt Hotel.

Jean Jacobs, executive vice president of the Wallmar Screen Printing Company, has purchased the Shelter Rock residence nearing completion on Lane Drive, between Meadow Farm Road and Denton Avenue, in Manhasset, L.I., according to Lane Realty, sales representative.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee completed its debate today on the long dispute over South Africa's administration of the Territory of Southwest Africa. Voting on the proposals before the committee was deferred until tomorrow.

The Museum of Modern Art is opening to the public today an exhibition entitled "Timeless Aspects of Modern Art," which may well prove to be one of the most controversial of all its exhibitions. It is the first in a series of special exhibitions designed, according to the museum's announcement, to relate modern art to the arts of other epochs and to clarify its place in our own time.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Mrs. Dvorah Rabinowitz of the Bronx was re-elected unanimously as president of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America, at the closing session of its twenty-third annual national convention here today.
The Temporary City Housing Rent Commission will be the subject of an investigation by John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday. The inquiry will begin today.

Comprehensive plans for what looms as a busy winter will be formulated by the Vermont Winter Sports Council at its annual meeting today at the Woodstock Inn, Woodstock, Vt. Representatives from ski areas, transportation systems, schools and colleges and manufacturers of ski equipment will discuss all phases of winter sports from 10 A. M. to 5 P. M.

James A. Roe, Queens County Democratic leader, replied in a letter made public yesterday to County Judge Thomas Downs' demand for his resignation by challenging the jurist to a test of strength in the executive committee.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16 -- As time flies, one month in the life of a football coach, who has devoted 34 of his 46 years to the gridiron sport, may not seem of great moment. For Charlie Caldwell, the Princeton tactician, however, the past thirty days have proved among the happiest and most successful in his long career.
International politics did not force a musical embargo last night in Carnegie Hall, when Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra presented a brilliant program exclusively of Russian music.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A proposal that the United Nations take up the China crisis, meeting at once the issue whether world peace was threatened by "Russian aid to China's Communists," was made today by a Republican member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

MONTREAL, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Joe Carveth, a veteran winger who failed to hit his best stride last season after being traded to Montreal by Boston, found the range last week to pick up four goals and an assist in three games and move into a third-place tie in the National Hockey League scoring race.

An extra dividend of 30 cents and a regular quarterly of 30 cents a share on the common, both payable on Dec. 15, have been voted by the American Colortype Company. A year ago an extra of 25 cents was paid.

OTTAWA, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's 1948 wheat harvest was placed at 393,300,000 bushels today by the Bureau of Statistics in its third and final estimate of the size of this year's grain, forage and root crops.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- Rigid discipline and the closest supervision will be applied to the Soviet Army of Occupation this winter, it was learned today from an unimpeachable American source. This emphasis will result from the unusually high number of desertions from the Soviet Army during corps maneuvers of the last six months and the general unhandiness of the troops in the field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A sharp rise in shipments of wheat, barley, grain sorghums and flour caused exports of food during August to increase 14 per cent over the July volume, the Department of Commerce reported tonight.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Jules Moch, Minister of the Interior, placed the blame today on the French Communist party for the fatalities and sabotage that had accompanied the coal strike. He made his charages while answering questions in the debate held in the National Assembly's first meeting after the election recess.

ROSELLE PARK, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Two 11-year-old boys, pupils of Aldene Public School here, were "sentenced" today to write essays on "Why I Should Take Care of My School" and "Why I Should Not Tell Lies" and fined 25 cents each after Patrolman Wesley Price said they at first denied and later admitted breaking into the school over the week-end.

The longer the life span in the civilized countries of the world, the greater the tasks confronting the medical sciences to make life worth while and endurable, Dr. Ambrose P. Merrill declared yesterday. Dr. Merrill is superintendent of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases and the affiliated institution for the aged, the Braker Memorial Home, Third Avenue and 183d Street, the Bronx.

Trust Relations A new manual, "Staff Relations With Trust Customers," has been prepared by the trust division of the American Bankers Association, according to an announcement by H. M. Bardt, president of the division and senior trust officer, Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Ambassador W. Averell Harriman said today he was not fearful of an outbreak of war "in the foreseeable future" but indicated that measures to strengthen Western Europe's security were needed to hasten its economic recovery.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16 -- Working behind locked gates on DeWitt Cuyler Field, the Yale varsity squad today began intensive preparation for the big game with Hardvard Saturday in a stiff hourlong scrimmage.

Deliberate breach by the Port of New York Authority of the leases to the airlines at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, which the Authority assumed in writing when it took over the property from the city was charged yesterday by George W. Whiteside, attorney for the nine airlines concerned.

News from Washington serves as a reminder that there is still at least a spark of life in the issue of portal-to-portal pay -- the issue which caused nation-wide consternation early in 1947 by raising for industry the specter of nearly $6,000,000,000 in damage suits for back wages.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Warrants for the arrest of nine persons accused of being members of an international ring of smugglers which has been furnishing bombers and guns to Israeli forces were mailed to widely scattered parts of the country today.

Members of the Millinery Creators Guild presented their hats for spring last evening at the St. Regis Hotel. Yellow, pale green and white were the prominent colors. Side-swept bonnets, cloches and sailors were featured.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Despite Arab requests for a delay, eight members of the United Nations Security Council adopted today a resolution ordering an armistice throughout Palestine. The resolu tion was voted paragraph by paragraph, with the Soviet Union and Ukrainian delegates abstaining throughout.

ROME, Nov. 16 -- A split in the Christian Democratic party was considered possible today as the result of a speech delivered in Pesaro by Giovanni Gronchi, President of the Chamber of Deputies, who criticized some of the Government's policy.

Formation of seventeen food advisory groups composed of industry leaders who will work with the National Security Resources Board was announced yesterday by F. Chapin, Weed, director of the board's food division, at the annual meeting of the Grocery Manufacturers of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PEIPING, China, Nov. 16 -- Communist troop concentrations are gathering northeast of the Peiping-Tientsin Railway and have reached a point within thirty miles of Peiping, according to well-informed sources here.
For the thirteenth year, a skating revue known as the Ice Follies assumed its regular place on the calendar of Madison Square Garden last night.

Helen Le Claire, Minneapolis contralto who has been heard here as a member of the New York City Opera Company, gave her first local recital last night at Times Hall. Her attractively chosen program included a Mozart concert aria, "Ombra Felice," songs by Francisco Mignone of Brazil, lieder by Schumann and new songs in English by John Duke, Jean Berger and Celius Dougherty.

ONE hundred and four years ago two French Catholic priests of the Vincentian order set out from Peking to traverse the steppes and deserts of Tartary and to penetrate to the inner fastness of Tibet, where they hoped to spread the Christian faith. They had no maps, little equipment and little money. But they spoke Chinese and Tartar and they had great courage and great faith.
A large dance entitled the Bal des Symphonies was given last night in the ballroom suite of the Plaza to augment the pension fund of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

AREQUIPA, Peru, Nov. 16 -- The shotless revolution that made Gen. Manuel Odria the provisional President of Peru began, like so many other Peruvian revolts, in this shining city that is the gateway to Lake Titicaca and the old Inca Empire.

The confusion in ethnological terminology by which an Indian may be a native of Asia or America is becoming a nuisance to citizens of the new state of India visiting this country, the native heath of those other Indians. So said Sirdar J. J. Singh, president of the India League of America, yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular in the late trading yesterday and closed 8 points higher to 3 points lower.

Further forward progress was made yesterday by the stock market as post-election jitters waned. The list on the Stock Exchange encountered some selling near the close, with steels and oils the targets, but the general complexion of the session was changed little as a result.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Herbert Morley, who has been in charge of materials procurement for Tucker Corporation since its formation, resigned today as vice president and a director of the company. In a letter to the board of directors, Mr. Morley charged that Preston T. Tucker, president, exerts "dominating influence" in the company and recently has withheld information concerning the corporation's financial status even from his own directors.

If "You Can't Take It With You" were crossed with "Grandma's Diary," something like "For Heaven's Sake, Mother!" might be born. It is not so harrowing as "Grandma's Diary," but it is not so amusing as "You Can't Take It With You." For some reason, which deserves a grand jury investigation, it was seen in public last evening at the Belasco Theatre with a cast that stars Nancy Carroll and Molly Picon.

The annual "cruise" dinner, or silver shower, at which the year's racing prizes are awarded, was held last night by the New York Yacht Club in its town house, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. The affair was attended by the owners and their guests who were on the club's cruise, at its 94th annual regatta at Edgartown, Mass., and the races in Buzzards Bay and other events.
NANKING, Nov. 16 -- The Chinese Ministry of Defense announced tonight the "complete collapse" of Gen. Chen Yi's Communist columns on the Lung-Hai Railway east of Suchow.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, reported yesterday that he would have the support of all but six of the 116 delegates elected to represent the union's big New York local at the TWU convention in Chicago next month.

Your mention of the fact that a fraternity chapter at Amherst College had been suspended by the national council for pledging a Negro brings to mind a fairly recent, but much more heartening, way of dealing with this ridiculous prejudice. A few years ago, the Ohio State University chapter of Phi Delta Kappa -- a graduate fraternity for educators -- admitted a Chinese student.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 2,170, against 2,483 last week and 1,800 in the similar week of 1947, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,012 arrivals yesterday, compared with 1,393 last Tuesday.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics recommends that for escalator clauses in business contracts businesses and other organizations use its monthly comprehensive wholesale price index and not the new weekly wholesale price index nor the estimate of the monthly index to be issued in connection with it, it was explained yesterday.

The Maria Moors Cabot gold medals, awarded annually by Columbia University for "outstanding contributions to understanding among the nations of the Americas," will be presented this year to four journalists, three South Americans and one North American, it was announced yesterday.

The North American Company reported yesterday that its net income for the twelve months to Sept. 30 was $11,335,000, equal to $1.32 a share, compared with $15,997,000 or $1.87 a share in the preceding twelve months.

Umbrella Ads Called False Complaints against misleading advertising, inaccurate labeling and "phony" sales were reported yesterday to have been made at a meeting of the Greater New York Umbrella Manufacturers, Inc. It was proposed that a shopper be hired to check such practices, and to institute unfair trade practices proceedings with the Federal Trade Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, verified today a report that he had advised President Truman against return of grain purchases for export into private channels at the present time.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt accepted as "a recognition of women and their contribution to the new world" the honorary degree of Doctor of Civil Law which Oxford University has conferred on her. It was that, of course. Until last May no woman in modern times had been permitted to address the Oxford House of Convocation, and the exception last May was made for the Princess Elizabeth.

A new technique of constructing homes for low income groups, featuring a fifty-ton concrete roof poured on the ground and raised eight feet by a hydraulic jack, has been developed by Philip N. Youtz, Westchester architect.

Discussions of domestic and foreign problems confronting the motion-picture industry were begun here yesterday by the presidents of the major film companies and their top executive aides at the first of three scheduled meetings presided over by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.
The baby Prince of Edinburgh was honored here yesterday with a special floral display in his name at the semi-annual flower show of the Metropolitan Retail Florists Association, Inc.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The last six articles of the draft convention on genocide were approved today by the Legal Committee of the United Nations General Assembly. It voted to have the convention remain in effect for a period of ten years after becoming effective.

Both the Western Powers and Soviet Russia have new replied to the joint communication addressed to them by President Evatt of the General Assembly of the United Nations and Secretary General Lie, urging "the desirability of immediate conversations and of taking all other necessary steps toward the solution of the Berlin question."
A commission empowered to tackle New York's costly traffic jam will probably be appointed by Jan. 1, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday.

A controversy over the recently adopted "single salary" schedule in the state education law threatens to split New York's 35,000 public school teachers into two opposing factions, it became known yesterday.

Carefully developed plans for complete industrial mobilization in the event of sudden attack are an absolute essential to peace, according to Maj. Gen. William H. Middleswart, Deputy to The Quartermaster General.

Frederick N. Goldsmith, 82-year-old forecaster of stock-market trends, whom the state is seeking to enjoin from selling information alleged to be based on either comic strips or spiritualism, told Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber yesterday that the spirits refused to help him in making money.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Spokesmen of all parties and of all faiths in the British Parliament joined today in praising the royal family and congratulating it upon the birth of the latest royal Prince -- that is, all except William Gallacher, one of the two Communists in the House of Commons.

The Garden Room of the Hotel Ambassador, Fifty-first Street and Park Avenue, took on the look of a sophisticated Santa's storehouse yesterday as the woman's branch of the New York City Mission Society opened its first big Christmas sale, which will continue through today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Grain markets continued on the upgrade on the Board of Trade today, wheat in the lead. The latter closed 1 1/4 to 2 1/4 cents higher, the latter on December, which sold at a new high since April 22, and finished at 7 5/8 cents over the Government loan, a figure said by elevator men to pay storage charges on the bulk of the new grain held in leading markets.

The citizens golden anniversary planting program initiated in September by the Park Association of New York City in connection with the greater city's fiftieth anniversary, will carry on into 1949, it was announced yesterday. The extended program will be highlighted by a city-wide all-day planting ceremony to be held early in April.
In his message to Congress of Sept. 6, 1945, President Truman asked for consideration of the following twenty-one points:

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 16 -- Addressing the Transvaal congress of Nationalist party delegates today, Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan dealt principally with racial relations and foreshadowed the introduction of a system of "racial registration." He said:
BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 16 (AP)-- A group of leading manufacturers of artificial abrasives agreed today to discontinue pricing practices the Government had challenged as illegal.

A government drive to tighten up enforcement of the Robinson-Patman Act is impending, but Government officials are not "trying to make America over," Burton Bigelow, president of the Burton Bigelow Organization, New York, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Navy vessels of the Mediterranean Fleet were asked by their commander today to share their Thanksgiving Day dinners with the "hungry and homeless" of the ports at which the ships may be stationed on Nov. 25.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- End of account influences slowed business in the stock market here today.

PARIS, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Following is the text of the official translation of Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky's letter to Herbert V. Evatt of Australia, president of the United Nations General Assembly, and Trygve Lie, Secretary-General of the United Nations, on the subject of the proposed Berlin negotiations:

The Yankees yesterday landed what they termed the "prize package" of the group of players recently removed from the Tigers' organization and made free agents by Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler.

A vacant plot 83 by 104 feet on the west side of Crescent Street, 126 feet south of Thirty-seventh Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by William B. Welsh for improvement with a commercial building. Mrs. Margot Lothman was the seller.

VIENNA, Nov. 16 -- The Arbeiterzeitung, central newspaper of the Socialist party, which has the largest circulation in Austria, hinted today that Irving Ross, member of the Marshall Plan mission here, might have been murdered by United States personnel.
CLEVELAND, NOV. 16 (AP) -- The Indians have signed a working agreement with San Diego of the Triple A Pacific Coast League, Hank Greenberg, Cleveland vice president, announced tonight.
SEATTLE, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A North Pacific storm today apparently claimed the lives of seven persons and sank three tugs. Other vessels were reported in trouble.
Two Queens landlords won court sanction yesterday of their right to file eviction suits against tenants whose apartments they wish to withdraw from the rental market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board recommended dismissal of a secondary boycott complaint against a union today because of the business connections between the "boycotted" employer who was engaged in the primary dispute.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 -- A note of caution to individual soft drink concerns to consider seriously consumer reaction in any contemplated price increases in their products was given today by Thomas F. Mansfield of Newark, N. J., president of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages.

BELGRADE, Nov. 16 -- Premier Tito today warned Communist leaders of the "peoples' democracies" that their unbridled attacks on Yugoslavia were endangering the success of the drive to spread "progressive movements" throughout the world.

"Days of Decision," a thirty-five-minute news film which documents the tenth anniversary assembly of Moral Rearmament held in Southern California last June, was shown yesterday morning before an invited audience at the Embassy Theatre, 33 West Fiftieth Street.

Two promotions calculated to improve Fordham's defenses against aerial attack were made yesterday by Coach Ed Danowski as the Rams underwent a series of special drills for Saturday's contest with Rutgers at New Brunswick, N.J.

As Americans in Peiping we fear that our fellow-countrymen at home are not fully aware of one way in which American "aid" to China is being used in a way that violates American interests as well as human decency and is working powerfully toward the losing of our battle for men's minds here.

VIENNA, Nov. 16 -- The Austrian Cabinet voted today to appeal to the Allied Council for Austria against a Russian order to turn over 540 locomotives and 5,575 railway cars for removal to Russia. The Soviet Union claims this equipment, which is not of Austrian origin, as war booty.

Losses in the week-old Atlantic Coast longshoremen's strike mounted steadily into the millions yesterday as cargo backlogs piled on idle piers. No progress was made toward a solution of the problem and no meetings have been scheduled for the disputing dock workers with their employers, while Government mediators marked time and awaited an opening for action.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 16 -- President Truman flatly rejected today all proposals for a four-power discussion of the Berlin crisis unless the Russian blockade of the city was unconditionally removed.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 16 -- Discussions and reports covering recent development in the field of public utilities featured today's session of the sixtieth annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 16 -- Warnings against the international dangers of communism were sounded today by speakers at the American Federation of Labor convention.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Johnson County Attorney Jack C. White said today he has sent to the President of the University of Minnesota a protest on "the conduct and language" of Coach Bernie Bierman.

The New York Telephone Company filed an application in Albany yesterday for an average 15 per cent increase in rates within the state that would total $49,000,000 a year. Pending decision by the Public Service Commission, the company asked an immediate 10 per cent addition -- about $25,000,000 -- to local service charges.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 16 -- Extortionate prices for new cars and the ever-increasing traffic muddle in New York City were denounced today at the annual national meeting of the American Automobile Association here.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The Irish Government may delay severing its last link with the British crown, it was reported after a conference here today between Sean McBride, Minister of External Affairs, and Patrick McGilligan, Finance Minister, on one side, and officials of the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and New Zealand on the other.
What is happening to the United Nations Appeal for Children?

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 16 -- President Truman sketched out today the course of his next Administration, giving as his main bearings his twenty-one-point domestic program of Sept. 6, 1945, which extended the New Deal, his program since then and the 1948 Democratic platform.

John M. Christensen, secretary of the New York State Athletic Commission, disclosed yesterday that the welterweight champion, Ray (Sugar) Robinson, has been placed on the "ill and unavailable list" because of his inability to go through with a scheduled bout at Buffalo, N. Y., Nov. 9, The United Press reported.

Starting preparations for the campaign finale, against R.P.I. Saturday, with the hope of setting an all-time Brooklyn College season record, the Kingsmen football squad went through a limbering up drill yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Treasury Department announced today an exchange offering of $6,698,160,150 of one-year 1 1/4 per cent certificates to holders of three Government security issues falling due by Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- After two days of public investigation into alleged questionable trade practices in the sale of new and used automobiles, the House (Macy) subcommittee reached two conclusions today.

Well selected as to style, color, fabric and price was the collection presented yesterday afternoon on the seventh floor of Russeks Fifth Avenue. All the clothes were from Henry Rosenfeld. They were distinctly holiday dresses, that is, fashions geared for the sunny South or West.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Plans for expanding with additional funds the State Department's cooperative educational and cultural projects with Europe, the Near East and Africa were considered at a two-day meeting ending today of the United States Advisory Commission on Educational Exchange.

Re-enactment of the delivery of Lincoln's Gettysburg Address, with participants attired in dress of the Civil War period, will take place on Friday in connection with the visit of the Freedom Train to Gettysburg, Pa. The occasion will mark the eighty-fifth anniversary of the military cemetery at the Gettysburg battlefield.

Retail slow-down in dress departments in the last few weeks is currently reflected in lagging sales in the New York dress market, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Manufacturers are seeking to stimulate sales by aggressive promotions of popular price spring lines but have found that buyers are more interested in goods for immediate or holiday delivery and will make only minor commitments beyond the end of December.

"We are pointing for Boston and not worrying about the Packers," was Jack Mara's smiling, tongue-in-cheek opening remark to the press at yesterday's weekly Football Giants' luncheon at the Polo Grounds.

For the first time on an industry-wide scale, a continuous method of making "hard soap," a basic change in manufacture, is now well under way, Walter Prosch, district manager of the Sharples Corporation, revealed in an interview yesterday at the 22d fall meeting of the American Oil Chemists Society at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Before he died a century ago the original John Jacob Astor pondered on a "fitting testimonial" to the country in which he had become the richest citizen. Some say he planned a "huge" monument to George Washington. He was talked out of this and persuaded to other projects.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 17 -- The United Council of Church Women voted unanimously today to ask each Protestant church in this country to find a job and a home for at least one displaced person or his family during the coming year.

Re-enactment of an excess profits tax with an "initial sparing of so-called small business" was predicted last night by Dr. Joseph J. Klein, certified public accountant and former president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, at the monthly dinner of the Metropolitan Controllers' Association in the Martinique Hotel.

Though it has been estimated that in 1952 American university and college teaching staffs should be double what they were in 1947, no comprehensive plan for recruiting new teachers has been planned, Oliver C. Carmichael, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, declared yesterday in the foundation's forty-third annual report.

The long-drawn-out effort of underwriters to place with investors $26,000,000 of new 4.50 per cent dividend preferred stock of the Reynolds Tobacco Company ended abruptly on an upbeat yesterday, marking the underwriters' first successful disposition of a major issue of prime preferred stock in many months.
For a coach whose team has to tackle the mighty Cleveland Browns on Sunday, Coach Red Strader of the football Yankees was as cheerful as could be expected yesterday.
Youthful maritime officers who served in the merchant marine in the last war urged yesterday that President Truman issue an executive order exempting them from the present draft.

The Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power sold yesterday an issue of $9,000,000 of electric plant revenue bonds due from 1949 to 1988 and callable in 1954 at an interest basis cost of 2.5431 per cent. The issue was awarded to a banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Hugh Dalton will head a strong British team at the forthcoming Paris meeting of a committee to consider "steps to be taken toward securing a greater measure of unity between European countries," it was announced today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 -- Foreign officials stationed in Belgrade today combed Premier Marshal Tito's speech in Ljubljana yesterday for hidden meanings to prove that he was shifting the main emphasis of his policy to the West.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- In separate statements the United States, British and French Governments rejected today direct four-power talks on Berlin so long as the Soviet blockade continued and insisted that the Security Council was the qualified body to deal specifically with the dispute over control of that city.

Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, was honored for his twenty-five years of service with that organization by the Metropolitan Opera Guild at its annual membership meeting yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 17 -- The Israeli-Arab peace talks have collapsed for the moment under the impact of the Security Council's resolution ordering the Israeli Army out of the Negeb.

The City Planning Commission reserved decision yesterday after a public hearing on its proposal to amend the city's zoning regulations to permit the construction of public parking garages as a matter of right in business and retail use districts.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks came from behind twice tonight to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 3, in a {National Hockey League game before 14,967 persons.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The South's roster for the Blue-Gray football classic totaled fifteen tonight with the addition of eleven players.

ATLANTA, Nov. 17 -- Herman Talmadge, the 35-year-old son of the late Eugene Talmadge, today took the oath of office of Governor of Georgia and became the youngest chief executive of any state in the union.

Zionist leaders, who gathered at a dinner last night at the Pierre Hotel in honor of Dr. Israel Goldstein, newly elected treasurer of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, asserted that continuous financial support from American Jews was imperative to assure a steady flow of immigration as well as a resettlement and rehabilitation program in Israel.

Although France's position has improved "enormously" in the last two years, the nation still faces a difficult situation resulting from frozen low wages and high prices, Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 17 -- Leaders of the American Federation of Labor today decided that they were in politics to stay and adopted the following comprehensive program:

Net income of the Cities Service Company and subsidiaries for the nine months to Sept. 30, was $48,631,629, equal to $13.13 on each of the 3,702,000 common shares outstanding, it was announced yesterday.

Lower prices and cold weather during the period directly ahead may reverse adverse trends in furs, it was indicated yesterday at a meeting held by the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc., at the Biltmore Hotel.

Increased visibility, riding comfort and reduction in over-all length for easier handling and parking were emphasized in nine restyled 1949 Buick cars, announced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation. The units, in the Super and Roadmaster series, are scheduled to go on public display Nov. 26 in dealer showrooms throughout the country.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina rejected yesterday a defense contention that "the present anti-Communist hysteria" made impossible a fair trial now for the twelve Communists accused of conspiring to advocate the forcible overthrow of the Government.

Revelations in the last few days by two legislative committees of unconscionable business practices in automobile sales and financing foreshadow one of two eventualities. Either the automobile makers and sellers must quickly get together to write and then enforce a code of honest business or such a code will probably be written into law and imposed on them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Some 300 new complaints of alleged questionable trade practices in retail sales of automobiles, issuing from about thirty-five states, poured in upon the House (Macy) investigating committee yesterday and today in the wake of two days of public hearings on conditions in the "sampling" area of Washington.

The factional feud between right and left-wing forces in the Transport Workers Union, CIO, got into court again yesterday when Austin Hogan, suspended president of the union's big New York local, sued for reinstatement.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis cannot merge in a joint fund-raising appeal with other national health and welfare agencies and also "fulfill its obligation to the public," Basil O'Connor, National Foundation president, declared last night at the Pierre Hotel.
Negotiations of striking longshoremen and their employers will be reopened tomorrow under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Counciliation Service, it was announced last night.

Denim Prices Remain Firm Denim prices for December, January and February will show no change, it was announced yesterday by Cone Export and Commission Company, Inc. Quotations of 34.80 cents a yard for 2.20 mill finish and 40 cents a yard for 8-ounce sanforized denim are the same as the last prices under price control.

The fundamental differences between states righters and those favoring election of the President by direct popular vote were expounded last night on THE NEW YORK TIMES' weekly radio forum, "What's On Your Mind?" A third view, seeking to reconcile the opposing camps, also was presented.

Although New York University's daily football practices at Ohio Field are devoid of heavy contact work, the team cannot escape the injury jinx. Coach Edward E. (Hook) Mylin revealed yesterday that Quarterback Joe Quinn had twisted an ankle and would not play against Kings Point Saturday.

CHICOPEE, Mass., Nov. 17 -- A four-engined converted Flying Fortress was winging tonight toward Argentia, Newfoundland, with a new set of bearings which it will try to drop at sea 1,300 miles east of Boston tomorrow for the crippled United States Army Transport Comfort.

Frances Magnes, who gave her third Carnegie Hall recital last night, is both a superb technician and an interesting musician. If she were a speaker, instead of a violinist, one would say she had an extraordinarily rich vocabulary.

A concert devoted to instrumental compositions by Isadore Freed was presented last night at Times Hall, under the auspices of the Julius Hartt Foundation of Hartford, Conn. The composer from Philadelphia performed the piano part in three of his works, and the other participants included Leonard Rose, 'cellist; Karen Tuttle, violist; Leonard Seeber, pianist, and the WQXR String Quartet.

The unexpectedness of last year's record snowfall is affecting the plans for this winter of two vital services that had trouble digging out -- the Department of Sanitation and the Long Island Rail Road -- it was learned yesterday.

The busiest period of lap-stealing since last Sunday's start of the six-day bike race at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory occurred last night as the ten teams reached the halfway point. While a crowd of 5,000, the biggest thus far, thrilled to their daring starting with the 9 P.M. sprints, the riders jammed throughout the night session.

The need for strengthening pediatric training in medical schools to provide better medical care for the nation's children, especially those in outlying areas, was emphasized yesterday by Dr. John P. Hubbard, director of the Committee for Improvement of Child Health, American Academy of Pediatrics.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said today that his remaining in the Cabinet was a question President Truman would decide.
Tens of thousands of rush-hour commuters on subways and on the Long Island Rail Road were delayed yesterday when two separate breakdowns occurred during the height of the rush hour.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- Jack Lavelle was driving Herman Hickman to the practice field from Ray Tompkins House and, needless to say, two free-loaders in the back seat were having plenty of laughs even though they were being bounced around, with the scales balanced 600 pounds to 350 against them.

In the midst of ominous forecasts of another winter of short gas supplies for home heating, the American Gas Association reported yesterday that a new gas manufacturing process would nearly double the present distribution capacity of gas companies and reduce considerably the cost of producing gas.
PASSAU, Germany, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A German denazification court today decided that Captain Fritz Wiedemann was a former Nazi but in name only.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 -- Congress may be asked at the next session to pass a bill requiring that all salt sold for human consumption be iodized in an effort to combat goiter and cancer of the thyroid gland, it was learned today at the annual assembly of the United States chapter of the International College of Surgeons.

Rockefeller Center will have on Nov. 29 the tallest Christmas tree ever displayed on Rockefeller Plaza -- a ninety-foot Norway spruce -- but this does not mean that the center is competing with Los Angeles or Redding, Calif., a spokesman said yesterday.

Study of the Russian language among all sections of the Rumanian population is being pushed at a tempo that outdistances the efforts to promote things Russian in the other Soviet satellite states, according to details of the program given by the latest issue of the Literary Gazette of Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today announced that potatoes in 1949 will be supported at 60 per cent of parity, instead of the 90 per cent which piled up surpluses under the Steagall amendment and the act passed by the last Congress.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Breckinridge Long's Loraine, a non-winner in five previous starts, developed a stretch punch today that carried her to victory in the second running of the $10,000 added Bowie Breeders Stakes. Bred by her owner, Loraine finished three and a half lengths in front of Bo Mowlee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 10, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

It isn't often that a father, seeing his son for the first time, finds himself being introduced to the son's wife. But that happened yesterday when Edward Colburn, 62-year-old retired Army man, stepped off a bus at the Capitol terminal in West Fiftieth Street, to be met by the 24-year-old son he had never seen.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Capitol the attraction is "The Kissing Bandit," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer romantic comedy drama, starring Frank Sinatra and Kathryn Grayson. Joe Pasternak produced and Laslo Benedek directed the offering from a screen play by sobel Lennart and John Briard Harding, J. Carrol Naish, Mikhail Rasumny, Sono Osato, Billy Gilbert, Ricardo Montalban, Ann Miler and Cyd Charisse appear in supporting roles.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- With British Government bonds showing new gains of as much as an eighth, the stock market here today started a new account on a cheerful note.

If present plans materialize, the television version of the Theatre Guild on the Air will be returning to the NBC video network next month under the sponsorship of General Foods. It would fill the hour between 8 and 9 P.M., presently occupied by "Author Meets the Critics" and Meet the Press."

For some time things have been a little better in one place or another because of the presence of Madeleine Carroll, and that is the happy situation on Broadway this morning. She is appearing in Fay Kanin's "Goodbye, My Fancy," which opened at the Morosco last evening and would be wise to stay open a long time.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The situation in China is receiving increasing attention in high levels of the British Government.

ROME, Nov. 17 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi faced a minor revolt in his Cabinet today when its two Liberal members refused to support the Government bill to reform agrarian contracts. The dissident Ministers are Giusseppe Grassi, Minister of Justice, and Alberto Giovannini, Minister without Portfolio.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Temporary State Commission on Rents, warned today that unless New York City exercises its state-granted powers to protect tenants from oppressive rents, the commission would act to that end.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Phil Strazzulla's Liberty Andy, a 5-1 shot, put on a blazing drive in the homestretch at Rockingham Park today to win the featured Pinkham Notch Purse before 8,327 spectators. Mrs. Samuel Orr's U.S. Bound was second, a length behind the victor.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES published Nov. 12 Frederic S. Burin 2d deplores that the United States has rejected a Soviet proposal to exclude "superior orders" as a defense argument on behalf of those accused of perpetrating acts of genocide. He deplores this on the ground that soldiers are under obligation to obey only "lawful" commands of their superiors.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 17 -- The coincidental announcement today that President Chiang Kai-shek of China had written to President Truman, and that James V. Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, was on the way here led to reports that the Chief Executive might be considering some new measure of support for the Communist-threatened country.

The election of Harry L. Shapiro, formerly executive director of the American Zionist Emergency Council, to the post of executive vice chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, was announced yesterday by Herman L. Weisman, acting chairman of the appeal.

Though Vienna's woods and waltzes overshadowed her cookery, the city's cuisine in happier days was great and good. Max Loew said so the other evening over an aperitif at his cheerful little restaurant, the Viennese Lantern, 242 East Seventy-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, asserted today that he was impressed by the progress of the Western European Union, a key element in the national...

To continue its rehabilitation work in military and veterans' hospitals, the American Theatre Wing has drafted John Golden, theatrical producer and philanthropist, to serve as temporary chairman of an intensive drive for funds, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Golden will substitute for Brock Pemberton, chairman of the permanent funds committee, who is absent in London.

LITTLE FERRY, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Blackie is still in the bad graces of this town's housewives. News that the capricious crow was under lock and key today made them smile with relief. But many still said he belonged in a pie.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Princeton's varsity eleven, apparently without injuries for the first time since early in the season, devoted practice today to the perfection of defensive measures that Coach Charlie Caldwell hopes will check Dartmouth when the teams close their seasons in Palmer Stadium Saturday.

A protest against the detention of an American-flag vessel at Port Said by Egyptian authorities has been filed with the United States State Department by Hans J. Isbrandtsen, president of Isbrandtsen Steamhip Company, Inc., owners of the vessel, it was made known yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Two ranking members of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly are returning to Washington by air shortly, the United States mission said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Seven Representatives will leave by Army plane on Saturday for an extensive tour of Latin America to study economic and political conditions. The group is made up almost entirely of members of a subcommittee on Latin-American affairs of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

A combination of circumstances resulting from labor troubles and other factors has severely damaged the prestige of the Port of New York despite the continued endeavors of civic-minded persons, Paul G. Boise, president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York, declared last night.
PARIS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Following is a joint statement issued by Dr. Herbert V. Evatt and Trygve Lie after they had received replies from the Big Four powers to their appeal for a Berlin settlement:

Twenty-eight fourth-year pupils at Public School 52, Broadway and Academy Street, in the Inwood section of Manhattan, gave their parents food for thought yesterday by making them eat their morning cereal.

The failure of the U.N. Appeal for Children not only feeds ammunition into the propaganda cannons that are trained against us but tends to obscure the fact, through all the publicity accorded the failure, that it is chiefly United States money that has been bolstering and is continuing to bolster the relief work and the economies of the war-ravaged countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- An announcement was made today that the United States would strengthen its force of Marines at Tsingtao, China. This came shortly after it was learned that President Truman had received a direct appeal from President Chiang Kai-shek to strengthen his hand in the present crisis.

When the average person buys his annual Christmas seals he thinks he is contributing to the fight against only one disease -- tuberculosis. But in reality he is also making a small but important contribution to the war against venereal disease.
PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The National Grange Convention started work today on a 1949 platform expected to feature a "states' rights" approach on national problems.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Poland called on United Nations aid today to make the United States stop feeding cereal foods to pigs and cattle while human beings in Europe and Asia still were going hungry.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Forty countries, including several that are not members of the United Nations, will sign a convention on Friday to bring new synthetic narcotic drugs under international control. Eventually it is hoped that seventy nations may become signatories.

Tighe E. Woods, National Housing Expediter, announced here last night that he was completing a national survey of housing conditions in all areas now under rent control with a view to lifting rent ceilings in many regions where the crisis in residential accommodations is found to have been passed.

James Lappin, 18-year-old senior of Bishop Loughlin High School, won the twenty-sixth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The winner's time was 13:35 for the two-and-one-half mile course.

The Soviet Ambassador, Alexander S. Panyushkin; the Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury Cathedral, and Henry A. Wallace were announced yesterday by the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship as the principal speakers at a rally to be held in Madison Square Garden Dec. 13.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The House of Commons approved tonight the Labor Government's proposal to nationalize the iron and steel industry by a vote of 373 to 211. Passage of the measure through a second reading in the House moved this most controversial proposal of the present Parliament past its crucial legislative stage by a comfortable majority.
Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, was honored last night by 300 business and professional associates of the American Jewish Congress at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel.

Tribute has been paid already on this page to the passing of the Hudson River Day Line boats from the metropolitan pageant. They were done in, it seems, by the motor car. But an old New Yorker remarks that this is just one more of the devastating effects of the internal combustion engine upon our too, too inhabited city.

The gauge of Rosalyn Tureck's seriousness as a musician is her determination to grapple with challenging tasks. In her Town Hall recital last night, the American pianist played an exacting all-Bach program. In a second program next month she plans another searching set of works, including a new sonata by David Diamond.

Julio Ramirez Perez, 29-year- old ex-convict, was convicted yesterday of first-degree murder in the slaying of Mrs. Vera Lotito, travel agent, last March 30 in her apartment at 144 East Fifty-fifth Street. The prisoner heard the verdict stoically as it was announced by Paul C. Smith, foreman of the all-male jury, which had deliberated one hour.

TOKYO, Nov. 17 -- There are many indications here that the Communists have begun to lose their once air tight grip on the Japanese trade unions. Labor circles are now openly discussing proposals to eject the party from the whole union movement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- United States exports to Russia and countries under its do domination dropped sharply in September, the Census Bureau reported today. A continued decrease in exports to countries participating in the Economic Cooperation Administration's program also was shown.
PARIS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The texts of the United States, British-and French replies today to the Evatt-Lie appeals for Big Four cooperation follow:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 17 -- The unusual position of banks today as credit handlers in finding themselves in a "buyers' market" when all around them the turn is going to the sellers' market, was discussed at the opening session of the New Jersey Bankers Association two-day midwinter conference.

Although earnings of the Crucible Steel Company of America for 1948 probably will exceed those of 1947, the board of directors considered it inadvisable to pay a dividend on the common shares, William P. Snyder Jr., chairman, announced yesterday.

NANKING, Nov. 17 -- A lull developed today in the Northern Kiangsu railway fronts as both sides continued to claim major victories on the Lung-Hai line east of Suchow. The nightly communique of the Ministry of Defense asserted that more than half of General Chen Yi's attacking Communist columns had been eliminated, while the Communist radio maintained that the Communists east of Suchow had destroyed the Nationalist Seventh Army Group.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- A series of resolutions calling for a strong United Nations, adoption Of the Baruch energy control plan, endorsement of a progressive social action program and the revocation of the United Nations order that Israeli troops evacuate the Negeb, were adopted here today at the concluding session of the seventy-fifth anniversary convention of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Senator James E. Murray expressed the opinion today that a Taft-Hartley Law repealer could be passed only as a part of new labor legislation.

The repurchase by O.B. Potter Properties, Inc., of the eleven-story showroom and loft building at 130 Fifth Avenue from the Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street Corporation, to whom it was sold last year, was reported yesterday by the H.D. Lehds Company, broker in both deals. The deal returns the property to the Potter family ownership in which it had been held for forty-four years before the 1947 transaction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Ninety-three per cent of the banking business arising from the Marshall Plan is concentrated in New York banks, the Economic Cooperation Administration disclosed today. The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, San Francisco, has handled almost all the rest.

As foreshadowed by President Truman, the United States, Britain and France, in their formal replies to the Evatt-Lie appeal for new efforts to speed the final peace settlements, reject further direct discussions with Soviet Russia until the Berlin blockade has been lifted and this threat to peace removed.

The transaction through which the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) will acquire a 30 per cent interest in the Arabian American Oil Company and the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., will get a 10 per cent interest in that company, will be concluded formally early next month, it was announced yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Master Sgt. Anthony Kievet, 52 years old, who thirty-three years ago first enlisted at Fort Slocum, re-enlisted today for his tenth "hitch," again at Fort Slocum, headquarters of the First Air Force.

The information presented in your editorial on the House Un-American Activities Committee is startling. All four Democratic members on the committee come from one part of the country -- Florida, Georgia, Mississippi and Louisiana. These four states have only 7 per cent of the membership of the House.

We doubt if anything Herbert H. Lehman ever has done has given him more satisfaction than presenting, jointly with Mrs. Lehman, a new four-story building at 305 Henry Street to the Henry Street Settlement. This is the kind of gift that can never be measured in dollars.

With industry profits running at an all-time high, there should be no hesitancy in re-imposing the excess profits tax, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, declared yesterday. However, the tax should be so devised, he said, to encourage investment of private capital in new competitive enterprise.

Retailers were urged yesterday to "take a leaf out of President Truman's book" and "give the public what it wants." Jackson Spears, president of National Mallison Fabrics Corporation, expressed that view at a luncheon meeting of the piece goods groups of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the New Yorker Hotel.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The proceedings in the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly came to a halt today while other delegates waited for the United States and Britain to continue their efforts to reach agreement on the proposed resolution to carry out the Bernadotte Plan for Palestine.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The United States asked the United Nations today to grant another year of life to the Little Assembly and immediately ran into a Soviet charge that Washington was using pressure to make an "obedient weapon" of the world organization.

The election will not alter the business pattern of the country which currently is tied closely to Government expenditures, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance, New York University, said yesterday.

The upturn of the stock market on the New York Stock Exchange ran into successive but mild waves of selling yesterday and, although support appeared, prices closed irregularly lower. The temper of the trading indicated, observers said, that switching operations were more general than outright liquidation.
BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Military Administration moved toward even tighter control of the Germans in the Eastern zone today.

The State committee of the American Labor party and the Communist party of New York State urged the Public Service Commission yesterday to reject the New York Telephone Company's application for increased rates.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 17 -- The Port of New York Authority plans to invite bids within a month on an issue of $7,000,000 of marine terminal bonds for the development of the Newark Seaport at Newark, N.J., Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Authority, announced here today at the annual meeting of the National Security Traders Association.

The executive committee of the Queens County Democratic Committee adopted unanimously a resolution of confidence in the County leader, James A. Roe, last night and rebuked Queens County Judge Thomas Downs for having "untruthfully criticized" the county chairman.

Private employment agencies must take a united nation-wide stand against possible attempts to grant administrative heads of state and municipal licensing bodies legislative powers, William E. Vogel, counsel for the National Employment Board, declared yesterday. He spoke before third-day sessions of the group's sixteenth meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 17 -- The third annual general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization opened here today with a plea from the interim president, Francisco del Rio of Mexico, to remember that its mission was "to fight back barbarism and the desolation of war."

Clyde Hampton, 215-pound tackle from Lusk, Wyo., will have the honor of leading Columbia's thirteen varsity seniors in their last game, it was announced by Coach Lou Little yesterday. Hampton was named game captain against Syracuse at Baker Field on Saturday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- David O. Selznick announced today that he has sold the screen rights o F. Scott Fitzgerald's 1934 novel, "Tender Is the Night," to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a prospective vehicle for Jennifer Jones. A film adaptation of the story, written by David Hertz for Selznick, was included in the deal.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The New York Rangers scored three times in the first four minutes of the second stanza tonight to earn a 4-4 tie in a National Hockey League game with the Detroit Red Wings before 12,606 fans at Olympia.

Unbeaten in Basketball Association of America competition, the Washington Capitols recorded their seventh straight victory last night, romping to a 73-62 triumph over the New York Knickerbockers at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The 3,564 fans on hand saw the Knicks drop their fourth decision in seven contests.
For four hours Tuesday night, Sugar Ray Robinson, the world welterweight champion, was banned from fighting in New York and five other states.

Higher education in this country "has had to be prodded and pushed unwillingly into its role of leadership by groups of citizens whose only method has been to administer one or two moral hot-foots in the public prints," Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, asserted yesterday.

The New York Telephone Company has applied to the Public Service Commission for a permanent increase in telephone rates to add 15 per cent to its annual income. Pending a decision on this application it has asked for a temporary rise in rates, applicable only to the local service charge on customers' bills, in order "to maintain our credit and to meet the most recent increases in costs."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The regular Republican minority in the new Congress intends to go all the way against outright repeal of the Taft-Hartley labor law, but is not likely to resist violently its substantial softening.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Britain's state-owned airlines lost 11,086,909 [about $44,500,000] in their operations for the year ending March 31, according to a report and accounts published tonight. The losses were 5 per cent higher than in the previous twelve months.

Mrs. Lorena B. Hahn, chief of the women's affairs section of the Office of Military Government of the United States, told leaders of women's groups here yesterday how they might join the Government as hostesses to thirty leading German women who are to visit this country.

The city of the future will be one which emphasizes vertical growth instead of a horizontal "sprawl" which has served to emphasize crowded conditions and unattractive planning, according to Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Heavy buying of wheat futures today by mills sent the price of that grain on the Board of Trade to a new high since April 21 on the December, with May in new ground since mid-July and July and sent September to a new seasonal high. May and July oats, September corn and May soy beans also went to a new seasonal high.

Charges and countercharges anent the foot and lung power of Gilbert's Valley Captain reverberated yesterday through Flatbush Court even though G.V.C., more familiarly known as Caesar, was absent. G.V.C., it turned out, is a 120-pound, twenty-month-old pedigreed Great Dane male who has won a blue ribbon at the Brooklyn Dog Show, but whose alleged noise in his owner's apartment was the bone of yesterday's contention.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- The steel mills of the Ruhr will be reorganized in such a fashion that they will regain control over certain coal and iron ore holdings, a high United States economics adviser said today.
Prices of rubber futures firmed on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. The near-by December standard contract, manifesting the greatest strength, advanced 15 points.

Luncheon guests in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel were treated to a view of Dein-Bacher's Palm Beach fur showing yesterday. Capes and stoles were of particular interest because of the working of the skins, which, in many instances were used horizontally rather than vertically, adding to the rounded look of the capes.

FOOTBALL scores have assumed monstrous and grotesque proportions this season. As Steve Owen sadly remarked after one of those basketball-like scoring jamborees in which his Giants repeatedly have gotten themselves involved, "Perhaps the solution is to restore the center jump." To tell the truth, the gridiron game has assumed alarming similarity to the dribble diversion.

Just as Jean-Paul Sartre, with his brand of Existentialism, is provoking discussion among savants of the present-day theatre, Elmer Rice was hailed and hooted when his expressionistic play, "The Adding Machine," was first staged here a quarter of a century ago.

Moss Hart's new comedy, "Light Up the Sky," which, like the week's earlier entry, "For Heaven's Sake, Mother!" deals with show people, will be unfolded this evening at the Royale Theatre. The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock. Joseph M. Hyman and Bernard Hart are the sponsors.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Tentative French proposals for quasi-permanent international control over the management and policy of the Ruhr's essential industries was handed today to representatives of the other powers attending the six-power Ruhr conference in London.

The influence of Paris "high style," long confined to exclusive shops and the products of custom dressmakers, may soon be evident in the clothes that women "run up" at home if a current trend among the patternmakers continues.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Jimmy Bivins of Cleveland reopened a cut above Joe Louis' left eye as the world heavyweight champion resumed his exhibition tour in a no-decision six-rounder at the Arena tonight before 10,086. The wound originally had been sustained in an exhibition with Johnny Shkor at Boston Nov. 8, when the two accidentally bumped heads.

Gasoline stocks in the United States last week were increased 418,000 barrels to 91,795,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A week earlier supplies were 91,377,000 barrels and a year ago they were 83,041,000.
All betting and attendance records for night harness racing tracks were shattered this year at Roosevelt Raceway, figures of the State Harness Racing Commission disclosed yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 17 -- J.B. Murphy, chief building and loan examiner of the Illinois Office of Auditor of Public Accounts, Springfield, was elected president of the National Association of State Savings, Building and Loan Supervisors at its ninth annual conference today in the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Hotel.

The cotton futures market closed somewhat irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 4 to 9 points higher on the day except the May, 1950, contract, which declined 1 point.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Louise Baker, author of "Out on a Limb" and "Party Line," who as a child lost a leg in an automobile accident, made a plea today for extra attention, particularly on the part of parents, to "a strong inner structure" in handicapped children.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $29,920,873 after taxes and all charges in the first nine months of this year, Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

Herb Seidell, center from Indianapolis, was elected yesterday by his Fordham team-mates as game captain for the second successive week. The only upperclassman in the Rams' starting line-up, Seidell had been one of the key men in the close contest waged against Holy Cross last week.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- A program for the curbing in Westchester of "objectionable and offensive" comic books that deal with crime and sex was adopted unanimously here this afternoon by the chiefs and other officers of the county's thirty-nine police departments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- high school football player was graduated from a school here last year, enrolled at another local high, and then played a full game this fall against his former teammates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Director-General Norris E. Dodd of the Food and Agricultural Organization today urged before the commission considering world food problems that the current FAO conference should start cooperative action among nations on food production, consumption and exchange.

Custom-designed handknit dresses and costumes were presented yesterday during luncheon at the Pierre Hotel by Mimi Pearce of 23 East Sixty-seventh Street. The designer explained her new service of creating individual patterns which a customer knits for herself.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The tribunal of inquiry into allegations of fraud in the Board of Trade completed today its investigations into one reported incident concerning a plan to use 10,000 [$40,000] to get an import license.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 17 -- The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, took decisive action yesterday to regain the membership of eight seceded New York locals. At the same time, delegates expressed unqualified opposition to all "subversive" groups within their union.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- A fourth-round wage increase for workers "is probably inevitable" and prices will rise, Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, declared here today.
Bill Fischer, Notre Dame guard, was named football lineman of the week yesterday in this week's Associated Press poll.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 -- St. Louis, more than 700 miles up the Mississippi River from the Gulf of Mexico, may become an ocean port of entry if plans for a new steamship line are carried out, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The recent election is still fresh in the minds of the real estate dealers of Washington, who, expecting a boom in real estate with a Republican victory, found instead numerous cancellations on their hands.

The inquiry being held by John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, into the affairs of the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission opened yesterday. Indignant hotel guests were on hand to say among other things that they had been threatened with eviction for not meeting rent rises assessed before the increases had been authorized.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations Steel Workers Union today revealed it is asking the Supreme Court to rule on the constitutionality of the non-Communist affidavit provision of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Eight of ten large ice cream manufacturers in Northern New Jersey shut down their plants today after representatives of their 600 unionized employes had refused to promise that the men would not strike without warning.

The gold medal of the Inter-Faith in Action Committee, which is awarded annually to a person who has distinguished himself in combatting racial and religious prejudice, was presented last night to former Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 17 -- The Northwest Airlines today reached an agreement with the United States Army authorities to establish an emergency airlift for an estimated 300 Americans stranded here by the diversion of Army transports for the removal of Americans from China.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A Congressional inquiry into the pricing policies of American business precipitated today a caustic verbal battle between Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, and Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana.

The new Federal Wage-Hour Regulations regarding Saturday, Sunday, holiday and night pay have been made effective and apply to banks, the New York State Bankers Associations said yesterday in its bulletin to members.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 17 -- Although factors are at hand to create an increasingly healthy economic situation, certain tendencies if not checked can produce a "very dangerous" development in western Germany, Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor, cautioned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, told the State and Territorial Health Officers Association today that human health, education and welfare were indivisible, and there should be a Cabinet post representing this field.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 17 -- Widespread shortages of electric power next winter are indicated as a result of "great strains" upon production capacity through sharply increased consumer demands, Richard B. McEntire, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, declared today at a convention session of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners.

Fear that the shipbuilding industry will lose thousands of its highly skilled workers and technicians within the next two years unless orders for commercial vessels are placed with private shipyards was expressed yesterday by H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Charles de Gaulle today bitterly condemned United States and British policy toward Germany, the Western European Union defense plan and the French regime.

About a month and a half has passed since Mayor O'Dwyer promised swift action on the proposal to establish a "policy making and planning" commission to grapple with New York City's traffic problems. He now hopes to have such a commission appointed by Jan. 1.

DUBLIN, Nov. 17 -- The first legislative step to sever Ireland's last link with the British Commonwealth through the Crown was taken in the Dail Eireann today when Prime Minister John A. Costello formally moved the first reading of the "Republic of Ireland Bill 1948."

MILFORD, Conn., Nov. 17 -- A round-up on the waterfowl shooting in this general area shows no scarcity of birds, with fair numbers of black duck on the marshes and large rafts of broadbill in many areas.

As landlords, the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church emerged yesterday as a possible model of solicitude for tenants' rights. Ending a long Municipal Court eviction proceeding against residents of a six-story building at 47 Claremont Avenue, the board fixed May 2, 1950, as the deadline, but only after the tenants assured the board it was all right.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Mrs. Ann Powers, 39-year-old unemployed waitress, who on Oct. 25 interrupted her trial for the murder of Police Capt. Thomas J. Rowe to plead guilty to manslaughter, was sentenced today to serve nine to ten years in the Clinton Women's Reformatory by County Judge Joseph E. Conlon. She betrayed no emotion during the proceeding.

The Atlantic Coast longshoremen's strike is going into its second week. Marshall Plan cargo piles up at the nation's piers and storage areas at the alarming rate of 20,000 tons, to a value of $2,000,000, each day. Railroads are dispensing with some of their cargo-handling staffs.

Canada Dry will follow up a preliminary tryout with an extensive large-space campaign in newspapers and magazines for its complete "family" of liquor products, it was announced yesterday. The campaign, which will use major newspapers in fourteen large cities throughout the country, is a supplement to an expanded schedule on individual brands.

We remind all our readers who want to see more effective city action against the smoke and soot nuisance that a rally at which they may express their interest will be held at 5 o'clock this afternoon at the Hunter College Playhouse, on Sixty-eighth Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

Although the longshoremen's strike has brought cargo shipping to a standstill, two sailings from this port yesterday demonstrated that some passenger lines have been able to offer service on a limited basis.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Tumult and, at one time, blows replaced the initial calm in the National Assembly as the French Government today sustained the shock of Communist attacks within the Palais Bourbon and the ironic gibes of Charles de Gaulle without.
Mrs. Oksana Stepanovna Kasenkina will leave Roosevelt Hospital tomorrow, ninety-nine days after her leap from a third-floor window of the Russian consulate set off international complications.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Nobby Warwick, the National Hockey League's top point-maker, accounted for both of the Boston Bruins' goals as they gained their fifth straight home victory with a 2-1 decision over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight before 13,900 fans at the Boston Garden.
A young man, using a pistol in lieu of a co-signer, took $700 yesterday from three women clerks of the Interboro Personal Loan Company office at 1476 Broadway at Forty-second Street.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 17 (UP) -- The "lost continent" of Atlantis never existed, a seagoing scientist claimed today after thirteen years of exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 17 -- The National Executive Board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations cleared the decks today in a five-hour session for a battle over the "Red" issue.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The Federal Government should encourage industry to expand production facilities by establishing tax incentive systems, Henry J. Kaiser, chairman of Kaiser-Frazer Corporation said today. Addressing members of the American Finance Conference, he suggested a plan of accelerated depreciation of capital investments for income tax purposes as a means of boosting output of steel and other basic materials.
