Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, the Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, appealed yesterday for trust and patience on the part of those who feel that Western Europe is not moving fast enough in the direction of federation.

THE art of writing a good travel book is more difficult than most people who try it suppose. It rarely wins much critical applause. And it rarely wins conspicuous surplus wealth. All too often this last pleasant reward is earned by the travel book that is a compound of gush, sentimentality and chitchat about shops and restaurants.
President Truman's toughmindedness in the last election was praised last night by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, as a trait that had made America great.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The American Investment Company of Illinois, St. Louis, Mo., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today proposing an exchange offering involving 168,425 shares of its Series A, $1.25 convertible preference stock, $25 par value, and 68,175.6 shares of 4 1/2 per cent preference stock, $25 par value.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- United States financial experts are flying from Washington and Berlin to Paris to study questions relating to the introduction of the Soviet zone mark as the sole currency in Berlin, authoritative sources said today. They were summoned to study the proposals presented by Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia in behalf of the six members of the United Nations Security Council not directly concerned with the Berlin dispute.

Citations honoring them for their contributions to the "cause of brotherhood and understanding among men" were presented last night to Henry Ford 2d and Roger Williams Straus at the twentieth anniversary extension fund dinner of the National Conference of Christians and Jews at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury which is conducting an anti-trust investigation of the du Pont industrial empire widened its inquiry today to include more than sixty companies.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 18 -- Pierre Cot, a former French Cabinet Minister, as counsel for Albania in the Corfu Channel mining case, told the International Court of Justice today in reply to Britain's complaint that under international law there was no right of innocent passage through territorial waters for warships.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Amazing new uses for electric power on the farm are just around the corner, Arthur W. Turner, head of agricultural engineering research for the United States Department of Agriculture, said today. He spoke at the National Farm Electrification Conference.
NEW HAVEN, CONN., Nov. 18 -- The Yale football squad completed preparation today for the climactic contest with Harvard in a spirited workout on Dewitt Cuyler Field.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Britain today introduced a resolution in the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly calling for a permanent settlement of the Palestine question on the basis of the final report by the late Count Folke Bernadotte, Mediator.
PARIS, Friday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Dr. Ralph Bunche, acting Palestine Mediator, to the seven Arab states and Israel concerning armistice negotiations:

The one bright factor in this troubled post-war world has been the growing solidarity of the Western World against the Russo-Communist tide which threatened to engulf it. This solidarity has manifested itself in the European Recovery Program, the West-European Union, and the project for a North Atlantic Alliance which would combine the power of the Old and the New World in defense of liberty and democracy against the new "progressive" slavery.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Creation of a Continental Air Command to strengthen the country's defenses against possible enemy attack was announced today by the Air Force.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 18 -- An address by Mrs. Sidonis M. Gruenberg, director of the Child Study Association of America and chairman of the National Committee for Parent Education, highlighted today's second session of the annual State Conference on Parent and Family-Life Education.

Two new films will open in local theatres this morning. At the Strand the attraction is "Fighter Squadron," a Warner Brothers adventure dealing with a wartime air group featuring Edmond O'Brien, Robert Stack and John Rodney. Seton I. Miller wrote and produced and Raoul Walsh directed.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- A military force of more than 4,000 men was preparing tonight to push its way through the barricades set up by dock workers in the battered northern port of Dunkerque. Defensive positions have already been set up by workers in anticipation of next Monday's strike, called by the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Without a single dissent, the United Nations General Assembly voted complete satisfaction today in the progress of work on its future permanent headquarters in midtown Manhattan, and gave formal thanks to the United States Government and New York State and City for their generous assistance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A tailless jet fighter, capable of over 600 miles an hour, and designed for use from carriers, has completed its basic test flights, it was reported tonight.
BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- The anti-Communist parties of Berlin's City Assembly unanimously refused today to accede to Russian orders to dismiss two high city officials.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 18 -- The Israeli Government accomplished tonight the difficult feat of accepting and rejecting at the same time the Security Council's demand for withdrawal of its victorious army from the Negeb.
PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The rights of children born out of wedlock were written into the international declaration of human rights by the Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly here today.

Two detectives finally caught last night a suspect who is said to have preyed on so many women recently, frightening them, snatching their purses and stealing their jewelry, that thirty-four detectives had to be assigned for several weeks to the scene of his operations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Labor's League for Political Education, an American Federation of Labor organization, set out today to cause a second member of the House of Representatives to be investigated for alleged Congressional payroll-padding and benefiting from kick-backs on salary checks.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 18 -- The conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization agreed tonight to admit observers of Jewish international nongovernmental organizations to the Beirut meeting if the organizations had applied.
SEA CLIFF, L. I., Nov. 18 -- Lawrence E. Graham, 28 years old, son of Mrs. Henry P. Graham of 29 Main Avenue, here, was killed yesterday in a deer-hunting accident at Wilmington, Vt.
CASCAES, Portugal, Nov. 18 -- Former King Humbert II of Italy said in an interview today he would always be prepared to return to his country as its ruler if the Italian people desired.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 18 -- A farm program of "realistic abundance" rather than restriction of crop production was advocated here today by Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture.

Brooklyn College went through its last offensive drill of the season yesterday in preparation for R.P.I. tomorrow in Flatbush. The greatest football record in the Kingsmen's history rests on tomorrow's clash as the Brooks attempt to win their eighth game of the campaign.

Domestic and foreign air carriers flying from the United States and Canada to Bermuda reported yesterday an increase in demand for frozen and fresh foods for the British resort colony. This was attributed to the dock strike by an airline spokesman who said that at present food can be delivered only by air to Bermuda.

The visitor, bearing a package wrapped loosely in newspaper and tied with what might have been binder twine, turned out to be our man with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn. Doffing his coat, from a pocket of which protruded a loaf of unwrapped bread he carefully untied the string encircling his burden, parted the paper and held up for inspection a bologna sausage.
Under a moderate volume of business prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 13 points net yesterday.

Dimitri Mitropoulos opened the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with his own orchestral transcription of the Bach G minor organ Fantasia and Fugue -- the "great" one in G minor -- and an uncommonly fine transcription it is.

The Isbrandtsen Steamship Company, Inc., of 26 Broadway, notified the owners of the Suez Canal yesterday that it was holding them responsible for all damages sustained in connection with the detention of the company's freighter Flying trader at Port Said, Egypt.

A 24-year-old man who spent nineteen months in prison for violating the 1940 Selective Service Act became the first person in this area sentenced to jail for failing to register under the 1948 version of the law when Federal Judge Harold R. Medina imposed a penalty of a year and a day on him yesterday.

Directors of the Electric Bond and Share Company declared yesterday, subject to approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission, a dividend on the common stock of the company payable on Dec. 24. This will be the first dividend on the common stock since an initial cash disbursement of 25 cents was made on Nov. 20, 1947.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis is conducting a "Marshall Plan" of its own to help the world on poliomyelitis, Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, declared yesterday. He spoke at the closing session of the foundation's four-day annual conference of state advisers at the Pierre Hotel.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A murderer was hanged at Norwich prison today in the first execution since the great and fruitless parliamentary controversy of the past year on capital punishment.

NANKING, Nov. 18 -- The Ministry of Defense continued to assert today that the Nationalist forces on the Lung-Hai railway line had scored an "unprecedented victory" east of Suchow, with the Government ground and air forces inflicting 130,000 casualties on the Communists, compared with 40,000 Nationalist losses.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Andre Marie, Minister of Justice, told the National Assembly today that the Government required a special series of laws to enable it to crush the new type of subversive activities described by Jules Moch, Minister of the Interior, as having been devised during the French coal strike.
The stock market lapsed yesterday into inaction.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal Court has overruled the state's motion to dismiss two suits challenging Alabama's Boswell Amendment. Judge John McDuffie, a member of the court, said today that a hearing on the merits of the suits against the voter qualification law, called one of the last bars to mass Negro voting in Alabama, would be held at an early date.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A recommendation that the Government own or control studio space which it could make available to independent British film producers was contained in a report published today by a special Government committee set up to consider the plan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Press Wireless, Inc., proposed today to the Federal Communications Commission a rise of one to two cents a word in most of its overseas press rates.
When the military pulled out of here after the war, the British, the natives and the missionaries raced with the jungle to fill the vacuum.

Lloyd B. Reid, former City Traffic Engineer of Detroit, will be named to the dual posts of chairman and consultant for this city's proposed traffic commission that will be established by local law by Jan. 1, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

DON'T look now, but the football season is almost at an end. The majority of the nation's colleges will close shop on the morrow, leaving just a few stragglers to wind up activities on Thanksgiving Day, the following Saturday and beyond. So this is virtually the last blind stare into the crystal ball.

Articles for the fight between Ray Robinson, Harlem welterweight who holds the world championship in his division, and Steve Belloise of the Bronx, were signed yesterday in the headquarters of the Tournament of Champions. The pair will meet in the Jersey City Armory on Dec. 9, a postponement from the original date of Dec. 2.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 18 -- An over-all reduction of 3 per cent in deaths caused by motor vehicle accidents in the last year was reported to the annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners today by C. L. Doherty, chairman of the association's committee on safety of operation.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The United Nations General Assembly accepted today the contention of the United States that the contributions of any one member country to the operating budget of the world organization should at some time in the future be limited to one-third the total.

Increased competition has brought larger promotional expenditures by department and specialty stores, according to a new study of these retailers' advertising and publicity spending announced yesterday by John H. Kavanaugh, general manager of the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

KEY WEST, Nov. 18 -- There was no discussion of whether James Forrestal would remain in the Cabinet during the visit of the Secretary of Defense with President Truman here today, Charles G. Ross, Presidential press secretary, told reporters.

At a meeting that packed the Council Chamber at City Hall the Community Service Society set in motion yesterday an emergency campaign to raise $1,400,000 by public solicitation to maintain its work in behalf of troubled families in this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The dramatic phase of the Nov. 2 election was, of course, the personal nature of President Truman's victory. His never-say-die attitude against strong opposition, first from the state leaders of his own party and the union labor chiefs who affiliate with it and then from what seemed to be a national trend, lent to the President's election one of the principal elements of drama.

This week the Sugar Branch of the Department of Agriculture conducted hearings to which it invited all persons interested in the determination of next year's consumption requirements for the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today that a major cause of high prices in the United States was a threefold increase in the money supply over the last ten years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 -- Vice Admiral William Ward Smith, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, told a press conference today that the commission was eager to get out of the shipping busness in favor of private enterprise.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 18 -- The United Council of Churchwomen ended its fourth biennial assembly here today with the unanimous adoption of a series of resolutions calling for the "immediate abolition of segregation and discrimination in the armed services, endorsing Federal aid to education and urging a broadening of social security legislation.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 -- Seven batteries of fog-piercing krypton lights, comprising forty-two in all, are being rushed to completion by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation here for installation by the Air Force at German airfields used in the Berlin airlift, it was announced here today.

Action the Board of Estimate yesterday paved the way for adding to the proposed 1949 capital budget $165,000 to meet the cost of rehabilitation or demolition of historic Claremont Inn at Riverside Drive and 124th Street, just north of Grant's Tomb.

The city Board of Higher Education began consideration yesterday of preliminary budget requests from the four municipal colleges that would bring the sum needed for 1949-50 to $19,390,000, about two and a quarter million dollars more than was granted by the Board of Estimate for the public colleges last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The United States, Great Britain and Canada closed a 100-year-old gap balking industrial cooperation today with formal signing of an agreement for the standardization of screw threads.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Periodic checking of bank loans to prevent frauds was supported here today at the closing session of the annual midwinter conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association.
GARDEN CITY, Kan., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A snowstorm blew eastward tonight from the Great Plains after halting highway travel and disrupting communications in six states.
BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- Jacob Aronson of New York, vice president of the New York Central Railroad, today was elected chairman of the board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

LONDON, Ont., Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) -- The Olympic movemeant, with its "inherent sense of fair play and sportsmanship, has captured the imagination of the world," Avery Brundage, chairman of the United States Olympic Committee, said here tonight.
ROME, Nov. 18 (Overseas News Agency) -- A unique medical institution that radios advice to ships at sea whose crew members take sick is one of Italy's most appreciated maritime services today.

ATHENS, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- The 87-year-old Premier Sophoulis ended the drawn-out Greek Cabinet crisis today with a Parliamentary loss of fifty-eight votes, chiefly from the split in his Lib eral party caused by the opposition of Sophocles Venizelos.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Declaring that an f.o.b. pricing system apparently was beneficial to big business and detrimental to small business and consumers, Senator Homer E. Capehart said today that it "might be necessary to subpoena the records" of some large industries to determine how much they have profited by this method.

Lorri Lail, mezzo-soprano, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. The program contained the aria, "Ah, mio core, schernito sei," from Handel's "Alcina"; Scarlatti's "Se Florindo e fedele," Schubert's "Der Atlas," "Der Wegweiser," "Die Liebe hat gelogen" and "Der Zwerg"; Wolf's "Auf eine Wanderung."

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18 -- Radioactive isotopes have proved to be an effective guide in diagnosis of hardening of the arteries, the United States chapter of the International College of Surgeons was told today.
A thorough revision of the city's seventy-five-year-old Sanitary Code has been authorized by the Board of Health, it was learned yesterday.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 18 -- President Truman and James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, conferred for forty-five minutes today almost wholly on European affairs. The crisis in China was not discussed, it was said officially.

The ballroom suite of the Plaza i was filled to capacity yesterday afternoon and evening for the tenth annual White Elephant Cocktail Party and Tea Dance in aid of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

Free public education in the city schools is being endangered by pressure groups that have a direct effect on decisions of top-ranking school officials, speakers at a meeting sponsored by fourteen civic, religious, education, parent and political organizations declared last night.

The Legal Aid Society gives to the judicial process a service essential to the true administration of justice, and to it should go a great deal of the credit for the fact that in New York State each person, rich or poor, gets his day in court, Robert P. Patterson, president of the Bar Association of the City of New York and former Secretary of War, declared yesterday.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, ordered an investigation of Public School 153, Queens, yesterday immediately after hearing a charge that first-year children have to bring their own chairs to classes because the Board of Education has provided no furniture for nearly a year and a half.

Prominent in a trio of group and one-man exhibitions is the first showing by members of the Creative Art Associates at the Riverside Museum. This group is a heterogeneous alliance of veteran exhibitors and neophytes, but happily their work maintains a general evenness of quality that such an arrangement might not be expected to provide.

A conference at City Hall yesterday between Mayor O'Dwyer and Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency, lent support to reports that the Mayor planned to ask next year for direct allocation of Government funds in aid of the city's school construction program.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 18 -- The family of Ruth Eisenberg, a young nurse of this city who disappeared more than three months ago, learned late this afternoon of the positive identification of her body.

Red Strader, whose Yankees must face the undefeated Cleveland Browns at the Stadium, and Carl Voyles, whose Dodgers tangle with the once-defeated San Francisco Forty-Niners at Ebbets Field Sunday, "took steps" yesterday aiming toward improvement of their squads.

Doubt of an early settlement in the Atlantic Coast longshoremen's strike was expressed yesterday by a Federal conciliator despite the scheduled resumption of talks of dock workers and their employers at 11 o'clock this morning.

The municipal bond market is keeping an eye on current developments suggestive of the kind of Federal housing legislation the Administration in Washington is likely to enact. Present expectations are for a redraft of the Taft-Ellender-Wagner bill offering municipalities direct subsidies for low-rent housing, slum clearance and urban redevelopment.

The first gas-turbine electric locomotive to be built in the United States now is undergoing track tests at the plant of the General Electric Company at Erie, Pa. After further tests have been completed in the East, the new locomotive, built by General Electric and the American Locomotive Company is scheduled to be placed in operation on a demonstration basis next spring by the Union Pacific Railroad, it was announced yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 -- Harvard held its final full-length practice at Soldier's Field today. After the light workout, the team jogged from the field through the traditional aisle of burning red flares.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Montana Stable's Accountant easily won the mile and thirty-yard Lonesome Lake Purse at Rockingham Park today, finishing four lengths ahead of Carl F. Herrmann's Float Me for a $9.20 mutuel pay-off.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Permission to substitute thirty-inch pipe for 1,210 miles of twenty-six-inch pipe in the $191,310,154 transcontinental natural gas line from Texas to New York City, has been granted by the Federal Power Commission, it was announced today.

The American Review of Soviet Medicine, which has served during the last five years as the only bridge linking medical workers in Soviet Russia with their colleagues on the other side of the Iron Curtain, has announced that the current issue, released yesterday, is to be the last, "at least for the time being."

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Santa Claus spoke to the British public today through the husky figure of John Strachey, Minister of Food, but with the austere voice of Sir Stafford Cripps, who holds the money bags. Christmas stockings will hold even fewer extra rations than last year.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Leaders of the European Council operating under the Marshall Plan now estimate that they may complete the long-awaited unified European Recovery Program for four years by the end of March.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers scored 26 points in a wild final quarter tonight to defeat the Baltimore Bullets, 67 -- 55, in a Basketball Association of America contest.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Working rapidly, the six-power conference on the Ruhr completed today its examination of the British, French and United States proposals for the establishment of an International Authority to allocate the output of the Ruhr's coal, coke and steel industries.

At a time when most amateur gardeners are hanging up their hoes and preparing to hibernate for a few months, the staff of the New York Botanical Garden is beginning to move into high gear, preparing for two forthcoming flower shows and bedding down most of their plant charges for the winter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- During the week ended Nov. 17, member reserve balances increased $6,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The United States moved today to bolster the hard-pressed Chinese Nationalist Government, ordering immediate emergency food shipments through the Economic Cooperation Administration to north and central China cities with a combined population of 12,270,000.
Beginning New Year's Day, the Pennsylvania Hotel will bear the name Statler Hotel.
Passing, running and kicking featured New York University's practice session at Ohio. Field yesterday. The Violet will meet Kings Point tomorrow at Tomb Memorial Field, Great Neck, L.I.

A team representing the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States will make a tour of Europe this winter. The highlight of the trip will be participation in the world's championship tournament in Stockholm, it was announced by Tommy Lockhart at a meeting of the New York Hockey Writers Association at Leone's yesterday.

A confessed apprentice pickpocket shamefacedly admitted in the Police Headquarters line-up yesterday that he had flunked his "examination" the night before despite the presence of two veteran "teachers." The novice, Plunk Williams of 2407 Seventh Avenue, a 37-year-old waiter, hung his head and told Acting Capt. John J. Cronin Jr., that, although he had tried hard to pick pockets, he had never actually succeeded.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -- Conferences held today between Ellis Arnall, former Governor of Georgia, and the executive committee of the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers at the Samuel Goldwyn Studio here indicated that Arnall may replace Donald Nelson, who resigned this year, as president of the society.

Norsemen probably established settlements in America at least one to two hundred years before the arrival of Christopher Columbus in the new world, in the opinion of Prof. Johannes Broensted, director of the National Museum at Copenhagen, Denmark, and one of the world's foremost scholars in Viking and medieval archeology.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) -- G.B. Gordon, president of Dominion Textile Co., Ltd., and Montreal Cottons, Ltd., announced last night that, consequent upon an earlier offer, Dominion Textile now was owner of all common stock of Montreal Cottons.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday estimated that its consolidated net income in the first nine months of this year approximated $290,000,000 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $10.25 a share on the capital stock outstanding.
PARIS, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The text of the British draft resolution on Palestine, submitted today to the United Nations Assembly Political Committee, follows:

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 18 -- Describing the situation in China as "extremely critical" the National Foreign Relations Commission of the American Legion charged today that a Communist blockade exists in Pacific Coast ports of the United States.
The five-story tenement building at 1955 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, accommodating thirty-seven families, has been sold by the Henard Holding Corporation to the 1651 Washington Avenue Corporation.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- In a series of unanimous votes, the United Nations General Assembly called today for greater educational opportunities for natives of trust territories and more emphasis on training for eventual independence.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation, in its operating statement for the first nine months of this year issued yesterday by C.N. Hilton, president, disclosed an increase in gross revenue to $31,072,642 from $30,613,807 for the corresponding period a year ago.

Two bills designed to cut the automobile accident rate will be introduced at the next session of the Legislature, State Senator Seymour Halpern, Queens, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems, announced yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 18 -- The Yugoslavs disclosed today that they had ordered a drastic upward revision of production targets under the five-year plan to meet the challenge of difficulties created by the allegedly discriminatory trade practices of the Communist Information Bureau bloc against Yugoslavia of which Premier Marshal Tito complained in his speech in Ljubljana on Tuesday.

Charge account collections for leading department, men's wear and women's wear stores here are down slightly from collections during this period last year, credit authorities disclosed here yesterday. Of twelve key stores reporting collections last month, seven showed declines against five with mall increases.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 18 -- Plans to ask the Government for $500,000,000 revolving fund to set up a huge stockpile of wheat and corn took shape today at a meeting of Farmers Union officers.

The doors will open at 10 A.M. today for the second annual Boys' and Girls' Book Fair at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street. A Children's Book Week event, the four-day fair is sponsored by the museum, THE NEW YORK TIMES and the Children's Book Council.

Painstaking studies for technological improvement are needed to put cotton on a par with competitive fibers for specific uses, it was pointed out yesterday by Walter M. Scott, director of the Southern Research Laboratory, United States Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The view of Henry Ford 2d that a fourth-round wage increase is "probably inevitable" may be based in part on the fact that one of his Ford Motor Company's principal competitors, the General Motors Corporation, already is committed to a three-cent increase next spring, labor sources suggested today.
PRINCE RUPERT, B. C., Nov. 18 (Canadian Press ) -- Canadian competition in freight shipments to Alaska likely would be one result of Alaska's rise to statehood, Gov. Ernest Gruening predicted today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 -- An exhaustive medical survey of smog conditions in the Monongahela River Valley sector was promised here today by the United States Public Health Service. It was announced at the annual meeting of the Industrial Hygiene Foundation at the Mellon Institute.

Frank Lloyd Wright, the architect, gave details yesterday of his plans for a "theatre of the future," designed on revolutionary principles, that will be erected next spring on the outskirts of Hartford, Conn.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- A market for 500,000,000 pairs of shoes annually is attainable, based upon the style consciousness of the American public and its need for low-priced shoes, Mark A. Edison, president of the National Association of Shoe Chain Stores and vice president of Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., said here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Nov. 13, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's comprehensive index reached 162.6 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.3 per cent below that of four weeks ago, but 2.6 per cent above that for the corresponding week of last year.

President Truman aptly bespoke the sentiments of the entire nation when, in his message congratulating the winners of the 1948 Lasker awards, he conveyed "the gratitude of the Government and of millions of Americans for outstanding contributions to the health of our people."

OSSIPEE, N.H., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Miss Ruth Eisenberg, 22, missing Newark (N.J.) nurse, was slain struggling with an attacker who jammed her silk underwear down her throat and threw her body in a lonely, foxhole grave, a medical examiner said tonight.

Pondering a collection of adverse notices, David Kay, sponsor of "For Heaven's Sake, Mother!" wasn't certain yesterday whether the Julie Berns comedy would continue after its seventh performance tomorrow night at the Belasco.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, breaking after an early showing of strength when December wheat advanced 1/2 cent to a new high since last April. Corn, however, weakened, causing all grains to decline sharply.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 -- Words of praise for the contemporary American family were delivered today by national authorities on family life at the opening session of the fifth biennial meeting of the Family Service Association of America.

A program to convert Tammany Hall into a civic-minded body to rid the New York County Democratic organization of a "stigma that has plagued it for more than a hundred years" was outlined yesterday afternoon by Manhattan Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, the Tammany leader.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- A national increase of 10 per cent in productivity can be obtained as a practical means of stopping the inflation spiral, Arthur J. Wieland, executive vice president, Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., Toledo, Ohio, declared here today.

The police of the midtown area were put on the alert last night in an effort to catch a man, believed to be traveling in a taxicab, who this week has wounded four persons with BB shot from an air rifle.

President Truman's naming of John Foster Dulles as Acting Chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations during the absence from Paris of Secretary of State Marshall, who is flying to Washington for a conference, is a notice to the rest of the world that the election has not altered the bipartisan approach to problems of foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The National Labor Relations Board heard argument today on a conflict between the secondary boycott ban in the Taft-Hartley Law and the free speech guarantees of the law and the Constitution.

The National Employment Board soon will conduct a mail ballot survey of its 200 private employment agency members in thirty-four states in an attempt to raise its current standards of practice, Mrs. Ruth Saugrain announced yesterday. She made the announcement at closing sessions of the board's sixteenth convention in the New Yorker Hotel.

Mindful of the bruising fight his team had on its hands in winning from Syracuse a year ago, Lou Little sounded a word of admonition yesterday for the benefit of those who regard Columbia as a sure thing in the Lions' finale with the Orange at Baker Field tomorrow.

Books by the brothers La Farge, Oliver and Christopher, are on the spring lists of two concerns. Oliver La Farge has written an account of the Air Transport Command, entitled "The Eagle in the Egg," which will be brought out by Houghton Mifflin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- The National Research Council today disclosed the formation of an American Geological Institute to help the geologic profession give greater service to the country.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 18 -- President Truman emphasized today that United States foreign policy would remain non-partisan by appointing John Foster Dulles, Governor Dewey's principal adviser on foreign affairs, as acting chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly in Paris.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 18 -- Elated by a forthright stand taken by President Philip Murray against the pro-Communist minority in the Congress of Industrial Organizations, right-wing members of the resolutions committee pushed ahead today with the intention of bringing the "Red" issue to the CIO convention floor by means of at least two resolutions.

The close competition that has featured the international six-day bicycle race at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory since its start on Sunday continued last night. As some 3,000 onlookers cheered, the ten teams maintained their sustained speedy riding.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18 -- Max Eastman, representing The New Leader of New York City, unsparingly condemned the Government's Far Eastern policy today in an address to the convention of the American Federation of Labor. He said that this policy was based on the "Moscow-manufactured hoax" that the Chinese Communists "were some kind of the middle-of-the-road agrarian liberals, who had no connection whatever with the Comintern."

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- John Foster Dulles, a member of the United States delegation at the United Nations, urged the democracies of Western Europe today to encourage the trend to a united Europe and to create an "unassailable citadel of freedom and well-being."

There were indications yesterday that the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission might rescind its recent order under which 230 hotels have increased rents of permanent guests up to 12 per cent. Such action would bring refunds to hotel residents who have been paying the higher rent since Oct. 1.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Arrested after a chase by a state trooper, which ended when their automobile collided with a truck and showered out counterfeit $10 bills and live chickens and turkeys on Camden-New York Route 25, near Roebling, two Bronx men were held tonight in Burlington County jail, here, for questioning in connection with passing bogus money.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov 13 1948, totaled 871,677 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 28,511 cars, or 3.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 6,606 cars, or 0.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 45,447 cars, or 5 per cent fewer, than during the corresponding week of 1946.

Widespread practice of "Fair Trade" has served as a valuable brake on inflation, members of the American Fair Trade Council, Inc., were told yesterday at their annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. They were warned, however, to be on the alert for cut prices and Fair Trade violations as the public's high spendable income "begins to run thin."

Before Mrs. Oksana Stepanova Kasenkina, the Russian schoolteacher, leaves Roosevelt Hospital this morning, she will hold a party for hospital personnel who have cared for her and will serve a good old American dish -- strawberry shortcake.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, Democratic national chairman, indicated today that he would favor replacing the Congressional Committee experts appointed by the Republicans in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 13 were 9 per cent below sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1947:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Strong indications that the triumphant Democrats in the new Congress intend to follow a policy of forgive-and-forget toward those who bolted in November, both at the left and right wings of the party, came today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Cleveland's Municipal Stadium was operating in the black today for the first time since its opening in 1931.
A winter collection of custom designs by Kreinick of 62 East Fifty-fifth Street was presented yesterday during luncheon at the Plaza Hotel.

A policy inviting churches and synagogues to sponsor Camp Fire groups was accepted unanimously yesterday by 100 delegates at a meeting of the National Council of Ca Fire Girls in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Business loans by banks in this area declined moderately last week, falling $32,000,000 to $5,639,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Repayments by sales finance, linseed oil, steel and airplane companies accounted for the reduction in borrowings from the twenty-five New York City member banks during the week ended on Wednesday.
The letter of Fred G. Hoffherr in your issue of Nov. 12 on the political scene in France contains a good bit of misinformation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Michigan's wily Wolverines and Ohio State's rebounding Buckeyes are set for Saturady's No. 1 football fracas -- a Big Nine game due to draw 80,000 fans into the big horseshoe stadium on the banks of the Olentangy.
TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 18 -- The Chase two-motored C-122 newly designed assault troop-cargo plane made successful test flights here today at Mercer Field before high Air Force and Army officers.

The City Council sent to its committee on civil employes yesterday a resolution calling on Mayor O'Dwyer, Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson and the Municipal Civil Service Commission to reduce promptly the "army" of provisional city employes and fill their places from civil service eligible lists.

The World Association of Mothers for Peace, which hopes to promote peace among the peoples of all races and lands and to establish communication with the mothers of the world, has been founded by Mrs. Victoria Booth Demarest, grand-daughter of Gen. William and Catherine Booth, founders of the Salvation Army, it was reported yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Brookmeade Stable's Me Always, apprentice Clarence Picou's third winner today, coasted into the finish line in the Colmar Manor Purse for 3-year-old fillies. The daughter of Menow, racing before a crowd of 8,878, was three lengths in front of Evening Rose, who ran a like margin ahead of Discovert in the field of eight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Two groups of stockholders today opposed before the Interstate Commerce Commission a proposal of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad to lease the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Company.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 18 -- Roger Dumontier, described by the police as a past master at passing worthless checks, slipped out of the hands of a patrolman on Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, last night and left his bride of a month to face charges of possessing stolen goods and a pistol today.

KINGSTON, N.J., Nov. 18 -- A day in the field with the Feather Dusters Club never fails to constitute what most pheasant hunters would term "an adventure with fowling pieces," and today's program was no exception.

Felix Nieto del Rio, Chilean Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday that his hope for a better public knowledge of Latin America in the United States was based on the fact that pan-Americanism was an indispensable element of world order.
PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A sweeping reorganization is now taking place in the Government-owned British Overseas Airways Corporation, under the direction of Sir Miles Thomas, former vice president of the Nuffield automobile manufacturing organization, who is regarded as one of the top trouble shooters in British industry.

After a study under way for about a year, the Regional Plan Association has now published a report on population trends in the metropolitan area for the seven years 1940-1947, which brings us up fairly well to date and offers guidance on some of our most critical problems.
United Nations site planners spent some time yesterday, chasing shadows.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The tribunal of inquiry into allegations of corruption in some Government departments was devoted almost entirely today to the questioning of a football pool promoter, Harry Sherman. He had "loaned," as he put it, 12,000 [about $48,000] to Sydney Stanley, a friend of John W. Belcher, Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Trade.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- Douglas C. Abbott, Canadian Minister of Finance, warned today that unless the United States increased its purchases of Dominion goods, his country would "be forced" to take reciprocal, restrictive measures.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A formal pledge by Britain's organized labor to cooperate with the Government and management in a drive for greater productivity was given here today at a special meeting of trade union leaders representing 180 unions affiliated with the powerful Trades Union Congress.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- With the accent on offense, Pennsylvania held its first scrimmage of the week today in preparation for Cornell's annual visit to Franklin Field on Thanksgiving Day.

The Brooklyn Museum is opening to the public today a comprehensive survey of American marine painting from 1800 to the present time. It is entitled "The Coast and the Sea," and it has been given a spacious and relatively chronological installation, by John I.H. Baur, curator of paintings and sculpture, in the special exhibition galleries on the main floor.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Most complaints concerning Pullman accommodations arise from a lack of sufficient private room space on the more popular trains and on those making seasonal runs, Justin J. Nolan, assistant passenger traffic manager of the Pullman Company, said today at the Interstate Commerce Commission's investigation into reserved space sales practices.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor, Arturo Michelangeli, piano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Bernard Greenhouse, 'cello, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Busch Quartet, Town Hall, 8:30; New York Little Symphony, Joseph Barone, conductor, Gordon Staples, violin, Tessa Ye, piano, Ulysses Kay, composer-conductor, Times Hall, 8:30; "Tosca," City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; Richard Hankinson, piano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Apart from the gold share section, where the favorites were in demand, the stock market here was quiet today. Cape buying was followed by London and some useful gains were seen at the close.

Philip H. Willkie, 28-year-old Indiana legislator and son of the late Wendell Willkie, proposed yesterday a national Republican conference convention in 1949 at which amateur and professional leaders might chart a more dynamic program for the party.

After eighteen years Moss Hart still has a good deal of "Once in a Lifetime" left in his system. In "Light Up the Sky," which opened at the Royale last evening, he has diverted it from Hollywood to Broadway in a loud, broad, tempestuous comedy that is acted at top speed by a wonderful cast.

An informal period of light music is the assignment of Adele Girard, harpist, and Johnny Andrews, singer-pianist, for WNBT's "Easy Does It," the television feature making its bow Tuesday night from 7 to 7:30 o'clock. The program, to be limited to the metropolitan area, also will be put on the air Fridays from 6:45 to 7:10 P.M., with arrangements under way for its extension to a five-a-week schedule.

An inexcusable by-product of the current maritime strike is the failure of the mails to go through. This is not so much the fault of the longshoremen, or of the shipping companies and the stevedoring employers, as it is of the United States Government and its departmental executives, who have been almost lackadaisical about this unhappy situation.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 17 -- Crossing the border from India into Pakistan after some months absence, one is immediately struck by the fear and suspicion of India that exists in this Moslem Dominion.

Chicago, Ill., Sanitary District yesterday sold $13,265,000 of construction bonds due Jan. 1, 1968, and callable from 1951 to 1968 to a syndicate headed by Chicago banks at an interest cost of 2.324 per cent figured to the call date and of 2.346 per cent figured to maturity.
The State Department of Education will be asked by local school authorities to prepare less difficult literacy tests for future first-voters, it was learned yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Coach Charlie Caldwell, still assigning his Princeton eleven a defensive role in its final game against Dartmouth Saturday, gave the Tigers another look at the Indian T-formation attack in their last scrimmage of the year today on University Field.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The United Nations General Assembly began tonight the last phase of its drawn-out debate on the reduction of armaments. The delegates were expected to vote overwhelmingly against the Soviet resolution -- defeated in committee and subcommittee -- calling upon the Big Five to slash armies, navies and air forces by one-third.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- John D.G. Gennerich, manager of the regional office of the International Business Machines Corporation in Mount Vernon, was found shot to death here this afternoon in the woods beside Ridgeway, west of Mamareck Avenue.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The National Grange Convention urged Federal financial aid for education today, but under conditions guaranteeing local control of school policies. Such help is needed by many schools, a resolution said, if adequate education opportunities are to be offered all children.

The price women will pay for Thanksgiving turkeys will not be announced by retailers until tomorrow, the City Department of Markets said yesterday. But a hint of how disheartening the cost will be came earlier this week, when the small turkeys (those less than thirteen pounds) now being offered again increased, to reach an average of 79 cents a pound.

VIENNA, Ga., Nov. 18 -- Senator Walter F. George of Georgia, who will return to the chairmanship of the Senate Finance Committee in January, asserted today that increased aid to Western Europe and additional funds for rational defense ruled out any hope for an income tax cut in 1949.

In the torrent of words poured forth by commentators in explaining, analyzing and interpreting the Dewey defeat, a cardinal reason has not been shown in its true perspective. The failure of Dewey was in large measure a reflection of American industry's failure properly to explain its policies and problems to the people.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 18 -- The German recovery program is due for an abrupt jolt when the facts about the financing of industrial development are faced, in the opinion of the highest Western Allied financial experts here.

ATHENS, Nov. 18 -- The revived Populist-Liberal coalition Cabinet under Premier Themistocles Sophoulis and with Constantin Tsaldaris as Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister, was sworn in today by King Paul.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The American Veterans of World War II today sued the Veterans Administration for alleged misinterpretation of law in restricting flight training for veterans under the vocational training program.

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice president of the City Council, assured an anti-smoke meeting in the Hunter College Playhouse yesterday afternoon that his smoke abatement bill, now before the City Council, would be law before the end of the year and in effect by March 1.

VIENNA, Nov. 18 -- Headquarters of the United States forces in Austria denied today that Irving Ross, a member of the Marshall Plan Mission here who was murdered Oct. 31, had been engaged in any form of intelligence activities by the United States Army or any other United States Government agency.

No announcement of the name of the man who will coach the Fordham football team next year will be made until after Nov. 28, Graduate Athletic Manager Jack Coffey said yesterday in a statement designed to cut short speculation about the possible dismissal of Coach Ed Danowski, whose contract expires after the Nov. 27 contest with New York University.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 (AP) -- There may be many anxious hours of waiting next Monday before the Rose Bowl vote of the Pacific Coast Conference is announced. "Anytime after 9 o'clock Monday morning (Pacific daylight time)," said the Conference commissioner's office today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- The United States rejected today a proposal by dollar-short nations to transfer a larger share of the cost of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization to this country.
Hide futures prices declined 50 to 60 points in trading yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Near-by December delivery sold off 60 points. Transactions aggregated 59 lots or 2,360,000 pounds.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 18 -- J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, has assumed "dictatorial power" in naming regional committees for supervising reclamation, irrigation, hydro-electric construction and operation projects, Harry E. Polk, president of the National Reclamation Association, asserted here today.

In consideration of cautiousness shown in buying by department stores, the blouse manufacturing industry will be conservative in its production during the coming season, Abraham Rosenthal, president of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc., told members of the group yesterday at the annual meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

HAMBURG, Nov. 18 -- The German heavyweight champion Hein Ten Hoff, was signed on a provisional two-year contract tonight by Lew Burston, representing the New York promoter, Mike Jacobs, and Emil Jung, Ten Hoff's manager who is also his father-in-law.
NANKING, Nov. 18 -- Details were disclosed here today on the exchange of letters between Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and President Truman on the Chinese civil war crisis.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Princeton and Dartmouth, two sophomore-laden teams that have grown steadily stronger this fall, will close out their 1948 campaigns in Palmer Stadium tomorrow with the invading Indians favored to win and thereby clinch third place in final Ivy League standings.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Aggressive buying of wheat futures featured trading in grain on the Board of Trade today. December wheat sold at a new high since April 20, and the July and September deliveries at new seasonal highs, the new crop months moving up rapidly in the face of favorable rain or snow over a wide area in the West and Southwest.
A work stoppage of 4,000 truck drivers, members of Local 282, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, was threatened yesterday for Monday morning.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 19 -- Dr. Marcus W. Collins, Professor of Sociology at John B. Stetson University at Deland, received the annual award of the Florida Academy of Science today at the academy's annual dinner at the University of Miami.

SEYMOUR, Ind., Nov. 19 (AP) -- At least eleven men were burned tonight when the "Big Inch" natural gas pipeline exploded at a pumping station eight miles north-east of here. State Police said one man was unaccounted for more than two hours after the blast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Demand for complete certainty in the interpretation of the law with respect to pricing policies of American business is one that is "impossible'' to satisfy, Walter B. Wooden, associate general counsel of the Federal Trade Commission said today

Out on the West Coast, where the favorite adjectives are "colossal" and "super-colossal," there's a type of crab that makes our own Eastern variety look as if malnutrition had stunted its growth. This giant of the crab clan is known as the Dungeness to its many devotees; it is found in the waters off the coasts of Washington, Oregon and California as far south as San Francisco.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Ohio Republicans, although badly beaten in the November elections, did not jump today at the chance for a recount.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 19 -- The creation of an Atlantic bloc expanding the military alliance of the Western Union Powers to both sides of the ocean and from Scandinavia to the Iberian Peninsula is a strategical necessity, according to Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, Premier of Portugal.

Charges that The Tablet, official newspaper of the Roman Catholic diocese of Brooklyn, exerted "pressure" on Board of Education officials to influence public school policy drew a reply yesterday from Andrew G. Clauson Jr., board president, that no such pressure had been exerted on him.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- This venerable city, a haven of the oppressed for 300 years, welcomed today its latest deputation, 802 displaced Europeans who arrived aboard the United States Army transport Omar Bundy as a new day broke over America's East Coast.

Last Summer's program of the New York City Youth Board, the first project undertaken by the new agency, in which 50,000 children from the fifteen police precincts with the highest rates of juvenile delinquency participated, was highly successful in the over-all picture and should be continued, the board's first report declared yesterday.

Medical science is not resting on its laurels in its successful development of the penicillin cure for venereal diseases, but is constantly seeking new remedies as a safeguard against the possibility that the drug would lose its effectiveness against syphilis and gonorrhea.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19 -- The football game that brought on the intercollegiate madness and decided the composition of the all America team before anyone in the East had heard of Notre Dame go into its sixty-fifth edition here tomorrow.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- The board of trustees of the State University announced today the appointment of Dr. Alvin Christian Eurich, acting president of Stanford University, as chief executive official of the board. The appointment is effective Jan. 1.
The inflationary spiral climbed a little higher last night before 1,200 of the nation's, leaders in finance, business and Government in the grand ballroom of the Astor Hotel.

Striking longshoremen, who have paralyzed Atlantic Coast shipping in a ten-day walkout from Maine to Virginia, reduced their wage demands last night in making an apparent "settlement" offer to the employers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Application of business methods to the promotion of civil rights, particularly in the case of funds and personnel, was urged here today by Leo M. Cherne of New York, secretary of the Research Institute of America, in an address before the second annual Conference on Intergroup Relations.

Sermons on Thanksgiving will be preached in many churches here tomorrow. The Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig will preach on "Gratitude, the Christian Motive" at 11 A.M. in the West End Collegiate Church, Seventy-seventh Street, West of Broadway.

After forty-three years Miss Belle da Costa Greene is stepping down as director of the Pierpont Morgan Library. Much that this remarkable institution today represents can be attributed to the earnest scholarship of Miss Greene. Her wide range of interest in cultural treasures is reflected in the library's fine paintings, its unusual collection of illuminated manuscripts, its rare volumes and letters, its etchings, stained glass and pottery.

The first airplane returned yesterday to the United States, place of its world-shaking birth, with less stir than was caused when the Wright brothers first flew it from the dunes of Kitty Hawk, N.C., forty-five years ago next Dec. 17.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin said today that he would ask the new Congress to lower estate taxes. His bill, he said, would make these exemptions:

Opposition to gambling devices to raise funds for Protestant churches has been raised in an open letter to Bronx Protestant churches by the Rev. Russell Damstra, chairman of the Human Relations Committee of the Bronx Division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, and by the Rev. H. Norman Sibley, president of the council's Bronx division, the latter announced yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The tribunal of inquiry into allegations of fraud in the Board of Trade completed its first week's investigations today. Once more Harry Sherman, football pool promoter, spent the entire day answering questions concerning his former belief that the money he had paid to one Sydney Stanley found its way in part into the pockets of John W. Belcher, Parliamentary Secretary of the Board of Trade, and others.

In an accelerated drive to curb double parking, one of the city's "most insolvable" traffic headaches, the police will send added summons details roving through Manhattan streets, it was learned last night.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Nine Labor Members of Parliament protested today against the decision to hand over control of the Ruhr's essential industries to German trustees.
CAIRO, Nov. 19 -- The reigning Queens of Egypt and Iran, who bore no sons to inherit the thrones, have been divorced by their royal husbands.

The pricing of two-large bond issues -- $50,000,000 of Public Service Electric and Gas Company fifteen-year debentures and $40,000,000 of Chesapeake Ohio Railway twenty-five-year bonds -- will occupy the attention of bond houses early next week. Bidding on the Public Service issue will take place on Monday, and on the C. O. issue on Tuesday.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Premier Henri Queuille at the close tonight of a our-day debate asked the National Assembly in effect to give the Government on Tuesday a vote of confidence as against the Communist.

A plea to the Treasury Department for "equitable" use of the last-in-first-out (Lifo) method of inventory valuation by retailers was disclosed yesterday by Robert A. Seidel, chairman of the National Retail Dry Goods Association's executive committee and vice president of the W.T. Grant Company, at the annual meeting of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- Representatives of both public and private welfare agencies today agreed that the giving of financial assistance must be accompanied by an understanding of the recipient's emotional needs in order to be of any substantial benefit to the client or the community.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The friends of Secretary of Defense Forrestal say that President Truman has now assured him he can remain in his present job.
ALBANY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The State Board of Regents today authorized ten schools to change their names and granted six charters to educational agencies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended Nov. 16, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index is now 164.3 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.1 per cent lower than four weeks ago and slightly less than 3 per cent higher than in the comparable week in 1947.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 19 -- The absent countries of the Soviet bloc were denounced today by Assistant Secretary of State George V. Allen of the United States before a plenary session of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization as the "anthithesis of democracy."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A trend from a sellers to a buyers market in lumber is "well under way," the Department of Commerce was advised today.

The glamor-repute of the Air Forces and the "hot rocks" who flew the fighter planes, which was cause for much ironic jesting among the lowly "doughfeet" during the war, is the stuff that Warner Brothers has exclusively put upon the screen in its loud, Technicolored "Fighter Squadron," which came to the Strand yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The State Attorney General's office said today it had "under advisement" a request to investigate election returns in Oneida and Oswego Counties.

Sid Tanenbaum, former New York University star who made his professional debut with the Knickerbockers last season, has again been signed to play with New York's entry in the Basketball Association of America, it was announced yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Because of his impressive showing at defensive left halfback against Pennsylvania in his first intercollegiate football game last week, Irving Reed has virtually clinched a regular berth in the Cadet backfield against Navy at Municipal Stadium.

Some cuts in delivery of newsprint from the Canadian drought area can be expected because of the 10 per cent reduction recently ordered in consumption of water-generated power, an American Newspaper Publishers Association spokesman declared yesterday.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The national executive committee of the Farmers Union today completed a six-fold legislative program for presentation to the Eighty-first Congress.

Welcome evidence of progress in breaking down the barriers to understanding between peoples of different cultures is provided by a recent story in this newspaper describing the successful efforts of the Netherlands Reformed Church to further the integration of Dutch immigrants into Canadian life by having them absorbed into the United Church of Canada.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

The Keller-Dorian Colorfilm Corporation of 350 Fifth Avenue filed an anti-trust suit in Federal Court yesterday for $250,000,000 in damages against the Eastman Kodak Company, Technicolor, Inc., and Technicolor Motion Picture Corporation.

The Esso Standard Oil Company, a distributing subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), yesterday announced a number of adjustments in the prices of petroleum products. These included an advance ranging up to 0.3 cent a gallon in the tank wagon price of gasoline and a reduction ranging up to a similar amount in tank car and barge prices of heating oils.

ATHENS, Nov. 19 -- With scarcely an exception, editorial comment in the Athens press today vehemently opposed the new coalition Cabinet and expressed the hope as well as the belief that it would not get a vote of confidence in the Chamber tomorrow evening.

It is not often that Americans on occupation duty have an opportunity to display their special abilities so spectacularly and so effectively as did former coal miner Private Salvatore Forte of Hatboro, Pa., in organizing the rescue of four Japanese imprisoned by a slide in a mine in Japan.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 19 -- Dr. James L. Hymes Jr., Professor of Education and coordinator of early childhood education at New Paltz State Teachers College, summarized the work of the fifteenth annual conference on Parent and Family Life Education in its concluding session today.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Final agreement on the draft of a North Atlantic defense pact was reached here today by delegates of the five Western Union powers, Britain, France, Belgium, the Nether lands and Luxembourg.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Scarsdale defeated its arch rival, Bronxville High, in mud and rain today, 13 to 7, winning when Olaf Jacobson blocked Durham Lawshe's punt on the first play of the fourth period and Bob Dehlendorf recovered.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 19 -- Since the borough itself was the scene of the fighting, it never will be possible for the Government to assume ownership of the entire Gettysburg battlefield, Oscar L. Chapman, Under-Secretary of the Interior, declared here today.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The feature of the stock markets here today was the late rush for Orange Free State gold-mining shares which, despite a fair amount of profit-taking, closed with gains up to 1/8 point. Elsewhere conditions generally were quiet.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 19 -- The National Reclamation Association was challenged today by Michael W. Straus, commissioner of reclamation, to rid itself of the influence of the power "monopolists'' who, he said, were more interested in protecting their own "monopolies" than in developing water resources.

Ever since the new government in Peru began digging itself in, following the successful revolt which took its leader, Gen. Manuel Odria, to Lima, the Peruvian capital, North Americans interested in South America have been pointing out that this latest of Peru's many civil conflicts conformed to an old tradition by exploding in the city of Arequipa, long known as the initiator of more revolutions than any other place in Peru.

A request for tenders of at least 56,688 shares of the capital stock of the Taylor-Wharton Iron and Steel Company of High Bridge, N.J., has been sent to shareholders by two prospective purchasers, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -The Public Housing Administration announced a reorganization today which will result in the establishment of ten field offices in various parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board gave out today its hearing schedule in the board's inquiry to determine whether National Airlines should be divested of its flying routes. The investigation, which is without precedent, followed a long period of operating loss reports by National, and a strike by National pilots who are members of the Air Line Pilots Association, AFL.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 19 -- The Socialist-Catholic coalition under the premiership of Paul-Henri Spaak handed its resignation today to Prince Charles, Regent of Belgium. This collective gesture by the twenty-month old administration followed the resignation of Catholic Minister of Justice Paul Struye last night after he had been criticized by the Socialists in the Chamber for having reprieved two Belgians condemned to death for war crimes.
Columbia and Syracuse will meet on the Baker Field gridiron today in the final contest of the season for both teams.
A plaque of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia symbolizing his civic and humanitarian ideals was selected here yesterday from among twelve entries in a contest sponsored by the Haarlem House Fund.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady in the late trading yesterday and final prices were 4 to 9 points net higher.

Two subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation yesterday increased prices of galvanized sheets and other products coated with zinc following an advance in the price of zinc. The rise in prices of the steel products was made in accordance with a standard formula under which prices of zinc-coated products are automatically advanced or lowered, depending on the current price of zinc.

Ted Collins, owner of the Boston Yanks of the National Football League, said yesterday he had no intentions at this time of taking the team out of the Massachusetts city and definitely no idea of quitting pro football.

The Temporary City Housing Rent Commission withdrew yesterday the tentative permission it had granted to 230 hotels here to bill permanent guests for rent increases up to 12 per cent. It directed that refunds be made of all such increases.

Julia Marlowe Sothern, actress, has sold two parcels of her property, comprising about nine acres, at Westhampton Beach, L.I., to Emerson Raynor. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers. The property, which had been in the Sothern family for many years, extends from the Atlantic Ocean to Moriches Bay, with a frontage of about 690 feet on both the ocean and the bay.

Hide futures strengthened on Commodity Exchange yesterday, recovering most of the losses of Thursday. Near-by December, which had led the decline, advanced to 29 1/2 cents a pound, 25 points below the high of the year. Sales aggregated fifty-three lots or 2,120,000 pounds.

Capt. Stephen Malloch, master of the freighter Flying Trader, was ordered yesterday to make all efforts "short of a shooting war" to reload any cargo taken from his ship at Port Said by Egyptian authorities. The vessel has been detained there since Sunday by the Egyptian Government.

The Port of New York Authority began yesterday its novel plan to move 225 families from the site of the proposed $20,000,000 midtown bus terminal into the eleven apartment buildings it has purchased mid modernized for these displaced tenants.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- Price increases were announced today by two divisions of the General Motors Corporation with Buick increasing its list prices, according to model, by $50 to $347, and Cadillac by $54 to $112 for 1949 cars.

Melio Bettina, Beacon, N.Y., veteran who once held the light-heavyweight crown, had enough left to take a unanimous ten-round decision over Enrique Felpi of the Argentine before 2,247 at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

Diverse interest attaches to three of the art exhibitions which opened this week. At the Delius Gallery there is a display of Venetian eighteenth-century drawings; at the A.C.A. Gallery the realist Harry Gottlieb presents his most mature show to date, and at the Luyber Galleries there is a debut of work by an expressionist, Samuel M. Adler.

The office of State Controller Frank C. Moore announced yesterday that bids will be taken Nov. 30 on an issue of $51,400,000 of state housing bonds maturing serially over fifty years. The issue is to be retired at the rate of $1,050, 000 annually from 1950 to 1998, with bonds due after Dec. 1, 1988, callable.

Elmo Roper, public opinion analyst and one of those red-faced men who were so badly defeated in the last election, says in THE TIMES of Nov. 8 in regard to the pre-election polls which were taken by him and others that we had in our hands an "almost microscopically accurate measuring instrument and didn't know how to use it."

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The simultaneous dissolution by divorce of two notably unsuccessful royal marriages is an event probably unprecedented in history. Oddity was added to the event by the fact that King Farouk and Empress Fawzia are brother and sister.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Manager Burt Shotton of the Brooklyn Dodgers said today his team may train Miami next spring.

World War II has produced profound unrest among the natives of the South Pacific. The colonial powers are worried over such fantastic movements as the "Cargo Cult" of New Guinea and the "Marching Rule" of the Solomon Islands.

BEIRUT, Nov. 19 -- Predictions that the Arab-Jewish conflict would not be so much as mentioned in UNESCO, the organization for promoting international understanding in the supposedly nonpolitical fields of science, education and culture were blown sky-high in the very first working session of the conference.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet Military Governor, accused the British Government of "inventing all sorts of fairy tales" about him in trying to explain the breakdown of the Berlin talks.
The big waterfowl flights are now on and according to reports from the vast Canadian breeding grounds the ducks and geese are pouring southward day and night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- While consumption of leather this year has been below deliveries by tanners, the inventory position of the tanning industry continues favorable, Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the Tanners Council, said here today.

Apropos your several recent editorials which touch upon the need for developing new revenues to meet the rising costs of local government. I should like to suggest a potential source of local revenue which would be particularly appropriate for a highly urbanized municipality such as the City of New York.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19 -- Organized labor's increased responsibility for international recovery, world amity and domestic well-being was stressed repeatedly today at the American Federation of Labor convention by W. Averell Harriman, roving ambassador of the Economic Cooperation Administration, and Hubert H. Humphrey, the 37-year-old Senator-elect from Minnesota.
WASHINGTON, Nov, 19 (AP) -- An expected battle on where to locate the permanent home of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization got under way today.

Sixty-five-year-old Leonard B. (Len) Wheeler made his last run as conductor on the Port Jefferson branch of the Long Island Rail Road out of Pennsylvania Station at 4:36 P.M., yesterday. When the train reached Port Jefferson, Mr. Wheeler began his retirement after forty-six years of uninterrupted service with the Long Island, thirty-eight of them as a conductor.

Dr. Mabel Newcomer, Professor of Economics at Vassar College; Earle S. Thompson, president of the West Penn Electric Company, and John D. Boyle, vice president of the W.T. Grant Company, were elected trustees of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America, it was announced yesterday by R. McAllister Lloyd, president.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A few trains began rolling slowly through blizzard-swept western Kansas tonight, though several towns were still isolated and hundreds of motorists were marooned by the first heavy snowstorm of the season.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 19 (Reuters) -- The Hungarian Ministry of the Interior announced today the arrest of Dr. Andras Zakar, secretary to Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, primate of Hungary.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- The United Nations General Assembly listened to the Western powers insist today that they could not and would not disarm now and went ahead to reject the Soviet demand for a one-third reduction in armies, navies and air forces of all the Big Five.

Faced with the task of entertaining the two scourges of the All-America Conference -- the Cleveland Browns and the San Francisco Forty-Niners -- on Sunday, the Yankees and Dodgers engaged in their final workouts yesterday and emerged in surprisingly high spirits.

A collection of William Saroyan stories, entitled "The Saroyan Special," will be published by Harcourt, Brace on Nov. 29. The volume will contain ninety-two stories selected by the author to represent "the full range of his talents." Don Freeman, who illustrated Saroyan's "The Human Comedy" and "My Name Is Aram," has done the drawings for this book also.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- Clifford J. Fletcher, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, asserted today that thirty-seven automobile driving schools in the City of New York had lost their licenses or faced revocation proceedings as a result of an investigation into accusations of racketeering.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The steel industry, speaking through representatives meeting here today with Government officials, agreed to extended voluntary allocation of their product to essential industries in a degree apparently, exceeding Government hopes.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins talked like a "Dutch uncle" today to more than 100 of the country's newspaper editorial writers.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 -- Former Justice Joseph M. Proskauer of New York, president of the American Jewish Committee, told the National Council of the Joint Defense Appeal today that an all-out fight against anti-Semitism in the United States was necessary to preserve the new state of Israel.

New York City's annual relief cost of $168,000,000 will increase "for many years to come" unless steps are taken now to reduce chronic invalidism among old people, Raymond M. Hilliard, Welfare Commissioner, said yesterday.

The press must inform, inspire, expose and educate, Dr. Alfredo Silva-Carvallo, director of La Union, Valparaiso, Chile, declared yesterday in accepting a Maria Moors Cabot gold medal from Columbia University. He was one of four recipients of the medals that are awarded annually for "outstanding contributions to understanding among the nations of the Americas."
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Postmaster Louis Reilly and local officials were preparing today for a ceremony on Nov. 29 to mark the start of the first postoffice bus service in the East.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -This year's housing construction will hit an all-time high, the Commerce Department predicted today.

A state prison sentence of two-and-a-half to five years was imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente on Dr. Paul Singer, 43-year-old gynecologist, who had been convicted of manslaughter in connection with the abortion death of Miss Jane Ward, daughter of a baking company executive.

MADRID, Nov. 19 -- Spaniards are nearing their first election since February, 1936, with absolute calm, if not actual apathy. The first section of the municipal elections will be held throughout Spain on Sunday, when heads of families will choose a third of the municipal Councilmen from candidates who arc themselves heads of families.

Throughout New York City's five boroughs there are 315 first offender parking violators who are going to get their fines refunded and will have to make a trip to traffic court all because they appended an explanation to their remittances.

Emerson Radio Phonograph Corporation is assisting its distributors in three Latin-American countries to set up assembling plants, Max Abrams, president of Emerson Radio Export Corporation, disclosed yesterday.
