All three countries, Argentina, Brazil and Mexico, bar import of complete radio receivers from the United States but issue licenses for importation of components from time to time.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The American Legion's National Executive Committee today selected Philadelphia unanimously as the Legion's 1949 convention city.
I want to protest, as strongly as possible, the withdrawal of northbound bus service on Ninth Avenue.

Weakened by injuries to key personnel, New York University will meet the United States Merchant Marine Academy eleven today at Tomb Memorial Field, Kings Point, L.I. A crowd of 4,000 is expected to watch the cadet parade at 1:30 P.M., with the kick-off slated a half-hour later.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 19 (AP) - Joseph W. Martin, Republican leader, tonight outlined common Congressional ground for joint action by his Republican minority and the Southern Democratic faction.

After meeting with the investors yesterday, David Kay, sponsor of "For Heaven's Sake, Mother!" announced the closing of the Julie Berns comedy following tonight's performance -- the seventh -- at the Belasco Theatre. In making known his decision, Mr. Kay revealed that the "backers" had gladly proffered to lay out more capital to keep the show going, but he considered it inadvisable.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The International Typographical Union, AFL, pursuant to a contempt decree against it, has distributed to local unions new contract proposals for the newspaper industry which are modeled after the New York newspaper agreement, with one exception.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, of Montana, denied today that he said a Taft-Hartley repealer could be passed only as part of new labor legislation, as reported yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Earnings of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the third quarter of the year, ended on Oct. 2, last, are estimated at $6,445,000 after taxes and all charges, the report disclosed yesterday.

Today's events Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert. Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor; James H. Fassett, narrator; Chorus of the Midwood High School, Brooklyn, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.; Little Orchestra Society Young People's Concert.

The Boston Pops Orchestra, under the direction of Arthur Fiedler, will be presented in the new "RCA Victor Show," which is scheduled to make its debut Sunday, Dec. 12, at 5:30 P.M., over NBC. Robert Merrill, baritone will be the sole vocalist.
BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Representative Paul W. Shafer, Republican of Michigan, urged today an increase in United States air strength and occupation personnel to meet the challenge of communism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A powerful micro-wave generator, designed to increase production and control utilization of electric energy from the higher ranges of the upper air, to amplify and improve existing means for the all-purpose transmission of intelligence of any kind was one of 576 inventions approved this week by the United States Patent Office.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- A favored Rutgers football team will seek to make Fordham its seventh victim of the season tomorrow in the Scarlet's final game. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 P.M.

Floral and foliage designs for decorative fabrics are given new impetus by the collection of drapery and slipcover materials designed in Denmark and now at Lord Taylor. Arne Jacobsen, Danish architect, has contributed the first in a series heralding an important new source for decorative materials.

Marc Worst, vice president of Lockheed Aircraft Service, has been given operational direction of Lockheed's bases at Sayville, L.I., and Burbank, Cal. W.R. Rhoads, base manager at Sayville, has been appointed assistant to vice president W.H. Wayman, and Duane O. Wood, supervisor of planning at Burbank, has been named work superintendent at Sayville.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The national grange convention voted tonight to support repeal of taxes on oleomargarine "if and when effective means are taken to prevent deception in its sale in imitation of butter." Heretofore the grange has strongly supported margarine taxes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 19 -- A six-point program, emphasizing the need for Federal and State legislation, was recommended here today to the executive committee of the American Legion by the organization's Child Welfare Commission.

Although "the over-all supply" of dressed turkeys will be adequate for the demands of the approaching holidays, officials of the Department of Markets said yesterday that prices were higher than they were last year, especially for lightweight fowl.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 -- The Peron regime, which is considered to be in control of all the afternoon newspapers and of one morning newspaper, Democracia, which was founded after the present Government came into power, acquired a controlling interest today in the conservative tabloid Mundo. Miguel Miranda, President Peron's economic chief, is among the three new directors who hold 51 per cent of the voting stock.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19 -- Back from Donora, Pa., scene of late October lethal smog which killed twenty residents, Dr. Clarence A. Mills of the University of Cincinnati, an expert on the effect of air pollution on the respiratory system, reported here today his belief that many other cities of the country had the setting for similar disaster.

With only one more day of competition ahead of them, riders in the six-day bicycle race at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory maintained their battle for first place last night. Virtually all survivors from the original field of twelve teams still held chances of victory, with the result that last night was featured both by daring individual efforts and by cautious team jockeying.

Trailing in the technological parade, the textile manufacturing industry must step up its research program as it enters a period of discriminating consumer buying, it was pointed out yesterday by speakers at the annual meeting of the Textile Research Institute.

"THE idea that man may some day journey into the other to discover other men and women, like or unlike himself, seems to be a conception the world will not willingly let die," Marjorie Nicolson writes in her new book, "Voyages to the Moon," a remarkable collection of tales about ancients and moderns moon-bent for travel in the widest of all open spaces.

A shortage of chairs at Public School 153, Maspeth, Queens, where, it was charged, first-year children had to bring their own from home, will be corrected "within the next few days," Dr. William Jansen, superintendent of schools, announced yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Without a dissent, the United Nations General Assembly approved tonight a voluntary program to aid 500,000 Palestine refugees, virtually all of them Arabs, during a nine-month period beginning Dec. 1.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- For the third year in a row the Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution today censuring the Union of South Africa for failing to place the territory of South-West Africa under the United Nations trusteeship system.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, branded today as "nonsense" any suggestion that military and industrial research in nuclear fission could be separated into two "neatly tied bundles."

LAHORE, Pakistan, Nov. 19 -- From being the granary of all India, the West Punjab, since the partition of the subcontinent a year ago, has become a food deficit province, to the detriment of the economy of the new dominion of Pakis

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 19 -- Lafayette College and Lehigh University will play here tomorrow in their eighty-fourth game since 1884, the longest unbroken football series in the nation. More than 20,000 spectators are expected.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- The delinquency prevention division of the New Jersey Institutions Department noted today a decline of 6.3 per cent in juvenile offense cases in the state during 1947, but found sex misconduct an increasing problem.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 19 -- The governmental crisis was considered tonight to be entering its final stage and the issue was expected to be decided within a very short time.

Warnings of staggering losses to real estate and the nation's economy resulting from failure to eliminate blighted conditions in American cities and lack of adequate protection for our agricultural lands were sounded at yesterday's sessions of the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in the Hotel Commodore.
PARIS, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of the disarmament resolution adopted today by the United Nations Assembly:

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Residents of Hillside Manor near here may rest assured that the name they selected for their branch postoffice two years ago, Hillside Manor, will be the one it will bear when it is completed on Dec. 1.

Bernard Greenhouse is a man who can make a cello sing, as he proved at his recital in Carnegie Hall last night. His tone and technique were refined to the point where every note had its own rich color and took its place in the musical continuity with inevitability and suavity.

The failure of the State Legislature to meet the needs of the New York City schools was assailed yesterday by Vincent R. Impellitteri, President of the City Council, and by James J. Lyons, President of the Borough of the Bronx.

Closing its first regular season under Ted Rosequist, the Brooklyn College eleven faces Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today at the Flatbush field. Because of the early dusk, the kick-off has been set for 1:30 P.M.

VIENNA, Nov. 19 -- Foreign Minister Karl Gruber announced at Salzburg today that he would protest to the United States High Commissioner, Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes, against his treatment by an American highway patrol that halted his car at the edge of Salzburg.

YONKERS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- A crisis in the financial affairs of Yonkers was imminent today as City Manager Thomas V. Kennedy made slow progress with the Common Council and none with Westchester County in his efforts to relieve the situation.

George Frankenthaler, Republican-Liberal candidate for Surrogate of New York County, defeated his Democratic opponent, General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen, by 1,150 votes, according to the official canvass completed late yesterday by the Board of Elections.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Max Bedacht, a founder, former national secretary and for many years a member of the top governing committee of the Communist party of the United States, has been expelled by the Communist party of New Jersey, the state organization said today.

Frank S. Gibson Jr., chairman of the Phoenix-Apollo Steel Company of Apollo, Pa., announced yesterday that sale of its Phoenixville properties this week to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation did not include the company's sheet-rolling mill at Apollo.

A child's storybook world of make-believe came alive in the American Museum of Natural History yesterday as the second annual Boys and Girls Book Fair opened for a four-day run under the sponsorship of the museum, THE NEW YORK TIMES and the Children's Book Council.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor met tonight and decided to defer further consideration of alleged Communist influence in the Canadian Trades and Labor Congress until January.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Damage officially estimated at $500 and unofficially at between $5,000 and $10,000 was caused by three youths in the summer home of a New York physician at Massapequa, L. I., on Halloween, it was learned today when they were arrested.

A uniform maximum speed limit of fifty miles an hour on highways from Delaware through the northeast region states and elimination of a factor that might cause "speed traps" were recommended yesterday at the thirteenth annual Regional Highway and Motor Vehicle Conference.

KHARTOUM, Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, Nov. 19 -- Violence and a boycott this week characterized the elections to the First Legislative Assembly of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, held in defiance of the will of the Government of Egypt.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- American industry should have some procedure under which some highly qualified executives could be made available for important Government assignments on a two-year tour of duty, Donald F. Carpenter, chairman, Munitions Board, declared here today.

War souvenirs, ranging from fountain pens to 155 mm. shells, have killed 6,000 persons annually in the United States since the war, Walter Carroll, investigator in charge of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury Department, said yesterday.

The Kansas City Southern Railway was among the carriers that yesterday took favorable dividend action. The directors of that road declared a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 15, to stock of record Nov. 30. This will be the first payment on that stock since 1931.

The interchange of letters between President Truman and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, following the loss of Manchuria and the Communist advances in North China, has revealed the urgent necessity of re-defining American policy in the Far East. If Nanking reports are correct, Chiang asked for more material aid in the present critical struggle.

The Costa Line, an Italian-flag company, will start a new three-ship passenger-cargo service between Genoa and New York with the arrival here Tuesday of the Maria C, it was announced yesterday by J.H. Winchester Co., agents for the line here.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis brought his exhibition tour home to Detroit tonight and even with bulky fourteen-ounce gloves, dumped Vern Mitchell of Detroit on the canvas twice in a non-decision six-round bout. Louis weighed 220, Mitchell 194 1/2.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 19 (AP) -- J.H. Brinks' Lookout Son, a Calumet Farm cast-off, took the White Hall Purse today. Qualifying nicely for the $10,000 added W.P. Burch Memorial Handicap next Wednesday, the son of Sun Teddy finished two lengths in front of Dart By.

The Navy's newest carrier-based fighter, the Chance Vought XF7U-1, revealed at Patuxent Naval Test Station on Thursday, turned out to be one of the most radically designed aircraft ever produced, more resembling a veined rocket than the conventional fighter planes which surrounded it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Interstate Commerce Commission examiners today wound up hearings on a proposal by the Nickel Plate Railroad (New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company) to lease the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The State Department instructed Jeferson Patterson, the United States Charge d'Affaires at Cairo, today to protest to the Egyptian Government against the holding and unloading of the American steamship Flying Trader at Port Said.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 19 -- The Military Governors of the three Western zones have signed a $300,000,000 trade agreement with France. The pact not only is the largest yet negotiated for the Western Germans but also the first involving the three Western zones jointly.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Britain's Labor Government, which has already provided free medical service for all citizens, now proposes to give free or assisted legal aid to persons of limited means.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Plenipotentiaries of forty-seven countries, including six nonmembers of the United Nations, at a ceremony here today signed a protocol establishing international control over synthetic narcotics.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 19 -- A race against flames in her hold ended in the harbor today for the China Transport, a 4,600-ton freighter.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 -- Many surgeons were misusing the technique of early ambulation for patients convalescing from surgery, Dr. Daniel J. Leithauser of Detroit, a pioneer in the field, declared today as the United States Chapter, International College of Surgeons, ended the formal meetings of its thirteenth annual assembly.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports today estimated car and truck production in the United States this week at 114,302 units.

In a move to enlist public support for higher pay, bridge and tunnel officers employed by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, who are members of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, staged mass demonstrations yesterday at the entrance to the Queens Midtown Tunnel.
The Cherry-Levis Company, packer of Penrose pickled meats, to the Clements Company, Inc., Philadelphia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- The board of governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has accepted the recommendation of a special committee that the annual awards prensentation next March 24 be held at a motion-picture studio on a sound stage.
MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Fifteen German war criminals were hanged today on the twin gallows in Landsberg prison, where Adolf Hitler wrote "Mein Kampf."

Establishment of a Continental Air Command and appointment of General Stratemeyer as its first commander are encouraging steps forward in the needed centralization of authority for plans and administration of the air defenses of the United States. They foreshadow, we hope, closer attention to, and better organization of, the Air National Guard and the Air Reserve in addition to the more obvious advantages of eliminating some overlapping functions and authority.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, and his political adviser, Ambassador Robert D. Murphy, who arrived from Berlin this morning, conferred with Secretary of State Marshall in the afternoon. They gave the Secretary detailed information on the latest developments in Berlin, authoritative sources said.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, ruled today that the Israeli reply had constituted acceptance in principle of his order for the return of Israeli forces in the Negeb, desert area in southern Palestine, to positions that they had occupied on Oct. 14.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 19 -- Sam Rayburn, who will resume the Speakership of the House with the advent of his thirty-seventh year in Congress, declared today that only a "man-made depression" could now endanger this country.

When the thirty-eight-mile Croton Aqueduct first brought Croton water to New York City on Oct. 14, 1842, the occasion was one for great rejoicing and civic ceremony. "Unstinted libation and ablution," in the words of a contemporary writer, was the new boon for the metropolis.

The New York Little Symphony, under Joseph Barone, gave its first concert of the season last night at Times Hall. This organization was formed by its conductor for the purpose of giving young American musical artists the opportunity of making an appearance before the public.

ROME, Nov. 19 -- The news that the Italian Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Efisio Marras, will visit the United States early in December as the guest of Gen. Omar N. Bradley, United States Chief of Staff, has unleashed a new offensive by the left-wing press against the Government's foreign policy.
Quick resales of contracts were among the realty transactions reported in Manhattan yesterday.

NANKING, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Triumphant government divisions today t drove home their first big victory in months of civil War, reportedly: fanning out seventy miles east and thirty miles north of Suchow.

Mrs. Oksana Stepanovna Kasenkina, whose leap from the third-floor window of the Russian Consulate last August resulted in the ending of consular ties between the United States and Russia, declared yesterday that she would "never" return to Russia.
The city will oppose the 15 per cent increase in rates sought by the New York Telephone Company, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- French Foreign Minister Robert Schuman appealed today to Secretary of State Marshall and Hector McNeil, British Minister of State, against the recent decisions of the United States and British Military Governors of Germany to return control of the Ruhr industries to German trustees.

The One Hundred Neediest Cases Fund of THE NEW YORK TIMES was named principal beneficiary in the will of Mrs. Sophie Louise Miller, widow of Henry Clifford Miller, who died in St. Luke's Hospital last Oct. 5, it was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court where her will was filed for probate.

Running from a hold-up he had committed, a man with two pistols invaded an Inwood apartment yesterday and terrorized a woman and her children for more than an hour before her husband came home and chased him away. The robber was caught later hiding under a baby's crib in another apartment, after a search in which 100 heavily armed policemen took part while a crowd of 1,000 gathered.

The whirlwind six-week honeymoon of Roger Dumontier and his bride from Cudahy, Wis., came to an end yesterday with his arrest in Brooklyn. The arrest came through the alertness of an assistant bookkeeper in the offices of the Brooklyn Telephone Answering Service, 66 Willoughby Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Lammot du Pont, a director of the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., today concluded his testimony before the special grand jury investigating the du Pont industrial empire. The jury, which is seeking to determine whether the du Pont interests engaged in monopolistic practices, is to meet again Monday, after which it will be recessed indefinitely.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 19 -- A resolution requesting that United States troops remain in South Korea until the Government is capable of self-defense was submitted today to the National Assembly's acting secretary, Dr. Clarence Ryee.

The stock market hit the recovery trail again yesterday and canceled out the moderate inroads sustained in the two preceding sessions. Business increased slightly on the new rally, which increased prices by fractions to about a point in some of the industrials, while wider gains were made in the rails and the composite rate was advanced by 0.40 point.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 19 -- A unanimous finding that left-wing officers of the Greater New York City CIO Council are guilty of violating the constitution of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and thwarting CIO policy is ready for presentation to the national executive board tomorrow morning, it was reported authoritatively tonight.

Gen. Nicolae Radescu, who was ousted as Prime Minister of Rumania in 1945 as a result of a Russian ultimatum, made an appeal here yesterday to all exiled Rumanians to unite in an organization that would work to liberate their country and. restore King Michael to the throne.

Contests between traditional rivals, with Conference titles and Bowl invitations at stake in several instances, mark the final Saturday of general activity in college football. For most teams in the East and the Midwest and many elsewhere today winds up the season.

Mayor O'Dwyer ordered yesterday that immediate steps be taken to protect the public from possible injury caused by fragments of stone dropping from the southerly frontage of City Hall near its entrances and building lines.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- City officials here considered as an act of retaliation today a refusal by New York City to allow Yonkers to use two acres of Van Cortlandt Park property in the Bronx, just across the boundary from this city, as an athletic field and playground.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Hiring by manufacturing industries leveled off at 49 per 1,000 employes in September, with a slight decline from August accounted for by the shorter work-month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Russian authorities laid the ground tonight for the dismissal of another important city official -- this time the City Treasurer, Friedrich Haas, a Christian Democrat.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- In a further development today in the politically potent Burlington County bridge deal, two former stockholders in a company that sold two Delaware River bridges filed a Federal Court action to recover an alleged profit of $3,459,000, which they said they did not share.

In your report of the recent meeting of the directors of the National Conference of Christians and Jews it was noteworthy not only that there was no mention of any plans for genuine interfaith work, but also that one of the speakers actually asserted that in the specific field of organized religion "there can be no cooperation."
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 -- Dr. John Ewart Wallace Sterling, historian and director, of California's Huntington Library, was chosen today as president of Stanford University.

The stock market pursued yesterday the narrow movements of the past week. Selected issues on the Stock Exchange managed to break away from the confined course and show major gains, but on the average, only fractional increases ruled and final quotations were irregularly higher.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Among competent military observers there seemed to be a growing tendency here this week to see China as a mortally stricken nation, a casualty of a tide of communism that is too strong now to divert.

CAIRO, Nov. 20 -- Egyptian police have arrested thirty members of the largest terrorist organization in Egypt and have solved the mystery of a series of bombings, political assassinations and attempted assassinations, authoritative quarters disclosed today.

GEORGE R. MAREK has been writing cheerful little essays on various aspects of opera -- music, composers, librettists, singers, theatres, conductors, audiences -- since 1942. The objective of these articles, as in the case of most program notes, is to be either revealing about the work in hand or stimulating about the subject in general.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 20 -- Northwestern's Rose Bowl express, gathering steam behind a great running attack, made just a whistle stop out of Illinois today.

The annual luncheon of the alumnae of the Ogontz School, Rydal, Pa., will be given on Dec. 6 in the private dining room of the York Club, 4 East Sixty-second Street, and will be preceded by a business meeting of the alumnae. Mrs. Ernest V.D. Moncrieff of Rye, N.Y., is chairman of the committee for the luncheon, which is being given under the auspices of the Eastern Ogontz Association.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Miss Nabia Abbott, scholar of Arabic writing and associate professor at the University of Chicago, has determined the original name of "The Arabian Nights," a question that has baffled scholars since Antoine Galland, the French scholar, introduced the fabulous tales to western civilization 250 years ago.
The Testing and Advisement Center of New York University will mark its third year of operation this month.
THE Wright brothers' original flying machine is back home after twenty years in England.

The New York City Hospital Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association has taken over the first benefit performance of Cole Porter's new musical, "Kiss Me, Kate," at the Century Theatre on Jan. 3. The proceeds will be devoted to the work of the committee, which for seventy-five years has sought to improve the condition of less fortunate patients in New York's municipal hospitals.

WHEN Dorothy McCullough Lee takes office next Jan. 1 as Mayor of Portland, Ore., she will be no novice in government. She has been in the public service almost twenty years, as a Representative in the State Legislature, as a State Senator and later as Portland's Commissioner of Public Utilities.
" When I'm angry and I think I'm going to hurt someone," said Donald Levine, "I read a book and it quiets my nerves."

In two sessions, on Tuesday and Wednesday, the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, will auction Chinese jades and snuff bottles, porcelains and pottery and Japanese art objects from the collections of the late Annie R. Bird of Kansas City, Mo., and Mrs. Dudley Olcott of New York.

Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas, four times Speaker of the House, recent minority leader and scheduled to be Speaker again, was in a cheery mood when the newspaper men lured him from the temporary White House in Key West on Friday. This mood seemed to reflect, or be reflected by, a coffee-colored shirt which, as Anthony Leviero reported to this newspaper, "was cluttered with cranes flexing their wings and with fringes of palm trees."

NANKING, Nov. 20 -- After a three-day lull padded out only by propaganda claims, the second phase of the battle of Suchow was reported to be in the making today with Gen. Chen Yi's Communist troops resuming their attacks east and southeast of that important northern Kiangsu rail junction.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 20 -- Thanksgiving in the Upper South finds a grateful people this year.

THE American cook-book world is in a wild state of flux. Fannie Farmer. stern mother of Level Measurements. has been deposed. Her "Boston Cooking School Cook Book. ruler of the range for a generation, is now well down on kitchen best-seller lists. Irma S. Rombauer's "Joy of Cooking" is pretty firmly established at the top.

Robert Burke, 25 years old, of 39-44 Forty-sixth Street, Long Island City, Queens, who said he was a free-lance private detective, was boked on two morals charges and a charge of unlawful entry yesterday afternoon at the Long Island City police station.

An international Christian community, patterned after this city and based on freedom, was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, associate general secretary of the World Council of Churches, as a means of achieving world peace.

The Rockefeller family will receive City Colleges" first Finley Award in the name of the late John H. Finley, president of City College from 1903 to 1913 and retired editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Dr. Nelson P. Mead, president of the college's Associate Alumni, announced yesterday.

THE temptations which watt on windy corners for hungry writers cannot compare with the snares and delusions which stalk the scribbler who has made some money, the man who is called an author. H. Allen Smith is an author. Smack in the middle of the war he found that he had enough money to get away from the shoddy, jerry-built, mechanistic, coming-at-you-slaunchwise life of New York City.

DETROIT, Nov. 20 -- No valid evidence of a "softening in new-car demand" could be found in a six thousand-mile tour of the country, it was reported today by Karl M. Greiner, vice president and general sales manager of the Packard Motor Car Company.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 20 -- The Republican party in New Jersey has not had such a bad outlook since 1936.

The battle for Suchow, still unfinished yesterday, apparently has resulted in an initial reverse for the Chinese Communist forces. Nanking has won a brief respite, but it is still the eleventh hour in China and the picture of decadence and dissolution has not been altered.

NANKING, Nov. 20 -- The Chinese Communist authorities in Mukden have seized the radio station of the United States Consulate there, thus cutting off direct communication between the United States' Nanking Embassy and the first American consulate that has tried to operate in Red territory.

To many men semi-arid land is energy in suspension which needs only work, ingenuity and patience to reconvert and bloom. In Wyoming the hope of turning such areas to profitable use is currently enjoying a run of optimism. The United States Bureau of Land Management has contracted for aerial seeding of 10,240 dry acres with crested wheatgrass to prevent erosion and provide feeding grounds for livestock.

STEWART HOLBROOK, a gifted researcher and expository writer, has the knack of digging up odd facts about well-known people and interesting facts about odd people. Not long ago he wrote a learned and highly readable book about a group of turbulent souls he called the lost men of American history.

Dimitri Mitropoulos conducted his first children's concert in New York yesterday morning and made some sort of musical history in doing so, He didn't say a word about any of the orchestral pieces he conducted. There were no jokes, no ancedotes about the composers, no explanations of form.

OF the hundreds of observations about war in this bitter reminiscence by an ex-GI and his brother, there is one that commends itself to all veterans quite readily: the man who retains a sane outlook in the midst of hostilities is pretty certain to be regarded as an eccentric.

ST. LOUIS. Nov. 20 -- Department store officials here ascribe the recent let-up in business to two influences, uncertainties over what the next Congress will do, and a delayed start in Christmas buying which had gotten off to an early start during the preceding five years as a result of shortage of wares.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- Premier Henri Queuille's Government is expected Tuesday to obtain a vote of confidence from the National Assembly to deal with the French Communists; but party groups have started to put conditions on cooperation in the Government's future program.

Repeal of the 15 per cent excess tax on railroad fares will be high on the list of importance for matters to be brought before the Eighty-first Congress in January, according to the legislative programs of several salesmen's organizations polled here last week.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The United States told the United Nations today that no changes must be made in Israel's borders without that state's consent, but insisted that any territorial additions Israel demanded over and above boundaries set forth in the United Nations partition resolution must be offset by her giving up land elsewhere.

A NEW high in film speed, making good photographic results possible under poor lighting conditions, has been reached with the advent of a du Pont Defender type 428 High Speed Pan sheet film, which will become available within about ten days.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Nov. 20 -- The State of New Jersey Manual Training School, which last year dropped from its name the phrase "for Colored Youth" under the non-discrimination clause of the new state constitution, was pointed out today as the only boarding school for high school youth in this area and as one with a program "not always popular with parents who want their children to be 'a success!'"

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 20 -- The sending of supplies from the International Children's Emergency Fund into the Soviet zone of Germany probably would drive a wedge in the blockade of Berlin, it was suggested here today.

TELEVISION and radio audiences will have their pick of an unusually varied fare on Thanksgiving Day. NBC will offer "Holiday Star Time" from 4 to 6 P.M. while CBS, which carried the show in former years, will put on a two hour "Thanksgiving Festival" during the same period.
DETROIT, Nov. 20 -- Non-military application of atomic energy in the industrial world has been brought nearer by its extensive experimentation, the Ford Motor Company said today.

Pioneering experiments on mice exposed to lethal doses of radiation, offering the first hope that means may be found some day to protect populations against radiation injuries, are reported in the Proceedings of Experimental Biology and Medicine and in the current issue of Nutrition Reviews by Drs. Anna Goldfeder, L. Cohen, C. Miller and M. Singer of the cancer division, New York City Department of Hospitals, and the New York University College of Medicine.

NANKING, Nov. 20 -- With the Communists threatening to extend their control over all of China, the implications for the world, and particularly for the United States, are gigantic, even though obscure. Fundamentally, however, it is necessary to keep in mind that although the United States could be of vast assistance to the Communists it is altogether unlikely they would sacrifice their basic ties with Russia to achieve this help.

FEW citizens deserve better of their countrymen than Archibald bald MacLeish. He has helped educate America in two ways. Esthetically: by his pre-war poetry, with its use of sprung rhythm, cumulative enjambement, French Symbolism, and a gusto for epic. Morally: by his wartime role in the Government as an urgently needed conscience.

CARL ROSE (whose illustrations for Mr. Cerf's latest potpourri are frequently fresher, if not funnier, than the text they accompany) leads off this time with a sketch of the editor and/or author, rising like a surrealist djinn from a filing cabinet.

A steadily increasing number of employers are securing needed personnel through private employment agencies, William D. Ingham, chairman of the board of governors of the Association of Private Office Personnel Agencies, declared in an interview last week. The group is composed of seventy-three private employment agencies in New York City.

FRIENDLY animal favorites of small children appear in this book first as babies and then as full-grown. Each set of pictures is accompanied by a verse describing the main characteristics of the animal, what he likes to do, what he likes to eat.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 20 -- The Netherlands Foreign Minister, Dr. Derek U. Stikker, will leave for Java tomorrow at the head of the most ambitious and powerful delegation that has yet taken up the task of finding a solution to the Indonesian problem.
Finis to a gridiron campaign that for thrills and suspense was unparalleled in Columbia history was written yesterday at Baker Field.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club in New York, was the sixth leading money-winner during the eight-month British flat racing season which ended today. Woodward, whose silks Black Tarquin carried to victory in the classic St. Leger Stakes, was the first American since the war to finish among the top ten.

BATAVIA, Java, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- The East Java Conference, which has been meeting at Bondowoso since last Monday, has decided to form a State of East Java, the Dutch Aneta news agency reported today.

" Coffee Sergeant Sammy" came back yesterday to the lane separating Police Headquarters and the building across the street housing the newspaper reporters. His stay was brief, as his body just passed through the narrow thoroughfare en route to its final resting place.

The National Art Education Association, a nationwide organization representing art educators at all school levels, has formally come into existence with the ratification of its constitution by the four regional art education bodies, Dr. Edwin Ziegfeld, president of the new group, announced yesterday.

WHEN Luke Munroe brought his bride Catherine to Argentina from Sussex she planted a garden with larkspurs, stocks and snapdragons "which grew with semitropical un-English blowziness or were eaten by locusts until nothing was left but the baked, cracked earth."

Younger members of society, headed by Miss Dolly Lowell, are serving on the debutante committee for the preview of a loan exhibition of Portraits of New Yorkers (1848-1948), to be held tomorrow afternoon at Portraits, Inc., for the benefit of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases.
THERE are major arts like painting, poetry, sculpture, music, architecture and drama. These are creative arts, whose products suffice unto themselves.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- A million dollar program to benefit German children in all four zones of occupation was announced today by the executive board of the United Nations Childrens Fund.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Minnesota's massive Gophers crushed Wisconsin, 16 -- 0, today on a wet, slippery field in the Western Conference football finale for both teams before 45,000 fans.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 20 -- By a vote of 38 to 5, the national executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today found the Greater New York CIO Council guilty of "slavish adherence" to "the line and dictates of the Communist party" and revoked its charter as of this date.

COMEDIANS on the radio are experiencing a new prominence which is not altogether to their liking. When the formal season on the air opened six weeks ago, they rallied to meet the competition offered by the summer's deluge of giveaway shows, hurling every available gag and witticism at the Santa Claus bogy which haunted broadcasting.

MADRID, Nov. 20 -- The Falange observed its most solemn annual occasion here today on the twelfth anniversary of the execution of Jose Antonio Primo de Rivera. A requiem high mass in the Basilica of San Lorenzo, where the Falange co-founder's remains are entombed in an honored place before the high altar, drew a crowd estimated at 10,000.

THE Rev. James G. Keller, a Roman Catholic priest of the Maryknoll Missioners, founded the Christophers in 1945. They are a group working to maintain Christian principles in everyday life, especially in such important fields as literature, education, labor relations, government, etc.

Headquarters of the First Army announced yesterday that members of the Organized Reserve Corps would be paid in this quarter for drills in which they participated since Oct. 1 even if their units had not been designated part of the new eighteen-to-twenty-five division Army Striking Force.

WILLIAM WALSH'S successful biographies of three Spanish Catholics (St. Theresa of Avila, Isabella and Philip II) have gained him an established place as a biographer. His wonder over the lack of a modern study of St. Peter gave him his latest subject.

Gone from the Ironbottom Bay Club here are the slot machines, gaudy murals of girls and polished bars. The place now shelters an Anglican prelate, the Right Rev. S. Gething Caulton, Bishop of Melanesia.

The crippling strike of Atlantic Coast longshoremen yesterday went through its eleventh day without solution and spread its effect to the port of Southampton. There the British crew of the liner Queen Elizabeth refused to sail their ship and announced that the seamen of the Queen Mary and the Mauretania would also be asked to join the walkout.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 20 (UP) -- On the strength of a series of inspired goal line stands and a hard-earned first period touchdown, California scored a thrilling 7-to-6 victory over its traditional rival, Stanford, today and became the top candidate to represent the Pacific Coast Conference in the Rose Bowl. The Bears finished the season with ten straight triumphs.

Refusal of the Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter, Protestant co-chairman of the Brooklyn Round Table of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, to support the sale of tickets for a Sunday benefit football game on Nov. 28 resulted yesterday in the resignation of the Roman Catholic and Jewish co-chairman in support of his position.

With the approach of the first anniversary of the United Nations decision to partition Palestine, "no direct action has been taken by the international body to honor its own decree," Rabbi David H. Panitz said yesterday in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street near Broadway.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- The British Military Government accused the Soviet Military Administration today of having aggravated the Berlin situation by having issued unilateral orders in such a way that they "scarcely indicate any Russian desire for a quadripartite agreement."

A new approach to the education of "problem" children, one that emphasizes personality development as well as intellectual growth, has been recommended by a special committee of the New York City Board of Education.
Like everything else concerning women, it has become stylish to create a new look, even in women's golf in the metropolitan district.
The futures market in the New York Cotton Exchange continued steady yesterday and closed 1 to 12 points higher than the day before with a moderate volume of business.

Thanksgiving Day will provide a lull in an otherwise busy week at the New York Public Library, which begins its 100th anniversary celebration tomorrow with special events and exhibitions. On Thursday the information desk and the main reading room will be open as usual from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M.
The third annual Thanksgiving Bake Sale for the Brooklyn Home for Children will be held on Tuesday in the home of Mrs. Hollis K. Thayer at 16 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

MANCHESTER, England, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Sports Master, a 20-to-1 shot owned by a tobacco merchant, posted a length victory today in the Manchester November Handicap as Britain's flat-racing season came to a close.

IF a house plant census were ever taken, vines would probably far outnumber any other kind of plant. Indoor gardeners are not the only ones who like these trailers. Any one is likely to buy a vine to grow in either soil or water somewhere in the house during winter.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 20 -- Prejudice is best fought by the creation of a favorable climate of opinion, and scientific studies of the prejudiced personality are of great importance, 300 delegates to the third annual meeting of the Joint Defense Appeal were told today.

While New Yorkers basked in warm sunshine yesterday, people in the Midwest and the Great Lakes region shivered with cold, struggled against high winds and dug their way out of huge snowdrifts left by the first big blizzard of the season.

The new Bizonal plan, as reported a few days ago, for the so-called reorganization of the Ruhr under German trusteeship, undermines the necessary safeguards against the revival of Germany's war-making power. It has caused dismay and alarm amongst Germany's neighbors, as reflected in the protest of the French Government.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Elizabeth Philp is only a bus conductor's daughter, but she win sleep in a $1,000 crib and sit on a throne of toys.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Wall Street's post-election jitters over the outlook for America's economic future are not reflected in the views apparently held by many business leaders in the Central West. It is the average man who frequently seeks assurance that a depression will not overtake him.
HONOLULU, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A scientific research center on the remote island of Koror is to become the first of a planned series of working memorials to America's Pacific war dead.

The United States, Canada and Great Britain formally signed an agreement last week for "Unified Screw Threads." This was immediately hailed by engineers and industrialists here as the most advanced single step taken since the end of the war to assure long-run savings in production costs.

New methods and devices for measuring radioactivity that promise greater efficiency than the long-used Geiger counter were described yesterday by Dr. Benjamin Schloss of the Nucleonic Sales Company at a symposium of the American Chemical Society's New York Section.

Labor's House When a Democratic Congress enacted the Wagner Act, in 1935, only about 4,000,000 American workers belonged to unions. Under the act, "labor's Magna Charta," organized labor grew rapidly.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The recent trials of Polish and Bulgarian Socialists have been denounced here as "mockeries of justice" based on "all the usual trumped-up charges."

Those who still expect the machine age to bring the millennium got a shock of disappointment last week when the telephone company announced that it was going to raise the rates on telephones. "Isn't the whole business mechanized ?" they said.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Derby County, which lost its first game of the season to Newcastle United last Saturday, reinforced its lead in the first division of the English Football League today by defeating Portsmouth, 1 -- 0, before a home crowd of 40,000.

Discovery of a new type of brain wave that appears to be associated with the process of thinking and hence may be described as a "thought wave" is reported in Science by Drs. John L. Kennedy, Robert M. Gottsdanker, John C. Armington and Florence E. Gray of the Institute for Applied Experimental Psychology, Tufts College, Medford, Mass.
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 20 (UP) -- Lowly Louisiana State, rising up after five successive failures, struck hard and often today to upset Alabama's unpredictable Crimson Tidesmen, 26 to 6.

BEHIND the lions who never roar on Fifth Avenue and Forty-first Street there is much to attract those interested in art. This week the centenary anniversary of the New York Public Library makes an occasion for surveying the inadequately known art activities of this many-sided institution.

BERKELEY SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 20 -- Perhaps the youngest "weather man" in the nation -- and certainly in West Virginia -- 12-year-old Henry Ruppenthal 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ruppenthal Jr., has been designated official cooperative Weather Bureau observer here.
HAVERFORD, Pa., Nov. 20 -- Haverford and Swarthmore Colleges today played their third tie game in thirty-nine years of football rivalry and the first since 1914. The score was 28-all.

AFTER long years of writing successful books about Japan in particular and the Orient in general, Mr. Price has now moved west, and in a work of somewhat uneven merit gives us a lively account of his travels by land, air and water, which took him and his wife over some 23,000 miles and twenty-seven countries or colonies.

DR. KENT ROBERTS GREENFIELD, a former Johns Hopkins professor who joined the Army in 1942 wondering "what a historian could do," today has charge of the first history of its operation the Army has ever published.

The headline "Object: Objectivity" on Gershon F'ishbein's article about Brookings Institution has raised some eyebrows. Careful appraisal of Brookings activities indicates something far short of complete objectivity.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Square-jawed Ed Songin, throwing a football so muddy it had to be wiped before each play, tossed three touchdown passes today to give Boston College a 19-to-7 victory over St. Mary's of California before 13,693 fans at Braves Field.
Retail activity continued good here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Toy departments reported Christmas business under way.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- What to do about the pricing policies of American business is destined to become one of the hottest issues on the agenda of the Eighty-first Congress.

READERS of the old Harper's Weekly and Frank Leslie's illustrated periodicals will remember pleasantly the innumerable engravings that decorated their pages, engravings often remarkably detailed and accurate if somewhat stiff for the modern taste.

THE Western Conference, or Big Nine -- also known at times as the Big Seven and, before Chicago dropped out in 1939, the Big Ten -- is termed by Howard Roberts, who has made an exhaustive study of its football history, football's toughest league.

" THEATRE, U.S.A.," produced by the American National Theatre and Academy, is one of the new season's brightest and most zestful radio shows. Presented at 7:30 Thursday evenings over the ABC network, the program is by broadcasting's present-day standards practically a paradox: it is a variety show, yet it has variety.
PRAGUE, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Czechoslovak customs officers arrested two butlers on the staff of the British Embassy in Prague on the Austrian border Thursday, it was announced here tonight.

The plight of the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company's Flying Trader at Port Said, Egypt, remained unchanged yesterday, according to reports to the company. The ship has been detained there since last Sunday.

THE creator of the inimitable Moffats here gives us three fanciful tales on highly original subjects: a runaway mountain, a little girl who loses her shadow, and a giraffe who lives behind a rubber plant in an apartment house.
MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Literary Gazette attacked today what it called "western bourgeois idealists" among physicists.

" LOVE LIFE" describes itself as "a vaudeville." In the encouragement of this conceit, the show opens with a magician suspending a gentleman in mid-air as well as sawing a lady in half, and it ends with the gentleman and lady anxiously groping toward one another on a tight-rope set high above the stage.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 20 -- In the words of Senator James E. Murray of Montana, "MVA is back on the map" today.

THE theme of this new novel by Roger Vercel (whose "Tides of Mont St. Michel" won two literary awards in France and was a Book of the Month Club selection here) is a young man's coming of age. Unlike most treatments of the subject, it is not the demise of youthful illusions that besets the hero, but the crack-up of his most cherished skepticisms.

TWO things are fairly certain for the Alvin Theatre tomorrow night. Standees will leave happily after the final curtain of "Mister Roberts." And then there will be festivities upstairs in the Green Room, one of the few places where Broadway and Hollywood meet without apology or fear of snooping columnists.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 20 -- Israeli leaders hailed the United States statement to the United Nations today as an important step forward to a Palestine settlement, particularly as in their opinion it asserted publicly that the United States no longer would follow the British lead on the problem.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Either sympathizing with New York dock strikers, or afraid of them, more than a third of the crew of the world's largest ocean liner, the Queen Elizabeth, walked off the ship today and made plans to enlist crews of two other liners in their strike.

ALBANY, N.Y. Nov. 20 -- Partly because of the increased birth rate and partly because of inflationary costs, New York State faces a serious shortage of school buildings and equipment. Within the next five or six years the state will need more than $1 billion to construct school houses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- When the tumult and the shouting have died it is altogether likely that the old captains of the Republicans will not have departed a step from their party's command in the new Democratically controlled Eighty-first Congress.

Four scholars prominent in the field of medieval culture will deliver the 1948-49 guest lecture series at the Medieval Institute of the University of Notre Dame. The series will open with five lectures from Dec. 13-17 on English and French civilization in the second half of the twelfth century and close with an interpretation of "The English Critics on Civilization in the Late Twelfth Century" to be given March 21-25.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Tulane's mighty Green Wave, hopeful of a post-season bowl bid, was battled almost to a standstill today by an underdog University of Cincinnati team but managed to score a 6-0 victory before a crowd of 12,000.

A crow goes winging across the valley, looking twice as black as he did two months ago. But it's the same crow, or at least one of the same flock, and though its plumage may be new, it is no different in color. The difference is in the background, which now is gray and brown, the slightly misted, leafless woods of late autumn.

MIKE DOLAN resigns from The Daily Times-Gazette just in time to escape being fired. The reason is that the managing editor refuses to print stories which Mike thinks should be printed. Mike is a crusader at heart, and he knows that neither The Times-Gazette nor any other paper in town has any use for a reporter of that type.

BEHIND the scenes in the British House of Commons an old battle shows signs of breaking out afresh to the entertainment and enlightenment of the British public. It is expected that a reinvigorated Winston Churchill will be ready to take the offensive again in this battle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States, concluding their annual meeting here, issued a statement today on "The Christian in Action," aimed against secularism and singling out as a special target the Supreme Court decision in the McCollum case.

THE new Graham Sutherland show at the Buchholz Gallery, his second here, may be expected to stir up controversy. It is uncompromising in its own way. The laconic and disjunctive composition, matted, dead color and horny shapes are far from gratifying the eye.
AUSTIN, Minn., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Distribution of $2,401,585.60 in joint earnings payments will be started the day before Thanksgiving by Geo. A. Hormel Co., meat packers and canners.

Last week's twentieth anniversary meeting of the National Conference of Christians and Jews was held at Columbia University in this city, but it had importance for all cities and all citizens. The Conference was founded two decades ago to represent men and women of all faiths who had been shocked by the hideous doctrines of the Ku Klux Klan and kindred organizations.

Guy C. Myers, fiscal agent for a group of public utility districts in the State of Washington, was reported yesterday to have completed a comprehensive plan for early sale of three privately owned utility systems to public power groups in that state.
