THE antics of friendly chickadees, sweet whistling of tufted titmice, and the sight of a softly colored female cardinal, who is much less shy than her brilliant crimson mate, are but a few of the obvious rewards of feeding birds around the garden in winter.

Changes in steel prices and supplies, due to shifts from basing point methods to f.o.b. mill schedules, will be taken up at the next meeting of the forty-eight New York region purchasing agents attending a six-week course on "How to Buy Steel."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Held scoreless in the first half, Holy Cross' Crusaders came up with a touchdown in each of the third and fourth quarters today to defeat Temple's Owls, 13 to 7, in the fourteenth renewal of their football series before 5,000 fans.

CENSORSHIP, it has been said more than once, often manifests itself in peculiar ways. The yardstick by which the morality or lack thereof in motion pictures is measured is not necessarily the same in New York and New Jersey.

Henry Sherek in his article "Piccadilly or Broadway -- The Show Goes On" writes that the acting pace of a play is much slower in Britain than in the United States. He does not emphasize the point enough.

The first train of streamlined new subway cars for the IND division of the city subway system began operating yesterday on the Washington Heights-Brooklyn line between 207th Street and the Broadway-East New York station of the Fulton Street subway in Brooklyn.
SALONIKA, Greece, Nov. 11 -- In strife-torn Greek Macedonia, a New York institution is doing a land-office business free from molestation.

IN the mid-Nineteen Twenties two events occurred which have come to be remembered as milestones in the history of design. The first was the opening in November, 1924, of the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
WATERVILLE, Me., Nov. 20 -- Two major gift to the Colby College library have been announced by the Colby Library Associates.

With most retail stores preparing to lengthen their shopping hours for the holidays, the question again arises as to whether the hours maintained by average stores are getting maximum sales results. Retailers are giving more thought to this phase of operation now, it is reported, due to their expectations of more competitive conditions during 1949.
THERE is ample precedent for this book. Especially on Fridays, when fish dealers are busy carving fillets of sole out of unsuspecting haddock, hake or fluke.

MR. NEWMAN'S well-polished verse, let it be asserted at the outset, skips trippingly over the tongue. And as an artificer of unusual rhymes ("lollipop" with "polyp pop," "day if" with "Mendeleef," "Cro-Magnon" with "canyon") he is nearly the peer of Newman Levy, who will be remembered as the gentleman who paced "Freudian" with "annoyed he an -- ," and "stupor sent" with "two per cent" in "Thais."

Generally in the case of a gift of income-producing property, the income is taxable to the recipient of the gift, and in a gift of income from property, the income is taxable to the donor. To differentiate between these situations for income-tax purposes frequently calls for fine distinctions.

The President's Executive Order, issued at Clarksburg, W. Va., Oct. 16, providing for training of defense reserves, is a most important document. Not only is it important for civilians, the Reserves and the National Guard to read and understand, but most important for the Secretaries of the national defense establishment and ranking commissioned officers of the Armed Forces to read, understand and comply with, in fact.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 20 (UP) -- George Blanda's mighty punts behind a savage line earned Kentucky a 0-to-0 tie with Tennessee today and it could have been a victory for the Blue Grass boys but for the inaccuracy of another big toe.
The vortex is Berlin. Around the city's Western sectors, with their 2,500,000 people, swirl the principal currents and pressures in the struggle between East and West.

SCIENCE is not concerned with purpose. It does not ask why the universe is constructed as it seems to be or why life evolved on the earth, but how. There is no way of investigating purpose by the scientific method; but not all scientists have been willing to brush aside purpose in their interpretations of the cosmos.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 20 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Premier and Foreign Minister in the Socialist-Catholic coalition that resigned yesterday, agreed tonight to form a new cabinet. He is expected to submit a list of ministers to the Regent on Monday.

Described as a "dangerous criminal who went on a four-hour criminal spree," John Barfield, 25 years old, an ex-convict, who said he was a porter at 20 Sickle Street, was held without bail for the grand jury by Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Felony Court yesterday.

HALIFAX, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Halifax longshoremen were reported today to be seeking new contract negotiations and at the same time continued to work ships diverted here by the United States port strike.

MIAMI BEACH -- Royal W. Ryan, director of the New York City Convention and Visitors' Bureau, announced at a meeting of travel officials here last week that a new program of tourist promotion was being undertaken jointly by New York City and the Visitors' Bureau, a nonofficial voluntary organization.

MOST Americans of rural or small town backgrounds -- and that's still a majority of us -- remember a weekly newspaper as our earliest medium of information and entertainment. Some of us still subscribe to such a newspaper.

DUNKERQUE, France, Nov. 20 -- At dawn today 4,000 troops moved in and occupied this battered seaport's dock area. None of the striking dock workers who for five days had loudly boasted of their intention to hold the area "to the end" was to be seen.
Today President Truman returns to Washington from his two-week vacation in Key West. Great problems -- domestic and foreign -- confront him.

SAN ANTONIO -- Irregularities in the sales of automobiles and the need for finding a solution to the problem took a prominent place in discussions at the annual meeting of the American Automobile Association held here last week.

WHEN Mrs. Party was 22, her husband and her father were killed in an automobile accident. Shortly after that, her mother suffered a paralytic stroke, and she was left penniless with a house, a mortgage, an invalid and no resources of a practical nature for coping with such a perilous situation.

Production and exports of timber by several European countries rose sharply in the first half of 1948, compared with the same period a year ago, according to a study released recently by the joint timber committee of the Food and Agriculture Organization and the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Army Signal Corps claimed a new balloon altitude record today, reporting that it had sent an instrument-bearing sphere aloft to 140,000 feet, about 26 1/2 miles.

A REGULAR feature of the British weekly. The New Statesman and Nation, is the Week-End Competitions, which are exercises in wit with a flavor of literary, political or social comment or what you will.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Renewed agitation since the election for repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act focuses attention on the questions: What is the background of this much discussed law? and What does it actually provide?

For the third successive week, retail sales here lagged behind the comparative period of last year. Department store sales here were estimated at about 10 per cent below the 1947 week. Soft lines continued to reveal mixed trends, but durable goods retained a strong upward tone.

Flying back to Washington this morning, President Truman will be entering on the major tasks which will face him during the four years of his elective term. Not least among these will be foreign policy. Even though that policy has been, and is, bipartisan, there remain many questions to be decided concerning its working out. Air. Truman has had what seemed to be a pleasant vac[tion at Key West.

THE existence of Canada is a problem that ought to interest all Americans, for the similarities between Canadian and American society are so great that the differences seem hard to explain. This life of Egerton Ryerson goes a long way to explain the differences.

THE really avid gardener never loses the feel of the soil or the thrill of growing things even though the calendar says that winter is coming. Careful planning, rich potting soil, correct temperature while roots are forming and good bulbs -- all these add up to flowers in the house all winter.

With the election of President Truman and a Democratic Congress, a firmer and more definite national policy with respect to assuring an adequate supply of oil products, both in peacetime and in war, appears to be in the making. In addition, there is the likelihood of the imposition of more controls over the industry, possibly including the regulation of prices should an effort be made to increase them much above their present levels.

Effective cooperation between military and civilian authorities has resulted in markedly lowered venereal disease rates among armed force personnel in this area, it was reported yesterday by Col. John S. Roosma, Provost Marshal, First Army, at his headquarters on Governors Island.

FOR THIS WEEK: Finish planting bulbs as quickly as possible. . . . Before frost settles in the ground, make certain that all labels are in place and also at least six inches below soil level. . . . Cover the strawberry bed with straw, pine needles or peat moss. Circle young fruit trees with fine mesh wire, twelve to eighteen inches above ground, to prevent nibbling by mice and rabbits. . . .

James Friskin, pianist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The scholarly artist devoted his program to compositions by Bach, a master whose major keyboard works he has presented, from time to time, in this city with marked authority and success.

VIENNA, Nov. 20 -- A strong group among the officials responsible for United States policy here is urging that the United States declare itself opposed to the further payment of occupation costs by the Austrian Government after the end of this year.

In a blazing display of sprinting ability in the final hour, the Italian team of Alvaro Georgetti and Cesare Moretti pedalled their way to victory in the six-day bicycle race that ended at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night.

FROM 1920 until his death last February, the appearance of Burns Mantle's annual ten best plays and yearbook of the American drama had been one of the few certainties in an uncertain world. Stacked together on the library shelves, in newspaper drama departments and elsewhere, they form today the only complete record of their kind that we have, a memorable series covering the period of the native theatre's most interesting history.

LET us turn this morning to something not intended for the ages but only for a quarter of an hour of innocent pastime. Ernst von Dohnanyi, Hungarian composer, wrote Variations on a Nursery Theme in 1922 and dedicated it "to the enjoyment of lovers of humor and to the annoyance of others."

TO children the coming of winter is as exciting as the first daffodil. In this picture book 4 to 6 years olds will feel and see the bustle of a new season as the geese fly south, raccoons and chipmunks seek soft beds for their winter's sleep, rabbits dance under a pale moon, while crows, chickadees and a lonely robin prepare to sit the winter out in the haunts they love.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 20 -- People in this area were talking of plans this week for Thanksgiving and Christmas and figuring on the Southern college football teams that were likely to get bids to the big New Year's bowl contests.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- It's hard to believe, but Pitt beat proud Penn State, 7 -- 0, today.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 -- Vice President-elect Alben W. Barkley warned the American Federation of Labor convention today not to expect any great "miracle" in the form of labor legislation very early in the next Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Officials of the National Security Resources Board plan to invite labor leaders to a mid-December meeting to discuss the tentative drafts of emergency manpower, wage and price controls.

PARIS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Following is part of the text of a statement on Palestine made in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today by Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States delegate:

A service of thanksgiving for the birth of a son to Princess Elizabeth was conducted yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Bishop Charles K. Gilbert of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York presided and gave the blessing.
A 21-year-old girl, Joy DeWeese Wehen of Sausalito, Calif., was announced yesterday as the winner of an essay contest sponsored by the English-Speaking Union. Her prize was $1,000.

UDAY SHANKAR will dance in this country again with a company of his own next season. This is good news, indeed, and since he made the announcement in person from the stage of the Ninety-second Street "Y" eight days ago, it should be pretty reliable.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- A minimum of twenty-three states will assemble yuletide trains for overseas relief during the week preceding Christmas, with dedications at shipside set for Dec. 25 at ten ports according to an announcement here by John D. Metzler, chairman of the Christian Rural Overseas program, sponsor of the trains.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Pakistan will have to take "appropriate military measures" unless something is done to correct the situation in Kashmir within a few days, Defense Secretary Iskander Mirza said today.

The Hotel Association of New York announced yesterday that it would seek hearings before Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh so that owners and operators could present their views of operating problems in the face of rising costs.

UNITED STATES stamps -- singles, blocks, sheets, covers -- from the collection of Harold L. Ickes, who was Secretary of the Interior in the Cabinets of Presidents Roosevelt and Truman, realized approximately $20,300 when sold at public auction by Edson J. Fifield at 500 Fifth Avenue last week.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Eamon de Valera said in Manchester today too much fuss had been made about the consequences of Ireland's intention to sever her last constitutional link with Britain.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Selling toward the close of the market either reduced or completely wiped out early advances in grains on the Board of Trade today. Some of the selling in wheat came from the Southwest and was said perhaps to represent hedging, but for the most part the late slump was attributed to profit-taking after a week of firm markets.

SALEM N.H., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Anthony J. Ryan's Rabies was a handy victor today in the Rockingham Park Autumn Handicap on the final day of the 84-day season that ended horse-racing in New England for 1948.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Sheriff John C. Leighton of Ossipee, N.H., announced tonight that the mystery of the slaying of Ruth Eisenberg of this city had been solved by the arrest of a wood chopper and the finding of the woman's wrist watch in his cabin at Rochester, N.H.

BY clever -- and painstaking -- editing, Ira Henry Freeman has succeeded with this anthology of excerpts from sailing stories in doing what so many fiction writers strive for: to paint a state of mind with words. Small craft, deep-sea sailing is a challenge and adventure.

YOU may believe, if you will, that everything that is beautiful is useful. Or conversely, you may believe that everything that is useful is beautiful. You may believe that "beauty is its own excuse for being." You may believe that beauty is merely an abstract and inherited superstition, and that everything is ugly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- An underrated George Washington football team today rose up to smash Georgetown by 13 -- 7 and end a jinx that had held since 1890. In the 58 years these teams have played football eighteen times, and never before had George Washington won. Two games ended in ties.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A quasi-official recommendation that the United States give heavy military aid, or none at all, to the Chinese Nationalist Government, in its desperate struggle against the Communists, was made public today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- The two former soldiers who lost both arms and both legs in World War II are on the road to becoming self-supporting citizens, the Veterans Administration reported today.

The European Recovery Program was characterized in a radio address yesterday by Ivan Matteo Lombardo, Italian Minister of Industry and Commerce, as a messenger of faith and encouragement to profitable and united work. Signor Lombardo is in the United States on a special mission for his Government and his address was broadcast in the "Voice of Local 89," weekly radio hour.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Southern California's Trojans and the Bruins of U.C.L.A. fought a bitter crosstown rivalry today and the favored Trojans ground out a 20-13 football triumph before 76,577 wildly excited followers.

AT Sunday evening performances, especially those given by the Phoenix Society, I used to admire Mr. Eliot's faultless dress, white waistcoat and all: whether at an evening party, or in the country (you will remember the "four piece suit") or in the city, always the poet made himself inconspicuous by the appropriateness of his costume.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Bishop Loughlin High of New York continued its stranglehold on the Eastern Interscholastic cross-country championship by easily defeating the field for the fourth straight year today.

THIS latest book to land on golfing fairway is the work of the present British open champion: a player of unusual perseverance and merit, Henry Cotton first won the "open" in 1934, repeated in 1937 and then achieved the distinction of winning once more (at the age of forty-one) in 1948.

IN "The Welcome," his second published novel, Hubert Creekmore has written what professes to be "a novel of modern marriage." As a novel it is a highly readable production; as an examination of modern marriage it comes closer to failure than it does to success.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20 -- A possible connection between a diet high in protein and a low incidence of heart disease was among the findings listed today in the report on a joint scientific expedition to the Aleutian Islands.

James Reston's article, "The Qualifies a President Needs," would lose half its meaning if we had been wise enough to accustom ourselves to the idea of women Presidents as the English and others are used to the idea of women sovereigns.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 20 -- The end of the seventy-ninth Rutgers football season today came with a 28-19 victory over Fordham this sunny afternoon before a gathering of 10,000.

GRANDMA SMITH, a hopeless invalid who knows that she has not long to live, sends for her granddaughter, Anne McGraw, to whom she wishes to confide a secret. But the girl who arrives is not Anne McGraw but Anne Hillyer.

An Associated Press story, dated Nov. 11, headed "Bears Jumping the Gun on Pennsylvania Hunters," told of increased activity by the animals as the opening of the big-game season drew near. This short item reminded the writer of an amusing editorial noticed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of early September, 1883.

PARIS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Argentine Foreign Minister Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, President of the Security Council, received today a long Russian reply to his questionnaire on the Berlin currency dispute.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The universal right to rest, leisure, reasonably limited working hours and paid holidays was adopted today as part of the draft of the International Declaration of Human Rights by the Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Gross national production reached a record annual rate of $256,000,000,000 in the third quarter of this year, an increase of nearly $6,000,000,000 over the preceding quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Michigan State's spirited Spartans, rolling almost at will on the ground, closed their home football season before 36,045 fans today with an impressive 40-to-0 rout of Washington State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Members of the Army, Navy and Air Force reserves who receive pay for drills and other training on inactive duty will be taxed after Jan. 1 for all income received from the government. The services said today that tax payments would be withheld at the source from military pay in the same manner as taxes are deducted from civilian pay.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- Approval of thirty-one hospital construction projects, eleven of them in the metropolitan New York area, as recipients of Federal grants-in-aid during the first and second years of the five-year construction program was announced today by the State Joint Hospital Survey and Planning Commission.

This is frankly a jeremiad on the commonness which has befallen the concert stage, with particular emphasis on singers. I write it not from a sense of permanent disillusionment but out of sorrow for the parlous times we are now passing through.

With few dissenting votes, the organized realty interests of the country went on record here yesterday as favoring prompt liquidation of all Federal housing and elimination of residential rent controls.

The domestic air transport industry, which has sustained heavy financial losses since the end of the war, is ready to press for substantially higher mail pay as the only possible solution to current serious difficulties, airline executives disclosed last week.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 20 (UP) -- Duke forgot to watch Charley Justice just once today. It was a fatal lapse. For after that North Carolina's Golden Boy aroused the Tarheels to a 20-to-0 victory and a certain Bowl assignment before 43,500 fans.

Clarification of the patent situation in Japan is one of the vital steps toward restoration of the economy of that country and toward a revival of participation of American companies in industrial progress there, it was said here last week.

The Maritime Commission and special committees of the shipping industry are engaged in intensive preparation of legislative programs for the Eighty-first Congress and expect to have them ready for the law-making bodies by the middle of next month, it became known yesterday.

In a letter printed in last Sunday's TIMES, Sheridan Gibney, president of the Screen Writers Guild, accuses me of what he terms is a flagrant violation of a decision rendered by the Guild Board of Arbitration. Mr. Gibney's accusation is based on the fact that in an interview with your Mr. Pryor, I mentioned that I thought it would be appropriate if Arthur Laurents received some acknowledgment for his contribution to "The Snake Pit."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Agustin Edwards, one of Chile's leading bankers, has a plan for United States investors to put their money in Latin American industries and get their dividends in dollars.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Purdue rose to its early season power today and smashed Indiana, 39 to 0, to bring the Old Oaken Bucket back to Lafayette.

The recent note in The Sunday TIMES called "Provincialism" did not seem quite fair. Though Bostonians have a special reputation, I do not think that the genuine music lovers of this city deserve to be called provincial. You should see how crowded the concerts are that the Harvard University music department, for example, gives, be the music performed ultra modern or well established.

TORONTO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins moved into a tie for the National Hockey League leadership with Detroit and the Toronto Maple Leafs crept out of the cellar as the clubs played to a 2-2 draw before 14,560 fans tonight. The world champion Leafs now have failed to register a victory in their last seven starts.

For the first time since it has had beautiful and rare books to display, the New York Public Library on Tuesday will be able to show some stellar examples in its collections to their greatest advantage.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- Although the airlift into Berlin, by which the Western sectors of this blockaded city live, has suffered a considerable reduction in tonnage carried thus far in November. American and British air officers are confident that transport planes will be able to maintain Berlin throughout the winter and even, when it grows colder, boost the pay load back to something approximating the shipments during the summer.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Vanderbilt's rampant Commodores ran their string of victories to six straight today with an easy 34-0 triumph over Maryland. A near-capacity crowd of 21,000 saw Maryland's Terrapins drop their third game and their first without scoring at least two touchdowns.

THE first of a series of guided camera trips by air will start for Puerto Rico Wednesday afternoon, returning to New York Sunday night. Organized by Jay Florian Mitchell, 56 West Forty-fifth Street, the group will meet at Teterboro Airport to board a twenty-eight-seat chartered DC-3 plane for a Thanksgiving week-end of picture-taking under Mr. Mitchell's guidance.

The Olympic Games, first of six new tankers for the Olympic Oil Lines, left here yesterday afternoon on her maiden voyage, it was announced by A.S. Onassis, president of the Panamanian corporation. The new ship is bound for Aruba, and thence to Dakar in Africa.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 20 -- The role of law publishers has grown tremendously in recent years, according to Lowe Berger, a vice president of the Bobbs-Merrill Company here.
OMAHA, Nov. 20 -- There is no way of making farming an easy job, but Midwestern farmers are being reminded by a series of meetings that much of the drudgery is being removed.

The appointment of Louter C. Westhoff as inspector in Brazil for the newly formed Holland Interamerica Line was announced yesterday by Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager of the Holland-America Line in the United States, Canada and Mexico.

Declaring that pessimism and a sour outlook on life are more harmful than most diseases, Dr. Simon R. Blatteis, consulting internist and pathologist of the Jewish Hospital, in an interview in his home at 80 Winthrop Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, prescribed for longevity "work, coupled with sufficient relaxation and diversion."

In the article titled "Laughs From Europe" you ask, "Has European humor dried up under the pressure of post-war hardships?" The answer is a very definite, and unqualified, "No." Nor do our humorists limit themselves, as your article seems to suggest, to satirizing our misfortunes.

A personal visit from a real, live and easy-talking Santa may now be arranged through an organization which started out as a personal gesture, but since has grown into a corporation. Manned by persons well acquainted with the art of the theatre, and augmented by the needed do-how from a business sense, Santa's Helpers, Inc., today boasts of the pick of stage, screen and radio performers to act the part of Santa for children.

SIR ARTHUR QUILLER-COUCH used to tell new acquaintances that his hyphenated Cornish name did not rhyme with sofa. But in England, at least, the question seldom arose. From his native Cornwall to his alma mater. Oxford Un/versity, and on to the great sister-unieaity at Cambridge, 'here he axniably lectured for thirty-odd years. everyone knew Sir Arthur by his pen-name of Q.
MR. DOUGLAS, still more magnificently obsessed than inspired, continues his religious fictionalizing in this lengthy new novel built around the life of Simon Peter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization hopes to solve its personal housing problem Monday by deciding what to do about a permanent home.

ACAPULCO, Mexico -- This tropical resort, nestling in the foothills of the Sierra Madre Mountains on the shores of the Pacific Ocean, is ready to prove that it no longer should be considered exclusively the playground for those with unlimited funds.

The new state-subsidized teacher training program of the city's four municipal colleges will meet the Board of Education's annual demand for 1,000 additional elementary school teachers in the next five years, Dr. Paul Klapper, temporary dean of teacher education, declared yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH -- Extension of the drive for repeal at the January session of Congress of the 15 per cent Federal travel tax to a nationwide campaign was voted here last week by the annual meeting of the National Association of Travel Officials.

Agreement by representatives of the five European countries that call themselves the Western Union on a North Atlantic defense pact will, if the United States and Canada subscribe to it, raise against any aggressor a barrier of almost 250,000,000 persons, whose seven countries are the most industrialized and collectively the strongest of any like political grouping in the world today.

Assistant Curator, the Museum of Modern Art Film Library To the current crop of new film talents must be added yet another European, Arne Sucksdorff. Sucksdorff, a Swede, has already gained some recognition abroad. His pictures won an award at the International Film Festival at Cannes, and two "Charlies" -- the Swedish equivalent of the American "Oscar" -- in his own country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (NANA) -- The Truman family has widely different tastes on bedroom decorations in Blair House, into which they will move upon their return to the capital.

ON a tiny budget, and for a tiny but enthusiastic band of televiewers, France's government-controlled television has moved forward since the end of the war to a point where in many ways it equals, and in a few instances surpasses, America's richly endowed commercial video.

As the United Nations General Assembly meeting in Paris nears its end, public attention on international affairs is focused on the results and accomplishments of their deliberations. This is "The United Nations" with which most people are familiar.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 20 -- Michigan's mighty Wolverines, their ground attack stymied by a stalwart Ohio State team, took to the airways today and came from behind to win, 13 -- 3.

MISS LEWITON'S first novel was an understanding study of one girl's adjustment to her parents' divorce. For this new book she has chosen an even more difficult theme to translate into teen-agers' terms. During her last year in high school Brook Falter and her older brother.

HERE is a beautifully printed and illustrated book about an idyllic cruise through the West Indies. It is, however, the tale of a cruise that only a few can make, an expensive trip that included a paid hand and entailed, to make things more costly, transporting a 46-foot ketch aboard a liner to the point of departure, Trinidad.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- An amazing five-touchdown scoring spree in the fourth quarter today gave Villanova College a 46-13 victory over San Francisco University before 10,000 at Shibe Park.

ACTORS EQUITY should require producers to list their needs at a central office. A bulletin board, such as in an airplane company's reservation office, should list these by categories. An actor who plays a certain line of parts could look at his section of the board to see if there is an opportunity for him.
UNION CITY, N.J., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Bergen Junior College rounded out its undefeated, untied season at Roosevelt Stadium today with a 19.6 triumph over Lincoln University of Chester County, Pa.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- Fear that the reparations plan adopted last year may be wiped out by the inquiry into the dismantling of German factories will be expressed in the French memorandum on the Ruhr that will be completed tomorrow for submission to Secretary of State Marshall.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- By a 44-to-6 vote the United Nations General Assembly's ad hoc political committee decided today to ask for another year of life for the Little Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Gideon's Army that Henry A. Wallace led through ten months of spectacular campaigning is bivouacked uneasily today on the Plains of Indecision. The dilemma that faces these forces is this: Shall they stack their arms and give up the fight, or close their ranks and carry on?

While recognizing the need for both basic and applied research, textile manufacturers have been showing a tendency to tighten up on laboratory expenditures, it was pointed out last week by testing instrument manufacturers. In the last year instrument sales have fallen off by more than 25 per cent and the backlog of orders carried over from war years has been entirely liquidated.

EXCEPT for a very short introductory story of Bleriot's first landing at Dover, these eighteen stories are all up to date, even including one of a supersonic test flight. There are stories of pilots overcoming fear, of emergencies, of a dog that saved a B-29, and a rabbit's foot that saved a squadron.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 20 -- Federal District Judge Luther M. Swygert ruled today that it "would appear" that the International Typographical Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, had complied with "the terms of purgation" of a contempt decree the court issued Oct. 14.
WHAT often seems to the parent or teacher an expression of something bad, needing strong corrective treatment, may be the child's own efforts to grow and develop, his striving to mature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The move for reform of the system by which Presidents and Vice Presidents are chosen through the agency of the Electoral College will doubtless be strengthened by the analyses of the returns of Nov. 2 which emphasize that the nation had a narrow escape from the projection of the contest into the House of Representatives for decision.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 20 -- Although the question of South-West Africa still has to be decided by the General Assembly of the United Nations, all South African parties hailed today as a victory for South Africa a resolution adopted last night by the Trusteeship Committee.

PETER VIERECK is primarily a poet of ideas. The ideas that have been flying around in his head for the past eight years find resolution in sporadic order. There's the rub: much tumult, much prestidigitation, variety of trials and effort, considerable learning, and the result is an uneven book of poems containing a good number of excellently realized pieces.
Banking executives are becoming increasingly concerned over the legality of "delayed posting" of checks and eagerly are awaiting a decision in the matter by the Federal Reserve Board.

WITH the seasons of Thanksgiving and Christmas pushing hard on the calendar, this morning's news appropriately enough concerns itself with two drives, for funds that show business will be putting on shortly.

Two of the most important problems of industry can be solved to a large degree through the use of equipment now available from America's office equipment manufacturers, Edward M. Douglas, president of the Office Equipment Manufacturers Institute, Washington, D.C., declared yesterday during an interview at the Harvard Club.

A 15-year-old Indian boy from the Republic of Panama, whose jaws have been fused together since birth, is in the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, 210 East Sixty-fourth Street, for a series of three major operations to restore his face to normal.

Brooklyn College's hopes for its best season in history were rudely upset by an underdog Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute eleven yesterday. The Engineers scored in every period to triumph by 47 -- 13 before 5,000 at the Flatbush field.

Doing all of its scoring in the first half, Manual Training captured the Public School Athletic League mythical championship of New York City by defeating Lafayette, 13 -- 0, at Ebbets Field yesterday. It was Manual's sixth straight victory.

THE opening sentence of an article written by Howard Taubman in your paper a short time ago: "A good measure of a man's musicianship is the quality of his ensemble playing," encourages me to write this letter.

GOOD technique in bridge is a matter, primarily, of giving yourself every possible chance to win a trick, no matter how far-fetched that chance may seem. The player whose technique is imperfect will often give up, on the assumption that a position is hopeless, where the fine technician will look for every break -- and, once in a blue moon, find a trick that wasn't there.

EVERY young poet whose apprenticeship has fallen during the last twenty years must feel that T.S. Eliot's eminence cannot wholly be accounted for by the excellence of his verse and criticism. The achievement of Yeats and Joyce we have admired no less than Eliot's.

Joseph Burns and Cardinal Sandiford of Iona College took an early lead in the City College invitation cross-country meet yesterday and held it over the five-mile Van Cortlandt Park trail to lead their team to victory over C.C.N.Y. by one point, 34 -- 35.

Early in the session of the United Nations Assembly, which began the middle of September, the Russian delegation proposed that the members of the Big Five agree forthwith to cut their armaments one-third in the next year. Thereafter there was tacked onto the resolution a provision banning the use of the atom bomb in warfare.

TOKYO, Nov. 20 -- There is a growing realization in both the Allied Supreme Command and in Japanese official circles that it is useless for Japan to expect any considerable foreign investments here until the present tax system, which is regarded as unfair, is modified.

Theatre parties continue as a means of raising funds for various philanthropic organizations. Headed by Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell, women who have long been active in the research work of the New York Botanical Garden have taken over the performance of "Kiss Me, Kate," the new Cole Porter musical production, on the night of Jan. 10 at the Century Theatre.

The formation of a cancer-prevention committee headed by Dr. William E. Smith, a member of the staff of the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, a division of Memorial Hospital Center, was announced yesterday.

FORTY years ago Julius Rosenwald, a native and resident of Springfield. Ill., where Abraham Lincoln lies buried, was shocked by an anti-Negro riot and lynching in the town. That event started him on a long and devoted career of safeguarding rights and gaining wider privileges for all suppressed peoples, in particular Negroes.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Brian Bell Jr. scored three touchdowns today as Washington and Lee University conquered the University of Delaware, 21 -- 14, before a crowd of 7,500.

THIS week will see the first pre-Broadway appearances of the Spanish dancer, Mariemma, as well as the formal recital debut of Jose Torres, another Spanish artist, who first appeared here as a guest with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo earlier in the season.

THIS is the best novel out of New Zealand I have seen since John Mulgan's "Man Alone" was published in 1939. Better still, it is a first-rate performance in its own right and well able to do battle for public attention on its individual merits.

NO city could match New York in military importance during the American Revolution. Second only to Boston for its rebellious spirit, the city witnessed Stamp Act riots, liberty poles and its own tea party. Later the scene of severe fighting, the city watched the defeat and evacuation of Washington's troops.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A six-year college course for the druggist, with the degree of Doctor of Pharmacy, was the goal set in a first report today from the two-year pharmaceutical survey sponsored by that industry and the American Council on Education.

In theory at least there is much to be said in favor of your suggestion last Sunday that certain films -- notably "The Snake Pit" -- be shown to specialized audiences. Under the present system of exhibition, though, I'm not quite so sure that this would prove practical.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- It is customary on occasions like the birth of a baby to Princess Elizabeth last Sunday to be gushing and sentimental. In fact, it is almost unavoidable and the very force of that impulsion was, in itself, a measure of the importance of the event.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 20 -- A plan aimed at improving the health of the estimated 39,000,000 children of the nation will be presented for discussion at a general session of the American Academy of Pediatrics here on Monday. It will include a preliminary recommendation for Federal aid for pediatric education, tempered with a suggestion that "action to seek Federal aid be held in abeyance without prejudice."

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- Gustav Klingelhoefer, chief of the city's economic department, called on the three Western Allies today to merge their sectors into one administrative unit and incorporate it politically and economically with the Western zones.

OTTAWA, Nov. 20 -- When William L Mackenzie King handed over his office as Prime Minister of Canada to Louis St Laurent last Monday, he might have boasted, although he did not, that he was handing over the direction of one of the most prosperous countries in the world.

Still fighting desperately to elect a Democrat as New York County Surrogate despite an officially-announced victory for George Frankenthaler, Republican, Tammany Hall's law committee moved yesterday to invalidate the absentee and war ballots cast for Mr. Frankenthaler.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 20 -- President Truman will end his two-week vacation here tomorrow morning and fly to the capital, facing important decisions both in the international and domestic fields. Topping his schedule will be a foreign affairs conference with George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, on Monday.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 20 -- Prime Minister Lee Bum Suk told the Korean National Assembly today that United States troops were preparing to withdraw from Korea.

AS the holiday shopping season approaches, retailers are more than a little concerned over the falling off in sales which has been registered in recent weeks. They had looked for increases of 5 to 10 per cent in the last quarter of the year but a definite sag has developed.

To strengthen America's economic fabric and to preserve its way of life, disciplined minds, objective scholarship and first-class business and financial talent are needed now more than ever, according to Edward F. McGinley, vice president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Now that representatives of the six powers interested in the control of the Ruhr are meeting in London to implement the plan for an International Authority for the Ruhr agreed upon last spring, it is apparent that the French are not fully persuaded that their interests were adequately guarded.

ORANGE, Va., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Adaptable 7-year-old bay gelding from the stables of Ella A. Widener of Philadelphia, came home first today in the Noel Laing steeplechase handicap, feature race of the Montpelier Hunt Races.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20 -- In two weeks, Argentine voters will go to the polls to choose representatives to the convention that is to reform the national constitution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The International Association of Machinists, largest independent union in the country, urged today that a joint committee of Congress conduct an investigation of lobbying in Washington.

TOKYO, Nov. 20 -- The Japanese Government today adopted tentatively a supplementary budget for 1945 of 62,500,000,000 yen [more than $2,600,000,000], the largest part of which will go for improvement in the pay of public employes.

The average New Yorker's Thanksgiving dinner will cost 12 per cent more than last year and 93 per cent more than it did in 1941, according to a report submitted yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer by Market Commissioner Eugene Schulz.
THE essence of Thanksgiving is that it must be as it has been before. Change the cranberries for chutney, the onions for asparagus, the mince pie for a mousse au chocolat, and what have you?

BUENOS AIRES -- The inevitable fatigue of a flight of 5,500 miles in less than twenty-four hours has been greatly lessened by the luxurious comfort of sleeper planes with which Pan American World Airways and Panagra are nightly linking the tip of Florida with Gen. Juan Domingo Peron's impressive capital on the Rio de la Plata.

In a thrilling battle that had the fans in a constant state of excitement, the New York Knickerbockers went into a second-place tie with Boston in the Eastern Division of the Basketball Association of America last night by halting the Philadelphia Warriors, 91 to 86, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

" TWICE A YEAR," the magazine of which Dorothy Norman is the founder and the editor and Alfred Stieglitz was until his death (and still is) the tutelary spirit, has been with us for a decade. I can still recall my pleasure in Paris, in the ominous fall of 1939, coming across an early issue of "Twice a Year," and first noticing its subtitle: "A Book of Literature, the Arts and Civil Liberties."

LEONIA, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Leonia High School's football team kept its hopes for Northern New Jersey interscholastic league's honors alive today by beating Teaneck High School, 20 -- 6. The setback prevented the previously undefeated Highwaymen from clinching the laurels.

Hook and Ladder Company 9, one of the oldest and proudest outfits in the New York Fire Department, is to move, reluctantly, tomorrow from the antiquated quarters at 209 Elizabeth Street that have been its home for eighty-seven years.

The Morristown Polo Club defeated Ramapo, 11 to 10, on Bob Johnson's shot in 3:45 minutes of a sudden death overtime period last night in the featured game of a double-header at the Squadron A Armory. Ben Johnson, brother of Bob and one of the three members of the family making up the Morristown side, scored the goal in the final 10 seconds of the regular play to send the game into the extra session.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 20 -- The 300,000 independent union workers in this state will get a fourth round of wage increases, Clarence F. Swann of Livingston, president of the Independent Unions of New Jersey, said today.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 20 -- Politically, strategically and economically, Spain, the most important dictatorship state in Western Europe, stands today at a crossroads. In historical terms a period of extremely slow political transition is in process.
PARIS, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Government leaders conferred today on the possibility of arresting and prosecuting Communist leaders caught inciting workers to sabotage or troops to desertion or mutiny.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 20 -- A declaration of civil rights for an end of segregation and discrimination and proposing individual, group and legislative action in support of the program was adopted this afternoon by a group of more than forty men and women representing almost every Southern state.

ALARMED by the shrinkage in business, the theatre industry will hold a general symposium next January to study the problem and to hear proposals for a solution. At a time when employment is unprecedentedly high in the country as a whole, more than 80 per cent of the professional actors are unemployed, and the same situation obtains in one degree or another in all the allied professions and crafts.

ATHENS, Nov. 20 -- The Chamber of Deputies met late today, with packed galleries, to hear the revived coalition Government of Populists and Liberals under Premier Thermistocles Sophoulis, 87-year-old Liberal chief, defend itself.

A pageant of six giant balloons, seventeen bedecked floats and nine bands, dispersed among 400 costumed marchers, will escort Santa Claus to town in Macy's Twenty-second Annual Thanksgiving Day Parade, the store announced yesterday.

Cleveland and San Francisco, twin titans of the All-America Conference, will display their showy wares for the benefit of local professional football fans today. The Browns will oppose the Yankees at the Stadium before an expected gathering of 40,000 and the Forty-Niners will face the Dodgers at Ebbets Field before about 10,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Dartmouth closed the books on its finest football season in years today by registering a smashing 33-to-13 triumph over Princeton. The victory completed a clean sweep over the Big Three for Tuss McLaughry's Indians.

I read with deep appreciation James Reston's brilliant article entitled, "The Qualities a President Needs." Your readers might be interested to know what John Adams wrote in 1776 about the requisites which should be possessed by the head of the United Colonies:

DETROIT, Nov. 20 -- Family agencies throughout the country were called on today by Frank J. Hertel, general director of the Family Service Association of America, to support public welfare programs providing financial assistance to families in need.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Kearney Oldsmobile Company, which figured in a House group's investigation of practices in the automobile sales business, has had its franchise canceled.

KONITSA, Greece. THIS is the story of Anastasia Noussis. It is the story of war and intervals of peace, of poverty and pride, of distress and the rising above distress. It is a commentary on Greece today.

HENRY CASTER adds the Spanglers to America's fictional list of happy families, with some fine sentiments, solid adventure and a wealth of lusty melodrama. The Spanglers are a nineteenth-century Pennsylvania Dutch family whose gustatorial habits remind us nostalgically of the Washington Irving era of fabulous food.

TOKYO, Nov. 20 -- More than a week after the sentences were imposed on Hideki Tojo and his fellow war criminals by the eleven-nation International Military Tribunal, both Japanese and Americans here were still attempting to assess the true meaning of the court's decision and, particularly, the implications of that decision for the future of Japan.
The Board of Elections announced yesterday that President Truman received a plurality of 138,558 votes in New York County last Election Day, with a total of 754,708 votes cast in Manhattan.

WHAT do people in Mexico City think of New York City? An informal poll from among both those who had been in New York and those who had not revealed almost all as having an opinion, some highly laudatory, others critical.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20 -- Brookmeade Stable's Inseparable, ridden by the sensational apprentice, Clarence Picou, drove to a head victory at Bowie today in the twenty-third running of the $10,000 added Prince George Autumn Handicap.

TO celebrate its 'twentieth anniversary, the Museum of Modern Art has set out to prove that modern art is no illegitimate child, but that it has a respectable family tree and can trace its lineage as far back as 75,000 B.C.

LAST year Jean Bothwell gave us a charming story of school life in India, as seen through the eyes of a boy pupil. Young readers who followed the education of the "River Boy of Kashmir" will welcome a new treat, the story of a little girl at a school with the lovely name of Charity Abide.

SINCE the end of World War II the public has been badgered and bewildered by a flood of books about that conflict -- especially about the Anglo-American campaigns in the Mediterranean and northwest Europe. There have been books written to prove that General This or Field Marshal That won the war.

A Stuyvesant team representing Connecticut and Westchester County defeated Boston, 3 -- 1, as competition started in the two-day Northeast field hockey tournament at Hunter College yesterday. A sectional combination for the national championship at Winnetka, Ill., next week-end will be selected on the conclusion of play today.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway's scheduled borrowing this week of $40,000,000 on long-term bonds is expected to throw light on a question of railroad financing which is likely to crop up more and more in the future if the strong post-was cash position of the carriers should become depleted generally.

THE latest Nobel Prize winner for Literature, Thomas Stearns Eliot, is tall and stooped, attentive, a little remote, and looks like a trapped, graceful bird. Mr. Eliot was appointed a member of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton (no connection with the university except a cooperative one), and arrived there on Oct. 1.

THE production shutdown by Warner Brothers until after Jan. 1, coupled with the earlier stoppage of filming at Eagle Lion and the prospect that RKO's production will stay at a minimum for another eight weeks, has given Hollywood a gloomy outlook for the Christmas season.

" MAN IS STRONG" was first published in Italy under the censorship of the Fascist Government. Although the novel is supposedly about the Soviet police state, suspicious Italian authorities cut portions of the first edition.

FOR Thanksgiving the airlines, railroads and bus companies will, as in past years, provide extra service for the crowds coming into and leaving the city for what will be a four-day holiday for many Americans.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- One million new elementary public school teachers are needed by the United States at the rate of 100,000 annually for the next ten years, according to an estimate in a teacher-recruitment program announced here today by a joint committee of the National Education Association and the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

WE all know, of course, that life goes on and on. But Anya Seton, in her new novel about ten generations of the Honeywood family, seems firmly bent on proving that life -- life in Marblehead, Mass., anyway -- goes on and on and on and on and on.

Dr. RALPH BIENFANG of the University of Oklahoma: Don't be surprised if the perfume advertisement in your daily newspaper some day smells fetchingly lovely, while, on the next page, the butcher's ad gives off with a steaky scent mingled with the odor of frying onions.

The threat of a work stoppage tomorrow morning by 4,000 truck drivers of Local 282, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, was continued despite the signing yesterday of contracts with fifty-five of the 466 truckers affected.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 20 -- Lafayette beat Lehigh for the fifty-fourth time today in the long football rivalry that has extended through eighty-four games, but nearly half of the 21,000 fans that formed the first sell-out crowd here departed feeling that the 23-13 Lafayette triumph was a rank injustice.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 20 -- The calendar shows that the rainy season now should be well under way on the West Coast. But the precipitation in parts of California, even below last year's subnormal at this time, is causing residents to wonder whether another period of drought, with accompanying power problems, is indicated.

THE week just ended, dating its beginning from an election day which may assume memorable proportions in American history, has to this department, and perhaps to many others, seemed full of signs and portents.

Five million dollars has been set as the goal in a three-year capital funds campaign announced yesterday by Barnard College authorities. The money will be used for improving the physical plant of the college, including a new academic building and improvements in Milbank Hall.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 20 -- With Government reports showing a record level of prosperity on ranches and farms, stockmen and growers nevertheless are "talking poor." This is, of course, a traditional wintertime sport in these parts.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 20 -- New York University's eleven, pointing for its important game with Fordham next week, barely got a workout today as it romped to a 35-6 triumph over the United States Merchant Marine Academy before 5,000 persons at Tomb Field.

HE always arrives promptly, and he feigns joviality to disguise his impatience and irritation. To him an interview is an opportunity to expand or to expound. "I've done a lot of magazine work," he says, "and I've written on a couple of movies.
BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- Unusually well-informed Western sources in Moscow believe that a division exists within the Politburo of the Communist party on the vital question of war or peace with the West.
THE triumph of London's operatic season to date is a "new" opera by Verdi, of all people -- "Simon Boccanegra" -- given for the first time in London this month by the Sadler's Wells company.
ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Georgia Bulldogs, outplayed most of the first half, unleashed a four-touchdown barrage in the last half today to defeat under-manned Furman, 33 -- 0.

CLEMSON, S.C., Nov. 20 (AP) -- It took the undefeated Clemson Tigers almost a full quarter to get started today, but after they got their first touchdown they went on to a decisive 42-0 conquest of Duquesne University from Pittsburgh.

WHEN the oil industry began its startling history roughly ninety years ago in northwestern Pennsylvania, it was fortunate enough to have an unofficial and unsolicited recording secretary in John A. Mather, an Englishman by birth, a photographer by trade and a patient and astute worker by temperament. Mather took thousands of photographs and although many of the negatives were destroyed, enough remained for a permanent record of those hectic days.

THE plot against Charles Graham has been in preparation for a long time, and the preparation has been most thorough. As the first result of it he finds himself without a home or a wife or a business. A stranger who looks enough like Charles to be his twin has taken his place with the connivance of Mrs. Graham and of Buster Cox, who is Graham's business partner.

It would be a perceptive thing for THE TIMES to indicate once in a while that the South is, in its virtues as well as its shortcomings, an integral part of the United States. Since I moved down here I cannot see that my new neighbors are profoundly different from the old ones.

IF "The Snake Pit" is as good a film as your critic and other critics claim, I cannot agree with Mr. Crowther that there is danger in presenting the picture in a so-called "indiscriminate 'entertainment' house."

Progress has been made throughout the country in breaking down discrimination in professional medical education and accommodation, but "there is evidence that Negroes are not fully exploiting all educational opportunities now open to them," according to Dr. W. Montague Cobb of Howard University.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Nov. 20 -- A national chaplains' "wing" within the Air Force Association has been started by fifteen chaplains of the World War II who were with the Air Force, the Air Defense Command announced here today.

WHILE doldrums and shutdowns have hit several Hollywood studios, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer plans to make more pictures in the immediate future than heretofore, Dore Schary, production chief of the studio, stated last week.

THERE are probably few persons in the United States who have been as close to the field of social work for so long a time as has Charles S. Bernheimer. For more than half a century he has devoted his energies to all phases of social welfare: relief, rehabilitation, educational and cultural advancement.

The slow-down in ready-to-wear sales last week was partly offset by an increase in Christmas shopping, according to a report on activity in the wholesale apparel market here, prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

THE Metropolitan Opera shows no sign of being affected by the economic recession that has been felt in other branches of the entertainment industry. The box office does not open for single-seat sales till Tuesday, but already there is so much money from subscriptions safely in the till that Earl R. Lewis, assistant manager in charge of the box office, is predicting another "walloping" season.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Wesleyan University Cardinals combined a passing and running attack today to defeat a game University of Rochester eleven, 26 -- 0, for their twenty-third successive football victory.

The most decisive battle of China's civil war was being fought last week around Suchow, the city which commands the gateway to Nationalist China's capital at Nanking. Should Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist forces win the battle the Nanking regime will get a breathing spell.

UNQUALIFIED enthusiasm for "The Fire Balloon" will make it hard to sustain a moderate complacency while reviewing it. Usually complacency is safer, because then you don't have so many differing people wondering what ailed you -- but if anybody turns up who doesn't like this salty novel of herring fishermen, their women folk, and some outside adventurers, male and female, the ailing is on his side.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The Western democracies must either fight Russia before she develops an atomic bomb or lie down and let the Soviet govern them, Lord Russell, British philosopher, who is better known to the public as Bertrand Russell, said today.

Taking all conditions into consideration, the Port of New York is as safe as any other in the country, in the opinion of James R. Young, president of the Security Bureau, Inc. The bureau is an organization of maritime industry companies, formed to combat waterfront theft and pilferings in this harbor.

AT the risk of destroying her own reputation, Patricia Kingsley perjures herself to give Steven Blake an alibi for the time when Jeff Nulty was murdered. The jury brings in a verdict of not guilty despite Blake's sworn statement that Mrs. Kingsley's testimony is untrue.

For not only is it primarily a titanic spectacle film, set in the same general region and the same era as the Olivier masterpiece, with costumes and modes and even characters conspicuously common to each, but it is shaped on the same dramatic structure as the pictorialized Shakespearean play.

IT may be less difficult to understand Russians and their attitude toward world events if we know the kind of news Russians are getting from their newspapers. What Ivan thinks stems from what he reads.

THE Peterson bird guides are generally thought of as the most useful handbooks of their kind ever published. If no better than Chapman's, for example, in textual coverage, they are far superior on the illustrative side, and correspondingly a boon to the beginner still in process of training his eye.

Security trading settled down to follow an irregular pattern last week as the "fear" selling of the two preceding weeks exhausted itself. This improvement imparted a better tone to sentiment and, as a result, prices closed slightly higher for the first time in a month.

The boy of today who wants a dog for Christmas does not seem to want just "any" dog, but, according to the letters now coming in from fathers as well as hopeful sons, a "hunting" dog is being specified.

THE first time Paul Brown addressed his Cleveland Browns football squad at training camp three years ago he made one statement which sunk very deeply on the impressionable youngsters who faced him. "I want this team," he said slowly, "to be the darling of professional football." It was a strange use of words, but the meaning was crystal clear.

ONE historian begins the modern movement with Cezanne, a second with the struggle between the classicists and romanticists at the outset of the nineteenth century and a third begins his consideration of modern art with Rubens.

MR. EDGE, sitting back in his seventy-fifth year, in his historic and beautiful home, Morven, which he has willed as a mansion for New Jersey's future Governors, has penned the story of his life. He is one of the most substantial citizens of his state. He was its Governor during World War I and was called back to its helm again during World War II.

CARACAS, Venezuela. Nov. 20 -- President Romulo Gallegos and his Cabinet signed today a decree suspending certain guarantees provided in the Venezulean Constitution. The guarantees relate to the press, the radio and public meetings and the reason given was the "circumstances that have created a state of alarm affecting the economic and social life of the nation."

CORRESPONDENTS take us to task, and correspondents praise us highly, according to the point of view, for our comment which appeared in THE TIMES on Mr. Mitropoulos' recent performance with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of Mahler's Seventh symphony.

TWO more poets have taken to fiction. One of them, Martha Bacon, may go far as a novelist. Her tale is uneven, but it contains many passages of which a practiced craftsman could be proud. The best hope that can be held out for James K. Feibleman is that "The Long Habit" is a false start.

THE viewpoint of the editors of this volume is in accord with the best of current scientific work on personality. This is hardly surprising, in view of the marked influence Harvard's Kluckhohn has had on anthropological work, and the contributions Murray has stimulated through his activities at Harvard and in the Office of Strategic Services.

In October 150 young Negroes, most of them veterans, took up the tools of learning at the newly established Booker T. Washington School of Industrial Training. They were the first students of the school that was organized this year on the site of the Negro educator's birthplace, twenty miles from Roanoke, Va.

ONCE more the White House is being rescued from decay and done over for the safety of all concerned -- especially the President and his family, who are moving to the Blair House across Lafayette Square. This is another milestone in a history that began 156 years ago when the cornerstone of the White House was laid -- on Columbus Day, 1792.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20 -- Crimson flares lit up Soldiers Field in the dusk and Harvard men tore down their own goal posts today in celebration of their first football victory over Yale since 1941.
DIFFICULT locations to plant are seldom an individual problem. There is, for example, the house that is set either above or below street level, with its resulting difficulty in grading and planting.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 20 (AP) -- William and Mary's Indians trampled North Carolina State's Wolfpack, 26 -- 6, today and immediately announced their acceptance of a bid to play in the Delta Bowl at Memphis on New Year's Day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- One of the certain fruits of being elected to Congress is that one's worthy but impecunious relatives need no longer constitute a drain on one's personal bankroll.

ATLANTA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets today routed the Citadel Bulldogs, 54 -- 0. Only a breather in preparation for the meeting with Georgia next Saturday, the game cost Tech the services of Hays McKinney, star guard, who broke his ankle.

AFTER turning out three-in-a-row, best-selling historical romances Frances Parkinson Keyes has given her latest novel a new twist. "Dinner at Antoine's" is a high-society mystery -- suicide or murder -- and to Capt. Theophile Murphy of the New Orleans police it looked like murder.

The Sanitation Department's invitation to tell of unsatisfactory neighborhood conditions was accepted by 3,575 New Yorkers in the first month the newly established complaint bureaus operated, it was announced yesterday by William J. Powell, Sanitation Commissioner.

Despite a motorcycle escort, the famous Kitty Hawk built by the Wright brothers and traveling in three separate crates in a Navy truck-trailer, moved inconspicuously through New Jersey yesterday on its way to a final resting place in the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

High school students attributed their interest in good reading to early association with good literature in home and school, in a discussion yesterday at the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 20 -- Officials of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization are considering a formal protest to the Lebanese authorities over the arrest yesterday Mustafa El Ariss, Lebanese labor leader, who was acting as an observer at the organization's conference for the World Federation of Trade Unions and over the detention inside the conference grounds of a group of demonstrators.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- Maine potato farmers were considerably interested this week in a proposal for a price-support plan under which all produce would be put into consumer channels, instead of some being sold to the Government.

OVER the years the proclamations issued by the nation's Chief Executive to set the date of Thanksgiving have grown to be more than the observance of a traditional custom -- they have also become useful footnotes on history.

Last week a large gathering of doctors crowded the New York Academy of Medicine to hear Dr. Walter Kempner tell about the rice diet originated by him about four years ago for the treatment of high blood pressure, heart and kidney disease, the major killers of civilized man.

WE Italians, if I may be permitted to say so, were among the first to recognize the poet in Eliot. He has entered into our taste, into our imagination; and even those of us who, not understanding his language, have to be content with translations, remain under the wand of the enchanter.

The East Coast longshoremen's strike forced new postponements yesterday in the sailings of the the world's two largest ocean liners, the Queen Elizabeth and the Queen Mary. The delays were counterbalanced by the first cautious notes of optimism in Government and shipping circles about the possibility that the costly tie-up would end this week.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 21 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy, represented by Red Smith and Jim Fegley, successfully invaded the fall's third frostbite dinghy racing session on Manhasset Bay today. The collegians, sailing Ernest H. Voigt's Fledgling, won four of the five Penguin Class contests and finished ninth in the other to wind up three points out of first place.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 21 -- The Slovak section of the Ministry of Information has published openly instructions under which by Dec. 1 Czechoslovak book publishers must present for official approval their complete program of publications for the first six months of 1949.

In a TIMES editorial you ask, "What is happening to the United Nations Appeal for Children?" The editorial further states: "The Appeal's goal was $60,000,000. * * * Final reports now coming through indicate that less than $20,000,000 was actually realized."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- With major foreign policy discussions in the immediate offing, President Truman flew back to Washington today, tanned and seemingly fit after a two-week Florida vacation.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 21 -Portugal is a curious anachronism in present-day Europe. It has a balanced budget and no income tax. Yet, situated in the extreme west of the continent, its illiteracy and disease rates are formidably high.

Hail to Michigan, king of the Western Conference again, if not the champions of all, with its string of twenty-three consecutive victories. Hail, too, to Ohio State, which gave the Wolverines the same rough treatment that Notre Dame and Army had to overcome against Pennsylvania and Northwestern.

BERLIN, Nov. 21 -- All sports activities in the Soviet zone have been placed under as close control as existed under the Nazi regime, it was learned today. Even chess clubs have been required to register their members with the new controlling authority, the Freie Deutsche Jugend [Free German Youth], Communist-dominated youth organization.

There is no place in the world where a limited financial commitment by the United States would pay bigger dividends than in the Republic of Liberia, the Right Rev. Bravid W. Harris, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Missionary District of Liberia, said yesterday at a service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Frederick Marvin is a good pianist. This fact became clear late yesterday afternoon when the young Californian played his first New York recital at Carnegie Hall.
Faced with a record enrollment this fall, American colleges and universities are planning a huge expansion program, a nation-wide survey conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES has shown.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- The appointment of H. Eliot Kaplan as deputy state controller in charge of administration of the New York State Employes Retirement System was announced here today by Controller Frank C. Moore.

The Veterans Administration in many instances is not cooperating with local communities in the planning of its hospital program, the Hospital Council of Greater New York asserted yesterday in its tenth annual report.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 21 -After six months neglect and delay, 25,000 letters from Utah school children are at last en route overseas carrying greetings to youngsters in many of the war-damaged countries.
Seven new films, including importations from England, Italy and Russia, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Man himself, God-created, is the "most perfect temple for the worship of God and the offering of sacrifice," the Rev. Timothy J. Flynn of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared at solemn mass there yesterday.

Walter Winchell heads the C.E. Hooper organization's bi-weekly computation of popularity among evening radio programs for the fifth consecutive time, according to the firm's latest report. Remaining in second and third places were "Radio Theatre" and "Fibber McGee and Molly," respectively.

The United States should adopt a new slogan, "Make Democracy Safe for the World," in the opinion of the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, president of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary. He spoke yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -Government statistics indicated today that marriage is on the wane.

ROME, Nov. 21 -- The tombs of sixteen Popes, friezes, mosaics, altars, burial crypts and ancient coins will be shown to visitors to Vatican City during the holy year of 1950 as the result of six years of excavation, it was made known today.

The right to filibuster in the United States Senate is an abuse of the right to full and free debate, and it has been found hard to end the abuse without infringing the essential right. Yesterday Senator Vandenberg, with twenty years of Senate experience behind him, made a proposal which is certainly worth considering.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions turned two Pittsburgh fumbles into touchdowns and Merv Pregulman booted a 33-yard field goal today as Detroit topped the Steelers, 17 to 14, before 16,189 shivering fans in Briggs Stadium. It was Detroit's second victory in nine National Football League games this season.

The Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, comprised of Columbia, the defending champion; Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Penn, Princeton and Yale, will play forty-two games between Dec. 11 and March 12, according to the schedule released yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21 -- Reports of preliminary talks for an Arab treaty with Britain persist here despite all official denials, and it is believed that a multiple system of alliances is being sought in connection with an eventual settlement of the Palestine situation.

The actual cost of housing units being constructed here in New York City by the New York City Housing Authority is no less than the cost of privately constructed housing. The current program of Authority projects is averaging approximately $12,000 per dwelling unit.

Now that the autumnal boreas has scattered summer torpor to the four corners of the city we realize that the walking season is upon us as the New Yorker lengthens his stride, quickens his pace and heads unflinchingly into the needle-point winds. We are -- although we cannot predict how long this condition will last -- the foremost perambulatory city in America.

St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church, East 106th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues, commemorated yesterday the seventy-fifth anniversary of its founding in a solemn pontifical mass of thanksgiving at which Cardinal Spellman presided.

IT was shortly after Penn State had muscled Penn out of the ranks of the undefeated that droll Bob Higgins of the Nittany Lions spoke some strangely phophetic words. "We usually do well against Penn," he said. "We're just country cousins who are out to make a good showing in the big city. But the one team that we always have trouble with is Pitt.

This city celebrates this week the one hundredth anniversary of one of its finest institutions, known and respected by scholars the world over, the New York Public Library. Although as its historian, Harry Miller Lydenberg, wrote in 1923, the library in present form is the union of "many isolated, independent efforts toward a common end, the public weal,"

Alarmed over Tammany Hall's attack on the validity of absentee ballots cast in the election for New York County Surrogate, the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations announced yesterday that it would defend the rights of salesmen to vote by absentee ballot.

The first week of the Metropolitan Opera Company's sixty-fourth season, beginning Monday night, Nov. 29, will include revivals of four operas and will feature four singers new to the company, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday.

The statement of the American position on Palestine, made by Dr. Jessup before a committee of the General Assembly of the United Nations, is only a preliminary exposition, and is, as Dr. Jessup emphasized, subject to modifications in a final statement to be made after a study of the proposals of other nations.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 -- Purchases of electric motors, generators, adjustable-speed drives and controls by key industries throughout the country next year will match and may exceed 1948 buying levels, according to estimates of fifty-eight district managers and engineers of the Reliance Electric and Engineering Company here.
W.E. Madden has been appointed vice president of George Haiss Manufacturing Company, Inc., manufacturer of materials handling equipment, and subsidiary of the Pettibone Mulliken Corporation, Chicago.

Running a smartly paced race, Victor Dyrgall of the Millrose A.A. annexed his eighth title of the year yesterday when he won the senior Metropolitan A.A.U. individual cross-country championship over a six-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (AP) -- This is Artillery Day in Russia and Soviet newspapers, in leading editorials, hailed artillery as "the god of war." At the same time, they criticized the United Nations General Assembly for having turned down Russian disarmament proposals.

A sidewalk battle at noon yesterday between five detectives and three young men resulted in the breaking of a store window at 35 East Fifty-third Street and the arrest of the trio on charges of conspiring to commit robbery and illegal possession of a pistol.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 21 -- Ernst Fischer, Austrian Communist leader, and his followers were accused today by Yugoslav Communists of having joined Austrian "Pan-Germanists, Nazis and Vienna reactionaries" to oppose Yugoslavia's territorial claims in Carinthia.

CAIRO, Nov. 21 -- The United States freighter Flying Trader sailed from Port Said last night after thirty-eight tractors and 4,000 bags of rice had been taken from the ship by Egyptian military authorities who alleged that the freight was destined for Israel.
