The executive committee of the Committee for Progressive Zionism, including four former presidents of the Zionist Organization of America, called yesterday on the United Palestine Appeal "to grant equal representation "to Jewish communities throughout America with that of existing Zionist organizations."

Tonight's events: Robert Goldsand, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Heitor Alimonda, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Symphonic Concert, conducted by Hugo Kortschak and Harris Danziger, Manhattan School of Music, 8:15; Busch Quartet, Barnard College Hall, 8:30; Stefania Batory, soprano, and Stuart Fastofsky, violin, Little Theatre, 5 West Sixty-third Street, 8:30; Symphonic Concert, conducted by Samuel Antek, Elaine Malbin, soprano, Walton High School, 8:30.

Herman L. Weisman, acting national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, announced yesterday that $236,496,000 would be required by the appeal's agencies in Israel for a comprehensive program of repatriating and rehabilitating the large number of immigrants who will enter the country in the fiscal year ending October, 1949.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Nov. 21 -- An effort to form a working vocabulary of the 5,000 words most clearly understood when a speaker is surrounded by the many noises of combat airplanes is being made here by the United States Navy. Similar studies are being made at Harvard University and at Purdue University.

DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER was an obscure lieutenant colonel in 1940. Four years later he was the most celebrated, admired and beloved soldier of the twentieth century. Today he is the man who would rather be true to his word and a college president than to be President of the United States by general acclamation. He is also the author of "Crusade in Europe," one of the most eagerly anticipated books of our time.

Two outstanding new exhibitions in the Thanksgiving week include the first New York showing of the Bakus collection of early German, Flemish and Dutch drawings and paintings at the Schaeffer Gallery and a benefit loan exhibition of portraits of distinguished New York personalities covering a period from 1848 to 1948, at Portraits, Inc.
A $6,000,000 goal has been set for establishment of a nonsectarian medical school to open in September, 1952, as an adjunct to Yeshiva University, it was announced last night.

ATHENS, Nov. 21 -- By 168 votes against 167 for the Opposition, the new coalition Cabinet of Liberals and Populists won a vote of confidence in the Greek Chamber of Deputies early today and obtained the Chamber's adjournment until Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, proposed today a drastic rule change by which 90 per cent of the Senate could force national emergency legislation to an immediate vote.

The proposal for creation of a transit authority to operate, rehabilitate, expand and finance the municipal transit lines was reported yesterday by Paul Windels, chairman of the Citizens Transit Committee.
THE TIMES does not agree with the suggestion, reported by this correspondent, that the White House be turned into a museum and a new Executive Mansion built for the President.

A little less than three hundred and twenty-eight years after the landing of the Pilgrims at Plymouth 802 displaced Europeans came last week into Boston Harbor. They were welcomed by Governor Robert F. Bradford, a ninth-generation descendant of William Bradford, second Governor of Plymouth Colony.
Your editorial entitled "Motor Vehicle Inspection" barely touches upon a point that must be given greater consideration if we are to reduce the appalling incidence of motor vehicle accidents.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 21 (AP) -The office of President Miguel Aleman announced today that the Sud-Pacifico Railroad, a subsidiary of the Southern Pacific Railway, will be returned to its owners.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- British seamen who are striking in sympathy with American longshoremen again prevented the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth from sailing today.

The national executive council of the Phi Kappa Psi fraternity will meet here Sunday to discuss what if any action it should take in the controversy over its suspension of the Amherst College chapter, which had asked a Negro student to join it.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Ordered by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to proceed in the state courts in an effort to upset the so-called Burlington County bridge deal, Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper said today he and his aides would prepare their first legal action tomorrow.

Ireland seems to be in an "economically good position" at the moment, with her people working hard to maintain the gains made in the post-war period, especially those in the maritime field, John Gammie, vice president of the States Marine Corporation, asserted yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 21 -- The death of Col. Gen. Andrei A. Zhdanov has unbalanced the whole delicately adjusted mechanism whereby the Politburo runs the Soviet Union and world communism, sources studying the Soviet situation believe.

Of 91,000,000 tires shipped in 1947 about 25,000,000 went to vehicle manufacturers, 3,000,000 were exported and 63,000,000 went to reshoe American cars and trucks, according to a study released last week on tire replacement sales at wholesale by Dr. Warren W. Leigh, of the University of Akron.
It was a quiet week in the foreign exchanges, the paucity of turnover limiting values to a narrow area which showed no substantial change over the preceding week.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- "We do not desire to prevent Germany from living and working for her recovery and that of Europe, but we should take the indispensable precautions," said Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, speaking in Metz today at the celebration of the fourth anniversary of its liberation.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Ch. Majara Mahabat, an Afghan hound belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Jagger of Dunellen, N.J., went to his first best-in-show in the 768-dog thirtieth all-breed event of the Newark Kennel Club on the tanbark of Essex Troop Armory today.
A new formula for establishing parking lots in shopping sections of the five boroughs has been submitted to the Board of Estimate, it was learned yesterday.
Airline men, both scheduled and unscheduled, read with interest here yesterday a statement by Col. W.E. McDonald that it was costing $100 a ton to fly supplies into Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Kamil Abdul Rahim, the Egyptian Ambassador, said tonight that his Government had denied a statement appearing in last Thursday's NEW YORK TIMES to the effect that an Egyptian had conducted private talks with Israeli representatives in Paris.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek today urged "immediate and definite" aid for the Chinese Government as a matter of American self-interest, lest the Communists conquer all Asia.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The "liquidation of clerical reaction" is imminent in Hungary, Erno Gero, the Communist Minister of Transport, said today in a new attack on the Catholic Church.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Bill Durnan lost a couple of teeth from a blow in the face by the puck tonight but the accident failed to deter the slick Montreal goalie, who blanked the Detroit Red Wings 3 to 0 in a National Hockey League game before 13,714 fans. It was Durnan's third shut-out over Detroit this season in four meetings.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -Paced by that devastating duo -Tommy Thompson and Steve Van Buren -- the Philadelphia Eagles put on a tremendously impressive exhibition of offensive football today in overwhelming the Washington Redskins, 42 -- 21, before a sell-out crowd of 36,254 at Shibe Park.

CAIRO, Nov. 21 -- Dr. Ibrahim Desouki Abaza Pasha, acting Foreign Minister, announced tonight that the Israelis were not withdrawing their forces to the new demarcation lines in the Negeb ordered by the Security Council. Abaza Pasha made this announcement after a three-hour Cabinet meeting.

Leading institutions sent congratulations yesterday to the New York Public Library, which begins the celebration of its 100th anniversary today at 5 P.M. with the dedication of two special exhibits in the newly decorated third-floor corridors of the Central Library Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
THORNWOOD, N.Y., Nov. 21 -Six persons were hurt shortly before 3 P.M. today in a collision between a pleasure car and a Grasslands ambulance at Franklin and Marble Avenues here.

Fred O. Cosgrove, president of the New York City Hotel Association, said yesterday that he would ask the temporary City Housing Rent Commission and Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh to place in escrow the rent increases collected from hotel tenants under a temporary order that the commission rescinded last Friday.

Anatole Kitain, Russian pianist, gave his annual Carnegie Hall recites last night. If it was fashioned on somewhat old-fashioned lines, it also had some of the magic of former days when recitals were less frequent and the appearances of virtuosi were spectacular and romantic occasions.

Representing an important segment of the industry, six major hardware manufacturers have adopted the City College training program in builders hardware for the preliminary training of sales and administrative personnel and are revising their own programs to make them complementary to this training, it was announced over the week-end.

The Manufacturers Trust Company, acting as agent for customers, has sent a letter to common stockholders of the Atlantic Gulf West Indies Steamship Lines, offering to purchase their common shares at $47.50 a share ex dividend, less the cost of transfer stamps.

The growing trend toward more repetition of the same advertisements as a cost savings was cited by an experienced advertising director here last week as likely to produce profitable sales results. Minus the cost factor, he said, the practice is akin to the old system of constantly repeating keyed ads found to produce high response.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 21 -- An eight-point economic program, including price controls, an excess-profits tax and rationing of essential commodities, was demanded today by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in his annual report, made public on the eve of the CIO's tenth constitutional convention.

Although the subscription series of ANTA's Experimental Theatre is bogged down in Broadway wrangling and filibustering, the invitational series has resumed operations very sensibly at the Lenox Hill Playhouse. Over the week-end it offered four performances of Euripides' "Hippolytus" in a practicable adaptation by Leighton Rollins.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 22 -Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today he hoped to render his decision some time this week in the case of Hideki Tojo and the twenty-four other convicted Japanese war lords.

The decision of the national executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to revoke the charter of the Greater New York CIO Council is a service to all the people of New York and, most of all, to the CIO members whose reputation for responsibility and patriotism the Council has done so much to tarnish.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -As a means of reducing overhead per unit of film production, Universal-International is working out a plan for entry into the field of contract commercial and industrial film production, it has been learned.

Miihal Kusevitsky, tenor and former Warsaw cantor, gave a recital on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall that attracted an audience of almost 2,900, including 200 persons who filled the additional chairs placed on the stage.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- The Western powers will submit tomorrow an outline of their plan for currency control in Berlin -- a plan that depends completely on action by Russia first to lift the blockade of the German capital.

Edwin F. Embree's letter with respect to fighting discrimination has what I believe to be several inaccuracies. Firstly, such prejudices should not have been excused fifty years ago. Prejudices of any type are never excusable. However, to end such prejudice presupposes a Utopia of sorts -- a Utopia for which this country is not quite ready.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 -- It appeared last week that the steel industry would hang up for November a production record that would come close to or exceed, that made in October. Steelmakers kept their output unchanged at 99.5 per cent of rated capacity.
The city's industry, already hard hit by the pier strike, will be further hampered by a scheduled walkout today of 2,000 truck drivers.

Lillian Shelby, 19-year-old soprano from Philadelphia, made her debut with the New York City Opera Company yesterday afternoon at the City Center as Nedda in "Pagliacci." The youthful artist, who made her initial operatic appearance last year with the American Opera Company in her home town, held the attention firmly because of her histrionic talent, which overshadowed her present attainments as a vocalist.

Two generals who were closely associated with the success of the American Air Forces will have books published next year. Gen. H.H. (Hap) Arnold has turned over to Harper the manuscript of "Global Mission," the story of his life from his boyhood in Montgomery County, Pa., through to his retirement after World War II.

Two thousand persons, many of them dressed in the colorful uniforms of their organizations, attended the twenty-seventh annual joint service of fifty-one patriotic societies yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Another top-notch number of dinghies, thirty-nine, engaged in the racing today in the Larchmont Yacht Club series competition.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The quietly rising trend of prices of securities continues, and there does not appear any prospect of early reversal of this slow but quite impressive movement. It has been going on for months in the face of happenings which normally would have shaken the stock markets severely.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Farm machinery manufacturers are hopeful that a little more steel will be available the rest of this year and in 1949 and have optimistically scheduled moderate increases in output, industry leaders revealed here.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Lard futures were unsettled on the Board of Trade last week, prices rising and falling rapidly in sympathy with grains and vegetable oils.

The promised land of peace and plenty can be realized in our time, the Rev. Dr. Lewis E. Christian declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 133 West Fourth Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Frank Minini scored thrice and Sid Luckman tossed a pair of touchdown passes as the power-packed Chicago Bears romped to a 51-17 victory over the Boston Yanks today before 18,048 fans, at Fenway Park, largest crowd of the local National Football League season.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Ben Agajanian kicked a field goal from the 17-yard line with 35 seconds to play to snatch a 17-14 victory today for the Los Angeles Dons over the Baltimore Colts before 25,228 fans in Babe Ruth Stadium.

Thanksgiving revolves around turkey, but close seconds on the menu in point of essentiality are cranberries and sweet potatoes. All three, incidentally, are native American foods, the appropriate stars of a feast that originated in this country in its earliest years.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 21 -Egyptian forces have occupied a series of new positions in the Negeb, desert area of southern Palestine, in an action of which the Israeli Army takes an "extremely serious view," it was announced here tonight.

The annual show of the Empire Cage Bird Association has proved that in at least one respect birds are not much different from people. Get several hundred of them under one roof and the exhibitionist with the smoothest line of gab will look best for a while.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 21 -- The American Federation of Labor's proposals for a global, democratic foreign policy which officials announced would be adopted tomorrow when the federation's convention resumes its sessions were completed today.

The 35,000-ton battleship North Carolina, a veteran of World War II and now a member of the Atlantic Reserve Fleet, will be moved tomorrow from Berth 19 at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, to her regular berth at North Wall, Bayonne, N.J., the Navy announced yesterday.

ZURICH, Nov. 21 -- Last Friday the shares of the Compania Hispano-Americana de Electricidad, popularly known as CHADE, were quoted in Zurich at 305 francs, which was a new record low. Since Dec. 31, 1945, when the price in Zurich was 1,025 francs, the trend has been consistently downward.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Small signs of improvement in the attitude of the Arab states toward Britain have been seen recently by London diplomatic observers, but they are waiting for more evidence before forecasting a complete reconciliation.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Some of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's comments on British wartime leaders and on Allied strategy contained in his book, "Crusade in Europe," were characterized as "absolutely untrue" and "grossly misleading" in a review of the book published today by The Sunday Times.

The New York Americans handed the Trenton Americans their second defeat in the championship competition of the American Soccer League by 2-1 before 2,500 fans at Sterling Oval in the Bronx. The teams were well matched, but at half-time the home side held a 1-0 lead.

Seven hundred and one thousand young persons, ranging from kindergarten pupils to high school seniors, have received free dental treatment under the cooperative health program sponsored by the New York schools and the Murray and Leonie Guggenheim Dental Clinic, Dr. Harry I. Goldberger, acting director of health education for the Board of Education, announced yesterday.

Industry is paying increasing attention to the health of its executives, according to a study of company medical and health programs released over the week-end by the National Industrial Conference Board. This is due, it was found, to the untimely death of many executives, young and old, and the growing need for qualfied leaders.
Before an overflow crowd of close to 10,000, Mount St. Michael and Memorial High School of West New York, N.J., played to a 19-19 tie at McGovern Field in the Bronx yesterday.

Milton Hanauer, former New York State champion, moved up into the lead in the championship finals of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday when he won his sixth-round game from Walter Goldwater, changing the leader's score to 4 1/2 -- 1 1/2.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Television not only may supplement radio but may displace it almost entirely, James D. Shouse, president and chairman of the board of the Crosley Broadcasting Corporation, asserted today.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Philadelphia teams won five of the eight contests today in the closing matches of the three-day Middle Atlantic women's field hockey tournament at Swarthmore College.

Dark for seven weeks, the Fulton will be relit tonight. On the stroke of 8:15, first nighters are warned, the curtain will rise on "The Young and Fair." An all-feminine cast, numbering twenty-one, will appear in the N. Richard Nash play, which Vinton Freedley is presenting in association with a buddy of long standing, Richard W. Krakeur.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks were shoved back into last place in the National Hockey League tonight as they played to a 3-3 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs who thereby moved into a fourth-place tie with the New York Rangers.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The plane piloted by Mrs. Richarda Morrow-Tait, 24 years old, British aviatrix, attempting to fly around the world, was wrecked in a forced landing today but neither she nor her navigator, Michael Townsend, was injured.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 21 -- The new Bank to Foster National Production, capitalized at 1,000,000,000 bolivianos, has just been established here as one of the best naturally endowed countries in South America struggles against the old handicap of bad transportation.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 21 (UP) -Chuckin' Charley Conerly, the Mississippi flash, threw three scoring passes and ran to a fourth touchdown himself today as the New York Giants handed the favored Green Bay Packers a record-breaking 49 to 3 defeat.

The Paganini Quartet and the pianist, Sari Biro, contributed to two notable chamber music performances late yesterday afternoon at the fourth of the season's concerts to be presented by the New Friends of Music at Town Hall.

Miss Helen Toebke of New York and Miss Florence Kunz of Long Island were among the players chosen yesterday for the Northeast first team as play ended in the two-day field hockey tournament sponsored by the regional association at Hunter College in the Bronx.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Plans for extensions costing 13,000,000 (about $52,000,000) in factories in the alkali division of Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., were announced today by Lord McGowan, chairman of the company board.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Tony Leswick counted twice, once without assistance, to pace the New York Rangers into a 4-1 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight before 13,900 fans at the Boston Garden. It was the host club's first setback at home in six starts.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 21 -- The picking of citrus fruit will begin throughout Israel this week, with the prospect of a crop almost equaling last season's in Jewish-owned groves but altogether of a little more than one-third of the pre-war production in Palestine.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The election of President Truman was cited by a leading British politician today as evidence of the ineffectiveness and unreliability of the right-wing press -- in Britain as well as in the United States.

MADRID, Monday, Nov. 22 -The Franco-Government endorsed candidates were leading by safe margins early this morning in thirty-four of Spain's fifty provinces in the municipal elections, according to official figures.

Twenty-two "heavenly children -- "ten do ji" in the Japanese language of their parents -- dressed in brilliant silks and wearing high tinkling crowns of gilded metal took part in a "gyo retsu," or traditional parade, yesterday in mid town Manhattan.

Some of the balm went out of the weather yesterday, but it remained warmer than usual for the season and was a comfortable contrast to conditions in the Midwest and Great Lakes regions, where the effects of a three-day snowstorm were still being felt.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- In Dunkerque today, two ringleaders of the dock strike were arrested on charges of interfering with the right of dockers to get to their work. The arrests caused a violent demonstration near the labor headquarters in which two women, one of them a Communist member of the City Council, were arrested for insults to the police.
Jerome Peterson began his scientific career developing a better scouring powder for housewives and worked up to chasing plagues in China as a public health officer of the United Nations.

RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 21 -- A Government press statement reviewing Burma's internal situation said today the White Flag (Stalinist) Communists had made peace overtures. The White Flag Communists have been warring with the Government since March.

Assets of the Canadian Bank of Commerce crossed the $1,500,000,000-mark for the first time in its history, the annual statement disclosed today. The total of $1,528,918,246 as of last Oct. 31, the end of the fiscal year, compared with $1,426,518,490 on Oct. 31, 1947.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Grain markets continued their upward movement on the Board of Trade last week with December wheat selling at $2.41 1/2, up 11 cents from the low of the previous week and in new ground since April 15, and with that exception was the highest since Feb. 4.

What ought to have been the game to end all football games was played in Ebbets Field yesterday by the San Francisco Forty-Niners and the Brooklyn Dodgers -- and there were only 9,336 eyewitnesses, exclusive of the press.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Jacques Heim designs cocktail gowns in rustling taffetas and moires that score by silhouette untouched by any trimming. Their dark rich tones, shot bronze, navy, chestnut brown and black, make of them a perfect background for jewels, but they can hold their own without benefit of sparkle if desired.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Eighty thousand Army airplane engine valves, valued when new at from $1,000,000 to $6,000,000, were located in a dump here by State Police today, acting on a tip.

One of these years the New York Yankees may succeed in taking the measure of the Cleveland Browns. If and when it happens, however, the chances are that the local athletes, currently drawing fortnightly salary checks, either will be missing or too old to enjoy the miracle.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- At least four of the seven members of the Common Council were reported today to be in agreement on a method of raising the $950,000 necessary to balance the $17,204,506 expense budget recommended for 1949 by City Manager Thomas V. Kennedy.

Surplus material which originally cost the Government $16,000,000 will be offered for sale by the War Assets Administration in early December, it was announced over the week-end by Walter F. Downey, regional director of the WAA.

It is reported that there are 962,909 citizens of New York State who, as Christmas savings club members, have accumulated $81,499,738 in deposits in anticipation of the coming Yuletide. This would appear to be a large, glittering sum of money, even in these days, until it is compared to something dull and prosaic, such as a year's interest on this city's bonded debt, which $81,499,738 at present would not by any means pay.

Labor professionals are preparing to profit by the prevailing impression that the organized labor vote beat the Republicans. That impression is superficial and false. It was the farm vote that beat the Republicans. That fact should be understood and should be given as much circulation as possible.
A "treasure hunt" in the windows of forty-five Fifth Avenue shops and Macy's department store will be sponsored this week by the United Hospital Fund.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 21 -- Louis Hollander, president of the New York State CIO Council, arrived here today and acted almost at once to take over the books, funds and property of the Greater New York CIO Council, found guilty by the national CIO executive board yesterday of "slavish adherence" to the Communist party line.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 (UP) -- California was the choice over Oregon tonight in the battle of the ballot for a Rose Bowl berth, but it will be noon tomorrow before a decision is announced.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Former Secretary of States James F. Byrnes said today he would not be a candidate for the United States Senate in 1950. In a statement to The Greenville News, Mr. Byrnes said.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 21 -- The Netherlands' foreign trade in October showed remarkable improvement. Although imports rose to 479,000,000 guilders from 442,000,000 in September, exports totaled 307,000,000 against 231,000,000. These figures show that in October imports were covered by exports to the extent of 64 per cent, a figure approaching normality.

Joss Torres, Spanish dancer, who made his local debut earlier in the season as guest artist with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, gave his first New York solo recital last night at the Ziegfeld Theatre, assisted by Elias de Quiros, pianist, and Antonio Rodriguez, guitarist.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 21 (AP) -- While the press of the United States failed to predict the outcome of the recent Presidential election, that was no reason for editors to hang crepe on their doors, Palmer Hoyt, publisher of The Denver Post, said last night.
The arrest of two former convicts who, police say, tried their hand at extortion while waiting to hijack trucks loaded with Thanksgiving turkeys was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The inter-service feud which began with two generals named Smith and spread over the Army and Marine Corps entered a new round today as the Marines opened their secret files on the battle for Saipan which set off the original dispute.

NANKING, Nov. 21 -- The Chinese Communist Central Executive Committee declared tonight that the dispatch of United States military forces to aid the "Kuomintang Government" of China would be considered an act of "armed aggression" and warned that "all the consequences thereof would have to be borne by the American Government."

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week centered on buyers' orders for women's spring coats and suits, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Worsted fabrics won widest acceptance in the suit division of the market
A forty-hour week with overtime pay for nurses has been instituted at New York Hospital, replacing the forty-four-hour week, it was announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The mortality rate of rheumatic fever, leading cause of death among all children, has dropped 80 per cent in this country since 1920, Dr. George M. Wheatley, vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, reported today.
John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of City Investigation, said last night that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was "looking into" reasons behind the increased cost of the city's milk to consumers.

The committee on economic policy of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States has just issued a forty-page study entitled "The Economics of the Money Supply." It concludes, according to news summaries, that "a major cause of high prices in this country has been the increase in the money supply."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Brookings Institution, a research organization, stated today that the Government must draw a clean line between "regulation" and "control" to preserve the country's time-honored system of private enterprise.

"Daddy's" shoulder was a prize vantage point for several hundred youngsters as 20,000 parents and children thronged the exhibit hall of the American Museum of Natural History from 1 to 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Out of eleven classifications of products bought by industry, prices of only two have been greatly affected by the shift of formulas to f.o.b. mill pricing systems as a result of the Supreme Court decision in the cement case, it was discovered last week through a canvass of leading industrial purchasing agents.

Prices for cotton future delivery were mixed in narrow trading last week and made small net changes. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 2 to 32 points, compared with net gains of 25 to 36 points in the previous week.

Ten thousand persons ranging from elementary school children to doctors of philosophy have passed through New York University's internationally known Reading Clinic, and all had the same problem -they wanted to learn how to read.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Fullback Pat Harder scored a touchdown, two field goals and three extra points as the champion Chicago Cardinals barely shaded the Los Angeles Rams, 27 -- 24, in a National Football League game before 29,031 today.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Prime Minister Attlee and Sir Basil Brooke, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, met yesterday at Chequers, the British Prime Minister's weekend home, and discussed Ireland's forthcoming departure from the Commonwealth, it was announced today.

The Exchange Buffet Corporation, in its statement to be issued today, for the six months ended on Oct. 31, showed a decline in net profit to $26,540, from $71,352 for the corresponding period of last year, despite a slight improvement in sales from $1,648,498 to $1,659,143.

Maxim Schapiro, Russian pianist, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. The program included Mozart's Sonata in C major (K. 279); Stravinsky's Sonata; Chopin's Sonata in B minor; Bartok's "Improvisations," Op. 20; Faure's Sixth Nocturne, de Falla's "Fantasia Baetica," and the Ten Etudes by Virgil Thomson.

While growing use of air freight is providing its own stimulus to development of new skyway packaging techniques, carriers are finding a major side problem in breaking shippers of old packaging habits, it was disclosed here last week by George F. Braender, New York traffic chief for Peruvian International Airways.

Disregard for the insidious danger of pride and the supreme virtue of humility was scored yesterday in his sermon by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

A move to obtain the cooperation of the Police Department and the Magistrates Courts in stopping destruction of trees and shrubs in city parks by "children in supervised groups" was announced yesterday by the Park Association of New York.

Your editorial of Nov. 18 dealing with "unconscionable business practices in automobile sales and financing" may be seriously damaging to the strength of our economy by giving support to persons who do not want to rely on market forces.
Representatives of 45,000 striking East Coast longshoremen rejected an employer settlement formula last night as "too vague" for submission to the union membership.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today a 75 per cent cut in the export quota for United States produced zinc slabs, pigs and blocks during the fourth quarter of 1948.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 22 -- It took "enemy" carrier-based planes, including many of the Navy's latest jets, exactly twelve minutes this morning to "destroy" the $8,000,000 United States naval air station at Pomona.

Registration of Central and South West Corporation's offering of 659,606 shares of common stock to stockholders at $10.25 a share at the rate of one share for each ten shares held is now effective. The subscription period, during which stockholders will have preference, will expire Dec. 3.

DETROIT, Nov. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was described today by one of its commissioners, Harry A. McDonald, as "a familiar and accepted landmark on our financial scene" that no longer is a subject of controversy.

IF Damocles at that famous banquet in ancient Syracuse had looked up at the sword suspended above his head by a single hair and then dismissed it from his mind, eaten his dinner with his usual appetite and spent the evening discussing politics and the high cost of living he would have acted very much like most of us citizens of the atomic age.

Sinclair Lewis has written his first historical novel and Random House has tentatively listed it for March 4 publication. Entitled "The God-Seeker," it is a story about an American missionary and his work along the Minnesota frontier in the Eighteen Forties.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 22 -- Scandinavian uneasiness about the possibility of a third world war is reflected by moves in Norway and Sweden for greater preparedness against invasion. Both the Norwegian Government and the Swedish commander in chief, Gen. Helge Jung, have just urged increased defense appropriations equivalent to $24,500,000 and $29,000,000, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today the number of American businesses continued to increase during the first half of 1948. But the rate was much slower than during earlier post-war periods.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 22 -- Navy swam through a scrimmage this afternoon as Coach George Sauer prepared his team for any kind of weather which may turn up Saturday at Philadelphia where the middies take on the cadets of West Point in the annual classic.

For the second time within a week Supreme Court Justice John H. McGeehan vacated yesterday an order of the City Rent Commission. In his latest ruling he voided certificates of eviction issued to Beth Israel Hospital.
PEIPING, China, Nov. 22 -- Chinese Government forces completely withdrew at 2 o'clock this morning from Paoting, capital of Hopeh Province.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- President Truman walked to work in the rain this morning like thousands of other government workers after leaving the new Presidential home, Blair House, just across the street from the White House. The Truman family moved into the new temporary quarters yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Targets poisoned by radioactive particles from an underwater atomic blast would, for all practical purposes, be deadly for eternity, an atomic scientist reported today.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 22 -- Delegates to the convention of the American Federation of Labor today called unanimously upon the Eighty-first Congress to repeal "the obnoxious Taft-Hartley law."
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 22 -- "Governments that lose wars never have to pay pensions."

Frederick Brown has resold the Tyler Building, fifteen-story office structure with basement and subbasement, at 17-23 John Street to an investing client of Henry Baker, broker in the transaction. Mr. Brown acquired the property last week from the Tyler Building Corporation.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company marketed yesterday $50,000,000 of fifteen-year debentures at an interest cost of 2.9436 per cent. The securities were acquired at competitive sale by a syndicate of ninety banking houses headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.68 for an interest coupon of 3 per cent.

One of the season's most expensive productions, "Magdalena," reported to represent an investment of at least $360,000, will call a halt to its Broadway career on Saturday evening, Dec. 4. It will terminate its engagement at the Ziegfeld Theatre after eighty-eight performances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- One of the three commissions of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations today voted, 22 to 17, that the choosing of permanent FAO headquarters again should be deferred pending further investigation by a special committee.
Three college football teams had their perfect records soiled over the week-end, leaving fifteen still in the unbeaten-untied class. Of these, eleven already have finished their regular campaigns.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The old man's going to try it again.

Dr. George F. Cunningham has purchased the three-story dwelling at 615 Third Street, Brooklyn, from Walter G. Chandler. L.L. Yearsley, broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the three-story house at 110 Prospect Park West for Sadie Stonbely to Isaac Nehleber.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall discussed the whole range of foreign affairs, from Asia to Europe, for an hour today, and may continue their talk tomorrow.

CAIRO, Nov. 22 -- Thirty-eight ten-ton armor-plated half-tracks, not thirty-eight tractors as previously reported, were seized from the United States freighter Flying Trader by Egyptian military forces at Port Said last week, it was learned today.

Prices on the stock market returned yesterday to about the level of a week ago as selling of limited proportions canceled out the gains of the last few sessions. Twice there were indications of a mild recovery, but the strength quickly waned.

In the city's Golden Jubilee year, Portraits Inc., 460 Park Avenue, Has gone one better -- has gone back a century; in fact, in its present loan exhibition: "New Yorkers: 1848-1948." The exhibition is being held as a benefit for St. Barnabas Hospital.

Firm tone on gray goods prices for the last three weeks should prove a factor in inducing wholesale buyers to come into the market for their spring cotton textile needs, according to Worth Street sources. Commission men said yesterday that they were optimistic concerning immediate prospects for business because large buyers can no longer delay making such purchases.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22 -- Rebuilding of a scale model of the Philistine Temple at Gaza, erected at Paramount for Cecil B. de Mille's "Samson and Delilah" at an estimated cost of $30,000, was under way today after an unsuccessful attempt to re-enact the famous collapse that took place, according to the Bible story, when the blind Samson thrust apart the pillars which supported the temple.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 22 -- In view of the emergency in China, the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund announced here today that it was speeding a three-month supply of foodstocks to Asiatic ports.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Pakistan is blamed by the United Nations Security Council's Kashmir Commission for the failure to bring about peace between the two Dominions on the Indian subcontinent, it was earned today.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's announcement today that he hopes to render a final decision this week in the cases of Hideki Tojo and other Japanese convicted and sentenced as war criminals is arousing much interest here. The general opinion both of Japanese and American observers is that General MacArthur's statement indicates that he will not alter the international court's verdict.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 22 -- Proud, wild Waziristan tribesmen, whom the British never completely subjugated, are now fighting and enthusiastic jihad (holy war) against the Indian Army in the rugged mountains of Kashmir. They have adopted Pakistan's war as their own and feel toward India in the occupation of Kashmir as they felt toward any British encroachment beyond the northwest frontier.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly wound up its work today for the current session by approving unanimously a report drawn up by Hermond Lannung of Denmark on the administration of the Territory of South-West Africa by the Government of the Union of South Africa.

BOMBAY, Nov. 22 -- Seven persons were killed and more than a hundred injured in the past twenty hours as Bombay was lashed by the fiercest cyclonic storm in its history. Stones weighing a quarter of a ton were displaced by wind and water, causing a hundred-foot breach in the sea wall at the Gateway of India.

LONDON, Nov. 22 (Canadian Press) -- A collision in Halifax Harbor between a Norwegian vessel and a United States ship carrying 1,400 tons of bombs that occurred in August, 1942, was the subject of an appeal today to the Privy Council.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Regular and frequent discussions of the long-stalemated Austrian peace treaty have started here again between representatives of Britain, the United States and France.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 22 -- Egypt has rejected the first overture of Brig. Gen. William E. Riley of the United States Marine Corps, Chief of Staff for the acting Mediator, to negotiate directly with Israeli representatives for an armistice in the Negeb, desert area of southern Palestine, it was learned tonight.

Directors of the Continental Oil Company (Delaware) at a meeting yesterday declared a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 20. This will increase total payments for 1948 to $3.50 from the $2.50 distributed last year.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The British Government in cooperation with industry is to make a frontal attack upon the "huge variety of uneconomic and unnecessary" sizes and styles of components and finished products in the manufacturing field, C.R. Strauss, Minister of Supply, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Military Air Transport Service increased its operations almost 54 per cent in September over the best mark set by the separate Air Force and Navy ort services before their merger into the MATS, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said today.

The Walters Construction Company, which recently completed eighteen low-cost bungalow-type dwellings on Bernard Street, between Mott and Pacific Avenues, in Lawrence, L.I., is starting an additional group of twenty-nine buildings in the immediate vicinity.
Ted Scown, a speedy halfback from Sul Ross (Texas) State College, broke away for six touchdowns last Saturday to gain the national football scoring leadership with 144 points.

GENEVA, Nov. 22 -- Output per factory worker was more than twice as great in the United States as in Britain during the five years immediately preceding the second World War, according to a study released today by the International Labor Office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Federal law against misbranding of drugs and cosmetics can be applied even though the false claims are in pamphlets sent separately from the articles themselves, the Supreme Court ruled today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Burton K. Wheeler, former Senator from Montana, and other attorneys challenged today the constitutionality of the Federal Lobbying Registration Act.

Brazil stands ready to supply the 200,000 tons of manganese and 500,000 tons of iron ore annually that the United States Steel Corporation hopes to obtain there, but the South American country first must improve its transportation, docks and harbors and must obtain more mining equipment, Dr. Jose Garrido-Torres, director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau, said here yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday, and closed at gains of 6 to 17 points net.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 22 -- The present Government of Portugal, which calls itself the "new state," is a curious development from the original military dictatorship established in 1926 by an officers' junta.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- A British pharmaceutical company announced today that it had succeeded in isolating from liver the anti-pernicious-anemia factor in pure crystalline form, although the substance is so scarce that a ton of liver yielded only a few grains of it.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 -- A proposed consent decree under which the Eastman Kodak Company of Rochester, N.Y., would refrain from alleged monopolistic practices in the distribution of professional motion picture color film was submitted to the Federal District Court here today and taken under advisement by Judge William C. Mathes.

The National Container Corporation, in its consolidated report for the first nine months of this year, yesterday reported a net profit of $5,124,469 after all charges, compared with $8,288,615 earned in the nine months ended with September, 1947.

Federal funds, which last week varied from 1 1/4 on Wednesday to 7/8 on Friday, were quoted yesterday at 1 7/16. Due to an outflowing of funds and excess Treasury bills purchased over total sales of all Government securities, reserve balances began the week with a deficiency of $58,000,000 for the member Federal Reserve banks in New York City which was carried over from Friday.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Something that hadn't happened in years took place in Oakland today. Both Pitt and Carnegie Tech celebrated football victories.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Lanky Bob Black, one-man entry from Rhode Island State, shattered a nine-year individual mark today to win the tenth annual N.C.A.A. cross-country run in a field of nearly 300.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- "A protective charter for man and above all for the working masses -- nerve and nucleus of that democracy which we serve and practice -- is provided by the declaration of old age right," Dr. Juan Atilio Bramuglia, Argentine Foreign Minister, told the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today.

Some leading quality bedroom furniture manufacturers will soon put into effect "indirect" wholesale price reductions of 5 to 10 per cent, retailers reporters yesterday. They emphasized that prices of current merchandise will remain unchanged but added that patterns now being cut for introduction at the January home furnishings markets will be sold at lower prices.

A Christmas buying season which may equal that of the peak years of 1946-1947 is anticipated by the billion dollar jewelry industry, according to W. Waters Schwab, president of J. R. Wood Sons, and one of the leading executives in the industry.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The White House today announced the resignation of Russell Hopley of Omaha as Director of Civilian Defense Planning.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) -- It was a big day at the University of California today as word spread that the football team had been selected for the Rose Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Harold Christoffel, once an active leader in strike troubles at Milwaukee, lost his appeal today from a jail sentence imposed for falsely denying he had Communist connections.

Prices of futures traded on the Commodity Exchange were off yesterday, with hides for December delivery registering declines of 15 to 30 points. With the exception of distant September, 1949, deliveries, which advanced 20 points on two transactions, all months declined.

BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, Nov. 22 (Reuters) -- The English touring cricket team won its fifth successive match in South Africa by defeating Orange Free State and Basutoland by nine wickets here today with half an hour to spare.

The Democratic party, flushed with its overwhelming victory, might do well to consider carefully its course of action over the next four years, and the effect that the fulfillment of its many campaign promises will have upon the national economy. The fear of drastic legislation, such as excess profits taxes, higher income taxes, material controls, higher wages and lower prices, has frightened every investor almost to the point of panic.

BELGRADE, Nov. 22 -- Milovan Djilas, a member of the Yugoslav Politburo and representative of the Yugoslav Central Committee to the second Congress of the Croatian Communist party, now meeting at Zagreb, issued a warning yesterday against complacency in the struggle with the Communist Information Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- No further action will be taken at present to develop a voluntary scrap allocation plan involving the scrap industry's formation of a corporation to act as a central buying agency in Germany for indigenous scrap and steel for shipment to this country, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, announced today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade today were firm at the start, dipped and then rallied sharply.
Fifteen hundred persons paid $100 a plate at the annual dinner of the American Red Mogen Dovid for Palestine last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Dissatisfaction within the ranks of the New York Teachers Association reached a high point today at the 103d annual meeting of the group's House of Delegates as members of a "liberal wing" upset tradition by presenting their own slate of officers in opposition to those approved by the association's nominating committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank of South Carolina, whose state went for Thurmond for President, offered today to shoulder the responsibilities of the chairmanship of one of the most important Senate committees, but asked that the actual chairmanship go to Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York.
FORT HANCOCK, N. J., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Workmen were tearing down today the big 16-inch coast guns that have been the principal weapons here for many years.

A man carrying a pick came into the office, confided that he was an archeologist, and took a chair. He wondered if we had read the conclusion of Dr. Johannes Broensted, the Danish professor, that archeological evidence proved the Norsemen to have made settlements in America a couple of hundred years before Columbus came.

Both the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor have now taken such decided action on the Communist issue that there can scarcely be any further illusions in the Kremlin as to where American labor stands on the great issue of our times.

A proclamation has been issued by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, as president of the American Jewish Congress, calling on the American people to join in an "action for Israel" program next Saturday, Sunday and Monday in celebration of the first anniversary, on Monday, of the United Nations decision to establish the State of Israel, it was announced yesterday.

That a certain amount of government regulation of business and industry is desirable and even necessary under the private enterprise system has now long been accepted as fact by even the most vigilant and uncompromising foes of Statism. But where, precisely, is the line to be drawn between such necessary regulation, on the one hand, and, on the other, regulation which, by interfering with the free functioning of the economy, does more harm than good?
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Showing a fondness for the sloppy track, Mrs. S.M. Pistorio's Golden Bull won the Hambleton, feature event of a dreary program at the Bowie track today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 22 (UP) -- President Truman's supporters in Alabama lost two more lower court decisions today, then started an action in the State Supreme Court in an effort to deliver the state's electoral vote to the President.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The French memorandum to Secretary of State Marshall on the Ruhr, cabled to Washington by the United States Embassy here yesterday, challenges the authority of Generals Lucius D. Clay and Sir Brian Robertson, American and British Military Governors in Germany, to decide that the ultimate ownership of the Ruhr industries should be determined by an elected German government.
ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The undefeated and untied Sul Ross (Texas) State College Lobes of Alpine, Tex., will play here in the third annual Tangerine Bowl football game New Year's night.

The earlier hopes that resumption of direct talks between major domestic airlines and the Port of New York Authority might settle their differences over airport terms have been disappointed. Both sides seem as far apart as ever on the major issues; the result is damaging to both, unpleasant advertising for New York City and, in time, will surely be harmful to the public.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- During the last year the Soviet Union has made good, though uneven, progress toward recovery from the second World War, but its recovery still is far from complete and the economy still suffers from notable weaknesses, according to sources in possession of much information gathered in Moscow.

ATHENS, Nov. 22 -- Representing all the opposition to the Liberal-Populist coalition, with the exception of Stylianos Gonatas' National Liberal party of twenty-four members, former Premier George Papandreou, Democratic Socialist leader, called on King Paul today with a protest against retaining the present Cabinet in power on the basis of the 168-167 vote it received in Parliament early Sunday.
NANKING, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Communists attacked with renewed vigor today on the east flank of Suchow, 200 miles northwest of Nanking.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- Frank L. Moore, New York State Controller, recommended today that states refuse to legislate in areas where local governments had the power, "but sometimes not the courage," to take responsibility.

Since the characters in N. Richard Nash's drama are "The Young and Fair," their problems are not momentous. The new play that turned up at the Fulton last evening is small in size, and the crises that grow out of it are petty. But on its own terms as a minor school drama "The Young and Fair" could hardly be better.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 23 -- In an announcement dramatically issued at 1:30 o'clock this morning, Buckingham Palace disclosed that King George was suffering from an illness that would make it "hazardous" for him to undertake a royal tour of Australia and New Zealand next year. Accordingly, the Palace announced that the tour had been postponed indefinitely.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22 -- P. James Pellecchia, who resigned as a Newark Police Judge after confessing he embezzled more than a half million dollars from the now defunct Columbus Trust Company, of which he was vice president and counsel, pleaded non vult today before County Judge Richard Hartshorne to four indictments charging that he was part of a conspiracy involving the borrowing of money at usurious rates.

DALLAS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Southern Methodist University players selected their first choice for a New Year's day Cotton Bowl opponent by unanimous vote late today -- but kept the name of the team a secret.
PRAGUE, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Loyal Communist party "secretaries" will rule Czechoslovakia's industry from now on.

Declaring that the current decline in savings and the sharp rise in consumer and mortgage debt are weaknesses of the American economy, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, urged last night that any enactment of new tax legislation should be based on a careful study of its effect upon capital formation.

Columbia's School of General Studies has created the Merle M. Hoover Scholarship, the first in the school's history, with a gift of $15,000, it was announced yesterday. The donor, a woman who wishes to remain anonymous, gave the money in gratitude because her "life has been enriched in many ways" as a result of courses she took in the school.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Compliance with the Westchester Board of Supervisors' instructions of a week ago to bar nonresidents from two county parks on busy days next year would be illegal, the County Park Commission told the board today.
Penn State and Army each grabbed a pair of positions yesterday on the All-East eleven selected by The Associated Press after consultations with coaches, scouts and other football experts.
"WHAT holds you up?" asked Greasy Neale, challengingly. "I thought you'd have to spend at least a full week in bed after the workout you got yesterday."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 22 -- The current trial in Skoplje, capital of Yugoslav Macedonia, where ten Macedonians have been charged with war crimes in the service of the Bulgarian Fascist Army of Occupation in the last war, has produced evidence that, in light of the Yugoslav struggle with the Communist Information Bureau, is calculated to incriminate the present Communist Government of Bulgaria and cause an uproar in the Communist world.

VIENNA, Nov. 22 -- The Red Army newspaper in Vienna, the Oesterreichische Zeitung, bitterly attacked today Karl Renner, President of Austria, asserting that he had announced Austria would not be neutral in the future but would join the Western bloc. The paper declared:

The Port of New York Authority will receive bids on Dec. 7 on an issue of $7,000,000 of marine terminal bonds for development of the port of Newark. The bonds will run for thirty years and will be callable after the fifth year for sinking fund purposes.

Thomas J. Cochrane, advertising manager of The New York Daily News, has been elected president and chairman of the board of the American Newspaper Advertising Network, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Charles J. Feldmann, national advertising manager of The Des Moines Register and Tribune.

The Lionel Barrymore dramatic series, "Mayor of the Town," was reported yesterday to be the subject of a deal, "very close" to completion, which would bring the program to the Mutual hook-up. Previously, the Barrymore episodes were carried by ABC, having last been heard over that chain late last June.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 22 -- The membership of the American Academy of Pediatrics approved today the report of its committee for the improvement of child health. The proposal is to provide complete medical care for the nation's 36,000,000 children under 15 years old.

Soviet propaganda efforts in Western Germany are being negated by the economic contributions of the airlift, William H. Draper, Under-Secretary of the Army, told several hundred members of the Bond Club of New York at a luncheon in the Bankers Club yesterday.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- In an atmosphere of good feeling, especially notable in the case of Russia, General MacArthur got the opinions of the eleven official Allied representatives today on the Tojo trial convictions.

The second annual Boys and Girls Book Fair ended its run at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday in a burst of community singing. By the time the last reluctant child had been cleared out of the exhibition hall, museum officials had totted up their attendance figures -- a full 105,000 for the four days. Total attendance last year was 25,000.

The first day of the second truck strike in two months yesterday saw its extension beyond the ranks of the striking union to a point where one-third of the general trucking industry in the city was estimated to be affected.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 10 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 6 per cent.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Frederick H. Osborn, Deputy United States Representative of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, declared tonight that a recent book by a British Nobel Prize winner supporting the Soviet view of atomic energy control was wrong in "almost every detail."

The country's reserve fleet of merchant vessels has surpassed the 1,900-vessel mark for the first time, it was announced yesterday. Statistics released by the United States Maritime Commission show that 1,901 ships are now undergoing the "moth ball" treatment at nine permanent and temporary lay-up sites maintained by the commission.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22 -- Yale's football squad today unanimously elected Levi Jackson, star halfback, its 1949 captain.

Answers to pressing problems of the manufacturing executive cannot be given if the accountant sticks to "commonly accepted accounting principles," said Allen H. Ottman, controller and vice president of the American Hard Rubber Company, speaking last night before the New York Chapter, National Association of Cost Accountants, at its monthly dinner meeting in Schraffts Concourse Restaurant in Radio City.

Directors of the Combustion Engineering Company, Inc., and the Superheater Company, both of New York and two of the country's leading producers of power equipment, approved yesterday a merger of the companies, subject to approval of stockholders of each at special meetings on Dec. 22.

The privately placed loan has become an increasingly important means of investing the assets of insurance companies and has raised the question whether such transactions should be governed more adequately by State legislation.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The difficulties that bar the way to agreement on quadripartite control of the Soviet mark in Berlin were brought into sharp focus today as well-informed sources said Moscow had maintained substantially the same views it had expressed in a white paper of last October dealing with that question.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Total personal income in the United States reached the record annual rate of $214,000,000,000 in the third quarter of this year. This was more than a fourth above the rate for the first quarter of 1946 and nearly triple the personal income of 1939.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Continued strength of British Government bonds helped maintain a generally firm tone in the stock market here today. Steady investment buying lifted prices as much as an eighth all around.

ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- Taking issue with a statement by John M. Murtagh, New York City Investigation Commissioner, that the state has shown "very little interest" in New York City milk prices, Senator Austin Erwin, chairman of the State Commission on Agriculture, declared today that the commission expects to report to the 1949 Legislature on the subject.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Anwar Museibeh, secretary general of the provisional Arab Palestine Government at Gaza, said today that he had come to London only to be fitted with an artificial leg and not to seek British recognition of the Gaza Government, as reported from Beirut, Lebanon, yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The United States demanded today that the United Nations Security Council reconsider the membership applications of six countries vetoed by the Soviet Union.

Representative Fred A. Hartley suggested last night that President Truman appoint a fact-finding board, as provided for in the Taft-Hartley Law, if current Federal mediation failed to end the dock strike here. The New Jersey Republican addressed the Personnel Management Association at the Columbia University Club.
OLEAN, N.Y., Nov. 22 (AP) -- It will be Notre Dame "Old Home Day" here Thursday as St. Bonaventure and San Francisco meet in a Thanksgiving Day football feature.
Throughout the nation and overseas, Americans are preparing to offer their gratitude for a bountiful year as they celebrate Thanksgiving Day on Thursday amid the troubled peace of the world.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 22 -- A clear intent to fight the state's contemplated court action to gain control of two Delaware River bridges bought recently by the Burlington County Bridge Commission was expressed today by the commission.

VIENNA, Nov. 22 -- Apparently authentic reports in Vienna today indicate Dana Superina, principal witness in the murder of Irving Ross, a member of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission here, has gone on a hunger strike.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 22 -- In language that brought delegates to their feet cheering wildly again and again, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today directed a bitter attack on left-wingers in the CIO and demanded to know whether it was their purpose to "carry out the same tactics in America that their comrades are carrying out in other countries."

Mass production of its new line of television receivers was announced in Chicago over the weekend by the Zenith Radio Corporation through Comdr. E.F. McDonald Jr., president. The receivers will go on sale in the Chicago area Nov. 29 and will be introduced into other television areas throughout the country as rapidly as expanding production permits.

Use of French Colonial citation medals as decorations for handbags by Harry Rosenfeld, Inc., manufacturers of high fashion handbags, has brought an opinion from the United States State Department that this use has not violated provisions of the International Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property, it was disclosed yesterday by Milton S. Graber, president of the handbag concern.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, predicted today that virtually all labor organizations, as current contracts expire, would seek another round of wage increases to catch up with prices. He said he had "no idea" how much of a pay rise would be sought.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- A witness today at the special tribunal investigating charges of corruption among British Government officials described John Belcher, parliamentary secretary of the Board of Trade, as behaving like a "man wrongfully accused" when he heard allegations that he had been bribed.

Mrs. George Hall of Wembley, England, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Washington to pay a debt of gratitude to Mrs. A. Whitman Crittenden of Rochester, N.Y. Mrs. Crittenden, who suffered a stroke last summer, cared for one of Mrs. Hall's children here during the bombing of England.
UVALDE, Tex., Nov. 22 (AP) -- John Nance Garner made more fuss with his pots and pans today in getting ready for a three-day hunting trip than he did in celebrating his eightieth birthday.

A 26-year-old convict, sentenced yesterday for an attempted holdup to twenty-five to forty years in Sing Sing as a second felony offender, was accused also of the slaying in 1947 of a motorcycle patrolman.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) Citation, current king of racetracks, heads the list of fourteen thoroughbreds nominated for the $50,000-added Tanforan Handicap on Dec. 11. Among the horses entered with Citation are Shannon II, a champion in Australia, and On Trust, top-ranking California-bred.

Lief Hendil, a Danish editor of Ekstrabladet of Copenhagen, took off from New York International Airport at Idlewild yesterday at 1:30 P.M. aboard a Scandinavian Airlines System plane with only half an hour to spare to make his goal of a strip around the world in seven days by scheduled airline.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The State Department accused the Communist regime in Bulgaria today of having smashed its last parliamentary opposition by jailing nine Independent Socialist Deputies after secret trials on trumped-up charges.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- American Communists have "dug into" some religious groups and are still "at it," the House Committee on Un-American Activities asserted today.

Everyone -- well, almost everyone -- has a soft spot in his heart for a lonely, hungry kitten. That is the case with Mrs. John S. Hunter. As president of New York's Empire Cat Club and a nationally known judge of felines, Mrs. Hunter has a love not only for hungry kittens but for all kinds of cats. She knows her Persians. She knows her Siamese.

Declaring that 60 per cent of the patients in all hospitals are suffering either from psychological illness or a combination of psychological and physical illness. Dr. S. Bernard Wortis, chairman of the department of psychiatry of the New York University College of Medicine, suggested yesterday that every doctor and nurse in the field of medicine have more psychiatric training.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A plan providing for the dissolution of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Consummation of the plan, which was preceded by several proposals which were rejected, would terminate proceedings instituted by the SEC in 1940 directing the company to comply with Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- Only nine days of life remain for the present session of the Imperial Diet and only one piece of legislation seems to have a chance of passage. This is the national public service law revision.

Robert Goldsand played much new music and so much old music last night in Carnegie Hall that the concert stretched to unusual lengths. It revealed a most accomplished pianist, although "revealed" applies no longer to the position in his field of Mr. Goldsand, who spent his gifts in a way that tended to build up classic rather than modern composers.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The Soviet Union demanded today that the United Nations General Assembly establish a permanent peace settlement in Palestine based "in substance" on the partition resolution adopted by the General Assembly a year ago.

A motion picture of dry construction methods will be shown at the luncheon meeting of the technical committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects today in the Architectural League Building, 115 East Fortieth Street.

No general increase in the 1,800,000 Federally controlled residential rents in this city and Long Island will be recommended by the New York City Rent Advisory Board, it was announced yesterday by Joseph D. McGoldrick, chairman.
ORANGE, Tex., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The small Nicaraguan motor vessel Explorer, overdue for a week with a million-dollar cargo, limped into Sabine Pass, 25 miles south of Orange, Tex., at 1:05 P.M. today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 22 -- Charging that the Thomas committee "has violated democratic principles by intimidation and sensational publicity against individuals," the Women's League of the United Synagogue urged the Government today to abolish the House Un-American Activities Committee.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The strikers from the liner Queen Elizabeth returned to work today but the ship still will be unable to sail until the New York longshoremen's strike is settled.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) -- California's Golden Bears will oppose Northwestern's Wildcats in the Rose Bowl on New Year's Day, and it will be a golden opportunity for California Coach Lynn (Pappy) Waldorf to teach his old school new tricks.

The shotgun killing of a 15-year-old boy and the wounding of another by an eccentric three weeks ago in the New Lots section of Brooklyn was attributed at a Board of Education budget hearing yesterday to a lack of playground facilities.

Architectural plans were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings for Parkside Houses, a project in the Bronx containing 868 apartments to be built without cash subsidy by the New York City Housing Authority. The development will occupy a site of nearly ten and one-half acres bounded by Adee Avenue, White Plains Road, Arnow Avenue and Bronx Park East.
OSSIPEE, N. H., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Ralph Jennings, 46 years old, a thrice-married woodchopper, today was charged with murder in the slaying of Ruth Eisenberg, 22 years old, a nurse of Newark, N.J.

Another three-cornered schedule conflict will find the local professional football teams scrambling for patronage on Sunday, when the Yankees engage the Buffalo Bills at the Stadium, the Giants oppose the Boston Yanks at the Polo Grounds and the Brooklyn Dodgers clash with the Baltimore Colts at Ebbets Field.

THE TIMES issue of Nov. 18 carried a letter signed "A Tenant," who seems to be under the impression that a tenant who signed a lease with a 15 per cent "so-called voluntary increase" is decontrolled and that upon expiration of the lease his rent may be raised to any figure.

That the Electoral College vote often fails notoriously to reflect the popular vote in Presidential elections has long been known, and is constantly being emphasized as we go from one election to another. Mr. Dewey, this time, carried New York State by the exceedingly slim margin of 55,000 votes in a total of more than five million cast, but received all 47 of New York's electoral votes while Mr. Truman got nary a one.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22 -- Sixty-two delegates representing twenty-three automobile clubs in seventeen countries of the Western Hemisphere registered today with the Inter-American Federation of Automobile Clubs, which will inaugurate its eighth annual general assembly here tomorrow.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Trainer Hirsch Jacobs announced today that Stymie will be bred to thirteen mares next spring and then go back to racing to shoot for $1,000,000 in total earnings.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Northwestern's football squad and 8,000 students massed in frenzied celebrations today when it was made known that the university's football team had been selected to play in the Rose Bowl.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- Royal S. Little, president of Textron, Inc., testified today that he had sold 10,000 shares of his corporation's stock to an agent for Helen Hayes, the actress, at a rate $5 a share less than his own simultaneous purchase of a similar block on behalf of the Rhode Island Charities Trust.
Despite the need for more teachers in this country, fewer students are preparing for the teaching profession this fail than a year ago, according to a nation-wide survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Wage and hour adjustments demanded by sixteen nonoperating railroad unions would cost the country's railroads more than $1,500,000,000 a year, members of a Presidential Fact-Finding Board were told today. The board is conducting hearings on the unions' request for a 25-cents-an-hour wage increase, a five-day week and various overtime concessions.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal Court today denied a Negro's plea to attend classes at the University of Oklahoma on a non-segregated basis.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22 -- To help homemakers choose accessories of good design instead of "white elephants," useful articles that cost $10 and less have been selected from local department stores by the Newark Museum for an exhibit of Christmas gift suggestions that opened today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Kitty Hawk, built by the brothers Wilbur and Orville Wright and officially adjudged as the original airplane, came home to Washington today after a twenty-year "exile" in London.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Wage and hour adjustments demanded by sixteen nonoperating railroad unions would cost the country's railroads more than $1,500,000,000 a year, members of a Presidential Fact-Finding Board were told today. The board is conducting hearings on the unions' request for a 25-cents-an-hour wage increase, a five-day week and various overtime concessions.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal Court today denied a Negro's plea to attend classes at the University of Oklahoma on a non-segregated basis.
If you can find a lake that is frozen over, which is not inhabited list of waters closed to ice fishing, you can cut a hole in the ice and try for some pickerel, pike and walleyes.

Failure to pass literacy tests prior to the recent elections cost 11,483 American citizens their right to vote. An analysis of the reasons for this failure, described by local school authorities, indicates that most of these failures were due to difficulty encountered in two of the nine questions asked in the examination.

As Thanksgiving Day approaches, most of us look forward to sitting down to a sumptuous turkey dinner with all the fixings which only an American harvest can provide. I say "most of us" advisedly, because with turkey at an all-time high and with other prices equally inflated, there are many who will be unable to join in this feast.

Acting under telephoned instructions from Louis Hollander, president of the State CIO Council, and Allan S. Haywood, Congress of Industrial Organizations vice president and director of organization, Morris Iushewitz moved yesterday to take over the offices of the Greater New York CIO Council at 1133 Broadway.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- J. Newton Garver, 20 years old, a student at Swarthmore College, was sentenced to jail today for refusing to register for Selective Service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upheld today the validity of a second major part of the portal-to-portal pay act, the "good faith" section.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- In each of the last three elections the principal public opinion polls have been increasingly favorable to the Republicans, but they were not scientific because the reason for the trend was not discovered at the same time, Professor Paul Hatt of Princeton University said tonight at a panel discussion at the university.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22 -- To help homemakers choose accessories of good design instead of "white elephants," useful articles that cost $10 and less have been selected from local department stores by the Newark Museum for an exhibit of Christmas gift suggestions that opened today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Kitty Hawk, built by the brothers Wilbur and Orville Wright and officially adjudged as the original airplane, came home to Washington today after a twenty-year "exile" in London.

The possibility of losing Center Herb Seidell, with a resulting all-sophomore line-up for Fordham's final game of the season with New York University Saturday, confronted Coach Ed Danowski at Rose Hill yesterday.

NANKING. Nov. 22 -- The housing shortage has ended in Nanking and rents are falling fast despite the inflation, except for the remaining foreigners who have already paid their rents in American money one year in advance. Today's edition of The Central Daily News carried nineteen classified ads offering "houses for sale" in this once-crowded city.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 22 -- A vast improvement in the regularity of all flying can be expected this winter, with automatic, all-weather flight probable by 1963.
