BERRYVILLE, Va., Nov. 22 -- "You have made it thoroughly obvious," remarked the owner of "Limestone," on the Shenandoah River four miles from this town, "that you know we are giving up the place and that you are deeply disturbed about your immediate and future security."

Senator Enrique B. Magalona of the Philippines appealed to the Government and people of the United States last night for greater economic and military aid to his country. Senator Magalona, soon to return home after studying labor and social security laws here, was interviewed at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

As chairman of the football coaches' rules committee, Lou Little, the Columbia mentor, spent a great part of the season listening to repeated blasts against the unlimited substitution rule. Here and there he made notes and infrequently joined in the general discussion.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 22 -- May 7 is the tentative date of the 1949 Kentucky Derby.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The proceedings of the United Nations:

Sirdar J. J. Singh, in your issue of Nov. 17, asks for suggestions to end the ambiguity in our indiscriminate use of the term "Indian." Here the onus rests on us Americans. Our scientists have been trying for many years to induce us to adopt generally their word "Amerind" for what we call "American Indian."

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Dr. Timothy Chi-Hsuen Liang, Chinese physician active in the treatment of tuberculosis with streptomycin, today had taken the first step toward American citizenship, the result of a fight by hundreds of Chautauqua County residents, that ended on the floor of Congress, to prevent his deportation.

RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 22 -- John Edward Rigney, 28 years old, of 1232 New Brunswick Avenue, a disabled veteran of World War II, was killed here today when struck by a westbound Pennsylvania Railroad passenger express on the Bridge Street trestle.

In the most modern tradition of exhibition policy, the New York Public Library, opening its 100th anniversary celebration yesterday, showed New Yorkers old prints of their city and contemporary works in newly arranged and decorated galleries.

Heitor Alimonda, 23-year-old Brazilian pianist, presents his music straight-from-the-shoulder, and, after his American debut recital at Town Hall last night, it must be reported that the directness of interpretation, coupled with his unusually fine technique, was easy to take.
Envisioning gay holiday parties, Russeks provided a showing yesterday at the Plaza Hotel of after-five and formal fashions.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 22 -- The Korean Government has been assured by Ambassador John J. Muccio, President Truman's representative here, and by Maj. Gen. John B. Coulter, United States commander in Korea, that no change has been made in United States policy concerning the withdrawal of troops from Korea.

Models by Jo Davidson, sculptor, and Ely Jacques Kahn, architect, for a proposed monument to the Warsaw ghetto massacres will go on public view today at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue. They will be displayed until February.

MADRID, Nov. 22 -- On the basis of still incomplete returns, members of the Falange party have won about 82 per cent of the seats in the first section of the voting in Spain's Municipal Council elections.

Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, Tammany Hall leader, promised yesterday that his organization would fight to the highest court to have General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen declared the winner of the Surrogate's post.

Football's spectacle of spectacles -- the Army-Navy game -- brings the intercollegiate season to a close in the East Saturday. In Philadelphia's vast Municipal Stadium 101,000, the year's largest gathering, will assemble for the forty-ninth meeting between the service academies.
It's hard to keep up with the merry-go-round of New York's fashion world.
Envisioning gay holiday parties, Russeks provided a showing yesterday at the Plaza Hotel of after-five and formal fashions.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 22 -- The Korean Government has been assured by Ambassador John J. Muccio, President Truman's representative here, and by Maj. Gen. John B. Coulter, United States commander in Korea, that no change has been made in United States policy concerning the withdrawal of troops from Korea.

Models by Jo Davidson, sculptor, and Ely Jacques Kahn, architect, for a proposed monument to the Warsaw ghetto massacres will go on public view today at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue. They will be displayed until February.

MADRID, Nov. 22 -- On the basis of still incomplete returns, members of the Falange party have won about 82 per cent of the seats in the first section of the voting in Spain's Municipal Council elections.

Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, Tammany Hall leader, promised yesterday that his organization would fight to the highest court to have General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen declared the winner of the Surrogate's post.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The two principal preoccupations on Pennsylvania Avenue these days are sight-seeing and speculation, both of which are a source of some annoyance to President Truman.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 22 -- A positive inducement is being offered to foreign capital to help build up Pakistan, Khwaja Nazimuddin, Governor General of the new Moslem state, declared in an interview today.

A long family ownership of 354 East Eighty-ninth Street has ended with the sale of the dwelling at that address by the Schramm heirs to clients of Baker Flaster, attorneys, who insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Robinson Plywood and Timber Company of Everett, Wash., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 271,025 shares of $1 par value common stock. The company proposes to offer 105,000 shares of the stock and the remaining 166,025 shares are to be offered by fifteen selling stockholders.

The Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I., maker of the wartime Thunderbolt fighter and the current Thunderjet F-84, showed yesterday at the Wings Club in the Biltmore Hotel, new molded reinforced plastic dies and tools as well as non-structural aircraft components made of plastics.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly proposed today that the boundaries of Israel and of the Arab part of Palestine be determined on the dual basis of the Assembly's partition resolution and the final proposals by the late Count Folke Bernadotte.

In the latest of its many protests against the Communist terror in the Balkans, the State Department formally declares that by jailing its last Parliamentary opposition the Bulgarian Government has terminated the final pretense of democracy and therewith violated again the Treaty of Peace signed by the United States.
As a Presidential Elector chosen by the State of Louisiana to vote for Thurmond and Wright, I beg to thank you for the editorial entitled "The Dixiecrat vote," appearing in your paper Nov. 7.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- Planned Economy, journal of the State Planning Commission, today reported an extended session of the Economic Institute of the Academy of Sciences in which Eugene Varga was severely criticized for his refusal to admit the error of his views.

The return of the Freedom Train to this city will be marked at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow by a ceremony at which Mayor O'Dwyer is scheduled to speak. The ceremony will be held in the Old Halloran Hospital Railroad Yard, Arlington, S.I., with 2,500 school children in costume and honor guards from the armed forces and the American region present to honor the train and its 127 historic documents.

The National Committee for Mental Hygiene opened yesterday a campaign for the nomination to the Hall of Fame of Dorothea Lynde Dix, a pioneer in the fight against mental illness in America 100 years ago. The committee announced its plains at a luncheon meeting at the home of Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, 29 Beekman Place, secretary of the group.
PARIS, Nov. 23 -- Egypt threatened publicly today to walk out of the United Nations if Israel were admitted to membership in the world organization.

The New York State Commission for the Blind will hold the silver anniversary Christmas sale of articles made by blind persons at 11 West Fifty-seventh Street from Monday through Dec. 18, it was announced yesterday. The sale will be supported by civic, religious, professional and social organizations of the city, with more than 1,000 members of these groups making up the volunteer sales staff.

" Face the Music," the 7:45 P.M. quarter-hour carried Mondays through Fridays by WCBS-TV, was reported yesterday to be labeled for early withdrawal from the television station's program schedule. The show is put on by Johnny Desmond, Sandra Deel and the Tony Mottola Trio.

It is the responsibility of management to lower distribution costs of merchandise they produce, Robert A. Whitney, president of the National Federation of Sales Executives, told members of the American Marketing Association yesterday at their monthly meeting in the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A bill for Federal aid to education, one of the items high on President Truman's legislative program, will be introduced in the new Congress on the day it meets, Jan. 3.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 23 The general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization voted tonight a $8,000,000 ceiling on its 1949 budget -- $317,000 higher than last year but $250,000 lower than the minimum Director General Julian Huxley pleaded for.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- A statement of the duties of the individual toward the community is an indispensable part of the Declaration on Human Rights, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today.
TOKYO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur will announce soon a "concession" to United States and other foreign business men on investments in Japan.

D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Temporary State Commission to Study Rents, requested Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday to furnish information on the City Rent Commission and on the inquiry into its affairs that is being conducted by John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation.

The directors of the National Lead Company voted yesterday year-end distributions for both stockholders and employes. The regular quarterly cash dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock was augmented by an extra cash payment of a like amount plus a stock dividend of one share for each twenty shares of common held.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- Creation of a coordinated State University System, authorized by the Legislature last spring, moved one step closer as the board of trustees of the proposed system held its first open hearing today.

There was no hysteria in the laughter among the football Giants at yesterday's weekly luncheon at the Polo Grounds press room. The mirth was genuine and wholehearted -- as well it might be after that stunning 49-3 beating Steve Owen's boys gave the Green Bay Packers in Milwaukee last Sunday.

When Menachem Begin, former commander-in-chief of Irgun Zvai Leumi, one of the Palestinian underground forces, arrived at La Guardia Field from Washington at 3 P.M. yesterday he received an enthusiastic reception from 500 persons gathered at the airport to greet him.

PRETORIA, Union of South Africa, Nov. 23 -- Within one week of the deadline for shipping goods from the United States if they are to escape currency control, indications here today pointed to probableh)0*0*0*irefusal of any extension of time.

A proposal for the inclusion of $1,000,000 in the 1949 capital budget to acquire a parking area for trucks near the lower West Side produce market was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The President and Mrs. Truman and their daughter, Margaret, will have their Thanksgiving dinner at Blair House, their first such celebration.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 23 -- The withdrawal of United States troops from Korea before the national defense forces were prepared to meet a Communist armed invasion would "result in complete disaster" for Korea and for the American position in the Far East, President Syngman Rhee declared today.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard indicated yesterday that the current "reinvestigation of the entire caseload" under the supervision of that department will lead, within the next six months, to the removal of all ineligible persons from the welfare lists.h)0*0*0*iO

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that an employer, in settling a strike, must maintain the relative pre-strike seniority of strikers and non-striking employes. Thus, an employer must count time spent on strike toward seniority credits for striking employes who return to work after a strike if he counts it for non-strikers.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Quiet conditions ruled in the stock market here today.

Alexander Borovsky gave first New York performances of the Sonatina, Op. 67, of Jean Sibelius and "The Kiss of the Christ-Child" from "Vingt regards sur l'EnfantJesus") by Olivier Messiaen at his piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 23 -- The convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations momentarily stopped the verbal chastisement of leftists within its ranks today to call unanimously for the repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act and substitution of the Wagner Act, without amendment.
The relinquishment of national sovereignty inherent in the Marshall Plan was praised last night by the new Swedish Ambassador to the United States, Erik Boheman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government asserted today that the Federal establishment could save $250,000,000 annually in buying supplies and equipment.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The United Nations Security Council was summoned today to meet on Thursday for consideration of the deteriorating situation on the Indian subcontinent. Both the Hyderabad and the Kashmir issues will be on the Council's agenda

The vast gap between enterprise in a democracy and business as it is conducted under a totalitarian regime is easy to see at all times, but is strikingly apparent in days preceding festival occasions; it is especially evident in advance of a certain holiday which falls on a date in late December.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 23 -- Spokesmen for organized labor will advise President Truman soon that "there cannot be two Secretaries of Labor, one in the White House and one in the Labor Department."

The underwriting spread of $21 per $1,000 bond generated out of yesterday's marketing of Chesapeake Ohio Railway bonds adds an old-fashioned ingredient to the stew of "spread" and "bidding cover" statistics which the sealedbid-and-deadline system has been serving up.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered the Boeing Airplane Company of Seattle today to resume collective bargaining with a local lodge of the International Association of Machinists (independent) and to offer full reinstatement to all employes who went on strike last April 22.

One of the most satisfying aspects of "American Textiles '48," the exhibition that opens today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is that visitors may give free rein to their imagination in deciding how each fabric is to be used.

It is now a virtual certainty that when 1948 is over, it will have been the worst poliomyelitis year in the United States since 1916 when there were 30,000 cases. In addition, there exists the possibility that the 1948 total may exceed the 30,000 mark and become the worst year on record.

In 1507, in the town of St. Die, France, the word America was set in type for the first time, by a printer who was publishing a work entitled "Cosmographiae Introductio" by the geographer Martin Waldseemueller.

As one who has been identified with the work of Dr. Walter C. Lowdermilk in the development of his much-discussed and apparently much-misunderstood Jordan Valley Authority plan, I was rather taken aback by the letter of George C. Russell Jr. printed Oct. 21.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 The blockade of Berlin has cost the Soviet zone more than 12,000,000 marks worth of bi-zonal products owed to the Eastern zones under a trade agreement, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, disclosed today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Levi Jackson's election as Yale's 1949 football captain was being cheered today, both on andh)off the campus.

After a day of arguments, Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga late yesterday afternoon instructed lawyers on both sides in the court contest over the election for Surrogate to submit briefs on the question of his jurisdiction in the case.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 23 Thomas W. Gibbs, a Negro student from Evanston, Ill., was one of sixteen sophomores initiated tonight into Phi Psi, formerly the Massachusetts alpha chapter of Phi Kappa Psi, national college fraternity, at Amherst College.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Reliable sources said that Premier Hasan Saka had told his ruling People's party today that Russia had suggested renewed friendship with Turkey.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Howie Houston, husky 22year old lineman who received honorable mention in the Associated Press All-East selections, today was elected captain of the Harvard football team for 1949.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 23 -- The Venezuelan political crisis neared its final stage this afternoon when the Cabinet of President Romulo Gallegos resigned, to permit him to name new Ministers. His Ministers said, in a formal letter to Dr. Gallegos:

DETROIT, Nov. 23 -- A blustering Russia dealing in words, not war, and lacking atomic bomb power was portrayed today at the fourteenth annual luncheon given by THE NEW YORK TIMES for automotive and industrial executives here.
GENEVA, Nov. 23 -- Europe's shortage of metallurgical coke seems to have come suddenly and dramatically to an end.

h)0*0*0*iOFailure of the New York dress industry to book business for immediate delivery has caused widespread lay-offs in the trade, it was learned yesterday. Popular price and lower ranges of medium price garments have been hardest hit, according to trade sources.

In the years immediately ahead, New York's public school system will have to provide for 250,000 more children, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, warned yesterday at a ground-breaking ceremony for the twenty-fourth new school project in the Board of Education's post-war construction program.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The United States and Britain have reached an agreement upon the future status of the Italian colonies that they are expected to support jointly when the question is taken up by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved within a narrow range yesterday and closed 7 points lower to 1 point higher.

Mrs. Walter Maynard gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 60 East Ninetyfirst Street, for members of the committee active in the sale of tickets for the performance of "Life With Mother" on the night of Dec. 7 at the Empire Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for Greenwich House.

VIENNA, Nov. 23 -- The Presidential Chancellery stated today that the attack by the Red Army organ, the Oesterreichische Zeitung, on Sunday on President Karl Renner of Austria was the result of a quotation from an interview appearing in the United States licensed Munich Neue Zeitung having been taken completely out of the context.

At 8 o'clock this evening the Theatre Guild will trot out its third subscription offering of the season, "The Silver Whistle," at the Biltmore. Starred in the comedy is Jose Ferrer, who enacts a garrulous hobo whose mission in life is to spread happiness, particularly among the inmates of an old folks' home.

NANKING, Nov. 23 -- A Nationalist relief force under Gen. Huang Wei was reported nearing Suhsien tonight as the Communist radio asserted that a Communist army had begun "stepping up" the second stage of its offensive against Government troops protecting the approaches to Nanking.

Four American artists were elected to membership yesterday in the American Academy of Arts and Letters. They are William Faulkner and John Steinbeck, novelists; Leon Kroll, painter, and Mark Van Doren, critic, poet and biographer.

Thanksgiving Day originally started in New England as a day when men and women gave thanks to Almighty God for the blessings of life. There is far too little thankfulness in America today. As Rector of the Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy for the past twenty-six years, I have urged the observance of Thanksgiving Day by attending divine service at 8 and 11 o'clock in the morning.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 23 -- Fifteen hundred Lafayette College students took part tonight in a mass demonstration lasting several hours because college authorities had announced earlier in the day their rejection of an invitation to the Leopards' football team to play in the Sun Bowl at El Paso, Tex., on New Year's Day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -Claude Binyon, writer-director at Universal-International since 1947, has moved over to Twentieth CenturyFox under a new term contract, it was learned today. Binyon's first assignment at Fox will be "The Doctor Wears Three Faces," which he will adapt from a forthcoming novel by Mary Bard as a vehicle for Maureen O'Hara.

Bernice Kamsler, who made her debut here in January, gave her second New York program of folk songs last night at Times Hall. Again she used changes of costume, acting and preliminary speeches to underline her interpretations.

While President Truman and Secretary Marshall continue to weigh the question of American aid to China, a new catchword is gaining currency in this field of foreign policy. We are being told that American aid must be "all or nothing." Either we must throw enough power into China to turn the tide of the civil war, or what we do will be wasted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has been appointed to a commission of twenty educators which will make a study during 1949 of the role of the public schools in the face of continuing international tensions.

The Railway Express Agency announced yesterday that it had embargoed almost all air and rail shipments into and out of its New York and New Jersey terminals because of a major slowdown strike of its clerical and platform employes.
MONTREAL, Nov. 23 (AP) -- This has been a lean season so far for the Toronto Maple Leafs, but not so for their smoothworking center Ted Kennedy.

The teacher holds in his hands today the future of our country, the perpetuation of the rights and freedoms we enjoy, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, told the members of the Museum of the City of New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Preston T. Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, Chicago automobile manufacturer, announced here this afternoon that the company would close its plant at 5 P.M. today for a "prolonged weekend."
The United States Golf Association yesterday announced that the international Walker Cup matches would be resumed next summer between the golfers of the British Isles and the United States.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Pennsylvania Roalroad borrowed money in the public bond market yesterday at a difference of about 1.32 per cent in interest cost. The Chesapeake Ohio sold $40,000,000 of term bonds maturing in twenty-five years at an interest cost of 3.96 per cent.

Dr. Alfred E. Cohn, member emeritus of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, has resigned from the board of directors of Sydenham Hospital, he announced here yesterday. Dr. Cohn was appointed to the board on Feb. 17, 1947, at which time he announced a plan for expanding the facilities of the hospital to include a research institute and an institute of community relations.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- Charles Edison, former Secretary of the Navy, accused the nation's business, industrial and financial leaders tonight of promoting the very "Federal centralization and Washington bureaucracy they invariably denounce."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A consolidated program in the child welfare field evolved today by common consent and enthusiasm at the American Parents Committee conference on legislation in the Eightyfirst Congress.

Negotiations in the lengthening Atlantic Coast longshore strike reached a new impasse last night when operator-employers announced that they would make no more offers to the 30,000 dock workers who walked out on Nov. 10.

Answering a request from Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, 140 teachers have volunteered to act as interpreters to United Nations personnel and to distinguished foreign visitors who may wish to visit the city's schools, it was announced yesterday.

Columbia's football squad chose Donald Scott Hawkins, reserve fullback, as honorary captain of the Lions' 1948 eleven in a post season election yesterday. Hawkins has been a member of the squad for four years.

The threat of a strike against the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company that may tie up the Hudson tubes beginning at 12:01 A.M. Saturday hung in the balance yesterday. The dispute, which will affect 215,000 persons who travel daily to and from New Jersey, was being mediated under the Railway Labor Act by officials of the Federal Railway Mediation Board.

CHICAGO, Nov 23 -- Chicago's newspaper printers will complete the first year of their strike at 9 o'clock tomorrow night. Since Local 16 of the International Typographical Union, AFL, ordered the 1,500 employes from their jobs in the five newspaper composing rooms, the strikers have lost an estimated $7,000,000 in wages, not counting overtime they might have received.

Tourist class fares on international airlines are a probability for the autumn of 1949. They will provide such a reduction from present first-class fares based on an average of 9 cents a mile as to make possible, in the words of Sir William Hildred, executive director of the International Air Transport Association, "a factory hand's holiday abroad."

There was encouraging news yesterday on the outlook for labor legislation from both the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations. At Cincinnati, where the AFL has been holding its annual convention, delegates adopted a resolution calling for repeal of what they termed "the obnoxious Taft-Hartley Law."

Gratitude to the many unknown donors who have helped keep alive their 7-year-old daughter for the last five years, Mr. and Mrs. Carmine Lupio of 40 Garfield Place visited the Greater New York Red Cross Center at 57 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, yesterday and made a "Thanksgiving blood donation."
BETHPAGE, L.I., Nov. 23 -- The first of 400 glassy-slick jet fighters ordered by the Navy for carrier service rolled off the assembly line of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation here today.
C. J. Blanford, Milk Market Administrator, informed Major O'Dwyer yesterday that milk producers had requested that the price of milk be cut two cents by next April.

Spokesmen for both fire and casualty insurance companies told the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Rates and Regulations yesterday that there was an adequate "capacity" to handle all the insurance requirements in the United States.

The city may expect "the heat to be put on" soon in the taxicab situation, organizers of John L. Lewis' District 50 told taxi drivers and workers in garages at two closed meetings yesterday morning and last night in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

A mild recovery near the close yesterday halted a new decline in the stock market. But earlier losses were not reduced materially and final prices on the Stock Exchange showed declines of fractions to about a point, with the composite rate down 0.33 on the day.

The Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended with September a net income of $5,365,432 after all deductions, including $3,751,253 provision for taxes.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The Ambassadorsh)0*0*0*iin Washington of the five Brussels Treaty powers have received instructions from their Governments to open negotiations with the United States regarding the proposed Atlantic pact whenever Washington officials are ready, it was said on high authority here today.

Thanksgiving Day, tomorrow, will have special significance for the thousands of persecuted and displaced Europeans who recently have found a haven and the beginning of a new life here. They will give thanks for their new-found freedom with America's 140,000,000 persons.
